title: City Opera and Union Avert Strike
description: After a negotiation session that lasted until 5:20 yesterday morning, the New York City Opera and American Guild of Musical Artists announced that performances would continue as talks proceed on a new labor contract. The union, which represents the singers, chorus, dancers, stage directors and stage managers, had said last week that it would strike if an agreement had not been reached by midnight on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, JAMES ROBERT JR., ''BOBBY''
description: STONE-James Robert Jr., ''Bobby'' 61, died at home on 9/2/97. He is survived by former wives Alice Jacqueline Marsh and Patricia Holmes, a brother Thomas H. Stone and wife Merna, an uncle, several cousins, and many friends. Viewing 3-9 P.M. Wednesday, Oct. 1 at Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street, Manhattan with a short service at 8:30 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROEHLICH, HILDEGARD, 89, (NEE HAAS)
description: FROEHLICH-Hildegard, 89, (nee Haas), Sept. 30, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Louis Froehlich. Mother of Eugene Froehlich and Rose Lipman. Grandmother of Marc, Andrew, Debbe Callaghan and Steve Lipman and the late David. Sister of Lina Dreifus and Ruth Moos. Services October 1, 10:45 AM, ''the Riverside'', 76th Street, Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in her memory may be made to Women's American ORT 315 Park Avenue South, NY, NY 10010.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Toys 'R' Us Colluded On Prices, Judge Rules

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: About New York; Downsizing Opens a Door For a Sculptor
description: THE ROARING 20's served Corrine Weinberg well during the Go-Go 80's. Her detailed Art Deco sculptures of flappers and elegant couples, which cost as much as $30,000, sold briskly to collectors and executives who identified with the era's good times and easy money. But the art market eventually shriveled up when, like the old days, the economy nose-dived and executives were downsized out of existence.

title: Police Chief in West New York Corruption Inquiry Resigns
description: The Mayor of West New York, N.J., announced yesterday that its Police Chief had resigned as Federal agents investigated allegations that the Chief and other senior officers had cooperated with Mafia-controlled prostitution, gambling and towing operations.

title: Hong Kong Legislature Has Some Democrats
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Very Risky Business For the Newest Ranger
description: THERE are some, perhaps many including at least one physician -- who believe Pat LaFontaine should spend all the rest of the hockey seasons of his life in front of the television set in his den. Not, as he plans now, in the middle of the ice, crashing into bodies padded like Godzilla, smashing into sideboards, and ducking -- or not ducking, as the case may be -- slashing hockey sticks.

title: Measure to Ban Import Items Made by Children in Bondage
description: As a result of a quiet maneuver by House and Senate conferees, Congress is expected to enact the nation's first ban on imports of goods made by forced or indentured child laborers, children who are sold into bondage by their parents and who must often work a decade or more to buy their freedom.

title: Business Travel; The slowing of many Pacific Rim economies means lower costs for corporate travelers.
description: FOR business travelers to the Pacific Rim, long accustomed to fighting for space on full planes and paying for pricey hotel rooms, the downturn in the region's economies and the continuing qualms about China's control of Hong Kong may prove to be a blessing -- not in disguise.

title: W.N.B.A. Growing By Two Teams
description: The Women's National Basketball Association, which made its debut this summer with eight teams, will add franchises in Detroit and Washington.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Sept. 21 about children's observations on the new Central Park Children's Zoo misspelled the surname of one girl. She is Sophie Racine, not Raccine. Another picture caption misspelled the name of a second girl. She is Julianna Cherston, not Juliana Cheresteron.

title: So Why Do H.M.O.'s Want to Be Regulated?
description: To the Editor:

title: Modify Killer Trucks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, FLORA
description: ROTHENBERG - Flora. NCJW New York section, is saddened by the passing of our former Executive Director, Flora Rothenberg. For 25 years she was a source of strength and vitality. She leaves us with a legacy of dedication and loyalty to the NCJW philosophy. Bernice Friedes, Jean Krosner, Co-Presidents Helen Caplin Heller, Exec. Dir.

title: Hillary Clinton Begins Drive To Improve Care for Children
description: Largely absent from Washington's policy battles since national health insurance died in 1994, Hillary Rodham Clinton embarked today on a campaign to improve child care for working parents, particularly for people moving off welfare and into jobs.

title: In Rochester, Parents Will Rate Teachers
description: After months of debate, the school board in Rochester reached an agreement with the teachers' union this month on a new way to evaluate teachers: formally asking parents to be part of the process.

title: Maddux Starts Off at His Best for Braves
description: Greg Maddux followed the script to the letter today as he shut down the heart of the Houston lineup, made an early lead stand up and pitched the Atlanta Braves to a nifty 2-1 victory over the Astros in the opener of their National League division series.

title: Immigration Service Is Fair on Asylum Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Enduring A Calculated Risk on Cone
description: SOME pitchers always get the benefit of the doubt. Bob Gibson was one of them. Whitey Ford was another. So was Orel Hershiser, then and now.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  THURMAN, BARRY LEO
description: THURMAN-Barry Leo. 1958-1987. 10 years does not diminish a thing. All my love. AJW and friends.

title: Cambodian Says He May Bar U.N. From Vote if Denied Seat
description: Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia said today that if his Government, which seized power from a coalition partner in July, was not given the country's United Nations seat, he would have to consider whether the organization would have any role to play in national elections scheduled for next May.

title: Pentagon Aide Warns Czechs to Upgrade Military for NATO
description: Just as three Central European Governments began detailed talks this month on how their forces would be integrated into NATO, a senior Pentagon official warned the Czechs that they were trailing behind in upgrading their military, according to Czech and American officials.

title: Republic and Toyota Reach Settlement
description: Republic Industries reached a settlement with the Toyota Motor Corporation today that clears the way for Republic to quickly add Japanese car dealerships to its chain of new-car showrooms.

title: Israel Frees Founder Of Hamas Movement
description: Israel released the imprisoned spiritual leader of the Islamic movement Hamas, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, and flew him to Amman, in response to a request from King Hussein of Jordan for ''positive steps to help the peace process.''

title: Bozell, Jacobs Quits Accountants' Review
description: KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting firm in New York, has reshuffled the roster for a review of its domestic account, with billings estimated at $12 million to $15 million, after a finalist withdrew.

title: Mickens Becomes Latest Boost Off the Bench for Parcells
description: When Bill Parcells coached the Giants, he created roles for bench warmers.

title: Dropping the Ball In Juggling Loans; A Lot of Fumbles by E.D.S. In Processing Student Debt
description: It seemed like a simple enough thing to do: consolidate 10 different Government-sponsored college loans due over 10 years into one jumbo loan payable over 25, slashing the monthly payment to $350 from $558. That was one of the last things standing between Shannan Elmore and mortgage approval for the house -- the one whose concrete foundation her husband had proposed in front of -- that she wanted to build near Boulder, Colo.

title: Venturesome Spirits Are Now Rousing Madrid Restaurants
description: LIKE Rome, Madrid is the capital of a peninsular nation, cut off from most of its neighbors by the mountains and the sea. But while Rome has been a hub of civilization for more than 2,000 years, Madrid, a much younger city, was isolated for four decades after the Spanish Civil War not only by geography but also by politics. As Franco's headquarters, it was something of a pariah until democracy was restored in the 1970's.

title: Restaurants; A New Le Cirque, the Same Old Magic
description: LOOK! Wasn't she on the cover of Vogue last month? Over there, the movie star! Isn't that the former Mayor at the corner table? The diva? The billionaire? Heads swivel, eyes turn: Le Cirque 2000 glitters with hysterical energy.

title: TV Notes; Few Winners, Many Sinners
description: Aside from the obvious -- that ''E.R.'' and ''Seinfeld'' are unmatchable successes -- the first week of the new television season left most network executives groping for indications of what viewers really like, and what they really, really don't like.

title: House Panel Takes a Slap At Clinton Over China
description: A House committee dealt a sharp if largely symbolic rebuke to the Administration's China policy today, just four weeks before President Jiang Zemin is to come to Washington, when it voted to deny visas to Chinese officials who violate human rights.

title: RACING: ROUNDUP
description: Cane to Freehold

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the obituary of the painter Roy Lichtenstein yesterday misidentified the high school he attended in Manhattan. It was the Franklin School (now called the Dwight School), not Benjamin Franklin High School.

title: Teacher Background Checks
description: Teachers and other employees would not be able to work in schools until their criminal background checks were completed, under a law proposed on Monday by the Whitman administration.

title: US Airways And Pilots in Tentative Deal
description: Ending more than a year of negotiations, US Airways and its pilots reached a tentative contract agreement late last night. At the same time, Airbus Industrie agreed to allow enough time for the union's rank and file to vote on the contract before the airline has to confirm an order for up to 400 planes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Pair of Elder Statesmen Urge That Soft Money Be Outlawed
description: Two mandarins of American politics, Walter F. Mondale and Nancy Kassebaum Baker, urged senators today to restrict currently unregulated donations to political parties, but the word in the cloakrooms was that the sponsors had not rounded up enough votes to pass such legislation.

title: CURIOUS COOK; Why Does Fish Spoil Faster Than Chicken?
description: NO food goes bad faster than fresh fish. I knew that. But until a recent gathering of curious San Francisco fish aficionados, I never stopped to wonder why fish should be more fragile than beef or chicken, or what -- if anything -- could be done to coddle it into keeping for an extra day or two.

title: Stanford Rook Shares Plunge on Drug Setback
description: Shares in Stanford Rook Holdings P.L.C. lost more than half their value yesterday on news of a setback in third-phase trials of the company's tuberculosis drug SRL172. An independent committee monitoring the trials in Durban, South Africa, found there were no differences between SRL172 and the best available therapy.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: OFFENSIVE ADS -- Over free-speech advocates' objections, transit officials will be allowed to reject ads they consider offensive. B3.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, MICHAEL
description: KANE-Michael. On September 29, 1997, aged twenty-two. Beloved son of Chester and Margot, loving brother of Elizabeth, Timothy and sister-in-law Ilene. Service on Wednesday, October 1, 2:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Doubt Cast on Witnesses Of a Missile in Jet Crash
description: The F.B.I. is nearing completion of an analysis of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 that appears to show that the streaks of light that some witnesses reported seeing when the plane crashed 14 months ago were not from a missile, officials said.

title: HALF THE STATES UNLIKELY TO MEET GOALS ON WELFARE
description: Fewer than half the states say they will meet the deadline to fulfill all the ambitious work goals in the 1996 welfare law, creating a tricky political situation for President Clinton and for some governors who pushed for the work requirements.

title: New Immigration Rules Hit Some Companies Hard
description: In SoHo, a Japanese restaurant closed its doors last Friday after the chef returned to Japan. In Westport, Conn., a construction company shut down when the owner, a Chilean immigrant, suddenly left with his family. And in a midtown Manhattan factory, where 25 employees work making fine jewelry 14 hours a day, the owner, a Ukrainian refugee, wonders whether he too should pack and leave.

title: DIVISION SERIES PLAYOFFS: Three Homers in a Row Pull Yankees Out of a Hole; Cone Rescued After Making A Rough Start
description: The first baseball soared into the upper deck in right field and tied the score. The second baseball spiraled into the left-field seats and gave the Yankees a lead. The third baseball soared over the center-field fence to inflate the edge and transform Yankee Stadium into a rollicking baseball setting.

title: Calendar
description: Oysters and Ale

title: Pataki Says Clinton Aides Seek to End Medicaid Fight
description: Gov. George E. Pataki said today that he had received assurances from top Clinton Administration officials that they would quickly try to resolve a long-running dispute between the White House and New York State that has jeopardized billions of dollars in Federal Medicaid assistance to the state.

title: Union Pacific Cancels Plan To Ship Some Cargo by Sea
description: The Union Pacific Corporation scrapped plans today to move some freight by sea, saying customers wanted to wait for space on its clogged rail system rather than risk longer delivery delays from a slow-moving cargo ship.

title: Why cruise? That's what the industry association's new campaign will tell you.
description: FOUR decades after Frankie Ford implored, ''Won't you let me take you on a sea cruise?'' the cruise industry is undertaking a big joint effort to transform landlubbers into cruise lovers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINTAVALLE, JOSEPH T.
description: QUINTAVALLE-Joseph T., of S.I. on Sept. 30. Husband of Betty (nee Barlow). Father of J. Michael and David T. Grandfather of Melissa. Father-in-law of Linda. Mass of Christian Burial St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Friday, 11 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visitation Thursday only, 2-5, 7-9PM, Dongan Hills Virginia Funeral Chapel, 1707 Hylan Blvd., S.I. In lieu of flowers, donations to Regis High School, NYC would be appreciated.

title: Temptation; Wheeling Out the Cheese (Six Tons' Worth)
description: THOSE who are thoroughly hooked on Vermont Shepherd -- a richly complex sheep's-milk cheese with a firm but buttery texture and a sweetly nutty yet tangy flavor -- have felt very deprived the last six months.

title: Sexual Abuse Tied to 1 in 4 Girls in Teens
description: Two new studies of adolescent girls have found that 1 in 4 has been sexually or physically abused or forced by a date to have sex against her will. In addition, those who have had such experiences are far more likely to show signs of depression and to engage in risky health behaviors, including smoking, drinking and using drugs, eating disorders, failing to use contraception and becoming pregnant.

title: Israel Frees Ailing Hamas Founder to Jordan at Hussein's Request
description: The spiritual leader of the Islamic movement Hamas, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, was released from an Israeli prison today and flown to Amman. The Army said he was freed in response to a request from King Hussein of Jordan and in view of the paraplegic sheik's deteriorating physical condition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINKER, BLANCHE SILVERMAN
description: LINKER-Blanche Silverman. Born on June 18, 1929. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister, aunt. Passed Tuesday, September 30, leaving a void in our lives. Her strength was an inspiration to us all. Services today at 1 PM, Parkside, Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Tidbit; Zero Fat Can Add Up
description: The nutrition facts on cans of spray-on vegetable oil may be more baffling than enlightening. They state that a serving from one of these cans contains 0 grams of fat. But the list of ingredients names vegetable oil as the principal ingredient. Fat, truth to tell, is very nearly the only thing these cans contain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERRY, CECELIA (RUBINSTEIN)
description: CHERRY-Cecelia (Rubinstein). Beloved wife of Paul, loving mother of Amy and Robert. Devoted sister of Kay, the late Manny Fenton, and the late Anna. Cherished grandmother of Marla & Jennifer. Will be missed by all. Services will be Friday, 10 A.M., at the Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue (corner Avenue M).

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We beg for the pardon of God, and we ask the Jewish people to hear this word of repentance.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMENFELD, SAM
description: BLUMENFELD - Sam. Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary mourn the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community here and in Israel, beloved father of Alvin J. (and Lois) Blumenfeld and Marlene (and Sholom) Leiser and cherished brother of George Blumenfeld, Ben Bloomfield, and Tillie Chalpin. Alvin Blumenfeld is Treasurer, RIETS Board of Trustees, and a YU and RIETS Guardian with his wife Lois. They established the Lois and Alvin Blumenfeld Scholarship at our undergraduate schools, and their philanthropy is a tribute to their father's teaching and influence. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, HARRY B.
description: CLARK-Harry B., of Huntington, N.Y., September 28, 1997. Beloved husband of Phyllis. Devoted father of Jane Swan, Gail Claydon, Priscilla Kahale and Jonathan, also survived by seven grandchildren. Visitation today 2-4 and 7-9 P.M., at A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home Inc., 1380 New York Ave., Huntington Station, N.Y. Religious service Thursday, 10 A.M. at Old First Presbyterian Church of Huntington, 125 Main Street. Interment in Locust Valley Cemetery.

title: TV Notes; A Brokaw Victory
description: NBC reported yesterday that its ''Nightly News'' with Tom Brokaw had defeated ABC's evening news for the entire broadcast year, the first time that has happened in 10 years. ABC's news program had its lowest rating in 26 years; but that's nothing compared to CBS's showing. The once towering CBS ''Evening News'' had its lowest rating since 1951. BILL CARTER

title: REPUBLICAN CHIEFS SAY THE TRADE BILL IS IN BIG TROUBLE
description: The Republican leaders of both the House and the Senate said today that legislation giving the President renewed authority to negotiate global trade accords had failed to gain enough support in Congress and blamed President Clinton for not doing enough to win Democrats to the cause.

title: Modify Killer Trucks
description: To the Editor:

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: James Cogan, 69, Lawyer Specializing in Estates
description: James R. Cogan, a lawyer who specialized in trusts and estates and was a volunteer for nonprofit organizations, died on Friday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 69.

title: As the Season Takes Off, Some Stars May Be Missing
description: Some of the sport's biggest stars are unlikely to be in uniform as the National Hockey League opens its 81st season this week.

title: YACHT RACING: A SAILOR'S JOURNAL -- WHITBREAD ROUND THE WORLD RACE; Spinnaker Is Strewn Across Atlantic
description: Ten yachts and about 120 sailors began the 31,600-nautical mile Whitbread Round the World Race from Southampton, England, on Sept. 20. The competitors are in the first -- and longest -- of nine stages, a voyage of 7,350 nautical miles south through the Atlantic to Cape Town. As of late Monday, Innovation Kvaerner led, with Merit Cup second. Katie Pettibone, an American on the all-female crew of EF Education of Sweden, will be filing periodic reports of life at sea until the race's scheduled return to Southampton next May. This is her second report.

title: Support From Across Hudson
description: In her first official act as a new member of the Democratic Party, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross of New York will lend support to State Senator James E. McGreevey, New Jersey's Democratic gubernatorial candidate, during a joint visit today to a day-care center in Newark.

title: 3 Agency Companies Make Acquisitions
description: Three agency companies announced acquisitions yesterday.

title: Many Girls Learn Better Without Boys Around
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FITZPATRICK, JOHN J.
description: FITZPATRICK-John J., 1910-1996. We miss you forever in our hearts. You'll always be in our thoughts. Catherine, Pat, Nancy and Scott.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GATEWAY 2000 INC., North Sioux City, S.D., said it would lay off or reassign 300 employees, about 2.5 percent of its work force, as part of its restructuring plan.

title: The Minimalist; As Easy as 1-2-3 Ingredients (Reductions Are the Secret)
description: ROZANNE GOLD is the leader of a minimalist sect, one that uses the fewest possible ingredients to produce dishes that are not just credible, but delicious. Her ''Recipes 1-2-3'' (Viking Penguin, 1996) is a guidebook to this style, with 250 three-ingredient recipes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, MILLARD J.
description: WILLIAMS-Millard J. Concert singer and long time resident of Teaneck, NJ. Died in Bermuda, on Saturday, September 22. He was 78. Mr. Williams studied at The Toronto Conservatory of Music winning a Canadian National Exhibition Prize. Later working in New York he was awarded The Martha Baird Rockefeller Scholarship which allowed him to study in London, Paris and Munich. He performed in concert in most of Western Europe's capitals and toured in the United States and Canada. A former member of The Porgy and Bess Company, The Leonard dePaur Chorus and The Harry Belafonte Chorus. Mr. Williams sang as a principal with The Metropolitan Opera Studio and as a chorister with The Metropolitan Opera House. Mr. Williams often appeared in various concerts and recitals including performances with the late Lance Hayward with the trio ''The Pilgrims'' and musical ensemble ''Opus 3''. For many years he was a baritone soloist primarily at The Central Unitarian Church in Paramus. In addition to his musical accomplishments Mr. Willliams was a printer by trade, held a position of Supervisor at The New York Times until his retirement. He is survived by his wife Rita, a daughter Carla and a sister Ruthmary of Bermuda. Funeral services will be held at Saint Paul's AME Church in Hamilton, Bermuda, Thursday, October 2, 1997.

title: Marvel's Bondholders Set to Pay Banks
description: Marvel Entertainment Group said yesterday that its controlling bondholders, High River L.P. and Westgate International L.P., had established a $385 million escrow account to buy the claims of Marvel's bank creditors.

title: Breast Cancer Brings 'Murphy Brown' Close To Real-Life Tragedy
description: It's no mistake that the opening scenes of tonight's ''Murphy Brown'' are all about loss. Murphy leaves ''F.Y.I.'' for a job at the White House; when she returns a month later, the ''F.Y.I.'' offices themselves are missing. And outside that fictional world other things are changing. Tonight's episode begins the series' final season. Candice Bergen and the producers said the same thing last year, but this time they swear they mean it. And they have decided to go out with an attention-getting roar. Though Murphy doesn't get the news until the end of next week's episode, it is no secret that she has breast cancer.

title: Haulers Plead Guilty to Controlling Garbage Routes With Violence
description: Five people and 13 garbage hauling companies pleaded guilty yesterday in what Federal officials said was the culmination of a 10-year investigation of the Mafia's longtime control of the garbage hauling industry in the suburbs north of New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICHMAN, STELLA JOLLES
description: REICHMAN-Stella Jolles. Died September 9 after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Henry Reichman. Loving mother of the late Thomas and Steven, grandmother of Jamie. Memorial service Wednesday, October 1, Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 Street at 2PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to Vassar College, Poughkeepsie, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARSON, JOHN
description: LARSON-John, 65, of Fairlee, VT died unexpectedly Sept. 28, 1997. Born in Morristown, N.J., the son of Dr. Henry M. and Margery (Watson) Larson. Educated at Phillips-Exeter Academy, Williams College, and the University of Virginia Law School. Former partner at Mudge, Stern, Baldwin and Todd in NYC. Retired to Vermont in 1975 to follow life-long interest in ephemera. Survived by wife, Marijke Larson of Fairlee; three daughters, Nancy Leete, Caroline Levine, and Alexandra Larson; three grandchildren; sister, Margery Gori-Montanelli of New York, NY. Donations to Fairlee Scholarship Fund, PO Box 95, Fairlee, Vermont 05045, or, Upper Valley Humane Society, Old Route 10, Enfield, NH 03748.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Footlights column of The Arts yesterday about the New York State Governor's Awards misstated the date of the 1997 presentation at the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center. It is next Monday; it was not this Monday.

title: DONNA KARAN PLANS TO LICENSE BRANDS TO ESTEE LAUDER
description: Donna Karan International Inc. said yesterday that it planned to take a fourth-quarter pretax charge of about $30 million and license some brands to the Estee Lauder Companies in a plan to restructure its ailing beauty business. Donna Karan said that without the restructuring, its beauty company would lose $7 million next year. The unit, created in 1992, makes fragrances, and bath and body and treatment products retailing from $15 to $375 at department and specialty stores. The agreement will give the New York-based Estee Lauder the exclusive rights to manufacture, market, sell and distribute all Donna Karan New York and DKNY fragrances, cosmetics, skin care products, beauty and beauty-related accessories. The terms were not disclosed.

title: Eleanor D. Larrabee, 74, Library Architect
description: Eleanor Doermann Larrabee, an architect who specialized in the construction and layout of libraries, died on Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 74 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNER, PAULINE STEINLAUF
description: TANNER-Pauline Steinlauf, after a long illness, cherished wife of the late Irving; loved by children Ben and Ellen Tanner Farkas, and Nicki and Harold Tanner; and grandchildren Esta and Paul Farkas, Gary and Lynn Farkas Schwartz, Peggy and David Tanner; Catherine Allegra and James Tanner, Kent and Karen Tanner Allen; and proud great-grandmother of 11. Her intelligence, love of, and loyalty to, family strengthened and enhanced our lives. Expressions of remembrance may be made to the Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem or to the Pauline and Irving Tanner Scholarship Fund at Cornell University. Funeral services will be Sunday, October 5, at 1:00 PM at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Renteria Outguesses The Giants In the 9th
description: Ahead in the count, Edgar Renteria shut out the mushrooming delirium around him and decided to guess. With the bases loaded and two out in the bottom of the ninth inning of a tie game, the Florida Marlins shortstop simply looked for a fastball on the outside part of the plate.

title: In a Passion for Antique Clocks, Executive Embezzled $12 Million
description: Francis X. Vitale Jr. was undone by time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VALDES, ESPERANZA VICTORIA
description: VALDES-Esperanza Victoria. On September 26, 1997. Beloved mother of Dr. Lesley Rankin-Hill; sister Mauricio C. Valdes. Respected & loved New York City teacher at Brandeis High School & JHS 43. Her caring, devotion, insight and wisdom touched the lives of countless people young and old. Her passing leaves a void in the universe. Donations in her memory may be made to The Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Medical Center South, NY, NY 10003.

title: Metro Business; Finalists in Bidding For Chrysler Building
description: With offers topping $200 million, the group of prospective buyers for the landmark Chrysler Building has been reduced to a hotelier, an investment bank, a trio of developers and several real estate companies.

title: Nuclear Energy Perks
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOFFER, STUART
description: SOFFER-Stuart, 55. On 9/26/97. He was the Supervisor of Music for the Bedford School District in Westchester. He is survived by his mother, Marion, adored sister, Janet, and brother, Marvin. Services were held Sunday.

title: Lewis Is the Champion No One Really Knows
description: ''Hey, anybody ever tell you, you look like that boxer Lennox Lewis?'' an elderly man said to Lennox Lewis as the two were riding an elevator at Caesars Palace.

title: LaFontaine Is Willing To Take The Risks
description: For the first time in nearly a year, Pat LaFontaine donned his skates, strapped on his protective gear and took part in a regular practice session today. He did so for a new team, the Rangers, with any number of questions still surrounding him.

title: When Optimism Meets Overcapacity
description: An edge of anxiety has crept into the celebration of America's supposed triumphant economy. Maybe because it's autumn. Manias and panics in the financial markets typically occur in October or November, for very human reasons. When the days are growing shorter, investor optimism may shrivel with the leaves.

title: Growth in Jewish Private Schools Celebrates Complex Mix
description: The head of school comes from a family of Methodist ministers. The principal is a former dentist from a fellowship program in Jerusalem that trains Jewish educators. And the 19 inaugural students come from Reform, Conservative and Orthodox families across the metropolitan sprawl of Atlanta.

title: Metro Business; Chase Reducing Some Fees
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation says it is cutting fees and lowering minimum balances for some checking accounts as the bank tries to increase its share of consumer business in the New York City region.

title: McCaughey Ross Endorses McGreevey
description: In her first official act as a new member of the Democratic Party, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross of New York will lend support to State Senator James E. McGreevey, New Jersey's Democratic gubernatorial candidate, during a joint visit today to a day care center in Newark.

title: Killer Convicted After Acquittal
description: After being acquitted in a killing linked to organized crime 20 years ago, Harry Aleman was found guilty of murder in the same death by a jury in Cook County Circuit Court today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENSTEIN, ROY
description: LICHTENSTEIN - Roy. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the passing of Roy Lichtenstein. From a vast array of sources in our common culture, he fashioned an art of sharp sophistication that was humorous, ironic, elegant, and continually inventive. His brashness on canvas was balanced in life by a quiet, self-effacing manner informed by tremendous good will and generosity. Few artists so admired in the inner circles of the art world have had such a global impact on the visual sensibility of their time, and fewer still have commanded such a special blend of love and respect from those who knew him. He altered the way we see our culture, and the way we think and feel about it. Though his career was long and productive, we thought that he, like his art, was permanently blessed with an unassailable edge of usefulness. A singular joy has been taken from us, and in our sadness and loss we offer condolences to his beloved wife Dorothy and his family. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director Kirk Varnedoe, Chief Curator, Department of Painting and Sculpture, The Museum of Modern Art, N.Y.

title: Tale of Cold War Spying, Told by Men Who Did It
description: BATTLEGROUND BERLIN

title: Council Backs a New Police Review Board
description: The City Council voted overwhelmingly yesterday to create an independent police review board, once again forcing a confrontation with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has long maintained that investigations into police corruption are best handled by the Police Department itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWYER, VIRGINIA A.
description: DWYER-Virginia A. Of New York City. Formerly of Baldwin, L.I. On September 29, 1997, after a long illness. Retired senior Vice President of A.T.&T. Survived by a brother and sister-in-law, Jack and Nancy Dwyer, of Erie, PA, and Naples, FL, and a sister and brother-in-law, Marie and Dale Buley, of Seaford, NY. Also survived by 8 nieces and nephews and 13 grandnieces and nephews. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC, on Thursday and Friday, 3-5 PM and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Saturday at 10 AM at St. Paul The Apostle R.C. Church, 415 West 59th St., NYC. Memorial contributions may be made to Virginia Dwyer Memorial Scholarship, University of Rochester, P.O. Box 270032, Rochester, New York 14627-0032.

title: For the Blacklisted, Credit Where Credit Is Due
description: The screenwriting credits on 23 films written by blacklisted writers in the 1950's, including ''An Affair to Remember'' and ''Cry, the Beloved Country,'' have been restored by the Writers Guild of America.

title: Service for McGuire Airmen
description: Nine crew members who died in a crash off Africa were eulogized yesterday as heroes who gave their lives for a humanitarian mission, The Associated Press reported.

title: Editorial Notebook; Have Charts, Will Travel
description: The brief but action-packed political career of Betsy McCaughey Ross, New York's Lieutenant Governor, took another turn this week when she became a Democrat. There are several ways to look at this development, only one of which involves the observation that it was typical of Ms. McCaughey Ross to compare her decision to jump parties to that of Winston Churchill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADAL, CARLOS G.
description: NADAL-Carlos G., at Southampton, N.Y., on September 28, 1997. Mr. Nadal was born in New YorK City on January 29, 1912, and was highly decorated during his service with the U.S. Marine Corps in World War II. In 1946 he founded Nadal & Baxendale, Inc., a general contracting firm, and was active in construction in New York City, Florida and the Cayman Islands. He retired to Southampton in 1977, where he served on the Southampton Village Zoning Board of Appeals & the Southampton Town Open Space Advisory Committee, in addition to doing volunteer work at the Southampton Hospital. He is survived by three sons, Gerrit L. Lansing of Greenwich, CT.; David W. Nadal of Southampton, N.Y.; and Dr. Evan C. Nadal of East Hampton, N.Y.; and a brother, Gordon Nadal Morford of Palm Beach, FL. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church in Southampton, Saturday, October 4th, at 11:00 A.M. Interment will be private.

title: Market Place; ITT soars as its suitor, Hilton Hotels, and traders anticipate a court-ordered vote.
description: The price of the ITT Corporation's stock jumped more than 8 percent yesterday, one day after a Federal judge ruled that the company's board could not split ITT into three companies without shareholder approval.

title: Battle at the Met? Yes, in a Regal Setting
description: Kathleen Battle's banishment from that gilded temple of operatic singing in Lincoln Center remains in effect. But on Monday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Ms. Battle presided at her own temple, literally, by presenting a recital at the Temple of Dendur in the museum's Sackler Wing.

title: Immigration Service Is Fair on Asylum Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, PHILIP C.
description: RICHMAN-Philip C. Passed away after a long illness at the age of 91. Beloved and faithful husband to his loving wife Edith for 51 years. Devoted father to Larry, his wonderful and caring son and companion, who loved his father deeply. Respected and well loved brotherin-law to his wife's family and a wonderful son to his parents. Rest in peace, dear Philip, you fought strongly and deserve a lasting peace. Services private.

title: Even With Big Cushion, Hershiser Goes Thud
description: Orel Hershiser knows the routine, especially in a short series. Lose a post-season game and you die a little; win and the momentum is all yours.

title: Boy Is Strangled, and Misgivings Arise Over Fund-Raising
description: An 11-year-old boy who was last seen selling candy for his school in Jackson Township was strangled, officials said today, and his death has prompted a round of soul-searching by parent groups that depend on such fund-raising to pay for things like playground equipment and class trips.

title: Metro Business; Business Activity Is Rising
description: Business activity in the New York metropolitan region continued to expand in September from the previous month, the National Association of Purchasing Management-New York said yesterday.

title: INSIGNIA PLANS TO ENTER RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY MARKET
description: Insignia Financial Group Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the closely held residential broker Realty One for $39 million in cash and stock, in its first foray into the residential property market. Under the terms of the agreement, Insignia will pay $35 million in cash and issue the balance in stock worth $20 a share. The Cleveland-based Realty One is the 10th-largest residential real estate brokerage firm in the United States. Realty One's mortgage banking unit, the First Ohio Mortgage Company, is included in the purchase. Insignia is based in Greenville, S.C.

title: TV Notes; Cable's 300
description: If the overall message from premiere week was mixed for the broadcast networks, the cable networks felt they had the goods to crow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, FLORENCE
description: ROTHMAN-Florence. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved former member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Bill, Russ, Doug, Phil and the entire family. Stanley Plonchak, President

title: Fans Find It's Hard to Match the Excitement of '96
description: Call it buzz light.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCLINTOCK, JOHN T.
description: McCLINTOCK-John T. The Board of Directors of Amsterdam Nursing Home records with sorrow the passing of our esteemed former director, John T. McClintock, on September 25, 1997. Mr. McClintock served from 1953, when we were known as the Home for Old Men and Aged Couples, to April of 1987. Despite his retirement from the Board, Mr. McClintock remained a devoted supporter of the nursing home until his death. We extend our sincere condolences to his entire family. Dyer S. Wadsworth, Chairman James Davis, President

title: Buoyant Blair Maps His Vision for Future
description: Riding a wave of extraordinary public approval and addressing members of his party in a victorious mood, Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that he hoped to forge post-empire Britain into ''the 21st century model nation, a beacon to the world.''

title: A Drinking Death Rattles Elite M.I.T.; Latest Fraternity Party Case Underscores Nationwide Problem
description: Near midnight last Friday, something went fatally wrong in the red-curtained Phi Gamma Delta house near the grassy Back Bay Fens here -- the kind of thing that often goes wrong during pledge week at fraternities around the country.

title: SHARES OF IMNET FALL ON NEWS OF AUDITING REVIEW
description: The stock of Imnet Systems Inc. fell more than a third yesterday after the company said its auditors had requested more time to review the company's finances. Shares of the company, which processes data for the health care industry, fell $13.5625, to $26.875. Imnet said its auditing firm, KPMG Peat Marwick, made the request after it received an informal inquiry from the Securities and Exchange Commission about a recent anonymous letter. The letter charged Imnet with using aggressive accounting practices to record revenue. As a result, Imnet will delay its scheduled annual filing with the S.E.C.

title: $25 and Under; Can You Clone Success?
description: IN the restaurant business, success breeds more restaurants. Expansion is, after all, the natural capitalistic response to prosperity. But it's no simple matter for a restaurant to duplicate the conditions that made it popular in the first place. Energy and focus are divided, but try as they might, chefs and staffs cannot divide themselves. Here are three restaurants that I liked very much in their original incarnations and which have taken the difficult step of cloning themselves in the last year.

title: Chinese Tycoon Gives Columbia $26 Million
description: Universities are ranging farther and farther afield in raising money, increasingly looking abroad to tap foreign alumni they have long ignored.

title: Talks Reported On Safety-Kleen
description: The Safety-Kleen Corporation, which cleans and maintains equipment for auto service stations and other industries, is in talks to sell the company for $1.6 billion to $1.7 billion, people associated with the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Sony and Toyota Plan Liquid Crystal Venture
description: The Sony Corporation and an affiliate of the Toyota Motor Corporation will spend 50 billion yen ($413 million) to build a plant to make liquid-crystal-display panels using a new technology that is less expensive than current methods. The 50-50 venture, to be called the ST Liquid Crystal Display Corporation, will help Sony and Toyota break into a growing market.

title: Sensual Medieval Songs, With Earthy Passion
description: The idea persists that medieval vocal music must be sung with utterly austere, focused tone without a trace of vibrato. That is not the approach of Lionheart, a New York-based a cappella ensemble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERRY, MARGARET HOEGL
description: CHERRY-Margaret Hoegl, of Glen Head, NY. On September 29, 1997. Beloved wife of Alan G., Jr. Loving mother of Alan G., III, Timothy, and Jennifer. Dear sister of Eleanor Ratchelous and Mary Lynn Schrage. Margaret enjoyed working in the North Shore School District for 20 years. Visiting 5-8 PM Wed., Whitting Funeral Home, Inc., Glen Head. Funeral service Wed. 7 PM at the funeral home. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital or the Cancer Research Institute.

title: Cordiant Provides Details on Division
description: Cordiant P.L.C. announced yesterday further details of its planned split, which will create separate operating companies centered on Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide and Bates Worldwide.

title: Aggressive Giant Defense Makes an Attitude Adjustment
description: Jessie Armstead was relaxing in January when he got a call from his agent, who was phoning to let him know that John Fox had been hired as the defensive coordinator of the Giants. And the call came with a warning.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about efforts to honor early blues musicians in the rural South referred incorrectly to a monument for Robert Johnson in Morgan City, Miss. It is a memorial, not a headstone; the site of Johnson's burial is in dispute.

title: Liberties; 'The Dirty Rascals'
description: It is odd, seeing this woman who unleashed so much passion, project so little passion. As the elegant, aloof Anita Hill begins her book tour, it is hard to conjure up the vicious intensity that crackled around that Congressional hearing six years ago.

title: TV Notes; The Senator vs. NBC
description: With NBC declining to volunteer to join the other networks' voluntary venture of assigning content labels to television shows -- V for violence, S for sex, L for coarse language and D for suggestive dialogue -- Senator John J. McCain, Republican of Arizona, has written to the network asking for a change of heart.

title: Survey Reveals More Pessimism in Japan
description: Japanese corporate managers have turned more pessimistic about the economy than they were three months ago and do not foresee improvement until 1998 at the earliest, the Bank of Japan said today in a widely followed survey.

title: Developer of Notes Program To Focus on New Venture
description: Ray Ozzie, the computer programmer who created I.B.M.'s popular Notes software, is cutting back his involvement with the product to develop new software that may or may not be sold by I.B.M.

title: Patriot Expected to Announce Carnival Hotels Purchase
description: Patriot American Hospitality Inc., a fast-growing real estate investment trust, is likely to announce as soon as today that it has bought Carnival Hotels and Resorts, a hotel management company based in Miami, according to people close to the negotiations. The sale price is expected to be almost $500 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASENCIO, ADELAIDA (NEE SANCHEZ)
description: ASENCIO-Adelaida (nee Sanchez). A strong and courageous woman passed away September 28, 1997 after a long illness. Beloved wife of Juan (Eliseo). Devoted mother of Dr. Eliseo Asencio and Dr. Marysol Asencio. Adored aunt of Myra Gonzalez and husband Jose. Adopted mother of Dr. Margaret Hynes, Fabio Silva and Dr. Pedro de Armas. Loving sister of Leonardo, Herberto, Nereida, Gilberto, Juan and Lidia. Also survived by aunts, uncles, nieces, nephews, cousins and friends who deeply cared for her. In lieu of flowers a contribution may be made in her name to the American Diabetes Association, 149 Madison Avenue, 7th Floor, NYC 10016 for research. The funeral will be held in Miami, FL.

title: Panel Urges That Immigrants Become Further Americanized
description: A Federal advisory panel called today for a major campaign to integrate new immigrants into American society, and it won support from an influential Republican Congressman for its proposal to dismantle the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Critic's Notebook; Literary Lions (Tigers? Cubs?) Find Joy in Mudville
description: How appropriate, with the baseball post-season just under way and millions of otherwise sensible Americans mesmerized in front of their television screens, that the most proclaimed novel of the year, ''Underworld'' by Don DeLillo, begins with the fabled 1951 playoff in which the Giants came from behind to beat the Dodgers on Bobby Thomson's ninth inning home run.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIEDLER, MORTON
description: FIEDLER-Morton. On Sunday Sept. 28, 1997. Beloved husband of Mrs. Carolyn Fiedler of Mt. Lebanon, PA. Father of Mrs. Arthur (Marjorie) Samuels Jr., Mrs. Philip (Patricia) Kardaras, both of New York, N.Y. Grandfather of Alexandra Kardaras. Services were held at the Burton L. Hirsch Chapel, 2704 Murray Ave., Pittsburgh, PA on Sept 30, 1997. Interment Beth Shalom Cemetery Pittsburgh., PA. Family suggests Contributions to a charity of the donor's choice.

title: Toys 'R' Us Led Price Collusion, U.S. Judge Says
description: Toys ''R'' Us, the dominant player in the nation's cutthroat toy business, violated Federal trade laws by colluding with manufacturers to keep prices for Barbie, Mr. Potato Head and other popular toys artificially high, a judge ruled today.

title: School Official Pleads Guilty
description: The former president of the Camden Board of Education pleaded guilty in Newark yesterday to stealing nearly $9,000 in public money in 1993 to pay for personal expenses, including food, drink and lodging during a weeklong vacation at Cape May's Grand Hotel, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, R. MARGUERITE
description: VOGEL-R. Marguerite, in her 98th year on September 26, 1997. Funeral service Thursday, October 2, at 11 AM. Saint Bartholomew's Chapel, Park Avenue at 50th Street. Interment October 3, in Albany Rural Cemetery, Albany, NY. Donations in lieu of flowers may be made to WIMSA-Women In Military Service, Dept 560, Washington, DC 20042-0560.

title: Despite Dismal Preseason, Islanders Hope for Playoffs
description: The Islanders went 0 for the preseason, scoring nine goals in six games, the lowest total in the National Hockey League. That dismal performance might be an ominous sign for most teams heading into a new season, but not for the Islanders.

title: William Conard, 41, Store Window Artist, Dies
description: William C. Conard, an artist who designed window displays for major New York department stores and who won many awards in a two-decade career, died on Sept. 13 at Beth Israel Medical Center in New York. He was 41 and lived in Manhattan. The cause was complications from pneumonia, said his partner, Arthur Fama.

title: A Turandot Who Grasps The Heart Of Sound
description: ''Turandot'' may be the last 20th-century opera truly to welcome the voice. There is, to be sure, twilight Strauss, which stroked and seduced it. But Puccini's last work goes further. It is a home designed for the comfort of the beautiful vocal sound. Its principal roles broker swift, effective transactions between a performer's assets and a listener's needs. ''Turandot'' cushions the lovely sound, frames it, rewards its qualities, enlarges its appeal with visceral climaxes and star-turn opportunities.

title: Soybean and Corn Prices Fall As Harvests Look Abundant
description: Soybean and corn prices fell on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday as harvesting intensified across the central United States. Crop forecasts are rising as early harvested yields are coming in higher than expected.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about increases in tuition omitted the effects of inflation in comparing college expenses with family income. Considering inflation, the real increase in tuition is expected to average 2.5 percent in 1997-1998, contrasted with an estimated 1.7 percent average increase in family income. The tuition increase is not expected to be three times as high as family income.

title: Learning to Love a Lover; Is Casanova's Reputation as a Reprobate a Bum Rap?
description: ''I have loved women to a frenzy,'' the 18th-century writer and adventurer Giacomo Casanova wrote in his huge memoir, ''History of My Life.'' And indeed he did. By one count, Casanova made love to 132 women during his life, a large number, at least by the preinflationary standards of the day.

title: Food Stuff; Changing Tastes In Chocolates
description: For the longest time, the people who make Godiva chocolates did not entirely trust the American palate. After Campbell Soup acquired the company about 30 years ago and Godiva started producing chocolates for the American market in Pennsylvania, it decided Americans were not sophisticated enough for some of the chocolates Europeans admire. Americans have tended to like their chocolates sweeter, with less intensity, and they have not preferred some favorite European flavors like hazelnut. Those tastes are changing now. Godiva is adjusting the line and including more European-style items, notably four chocolates with hazelnut fillings. Truffles, Godiva's most popular line, are also changing: The hard chocolate coating is being made thinner. (In Europe, truffles are usually made with no chocolate coating at all, just cocoa.) Nonetheless, the difference between the new and the old truffles seems minimal. Also new are specialized assortments, including all-chocolate or caramel and nuts.

title: In the Race For Mayor, The Suburbs Give Heavily
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his Democratic opponent, Ruth W. Messinger, have both raised most of the money for their campaigns from residents of Manhattan, and their second-best source of cash has been people from outside the city, who have contributed more than those in the other four boroughs combined, according to a study released yesterday.

title: 11 Fathers Are Arrested Over Child Support
description: Announcing the arrests of 11 so-called deadbeat dads, the Brooklyn District Attorney said yesterday that he would push for state legislation to toughen the laws covering parents who egregiously flout court orders to pay child support.

title: Frank Torre Watches From a Familiar Place
description: Joe Torre's 65-year-old brother, Frank, will watch the first round of the playoffs from the same hospital room he watched the Yankees win the World Series from last year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Don't call her Mrs. Mazzucchelli anymore. Ivana Trump Mazzucchelli (now just IVANA TRUMP) was granted a divorce on Monday from her third husband, RICCARDO MAZZUCCHELLI, an Italian businessman to whom she had been married for 20 months. The divorce was granted by Justice Walter B. Tolub of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, DANIEL G.
description: ROSS-Daniel G. On September 29, 1997. Beloved husband of Grace Jarcho Ross. Loving father of Ann & Michael Loeb, James & Laura Ross, Lynn & Edward Rosenfeld. Adored grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of 6. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday 7-9 PM with service Wednesday 9:45 AM. Please omit flowers.

title: Neighbors Grieve for 11-Year-Old Slain as He Tried to Win a Top P.T.A. Prize
description: Edward P. Werner's friends say he was consumed by a singular dream: winning a set of walkie-talkies by outselling all other students in his school's fall fund-raising drive.

title: Seeking Something to Blame When Breast Cancer Strikes
description: All those who ever wondered to what extent breast cancer has become politicized should watch two programs that were produced to commemorate National Breast Cancer Awareness Month. ''Rachel's Daughters: Searching for the Causes of Breast Cancer,'' tonight on HBO, and ''Say It, Fight It, Cure It,'' Sunday on Lifetime, feature some of the same women and some of the same scenes. But, more chillingly, they also display, in grand fashion, the thinking of those who inhabit a parallel universe of breast cancer awareness.

title: Women Hold 10.6% of Fortune 500 Board Seats, Study Says
description: Director seats held by women at the nation's largest 500 companies rose last year to 10.6 percent of the total, although the rate of increase slowed compared with previous years, according to a census conducted by Catalyst, a nonprofit women's research group based in New York.

title: Much Hand Wringing, With Gloves Off, At a Publishing Debate
description: After the mushroom-puff appetizers were served and air kisses exchanged, the public scolding began.

title: So Why Do H.M.O.'s Want to Be Regulated?; Dilemma for Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Theater in Review
description: Clerical Impiety Raised

title: Aim Sanctions at Iran, Not France
description: The $2 billion Iranian gas-field development contract signed by the Total Oil Group of France, Gazprom of Russia and Petronas of Malaysia is doubly unfortunate. It will provide new funds to a Government that is exporting terrorism, developing nuclear weapons and disrupting peace efforts between Israel and the Arab world. The contract could also trigger the first application of the Iran-Libya Sanctions Act, an ill-advised law that attempts to impose American penalties on foreign companies doing energy business with Iran or Libya.

title: Of Collecting and Embezzling
description: Francis X. Vitale Jr. was undone by time. His passion for antique clocks, he said yesterday, became an obsession and led him to embezzle more than $12.4 million from the Engelhard Corporation, where he had been a senior vice president.

title: INSIDE
description: Boy's Death Raises Issues About School Fund-Raising

title: National News Briefs; Seeking Death Penalty In Bomb Case Is Upheld
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit here today upheld the decision by a Federal judge not to challenge the method Attorney General Janet Reno used in authorizing the United States Attorney in Oklahoma City to seek the death penalty for Terry L. Nichols in the bombing of the Federal building there.

title: Nomura Combines Units In Deregulation Move
description: The Nomura Securities Company will merge its asset management and mutual fund units today, creating Japan's biggest money manager. The merger is one of several set to take place as Japanese companies pool their resources in a race to cash in on the Government's ''Big Bang'' deregulation of financial markets. More such unions between fund management subsidiaries of banks and brokers are on the way, analysts said.

title: New U.S. Envoy to Paris Ponders His Stormy Start
description: Barely three weeks after presenting his credentials as the new American Ambassador to France, Felix G. Rohatyn found himself today in the middle of a full-fledged crisis over a $2 billion investment in Iran by the French oil company Total.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What is the most fitting way to pay tribute to MARY ROBINSON, the former President of Ireland who became United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights on Sept. 12?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBMAN, CHARLES J.
description: LIEBMAN-Charles J., a scholar, author and collector, died on September 24, 1997. He was 87 years old. Mr. Liebman attended Harvard College and subsequently moved to Paris to study at the Ecole des Hautes Etudes. He received his diploma after submitting a thesis entitled ''La Vie Prose de St. Denys''. Mr. Liebman's publications include numerous articles on medieval literature and a book regarding the life of Simon de Tournai. He was often consulted by the Morgan Library to assist in the identification of manuscripts in its possession. He collected rare maps of Paris, which he exhibited at the Grolier Club, of which he was a member. Mr. Liebman is survived by his loving sister, Margaret L. Berger and brother-inlaw, Adolph R. Berger, M.D.

title: Justice Should Always Be Blind to Agony
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Refuses to Extradite a Murder Suspect
description: Israel has decided not to extradite a Maryland high school student wanted for murder in the dismemberment of another teen-ager, saying he would be tried there instead. But both Montgomery County officials and the defendant's Israeli lawyer complained today that that would make it impossible to try the case properly,

title: Trent Lott's Poison Pill
description: Trent Lott, as expected, has come up with a perverse stratagem to kill campaign finance reform this year. The Senate majority leader would add a provision to the McCain-Feingold bill requiring unions to get approval from workers before using their dues or fees for political purposes. The idea might deserve consideration another day, but Mr. Lott's purpose today is to scuttle the bill by making it unacceptable to Democrats.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DENERSTEIN, EZRA J.
description: DENERSTEIN-Ezra J. Today on his birthday and every day we remember with love our dearest father and grandfather. Susan and Harris

title: $3.7 Billion Project for Bangkok Canceled
description: Hopewell Holdings Ltd., a Hong Kong engineering company with big regional aspirations, has lost what was to have been its largest asset.

title: Evelyn Jablow, 78, Decorator And a Designer of Furniture
description: Evelyn Jablow, a widely known decorator and furniture designer, died on Sunday at her weekend home in Delhi, N.Y. She was 78 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about four women who are running for President of Ireland misstated former President Mary Robinson's new position at the United Nations. She is High Commissioner for Human Rights (not Refugees).

title: New M.T.A. Rules on Ads Anger Civil Libertarians
description: Over the objections of gag-wearing free-speech advocates, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority adopted new rules yesterday allowing transit officials to reject advertising for the subways, buses or trains that might be offensive to a significant segment of the public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, ISABEL
description: FITZGERALD - Isabel, 93, of Greenwich, Conn., on September 28, 1997. Wife of the late Clifford Fitzgerald. Beloved mother of Shirley Gately, Joan Schaffer, and Clifford Fitzgerald Jr. Memorial service to be held at the First Church of Round Hill, 464 Round Hill Road, on October 5, at 2 PM.

title: Mother Who May Have Fed Her Son Improperly Is Charged in His Death
description: In the days after her 2-month-old son died, Tabitha Walrond wept openly in the dim hallways of her brick tenement in the Bronx, telling neighbors she so missed her gurgling baby that she could not eat or sleep.

title: Japanese Phone Giant Buys a U.S. Stake
description: Making its first significant push into the American telecommunications market, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $100 million for a minority stake in Teligent Inc., a small wireless communications company.

title: Theater in Review
description: Comedy and Cruelty Make Up

title: Off the Menu
description: A Pasta Salute to Opera

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIMBERGER, GERTRUDE
description: TIMBERGER-Gertrude. On September 29, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Sol; loving mother of Miriam Label and Dr. Robert Timberger; dear mother-in-law of William Label, Marilyn Timberger and the late Elizabeth Ann Timberger. Cherished grandmother of Robyn, Nick, Jennifer, Richard, David and Matthew. Devoted sister of Dorothy Weinstein. Services Wednesday, 10 A.M., ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York. Contributions may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOOS, CHARLES
description: MOOS-Charles. The Board and staff of the League Treatment Center mourn the passing of our former president Charles Moos. We send our sympathies and best wishes to his son Joel and his entire family.

title: How Do You Spell Relief? Yanks Know
description: One inning he retires Bernie Williams on a foul pop and throws a third strike past Tino Martinez with the bases loaded. The next inning he throws pitches that Tim Raines and Derek Jeter slug for consecutive home runs.

title: Police Back Whitman
description: Governor Whitman, like the incumbent before her, was endorsed yesterday by the State Policemen's Benevolent Association, an umbrella group of 350 local police unions with 32,000 members.

title: Betting Inflation Stays Dormant, Fed Leaves Interest Rates Alone
description: The Federal Reserve voted today to keep interest rates unchanged, again showing its willingness to tolerate strong growth as long as the economy displays no clear signs of incipient inflation.

title: A Lesson To New York On Grace In Theater
description: On that nippy Friday night, it seemed so much easier to talk about love. The tall young man with the long red ponytail, standing beneath the wide, wide sky that hangs over this small town near the California border, may have been a bit awkward in first meeting the woman he adored. But in describing her, the enthusiastic imagery danced right off his tongue.

title: Sips; Waiters' Challenge: An Unspilled Martini
description: I STARTED drinking martinis again at a steak place called Shula's on the Beach in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. And the words came back to me after all these years with fine precision. ''I'd like a gin martini, up,'' I told my waiter, ''with an olive.''

title: Bridge Toll Dropped for Rockaway Residents
description: For nearly 60 years, residents of the Rockaways, a marshy peninsula jutting into the Atlantic Ocean on the southeastern tip of Queens, were the only New Yorkers required to pay a toll to make the trip to and from their homes and the rest of their borough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAMPLER, WALTER
description: TRAMPLER-Walter. The Board of Directors, Artists and Staff of The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center mourn the loss of our beloved colleague and friend Walter Trampler. A distinguished violist and founding Artist Member of the Chamber Music Society, Walter delighted our audiences for 25 seasons. His long and extraordinary career as a soloist and chamber musician profoundly influenced the art of string playing. His passionate commitment to new music helped significantly to expand the chamber music repertoire and to strengthen the viola's prominence as a solo and ensemble instrument. Walter's stately presence will be missed by all. We extend our sincere condolences to his family and friends. Donaldson C. Pillsbury, Chairman Mrs. John D. Coffin, President David Shifrin, Artistic Director Jacqueline M. Taylor, Executive Director Charles Wadsworth, Founding Artistic Director

title: President Nudges His Race Panel to Take Action
description: As his advisory board on race relations continued to try to define its mission three months after its appointment, President Clinton today gently but pointedly tried to push the group along.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BARNER, STOCKMAN
description: BARNER-Stockman. Memorial service October 6 at 11 A.M., at Madison Avenue Presybterian Church Chapel, 73 Street entrance.

title: Bonds End Quarter on Some Profit Taking
description: The prices of Treasury securities finished generally lower yesterday, though they closed out the third quarter far higher than where they were at the end of the second quarter.

title: EXABYTE PLANS TO CUT 250 JOBS AND POST LOSS
description: The Exabyte Corporation, a maker of tape drives and automated-tape libraries, said yesterday that it would cut 250 jobs, or nearly 15 percent of its work force, in an effort to save $12 million a year. The company, based in Boulder, Colo., also said it would post a loss of 55 cents to 65 cents a share for the quarter that ended on Sunday, compared with profits of 17 cents a share a year earlier. Exabyte's shares fell 50 cents, to $11. The company attributed about 20 cents to 30 cents of the decline in the latest quarter to the job cuts, as well as the ending of certain development programs and the phasing out of some product lines. Exabyte said it expected to report third-quarter revenues of about $80 million, compared with $92.7 million a year earlier.

title: EXTENDICARE OF CANADA PLANS TO BUY ARBOR HEALTH CARE
description: Extendicare Inc., a Canadian operator of long-term-care facilities, agreed yesterday to acquire the Arbor Health Care Company for $45 a share, or $325 million. It will also assume $107 million in Arbor debt. Arbor's shares rose $5.125, or 13 percent, to $44.125, while Extendicare's United States shares gained 56.25 cents, to $16.50. Extendicare, based in Markham, Ontario, operates 279 nursing homes with about 28,300 beds in the United States, Canada and Britain. Arbor Health, based in Lima, Ohio, has 31 nursing homes with about 3,700 beds and also operates pharmacies and rehabilitation facilities.

title: Test Kitchen; When 'Open Sesame' Doesn't Quite Pop It
description: FOR some people, opening a bottle of wine is a hold-your-breath experience. Will the cork pull effortlessly? Will the trip from bottle to lip be seamless or a debacle of crumbled cork and cracked glass? Even professionals sometimes stumble, foiled, most often, by old, dry corks that can be removed only by a skilled hand and more than a little luck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHEL, EVELYN JABLOW
description: MICHEL-Evelyn Jablow. On September 28th, died peacefully. Beloved wife of Curtis, mother of Joanne and Jeffrey, grandmother of Daniel and Adam, sister of Gloria Eisner. The family held a private service Tuesday, September 30th.

title: SONY'S LOEWS TO MERGE WITH CINEPLEX ODEON
description: The Sony Corporation agreed yesterday to merge its Loews Theaters unit with the Cineplex Odeon Corporation to create one of the world's largest movie theater companies, with annual revenue of about $1 billion. Sony will own 49.9 percent of the voting shares of the combined company, to be called Loews Cineplex Entertainment. The Seagram Company's Universal Studios will own 26.7 percent after investing $85 million in the new company. The Charles Rosner Bronfman Family Trust will own 9.6 percent and public Cineplex shareholders will own 13.3 percent. Cineplex Odeon shares will be exchanged for shares in the new company. The combined company will operate more than 2,600 screens in about 450 theaters.

title: Ivanisevic Out
description: It was another brief week for Goran Ivanisevic.

title: Syracuse and S.E.C. Settle a Case Alleging Bond Fraud
description: Budget officials in Syracuse fraudulently misled the bond market about the crumbling state of the city's budget in selling $23.1 million in bonds in late 1995 and early 1996, the Federal Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday.

title: French Church Issues Apology To Jews on War
description: The Roman Catholic Church in France apologized to the Jewish people today for its silence in the face of French collaboration with the Holocaust.

title: Meatloaf Is Proof That an Old Love Can Be the Best Love
description: THE American love affair with meatloaf is not only enduring, but if anything, it is also intensifying. The restaurant trend continues unabated, as establishments serve meatloaf with great pride, although their concoctions are generally no better than the humble ones made at home.

title: Early Account Of Shooting In Dobbs Ferry Is Recanted
description: Shortly after an off-duty police officer killed a man in a dispute over a parking space, a witness, Michael Dillon, told the police and television reporters that he thought the killing was justified.

title: HANIFEN, IMHOFF TO SELL FINANCIAL CLEARING UNIT TO FISERV
description: Hanifen, Imhoff Holdings Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its financial clearing operations to Fiserv Inc. for $97.2 million in cash and stock. The Denver-based Hanifen, Imhoff Inc., the investment banking arm of the firm, would continue to operate as an independent company, the company said. Fiserv, based in Brookfield, Wis., provides financial data-processing systems and related information-management services. Its stock fell $1.125, to $43.875. The clearing operation will continue to provide its services for the investment banking activities of Hanifen, Imhoff, the company said.

title: Seattle's Lefties Leave The Orioles Uncertain
description: The questions dominating the thoughts of Baltimore Manager Davey Johnson are commonplace in April and May, but not now, not this time of year, when the Orioles are preparing for their division series against Seattle that starts Wednesday.

title: Queens Student Accused Of Slashing School Aide
description: A 13-year-old student with a history of emotional problems used a box cutter to slash a classroom aide in a music class at a special-education school in Queens yesterday, a Board of Education spokesman said.

title: Fur Is Coming Out of the Fashion Industry's Closet
description: Perhaps it started in the spring, when the fashion model Naomi Campbell, who once posed nude for an advertisement that read ''I'd rather go naked than wear fur,'' strolled down the Fendi runway draped in a sable-lined coat from the Italian fashion house. Or maybe it was this fall, when all the important American retail fashion directors announced that they were buying something with fur. But what surely sealed it was the September issue of Vogue, whose cover featured a baby-blue Mongolian lamb jacket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARHAM, CONSTANCE C.
description: BARHAM-Constance C., Peekskill, Sun., Sept. 28. Requiem Eucharist will be offered in thanksgiving for her life on Wed. (today) at 11 AM, St. Peter's Episcopal Church, Peekskill. Interment Hillside Cemetery. Donations to St. Peter's Episcopal Church or Community Outreach Center, 137 N. Division Street, Peekskill, New York 10566

title: American Restaurants Offer a Taste Of Fresh Argentine Beef
description: FOR the first time in 65 years, fresh beef from Argentina is being imported into the United States, destined for steak houses and, eventually, for high-end retailers. The United States Department of Agriculture lifted its ban last May, after determining that Argentine cattle are free of hoof-and-mouth disease. Until then, only cooked and canned beef from Argentina were permitted.

title: Housing Court Is Scheduled For Reshaping By the State
description: Top New York State court officials announced major changes in the city's Housing Court yesterday in an attempt to repair a system that is widely considered chaotic and monumentally overburdened.

title: Lieutenants to Replace Desk Officers
description: Asserting that the New York Police Department needs more senior supervisors overseeing its day-to-day operations, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that beginning today the desk officers in each of the city's 76 precincts would be replaced by higher-ranking lieutenants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'ROURKE, JAMES D. ''BUZ''
description: O'ROURKE-James D. ''Buz''. On Sept. 28, 1997, of Bayside, New York. (Assistant to the Borough President of Queens). Husband of the late Joan. Devoted father of James F., Joanne Coffin, Kathleen Reilly, Bill and John O'Rourke. Dear brother of Reverend William O'Rourke & Margaret Kavanaugh. Also survived by ten loving grandchildren. Reposing at the Lloyd Funeral Home, 39th Ave. at 215 Street, Bayside. Mass Sacred Heart Church, Thursday 10:45AM. Memorials to Ozanam Hall Nursing Home, 42-41 201 St., Bayside, NY 11361, would be appreciated.

title: Essay; Flunk That Test
description: At the moment when Congress is grappling with the education lobby's bid to centralize power with the national testing of students, comes The New York Times with a stunning series that shows how the world's leading testing organization has for years been a patsy for cheaters.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERNSTEIN, LOTTELORE
description: BERNSTEIN-Lottelore. Love beyond space and time. Remembering. George

title: Many Girls Learn Better Without Boys Around
description: To the Editor:

title: At the New Year, a New Day for Riverdale; A Bronx Neighborhood Is Now a Lively Center for Orthodox Jews
description: Like many college seniors, Noah A. Hammerman finished his education last June with a B.A. in economics and no clear plan for the rest of his life. Unlike most, he saw his prospects in the Riverdale section of the Bronx and bought a kosher butcher shop there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGART, MARK A.
description: BOGART-Mark A. On September 29, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Lilian, loving father of Susan Herrmann, Laura and Lawrence Heimowitz. Cherished brother of Elizabeth Nadel, devoted grandfather of Andrew, James, Peter, Emily and Nicholas. Adoring great grandfather of Olivia and Jake. Former tax commissioner of the City of New York. Service Wednesday, 9:45AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Cantor Fitzgerald Shutting a Trading Unit
description: Cantor Fitzgerald L.P., a New York brokerage firm, said yesterday that it planned to shut down its fixed-income trading unit, known as the Global Trading Securities Group.

title: Both Candidates Are Faulted
description: The Black Ministers' Council is not particularly happy with either Gov. Christine Todd Whitman or her main rival, Senator McGreevey, after interviewing both candidates yesterday, its leader said.

title: So Why Do H.M.O.'s Want to Be Regulated?; Let Patients Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: When Mother Has a Secret and Mum's the Word
description: It's too early to say for sure, but the walkout champ at this year's New York Film Festival looks like ''Kitchen,'' adapted by Yim Ho from the arch novella by Banana Yoshimoto. Slow and hypersensitive from its opening shots of rain to its closing shots of rain, this moody film looks stylish but fails to find a visual vocabulary for its characters' unspoken thoughts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINBY, WILLIAM CONANT
description: QUINBY-William Conant, 78, of Greenwich died September 24 at home. Husband of Constance Pierce Quinby; father of Edward Quinby, James Quinby, Susan Liu, Elizabeth Manogue; grandfather of seven. A memorial service was held Monday in Christ Church, Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Greenwich Hospital Hospice Unit, 5 Perryridge Rd, Greenwich, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAUTNER, MATTHEW ERICH
description: MAUTNER-Matthew Erich. October 1, 1997. Darling Mackie, listening to you every day.

title: So Why Do H.M.O.'s Want to Be Regulated?; Treatment Isn't 'Futile'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTHROP, STUART JOHNSTON
description: NORTHROP-Stuart Johnston, in Scottsdale, Arizona on September 27, 1997 at age 71 after a long illness. Retired Chairman and CEO of the Huffy Corporation of Dayton, Ohio and a Director of numerous other companies, including BancOne Corporation and Dayton Power and Light Company. Resident of Naples, Florida. Son of the late Christine Johnston Northrop and the late Filmer Stuart Cockow Northrop, Sterling Professor of Law and Philosophy at Yale University and former Master of Silliman College there. Graduate in 1943 of the Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass. and in 1948 of Yale University. Survived by his wife, Judith, a daughter, Christine, of Haverford, Pennsylvania, a son, Richard, of Greenwich, Connecticut, and a brother, Johnston, also of Greenwich. A memorial service will be held at noon on Saturday, October 4, in Dwight Memorial Chapel on the Old Campus of Yale University. A reception will follow at Silliman College, 71 Wall Street, New Haven. Burial will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to the Office of Academy Resources at Phillips Academy, Andover, MA 01810, or the Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Association, Valley of the Sun, 3507 North Central Avenue, Phoenix, AZ 85017

title: Ready or Not, Here Comes the Bread
description: USING his plastic tongs as a pointer, a waiter at Aquavit quickly indicates the key sectors in his teeming wicker breadbasket. There are slices of sourdough bread, seven-grain bread and semolina with golden raisins and fennel.
