Off to either side lurk a dried-blueberry-and-walnut roll and a stern-looking flat Swedish rye bread. The basket sags under the weight. The tongs hover expectantly. The pressure builds. For the unprepared diner, it's like a lecture followed by a pop quiz. Was that fennel-blueberry, or walnut seven-grain? Is there a right answer?

title: Colina Journal; Latin America's Disabled: Unsafely Hidden Away
description: At a morgue in this suburb of Santiago, 20 bodies lay unclaimed today, a poignant illustration of how this society treats the mentally and physically handicapped.

title: Gains Harder For Blue Chips In 3d Quarter
description: Call it the crash of the titans.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, MIRIAM
description: MENDELSON-Miriam. Beloved wife of the late Julius, devoted mother of Steven Mendelson, and Barbara Migdal, loving grandmother of Jessica, Noah, Jonathan and Daniel, cherished sister of Morton and Beatrice, adored sister-in-law of Dorothy, Jeanette, and Abe, dear mother-in-law of Larry. A loving woman of great warmth and kindness, who will be deeply missed by many. Services Wednesday 10 A.M. at Parkside Chapel, Rego Park.

title: Experts Envision Battle Between Drug and Tobacco Companies
description: The increasing popularity of smoking-cessation aids like nicotine gum and skin patches portends intense competition between drug makers and tobacco companies to deliver smoke-free nicotine to millions of Americans who now smoke, tobacco researchers and market analysts say.

title: I.R.S. to Begin Forums With Taxpayers
description: Seeking to carry out a promise to improve handling of tax disputes, the Internal Revenue Service pledged today to open its regional offices nationwide on Nov. 15 so taxpayers with unresolved cases can meet face-to-face with officials.

title: Wine Talk; Another Rothschild Stands Behind a Bordeaux
description: WHO would have thought, a decade ago, that by the turn of the century two of the four Rothschilds most closely identified with Bordeaux wine would be women?

title: In Spending Bill, a Gauntlet On Census Is Thrown Down
description: The House today approved a compromise $31.7 billion spending bill for the Departments of Commerce, Justice, and State, setting up a clash with the Clinton Administration over a provision that would restrict the implementation of statistical sampling in the next census.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, MYRON L. (MIKE)
description: GREENE-Myron L. (Mike), 79, died suddenly on September 28th, 1997. Beloved husband of Shirley, devoted father of James and Robert, father-in-law to Marinita and Debra, loving grandfather of Anthony, Max, Lindsay, Benjamin and Hannah, adoring sisters Gloria Kaye, Arleen Gevanthor, loving sisters-in-law Hinda and Anita, many nieces & nephews. Private graveside service Wednesday, October 1st at 11:30 AM at the Westchester Hills Cemetery, 400 Saw Mill Rd., Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. He will be deeply missed.

title: By the Book; Revisiting the Cuisine of Italy With a Master
description: MARCELLA HAZAN is at her warmest and most genial in ''Marcella Cucina'' (HarperCollins, $35), trying dishes she has discovered in Italy and the United States and revisiting old favorites rooted in the cuisine of Venice.

title: The Chef
description: IN the farmers' markets the vivid colors of summer's produce are giving way to the burnished hues of the autumn harvest. This week's main course -- red snapper fillet with a simple tomato-onion compote and a flavorful tomato nage -- suggests the softer colors of the new season.

title: Canada Raises Key Rate
description: The Bank of Canada today raised its benchmark overnight lending range to commercial banks by 25 basis points, to 3.25 percent to 3.75 percent, to help ward off inflation. The central bank last raised its official rate on June 26 by 25 basis points.

title: Latest Reports Give Economy A Little Chill
description: Manufacturing growth slowed for the second consecutive month in September, a group of manufacturing executives said today in a sign that the overall economy may be cooling.

title: Clinton Nudges TV Forecasters On Warming
description: It was cloudy and cool outside the north portico of the White House this morning as Steve Doocy, the jovial Fox News Channel weatherman, asked Al Roker, the ebullient NBC weatherman, just why it was that the President of the United States had invited them over.

title: Turn-of-the-Century Building Is Now Expected to Go Luxury
description: The sturdy brick building on Seventh Avenue at 24th Street in Manhattan that served as a turn-of-the-century garment factory and later as an office building is expected to undergo yet another transformation, this time into a luxury apartment house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DWYER, VIRGINIA A.
description: DWYER-Virginia A. Retired Senior Vice-President of AT&T, died Monday, September 29, 1997 following a lengthy illness. She was 76. ''Ginny'' was a major presence. She was a Director and Deputy Chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York; Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the University of Rochester; and a Board member of Eaton Corporation, Schering-Plough, Borden, Southern Company, the Atlantic Companies, and Georgia Power. She also served as a Director of St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan, Chairman, Finance Committee of the National Council-Girl Scouts of America and consultant to the Financial Advisory Board of the Sisters of Charity. She was named Dame of Malta by Pope John Paul and was a Director of the YWCA of New York. She joined Western Electric in 1943 in actuarial operations. She progressed through Western and then AT&T where she was named Treasurer in 1981. Four decades after joining the company she was asked to set up the organization that implemented the court-ordered divestiture. She retired in 1986. She is survived by a brother and sister-in-law, Jack and Nancy Dwyer of Naples, FL; a sister and a brother-in-law, Marie and Dale Buley of Seaford, LI; eight nieces and nephews and thirteen great nieces and nephews, and many, many friends. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street, NYC on Thursday and Friday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Saturday at 10 AM at St. Paul the Apostle R.C. Church, 415 W. 59th St., NYC. Memorial contributions may be made to Virginia Dwyer Memorial Scholarship, University of Rochester R.C., Box 270032, Rochester, N.Y. 14627-0032.

title: Bridge; An Editor of Daily Bulletins Begins a Busy Retirement
description: A leading bridge journalist is now retired, but only slightly. In June, Henry Francis of Memphis handed over the reins to Brent Manley after 25 years as editor of The American Contract Bridge League Bulletin.

title: FLORIDA PAPER COMPANY TO BUY REAL ESTATE DEVELOPER
description: The St. Joe Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Arvida Company, a Florida residential developer, as part of St. Joe's plan to transform itself from a paper company into a developer. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. ''With the proposed transaction, St. Joe stakes its claim on becoming Florida's leading residential and commercial developer,'' said Peter Rummell, the company's chairman. Shares of St. Joe, which is based in Jacksonville, Fla., soared $16, to $115, or 16.2 percent, on the New York Stock Exchange. Arvida, which is based in Boca Raton, Fla., is one of the state's biggest and oldest developers. Since 1958, Arvida has developed more than 50 communities and more than 35,000 homes. It has also developed about five million square feet of commercial real estate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVECK, LAWRENCE
description: NOVECK-Lawrence. Larry Noveck, 92, died peacefully, on Friday, September 26, 1997, at Palm Beach, Florida. He was the loving husband for thirty years of Carolyn Schnurer Noveck, a wellknown Coty Award winning fashion designer. He is most lovingly remembered by his daughter, Jane Blyn Strompf and son, Ralph Noveck, whose mother Anne Blyn Noveck died in 1963. He is also survived by a stepson, Dr. Tony Schnurer & grandchildren, Jocelyn and Daniel Blyn Noveck, Lisa Blyn Buseck and Andrew Blyn and Frederic Siegel and four great grandchildren, Adam Blyn and Hayley Siegel and Eve and Peter Blyn Buseck. Family services were held in Palm Beach on September 29, 1997. A Memorial Service will be held at a date to be announced. For further information contact Quattlebaum - Holleman - Burse Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, Florida.

title: Chrysler, After Sales Plunge, Is Hopeful on New Models
description: All year long, the Chrysler Corporation has watched its sales lag behind last year's record levels, and in September its disappointment deepened.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASSABNI, NICHOLAS
description: MASSABNI - Nicholas. Beloved brother of Norma Feanny. Graduated from Pace University in Finance. His first job was with Brythe, Eastman & Dillon who were subsequently bought out by Paine Webber with whom he worked with as Vice President until he retired in 1995.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about restaurants in Madrid included a misplaced description. The phrase ''several of them trailblazers, all of them pretty pricey'' referred to the dozen restaurants given a single star by Michelin, not to the city's traditional places.

title: Union Pacific Plans to Move Containers
description: In the midst of what some customers and analysts are calling a major freight congestion crisis, the Union Pacific Corporation announced a plan late today to move as many as 40,000 containers off its system to get stalled trains moving again. But Union Pacific said the problems could hurt its bottom line into the first quarter of 1998.

title: Cone Still Torre Pick To Pitch Game 4
description: David Cone concedes that he has been stubborn about wanting to pitch in the division series, even with tendinitis in his right shoulder. So is Yankees Manager Joe Torre about wanting to start Cone again in a possible Game 4, even after Cone was cuffed for six runs in three and a third innings in New York's 8-6 victory on Tuesday night.

title: Calendar; Shows, Talks and a Festival
description: Fashion Retrospective

title: People
description: * Mark Weiss, chief executive at Rowland Americas, New York, was promoted to president and chief executive at Rowland Worldwide, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C. He succeeds Martin Franken, who will take a new executive position to be determined at Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., a company that will be formed by the planned breakup of Cordiant in December.

title: On Thalidomide, Let the Sick Choose
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Announces a Program to Reduce Illegal Drug Use
description: Announcing a series of antidrug measures that he hopes to make the hallmark of a second term, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would expand special police drug-fighting efforts into Queens and the Bronx, offer more treatment for addicts and make Washington Square Park a drug-free zone by placing it off limits to those convicted of selling drugs there.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on the front page of House and Home today about residential development in Manhattan's meatpacking district refers incorrectly to a place where Ed Filipowski, who is moving his office to the neighborhood, stopped to comment on the area. It was a coffee bar, not a bar, where he said ''It does me good to see this place every once in a while to remind myself I'm not crazy.''

title: Metro Matters; Switch-Hitter Could Blast A Home Run
description: WHEN Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross quoted Winston Churchill on Tuesday to explain the latest twist in her political career, she might as well have taped a big sign on her back saying: ''Kick Me.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNER, PAULINE STEINLAUF
description: TANNER-Pauline Steinlauf, after a long illness, cherished wife of the late Irving; loved by children Ben and Ellen Tanner Farkas, and Nicki and Harold Tanner; and grandchildren Esta and Paul Farkas, Gary and Lynn Farkas Schwartz, Peggy and David Tanner; Catherine Allegra and James Tanner, Kent and Karen Tanner Allen; and proud great-grandmother of 11. Her intelligence, love of, and loyalty to, family strengthened and enhanced our lives. Expressions of remembrance may be made to the Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem or to the Pauline and Irving Tanner Scholarship Fund at Cornell University. Funeral services will be Sunday, October 5, at 1:00 PM at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: On Thalidomide, Let the Sick Choose; Brazil Warning Label
description: To the Editor:

title: Honda Files Lawsuit Against Republic
description: The Honda Motor Company's American unit said today that it had filed suit against Republic Industries to halt Republic's proposed acquisitions of Honda dealerships in Tennessee and Alabama in the latest of several similar actions against Republic.

title: COLGATE TO SELL HEATING FUEL BUSINESS FOR $70 MILLION
description: Blyth Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the portable heating fuel business, including the Sterno and Handy Fuel brand names, from a unit of the Colgate-Palmolive Company for $70 million. Blyth Industries, based in Greenwich, Conn., makes candles and home-fragrance products. Colgate Palmolive, based in New York, makes consumer products including Colgate toothpaste and Mennen deodorants. The purchase, which is expected to close by the end of the year, includes manufacturing and distribution operations in Texarkana, Tex.

title: Critics of Trump's Riverside South Focus on Road Plan
description: About a year ago, Donald J. Trump, whose gigantic Riverside South development is now beginning to rise out of the Upper West Side waterfront, decided to build the road leading to his new towers atop a mound of landfill, instead of on a steel frame.

title: Youth Accused in Slaying
description: A 15-year-old youth was arrested yesterday and charged with murdering and sexually assaulting an 11-year-old boy who was selling candy Saturday afternoon for a school fund-raiser.

title: The Tyranny of Tests
description: The debate over President Clinton's proposal for voluntary national testing in reading and math has paid too little attention to whether a national curriculum benefits American children.

title: Grants for Resident Workers
description: A measure that would offer $5,000 grants to city employees who buy market-rate homes in Newark got preliminary approval yesterday from the City Council.

title: Teamsters President Becomes Grand Jury Witness
description: Ron Carey, the embattled teamsters' president, appeared yesterday before a Federal grand jury in Manhattan and defended himself against accusations that he knew of a fraudulent scheme to divert the union's money into his campaign coffers.

title: Spare Commuters a Barrage of Advertising
description: To the Editor:

title: The Art Behind the Art Show; Wheeling and Dealing to Get Monet to Brooklyn
description: Museum curators may have doctoral degrees, but they spend much of their time haggling with their counterparts at other institutions and reinventing the truism that everything has its price.

title: Pataki's Chief Deal Maker Departs
description: After 14 years as Gov. George E. Pataki's chief problem solver, Michael C. Finnegan boarded the 6:34 Metro-North train here this morning and headed to Wall Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTESMAN, ESTHER (GARFUNKEL)
description: GOTTESMAN-Esther (Garfunkel), on October 1, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin, adored mother of Milton, David and the late Alice, and loving mother-inlaw of Ruth. Devoted sister to Florence, Harold, Julian and the late Elsie and Mildred. Wonderful grandmother of Robert and Trudy, Alice and Larry, William and Debra. Loving great-grandmother of Benjamin, Sarah, Alan, Clara and Zachary. Funeral service is at 12 Noon, Sunday, October 5, at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, 125 East 85th Street, NYC. Family requests no flowers be sent.

title: REBORN AS RUGS: OUTSIDER ART, UNDERFOOT
description: When the self-taught Alabama artist Bill Traylor, a former slave, died in poverty in 1947, he probably could not have imagined that his painting of a leaping stag might someday become a custom-made wool rug (below) selling for $65 a square foot. And the anonymous creator of a 1942 game board (left) would probably be similarly surprised to see his design's new use.

title: Once Burned by British, Arbitragers Prove Shy
description: Speculators who bet on takeovers are usually gleeful when they see a new deal. But yesterday this group of high-stakes investors, who are known on Wall Street as risk arbitragers, were cautious as they assessed Worldcom's surprising $30 billion bid for MCI Communications.

title: Personal Shopper; Cuddled in Cotton
description: WHERE has all the polyester gone? Not long ago, pure cotton was hard to find in anything other than the high end of the bed linen market.

title: Conviction For Figure In Art Case
description: William P. Youngworth 3d, the Boston-area antiques dealer who claims he can help recover up to $300 million worth of art stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston in 1990, was convicted yesterday in an unrelated case of receiving a stolen van. As a habitual offender, he could get more than 15 years in prison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROLL, JANET SMYTH
description: CROLL-Janet Smyth. A memorial service will be held at St. James Chapel, Madison Avenue at 71 St, at 11 AM on Thursday, October 9.

title: From Tharp, a New Spirit For Her New Troupe
description: What goes round, zigzags back in Twyla Tharp's case. The spunky dance premieres she choreographed for her first program at City Center on Tuesday night share the creative spark of ''The Fugue,'' the 1970 Tharp classic on the same bill.

title: On Thalidomide, Let the Sick Choose; Inadequate Safeguard
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Troops in Bosnia Silence Karadzic's Television Station
description: NATO peacekeepers today seized four key television transmitters controlled by the hard-line Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, putting his party's television station off the air because it had refused to end attacks against international organizations working in Bosnia.

title: Fuel Law and Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  APFEL, IKE
description: APFEL-Ike. 6/1/52-10/2/92. Celebrating your life, you are always with your mother and your brother and The Rhinestone Gang. All our love.

title: A Swiss Lesson For U.S. Drug Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Harpsichord Debut Puts Emphasis On Bach
description: Arguments once raged as to whether Bach's music could be served as well on piano as on harpsichord; indeed, whether it should be played on piano at all. All things are never equal, however, and many of us who revel in the sound of a good harpsichord have come to prefer the best pianists plying this repertory to even the best of the harpsichordists. By and large, they play it better.

title: GILT BY ASSOCIATION: CONFOUNDING THE DEBATE OF THE ANCIENTS VS. THE MODERNS
description: ''Antiques and contemporary art can enhance each other,'' said Catherine Weinstock. In January, when she opened San Lorenzo, her shop at 123 West Broadway (Duane Street; 212-766-4770), she set European antiques against art that is strictly now. ''I didn't want to put doggy and horsy pictures on my walls,'' Ms. Weinstock (right) said. Instead, she offered artists monthlong solo shows. The 400-square-foot shop feels spare and modern despite the 18th- and 19th-century antiques. A carved 18th-century Italian walnut chest (right, $5,500) topped with slightly asymmetrical white ceramic bowls ($295) is set against a painting by Gregory Hilton, a New York artist. Swedish empire birch chairs (left; set of six, $9,000) complement another of Mr. Hilton's paintings, which sell for around $8,000.

title: Contract for PATH Union
description: The Port Authority said yesterday that it had reached a contract agreement with the union representing the 168 conductors, dispatchers and tower operators who run the PATH rail system.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Referendum on Lilco Plan Is Ordered Off Suffolk Ballot
description: A referendum on the state's proposed partial takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company was thrown off the Suffolk County ballot yesterday by a judge who ruled that it was an illegal opinion poll and misleadingly worded.

title: Top U.S. Health Officials Defend Third-World H.I.V. Research
description: Two of the Government's top health officials have issued a pointed defense of controversial experiments on H.I.V.-infected pregnant women in the third world, saying that the studies adhere to international principles of ethics and that they ''address an urgent need in the countries in which they are being conducted.''

title: Public Eye
description: ''Eat with our eyes,'' said Andrew Selvaggio, McDonalds's top cook and the self-described author of the Arch Deluxe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAITTONEN, EDITH
description: TAITTONEN-Edith, September 30, 1997. A graduate of Ohio State University, a veteran of the U.S. Navy, a New Yorker since 1957, she worked for many years for the Community Service Society and for the Community Council of Greater New York, and was an active member of the Women's City Club. She is survived by her sister, Thelma Whitehead of Westland, MI, a niece and nephew, and five grand-nephews and grand-nieces. She was a good, direct and helpful person, and her family and her friends and associates mourn her. A memorial service will be held at the Women's City Club. Contributions may be made to any good cause of your choice. The Addiss Family

title: A Step Toward Lawyer Integrity
description: While the struggle over Federal campaign financing intensifies on Capitol Hill, top leaders of New York State's judiciary must confront a campaign reform challenge closer to home. At issue are the contributions that bond lawyers pour into the campaigns of state and local officials to improve their chance of securing lucrative bond business -- a seamy political dance known as ''pay to play.''

title: The Endless Dance Around Belief
description: NEARER, MY GOD

title: Stanford Opotowsky, 73, Editor At New York Post and ABC News
description: Stanford L. Opotowsky, a former managing editor of The New York Post and director of news coverage for ABC News, died yesterday at his home in Orlando, Fla. He was 73.

title: In Her Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STYLES, JAMES G.
description: STYLES-James G. The Board of Directors and membership of the Junior League of Northern Westchester extend their heartfelt condolences to Ann Styles, past president; her children, Gordon and Connor, and their entire family. His warmth and generosity of spirit will be remembered and cherished by all whose lives he touched. Betsy Isles, President

title: OUTDOOR OUTLINES: AN AUTOBIOGRAPHY ON THE WALLS OF PARIS
description: In Paris, even the graffiti are stylish. Miss.Tic, who uses the walls of Paris as pages for her autobiography (above), is one of many contemporary artists who work outdoors in stencil. ''Ambush in the Streets: A Photographer's Encounter With the Stencil Art of Paris'' is an exhibition of 70 images by Jules Backus, who died last year. It opens Tuesday and runs through Dec. 6 at Cooper Union's Foundation Building, 7 East Seventh Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREYFUSS, KLEIN, BERTHA (NEE ROHR)
description: DREYFUSS-KLEIN-Bertha (nee Rohr). On October 1, 1997. Beloved mother of Ralph (Helen). Loving grandmother of Michele (Fred), Jamie, and Madeleine (Paul). Dearest great-grandmother of Philip, Teddy, Emily and Isaac Sherrill, Jordana Dreyfuss, Justin and Amanda Schnell. Graveside service Sunday, 2PM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, N.J.

title: As Hershiser Goes, So May Go the Indians
description: Barring unexpected developments, the Cleveland Indians lost the opening round of the American League playoffs in the opening game Tuesday night.

title: Russia's Former Head of Privatization Faces Bribery Charge
description: Russia's former privatization chief is being accused of receiving a bribe in a politically explosive case that has cast a cloud over the Yeltsin Government's program to sell billions of dollars in state assets.

title: Release of a Hamas Leader: A Tangle of Mideast Intrigue
description: In the hours after Sheik Ahmed Yassin, the spiritual leader of Hamas, was flown from an Israeli prison to Jordan early this morning, the Israeli and Jordanian press have produced growing evidence that his release was part of a secret deal to placate King Hussein after an Israeli attempt to assassinate a Hamas leader in Jordan.

title: On Thalidomide, Let the Sick Choose; Benefits Surpass Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Slum Dwellers in Rio Await the Pope's Return Visit to Brazil This Week
description: As she passed the chapel where, 17 years ago, Pope John Paul II blessed the poor in her hillside shantytown, Vidigal, Manuelinha Alves Sobrinho could not resist stopping in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRISWOLD, SUSAN SOMERVELL
description: GRISWOLD-Susan Somervell, of Essex, MA., September 30, at 74, wife of the late John Wool Griswold and daughter of the late General Brehon Burke Somervell and Anna Purnell Somervell. Survived by two sons, John A. of New York and Brehon S. Griswold of Ipswich, Ma., three grandchildren, Chester, William, and Kathryn, two sisters, Mary Ann Somervell Brenza of Carthage, N.C. and Constance Somervell Matter of Pittsburgh, PA. A memorial service will be held Saturday, October 4, at the Emanuel Episcopal Church, Masconomo Street, Manchester-bythe-Sea, MA., at 11:30 A.M.

title: Casino-Guichard Favors Offer From Rallye
description: Casino-Guichard Perrachon, a unit of Groupe Casino, said yesterday that its board favored a modified offer by Rallye S.A., which owns a third of the company, and rejected a sweetened one by Promodes S.A. The board, headed by Jean-Charles Naouri, whose investment company Euris owns 75 percent of Rallye S.A., made the statement less than a week after Rallye modified its bid for Casino.

title: Salomon's Equity Derivatives Chief Quits
description: Jonathan E. Sandelman, 39, the managing director in charge of equity derivatives trading at Salomon Brothers Inc., has resigned after differences with the management of the firm's equity department.

title: Jefferson Opposed Local Rule on Education; Hamilton's 'Humiliation'
description: To the Editor:

title: An Acquisition in Pet Care
description: Petco Animal Supplies agreed today to acquire Petcare, a closely held company in Chicago, for stock valued at $53.3 million, expanding in nine states in the Midwest and South. Under the deal, Petcare owners will receive 1.7 million shares of Petco stock. Petco, a pet-care supply chain based here, will also assume an unspecified amount of debt. After the purchase, it will have 430 stores in 31 states.

title: Metro Business; Plan to Buy Nuclear Plant
description: GPU Inc., an electric utility holding company in Parsippany, N.J., said yesterday that it was in talks with a company that wants to buy the Three Mile Island nuclear plant, site of the worst nuclear accident in the United States, and its Oyster Creek nuclear plant.

title: With Inventories Up, Crude Oil Prices Fall
description: Crude oil prices fell yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after a report showed inventories on the rise, particularly on the East Coast, assuring traders of ample supplies heading into winter.

title: Inspector Morse Would Not Approve
description: Passionate fans of John Thaw, who is best known in the United States as the Oxford sleuth Inspector Morse, will undoubtedly be both eager and skeptical as they tune in to ''Into the Blue,'' a two-hour ''Mystery!'' being broadcast in its entirety tonight. And that's as it should be. Mr. Thaw is back, which is clearly good news, but he is not back as Morse. The chances of that being good news are, alas, pretty slim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICKOLIC, LAURENCE
description: MICKOLIC-Laurence. The Fresh Air Fund mourns the loss of its beloved staff member, Laurence Mickolic. Larry dedicated 29 years of his life to working tirelessly on behalf of our Fresh Air children. He was admired for his commitment, leadership and warmth. He will be remembered with fondness and respect. Susan Newhouse, Chairman Jenny Morgenthau, Exec Director

title: Senate Panel Lets Trade Bill Easily Clear First Hurdle
description: A day after Republican leaders said Congress was increasingly unlikely to give President Clinton wide authority in negotiating trade agreements, the Senate Finance Committee voted overwhelmingly today to do so.

title: UPSTART OFFERING $30 BILLION TO BUY MCI, USING STOCK
description: Barging in on a grand trans-Atlantic telecommunications alliance, an upstart long-distance telephone company made an unsolicited offer yesterday to buy the MCI Communications Corporation for $30 billion in stock.

title: Summer Is Over, but 'Fore!' Is in Air
description: The day after Labor Day is the end of the golf year for a large percentage of those who play the game. These are people who consider golf just another diversion, or perhaps a business networking device, or a social status sort of thing.

title: Trusting in Test Scores Is Perilous; Meaningless Scores
description: To the Editor:

title: Mercedes-Benz Is Lured Away From New Jersey
description: In the latest tug-of-war for business between New York and New Jersey, this one pitting one suburb against a neighboring town, Mercedes-Benz of North America said yesterday that it had accepted a $5.4 million package of New York State incentives to move its headquarters just over the state line, only a brisk 20-minute bike ride from its current location in New Jersey.

title: Harassment Law Is Proposed
description: A Democratic lawmaker said yesterday that he would introduce legislation to require the State Attorney General to investigate all charges of sexual harassment filed against state employees before agreeing to pay for their defense and settlement costs.

title: Dentsu to Combine 2 California Agencies
description: Dentsu USA is combining two California agencies by making Hajjar & Partners in Marina del Rey an independent unit of a sibling shop, Colby Effler & Partners in Santa Monica.

title: U.S. Starts Trade Sanction Process Against Koreans and 4 Others
description: Seeking to show its toughness on trade both to other nations and to Congress, the Clinton Administration listed the countries today that it said were failing to live up to their free trade obligations, citing South Korea, in particular, for obstructing access to American automobile exports.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Bloomberg News in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about a proposed merger of the movie theater operations of the Sony Corporation and the Cineplex Odeon Corporation misstated part of the arrangement. Universal Studios will invest $84.5 million to obtain a 26 percent stake in the new company; the figures are not $85 million and 26.7 percent.

title: Cigna Says Quarterly Earnings Will Be Short of Expectations
description: The Cigna Corporation said yesterday that it expected its earnings to fall short of analyst estimates in the third quarter because of higher-than-expected costs at its health plans. The news followed a similar announcement by another big insurer, Aetna, earlier this week.

title: Alou's Bat Wakes Up Just in Time
description: Standing in the batter's box with the game on the line, facing a man with a 100-mile-an-hour fastball, Moises Alou had to cast aside the fact that he had no hits in eight playoff at-bats.

title: First Lady Is Low Key On Overhaul Of Child-Care
description: In a day packed with a half-dozen public events to promote good child care, Hillary Rodham Clinton demonstrated today that she had learned some lessons from the failure of her 1994 campaign to enact national health insurance.

title: Coach Switzer Explains It All: Cowboys, Guns and Jones
description: Coach Barry Switzer comes to Giants Stadium with his Dallas Cowboys this weekend. And while there is anticipation for yet another chapter in this enduring rivalry, if you are Switzer, there are always other issues to discuss first.

title: Residential Resales
description: Big Deal

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about William Craig, a historian, misidentified a surviving son who lives in Seoul, South Korea. His name is Richard; Mr. Craig did not have a son named Edward. The obituary also misidentified the person who reported the cause of death. It was Mr. Craig's son William Jr., not the son misidentified as Edward.

title: Landlords Sue State Housing Officials to Preserve Rent Increases
description: In an attempt to block Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council, the city's largest landlord groups sued state housing officials yesterday to try to preserve a rent increase for about 55,000 rent-controlled apartments in the city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINTAVALLE, JOSEPH T.
description: QUINTAVALLE-Joseph T. The Regis High School Board of Trustees, Administration, Faculty and Students mourn the loss of Joseph T. Quintavalle. Joseph was an alumnus, Class of 1930, and former faculty member. Joe has left an indelible impression on the students and the Regis community where he taught for 39 years. He will be remembered as a legendary teacher and a very dear friend. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, Betty, and his family. May Joseph rest in peace.

title: Trusting in Test Scores Is Perilous
description: To the Editor:

title: A Riverboat Gamble Pays Off as Orioles Pound Mariners
description: Imagine having the gall to bench Joe Montana for a playoff game, or Michael Jordan, or Mark Messier. Baltimore Manager Davey Johnson benched two stars tonight, and he got away with it. In a big way.

title: Marvin Rothenberg, 79, Dies; Director of Legendary TV Ads
description: Marvin Rothenberg, a director who staged some of the most memorable television moments of the 1950's and 60's -- all during commercial breaks -- died last Thursday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 79.

title: British Quartet Rocks Jamaica
description: While surfing the World Wide Web earlier this year, Coach Steve Sampson of the United States came across a German soccer player named Michael Mason. The midfielder spoke little English and had never set foot in this country, but Mason's father was a retired serviceman born in Philadelphia.

title: Officials Agree On Modest Plan For a Rail Link To One Airport
description: After nearly 30 years of bickering, false starts and failed attempts to build a rail system linking New York City and its airports, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki have agreed on a scaled-down connection to Kennedy International Airport from the train station in Jamaica, Queens, both officials announced yesterday.

title: Fassel Will Use Pegram on Third Down
description: The Giants' acquisition of running back Erric Pegram on Tuesday underscores what has been increasingly obvious for several weeks: the Giants expect little, if any, production from Rodney Hampton this season. And today, Coach Jim Fassel only pushed Hampton down a notch on the depth chart when he named Pegram, who practiced with the Giants for the first time today, the third-down back for Sunday's game against the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Valentine Off To the Orient
description: Bobby Valentine, the Mets' manager, will scout two South Korean pitchers and a Japanese pitcher on a trip to the Far East that he will begin today, a Mets official confirmed yesterday.

title: Accounting Issues Prompt Clash at Hearing
description: In a rare display of pique, Congressional lawmakers demanded to know today why a private sector body was proposing accounting rules that have produced howls from big business.

title: Senate Election Inquiry Clears Democrat From Louisiana
description: A Senate committee voted unanimously today to drop its inquiry into the election of Senator Mary L. Landrieu after months of partisan wrangling, the expenditure of hundreds of thousands of dollars and a foray into the roguish world of Louisiana politics.

title: A Long-Distance Visionary
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, the blunt, folksy 54-year-old chief executive of Worldcom Inc., is an entrepreneurial stepchild of the telecommunications revolution set off by the breakup of AT&T just over a decade ago.

title: Judge Upholds 'Harsh' Law On Retirement Accounts
description: A Federal law that prevents millions of Americans from taking a tax deduction for contributions to individual retirement accounts in years when they change jobs is ''harsh,'' a Tax Court judge has held, but he added that he had no power to overturn it.

title: MANITOWOC TO ACQUIRE MAKER OF BEVERAGE DISPENSERS
description: The Manitowoc Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Servend International for $65 million to $75 million in cash to complement its food-service business. Servend, which is a closely held maker of beverage dispensers and dispensing valves based in Sellersburg, Ind., is expected to have 1997 sales of $50 million. Manitowoc said it had derived about half of its 1996 revenue of $500 million from sales and service of its ice cube and commercial refrigeration equipment. Its shares rose $2.1875, to $37.875.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLETS, THOMAS SEAMAN
description: WILLETS-Thomas Seaman, of Essex, CT., died Sept 30. Memorial service October 4, 1 P.M. at St. John's Episcopal Church, Main St. Essex. Contributions to Coast Guard Fdtn. (Sailing Program), 394 Taugwonk Road, Stonington, CT. 06378 or St. John's Building Fund, P.O. Box 422, Essex, CT. 06426.

title: Esther G. Gottesman, 98, Zionist With Role in Scrolls Acquisition
description: Esther G. Gottesman, whose service to the Jewish community spanned more than 60 years and who played an important role in the acquisition of the Dead Sea Scrolls for Israel, died yesterday at her home in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 98 and had homes in Palm Beach and Manhattan.

title: One Incident, Two Accounts; Insubordinate Officer or Peacemaker? A Matter of Perception
description: The police say the incident began when a 27-year-old college student named Jens Nerestant stood in front of a police cruiser one late night last summer in St. Albans, Queens, and took a defiant swig from a 40-ounce bottle of beer.

title: Major Leagues' Tax Man Will Collect From Yankees
description: The Yankees may hold off the Cleveland Indians, and maybe they will hold off one or two more teams this month as they try for a second successive World Series championship. But they will not be able to hold off baseball's tax man.

title: Spare Commuters a Barrage of Advertising; No Censorship Here
description: To the Editor:

title: Merrill Settles Bond Fund Suit
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to settle a class action suit involving shareholders of two of its mutual funds for $90 million in cash and coupons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENSTEIN, ROY
description: LICHTENSTEIN - Roy. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art mourn the passing of Roy Lichtenstein. From a vast array of sources in our common culture, he fashioned an art of sharp sophistication that was humorous, ironic, elegant, and continually inventive. His brashness on canvas was balanced in life by a quiet, self-effacing manner informed by tremendous good will and generosity. Few artists so admired in the inner circles of the art world have had such a global impact on the visual sensibility of their time, and fewer still have commanded such a special blend of love and respect from those who knew him. He altered the way we see our culture, and the way we think and feel about it. Though his career was long and productive, we thought that he, like his art, was permanently blessed with an unassailable edge of youthfulness. A singular joy has been taken from us, and in our sadness and loss we offer condolences to his beloved wife Dorothy and his family. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director Kirk Varnedoe, Chief Curator, Department of Painting and Sculpture, The Museum of Modern Art, N.Y.

title: At Odds With U.S., France Says No to NATO Role
description: France told the NATO allies today that French officers, absent from the alliance's military command structure since 1966, would not rejoin when it is reorganized at the end of this year because the United States was not ready to let a European officer take over the key Southern Command in Naples.

title: Golfers Robbed on Course
description: The serenity of a private golf club in Wayne was shattered Tuesday when a masked gunman robbed two golfers of their diamond jewelry, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSLEY, MARTIN
description: KINGSLEY-Martin. On September 30, 1997. Beloved father of Claudia Kingsley, devoted son of the late Sadye and Harry Kornhauser, loved brother of Edna Kasner and dear uncle of Karen Winik and Jay Kasner.

title: On Thalidomide, Let the Sick Choose; A Tale of Two Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Co-op Board Members Fret Over Ruling on Liability
description: A Brooklyn judge has ruled that board members of cooperative apartment buildings can face criminal charges for actions by the board, a decision that has alarmed many volunteers who serve on co-op boards throughout the city.

title: Knicks: New Test, Old Goal
description: It is time to pull the wraps off the hermetically sealed Knicks, a team whose personnel and style have been preserved for another season. Once again, they are seeking the same goal as they begin training camp in Charleston, S.C., on Friday. And yet there is an added urgency to win a championship. There are only so many coats of paint left on Patrick Ewing and only so much time before the bubbling new group of Atlantic Division upstarts begin chipping away at the Knicks.

title: Bank of Nova Scotia To Buy Mocatta Bullion
description: The Bank of Nova Scotia said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Mocatta Bullion and Base Metals, the London Metal Exchange gold-dealing unit of Standard Chartered P.L.C., becoming one of the largest precious and base metal dealers in the world.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Metro Business; 2 New Stores for Guess
description: Guess Inc., the Los Angeles-based clothing company best known for its line of jeans, has arrived in Manhattan, with a new store in SoHo and another on the way in the South Street Seaport. After opening 119 stores around the country since its founding in 1981 by three brothers -- Armand, Maurice and Paul Marciano -- Guess determined that it was ready for New York.

title: Cancer Study on 50's Bomb Tests Is Released
description: The National Cancer Institute today released information from a study of radiation doses from atomic bomb tests in the 1950's that was long, long-awaited and mostly inconclusive: 115,000 pages produced over 14 years that predict an increase in thyroid cancer of 2 percent to 20 percent above normal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSON, VIVIAN A.
description: OLSON-Vivian A. On Sept. 30, 1997. Beloved mother of Kathryn and Alan Greenberg, Connie and Ronald Fishbach. Adored grandmother of Daniel and Stephen Fishbach. Contributions in her memory may be made to Diabetes Research Institute Foundation, 11 Penn Plaza, New York, NY 10001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, IRVING
description: FRIEDMAN-Irving, on October 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Hortense Friedman. Dear father of Ruth Milberg-Kaye and the late Michael Friedman, adored grandfather of George, Seth and Laurie. Cherished brother of Alex Friedman. Services private.

title: Chocolate Toy Withdrawn
description: The Nestle candy company announced today it was immediately withdrawing a product called Nestle Magic, which had drawn sharp criticism from consumer groups that said it presented a choking hazard for small children.

title: Jefferson Opposed Local Rule on Education
description: To the Editor:

title: In His Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Foreign Affairs; Missile Myopia
description: What is coming to be known as the Iran missile crisis is in many ways the quintessential post-cold-war foreign-policy problem. But before we go to war with Iran to solve it, let's sort out fact from hype.

title: Paris Journal; Gasping for Air, the City of Light Takes a Breather
description: Endowed with grand boulevards and mansions, Paris has always held itself to be somewhat above other less handsome, more gritty cities. So it has come as a shock, just when everyone was enjoying the pleasures of an Indian summer, to hear that in recent days the City of Light had become the City of Smog.

title: White House Awaits Reno Ruling on Gore
description: The White House today played down the significance of Attorney General Janet Reno's expected decision to expand a Justice Department inquiry into whether to seek an independent prosecutor to investigate Vice President Al Gore's telephone fund-raising calls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONARD, DOROTHY S.
description: LEONARD-Dorothy S., formerly of Bronxville, NY, on Sept. 30, 1997. Wife of the late Richard M. Leonard. Mother of Richard M. Leonard, Jr. and Eugene A. Leonard. Service and interment private.

title: FOR FAMILIES THAT PLAY TOGETHER: WHAT NEXT? SHOOTING HOOPS IN THE BASEMENT
description: What makes the basement of this house in Brooklyn different from most others?

title: SWEDISH MODEM: FROM IKEA, HOME OFFICE BY CATALOGUE
description: Just as the market for home office furnishings has grown, so has Ikea's catalogue. In 1996, the Swedish retailer tested its first business catalogue; it was 18 pages. This year, there were 66 pages of square, rectangular and bullet-nosed desks that could be arranged in hundreds of configurations, along with lamps and storage units. Last year, some of the 12 Ikea stores in the United States carried the merchandise. This year, all the stores will have it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRAMPLER, WALTER
description: TRAMPLER-Walter. The Board of Directors and staff of Young Audiences/New York mourn the passing of our esteemed Advisory Council member. We will deeply miss his commitment to the arts and the children of New York. We extend our condolences to his family. Stephen Gray, President

title: Market Place; A record year for underwriting seems to be a certainty.
description: WITH the stock market continuing its phenomenal ascent and interest rates holding steady, stock and bond underwriting reached record levels last quarter, putting the new issues market on course to have its best year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEEHERN, RICHARD J.
description: GEEHERN-Richard J. On October 1, 1997. Of Scarsdale, New York. Husband of Margaret K. Father of Constance M. Brother of Joseph J. Family will receive friends at Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, N.Y., Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Fatima Church, Saturday 10 A.M.

title: DEAL TO COMBINE 2 MANUFACTURERS OF MODEMS
description: Westell Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the Amati Communications Corporation for $394 million in stock, combining two makers of equipment that sends information at high speeds over phone lines. Amati shareholders will receive nine-tenths of a Westell share for each Amati share. Based on Tuesday's closing price, the transaction values Amati at $19.97 a share. Amati's shares gained 43.75 cents, to $19.125, in Nasdaq trading yesterday. Westell rose $1, to $23.1875. The two companies make asynchronous digital subscriber-line modems. Amati, based in San Jose, Calif., will become a wholly owned unit of Westell, which is based in Aurora, Ill.

title: TALISMAN ENERGY TO BUY ANOTHER CANADIAN OIL CONCERN
description: Talisman Energy Inc., an oil and natural gas company, agreed yesterday to acquire Pembina Resources Ltd. for $501 million (Canadian), or $362 million (United States), plus assumed debt of $104 million (Canadian), or $75 million (United States). Pembina, a unit of the Loram Corporation, is a privately held oil and gas company with operations throughout Canada. It produces 10,000 barrels a day of liquids and 92 million cubic feet a day of natural gas. It also produces more than 60 percent of Ontario's crude oil. Talisman and Pembina are based in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the trial of a police officer charged with murder in a dispute over a parking space in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., misstated the role of a lawyer, Stephen Lewis. He represents Robert Errico, a co-defendant, not the officer, Richard D. DiGuglielmo.

title: Before He Gets to Golota, Lewis Is Battling His Promoter
description: When Lennox Lewis arrived here Sunday night, there was no car waiting for him at the airport. By his own estimation, Lewis and his entourage waited half an hour for cars to take them to their hotel.

title: A Filmmaker at High Tide Since France's New Wave
description: Agnes Varda has always been a fiercely independent filmmaker, working outside the mainstream and unallied with any group or genre. From the first, she was known as the woman of the New Wave, but even that was something of a misconception. Having made her first feature, ''La Pointe Courte,'' in 1954, she predates most of her French directorial colleagues who made their names in the late 1950's and early 60's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, DANIEL G.
description: ROSS-Daniel G. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services mourn the passing of Daniel G. Ross, a leader in the Jewish community and the father-in-law of Laura Ross, a trustee. JBFCS extends its deepest sympathy to Ms. Ross and her family. Seymour R. Askin, Jr., President Joseph S. Kaplan, President-Elect Fredric W. Yerman, Chairman Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Executive Vice President

title: Jury Finds Police Department Guilty of Age Discrimination
description: A Federal jury ruled yesterday that the New York Police Department committed age discrimination against four deputy police chiefs during its reorganization in 1994. The court awarded $450,000 in damages to each of the men, who said they were transferred to an undesirable night assignment because they were over 50 years old.

title: Depositions Unsealed in Suit Against Milbank, Tweed Firm
description: Lawyers at the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy wrote off $324,000 of work for Mikael Salovaara, a Wall Street financier, after they began to fear that the assignment would conflict with Milbank's representation of a mining equipment company in which Mr. Salovaara had been deeply involved, according to depositions unsealed today in a Federal court in Milwaukee.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MCI Draws Rival Bid Valued at $30 Billion

title: For Rangers, a Rookie Left Wing Who Displays a Look of Experience
description: Only a team as old as the Rangers would have an experienced 26-year-old, first-year player who is too old to qualify for the Calder trophy as rookie of the year. He is Johan Lindbom, drafted in the third round last summer, and he might be a major discovery of training camp.

title: Ex-Officer Convicted of Choking Teen-Ager
description: Francis X. Livoti, the former police officer acquitted in the death of a Bronx man but later expelled from the force for using an illegal choke hold, was found guilty in Bronx Criminal Court yesterday of slapping and choking a teen-ager in a separate confrontation.

title: Success in the Fast Lane Worth Fortune to Glenn
description: Sign a new contract in the National Football League -- especially a nice, fat one -- and everyone has his hand out. Or at the very least your teammates make jokes about how rich you are. Cornerback Aaron Glenn's salary has gone into orbit, which means the jokes now come fast and furious.

title: Economics 101: Slaughter Makes Sense
description: Early last month, a couple, perhaps in their mid-60's, took in the sights of Jacksonville, Fla. Their matching jackets and caps identified them as proud Central Michigan University supporters.

title: The Tide Is Not Lifting Everyone
description: The Census Bureau set the White House aglow this week when it reported that in 1996 median income rose for the second consecutive year while black and Hispanic poverty rates fell. President Clinton said the report proved that his economic policies were working and that the middle class was finally on the rise. But a deeper look at the census report finds a gloomier perspective -- the middle class is not doing very well and the poor are falling further behind.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 25 about the previous day's memorial tribute to Willem de Kooning at the Museum of Modern Art misspelled the surname of the composer of a work played at the tribute. He is Pete Calandra, not Calandro.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Travel Update : The Wealthy and Worried Build 'God Forbid Rooms'
description: Crime rates have been falling across much of America, but you wouldn't know it from the way some people spend their money. Sales of body armor are up in this country where there is nearly one privately owned gun (223 million) for every inhabitant, children included. Even bulletproof bras are selling. And small, but growing numbers of people are building secret, heavily protected redoubts into their houses. Some people, reports The New York Times, call them the "God forbid room," as in "God forbid that a kidnapper should come storming in here with a gun."

title: Questions on Accepted Legal Practice
description: It is a curiosity that cuts against the grain of basic American notions of fairness: a citizen not convicted of any crime -- or even charged with one -- can be held in jail for months on end, simply for refusing to answer a court's questions. It also happens to be a well-settled practice of Anglo-Saxon jurisprudence.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEIT, SOL
description: LEIT-Sol. Happy 70th Birthday, we miss you and love you, Your Family

title: Rent Warriors
description: CRAIG FERGUSON, a freelance cartoonist in Manhattan, should have considered himself lucky. In the tightest rental market in recent New York history, he was paying only $622 a month for a large studio apartment on one of the best blocks in Chelsea.

title: Economic Scene; Wanted: a global warming policy that stands a chance.
description: IT'S crunch time at the White House on climate change policy. With the meeting on global warming set for Kyoto, Japan, in December, the Clinton Administration has less than three weeks to come up with its own proposal before the agenda is locked in place by meeting planners and America is reduced to the role of commentator.

title: Betting the U.S. Economy on a Rising Stock Market
description: Twice in the 1990's, the American economy has produced nearly identical periods of booming growth. Yet the experts looked at what was happening and saw in the first surge, in 1994, the makings of a disaster and in the second, this year, nirvana.

title: With Pilots Finally on Board, US Airways Plans New Direction
description: Having finally reached a tentative labor agreement with his company's pilots, Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman and chief executive of US Airways, must now determine how the carrier can elbow its way into the top ranks of the airline industry. It will not be easy.

title: LAND O'LAKES TO BUY ALPINE LACE BRANDS IN NEW JERSEY
description: Land O'Lakes Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Alpine Lace Brands Inc., a cheese and meat marketer in Maplewood, N.J., for $62 million. Land O'Lakes, the privately held food and agricultural cooperative based in Arden Hills, Minn., will pay $9.125 a share in cash for Alpine Lace and will assume some of its debt, an Alpine Lace spokesman said. A specific debt amount was not available. The deal, which has been approved by both boards, is expected to close by late 1997 or early 1998. Shares of Alpine Lace closed at $8.65625, down $1.34375, on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Windbreakers, Jeans, Pajamas and Hairless Chests
description: Pop's most enthusiastic audiences are its youngest ones: grade-school and junior-high girls who shriek with joy for their current infatuations. Three years later, they may be embarrassed by their former fixations, but for the moment there are albums, T-shirts, posters, videos and personalized throw pillows to be acquired.

title: Life on the Carving Edge: The Herd Arrives
description: IN the late afternoon, Gansevoort Street still has the look of a demented Edward Hopper painting. The light spills across the cobblestones onto empty meat warehouses with bricked-over windows and faded signs that advertise goose necks, pigs knuckles and ''top sirloin butts.''

title: Smart Enough to Run but Too Dumb to Cover Their Tracks
description: The casually sulfurous tone of the Australian film noir ''Kiss or Kill'' is set in its opening scene, a homage to ''Kiss Me Deadly,'' in which a little girl named Nikki watches traumatized as her mother, clad only in a white bathrobe, answers a knock on the door and goes up in flames from a killer's tossed match. Flash forward to the present: the grown-up Nikki (Frances O'Connor), is now a cold-blooded grifter in cahoots with her boyfriend, Al (Matt Day). In their standard modus operandi, Nikki flirts with a businessman in a bar, and Al barges onto the scene to pick a fight that he intentionally loses. Accompanying the mark to his hotel room, Nikki drugs him, and Al shows up to strip the victim of money and valuables.

title: Four Straight Walks Help Braves Rout Astros
description: After playing a nearly flawless game and still losing to the Atlanta Braves Tuesday, the Houston Astros staggered through Game 2 and this time lost big, 13-3.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CCA PRISON REALTY TRUST, Nashville, a real estate investment trust, bought the Torrance County Detention Center in New Mexico from Corrections Corp. of America for $38.5 million.

title: 1997 BASEBALL PLAYOFFS
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Hard-Line Communists Plunge Italy Into Crisis Over Budget Cuts
description: Just as Italy was beginning to enjoy an unaccustomed reputation for fiscal responsibility and political stability, the Government was thrown into crisis today by a small party of hard-line Communists balking at further cuts in the welfare state.

title: THE NEW P.S. 1: CONTEMPORARY ART, BUT THE BUILDING'S THE STAR
description: When P.S. 1, the city-sponsored contemporary-art center in Long Island City, Queens, reopens on Oct. 29, it will contain works by more than 170 artists. But the star of the show may be the building itself, an 1890 Beaux Arts Romanesque brick school, which has had an $8.5 million renovation during the last two years. Alanna Heiss, the founding director of P.S. 1, did not want the building to be gutted, or made pristine. Frederick Fisher of Frederick Fisher & Partners in Los Angeles was asked to expose the bones of the 100,000-square-foot space and create a startling variety of galleries and installation spaces, indoors and out. He did: there are 36 galleries. ''We have finished spaces with smooth white walls and spaces with exposed-brick vaulted ceilings and spaces with original tin ceilings,'' said Mr. Fisher, the design architect. And lest the stairwells go to waste, Ms. Heiss invited artists to paint them. P.S. 1 is at 22-25 Jackson Avenue (46th Avenue). For information: (718) 784-2084.

title: Surprise Offer Swells Trading on Nasdaq
description: The Nasdaq stock market said a record number of shares traded on the exchange yesterday in the wake of Worldcom's $30 billion offer to buy MCI Communications, with the final tally registering just shy of one billion shares.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BILL COSBY's wife, CAMILLE, has pledged $20,000 to help buy and preserve a tract of land in Greenfield, Mass., that is an ancient Indian burial ground, a group of conservationists said.

title: Messinger Urges Broad Overhaul Of How Schools Are Being Run
description: Ruth W. Messinger called yesterday for an overhaul of the New York City school system, saying major decisions on running public schools should be shifted to principals. She also said incompetent principals should be dismissed, failing students should be held back and the city's most problem-plagued schools should be closed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZANCA, JOSEPH A.
description: ZANCA-Joseph A. On October 1, 1997, of Forest Hills, N.Y. Veteran W.W. II Battle of Bataan. Bronze Star recipient. Beloved husband of Barbara G. Devoted father of Steven A., Monte K. and Russell G. Zanca. Father-in-law of Minerva M. and Monica. Loving grandfather of Veronica and Joseph Zanca. Brother of Albert, Sadie and Violet. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, today, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Service Friday 10:45AM. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Desperate Hours in Nigeria
description: The Nigerian Government's Rambo-like assault on a farewell party for the American Ambassador last month, when heavily armed police burst into the room threatening to shoot the speakers, was just the latest in a string of bizarre acts by an increasingly desperate regime. The televised speech by Nigeria's dictator, Sani Abacha, on the country's independence day yesterday offered further evidence of his personal and political weakness. General Abacha's problems provide Washington with the opportunity to have an unusual impact with a modest sanctions bill now in Congress.

title: Devils May Add Emphasis to Their Offense
description: Jacques Lemaire has enjoyed enormous success as the Devils' coach because the players believe in his system: you may think offense, but never forget to play defense. That philosophy brought a Stanley Cup to New Jersey in 1995.

title: Princeton Poet Wins Prize
description: The Irish Times, a Dublin newspaper, awarded its 1997 Irish Literature Prize for Poetry yesterday to the director of the Creative Writing Program at Princeton University.

title: Sports of The Times; A Study In Becoming A Yankee
description: AT a couple of minutes past 8 on a cool, breezy night in the Bronx, Rey Sanchez trotted out to second base, entering the twilight zone of post-season baseball for the first time. He is a 30-year-old former Chicago Cub, which tells you all you need to know about his Octobers past, spent at home in Rio Piedras, P.R.

title: Tour of India's Classical Styles
description: Although the traditional dances of India often concern gods and goddesses, they can be playful as well as solemn. The charm of Indian dance was emphasized in a program called ''Indrani: Dancers and Musicians from India'' on Tuesday night at the Kaye Playhouse at Hunter College.

title: Next Door, New Friend Endorses McGreevey
description: He described the experience of standing next to her as ''humbling.'' She praised his values and patted his shoulder.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Basically, we'd receive instructions from the D.N.C. and an amount would be transferred to us, and we would then transfer the money for the media buy.''

title: House Proud; A Place to Hear the Wind in Those Willows
description: Quirky, idiosyncratic, the small gingerbread cottage looks like a model for Toad Hall in ''The Wind in the Willows.'' Called Keeper's Lodge, it is set in a 100-acre woods and inhabited and decorated by someone who might be England's answer to mad King Ludwig of Bavaria.

title: Bonds Rise on Weak Report From Purchasing Managers
description: Treasury securities rallied yesterday on an unexpectedly weak manufacturing report that suggested the economy is slowing enough to suppress inflation, substantiating the Federal Reserve's decision the day before to leave interest rates unchanged.

title: INSIDE
description: Visions for New York City

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMS, MARIAN
description: SIMS-Marian. Beloved wife of George. Devoted mother of Doris and Murray Eskenazi and Richard and Joyce Sims. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother of Lynn and Steve, Nancy, Jonathan and Stephanie, and Elizabeth and Jake. Services Friday, 1:30 PM, at ''Boulevard - Riverside Chapel,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Importing Assault Weapons
description: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms should not have granted permission to a munitions manufacturer owned by the Israeli Government to sell two types of semiautomatic weapons, the Uzi American and the Galil Sporter, in this country. The prospective sales appear to violate the law and in any case are dangerous to public safety. With police and policy makers struggling to keep assault weapons off the streets, it would be senseless to allow more to come in from abroad.

title: Petersen Publishing Plans Initial Offering
description: The Petersen Companies, which publishes established magazine titles like Hot Rod, Motor Trend, Guns & Ammo and Teen, plans to go public today with seven million shares at $17.50 a share, according to a spokeswoman for the company.

title: McDonalds's starts a big campaign to revive its brand image.
description: THE McDonald's Corporation is striving to revive its brand image with a big national campaign, starting tonight, centered on the experience of eating at its restaurants.

title: The Grit & the Glory; Help From the Home Doctor
description: MODERN versions of the old ''barn raising'' have been taking place in New England as interest in straw-bale house construction grows. In this age of plastic joint fasteners and pop-in windows there is something romantic about putting a wall together with manger material.

title: The Unabashed and Unalterable Foe of the Campaign Finance Bill
description: Suddenly mousetrapped as he led the debate against the campaign finance bill, Senator Mitch McConnell had to stand before his peers the other day and retreat to a bit of down-home Kentucky candor in confessing to the creation of ''a five-legged dog.''

title: Metro Business; Ticket Price an Issue In a Theater Merger
description: If the proposed merger between the Sony Corporation's Loews Theaters and the Cineplex Odeon Corporation is completed, the combined company would control 43 percent of the movie screens in New York City and 61 percent in Manhattan alone, prompting fears that ticket prices may climb.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, ISABEL
description: FITZGERALD - Isabel, 93, of Greenwich, Conn., on September 28, 1997. Wife of the late Clifford Fitzgerald. Beloved mother of Shirley Gately, Joan Schaffer, and Clifford Fitzgerald Jr. Memorial service to be held at the First Church of Round Hill, 464 Round Hill Road, on October 5, at 2 PM.

title: Suspect Apparently Has a Web Site
description: A site is posted on the World Wide Web under the name of the 15-year-old suspect charged with murdering and assaulting an 11-year-old New Jersey boy.

title: Cuts to Arts Budget Would Hit New York Hardest
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has survived its annual Congressional ordeal with only modest cuts in overall financing, but officials said today that restrictions would mean drastic cuts for New York State, always the agency's biggest beneficiary.

title: 15-Year-Old Held in Young Fund-Raiser's Slaying
description: A 15-year-old youth described by acquaintances as aloof, bright and preoccupied with his home computer was arrested early today and charged with murdering and sexually assaulting an 11-year-old boy who was selling candy Saturday afternoon for a school fund-raiser.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUNDERS, ROSETTA J.
description: SAUNDERS-Rosetta J., 77, a retired financial director of several publishing companies, died on September 30 at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, MD. The cause of death was complications associated with smoking-induced lung cancer and emphysema. A native New Yorker and longtime resident of Putnam and Westchester counties, she and her husband relocated to the Washington, DC area in 1987. Mrs. Saunders, nee Rosetta Arvonio, attended New York University, where she graduated with honors in 1942. Following her graduation and her marriage in 1943, she began her career in laboratory science; she then became a financial executive of Peter Arvonio Inc., a family manufacturing business, and later in the publishing industry. Mrs. Saunders embraced the charitable works of the Franciscan Friars of the Graymore Mission in Garrison, NY. Throughout her life, she also energetically supported local charities, both with her time and her donations. During her life she touched many with her effervescent spirit and professional acumen. She was an avid tennis player, swimmer and sports enthusiast. She is survived by her husband of 54 years, Stephan L. Saunders, of Silver Spring, MD; her two daughters, Stephanie Saunders Fouch of Chevy Chase, MD and Melody Saunders MacNamara of Birmingham, AL; and her granddaughter, Charlotte Michaux Fouch, of Chevy Chase. She will repose at Joseph Gawler's Sons 5130 Wisconsin Ave. NW Washington, DC 20016 on Thursday October 2nd from 79PM. A funeral liturgy will be held on Friday October 3rd at 11AM in The Blessed Sacrament Church 6001 Western Ave. NW (Chevy Chase Circle) Washington, DC. Interment will be at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY on Monday October 6 at 1PM. In lieu of flowers the family has requested that donations be made in Mrs. Saunders' name to the Franciscan Friars of the Atonement Gray more POB 309 Garrison, NY. 10542.

title: ON BASEBALL ; Wright Is Young, Raw and Ready
description: When the Yankees play host to the Cleveland Indians in the second game of the American League division series tonight, the fate of one team will be in the hands of one so young he looks as if he should be cramming for Psych 101 and figuring out what fraternity to rush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNGBERG, ROBERT W.
description: YOUNGBERG-Robert W. On September 30, 1997 at the age of 70. Of East Norwich, New York. Beloved husband of Claire. Cherished father of Christine, and Robert W. IV. He is pre-deceased by his sister Eileen Fornal. He is survived by his sister-in-law Ruth Schoenemann, and nieces and nephews Kathy, Keith, Reed, Karen, and Lee. Visiting at the Francis P. DeVine Funeral Home Inc, 293 South Street, Oyster Bay, Thursday and Friday 3-5, 7-9 PM. Funeral Service 8 PM Friday. Funeral Saturday 9:30 AM at the funeral home. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLLICONE, WAYNE PETER
description: MOLLICONE-Wayne Peter, of New Rochelle, NY, passed away on September 30, 1997. Beloved son of Peter & Antoinette (Nettie), cherished brother of Vi Purchia. Reposing at Yannantuono Funeral Home, Mount Vernon, New York, on Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 79 PM. Funeral Mass, Saturday at The Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale.

title: Arts Abroad; Britain's Enfant Not-So-Terrible of the Dread P-Word
description: The coming act is announced, and the crowd begins to quiet down. It's Murray Lachlan Young, who is going to recite his own work.

title: Trusting in Test Scores Is Perilous; Successful Cheaters?
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: There are halls of fame for superstars in basketball, football, rock-and-roll and country music, and now there is to be one for cancer survivors.

title: Review/Fashion; Flash, Trash and Vaudeville in London
description: Julien MacDonald's triumphant march out onto the catwalk, closing the London fashion shows on Tuesday night, said it all. Flanked by the models Naomi Campbell and Jodie Kidd in body-baring scraps of dresses, he drunkenly waved his hands above his head like Muhammad Ali, weaved back down the runway, then charged down it again. Every designer is vying to be the greatest superstar of them all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHERRY, CECELIA (RUBINSTEIN)
description: CHERRY-Cecelia (Rubinstein). Beloved wife of Paul, loving mother of Amy and Robert. Devoted sister of Kay, the late Manny Fenton, and the late Anna. Cherished grandmother of Marla & Jennifer. Will be missed by all. Services will be Friday, 10 A.M., at the Nieberg Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue (corner Avenue M).

title: Gunman Robs Women As They Play Golf
description: The serenity of a private golf club in Wayne was shattered Tuesday when a masked gunman robbed two golfers of their diamond jewelry, the police said.

title: In America; The Keys To Cutting Crime
description: In a culture dominated by chase scenes and shootouts -- from cowboy movies to cop shows and even the nightly news -- there is an overwhelming tendency to view the crime problem one-dimensionally.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RICHMAN, PHILLIP CARL
description: RICHMAN-Phillip Carl Oh Daddy, my daddy. I worshipped the ground you walk on. Larry

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Deliverers Lose Lawsuit Over Erroneous Tickets
description: A Federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit that accused New York City of unfairly enforcing parking rules against some types of businesses.

title: Blacks in South Africa Find New Wealth but Old Biases
description: In the last three years, Beryl Kerr's income has more than doubled. She has been able to buy her own home -- her first -- in a formerly white section of town and she no longer thinks twice about the cost of a weekend in the country to see the flowers in bloom.

title: Oklahoma Bombing Trial Ends 3d Day on Jury Pool
description: A psychic from Boulder who is a potential juror in the Oklahoma City bombing trial of Terry L. Nichols asked the judge today if she should let him know if she gets extrasensory information about a witness on the stand.

title: Top Sergeant Is Step Closer To Army Trial
description: The Army's highest-ranking enlisted soldier came a step closer today to a court-martial after a reviewing officer concurred with a recommendation that he be tried for sexual misconduct, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREBLE, ALLEN A.
description: PREBLE-Allen A. The Directors, Officers and Members of the Commercial Finance Association express their profound sorrow at the death of its Vice President Allen A. Preble. Robert I. Weisberg Chairman of the Board Irwin Teich, Pres. Leonard Machlis, Exec. Director

title: Speeding Up Play: Rounds on the Run
description: How about a round of golf in less than 40 minutes? And without a cart. Jay Larson has accomplished such a feat on a 6,500-yard course with a slope rating of 125. And he shot 75 in the process, which is a few strokes above his handicap.

title: French Hypocrisy
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Charge Man, 28, In Grandmother's Killing
description: A 28-year-old Brooklyn man on probation for a 1996 weapons possession conviction was arrested yesterday morning and charged with murdering his 67-year-old grandmother, the police said.

title: Asians Suffer Further Damage On Malaysian's New Remarks
description: Southeast Asian currencies again fell to record lows against the dollar yesterday, and analysts said further declines were likely because of continued concerns about the region's faltering economic growth.

title: Surprise Offer Aims to Make Mississippi Firm 2d to AT&T : A $30 Billion Bid By WorldCom To Take Over MCI
description: NEW YORK  WorldCom Inc., the fourth-biggest U.S. long-distance company, made a surprise takeover bid worth about $30 billion for MCI Communications Corp. on Wednesday in what would be the largest-ever U.S. acquisition.

title: Wild World of Couches
description: IT was Mother's day off.

title: City's Workfare Employees Are to Vote on Forming Union
description: A community group seeking to organize New York City's 38,000 workfare employees announced a novel plan yesterday to pressure Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani into recognizing them as a union: the workers will vote in a nonbinding election later this month on whether to unionize.

title: Baltimore Cites Success With Alternative to 911
description: Until a year ago, the owner of a cat stuck in a tree and the spouse of a shooting victim would be likely to call the same number for help: 911.

title: Hitachi Lowers Pretax Earnings Forecast
description: Hitachi Ltd. lowered its full-year pretax earnings forecast 36 percent yesterday, citing falling prices of computer chips and a decline in sales of major appliances in Japan. The company said it expected to report pretax profit of 70 billion yen ($578 million) for the year that will end in March 1998, down from 84 billion yen last year. It previously forecast a rise to 110 billion yen.

title: DEMOCRATS USED THE STATE PARTIES TO BYPASS LIMITS
description: The Democratic National Committee quietly transferred at least $32 million to state Democratic parties in the last election as part of an elaborate plan to spend more money than Federal election law appeared to allow on a huge advertising campaign that indirectly helped re-elect President Clinton.

title: Dow Again Passes 8,000, Rising 70.24
description: The stock market rose yesterday after the Government reported that manufacturing activity cooled in September. The report, which traders took as an indication that the economy is not about to overheat, helped lift prices in the bond market, and the rally spread to the stock market, sending the Dow Jones industrial average above 8,000 for the first time since Aug. 20.

title: A Prayer for the Days of Awe
description: Master of the Universe, let us make up. It is time. How long can we go on being angry?

title: Sweet Dreams Are Made of This
description: WE couldn't do much about the neighborhood's new motorcycle club. So we did something about the mattress.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HANKIN, HENRIETTA
description: HANKIN-Henrietta. Mom, 15 years cannot diminish the love we feel. You are always in our hearts and minds. Judy, Naomi, and Bob

title: W. H. Smith Rejects Recent Takeover Offer
description: The W. H. Smith Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it had rejected a takeover offer from Tim Waterstone, the former owner of Smith's Waterstone's book-retail unit. Smith, Britain's largest book retailer, said the offer of 200 pence ($3.24) a share, which values Smith at $:568 million; the acquisition of Waterstone's children's goods retail business, and the appointment of Mr. Waterstone as chief executive, was not in the interests of its shareholders. The proposals ''offer no real value to our shareholders,'' said Richard Handover, Smith's chief executive. He was appointed two weeks ago after the unexpected resignation of Bill Cockburn in June.

title: Yanks Are Eager to Pick Up Where They Left Off
description: Manager Joe Torre would have preferred it if the Yankees had played the second game of their division series against the Cleveland Indians last night, or yesterday afternoon, or even yesterday at dawn, instead of having to wait until tonight.
