Torre wanted to keep the amazing vibes flowing from Tuesday night, when the Yankees clubbed three straight homers during a stylish comeback and stunned the Indians, 8-6, in Game 1 at Yankee Stadium.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; Latter-Day Mirth From Unkindred Spirits
description: One of the smartest ideas Deutsche Grammophon has had in recent years was to engage Oliver Knussen to conduct a series of recordings of 20th-century music. The latest fruits of this project are disks devoted to Stravinsky and Ruth Crawford Seeger, composers who, had they ever met, would probably have detested each other, but who are both happily served by Mr. Knussen's fine care, musicality and abundant good humor.

title: Reporter's Notebook; In New York, All Sides Give Albright Advice
description: The problem with reaching out to the American people -- if you're Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright -- is that the American people feel free to reach out right back.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: ON LIABILITY

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Runoff Problems Reported
description: Half of New Jersey's watersheds have serious water pollution problems, mainly because of runoff from factories, sewer plants and farms, according to the United States Environmental Protection Agency. In its first comprehensive assessment of the nation's watersheds, the agency said yesterday that it had found extensive water pollution in seven of them in New Jersey -- from the Hackensack-Passaic area through parts of central to southern New Jersey. Only three watersheds in the western part of the state have good water quality, the report said.

title: Congress Should Support Condom Distribution
description: To the Editor:

title: Cancer May Be the Cost of Modern Life Style; High Fat, High Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINER, JULES
description: REINER-Jules. Caring husband of Norma for fifty-five years. Beloved father of Charles, Elizabeth, Nanette and Barry. ''Head of the herd'' of nine grandchildren. Passed away the evening of October 1, 1997. He was 81. Services at 9 A.M., Sunday, Temple Anshe Amunim, Pittsfield, MA. Interment 1 P.M., Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, N.Y. Any contributions to the usher-sponsored Harry Steadman Scholarship Fund of Tanglewood, Lenox, MA. 01240.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FEIDEN, ROBERT T.
description: FEIDEN-Robert T. As the years go by we miss you more and more and think of you every day. Mom, Dad and Rica

title: Casanova Complex: Collecting For the Kill
description: There is something sad and brave in the spectacle of an actor as dedicated as Morgan Freeman meticulously trying to infuse his stock character in the thriller ''Kiss the Girls'' with a dramatic integrity that transcends the genre. As Alex Cross, a police forensic psychologist and crime reporter whose niece is kidnapped by a madman and forcibly inducted into his personal harem, Mr. Freeman projects a kindness, patience and canny intelligence that cut against the movie's fast pace and pumped-up shock effects. His performance is so measured it makes you want to believe in the movie much more than its gimmicky jerry-built plot ever permits.

title: Chief of Thomas Nelson Settles S.E.C. Case
description: Thomas Nelson Inc. said this week that its chief executive, Sam Moore, had agreed to settle a Securities and Exchange Commission case involving allegations of stock price manipulation.

title: The Promise Keepers, in Perspective
description: As the evangelical men in the Promise Keepers are marching in Washington tomorrow, they will be listening to a different drummer from the one who sets the pace for most movements.

title: Metro Business; Retail Space Shortage
description: The same frenetic real estate market that has made it so hard to find an apartment in New York City is tightening the supply of retail space, too. The number of stores available to rent in Manhattan fell to 1,893 from 2,205 in the first six months of this year, according to a study by Garrick-Aug Associates Store Leasing, a retail brokerage firm.

title: BROWNING-FERRIS TO PAY $585 MILLION FOR 7% OF ITS STOCK
description: Browning-Ferris Industries said yesterday that it would pay $585 million to repurchase about 7 percent of its common shares outstanding as part of a planned $1 billion stock buyback. Stockholders offered to sell 33.8 million shares at $39 each, exceeding the 15 million shares the company said it would repurchase. As a result, Browning-Ferris plans to buy back about 44 percent of the stock from each shareholder offering 100 or more shares. The company is to purchase, in full, any shares offered in lots of fewer than 100. In the second part of the stock repurchase program, the Houston-based Browning-Ferris plans to buy $415 million of its shares on the open market by Sept. 30, 1998. The company's shares fell $1, to $37.8125.

title: Gretzky Gets a Raise, and Rangers Get Ready
description: With a theatrical flourish, the Rangers gave Wayne Gretzky a raise and a contract extension yesterday. It was the middle piece of this week's hat trick of personnel decisions that set the stage for the regular season for a greatly revamped team.

title: Love to Build Them Up, Love to Tear Them Down
description: When the play's protagonist is 110 years old, it's a safe bet that the playwright has time on his mind. Which is indeed the case with ''Skyscraper,'' a cerebral comedy concerning the past, the future, chance meetings and changing perspectives in, around and on the roof of a soon-to-be demolished Chicago office tower.

title: Messinger Ad Strikes Back at Giuliani Over a Commercial on Sex Businesses
description: Ruth W. Messinger released a new television advertisement yesterday in an effort to rebut a Giuliani campaign commercial that she says distorts her position on sex businesses in New York City. Her ad accuses the Mayor of using ''false quotes'' and of ''throwing garbage.''

title: 4 Accused of Raping and Torturing Escorts
description: Four Brooklyn men arranged to have two employees of an escort service attend a party in Dyker Heights on Wednesday night, then imprisoned, tortured and raped the women after they arrived, the police said. One of the victims was sexually assaulted with a foreign object and had to undergo surgery for her injuries, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILL, BEATRICE
description: GILL-Beatrice. Of S.I., NY. Wife of the late William, loving mother of Margaret Mary Gill, Terry Nolan, Christine Kane, Liam and Kevin Gill, also survived by nine grandchildren. Reposing Harmon Home For Funerals, 571 Forest Avenue, S.I., Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady of Good Counsel Church, Saturday 11 A.M. Interment St. Peter's Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Pax Christi Hospice Program or Our Lady of Good Counsel Church Building Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERMAN, ROBERT
description: FERMAN-Robert, on October 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Bernice. Dear father of Pam, Seth (Miriam). Dear brother of Harold, Selma and Herbert (Aphrodite). Bob was much loved by those who knew him. Services Sunday, Oct. 5 at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Contact chapel for time of service 212-362-6600.

title: Art In Review
description: Aziz and Cucher

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, AARON
description: WEINSTEIN-Aaron. on October 2, 1997. Beloved husband and best friend of Ruth for 60 years. Loving father of Robert (Lois) and Michael. Adoring grandfather of Cheryl, Leslie and Eric. Retired principal of PS 47X. Graveside services Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, New Jersey, Monday, October 6.

title: British Telecom, Outbid for MCI, Is Facing Hard Choices
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. gave no hint yesterday how it planned to respond a day after Worldcom Inc. offered $30 billion for MCI Communications, a deal that would torpedo the British phone giant's plan to acquire MCI for $19 billion.

title: Realism Unvarnished For Gluck's Bonded Males
description: Paul Kellogg, the artistic director of Glimmerglass Opera, knew he was in for some tough criticism this summer. It was July, and the summer company in Cooperstown, N.Y., had just unveiled its production of Gluck's ''Iphigenie en Tauride.'' With a Greek princess held in captivity by a leering, leather-clad Scythian king, and bloody human sacrifices in a temple to Diana that looked more like a grim high-security prison, the production was certain to provoke people.

title: Another Bullpen Blowup Costs Mariners
description: Lou Piniella is to tantrum throwing what Robert Oppenheimer was to nuclear science. The Seattle manager could justify a little rage today, for his Mariners are on the verge of being swept by the Orioles after a second straight 9-3 thumping in Game 2 of the American League division series.

title: On a Soaring Ride Of Reminiscence, Speed and Wonder
description: My father left Flatbush 55 years ago, and now, on a bright fall day, I find myself going back to deepest Brooklyn, to Coney Island, to the last stop on the F train.

title: Classical Music and Dance Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: Eating Out; Smokers' Refuges
description: Where have all the smokers gone? Gone into hiding every one, almost. Here and there are little oases where smokers are not pariahs and can puff in peace. Some are legal, either seating fewer than 35 people or having separate dining rooms; others are simply tolerant. Basically, these New York restaurants fall into three categories: First are the restaurants that reflect lax European attitudes toward smokers; second are those that delight in the forbidden, that is, meat, cocktails and tobacco; and third are those that indulge the fancies of cigar connoisseurs. All have one thing in common: ashtrays. (Here are summaries, written by Eric Asimov, taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: PCS to Expand Drug-Claim Role
description: Eli Lilly & Company's PCS Health Systems unit agreed today to administer pharmacy claims for 5.9 million health plan members of Humana Inc., as PCS seeks to increase its mail-order business.

title: Red Storm Thinking Of Repeat
description: St. John's soccer coach, Dave Masur, lined up his players at the start of practice Tuesday and ordered them to sprint 30 yards back and forth for 10 minutes.

title: The Modern's Trendy Windfall
description: After a prolonged courtship involving competing museums, the Museum of Modern Art won the Dannheisser sweepstakes last year, landing 82 works of American and European art from the collection assembled by Elaine Dannheisser and her husband, Werner, during the 1980's and early 90's. Now the museum is sealing the deal with the requisite exhibition, a handsomely installed affair that spreads through half the museum's third floor.

title: In Memorial On Holocaust, Message Is Life
description: YESTERDAY, on the first day of Rosh ha-Shanah, observant Jews prayed along the banks of the city's rivers and creeks, heeding the New Year's imperative to cast one's sins ceremonially into the waters.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For the last two years, when JANE PAULEY, the ''Dateline NBC'' anchor, was Principal for a Day at Public School 68 in the Bronx, she saw in the school's closets old, rusted horns and violins, ruined by a leak in the roof. On every floor, she saw pianos that hadn't been tuned in years, let alone played. ''There was a time that all teachers could play the piano,'' Ms. Pauley said yesterday.

title: Dorothy Kingsley, 87, Writer Of 1950's MGM Screenplays
description: Dorothy Kingsley, a leading screenwriter in Hollywood in the 1940's and 50's, died on Sept. 26 at the Community Hospital of the Monterey Peninsula, in Monterey, Calif. She was 87 and lived in Carmel.

title: On Stage and Off
description: An Unusual Opening Night

title: Shades Of Gray Amid The Gold
description: It is always autumn in Serge Bennathan's ''Arbres d'Or,'' performed by Dancemakers on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater. The darkness of night becomes late afternoon sunlight, which in turn shifts to dusk and the chill gray of early morning. But the leaves that cover the stage floor are always there, as are the nine young men and women in their early autumn clothes.

title: Toys 'R' Us Is Accused Of Acting to Rig Prices
description: Echoing a Federal judge's ruling earlier this week, State Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco filed suit yesterday against Toys ''R'' Us, charging that the world's largest toy retailer colluded with manufacturers to inflate prices on their most popular products.

title: FORD SAYS IT PLANS $1 BILLION FACTORY IN BRAZIL
description: The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it planned to spend up to $1 billion to build a factory in southern Brazil, at the heart of the fast-growing Mercosur free trade area. The new plant will produce 100,000 units of a yet-to-be-identified model by 2001, Ford said. The investment brings to at least $3 billion the amount Ford plans to spend in Brazil between 1995 and 2000 to improve its lagging market share amid a regional boom in car sales there. The company's immediate goal is to sell up to 30 percent of the plant's output to neighboring Mercosur countries -- Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay -- and the rest in Brazil. Ford's stock was up $1.1875 at $46.8125.

title: McCain Lacks Votes to Lift Deadlock on Campaign Bill
description: A chief sponsor of the main bill to overhaul the campaign finance system said today that he did not have enough votes to break an impasse on it, and a group of moderate Republicans struggled to come up with a way to lift the stalemate.

title: LAZARD FRERES FUND AGREES TO BUY NURSING HOME OWNER
description: Lazard Freres & Company's real estate fund agreed yesterday to buy the Kapson Senior Quarters Corporation for $250 million, including the assumption of debt, in the latest investment by a Wall Street investment bank in a nursing home owner. Lazard Freres said its Prometheus Senior Quarters L.L.C. fund would buy 92 percent of Kapson's 7.8 million common shares for $16 each. It will also buy all of Kapson's 2.5 million convertible preferred shares for $30.82 each. Shares of Kapson, based in Woodbury, N.Y., rose 62.5 cents, to $15.25. Kapson owns 20 nursing homes in Connecticut, New Jersey and Long Island.

title: Colleagues Vow to Learn From Chemist's Death
description: At 48, Karen Wetterhahn was a distinguished research chemist, a world expert on how heavy metals cause cancer, a sunny mother and wife, a tenured professor and a former dean at Dartmouth College. She was a happy, warm, lucky, busy person.

title: A Town Bereft, Limping Into the Future
description: The lone special effects shot in ''The Sweet Hereafter'' is beautifully executed and terrible to see. A school bus skids off an icy road and sinks into a frozen lake, taking with it the children of a tiny, once neighborly Adirondack town. Presented midway through this latest, biggest and most wrenching film by the brilliantly analytical Atom Egoyan, this image becomes the basis for a many-faceted moral inquiry. In the aftermath of such calamity, how does life go on?

title: An Overview of the Everyday
description: No one can quarrel with the importance of design in our daily lives, but the ambitious array of objects in ''Design for Life: A Centennial Celebration'' at the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, is set out with an advocate's passion. This forgivably self-congratulatory visual feast celebrates the 100th birthday of the museum. And its panoply of wearables, eating paraphernalia, art, furniture, fabrics, lighting fixtures, jewelry, communications devices, travel aids and architectural renderings give eloquent testimony to the Cooper-Hewitt's acquisitive ardor as well as its interest in public taste.

title: Smog Is Blotting Out Asian Economies, Too
description: SINGAPORE  As Southeast Asia enters a fourth successive month shrouded in smoke and smog, it is starting to count the economic costs in terms of falling tourism, disrupted transport, damaged crops and diminished investor confidence.

title: Giants Take Precaution As Brown Nurses Injury
description: Dave Brown has a strained muscle in his chest near his throwing shoulder, and though he insisted he will play Sunday against the Dallas Cowboys, Danny Kanell was taking the snaps with the first unit in today's practice.

title: Heavies In Sight For Jones
description: Roy Jones Jr., the World Boxing Council light-heavyweight champion, is a step closer to legitimately moving up to fight in the heavyweight division.

title: Critic's Choice/Film; Mayhem and Young Love In a Chilling Prototype
description: It arrived in 1973 and still casts its long shadow as the handsome, chilling prototype for tales of affectless mayhem linked with young love. And if you haven't lately seen Terrence Malick's now classic ''Badlands,'' showing for two weeks with a new 35-millimeter print at the Film Forum, it's worth a new look.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''My car spun around and he just drove off down the street. I looked in my rear view mirror and saw the bus speeding down Fifth Avenue. I was praying it wouldn't hit anyone else.''

title: Embracing the Foreign in Silver and Sombreros
description: The 17th- and 18th-century religious art in ''Potosi: Colonial Treasures and the Bolivian City of Silver'' at the Americas Society was meant to be overwhelming: to bedazzle the eye, baffle logic, disarm the critical faculties. And it fulfills its purpose with remarkable elan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, MIRIAM (NEE AMDUR)
description: SIEGEL-Miriam (nee Amdur). Devoted wife of Dr. Morris Siegel, loving mother of Nancy Peress and Robert Siegel, dear mother-inlaw of Hazel and Richard, loving grandmother of Alexandra, John, Ari and Lauren.

title: On My Mind; What They Do Get
description: The Secretary of State was saying that some of America's friends and allies ''don't get it.''

title: Prudential Said To Have Put Health Unit On the Block
description: After swallowing enormous losses for years, the Prudential Insurance Company of America is trying to sell its health care business, which provides coverage for almost seven million people nationwide, industry executives said yesterday. But Prudential could hardly have picked a worse time to seek a buyer, they added.

title: Fernandez Produces
description: Before Derek Jeter, there was Tony Fernandez.

title: CNN Halts Companies' Ads Attacking Administration on Warming Treaty
description: The Cable News Network told a coalition of industrial companies today that it would no longer broadcast the group's advertisements criticizing the Clinton Administration's negotiating stance in international talks on controlling global warming.

title: Don't Cut Legal Aid
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE METRO
description: VIEW FROM THE PARK -- A day after Mayor Giuliani declared that he would make Washington Square Park a ''drug free zone,'' many parkgoers said they had heard that tune before. B3.

title: For U.S. Against Jamaica, Time Is of the Essence
description: At Robert F. Kennedy Stadium, long abandoned by professional baseball, the United States soccer team intends to swing for the fences Friday night in a crucial World Cup qualifying match against Jamaica.

title: INSIDE
description: Landlord Held in Death Plot

title: Corrections
description: The On College Football column yesterday, about the Mid-American Conference's rigorous schedule, omitted one school from the number in the conference. There are 12, including Northern Illinois. The column also misidentified Bowling Green's opponent for tomorrow; it is Northern Illinois.

title: Broadway is using nontraditional methods to attract Hispanic people to the theater.
description: ADVERTISERS have long turned to Spanish-language newspapers, TV and radio stations to attract audiences to Broadway shows. But producers are now pursuing the 2.1 million Hispanic people in the New York metropolitan region as never before.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAYNIS, DAISY
description: KAYNIS-Daisy. Dear Daisy: Today, if you were alive, you would be 90 years old. I think of you every minute of the day and I never realized what your presence meant to me until now. I miss you, Daisy. Love, Sam

title: Torre's Lineup Massaging Can't Take the Stress
description: What Joe Torre set in stone in terms of a lineup going into the division series against Cleveland was not as intriguing as Orioles Manager Davey Johnson's plot to take on Seattle's Randy Johnson without Rafael Palmeiro, Roberto Alomar and B. J. Surhoff.

title: A Darker Shade of Noir, From Oliver Stone
description: ''U-Turn'' is a steamy film noir anomaly in the never dull, ever-checkered career of Oliver Stone. Shot in a hurry (42 days) with a big cast and a smallish budget ($20 million), it tells a relatively unencumbered tale of greed, lust and the usual etceteras, a story in which sooner or later someone is bound to offer a business proposition with the caveat: ''It's gotta look like an accident.'' However simply he approaches this familiar milieu, Mr. Stone winds up treating his story's sin-soaked connivers the way Francis Ford Coppola treated vampires. Neither of them is really capable of anything plain.

title: A Brigadoon, Minus Music And Magic
description: You don't need a radar map to read the weather when Janeane Garofalo is on the screen. The mercurial intensity of this dark-eyed, sarcastic comedian says it all: unsettled. Ms. Garofalo, who plays a character in ''The Matchmaker'' very much like her stand-up comic persona, conveys the attitude of an impatient, hypercritical skeptic who can see through anybody. If she doesn't give her trust easily, it can still be won. Once she has lowered her storm warnings, Ms. Garofalo is capable of projecting an endearing childlike rapture. In those fitful moments when the sun bursts through the clouds, it blazes.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ''I am the most difficult person you will ever take to dinner,'' my doctor told me recently. ''There are so many things I cannot eat.'' Since the forbidden foods include garlic, onions, seafood and alcohol, I thought she might have a point.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILEY, EDITH L.
description: HILEY-Edith L., of Sarasota, Florida, September 30, 1997. Survivors include her son, David B. of Katonah, NY; sister, Marie M. Luhr of Sarasota; six grandchildren; and eight great-grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to the American Lung Association.

title: 50th Anniversary for Actors Studio And Its 'Streetcar' Ride to Renown
description: On Dec. 3, 1947, Tennessee Williams's play ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' starring Jessica Tandy as the doomed Blanche DuBois and Marlon Brando as Stanley Kowalski, her brutal executioner, opened on Broadway. Thronged with theater and Hollywood notables and electric with the excitement of a once-in-a-lifetime occasion, the premiere announced a new cultural era, establishing Williams as America's leading dramatist and making the Actors Studio, a workshop founded only two months before, the mecca for aspiring American actors.

title: Sewage-Treatment Plants Are Faulted in Study
description: More than a dozen small sewage-treatment plants are fouling the Catskill and Delaware watersheds, which feed New York City's water supply, but environmental officials have done little to halt the pollution, according to a report released yesterday by the City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi.

title: U.N. Official From U.S. Is Convicted of Fraud
description: An American who worked for the United Nations in Switzerland has been convicted of defrauding the organization of half a million dollars by collecting expenses for nonexistent training programs he claimed to have arranged.

title: Family Fare
description: Getting a Jump On Halloween

title: Plan for Park at Reagan Ranch Is in Doubt
description: The Government's plan to buy Ronald Reagan's mountaintop retreat for $5 million and turn it into a state park may have fallen apart this week, in the face of a duststorm of local opposition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUNCH, MARVIN W.
description: BUNCH-Marvin W., 75, husband of Madeline (Walsh) Bunch, Indianapolis, IN. Father of Robert Bunch, Queens, NY, William Bunch, Las Vegas, NV, Susan Belli, Long Island, N.Y., and Cynthia Cornacchio, Orange County, NY. Brother of Paul Bunch, Foley, AL and Gene Bunch, Sherman, TX. Also survived by 10 grandchildren and 2 great-grandchildren. Funeral Services Saturday October 4, 1997 at 1:00PM at Daniel F. O'Riley Funeral Home, Indianapolis, IN.

title: Immigrants Celebrate A Pastor Of Tolerance
description: Inside a crowded church, with the sounds and smells of Chinatown edging their way to the altar, Chinese and Cuban Catholics yesterday honored a 19th-century Cuban immigrant who spent half his life defending Irish immigrants in New York.

title: For Salomon, as Adviser, Millions Plus Revenge
description: The only company with as much to gain from Worldcom's $30 billion bid for MCI as Worldcom itself may be Salomon Brothers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JACKSON MANN, VIRGINIA
description: JACKSON MANN-Virginia. A Memorial Mass in memory of Virginia Jackson Mann will take place on Saturday, October 4th, at 10 A.M., at St. John the Evangelist Church, 348 East 55th Street, in Manhattan.

title: The Contradictory Degas Does It Again
description: The standard story has always been that Degas spent his later years as a nasty recluse, turning away friends, collectors and especially nosy journalists. A model described his studio as a vast and gloomy room, cluttered and filthy, a wall of windows obstructed by a curtain that let in only a feeble light. His anti-Semitism, fueled by the Dreyfus affair, is well known, as is his reputation for misogyny. Women ''hate me and feel that I am disarming them,'' he said, because he showed them in his art ''without their coquetry.''

title: French Oil Official Asks If U.S. Law Reaches Iran
description: One of the warmest memories of Thierry Desmarest, chairman of the French oil company Total S.A., came when, fresh out of France's finest schools, he was on his own managing a mine in New Caledonia.

title: Clash of the Dazzling And the Meek, Again
description: Bracing and perfectly cast, Agnieszka Holland's version of ''Washington Square'' underscores the vitality of Henry James's novella. This story of star-crossed courtship, adapted less faithfully as ''The Heiress'' (for which Olivia de Havilland won an Academy Award), remains cautionary and fresh. So does the way it is set in motion by doe eyes and rosy lips, though these do not belong to its drab heroine. Instead, they are the temptations that threaten to lure a rich and meek young woman out of her father's shadow.

title: Magnet School in Buffalo Is Challenged on Quotas
description: The parents of a sixth-grade student are suing the Buffalo Board of Education, contending that their daughter has been unfairly prevented from attending an honors school because she is white.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNINGHAM, RUNDLES, MARY ALICE
description: CUNNINGHAM - RUNDLES - Mary Alice. New York City, September 28th, 1997, age 84. Beloved mother of Ward, Susanna, Charlotte, daughter-in-law Marietta, son-inlaw Jim, grandmother of Kiki and Alison, sister of Jane. Teacher of 19 years of classes of medical students at New York University Medical Center. A burial service was held October 1 for the immediate family at the Cathedral of St. John The Divine. Contributions in her memory may be sent to The Children's Blood Foundation, 333 East 38th Street, New York, New York 10016-2745.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMS, MARIAN
description: SIMS-Marian. A wonderful woman, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother has unexpectedly died and left us deeply saddened. We will always remember her soft and genuine qualities. Our love and sympathy to her husband George, her daughter Doris Eskanesi, Murray Eskanesi, their children and grandchildren, and to our dear brother-in-law and uncle, Richard Sims, his wife Joyce and children Elizabeth, Jonathan and Stephanie. Marsha, Steve, Mylissa and Jessica Braun.

title: Landlord Is Charged With Waging Campaign of Terror
description: A Manhattan landlord with a string of aliases, a store of weapons and a hefty real estate portfolio conducted a campaign of terror to drive tenants out of a Lower East Side building so that he could raise rents, according to prosecutors, who yesterday charged the man with arson and attempted murder.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Winnie Mandela Faces Accusers With Display of Silent Witnesses
description: A week after being questioned during closed hearings of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, President Nelson Mandela's former wife, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, lashed back today, producing five witnesses she said would prove she was not guilty of murder and any acts of violence.

title: Devils' Lines Unsettled
description: With the wings Bill Guerin and Brian Rolston still unsigned and away from the team, the Devils will go into their season opener Friday night at Tampa Bay with just one line set -- Bobby Holik centering for Dave Andreychuk on the left and Randy McKay on the right.

title: Art In Review
description: Marcel Broodthaers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALIN, ANNA
description: PALIN-Anna, on October, 2, 1997, age 87. Devoted wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Michael (Caryl) and Carole Sehres (Mort). Devoted grandmother of Jill, Stacey, Dorothy, Andrea and Dean. Loving great-grandmother of ten. Devoted sister of Jules and Sol. Funeral services Sunday, October 5th, 10am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Old Montefiore Cemetery.

title: U.S. to Fire Laser Weapon at a Satellite
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen has approved firing the nation's most powerful military laser at a $60 million Air Force satellite to test its destructive power, the Defense Department said yesterday.

title: A Casanova Revival?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bosnian Muslims Are Reported to Rearm Secretly
description: The Muslim-led Government in Sarajevo appears to be intensifying a clandestine program to arm and train its military, and senior NATO officials say it is close to -- or may already have achieved -- the ability to mount a crushing offensive against the Bosnian Serb-held part of Bosnia.

title: Abroad at Home; Fanning the Flames?
description: The United States is famously a country of immigrants. It is also a country with a strain of nativism going back at least to the Know Nothing movement of the 1850's, anti-Catholic and anti-immigrant.

title: Young Teresa, Saintly but Not Yet Lionized
description: It was one of Mother Teresa's last publicly expressed wishes that this movie would go away. She hadn't seen Geraldine Chaplin, towering and poised, in a story devoted to the middle-aged Teresa's first years among the poor. And it is just as well that she never saw a press kit sent out by the Family Channel, an elaborate box that included a replica of a beggar's bowl inscribed with her words, ''Love has to be put into action.'' What would she have made of the beggar's bowl as tchotchke?

title: Sports of The Times; David Cone And Yankees Now Tenuous
description: SOME losses are worse than others. Joe Torre and the Yankees not only have to cope with the sudden disintegration of Andy Pettitte in last night's 7-5 loss to Cleveland, they also have to face the incapacity of David Cone for the foreseeable future.

title: Veteran C.I.A. Official Quits But Will Finish Investigations
description: Fred Hitz, the inspector general of the Central Intelligence Agency, who once jokingly defined his job as having to ''shoot the wounded'' on the battlefield of espionage, said today that he would leave to teach at Princeton University, where he was recruited to join the agency 36 years ago.

title: Residential Real Estate; Surge in Lower East Side Apartments
description: Manhattan's strong residential market is having a ripple effect on the Lower East Side, where property owners are renovating into rental apartments the upper floors of older buildings, floors that for decades were empty or used for storage, and new housing is springing up on empty lots.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stocks were higher here early today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 128.38 points, or nearly three-quarters of 1 percent, at 17,583.42. On Thursday, the Nikkei index fell 387.12 points, or 2.17 percent, on worries over corporate earnings prospects and lack of action to spur the economy.

title: Corrections
description: Two photographs in Weekend on Sept. 26 with an art review of Richard Serra's ''Torqued Ellipses,'' steel sculptures installed at the Dia Center for the Arts in Manhattan, carried incorrect credits. The color photo on the cover and the bottom photo on the continuation page were by Allen Glatter. Ivory Serra made the third photo, at the top of the continuation page.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 6
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: MOTOROLA IS SAID TO CONSIDER SELLING MODEM BUSINESS
description: Motorola Inc. has hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to seek buyers for its struggling modem business, industry and financial executives said yesterday. Motorola has sent information on the unit to potential buyers, including rival modem makers, according to two executives who reviewed the documents. The documents say that Motorola's Transmission Products division, based in Huntsville, Ala., expects revenue to fall 15 percent, to $179 million, this year, a modem industry executive said. Motorola declined to comment on the possibility of selling its modem division. A Goldman, Sachs spokeswoman also declined to comment.

title: Bond Unit Chiefs At Merged Firm
description: Salomon Brothers and Travelers Group Inc.'s brokerage unit, Smith Barney, have named the heads of bond businesses for the combined company, according to an internal memo.

title: Most Stock Indexes End Day at Highs
description: Stock prices rose modestly yesterday, but the gains were enough to send most major indexes to record highs.

title: Barclays Reportedly Ready to Scale Back
description: Barclays Bank P.L.C., the third-biggest bank in Britain, is selling large parts of its Barclays de Zoete Wedd investment banking arm to improve profitability, two British newspapers reported in today's editions.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Bail Denied in Killing
description: The oldest of the three suspects in the kidnapping and murder of the New Jersey millionaire Nelson G. Gross made his first appearance in the Federal courthouse here yesterday and was ordered held without bail. Flanked by his newly appointed lawyers from the Federal Public Defender's office, the suspect, Tony Estevez, 18, nodded his assent as Judge Joel A. Pisano informed him of his rights and sought to determine whether he understood them. He then waived his right to a preliminary hearing. The appearance yesterday means that the United States Attorney for New Jersey has 30 days to indict Mr. Estevez formally. Mr. Estevez and two 17-year-olds, Christian Velez and Miguel Grullon, are facing charges in the Sept. 17 robbery and kidnapping of Mr. Gross, 65, a developer and former head of the state Republican Party.

title: Diana Coverage Said to Hurt Retail Sales
description: Growth in retailers' sales during September was slower than expected because consumers stayed home at the beginning of the month to watch television coverage of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, Telecheck Services Inc. said today.

title: Cancer May Be the Cost of Modern Life Style; Unnecessary Pesticides
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Probation Officer Is Charged
description: An Essex County probation officer accused of falsifying the records of a defendant he was supervising was charged yesterday in Superior Court with official misconduct, prosecutors said. The officer, Peter Vaccarelli, 45, of Belleville, submitted documents to a Superior Court judge falsely stating that the defendant, Hassanain Aly, had completed an assigned 50 hours of community service, said Frederic R. McDaniel, a deputy first assistant prosecutor. As a result, Mr. Aly, 33, was discharged early from a pretrial intervention program, and a weapons charge against him was dismissed, Mr. McDaniel said. If convicted, Mr. Vaccarelli faces up to 11 1/2 years in prison, a $107,500 fine and dismissal.

title: Theater Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth last weekend for last Friday and Saturday nights' performances.

title: Spare Times
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Wolves May Be Limited By Garnett's Contract
description: On the surface, Kevin Garnett was back in good graces with Ned and Mabel from Mankato. The throng of Minnesota Timberwolves fans who had turned on him over the summer were delighted to see their Kevie sign with the home team -- for more than $125 million over six seasons.

title: Art In Review
description: James Esber

title: Market Place; From Wall St., Tale of Fraud And Threats
description: The dark side of Wall Street is becoming an increasingly dangerous place -- and not just for investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLLICONE, WAYNE PETER
description: MOLLICONE-Wayne Peter, of New Rochelle, NY, passed away on September 30, 1997. Beloved son of Peter & Antoinette (Nettie), cherished brother of Vi Purchia. Reposing at Yannantuono Funeral Home, Mount Vernon, New York, on Thursday and Friday 2-4 and 79 PM. Funeral Mass, Saturday at The Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Scarsdale.

title: Too Soon to Sell Reactors to China
description: Of all the nuclear powers, China has been the most reckless in exporting technology and materials that other countries can use to develop their own bombs. In the 1990's, Iran, Iraq, India and Pakistan have received Chinese help in evading international restrictions on nuclear trade. Iran and Pakistan still receive Chinese assistance. Despite recent promises to exercise restraint, China remains the only nuclear-weapons state selling material and technology to countries that close some of their nuclear installations to international inspectors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, DORIS
description: GOLDBERG-Doris. Died on September 29, 1997. Beloved mother of Marilyn Reiman and Florence Bader. Graveside services 10 A.M., Sunday at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island.

title: An Attack on Privacy Rights
description: The Clinton Administration has proposed several unworkable plans over the years to keep powerful encryption programs that scramble telephone and computer messages out of the hands of foreign terrorists and criminals. But it has never tried to put the need to eavesdrop on criminals above the privacy rights of ordinary Americans. Last month the F.B.I. Director, Louis Freeh, crossed that line by urging Congress to outlaw the manufacture and distribution of encryption programs the Government cannot instantly crack.

title: Congress Should Support Condom Distribution; Price of Acceptance
description: To the Editor:

title: M. Bashir, 67, Master Player And Preserver Of Arab Music
description: Munir Bashir, a virtuoso oud player who was considered one of the greatest living masters of Arabic classical music, died on Sunday in Budapest. He was 67 and lived in Jordan.

title: Two Authors Have a Chat About Roller-Coaster Lives
description: Tennessee Williams and Carson McCullers were certainly fascinating wrecks, and the temptation to psychoanalyze them, and what they wrote, is almost irresistible. In ''Adjoining Trances,'' Randy Buck does resist, and one is grateful. But his play leaves the impression that he wants to avoid making judgments altogether, or even seeking insights into the appalling emotional and physical deterioration of both people after huge early success.

title: An Ordinary Morning, Then Disaster
description: Alex Castro, a Cuban immigrant known to friends and acquaintances for his gentlemanly demeanor and his love of mystery novels, was pushing a wooden handcart stuffed with architectural papers during the morning rush yesterday when a city bus barreled down Fifth Avenue and slammed into him, killing him instantly.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''People have feelings of isolation and of loneliness,'' the actress EMILY SKINNER said yesterday, ''and to want someone who will love you as you truly are.''

title: Yen Falls on Economy Woes; Mark Up on Rate-Rise Talk
description: The dollar climbed against the yen yesterday on further signs that Japan's economy was faltering, but fell against the mark on renewed speculation that Germany might soon raise interest rates.

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC AND CONOCO PLAN 2 JOINT VENTURES
description: The American Electric Power Company and Conoco Inc. said yesterday that they had agreed to form two joint venture companies to provide energy management and capital. Conoco is the energy subsidiary of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. DuPont and American Electric are to each invest about $125 million in stock, with the remainder of the joint ventures to be financed through debt. AEP Conoco Energy Capital is to acquire and lease back energy assets at industrial and large commercial plants. AEP Conoco Energy Management Services is to provide energy management services, like maintenance, energy reduction services, technical support and energy and fuel procurement.

title: Art In Review
description: Rona Pondick

title: Chief Named at Corporation for Public TV
description: Robert T. Coonrod has been named president and chief executive of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, its board announced on Wednesday, adding that he was ''unanimously and enthusiastically'' chosen. The corporation, a private, nonprofit group, oversees the development and financing of public television and radio in this country.

title: Islanders' New Lines and Young Defense Face a Test
description: The Islanders have many questions as they head into Madison Square Garden on Friday night to face the Rangers in the season opener.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes highly recommended shows.

title: Car Makers Voice Complaints About Limiting Gas Emissions
description: President Clinton met this evening with the chief executives of General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler to promote his trade policies, but received instead an earful of complaints about the Administration's interest in limiting emissions of gases that may contribute to global warming.

title: At the Movies; Director Scales A Personal Peak
description: Few recent movies have set off as much political debate as ''Seven Years in Tibet,'' the unexpectedly touching tale of how an Austrian mountain climber's accidental encounter with the Dalai Lama in Tibet while fleeing the British during World War II opened his once stony heart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEEHERN, RICHARD J.
description: GEEHERN-Richard J. On October 1, 1997. Of Scarsdale, New York. Husband of Margaret K. Father of Constance M. Brother of Joseph J. Family will receive friends at Bennett Funeral Home, 824 Scarsdale Avenue, Scarsdale, N.Y., Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Fatima Church, Saturday 10 A.M.

title: Room Service a l'Americain; Old World Charm Bumps Into New World Economics
description: It's not that Sol Melia, a Spanish hotel chain, was in financial trouble. It's just that it wasn't sufficiently Americanized.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENSTEIN, ROY
description: LICHTENSTEIN-Roy. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Parrish Art Museum deeply mourn the passing of Roy Lichtenstein. His wry brilliance enriched the way we all see. We extend our sympathy and heartfelt condolences to his wife, Dorothy and their families. Mildred C. Brinn, Chairman, Board of Trustees Trudy C. Kramer, Director The Parrish Art Museum Southampton, NY

title: Police Link a Single Suspect To 5 Queens Rapes Since July
description: Detectives are searching for a man they believe has committed five sexual assaults and attempted a sixth in homes around northeast Queens since July 29. The victims were 9 to 25 years old. It is only since the last attack, on Sept. 19, that the crimes have been linked to a single assailant.

title: Yes to National Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Even Before First Tip-Off, Nets Dare to Utter Playoffs
description: One by one, with cautious optimism, the players who assembled here today for their preseason physicals spoke about basketball's promised land -- the playoffs -- as something within their reach.

title: Was There a Boy or Not? Secrets, Lies and Ghosts
description: ''Mickey's Home'' is an enigmatic little play of secrets, guilt and roiled psyches that unravel in the apartment of an elderly Jewish couple on the Lower East Side.

title: Factory Orders Jump 1.3% On Big Electronics Demand
description: Orders placed with factories increased 1.3 percent in August, helped by the strongest rise in demand for electronic components in almost four decades, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Suspect Is Denied Bail In Slaying of Millionaire
description: The oldest of the three suspects in the kidnapping and murder of the New Jersey millionaire Nelson G. Gross made his first appearance in the Federal courthouse here yesterday and was ordered held without bail.

title: Art In Review
description: Jutta Koether

title: Paint on Diana's Car Suggests Collision With Fiat Just Before Crash
description: French investigators have determined that paint found on the Mercedes in which Diana, Princess of Wales, was killed here on Aug. 31 came from a black Fiat Uno that apparently collided with the Mercedes just before it smashed into a tunnel support pillar, officials said today.

title: Art In Review
description: Andy Warhol

title: Attacking and Defending The Internet, Yet Again
description: When the authorities said yesterday that the New Jersey teen-ager accused of sexually assaulting and strangling an 11-year-old neighbor was himself the victim of sexual assault by a man he met in an America Online chat room, people on both sides of the Internet debate had the same reaction: not again.

title: Home Video; DVD, a Goliath And So Versatile
description: It's still early for the digital video disk, or DVD, but already the five-inch sphere with a movie on it, introduced in March, is displaying both versatility and a continuing power to start a ruckus.

title: Sanofi and Bristol-Myers Will Market Drug
description: Sanofi S.A., the French drug maker, and the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company have received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to market Irbesartan, an anti-hypertension drug, a spokesman for the F.D.A. said yesterday.

title: Calmly Out of the Closet and Into the Clothes
description: Childhood transvestism could hardly look more dignified than in the regally poised figure of Georges DuFresne, the extraordinary young actor who plays Ludovic Fabre in ''Ma Vie en Rose'' (''My Life in Pink''). Although Ludovic is only 7, when dressed as a girl, this dark-eyed misfit who insists he belongs to the opposite sex contemplates the world with the serene hauteur of a natural-born diva. On the rare occasions his solemn face lights up, his lower lip crinkles just like Diana Ross's when she is flashing one of her blinking-back-tears, beauty-pageant smiles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOXHAM, VIRGINIA HUNTER
description: MOXHAM-Virginia Hunter. December 14, 1912-October 1, 1997. Wife of Egbert Moxham, Jr. of Crossland, Kennett Square, Pa. Funeral arrangements private.

title: Remember 'Galway Bay,' And 'No Irish Need Apply'?
description: The title is only partly facetious. ''The Irish . . . and How They Got That Way,'' a singing history lesson by Frank McCourt at the Irish Repertory Theater, assembles a tower of nuggets of fact and folklore that are indeed meant to convey some rationale behind the enduring stereotype of the drinker, fighter, poet and hater of the English.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Familiar Tune in Washington Square
description: It has been some time since Washington Square Park offered what Henry James called ''a kind of established repose which is not of frequent occurrence in other quarters of the long, shrill city.'' These days the park has been a haven for skate punks, folk singers, buskers and bikers, a draw for tourists looking for the unusual, and, much to the chagrin of the police and neighbors, a drug bazaar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, AZALEA
description: SIMON-Azalea. Sister of Robbie, & friend to many. Our love is with you. Memorial service at the Park Avenue Town House, 47 East 29 St, NYC, Tuesday, Oct. 7, 2 P.M.

title: Yeltsin Opens Door He Once Closed to a 3d Term
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin often makes news with his announcements. But it was what Mr. Yeltsin did not say today that has got political analysts aflutter.

title: Film in Review
description: 'Like a Bride'

title: Head of Kodak's Ailing Consumer Division to Step Aside
description: The Eastman Kodak Company replaced the head of its ailing consumer division yesterday, part of an accelerating effort by the company's chairman, George M. C. Fisher, to slash costs and reconstruct its photography business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSSELL, MARION WHITNEY
description: RUSSELL-Marion Whitney. On October 1, 1997. Beloved wife of the late W. Frank Russell; mother of Francia Russell Stowell and Marilyn Russell. Grandmother of Christopher, Darren and Ethan Stowell. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Friday 4-7 PM. Mass of Christian burial at Corpus Christi Church, 529 W 121 St, Saturday 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory may be made to Friends of Liturgical Music at Corpus Christi Church.

title: For Seattle, No Signs of Relief
description: The Seattle Mariners are an aging team, the window of opportunity for the likes of Jay Buhner, Randy Johnson and Edgar Martinez shrinking. General Manager Woody Woodward was cognizant of this when he acquired relief help just before the trade deadline. He traded Jose Cruz Jr. -- one of baseball's top prospects -- to Toronto for left-hander Paul Spoljaric and right-hander Mike Timlin, and two other prospects to Boston for Heathcliff Slocumb.

title: Metro Business; 47 Ticket Brokers Investigated by City
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs started to subpoena the business records of all 47 of the city's licensed ticket brokers this week to see whether they are reselling tickets at illegal prices.

title: The Selling of T. Sue; Tyrannosaur Skeleton May Bring $1 Million, But It's Already Brought Plenty of Trouble
description: Great issues (and probably upward of $1 million) will hang in the balance tomorrow when a tyrannosaur named Sue, believed to be the most costly fossil ever to reach the open market, will fall under the auctioneer's hammer at Sotheby's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNER, PAULINE STEINLAUF
description: TANNER-Pauline Steinlauf, after a long illness, cherished wife of the late Irving; loved by children Ben and Ellen Tanner Farkas, and Nicki and Harold Tanner; and grandchildren Esta and Paul Farkas, Gary and Lynn Farkas Schwartz, Peggy and David Tanner; Catherine Allegra and James Tanner, Kent and Karen Tanner Allen; and proud great-grandmother of 11. Her intelligence, love of, and loyalty to, family strengthened and enhanced our lives. Expressions of remembrance may be made to the Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem or to the Pauline and Irving Tanner Scholarship Fund at Cornell University. Funeral services will be Sunday, October 5, at 1:00 PM at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Jobs Outlook Lifts Bonds; 30-Year Yield Falls to 6.30%
description: Treasury prices continued to climb yesterday, as investors looked somewhat optimistically ahead to today's employment report for September.

title: PRESIDENT WANTS F.D.A. TO REGULATE FOREIGN PRODUCE
description: Acting after several outbreaks of disease linked to the burgeoning global trade in produce, President Clinton announced today that he would ask Congress to require Federal regulators to ban imports of fruit and vegetables from countries that did not meet expanded American food safety standards.

title: Weekend Warrior; Look! Is It A Bird? A Plane? It's . . . Me
description: ''Think of yourself as a kite,'' Jason Gephart is telling my friend Bill and me as we step gingerly onto his boat. ''A human kite, because that is what you are about to become.''

title: New Video Releases
description: Anaconda

title: Moral Victories Don't Count
description: He took the worst job in college football.

title: A Daughter's Memories Of a Mentally Ill Mother
description: DAUGHTER OF THE QUEEN

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Clean Air Case Is Settled
description: For the first time in New Jersey, an environmental group has forced a private company to settle a lawsuit claiming violations of Federal clean air laws. The group, the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, announced yesterday that the Warren Energy Resources Company in Oxford Township, which operates a waste-to-energy incinerator, agreed last week to pay $200,000 to a land conservancy group and more than $300,000 to improve air-pollution control at its plant. Those payments were in addition to $140,000 in penalties already paid to the State Department of Environmental Protection.

title: Film in Review
description: 'The Locusts'

title: World News Briefs; Spain Faces Damages In Toxic Cooking-Oil Suit
description: A high court today held the Government responsible for not preventing the sale in 1981 of toxic cooking oil that killed 700 Spaniards and poisoned some 30,000 others, and it doubled the damage payments a lower court assigned to the State last year. They could now exceed $2 billion.

title: Art In Review
description: Paul Feeley

title: Yankee Fortunes Take Serious Turn for the Worse
description: The division series between the Yankees and the Indians is a serious series again. Very serious. The Yankees wanted to ride Andy Pettitte's arm and their momentum from winning the thrilling opener to flatten the wobbly Indians and set up a brief, yet enjoyable, weekend in Cleveland. It never materialized that way and their dreary evening got drearier because David Cone's right shoulder is hurting and his season could be over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAI, KOCKMAY IRENE
description: KAI-Kockmay Irene. Passed away 9/27/97. Beloved wife of Heng Tan. Loving mother of Quinnie Sg Tan. Born 10/20/50. Received her degree in Gemology, Hong Kong Baptist College. Member of Fellowship of Gemological Assocation of Great Britain. FGA/ GIA appraisal diploma. Owner of Abacus Jewelry, Inc. Truthful, sincere, lofty character, diligent, dynamic her whole life, but the killing illness shattered her dream. Burial on Saturday, October 4, at 10 AM, Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HONIG, JEANNETTE S.
description: HONIG-Jeannette S. October 3, 1990. In loving memory of a beautiful sister. The Schonfeld family

title: Ad Group Chooses 6 For 1997 Honors
description: The American Advertising Federation in Washington has selected six executives 40 and younger to be inducted into the Advertising Hall of Achievement for 1997. The honors complement the organization's Hall of Fame, which pays tribute to older executives.

title: BASEBALL PLAYOFFS: NOTES
description: TEXAS

title: Anheuser-Busch Queried On Distribution Practices
description: The Justice Department is investigating whether Anheuser-Busch Inc. has been using its enormous muscle to squeeze smaller competitors out of the beer market.

title: Art Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Bird Lovers Fight for Crabs
description: The New Jersey Audubon Society is not giving up on its quest to stop the fall harvest of horseshoe crabs. Society members said the harvest endangers migratory shore birds that feed on horseshoe crab eggs when they pass through New Jersey on their 10,000-mile journey from Argentina to the Arctic each spring. The Audubon Society, which has taken the lead in trying to ban the wholesale harvesting of horseshoe crabs, planned to ask an appellate court today to stop the fall crab harvest, which accounts for 60 percent of the 800,000 crabs taken annually. Each spring, the horseshoe crabs lay millions of eggs on the banks of the Delaware River, and four species of shore birds feed on the eggs.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Suspect Was Also a Victim
description: A New Jersey teen-ager charged with sexually assaulting and strangling an 11-year-old neighbor was himself sexually abused last year by a convicted pedophile from Long Island who lured the 15-year-old from an on-line chat room to various locations for sex, prosecutors disclosed yesterday. The Long Island man was arrested last week, and until recently the teen-ager had been cooperating with the investigation, the authorities said.

title: Oil Surges on Fear of Break In Iraq and Colombia Supplies
description: Crude oil prices rose to their highest level in four months yesterday because of tensions between Iraq and United Nations weapons inspectors and concern over an impending strike by oil workers in Colombia.

title: Safety Standards for Imported Food
description: Global trade allows Americans to satisfy their appetites for strawberries in spring, apples in midsummer and asparagus in autumn. Last year 38 percent of fruits and 12 percent of vegetables consumed here came from foreign fields. But getting fresh produce year round also means that consumers are exposed to foreign food production systems that may not be well regulated. Although the vast majority of the 30 billion tons of food imported annually is wholesome, recent incidents of illness caused by tainted Guatemalan raspberries and E. coli-contaminated domestic meat and fruit juices have made food safety a public concern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DREYFUSS, KLEIN, BERTHA (NEE ROHR)
description: DREYFUSS-KLEIN-Bertha (nee Rohr). On October 1, 1997. Beloved mother of Ralph (Helen). Loving grandmother of Michele (Fred), Jamie, and Madeleine (Paul). Dearest great-grandmother of Philip, Teddy, Emily and Isaac Sherrill, Jordana Dreyfuss, Justin and Amanda Schnell. Graveside service Sunday, 2PM at Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, N.J.

title: Call Anderson a Fullback, But Try Not to Label Him
description: Richie Anderson doesn't like labels, especially the ones that are attached to him. He has heard them: pass catcher, too small to be a true fullback. Those sorts of tags have followed him for five years in the National Football League and they frustrate him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPELMAN, LEONARD A.
description: SPELMAN-Leonard A., 88 years, on October 1. A longtime Great Neck resident and community leader. Beloved husband of the late Louise (Rosenfeld) and Betty (Siegmeister). Devoted father of Susan Spelman and Barbara and Tony Josepher. Loving grandfather of Mark and Laura Josepher and Juan Brea. Services Friday, 1 PM at ''Riverside-Nassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza (opp LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Merger Talks Are Ended
description: Home Products International Inc. has ended its merger discussions with Zag Industries Ltd. after the two companies could not resolve ''key operational issues.'' Zag Industries agreed last month to buy Home Products for about $100 million in stock. Under the agreement, each Home Products share was to be exchanged for 1.1 Zag shares. The Chicago-based Home Products makes plastic products. Zag, based in Israel, also makes plastic consumer products.

title: As Torre Stands Pat, Fielder Sits on Bench
description: Cecil Fielder continued to watch and wait last night.

title: The Impact of Condoms in Schools
description: A study published in the American Journal of Public Health provides strong evidence that making condoms available in schools does not encourage adolescent promiscuity, as critics of condom programs had feared. The researchers compared the experiences of several thousand students in New York City high schools where condoms are available as part of an AIDS education program with the experiences of students in Chicago where condoms are not available in schools. They found that condom access did not increase the rate of sexual activity but did modestly increase condom use among students who were already sexually active.

title: National News Briefs; Photos of Stolen Artworks Are With ABC and Paper
description: Color photographs purporting to show two of the Rembrandt paintings stolen from the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston in March 1990 have been obtained by two news organizations, the museum said in statement yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTESMAN, ESTHER (GARFUNKEL)
description: GOTTESMAN-Esther (Garfunkel), on October 1, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin, adored mother of Milton, David and the late Alice, and loving mother-inlaw of Ruth. Devoted sister to Florence, Harold, Julian and the late Elsie and Mildred. Wonderful grandmother of Robert and Trudy, Alice and Larry, William and Debra. Loving great-grandmother of Benjamin, Sarah, Alan, Clara and Zachary. Funeral service is at 12 Noon, Sunday, October 5, at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, 125 East 85th Street, NYC. Family requests no flowers be sent.

title: Film in Review
description: 'Forgotten Siver'

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; A Chrysler for Developing Nations
description: THE Chrysler Corp. has developed a small car aimed at developing nations that would cost half as much as its cheapest American-built model, would be almost totally recyclable and could go 50 miles on a gallon of gasoline. Perhaps more important, it could be made in a way that eliminates expensive and pollution-prone operations in assembly plants, with body panels molded from the plastic used for soda bottles.

title: Varian Seeks a G.E. Unit
description: Varian Associates Inc. said today that it had offered to purchase GE Medical Systems' radiotherapy service and customer support business for an undisclosed amount of cash. Varian, a high-technology company with interests in medical services and semiconductors, said it expected to close the transaction by the end of the year. GE Medical Systems is a unit of the General Electric Company. GE Medical Systems said the proposed sale included all of its radiotherapy service and customer support operations.

title: Yankees Make Donation
description: The Yankees celebrated the 50th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's breaking of baseball's modern color barrier by donating $100,000 to the Jackie Robinson Foundation scholarship effort. CLAIRE SMITH

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK
description: Yale

title: Accounts
description: -- E*Trade Group, Palo Alto, Calif., to Pickholz Tweedy & Cowan, New York, as the first agency to handle the direct marketing portion of the estimated $25 million account of the on-line investment service. Gotham Inc., New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., continues to handle the advertising duties.

title: FACING A LOSS, NASHUA MAY SELL SOME OF ITS ASSETS
description: The Nashua Corporation said yesterday that it might sell some assets and that it expected a third-quarter loss from operations of about $2.6 million, or 40 cents a share, on poor demand for its mail-order film-processing services. Nashua said it had hired BT Alex. Brown Inc. and Braxton Associates to look into its options, which include selling the company. The company, based in Nashua, N.H., said the third-quarter loss stems from rising competition among retailers and other mail-order businesses in the United States and Britain. Nashua's stock rose $1.25 yesterday, to $12.6875.

title: Suspect in New Jersey Strangling Was Reportedly Sex-Case Victim
description: The New Jersey teen-ager charged with sexually assaulting and strangling an 11-year-old neighbor boy was himself sexually abused last year by a convicted pedophile who lured him from an on-line chat room to his home on Long Island and to motel rooms in Ocean and Monmouth Counties, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Give the Kid an Inning, He Hijacks the Game
description: Nothing could have prepared him for this, nothing in Jaret Wright's wild ride this season from Class AA to post-season play. A season that began for Wright with the Akron Aeros appeared to reach the beginning of the end on the mound at Yankee Stadium last night.

title: Pitney Bowes Credit Chooses an Agency
description: The Pitney Bowes Credit Corporation in Shelton, Conn., named Merkley Newman Harty in New York as agency of record to sell its financial services and equipment to customers in the small-office and home-office markets. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million for the introduction. Merkley Newman, a unit of Omnicom Group, received the account after a two-month review that had been narrowed to that agency and Hal Riney & Partners/Heartland in Chicago.

title: Inside Art; Sotheby's Loses Albers Estate
description: When Sotheby's bought the Andre Emmerich Gallery in Manhattan last year, officials there said one reason was that it gave them a vehicle for handling artists' estates. But what Sotheby's didn't realize was that not every estate wants to be represented by an auction house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEINMAN, GEORGE
description: KLEINMAN-George, 86, of Flushing, NY and Coconut Creek, Fl. Beloved husband of Florence, father of Robert and Alan, father-in-law of Doris, grandpa of Ruth, Allison, Eli and Lea. Salesman, fundraiser and family patriarch. Funeral at Parkside, 98-60 Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Sunday, 10 AM.

title: Art In Review
description: Michael Ray Charles

title: Faulty Vote Count
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop and Jazz Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Metaphors of the Kitchen For Autoerotic Fantasies
description: ''Nenette et Boni'' isn't the first film by the French director Claire Denis to evoke the roller coaster of adolescence with an uncanny feel for the jagged emotional rhythms of youth. Ms. Denis's 1994 made-for-television film, ''U.S. Go Home,'' slipped so deeply into the skins of its teen-age characters in various stages of sexual experience that to watch it was to resurrect the goose bumps of one's own tremulous adolescence.

title: Losing Late Has Giants Set to Take Their Turn
description: The San Francisco Giants' bandwagon is not as full now, after the Florida Marlins crafted two wrenching victories in their last at-bat in the three-of-five-game division series. That's just fine with Giants Manager Dusty Baker.

title: Congress Should Support Condom Distribution
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Goodby Employees Forming Agency
description: Three employees at Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, a unit of the Omnicom Group in San Francisco, are leaving to open their own shop.

title: TV Weekend; 'S' for Success in the Story of Truman
description: It's been many years since historians installed Harry S. Truman among the nation's least-likely-to-succeed and most successful Presidents. If he is not elevated to the very-least-likely, most successful of all, it will not be the fault of ''Truman,'' the four-and-a-half-hour appreciation that begins Sunday night on PBS.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GREENBRIER COS., Lake Oswego, Ore., a supplier of transportation equipment and services, agreed to sell its shipping assets to GE Capital Services' Transport International Pool unit for $72 million in cash.

title: Cancer May Be the Cost of Modern Life Style; Incentives for Research
description: To the Editor:

title: In August, Fed Had Concern On Labor Cost
description: Federal Reserve policy makers decided unanimously to hold interest rates steady at their Aug. 19 meeting but expressed concern about rising labor and health care costs.

title: Arafat Meets In Jordan With Cleric Freed by Israel
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, flew to Jordan today and met Sheik Ahmed Yassin, the Hamas religious leader who was released on Wednesday from an Israeli prison, in a visit that underscored the potential impact of the cleric on the balance of Palestinian politics.

title: Antiques; Toy Story: Not Just Fun And Games
description: ''If I watch you play, I will tell you who you are,'' Karen Hewitt said philosophically. How young people have been playing since 1800 is the subject of a show for which Ms. Hewitt is the curator, ''Toying With Architecture: The Building Toy in the Arena of Play,'' an amusing, thought-provoking exhibition at the Katonah Museum of Art, in Westchester County, through Jan. 4.

title: White House to Propose Boards to Review I.R.S.
description: The White House will soon propose the creation of independent review panels across the country to hear complaints from taxpayers about the Internal Revenue Service, a senior Administration official said tonight.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: In a Shake-Up, Kodak Replaces Consumer Chief

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Rosh ha-Shanah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORTHROP, STUART JOHNSTON
description: NORTHROP-Stuart Johnston, in Scottsdale, Arizona on Sept. 27, 1997 at age 71 after a long illness. Retired Chairman and CEO of the Huffy Corporation of Dayton, Ohio and a Director of numerous other companies, including BancOne Corporation and Dayton Power and Light Company. Resident of Naples, Florida. Son of the late Christine Johnston Northrop and the late Filmer Stuart Cockow Northrop, Sterling Professor of Law and Philosophy at Yale University and former Master of Silliman College there. Graduate in 1943 of the Phillips Academy, Andover, Mass. and in 1948 of Yale University. Survived by his wife, Judith, a daughter, Christine, of Haverford, Pennsylvania, a son, Richard, of Greenwich, Connecticut, and a brother, Johnston, also of Greenwich. A memorial service will be held at noon on Saturday, October 4, in Dwight Memorial Chapel on the Old Campus of Yale University. A reception will follow at Silliman College, 71 Wall Street, New Haven. Burial will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to the Office of Academy Resources at Phillips Academy, Andover, MA 01810, or the Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Association, Valley of the Sun, 3507 North Central Avenue, Phoenix, AZ 85017

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; 10 Charged in Beating
description: Prosecutors say it started when a young man walked into a restaurant asking for change and was refused by the owner. Yesterday, the youth and nine other black men -- ranging in age from 17 to 25 -- were charged with a racially motivated beating on May 17. The victim, Zhi Gen-lin, lapsed into a coma after he was beaten outside the Kam Kwoon Restaurant, said Boris Moczula, a prosecutor. Charges included attempted murder, aggravated assault, rioting and harassment with a bias element, he said.

title: Religious Rally in Capital Is a Test of Faith
description: The Mall in Washington is the nation's shrine to democracy, but Bill McCartney, a college football coach turned evangelical Christian leader, envisions its 146 acres as a vast church tomorrow, one filled by hundreds of thousands of men, kneeling in prayer to ask for God's mercy on socially troubled America.

title: Debate Aside, Fund-Raising Doesn't Stop
description: Shortly after 9 P.M., as the 70 or so guests picked over the last crumbs of their almond tuile with peaches, plums, pears and seasonal berries, President Clinton scanned the candlelit room of eight round tables filled with the wealthiest Democrats in Texas.

title: MCI-Worldcom Match: How They'll Fit, or Won't
description: As MCI Communications weighs Worldcom Inc.'s unsolicited takeover offer, clues as to how the top executives of the two companies would fare if they wound up in the same corporate phone booth may lie in an incident last winter, when the companies threw elbows during a contract dispute.

title: Heavy Traffic to the Third World
description: NEARLY all the world's leading auto manufacturers are developing inexpensive cars and new, cost-efficient manufacturing methods to produce affordable vehicles in the emerging markets of Southeast Asia, India and South America.

title: 5th Ave. Bus Runs Wild; Messenger Killed and Cyclist Hurt
description: A city bus driver with a history of medical problems and two suspensions for substance abuse a decade ago lost control of his bus at the height of the morning rush yesterday and it bounded wildly down Fifth Avenue in midtown Manhattan in a seven-block journey of destruction. The bus caromed off another bus and plowed into cars, a bicyclist and a messenger before slamming into a chinaware store at 27th Street.

title: Art In Review
description: Jack Youngerman

title: Confidence in Police Has Fallen, a Poll Finds
description: Less than two months after the case of Abner Louima ignited an outcry against police brutality, a poll released yesterday shows that New Yorkers' confidence in the Police Department has dropped significantly in the last year and a half.

title: Cancer May Be the Cost of Modern Life Style; Data Are Murky
description: To the Editor:

title: Runaway Bus Hits and Kills Bronx Boy, 9, At an Orchard
description: An out-of-control school bus careered across a parking lot and down a hill yesterday at an orchard in Warwick, N.Y., injuring several children and killing a 9-year-old boy from the Bronx who was waiting to ride a pony.

title: Metro Business; Gym Reimbursements
description: The State Attorney General's office has moved to confiscate $275,000 from Living Well Lady, a women's health club chain that abruptly closed 12 outlets this month in New York, Long Island and Westchester, as well as clubs in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, a spokeswoman said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASKENAS, WARREN
description: ASKENAS-Warren, 63, on September 30, 1997. Husband of Merle. Beloved father of Mitchell and Wendy, and Caren and Gary Cohen. Big Bacca and Grandpa to Lyndsey, Brenna and Robby. Dear brother of Irma and Harold Goshin. You were taken away from us so suddenly, and you will be missed terribly. Funeral services to be held Sun., Oct. 5, 9:45AM, at Sinai Chapels, 718-445-0300.

title: Bodrum Journal; Ataturk the Icon Is About to Take a Bit of a Hit
description: A potent shadow, a legend that has grown into an officially sanctioned cult, envelops every aspect of Turkish life. It is the shadow of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, founder of the Turkish Republic and a virtual deity here.

title: Nobuo Fujita, 85, Is Dead; Only Foe to Bomb America
description: Nobuo Fujita, a Japanese pilot who flew bombing runs over Oregon in 1942, apparently the only time that an enemy aircraft has ever bombed the American mainland, died on Tuesday at a hospital near Tokyo. He was 85.

title: Cancer May Be the Cost of Modern Life Style; Radiation as Carcinogen
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the choice of breads now offered in restaurants misstated the given name of the owner of the Bouley Bakery in Manhattan. He is David Bouley, not Daniel.

title: Art In Review
description: Lorna Simpson

title: Virginia A. Dwyer, 76, Former AT&T Executive
description: Virginia A. Dwyer, a former senior vice president for finance at the AT&T Corporation and one of the first women to gain a top position at a major American company, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. Miss Dwyer, a resident of Manhattan, was 76.

title: A Guitarist Of Precision And Calm
description: Pat Martino's first set at Birdland on Wednesday night, delivered with few words and mostly head down in guitar harmony, brought a studious, monkish atmosphere to the room. Mr. Martino, a stylistic descendant of Wes Montgomery, is a deity among guitar students; he has a new album on Blue Note, ''All Sides Now,'' which pairs him in duets with a roll-call of guitar heroes from rock, jazz and soft-jazz. But since that's not a concept easily translated to a nightclub performance, he's in town with a group of musicians from Philadelphia, his home town.

title: Movie Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Running times and ratings of films are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 7.

title: Stepdaughter Says Driver Has Seizures
description: The driver of a city bus that raced out of control down Fifth Avenue yesterday and killed a pedestrian suffers from epileptic seizures, his stepdaughter said last night.

title: From Steel Mills to Museums, A City Rises Out of Disrespect
description: Cleveland hasn't always had a bad press. At the turn of the century, under the reform Mayor Tom L. Johnson, it was described as ''the best-governed city in America.'' John Gunther liked it when he passed through doing research for ''Inside U.S.A.,'' and the local power company got good mileage out of the smug slogan ''The Best Location in the Nation.''

title: RENO IS EXPANDING INQUIRY INTO CALLS BY GORE FOR CASH
description: Attorney General Janet Reno has decided to expand the Justice Department's inquiry of Vice President Al Gore's fund-raising telephone calls, moving to the next phase in the process of determining whether to seek an independent prosecutor, Government officials said today.

title: B-Movie Actor Is Rising Star of Philippines Politics
description: His biggest accomplishment as a senator was passage of a bill to protect the water buffalo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, PHILIP CARL
description: RICHMAN-Philip Carl. Oh, Daddy. My Daddy. My Captain. I worshipped the ground you walked on. Larry

title: Ellis Island Fight Doesn't Belong in Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Dept. and Pentagon Clear Raytheon-Hughes Deal
description: The Raytheon Company won approval today from Federal antitrust officials to buy the military business of Hughes Electronics in a $9.5 billion deal, but the companies agreed to take several steps intended to maintain competition.

title: Cancer May Be the Cost of Modern Life Style
description: To the Editor:
