title: Stuart Northrop, 72; Led Huffy Company
description: Stuart Johnston Northrop, a former chairman and chief executive of the Huffy Corporation, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Scottsdale, Ariz. Mr. Northrop, a resident of Naples, Fla., was 72.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: GEON IN $76 MILLION DEAL TO BUY SYNERGISTICS INDUSTRIES
description: The Geon Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Synergistics Industries Ltd. of Canada for about $15.90 a share, or about $76 million

title: Cosmic Buddhist Diagrams On Show
description: Even in the city vaunted as the art world's capital, it's not often that in one year there are two shows of religious art so dazzling that attendance is compulsory.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Sept. 16 about Jews' occupation of a house in an Arab neighborhood of Jerusalem referred incorrectly to an Arab tenant's status. The building, owned by a Jewish investor, had been vacated by its Arab tenant; though he has since asserted that he left only temporarily and wants to return, there is no evidence that he was ousted.

title: Drinking To Fit In
description: No one wanted me when I was an undergraduate at Princeton. Ivy Club didn't want me. Cap and Gown didn't want me. Tiger Inn didn't want me, either. These were a few of Princeton's eating clubs, the university's genteel equivalent of fraternities and sororities, and not to be wanted by them was a miserable, humiliating experience.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Family Sought to Commit Boy
description: Three days before a sixth grader from Jackson Township was strangled while selling school candy near his home, a state judge refused to order that the 15-year-old boy now charged with the slaying be committed to a psychiatric institution, court documents show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHBURN, FRANK DAVIS
description: ASHBURN-Frank Davis, age 94, of Westwood on October 2, 1997. Distinguished Headmaster Emeritus of Brooks School, N. Andover, Massachusetts. Beloved husband of Jean (Lang) Ashburn and the late Phyllis (Batcheller) Ashburn. Devoted father of the late Phyllis A. Kissel and Nancy A. Whitaker. He is survived by 7 grandchildren & seventeen great-grandchildren. Private service and burial at the Ashburn Chapel, Brooks School. Memorial services will be at Brooks School on Saturday, November 1, 1997, at 11:00 AM and at the Chapel of St Bartholomew's Church, Park Ave at 51st St, New York City, on Monday, November 3, 1997, 2:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to The Ashburn Chair, Brooks School, N. Andover, MA 01845. Information: the Holden-Westwood Funeral Home, Westwood, MA.

title: Suspect in Park Slaying 'Flipped Out,' Friend Told Police
description: In the hours after a 44-year-old real estate agent was stabbed to death in Central Park last spring, one of the young suspects gave a series of rambling statements to the police in which she said that her friend had taken LSD and committed the crime after ''he just went nuts,'' according to court documents.

title: At 15, Next Wave Still Tests the Edge; How Brooklyn's Window on Innovation Became a Powerhouse
description: The view from the precipice of the first opening night filled the producers with terror. Fifteen years later, terror has turned to awe that the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival has become the foremost showcase for contemporary experimental performance in the United States.

title: On the Verge of 100, a Racing Legend Looks Ahead
description: Just in time for his 100th birthday, Fred W. Hooper was driven to the barbershop by his wife to get spruced up for three parties in the next three days, greetings from President Clinton and more than 300 guests who will honor perhaps the most durable and respected figure in thoroughbred racing.

title: Time for a Real Campaign
description: In a month, New York City voters will elect the mayor who will lead the city into the next millennium. Right now they have a good idea of how the incumbent, Rudolph Giuliani, has performed over the last four years, but little sense of his vision for the future. His Democratic opponent Ruth Messinger has told them a lot about where she thinks Mr. Giuliani has gone wrong, but much less about how she would run things herself. It is time for both candidates to start talking specifics.

title: Bridge; Achievement of a Lifetime: A Rare Double Grand Coup
description: In the early days of the game writers and theorists were greatly excited about a rare play, the grand coup, and an even rarer one, the double grand coup. These terms are rarely used nowadays, and few players know what they mean.

title: HBO TO BUY NATIONAL HEALTH ENHANCEMENT FOR STOCK
description: HBO & Company, a provider of information systems for hospitals, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire National Health Enhancement Systems Inc. for about $70 million in stock. National Health, based in Phoenix, sells call-center products and health-management software and has approximately 235 employees. Under the agreement, expected to close late this year, HBO, of Atlanta, will exchange 0.32 share for each National Health share. The terms will be adjusted if HBO shares fall below $35.37 or rise above $43.23 before the deal closes. HBO shares rose $1.375, to $40.375, while National Health's shares slipped 18.75 cents, to $11.9375.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about the Mayberry Days festival in Mount Airy, N.C., misstated the name and number of an episode of ''The Andy Griffith Show'' in which an actress named Jackie Joseph appeared as Sweet Romeena. It is ''My Fair Ernest T. Bass'' and is episode 113, not 13.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Loans for Energy Efficiency
description: Public Service Electric and Gas Company is offering loans of up to $15,000 to residential customers who want to make their homes more energy efficient, company officials said yesterday.

title: FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK
description: Surgery for Jackson

title: Worms Profit Climbed 55% in First Half
description: Worms & Cie said yesterday that its first-half profit rose 55 percent compared with the period a year earlier as three of its four main businesses -- sugar, paper and insurance -- posted higher earnings and its shipping unit returned a profit. Profit rose to 1.18 billion French francs, or $197 million, from 761 million francs, or $127.8 million, in the six months a year earlier.

title: 'A Careful Dance' for U.S. Envoy in Switzerland
description: In her inaugural speech as Governor of Vermont 12 years ago, Madeleine May Kunin proclaimed that her victory had changed state history.

title: America Has a Labor Shortage. Europe Has the Answer.
description: One month, the financial markets are bent over backward because the United States economy is supposedly growing too fast. Interest rates are pushed higher. The next month, fresh statistics cool the inflation fever, and the markets calm down.

title: 'A Big Pain' at ESPN Shifts Focus at MSNBC
description: Keith Olbermann was the Groucho Marx of sportscasting. As the co-anchor of ESPN's ''Sportscenter,'' he wryly connected his wisecracks, intelligence and pop culture obsessions to the nightly stew of news, scores and highlights.

title: Do Numbers Add Up to Victory for Iowa?
description: They have got everyone's attention around here. The Iowa Hawkeyes came to town with eye-popping statistics, big-play capability, Rose Bowl hopes. . . .

title: STANDARD PACIFIC TO ABSORB DUC DEVELOPMENT
description: The Standard Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Duc Development Company, a privately owned home builder, and related real estate assets for $71 million plus assumed debt. Standard Pacific, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., builds single-family homes in Northern California and earned $8.4 million on sales of about $400 million last year. The purchase price includes $16 million for the company, $55 million for the real estate assets and $8 million in assumed debt. The acquisition gives Standard Pacific an additional 1,400 single-family lots and 12 new projects.

title: Workaday, and Everyday, Shortstop
description: There were enough tangible reasons for the scout to ignore the thinly built college shortstop. He didn't hit much, he would never run well enough to steal bases as a professional. But J. P. Ricciardi, the scout, liked the way the kid played, respected his intensity, loved how he refused to yield to runners when turning double plays. Perhaps, Ricciardi thought, if the youngster worked really hard, he might become a utility infielder in the majors.

title: McCall Criticizes Assumptions in Planned Nassau County Budget
description: The State Comptroller has raised doubts about a total of $100 million in revenues in the $2 billion budget proposed by the Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, including $16 million from a nationwide tobacco-litigation settlement that has yet to be approved.

title: Let's Teach Young People to Drink Sensibly
description: To the Editor:

title: World Cup Stays in Distance For U.S.
description: This was the night that the United States soccer team, fit and healthy for the first time in months, would display its abundant skills. It would score goals and play impenetrable defense, and as the players confidently predicted, easily defeat Jamaica. But all of this haughty talk was just that, talk.

title: A 60's Summer Through a 90's Lens
description: The Summer of Love may be 30 years gone, but a lot of us still trust in it. The image of that fabled mirage still shimmers in our vaguely guilty brains, somehow simultaneously within reach and just out of reach. And now comes the inevitable anniversary hoopla here in the epicenter of hippiedom.

title: Blazers Sign Pair
description: The Portland Trail Blazers signed the veteran center Alton Lister and the swingman Sean Higgins yesterday.

title: Text of the Attorney General's Letter Sent to the House Judiciary Chairman
description: Following is the text of a letter from Attorney General Janet Reno to Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Illinois Republican who is the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, as made public today by the Justice Department:

title: Some Local Cheers for 'Creeping Socialism'; A Few Towns Build Their Own Cable Companies
description: In an America where free-enterprise advocates have routed their critics, few people would expect local governments to plunge into competition with the private sector in the fast-evolving information industries. Yet that is what is happening in a growing number of communities.

title: Gooden Hopes He'll Rise to Occasion
description: Dwight Gooden was visibly uncomfortable discussing the possibility that he might replace David Cone and start Game 4 of the division series before the Yankees announced the switch. Once they did, Gooden displayed his excitement about his first post-season start since 1988, when he was with the Mets.

title: CHIRON SAYS IT MAY SELL IDLE PUERTO RICO PLANT
description: The Chiron Corporation, a maker of health care products, said yesterday that it might sell an idle pharmaceutical plant in Puerto Rico to streamline operations. Costs associated with a write-down of the plant's value will lower third-quarter earnings by more than $25 million, the company said. The costs will have an ''adverse impact'' on third-quarter and full-year operating earnings, Chiron said. Analysts had expected the company, which is based in Emeryville, Calif., to earn 9 cents a share for the third quarter, which ended Sept. 28.

title: Smoltz Is Overwhelming As Braves Finish Off Astros
description: A series that looked like a mismatch on paper was also a mismatch on the field.

title: Fielder Finally Gets His Chance
description: Cecil Fielder, often accused of mouthing off this season when in actuality no words were being spoken, was nonetheless labeled a miscreant and the creator of a budding evil empire of dissension during the Yankees' early-season struggles.

title: More Southeast Asia Turmoil Raises Fears of Bank Losses
description: The Indonesian currency tumbled as much as 9.3 percent against the dollar today amid concern that high interest rates and slowing economic growth could lead to losses at the nation's banks and other companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYMES, BEATRICE G.
description: HAYMES-Beatrice G. On October 2, 1997, of Fort Lauderdale, Florida, passed away in Westhampton Beach, New York. Widow of Morice, beloved mother of Stephen D., loving grandmother of Starr and Evan, dear sister of Sylvia Goodzeit, Pearl Schagrin & Lillian Weiss. Services on Sunday, October 5, 10:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, followed by interment at Salem Fields Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions to the R.W. Morice and Beatrice Haymes Charity Fund of the 8th Masonic District of Manhattan, c/o Harry S. Truman Lodge #

title: Doors That Offer Hope May Shut; A Program That Has Housed the Mentally Ill Lapses
description: A landmark agreement that created housing for thousands of the city's homeless mentally ill has quietly expired, but officials say it did not build enough apartments for the hundreds of troubled people who continue to seek permanent housing.

title: A Tenor Whose Shyness Boosts His Popularity
description: Like the British bobby or the Russian bear, the Italian tenor is a stock-in-trade stereotype: the difference is that a tenor is exportable. Take the case of Andrea Bocelli, a 39-year-old blind singer who, with a medley of Italian love songs and operatic melodies, has soared this year to the top of the charts across Europe and in Canada, Korea and Argentina.

title: Sharpton Hails Witnesses In Bias Murder Trial
description: Impressed by the testimony of two white boys who said they saw a white off-duty police officer shoot a black man, the Rev. Al Sharpton said yesterday that outrage over the killing seemed to have crossed racial lines.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Days Before Slaying, Parents Of Suspect Pleaded for Help
description: Three days before a sixth grader from Jackson Township was strangled while selling school candy near his home, a state judge refused to order that the 15-year-old boy now charged with the slaying be committed to a psychiatric institution, court documents show.

title: President Might Veto Congressmen's Projects
description: Three months ago the Republican-controlled Congress approved a balanced budget agreement. But that does not mean that lawmakers have given up vying for public works for their districts.

title: Auto Sales Weaken as Buyers Await Deals
description: Call it the car buyer's revenge.

title: Midtown Bus Accident
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: TURNER INVESTMENT TO BUY SOLON ASSET MANAGEMENT
description: Turner Investment Partners Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Solon Asset Management L.P., a fixed-income fund management firm with about $350 million in assets, for an undisclosed amount. Turner Investment signed a letter of intent to acquire Solon, which is owned by James and Deborah Midanek. The acquisition, Turner Investment's first, is intended to expand the company's fixed-income business, Stephen Kneeley, the firm's co-founder, said. Solon, based in Walnut Creek, Calif., manages two short-term government bond mutual funds. Turner Investment, based in Berwyn, Pa., is a stock fund manager that oversees about $2.3 billion in assets.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Political Ad Ruled Legitimate
description: Lawyers for State Senator James E. McGreevey, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, were unable to persuade election officials yesterday that a television commercial paid for by the Republican National State Election Committee was actually a campaign advertisement for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: Job Growth Was Modest Last Month
description: For a second consecutive month, America's employers have added only modest numbers of new workers to payrolls, the Labor Department said today, releasing September data widely regarded as further evidence that the pace of economic growth is slowing.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER ANNOUNCES PLANS FOR PLANT SALES
description: The International Paper Company said yesterday that it had sold a packaging business to the closely held Southern Bag Corporation for undisclosed terms and would sell and close other plants as part of its plan to cut about 10 percent of its work force and sell $1 billion in assets. As part of the plan, it also said on Thursday that it would sell a coated-paper unit in France to a group led by the unit's chief executive and would close two California container plants. The packaging business makes multiwall kraft paper for heavy-duty bags used for dry cement, dog food and other bulk goods. International Paper's shares slipped 50 cents, to $54.8125.

title: Grant Wins Race
description: Michael Grant, a junior from Columbia, pulled away from his teammate Tom Kloos to win the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Cross Country Association championship yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx. His winning time of 25 minutes 25 seconds in the five-mile event helped lead the Lions to a successful defense of the team title.

title: Tropical Forests Are Ravaged by Free Trade; New York Resolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, TEDDY
description: KAPLAN-Teddy. Beloved husband of Sylvia, devoted father of Barbara and Mark Raifman and Dennis and Anna Kaplan. Cherished grandfather of Jay, Lee, Jaime and David. Loving uncle, great uncle and great great uncle. Services 1:45 PM Sunday at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapel'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: 2 Apartment Projects Sold
description: United Dominion Realty Trust Inc. said today that it had acquired two apartment communities for about $27.8 million in separate transactions. The company said it had acquired the 265-unit Waterside at Ironbridge, south of Richmond, for $15 million. It also said it had bought the 240-unit Deep River Pointe in High Point, N.C. United Dominion, a real estate investment trust, is based in Richmond.

title: Boeing Halts 747 Output to Clear Up Bottlenecks
description: Struggling to meet surging demand for its commercial aircraft, the Boeing Company said yesterday that it would halt production of its 747 jumbo jet for 20 days, and would not begin building new versions of the 737 model for 25 days, to allow it and its suppliers to catch up on a big shortage of parts.

title: About New York ; A Champion Of Marijuana On the Stump
description: TOM LEIGHTON twice ran unsuccessfully for Congress as an independent allied with the Green Party. Unfazed, he boned up on the issues as he embarked on his current quest to become Manhattan borough president. While he isn't exactly on a roll this time, at least one of his issues is.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Protest Against Sweatshops
description: Many people associate sweatshops with Third World countries, but even in New Jersey, as many as 100 unregistered garment factories are operating without the scrutiny of state inspectors, union officials said yesterday.

title: NORTHERN TRUST TO BUY FIRST CHICAGO NBD UNIT
description: The Northern Trust Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the ANB Investment Management and Trust Company, a unit of the First Chicago NBD Corporation, for about $50 million, as it expands its passive investing business. Northern Trust, the 17th-largest money manager in the United States, with $159 billion in assets, gains ANB's expertise in index fund investing as well as $28 billion in assets the company has under management. Northern Trust, based in Chicago, has offices in eight states, Canada, Britain and Asia. It has $26 billion in total assets and administers $898 billion in trust assets. Shares of First Chicago NBD, which is also based in Chicago, rose $1, to $78.5625, while Northern Trust fell 50 cents, to $60.75.

title: Physicists Take Philosophes to Task in Paris Book
description: In the country that invented Cartesian logic, the philosopher is king. So Alan Sokal, professor of physics at New York University, and Jean Bricmont, a colleague at the University of Louvain in Belgium, may be in big trouble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOBGOOD, ADELE (BANK)
description: HOBGOOD-Adele (Bank), of Whitinsville, MA, formerly of Huntington, New York, died Friday, Oct. 3. Loving family, husband Hobby, son John, daughter-in-law Debbie, grandsons, Adam and Andrew, daughter Sherry, son-in-law, Dean, grandsons, Marshall and Corey. Burial Monday in V.A. Bourne National Cemetery. Memorials to United Presbyterian Church, 7 Spring Street, Whitinsville, MA 01588 or to Plainview L.I. Reformed Church, 560 Old Beth Page Road, Plainview, New York 11803. www.bumafuneralhome.com

title: On the Road and the Stage With Grunge's Baggy Forefather
description: ''The Neil Young universe,'' as one fan in ''Year of the Horse'' fondly describes it, is not the place where most aging rock stars dwell. It's not a place of slick concerts, fancy outfits or image control. It's not a place for living legends. It's not even a place for what Poncho Sampedro, a member of Mr. Young's veteran band Crazy Horse, pointedly denigrates as a hip New York filmmaker type, although it happens to suit Jim Jarmusch just fine. Mr. Jarmusch, who fits right into Mr. Young's world of defiant artistic purity and try-anything abandon, has made this a rip-snorting concert documentary that the faithful are sure to love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLAUT, LOUIS B.
description: PLAUT-Louis B., of Garden City South, NY, on September 27, 1997. English professor at St. John's University, Jamaica, NY, for 43 years. Beloved husband of Lee. Dear father of Louise Rafferty, Marguerite Frank, Gerald and Daniel. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Memorial Mass on Saturday, October 11th, 12:30PM, at St. Thomas the Apostle R.C. Church, West Hempstead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARRABEE, DOERMANN, ELEA NOR
description: LARRABEE - DOERMANN - Elea nor, AIA. The members of the American Institute of Architects New York Chapter, mourn the death of our colleague Eleanor Doermann Larrabee. A member of the AIA New York Chapter Architecture Dialogue Committee. She was devoted to the well being of the community and its architecture. A graduate of Radcliffe College and Columbia University, a Trustee of Barnard College, a member of the Alliance of Women in Architecture, she had an abiding concern for knowledge and education, which was manifest in her distinguished work for more than four decades as an architect, and leader in the planning and design of libraries for colleges and universities. One of her libraries was hailed as ''a national model of urban community colleges preparing its non traditional student body for the cultural and economic mainstream.'' Robert Geddes, FAIA, President Carol Clark, Executive Director The AIA New York Chapter

title: Dyno of Norway Raises Offer for Krems Chemie
description: Dyno Industrier A.S.A., a Norwegian explosives and chemicals producer, said yesterday that it had raised its bid to buy the Austrian chemicals company Krems Chemie A.G. to 720 schillings, or $57.80, a share from the offer of 650 schillings, or $52.18, that it made on Monday. Dyno already holds more than a 10 percent stake in Krems Chemie.

title: Al Collins, 78, the Disk Jockey Of the Purple Grotto on Radio
description: Al (Jazzbo) Collins, a disk jockey and television host who broadcast his favorite music from the imaginary Purple Grotto, died on Tuesday. He was 78 and lived in Mill Valley, Calif.

title: With Brown Ready to Play, Giants Focus on Sanders
description: Dave Brown practiced today, threw dozens of passes and promised he would play Sunday against the Dallas Cowboys. Coach Jim Fassel delivered a similar assessment of his quarterback's availability. So the Giants moved on to a more pressing problem: what to do when Deion Sanders returns a punt.

title: COMCAST AGREES TO BUY SYSTEMS FROM JONES INTERCABLE
description: The Comcast Corporation said yesterday that its partnership had agreed to purchase cable systems in Broward County, Fla., for $140 million in cash from a Jones Intercable Inc. partnership. The systems to be acquired serve parts of Broward County, including the cities of Davie, Cooper City, Dania and Lauderdale Lakes. Comcast said the acquisition is expected to close in the first quarter of 1998 and will be made through its MHCP Holdings L.L.C. unit. The Philadelphia-based Comcast owns 55 percent of MHCP Holdings, an entity formed in 1994 with the California Public Employees' Retirement System to acquire the former United States cable operations of Maclean Hunter Ltd.

title: Modernizing the F.D.A. Wouldn't Cripple It
description: To the Editor:

title: Australian Concern To Sell Its Spice Unit
description: Burns, Philp & Company agreed yesterday to sell its money-losing herb and spice business in the United States and Europe to a group of managers at its plant in Ankeny, Iowa, for a lower-than-expected $171 million. Burns, Philp, which is based in Sydney, Australia, decided in May to sell its herb and spice units, which make Durkee-French, Spice Islands and Tone's brands, to help stem its declining profit and stock price.

title: Giuliani Has A Wide Lead At the Bank
description: Building a war chest for the final weeks before the election, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign reported yesterday that its fund-raising efforts had been so successful that it had nearly three times as much money as the campaign of his Democratic opponent, Ruth W. Messinger.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; No Curfew for Hindu Festival
description: The organizers of a traditional all-night Hindu festival, Navratri, said they were not being forced to shut down at midnight, thanks to a ruling issued yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit.

title: Isles See a Future in Their Shooting
description: If there was one area of concern more pressing than any other for the Islanders coming into this season, it was the lack of offensive potency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACE, WILLIAM M.
description: PACE-William M., of Chester, Connecticut, died October 2. Born in Yonkers he graduated from Syracuse University and worked for Time Magazine and United Technology, and Bill Pace Assoc Inc. Contributions to The Company of Fifers & Drummers Inc., P.O. Box 525 Ivoryton, CT. 06442.

title: Vancouver Journal; Over the Airwaves: All-Whale Radio
description: They are eerie, mysterious sounds clicks and howls and forlorn whistles that seem to come from deep in a primordial past linking the killer whales that make the calls to the people who, with modern tools, can now listen to them.

title: Inherited English Talent
description: Martin Carthy, a prime mover in England's folk revival of the 1960's, married into a musical family. Norma Waterson, his wife, sang with her siblings in the Watersons, a group that performed traditional ballads and maintained a rural tradition of richly harmonized a cappella singing. She was part of the family's third generation of musicians, and now there's a fourth: Eliza Carthy, their 22-year-old daughter, who is a first-rate fiddler and singer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, PEARL SCHWEIGER
description: SILVERMAN-Pearl Schweiger. Beloved wife of Julian and the late Milton. Devoted mother of Maxine Rosenberg, Marjie Ginsburg and Bonnie Crane; and step-mother of Arthur, Lewis and Bruce Silverman. Also survived by eight grandchildren. Loving sister of Dorothy Braverman and Milton Skolnik. Services, Sunday, 10:30 a.m. at I.J. Morris Inc., 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, L.I.

title: INSIDE
description: Job Growth Is Modest

title: Tropical Forests Are Ravaged by Free Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Cooke Estate to Sell Los Angeles Paper
description: The estate of Jack Kent Cooke, the late owner of the Washington Redskins football team, has put The Daily News of Los Angeles up for sale.

title: Microsoft Browser Heavily Downloaded
description: The Microsoft Corporation said today that more than one million users had downloaded its Internet Explorer 4.0 browser in the first 48 hours, threatening to erode the Netscape Communications Corporation's leading market share.

title: McCaughey Ross Plans To Appear With Gore
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross, the newly minted Democrat, said yesterday that she would attend a fund-raiser starring Vice President Al Gore next week in New York City.

title: Earthquake Damage in Italy Strikes at Its Cultural Heart
description: After the initial earthquake on Sept. 26 rocked the Umbrian hill town of Montefalco in the middle of the night, Luigi Gambacurta, the Mayor and a geography teacher there, awoke and checked to make sure the schools were safe. Then with an engineer he headed for the local museum to check its precious Renaissance frescoes by Perugino and Benozzo Gozzoli.

title: At Stake, Title Shot And 2 Reputations
description: Lennox Lewis is looking to polish his lackluster reputation, and Andrew Golota is looking to shed his tarnished one. But those are not the only things that will be at stake when Lewis, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, steps into the ring against Golota tonight at the Atlantic City Convention Center.

title: RENO, IN LETTER TO CONGRESS, REJECTS MOST ALLEGATIONS THAT CLINTON VIOLATED LAW
description: Sweeping away dozens of allegations from Republicans of campaign finance abuses by President Clinton, Attorney General Janet Reno today absolved Mr. Clinton of most of them, saying she had found no evidence so far that he misused his office to raise money, improperly allowed contributors to stay overnight at the White House or sought contributions in exchange for political favors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEAGAN, CHARLES, M.D.
description: BEAGAN-Charles, M.D. died on October 2, 1997. Beloved father of Patrick and Susan. Mourned by Evelyn Beagan and Nina Smith. Service will be on Sunday, October 5, at Jacobsen F.H., Huntington, LI. Mass on Monday, October 6, at 10:15AM, St. Hugh Of Lincoln Roman Catholic Church, Huntington. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the V.N.S. Hospice, Suffolk County.

title: LaFontaine Returns With a Goal as Rangers Tie Islanders
description: After all the concussions and all the debate about his right to play this dangerous game, Pat LaFontaine returned to the National Hockey League last night and scored an important goal for the Rangers on opening night at Madison Square Garden. After being sidelined for almost a year, LaFontaine won a key face-off in the third period and scored on a power play to give his new team a 2-2 tie with the Islanders.

title: Eight Nikko Executives Resign Over Scandal
description: The chairman, president and six other executives of the Nikko Securities Company resigned yesterday to apologize for payoffs to a gangster in a scandal that has already seen top executives from the rest of Japan's Big Four brokerage firms resign. The brokerage firms are said to have paid millions of dollars in hush money to the racketeer Ryuichi Koike.

title: Alternative Sentencing
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Fitted for Hearing Aids After Tests in Annual Physical
description: President Clinton was fitted for small hearing aids in both ears today after tests confirmed that he had moderate loss of high-frequency hearing. Mr. Clinton has complained privately for several years that he has difficulty hearing in crowded rooms and at noisy rallies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRISKIE, JULIUS
description: BRISKIE-Julius on October 2, 1997. Beloved husband of Bess for 59+ years. Loving father of Jane Sylvester of Portland, Oregon. Devoted father-in-law of Robert Sylvester. Adoring grandfather of Jonas Sylvester. Caring brother of Celia Epstein. Dear uncle of Lenore, Howard, Stephen, Jane and Gary Spitalny, Peter, Lewis, Judy, Elin, Napo and Vera Goldman, and Joyce Briskie. Service on Sunday 9:30 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Poisonous Mold Shuts a Renovated Library on Staten Island
description: The storybook renovation of the charming Tottenville Library was supposed to have a happier ending.

title: An Intimate Glimpse Of Hope and Despair In a Housing Project
description: ''Public Housing,'' the latest landmark documentary from Frederick Wiseman, sustains Mr. Wiseman's clear-eyed objectivity, a simple but uncanny means of immersing an audience in the world that the camera studies. But in his anatomy of the Ida B. Wells housing project on Chicago's South Side, Mr. Wiseman allows himself one faint bit of editorializing. Several times during the course of this monumental 3-hour-and-20-minute community portrait, Mr. Wiseman lets the viewer notice an ice cream truck that cruises this grim neighborhood and listen as it tootles absurdly cheery nursery songs (e.g. ''Pop Goes the Weasel''). For the 5,000 residents of Ida B. Wells, how can this mean anything but a false promise or a cruel joke?

title: Frederick Haas, 85, Ex-Counsel at Liggett
description: Frederick P. Haas, a lawyer who became general counsel for the Liggett Group, died after a long illness last Sunday at the Watrous Health Center in Madison, Conn. He was 85.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERMAN, ROBERT
description: FERMAN-Robert. A wonderful man of wisdom, courage and love, adored by his wife, Bernice, his children, Pam and Seth, and the rest of his family, including Miriam, Selma, Harold, and so many other family and friends. Everyone who knew Bob loved him. He was genuine, caring and passionate about everything-his family, his friends, his work, his life. People where drawn to Bob, and often surprised by his intense interest in their lives, whether he knew them for seven seconds or seven decades. Class, religion, race, were just words to him when it came to people. Each person was moved by him, impressed by him, and better for having met him. He grew up poor, during the depression, but crafted a life built on integrity, commitment and kindness. He loved his work, from his little theater in The Bronx to successful, multi-theater company. He was respected both for his great success in business and his high moral ethic. Above all, he lived for and devoted his energies to his family. He took care of everybody. In the last ten years, he and Bernice proved to be an even greater inspiration to those around them, facing an increasingly debilitating illness with courage and grace. They both remained optomistic during the worst of times. His strength, her devotion, their love, went beyond our imagining. You always wanted us to be happy, and we will try. But in this moment, and every moment hereafter, we will miss you desperately. Services will be 12:30 PM Sunday at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, NY

title: Tropical Forests Are Ravaged by Free Trade; Indonesia's Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Accused In Smuggling Of Chinese Is Extradited
description: Nearly two years after he was captured in Thailand, the man accused of masterminding the smuggling of hundreds of Chinese immigrants aboard the Golden Venture in 1993 has been ordered extradited to the United States, Federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Making a Dry Report More Interesting
description: Edward S. Seeley Jr.'s 49-page report on New York City's economy and transportation system might easily have suffered the fate of so many technical planning studies that emerge from city government -- the ignominy of being unread. The report says that New York's economy is expected to produce more jobs over the next 25 years than its transit system can handle, and that major investments must be made now to capture the potential growth. Planners and economists would find that predicament fascinating.

title: Tomkins Buys Maker Of Consumer Products
description: Tomkins P.L.C., the British manufacturing conglomerate, said yesterday that it had acquired Golden West Foods, a bakery and liquid products maker, for $:70.5 million, or $114 million, including assumed debt. Tomkins makes products ranging from baked goods to handguns. Tomkins's liquid-products plant in Britain makes syrups and ketchup for distribution in Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALIN, ANNA
description: PALIN-Anna, on October, 2, 1997, age 87. Devoted wife of the late Louis. Loving mother of Michael (Caryl) and Carole Sehres (Mort). Devoted grandmother of Jill, Stacey, Dorothy, Andrea and Dean. Loving great-grandmother of ten. Devoted sister of Jules and Sol. Funeral services Sunday, October 5th, 10am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Old Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Liberties; Promises, Promises, Promises
description: I'm still working out the math from the last time a horde of guys descended on the Mall and prayed to be more manly men.

title: The Tooth Fairy, Played With a Lot of Lip
description: Kirstie Alley can do no wrong these days. In the midst of a lackluster new television season, she is at the center of ''Veronica's Closet,'' one of the few sure hits. Beyond that, she can even make you believe that a two-hour television movie about the tooth fairy isn't such a lousy idea after all.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Monday and Tuesday about a French energy company's decision to go ahead with a deal with Iran misstated the maximum amount of investment in Iran that is permitted under American legislation restricting commercial investment there. The ceiling is $20 million, not $40 million.

title: No Vows by Knicks, Except to Work
description: Patrick Ewing was fumbling with the earpiece for his portable disk player, trying to keep it in. It was no use. Now he was forced to listen to the questions that followed him as he covered the length of a hallway in long, loping strides today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REINER, JULES
description: REINER-Jules. Caring husband of Norma for fifty-five years. Beloved father of Charles, Elizabeth, Nanette and Barry. ''Head of the herd'' of nine grandchildren. Passed away the evening of October 1, 1997. He was 81. Services at 9 A.M., Sunday, Temple Anshe Amunim, Pittsfield, MA. Interment 1 P.M., Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, N.Y. Any contributions to the usher-sponsored Harry Steadman Scholarship Fund of Tanglewood, Lenox, MA. 01240.

title: Image-Conscious N.B.A. Suspends Iverson and Rider
description: After a summer of disturbing events involving National Basketball Association players, Commissioner David Stern yesterday suspended Philadelphia's Allen Iverson for one game and Portland's Isaiah Rider for two games for behavior detrimental to the game.

title: Chief of AIDS Study Effort Plans Return To Lab Post
description: Dr. William E. Paul, the director of the Federal AIDS research effort for almost four years, said today that he would leave that job to return to laboratory research.

title: Van Horn's Purpose? Shoot, Shoot, Shoot
description: Midway through the second session of the Nets' first official practice of the season, John Calipari blew his whistle, signaling a stop right in the middle of a set of full-court drills.

title: Prosecutors Raid Accused Landlord's Buildings for Records
description: Prosecutors raided a number of Lower East Side buildings yesterday, seizing financial records and other information as they tried to unravel what they believed was the landlord's extensive criminal enterprise -- a complex web of illegality that they say included tenant harassment, contracts with drug dealers and even a murder plot.

title: Battle Loomed in Fight Over Toy-Candy Item
description: When Nestle USA announced this week that it was pulling from shelves a product called ''Nestle Magic'' in the face of complaints that it was dangerous for children, a coalition of food safety advocates and their lobbyists claimed victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGETT, CHARLES
description: MARGETT-Charles, The Honorable. Retired Justice of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court. Beloved husband and friend of Doris Rosen. Stepfather of Sanford Rosen. Dear uncle of Ronald and Monte Posner, and cherished granduncle. Services Monday, 1:00PM, at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR.

title: 2 Boys Are Charged With Rape and Sodomy
description: Two boys, ages 11 and 12, were arrested and charged yesterday with raping and sodomizing a 10-year-old girl in Queens, the police said.

title: Tropical Forests Are Ravaged by Free Trade; Labels Won't Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DROPKIN, LOU
description: DROPKIN-Lou, 82, of South Nyack. Survived by wife Gus and daughter Alane. Memorial service October 18, 2 P.M., Unitarian Church, Pomona, NY. 914-354-1789

title: Love, Bouncing Back, Shares the Buick Lead
description: Buick Challenge

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHALFIN, MORRIS
description: CHALFIN-Morris. Today is your birthday. Your memory will live in our hearts and minds forever. Your children and grandchildren

title: Aggressive Justice System in Jacksonville, Fla., Intervenes to Ward Off Juvenile Crime
description: After hitting a young girl in the head with a brick, 7-year-old Freddie would have had a predictable fate in most cities.

title: One Who Dares to Reveal A Tuba's Discreet Charms
description: A tuba, when used effectively in a Wagner opera, a Stravinsky ballet score or a Shostakovich symphony, can be glorious. But let's face it: the tuba as a solo recital instrument is funny.

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS REPURCHASE OFFER FALLS SHORT
description: Tele-Communications Inc. said yesterday that 12.2 million shares of its Liberty Media programming unit were tendered before its offer to buy the stock expired on Thursday, short of its goal. Tele-Communications had hoped to buy 15 million class A and class B shares for $30 each. Tele-Communications, which is based in Englewood, Colo., had a hard time attracting more shares because the value of its cable programming holdings keeps rising, analysts said. Liberty holds stakes in several cable channels, including the Discovery Channel, QVC Inc. and HSN Inc. Tele-Communications first offered $27 for 10 million Liberty shares with a deadline of Sept. 17. The company later raised the offer to $30.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Thursday about La Bodega de la Familia, a crisis center for families of drug abusers in Manhattan, misstated the role of the Vera Institute of Justice. The institute designed and operates the program, but does not finance it.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Philosophy as Red-Hot Adventure In 12th-Century Spain and France
description: Had Cecil B. DeMille larded musical comedy numbers into one of his quasi-religious epics, the movie might well have resembled ''Destiny,'' the Egyptian filmmaker Youssef Chanine's rip-roaring entertainment about the struggle for survival of free speech, literacy and rationalism in 12th-century Spain. The hero of this bluntly pointed allegory, tricked out with some wildly impassioned Gypsy songs and dances, is the great Spanish-Arabian philosopher Averroes (Nour el-Cherif), who shocked his contemporaries by insisting that reason and faith need not be incompatible. Averroes's philosophy drew intense fire from both Christian and Muslim zealots. And ''Destiny'' turns his struggle against fanatic oppressors into a hot-blooded romantic adventure acted by a glamorous cast in a flamboyant if slightly tongue-in-cheek Hollywood biblical style.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENSTEIN, ROY
description: LICHTENSTEIN-Roy. The staff and trustees of the Whitney Museum of American Art are deeply saddened by the loss of Roy Lichtenstein, truly an American innovator. His brilliance as an artist and commentator captured the essence of American culture during some of its most complex times. We are proud to have supported him as an artist and to have counted him as a friend of the museum. Flora M. Biddle, Hon. Chairman Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Gilbert C. Maurer, President David A. Ross, Director

title: Bones to the Highest Bidder
description: Today's auction at Sotheby's of a near-perfect fossil of a tyrannosaur named Sue was bound to happen now that dinosaurs have become objects of consuming popular interest. Markets come into being for things that people want, and the market for dinosaur bones is no exception. But this sale raises some troubling issues for the future of fossil hunting and of scientific research.

title: Devils Look Sharp, Despite Late Slip
description: Jacques Lemaire was in a good mood tonight until someone told him he had coached his 200th National Hockey League victory.

title: Air Force Orders Inspections Of All F-117 Stealth Fighters
description: The Air Force announced today that it had ordered the inspection of all F-117 stealth fighters after discovering that a ''significant defect'' in a wing support might have contributed to the crash of one last month at an air show near Baltimore.

title: Beliefs
description: Mark Lombard uses a football metaphor to describe his role at the huge Promise Keepers assembly in Washington today, which is only fitting for a religious ministry founded by a football coach and doing much of its work in stadiums.

title: A Bit of Evangelical Evasion
description: A few weeks ago, I decided to experience the Promise Keepers' ''Stand in the Gap'' rally, which will be held today in Washington. I wanted to stand shoulder to shoulder with these ''weekend weepers.'' I sent in a registration form under my own name, and shortly after got a confirmation, addressed to me in my own name, with the salutation ''Dear Brother in Christ.''

title: Modernizing the F.D.A. Wouldn't Cripple It
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Wearing a 'C,' Bearing The Pressure
description: THERE'S nothing like the blossoming of a new season to inspire high hopes. The Mets and Yankees savor April before it gives way to summer and fall. The Jets and Giants enjoy late summer before time gives way to autumn and the harsh realities of winter.

title: FIRMS ACQUIRE KINETIC CONCEPTS STAKES
description: Kinetic Concepts Inc., a maker of therapeutic beds, agreed yesterday to sell most of the company to two San Francisco investment firms for as much as $875 million. The agreement calls for Richard C. Blum & Associates L.P. and Fremont Partners L.P. to pay $19.25 a share. The stock rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $19. Under terms of the agreement, Fremont will own 40 percent of the company and Blum 26.5 percent. The firms will acquire the shares from James R. Leininger, Kinetic's founder and chairman and its largest shareholder, and outside investors. After the deal, Mr. Leininger will own 33.5 percent of the company, down from 43 percent. Kinetic Concepts, which is based in San Antonio, makes and rents beds used for patients who are paralyzed or severely burned or suffer from serious illnesses.

title: Party Officials Orchestrated White House Sleepovers
description: Top Democratic Party finance officials specifically arranged overnight stays in the Lincoln Bedroom for at least 20 wealthy donors to reward them for their large contributions or to encourage their generosity, according to documents and interviews that reveal new details about White House sleepovers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Auto Makers Offering Rebates as Sales Slump

title: Times Co. Makes Deal to Sell 6 Magazines
description: Miller Publishing Group L.L.C. has entered into an agreement with The New York Times Company to acquire its tennis, sailing and ski magazines. The terms of the deal, announced yesterday, were not disclosed.

title: Driver's Health Unknown In Bus's Fatal Rampage
description: Investigators said they were still perplexed yesterday over what caused a city bus driver to lose control of his bus on Fifth Avenue on Thursday, sending it bounding wildly down midtown Manhattan, killing a pedestrian and critically injuring a bicyclist.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GAINES, SOLLY
description: GAINES-Solly. Truly a one-in-amillion man on Sept. 18, 1996. He is remembered with great affection by a myriad of friends and former colleagues from more than 50 years including the Weinsteins, the Habers, the Berkowitz's, the Kretchmers, and Artie Reichel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MIHAI, EUGEN, FR.
description: MIHAI-Eugen, Fr., 84, of St. Mary's Romanian Byzantine Rite Catholic Mission, Astoria, New York. A veteran of W.W. II and 12 years of communist prisons, at age 75 he risked jail by returning to Romania to be ordained, May 18, 1988 in the still banned church. He served well, was loved by all and will be missed.

title: '97 BASEBALL PLAYOFFS
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: A Tearful Cone Exits Stage as Gooden Re-enters
description: David Cone's voice cracked as he discussed the emotions he has wrestled with for the last six weeks while trying to overcome the pain in his right shoulder and pitch for the Yankees. Cone sometimes sounded as if he was giving a personal eulogy about his trying season after the Yankees announced today that Dwight Gooden would replace him for Game 4 of the division series on Sunday night.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DUKE REALTY INVESTMENTS INC., Indianapolis, a real estate investment trust, spent $90.4 million to acquire two properties and develop six others.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINSTEIN, AARON
description: WEINSTEIN-Aaron. on October 2, 1997. Beloved husband and best friend of Ruth for 60 years. Loving father of Robert (Lois) and Michael. Adoring grandfather of Cheryl, Leslie and Eric. Retired principal of PS 47X. Graveside services Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, New Jersey, Monday, October 6.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNER, PAULINE STEINLAUF
description: TANNER-Pauline Steinlauf, after a long illness, cherished wife of the late Irving; loved by children Ben and Ellen Tanner Farkas, and Nicki and Harold Tanner; and grandchildren Esta and Paul Farkas, Gary and Lynn Farkas Schwartz, Peggy and David Tanner; Catherine Allegra and James Tanner, Kent and Karen Tanner Allen; and proud great-grandmother of 11. Her intelligence, love of, and loyalty to, family strengthened and enhanced our lives. Expressions of remembrance may be made to the Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem or to the Pauline and Irving Tanner Scholarship Fund at Cornell University. Funeral services will be Sunday, October 5, at 1:00 PM at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, RUTH STOLZ
description: LAZAR-Ruth Stolz. Cherished wife of the late Dr Alfred E. Lazar, beloved mother of Laura (Stephen) Siegel, Kenneth S. (Valerie) Lazar and Fran (Dr. Jeffrey) Ashkin; adored grandmother of Shari, Jonathan (Majorie), and David Siegel, Emily and Michael Lazar, Eric, Hillary and Adrienne Ashkin; dear sister of Samuel Stolz and Barbara Roth, and the late Irving H. Stolz, Fannie Wander and Rachael Murrey. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY, 12 noon, Sunday.

title: Libya Is Said to Evade Sanctions By Buying U.S. Goods in Europe
description: In order to evade economic sanctions imposed by Washington, Libya is buying American-made goods through front companies in Britain and other NATO countries, according to interviews with American and European officials, court records and other public documents.

title: Jerome H. Lemelson, an Inventor, Dies at 74
description: Jerome H. Lemelson, a prolific inventor who became a hero to fellow inventors when he dared to force giant corporations to pay him for his ideas, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 74 and lived outside Lake Tahoe, Nev.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the On Stage and Off column on Sept. 26 about plans for a Broadway revival of ''The Sound of Music'' misstated Julie Andrews's Academy Award record for her role in the film version. She was nominated for best actress but did not win an Oscar in 1965.

title: Markets Soar, Then Plunge, On Their Way To Slight Gains
description: For those not watching yesterday, nothing much happened in the bond and stock markets as prices ended a little higher.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: STORM OVER A STUDY

title: Big Opening Is at Risk In Chicago
description: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra is to christen Symphony Center, its new $110 million home overlooking Grant Park here, with a gala performance on Saturday night, but a labor dispute has left in doubt whether it will play at all. With the baton of Daniel Barenboim virtually poised in the air, the musicians and the orchestra management continue to wrangle over a new three-year contract.

title: FOOTBALL: ROUNDUP
description: S. Connecticut 39, Pace 20

title: CAMERON ASHLEY IN $142.5 MILLION DEAL FOR BRADCO
description: Cameron Ashley Building Products Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Bradco Supply Corporation for about $142.5 million, to expand its commercial roofing sales and reach into new markets. The Dallas-based Cameron Ashley will pay about $25.9 million in cash, issue 1.85 million new shares and assume about $80 million in long-term debt for Bradco, an Avenel, N.J., distributor of roofing and exterior building products that had $468 million in sales in the latest year. The combined company will have sales of about $1.3 billion, Cameron said. The closely held Bradco operates 56 branches in 14 states. Cameron Ashley's shares rose $1.5625, to $19.8125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASKENAS, WARREN
description: ASKENAS-Warren, 63, on September 30, 1997. Husband of Merle. Beloved father of Mitchell and Wendy, and Caren and Gary Cohen. Big Bacca and Grandpa to Lyndsey, Brenna and Robby. Dear brother of Irma and Harold Goshin. You were taken away from us so suddenly, and you will be missed terribly. Funeral services to be held Sun., Oct. 5, 9:45AM, at Sinai Chapels, 718-445-0300.

title: Several Are Hurt as a Car Plunges and Hits a Train
description: A car collided with another car yesterday in Mount Vernon, N.Y., then plunged down a 19-foot railroad embankment and slammed into a moving commuter train, said officials of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad. Windows on the train shattered. Three children and one adult on the train suffered minor injuries and were treated at the scene, Dan Brucker, a Metro-North spokesman, said.

title: Clinton Hones Sales Pitch On Global Warming Pact
description: As it seeks a new treaty to fight the threat of global warming, the Clinton Administration has turned marketing on its head: first comes the sales pitch, and later the product will be unveiled.

title: Gore Changes His Location And Themes in New Approach
description: On what had the makings of a particularly gloomy day in his political career, Vice President Al Gore flew today to sunny Florida for a full schedule of official events and insisted that he was unfazed by Attorney General Janet Reno's decision to expand the Justice Department's inquiry into his fund-raising practices.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Bus Service to Be Expanded
description: Responding to a rising demand for bus service in the southern part of the state, New Jersey Transit said yesterday that it would increase service on major north-south roads and give permanent status to several routes across Gloucester County that have been operating on a trial basis for three years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MINNIE, NEE TRACHTENBERG
description: COHEN-Minnie, nee Trachtenberg. Beloved mother, grandmother, great grandmother died October 3, 1997. Survived by her children Jack, Lawrence and Arthur Cohen and Roslyn Blumberg. Service will be held Sunday, October 5, 10:45AM at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island. Burial Ellenville, New York.

title: Barclays to Curtail Investment Banking, Ending Global Ambitions
description: Ending ambitions to build a global investment bank, Barclays P.L.C. said today that it would sell the least profitable parts of its BZW subsidiary and concentrate on the corporate banking and treasury businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LU, MEI, CHIH CHEN
description: LU-Mei-Chih Chen, 71, on Sept. 24, 1997. Formerly of Tainan, Taiwan. Beloved wife of Teng-Yi. Loving mother of Susan, Nan-Shiang, Lung-Yueh, Ching-Lien, Sonia and Daniel. Beloved grandmother of Celia, Tricia Huei-Yi, Baldwin, Chien-Chang, Chien-Chih, Po-Tsun, Steven, Henry, Xue-Yuan. Service October 4, 10 AM at the Bowne St., Taiwanese Church in Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: It's a Far Cry From New York
description: Even since William P. Bratton, New York's former Police Commissioner, visited Germany this summer to preach a gospel of zero tolerance toward crime, the German authorities have been publicly and divisively pondering a question: will what is called the New York model of combating crime work in Germany's big cities?

title: ROUNDUP
description: St. John's Loses

title: Advertising vs. Editorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Smith Barney Executive Charged
description: Robert B. Maloney, a former regional director of Smith Barney Inc., was charged today with Federal election fraud. The Government said he had funneled $39,000 through co-workers to his brother's Congressional campaign.

title: Leaks at Plant Not a Threat, Testing Shows
description: Fuel leaks at the Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant did not result in dangerous radioactive contamination outside the grounds of the plant and appear to pose no immediate public health threat, according to test results released today by state environmental officials.

title: Corrections
description: The Collecting article on the Automobile page on Sept. 26, about rare cars displayed at the Louis Vuitton Classic in Rockefeller Center, misidentified the only race driver to win world championships for both cars and motorcycles. He is John Surtees, not Stirling Moss.

title: YROUNDUP
description: Swiss Indoors

title: J. C. Cabrera, 62, Search Firm Executive
description: James C. Cabrera, vice chairman of the executive search firm Drake Beam Morin Inc., died Tuesday at Greenwich Hospital in Greenwich, Conn. He was 62 years old.

title: John Stichnoth, 74, Top Counsel To Union Carbide During Crisis
description: John A. Stichnoth, a former vice president and general counsel of the Union Carbide Corporation who helped devise the company's legal strategy following the world's worst industrial disaster in Bhopal, India, died on Wednesday at Danbury Hospital, near his summer home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 74 and also lived in North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Shepherdstown Journal; 18th-Century Town, 20th-Century Ill
description: Imagine horses instead of cars, and it might be fairly well impossible to know that the year is 1997, not 1797.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The damage in the basilica in Assisi is terrible, of course, but we must not forget that the earthquakes have struck a large zone with lesser buildings and art that altogether characterize the region. To lose them is to lose the region's character.''

title: DIVISION SERIES PLAYOFFS; Wild-Card Marlins Advance to the Next Level
description: For the wild card, it was a wild night and a trip into the National League Championship Series.

title: Wavering on War Crimes

We were well taken care of and lacked only sleep. The welcome we received in the towns will always be with us.

But as much as the service has become part of life's glorious fabric in many parts of America, it has been a resounding failure here in Britain.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Feats of Clay
description: Above the heads of New York City dwellers lies a mythic realm peopled by pensive gargoyles, mossbacked mermen, dashing Mercurys and enough animal characters -- foxes, flying fish, sea horses and salamanders -- to populate a Japanese folk tale. Susan Tunick's TERRA-COTTA SKYLINE: New York's Architectural Ornament (Princeton Architectural Press, $45) is a first-rate Baedeker to the astonishing variety of terra cotta decoration in the city. Terra cotta (literally ''burnt earth'') is kiln-baked clay, a light, economical architectural material capable of holding high definition and rainbow hues. The rise of the terra cotta industry and the New York skyscraper are inseparable: the facade of Daniel Burnham's Flatiron Building of 1901-3 featured richly modeled masks of Greek women, and Cass Gilbert's Woolworth Building of 1910-13 was clad in cream-colored terra cotta in a flamboyant Gothic style. The use of terra cotta reached its acme in 1930-31 with the sea-colored McGraw-Hill Building (now badly chipping); fell into a serious slump with post-World War II glass and steel buildings, and is now making a small return with the restoration of such clay classics as City Center. Some technical chapters on how terra cotta is actually produced may make the average reader's eyes glaze over, but the enthusiasm of Tunick -- who is also president of the Friends of Terra Cotta, a preservation society -- for her subject is contagious. Peter Mauss's photographs are breathtaking. Eric P. Nash

title: RECORDINGS VIEW; A Brahms Tradition Lives in Remnants
description: IN MUSIC COMPOSED NEAR the dawn of recorded sound, the search for an ''authentic'' style of performance often yields surprising results. We have been reminded, for example, that interpretations of Mahler symphonies by conductors early in this century, which sound strangely unlike current versions, may well be closer to the composer's ideas.

title: With Popularity, Comes An Upswing in Music

Just 1997 musical business as usual? Yes, except that all of those events also occurred in 1977, when the Westchester Weekly was started.

title: Learning To Live With the Guns

title: A Strategy Clicks, So Far

O'Shaughnessy, the author of ''What Works on Wall Street,'' the fund has shot up 29 percent, placing fifth among all diversified domestic equity funds in the last three months, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago fund trackers.

title: When E-Mail Strikes the Wrong Target

Maybe E-mail, like pistols and rifles, should come equipped with a safety catch so that no one blasts off a message without indulging in what the lawyers like to call forethought. Misdirected messages, as the anecdotes that follow make clear, can be dangerous. But while the words of the unwise often cause mischief, they are sometimes the stuff of love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTESMAN, ESTHER
description: GOTTESMAN-Esther. The leadership and staff of UJA-Federation mourn the passing of Esther Gottesman of New York and Palm Beach, a dedicated and fervent supporter of Israel and the Jewish community through her lifelong involvement with Hadassah and a multitude of Jewish educational institutions, including the Board of Jewish Education in New York and Palm Beach. She actively supported the creation of the Jewish state, and played a major role in acquiring the Dead Sea Scrolls in Jerusalem. Our deepest sympathies go to her beloved son, David Gottesman (Sandy), who has so effectively emulated his family's humanitarian concern through his extraordinary philanthropy, dedication and leadership on behalf of UJA-Federation, Yeshiva University and many communal organizations nationwide. We extend our sincerest condolences to the entire Gottesman family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: A Folk Art Menagerie Of Carnival Castoffs
description: BRASS-BAND MUSIC, THE sound of laughter and, best of all, those sturdy, fancifully colored creatures gently bobbing up and down: in the pre-plastics age, they were the carousel, a whirligig of joy whose art could be said to constitute its own heady ride. For years, fairground art was used, if at all, to decorate restaurants that got a kitschy kick out of brightly colored horses and centaurs propping up the bar, or maybe a barrel piano alongside the inevitable period jukebox.

title: Alaskan Brews
description: To the Editor: My husband and I enjoyed Susan Spano's article ''A Five-Day Jaunt in Juneau'' (Frugal Traveler, Sept. 7); we spent two weeks there in June. We had a wonderful time -- lots of great hikes, a four-night trip to Glacier Bay. We, too, learned sea kayaking. But we were disappointed that Ms. Spano bought Foster's Lager for her kayak trip when she was right there in the town where Alaskan Beer is brewed. In the local bars and restaurants, we sampled all of their varieties, and even managed to track down the last remaining bottles of a seasonal brew called Smoked Porter. Alaskan Beer is available only in Alaska and a few Western states where it can be shipped directly, so it is a treat to be enjoyed whenever possible.

title: An Upstart Roils the Phone Industry
description: The proposed takeover of MCI Communications, which controls about 20 percent of the long-distance telephone market, by the upstart Worldcom Inc., which controls only about 5 percent, is more than brazen. The merged company could become the first do-it-all telecommunications company, bringing customers local, long-distance, Internet and, perhaps someday, wireless services. If Worldcom's lead forces AT&T and the regional Bell companies to follow, then the barriers that have kept competition out of local phone markets will finally fall.

title: Michele Forzley, Gordon Bock
description: Michele Diane Forzley, a lawyer practicing in Lynnfield, Mass., was married yesterday to Gordon Honold Bock, the editor of the Old-House Journal, a magazine in Gloucester, Mass. The Rev. Joseph Longofono performed the ceremony at St. George's Antiochean Orthodox Church in Danbury, Conn.

title: Altruism for Fun and Profit
description: As riders in the first Philadelphia to D.C. AIDS Ride in 1996, we were disappointed to read Pallotta's justification for the amount of money his company makes from these events. In comparing his ''business'' to that of Microsoft or Nike, he misses the point. He is not selling a product. To the contrary, he makes money because people like us ask our friends, family, co-workers and even strangers to support the AIDS Ride and to help us raise money for AIDS organizations in our community. People give to participants in these rides in the expectation that most of the money will go to the cause we are asking them to support.

title: It's in the Numbers: Waves of New Faces
description: THE last two decades have brought many changes in Westchester County. But nowhere can they be seen more clearly than in the county's shifting demographics. The most pronounced changes have taken place in the racial and ethnic makeup of Westchester. While the county for the moment remains predominantly white and wealthy, it will not be that way for long.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Opel Omega Sport and Cadillac Catera; Fraternal Twins an Ocean Apart
description: EVER salivate over the delicious variety of unfamiliar cars whizzing by on European highways and wish you could try them out back home? Renault may never send a Twingo your way; Lancia keeps the Dedra at home, and Ford has no plans to import its cute little Ka. But General Motors heard your prayers, rebadging the German-built Opel Omega as the Cadillac Catera -- the one that zigs.

title: Gooden to Face Hershiser With No Time for Nostalgia
description: Dwight Gooden remembers firing the pitch Mike Scioscia ripped for a two-run homer to even the score in Game 4 of the 1988 National League Championship Series between the Mets and Dodgers. The Dodgers eventually won the game and Gooden's shabby pitch helped swing the series in their favor.

title: Why Whisper About It? 'The Life' Is a Joy
description: BROADWAY'S BEST-KEPT secret isn't that ''The Life,'' the Cy Coleman show at the Ethel Barrymore Theater, is the best musical of 1996-97. It was given that not always significant distinction by the Drama Desk, the Outer Critics Circle and the Drama League. Awards don't really tell you much when the competition is feeble or simply nonexistent, as was the case the year that ''Sunset Boulevard'' won its Tony. Such prizes are for use in advertising and promotion and to impress the folks back home.

title: Ho-hum. The Kiss That Didn't Rock the World.
description: THE credits rolled and the houselights went on, but the applause continued even as the ushers began sweeping candy crud from the aisles of the sold-out movie theater. It was Friday night at the Mall of America in suburban Minneapolis, and spilling out from one of two auditoriums showing ''In and Out'' was a cross-section of Middle America: couples on dates, the elderly and teen-agers let loose in America's biggest consumer smorgasbord.

title: State Plans for Route 25 A Meet Opposition
description: THE question of what to do with Route 25A might be a classic case of which came first, the chicken or the egg. Even as preservationists and civic groups accuse the state of trying to turn the road into a main east-west thoroughfare, state officials say all they are trying to do is keep the road safe. As long as municipalities continue to allow development, they say, they have no choice but to straighten, widen, create turn lanes and add lights to the road.

title: Long Island Q&A: Jeffrey Jurick; At the Helm of the Direct Mail Business

title: Maintenance Tips for the Home
description: EVERYONE knows that older homes need regular maintenance. While new homes require considerably less maintenance than older ones, they are still not maintenance-free. If you own a new home, it is important to first inspect the home for potential problems, then begin an annual maintenance schedule to keep your house in top condition.

title: ''And in this Chamber . . . ''
description: Only eight men and women showed up for debate on the floor of the State Assembly. The poor showing was understandable. Just one bill had been posted, and action on the issue would hardly determine anyone's political future. They considered legislation that would mandate a public-education campaign on winter's ''lethal missiles'' -- the hazardous accumulation of snow and ice that can fly from the tops of speeding motor vehicles. After a half hour of give and take, the measure passed and the session was adjourned.

title: Port-Hoppers With Lofty Aspirations
description: TO cruise is not to travel. Travel exhausts, demands, rewards, but the cruise comforts, soothes, nannies you along. It is the choice of the elderly, the fatigued, besotted lovers and hopeful widows. Adventure is not an ingredient. Or so I argued to my husband, Steve, before finally agreeing to a voyage in February on board the Minerva.

title: E. P. Schonfeld, 54, Founder of Group On Kidney Cancer
description: Eugene P. Schonfeld, who founded the National Kidney Cancer Association in 1989 after learning that he had the disease, died on Sept. 25 at his home in Highland Park, Ill., the association said. He was 54.

title: The State Is Ranked No. 2 In Pedestrian Deaths . . .
description: Crossing the street can be hazardous to your health in New Jersey, especially for senior citizens and children. The state has the country's second-highest rate for pedestrian injuries and deaths, following New York, according to a new study.

title: After 9 Long Years, Madrid's Opera House Reopens
description: The reopening of Madrid's opera house, Teatro Real, on Oct. 11 after a nine-year closing, has caused so much excitement that security had to be stepped up to discourage fans desperate for a peek at the completely refurbished and modernized interior. If they can wait, they won't be disappointed. Inaugurated in 1850 during the reign of Isabella II, the 1,750-seat theater, adjacent to the gardens of the Royal Palace, will now combine advanced acoustic and stage technology with its original sumptuous 19th-century character.

title: Home Cooking
description: VINCENZZO AND PERRI URSO are the affable husband-and-wife owners of Enzzo's, a small, come-as-you-are trattoria where you can dine well and inexpensively in affluent Short Hills. The restaurant doesn't have a liquor license, but the outdoor patio and newly opened back room, built and designed by Mr. Urso, are pleasant places in which to enjoy your own wine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERBIN, JEREMY
description: WERBIN-Jeremy. Age 44. Died from diabetes complications in Ithaca, NY, Oct. 2, 1997. Dearly beloved son of Milton and Ann, brother of Karen, brother-in-law of David Eckert and uncle of Aaron and Sari. Burial at New Montefiore Cemetery, Amityville, Sun, Oct 5.

title: Golota Is Hospitalized After Lewis's Knockout
description: Lennox Lewis made quick work of Andrew Golota tonight, retaining his World Boxing Council title when Referee Joe Cortez stopped their fight at 1 minute 35 seconds of the first round. By that time Golota had been knocked down twice.

title: Sept. 28-Oct. 4; Falling Short on Welfare Rules
description: A welfare deadline arrived last week, and fewer than half the states met all the goals. Under last year's landmark law, states were supposed to have 75 percent of their two-parent families working by Oct. 1. But a survey by The Associated Press found that only 17 states were confident of having met the mark. The significance lies more with politics than policy. Two-parent families account for just 7 percent of all welfare cases. And most states will meet the more important work standards, which apply to their entire welfare populations. JASON DePARLE

title: Abby Jaques, Tomas Mendez
description: Abby Everett Jaques and Tomas Currier Mendez were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York. The Rev. James Burns officiated.

title: Sports of The Times; After a Failure, Johnson Talks of Redemption
description: The autumnal shadows start creeping toward home plate shortly after 4 o'clock in the afternoon. That is when Randy Johnson will uncoil his 6-foot-10-inch body and heave his first pitch today.

title: Want a Day Off? Take It From the Bank
description: TIME off isn't what it used to be for American workers. Some want Hanukkah off; others want Christmas. Some want Columbus Day, others Martin Luther King Jr. Day. Some take sick days when they're sick. Some when their kids are sick. Or when their car is sick. Or when they are just sick of their jobs.

title: The Market's Moods, and How to Read Them
description: BERNIE SCHAEFFER, president of the Cincinnati-based Investment Research Institute, is a student of investor sentiment. Such sentiment is what investment experts call a contrary indicator: if it points in one direction, it means the market may soon go in the other.

title: Sept. 28-Oct. 4; Fur Is Back, and It's in Lavender
description: Along with perilously high spiked-heeled shoes, cashmere sweaters and leather pants, fur is once again the star of fashion magazines, and dozens of designers have jumped on board, working fur into everything from wool suits to shoes to pullover sweaters.

title: Great Northwest
description: At the Owl Woman Saloon

title: The Power of History
description: What Don DeLillo brought to my mind in ''The Power of History'' (Sept. 7) is the inadequacy of the history lesson. We need to feel the humanity of historical figures before we can understand their actions.

title: Crime
description: The way Martha Grimes tells it in THE CASE HAS ALTERED (Holt, $24), there is no more atmospheric setting for murder in all of England than the Lincolnshire fens. In somber descriptive passages, she captures both the eerie beauty and the utter desolation of this flat and watery countryside where two women have met silent, lonely deaths. ''It wasn't a place he'd care to live in,'' Grimes's Scotland Yard detective, Richard Jury, decides. ''It lay too heavily upon the soul. It would take a greater subtlety of mind than his to appreciate it, the nuances of light and shadow, wind and weather.''

title: Saving Spring
description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Object Fixation
description: Things. How we love them. We may rhapsodize over the architecture of a room so well designed that it almost needs no furniture, but, ultimately, it is the objects that fill a room that are closer to our esthetic hearts. It may be a question of scale and the sense of touch -- you can hold a bowl in your hand, recline on a chair or feel the texture of a piece of fabric, none of which you can do with a room. It may also be that things are portable: unlike houses, you can take them with you, as well as all the associations they eventually come to embody.

title: Winning Ugly; Bashing America for Fun and Profit
description: THE Ugly American has a new look around the world.

title: No Comparison
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Nurse Practitioners Can't Take Place of Doctors; More Consumer Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Squatterland
description: LITTLE MASTERS

title: For the Elderly, The High-Rise, High-End Life
description: WHEN we were young we thought we would retire to some exotic place,'' said Hugh Appling. ''In the end we went where the children were.''

title: Couture House
description: In an age where labels are all-important, Calvin Tsao and Zack McKown are hard to pigeonhole. They have designed gigantic commercial projects, but they were known first, and are still known best, for their elegant residential interiors. They are modernists by disposition, but a sound grasp of architectural history resonates throughout their work. They are architects by profession, but their enthusiasm for, and knowledge of, the finer points of decorative arts and furniture make them accomplished decorators as well. This consideration for the small scale and the domestic informs all their projects. ''We believe that houses and apartments are the DNA of architecture,'' says Tsao. ''And we always go back to the question of how people live. When architecture and the principles of decorating come together, you get the best of both worlds.''

title: Fed Policy On Rates Seems Tough After All
description: The Federal Reserve's policy-making committee met last week and, again, did not raise interest rates -- a move that, for some, is evidence that the central bank is prolonging its ''experiment'' with inflation and growth.

title: Sept. 28-Oct. 4; More Childhood Cancer, Less Death
description: A child born today has 1 chance in 600 of developing cancer by age 10, according to Environmental Protection Agency officials. The incidence of childhood cancer has been creeping up for years, and while nobody knows the reason, many researchers suspect it may be linked to environmental factors.

title: Recalling Roy Lichtenstein on Long Island
description: ROY LICHTENSTEIN, who died on Monday at 73, was usually described in terms that would never have been applied to his art. Lichtenstein the man was often called retiring, soft-spoken and reticent, while his work prompted adjectives like brash, flamboyant and larger than life.

title: The Big City; The Needle Trade
description: It takes a refined sensibility to fathom the taboos on Avenue C between Third and Fourth Streets. A new city law bans X-rated businesses from this block of the East Village, since there are churches and apartment buildings nearby. Smoking, too, is pretty much out of the question, at least inside stores and businesses.
