Soon, if city officials go ahead with their plan to ban tobacco advertising within 1,000 feet of a school, it will be illegal even to put a cigarette sign inside one of these stores. All in all, it is not a good block for vice unless you're interested in mainlining heroin.

title: Nurse Practitioners Can't Take Place of Doctors; Listening to Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERENFELD, GERALDINE E.
description: STERENFELD-Geraldine E. Of Lake Worth, FL, formerly of Great Neck, NY. Devoted wife of Benjamin Walter Sterenfeld. Loving mother of Gail S. Davidson and Greer S. Goldman, and their husbands Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson and Gerald Goldman. Proud and adoring grandmother of four grandsons, Joshua, Jeremy, Jonathan and David. Funeral service today, 1:30 PM, at Temple Beth-El, Great Neck, NY. Contributions may be made to Temple Beth-El, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY 11023.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALIN, ANNA
description: PALIN-Anna. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with sorrow the death of Anna Palin, wife of the late Louis Palin. We extend sincere sympathies to her children, our respected friend and Director of the Hebrew Home Board of Directors, Michael (Caryl) Palin and Carol (Mort) Sehres; grandchildren Jill, Stacey, Dorothy, Andrea, and Dean and her ten greatgrandchildren. Our thoughts are with you at this unhappy time. Milton A Gilbert, President Bernard Goldberg, Chairman Jacob Reingold, Vice Chairman Daniel A. Reingold, Exec VP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANNER, PAULINE STEINLAUF
description: TANNER-Pauline Steinlauf, after a long illness, cherished wife of the late Irving; loved by children Ben and Ellen Tanner Farkas, and Nicki and Harold Tanner; and grandchildren Esta and Paul Farkas, Gary and Lynn Farkas Schwartz, Peggy and David Tanner; Catherine Allegra and James Tanner, Kent and Karen Tanner Allen; and proud great-grandmother of 11. Her intelligence, love of, and loyalty to, family strengthened and enhanced our lives. Expressions of remembrance may be made to the Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem or to the Pauline and Irving Tanner Scholarship Fund at Cornell University. Funeral services will be on Sunday, October 5, at 1:00 P.M., at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Yashmak Prevails
description: Occasionally -- but only occasionally -- a horse race will end this way: four horses across the track burning toward the finish in a group photo. And yesterday, with $400,000 on the line in the Flower Bowl Invitational at Belmont Park, they were separated by no more than one length as they flew home, with the filly Yashmak prevailing in her first race in the United States.

title: Helping Women Overcome Barriers and Achieve Success
description: MY own definition of success is reaching whatever your goal is, and once you reach it, it's even changing goals,'' said Tina Santi Flaherty in her native Memphis drawl as she stroked her yellow Labrador retriever, Liam, in her sumptuous Remsenburg home adjacent to Moriches Bay.

title: Cooked Radicchio Gets Sweeter When It Loses Its Autumn Hue
description: IT is hard to believe that just a decade ago, unless they had been to Italy, few Americans knew what radicchio was. Now this red-leafed chicory is widely available, a staple in ready-made supermarket salad mixes as well as sold on its own. I like it well enough raw, but I much prefer it cooked.

title: Shelby Brown and Cy Coleman
description: TO arrange their wedding, Cy Coleman, the Broadway composer and producer, and Shelby Brown, who has done everything from writing romance stories to surveying roads in Idaho, dialed (800) 785-LOVE.

title: For Guts, Glory and Absolutely Nothing Else; The Ways of Pudgie Walsh: 41 Years of Neolithic Combat of the Semipro Fields of Brooklyn
description: NOTHING stops Pudgie Walsh. Nothing. And thus, on this drowsy, sun-splashed Brooklyn morning, he could not imagine that he would be unable to break into his car trunk. He had bagels inside the trunk and it wouldn't open. His jaw was set. His mien was determined. The man was hungry. So: he jiggled the lock. He pounded the trunk. He swore at the trunk. He beseeched the gods. The trunk was unyielding. No bagels in Brooklyn.

title: 90 Leave New York, In Search Of Unity
description: A group of 90 Promise Keepers from New York spread sleeping bags on the cold floors of a church here early this morning and did not worry about using the ladies' room because there were no women around. By 8:30 A.M., the men were singing hymns, preparing for a rally they said had a particular meaning for them, even if New York has been a city especially skeptical of the Promise Keepers' message.

title: S.E.C. Sees Tangled Dealings at High-Tech Company
description: HOW many ways can a chief executive hype his own stock?

title: Kenya Thaw Brings Hope, And Doubts, On Reforms
description: The political stalemate that has led to violence here over the last six months has been broken, after President Daniel arap Moi's agreement last week with opposition leaders on reforms that would level the playing field somewhat before the coming election.

title: Food; Cod Is Good
description: As cod goes, so go the fortunes of the working fisherman. This oft-heard sentiment is as true today as it was in 1784, when Massachusetts hung a carving of the cod in its Statehouse, in grateful appreciation.

title: Freshman Democrat Is Dogged by Relentless Foe
description: The champagne bubbled, balloons kissed the ceiling and Loretta Sanchez stood center stage two weeks after the election, savoring the clatter of voices at her official victory party, thinking to herself it was all finally over.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHUSTAK, EDWARD L.
description: SHUSTAK-Edward L. April 28, 1924-October 7, 1987 Remembered with love, always

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  AGUIRRE, ISABEL (BELA)
description: AGUIRRE-Isabel (Bela). A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, October 8 at 6PM, at St. John the Evangelist Church, East 55th Street and 1st Avenue for Bela, who passed away on September 15, 1997. Please join us.

title: Correction
description: An article and a picture caption last Sunday about a former gatehouse in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., misstated its purchase price and the occupation of one co-owner. The price was $305,000, not $327,000; the co-owner, Nancy Potter, is a production manager, not an office manager.

title: Fiscal Woes Turn Special Education Upside Down
description: LIKE many youngsters throughout Long Island, two young boys on the East End, both named Zachary, entered preschool early in September.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, MILLARD J.
description: WILLIAMS-Millard J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Millard J. Williams associated with The Times from 1958, until retiring in 1983.

title: Potato Chips Cum Laude
description: IT was a scene probably rarely seen at Gracie Mansion. On Tuesday night, the city's first lady, Donna Hanover, pushed back her sleeves, washed her hands and got to work in the kitchen. The occasion was the Cooks for Kids benefit at the Architects and Designers Building on East 58th Street, featuring a menu created by a number of restaurants in model kitchens throughout the building's 12 floors.

title: Tara Vent, John Tucker
description: Tara Lynn Vent, an assistant district attorney in the Bronx, and John Brian Tucker, a news anchor for both Bloomberg Radio and Bloomberg Television in Manhattan, were married yesterday in Middletown, N.J. The Rev. Barbara Rambach, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Monmouth Hills Club.

title: A Spanish Princess's Wedding Is Rich in Regional Symbolism
description: Princess Cristina, the third in line to the Spanish throne, married a Basque commoner who is a professional athlete today in a ceremony that paid tribute to Spain's diverse regions.

title: With Maturity and Financing, the Arts Expand and Blossom
description: MANHATTAN cast a long shadow on Westchester's art scene in 1977. City venues were considered more glamorous, professional and trustworthy. Many people figured that for the price of a baby sitter and parking they were at least guaranteed the best play or concert money could buy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDOUGALD, CORNELIUS.
description: McDOUGALD-Cornelius. 85, long time attorney in NYC. Died on October 3, 1997 of Somers, NY formerly of Manhattan. Husband of Mildred. Father of Cornelia and Cornelius Travis McDougald and the late Mary McDougald Kohn. Grandfather of Sarah and Jeremy Kohn. Father-in-law of Imre Kohn and Deborah McDougald. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, RUTH L.
description: COOPER-Ruth L. Dear friend and loyal supporter of the purebred dog. She will be sorely missed. Luc Boileau Matthew H. Stander

title: A Cadillac With Global Ambitions
description: AFTER dropping the rear-drive Fleetwood and introducing a new entry-level model, the Catera, last year, Cadillac has moved to shore up its new lineup, redesigning the Seville sedan.

title: Helen Poole, R. F. Corroon 2d
description: Helen McPherson Vernon Poole, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Poole of Fredericksburg, Va., was married there yesterday to Richard Francis Corroon 2d, a son of Helen Maitland Corroon of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Robert Francis Corroon. The Rev. Charles Sydnor performed the ceremony at St. George's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Michael Moynihan, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: For Fairway Partners, Deep-Freeze Chill
description: When the uptown Fairway, a sprawling, warehouse-sized supermarket selling fresh food to the public at wholesale prices, opened in December 1995 at 133d Street and 12th Avenue, shoppers from near and far fell in love with it, and the supermarket industry sat up and took notice. The space was ample, the produce just picked, the selection wide. It even had that most coveted of Manhattan resources: parking.

title: The Nation; More Work, Less Play Make Jack Look Better Off
description: THE Census Bureau announced last week that the median income of American households rose in 1996 for the third year in a row, even after allowing for inflation. At last, the economic expansion appears to be lifting a lot of boats. Certainly the Clinton Administration says so. After years of stagnant incomes, the President said, ''America's middle class, no longer forgotten, is rising fast.''

title: QUICK BITE/Edgewater; A Coffee Break, and Some Alternatives
description: When it comes to coffee, I don't like alternatives. I like caffeine.

title: The Floor is Theirs
description: A stunning pastiche of customized rug samples covers the glass-topped table in V'Soske's Manhattan showroom. Potholder-size or larger, the silk and wool confections both reflect and absorb the afternoon light streaming through the bank of windows. On one of the luxurious fragments, a small field of brushed, cut-pile wool, dyed a flaming fuchsia, jousts with a more delicate section of loop-silk tapestry, dyed an acid green. Resembling miniature works of art, the densely textured samples elicit a feast of sensual associations, from a Neo-Assyrian wall relief to a minimalist painting by Agnes Martin.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, CLAIRE
description: GOODMAN-Claire. Age 85. Died October 2, 1997 in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida after a long illness. Claire was a pioneer in the New York decorative fabric business, having been the first woman to hold an executive sales position in that industry. A loyal and caring friend with a wonderfully unique and often irreverent sense of humor, she will be sorely missed by her friends and family. Claire is predeceased by her husband, the late Philip Goodman, and survived by her loving nieces, Linda Yellin and Joan Kasler of Southern California and nephew Richard Kaplan of San Francisco.

title: New Releases
description: 'JOE HENDERSON: PORGY AND BESS' Verve

title: Over the Years, Government Has Taken a More Visible Role
description: TWENTY years ago, 2000 seemed so far away that the various government and civic groups that would later be formed to study how to prepare for the millennium had not been thought of yet.

title: Wanted: More Lights on East End Ave.
description: Community Board 8 recently asked the city's Department of Transportation to install ''without delay'' traffic signals at each intersection of East End Avenue, the leafy thoroughfare a block west of the East River that includes Gracie Mansion.

title: Rally Taps Men's Desire For Sense of Community
description: Among the many thousands of men gathered today on the Washington Mall to join in a mass prayer rally sponsored by the Promise Keepers organization, there are those who speak as if they have caught a glimpse here of a better world, a place uplifted and imbued with racial harmony, set apart from what they see as a deeply troubled nation.

title: Off to a Fine Season
description: Benefits for the homeless, AIDS care, art education in the public schools and a historic Jewish home.

title: Newport Private Homes On Columbus Day Tour
description: It is often only the well-heeled of Newport, R.I., who get to see the interiors of some of the city's grand or unusual private homes. But on Columbus Day weekend, Oct. 11 to 12, the public is invited, too.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 8 of the Travel section today about Auckland, New Zealand, refers incorrectly in some copies to the number of boat owners there. It is about one resident in 6, not in 12.

title: Reinventing Cities In a Mixed Market
description: IN 1977 many big city dwellers were skeptical of reports that the third largest concentration of Fortune 500 companies after Manhattan and Chicago was in Fairfield County. More than 100 companies had moved to Connecticut by then, mostly out of New York City, and 33 of them were on the Fortune 500 list, about the same number as Chicago's.

title: ON THE MAP; Where Soldiers Left for War and Refugees Found a Safe Haven
description: Behind iron bars and broken windowpanes, in hushed disarray, chairs are scattered across a dusty wood floor, juxtaposed as if their occupants had just been talking to one another and left the cobwebbed room. A group of Hungarian refugees likely sat here 41 years ago filling out immigration forms for admittance to America.

title: Europe on the Shoals
description: Europe Adrift

title: The Boy Who Gave Away the Bomb
description: In ''The Boy Who Gave Away the Bomb'' (by Joseph Albright and Marcia Kunstel, Sept. 14), the physicist Theodore Hall justifies passing atomic secrets to the Russians -- by himself and my late father, Saville Sax -- with the presumed consequences of an American monopoly of atomic weapons. This argument has an eerily technocratic ring. It reminds me of the arguments used to justify the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki: that this allegedly kept the bomb from being used again for over half a century.

title: Women, on the Rally's Edge, Mirror Divided View of Group
description: First Street between Louisiana and Constitution Avenues, just west of the Capitol, might as well have been America's Berlin Wall.

title: Still Spinning
description: WALK into any large record store in Manhattan and you are likely to find books, magazines and computer programs, as well as prerecorded tape cassettes and compact disks. Everything, it seems, but records. But in a growing number of small independent record stores around the city, sales of record albums are thriving, as are sales of an even more specialized vinyl relic: the 45 r.p.m. single.

title: A Rueful Reminder
description: To the Editor:

title: Shadow Worlds
description: The Fabric of Reality

title: Why Are American Workers Losing Ground?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KINGSLEY, MARTIN
description: KINGSLEY-Martin. On September 30, 1997. Beloved father of Claudia, devoted son of the late Sadye and Harry Kornhauser, loved brother and brother-in-law of Edna and Edward Kasner and dear uncle of Karen Winik and Jay Kasner. Services are private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASKENAS, WARREN
description: ASKENAS-Warren, 63, on September 30, 1997. Husband of Merle. Beloved father of Mitchell and Wendy, and Caren and Gary Cohen. Big Bacca and Grandpa to Lyndsey, Brenna and Robby. Dear brother of Irma and Harold Goshin. You were taken away from us so suddenly, and you will be missed terribly. Funeral services to be held Sun., Oct. 5, 9:45AM, at Sinai Chapels, 718-445-0300.

title: Small World
description: If you think you're looking at life-size objects under towering evergreens, think again. Miniature furniture, books, garden tools and even shoes may be diminutive, but they're big with collectors. This whimsical gathering takes place in a tiny enchanted forest: a potted, two-foot-high grove of half-century-old bonsai juniper trees. It's the little things that mean a lot.

title: Corrections
description: The sports program listing on page 3 of the Television section today is outdated in some copies. Correct versions show the Dallas Cowboys vs. the Giants as the first entry. A correct copy appears in SportsSunday, section 8, page 14.

title: The View From: Stamford; From Sleepy Town To High-Rise City
description: AN often-heard plaint of Stamford residents, on returning to the city years after having moved away, is that they no longer recognize their home town. Indeed, it is not uncommon even for those who still live in the city to get lost amid the high-rise glass towers that seem to have sprung up without design, without symmetry.

title: Sept. 28-Oct. 4; Fixing the Price of Joy
description: It was, the judge said, a tawdry toy story. A Federal judge ruled that Toys ''R'' Us, the nation's largest toy retailer, used its market muscle to keep Mr. Potato Head, Hollywood Hair Barbie and dozens of other popular products off the shelves of its emerging chief competitors, warehouse clubs like Price/Costco and Sam's Club.

title: Whistle-Blowing Marshal Tells of Long Harassment
description: As a police officer and investigator, Stephen M. Zanowic Jr. spent 10 years on the streets, mainly chasing muggers and corrupt officers. In 1988, he thought he had found a prestigious law enforcement niche when he was appointed a United States deputy marshal in Manhattan.

title: It's the Old Ball Game, And the Same Old Pitch
description: AL had on an old baseball cap and a shirt that flapped over his belly when he raised his arms to make his announcement.

title: SOAPBOX; The World on a String
description: WOW. You're pretty good with that,'' observed my secretary, Flo. She was watching me play with my yo-yo. Occasionally I take it from the out basket and do a few walk the dogs and rock the babys to relieve tension. ''Where did you learn to do that?'' she asked.

title: A Floating Playground
description: ONE of the joys of taking a sea cruise with your children is that you can sometimes forget you have them. They tend not to fall overboard, but on a big cruise ship with its limitless possibilities of exploration, they do disappear for long stretches.

title: For a PBS Audience Way Beyond Big Bird
description: AS THE OFFSPRING OF A MARRIAGE between a bird and a dragon, Wimzie has fuzzy fuschia hair, a pert orange beak and little red wings sprouting behind her pigtails. Her zany 150-year-old grandmother, Yaya, who once played in a rock band, runs a day-care center from the family's cozy home, where the walls tilt at odd angles and breakfast cereal is bright blue.

title: SOAPBOX; Bitten at the Flea Market
description: ONE Sunday a few months ago I was happily flouncing around lower Manhattan (as I am wont to do on a Sunday when it's warmish and the sun is shining and the flea markets are in full bloom), when out of the corner of my left eye, just as I was casually Reebokking my way across Grand Street and Broadway, I caught sight of a glaringly lopsided sign placed dead center in a parking lot flea market, advertising ''Classical CD's, One Dollar Each.''

title: Parents at P.S. 3 Say Two Into One Won't Go
description: It has long been a point of pride for P.S. 3, an alternative elementary school on Hudson Street founded by liberal parents and teachers in 1971, to welcome students from other neighborhoods in the city. With its open classrooms, emphasis on creativity and a staff that is more comfortable than most with alternative life styles, P.S. 3 offers what many would call progressive education.

title: Scaling the Heights
description: Fingers fly, sweat drips, jaws clench, and, in the end, after 17 grueling days of solo recitals, chamber music and concerto performances, one young artist emerges victorious -- the gold medalist in the Olympics of the music world, the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition. PLAYING WITH FIRE is a 90-minute documentary offering an in-depth look at the 10th quadrennial competition, which took place this year from May 23 to June 8 in Fort Worth, Tex. It follows the 35 pianists chosen to vie for first prize, from the first round when 12 semifinalists are selected, to the finals, when the last 6 survivors contend for the coveted bronze, silver and gold medals.

title: Old Bones From Gobi Desert Spur a New Look at Evolution
description: Paleontologists sifting through 80-million-year-old bones collected from the Gobi Desert in Mongolia have discovered some puzzling but potentially revealing specimens: a dinosaur wishbone that may demonstrate kinship to modern birds, and some peculiar pelvic bones that seem to undercut traditional ideas about the evolution of mammals.

title: Where Everything Old Can Be New Again
description: Not long ago, Jane Barton donned white coveralls, a harness and a hard hat and, accompanied by a professional climber and a structural engineer, rappeled off the top of the crumbling dome of the New Jersey State House dome. It was all in a day's work -- a somewhat unusual day, to be sure -- for Ms. Barton in her role as New Jersey's chief of restoration and heritage programs as she supervises the work at the State House, which was originally built in 1792.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEAGAN, CHARLES, M.D.
description: BEAGAN-Charles, M.D. died on October 2, 1997. Beloved father of Patrick and Susan. Mourned by Evelyn Beagan and Nina Smith. Service will be on Sunday, October 5, at Jacobsen F.H., Huntington, LI. Mass on Monday, October 6, at 10:15AM, St. Hugh Of Lincoln Roman Catholic Church, Huntington. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the V.N.S. Hospice, Suffolk County.

title: Singing the Blues? Not State's Musicians
description: THE Tokyo Quartet playing at Norfolk, Johannes Somary leading the Fairfield County Chorale, the Greenwich Symphony performing under David Gilbert, Brahms and Schubert concerts at Music Mountain. These were among the highlights of 1977.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE -- In 2 Corners of City, a Surge in Hispanic Power; Brooklyn Area May Put Puerto Rican on Council
description: Watching Angel Rodriguez enter the Sunset Park Senior Citizen Center is something like witnessing the second coming of Elvis. Men shout and offer handshakes; women swoon and demand besos, or kisses. Mr. Rodriguez, 40, circulates, giving hugs, besos and advice, even joking about his bulging belly with a group of women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZAR, RUTH STOLZ
description: LAZAR-Ruth Stolz. Cherished wife of the late Dr Alfred E. Lazar, beloved mother of Laura (Stephen) Siegel, Kenneth S. (Valerie) Lazar and Fran (Dr. Jeffrey) Ashkin; adored grandmother of Shari, Jonathan (Majorie), and David Siegel, Emily and Michael Lazar, Eric, Hillary and Adrienne Ashkin; dear sister of Samuel Stolz and Barbara Roth, and the late Irving H. Stolz, Fannie Wander and Rachael Murrey. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY, 12 noon, Sunday.

title: Nurse Practitioners Can't Take Place of Doctors; Nurses, Beware
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Is Likely to Wink At Pope's Call to Behave
description: In a country where bare buttocks are common on the beaches, newsstands openly sell pornographic videos and the most popular dance involves gyrating the pelvis above a soda bottle, Pope John Paul II is urging Roman Catholics in Brazil to return to traditional family values.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARGOLIN, BORIS
description: MARGOLIN-Boris. He entered eternal life Rosh Hashonah 5745. A loving man and a learned Jew. Dorothy

title: On Our Own Two Feet; Step by Step, From High Point to Cape May
description: THE CLUB The Fort Monmouth Shore Walkers is a club of about 50 active members affiliated with the American Volkssport Association, which has about 700 clubs dedicated to noncompetitive walking as a social and recreational pursuit. The Volkssport movement started in Germany in the 1960's, and there are thousands of Volkssport clubs around the world. the name simply means ''people sports.'' Formed in 1991 as the Fort Monmouth Road Warriors, the Shore Walkers is one of four walking clubs in New Jersey. The clubs sponsor events that are open to anyone who wants to participate.

title: Nurse Practitioners Can't Take Place of Doctors; A 'Glut' of Doctors?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hold the Caveat
description: To the Editor: I disagree with the statement of Thomas A. Dickerson that, to a large extent, travel ''operates under the principle of caveat emptor'' (Practical Traveler, ''Who's Minding the Agents?'' Sept. 14). Travelers can protect themselves by working with travel professionals who belong to an association that provides a consumer protection plan, requires members to carry liability insurance and enforces strict membership requirements and a code of ethics. The National Tour Association -- which was not mentioned in the column -- is such an organization.

title: Tyrannosaur Skeleton Is Sold To a Museum for $8.36 Million
description: Sue, the most complete fossil of a Tyrannosaurus rex ever found, was auctioned yesterday for a staggering $8.36 million to the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago.

title: Style; Dance Partners
description: On a Tuesday afternoon in July, in a sun-filled studio on the top floor of a building in Greenwich Village, Merce Cunningham and Rei Kawakubo are about to find out what happens when her costumes and his choreography come together for a dance called ''Scenario,'' which will make its debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Oct. 14. Other fashion designers have dressed dancers for the stage, with more or less predictable results -- the costumes subordinate, if not incidental, to the dancing. But Cunningham clearly regards Kawakubo as an equal partner, and they seem especially well matched. ''We both believe in accident, experiment and risk,'' Kawakubo explains.

title: Why We Play Semipro
description: LOTS of people love football, but the gentlemen of the Brooklyn Mariners really love football. ''You can't worry about getting hurt -- when you're out here playing you just can't think about it,'' said Frankie Smith, 36, a linebacker and owner of Competent Fire Sprinkler, though when he hurt his knee in a game three years ago he said, ''The first thing I thought was, 'What am I going to do Monday morning?' ''

title: Ahab's Totalitarianism
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nike Railroad
description: Teen-agers in Tokyo have created a $10 million annual market for used sneakers. Following the craze for vintage Levi's and worked-in work boots, well-to-do Japanese youth -- mostly males, from junior-high to college age -- have turned old Nikes into a collector's item, paying huge prices for elusive ''6th edition'' Air Jordans and hard-to-find Dunks (made only in 1985 for select college and high-school teams). Prices in Japanese shops routinely reach $2,000 or more, and the trend -- now in its third year -- shows no sign of letting up. For used-sneaks entrepreneurs like Jeff Morgan and Hugh Farley, owners of the New Jersey-based Vintage Emporium, the steady demand requires a sophisticated distribution system. Here's how it works.

title: Is the Kitchen Shipshape?
description: JON SCHNOOR of the United States Public Health Service, who inspects cruise ship kitchens, water supplies and pools, says that almost no New York restaurant could pass the tests applied to the dining facilities of the 114 vessels he and his colleagues see. On the other hand, he said, if visitors do not like the looks of a New York bistro, they can go elsewhere, not an option for passengers at sea.

title: Japan's Goal Of Leading On Climate Is in Doubt
description: When Japan was chosen as the site of this year's conference on climate change, it relished the chance to play host to a landmark meeting to help save the planet from global warming.

title: New Releases
description: PATTI SMITH: 'PEACE AND NOISE'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONTZOFF, VADIM F.
description: GONTZOFF-Vadim F. Passed away in New York Hospital October 2, 1997, after a long illness at the age of 81. Burial will be private. He will be missed by Annikki, friends and Midnight.

title: Essay; The Boris & Jacques Show
description: French President Jacques Chirac met with Boris Yeltsin in Moscow to cook up an Iranian natural-gas deal that would (1) enrich their business interests, (2) gain a diplomatic foothold in the Persian Gulf by helping terrorists obtain missiles and (3) distract their restive unemployed by sticking a thumb in the U.S. eye.

title: Dream Weaves
description: Luxurious fabrics, and their often stratopsheric price tags, are the product of first-rate fibers, subtle colorings and complex, often laborious manufacturing processes. On the following pages, traditional and contemporary textiles that pamper any room.

title: Catherine Dillon, Stephen Perreault
description: Catherine Alice Dillon and Stephen George Perreault, United States Navy ensigns, are to be married today. The Rev. Gurdon Brewster, the Episcopal Chaplain at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., is to perform the ceremony there in the Sage Chapel.

title: After Tobacco Settlement, Florida Battles Its Lawyers
description: When Florida officials decided to sue tobacco companies to recover Medicaid expenses for smoking-related diseases, they enlisted the help of the top lawyers in the state. The state managed to settle with the tobacco companies, but now it is fighting its lawyers.

title: Lucinda Williams Is in Pain
description: Perfectionist tendencies are admirable, but they can also be a hindrance to the culmination of a project. I have been waiting a long time for Williams's next disk. Would someone please acquaint the lady with the phrase ''good enough''?

title: Hundreds of Thousands Gather On the Mall in a Day of Prayers
description: In a religious revival rally that stretched a mile from the Capitol past the Washington Monument, hundreds of thousands of Christian men hugged, sang and sank to their knees today, repenting for their own sins and what they see as a secular and socially troubled America.

title: Exhibitions Have Found Patrons and Appreciation
description: FACED with the prospect of covering art in Westchester, I told myself, ''No way.'' It was 1978 and from what little I knew, galleries were few and far between, museums even fewer and the chance of finding shows for 52 columns a year seemed slim. That I was wide of the mark soon became obvious, but not until studying almost 20 years' worth of reviews did I realize that in Westchester as in Manhattan, the last batch of good old days for art has come and gone.

title: Those Shiny New M.B.A.'s Get Signing Bonuses, Too
description: WHEN Eric Dunkelberg, 27, finished his M.B.A. at Emory University last spring, he chose among nine job offers. Almost all of them included a signing bonus.

title: Commentary; The Environment: Worth Fighting For
description: AS I wander the landscapes of northern Westchester these days and see the ground pocked with new percolation holes and saplings festooned with pink surveyors' ribbons, I wonder about the county's future and think about the great environmental battles that have been fought across this terrain for 20 years. Westchester's extraordinary tradition of environmental advocacy has always been fueled by water.

title: Good Things For Those Who Waited
description: ANYBODY remember Paul Wick?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, ELEANORE POTTER
description: HARRIS-Eleanore Potter. (Mrs. John W. Harris). On October 3, 1997 of East Hampton, NY. Beloved mother of Richard and Frederick Ayer. Loving grandmother of Debra, Constance, Richard, Dayna, Frederick and Edward. Dearest great-grandmother of Frederick, Ashley, Justin and Sable. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Friends of Baileys Arboretum, Locust Valley, NY. For further information, contact Williams Funeral Home of East Hampton.

title: The Fight Over Kudirat Abiola St.
description: Tip O'Neill, the House Speaker from 1977 to 1987, once said that ''all politics is local.'' That is especially true in New York, self-proclaimed capital of the world, where even a local issue like naming streets can have global implications. The latest example is an effort to name the northeast corner of Second Avenue and 44th Street after Kudirat Abiola, the slain wife of Moshood K. O. Abiola, who was elected President of Nigeria in 1993 but has been imprisoned since 1994 by the military Government of Gen. Sani Abacha.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARIS, DR. LEON
description: PARIS-Dr. Leon. Age 88, died suddenly on September 23, 1997, in Florida. Predeceased by loving wife Jerry. Beloved father of Lenny (Alvin) Katz, Philip (Sally), Michael, and Judy. Brother of Sarah. Devoted Poppop to grandchildren and great-grandchildren. He will be greatly missed.

title: A House With a Mind of Its Own
description: It's morning in the Pacific Northwest, and as the sun comes up, Charles Simonyi's bed rotates toward a window, music from a favorite CD wafts into the room, and the blinds automatically rise, offering a panorama of Lake Washington.

title: In a Niche Between Marple and Tennison
description: IN the new ''Mystery!'' series, ''Hetty Wainthroppe Investigates,'' the title character is a 60-year-old Lancashire housewife who becomes a detective, and steps into that vast middle ground between Miss Marple and Jane Tennison. As played by Patricia Routledge, Hetty is as practical as she is inquisitive, and she stands for no nonsense as she solves crimes in the North of England.

title: SOAPBOX; Skull Sessions
description: NINE animal skulls -- a deer, woodchuck, raccoon and possum among them -- a turtle shell, a cow leg bone, a plaster cast of a bear-paw print, a fake Indian arrow and a varnished turtle.

title: Stores Sued in Sale of Box Cutters to Minors
description: Saying that box cutters have become a favorite weapon of youth gangs, the City's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Jose Maldonado, filed a lawsuit yesterday against nine businesses that had repeatedly violated a law prohibiting the sale of these tools to minors.

title: Prairie View Loses Again
description: When the game between Grambling State and Prairie View A&M ended tonight, a couple of milestones grew by one. Grambling Coach Eddie Robinson, college football's career leader in victories, notched No. 407.

title: That's Entertainment
description: WHAT -- The GMC Suburban, in a limited edition of 100, sold by Neiman Marcus for $72,975. That's more than twice the price for the basic nine-passenger vehicle, a gas-guzzling land yacht popular with everyone from soccer moms to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who is driven around in one instead of a limousine.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: The New Look of Liberalism on the Court
description: The most unguarded conversation i've had with justice ruth bader ginsburg occurred at the Washington Opera. It was two years ago, during the first intermission of a production of ''Cosi Fan Tutte,'' and I ran into Justice Ginsburg and her husband on the stairs. ''Cosi'' is the one about the two lotharios who make a bet that their girlfriends will be faithful, disguise themselves as Albanian soldiers, try to seduce each other's girlfriend and find that the women aren't faithful after all. The director had tried to add a feminist twist by having the women overhear the bet in the first act, so that they were only ''pretending'' to be unfaithful in the second. I suggested to Justice Ginsburg that perhaps this conceit was hard to reconcile with the sexual double standards of the 18th century, which were central to the plot and reflected in the traditional translation of the title: ''Never Trust a Woman.''

title: Schools Shouldn't Need Student Fund-Raising
description: To the Editor:

title: An Uneven Race for Nassau Chief
description: Over 28 years, Lewis J. Yevoli has built a career as a political outsider -- first as a Democratic underdog winning on Republican turf in Nassau County, then as a maverick tangling with his own party's governors and Assembly Speakers.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Malverne, L.I.; Mom-and-Pops and a Working Farm
description: EARLY last year the tiny Nassau County village of Malverne, not to be outdone by Punxsutawney's Phil, the Pennsylvania groundhog who gained national fame by yearly predicting the end of winter, introduced its own groundhog forecaster, Malverne Mel.

title: A French Director With a Taste for the Gritty and Unglamorous
description: AS SHE SITS AND TALKS IN her agent's offices on an elegant boulevard near the Place de l'Etoile, the director Claire Denis is a long way from the remote French colonies and the working-class urban neighborhoods in which she has set each of her four feature films. But Ms. Denis navigates the distance gracefully.

title: Meetings Around Manhattan
description: DISTRICT 1 -- Battery Park, TriBeCa. Next meeting Oct. 21, 5:30 P.M.; Seamen's Church Institute, 241 Water Street; Board Chairwoman: Anne Compoccia. District Manager: Paul Goldstein. (212) 442-5050.

title: On Our Own Two Feet; If the Pain Persists See Your Podiatrist
description: For a state with more than 6 million cars, New Jerseyans spend a lot of time on their feet. Here's a guide on how to pamper them and have some fun, too. (An introduction appears on Page 1.)

title: Hunt Club
description: Those for whom objects of beauty are a part of the job are often passionate collectors themselves. Here is a sampling of their favorite finds and how they found them.

title: In Praise of Autumn's Subtle Performers
description: WHEN trees are mentioned at this time of year, thoughts usually go toward the brilliant scarlets of maples, golds of oaks and yellows of birches in contrast to the deep greens of evergreens.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Knee High to a Sibling

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 5, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Sept. 28-Oct. 4; New Push Against Child Labor
description: After years of denouncing child labor, Congress enacted legislation barring imports of goods made by children in bondage. This practice is prevalent in India, where desperately poor parents sell children into slavery, sometimes as early as age 4, and where the children must often work a decade or more to buy their freedom. Bonded child laborers are often used to make rugs, rattan baskets and leather goods, and are sometimes chained to looms. STEVEN GREENHOUSE

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE STRANGE CASE

title: Some Maintenance Tips for the Home
description: EVERYONE knows that older homes need regular maintenance. While new homes require considerably less maintenance than older ones, they are still not maintenance-free. If you own a new home, it is important to first inspect the home for potential problems, then begin an annual maintenance schedule to keep your house in top condition.

title: The Nation; The Future Came Faster In the Old Days
description: Evidence accumulates daily, as advances are declared in computing, biotechnology or some other cutting-edge field of the modern economy. And a striking sign that we seem to live in a period of unprecedented technological change has come in the last few weeks with the repeal of Moore's law.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 5, 1997
description: Weeks

title: What the Left Left Behind
description: THE FUTURE ONCE

title: Managing the Grief
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Remaking Part of Downtown White Plains; Mixed-Use Plan For Former Macy's
description: An ambitious public/private partnership involving the transformation of a city block in the heart of downtown White Plains has been proposed by Manhattan-based developer Tishman Speyer Properties, co-owner of Rockefeller Center.

title: A Bar Baron, Debt-Laden, Hits a Dry Spell
description: In more than a decade as a player in the hotly competitive Greenwich Village bar scene, Alan Whelan built two successful establishments on Bleecker Street and recently expanded his fief by opening what was to have been a chi-chi bistro on West 10th Street, one of the neighborhood's toniest residential blocks. A burly Irishman with a residual brogue, Mr. Whelan also built a reputation as a scrappy but successful opponent of the community board.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: SOHO

title: Art's New Looks Inside and Out
description: IN 1980 the ''Connecticut Impressionist Art Trail,'' an alliance of 12 institutions that collect Impressionist painting, was formed, and it has since become a major booster of the state's image.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCUTCHEON, JOHN F.
description: McCUTCHEON-John F. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John F. McCutcheon, associated with The Times from 1971, until retiring in 1991.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sept. 21 about Richard Lipsky, a lobbyist, misidentified the employer of Raymond Thek, who was speaking on behalf of a former Lipsky client, Krasdale Foods. Mr. Thek is general counsel of Alpha I Marketing Corporation, an independent company that serves stores supplied by Krasdale. He does not work for Krasdale.

title: Sources
description: A selective list of where to find the architects, designers and products featured in this issue.

title: One-Stop Shopping For Land and Sea
description: CRUISE lines have long offered land packages, but as the cruise industry struggled in recent years to cope with overcapacity, which in turn led to the proliferation of discount fares, the packages also proliferated in number, scope and cost. Yes, Virginia, there may well be a Santa Claus; however, except for a few luxury lines where the price is built into fares bearing luxury price tags, his gifts do not include free land packages.

title: China Boon
description: Chinese art and objects, old or new, are becoming almost as prized as they were when the Silk Routes first opened.

title: Legacy of One-Party Rule and the 'Pledge'
description: WHEN Ella T. Grasso won her second term as Governor nearly 20 years ago, two basic truths prevailed in Connecticut politics: the Democratic Party called the shots, and its leaders were adamantly opposed to an income tax.

title: True to Form, O'Neill and Martinez Are Producing Big Hits for the Yankees
description: When the Yankees won the World Series last year, perhaps the only bittersweet footnote was that they did so with Paul O'Neill and Tino Martinez just shadows of their former selves, because of injury and exhaustion.

title: The Boy Who Gave Away the Bomb
description: Certainly Hall's espionage reveals just how much the Soviets depended on their vast network of spies to gain atomic parity. It also shows how the Soviet spymasters were not content with gaining their information merely from one source. In this regard, it is unnecessary to denigrate the ''contributions'' to the Soviets made by other agents, including Klaus Fuchs and David Greenglass.

title: The Swing Senators
description: It takes many routine votes to build and sustain a Senate career, but one memorable vote can destroy a reputation. For a handful of Republican senators who have championed campaign finance reform, that fatal vote could come on Tuesday if they kill the McCain-Feingold bill. It is hard to imagine how Olympia Snowe of Maine, James Jeffords of Vermont and John Chafee of Rhode Island can face their constituents if they bury the best chance in a generation to fashion a more rational system of financing Presidential and Congressional campaigns.

title: Singles
description: HERMITS The Insights of Solitude. By Peter France. 240 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $23.95.

title: Lost in the Stacks
description: Don't bother asking Richard Meier how many books he has. Not only does he not know, he won't even venture a guess. And with good reason. The 62-year-old architect of the long-awaited, soon-to-open Getty Center in Los Angeles, Meier has been collecting books, mostly on architecture and art, since he was a student. The bookcases that line two walls of his otherwise sparely furnished living room on New York's Upper East Side filled up long ago, and now their owner arranges the overflow in towering but precisely placed -- and categorized -- stacks. The effect, appropriately enough, is that of a mini-Manhattan rendered in both hardcover and soft. But instead of an Empire State Building, there is a Picasso stack (actually, there are at least two); instead of a Chrysler Building, there is a Matisse stack. There are first editions on the works of Le Corbusier and the artist Kasimir Malevich, rare books on Italian gardens, illustrated portfolios of Charles Garnier's Paris Opera House and a signed first edition of Frank Lloyd Wright's autobiography, to name but a few. A very few.

title: Managing Managed Care
description: Stop me if you've heard this one. Three doctors are driving in a car; the car goes over a cliff, and all three are killed instantly and go up to heaven. St. Peter greets the first one and asks what she did in her life. ''I was a family doctor, I healed many people and took good care of my patients,'' she says. ''Welcome to heaven, come right in,'' says St. Peter. The second doctor answers, ''I was a cardiologist, and I helped many people with heart trouble to lead healthier lives.'' ''Welcome to heaven, come right in.'' The third doctor says, ''I worked for managed care.'' ''Welcome to heaven,'' St. Peter says. ''Your stay is limited to 24 hours.''

title: Law Disorder
description: ''The Feds are power-mad pit bulls,'' says Justice Charles Stewart of Sandy, Ore. Strong words for a judge, but Stewart occasionally presides over the Multnomah County Common Law Court, a bootleg, far-right body that exists in defiance of the real American justice system. According to the Klanwatch Project, there are 137 of these courts in 35 states, and their creators claim the right to call juries, try cases and even issue death warrants against public officials. Very frightening. But as a typical Multnomah session shows, they can also be very silly. Here's a look.

title: Caps Slice Up Devil Defense
description: The first sign of vulnerability in the Devils' defense came a night earlier, when they allowed two goals 16 seconds apart in a victory at Tampa Bay in the season opener. More evidence of that vulnerability came to the surface tonight in a 4-1 loss to the Capitals.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: A Gracious Plenty

title: Judge Is Ready, Prosecutor Is Not, Case Dismissed
description: When the O. J. Simpson case ended, critics said it had lasted far too long. But what will they say about the case of Aubrey Lindo?

title: Dianne Acuna and Gabriel Garcia
description: Dr. Dianne Silvia Acuna and Gabriel Henry Garcia are to be married today. The Rev. John A. DeBellis is to perform the ceremony at Our Lady Queen of Peace Roman Catholic Church in New Dorp, Staten Island.

title: Wiseguys, Boss Talk and a Stand-up Granny
description: The 1976 funeral of the legendary underworld boss Carlo Gambino was closed to the press, but Jerry Capeci was there. He slipped into the Brooklyn church through a side door and walked out with the mourners and a story. A few years later, Mr. Capeci made the mob his beat. His Gang Land column in The Daily News, which ran from 1989 through August 1995, was a must read for many New Yorkers, including members of the Genovese, Gambino, Colombo, Lucchese and Bonnano families.

title: The Second Time Around
description: The phrase ''everything old becomes new again'' rings with particular clarity in this East Side apartment in Manhattan designed by Ashkar & Paul Associates. Located in a prewar building, the apartment had been modernized and stripped of its traditional architectural ornament when it was first purchased by its current owners in the 1960's. Now that their children are grown, the couple decided to stay put instead of move and to undertake a significant renovation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREIMAN, ROBERT
description: FREIMAN-Robert, died September 3. Born in New York. Artist who studied at The Art Students' League, The National Academy of Design, Parsons School of Art, Pratt Institute, Ecole des Beaux Arts, Fontain Bleau, where he was awarded first prize by The French Republic. He was a member of The American Water Color Society, and Who's Who in American Art. Bob will be missed by many. Dr. and Mrs. Hugh Barber Molly and Bill Reed

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Pure Slaughter Value By Robert Bingham. Doubleday, $21.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STICHNOTH, JOHN A.
description: STICHNOTH-John A., of North Palm Beach and Ridgefield, CT. On October 1, 1997 in Danbury, CT. Husband of Patricia (nee Miller) Stichnoth. Funeral on Tuesday at 10:30 AM, at St. Mary's Church, Ridgefield, Connecticut. For more information Kane Funeral Home, Ridgefield, CT.

title: Nurse Practitioners Can't Take Place of Doctors; Good Care vs. No Care
description: To the Editor:

title: 49ers Regain Their Edge, and They Intend to Keep It
description: Before reporters were allowed into the Carolina locker room after the Panthers were blown out by the San Francisco 49ers on Monday night, it was a highly emotional scene. Many players were angry, cursing not at anyone in particular, just out loud. Some tossed items around the room. Coach Dom Capers told the team that each player would have to look himself in the mirror and figure out what he could do to change the team's fortunes.

title: A Tarnished Yonkers Survives but Finds That It Still Suffers
description: STILL licking its wounds from the past, this aging metropolis continues to suffer from a bruised public image -- earned in part from years of rancor over a federally mandated integration order, decades of failure to control its municipal finances and a long line of ill-fated mayors.

title: Karen Body, Edward Brennan
description: Karen Elizabeth Body, a daughter of Barbara and Louis F. Body 4th of Plandome, N.Y., was married yesterday in Manhasset, N.Y., to Edward Michael Brennan, a son of Margaret D. Brennan of St. Louis and the late Donald C. Brennan. The Rev. James B. Only, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the Congregational Church of Manhasset.

title: Classics All Over
description: For four days, the streets of Rockefeller Center were covered in gray carpeting for the second annual Louis Vuitton Classic, a display of 49 exotic antique passenger cars and racing cars. Early in the century, the automobile show ranked with the horse show and opera events that opened the social and fashion season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLVEK, SIDNEY
description: WOLVEK-Sidney, 74. Died on October 2, 1997. Loving husband of Irma and surived by sons Joseph and Ethan. He was a hero to his family, and his remarkable life was an inspiration to everyone who knew him. Donations in lieu of flowers should be made to Cornell New York Hospital or a charity of your choice. Services will be on Sunday at 4 PM at Temple Beth Emeth, 83 Marlborough Road at Church Ave., Brooklyn.

title: Maya Rutherford, Peter Baran
description: Maya Virginia Rutherford, a daughter of Toni P. Lucey and the stepdaughter of Dr. Denis J. Lucey 3d of Chestnut Hill, Pa., was married there yesterday to Peter Baran, the son of Ivan Baran of Toronto and the late Anna Baran. The Rev. Robert L. Tate, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Martin-in-the-Fields.

title: A Doctor's Insight Into H.M.O.'s
description: My heart goes out to Sarah Hartmann, who describes the tragic circumstances under which the death of her newborn was made so much worse by the insensitivity of the H.M.O. [''Who Protects Us From H.M.O.'s?'' Sept. 21]. In my practice of obstetrics and gynecology, I see similar situations rather frequently.

title: Sept. 28-Oct. 4; Reno Sees No Evidence Of Clinton Wrongdoing
description: Attorney General Janet Reno said she had found no evidence that President Clinton misused his office to raise money, improperly allowed contributors to stay overnight at the White House or sought contributions in exchange for favors. In a letter to Republican lawmakers, Ms. Reno presented the Justice Department's most detailed report of its inquiry into campaign finance abuses.

title: Governments vs. Journalists; Latin News Media, Hard-Pressed
description: NINE months after the gruesome murder here of a news photographer who was investigating police corruption, thousands of angry Argentines continue to wear black ribbons and hold rallies in bitter commemoration.

title: A Director Who Dropped Out Drops Back In
description: THE VERTIGINOUSLY ANGLED road rising from the rain forest to the top of a hill known as 210 is open only to four-wheel-drive vehicles. Below, signs beside streams warn of crocodiles.

title: Those Were The Days . . .
description: AS years go, 1977 was a pretty good one in Connecticut. The economic outlook was so bright that some workers, sure they could always find a job elsewhere, went on strike to get more of a piece of the pie. Teachers in Waterbury and Greenwich walked picket lines, musicians struck the Hartford Symphony, gravediggers held up picket signs at Catholic cemeteries.

title: As Ceilings Leak, Tenants' Ownership Dreams Turn Dark
description: When Evan Spencer, a technician at New York Blood Services, and his wife, Damaris, an emergency service technician, moved into a two-bedroom apartment in the Frederick E. Samuel Houses in 1995, they thought it was a dream come true.

title: L.I. Vinves
description: Chardonnay Siblings

title: Pioneer in the Nuclear Age, and in Its Steep Decline
description: WHEREVER America is going, Connecticut often seems to get there first, and that includes nuclear technology. The state was one of the first to jump in, and now seems on its way to being one of the first out.

title: One Hundred Years of Adolescence
description: THE BODY PROJECT

title: A Bit of Country Amid the Condos
description: IN the 50's, when I first moved to Westport, the moving vans had scarcely pulled away when the telephone rang and I was asked to participate in a writers versus artists basketball game to benefit the March of Dimes.

title: How the Towns View Changes to Route 25A
description: FOR decades, bounded by long empty stretches of farmland to the south and hilly residential communities to the north, the two-lane road that made up Route 25A from Mount Sinai through Rocky Point provided a pleasant ride after leaving the hustle and bustle farther west. But development of farmland and housing began to put a strain on the road. Nowhere was this felt more acutely than in Rocky Point, where residents essentially have only one north-south route available.

title: Reno's Off-and-On Mood for Counsel Is Off Again
description: For Democrats and Republicans, when it comes to the appointment of an independent counsel, where you stand can depend on where you sit.

title: Upscale Tastes Demand Quality, and Restaurants Raise Sights
description: DURING the last two decades, the county's population has exploded, and restaurants have multiplied rapidly to appease the appetites of those who have arrived with different, often sophisticated tastes.

title: The Feel of Africa in a Market
description: Cars brake, necks crane, eyes peel, as passers-by take in the sight of a woman standing outside a store on Fourth Avenue. The woman is tall. She is voluptuous. She is wearing a low-cut dress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARK, SYLVIA
description: CLARK-Sylvia. Passed away in the home she loved on Oct. 1, 1997. A brilliant and vibrant woman of the highest moral integrity whose grace, beauty, dignity and dedication to her family shall always be with us. Beloved wife of Ronald H. Clark. Devoted mother and best friend of Alice M. Clark. Cherished mother-in-law of Dr. Peter B. Schiff. Adored grandmother of Sarah Clark Schiff and Jenny Clark Schiff. Dear youngest child of the late Sarah and Marcus Buller. Loving sister of Joseph Buller and the late Frances Weiner. Fond sisterin-law of Ann Buller. May the memory be green. For funeral service information contact the John J. Fox Funeral Home, 914-834-0144.

title: Keyboard Virtuoso
description: No two pianos sound exactly alike, but appearance is quite another matter. Consider the classic grand -- substantial yet sensual, with a curvaceous lid and a lustrous case poised on three sturdy legs. For more than a century, this has been the standard-bearer, the masterstroke, the music-lover's version of the Model T -- available in any color you want as long as it's black.

title: Allison Baird, Stewart Lewack
description: Allison Virginia Baird, the daughter of Prof. and Mrs. James C. Baird of Foster, R.I., was married yesterday to Stewart Allen Lewack, a son of Maxine G. Lewack of Silver Spring, Md., and the late Harold I. Lewack. The Rev. Daniel Burke, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Stone House Club in Little Compton, R.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBMAN, CHARLES J.
description: LIEBMAN-Charles J., a scholar, author and collector, died on September 24, 1997. He was 87 years old. Mr. Liebman attended Harvard College and subsequently moved to Paris to study at the Ecole des Hautes Etudes. He received his diploma after submitting a thesis entitled ''La Vie Prose de St. Denys''. Mr. Liebman's publications include numerous articles on medieval literature and a book regarding the life of Simon de Tournai. He was often consulted by the Morgan Library to assist in the identification of manuscripts in its possession. He collected rare maps of Paris, which he exhibited at the Grolier Club, of which he was a member. Mr. Liebman is survived by his loving sister, Margaret L. Berger and brother-inlaw, Adolph R. Berger, M.D.

title: 'Dave Who?' Goes to Washington
description: TO a man who has given almost 30 years of his life to teaching history in a community college in this battered and struggling city and preaching the relevance of the humanities for these two-year institutions that are stigmatized by some academicians as merely trade schools, receiving an award from the President of the United States was something David A. Berry never would have dared to imagine.

title: Backtalk; Another Barrier That Fell 50 Years Ago Is Recalled
description: A half century later, Harvard teammates clearly recall the day when Chester Pierce made history on a hostile football field in Charlottesville, Va. Pierce remembers that autumn afternoon, too. But as the eye of a storm that attracted national attention 50 years ago this week, the soft-spoken Long Island native shrugs off his niche.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; Be Patient, And I'll Be A Loyal Customer
description: OTOBER is Brain Injury Awareness Month, but I do not need a calendar to be aware of the devastating impact of this often invisible injury. Ever since a BMW crashed into my Chevrolet in June 1994, I have been trying to take back my life.

title: Lives; Wait Till Next Year
description: When my mother died, our house seemed to shrink around us, one room after another disappearing as my father found himself unable to endure the porch where he and my mother had shared cocktails every evening, unwilling to eat in the breakfast nook where their day had begun, incapable of sleeping in the bedroom where she had died. My father's depression left him no choice but to sell our house as quickly as possible.

title: On Our Own Two Feet; A Random Guide To Saving Soles
description: For a state with more than 6 million cars, New Jerseyans spend a lot of time on their feet. Here's a guide on how to pamper them and have some fun, too. (An introduction appears on Page 1.)

title: Mignon Loh, Michael Vostrejs
description: Dr. Mignon Lee-Cheun Loh, a pediatrician, and Dr. Michael Vostrejs, an orthopedic surgeon, were married yesterday in New York at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. The Rev. Timothy S. Valentine, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Young People and Smoking
description: How would you suggest discouraging young people from smoking?

title: For Big Game at R.F.K., Jamaicans Had More Drive Than Yanks
description: THEY came roaring down Interstate 95, an armored division of cars and vans, proudly bearing the green and yellow markings of the Jamaican flag. They drove hard, they drove fast, they drove purposefully. And so did their soccer team.

title: New Party Embraces Perot's Message, Not Perot
description: They helped Ross Perot start his political organization, United We Stand America. They went door-to-door for him in 1992 and suffered for him again in 1996. For 2000, they will have another horse.

title: 64 Marriage Proposals
description: To the Editor:

title: One Family's Unabashed Joy Of Living Well in the County
description: THE Alkalays, Florence and Peter, are celebrating their 20th anniversary -- not of their marriage but of their lives in the county. Like many who call Westchester home, they came from the Bronx seeking green grass, good schools and a safe environment for their children.

title: Lucinda Williams Is in Pain
description: Suburban Connecticut at 6:30 on a Saturday morning is about as far from a late-night Los Angeles recording studio as you can get. But Darcy Frey's profile ''Lucinda Williams Is in Pain'' (Sept. 14) put me there. While news of yet another delay in the release of her new album wasn't a great way to start the day, the insights into why were. So we'll wait and appreciate it all the more when she's decided she's happy with it.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE BLUE SUIT: A Memoir of Crime

title: Miss Alexandre, Mr. Jacobsen
description: Margaret Mary Alexandre, a founding partner of Renaissance Fund Advisors in New York, was married yesterday to Richard Carl Jacobsen Jr., a director in the investment banking division at Salomon Brothers in New York. The Rev. Joseph Bonadio performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of Mary Our Queen in Baltimore.

title: I've Been Very Bad
description: It's no secret that the confessional writing trend -- sparked by memoirs like ''The Kiss,'' Kathryn Harrison's story of her sexual affair with her father -- has writers everywhere hurling skeletons out of their closets. But now, with the publication of ''Close to the Bone: Memoirs of Hurt, Rage and Desire'' from Grove Press, the fashionable literary form has soared to new heights -- or, depending on your point of view, plunged to new depths. Among the anthology's eight nonfiction tales are accounts of whipping, homeless crack addiction and incest between a brother and sister. It sounds like Sally Jessy Raphael stuff, but Grove is giving it a Charlie Rose spin.

title: 'The Swimmer,' 1997: A Suburban Update
description: Swim home across Westchester from pool to shining pool? That was the goal in ''The Swimmer'' by the Pulitzer Prize-winning author John Cheever, America's most famous chronicler of suburban life. His son, Benjamin Cheever, puts a '97 spin on the short story.

title: Hilary Harlow, Harry P. Tower
description: Hilary Lee Harlow and Harry Payne Tower were married yesterday in Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Dr. David Johnson Rowe performed the ceremony at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church.

title: Feasting Stem to Stern
description: DINING aboard ship is becoming more inventive these days as vessels offer passengers a choice of restaurants, a variety of cuisines, and different kiosks, counters and corners for wine tasting, caviar sampling, coffee comparison and bites of pizza, pastry and ice cream.

title: On the Road Again
description: PILGRIMS By Elizabeth Gilbert. 210 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $22.

title: Corporate News, Quickly
description: To the Editor:

title: Echoes From Tennessee Williams
description: BLANCHE lives.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; What Rough Beast?
description: It's late in 1999, 33 years after the birth of the son of Satan in ''Rosemary's Baby,'' and somewhere, if he still lives, the child has reached the traditional age of Christ at His crucifixion. But this is not the first thought that occurs to his mother. As Ira Levin's latest novel, SON OF ROSEMARY (Dutton, $22.95), begins, Rosemary herself is miraculously emerging from the coma she has been in for 27 years, struggling to understand the world into which she has been reborn, a world where virtually the entire population sports ''I k Andy'' buttons. Yes, it turns out, this Andy is her Andy, the demonic son who was taken from her so many years earlier. But why all the adoration? Isn't he still a prisoner of evil? Or has he really become the incarnation of good? Cleverly, in this sequel to his best seller of three decades ago, Levin leaves such questions hanging. When she and Andy are finally reunited, Rosemary helps her son to prepare for the global lighting of candles with which he and his organization, God's Children, will greet the millennium, and ''I k Rosemary'' buttons also begin to appear. But, disturbingly, Rosemary notes that Andy sometimes demonstrates incestuous feelings, and his eyes occasionally take on the satanic cast she remembers so vividly from his childhood. Is her son leading humanity toward extinction or rebirth? All these things are not quite resolved in an ambiguous, not entirely satisfying conclusion. James Polk

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: YANKESS -- 6

title: Christopher McKee, Elizabeth Sloane
description: Elizabeth Ann Sloane, a daughter of Alison S. Tress of Rydal, Pa., and Robert G. Sloane of Ambler, Pa., was married last evening to Christopher Scott McKee, a son of Margo and Gerald McKee of New York. Rabbi William I. Kuhn performed the ceremony at the Rittenhouse Hotel in Philadelphia.

title: Savor That Bank Bill. You Might Be Paying for It.
description: If you were certain your bank was charging you for every service possible, think again. Customers who renew safe-deposit boxes at Chase Manhattan Bank may have to pay a $5 ''invoice processing fee'' if they do not have an account with the bank.

title: Survivors of the Cold War
description: Underworld By Don DeLillo. 827 pp. New York: Scribner. $27.50.

title: Women on the Tightrope: Two Views
description: ''I SUPPOSE a lot of chief executives can find a way to balance work and family, but I couldn't figure out how to do it,'' Brenda Barnes said recently, announcing that she was quitting as chief of Pepsico's North American beverage empire.

title: You Can't Get Here From There
description: California's Over

title: Keys, Lots And Lots Of Keys
description: SEVERAL recent photographs showed my body leaning slightly to starboard, like a badly loaded cargo ship. What could be the problem? Osteoporosis? Brain damage brought on by the new television season? My doctor reassured me that it was nothing serious. ''It's just the keys,'' he pointed out. And, indeed, hanging from my belt was a bunch of keys that might have belonged to a medieval dungeon guard. These keys, like gray hairs, just crept up on me.

title: Messy Free-Market Plunge Rattling China's Businesses
description: Lu Yaqin cheerfully admits that, for a chairwoman of the board, she does not know much about business.

title: Off the Spike and Onto the Stage, an O'Neill Reject
description: THE OPPORTUNITY TO attend the American premiere of an unknown play by Eugene O'Neill would tantalize even the casual theatergoer. Ivo van Hove, the Belgian director of ''More Stately Mansions,'' opening Tuesday at New York Theater Workshop, understands this: ''People from your country naturally want to see this play. O'Neill is America's Shakespeare. This is very clear.''

title: The Problem: Getting There From Here
description: OF all the projects and programs aimed at improving transportation in Connecticut over the past 20 years, the single most important event came by way of accident, a tragic one. It happened on June 28, 1983. At 1:30 A.M. that day a 100-foot northbound section of the Mianus River Bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike collapsed. Three people died and three more were injured as vehicles plunged into the shallow river in Greenwich.

title: Mary Petersen And Paul Asel
description: Mary LeGrand Petersen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Petersen of Fairfax, Va., was married there yesterday to Paul Jonathan Asel, a son of the Rev. Virginia E. Asel of Royalston, Mass., and the Rev. David Asel of Goffstown, N.H. The Rev. Martyn Minns performed the ceremony at Truro Episcopal Church. The Rev. Robert W. Prichard, the bride's cousin who is an Episcopal priest, took part in the service.

title: Serious Crime Has Declined For Fifth Year, F.B.I. Says
description: Serious crime fell 3 percent in 1996, its fifth consecutive annual decline, led by a 9 percent decrease in murders, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported yesterday.

title: Accounting for Taste
description: For a long time now, connoisseurship has had a bad rap. The conscious pursuit of beauty and taste, elevated to the status of a quasi- or pseudo-science, has become increasingly disdained as inimical to both intellectual and socially progressive values. By a curious but by no means incomprehensible turn of events, quality has come to be seen as a code word for oppression, and beauty as a pernicious bourgeois scam. But why? What's wrong with liking and promoting what's good? Just because you fancy Chinese-export porcelain, does that mean you condone the excesses of the Opium War? You may love El Greco, but do you love the Inquisition? Sargent's brush strokes are divine, but don't those rich people he painted still make you sick?

title: Working Woman
description: MEMOIRS OF A GEISHA By Arthur Golden. 434 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: An Olympian Effort by LaFontaine
description: Had Pat LaFontaine chosen the easy road, he could have accepted the warnings of skeptical doctors, taken early retirement and cashed nearly $10 million worth of paychecks over the next two years for sitting around and doing absolutely nothing. To an average citizen, this would be like winning the local lottery. What would be left to discuss?

title: Holocaust Apologies
description: To the Editor:

title: Capitalism With A Vengeance
description: BILL BROWDER started buying Russian stocks before there was a stock market here. It was 1993, the year President Boris N. Yeltsin defeated Communist hard-liners by shelling the Parliament. Industrial output was collapsing; inflation was rampant.

title: Waldo's Easy. Where's Turandot?
description: THE METROPOLITAN OPERA HAS TWO seasons. One is about opera. The other is about the opera stage. Puccini's ''Turandot'' provided opening night for the second category on Monday. Somewhere in the house that night an opera, and a rich and stageworthy one at that, was going on. It really didn't matter, though. All the glitter and grandiosity descending over it made certain that music wouldn't get in the way of an evening's entertainment.

description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

description: State officials say they see worrisome signs that some health insurance companies are circumventing a new law intended to make coverage more readily available to millions of Americans who change or lose their jobs.

description: Clutching hands and standing in a tight cluster, six men who are among the hundreds of thousands who came here today for a Christian rally bowed their heads as their Congressman, Representative David M. McIntosh, led them in prayer on the floor of the House of Representatives.

description: Jason Sehorn never minded the duct tape that held his shoes together from month to month in grammar school.

description: The jukebox is boxed and the book jackets are scattered. A few shy volumes of literature are stacked on the bar, but toward the back are two machines that look suspiciously like video games. There's still plenty of booze, to be sure, but not a lion of any shape or size in sight.

Memorial services will be at Brooks School on Saturday, November 1, 1997, at 11:00 AM and at the Chapel of St Bartholomew's Church, Park Ave at 51st St, New York City, on Monday, November 3, 1997, 2:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to The Ashburn Chair, Brooks School, N. Andover, MA 01845. Information: the Holden-Westwood Funeral Home, Westwood, MA.

description: The San Francisco Giants, gone so quickly they were hardly noticed, were the season's most surprisingly good team that reached the playoffs. The Detroit Tigers and the Pittsburgh Pirates were the most surprising teams that didn't.

title: Natalie Williams, Erik Umlauf
description: Natalie Renee Williams, the daughter of Jacqueline and Nathaniel Williams of Brooklyn, was married on Friday to Erik Umlauf, a son of Dr. Eva Umlauf of Munich and Dr. Bernd Umlauf of Paris.

description: NERODA-Walter. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Walter Neroda, associated with The Times from 1977, until retiring in 1993.

title: Taking a Window Box From Fall to Frost
description: Autumn is a challenging moment for all horticultural pursuits. Most summer bloomers have grown tattered and weary, while many tender annuals perish at the first tinge of frost. It's a tough time for borders, to be sure, but it's a worse moment for window boxes. There they sit, front and center, the object of your neighbors' constant scrutiny.

description: Whatever happened to gloomy Gus, the downcast brother of Fred Opper's 1904 cartoon character, Happy Hooligan?

title: From Subs to Casinos, an Economic Upheaval
description: IF one were to compress the last 20 years of the the state's economy into just two points on a time line -- 1977 leaping directly across the years to 1997 -- the result would look as placid as the Connecticut River in October, taking its own sweet time, going nowhere in particular.

description: For a state with more than 6 million cars, New Jerseyans spend a lot of time on their feet. Here's a guide on how to pamper them and have some fun, too. (An introduction appears on Page 1.)

title: City Bus Kills Teen-Ager Riding Bicycle in Bronx
description: A city bus struck and killed a 17-year-old youth riding his bicycle in the Longwood section of the Bronx yesterday evening, the police said. The teen-ager, George Losada, was riding beside the bus on Westchester Avenue near Faile Street when he was hit at 6:53 P.M., the police said.

description: MATINECOCK is not exactly a household word to Long Islanders, much less so to those outside the region. Nestled north of 25A, bordered by Glen Cove, Mill Neck and Locust Valley, the incorporated village of Matinecock is home to fewer than 900 residents who live in expansive houses on at least five acres of land, imperceptibly cloistered several hundred feet from the road.

description: Those who find it hard to follow the intricacies of NATO expansion and peace in Bosnia will be glad to know that these two preoccupations of American foreign policy are about to be welded together to form an even more complicated mosaic. By chance and circumstance, NATO's plan to expand eastward may well rise or fall on developments in Bosnia over the next nine months.

title: Park Warily Tends a Wound
description: For the last two years there has been a tall chain link fence cutting a 20-acre patch of woodlands off from the rest of Prospect Park. The fence curves around a pond at the eastern end of the park's much-used Long Meadow and it has been tempting people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENSTEIN, ROY
description: LICHTENSTEIN-Roy, I had a friend, just the other day, my friend Roy, he died today. Where will you plot next? In New York City he passed away. Center of POP for you and me. I'll be there; will U2? In the city; glorious lights. Mondrian's Broadway; city delights. Have a cup of coffee; it's all I can offer, to a god of pop. A god of pop. D.G. Harth. 1245am 9-30-97.

description: Sheila Mara Concannon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Concannon of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joseph Taylor Melvin 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin S. Melvin of Greensboro, N.C. Msgr. James P. Cassidy performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.
