description: SIEGEL-Jeffrey Irwin. 10/6/54. You are our shining star. The years go on but not a day goes by without thoughts of you. We love and miss you. Happy Birthday. Mom, Deb and Susan

title: From Peace Process To Police Process
description: One does not have to be an admirer of Yasir Arafat or Jibril Rajoub to predict that should they be removed from the scene, they will almost instantly be mourned by right-wing Israelis and American friends of Israel as martyrs (''From Peace Process to Police Process,'' by Jeffrey Goldberg, Sept. 14). Their demise will be invoked to prove that any Arab who accepts coexistence with Israel will be eliminated by their Arab brethren. They will become just one more piece of evidence that peace with the Arabs is impossible.

title: The Educated Eye
description: In design, as in so many other endeavors, you get what you pay for. That is not to say that good design can't be affordable, but when it comes to quality craftsmanship and materials, the price tag invariably creeps (or races) upward. Whether it's a plaster wall, fine cabinetry or luxurious furnishings, there's a certain level of solidity, finish and visual and tactile richness that, more often than not, usually only money can buy. The interiors shown in this issue all express a common aspiration, by their designers and architects, to create work that is better than just O.K. These are spaces that are meant to wear well, to keep their good looks 20 years from now. They offer examples of how proportion, light, detail, color and texture affect the way it feels to be in a room. And for those who are working without a designer, these lessons are all the more valuable. If these rooms are beyond the reach of many, does it really matter? Would those of us who love paintings bypass the Rembrandts or Matisses in a museum because we could never afford to buy one?

title: In the Region/Westchester; A Supermarket for Struggling Hartsdale Downtown
description: THE long-awaited opening of a new supermarket, a needed anchor to this hamlet's struggling downtown, is scheduled today on East Hartsdale Avenue. It promises to enliven a shopping district that has lost much of its vitality because of chronic vacancies.

title: Europe Heads a Very Short List Of Foreign Investment Prospects
description: INVESTORS looking to diversify abroad from pricey American stock markets face an ever bigger quandary: The places most insulated from a downturn in this country are places you may not want to send your money.

title: Averting Strike, Orchestra Ratifies Chicago Contract
description: The musicians of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra voted unanimously this morning to accept the terms of a new three-year contract. They had been working without a contract since Sept. 14, when the old one expired.

title: The Boy Who Gave Away the Bomb
description: The article relates that Hall was ''a conscience-driven idealist'' who ''worried about the dangers of an American monopoly of atomic weapons'' in the postwar world. His passing to Soviet agents of a diagram of the bomb and the triggering device was of inestimable value to the Soviets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUNNINGHAM, RUNDLES, MARY ALICE
description: CUNNINGHAM-RUNDLES-Mary Alice. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family notes with sadness the passing of Mary Alice Cunningham - Rundles, beloved mother of our dear friend and colleague, Ward Cunningham Rundles, M.D., longtime member of the medical staff at our North Division. To Ward, and his family, our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President Martin Feuer, M.D. Associate Chairman, Medicine Ruth E. Hennessey Vice President, Operations North Division

title: Fordham Literally Punts One Away to Brown
description: Two punts that were blocked and returned for touchdowns, and one that was botched, all within nine minutes of the third period, shattered Fordham's hopes and eased the way for a 45-14 victory by Brown yesterday at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx.

title: Plaza in Kansas City Is Expanding Within
description: FOR 75 years, residents and countless visitors have enjoyed a 15-square-block midtown enclave of upscale shops and restaurants known as ''the Plaza,'' where wide sidewalks, small bridges, trees, fountains and statuary invite strolling, hand-holding and splurging.

title: The Big Picture, on Small Disks as Well as Large
description: JUST WHEN YOU THOUGHT IT WAS safe to buy a digital video disk player, along comes an ominous mutant called Digital Video Express, and the home entertainment waters are churning again. Digital Video Express signals an aggressive effort to propel the DVD into the consumer mainstream: indeed, to establish it as the successor to VHS tape in the hearts of movie renters everywhere. Unfortunately, the proposed system, expected to reach stores next spring, is incompatible with existing DVD players.

title: New Releases
description: BJORK: 'HOMOGENIC'

title: Ideas & Trends; Sullen Got Old. The Attitude Now Is Fabulous.
description: DOWN through the decades, advertising and popular culture have defined happiness as a warm puppy, the taste of Kent cigarettes and a thing called Joe. Now it appears happiness is a thing that's back in a big way.

title: 'The Brady Bunch' No More: Families Grow Less Traditional
description: TWENTY years ago, the term working mother was still new. Phrases like latch-key children and having it all were also popular. There were few offerings like Mommy and Me classes because few parents wanted to pay for scheduled play time with their toddler. Parking was no problem for Metro-North commuters since a system known as ''kiss and ride'' predominated, in which a wife dropped off her husband at the station, then left with the family station wagon.

title: Monkey Business
description: SUMMER FOR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFER, GEORGE, M.D.
description: SCHAEFER-George, M.D. Age 84, died peacefully at home on Sept. 27. Beloved husband of Shirley, father of Jay and Michael, grandfather of Daniel and Julia, brother of Minnie Reiter. He graduated Phi Beta Kappa from NYU and Cornell University Medical College in 1937, and was an Attending Physician and on the faculty of Cornell-New York Hospital from 1951 to 1978. He moved to San Diego, was appointed Director of Residency Teaching Program in Obstetrics at Mercy Hospital. He was one of the foremost authorities on tuberculosis in OB/GYN. Author of many articles and books, including ''The Expectant Father.'' Rememberd with love and admiration.

title: F.Y.I.
description: The Islamic Angle

title: Ideas & Trends; The Blacklist Era Won't Fade to Black
description: THE blacklist still torments Hollywood.

title: Safety Zone
description: To the Editor: I think airports should paint a three-foot-wide yellow line and crosshatched area around baggage-claim conveyor belts. People would be expected to stand back from the belt until their bags were in front of them, when they could step forward into the no-standing zone and grab their bags. At present when everyone crowds up, it is hard to see and seize your bag. Small children should not be allowed to stand next to the belt; one risks hurting them when pulling a heavy bag off the belt.

title: Ohio State Stops Iowa And Banks
description: Tavian Banks ran into a wall today. From the first loud, yardless carry in Ohio Stadium, the leading rusher in the nation and his Iowa Hawkeye teammates lost the hope of an undefeated season and the credibility they had built on imposing, but empty, statistics.

title: Bus Driver Transferred To Undergo More Tests
description: The driver of the bus that killed a pedestrian and critically injured a bicyclist on Fifth Avenue on Thursday was transferred from Bellevue Hospital Center to another hospital Friday evening to undergo additional tests that investigators hope will reveal what caused him to lose control of his vehicle.

title: Older Faces Affect Colleges
description: WITH substantially smaller enrollments, more homogeneous student bodies and, in many cases less modern campuses, the college landscape of a generation ago was significantly different from today's. Many programs that have become entrenched as institutions at various colleges did not exist or were in their infancy. Demographic and social changes, including an overall shrinking traditional college population and the return of women to both college and the work force, transformed the county's colleges.

title: Streetscapes/78th Street Between Amsterdam Avenue and Broadway; 1887 Property Restriction Gives Block a Rare Charm
description: WHEN the architect Andrew Tesoro, president of the co-op at 210 West 78th Street, designed a decorative sidewalk and planting area in front of his 1925 building, he didn't think much about its peculiar five-foot setback from the normal building line. Indeed every building on the block is set five feet back, giving the street a rare charm -- the result of an unusual property restriction 110 years old.

title: Peter Serkin, Following His Own Path
description: MOST interviews with Peter Serkin note that he rarely grants interviews. (Obviously he does, though he would rather be practicing.) They often make mention of his satisfying present life, now that he is acknowledged as a pianist unsurpassed in the wide-ranging repertory he embraces, and is happily married with a houseful of children.

title: An Education Source On the Holocaust
description: ''Holocaust Memorials Multiplying on Island'' [Sept. 21] featured the efforts of many organizations that foster ''a greater understanding of the causes and consequences of one of the darkest periods in history.''

description: INTERNATIONAL 3-16

description: Pamela Ross is a pianist, an actress and a playwright who lives in TriBeCa. Her most recent work is a live concert video seen on the ''Virtuoso Pianist'' series on the Arts and Entertainment cable network.

description: When former President Ronald Reagan disclosed in November 1994 that he had Alzheimer's disease, many people could not help suspecting that the illness had begun to rob him of memory while he was in the White House.

description: To the Editor:

title: Emerging From Chaos, Blue-Chip Paragons
description: DESPITE Russia's well-earned reputation for companies run like gangster fiefs, a small but growing number of blue-chip concerns now embrace ideas like shareholder rights, open disclosure and bottom-line management.

title: Correction
description: An article on Sept. 21 about scholarly speculation on the sexual orientation of the German poet Goethe referred incorrectly to Christiane Vulpius, one of his lovers. Goethe met her in Weimar, Germany, not in Rome.

title: The Giuliani-Steinbrenner Ticket?
description: IF the election were held this Tuesday, I would vote for Ruth Messinger for mayor because she stood up to George Steinbrenner and said she would not spend a penny on a new stadium for the Yankees without a public referendum. The moment Ms. Messinger rejected Mr. Steinbrenner's long-running, free-floating ransom note, I was on her team, shouting that this could be the Ruth to free the city from being held hostage in the House that the Other Ruth Built. I even had a new campaign slogan: ''Two Sluggers for New York, Babe Ruth and Ruth Babe.''

title: John Tesh
description: John Tesh's 15th album, ''Sax All Night,'' is due this week.

title: Is This Karaoke? Is 'Godzilla' Art?
description: THE tune may be familiar but the words have been changed to confuse the innocent.

title: Opening Night

Or at the very least, a worthwhile investment in the eyes of his boss, the most rabid of talk radio Yankee callers.

title: Three Different Pathways To the City's Waterfront
description: New York's waterfront has long inspired dreamers and schemers, with visions small and grand. Yet the waterways that surround the city and have shaped its development now seem strangely removed from the daily lives of most New Yorkers. In ''The New York Waterfront,'' Kevin Bone has collected essays and historical photographs and drawings, ''so that the lessons of the past can inform decisions about the future.'' JoAnne Abel Goldman's research on ''everything and anything that went into the Hudson River'' led her to write ''Building New York's Sewers.'' Francisco Goldman's novel ''The Ordinary Seaman'' offers a different view of the waterfront through the story of Esteban, a 19-year-old veteran of the war in Nicaragua who is stuck, more or less, on a rusting, stateless ship in Brooklyn.

title: VIEWPOINT; Selling the Free-Trade Story
description: NOW that the battle over the so-called fast-track legislation is fully engaged in Washington, proponents of further trade liberalization should reflect on the effectiveness of their arguments.

title: Singles
description: HERMITS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSAFT, DR. HADASSAH BIMKO
description: ROSENSAFT-Dr. Hadassah Bimko. October 3, 1997. On Friday night after Rosh Hashanah, surrounded by her children and granddaughter, our beloved, heroic, unique Hadassah left us at the age of 85 after a valiant battle with liver failure resulting from malaria and hepatitis she contracted at Auschwitz. After saving the lives of hundreds of Jews at Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen, and keeping alive 149 Jewish children at Belsen, she organized and led the efforts to restore to health the liberated Jews of Belsen. One of the earliest leaders of the survivors of the Holocaust together with her late and unforgettable husband Yossel, she was the principal witness for the prosecution at the first war crimes trial of the German murderers apprehended at Belsen. She served as head of the Health Department of the Jewish Committee of Belsen and the Central Commitee of Jews in the British Zone of Germany. She was a member of President Carter's Commission on the Holocaust and one of the founding members of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, where she served until 1994 as Chair of the Archives Committee and on the Executive Committee. She was the honorary President of the World Federation of BergenBelsen Survivors. The beloved mother of Menachem and Jeanie and devoted, cherished grandmother of Jodi, she will live in our hearts forever. Services Monday, 12 noon, Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 E. 87th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Dr. Hadassah Bimko Rosensaft Memorial Fund of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington, DC.

title: The Public Schools Struggle to Survive
description: PUBLIC schools in Connecticut went through a wrenching period of change during the last two decades, in terms of financing, standards required of teachers and students, and inequities between rich and poor districts.

Backs were pounded after the hero this time, Devon White, had pounded a ball into the chill air for a grand slam. But the Florida Marlins knew they would be judged on what lay ahead, not what was behind.

title: . . . But Is Lowest In Suicide Rate
description: New Jersey has the lowest suicide rate of any state, according to a recent study of mortality rates by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. New Jersey residents commit suicide at an annual rate of 6.8 for each 100,000 people, the study found, far below the rate in Nevada, the state with the highest rate at 22.2 per 100,000. Thirty states have suicide rates between 11 and 14; the Northeast is lowest of the regions.

title: REAGAN'S TWILIGHT -- A special report.; A President Fades Into a World Apart
description: In February of last year, George P. Shultz went to visit his old boss, Ronald Reagan, at the former President's home in the Bel Air neighborhood of Los Angeles. He drank tea with Mr. Reagan and his wife, Nancy, and talked a little politics. In all, he stayed perhaps an hour.

title: O'Neill's Grand Slam Powers the Yanks to the Brink of Advancing
description: Paul O'Neill shouted ''Get out! Get out!'' and flailed his arms forward to try to nudge the ball over the center-field fence as he ran toward first base. O'Neill stayed focused on the ball that was about to become a grand slam, but it did not need extra guidance. It left Jacobs Field, and now the Yankees are one victory away from leaving here with their invitation to the American League Championship Series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, ROBERT
description: MORRIS-Robert. Age 85. Of West Palm Beach, formerly of Great Neck, New York. Passed away on September 28, 1997 after a short illness. Survivors include his wife Mildred M. Morris, children Bernard, Marthe and Barbara and 4 grandchildren. He was a practicing attorney in New York City for over 50 years. He was very active in social and community affairs in both Great Neck and West Palm Beach. He was a member of the Glen Oaks Country Club in New York and the Sherbrooke Country Club in Florida. Private services were held in West Palm Beach and a memorial service will be held at a later date.

description: THE world never came closer to nuclear war than it did 35 years ago this month in the Cuban missile crisis. Now, from transcripts of decaying tapes kept secret for decades, Americans can learn what their leaders actually said and thought while contemplating Armageddon in 1962.

title: In Hills of Pennsylvania, Lions Find Only Futility

The red- and orange-speckled foliage provides an inviting backdrop, especially on an Indian summer day. And as a bonus for visiting Columbia, Lafayette had not won in its previous four games and appeared primed to play the generous host.

title: Chris Rock Has No Time for Your Ignorance
description: Who's more racist: black people or white people? Black people. You know why? Because black people hate black people, too. Everything white people don't like about black people, black people don't like about black people. ... Every time black people want to have a good time, niggers mess it up. ... Can't keep a disco open more than three weeks. Grand opening? Grand closing. Can't go to a movie the first week it opens. Why? Because niggers are shooting at the screen. ... I know what all you black readers think. ... ''It isn't us, it's the media. The media has distorted our image to make us look bad.'' ... Please. ... When I go to the money machine at night, I'm not looking over my shoulder for the media. I'm looking for niggers. -- from ''Rock This!'' by Chris Rock

title: The Hackensack Riverkeeper: Living With Nature in the Meadowlands
description: IN the 1950's, when Bill Sheehan was growing up in Secaucus, he spent long hours crabbing, fishing, catching turtles and snakes, and watching the migrating waterfowl in the 7,000 acres of wetland along the 32 miles of the Hackensack. Now, when he isn't driving his cab, Mr. Sheehan, 48, is watching over the river, its tributaries and their great delta, the Meadowlands. He is Hackensack's Riverkeeper, one of 19 Bay and Riverkeepers designated by a national environmental alliance. ''This estuary is the home of the New York Giants,'' he says, with a nod to their arena, ''and 265 species of birds. It is a special place and worth protecting.'' Clockwise from right: Canada geese; Mr. Sheehan in his canoe; great egrets; Mr. Sheehan with Andy Wilner, a Baykeeper; and cormorants drying their wings.

These ubiquitous little vehicles are almost always equipped with a tape deck blaring out popular music, and are quite flexible about destination.

Only 30 people had called ahead to say they were coming to the breakfast for the new police commander of the 33d Precinct, Capt. Garry F. McCarthy. But more than 70 Dominican, Puerto Rican, African-American, Jewish and Irish movers and shakers in upper Manhattan were already there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, GEORGE
description: FRANK-George, 94, master wood finisher with works in the Louvre and Metropolitan Museum, died September 2 in his native Budapest, Hungary. He lived in Paris, where he established his atelier, moved to New York and founded the George Frank Cabinet Corporation. On retiring to Florida, he became Consulting Editor for ''Fine Woodworking'' magazine and published ''Adventures in Woodfinishing'' and ''Wood Finishing with George Frank'', both classics in the field. He was married to the late Catherine Hevesi and is survived by Eva Frank of Sarasota, FL, Liliane Akyali of New York City and Christine Frank Green of San Antonio, TX, five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Memorial services will be held in New York City, October 12th at the First Hungarian Reformed Church. Donations may be sent to the Dakota County Technical College, Rosemount, MN. 55068.

title: A Remarkable Deal for Wholesome Fare
description: IT is 5 P.M. on Monday and everyone at the Merrineck Shopping Center on Merrick Road in Copiague is heading in the same direction: Mama's Restaurant. Pregnant women, old men on crutches, muscular young huskies wearing tank tops and baseball caps, toddlers sucking pacifiers, clutching their mothers' hands and whole families are hustling to get on the end of a long line that is already snaking out the door at 922 Merrick Road (842-9889).

title: SUN-B-GONE
description: * Autumn is prime time for the use of eyeblack in sports: baseball players in daytime playoff games and football players put dark stuff under their eyes, supposedly to reduce glare bouncing off their cheeks. * One popular smear, called No Glare, contains crushed charcoal, paraffin, beeswax and petrolatum. * Does it do anything? Dr. Oliver Schein, an opthalmologist at Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, says, ''Probably not.'' * Even so, it's a tradition. The Pro Football Hall of Fame has a photo of the Washington Redskins fullback Andy Farkas using it way back in 1942. * Bobby Valentine, when he managed the Texas Rangers, once wore eyeblack in the dugout. * Boog Powell, the former Baltimore Orioles star, used it during his 17 years in the majors. ''I don't remember it ever doing any good,'' he says. ''But you looked cool.''

description: RETRENCHMENT dominated the debates about schools a generation ago, as districts in the county contended with declining enrollments leading to reduced teaching staffs and closed classrooms, a striking contrast to today's challenges of accommodating the surges in the student population.

title: Correction
description: The ''On the Map'' column on Sept. 21, about a first aid station in Spring Lake, misstated the number of emergency calls made yearly by the first aid squad. It is more than 900, not 400.

title: Lure of Fishing Retains Its Magical Hold
description: TROUT fishing, like mankind itself, has a long history that continues to be revised. For many years, Izaak Walton was said to be its first chronicler; his ''Compleat Angler'' was published in 1676. Then a precursor appeared, by another angler: Dame Juliana Berners had written ''A Treatyse of Fysshinge With an Angle'' almost 200 years earlier. And now there is knowledge of Aelian, A.D. 170-230, who recorded fishing in Macedonia with a curl of red wool for ''fish with speckled skins.''

title: The Nation; Why Bork Is Still a Verb In Politics, 10 Years Later
description: HE start of the Supreme Court's new term tomorrow falls on an anniversary the Justices will surely not observe, but one that should not slip by unnoticed.

title: For the Stones, New Tour Ergo New Album
description: THE ALBUM FORMAT IS A TYRANT. As the basic unit of rock marketing, and the standard since the 1960's for musicians who want to be taken seriously, the album begs to be filled, and in the CD era customers feel cheated if it holds less than an hour of music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELOACHE, NATALIE
description: DELOACHE-Natalie, in her 89th year, after a brief illness. Sister of the late, beloved Lillian Lawrence. Natalie will be remembered for her love of art, beauty and animals, and her incredible ability to ''amuse and amaze'', which stayed with her until the very end. Followed into eternity by her constant companion, Sheeba. In accordance with her wishes, there will be no service or memorial. May she rest in peace. Susie

In his six seasons as music director of the New York Philharmonic, Mr. Masur has already performed several of them prominently. And since there is not a large repertory of such works, he has had some made to order, commissioning texts from various authors.

''When rates got down to 6.30 percent, I was up 30 percent,'' said the investor, who is also editor of the Value Line Mutual Fund Survey newsletter.

title: ART; Riding Horses on the Beach, Talking Art in a Loft
description: ROY LICHTENSTEIN, WHO died on Monday at the age of 73, produced work that was more complicated than it looked, and so was he. The man now considered the father of Pop Art was affable, easygoing, and loved silly jokes; he had a keen sense of the ridiculous and could sit around and make merciless fun of the nutty things that happen and that people do. Yet he was also rather remote, with a steely intelligence, and intransigent in his commitment and work habits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORSE, ASTRITA
description: MORSE-Astrita, on October 2, 1997. Loving wife of Eanos, cherished mother of Lucian and Anna. Service Sunday 12N on October 5, Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, (76 Rd) Forest Hills, New York.

title: Leggo My Logo
description: With some 1,300 microbreweries dotting the nation, it's getting harder to name your beer without hiring a lawyer first. Take Big Sky Brewing Company, based in Missoula, Mont., which made its debut in 1995 with an ale called Whistle Pig Red. Oops. There were already two Whistling Pig microbrews on the market. Big Sky voluntarily dropped the name and introduced a brown ale called Moose Drool (label above). Oops again. Late last year, Moosehead Breweries Limited, a Canadian company, informed Big Sky that it owns the Moose family of names. It has asked the United States Patent and Trademark Office to deny Moose Drool's trademark application.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Mrs. Whaley and Her Charleston Garden

title: Cory Azumbrado and Nick Charles
description: Cory Anne Azumbrado, a daughter of Anne and John Azumbrado of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Nick Charles, a son of Rose Nickeas of Chicago, and the late John Nickeas. The Rev. Ravi K. Zacharias, an evangelical Christian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at Canoe Restaurant in Atlanta.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Spring Lake Grand-Hotel Revival Aims at the Aging
description: AFTER two and half years of legal haggling that ended in a settlement three weeks ago, plans are moving forward to redevelop the once grand Essex and Sussex Hotel, which since 1985 has sat vacant on its perch overlooking the Atlantic Ocean in the shore community of Spring Lake.

title: Uzbeks Offer Plan to End Afghan War
description: The Foreign Minister of Uzbekistan, a country that is emerging as a linchpin of United States policy in Central Asia, has devised a new proposal aimed at ending the war in Afghanistan and will present it to the United Nations on Tuesday.

title: Trying to Make It Easier
description: ROAD construction in the last 20 years in Westchester County has included developing the corporate corridor of Route 119 in Tarrytown, building on Route 120 in Purchase and widening the Taconic Parkway from Hawthorne to Millwood. The completion of the Springbrook Parkway north of I-287 in 1981 led to a decrease of traffic on Route 9A north of I-287, while the number of cars on the Bronx River Parkway increased by 12 percent.

title: Angela Sampson, Bernard Keller
description: Angela Elizabeth Sampson, a clinical social worker, and Bernard Jeffrie Keller, an English teacher, were married yesterday at the Bridge Street African Wesleyan Methodist Episcopal Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. David B. Cousin Sr. performed the ceremony.

title: Stick to the Original
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRASNOW, RALPH
description: KRASNOW-Ralph. Age 78, of Boca Raton, FL, passed away September 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Elaine. Loving father of Steven, Michael and David. Dear brother of Florence Alderman. Cherished grandfather of Chad and Evan. A longtime Flushing businessman and former President of Flushing Merchants Association. Services were held in Boca Raton, FL.

title: Altruism for Fun and Profit
description: If Pallotta wishes to use his talents to do good and become wealthy, I suggest he split his time: 57 percent to run his business promoting for-profit products and 43 percent on charitable activities for a nominal fee.

title: Call a Timeout
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Westchester Q&A: James Feron; Turning Outpost Into a Career Milestone
description: HE had covered the Six-Day War in Israel, had written about the Great Train Robbery in England and had reported on President Nixon's trip to Warsaw. After James Feron spent 12 years abroad as a foreign correspondent, editors at The New York Times felt Westchester was the perfect next destination for him. After all, Westchester County was in a way an outpost assignment -- a place where a correspondent needed to work on his own and be a self-starter who could cover a lot of territory.

title: Messinger Accuses Giuliani of Keeping Some Illegal Donations
description: Renewing her attack on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's ethics, Ruth W. Messinger plans to file a complaint with city regulators charging that Mr. Giuliani's re-election campaign has collected even more in illegal contributions than previously disclosed.

title: SEVERAL MINUTES IN TIBET
description: ''Seven Years in Tibet,'' opening this week, was shot mainly in Argentina, so if authentic backdrops are what you're after, consider ''Windhorse.'' A tiny-budget feature that portrays the political struggle of three young Tibetans living under Chinese rule, ''Windhorse'' was shot in Nepal and Tibet last year by Paul Wagner and a minuscule crew. All the actor scenes were done in Nepal, but to cop some nifty scenery, Wagner -- an Oscar-winning documentarian -- entered Tibet with a digital camera, posing as a tourist. He shot in places like Lhasa's Jokhang Temple (tourists can do that, film makers can't). Now, like all indies, he faces one more uphill struggle -- finding a distributor, a process that starts as soon as post-production is complete.

title: Tax Cuts Help the Wealthy in the Strong Economy
description: In the tough years of the early 1990's, the states raised taxes that hit the poor harder than the affluent. Now that the booming economy has made the states flush with money, they are cutting taxes -- for the affluent.

title: Art and Commerce in a Contest for the State's Stages
description: BY 1977 the regional theater movement, which was conceived as a sane alternative to the monopoly of Broadway, had three prototypes in Connecticut that would all be stars in ascent over the next two decades: Yale Repertory, then 11 years old, Long Wharf, 12, and Hartford Stage, 14. Hartford Stage scaled artistic heights. Long Wharf seesawed but served theater history with style and with stars; it was in 1977 that Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy played in the world premiere of ''The Gin Game.'' Yale changed identities with each new artistic director, from Robert Brustein, its founder, to Lloyd Richards (1979 to 1991 with five new August Wilson plays and three by Athol Fugard) to Stan Wojewodski Jr. (1991 to the present).

title: Civil War Symposium To Take Place in Princeton
description: One of the the South's Civil War victories will be relived in New Jersey. The defeat of three Union armies by outnumbered Confederate General Thomas J. (Stonewall) Jackson during the Shenandoah Valley Campaign from January to June in 1862 will be the subject of a daylong symposium at the Woodrow Wilson School at Princeton University on Oct. 18.

title: Corrections
description: A review of ''The Way We Really Are,'' by Stephanie Coontz, on Sept. 14 misstated the location of Evergreen State College, where she teaches. It is in Olympia, Wash., not in Oregon.

title: Advocate, Not Lobbyist
description: To the Editor:

title: The Preachers: A Test of Political Faith
description: The mood inside the camp of James E. McGreevey was jubilant last week after the Democratic gubernatorial candidate delivered an impassioned appeal for support from the Black Ministers Council of New Jersey, a statewide group with the growing political power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREGER, BEATRICE
description: BREGER-Beatrice. 85, formerly of Forest Hills, Queens on October 2, 1997, in Chevy Chase, MD. Beloved wife of the late Miles Breger, cherished mother of Lynne and Howard Tag of Washington, DC and Marshall and Jennifer Breger, of Silver Spring, MD. Also survived by her devoted sister Hannah Beroza and her adored grandchildren Sarah and Esther Breger and Miles Tag. Graveside service on Sunday, October 4, at 2 PM, Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Richmond Avenue, Staten Island, NY.

title: Baby Makes Two
description: ON OUR OWN

title: In Russia, It's 'Let the Figure Skater Beware'
description: Another Olympic figure skating season having arrived, Artur Dmitriev and Oksana Kazakova entered a dance studio above the Troika nightclub on a recent night. Chorus girls usually rehearse in the cramped studio, but Dmitriev and Kazakova came to polish the choreography in their pairs routine.

title: On Our Own Two Feet
description: IT'S time for New Jersey residents to put their feet down, all 15.6 million of them.

title: How Roast Beef Gave Way to Lemongrass and Focaccia
description: IMAGINE waking up after a 20-year snooze a la Rip Van Winkle and ambling into a restaurant in Connecticut today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRUCKER, MAURICE
description: DRUCKER-Maurice. On Oct. 2, 1997. Beloved husband of Marian. Devoted father of Nancy (David) Rabbach and Ronnie (Marty) Trugman. Cherished grandfather of Brett, Alana, Darius and Justin and great grandfather of Jenna. Services 12:30 Sunday, Oct. 5, from ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', 114-03 Queens Blvd. (76th Rd), Forest Hills.

title: A Boom in Housing That Started in the 70's
description: MANY of the trends that seem fixed features of Westchester County's housing profile today have their origins in the 1970's.

title: The Issues and Events That Stirred Debate
description: SOME of the important government and political events of the last two decades follow:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FERRARA, RONALD A.
description: FERRARA-Ronald A. In loving memory of you on your birthday, October 6, 1938. Forever missed and cherished. Jane

title: Not on the San Andreas Fault, But the Turnpike Will Be Ready
description: Earthquakes seldom strike New Jersey, but the Turnpike Authority wants to be prepared just in case.

title: Shopping Strategies From Four Families
description: IT'S just a nice way of saying ''hunting.''

title: Glory Days for the Art Museum
description: ROBERT P. BERGMAN IS SURE HE IS having the last laugh. Sixteen years ago, when he left an enviable post as associate professor of fine arts at Harvard to become director of the Walters Art Gallery in Baltimore, ''I got a lot of pats on my shoulder from my colleagues,'' he recalled recently, ''a lot of 'Poor Bob, there he goes to dust off the sarcophagi.' Museums were on a trajectory to be marginalized.''

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Big Five-Oh!

title: Love Finds Old Form With a 5-Under-Par 67
description: Buick Challenge

title: Before Downsizing, Jobs Seemed Secure in a 'Golden Age'
description: IN 1977, employees of International Business Machines wore white shirts to work and were virtually dismissal proof. Westchester had only three major hotels, and the first visitors and convention bureau was organized. Companies were leaving Manhattan in droves to resettle in the county. And 500 automotive workers were on the General Motors plant payroll in North Tarrytown.

title: Quality Time
description: I have always had a taste for what are known as the finer things, but I have never had the money to buy them. After spending years in a state of decision-making paralysis (and a near-total absence of furniture), I decided, in domestic design terms, to get a life. What I lacked in funds I would have to make up in resourcefulness -- something, as I finally admitted to myself, that I had been preparing for since childhood.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE ENGLISHMAN'S BOY

title: Hargrove Seeks Relief; Instead, He Gets Ogea
description: Chad Ogea had not entered a game with the bases loaded the entire season. That means the 26-year-old pitcher had not thrown a pitch in relief that became a game-deciding grand slam. In fact, Ogea had not pitched in relief all season.

title: A Hideaway With Commendable Food
description: IF location, location, location were as vital for restaurants as it is for homes, Opal Basil would be in trouble, trouble, trouble. Situated in a small strip shopping center between a 7-Eleven and a Dairy Barn on Merrick Road in Massapequa, the stylish newcomer, with its elegant ambiance and fine food, is in sharp contrast to its neighbors.

title: Sept. 28-Oct. 4; Apologies for the Holocaust
description: In extraordinarily frank terms, the Roman Catholic Church in France apologized to the Jewish people for its silence and its acquiescence in the face of French collaboration with the Holocaust.

title: POSTINGS: Downtown Open House Next Sunday; Walking Tour Along Lower Broadway
description: The Corinthian capitals, giant arched windows and triple tiers of electronic monitors on the 43,000-square-foot trading floor of the American Stock Exchange -- which is normally off-limits to the public -- can be seen next Sunday from noon to 5 P.M. as part of a self-guided Downtown Open House sponsored by the Alliance for Downtown New York.

title: The Task of Finding Viable Alternatives To the Automobile
description: THE signs are as clear as a flashing neon light or a brick wall signaling the end of the road. The equation of the suburbs with the automobile is as out of date and self-defeating as a wobbly old tire on a new Mercedes.

title: Nitrogen-Cutting Plan For Sound Is Attacked
description: A COALITION of sewer districts on the North Shore is challenging cost estimates and scientific assumptions in a Federal and state plan to reduce nitrogen discharges to Long Island Sound by 58.5 percent over 15 years.

title: To the Dragon's Lair
description: THE ''bride'' was out of control, trying to hide hysterical laughter behind the sheer veil she was holding over her face during a ceremonial dance at a mock Muslim wedding. One of the smallest of the dancers was vigorously chewing gum as she executed her turns.

title: In Auckland, Life Is Alfresco
description: ONE early evening in Auckland, New Zealand's largest city, I was riding a bicycle along Tamaki Drive, the harborside boulevard that runs from the center of the city along the water into the eastern suburbs. The light was a lovely, early summer sort, glinting off the blue-green waters of the Hauraki Gulf, illuminating the still islands that separate the city from the South Pacific. Sailboats dotted the gulf; Auckland, where about one out of every 12 residents owns a boat, calls itself the City of Sails.

title: Julina Tatlock, John Gill
description: Julina Cristin Tatlock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Tatlock of New York, was married yesterday to John Freeman Gill, the son of Jill Freeman Gill and Ardian Courtland Gill, both of New York. Suzanne Eismann, a justice of the peace in New Marlborough, Mass., officiated at the Gedney Farm there.

title: Puppy Love
description: DOGS NEVER LIE

title: An Old Ritual Goes Black Tie
description: THE thunderous drumming stopped suddenly, making the silence all the more striking as a Ghanaian holy man made his way onto the stage of Town Hall in midtown Manhattan.

title: Slaying Victim, 11, Is Buried in Sadness
description: Edward Peter Werner was buried here this morning, one week after he was strangled and three months before he would have turned 12. When his small wooden coffin was carried from St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church, even the police officers standing watch at his funeral Mass wept out loud.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: SEPARATING POWER

title: Beyond Fairness; Picking and Choosing Among the Truly Needy
description: TO put a harsh light on it, everyone's a beggar at the Samaritan Center. Just off the courthouse square of this little city in the foothills of the Ozarks, the private charity is a disheveled barn of a room, stacked with food, castoff clothes and toys. It's the last resort for the city's indigent, and like them, Carolyn Kelsay, the center's director, has her hand out, a posture that makes her as queasy as she says it makes her clients.

title: Ms. Teschemacher, Mr. Thygeson
description: Corinne Mary Teschemacher, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl A. Teschemacher Jr. of Morris Township, N.J., was married yesterday to First Lieut. William Elwood Thygeson Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thygeson of Hatboro, Pa. The Rev. Charles Gonzales performed the ceremony with the bride's uncle the Rev. Raymond F. Sullivan at Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church in Chatham Township, N.J.

title: The Boy Who Gave Away the Bomb
description: Your article includes many sympathetic and sanguine descriptions of Hall, including ''whiz kid,'' ''conscience-driven idealist'' and ''typical grad student with garden-variety radical ideas.'' Conspicuously absent is the word that best describes a person who purposely betrays the trust of his country: traitor.

title: Hotel Heaven
description: To the Editor: Patricia Volk's article on Aug. 3, ''Entering Hotel Heaven,'' a k a the Osterreichischer Hof Hotel in Salzburg, revived fond memories of our stay there during the 1986 winter Mozart Festival. We were there with Great Performance Tours, near Lincoln Center. She had it right about everything, including partaking of a celestial Salzburger Nockerl.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUOTOLO, ANDREW KEOGH, JR.
description: RUOTOLO-Andrew Keogh, Jr. November 5, 1952-Sept. 21, 1995. ''Now you will not swell the rout Of lads that wore their honours out, Runners whom reknown outran And the name died before the man.''

title: BOOKEND; Yes I Said Yes I Will Take My Prozac Yes
description: ADVANCES in psychopharmacology and a close reading of the fourth edition of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV) of the American Psychiatric Association suggest that many of the great tragedies of Western literature could have been prevented. Proper diagnosis and timely therapeutic intervention might have spared much unnecessary suffering in the annals of fiction. What follows is but a sample:

title: Women and the Promise Keepers; Good for the Gander, but the Goose Isn't So Sure
description: ALONG comes a men's movement that blames men for every modern malaise, from welfare to teen pregnancy to drug abuse. By the hundreds of thousands, men are falling to their knees to beg forgiveness for abandoning their children or cheating on their wives or gambling the mortgage or working every weekend. These men behaving badly vow to behave better. They promise to share the dishes and diapering, to make time for heart-to-heart talks, to be humble.

title: Neighborly Spots Abound in SoHo
description: AQUAGRILL** [rating: two stars]

title: Amid Fragmentation, Hints of Narrative
description: EVERYDAY life has become an increasingly fragmented and unpredictable experience for many of us, and art could hardly help but follow suit. Still, I don't think I'm being excessively old-fashioned in hoping for exhibitions that mitigate some of that fragmentation and haphazardness by offering a coherent perspective on contemporary practice in the arts.

title: Altruism for Fun and Profit
description: The best measure of the AIDS Rides is this: how much new money (i.e., money that wouldn't otherwise go to AIDS organizations or, for that matter, to any charity) do they bring in? The answer is now in the tens of millions of dollars.

title: How Sweet It Is
description: What's Molly O'Neill got against beets (''How Sweet It Is,'' Sept. 7)? What's all this nonsense about too much sweetness? Boil them, add a bit of salt and pepper and a dollop of butter. You want something better? You don't know what better is.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 21 about a threat by President Clinton to veto a spending bill, if it contained amendments blocking several of his favorite education initiatives, included one proposal erroneously among those potentially affected. The creation of college scholarships resulted from a different bill, signed by Mr. Clinton in August.

title: Stardom Seasoned With a Yearning For Home and Kin
description: THE ARC OF CARLOS ACOSTA'S life has already taken him far in his 24 years -- from the barrios of Havana, where his father forced him into ballet school at the age of 9 to stave off a budding career in juvenile delinquency, to some of the most fabled dance stages in the world.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When you see him and talk to him, you hardly notice any change. And his physical behavior -- he shakes hands, he smiles and his eyes sparkle. It's just that you don't wind up in any meaningful conversation.''

title: Bucks County
description: Although Bucks County is known as the rural retreat discovered early in the century by a galaxy of New York artistic personalities including Moss Hart, Dorothy Parker, Oscar Hammerstein 2d and Pearl Buck, this rolling, wooded part of Pennsylvania was settled initially by pioneering farmers -- and autumn, with its still bountiful harvests, is the season that remembers them best.

title: Smiling on Smaller Stocks
description: CALL it the revenge of the small stocks. In the third quarter these stocks not only outperformed their larger brethren -- a rare event in itself recently -- but by a margin not seen since the fourth quarter of 1992.

title: The Story Behind the Story of a Beset Newsstand Vendor
description: At first glance, it is a story of an entrepreneur and an interloper, of a man playing by the rules and a competitor evading them. At second glance, it is more complicated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOCK, SYLVIA
description: CHOCK-Sylvia. Loving sister of the late Leon and Jesse. Adored aunt of Alan, Betty (Stone) and Robert. Cherished great- and great-great-aunt. Special tante to 3 generations. Graveside service Wednesday, 2 P.M., Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson.

title: God Help the Queen
description: The Queen

title: Corrections
description: A front-page contents listing in the Travel section today refers incorrectly in some copies to the author of an essay about Israel. She is Edith Pearlman, not Brenda Fowler.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIFFIN, DAVID FREDERIC ''FRED''
description: GRIFFIN-David Frederic ''Fred''. Cherished husband of Marion. Beloved and adored father of Joan Meyer, Gerald Brian, and Robert Griffin, son-in-law Charles Meyer, and daughter-in-laws Julie, Janice, and Regina Griffin. Precious grandfather of Colleen, Lauren, Peter, Jamie, John, Robert, and Matthew Griffin. Fred was loved by all who knew him. He was a man of honor and a gentleman. We will miss him forever. For information, contact the Walsh Funeral Home in Malverne.

title: In Seattle, the Ingredients Shine
description: WHEN it comes to food, Seattleites are a dedicated lot. Although they expect to find the bounty of the Pacific Northwest at the city's markets, they often go so far as to grow, gather and catch many of their own ingredients.

title: Next! The Art and Arduousness of Casting a Movie
description: IT'S SUNDAY, APRIL 13, AND INSIDE the doors of the North Hudson County Y.M.C.A. in Hoboken, N.J., Sunday athletes cross paths with protective stage mothers who are ushering their elementary-school-age sons up the stairs into a large front hall. Lining the perimeter of the hall, parents and children clutch pages of script and rehearse lines in hushed tones. One round-bodied 9-year-old skulks toward the entrance, moaning, ''I'm nervous.'' His mother tails him, pleading: ''Get in here! You've got to practice!''

title: Flowers Were Sent
description: To the Editor

title: Sonoma Sanity
description: To the Editor: I was delighted that ''What's Doing in Sonoma and Napa'' (Aug. 24) was tilted almost entirely toward Napa Valley. It will steer visitors to an already glutted area and help to preserve the relative sanity of the Sonoma area.

title: Do Big Shoulders Make the Woman?
description: FORGET that the garment in question has been a staple of women's wardrobes for more than 150 years and a uniform for working women for half that time. The woman's suit has made a comeback, at least according to the weighty fashion tomes that arrive with a mighty thud come fall.

title: Three Quite Different Books In a Busy Year for a Writer
description: Leading in the race to be named busiest bridge writer of 1997 is Barry Rigal of Manhattan, who offered three quite different books to the bridge public in the spring.

title: F.C.C. to Defer Decisions on Phone Deals
description: The Federal Communications Commission chairman, Reed E. Hundt, has informed the office of John McCain, Republican of Arizona and chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, that the present commission does not intend to decide two highly visible matters pending before it, preferring to wait until the Senate approves its new members and chairman.

title: AMERICAN LEAGUE
description: YANKEES -- 2

title: Messinger Faults Giuliani in Attack in Jewish Paper
description: Ruth W. Messinger accused Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday of orchestrating ''an attack by one Jew against another Jew'' after a political ally of the Mayor's wrote a letter to a Jewish newspaper describing the prospect of a Messinger mayoralty as ''our worst nightmare.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYER, HERBERT
description: BOYER-Herbert. On October 3, 1997. Brother of Arthur and Barbara Boyer. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street Monday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Interment private. Mr. Boyer was an active member of the Metropolitan Club.

title: Finding Roots in the Heart of an Ancient Aunt
description: ''Wisdom is bodily decrepitude,'' wrote William Butler Yeats, who railed as eloquently as anyone at the indignities of senescence. This bitter observation runs to the heart of ''Voyage to the Beginning of the World,'' an exquisitely sad and moving reflection on memory and personal roots by the 88-year-old Portuguese-French director Manoel de Oliveira.

title: Calipari Tells Nets To Get Defensive
description: As hard to believe as it may seem, the Nets those perennial National Basketball Association sad sacks -- have more talent in camp this year.

title: Equity and Convertible Issues Set to Be Offered This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Celebration in Chicago For Reborn Orchestra Hall
description: It shaped up last week as, in the words of an old song, all or nothing not all. In the end, it was all, or nearly so, old songs included.

title: Yankee Faith Questioned, Mayor Is Feeling Put Out
description: As the mayoral campaign heads into its final month, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani frequently tries to deflect accusations that every word and deed is now choreographed to play to voters.

title: Editorial Notebook; Mr. Clinton and Global Warming
description: The debate over global warming has taken on all the characteristics of a political brawl, complete with spin doctors and aggressive advertising. A badly confused public is told one day that only a quick and dramatic reduction in energy use can avert meteorological disaster, then warned the next that any such prescription would send energy prices through the roof and the economy through the floor.

title: A Glimpse Of Politics Is Caught On Tape
description: An unidentified man with wire-rimmed glasses, a bright red handkerchief and a patterned red tie became the unlikely star of this city's cinema verite today when the White House released videotapes of coffees held at the White House for contributors to President Clinton's re-election campaign.

title: NBC and some powerful politicians square off over the new ratings system.
description: A NASTY game of chicken has arisen between the nation's most successful television network and one of its most powerful politicians. And it all began over an almost esoteric debate -- should letters like V for violence or S for sex be added to the age-based categories in the new television ratings system?

title: INSIDE METRO
description: BUS ACCIDENT -- The Transit Authority has reassigned two drivers while it investigates an accident in which a bicyclist, 17-year-old George Lozada, above, was hit and killed by a bus in the Bronx. B3.

title: Chronicle
description: A chance encounter with a 2-year-old toddler on a street corner five years ago led LAUREN HUTTON, the model and actress, to take the child and his friend on an extraordinary adventure to Africa -- and to make a television documentary about their trip in the bargain.

title: Lewis's Future Is Rosy, But Golota's Is in Doubt
description: While a victorious Lennox Lewis was working the Marcus Aurelius room at Caesars Palace during his post-fight celebration Saturday night, Andrew Golota lay in a room in the intensive-care unit of the Atlantic City Medical Center in stable condition.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREEN, FREDA AND SAMUEL H.
description: GREEN-Freda and Samuel H. On this the week of your birthdays and High Holy Days, we love and miss you even more. Your girls

title: Sierra Club Sits Out Race
description: Breaking with other state environmental groups, the 20,000-member Sierra Club said Friday that it would endorse neither Gov. Christine Todd Whitman nor her Democratic challenger, State Senator James E. McGreevey, in this fall's governor's race.

title: Canada's Quick-Change Artist; Nortel Goes From Big Loser to Big Winner in 4 Years
description: Visually suited to one of southern Ontario's less picturesque neighborhoods, just down Dixie Road from the Tequila Monster cafe and hard by a cemetery, is the uninspiring facade of Northern Telecom Ltd.'s headquarters, little changed since the building went up in the early 1960's.

title: L. T. Johnson, 91, Plaintiff Who Helped Integrate U. of Kentucky
description: Lyman T. Johnson, the plaintiff in a lawsuit that led to the integration of the University of Kentucky in 1949, five years before the Supreme Court paved the way for the desegregation of all public schools in Brown v. Board of Education, died on Friday in Jewish Hospital in Louisville, Ky. He was 91 and lived in Louisville.

title: Rejuvenated Yale Marks Bountiful Fund Drive
description: When Yale embarked on its $1.5 billion capital drive in May 1992, the largest ever announced by a university at the time, the mood on campus could not have been more strife-ridden. Yale was running a $12 million deficit and expected the red ink to increase. Buildings were in growing disrepair. A strike had closed classes and dining halls. Faculty members protested a plan to shrink their numbers by more than 10 percent. And there was a general loss of confidence in the president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., who announced his resignation less than a month later.

title: Foreign Affairs; Down With Chips!
description: I'm starting a new political movement. It's called ''Americans Against Voice Mail.''

title: Updates/Media and Technology; CBS Offering $1,000 For Network News Tips
description: CBS News is offering to pay journalists as much as $1,000 for tips that lead to reports on its network news broadcast or on network news magazines like ''60 Minutes.''

title: Patents; A gene therapy technique that is seen as easier and less expensive than the main alternative.
description: IN dozens of laboratories around the country, researchers are working to perfect a great leap in medical technology, one they hope will enable doctors and scientists not only to cure lethal diseases, but to prevent them.

title: 2 Marketers Shift Portions of Accounts
description: Two marketers have made decisions on portions of their accounts.

title: Mussina Beats the Mariners Coming In and Going Out
description: A dark expression dominated Mike Mussina's face more than an hour after he left the mound today, his temper foul. If his shirt were not soaked with Champagne, the Orioles ace could have been mistaken for a losing pitcher.

title: Chronicle
description: GEOFFREY BEENE is off to see his high fashion designs this month, not on runways, but in the more rarefied halls of art museums.

title: Rivera's Right Pitch Brings Wrong Result
description: Yes, the Yankees acknowledged, the home run was a shock.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOWITZ, ROY M. Z.
description: MOSKOWITZ-Roy M. Z. On October 3, 1997, at the age of 96. Loving son of the late Sam Moskowitz and Henrietta Moskowitz Gottlieb. Loving uncle and friend to many. Services Monday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, New York.

title: Sports of The Times; The Mariners Fall Short of Raised Expectations This Year
description: IT has come to this with the Seattle Mariners: Once upon a time they skulked about in the soft underbelly of the American League, but now they trudge in the nether world of good teams with high hopes that never quite won a World Series, or even reached a World Series.

title: Metro Matters; Workfare Makes a Break Hard to Give
description: FOR the last 12 years, Cooperative Home Care Associates, centered in what it proudly refers to as ''the heart of the South Bronx,'' has been helping women on welfare get jobs.

title: Brown May Miss The Next Game
description: Quarterback Dave Brown got to his feet slowly after the Dallas Cowboys' Hurvin McCormack knocked him to the Giants Stadium turf late in the second quarter of the Giants' 20-17 victory over the Cowboys yesterday. Brown ran to the sideline with the stiff, peculiar gait of a man in pain trying not to show it.

title: Charge Against Suspect Questioned in Attack on Technician
description: Calling on prosecutors to send a strong signal that attacks on the city's uniformed workers will not be tolerated, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani criticized the Bronx District Attorney, Robert T. Johnson, yesterday for charging a Bronx man with attempted assault, instead of attempted murder, in a knife attack on a medical technician early Saturday.

title: Actors Studio's 50th
description: To the Editor:

title: Stevens's Goal Helps Rangers Salvage Tie
description: In earning their second 2-2 tie in two games last night, the Rangers won one and lost one to the video judge in Madison Square Garden. Their first apparent tying goal, by the rookie Marc Savard, was disallowed because Pat LaFontaine had his skate in Stephane Fiset's goal crease in the final minute of regulation time. It would have been the first goal of Savard's career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANOVER, LILLIAN H.
description: JANOVER-Lillian H., died peacefully in her sleep October 2, 1997 at age 95. Widow of the late Cyrus J. Janover. Mother of Robert H. Janover of Bloomfield Hills, Michigan and Evelyn J. Halpert of New York City. Grandmother of James J. and David J. Halpert and Laura Janover. Great grandmother of Samuel I. Halpert. Funeral private. In lieu of flowers donations to Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 107 East 70 Street, NYC 10021.

title: $250 Million Stock Deal for Microprose
description: The GT Interactive Software Corporation, an interactive entertainment company, said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Microprose Inc., which develops and publishes interactive entertainment software, for about $250 million in stock.

title: Israelis Bemoan Failed Attempt on Hamas Official
description: After three days of silence about allegations of a botched Israeli attempt to assassinate a Palestinian leader in Jordan, Israeli politicians and the press loosed a fierce barrage of criticism today against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu over a crisis that stood to damage Israel on political and security fronts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOB, MARGARET (NEE FUCHS)
description: JACOB-Margaret (nee Fuchs). On October 4, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Ludwig Jacob, dear sister of Charlotte Magnus and the late Gerda Lippmann. Cherished aunt of Frank (Fannie) Lippmann, Thomas (Susan) Lippmann, Moshe (Yael) Jacobi, Sue and the late Martin Magnus. Adored greataunt of Sharon, Deborah, Greg, Ehud, Mark, Dan, Michael, Tamar, Steven and Yoav. Services were held on Sunday, October 5. Donations may be made in Margaret's name to Congregation Habonin, 44 West 66th Street, NYC 10023.

title: WHITE HOUSE GIVES TAPES OF CLINTON AND RICH DONORS
description: The White House today released a videotape showing President Clinton greeting potential donors at 44 coffees before the 1996 election. And Republicans seized on the tape to accuse Attorney General Janet Reno of acting too hastily on Friday in clearing Mr. Clinton of several allegations of campaign finance abuse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREISMAN, LOTTIE
description: KREISMAN-Lottie. At the age of 102. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Loving mother of Raymond (Esta) and Leonard (Ruth). Adoring grandmother of Laura, Marcie, Eric, Sarah and Rachel. Contributions may be made in her memory to either NJ Geriatric Center, 225 W. Jersey St, Elizabeth, New Jersey 07202, or Center for Hope Hospice, 176 Hussa St, Linden, New Jersey 07036.

title: China's Nuclear Goals
description: To the Editor:

title: Ohio State-Penn State Promises to Be Fierce
description: The older ones remember the sound that greeted them again and again in Happy Valley, a snarling Nittany Lion who was turned up as loud as the volume could go, feeding the frenzy on a bizarre Saturday afternoon at Beaver Stadium.

title: Schools Need Standards; Boys and Girls
description: To the Editor:

title: De Kooning Intrigues Live On
description: In the six months since Willem de Kooning's death, tales about his life, his work and his estate have become as complex as his most famous paintings. Few in the international art world would dispute his stature as one of the greatest figures of American art, but de Kooning, the Abstract Expressionist painter who had become a recluse by the time he died in March at 92, continues to fascinate collectors and dealers, auction house experts and art historians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, PETER (PINCAS)
description: RUBIN-Peter (Pincas). Age 86, on Oct 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Julie; loving father and father-inlaw of Bette and Stephen Weinberger; adoring grandfather of Joshua and Aaron. Loving brother of Esia, Micha and Daniel. Services were held Sunday, Oct 5, 1997.

title: To Keep Victory, The Jets Throw The Ball Away
description: Neil O'Donnell didn't know the rule, he admitted later. But then again, few people on either the Jets or Colts could understand what was going to unfold in the last seconds today.

title: Death Penalty Is Posing Test For Prosecutor
description: The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, facing the biggest test yet of his personal opposition to capital punishment, must decide by Wednesday whether he will seek the death penalty against a man accused of killing a police officer in May.

title: America Online Turns to TV as a Model
description: Starting next week, America Online will begin overhauling its service in an effort to attract another two million to three million subscribers during the next year.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: EXTRA POINTS ; Up and Down Since Super Bowl
description: The Jets broke a long stretch of futility against the Colts with yesterday's victory. Indianapolis had won 5 games in a row from the Jets, and 16 of the last 20.

title: Tchmil Truimphs In a 2-Man Sprint
description: Because the course is so flat, the long and venerable Paris-Tours bicycle race almost always holds a big pack of riders together and ends in a sprint, as it did yesterday. Usually it is a mass sprint -- 30 or 40 riders digging together for the finish -- not simply 2 men, head to head.

title: 5 Executives Are Honored
description: The Alliance of Sales and Marketing Executives has inducted five executives into its National Sales and Marketing Hall of Fame. They are: Charlotte Beers, 60, chairwoman emeritus at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, a unit of WPP Group; Vern Brunner, 57, executive vice president at the Walgreen Company; Richard Gelb, 73, chairman emeritus of the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company; Bernard Marcus, 68, chairman and co-founder of Home Depot, and Ted Turner, 58, vice chairman of Time Warner Inc.

title: Sports of The Times; Another Opportunity Lost for Gooden
description: THE clock cannot be turned back for Dwight Gooden, but here is what he was able to do last night: give every bit of experience, everything he had in place of his friend David Cone. He gave the Yankees five and two-thirds courageous innings, which is all they could have reasonably expected or asked.

title: Principal Charged in Abuse
description: The principal of a Roman Catholic high school has been accused of abusing a young boy during summer vacations on Long Beach Island and was charged with sexual assault and endangering the welfare of a minor, The Associated Press reported.

title: Stricter School Bus Tests
description: After surprise inspections of school buses conducted over the summer revealed hundreds of serious defects, a State Assemblyman is proposing legislation that would strengthen the standards for bus inspections.

title: Rail Links to Airports
description: To the Editor:

title: A Day When the Pews Are a Jumble of Paws
description: Chelsea Anderson has never been what you would call a regular churchgoer. To her thinking, Sunday mornings were meant for lazing around the house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, VIDA (NEE KAUFMAN)
description: GINSBERG-Vida (nee Kaufman). Beloved wife of the late Elias. Dear stepmother of Barry. Loving aunt and great-aunt. Services today, 10 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapels, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave, New York City.

title: 6 Held in Death After Party
description: Six people, including a liquor store owner and four minors, have been arrested in connection with an unsupervised party in Cranford that was attended by a high school senior who later died after she was struck by a car, the A.P. reported.

title: Putting Politics Aside
description: By choosing to convene a religious revival meeting of Christian men on Saturday in the nation's political capital, the leaders of the evangelical men's movement called Promise Keepers were forced to spend much of the day forswearing any political motivation.

title: Even After Conviction and Jail, Police Deliberation Grinds On
description: Nearly two years after he was convicted of attempted assault in Brooklyn, Officer Rolando Baquadano is still collecting his paycheck from the New York City Police Department, even after spending 90 days in jail for violating his probation.

title: Photos of Boys Lead to Arrest Of Mother And Friend
description: Two boys were in the care of city children's services officials last night after the police discovered sexually explicit photographs of them in a Brooklyn apartment where the officers were searching for drugs, the authorities said.

title: Man as a Window Washer And a Metaphor for Futility
description: Like Cal Ripken, Pina Bausch stays the course. She is, in her own brilliant way, reliable and an exception to the rule. Yet for the first time, the underlying effort is beginning to show.

title: Pesticides Contribute to Food Safety Problem; Free-Trade Barrier
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools Need Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Over the Din of New Media, a Voice for the Audio Arts
description: ''Sound matters!'' Elizabeth Cohen preached to the audience of 600 audio experts. ''No longer will we be the bastard child to pictures!''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Most of the people in the Senate these days think the word compromise means wimp and that's why they don't legislate. It's worse in the House. It's like a slave ship over there, where the Republicans came out of the hold after 40 years down there and slaughtered everyone on deck.''

title: High-definition television: Screens reflect back the business interests of the executive beholder.
description: AS the heads of the major television networks are learning, high-definition television is a squishy term whose true meaning lies in the eyes of the beholder.

title: Pretoria Journal; House of Hair-Raising Horrors, the Police Version
description: ''Yaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa!''

title: Two Accused of Trying To Alter Officer's Test
description: A police officer who had failed an exam for a promotion to sergeant and an employee of the State Department of Personnel have been indicted and accused of scheming to alter the officer's test score, state officials said.

title: Seeing Politics, and Mirrors, In the Coverage of Capitol Hill
description: Sandy Hume, the star reporter of The Hill, a weekly paper, is among a new breed of correspondents burrowing so deep inside Congress that legislation itself has become largely beside the point. And a proliferation of the news he calls ''the juicy inside stuff'' is making this corner of the world more insular than ever.

title: Pesticides Contribute to Food Safety Problem; Growing Your Own
description: To the Editor:

title: Wedding in a Cemetery, Ideal for Jealous Killings
description: It takes a lot of nerve to build a film around characters as grotesquely unsympathetic as Coral (Regina Orozco) and Nicolas (Daniel Gimenez Cacho), lovers who cut a murderous swath through Arturo Ripstein's gruesome comedy, ''Deep Crimson.'' Based on the same true crime story that inspired the 1969 cult film ''The Honeymoon Killers,'' the film, set in Mexico in 1949, is a ferociously anti-romantic portrait of an obese nurse and a seedy small-time gigolo whose bungling scheme to swindle a succession of lonely women out of their life savings turns into a killing spree.

title: Clinton to Veto Up to 50 Projects In Bill for Military Construction
description: President Clinton plans to wield his veto pen on Monday by crossing out as many as 50 pet projects worth about $300 million in the $9.2 billion military construction bill, White House officials said today.

title: Jets Come Up Short In the Running Game
description: Bill Parcells won two Super Bowl rings with the Giants by gaining a lead and sitting on it until it hatched with a running game. The callow Jets occupy the same home stadium as the Giants, but do not share their old mastery at protecting a lead.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUBENSTEIN, HENRY
description: RUBENSTEIN-Henry. After five years missing you and loving you has not faltered. Your Beatrice

title: Once Again, Hershiser Is a Post-Season Hero
description: When Orel Hershiser stepped from the mound after seven innings, he left the game against the Yankees a hero. A tragic hero, it first seemed, but a hero nonetheless after shutting down the Yankees' offense in a game the Indians could not afford to lose.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Chicago Troupe Rises to a Challenge With 'Grimes'
description: Attention was hard to come by here this weekend. The Chicago Symphony was involved in a game of brinksmanship in contract negotiations leading to the opening of its new Symphony Center on Saturday. And the Bears were involved in an operatic drama, with a onetime local hero, Mike Ditka, returning on Sunday as villain, the coach of the New Orleans Saints.

title: Sierra Club Won't Back Candidates for Governor
description: Breaking with other state environmental groups, the Sierra Club said it would endorse neither Gov. Christine Todd Whitman nor her Democratic challenger, State Senator James E. McGreevey, in the race for governor.

title: Easter Seal Society Selects Recipients
description: The National Easter Seal Society has named the recipients of its eighth annual Equality, Dignity and Independence (EDI) Awards, which honor communications judged to enhance the independence of people with disabilities.

title: Cowboys Stick Together After Loss
description: The Dallas Cowboys offense stalked off the field today after Troy Aikman's second interception of the game with about 10 minutes to play. The game was slipping away, and the Cowboys were not taking it well. Aikman gestured angrily and animatedly at the bench; offensive lineman Erik Williams did more than gesture, ripping his helmet off and flinging it toward the bench.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHHAUSER, DAVID R.
description: HOCHHAUSER-David R. On Oct. 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Rita. Loving son of Goldie and the late Harry. Dear uncle of fourteen nieces and nephews. He will be missed by his many cousins and friends. Services were held.

title: Greenwich Rider Wins Competition
description: Ellie Rich of Greenwich, Conn., riding Lagretto, a horse who formerly competed for the German equestrian team, beat a field of 48 other qualifiers to win the United States Equestrian Team's Young Riders Championship in Gladstone, N.J. Her victory means that she will receive prime consideration for further training with the United States Equestrian Team.

title: Dave Marr, 63, Golf Champion And Television Commentator
description: Dave Marr, the jocular Texan who won the 1965 Professional Golfers' Association Championship and then traded on that victory and his homespun wit to forge a career as a television commentator, died of cancer yesterday. He was 63.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORTION, ELINOR MOSES
description: ORTION-Elinor Moses. On October 1, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Edward Joseph Ortion. Loving mother of Jocelyn Burns-Graham of Harbor City, CA. Friends may call at Frank E. Campell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Monday 24 PM, with service Tuesday, 11:30 AM. Interment Independence, MO.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROLL, JANET SMYTH
description: CROLL-Janet Smyth. A memorial service will be held at St. James Chapel, Madison Avenue at 71 St, at 11 AM on Thursday, October 9.

title: Haggar men's wear turns to more sophisticated consumers: women.
description: LAST fall, the Haggar Clothing Company pitched its ads for slacks and shirts to men too lazy to get up for a beer during World Series commercials. This time, the company will hawk its men's wear to a more sophisticated shopping crowd -- women.

title: Victory for Owner Turning 100
description: Fred W. Hooper's stable stretched 1,000 miles to present the legendary racing figure with a gift for his 100th birthday today: a victory in yesterday's feature race at Belmont Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOCHTENBERG, ESTELLE
description: DOCHTENBERG-Estelle. Beloved wife of Harry. Devoted mother of Phyllis and Andrew Fier, and Donna and Leonard Berg. Dear sister of Anne Sherman. Loving grandmother of Amy Gitlin, Lisa Fier, Adam and Jacqueline Berg. Adoring great-grandmother of David, Elkanah and Chava Gitlin. Funeral service Monday, 1:30PM Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street at Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Credit Offerings Planned During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week has today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and sales of a five-year inflation-index note on Wednesday and a 52-week bill on Thursday.

title: 1 Step Forward for Wheatley, 2 Steps Back for Brown
description: Last week, Giants quarterback Dave Brown was in much more pain than either he or the Giants were saying. And running back Tyrone Wheatley was more focused in practice than he had ever been. Yesterday against the Dallas Cowboys came the biggest victory of the Jim Fassel era so far, but equally important was that this game may have altered the paths that Brown and Wheatley were traveling. And for now, at least, they could not be going in more different directions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYMES, BEATRICE
description: HAYMES-Beatrice. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our dedicated benefactor and founder, Stephen D. Haymes. Heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. May her memory be a source of blessing and inspiration. Rabbi Marc Schneier Michael B. Weisbrod, President Seymour G. Siegel, Treasurer

title: Nationwide Phone Directory Assistance, on the World Wide Web
description: For some users of the World Wide Web, calling telephone directory assistance at 411 or 555-1212 may become a thing of the past if a partnership of two companies catches on.

title: Pope, in Rio, Uses Showmanship to Champion the Family
description: Pope John Paul II wrapped up his second world meeting on families today with an open-air Mass that seemed to rival the increasingly popular television evangelists here for color and entertainment, but that reaffirmed the Roman Catholic Church's traditional stance on the inviolability of the family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSKOWITZ, ELAINE
description: MOSKOWITZ - Elaine. Beloved wife of Herb. Loving mother of Scott and Judy Moskowtiz, and Stacy and Andrew Lieberman. Cherished grandmother of Steven and Matthew. Darling daughter of Sally Siegel and devoted sister to Anita Sherman and Ruth Rubin. Elaine fought a valiant battle with cancer for many years.

title: Bullpen Blows Up, and Now Yanks Face Game 5
description: The wild evening switched from exciting to agonizing to excruciating for the Yankees. They went from having Mariano Rivera on the mound and needing four outs to qualify for the American League Championship Series to watching a mob of Indians celebrate after a dramatic 3-2 victory tonight in Game 4 of the division series.

title: Serb's Iron Rule: Belgrade Power Play May Light Fuse
description: President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, in the second and final round of today's presidential elections, is hoping to consolidate his hold on power into the next century despite profound fissures in his authoritarian edifice.

title: France Amasses Bitter Evidence Five Decades After the Holocaust
description: Georges Gheldman was 11 when the French police in Dax, acting at the bidding of the Germans then occupying southwest France, came for his mother on July 16, 1942. Coming home from school that day, he found a handwritten note that said, simply, ''Come quickly and meet me at the police station.''

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Owner of Mill Accepts Deal, Sparing Grove Of Old Cedars
description: One of the nation's most valuable stands of trees is safe from chainsaws, thanks to a land swap between the United States Forest Service and a sawmill owner.

title: Deterring Immigration
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a brief report on Sept. 28 about a microbe that has killed fish in the Chesapeake Bay area misstated its effect on humans. People who have been exposed to waters where the microbe has killed fish have reported health problems, but there is no evidence of anyone having been harmed by eating infected seafood.

title: Bucs Find Trouble Playing From Behind
description: BUCCANEERS 16

title: Odd Couple Cross Political Lines to Fight System
