description: One is a epublican, the other a Democrat. One is a conservative, the other a liberal. One is Episcopalian, the other Jewish. One is 61 years old, the other only 44. One is a man of action, a former fighter pilot, the other an intellectual, a former Rhodes scholar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTSHULER, DR. BERNARD
description: ALTSHULER-Dr. Bernard. On October 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Lillian Altshuler. Dear father of Jean and Miriam Altshuler. Father-in-law of Corrado Fasciano and Tom Mansfield. Adored grandfather of Caleb, Rebecca and Erica. Dear brother of Beatrice Mintz, Herbert Altshuler and Eugene Altshuler. Services Monday, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions can be made in Bernard's name to Courant Institute, New York University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, FLORENCE
description: MEYER-Florence. On October 5, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Meyer. Dear mother of Marilyn (Abe) Wertheim and Jeffrey (Anne) Meyer. Adored grandmother of Robert, Eric, Karyn, Rachel and Rebecca. Cherished aunt. Services Wednesday, October 8, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: The Eve of Construction; Refugees From City Fear They've Started a Boom
description: By moving from a Hoboken, N.J., brownstone to Putnam County, Aegis Frumento, a New York lawyer, and his family found what seems impossible in the region these days: a house on a 5 1/2-acre plot of wooded land for $270,000, good schools, relatively low taxes and a community where crime is almost unheard of.

title: H. E. Rosvold, 81, Neuroscientist Who Focused on Brain Function
description: Haldor E. Rosvold, a retired neuroscientist known as a pioneer in studying the role the brain's frontal lobes and networks play in numerous mental processes, died at his home in Silver Spring, Md., on Sept. 26. He was 81.

title: Jews Return to Selma, Underscoring Exodus
description: For a brief time during this Jewish holiday season, David and Lynn Barton succeeded in re-creating a disappearing way of life in the South.

title: Sex Abuse Suspect Held In Dozen Other Attacks
description: A Manhattan man who was arrested early Saturday after he grabbed a woman sexually on the Upper East Side is also being investigated as a suspect in 12 other cases of sexual abuse over the last two months, the police said yesterday.

title: Booksellers Getting $25 Million Settlement From Penguin
description: Freed from a carefully negotiated vow of secrecy, the American Booksellers Association started alerting its national membership on Friday that it had won $25 million as a settlement in its lingering dispute with Penguin Group USA over discounts arising from the publishing company's accounting scandal.

title: Dams Aren't Forever
description: Sometimes when Congress holds hearings, things don't work out as intended. A good example occurred last month when the House Resources Committee met to discuss a plan to drain the reservoir behind Glen Canyon Dam upstream from the Grand Canyon. By draining the reservoir, known as Lake Powell, we would be restoring a natural wonder: the magnificent Glen Canyon, which has been underwater since 1963.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONDON, HERBERT
description: LONDON-Herbert. Age 83, on October 4, 1997. Father of Evelyn London and Susan London-Payne. Grandfather of Katherine Payne. Funeral services private.

title: Pettitte Hampered By Pain In Back
description: Andy Pettitte has experienced lower back spasms for more than a month. It is a pain that spreads across his back, sometimes hampers him at the end of his pitching motion and bothers him most after an outing in which he has thrown at least 110 pitches. It is something Pettitte tries to ignore and tries not to discuss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDHEIM, ERIC
description: FELDHEIM-Eric. On 10/2/97. Husband of Marcia. Father of Daniel, David and Shira. Stepfather of Leslie, Judy, Rachel and George. Grandfather of twelve.

title: INSIDE
description: Court to Consider Job Bias

title: Safir Has Dismissed 106 Officers, 8 for Brutality
description: In furtive meetings, David Tsang, a New York City police officer, accepted thousands of dollars in cash bound with rubber bands from a downtown Manhattan brothel as a favor for his brother, who was in jail. It cost him his career.

title: A 13-Year-Old's Railroad Journey to Fantasy and Self-Knowledge
description: THE ZIGZAG KID

title: Taking In the Sites; Vantages On Markets For Expert And Novice
description: Almost since computers were conceived more than half a century ago, versions of them have been used as basic tools in the financial business -- crunching numbers, analyzing data and spawning an industry devoted to tracking what is happening in the stock, currency, options and commodities markets.

title: Bee Pollen Bureaucracy
description: There's a source of embarrassment in Washington these days that has nothing to do with campaign financing. It's the Office of Alternative Medicine, part of the National Institutes of Health.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Shift in Banking Rules, With Caution, Is Urged

title: Supreme Court to Consider Major Case Concerning Race in the Workplace
description: The new Supreme Court term opening Monday brings the Justices their most important affirmative action case in years, an employment dispute that could rewrite the ground rules for taking race into account in both public and private workplaces.

title: 2 Indicted in Test Tampering
description: A police officer who had failed an exam for a promotion to sergeant and an employee of the State Department of Personnel have been indicted on charges that they schemed to alter the officer's test score, state officials said.

title: Day of Prayerful Messages For the Crowd on the Mall
description: In violation of a commandment of television-age news, Saturday's big Promise Keepers prayer meeting was a no-show for the home viewer. Here was an event that kept its promise, a smash hit by most standards, yet a television washout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NACHBAR, MARTIN
description: NACHBAR-Martin. On October 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Paul; loving brother of William and Edwin. He was a Board member of the Mental Health Assocation of Nassau County and a Board member of Central Nassau Guidance and Counseling Services, Inc. He was retired from BDO Seidman, CPAs, as managing partner of the Long Island office. Services Monday, 12 noon, at ''Gutterman's, Inc,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIERNAN, JOHN ALLYN
description: KIERNAN-John Allyn. Of Bernardsville, NJ, on Thursday, Oct 2, 1997. Beloved husband of CarolMarie Byrne Kiernan. Devoted father of Kelly Kiernan, of St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands, and Kevin Kiernan of Eugene, OR. Brother of Mary C. Pearman of Palo Alto, CA, and Sarah Torodash of Lennox, MA. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Tuesday, Oct 7, 1997, at the Holy Family Chapel of the College of St. Elizabeth, Convent Station, NJ, at 1 PM. Hours of visitation at the Doyle Funeral Home, 106 Maple Ave, Morristown, NJ, on Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in John's memory to the United Negro College Fund would be greatly appreciated.

title: Italian and French Offerings Are Latest of State Asset Sales
description: Italy's Treasury said this weekend that it would sell 32.8 percent of Telecom Italia S.p.A., the national telephone company, in a share offering this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURCHIOE, JAMES F.
description: TURCHIOE-James F. Died suddenly on October 4, 1997. Adored husband of Peggy Rose Turchioe. Devoted father of Brian and Elisabeth. Special son of Louis V. Turchioe and Susan and Irl Rose. Brother of Robert, Lois, Louis, John, George, Mary, Richard, Dominick and Thomas. He was a special man, loved by everyone. Funeral service at the BallardDurand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY, Monday, October 6, 11:30 AM.

title: Tango as Pure Melody Slinks Into a Staid Concert Hall
description: It takes only a few words and a change of scene to dissolve the line between classical and popular music. The power of the label is inexplicable but very real. When we blur the names, encroachments follow. Lately they have been one-way, as the insinuation of the vernacular into the concert hall becomes daily more invasive.

title: Cartoons On the Web, From an Iconoclast
description: From the not-quite-underground headquarters of Spumco Inc., in a nondescript building just west of the imposing iron gates of Paramount Studios, John Kricfalusi, rabble-rouser and cult hero to alienated youth -- and adults -- everywhere, is plotting a cartoon revolution.

title: AT&T Cellular Phone Service To Allow Links to the Internet
description: AT&T's Wireless Services Division plans to announce today the retail introduction of a service that permits a cellular phone user to tap into a variety of information sources and electronic mail via the Internet.

title: Accounts
description: * Schering-Plough Health Care Products, Liberty Corner, N.J., to B.J.K.& E. Media Group, New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, to handle broadcast media buying for brands like Coppertone and Dr. Scholl's, which had been handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $50 million.

title: Microsoft Is the Latest Target of Nader's Consumer Crusade
description: The Microsoft Corporation, which has so far fended off accusations from competitors that it holds monopoly power over the computer software industry, has now drawn a new adversary, the consumer advocate Ralph Nader.

title: A. L. Rowse, Masterly Shakespeare Scholar, Dies at 93
description: A. L. Rowse, the brilliant authority on Shakespeare and Elizabethan England whose grandiose opinions of his scholarship were not always shared by rival historians he invariably dismissed as third-rate, died on Friday at his home in Cornwall. He was 93 and best known for his confident identification of ''the Dark Lady'' of Shakespeare's sonnets.

title: Doubts on Cost Are Bedeviling Climate Policy
description: With President Clinton having accepted the dominant view among scientists that global warming is a serious matter, the increasingly urgent debate over what to do about it has largely shifted to the question of how restricting emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide may affect the nation's economy. And there, perplexity reigns.

title: Pesticides Contribute to Food Safety Problem; Produce-Labeling Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Pesticides Contribute to Food Safety Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Johnson Lets Out This Cry: Bring On the Yankees
description: Lest there be any doubt which team Davey Johnson, the Baltimore manager, wants to play in the American League Championship Series, which starts here Wednesday night, he announced his feelings tonight.

title: Critic's Notebook; Film (and Song) Noir When Shadows Are Lighter
description: All that's missing from our pre-millennium film noir craze are the truly haunting women who were at the center of the whole thing. They drove the stories with their sexuality and their calculating intelligence. And they never confined themselves to just one style.

title: The Plane Train, on Track
description: After years of false starts, the long-awaited train from Manhattan to the planes at Kennedy International Airport seems to be going ahead. The $1.5 billion system approved last week will be far from a seamless ride. Passengers will leave from Penn Station on the Long Island Rail Road, then transfer at the Jamaica, Queens, station to an elevated rail service to the airport. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani was right in expressing doubts about how many people will want to use the service. It will be up to the Port Authority to prove that the system meets its goals.

title: One Certainty Amid the Chaos: Giants Shock The Cowboys
description: The end was chaotic, with a hurried play, a penalty flag and a meeting of the game officials. But if the game crept to a vague, confusing conclusion, its result hinted of distinct, new beginnings.

title: Condom Program Puts Kids at Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: The Supreme Court Returns
description: The Supreme Court, which opens its new term today, has fewer blockbuster cases on its docket than it did a year ago. But the cases it does have will challenge its sense of fairness and racial justice. The central drama will be provided by a major affirmative action case from New Jersey. At issue is the future of an important but controversial tool for overcoming discrimination and achieving diversity in the public and private workplace.

title: A Managerial Farm Team?
description: While Joe Torre flirts with another possible award as American League manager of the year, three other Yankee employees wonder whether they are in line to become his peers next season. Gene Michael, Chris Chambliss and Willie Randolph all acknowledge that they are being portrayed as hot commodities in places with managing vacancies.

title: D.N. Medearis, 70, Pediatrician Who Studied Emergency Care
description: Donald N. Medearis Jr., who as chief of pediatrics at Massachusetts General Hospital pushed for nationwide improvement in emergency care for children, died last Monday at that hospital. He was 70 and lived in Winthrop, Mass.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Late Defensive Stand Allows Dolphins to Cling to Victory Over Chiefs
description: Before the game's fateful play today, Miami Dolphins linebacker Anthony Harris screamed at his teammates in the defensive huddle.

title: Black-Owned Bookstores Defend Niche
description: When Coretta Scott King visits here on Oct. 12 for her only Southern California stop in a speaking tour in the West, the event is expected to draw 10,000 people to a minor-league baseball stadium and bring the city center to a standstill. Church choirs are rehearsing for a performance, and a special section is to be set aside for local residents who helped establish a City Hall memorial to Mrs. King's husband, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: The Heroes May Be in Love, but It's the Staging That's Peculiar
description: The New York City Opera has long excelled in creating the expectation that certain of its new productions will be daring, provocative and perhaps even slightly scandalous, and therefore the talk of the opera world. Sometimes the company delivers on these promises. Its staging of Zimmerman's searing ''Die Soldaten'' comes to mind. But often these promised provocations prove surprisingly tame. That is the case with the company's new staging of Gluck's ''Iphigenie en Tauride,'' which opened on Saturday evening.

title: Seeking Answers in 2d City Bus Fatality
description: The second fatal accident involving a city bus within a week is proving just as much a mystery as the first.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGETT, CHARLES
description: MARGETT-Charles, The Honorable. Retired Justice of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court. Beloved husband and friend of Doris Rosen. Stepfather of Sanford Rosen. Dear uncle of Ronald and June, Monte and Barbara Posner, and cherished grand-uncle. Services Monday, 1:00PM, at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite LIRR.

title: Updates/Media and Technology; Software to Track Business Prospects By Web Visits
description: One of the biggest fetters on the growth of advertising on the World Wide Web has been advertisers' uncertainty about how many people are actually seeing the banners and other visual gadgets they are spending to promote.

title: At the U.N., a New Voice Stresses Balance in Approaching Human Rights
description: The Government leaders who flock to the United Nations every autumn to make speeches, drink toasts and dabble in back-room diplomacy found something new on their appointment calendars this year: human rights and Mary Robinson.

title: Trash Disposal System Is Fragmented by a Court's Ruling
description: Waste collection and disposal in New Jersey have never been simple matters, although there have long been two constants: that the state's disposal costs were the highest in the nation and that the state controlled where the garbage ended up.

title: Pesticides Contribute to Food Safety Problem; What's Inside?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cashmere Journal; Old-Fashioned Town Sours On Candymaker's New Pitch
description: Car manufacturers do it. Major League sports teams do it. Hollywood stars do it. So perhaps it is no surprise that a 79-year-old candymaking factory in a little Cascade Mountain town has decided to play a very modern game of corporate hardball.

title: Omnicom Unit Buys Newell & Sorrell
description: The Interbrand Group, a corporate-identity consultancy that is owned by Omnicom Group, has acquired Newell & Sorrell, an identity and design consultancy in London, and has merged it with its existing office there. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSAFT, DR. HADASSAH BIMKO
description: ROSENSAFT-Dr. Hadassah Bimko. October 3, 1997. On Friday night after Rosh Hashanah, surrounded by her children and granddaughter, our beloved, heroic, unique Hadassah left us at the age of 85 after a valiant battle with liver failure resulting from malaria and hepatitis she contracted at Auschwitz. After saving the lives of hundreds of Jews at Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen, and keeping alive 149 Jewish children at Belsen, she organized and led the efforts to restore to health the liberated Jews of Belsen. One of the earliest leaders of the survivors of the Holocaust together with her late and unforgettable husband Yossel, she was the principal witness for the prosecution at the first war crimes trial of the German murderers apprehended at Belsen. She served as head of the Health Department of the Jewish Committee of Belsen and the Central Commitee of Jews in the British Zone of Germany. She was a member of President Carter's Commission on the Holocaust and one of the founding members of the United States Holocaust Memorial Council, where she served until 1994 as Chair of the Archives Committee and on the Executive Committee. She was the honorary President of the World Federation of BergenBelsen Survivors. The beloved mother of Menachem and Jeanie and devoted, cherished grandmother of Jodi, she will live in our hearts forever. Services Monday, 12 noon, Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 E. 87th St., NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Dr. Hadassah Bimko Rosensaft Memorial Fund of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington, DC.

title: Abroad at Home; Reno's Common Sense
description: Once in a rare while a clear voice cuts through the din of Washington, D.C., and recalls us to our senses. It happened last week, when Attorney General Janet Reno in large part rejected demands for appointment of an independent counsel to investigate how money was raised for President Clinton's 1996 campaign.

title: Pesticides Contribute to Food Safety Problem; U.S. Isn't Blameless
description: To the Editor:

title: Computers Let Japan's Drivers Play in Traffic
description: Kaoru Hinata's car navigation system can plot a course and guide him to his destination, telling him when to turn left or right. If he's hungry or low on fuel, it can show him the location of the nearest fast-food joint or gasoline station. And it even can receive the latest traffic information and tell Mr. Hinata which roads are congested and which parking lots still have space available.

title: Updates/Media and Technology; 4 British Cable Channels Enlisted Against B Sky B
description: Four British cable television companies would create pay-per-view movie channels under a proposed agreement with Time Warner's Warner Brothers studio, which would supply the films, The Financial Times reported Saturday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: A Warm Climate Prevails as Experts Study Ecological Problems
description: President Clinton today convened a daylong conference on climate change that produced a series of optimistic discussions about harnessing technology, ingenuity and the entrepreneurial spirit to save the planet from global warming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASCIANA, TERESA
description: MASCIANA-Teresa. On Oct 4, 1997. Born in Reggio, Calabria on April 15, 1924. Beloved wife of the late Bruno. Survived by sons Aldo and Bruno and Lon Devitt, daughter-in-law Cindy and granddaughter Clarissa, as well as family and friends in Italy and Manhattan. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20 St.), Tues, Oct 7th, 2-5, 7-9 p.m. Mass of Christian Burial 10 a.m. Wed at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Green-Wood Cemetery. Donations can be made in her name to the American Cancer Society, 19 W. 56 St. NYC 10019; attn: Memorial Dept.

title: Poor Gussie Fink-Nottle: He's Still Stuck in Red Tights
description: Volleys of dinner rolls whistled around the room in the best tradition of the Drones Club when some 200 members of the American Wodehouse Society held a banquet here on Saturday, the final evening of a jamboree held every other year to celebrate Pelham Grenville Wodehouse (illogically pronounced WOOD-house), perhaps the greatest English-language humorist of the century, and appropriately titled ''What Ho, Chicago! -- and All That Jazz.''

title: RICKEL HOME CENTERS PLANS STORE CLOSINGS AND LAYOFFS
description: Rickel Home Centers said yesterday that it would close its 49 home improvement stores and cut 2,800 jobs in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, New York and Delaware because it ran out of cash after almost two years in Chapter 11 bankruptcy. The closings and layoffs, including 2,000 in New Jersey, will be completed by the end of the year, the company said. Rickel Home Centers, based in South Plainfield, N.J., filed Chapter 11 reorganization Jan. 10, 1996. The company said that its creditors had agreed to the store closings.

title: Adult Trials in Gross's Death
description: Federal prosecutors have decided to try as adults two juveniles accused of kidnapping and killing Nelson G. Gross, a developer and the former head of the state Republican Party, a lawyer for one of the juveniles said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARD, REV. MSGR EUGENE F.
description: RICHARD-Rev. Msgr Eugene F. on October 6, 1997. Beloved brother of Veronica Gray and Ronald Richard. Reposing at Lloyd Maxcy Beauchamp Chapel, Shea Place, New Rochelle, on Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9pm, Thursday 2-4pm. Mass of the Holy Eucharist at Blessed Sacrament Church, Thursday 7:30pm. Mass of christian burial, Friday 11am. Interment Holy Sepulchre Cemetery.

title: School in Harlem Is Shut Indefinitely Because of Fumes
description: A Harlem elementary school that opened last month in a building that once housed a dry-cleaning operation was shut down suddenly and indefinitely at midday yesterday, after tests revealed the presence of potentially hazardous fumes at levels exceeding state guidelines.

title: Possible Deal by 2 Chip Makers Is Hinted
description: Is Digital Equipment about to give up on its troubled Alpha chip to settle its patent infringement suit against Intel?

title: AUTOS: ROUNDUP
description: I.R.L. Expands Its Schedule

title: Stocks Down in Tokyo
description: Stocks were lower here this morning. At the midday recess in trading, the Nikkei index of 225 leading issues was down 178.63 points, or 1 percent, at 17,646.15. On Monday, the Nikkei gained 177.33 points, or 1 percent.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: EX-CAMPUS REBELS HELD IN SPY CASE
description: Three onetime student radicals at the University of Wisconsin were charged today with spying for Communist intelligence services since the 1970's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, LEVERITT A.
description: WALLACE-Leveritt A. On October 5, 1997. Husband of Marcia and the late Bernice Krasne. Father of Nancy Cooper, Benjamin and Elizabeth. Step-father of Susan, Laura, Jonathan and Benjamin Svetkey. Father-in-law of Stephen Houze, Charles van der Horst, Jeannie Hatcherson and Ilana Svetkey. Grandfather of nine. Brother of Barbara, Edward, Emmett, Priscilla Strauss, Caroline Darack. Funeral services 1PM today at The Chapel in the Woods, Kol Ami (Jewish Community Center), 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, N.Y.

title: Legislators to Consider Letting Military Recruiters on Campuses
description: Fearing that Connecticut's public universities will lose up to $70 million a year in Federal aid because of a state ban on military recruiting on campus, lawmakers will consider changing state law at a special session of the Legislature announced today by Gov. John G. Rowland.

title: By Design; Romantic for After 5
description: Fall isn't all power suits and stilettos. Soft fabrics, prints and embroideries on clothes and accessories have a romantic quality that may not be right for the office but exudes femininity for those special after-5 hours.

title: Democrats Affirm Allegiance to Party, and to Messinger
description: Stung by the defection of several prominent Democrats to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, about three dozen Democratic elected officials reaffirmed their allegiance to the party and to Ruth W. Messinger at a rally yesterday afternoon in a Manhattan union hall.

title: INSIDE
description: Victory for Tribunal

title: Red Bank's McCoo Puts Up Big Numbers
description: Eric McCoo's press clippings rest on his coach's desk beneath a batch of his impressive statistics, which rest beneath a stack of letters from major college football programs, which rest beneath a single sheet of paper titled ''Graduation Rates Report.''

title: A Taste for Catfish Lands a Bird in Trouble as Farmers Seek to Arm
description: HARDLY anybody loves the double-crested cormorant. Least of all fishermen, who since Colonial days have tended to view these large, greenish-black water birds with hostility in the belief that they consume tremendous quantities of commercial and game fish. Until the early 1960's, fishermen on the Great Lakes in Canada, with official acquiescence, destroyed cormorant colonies by killing the adult birds with shotguns and smashing their eggs.

title: West Siders Testing a Plastic Substitute for Pocket Change
description: Credit cards, debit cards, bank cards and transit fare cards already stuff the wallets of sophisticated New Yorkers. Now, the question being asked on Manhattan's Upper West Side is whether to bother with still another kind of plastic card that promises to make it possible to go shopping without pennies, nickels, dimes or paper money.

title: UNION PACIFIC RESOURCES REVISES ITS OFFER FOR PENNZOIL
description: Union Pacific Resources Group Inc. said yesterday that it had offered to pay $84 a share in cash for all of the Pennzoil Company's shares, revising its original offer. In June, Union Pacific Resources offered cash for 50.1 percent of Pennzoil's shares and stock valued at $84 a share for the remaining Pennzoil shares. Pennzoil, based in Houston, rejected the $6.4 billion offer. Pennzoil said it would review the latest offer. Shares of both oil companies were halted in late trading. Pennzoil shares last traded at $82.50, up from their closing price of $81.4375 Friday. Union Pacific Resources shares last traded at $26.625, up from Friday's closing share price of $26.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, NATHAN H.
description: MANN-Nathan H. On October 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Estelle. Dear uncle to Howard, Alan, Edward and Eric. Brother-in-law to Gus. A caring and warm soul. Services Wednesday 12 noon at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', Queens Blvd. (76th Road), Forest Hills.

title: A Price Tag Of Billions In Nazi Gold
description: A study conducted for the World Jewish Congress concludes that Nazi Germany looted at least $8.5 billion in gold between 1933 and 1945 and for the first time estimates the amount -- nearly a third -- that came from individuals and private businesses rather than central banks.

title: The Masters' Voices; An Oral History of American Musicians In the 20th Century Slowly Wins Respect
description: The idea behind oral history could not be more simple: In every field of human endeavor there are people around right now who have made history, or at least been witness to it. While they are still alive, someone should sit them down and get them to tell their stories for the record.

title: On My Mind; Giuliani's Drug War Pledge
description: The Mayor of New York City has done what no other political candidate in the country has dared. He staked his name and future on fighting the drug war.

title: Game 5 Is a Bad Time for a Nap
description: The Yankees, having lost the fifth and final game of the first phase of the playoffs for the second time in three years, will have all winter to sleep. So why did Andy Pettitte have to take a snooze in the third inning last night?

title: COGNEX AGREES TO BUY APPLIED INTELLIGENT SYSTEMS
description: The Cognex Corporation yesterday offered to buy the closely held Applied Intelligent Systems Inc. for $105 million in stock, a move that would expand its base in the market for ''seeing'' computers. Applied Intelligent Systems, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., is a rival maker of machine vision systems, or computers that can ''see.'' The computers are used in the manufacture of items produced too quickly or within tolerances too small to be analyzed by human eyes. Cognex, based in Natick, Mass., made the announcement after the markets had closed. Its stock fell 62.5 cents, to $33.75.

title: JOLTED FROM A DREAM
description: The fairy tale will not finish with the Yankees wearing glass slippers this October. The storybook will not end with them as heroes again this season. The thrilling ride will not climax with them veering down Fifth Avenue in a ticker-tape parade this autumn. The defending World Series champions lost a chance to continue defending the title by losing in excruciating fashion to the Cleveland Indians, 4-3, in Game 5 of the division series tonight.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Al (Jazzbo) Collins, the disk jockey who broadcast from the imaginary Blue Grotto, misstated the band on which radio station WNEW broadcast in New York when it hired him in 1950. It was AM then; it is FM now.

title: Medicare and the Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Kirov Dancers Go Touring, With a Mix of Stars and Youngsters
description: The Russians are coming, and as this season suggests, they will keep on coming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLER, GERTRUDE E.
description: MULLER-Gertrude E., on October 2, 1997. Wife of John (Hans). Mother of Susan. Grandmother of Elyse. Service was held Sunday, October 5, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK
description: Some Bad News For Minnesota

title: Girl, 14, Is Slashed By 2 Youths in Subway
description: A 14-year-old girl was slashed across the face yesterday as she was exiting a Manhattan subway station, the police said. The suspects -- a girl and boy ages 15 to 18 -- escaped, said Officer Valerie St. Rose, a Police Department spokeswoman.

title: Clinton Vetoes 38 Military Items, Drawing Many Lawmakers' Ire
description: President Clinton used his new line-item-veto power today to pinpoint and strike from a vast military construction law more than three dozen projects across the country, angering home-district lawmakers who had won Congress's support for them as essential to the national defense.

title: The Sting of Bias
description: WHAT good is a male paper wasp to its sisters, who, after all, do all the work to maintain the colony and produce its future workers, all of them female? Apparently, a new study says, female wasps regard their brothers as little more than a drain on the colony's food supply.

title: Big Men's Mishaps Point Up Nets' Flaw
description: The first frightening moment of the Nets' training camp occurred just after 11 A.M. today, when Chris Gatling went down with a thump and a yelp, clutching his right knee in pain after he had slipped on a wet spot on the court.

title: The Battle For Hearts And Tonsils; Hospitals Specialize To Enhance Profits
description: As traditional hospitals with more offerings than Macy's decline, a new type is taking their place: the specialized hospital or clinic, designed to conquer a profitable niche.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERENFELD, GERALDINE
description: STERENFELD-Geraldine. The entire Beth-El family records with profound sorrow the passing of its long time member Geraldine Sterenfeld. We extend heartfelt sympathy to Dr. Gail Davidson, Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi Joshua Davidson and Jeremy Davidson. Shelley M. Limmer, President

title: Occidental Chief Gets $95 Million Contract Buyout, and New Pact
description: Ray R. Irani, the chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, appears to have learned something about pay packages from his predecessor, Armand Hammer.

title: How Grapefruit Juice Makes Some Pills More Powerful
description: FOR four years, the patient was one of Dr. Paul Pizarik's bigger problems: a 63-year-old Arizona man with heart, lung and kidney disease, and blood pressure that stayed dangerously high despite combinations of a half-dozen different advanced medications.

title: Alice's Adventures in Boredomland
description: A PHRASE like ''based on extensive research'' tells you as much about the quality of a computer program as the phrase ''years in the making'' does about a movie. ''Ishtar,'' ''Waterworld'' and ''Heaven's Gate'' may have spent many moons in the ovens of production, but they still emerged half-baked. In the computer world, ''research'' has lately served as justification for mistakes like the late Microsoft Bob.

title: Delaying Kindergarten May Hurt Child Later, a Study Finds
description: Parents who are thinking about delaying their children's entry into kindergarten so they can better cope emotionally and academically with school should think again, a new study has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSON, VIVIAN A.
description: OLSON-Vivian A. The leadership and staff of UJA-Federation mourn the passing of Vivian A. Olson, beloved mother of Kathryn Greenberg, a cherished leader in our community, and founder and Chairman of the Board of the New York Legal Assistance Group, a UJA-Federation beneficiary agency. Kathryn and her husband, Alan C. Greenberg, are enormously beloved, admired and respected throughout the community for their extraordinary leadership, commitment and philanthropy on behalf of UJA-Federation and many other organizations worldwide. We extend our sincerest condolences to the entire family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: De La Hoya Hits Town With a Title in Mind
description: Oscar De La Hoya, the World Boxing Council welterweight champion, brought his road show east yesterday to talk about his championship bout against Wilfred Rivera at the Atlantic City Convention Center on Dec. 6.

title: Abolishing Fraternities Isn't Answer to Drinking; Conformity in a Bottle
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: JAMES A. MICHENER, the Pulitzer Prize-winning historical novelist, is making the University of Northern Colorado the only recipient of his manuscripts, personal documents, notes, research, even the furnishings of the various rooms in which he wrote his more than 40 books.

title: 6 Youths Held In Sex Assault On a Girl, 13, In High School
description: Four teen-age boys and two teen-age girls were arrested yesterday and charged with sexually assaulting a 13-year-old girl in a boy's bathroom at a Manhattan high school, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOCHTENBERG, ESTELLE
description: DOCHTENBERG - Estelle. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Estelle Dochtenberg beloved mother of our devoted members Phyllis and Andrew Fier. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Death-Row Inmate Loses Bid
description: Robert O. Marshall, the inmate on death row whose contract killing of his wife became the subject of a best-selling book and a television movie, suffered another legal setback yesterday when the United States Supreme Court refused to hear his latest appeal, the A.P. reported.

title: Abolishing Fraternities Isn't Answer to Drinking; Social-Club Innovator
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. to Demolish Artists' Mercury-Tainted Building
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it planned to demolish a former factory building here that just three years ago was envisioned as the first step in transforming an aging industrial area into an artists' mecca, with SoHo-style lofts at bargain prices.

title: Cries of 'Foul' as Networks Buy Into Shows
description: Wedged between the tried-and-true hits on NBC's powerhouse Thursday night schedule this fall is a newcomer that has generated a good deal of industry buzz, not about its content or quality but about its ownership.

title: For Malaysia, Can One 'National Card' Do It All?
description: KUALA LUMPUR  If the Malaysian government has its way, every person over 12 years old in this country of 20 million will soon have a piece of silicon in his pocket.

title: Looking for Tripwires, Ickes Heads to the Witness Stand
description: To Harold M. Ickes, the tart-tongued self-described ''bottom-line guy'' in President Clinton's re-election campaign, his latest Congressional summons for more testimony about big-money fund raising at the White House is merely the latest round of what he dismissively terms the great Washington game of ''Gotcha.''

title: Enough Chitchat? Bring In da Tapping
description: The explosion of energy onstage makes it possible to claim that the autumn season at Columbia University's Miller Theater got off with a bang on Sunday night. But it would be more accurate to say it began with a clatter, with ''A Tribute to Savion Glover,'' honoring the young tap dancer who has created a sensation in ''Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk'' and other productions.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Federal Express to Buy Trucker for $2.4 Billion

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, FLORENCE
description: MEYER-Florence. On October 5, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Meyer. Dear mother of Marilyn (Abe) Wertheim and Jeffrey (Anne) Meyer. Adored grandmother of Robert, Eric, Caryn, Rachel and Rebecca. Cherished aunt. Services Wednesday, October 8, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 27 about a dispute over a New York City police officer who refused a medal sponsored by a gay police group, the Gay Officers Action League, misstated the given name of the group's president. He is Edgar Rodriguez, not Edwin.

title: Two Party Officials Describe a Failed Plan to Swap Donations Between Campaigns
description: As the Senate panel investigating fund-raising excesses in the 1996 election turns its attention to ties between the Democratic Party and the troubled teamsters union, two former Democratic National Committee fund-raising officials today said that they had been involved in a failed effort to steer a donor to the campaign of the teamsters' president, Ron Carey.

title: No Winner in 2 Yugoslavia Presidential Votes
description: The races for President in the two republics that make up Yugoslavia tonight appeared to be headed for a deadlock that would force a new election in Serbia and a runoff in Montenegro, according to official results.

title: MANY MORE TAPES COULD BE FOUND, WHITE HOUSE SAYS
description: As White House officials tried for a second day to explain their failure to turn over to investigators long-sought videotapes of President Clinton at 44 coffees with wealthy supporters, they acknowledged that even more tapes of political events and Presidential fund-raisers had surfaced and that they were likely to find still more.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Appearing on a soap opera seems almost a rite of passage for anyone in the public eye these days, so one ought not be surprised by the fact that the British Prime Minister, TONY BLAIR, took time during the course of his whirlwind visit to Moscow yesterday to appear on a radio soap there.

title: Studies Note Pervasiveness of Chemical
description: For more than 60 years, cleaners have dipped delicate garments in a powerful solvent, perchloroethylene, to lift stains without damaging fabric. It is this pungent chemical that one smells when a plastic-sheathed suit or dress is unwrapped. The waterless process is ''dry'' cleaning.

title: Warning on Global Warming
description: New Jersey environmentalists, backed by Rutgers University professors and other experts in climate patterns, urged the Clinton Administration yesterday to lead the world in reducing greenhouse gases to fight global warming.

title: Gaza Gives Freed Sheik Welcome Fit for a Hero
description: The excitement had been building for hours in the heat and dust of Yarmuk Stadium in downtown Gaza, but at 4:50 this afternoon, when Sheik Ahmed Yassin was finally borne into the main grandstand, the crowd erupted in a thunderous roar.

title: Ahmanson In Deal for Coast Federal
description: H. F. Ahmanson & Company took a big step yesterday to enlarge its California presence with a deal to buy Coast Federal Savings for about $901 million in stock.

title: Impasse Now Seems Probable In Campaign Financing Bill
description: On the eve of crucial Senate votes that could determine the fate of campaign finance legislation this year, two important Republican swing Senators had very different days.

title: Metro Business Briefs; Law Firm Bought
description: Brumbaugh, Graves, Donohue & Raymond, a New York City law firm that specializes in intellectual-property disputes, has been acquired by Baker & Botts L.L.P., a general practice law firm headquartered in Houston, the firms announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNETZ, FRANK J.
description: DUNETZ-Frank J. Beloved husband of Marion Munde Dunetz and the late Sophie. Loving father of Marcia and Nancy. Adored step-father of Richard and Pamela Munde and Susan and Maurice Tieman. Dear brother of Sadie Levy, Margaret Swann and the late Isabelle Dunetz. Cherished grandfather of David and Donna Johnson, Juliet Munde and Jameson Tieman. Graveside service at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, N.Y. Thursday, 12:30PM. Visitation Wednesday, 7-9PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave, NYC.

title: Baltimore Counts On Big Finish By Bullpen
description: The Baltimore relievers were the last Orioles spraying Champagne and beer and sloshing water in the home clubhouse at Camden Yards on Sunday, and that was apropos. Once more the bullpen finished the action, the likes of Armando Benitez, Alan Mills and Arthur Rhodes celebrating with each other after beating Seattle in the division series.

title: Accounts
description: * Qualcomm Inc., San Diego, to Ingalls Moranville Advertising, San Francisco, a unit of Davis Elen Advertising, to handle creative duties for Eudora E-mail, which had been at Resource Marketing, San Francisco. Billings were $3 million. Media duties are handled by Susan Schermerhorn Media, San Francisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURT, MICHAEL, M.D.
description: BURT-Michael, M.D., Ph.D. October 4, 1997. Beloved husband of Kathleen. Dear son of Shirley and Maurice Mastromonico. Loving father of Bryan and Lauren. Dear brother of Gail Jannicelli and much loved son-in-law of Kathleen and John Ahearn. Friends may call Tuesday 2-4 and 6-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Funeral Mass at St. Catherine of Siena RC Church, 411 E. 68 St, Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, E. Hanover, NJ. Contributions may be made to the Dr. Michael Burt Memorial Fund for Cancer Research, Dept of Surgery, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, NYC 10021.

title: Women at Helm of New Hampshire Politics
description: Walk down the long, silent halls of the New Hampshire State House, and self-important looking old men with names like Styles Bridges, Huntley N. Spaulding and Henry Quinby peer down at you from their oil portraits in musty complacency.

title: Norwegian Leads
description: Innovation Kvaerner, the yacht from Norway skippered by Knut Frostad, opened up a lead of 46 miles yesterday, the 16th day of the Whitbread Round the World race. EF Language (Paul Cayard) was second after moving ahead of Merit Cup (Grant Dalton), three miles farther back in the 7,350-mile first leg to Cape Town. There are 10 yachts competing for the Volvo trophy.

title: U.S. Oilfield Will Be Sold To Occidental
description: The Federal Government moved to get out of the oil business yesterday by accepting a bid of $3.65 billion in cash from the Occidental Petroleum Corporation for the Government's share of a huge oilfield in California that was acquired in the early 1900's to insure that the Navy had plenty of oil in reserve as it converted from coal.

title: Patterns
description: From the New Look to Now

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCH, REV. THOMAS, O.F.M. CAP.
description: MARCH-Rev. Thomas, O.F.M. Cap. The Capuchin Friars and Parishioners of St. John the Baptist, New York City mourn the loss of Father Tom whom God called to eternal life at 48 years of age, 25 years as a Capuchin and 19 years a priest. Our sympathy is with St. Joseph's Parish, East Patchogue at the loss of their pastor. Our gratitude is to God who gave us Father Tom.

title: Behind the Glitz, Scrappy but Cool
description: There was something resembling a light show at the Foo Fighters concert on Sunday night at Roseland -- strobes, some flashing of the group's Art Deco typeface logo -- but it felt unnecessary, a layering of pure formality. Not just because Dave Grohl, the band's singer-guitarist-songwriter frontman, is wired enough without special effects; more because he and his band spurn the mythology and posing of rock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WECKSELL, ANNE
description: WECKSELL-Anne. On Oct 5, 1997. Beloved wife of Dr. Irving Wecksell. Devoted mother of Alan Wecksell, mother-in-law of Marilyn. Loving grandmother of Evan, Beth, Wendy and Debbie.

title: Jury Is Selected For Antitrust Suit
description: ST. LOUIS

title: Burson-Marsteller Names a Chairman
description: Burson-Marsteller in New York, the public relations unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., has named Graham Phillips, a longtime advertising executive, as chairman, effective Nov. 1.

title: The F.D.A. Approves a Drug. Then What?
description: WHEN Dr. Brian L. Strom gives talks to medical groups, he shows a slide of the Food and Drug Administration's form for reporting adverse reactions to drugs. ''How many of you have ever seen that?'' he asks the doctors in the audience. On average, fewer than a third raise their hands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATIS, DR. JACOB D.
description: MATIS-Dr. Jacob D. died October 6, 1997 at his home in West Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Rosalie. Devoted and adored father of George Matis and Nancy Dreyfuss. Loving grandfather of Jessica Matis and Leah Dreyfuss. Beloved brother of Edith Helsel. Services Thursday 12 pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Roosevelt Hospital.

title: Bus Driver in Fatal Crash Shows Signs of Seizures
description: A neurologist said yesterday that the driver of the runaway city bus that killed a messenger and injured a bicyclist on Fifth Avenue last week experienced ''events consistent with seizures'' during the crash and probably not a heart attack.

title: A Toll of 'Disappearances' In Mexico's War on Drugs
description: The disappearance here earlier this year of Manuel Hernandez, a Texas drywall contractor and former marijuana dealer, with two relatives began like many others. Uniformed federal policemen smashed into a working-class home and dragged the men away, in full view of municipal police officers and frightened neighbors.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: AUTUMN HEAT -- The calendar said Oct. 6, but it felt like July as the mercury reached into the 80's. B6.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORTGANG, PEARL B.
description: FORTGANG-Pearl B., 90, died in Dallas, Texas, October 5, 1997. Interment Dallas, Texas. Preceded in death by her husband, Irving Fortgang. Donations may be made to American Heart Association.

title: African Skull Suggests Diversity of Early Human Relatives
description: A TEAM of Japanese, American and Ethiopian paleontologists, embodying the diversity among modern humans, has found a 1.4-million-year-old skull in Africa and a new reason to think that individuals within fossil species of early human relatives were also manifestly diverse.

title: White House Misses on Children and Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, MIRIAM
description: JACKSON-Miriam. On October 6, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Dr. M. Elliot. Loving grandmother of Jessica Stern and Sarah Fishman, great-grandmother of Elly and Adam Fishman. Donations to Meals On Wheels and the Hugh Doyle Senior Center of New Rochelle. Funeral Wednesday, 12 noon, from the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Le Count Place, New Rochelle. Interment Mt. Eden Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Dow Rises 61 as Broader Indexes Set Records
description: Declining interest rates on the bond market moved stocks higher yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining more than 60 points. And though other major stock market indexes had more modest point gains, those moves were enough to push those indexes to new closing highs.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the pending decision by the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, on whether to seek the death penalty in the killing of a police officer referred incorrectly to Mr. Morgenthau's re-election effort this year. He is not unopposed; Harry Kresky is running on the Independence Party line.

title: Lucent's Chief Executive Post Is Awarded to Expected Heir
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. announced yesterday that Henry B. Schacht, who guided the company's successful spinoff from the AT&T Corporation last year, had ceded his post as chief executive to Richard A. McGinn, the company's president.

title: Kanell Subs for Brown; Let the Debate Begin
description: Danny Kanell's time has come sooner than some expected, not soon enough in the eyes of others.

title: Abolishing Fraternities Isn't Answer to Drinking; European Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACY, ARTHUR
description: TRACY-Arthur ''The Street Singer.'' One of the brightest stars of radio, motion pictures and nightclubs passed away Sunday evening in Manhattan. Mr. Tracy lived here for most of his 98 years. He is survived by his dear brother Bert, beloved ex-wife Blossom and many loving nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, 3080 Broadway, NY, NY 10027. Service on Wednesday, October 8, 12:30 PM at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Berlin Journal; In Tomorrow's City, What to Do With Yesterday?
description: Berlin sometimes seems unable to shake the impression that it is no more than Europe's biggest construction site -- a cacophony of traffic and cranes, a snarl of pumps and earthmovers gouging the foundations of what is supposed to be a glittering metropolis to greet a new millennium.

title: The Predator Falcons
description: As unbeaten Air Force prepares to face its service rival Navy on the road Saturday, Chris Gizzi, the Falcons' senior inside linebacker, has vowed to bring back the Commander-in-Chief trophy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEWY, MADELINE F. (NEE SCHACK)
description: LOEWY - Madeline F. (nee Schack). On October 5, 1997, in Florida. Beloved wife of the late Henry, loving mother of Jeffrey and Ira, cherished grandmother of Ben, Jon, Brad, and David. Devoted mother-in-law of Nancy Jane and Jackie and sister-in-law of Claire. Memorial service at 11 A.M., Sunday, October 12, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Tamarac Fl.

title: Big Pay Packages at Top of Bear Stearns
description: The Bear Stearns Companies paid its top five executives a total of $87.8 million for the investment bank's 1997 fiscal year, ranking them among the highest-paid Wall Street executives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOMITOR, JEAN
description: KOMITOR-Jean. On October 4, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Joseph Komitor. Dear mother of Eleanor (Allan), Crystal and Stanley (Rookie) Komitor. Adored grandmother of Francine, Jeffrey, Howard, Barry, Jamie, Jodi, and great grandmother. Cherished aunt. Services Tuesday October 7, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations can be made in Jean's name to Hospice Foundation of America, 777 17th St, Ste 401, Miami Beach, FL 33139.

title: Bail Denied to Suspect In Immigrants' Smuggling
description: The man accused of masterminding the Golden Venture's 1993 voyage, an ill-fated effort to smuggle hundreds of Chinese immigrants into the United States on a decrepit freighter, pleaded not guilty yesterday in a Brooklyn court and was held without bail to await trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOERFLINGER, JANETTE
description: DOERFLINGER-Janette on October 3, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Loving aunt of Rosemary Schiff and Joyce Edward. Sister of the late Florence and David Levy. Services were private.

title: PUBLISHER SAYS IT WILL REPORT A LOSS AND TAKE A CHARGE
description: The Reader's Digest Association Inc. said yesterday that it expected a loss in its first fiscal quarter because of weak sales and the negative impact of the dollar's strength on overseas revenue. The publisher also said it would take a pretax charge of about $70 million to discontinue some businesses and cover severance costs for job cuts in Europe and the United States. Reader's Digest warned earlier this year that its fiscal year 1998 earnings would be lower than 1997's as it invested in marketing to help reorganize its struggling business.

title: Observer; No Time for the Future
description: A seventh-grader named Pete beat me up in the schoolyard in 1937. Lately, whenever the phone rings, memory swings me back over a chasm 60 years wide, and I think of Pete's fists making my skull bounce up and down on the schoolyard bricks as they played a tattoo on my chin and nose.

title: Pentagon Chief Says Iran Gas Deal Won't Hurt Ties With France
description: Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen said today that whatever action the United States took in response to a French oil company's decision to invest $2 billion in Iran would not undermine close relations between the United States and France.

title: Checketts Has High Hopes For the Knicks Once Again
description: Dave Checketts, wearing khakis, leaned against a wall in a hallway. The setting and wardrobe can be altered, but there is little deviation from the plot.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There are still people who don't believe that a protein can cause these diseases, but we believe it.''

title: Ramirez Rises; Williams Fades
description: Both the Yankees and the Indians entered the most pivotal game of their year hoping to wake the sleeping giant in the middle of the lineup. Do so, and the chances of advancing to the American League Championship Series would be greatly enhanced. Fail and it would be a long off season of wondering what went so wrong for Manny Ramirez, for Bernie Williams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSH, RUTH
description: KOSH-Ruth, 87, of Key Biscayne, FL, passed away October 5, 1997. Ruth had made her home in South Florida for the past 21 years coming from NYC. Ruth was born in New York City and raised in the Seagate Section of Brooklyn. She attended Hunter College. She, with her late husband David of 64 years was his helpmate with his activities at Temple Beth Emeth of Brooklyn, City College of NY and Jewish Federation. Ruth was a great supporter of the Arts, Miami City Ballet, Bass Museum and Florida Philharmonic. Beloved wife of the late David Kosh, devoted mother of Joyce (Dr. Gerard) Kaiser, loving sister of Roselle Schreiber, adored grandmother of Beth (Shai) Gold, Jordan (Elizabeth) Kaiser, Dr. Charles (Hope) Kaiser, dear great-grandmother of Benjamin Gold, Sasha Gold, and Joshua Kaiser. Funeral services will be held 9:30 AM Wednesday, October 8, 1997 at Temple Israel of Greater Miami, 137 NE 19th Street, Miami, FL, with interment to follow at Mt. Nebo Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory may be made to the Friends of the Bass Museum, 2121 Park Avenue, Miami Beach, FL 33139, or the Miami City Ballet, 905 Lincoln Road, Miami Beach, FL 33139. For further information contact Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapel, 1717 S.W. 37th Avenue, Miami, Florida, 305-535-4626.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Tangled Tale of Friends, Partners and Politicians
description: Reflecting on the intimacies between politics and business in the state of Arkansas, James B. McDougal, of Whitewater notoriety, explains tonight that ''politics was seen as an avocation, something you did to pass the time'' while you went about the serious matter of making money.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NACHBAR, MARTIN
description: NACHBAR-Martin. We record with deep sorrow the death of Martin Nachbar, long time and faithful board member. He will be missed. Board of Directors and Staff Mental Health Association of Nassau County

title: Couple Slapped Adopted Russian Girls on Flight, Other Parents Testify
description: Three airline passengers testified yesterday that they saw an Arizona couple repeatedly slap their newly adopted Russian girls on a flight last May from Moscow to New York.

title: Davis Carries the Load as the Broncos Remain Unbeaten
description: After flirting with the New England Patriots for a half, the Denver Broncos put themselves squarely in their place tonight.

title: 2 May Be Tried as Adults In Developer's Killing
description: Federal prosecutors will seek to try as adults two juveniles accused of kidnapping and killing Nelson G. Gross, a developer and the former head of the State Republican Party, a lawyer for one of the teen-agers said yesterday.

title: Giuliani Seeks Curbs On Casino Cruises
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani urged Federal officials yesterday to rule that casino cruises must sail at least 12 miles instead of 3 miles from shore before passengers can start gambling.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 26 about the emerging entertainment scene around Ludlow Street in Lower Manhattan misstated Chris Antista's position at the Lansky Lounge. He is the manager, not a co-owner; the club is owned by Ratner's restaurant.

title: Reverently Naked for Rites in Church
description: ''Study for a Resurrection'' would be effective anywhere. But this new hourlong work surely has special impact in a house of worship. It created a powerful impression when it was presented in the spacious sanctuary of St. Mark's Church by the Creach/ Koester Dance Company, the all-male troupe Mr. Creach founded with Steve Koester.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Agnelli Family and Insurer Top a Bid for Worms & Cie
description: The Agnelli family of Italy and a French insurer bid 31.7 billion francs, or $5.4 billion, today for Worms & Cie, the French sugar, paper and insurance company, topping an earlier offer from the investor Francois Pinault.

title: At the Old Vic, the Show May No Longer Go On
description: Built 180 years ago in an attempt to spruce up the dank and wild South Bank here, the Old Vic theater has as rich and varied a history as they come, having been used over the years as an opera house, a music hall, a college, a temperance hall and a venue for some of the most distinguished acting seen here this century. The Old Vic, near Waterloo Station, is where Lilian Baylis ambitiously staged all of Shakespeare's plays some 80 years ago. It is where Sir John Gielgud made his modest London debut in 1921, appearing as a herald in ''Henry V,'' and where, almost 35 years ago, Sir Laurence Olivier directed the National Theater. And it is where, for the last 10 months, Sir Peter Hall's acclaimed repertory company has injected more than a frisson of excitement into the London theater world with its productions of 13 plays, including ''Waiting for Godot,'' which is to move to New York in January; David Rabe's ''Hurlyburly,'' and Harley Granville-Barker's classic political and sexual morality tale, ''Waste.''

title: Assassination Ill Befits Israel
description: Israel has damaged its own interests with a bungled assassination attempt against a Hamas leader in Amman, Jordan. Even if the two agents of its Mossad intelligence service had succeeded in killing Khaled Meshal with an injection of poison, Israel would have compromised its relations with three important friends -- Jordan, Canada and the United States -- for no obvious security gains. Israel's fury and frustration over terrorist bombings are understandable, but trying to assassinate Palestinian leaders in revenge is not the answer.

title: Breast Cancer Awareness May Carry Its Own Risks
description: HAS the concern about breast cancer gone too far, prompting many women to neglect far more serious risks to their health and life? Two 1997 polls certainly suggest that. A New York Times/CBS News Poll found that 52 percent of women think that they are more likely to die of breast cancer than heart disease. And a survey of 1,000 women 30 to 80 years old by Merck Media Minutes, a newsletter from Merck & Company, reported that women ranked breast cancer as the leading risk to their health, above heart disease and lung cancer. But the facts say otherwise.

title: GUIDANT AGREES TO BUY ENDOVASCULAR FOR $170 MILLION
description: The Guidant Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Endovascular TechnologiesInc. for about $170 million in stock, adding a device intended to prevent ruptures in the body's largest artery to Guidant's products for treating heart disease. Under the agreement, each Endovascular share will be swapped for $20 worth of Guidant stock. Endovascular holds patents that could help Guidant dominate a potential $1 billion worldwide market for fixing aneurysms, or swellings, which can rupture the abdominal section of the aorta, said Samuel Navarro, an analyst with UBS Securities. Shares of Endovascular rose $2.625, to $19. Guidant fell 25 cents, to $60.625.

title: U.S. Scientist Wins Nobel for Controversial Work
description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded yesterday to Dr. Stanley B. Prusiner, a 55-year-old maverick scientist in San Francisco whose discoveries about infectious particles called prions have been criticized by other researchers as unproved.

title: Bond Sale for Apartments
description: The State Housing and Mortgage Finance Agency announced a $100 million bond sale yesterday, the biggest bond sale to build affordable apartments in a decade.

title: Researchers Develop Techniques To Battle Normal Forgetfulness
description: GABRIEL ABBINANTI had always taken pride in his sharp memory, but when he reached his early 60's, he started forgetting things: the car keys, his glasses, people's names. Last fall, he heard about a memory enhancement course given at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, and he decided to give it a try.

title: Pataki to Seek Laws to Curb Violence In the Home
description: Releasing the results of a year-long state study into domestic violence fatalities, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he would renew his efforts next year to pass legislation intended to broadly expand the powers of police officers and prosecutors in handling domestic violence cases.

title: Sports of The Times; Meaningless September Didn't Help
description: RIGHT from the start of the game that would end their season, the Yankees' karma was bad and their execution was worse. The edge that had won them nine straight road post-season games starting last October in Texas all the way through Game 3 here Saturday was as far gone as 1996.

title: WESTERN PACIFIC AIRLINES SEEKS BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
description: Western Pacific Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it had filed for bankruptcy protection from creditors, a week after scrapping plans to buy Frontier Airlines Inc. to compete better with United Airlines in Colorado. The two-year-old airline also said it was talking to an investor about providing debtor-in-possession financing, a kind of financing for companies in bankruptcy court proceedings. It did not name the investor. And it suggested it might sue four directors who resigned abruptly on Friday, raising speculation Western Pacific was headed for bankruptcy court. Western Pacific lost more than 60 percent of its market value after the announcement. Its shares fell $1.8125, to $1. Before trading was halted pending the airline's announcement, the shares touched 75 cents. Western, a low-fare carrier based in Colorado Springs, would not say how much it owed creditors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, LOUIS P.
description: ROSENBERG-Louis P. Beloved husband of the late Ruth M. Loving father of Richard A., Kenneth N. and Kathleen. Cherished grandfather of Jason and Sean. Dear brother of Lillian Sherman, Joseph, Alfred A., and Sylvia Ginsberg. Private funeral services were held on Tuesday, October 7. In lieu of gifts, please donate to the American Cancer Society.

title: Davis Won't Blame His Players
description: Miami's fall from the pinnacle of the Big East -- one victory followed by four straight defeats -- happened because the Hurricanes simply ran out of experienced players, Coach Butch Davis said.

title: Market Place; The Dow becomes another hot product for sale in Chicago.
description: SOME say offering small investors a way to trade futures and options on the Dow Jones industrial average, the world's most famous basket of stocks, is courting disaster. Others proclaim it a wonderful breakthrough that gives such investors valuable new tools to manage their stock portfolios. One thing is certain: the debate is no longer theoretical.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPELMAN, LEONARD
description: SPELMAN-Leonard. The Great Neck United Community Fund notes with profound sadness the passing of Leonard Spelman, Past President of the Fund and a volunteer for over 40 years. Condolences are extended to his family. Richard Arenella, Pres. & Board Grt Nk United Community Fund

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAKIM, EDWARD GEORGE
description: HAKIM-Edward George. On October 6, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Ann (nee Canning). Most devoted father of Edward, Pamela and Diana. Grandfather of Drew, Aisha, Christopher and Ryan. Brother of Violet. Dear companion of Kathryn. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10:15am at St. Patrick's R.C. Church. Visitation Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 at McLaughlin and Sons, 97th Street at Third Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, SONIA
description: KLEIN-Sonia. Died peacefully in Hollywood, Fla., on Monday, Oct 6, 1997. She was the beloved wife of Myron Klein and mother of Eliane. She is survived by her grandchildren Barbara, Daniel and Mark; their spouses and five loving great grandchildren. May she rest in peace.

title: The Double-Decker Bus Wars; 4 Companies Battle for Tourist Business, and With Police
description: It was 8:30 on a brilliant September morning as Kasai Dear, an aspiring East Village novelist and double-decker tour guide, prepared for the rigors of the day -- four windswept loops around the southern third of Manhattan with busloads of wide-eyed visitors under his tutelage and care.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 18 about observances of the 50th anniversary of India's independence from Britain referred incorrectly to the emblem at the center of the Indian flag. It is the dharma chakra, the wheel of the law, an ancient symbol associated with duty and piety. It is not the spinning wheel adopted as the symbol of the Indian National Congress, the nationalist movement that led the campaign for independence. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: No Nobel Prize This Year? Try Footnote Counting
description: OCTOBER is nail-biting season for many senior scientists who hope to be awoken by an early morning call from Stockholm bearing news of their sudden celebrity.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; Love Can Get Complicated (Ouch!)
description: As the 20th century ends, romance and technology have grown inseparable. Connections are made (and broken) by E-mail and answering machine; more trysts are illuminated by video screens than by candlelight. Naturally, the modern love song has adapted to its new circumstances. On the albums reviewed below, samples of old songs drift by like tenacious memories, while stray noises and allusions appear like random souvenirs from cyberspace. Meanwhile, singers still flirt and pine for human contact.

title: Mitsubishi Seeking One Dealer Agency
description: Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America in Irvine, Calif., said yesterday that it would consolidate the accounts of its dealer groups around the country, with billings estimated at $70 million to $80 million, and seek a single agency to handle that assignment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, BENJAMIN
description: GOLDSTEIN-Benjamin. On October 5, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Jean. Loving father of Elaine Brower, Marcia Fergang. Cherished grandfather to Mark, Roy, Robin, Caryl, Yale and Julie. Also survived by five great-grandchildren. Graveside services Tuesday, 2 PM, at Wellwood Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENSAFT, DR. HADASSAH
description: ROSENSAFT-Dr. Hadassah. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Dr. Hadassah Rosensaft ''Matriach of the Survivors'', and extend our deepest sympathies to her children Menachem, Jean and Jodi, and the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AVIATION SALES CO., Miami, an aircraft spare parts company, agreed to acquire the assets of Kratz-Wilde Machine Company, a Cincinnati-based manufacturer of jet engine, auto and faucet components, for about $42.5 million.

title: Clinton Aides Confident On Eve of NATO Debate
description: PARIS  Clinton administration officials said Monday they were confident of winning what promises to be a difficult debate in the Senate over NATO enlargement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, PATRICK JOSEPH
description: MURPHY-Patrick Joseph, formerly of Valley Stream, NY, died Friday, October 3, 1997. He was a graduate of CCNY, a Golden Gloves boxer, and served during W.W. II as a Marine Corps fighter pilot. He was the first Commander of the Catholic War Veterans in LIC. During Mr. Murphy's career he was a NYC Police detective, FBI Special Agent, Deputy Commissioner of Investigations for NYC, and the President of Proudfoot Reports. He is survived by his wife Mary Elizabeth Murphy. Memorial donations in Mr. Murphy's name may be made to Precious Blood of Christ Church Building Fund, 455 Waverly Shell Rd., Pawleys Island, S.C. 29585.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGEL, MIRIAM
description: ENGEL-Miriam. Beloved wife of Jack. Devoted mother of Martin. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Dear sister. Services and interment at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Babylon Rd., Farmingdale, Wednesday, October 8, 12:30 p.m.

title: Abolishing Fraternities Isn't Answer to Drinking
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTESMAN, ESTHER G.
description: GOTTESMAN-Esther G. Librarians and staff at Yeshiva University's Mendel Gottesman Library extend heartfelt condolences to children David S. and Ruth Gottesman and Milton Gottesman, grandchildren, great-grandchildren, brothers, sister, and the entire family upon the passing of a woman of dignity, creativity, and dedication to principle and community. May the education she so valued and the tradition she so cherished be transmitted to generations of young men and women through the Library which bears the Gottesman name. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Pearl Berger Benjamin Gottesman Librarian Yeshiva University

title: Politicizing the Death Penalty
description: The Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, is under considerable pressure from Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani to seek the death penalty for Scott Schneiderman, who is accused of killing New York City police officer Anthony Sanchez in May. Mr. Morgenthau's decision is expected tomorrow.

title: Earnings Rise 29% at Motorola
description: Motorola said yesterday that earnings rose 29 percent, helped by sales of wireless phones and chips. But profit from paging fell and the company warned of slower sales growth in the fourth quarter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEMELSON, JEROME H.
description: LEMELSON-Jerome H. The Board of Trustees, President David C. Chang, the faculty, students and alumni of Polytechnic University profoundly regret the passing of Jerome H. Lemelson, one of the world's most prolific and courageous inventors and a hero to all who follow in his footsteps. Mr. Lemelson, a graduate of New York University's School of Engineering, which was absorbed by Polytechnic in 1973, held a 1995 honorary degree from Polytechnic for being ''the incomparable entrepreneur of our high-technology age'' and for his unstinting support of creativity and innovation as key values for American education and business. Mr. Lemelson's patent portfolio will be second only to that of Thomas A. Edison as the nation's most prolific inventor. The Dorothy and Jerome Lemelson Foundation he established is devoted to raising public consciousness about the importance of inventors and preventing their exploitation. The Lemelson National Program supports, among many causes, the Hands-On Science Center at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C. Our heartfelt condolences go to his wife, Dorothy; two sons, Eric and Robert; two brothers, Howard and Justin, and two grandchildren.

title: Rangers Missing the Power in Power Play
description: Lost in the fuss over the in-the-crease rule that reared its head in the Rangers' 2-2 tie with Los Angeles on Sunday night was the fact that the Rangers' power play was remarkably ineffective.

title: A Voyage of Discovery to the Ringed Planet
description: RESTING atop a rocket at Cape Canaveral, Fla., is a spacecraft being groomed for the most expensive and ambitious single mission of planetary exploration thus far, a seven-year journey to the beautiful ringed planet Saturn. The Cassini craft will undertake to orbit Saturn, get close-up views of its 18 known moons and dispatch a probe to the largest of these, Titan, which may hold answers to the mystery of life's origins.

title: Tumultuous Past
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Contends Billing Fraud At Columbia Was 'Systemic'
description: Government investigators have obtained evidence that the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation engaged in ''a systemic corporate scheme perpetrated'' by its executives and managers in at least four states, according to an affidavit by the senior agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation who is involved in the case.

title: Disco-Driven 'Heroes,' With Shiny Silver Pants
description: ''Heroes' and ''66'' were the New York premieres presented by Twyla Tharp's new company, Tharp!, on Saturday night.

title: Patience Rewarded and Rewarding
description: Much about Greg Tardy's concert at the Minetta Lane Theater on Saturday night was an encouraging experience: exciting and good for jazz. The theater, which has just started to present jazz on weekends and Mondays after its playgoing crowd empties out, has fine natural acoustics, and even a heavyweight drum solo with a lot of cymbals -- Marcus Baylor's finishing touch to the first set -- didn't fry anyone's ears. Admission was shockingly cheap, only $5 for some seats, and the house was full of students demanding excitement.

title: Banks Take On Credit Unions Over the Limits of Membership
description: Two fierce competitors for the consumer banking dollar banks and credit unions -- battled before the Supreme Court on its opening day today in arguments over the validity of a Federal regulation that has permitted credit unions to expand far beyond their traditional base among employees of a single company or members of a single occupation.

title: Second Condom Survey
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVEY, GERTRUDE
description: LEVEY-Gertrude. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Arthur, Matthew, David and Shira. Cherished grandmother of Maxwell. Dear sister of Daniel. Services Wednesday 2PM at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Justices Begin New Term by Turning Down Two Campaign Finance Cases
description: The Supreme Court today refused to hear two campaign finance cases that might have moved the Justices from the sidelines to the center of the public debate over money and politics.

title: Silicon Graphics Expects A Loss, and Its Stock Dives
description: Shares of Silicon Graphics lost a third of their value today after the company said it expected to report a loss for its first fiscal quarter.

title: A Rookie and a Veteran Were Cleveland's Keys
description: The Cleveland Indians, a curious mixture of youth and experience, could not hide that disparity when they turned their fate from Orel Hershiser in Games 1 and 4 to the rookie Jaret Wright in Games 2 and 5.

title: Supreme Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Bre-X Is Facing a New Suit in Alberta
description: Bre-X Minerals Ltd. faces another class-action suit as early as Tuesday, a lawyer representing shareholders of the collapsed mining company said today.

title: Man Who Bilked Friends and Relatives of Millions Is Sentenced to 4 Years
description: An investment adviser who swindled millions of dollars from relatives, close friends and others was sentenced to the maximum of four years and three months in prison yesterday after some of his victims, confronting him emotionally in court, asked how he could have bilked people who had loved and trusted him.

title: 10 Bosnian Croats Surrender to War Crimes Tribunal
description: After several months of intense negotiations between Washington and Croatia, 10 Bosnian Croats, including one of the most-wanted war crimes suspects in Bosnia, turned themselves in to the international tribunal in The Hague today.

title: Federal Express Buying Trucking Concern
description: The Federal Express Corporation, seeking to snatch more business from the strike-weakened United Parcel Service, is buying the Caliber System Inc. trucking company for about $2.4 billion in stock.

description: World Cup
