title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFF, GEORGE EDWARD
description: HOFF-George Edward, who was President of CPC International Inc. Worldwide Corn Wet Milling Division from November 1983 until his retirement in June 1985, died on Sunday, October 5, at his home in Oradell, N.J. Mr. Hoff, 77 years old, had Parkinson's Disease. Beginning his career with CPC in 1947 at Argo, IL Corn Products Plant, Mr. Hoff rose to be Director of Engineering. After being promoted to a corporate position, he was transferred in 1968 to the company's headquarters in Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Mr. Hoff advanced through positions in engineering and administration in its Corn Wet Milling Operations, traveling extensively throughout the world. At the time he was President, Mr. Hoff directed a division that had worldwide sales of over $1.5 billion, 38 manufacturing plants in 21 countries, and over 12,000 employees around the world. It was the largest such operation in the world. Mr. Hoff who was born in Waukegan, IL, in 1920, held a Bachelor of Science and a Master of Science Degree in Chemical Engineering from Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago. He was also a graduate of the Harvard Business School Advanced Management Program. He served throughout World War II with the rank of Lieutenant in the United States Navy as a Torpedo Officer in the Pacific Theatre. He was an active member of St. Joseph Catholic Church in Oradell, N.J. for 29 years and before that the Divine Infant Church in Westchester, IL for 14 years. Mr. Hoff was a member of the Hackensack Golf Club in Oradell, N.J. and a retired executive of the Men's Group Adventures Unlimited. Mr. Hoff is survived by his wife of 49 years, the former Mary Catherine Tuomey of Chicago. His seven surviving children are Mary Ilene Roof, Nancy Tishman, both of Arlington, VA; Walter Hoff of Atlanta, GA; Vincent Hoff of Honolulu, Hawaii; Edward Hoff of Cambridge, MA; Geri Havill of Packanack Lakes, N.J.; and James Hoff of Tulsa, OK. He is also survived by his children's seven spouses, 17 grandchildren and his sister, Agnes Gerthar of Sun City, AZ. A son, Thomas Hoff, died in 1965 as a result of Cerebral Palsy.

title: Principal Is Suspended
description: The principal of a Roman Catholic high school was suspended from his job yesterday following allegations that he had abused a young boy for seven years, beginning when the boy was 6 years old, The Associated Press reported.

title: Monkeys, Like Mice, Live Well and Prosper On Low-Calorie Diet
description: IF you eat less, will you live longer? It is tempting to quip that life would at least seem longer. But the question is serious and has intrigued scientists since the 1930's, when it was discovered that a very low-calorie diet would lengthen rats' maximum life spans from three years to four, an increase of 33 percent.

title: CHESS
description: The advantage of playing an old workhorse like the Queen's Gambit Declined is that unless you just forget what you are about, you are not going to get blown off the board. Also, you are not going to get chances for keen counterattacks. Whatever you are going to do must be done patiently in the middle game.

title: Treasuries Up In Optimism On Economy
description: Faced with reduced prospects of an interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve after a benign employment report on Friday, and with few economic reports due early this week, investors bought Treasury securities yesterday amid optimism that economic growth was slow enough to keep inflation at bay.

title: N.B.A.: NOTEBOOK
description: Atlanta

title: CREATIVE IS IN TALKS TO BUY CAMBRIDGE SOUNDWORKS
description: Creative Technology Ltd. is in talks to buy Cambridge Soundworks Inc., Cambridge said yesterday. Creative, which is based in Singapore, makes Sound Blaster and other sound and video products for desktop computers. It owns about 25 percent of Cambridge Soundworks' stock and is the largest buyer of the company's multimedia sound products. Shares of Cambridge Soundworks, based in Newton, Mass., rose $2.875, to $10, on trading of 226,500 shares, more than 15 times the three-month daily average. Shares of Creative fell 93.75 cents, to $24.5625.

title: Scientists Split Over Prior Hypothesis
description: The prion hypothesis has never gone down easily among scientists.

title: ARCO CHEMICAL TO TAKE $116 MILLION CHARGE
description: The ARCO Chemical Company said yesterday that it would take a third-quarter charge of $116 million, or $1.20 a share, for plant closings, job cuts and write-offs as part of a plan to reduce costs and raise its stock price. ARCO Chemical, a unit of the Atlantic Richfield Company, announced the reorganization plan in May. In June, it said it would cut as many as 1,100 jobs, or about 20 percent of its work force, by the end of 1998. The company was expected to earn 71 cents in the quarter, according to the average estimate of five analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International Inc. Shares of ARCO Chemical, based in Newtown Square, Pa., rose $1.125, to $48.125, yesterday.

title: Rockefeller Foundation Names Briton Its Chief
description: The Rockefeller Foundation has chosen Gordon Conway, a British agricultural ecologist and the vice chancellor of the University of Sussex in England, to be the 12th president of the foundation, one of the nation's oldest and largest.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Free Speech Gets Lost In the Smoke
description: IF you were looking for moral high ground, you could have done worse than to watch New York City Council members yesterday as they inveighed against the tobacco industry and demanded a law banning outdoor cigarette advertisements near schools, playgrounds, amusement arcades and other places where youngsters hang out.

title: CSX ASKS STATE COURT TO OVERTURN $2.5 BILLION VERDICT
description: The CSX Corporation yesterday asked a Louisiana appellate court to overturn a $2.5 billion punitive damage verdict handed down last month for a 1987 railroad tank car fire that forced the evacuation of almost 8,000 New Orleans residents. The company argued that it had been subjected to an excessive penalty and was not responsible for the accident. Lawyers for the plaintiffs successfully argued during the trial that under Louisiana law, property owners have broad responsibility to guard against damage to others. The fire broke out in a rail yard owned by the company.

title: Rosemary R. Gunning, 92, Foe of School Busing
description: Rosemary R. Gunning, who led fights against school busing in New York City in the 1960's and went on to become one of the first female Assembly members, died on Saturday night at the home of a niece in Roslyn, N.Y. She was 92.

title: In a Shaky Business, Who Rules?
description: There must be a place where head coaches go to seek help for all the madness around them. ''Listen, doc,'' they would begin, ''sometimes I just can't understand this National Football League thing. One week my team plays mad as a bear, the next week they lose to the Bears. Help me get inside their heads, please.''

title: A Steamy Summer Leftover
description: Having peeled off his T-shirt yesterday morning in Central Park, Matthew Cornelissen said he was surprised that it was so warm in New York. He said he expected it to be about 10.

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP
description: Corel to End Sponsorship Deal

title: Just Too Good to Be True
description: It sounded like an easy way to make a buck, according to a booklet mailed out to thousands of New Jersey residents: Send in $20 or $25, and in return receive ''one hundred in legal currency'' by manipulating international money markets.

title: GTE Sues Netscape and Yahoo Over Internet Yellow Pages Access
description: The GTE Corporation filed an antitrust suit yesterday accusing the five regional Bell telephone companies, as well as two Internet companies, Netscape Communications and Yahoo Inc., with conspiring to limit competition in the emerging market for on-line yellow pages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASS, DR. SHELDON
description: PASS-Dr. Sheldon. Beloved husband of Sheila, devoted father of Dr. Adam and Dr. Robert, dear brother of Lenore Feldman, cherished grandfather of Scott, loving father-in-law of Joanne and sonin-law of Sylvia Waldinger. Services were held Monday, 1 pm at Parkside Memorial Chapel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ARTHUR E.
description: SMITH-Arthur E., nationally renowned interior designer, died Friday of complications from cancer and renal failure at New York Hospital. He was 56. A native of Vidalia, Ga, he graduated from Auburn University's Interior Design program in 1960. Mr. Smith moved to New York City in 1962 where he worked with Billy Baldwin, first as his protege and then as his partner until Mr. Baldwin's retirement in 1972. Mr. Smith has had his own firm since that time. In 1988 he decided to expand his business and opened A Smith Antiques, Ltd. Mr. Smith's work has been featured in Architectural Digest, House & Garden and Veranda Magazine, along with the New York Times and other cultural publications. In 1990 Architectural Digest included Mr. Smith in its top 100 world-wide listing of interior designers. He is survived by his mother, Mary C. Smith and sister, Marilou Smith Russell, both of Vidalia as well as a nephew, Chris Russell of Charleston, SC, a niece, Sue Ann Wilson of Marietta and three great nephews. Memorial services will be held in New York and Vidalia. The funeral will be private. In lieu of flowers the family has requested donations be made to: Blood and Cancer Research Fund, in memory of Arthur E. Smith, 525 East 68th Street, New York, NY 10021.

title: American Nativism Has 19th-Century Roots
description: To the Editor:

title: Sex Complaint Surfaces Against Whitman Official
description: Just after Christine Todd Whitman became Governor of New Jersey in 1994, a woman accused one of her Cabinet choices of making unwanted sexual advances. After an investigation by the Attorney General substantiated the complaint, the Governor kept the man, Gualberto Medina, in office and sent a reprimand to his file.

title: Schools as a Path to Political Power
description: Tonight we meet Donna Mengel, a school board member in a Philadelphia suburb, as she is denying charges that she made a remark about ''Jews burning in hell.'' But ''New School Order'' is not essentially a report on anti-Semitism. Ms. Mengel turns out to be leading a campaign in the North Penn School District in Lansdale, Pa., to save money and shape the curriculum by scrapping plans to build a high school (''Kill that project!'') and seeing to it that teachers concentrate on the basics instead of giving attention to sex education, art, music and the like.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, JULIUS (JULIE)
description: HOROWITZ-Julius (Julie) Beloved husband and best friend of Jean. Devoted Father of Susan, Bobbi, Eileen and the late Mindy. Good friend to sons-in-law Jon, Bruce and David. Best Pop Pop to Andrew, Elizabeth, Stephen, Hadley, Alex and Michael. Brother of Arthur. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 10am Tuesday.

title: Rubbermaid-Amway Deal
description: Rubbermaid Inc. will introduce a line of food storage containers this month to be sold exclusively by the Amway Corporation in the United States and Europe, the first products developed under an alliance between the companies. The three sets of dishes are clear and made from a plastic material similar to that used to make bulletproof glass, said Rubbermaid, which is based in Wooster.

title: Two Unions Back Whitman
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman picked up endorsements yesterday from two labor unions for her re-election campaign against her Democratic challenger, State Senator James E. McGreevey.

title: 2 BIOTECHNOLOGY COMPANIES, ALZA AND ALKERMES, IN DEAL
description: The Alza Corporation said yesterday that it would pay Alkermes Inc. $10 million to help Alkermes develop its agent to ease the delivery of tumor drugs to the brain, and possibly $50 million more pending further studies of the agent and regulatory approval. Alza will pay the $10 million immediately to finance advanced clinical study of RMP-7, which speeds delivery of tumor-treating drugs to the brain. In exchange, Alza will receive the option to exclusively market RMP-7 worldwide, the companies said. Alza, based in Palo Alto, Calif., and Alkermes, based in Cambridge, Mass., will split profits from RMP-7 if it is cleared for sale. Shares of Alkermes rose $1.625, to $23.625, while Alza stock fell 62.5 cents, to $27.625.

title: Campaign Laws, Old and New; The Justice Department Meltdown
description: Well, the White House damage-control team has embarrassed Janet Reno yet again, and the guess here is that the Attorney General is pretty calm about it. It has been a full year since Ms. Reno was confronted with initial evidence of the biggest political money scandal in a generation, and her response shows little concern with her place in history as a custodian of the Justice Department. So it is unlikely that she would be chagrined that only one day after she assured Congress that there was no need for an independent counsel to investigate foreign money or influence peddling on White House premises, Time magazine disclosed the existence of videotapes of White House fund-raising events that she and her investigators had not found.

title: Netanyahu Defiantly Defending Botched Assassination Attempt
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu today defended the costly Israeli assassination attempt against a Hamas leader as a setback in a ''just and vital fight'' against terrorism, making no apology and defiantly vowing to carry on.

title: Mahler Songs, Miniaturized but Unmistakably His
description: The main work on the program for Friday's concert at the Metropolitan Museum was a version of a version of Mahler's ''Song of the Earth.'' Mahler intended that piece for two singers declaiming heroically over a large orchestra; Schoenberg had the notion of reducing the orchestra to a chamber group of around 15 players, in the way he liked to do in order to make big scores performable by the private concert organization he ran for a few years after World War II; Rainer Riehn, in the 1980's, eventually carried through Schoenberg's project.

title: Playoffs Are on Jets' Minds
description: It will not quite be real for another two games. By then, Coach Bill Parcells and his players indicated today, they will be ready to acknowledge it: a playoff race.

title: Johnny Vander Meer, 82, No-Hit Master, Dies
description: Johnny Vander Meer, the Cincinnati Reds left-hander who in 1938 threw two consecutive no-hit games -- the only pitcher in major league history to accomplish the feat -- died yesterday at his home in Tampa, Fla. He was 82.

title: People
description: * Pierre Lecosse, chief executive at Euro RSCG Asia/Pacific, Singapore, part of Havas Advertising, was named president and chief executive at Euro RSCG Europe, a vacant post, initially dividing his time between Europe and New York.

title: Campaign Laws, Old and New; Trent Lott's Strangulation Strategy
description: Trent Lott, the majority leader, has picked today to bury the McCain-Feingold campaign finance reform bill in the Senate. He hopes the public will not notice his effort to block a ban on unlimited contributions from corporations, rich individuals and labor unions that sustain both parties. But Mr. Lott and his allies are in denial. These donations are driving the public toward cynicism and despair about their political leaders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUCKER, WALTER
description: TUCKER-Walter. Died Friday, October 3, 1997. Brother of Malvina Cook and Frances Brown. Devoted uncle to Deborah Cook. Good friend to many. Admired 30 year employee of NYU with a heart of gold. Your compassion, thoughtfulness, love of music and independence will be sorely missed by all. Through your dreams and in our hearts you will be remembered. Cheers Handsome, to Leontyne, Venice, your life and peace. Friends and Family

title: Childhood Hurt and Fear as a Writer's Inspiration
description: BOYHOOD

title: France Telecom Shares Priced
description: The French Government priced the sale of a stake in France Telecom S.A. at 187 francs ($32) a share today. The sale, the country's biggest initial public offering, will raise 42 billion francs ($7.19 billion).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, SYLVIA
description: HOFFMAN-Sylvia, at age 100, on October 5, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Stephen R., devoted mother of Roslyn Masters and Marjorie Hausman. Cherished grandmother of Wendy Jupiter, Linda Barrows, Dion Kreizel, Fredrick Masters and Richard Hausman. Loving great grandmother of six.

title: Yankees' Bid For a Repeat Is Over Early
description: Unlike their predecessors of two decades past, the Yankees will not repeat as World Series champions this year. With a 4-3 victory tonight, the Cleveland Indians captured the decisive fifth game of their division series and ended the Yankees' chance to match their 1977-78 teams.

title: Marlins Hope Rotation Will Baffle the Braves
description: There are no secrets to beating the Atlanta Braves, no code to be broken, no riddle to be solved. Everybody knows the solution -- you must neutralize the impact of a pitching rotation that is among the best in baseball history.

title: The Only Exit From Bosnia
description: The Clinton Administration has gotten itself into a real pickle in Bosnia. Congress wants American troops out by June 1998, but the Clinton team has no exit strategy. Indeed, its current policy of keeping Bosnia together guarantees an endless American military commitment. Congress will eventually compel a withdrawal -- whether in 1998 or later -- because the United States cannot keep troops in Bosnia forever. But war will erupt again when we leave, bringing vast harm to Bosnia and jeopardizing American policy in Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RONA, ELIZABETH
description: RONA-Elizabeth. On October 4, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Gustav Geza Rona. Loving mother of Peter and grandmother of Jessica. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Thursday, 11am-12 noon with service at 12 noon.

title: Q&A
description: Getting Some Shut-Eye

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNNING, (MOFFETT) ROSEMARY R.
description: GUNNING-(Moffett) Rosemary R. of Ridgewood, Queens, New York born 1905. Died peacefully at home among family after a brief illness. Practicing attorney and former member of the New York State Assembly from 1968 to 1972. Beloved wife of the late Lester Moffett. Dear aunt to John, Joan, Marie and Ann. Also survived by thirteen grand nieces and nephews, and her cousin and friend Sylvia Boyland. Visitors may call at the Morton Funeral Home, 580 Onderdonk Ave, Ridgewood, NY, Tuesday 2-5 and 7-10pm. Mass of christian burial Wednesday 10am, St. Brigids Roman Catholic Church. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. Donations may be made in her memory to St. Brigids RC Church, 409 Linden Street, Brooklyn, New York, 11237.

title: Joint Venture Forms To Market Jaguar
description: Jaguar Cars Inc., the luxury-car maker owned by the Ford Motor Company, said yesterday that the lead Jaguar agencies -- Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and the J. Walter Thompson Company -- would form a joint venture to handle the worldwide Jaguar marketing account, with combined billings estimated at $50 million to $60 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MC COY, ESTHER
description: MC COY-Esther. Passed away on October 6, 1997 at age 93. Born in Spokane, Washington. Graduate of University of Iowa. Accountant active in business for several decades, active with Ladies of Charity, Archdiocese of New York and numerous other charitable and cultural organizations. She is survived by her beloved cousins Mary and Gerard Ryan of River Edge, NJ and Br. Patrick Flanagan, S.J. of St. Peter's College, NJ. Visiting at Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 W 72nd St, Tuesday 6-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Corpus Christi R.C. Church, Wednesday, 10am. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, ELLA
description: RAPPAPORT-Ella. On October 5, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Philip Rappaport. Dearest friend of Walter Goodman. Dear mother of William J. Rappaport and Dr. Irwin Rappaport. Mother-in-law of Marcia and Barbara Rappaport. Adored grandmother of Linda, Susan, Michael, William and Karen and great grandmother. Cherished sister of Fannie Lande. Services Wednesday October 8 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions can be made in Ella's name to the Millennium Fund 2000, the New York Hospital, 525 East 68th Street, NY, NY 10021 Rm. J-114.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFIELD, DR. RICHARD E.
description: ROSENFIELD-Dr. Richard E. On October 3, 1997. Beloved husband of 53 years of Olive L. Rosenfield. Loving father of Cantor Richard, Jr., Dr. Allan and Phyllis Steele. Devoted grandfather of Lauren, Anna, Dorianne, David, Alexandra and Jeffrey. May his wonderful spirit live within our hearts forever. Services were held at the Riverdale Temple, 4545 Independence Ave on October 6. Contributions may be made to the National Hemophilia Foundation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGELARI, RICHARD D.
description: ANGELARI-Richard D. On October 5, 1997. Loving husband of the late Margaret (nee McAuliffe). Father of Marguerite and Richard. Friends may call at Dalton Funeral Home, 125 Hillside Ave, New Hyde Park, NY Wednesday, 2-5 and 7-10. Funeral service, Thursday, 10:30am, St. Gregory's the Great, 242-20 88th Ave, Bellerose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITTLIN, A. SAM
description: GITTLIN-A. Sam, of South Orange, NJ, and Bal Harbor, FL, passed away in his home on October 5th. He was 82 years old. A leader in business and in his religious community, he was a man whose integrity and foresight were an example to all. His support of family and friends had a lasting impact on the lives of countless people. Beloved husband of Fay for fifty-nine years. Devoted father of Carol Franklin, Reggie and Peter Gross, Ethel and Bruce Gittlin, and Robert Gittlin. Cherished grandfather of nine and proud great-grandfather of six. Caring brother of B. Morton Gittlin and Richard Gittlin. Services Temple B'nai Abraham, 300 E. Northfield Road, Livingston, NJ, on Tuesday, October 7th, at 11 am. Memorial donations to the A. Sam Gittlin Memorial Fund at Temple B'nai Abraham would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERT, MITCHELL LOUIS
description: SILBERT-Mitchell Louis, of Pembroke Pines, FL and Ridge, NY, on October 6, 1997 in his 79th year. Beloved husband of the late Shirley. Loving father of Alan, Joan and Carol. Dear grandfather of Jennifer and Lauren Silbert, Eli and Adam Cook, and Joshua Streit. Service on Thursday, 1:30 PM at the I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Dix Hills, followed by burial in Mt Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale. Shiva on Thursday night, 6-9 PM and Friday morning, 11-1 at the family's home in Shoreham. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to Mitchell Silbert Memorial Scholarship Fund for Optometrists/Joan Cook, Southwest School, 1095 Joselson Ave, Bayshore, NY 11706.

title: Campaigns paint a new, friendly image for corporations.
description: THE Bank of America is setting in motion an estimated $60 million branding campaign centered on, well, motion.

title: 2 Passers-By Are Killed By Gunfire In Brooklyn
description: They were total strangers, two passers-by who had never spoken and never met, and just happened to be on the same Coney Island street corner early yesterday when the gunfire started, the police said.

description: To the Editor:

description: In percent

title: Better a Broken Heart Than Shot in the Heart
description: Watching Wong Kar-Wai's frenetic urban comedy ''Fallen Angels'' feels a little like being shot out of a pinball machine and bounced around the Hong Kong equivalent of Times Square in its former honky-tonk glory. The movie, which the New York Film Festival is showing this evening at 9:15 in Alice Tully Hall, is the follow-up to Mr. Wong's cult favorite, ''Chungking Express,'' a romantic caper whose cheeky visual flair has seduced some critics into proclaiming the Hong Kong director a major international filmmaker. Well, maybe. ''Fallen Angels'' certainly abounds in visual pizazz, clever in jokes and trendy pop references, but such things can carry a movie only so far.

title: Review/Fashion; In Milan, the Versace Drama Continues
description: It is one of the most important seasons in the history of Italian fashion, and all who are witnessing it know it. They are spectators for the change of hands in the house of Gianni Versace, where his sister, Donatella, has become, by the slaying of her brother, the most powerful female designer in the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARROW, CONSTANCE BRUEN
description: BARROW-Constance Bruen. Beloved wife of the late Donald F. Barrow, mother of Elizabeth B. Doering and Constance B. Hurley, grandmother of Dennis and Elizabeth Hurley and Lily Doering. Services on October 10th, 11 AM, at St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor. Private interment October 11. In lieu of flowers, donations to Animal Rescue and Rehabilitation, POB 61 Syosset, N.Y. 11791.

title: Defamation Suit Leaves Small Publisher Near Extinction
description: Steve Wynn, the millionaire casino owner, angered over a critical unauthorized biography, moved yesterday to collect on a defamation award of more than $3 million that could shut down a small New York publishing house that thrives on controversy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 1 about Congressional appropriations for the Departments of Commerce, Justice, and State referred incorrectly to funds for the Legal Services Corporation. House and Senate negotiators remain to settle differences in their spending bills, but legal services officials said they expected to have adequate funds for 1998. The House Appropriations Committee has not recommended cutting the agency's budget in half.

title: Niedermayer Out for a While
description: Florida Panthers center Rob Niedermayer may miss a month after sustaining a concussion in the team's season opener last Wednesday.

title: Neocolonialists Seize French Language; An Invading Legion of Foreign Writers Is Snapping Up the Medals
description: The fact that Tolstoy, Strindberg and Wilde all wrote works in French is proof enough that foreign authors have long been attracted to this rich and demanding language. Indeed, two of this century's greatest French-language playwrights were Samuel Beckett, an Irishman, and Eugene Ionesco, a Romanian, while the heir to Andre Gide as the French literary diarist is Julian Green, a 97-year-old American.

title: CHRONICLE
description: News from the parental front:

title: Powerless And Vicious In a Corner Of France
description: In a northern French village as quiet as a ghost town, trouble is brewing. It develops slowly and precisely in ''La Vie de Jesus,'' the first film by Bruno Dumont, who works with grim exactitude to capture the essence of unhappiness in this becalmed setting. His film's main character, with a sad, inexpressive face and a brutish skinhead look, is Freddy (David Douche). Gradually adding layer upon layer of vague dread, Mr. Dumont finally conveys the full misery of Freddy's world.

title: Addicts and Mentally Ill Need Community Help; Revolving Doors
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARROW, CONSTANCE BRUEN
description: BARROW-Constance Bruen. Beloved wife of the late Donald F. Barrow, mother of Elizabeth B. Doering and Constance B. Hurley, grandmother of Dennis and Elizabeth Hurley and Lily Doering. Services on October 10th, 11 AM, at St. John's Episcopal Church, Cold Spring Harbor. Private interment October 11. In lieu of flowers, donations to Animal Rescue and Rehabilitation, POB 61 Syosset, N.Y. 11791.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHEL, CARLTON MARK
description: FISHEL-Carlton Mark, age 88, suddenly on October 6th, 1997. Former Chairman of the Board of Trifari, Krussman & Fishel, Inc. until he retired in 1975. A graduate of Phillips Andover ('26) and Yale ('30), he was a founding member and past President of the Advisory Board of St. Vincent's Hospital, Harrison, New York on which he has served for over 40 years. He was a Knight of Malta and a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre. For many years he served as a member of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, Catholic Charities, the Board of the United Hospital's Fund of New York and was affiliated with numerous other religious associations of the Archdiocese of New York. He was also an active parishioner of Resurrection Church in Rye. He was a past President of the ''24 Karat'' Club of New York (a fine jewelers' association). As a member of the Yale Club of New York City and the Apawamis Club of Rye, he enjoyed golf until the time of his death. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 61 years, Helen M. Fishel, and is survived by two daughters, Penelope F. McDermott of Rye and Kathleen F. McCullough of Chatham, MA, son-inlaw William H. McCullough, 7 grandchildren and 9 adored greatgrandchildren. Visiting hours will be at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York, Thursday, October 9th, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass will be held at 10 AM Friday, October 10th at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye. Interment immediately following at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Vincent's Hospital of Westchester, 275 North Street, Harrison, New York 10528 or United Hospital Medical Center, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, New York 10573.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUSKY, HELEN M.
description: TAUSKY-Helen M. On October 6, 1997. Loving cousin of Robert Schmeidler. Graveside services on Thursday, October 9, 1997, 2:00 P.M., at Linden Hills Cemetery, Maspeth, Queens.

title: Chip Maker's Loss Bigger Than Forecast
description: After warning last month that it expected a loss for the fiscal third quarter, Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reported one today that was larger than anticipated by Wall Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBES, RENA
description: TAUBES-Rena. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved wife of Leo Taubes, lecturer in English at Yeshiva College, and mother of Rabbi Michael Taubes, principal of The Marsha Stern Talmudical Academy-YU High School for Boys of our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary; Daniel Taubes; and Judy Sternman. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Elliot Gibber, Chairman YUHS Board

title: Temptations; A Sandwich to Make Vegetarians Tremble
description: EVERYBODY knows about the bread at Amy's Bread, but the sandwiches are something else again. There are thin olive ficelles wedged open with slices of mozzarella and tomato and basil leaves, ham and Gruyere on caraway rye and an offbeat grilled Cheddar-cheese sandwich spread with spicy chipotle pepper puree.

title: TV Notes; Upkeep of a Star
description: In the inflationary battle to hold onto top talent, Disney's ABC has just agreed to increase the paycheck of Tim Allen, star of ''Home Improvement,'' to $1.25 million per episode next year, which will be his and the show's eighth season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, ROBERT
description: FELDMAN - Robert. Women's American ORT, American ORT and the World ORT Union note with deep sorrow the passing of the beloved husband of our distinguished leader, Reese Feldman. A dedicated supporter of the Jewish community, he was a devoted husband, father and grandfather who took great pride in his wife's work and commitment on behalf of the worldwide ORT program. In a lifetime of service to ORT, Reese Feldman served as National President of Women's American ORT from 1987 to 1991, is an officer of American ORT and shares the Administrative Committee of the World ORT Union. We extend heartfelt sympathy to the Feldman children, Larry and Kathy Feldman, Bill and Ava Feldman and Renay and Paul Becker, and to the grandchildren. Ruth S. Taffel, Nat'l President, Women's American ORT Pepi Dunay, First Vice President Rosina K. Abramson, Esq., Nat'l Executive Director/CEO Paul Borman, President American ORT Brian J. Strum, Exec. V.P. Justice Richard Goldstone, President, World ORT Union Dr. Ellen Isler, Dir. General

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I know it is customary for witnesses to express their great pleasure to appear before you, but because I am under oath, I am unable to say I share that sentiment.''

title: Addicts and Mentally Ill Need Community Help
description: To the Editor:

title: A Murder, A Mystery, A Window On History
description: BIG TROUBLE

title: Stripping Parts Away for More Impact
description: Finley Quaye has one thing in common with his nephew Tricky, the trip-hop innovator. Both men respect and understand silence; they know how to make an absence become eloquent. Where Tricky has melted down genres, however, the 23-year-old Mr. Quaye uses more established styles -- reggae and updated 1960's soul -- though he skews them along his own private vectors. This English songwriter made his United States debut on Friday night at a packed S.O.B.'s, anticipating the American release of his album, ''Maverick a Strike'' (550 Music/Sony), on Nov. 4.

title: Every Bite a Risk
description: To the Editor:

title: For Nets, Encouraging Signs
description: A year ago, after the final intrasquad game of training camp, the Nets' Kendall Gill had one thought.

title: Wine Talk; No Need to Break the Bank to Pop the Cork
description: WHEN the great 1961 Bordeaux arrived here in 1963, they cost as much as $10 a bottle. Wine buffs were aghast; no one had ever paid that much for wine. Now, with some 1996 Bordeaux quoted at $200 a bottle, a lot of people are wondering whether there is anything drinkable for as little as $10.

title: Sports of The Times; Vander Meer's Feat May Never Be Bettered
description: NINE years ago, in June 1988, I called Johnny Vander Meer at his home in Tampa, Fla., and got his wife, Lois. Johnny had gone fishing, she said, and she didn't know when he would be back.

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: Stocks were trading higher here today. At the end of the morning session, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 95.10 points, or slightly more than half a percent, at 17,606.29. On Tuesday, the Nikkei fell 313.59 points.

title: Consultant's Report Clears Bre-X Chairman
description: The chief executive of Bre-X Minerals Ltd., David Walsh, was unaware of tampering by company geologists that helped to convince investors that the company had found the world's largest gold deposit, a report commissioned by Bre-X concludes.

title: High Cost of Condoms
description: To the Editor:

title: Eating Well; For Organic Food, a Moment of Eloquence
description: The four wine glasses at each place on the candlelighted tables were a tip-off. The first organic harvest dinner at Restaurant Nora last month was a sybaritic celebration, a sign of how far organic food has come since the beginning of the decade. For the producers of organic food -- and the consumers who wish they could bring themselves to love it enough to pay more -- it addresses a threshhold issue. Organic is not simply about health but about food that actually tastes better.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: BANK OF NEW YORK ADDING ESI SECURITIES AND B-TRADE
description: The Bank of New York Company agreed yesterday to buy ESI Securities Company and its affiliate, B-Trade Services, for an undisclosed sum. ESI Securities provides trading, trade execution and trade management services to institutions. ESI's 130 employees serve about 250 clients, including investment managers, mutual funds, bank trust departments and insurance companies in 20 countries worldwide. Bank officials said that the purchase of ESI would allow for quicker development of the institutional business. The bank plans to run ESI as a stand-alone division, and will fold the institutional services of BNY Brokerage into ESI. Shares of the Bank of New York's rose 56.25 cents, to $51.875.

title: National Tests Can Help Combat Education Fads
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Notes; A Month Later, The Fallout Hits
description: The fallout from CBS's disastrous performance the night that Diana, Princess of Wales, was killed in Paris became clear yesterday as CBS News announced that it was reshuffling executives to change its management of breaking news stories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRASNER, MARIAN
description: KRASNER-Marian. On October 4, 1997. Beloved wife of Dr. Charles Krasner. Devoted mother of Donna and partner Susan, and Gena. Cherished mother-in-law of Jochem. Loving sister of Barbara and Ken Jensen, and aunt of Glenn. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her. Family receiving visitors Wednesday evening, 10/8, 7:30-9:30 PM. Services Thursday, 10/9, at ''Sinai Chapels,'' 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Liberties; Checks, Lies and Videotape
description: Everyone, even Trent Lott, thinks Fred Thompson has mangled his campaign finance hearings.

title: An Actor Whose Talents Are the Sum of His Parts
description: Everything about ''Boogie Nights'' is interestingly unexpected, even the few seconds of darkness before the film's neon title blasts onto the screen. The director, Paul Thomas Anderson, whose display of talent is as big and exuberant as skywriting, seems to mean this as a way of telling viewers to brace themselves. Good advice.

title: '97 BASEBALL PLAYOFFS  NATIONAL LEAGUE  FLORIDA 5  ATLANTA 3  The Florida Marlins getting all their runs as a result of errors, defeated the Braves, 5-3, in Atlanta last night in game 1 of the National League Championship Series.      SportsWednesday, page C1.
Daimler Plans Switch To Euro in 1999
description: Daimler-Benz said yesterday that it would adopt the euro as its corporate currency on Jan. 1, 1999, becoming one of the first German companies to announce a switch to the single European currency. The company, Germany's largest manufacturer, will convert its accounting and sales practices from marks to euros at the start of 1999. It will report first-half 1998 earnings in euros. Customers will have the option of ordering goods in euros or marks during a transition before euro notes and coins are introduced in 2002.

title: I.M.F. Aid Plea By Indonesia Appears Near
description: Struggling to defend its beleaguered currency, Indonesia appears on the verge of asking the International Monetary Fund for financial help, American officials and Asian diplomats said today.

title: Andrew Young Reportedly Picked by U.S. for Congo Mission
description: The Clinton Administration plans to send a special envoy to Congo, the former Zaire, to discuss a stalled international investigation into allegations that Rwandan refugees were massacred in the eastern part of the country over the last year, American officials said tonight.

title: Pataki and D'Amato Back Constitutional Convention
description: The state's highest ranking Republicans, Gov. George E. Pataki and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, announced today that they support holding a convention in 1999 to rewrite the State Constitution. The move positioned both men to cast themselves as reform-minded outsiders in next year's election, even as Democrats prepare to attack them as political bosses.

title: The Parking Lot Lottery; Odds Rise Against Riders Needing to Park at Stations
description: In the unfolding of a human life, some events stand out as landmarks: marriage, the birth of a child, the purchase of a home. And for many in the suburbs, the receipt of a permit to park at the train station.

title: Messinger Proposes Domestic Abuse Curbs
description: Ruth W. Messinger said yesterday that as mayor she would initiate sweeping measures to counter domestic violence and to protect victims of abuse, promising to add 500 beds at shelters for battered women during her first year in office. Ms. Messinger also said she would seek legislation to establish domestic violence as a felony under the state penal code.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, ALBERT
description: CARROLL-Albert, October 6, 1997 of Devon, Pennsylvania, formerly of Hartsdale, New York. Husband of Rhoda (nee Freudenthal), father of David William Carroll and Barbara Kay, brother of Evelyn Freedman, also survived by four grand children. Relatives and friends are invited to graveside services on Thursday, October 9, 1997 at 11:30 A.M., at the Roosevelt Memorial Park, Trevose, Bucks Co., PA. The family will return to the Kay residence & respectfully requests that contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of the donor's choice.

title: Study of Doctors Sees Little Effect Of Affirmative Action on Careers
description: In a report certain to fuel the debate over affirmative action, an extensive study of doctors trained at the University of California at Davis over a 20-year period found that those admitted with special consideration for factors like race or ethnic origin had remarkably similar postgraduate records and careers to those admitted on academic merit alone.

title: Devils Still Searching For Best Defensive Mix
description: The season is young but the Devils have failed to fill their defensive void.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAHAN, JOHN J.
description: CALLAHAN-John J. Beloved husband of Audrey, sons Craig and Scott J., brother Francis, sisters Margaret and Patricia, died suddenly at the age of 68. He was a longtime sailor on Barnegat Bay in New Jersey, where he sailed Mscows, E-scows and Barnegat Catboats. He owned and summered on the renowned antique yacht, ''The Gatsby''. Born in Elizabeth, New Jersey, he and his family have lived in Westfield for 35 years. He was a graduate of Seton Hall University and Stevens Institute of Technology. He retired three years ago and was head of Engineering Research for Georgia Kaolin Company. Services will be held at All Saints Episcopal Church, Bay Head, N.J., at 11 AM on Friday, October 10. A luncheon reception will follow the service. His ashes will be sprinkled on Barnegat Bay in a private ceremony.

title: Winning Everything but the Fans
description: His first half had ended on the fourth play of the second quarter, when his left leg, planted into the grass at Ohio Stadium, absorbed a frightening blow. Stanley Jackson, the starting quarterback of the Ohio State Buckeyes, limped off the field; Joe Germaine, the most outstanding player of the Rose Bowl, jogged toward the huddle.

title: Restaurants; Earthy French Kitchen Flourishes in Fall
description: GERTRUDE'S is going to be a great restaurant. But first it has to get over itself.

title: Light's Still on Julia Child, as Her Soul Mate Wanted
description: ''It reads as if I'm dead,'' Julia Child said of ''Appetite for Life,'' a new biography of her by Noel Riley Fitch. ''But then, I guess I always assumed I would be by the time it came out.''

title: France Telecom Bids For Dutch Cable Unit
description: Royal PTT Nederland N.V. said yesterday that it had received several bids for its cable TV operations since it put them up for sale to satisfy regulatory concerns as the Dutch market opens to competition. France Telecom S.A. said it was among the bidders for the Dutch cable business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNNING, ROSEMARY
description: GUNNING-Rosemary. The Advisory Council to the Housing Part of the Civil Court mourns the passing of Rosemary Gunning. As a State Assemblywoman, Rosemary sponsored the legislation which created the Housing Court. For more than two decades, until her retirement last year, Rosemary served as a stalwart member of the Advisory Council, devoting her indefatigable energy, piercing intelligence and infectious wit to nurturing and strengthening the Housing Court, which appropriately has been called ''Rosemary's Baby.'' Rosemary will be sorely missed, but never forgotten. David Rosenberg, Chair

title: 18 Jobs Cut at Hambros
description: The Hambros P.L.C. investment banking firm has cut 18 employees from its treasury operations as part of a revamping of the business by Duncan Wilson, the division's head, a company spokesman said yesterday. The employees, about half of whom were in administrative jobs, were dismissed this week, the spokesman, Michael Sandler, said.

title: Arab Donors, Too, Are Buying Land in Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFIELD, RICHARD E. M.D.
description: ROSENFIELD-Richard E. M.D. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center note with sadness the passing of our esteemed colleague, Richard E. Rosenfield M.D., Emeritus Professor of Medicine and Director Emeritus of Blood Bank and Clinical Microscopy. Associated with Mount Sinai for more than half a century, Dr. Rosenfield was a distinguished authority on blood types and blood transfusion, a pioneer in exchange transfusions on ''Rh babies'', and a prolific author on nearly every aspect of immunology, including seminal studies of monoclonal anitibodies and receptors. Admired as an accomplished clinician, insightful researcher and devoted teacher, Dr. Rosenfield was a recipient of the Jacobi Medallion, highest award of The Mount Sinai Alumni. We extend our condolences to his wife, Olive, to his children, Cantor Richard Rosenfield Jr., Dr. Allan Rosenfield and Phyllis Steele, to his grandchildren, and to the entire family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman John W. Rowe, M.D., President Arthur H. Rubenstein, M.B.B.Ch., Dean Barry R. Freedman, Executive Vice President Wendy Z. Goldstein, Director Alan L. Schiller, M.D. President, Medical Board

title: Calendar
description: Barolos, as the Headliner

title: Market Place; Just in time for the millennium: an issue of 1,000-year bonds.
description: WILL Republic National Bank still be around in 2997?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LACHMAN, LAWRENCE
description: LACHMAN-Lawrence, 81. Passed away in his sleep on October 7, 1997. He will be sorely missed by his family and friends. Beloved husband of Judith for fifty-two years. Devoted father of Robert and Charles. Grandfather of Elizabeth and Peter, Amy and the late Jill Lachman. Father-in-law of Dianna and Emily. Loving brother of Frances. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Wednesday, 6-8PM with service Thursday, 11:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The Jill Lachman Memorial Fund, c/o EVAC, P.O. Box 743, Englewood, NJ 07631, or the charity of your choice.

title: How Hot Is Hot?
description: History can be made in subtle ways, almost without anyone noticing. This happened on Monday at President Clinton's conference on global warming. The meeting was intended to build national support for some effort to reduce carbon dioxide output in the United States, a pep rally before our team heads off in December to Kyoto, Japan, for the negotiations on a treaty regulating global emissions of greenhouse gases.

title: Rethinking Pesto Means Breaking the Rules
description: TO most home cooks, pesto means the classic sauce made from basil, pine nuts, oil, garlic and Parmesan cheese. But restaurant chefs, being adventurous types, have stretched the definition of pesto to include sauces and salsas using savory ingredients like cilantro, arugula and fennel. One of the most adventurous, Odessa Piper of L'Etoile in Madison, Wis., for instance, came up with a fennel pesto for a dazzling salmon dish.

title: Unearned Runs Against Maddux Benefit Brown
description: Not wanting to leave anything to chance, the Florida Marlins spent $50 million on talent and hired the National League's most renowned manager, Jim Leyland. But the club's fate is in the hands of a wild card -- Kevin Brown, the temperamental pitcher who beat the Atlanta Braves and Greg Maddux, 5-3, in Game 1 of the N.L. Championship Series tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ASKENASE, MIRIAM
description: ASKENASE-Miriam. In loving memory of you on your 95th birthday and always. Forever loved, forever mourned. Wilma, Your Grandchildren and Eight Great-Grandchildren

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Suit Filed Over School Board
description: A New Brunswick community group filed a lawsuit against the city yesterday in an attempt to force a referendum on whether the local school board should remain an appointed body or become an elective one.

title: At Last, Alou Hits Braves
description: Moises Alou was the unlikely hitting star, driving in four of the Marlins' five runs in their 5-3 victory over the Braves. He hit .292 during the regular season with 23 home runs and 115 runs batted in. Against the Braves, he batted only .231 with no home runs and six r.b.i. He had no r.b.i. against Greg Maddux.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIMAN, BARBARA
description: KLEIMAN-Barbara. On October 7, 1997. Beloved daughter of Bella Kleiman and the late Murray Kleiman. Sister of Michael and Mark Kleiman and Isabel Byron. Aunt of Molly Kleiman. Cherished of Stan Diglio. Assistant Commissioner, NYC Dept of Homeless Services. Passionate advocate for services to the poor. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St, Mount Vernon, N.Y. Thursday, October 9th, 10AM. Contributions in her name may be made to local services for the homeless.

title: Critic's Notebook; Bootlegging as a Public Service: No, This Isn't a Joke
description: About a year ago, the police raided two shops in Greenwich Village that sold bootleg CD's, the unauthorized recordings of concerts, radio broadcasts and studio outtakes that collectors prize because they give a broader perspective on a musician's work than can be had by listening solely to commercially released recordings. Bootlegs cover the waterfront, from classic rock to the latest bands, from jazz to symphony and opera: wherever there is a devoted audience, there are bootleggers.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Islanders Collect Goals and Confidence
description: After averaging 1.5 goals a game in six preseason losses, the Islanders have found a knack for scoring. They have tallied five goals in the first two games of the regular season. The defense and goaltending have been there, too, allowing only two goals.

title: Where the Office Orientation Includes On-the-Job Straining
description: Ambition can be a good thing, of course, but the creators of NBC's new show ''Working'' are displaying too much of it. In trying to make fun of the dehumanized corporate workplace by using the broadest sort of satire, they manage to dehumanize the traditions of the workplace sitcoms, and there can't be a future in that.

title: The Great Green Hope; Are Fuel Cells the Key to Cleaner Energy?
description: In their crusade to find a cheap, clean, efficient source of power, car makers, utilities, transit operators and even submarine builders have all made their way to a muddy suburban office park here on the outskirts of Vancouver.

title: TENNIS: YESTERDAY
description: DAVIS CUP

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about elections in the two republics that make up Yugoslavia referred incorrectly in some copies to the next steps in the process. In Serbia, because of low turnout, new elections will be held in two months to replace Slobodan Milosevic as President. He has since become President of Yugoslavia. In Montenegro, a runoff will be held on Oct. 19 to choose a new President. The runoff in Montenegro does not involve filling a vacancy created by Mr. Milosevic's new position.

title: GOLF: ROUNDUP
description: GILLETTE TOUR CHALLENGE

title: At the Core of the Milky Way, The Brightest Star Ever Seen
description: Try to imagine a star so big that it would fill all of the solar system within the orbit of Earth, which is 93 million miles from the Sun. A star so turbulent that its eruptions would spread a cloud of gases spanning four light-years, the distance from the Sun to the nearest star. A star so powerful that it glows with the energy of 10 million suns, making it the brightest ever observed in our galaxy, the Milky Way.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: $25 and Under; A Place Where Even the Hookahs Are Authentic
description: MY friend Michael was on the phone, practically chortling with glee. ''I found a place for great Middle Eastern food, and you'll never guess where,'' he said.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH TO BUY BACK $1 BILLION IN STOCK
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back $1 billion in stock and that it expects to beat analysts' third-quarter earnings estimates as sales of its allergy drug Claritin lift profits. Claritin is the No. 1 antihistamine in the United States market, with $1.2 billion in 1996 sales. Shares of Schering-Plough rose $2.375, to a new closing high of $56.875. The company, which is based in Madison, N.J., expects to earn 48 cents a share in the third quarter, two cents higher than the average estimate of 25 analysts surveyed. The company earned 39 cents a year ago. Schering-Plough said it would begin the buyback as soon as it completed an earlier $500 million stock repurchase program. That program is about 85 percent complete.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UBERMAN, MURRAY
description: UBERMAN-Murray. Passed away October 6, 1997. Will be interred today in New Montefiore Cemetery in Pinelawn, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, ARCHIBALD A.
description: PATTERSON-Archibald A. On October 6th, 1997, at the age of 81. A graduate of Hobart College and Harvard Law School, he practiced law in NYC and was a fifty year member of the American Bar Association. He was an accomplished bridge player and member of the University Club. He is survived by his wife, Esther; his sister Janet Feeley; a daughter Marcia; four sons, Bruce, James, Roy and Robert; a stepdaughter Noma; and eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held from 6-8 PM, Thursday, October 9th, at Krtil Funeral Home at 70th and 1st.

title: Borrowing Pace Slowed During August
description: Borrowing by United States consumers increased at a slower-than-expected pace in August, further evidence that the economy is cooling, Federal Reserve figures showed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAPELLI, ARTHUR
description: CAPELLI-Arthur. The partners and staff of Lipsky, Goodkin & Company, PC, are deeply moved by the loss of Arthur Capelli. He will truly be missed. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. Lipsky, Goodkin & Co.

title: Essay; 'James Riady Sent Me'
description: There he was at last, the little Indonesian gardener who started it all, his image preserved on long-concealed White House videotape shaking the hand of Bill Clinton.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 30 about the sale of the landmark building at 55 Wall Street misstated the connection of one buyer, T. Richard Butera, to the Hotel Jerome in Aspen. He sold his stake in the hotel in 1990 and is no longer associated with it.

title: CAMPAIGN FINANCE MEASURE BLOCKED IN 2 SENATE VOTES; MAIN FOE SAYS BILL IS 'DEAD'
description: The Senate today all but buried a bill to overhaul the country's campaign-financing system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSMAN, JOSEPH
description: WEISSMAN-Joseph. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed past president, beloved husband of Miriam Weissman. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Sheldon Steinmetz, President

description: Netanyahu Meets Arafat

title: Do Whatever It Takes?
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, STUART MALCOLM, (U.S.N. CAPTAIN RETIRED)
description: STRAUSS-Stuart Malcolm, (U.S.N. Captain Retired), of Alpine, NJ on October 7, 1997. Beloved husband of Lenni, father of Susan Kelly and Ellen Sanford, grandfather of Gates, Owen and Cooper, stepfather of Marc & Glenn Staubley. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hospice at Englewood Hospital, 75 Demarest Ave., Englewood, New Jersey 07631.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Sun Sues Microsoft In Dispute Over Java

title: Albright Seeks Early Vote In Senate on Larger NATO
description: Opening the Administration drive to win Senate approval of NATO expansion, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today that excluding Europe's new democracies from the western alliance would cause confidence to ''crumble'' in the region and lead to costly arms buildups and instability there.

title: PNC BANK BUYS INVESTMENT COUNSELOR STOLPER
description: The PNC Bank Corporation yesterday acquired the investment counselor Stolper & Company in a move to expand services for wealthy individuals and increase fee-based income. PNC, which is based in Pittsburgh, is integrating Stolper and PNC Family Wealth Management Group into a new group called Hawthorn, which has $10 billion in assets under management and $7 billion in assets in custody and reporting relationships. Hawthorn has 50 employees, with offices in Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and a Philadelphia suburb, Edgemont. Hawthorn's three primary lines of business are investment counseling and fiduciary services; custody and customized reporting services, with after-tax reporting, and limited partnership investments.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Overturns Law Limiting Legislators' Terms in California
description: A Federal appeals court in San Francisco today struck down California's tough law on legislative term limits. The ruling was issued seven years after the measure was approved by 51 percent of the state's voters in a hard-fought ballot initiative at a time when term-limit fever was sweeping the country.

title: A Top Dresdner Bank Executive Will Resign
description: A top executive of Dresdner Bank A.G. announced today that he would resign from the company's board of managers after having admitted to evading income taxes.

title: The Slowly Rising Price Of Delay and Foul-Ups
description: Most Presidents and their Administrations would rather spend a winter at the South Pole, rather be audited by the Internal Revenue Service, than have people describe them as bumbling and ineffective.

title: G.O.P., Eye on '98, Builds Education Plank
description: Stealing a technique from President Clinton, Speaker Newt Gingrich was using an inner-city school as a backdrop to promote proposals with which Republicans hope to cut into the Democratic advantage on the vote-rich education issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACKSON, MIRIAM
description: JACKSON-Miriam. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved former County Chairwoman. Her bright smile and helping hand were always there, helping us lead the way. David A. Alpert, Chairman Westchester County Democratic Committee

title: Childs Is Relaxed and Ready to Go
description: The cool edge of a breeze hit him perfectly Monday evening. And the lazy walk back from the gym to the hotel -- a pleasant six blocks -- felt even better for Chris Childs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLACE, LEVERITT
description: WALLACE-Leveritt. Congregation Kol Ami Jewish Community Center of White Plains records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member and convey sincere condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Shira Milgrom Rabbi Tom Weiner Mark Hershey, President

title: National Tests Can Help Combat Education Fads; Civics Standards Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVEC, PIERRE
description: LEVEC-Pierre. The Four Nations Ensemble mourns the passing of our friend and patron. His gentle encouragement and warm appreciation will continue to nurture our work.

title: Told to Rest at School, Boy Passes Out and Dies
description: A 13-year-old boy told by a teacher yesterday to rest his head on his desk at an intermediate school in Starrett City, Brooklyn, passed out, fell from his chair and died, the police and school officials said.

title: Pentagon to Check Security After Lawyer's Arrest for Spying
description: The Department of Defense will weigh its losses and review its security procedures after the arrest of a Pentagon lawyer in an espionage case, Defense Secretary William S. Cohen said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKFURTER, ESTELLE S.
description: FRANKFURTER-Estelle S. The Board and Staff of the American Associates, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, mourn the passing of Estelle Frankfurter of New York, a longtime, generous supporter and friend of Ben-Gurion University. We extend our sincere and heartfelt condolences to her family. Kenneth L. Tucker, Pres. AABGU Vered Mallon Greater N.Y. Regional Dir. Lis Gaines N.Y. Regional Chairperson

title: INSIDE METRO
description: GANG CONNECTION -- A teen-ager invoked the name of a gang in forcing a 13-year-old girl to perform a sex act, prosecutors charged. B3.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Compromise on Slot Machines
description: Offering a compromise between casino and horse racing interests, a state commission has recommended that slot machines be allowed at New Jersey's five race tracks, but only after neighboring states introduce them, The Associated Press reported.

title: Gooden Warns Yanks on '98
description: Dwight Gooden expressed serious disdain for the way that he was treated by the Yankees and claimed that he will not return if they refuse to exercise his $3 million option. The Yankees could pass on Gooden's option and try to sign him at a lower salary as a free agent, but the pitcher warned them not to attempt that strategy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERBACH, RABBANIT RECHA
description: AUERBACH - Rabbanit Recha. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the beloved sister of our member, Manfred Meyer. May her entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President

title: Ex-Salesman's Book Gets a Chilly Morgan Stanley Review
description: Wall Street, and particularly the Morgan Stanley Group, one of its most prestigious firms, is a savage place where sharklike financiers devise increasingly complex securities that in traders' argot may ''blow up'' or even ''rip the faces off'' their clients: insurers, mutual funds and, increasingly, unsuspecting individual investors of Main Street.

title: Hadassah Rosensaft, 85, Dies; Saved Auschwitz Inmates
description: Dr. Hadassah Rosensaft, who is credited with having saved hundreds of Jewish inmates while a prisoner at Auschwitz, died on Friday in Tisch Hospital of New York University Medical Center. She was 85 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Closing of Helium Reserve Raises New Issues
description: Of all the Federal programs that have ever come under attack, perhaps none has been more ridiculed or more reviled than the national helium reserve, here on the high plains of the Texas Panhandle. It is a collection of pipelines and pumps and vats and, most of all, a seemingly staggering amount of helium: 31 billion cubic feet, enough to supply current Federal needs for 100 years.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There are museum galleries, hospital wings and sculpture gardens that bear the names of IRIS CANTOR and her late husband, B. Gerald Cantor, the financier. Now there is to be a cafe named for Mrs. Cantor's mother, Faye Gable, who died two years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, JULIUS (JULIE)
description: HOROWITZ-Julius (Julie). Loving husband of Jean, father of Susan, Bobbi, Eileen and the late Mindy, father-in-law of Jon, Bruce and David, grandfather of Andrew, Elizabeth, Stephen, Hadley, Alex and Michael. Dear friend, a loss sustained by us all. Your friendship, your counsel, your wit, your leadership will never be forgotten. You are forever in our hearts. We wish the family no more sorrows, only good health and happiness for now and forever. Our love, The Longfellow Guys and Gals

title: Corporate Ingratitude
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Clinton to Help McGreevey
description: Hoping to boost the prospects of Democratic gubernatorial candidate James E. McGreevey, President Clinton is scheduled to make his first trip of the campaign season to New Jersey today, attending a fund-raising luncheon at Mayfair Farms in West Orange that is expected to raise $1.5 million for the Democratic State Committee.

title: AT&T Talking To GTE About Teaming Up, Executives Say
description: Seeking a partner to invigorate its torpid local telephone strategy, the AT&T Corporation is discussing a merger with the GTE Corporation, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Empire's Strategy for Health Care
description: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, New York State's largest health insurer, is developing a novel way to win back the trust of its customers. It plans to compete against itself. That may sound zany, but in fact it makes sense. Empire would create several small managed-care plans offering different choices of doctors and hospitals and different levels of convenience and price. The idea is to create competitive pressures so that each will perform well. A state that has no stellar health plans -- nothing that provides quality care like Harvard Pilgrim in New England or Group Health Cooperative of Puget Sound -- needs attractive alternatives. Empire's strategy may be one answer.

title: N.B.A.: NOTEBOOK
description: CHARLOTTE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEWY, MADELINE F. (NEE SCHACK)
description: LOEWY - Madeline F. (nee Schack). On October 5, 1997, in Florida. Beloved wife of the late Henry, loving mother of Jeffrey and Ira, cherished grandmother of Ben, Jon, Brad, and David. Devoted mother-in-law of Nancy Jane and Jackie and sister-in-law of Claire. Memorial service at 11 A.M., Sunday, October 12, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Tamarac Fl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATIS, DR. JACOB D.
description: MATIS-Dr. Jacob D. died October 6, 1997 at his home in West Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Rosalie. Devoted and adored father of George Matis and Nancy Dreyfuss. Loving grandfather of Jessica Matis and Leah Dreyfuss. Beloved brother of Edith Helsel. Services Thursday 12 pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Roosevelt Hospital.

title: Japanese Banks Take Bad-Loan Write-Offs
description: Japan's biggest banks are rushing to wipe an estimated 28 trillion yen ($230 billion) of bad loans from their books by the end of the fiscal year next spring. Sumitomo Bank Ltd. said this week that it had sold 40 billion yen of debt, joining a long list of banks that have formally announced accelerated loan write-offs.

title: National Tests Can Help Combat Education Fads; Tyranny of Textbooks
description: To the Editor:

title: North Fork Banking Concern To Acquire New York Bancorp
description: The North Fork Bancorporation agreed yesterday to buy New York Bancorp, parent of the Home Federal Savings Bank, for $800 million in stock to expand its business in Long Island and Brooklyn.

title: About New York; A Safety Net Made of Books Is Unraveled
description: THE bookcases have been emptied in an office that is following suit at El Barrio Popular Education Program on First Avenue near 101st Street in Manhattan. The books had had a good workout since 1985, helping hundreds of women in East Harlem to learn how to read and write in Spanish before giving them similar English skills and a shot at a high school equivalency diploma.

title: TV Notes; He Outdoes Himself
description: David Grubin was competing with himself when PBS broadcast ''Truman,'' his two-part, four-and-a-half-hour documentary on Harry S. Truman this week.

title: TV Notes; Raising the Profile
description: The lust for ratings among the network news-magazine programs -- the kind that NBC's ''Dateline'' seems to be generating regularly with its highly promotable stories -- is apparently driving a rush toward the most high-profile stories each program can turn out.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Evening Hours column on Sunday about a benefit at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan for the Franciscan Friars of the Atonement misstated the surname and title of one guest. He was Juli Minoves-Triquell, the Ambassador of Andorra, not Russia.

title: Another Girl, 15, Is a Slashing Victim; Gang Link Is Sought
description: In the second such attack in two days, a 15-year-old girl was slashed in the neck and face on a Harlem street last night by two teen-age girls who the police said asked her whether she was a member of the Bloods street gang.

title: Orchestral Harmony From Cuban Voices
description: Trumpets and trombones and saxophones, timbales and congas and scrapers and bass: they're invisible but unmistakable in the music of Vocal Sampling, the Cuban group that performed on Monday night at S.O.B.'s. The unfortunately named group is all vocals and no sampling, a six-man a cappella group with boundless vitality and ingenuity.

title: Turner's Infield Does In Braves
description: From Camden Yards to Jacobs Field to Coors Field, the majority of the ball parks that have opened this decade have been hitters' parks, aiding and abetting batters with short dimensions.

title: Ha-Lo Executive Reduces Ownership
description: Linden D. Nelson, the vice chairman of Ha-Lo Industries, has reduced his ownership of the advertising products company to 10.3 percent from 13.4 percent of outstanding common shares.

title: Metro Business; Billboard Live Shifts Project Down 42d St.
description: Billboard Live International, a theme restaurant featuring live music, is negotiating to move into an entertainment complex on 42d Street in the reviving Times Square area.

title: 2 Killer Detectives and Lots of Plot
description: ''Gang Related'' is a preposterously overplotted tale of two police detectives with moral compasses so defective that they have buried their brains and consciences along with 10 of their murder victims long before the film even begins.

title: Criminal Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sept. 23 showing median prices of existing houses in the New York region for the last five years, with an article about the New Jersey economy, mislabeled one set of data. The line showing the highest figures represented median prices in New York City and Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties, not prices for the entire state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, DONALD J., MD
description: ADAMS-Donald J., MD, child psychiatrist, of Scarsdale, New York. October 6, 1945-October 6, 1997. Beloved husband of Audrey Stier-Adams, cherished father of Sarah and Rachel Adams, devoted son of David C. Adams and the late May Adams, loving brother of the late Jonathan Adams, dearest nephew of Eleanor Stier. Services were held on Tuesday, October 7, 1997.

title: Business Travel; A special cell phone lets users far away tap into data from their own PC's and the Internet.
description: A NEW cellular phone service introduced by the Wireless Services division of AT&T this week offers access to a broad spectrum of information to help travelers.

title: Talk, Talk, Talk: O'Neill in the Raw
description: Simon Harford will not shut up. There he is, horizontal, with his lusty wife, Sara, crawling all over him. Yet Simon can't stop vomiting words: about Rousseau and materialism and idealism. Poor Sara finally clamps a hand over his mouth. Can you blame her?

title: U.S. SAFETY BOARD CRITICIZES AMTRAK IN '96 DERAILMENT
description: The Amtrak train derailment last November in Secaucus, N.J., which sent three coaches tumbling down an embankment and injured 42 people, occurred largely because Amtrak's top managers were more interested in keeping the trains running than in assuring safety, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPELMAN, LEONARD
description: SPELMAN-Leonard. The Board of Governors and we of North Shore Country Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed former member, Leonard Spelman. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Donald Stein, President Howard Jacobs, Secretary

title: Investigator Urges Ouster Of Officer From School
description: The Board of Education's top investigator yesterday recommended dismissing a New York City school security officer who had admitted that he was a leader of the Latin Kings, a tightly organized street gang that officials say enforces its rules through violence.

title: RECKSON ASSOCIATES ADDING STAKE IN MORRIS COMPANIES
description: The Reckson Associates Realty Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to invest $150 million and to acquire a controlling interest in the Morris Companies, a Secaucus, N.J., industrial space company. Reckson, a Melville, N.Y., real estate investment trust, said it would make an initial $87 million investment for a 68 percent stake in Morris. Reckson/Morris will be formed as a private real estate investment trust. The Morris portfolios consists of 23 industrial properties in New Jersey, including two projects under development and contracts or options to acquire about 365 acres of developable land.

title: Whitman Is Criticized For Handling Of Complaint
description: A group of Democratic legislators, all of them women, criticized Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today for her handling of a 1994 sexual harassment complaint against her Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development, Gualberto Medina.

title: Authorities Ask Adult Trial In the Slaying Of 11-Year-Old
description: New Jersey authorities filed court documents today seeking an adult criminal trial for the 15-year-old youth charged with sexually assaulting, robbing and strangling a sixth-grader as he sold school candy door-to-door on Sept. 27.

title: The Chef
description: OUR pastry chef, Stacie Pierce, taught me a terrific variation on the familiar apple pie. I'm fond of it because it takes the homespun taste of the classic deep-dish pie and adds a twist -- a crisp crumb topping -- and it also avoids one of the major pitfalls of apple pie. The usual approach, placing raw apples in a raw pie shell and baking them together, often results in runny pie filling and a gummy, undercooked inside crust.

title: LORAL SPACE TO ACQUIRE ORION FOR $490 MILLION
description: Loral Space and Communications Ltd. agreed yesterday to buy Orion Network Systems Inc. for about $490 million in stock. Orion owns and operates the Orion 1 satellite, which covers European, trans-Atlantic and United States markets, and has two more satellites under construction. The company provides video communications and other services to about 260 multinational businesses and Internet-service providers in 47 countries. Loral said it expects Orion's revenue to rise about 80 percent, to $75 million this year. Orion will post cash flow, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, of about $9 million this year. It will have a loss of $125 million this year, mainly because of depreciation and interest expense. Shares of Loral Space rose 18.75 cents, to $22.4375

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTSHULER, BERNARD, PH.D.
description: ALTSHULER-Bernard, Ph.D. The Trustees, Faculty and staff of NYU Medical Center deeply mourn the loss of Bernard Altshuler, age 78, Professor of Environmental Medicine at NYU School of Medicine. Dr. Altshuler was well known for his mathematical approach to biology and environmental health, particularly for mathematically predicting cancer risks. He joined the faculty at NYU School of Medicine's Institute for Environmental Medicine in 1951 and served NYU for 46 years until his death on October 4, 1997. In 1988, he wrote a book on the link between cigarette smoke and lung cancer. He also published extensive research in scientific journals on experimental models of cancer, health risk analysis and airborne carcinogens. Over the years, the U.S. Government asked Dr. Altshuler to advise several national commitees about environmental issues including air pollution, cancer, ozone and pesticides. His wife, Lillian Schulsinger Altshuler and children Jean and Miriam survive him. We express our deep sympathy to Dr. Altshuler's wife and family. E. John Rosenwald, Jr., Chairman, Board of Trustees, NYU Medical Center Noel Cohen, M.D., Interim Provost and Dean, NYU Medical Center/ School of Medicine Max Costa, Ph.D., Professor and Chairman, Dept of Environmental Medicine, NYU Medical Center/ School of Medicine

title: YACHT RACING: WHITBREAD ROUND THE WORLD RACE -- A Sailor's Journal; Seeking a Door Through the Doldrums
description: Ten 60-foot yachts and about 120 sailors began the 31,600-nautical mile Whitbread Round the World Race on Sept. 21. The competitors are in the midst of the first of nine stages, a monthlong, 7,350-nautical-mile voyage south through the Atlantic to Cape Town. As of yesterday, Innovation Kvaerner led Merit Cup by some 29 nautical miles and EF Language by 43, while the Dutch boat Brunel Sunergy was heading for the Brazilian port Recife to replace a rudder that was damaged in a collision with a whale. Katie Pettibone, an American on the all-women's crew of EF Education, currently 10th, will be filing periodic reports about life on board until the race's scheduled return to Southampton, England, next May. This is her third report.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE VRIES, HARRY
description: de VRIES-Harry. October 6th, 1997, of Larchmont, NY. Devoted husband of Mary (nee Brischetto). Loving father of Henry. Cherished son of Irmgard de Vries. Dear brother of Werner. Survived by three grandchildren. Funeral from Fox Funeral Home, Inc., Post Road, Larchmont, NY. Funeral service on Thursday morning at 11 A.M., at the funeral home. Visiting hours Wednesday, 2-4, 7-9 P.M.

title: Mary Jayne Gold, 88, Heiress Who Helped Artists Flee Nazis
description: Mary Jayne Gold, a Chicago heiress who used some of her fortune to help prominent Jewish or anti-Nazi artists like Chagall flee Nazi-occupied France, died on Sunday at her home near St.-Tropez on the French Riviera. She was 88.

title: Kanell Knows the Script For First Starting Role
description: From the stands, the calls have come for Danny Kanell for almost a year. From the news media, the same calls have come with each incompletion or loss for Dave Brown. And with Brown's torn pectoral muscle clearing the way, the call has come from the Giants coaches for Kanell to make his first professional start at Arizona on Sunday.

title: FRONTIER ACQUIRES MEDICAL MALPRACTICE BUSINESS
description: Frontier Insurance Group Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the Western Indemnity Corporation for $48.5 million to bolster its medical malpractice insurance business. Frontier expects to pay cash for the company, which is now owned by the Galtney Group Inc., a Houston-based broker of insurance to hospitals and other medical organizations that last year was the 24th-largest United States broker. In selling Western Indemnity, Galtney Group leaves the business of underwriting insurance. Shares of Frontier, which is based in Rock Hill, N.Y., dropped 81.25 cents, to $35, extending a slide that began Friday after news that the company's president and chairman, Walter A. Rhulen, was hospitalized with leukemia.

title: Thunder in the Senate
description: In its substance and its drama, yesterday was a climactic day in the Senate's yearlong struggle over campaign money.
