The heretofore cocky majority leader, Trent Lott, failed in his effort to scuttle the McCain-Feingold campaign reform bill by attaching an anti-labor amendment. Meanwhile, at the hearings on fund-raising abuses of last year, Senator Fred Thompson issued a blistering challenge to President Clinton to rip down the investigative blockade erected by his Attorney General, Janet Reno. And Senator Joseph Lieberman, warming to his role as the committee's most fair-minded Democrat, said the logical response to White House obstruction was to extend the committee hearings past the Dec. 31 deadline. ''We've got to keep charging the wall that's being erected to block our inquiry,'' Mr. Lieberman declared.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Cities Receive Housing Funds
description: Housing authorities in three northern New Jersey cities yesterday received $82.6 million in Federal grants to replace existing high-rise public housing projects with single or two-family townhouses, officials said.

title: Bell Atlantic Internet Pact
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation said yesterday that it had picked equipment by Farallon Communications as the router for its Internet access service. Bell Atlantic Internet Solutions said that its integrated services digital network/local area network service packaged with Farallon's Netopia router was priced at $115 a month for unlimited Internet access, based on a three-year contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, FLORENCE
description: MEYER-Florence. On October 5, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Arthur Meyer. Dear mother of Marilyn (Abe) Wertheim and Jeffrey (Anne) Meyer. Adored grandmother of Robert, Eric, Caryn, Rachel and Rebecca. Cherished aunt. Services Wednesday, October 8, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILBERT, MITCHELL LOUIS
description: SILBERT-Mitchell Louis, of Pembroke Pines, FL and Ridge, NY, on October 6, 1997 in his 79th year. Beloved husband of the late Shirley. Loving father of Alan, Joan and Carol. Dear grandfather of Jennifer and Lauren Silbert, Eli and Adam Cook, and Joshua Streit. Service on Thursday, 1:30 PM at the I.J. Morris Funeral Home, Dix Hills, followed by burial in Mt Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale. Shiva on Thursday night, 6-9 PM and Friday morning, 11-1 at the family's home in Shoreham. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to Mitchell Silbert Memorial Scholarship Fund for Optometrists/Joan Cook, Southwest School, 1095 Joselson Ave, Bayshore, NY 11706.

title: Morgenthau Rejects The Death Penalty In Killing of Officer
description: Despite a chorus of calls for the death penalty, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, announced yesterday that he would not seek capital punishment against a failed stockbroker accused of killing a police officer after a botched attempt to rob his wealthy father's apartment.

title: Commerzbank Considers Buying Barclays Units
description: Commerzbank is considering buying the BZW corporate finance and stock brokerage businesses of Barclays, a management board member of Commerzbank said yesterday. Board members are concerned that the operations are too big for Commerzbank and would be difficult to integrate, said the board member, who declined to be identified.

title: Ad Spending Rises In Gay Publications
description: Advertising spending in publications aimed at gay and lesbian consumers rose significantly during the last year, an annual survey reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUDON, MALCOLM JOHN
description: LOUDON-Malcolm John, Wing Commander, DFC, on 9/20/97 in the UK at age 81. RAF, Battle of Britain, WWII 1935-1946. Mentioned in dispatches for distinguished service. POW at Stalag Luft III from 1944 to 1945. He moved to USA in 1946, where he married and had two children. He returned to the U.K. in 1988. He will be missed greatly by his two daughters, Gay Wells Loudon-King and Serena Ford Loudon, as well as by his friends.

title: Real Estate; Library Is Transformed Into Synagogue's Home
description: For more than 20 years, the two-story building at 69th Street and Amsterdam Avenue was a branch of the New York Public Library, offering thousands of books for loan. These days, the building's occupants frequently focus on five books -- the Torah, the Five Books of Moses.

title: Cuba's Communists Likely to Hold Line
description: Revolutionary banners and slogans are posted everywhere, and some 1,800 delegates have already arrived in the capital. After months of preparation that have emphasized ideological discipline and ''socialist values'' over change, Cuba's Communist Party begins its first congress in six years on Wednesday.

title: National News Briefs; School Leader in Dallas Quits, Admitting Guilt
description: The superintendent of the troubled Dallas school system agreed today to plead guilty to misapplying public funds to buy herself bedroom furniture, and the school board accepted her resignation tonight.

title: Union Defeated at Airline
description: America West Airlines said today that its baggage handlers and other ramp workers had rejected a bid by the Transport Workers Union to represent them. Of 1,899 employees eligible to vote, 1,028, or 54 percent, voted against forming a union, according to results tabulated on Monday at National Mediation Board headquarters. Officials of the union, which already represents America West dispatchers, could not be reached for comment today. America West, a unit of America West Holdings based here, has 11,000 employees. Its flight attendants, mechanics and pilots are represented by other unions.

title: Bulls' Pippen Will Miss 2-3 Months After Toe Surgery
description: The Chicago Bulls, known almost as much for their resiliency as for their talent, will have to make do without Scottie Pippen for the next two to three months. Pippen, the All-Star forward, underwent toe surgery Monday in Manhattan, the team said yesterday, leaving Michael Jordan to shoulder the load as the Bulls seek their third straight championship.

title: Off the Menu
description: Italian Grill

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAURA, OSCAR R.
description: FAURA-Oscar R., 80, died on September 30, 1997, in Atlanta, Georgia. Mr. Faura served in the United Nations for 25 years. He is survived by three daughters, 4 granddaughters, and one greatgrandson. The memorial service will be at 4 PM, Thursday, October 9, 1997, at All Saints Episcopal Church in Atlanta. National Cremation Society, 404-851-1333.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, JEANNE (NEE GOLDFINE)
description: SMITH-Jeanne (nee Goldfine), on October 6, 1997, of Elmhurst, NY. Beloved mother of Michael, Edward, Meryl Strome-Cohen, and Deborah McDonald. Cherished sister of Herman, William and Secye Yaro. Adored grandmother of 7. Services today, 10:30AM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: New U.N. Monitor Says Iraq Is Still Hiding Data on Weapons
description: In his first report since taking office in July, the new United Nations chief monitor of Iraq's weapons programs concludes that the Government of Saddam Hussein is continuing to hide information on biological arms and is also withholding some data on chemical weapons and missiles.

title: Spano Accepts Guilty Plea Agreement
description: John Spano, the 33-year-old Texas entrepreneur who bought the Islanders last November and then lost them when his financing collapsed, pleaded guilty yesterday to four Federal fraud charges.

title: U.S. Steps Up Patrols in Iraqi No-Flight Zone
description: The Pentagon announced today that American jet fighters had stepped up their patrols over the American-enforced no-flight zone in southern Iraq after Iraqi planes breached the zone several times during the last week.

title: China's Nuclear Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: Netanyahu And Arafat Said to Discuss 'New Start'
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat of the Palestinian Authority held their first face-to-face meeting in eight months early this morning in an American-mediated effort to find ways out of the deadlock in their search for peace.

title: 13 Days in October
description: John F. Kennedy was a man of many secrets. In his private life, his character was questionable or mysterious enough that a reporter as serious as Seymour Hersh and two network news departments could fool around with fraudulent documents ''proving'' the President was being blackmailed by Marilyn Monroe. In his public life, his work was important enough that his decision-making during the Cuban missile crisis 35 years ago is still worthy of admiring study.

title: Sun Sues Microsoft on Use of Java System
description: In a clash of opposing computer industry camps, Sun Microsystems Inc. sued the Microsoft Corporation today, charging the giant software publisher with trying to steal Sun's Java standard by shipping a conflicting version of the programming language.

title: Iran Says U.S. Overreacts
description: Iran's new Defense Minister, Ali Shamkhani, said today that the American decision to send the aircraft carrier Nimitz to the Persian Gulf ahead of schedule was nothing more than an attempt by the United States ''to justify its presence.'' Iran is trying to steer sentiment in the region toward its view that the dispatch of the aircraft carrier represented just another American overreaction.

title: People
description: * Mark Linder was named to the new post of worldwide client service director on the Ford Motor brand business at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, Detroit, a unit of WPP Group. He had been vice president for marketing at Mainspring Communications, Cambridge, Pa. Also, Ross Sutherland, senior partner and creative director at Ogilvy, New York, was named to handle new duties as the lead creative director on the Ford business.

title: Emotional vs. Staid
description: The Braves concede that their clubhouse, whether winning or losing, is as sedate as an insurance office -- no loud music, no noisy players, no gyrating swings in mood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, SONIA
description: KLEIN-Sonia. Died peacefully in Hollywood, Florida, on Monday, October 6, 1997. She was the beloved wife of Myron Klein and mother of Eliane. She is survived by her grandchildren Barbara, Daniel and Mark; their spouses and five loving great grandchildren. May she rest in peace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENDER, MICHAEL L.
description: BENDER-Michael L., who produced ''Beetlejuice,'' died on Friday, October 3rd, 1997 at Tarzana Encino Hospital, due to complications from HIV. He was 51. Mr. Bender began his career as an entertainment lawyer for Warner Bros. and Avco Embassy. His family requests any donations be made to AIDS Project L.A. or Project Angel Food.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINSTEIN, THERESA M.
description: FEINSTEIN-Theresa M., 89, of North Brunswick, N.J., formerly of Brooklyn, on October 6th, 1997. Retired NYC School Teacher in Brooklyn. Wife of the late Lester. Mother of Janet and Robert (Barbara). Grandmother of Michael (Suzanne) Feinstein and Linda (Ed) Schnell. Great-grandmother of Lauren. Aunt of Sidney and Eve Mayer. Service 10:45 AM Wednesday, Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, Cranbury Rd. at Evergreen Boulevard, East Brunswick, NJ. Burial Beth David Cemetery. Memorial gifts to Hadassah.

title: Hearst Names Marketing Officer
description: Michael A. Clinton, a former top executive at the Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications, has joined Hearst Magazines in the new post of senior vice president and chief marketing officer.

title: Most Major Stock Indexes Hit Record Highs
description: The stock market, buttressed by favorable earnings reports and falling interest rates, rose again yesterday, sending most of the major stock indexes to record highs.

title: Gillick's Reason Yankees Lost: Cone
description: Pat Gillick, the Baltimore Orioles' general manager, said today that the absence of David Cone most likely undermined the Yankees' chances against Cleveland in their playoff series more than people realize.

title: Video Helps Bring Arrests In Fraud Cases
description: After falling at work in the Saks Fifth Avenue beauty salon here, Florence Steinbrecher suffered such severe back, neck and head pain that she could no longer work and spent all her days at doctors' offices.

title: Belle of the Bivalves: the New Mussel ; After a makeover, the wallflower of shellfish gets to dance.
description: AT the Fulton Fish Market, forklifts are buzzing from stall to stall, many of them piled high with sacks of mussels. At one, a fishmonger is already inspecting the stacks that arrived that day. He has mounds of cultivated mussels from Prince Edward Island, all evenly sized, their shells clamped tight. They are so clean they sparkle. There's a small pile of New Zealand mussels, their shocking green shells gleaming through holes in the boxes.

title: THERMO ELECTRON IN DEAL FOR ALLIED HEALTHCARE UNIT
description: The Thermo Electron Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the ventilator business of Allied Healthcare Products Inc. for $37.5 million in cash. Thermo Electron, which is based in Waltham, Mass., makes a range of industrial and consumer-related products, including analytical instruments, heart pumps, power plants and hair-removal lasers. Allied Healthcare, based in St. Louis, makes medical gas equipment and emergency medical products. Thermo Electron shares rose 25 cents, to $41.25, while Allied's shares rose 12.5 cents, to $8.

title: Sports of The Times; The Alomars Meet Again In October
description: SOMEWHERE within a yard or two of Roberto Alomar, there was probably an official major league pronouncement forbidding fraternization between players of opposing teams.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLADES, WILLIAM B.
description: BLADES-William B. Dearest friend, handsome and distinguished Southern gentleman. A celebration of his life will be announced. Roderick R. Denault Richard L. Ridge

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENHEIN, BEVERLY (CHAMOW)
description: ROSENHEIN-Beverly (Chamow), on October 6. Beloved wife of Elihu. Adored mother of Larry, Jon (Ellen), and Debby (Gary) Carlton. Cherished grandmother of Lindsay, Julie, Matthew and Joanna. Loving sister of Robert and Arthur, and sisters-in-law, Dorothy & Clara. In lieu of flowers, donations to the American Cancer Society. Services on Wednesday, October 8th, at 12:00 Noon, at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.

title: House Approves Bill to Speed Review of Medicines
description: The House passed a Food and Drug Administration modernization bill today that would allow faster approval of new medicines for AIDS, cancer and other diseases and would make it easier for doctors to prescribe experimental drugs.

title: BOEING WINS AN ORDER FOR 26 737-800 AIRCRAFT
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it had won an order for 26 new 737-800 aircraft valued at $1.3 billion from Turkish Airlines, beating an offer from rival Airbus Industrie. Turkish Airlines took options for 23 more 737-800s. If all the options turn into firm orders, the sale would be valued at $2.5 billion at list prices, Boeing said. The order will help Boeing make good on its repeated claim that it could get as many new orders this year as it did last year, when it sold 712 airplanes. Including the Turkish order, Boeing has sold about 370 aircraft so far this year. The order comes as Boeing is struggling to keep up with surging demand for planes from the world's airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELDEN, JOHN E.
description: SELDEN-John E., retired Chairman of Pennzoil Company died Oct. 3, 1997 at Pennswood Village, Newtown, Pa. A graduate of Princeton Univ., Harvard Law School, Mr. Selden was general counsel for South Penn Oil Co and became chairman of Pennzoil and retired in 1962. Mr. Selden is the husband of the late Dorothy Ayers Selden and is survived by a brother, William Selden of Newtown, Pa. Private family services will be held in Oil City, Pa at a later date. For information Swartz/Givnish Funeral Home, Newtown.

title: Brahms, More Assured Than Wistful
description: Kurt Masur has made a point of including symphonic cycles in his programming ever since he took up the directorship of the New York Philharmonic in 1991, but for the most part, and particularly with bigger cycles like the Shostakovich and Beethoven symphonies, he has spaced the installments over several seasons. But if the point of surveying a composer's symphonies is to trace the development of a distinctive compositional voice, the works must be offered in close succession, and this is the approach Mr. Masur took with the Brahms symphonies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOCHTENBERG, ESTELLE
description: DOCHTENBERG - Estelle. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our member, Phyllis Fier. May her entire family be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob J. Schacter, Rabbi Samuel Goldman, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, SYLVIA
description: KAUFMAN-Sylvia. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member, Sylvia Kaufman. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Malaysia and Thailand Offer Bargain Hunter's Paradise : A Currency Crisis Fire Sale
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Attention shoppers! The Southeast Asian sale of the decade is on! Buy now while supplies last!

title: Surprising Voices for Irish Peace
description: The success so far of peace talks in Northern Ireland is the achievement of many different groups, but two unlikely organizations figure prominently in the effort. They are small Protestant parties, the Progressive Unionist Party and the Ulster Democratic Party. Both grew out of violent paramilitary organizations and count among their leaders men who have served time in prison. Their members and leaders are not part of Northern Ireland's white-collar class that has dominated Protestant politics. All these factors could have helped tie the two parties to violence, but instead have increased their commitment to peace.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in some copies yesterday about the Yankees' loss to Cleveland misidentified the player standing next to Derek Jeter. He was Tino Martinez, not Paul O'Neill.

title: Alexander Plans to Resign As Leader of Arts Agency
description: Jane Alexander, who as chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Arts has spent most of the last four years battling Congressional conservatives to save the agency, plans to resign after Congress approves the agency's new budget, friends in the arts community report.

title: Clinton Lawyer Is Subpoenaed On Tape Delay
description: In an expression of frustration with the White House, the Justice Department today subpoenaed a top Presidential lawyer to appear before a Federal grand jury to explain why videotapes showing President Clinton with wealthy supporters at coffees and other events in the White House had been withheld for months, Government officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARIS, SAMUEL L.
description: PARIS-Samuel L. A curtain of sorrow has descended upon the family of Sam Paris. His life was a synthesis of commitment and love. May we all be blessed by the same indomitable spirit, uncompromising intellect and gift for touching others' lives. To his cherished wife, Shirley, beloved children, Deanne and Dr. William Chenitz, Patti and Dr. Robert Sacks, adored grandchildren, Ali and Kara Chenitz, Anne and Victoria Sacks, whose burden will be lightened by the awareness that this was a life that enriched us all and left a legacy of much love and respect. Services 1 P.M., Wednesday, West End Temple, 147-02 Newport Avenue, Neponsit, NY.

title: Critic's Notebook; Seeking Perfection in a Sea of Crab Cakes
description: I THINK I've finally found the perfect crab cake. It will make the woman in the penthouse very happy.

title: Metro Business; Fresh Meadows Sale
description: The John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation said yesterday that a sales contract had been signed on the 147-acre Fresh Meadows apartment and retail complex in Queens. The foundation had been a partner of the late Harry B. Helmsley in the ownership, and it acquired full title two years ago.

title: Jury to Start Deliberations In a Racketeering Trial
description: A Manhattan jury is expected to begin deliberations today in the racketeering trial of two men accused of leading a Mafia cartel that dominated the billion-dollar garbage industry.

title: Johnson, Ex-Giant, Now Jets' Statesman
description: In younger days, Pepper Johnson was as earthy as his nickname. On the football field, he played with fervor. In the locker room, he kept teammates loose with his vitality.

title: Yanks Win Television Battle
description: At least the Yankees won the New York City television battle.

title: Executive Changes
description: ALLERGAN INC., Irvine, Calif., named David Pyott president and chief executive, and Herbert W. Boyer, chairman, effective Jan. 1. The health care company said that Mr. Pyott and Mr. Boyer would succeed William C. Shepherd.

title: Canadians' Charge of Graft In Mexico Causes Tempest
description: Since the dawn of continental free trade in North America nearly four years ago, it is the United States and Canada that have generated the big money, and the United States and Mexico that have set off the big political battles.

title: U.S. to Look Into Fees for 401(k) Services
description: The Labor Department is concerned that some employers who offer 401(k) plans may be paying ''excessive'' fees to outside administrators and wants to shed more light on the issue, a senior official said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANE, ANNE G.
description: SHANE-Anne G. Oct 6, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Adored mother of Michael, Stephen (Jasmine) and Joseph. Beloved sister of Helen Bernstein. Cherished grandmother of Samantha and Jessica. Services Wednesday 1pm ''Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapels'' 76 Rd and Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Food Chain
description: A Risotto Trick

title: Listen Up Now: Grandmother's Come to Teach
description: SHE had a feeling it would happen, and it did.

title: Wryly Defiant, Ickes Invokes Reagan, Bush and Jay Leno
description: After weeks of hearings, senators investigating 1996 campaign finance practices came face-to-face today with the man they believed stretched the law and then leapt through loopholes to help raise tens of millions of dollars for President Clinton.

title: Sex Attack at School Is Tied to Gang Threat
description: The 13-year-old girl who said she was sexually abused this week in a boys' bathroom at a Manhattan high school told investigators that an older girl identified herself as a gang member and warned the victim that she would ''be in trouble'' if she refused to perform sex acts on four boys, according to a criminal complaint filed yesterday by the Manhattan District Attorney's office.

title: A Challenge for Brad Pitt: Making a Nazi Charming
description: For better and definitely for worse, the renowned explorer Heinrich Harrer is a more interesting figure than the Brad Pitt character in Jean-Jacques Annaud's picturesque new picture, ''Seven Years in Tibet.'' The octogenarian Mr. Harrer has devoted a lifetime to exploits much more grueling than those seen in the movie, and until recently he had two secrets that were difficult as well. These were his Nazi past as a member of Hitler's elite SS and his having left his unborn son for the sake of a long Himalayan adventure.

title: Again, Parents Faulting Class Sizes Are Appeased
description: For the second time in two weeks, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew yielded yesterday to parents so angry about large class sizes that they had raised money themselves to pay an extra teacher's salary.

title: As Parents Scramble, Questions Swirl Over a Closed School
description: As parents and teachers struggled yesterday over what to do with 500 children suddenly in need of classroom space, officials tried to sort through the circumstances that led to the opening and abrupt closing of a Harlem elementary school in a building that once housed a dry-cleaning operation.

title: New TV Ad For Rowland Shows Voters His Soft Side
description: After cultivating a reputation as a conservative Republican who slashed welfare benefits, pushed for a broader death penalty and took on state employee unions, Gov. John G. Rowland today began an effort to highlight his softer side: he cares about children.

title: Calls Renewed to Rid Apartment Buildings of Dry Cleaners
description: For tens of thousands of New York City apartment dwellers, the pungent tang of dry cleaning fluid does not just come from plastic-wrapped garments hanging in the closet. It can also waft through the floor or walls from the dry cleaning shop on the ground floor.

title: Freed Hamas Leader Suggests Terms for Truce
description: The newly freed leader of the militant Islamic movement Hamas, guiding it again as a free man, laid out a series of positions today that seemed to hold out a prospect of compromise without abandoning the traditional aims and methods of Hamas.

title: Sips; In California, the Water May Taste Like a Cucumber
description: WHEN the worker bees in the Napa Valley aren't drinking wine, they might well be drinking iced cucumber water -- a casual mix of H2O, cukes and citrus slices or herbs.

title: Only Indians Can Play for Revenge
description: Right after the Baltimore Orioles won their division series against the Seattle Mariners, Davey Johnson, never too shy to express his opinion, cried, ''Bring on the Yankees.'' The Yankees, the manager said, ended the Orioles' season last year, so it would only be fitting for the Orioles to end theirs this year.

title: Day of Wrangling in the Senate Over Campaign Finance Laws Is Cut Short
description: A Senate day of rich, partisan fury ended with such abruptness that it even caught short Harold M. Ickes, President Clinton's White House re-election chief, as he sat urging ranking lawmakers to ''begin the debate to change the system'' of big-money campaign financing.

title: German Unemployment Rises to Postwar Record
description: Job losses in eastern Germany in September pushed the number of unemployed in Germany up 34,000, to 4,497,000, a postwar record, the Federal Labor Office said yesterday. The larger-than-expected rise included a gain of 7,000 job losses in western Germany, adjusted for seasonal factors. Unemployment in eastern Germany, which makes up a tenth of the economy, rose by 26,000. A Federal Labor Office spokesman said his office was expecting unadjusted jobless rolls to average 4.4 million this year, higher than the 4.3 million previously expected.

title: Arthur Tracy, 98, Musical Star Known as the Street Singer
description: Arthur Tracy, the celebrated Street Singer on radio and recordings in the 1930's and 40's, died on Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 98 and lived in Manhattan.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GMAC COMMERCIAL MORTGAGE CORP., agreed to buy $7.1 billion in mortgage servicing from GE Capital Asset Management, increasing its servicing portfolio to more than $36 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAPIRO, MURRAY H.
description: SCHAPIRO-Murray H. On October 6, 1997. Beloved son of the late Minnie and David. Brother of the late Miriam and Harold. Uncle of Harold and Flora Bofshever. Grand-uncle of Jon and Miriam and great-granduncle of Scott. Devoted friend and companion of Samuel Altman. Graveside services on Thursday, 11 A.M., at Mount Hebron Cemetery.

title: Espinosa de Henares Journal; The Nuns' Sad Story Inflames a Village in Spain
description: The sturdy two-story convent with white stucco walls and red tile roof is nestled along the Henares River, overlooking cornfields and its own bountiful garden, which bears apples, pears and tomatoes.

title: House Tweaks Clinton Over Creation of National Monuments
description: The House voted today to limit President Clinton's authority to declare Federal lands to be national monuments, a gesture of legislative anger by the Republican majority over his designation last year of 1.7 million acres in southern Utah as a national monument.

title: F.D.A. Grants Its Approval For Amgen's Hepatitis Drug
description: Amgen Inc. said yesterday that it had received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to market Infergen, a new drug for treating chronic hepatitis C, a viral infection of the liver.

title: Bond Prices Drift Higher in Light Trading
description: The prices of Treasury securities drifted higher yesterday in light trading, with yields still at their lowest levels since early last year. Investors remain cautiously optimistic that the economy is not expanding at a pace fast enough to heat inflation.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MENZI, MATLEA
description: MENZI-Matlea. In my heart and my soul always. I celebrate your life and light. Sharon Lauer-Wolf

title: Food Stuff
description: Late-Season Strawberries Stay Sweet With Less Sun

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: $1 Toy Necklaces Being Recalled
description: Some toy necklaces and bracelets sold in discount and dollar stores can break into pieces that small children could swallow, the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission said today.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL SELLS A WEST VIRGINIA COAL MINE
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had sold a West Virginia coal mine, the last of its nonsteel businesses, to the closely held A. T. Massey Coal Company for an undisclosed amount. The High Power Mountain mine in Nicholas County, W. Va., supplies low-sulfur steam coal to power plants. Bethlehem had 1996 sales of $4.68 billion. Bethlehem shares were unchanged at $10.

title: The Minimalist; Tomato Sauce With a Little Meat to It
description: ANY kitchen minimalist has to be familiar with a basic tomato sauce. Typically, you make it by coloring a little garlic or onion in oil, then adding crushed tomatoes and cooking over medium-high heat. When the mixture becomes ''saucy,'' about 20 minutes later, it's done.

title: A Couple of Reliable Aces Go Bust
description: Went to a National League playoff game last night and a funny thing happened. An American League game broke out. Florida Marlins hitters, many in their first league championship series, looked out at the mound, saw the four-time Cy Young Award winner Greg Maddux and treated him like a punching bag.

title: This Time Around, the Breaks Betrayed the Yankees
description: The custodian carried one gallon of white paint, a paint brush and a ladder around Yankee Stadium yesterday. Using methodical strokes across a white cinder block wall, he painted over the blue ''1996,'' then painted over the blue words ''World'' and ''Champions'' until all that remained was the Yankees' interlocking NY. It is still a proud symbol, but it is no longer the symbol of the best team in baseball. Not after Monday night.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Call to Avert Amtrak Strike
description: Two weeks before a Federal cooling-off period is due to expire, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday called on Amtrak workers and Federal officials to avert a labor strike that she said could cripple New Jersey's commuter and commercial rail systems.

title: Marketing Agencies Announce Merger
description: Two agencies specializing in integrated marketing -- Integer Group in Denver and Kragie/Newell in Des Moines -- are merging to form a shop with combined billings estimated at $305 million. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Levi Strauss campaigns become pieces at an exhibition.
description: THE Art Directors Club is entering its blue period with an extensive exhibit devoted to almost a century and a half of advertising, graphic design and products by, for and from Levi Strauss & Company.

title: Enron in Bid to Be Pennsylvania Utility
description: The Enron Corporation is seeking to take over the Pennsylvania service area of the Peco Energy Company, offering to lower customers' electric rates by 20 percent and assume $5.5 billion in Peco costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORENSTEIN, ALBERT
description: ORENSTEIN-Albert. Beloved husband of Clara. Cherished Uncle and dear friend to so many. Services Wednesday 10:30 AM, ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Boulevard at 66th Avenue, Forest Hills, NY.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Less Spending for More Taxes
description: New Jersey residents last year each paid an average of $1,915 more in Federal taxes than they got back in spending, the worst such ratio in the nation, a report released yesterday by the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University determined.

title: WAL-MART EXPECTS TO OPEN 185 STORES NEXT YEAR
description: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said yesterday that it would open about 185 stores in the fiscal year beginning Feb. 1 in a plan to bolster merchandise and food sales. The company, which is based in Bentonville, Ark., said the openings would include 120 to 125 supercenters, 50 discount stores and about 10 Sam's Clubs stores. The retailer currently has 2,771 stores. Wal-Mart said about 90 of the supercenters would be expansions or relocations of its discount stores. Supercenters combine Wal-Mart's traditional discount stores with grocery stores. Wal-Mart said its planned growth would add about 26 million square feet of retail space. To support the growth, the retailer said it also planned to open one general merchandise and two food distribution centers in the next fiscal year. Shares of Wal-Mart fell 31.25 cents, to $36.5625.

title: In America; Affirmative Action's Rollback
description: There are times when you have no choice but to try to cut your losses. Such is the case now with affirmative action.

title: North Korea's Favorite Son Wins Top Title
description: North Korea's ''Dear Leader,'' Kim Jong Il, today assumed the country's top leadership post, which had been vacant since the death of his father, the ''Great Leader'' Kim Il Sung, three years ago. Some experts say they believe the official elevation creates possibilities for changes in North Korea that could reverberate around the Pacific Rim.

title: In California, Wider Test of Same-Sex Schools
description: While New York City's only public school for girls, now in its second year, struggles to fend off a legal challenge, the State of California has begun the nation's most ambitious experiment in single-sex education, a pilot program encouraging school districts to make separate but equal boys' and girls' ''academies'' an option for middle and high school students.

title: Beltway Accounting
description: The Congressional Budget Office has just pointed out a reality: the ''balanced budget'' is not balanced. And there is little hope that it will become balanced.

title: Metro Business; Employees to Buy AIL
description: The New York State Empire Development Corporation has helped create an employee stock ownership plan that state officials said would safeguard 900 jobs at an electronics company on Long Island.

title: PRESIDENT LEADS A BROAD DEFENSE OF FUND-RAISING
description: Hoping to calm the political tempest over belatedly discovered White House videotapes of the President Clinton's meetings with Democratic donors, Mr. Clinton today defended his fund-raising practices, while current and former White House advisers carried the same message to Congress and a Federal grand jury.

title: Indonesia Asks I.M.F. and World Bank Aid
description: Indonesia asked the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund today for help in overcoming an emerging financial crisis as economic problems continued to spread through Southeast Asia.

title: Not Asbestos, but a Mess, Closes 8 Classrooms
description: The air quality in a public school in Brooklyn was tested yesterday after teachers expressed concern that crumbling plaster contained asbestos, but school officials said the tests showed that the school was safe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, ROBERT H.
description: O'BRIEN-Robert H. Mr. Robert H. O'Brien, retired motion picture industry executive who when President of Metro Goldwyn Mayer shepherded the filming of ''Dr. Zhivago'' and ''2001 A Space Odyssey'', died October 6th in Seattle, WA. He had lived in Washington State since retiring from the MGM executive position. He was born in Helena, Montana, on September 15, 1904 to Montana pioneers, Joseph G. and Margaret V. O'Brien. As a child he lived with his family in the now ghost mining towns of Elkhorn and Marysville MT. His family moved to Butte, MT. in 1912. There he starred in football and graduated from Butte High School in 1920. He attended Beloit College where he played football under Tommy Mills. In 1925, he returned to Butte and worked for several years in the Geology & Sampling Department of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company before he returned to school. He graduated from the Law School of the University of Chicago in 1933. That same year he began his distinguished career with the Legal Department of the Public Works Administration. He joined the newly formed Securities and Exchange Commission in 1934 and there advanced very rapidly. He was appointed Commissioner of its utliity division by President Frankin D. Roosevelt on February 3, 1942. This post he held until his resignation from the SEC, on December 29, 1944. He became associated with the entertainment and film industry in January 1945, joining Paramount Pictures as assistant to the President. After the division of the Paramount Pictures Corporation & its acquistion of the American Broadcasting Company, he was appointed Executive Vice President of ABC-Paramount Theatres. In 1957 he left ABC-PT to become Treasurer and Vice President of Metro Goldwyn Mayer. He was appointed President of MGM in January 1963. Other films brought to the screen during his tenure at MGM included ''The Dirty Dozen'', ''Far From The Madding Crowd'' and ''Ryan's Daughter''. He retired from MGM in 1970. He served as a member of the Advisory Council of the Business School of the University of Notre Dame from 1948 to 1970. He was a member of the Board of Trustees of Beloit College for many years. Early in his career he was invited into membership into The Knights of Malta, a Roman Catholic Lay organization. In 1964, the University of Montana recognized him as an outstanding Montanan and presented him with its Order of the Grizzly Award that year. His contributions to the film industry were recognized with his being named Recipient of the 1965 Motion Picture Pioneer of the Year Award. In 1966, he was selected as the recipient of The Brotherhood Award from the National Conference of Christians and Jews for distinguished service in the field of human relations. He served on numerous other Boards and received many other awards during his career. He is survived by his devoted and beloved wife, Minna in Seattle, WA. Other living relations include one nephew, Dr. D.J. McGonigle of Seattle, WA; six grand nieces and grand nephews, Dr. Mary A. McGonigle Wolak of Seattle, Dr. Kathryn F. McGonigle Rawlings of Santa Monica, CA.; D.J. McGonigle, III of Spokane, WA.; Michael E. McGonigle of Seattle; Anne T. McGonigle Witter of Seattle and Patricia J. Tokheim of Menlo Park, CA. He has three great grand nieces and one great grand nephew. He was preceded in death by his wife, Ellen O'Brien and their child Jo Ellen. A sister, Alice K. McGonigle, two brothers, Dr. J. Grant O'Brien and James Harold O'Brien. His life will be honored at a requiem mass and burial in Butte, Montana. He was greatly loved by his family and he will be deeply missed.

title: Personal Shopper; Haut Wheels
description: LIFE just got easier for the intrepid schlepper: no longer bound to the standard-issue wire shopping cart, focused shoppers now have several new ''haut'' options.

title: Burnett to Sell Stake In Its Headquarters
description: The Leo Burnett Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell majority ownership of its world headquarters building in downtown Chicago to affiliates of two real estate investment and development companies, Starwood Capital Group L.L.C. and the John Buck Company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: GUN MAKERS AGREE ON SAFETY LOCKS
description: After quietly negotiating with the Clinton Administration, the manufacturers of most handguns in the United States plan to gather at the White House on Thursday to announce that they will provide child-safety locks with their firearms by the end of next year, a senior White House official and a representative of the gun makers said today.

title: New York Adopting Plans To Improve Vote Counting
description: New York City officials are adopting new procedures to try to improve the accuracy of the election results they release soon after the polls close, hoping to forestall a repeat of the blunders that led to the mistaken impression that there would be a runoff in the Democratic mayoral primary last month.

title: Carolina Awaiting Dean Smith's Goodbye
description: The University of North Carolina has scheduled a news conference today amid speculation that Dean Smith might be ready to step down as basketball coach.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAINDA, KARL JOSEF
description: MAINDA-Karl Josef. 12/29/47 to 10/9/87. In loving memory. The Minichiello Family

title: U.S. Labels 30 Groups As Terrorists; Omits I.R.A.
description: Under a Congressional mandate, the State Department designated 30 groups as foreign terrorist organizations today, making it illegal to provide funds for them and denying their members visas.

title: Charity Diversion
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Metro Business column yesterday about the sale of the Fresh Meadows residential and commercial complex in Queens misstated the name of one participant in the purchase. It is the Federal Realty Investment Trust, not Federated.

title: ENDURING LOVE
description: ENDURING LOVE .By Ian McEwan. Jonathan Cape. 247 pages. 15.99.

title: Greenspan's Remarks Roil Stocks and Bonds
description: The stock and bond markets fell sharply yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, suggested that they should not assume interest rates will remain low for some time to come.

title: Mayor Moves To Stanch Gang Violence
description: Responding to what he called an outbreak of gang-related violence in schools and on the streets, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would expand special police efforts against gangs and seek tougher state laws against them.

title: A Teen-Ager Betrayed
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters; Divisive Idea Calls Cuomo Out of Shell
description: THERE was a time, not so long ago, when a hint -- or even a hint of a hint -- from Mario M. Cuomo about his political ambitions was enough to trigger press speculations of an almost Talmudic intricacy.

title: Yanks' Focus Is on '98 And on More Pitching
description: When George Steinbrenner assembles his baseball executives in Tampa, Fla., today for three days of meetings, the focus will be on how to avoid too much damage in next month's expansion draft and on how the Yankees can upgrade their pitching staff, General Manager Bob Watson indicated yesterday.

title: Arts Head Attacks Critics
description: Jane Alexander, confirming that she would resign as the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts by the end of the month, said yesterday that arts groups had stopped seeking Federal financing for provocative work because of Congressional hostility toward her agency.

title: APACHE TO ACQUIRE OIL AND GAS INTERESTS FROM MOBIL UNIT
description: The Apache Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay a subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation $310 million in cash for interests in oil and natural gas properties off Australia's west coast. Apache, an oil and natural gas exploration company in Houston, said it would buy three companies with interests in the properties and production operations from Mobil's Ampolex Group unit. The acquisition will increase Apache's interest in the Carnarvon Basin's Harriet area to 47.5 percent from 22.5 percent and increase its interest in the nearby East Spar field to 55 percent from 20 percent. Apache shares fell 18.75 cents, to $43.4375, while Mobil fell 50 cents, to $76.50.

title: Man of Strong Passion, Earthly and Otherwise
description: Euliss (Sonny) Dewey, played with foxy charm and volcanic energy by Robert Duvall in his lovely, heartfelt film ''The Apostle,'' is a man of the cloth. But the cloth from which this Pentecostal preacher is cut may seem familiar at first, at least in movie terms. As a white preacher whose specialty is rousing black churchgoers to a holy fury, Sonny does look like something of a flimflam artist. And behind the kindly manner and beatific smile we know there is a man with serious marital troubles. Does the equally devout Jessie (Farrah Fawcett) want to leave Sonny because of his wicked ways? Is Sonny's overbearing godliness merely a cynical trick?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHLAIN, GAYLE
description: SHLAIN-Gayle. Died Sept. 19, 1997. Gifted psychoanalyst, esteemed colleague, beloved friend.

title: Early Breakdowns Doom Isles to First Loss
description: The Islanders were betrayed in the first period tonight by all of the elements that had helped them get off to their best start in three years.

title: Champion Set To Sell Assets And Cut Staff To Bolster Net
description: The Champion International Corporation announced yesterday that it would sell nonstrategic assets accounting for $1.4 billion of its $4.9 billion in sales and employing a quarter of its workers. The plan, which was widely anticipated on Wall Street, would effectively take Champion out of newsprint manufacturing, paper recycling and other businesses.

title: Expeditions; Revisiting the Empire, but Just for Design
description: THE fondest dream of Cecil Rhodes, diamond magnate and founder of Rhodesia (when he wasn't scheming to return America to British rule) was to build a railway from the Cape of Good Hope to Cairo, traversing British territory all the way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASS, SHELDON, M.D.
description: PASS-Sheldon, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center records with sorrow the death of Dr. Sheldon Pass. Dr. Pass was affiliated with Maimonides Medical Center in the Department of Ophthalmology serving as the Attending in Charge for many years. He will be sorely missed by all his colleagues, friends and patients. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. Warren Wexelman, M.D., Pres. Jacob Shani, M.D., Pres. Elect David Feldman, M.D. Secretary Salvatore DeGliuomini, M.D., Treasurer

title: Otto Remer, 84, Nazi Officer; Helped Foil Anti-Hitler Plot
description: Otto Ernst Fritz Adolf Remer, an unrepentant Nazi who as a young officer helped Hitler retain control of Germany in the crucial hours after a failed assassination attempt in 1944, died on Saturday at his home in Marbella in southern Spain. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREUS, PAUL
description: PREUS-Paul, Capt. 77, of Toms River formerly of Tenafly on Oct. 8, 1997. Beloved husband of Mary Lou nee Gibson. Devoted father of Glenn of Honolulu, Hawaii and the late Heather Preus. Dear brother of Irving Preus of Vero Beach, Fla., and Gloria Corsa of Tenafly, N.J. Loving Grandfather of Kalena Preus of Honolulu, Hawaii. Funeral services will be conducted at Carmona-Bolen Home For Funerals, 412 Main Street, Toms River, on Saturday, October 11, 1997, at 10 A.M. Burial is at Saint Joseph Cemetery, Toms River. Visiting Hours: Friday 2-4 & 7-9 P.M.

title: Secret Birth Revealed When Baby Is Found in Closet
description: When Stephanie Clark went into her daughter's bedroom looking for a pair of pants on Tuesday, she was shocked to find a tiny baby boy there, nestled in a blanket on the closet floor.

title: Kite Insists Ballesteros Did Not Outmatch Him
description: Even though he has had time to digest last month's Ryder Cup experience, Tom Kite acknowledged yesterday that the loss was still difficult to swallow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, WILLIAM
description: ALTMAN-William. We record with sorrow the passing of our long time member and treasurer. Services Fri., 9:45 AM, Riverside Chapel, 75th St & Amsterdam Ave. Rubin Huffman, President, Penn South Chelsea Greenwich Lodge B'nai B'rith

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIDENBAUM, DAVID
description: WEIDENBAUM-David. Of Englewood, N.J. Beloved husband of the late Alice; devoted father of Howard Weidenbaum and Brenda Rothman; dear brother of Herman & the late Sylvia; loving grandfather of Lyz, Lisa, Jennifer, Nicole. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Englewood, N.J., Thursday at 9 A.M.

title: Youth-Smoking Study Sees Little Effect in Sting Efforts
description: Regulations adopted by the Federal Government last year to make it harder for children to buy cigarettes and chewing tobacco are unlikely to have any effect on teen-age tobacco use, according to a study of six Massachusetts communities that is being published today in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: Rights Report Says Kabila's Troops Are Killing Civilians
description: A report by two human rights organizations says there is irrefutable evidence that President Laurent Kabila's troops in Congo have killed large numbers of civilian refugees since last fall, and that killings continue.

title: A Teen-Ager Betrayed
description: To the Editor:

title: Drinking and Office Politics as the Primary Sports
description: THE FRANCHISE

title: Photographer Is Arrested
description: A photographer for The Courier Post of Cherry Hill was arrested Tuesday morning while taking pictures of a fatal accident on Interstate 295, the state police said.

title: Supporters of Fund-Raising Overhaul Fail to Make a Persuasive Case to 'Disarm'
description: Campaign finance legislation is nearly dead, once again, for a single overriding reason. Across months of debate, no one has presented a compelling rationale for the Republicans to disarm in a fund-raising race that they are winning. And so only a handful of Senate Republicans are backing change.

title: Natural Gas Supported
description: Electricity consumers would probably save $1 billion in the next two decades if the newly renovated Salem Nuclear Generating Station were retired and replaced with a plant powered by natural gas, according to a report released yesterday by the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group.

title: The Blips of Outrageous Fortune
description: Call it the ''Hamletcam.'' Affixed to the blade of Laertes's sword, the device is Robert Lepage's contribution to the art of weird video pioneered by David Letterman. It's also one of the means by which Mr. Lepage, the thoroughly original Canadian director and visual stylist, provides a Shakespearean tragedy from all sorts of odd angles in ''Elsinore,'' his technologically impressive if scrambled and impassive rendition of ''Hamlet.''

title: INSIDE METRO
description: ECONOMIC PLAN -- Ruth W. Messinger outlined an economic development strategy that would direct tax breaks and other city assistance to small businesses. B3.

title: Top Sergeant In Army Faces Military Trial
description: The Army announced today that it would court-martial its highest-ranking enlisted soldier, Gene C. McKinney, the Sergeant Major of the Army, on accusations by six female soldiers of sexual misconduct.

title: Airlines to Begin Inspections of Fuel Tanks
description: Airlines around the world will begin inspecting their planes' fuel tanks for conditions that could cause an explosion like the one that destroyed Trans World Airlines Flight 800, the airlines and plane manufacturers announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDOW, MARK H.
description: LANDOW-Mark H. On Sunday, September 28, 1997. Of New York, N.Y. Died at New York University Medical Center. He was the son of Rebecca and Leo Landow of Detroit, Michigan and Bronx, N.Y. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 18 at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64 St, New York, N.Y. beginning at 1 PM. Memorial contributions may be made th the City College of New York Scholarship Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMBLE, THOMAS O. III
description: GAMBLE-Thomas O. III. The Bronx Zoo Design Dept. expresses deepest sorrow on Tom's tragic death. Tom enriched our lives with his creativity, spirit, and love of animals. His award-winning work lives on in the Zoo's exhibits. Heartfelt sympathies to his family, son Giacomo, and all who loved him. We miss Tom.

title: Specialty clothing retailers this fall want to let shoppers know that they, too, are a brand.
description: FOR the last few years, department stores have stolen the limelight from specialty clothing retailers, luring shoppers with designer names and constant sales.

title: Europeans Reject U.S. Plan On Electronic Cryptography
description: The European Commission has rejected proposals by the United States aimed at insuring that police agencies can crack coded messages over telephone and computer networks.

title: THE NEW GETTY: Museum Trip (Park and Ride)
description: It floats!

title: Warsaw Journal; Infidelity, Wife-Beating and Greed: Must-See TV
description: Should Pawel, a talented surgeon at a public hospital, switch jobs and make money doing plastic surgery at a private clinic?

title: Excerpts From Fed Chief's Statement
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, omitted large portions of his prepared text in his oral testimony yesterday before the House Banking Committee in Washington. He chiefly spoke on long-term budget issues like Social Security and Medicare. But the financial markets reacted to the prepared remarks, which were released yesterday morning. Following are excerpts from his prepared testimony:

title: Campaign Status Quo?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The About New York column on Saturday, about a man running for Manhattan borough president as the candidate of the Marijuana-Green Party, misstated the number of arrests for marijuana sales in New York City in 1996. According to state statistics, the correct figure is 7,261, not 3,765.

title: Ickes, Under Questioning, Gives Committee No Quarter
description: At times combative, at times whimsical, Harold M. Ickes today parried every thrust and swipe from Republican senators investigating campaign finance practices, never giving an inch or wavering in his loyalty to President Clinton.

title: Glavine Pitches A Gem
description: Just when the Atlanta Braves appear to lack enough relief pitching or defense or motivation, one of their pitchers spins a three-hitter and reminds us all why they are the decade's best team. They're too good to play as badly as they did Tuesday for too long.

title: Foreign Affairs ; Disquiet on Israel
description: An American-Israeli educational institution recently invited me to deliver a lecture at its upcoming gala dinner. But the lecture offer came with an unusual condition: It said my speech on Arab-Israeli affairs had to end on an uplifting note. There was a time when people didn't worry about that; now it has to be written into the contract. I declined.

title: INVENTOR AT WORK: Roll Over, Buckminster Fuller: Is It a Geodesic Sphere?
description: It grows! It shrinks!

title: Promise Keepers Show Anti-Equality Colors; Where Are Feminists?
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Eye
description: IN the early 18th century, Peter the Great amassed a collection of preserved anatomical parts for his chamber of curiosities that would shock a modern viewer -- including infant heads in lacy bonnets that so touched the Romanov monarch he bestowed on one a gentle kiss.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Greenspan Jars Markets With Warning on Inflation

title: Hutu Rebels Attack Town In Rwanda, Army Says
description: More than 1,000 Hutu guerrillas attacked the border town of Gisenyi in western Rwanda today, battling Government forces for seven hours before retreating, Rwandan military officials and aid workers said.

title: WARM HELLO: The Buzz At the Door
description: It rings!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOSS, GUSSIE
description: FOSS-Gussie, on October 7, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Adored mother of Daniel. Cherished grandmother of Emily.

title: Dana to Build Plant in China
description: The Dana Corporation, a maker of auto parts, said yesterday that it would build an axle factory in China's Fujian province, part of the company's efforts to offer customers in the Asia-Pacific region better support.

title: Blue Jays and Randolph Discuss Manager's Job
description: Willie Randolph, the Yankees' third-base coach for the last four seasons, is among 12 candidates who will be interviewed for the managing vacancy in Toronto.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, THOMAS J.
description: SMITH-Thomas J., 88. On October 3, 1997. Of Laguna Hills, California. Formerly of Oradell, N.J. Director and former President of Farrell Lines, Inc. Survived by daughters Ruth Anne Smith of Costa Mesa, California, and Mary Ellen Opel of Monrovia, California, son Thomas J. Smith, Jr., of Manasquan, New Jersey and three grandchildren. Services were held October 7.

title: Metro Business; Developers Erecting Speculative Building
description: SJP Properties and Prudential Real Estate Investors have broken ground for a 340,000-square-foot office building in the Morris Corporate Center in Parsippany, N.J., about one mile west of the intersection of Interstates 80 and 287.

title: DuPont to Build Plant
description: A unit of the DuPont Company said yesterday that it planned to build a 65,000-square-foot production facility in Gresham, Ore., by the end of 1998. DuPont Photomasks makes photomasks, which are quartz plates used in manufacturing semiconductor wafers. The unit said it would invest $75 million in the plant in the next four years and expected to employ about 200 workers when the plant reached full production.

title: Allow Alternative Medicine to Prove Itself
description: To the Editor:

title: Coffee Prices Rise as a Storm Threatens Mexico's Harvest
description: Coffee futures prices rose yesterday on speculation that a hurricane approaching the Pacific coast of Mexico could cause damage and shipping delays of the country's crop at a time of low inventories and strong demand.

title: For Now, the Giants' Job Is Kanell's to Lose
description: Danny Kanell ran the Giants' first-string offense. Dave Brown watched from the sideline. It was a scene from today's Giants practice. It could be a scene from any Giants practice or game for the rest of this year, or for years to come.

title: U.S. Seeks New Power to Regulate Meat Safety
description: The Clinton Administration began its formal push on Capitol Hill today for broad powers to enable the Department of Agriculture to order the mandatory recall of contaminated meats and poultry and, for the first time, levy civil fines against violators.

title: A Disappearing Garden
description: To the Editor:

title: An Engine Of Sound, Operating Full Power
description: It takes a big alarm clock to rouse a major institution from its summer sleep, so with a new and busy season in front of it, Carnegie Hall set the visiting Chicago Symphony to go off at 7 P.M. on Monday. No snooze button here. On consecutive evenings, the Chicago under Daniel Barenboim hammered audiences to an upright and alert position. Aficionados may debate which is the best American orchestra, but as to the loudest there is little argument.

title: LOUNGE CULTURE: A Chair's Good Vibrations
description: It sings! It purrs!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGATE, ANITA KAUFMAN
description: AGATE-Anita Kaufman, on October 8, 1997. Peacefully at home. Beloved wife of the late Sanford S. Agate. Adored mother of Constance Austin. Loving grandmother of Anita Dann Friedman and Caroline Dann. Adored greatgrandmother of Adam and Jonathan Friedman. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st, Friday at 10AM. Kindly omit flowers.

title: House Panel Backs Wide Powers for President in Trade Deals
description: The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to give President Clinton broad authority to negotiate global trade agreements, but the Administration won the support of only a handful of the panel's Democrats despite a late flurry of lobbying.

title: After The Torch Has Passed
description: JED JOHNSON had a way of speaking volumes with his silences. Famously retiring (like his mentor, Andy Warhol), the New York interior designer could win over prospective clients -- Mick and Bianca Jagger, Yves Saint Laurent, Richard Gere -- without saying much of anything. His mystique owed as much to his shyness as to his intuitive feel for good taste.

title: Metro Business; Kodak Cutting Managers
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said on Tuesday that it had notified 200 managers in recent days that they are to be be dismissed as part of the company's effort to cut costs, stem market share losses and increase profit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERBACH, RABBANIT RECHA
description: AUERBACH - Rabbanit Recha. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved sister of Manfred H. Meyer. Mr. Meyer is a YU Guardian who endowed the Eva and Manfred Meyer Course in Modern Jewish Problems at our Stern College for Women. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Burton P. Resnick Chairman, Executive Committee Board of Trustees

title: Frank Davis Ashburn, 94, School Headmaster
description: Frank Davis Ashburn, a lionized Yale graduate who gave up a chance for sure-fire success in business or the law to devote his life to giving other boys the same advantages he had had as a boarding student at Groton, died last Thursday at a nursing home in Westwood, Mass. He was 94 and had spent 46 years as the founding headmaster of the Brooks School in North Andover, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, MARION M.
description: RYAN-Marion M. Of Bronxville, N.Y., October 7, 1997. Dear sister of Eileen M. and Anne P. Ryan. Served for over forty years at Newtown High School in Elmhurst, Queens in the varied roles of teacher, teacher counselor, dean, cooperative course administrator and assistant principal in charge of guidance. When she retired in October 1980 she left behind a strong guidance department as her legacy. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville 2-4 and 7-9 PM Thursday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Friday, October 10 at 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in her name to the Maryknoll Fathers or Maryknoll Sisters, Ossining, New York 10545.

title: GGT Group to Merge Its London Agencies
description: GGT Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it would merge its two London-based agencies, GGT Advertising and BST-BDDP, to form BDDP GGT, a shop that would be ranked among the 15 largest in Britain. The merger is the most recent in a series of changes at GGT after the acquisition of BDDP Worldwide, which was completed in April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, ROBERT
description: FELDMAN - Robert. Women's American ORT, American ORT and the World ORT Union note with deep sorrow the passing of the beloved husband of our distinguished leader, Reese Feldman. A dedicated supporter of the Jewish community, he was a devoted husband, father and grandfather who took great pride in his wife's work and commitment on behalf of the worldwide ORT program. In a lifetime of service to ORT, Reese Feldman served as National President of Women's American ORT from 1987 to 1991, is an officer of American ORT and chairs the Administrative Committee of the World ORT Union. We extend heartfelt sympathy to the Feldman children, Larry and Kathy Feldman, Bill and Ava Feldman and Renay and Paul Becker, and to the grandchildren. Ruth S. Taffel, Nat'l President, Women's American ORT Pepi Dunay, First Vice President Rosina K. Abramson, Esq., Nat'l Executive Director/CEO Paul Borman, President, American ORT Brian J. Strum, Exec. V.P. Justice Richard Goldstone, President, World ORT Union Dr. Ellen Isler, Dir. General

title: The Street Gang Threat
description: Street gangs have not been as prominent or destructive in New York City as they have in Los Angeles or Chicago. But a series of what appear to be gang-related incidents has now prompted Mayor Rudolph Giuliani to ask the police to take new and sterner measures against gangs. His announcement followed a report by the Special Commissioner of Investigations, Edward F. Stancik, warning that gangs could become increasingly fashionable among teen-agers in poor neighborhoods. Mr. Giuliani clearly wishes to be seen as moving aggressively on this issue four weeks before the mayoral election. Even so, his initiative and Mr. Stancik's warning are sensible steps to prevent an incipient problem from becoming an epidemic.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It has been 30 years since ''In the Heat of the Night,'' the searing film about a bigoted Mississippi sheriff and a black Philadelphia police detective who work to solve a murder in a Southern town, riveted movie audiences and won five Academy Awards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, ARTHUR E.
description: SMITH-Arthur E. As Greg Dawson once wrote: ''I am not one but half of two. Only divisible by you.'' We had hoped we would not see the day the other went first. Dear Arthur, I lost. Andrew

title: FRITO-LAY TO BUY CRACKER JACK LINE FROM BORDEN
description: The Frito-Lay unit of Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Cracker Jack snack line from the Borden Foods unit of Borden Inc. Terms of the purchase were not disclosed. Cracker Jack, a candy-coated mix of popcorn and peanuts, is a 104-year-old brand best known for the song ''Take Me Out to the Ball Game,'' which refers to the snack, and for the toy in each box. Cracker Jack had $60 million in sales last year, said Lynn Markley, a spokeswoman for Frito-Lay. Analysts expect Frito-Lay to use its existing factories and delivery trucks to make and distribute Cracker Jack. Shares of Pepsico rose 50 cents, to $39.25.

title: INSIDE
description: Changes in North Korea

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARTENSTEIN, MORRIS
description: GARTENSTEIN-Morris. At 86 years. Beloved husband of Mollie; devoted father of Gail and Victor and the late Robert; cherished grandfather of Lauren and Steven, David and Anna and Ilene; loving great grandfather of Jessica. Services were held Wednesday, October 8, 1997.

title: Reporter for Russian TV Freed By Belarus, Easing Tensions
description: Belarus has freed a reporter for a Russian television network in a case that has gravely strained the Slavic ties between the two states.

title: REGENCY HEALTH SELLS 24 NURSING HOMES AND 2 HOSPITALS
description: Omega Healthcare Investors Inc. said yesterday that it had bought 24 nursing homes and two rehabilitation hospitals from Regency Health Services Inc. for $86 million as the real estate investment trust expanded its holdings of health care operations. The properties are in California, Ohio, West Virginia and North Carolina. Omega, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., said it had leased the operations to Sun Healthcare Group Inc., which completed its $369 million acquisition of Regency yesterday, for $8.3 million a year for 14 years. Sun Healthcare is a long-term-care and pharmacy services business based in Albuquerque, N.M. Omega shares rose 75 cents, to $37.75.

title: Earle Palmer Brown Buys Agency Stake
description: Earle Palmer Brown has acquired an equity stake in Yesawich, Pepperdine & Moss, a New York shop that has been renamed Yesawich, Moss & Brown. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Housing Project Demolition
description: A tenants group plans to sue this month to block the Paterson Housing Authority's plans to demolish their high-rise public housing projects and replace them with single- or two-family townhouses, a lawyer for the group said yesterday.

title: New York Grind
description: ''LOOK, I'll be honest with you,'' Albertina Fiumano was saying one evening recently, standing in her 25th-floor apartment in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, gazing at the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. ''I'm 100 percent American. This is a great country.''

title: G.O.P. Presses for New Property Rights Bills to Aid Landowners
description: Republicans in Congress are pressing ahead with new legislation making it easier for private landowners to challenge in court Federal and local regulations that block development on their property.

title: Close-Order Drill With a Salsa Beat
description: Inside a cozy nightclub with starfish on the walls and silk palm leaves shooting out of chandeliers, the crowd on the dance floor on a recent Friday night suddenly parted to make room for the rueda, a circle of couples. Beginning their dance to the one-two-three salsa beat but hardly looking at each other, the couples instead fixed their attention on one of the men, their leader. With a barked command or abrupt hand signal, he made them step and spin and exchange partners in unison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, GERTRUDE B.
description: HOPKINS-Gertrude B., died of heart failure October 7 at St. Vincent's. She was an actress who starred on Broadway in the play ''Janie'', and who played ''Mary'' in ''Life With Father'' among many other roles in the 1940s.

title: Undercover Policeman Is Shot During Buy-and-Bust Operation
description: A police officer conducting an undercover narcotics operation was shot and slightly wounded in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, the police said. The officer was treated at Kings County Hospital and released last night.

title: Yevgeny Khaldei, 80, War Photographer, Dies
description: Yevgeny Khaldei, the photographer whose pictures of Soviet soldiers hoisting the red flag over the Reichstag in Berlin are among the best known images of World War II, died on Monday night in Moscow. He was 80.

title: Travel Agencies Consider Charging Fees
description: Brace yourself for the fade-out of another nicety. The days when you could wander into a corner travel agency and have that Caribbean cruise or Roman holiday booked for free may be drawing to an end.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMOCO CORP., Chicago, Ill., the petroleum and chemical company, said it had formed a cooperative buying group that will help its service stations acquire convenience store goods at lower prices.

title: Company Plans Big Sale Of Land in Adirondacks
description: For a century, some of the finest white-water canoeing and trout-fishing rivers in the state have been off limits to the public because they coursed through Adirondack hardwood forests owned by a succession of timber companies, most recently Champion International Corporation.

title: Bridge; Doubling Into a Game Raises the Tension
description: Tension at the bridge table reaches a maximum when the contract is a doubled part-score that will produce a game if successful. In a pair competition, it is likely that the side with a plus will have a top score, particularly if the declarer is vulnerable.

title: The Great Umbrella Debate
description: The news media have had a good chuckle over the ''umbrella debate'' that has got the generals of the Army and the Marines in such an uproar.

title: AIDS Research in Africa: Juggling Risks and Hopes
description: Cecile Guede, a 23-year-old H.I.V.-infected mother and patient in an American-financed AIDS treatment experiment here, doesn't yet know if the disease has spared her year-old son.

title: Thomson-CSF Posts Profit Rise of 39%
description: Thomson-CSF S.A., Europe's biggest military electronics equipment maker, said yesterday that first-half profit rose 39 percent as taxes fell and it expanded abroad to offset contraction in its home market. Thomson-CSF's operating profit fell to 903 million francs ($153 million), or 5.5 percent of sales, from 940 million francs ($159 million), or 5.7 percent of sales. The company said its operating margin -- operating profit as a percentage of sales -- was likely to remain at 5.5 percent for the year as a whole.

title: Woman Denies She Abused Adopted Children on Plane
description: The Arizona woman who is accused of abusing her two newly adopted Russian children on the May 28 flight from Moscow to New York testified yesterday that she did slap one of the girls, once, out of anger, frustration and embarrassment. But she said she was disciplining the child, not abusing her.

title: Mattel's Chief Adds Title of Chairwoman
description: Mattel Inc. said today that it had named its president and chief executive, Jill E. Barad, as chairwoman.

title: Turf; Cashing In and Moving On, Tax-Free
description: YELLOW Post-it notes are stuck to the walls of Lawrence Tan's bedroom overlooking East 57th Street, each emblazoned with a different goal: ''The Movie.'' ''The Course.'' ''The Flier.'' Anything, it seems, is possible for Mr. Tan, a meditation and martial arts master, who has now decided to sell his two-bedroom co-op.

title: Autumn Colors In Piscataway
description: The football season of horrors continues for Rutgers tonight when the Scarlet Knights (0-5) face Syracuse (3-3), one of the better Big East teams, at Rutgers Stadium in Piscataway, N.J. The game will be televised by ESPN at 8 P.M.

title: Sports of The Times; Big Guns Take Over For a Night
description: STRANGE things can happen in the post-season. We were all reminded of this a year ago when a 12-year-old boy from New Jersey reached out and touched the ball, turning a long fly into a Yankee home run and setting the tone for a five-game Yankee romp.

title: Southern Town Stunned by Arrests in Murder Plot
description: Clearly the seven students were friends. Perhaps they even qualified as a clique, with at least some of them sharing an unusual interest in Nietzsche and Latin. Now the police in this suburb east of Jackson have said that the students were also co-conspirators in a plot to kill fellow students at Pearl High School.

title: Design Notebook; Where the Ram's Horn Sounded in the Land of the Sultans
description: THE seductive, slender minarets of monumental mosques may be the ubiquitous symbols of Ottoman Turkey. But they tell only part of the story of that sprawling and complex empire. Jews were a substantial and influential piece of the Ottoman mosaic, especially those driven out of Spain in 1492. A long line of Sultans invited them in, and they prospered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RING, ROSE (NEE LEDDY)
description: RING-Rose (nee Leddy), on October 7, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Thomas F. (FBI). Devoted sister of Anne O'Brien and sisterin-law of James O'Brien. Dear aunt of Maureen Sears, Joseph and James O'Brien. Great-aunt of seven. Friends may call at The Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20th Street), NYC. Thursday and Friday, 2-5 & 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Epiphany RC Church, Saturday 9:45AM. Interment Saint Charles Cemetery. In lieu of flowers contributions to: Former Agents of FBI Foundation, POB 1027, Quantico, Virginia 22134-1027.

title: Arts Abroad; The Poetic Spirit Unbowed Despite Fear and Danger
description: In the central square of this stately capital, facing an 800-year-old fortress that overlooks the Caspian Sea, a pantheon of six larger-than-life statues towers above the bustle of daily life.

title: Hinge of the Seasons
description: Autumn is in the air -- somewhere, if not yet on the streets of New York. At 7:30 A.M. young men rush across midtown holding their suit jackets on fingers crooked in front of them, just as they did all summer. They try in vain to walk within the creases of their carefully pressed shirts and pants, hoping to catch a breeze. A soot-stained cloud, some vestige of a summer thundershower in a Winslow Homer watercolor, darkens the north end of the crevasse that is Madison Avenue, and the short-sleeved doorman at a midtown hotel leans heavily on one arm against a pillar, head bowed, sound asleep. The only real sign of fall marks the trees in front of the New York Public Library, which have begun to turn copper-yellow. But even that seems illusory, artificial, as though somewhere deep in the bowels of the library a workman had accidentally brushed against the rheostat that controls the tint of the leaves outside.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCFARLIN, SARAH
description: McFARLIN-Sarah. The Board of Directors and staff of the League Treatment Center mourn the passing of Sarah McFarlin. We send our deepest sympathies to Guy and the McFarlin family.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World News Briefs; U.N. to Impose Sanctions Over Sierra Leone Coup
description: Frustrated by a lack of progress in dislodging the troops who deposed the elected President of Sierra Leone in May, the Security Council voted unanimously today to impose sanctions on the West African country, prohibiting the import of oil products and military equipment.

title: Anderson Staggers the Indians With a 1-2 Punch
description: Talk about setting a tone for a series.

title: Supremacist Is Convicted On 4 Counts
description: Peter Langan, the leader of a white supremacist gang that the authorities say robbed 22 banks to finance the overthrow of the Federal Government, has been convicted of four charges related to assault and weapons.

title: Georgian Diplomat Pleads Guilty in Death of Teen-Age Girl
description: An embassy official from the Republic of Georgia pleaded guilty today to charges of involuntary manslaughter and aggravated assault for driving while intoxicated and causing the death of a teen-age girl and injuring four other people in an accident in January.

title: Income Gap Widens
description: The gap between New Jersey's well-to-do and lower-income residents widened during the first half of the decade, according to a Rutgers University study released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KONKOY, WILLIAM J.
description: KONKOY-William J. Forever in my heart.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Late-Blooming Cosmos

title: Netscape's License Deal With Pentagon
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation said today that it planned to license its software to the Defense Department, landing its largest-ever Government contract as it seeks customers among corporations and big institutions.

title: MCDONALD'S PLANS TO INVEST $1 BILLION IN LATIN AMERICA
description: The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that it would invest more than $1 billion in the next three years to double its restaurants in Latin America. The fast-food company, based in Oak Brook, Ill., is stepping up its efforts abroad to offset its stagnant business in the United States. Latin America contributed $1.27 billion to the company's total sales of $31.8 billion in 1996. Sales in the region are expected to reach $1.5 billion this year. Sales outside the United States last year accounted for 49 percent, or $15.4 billion, of McDonald's total sales and are growing faster than United States sales. International sales rose 10 percent last year, while sales in the United States grew by just 2.9 percent.

title: Gas Find to Help 3 Giant Companies
