description: The Exxon Corporation., the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Norsk Hydro A.S.A. will benefit from the discovery of a field in Norwegian waters that could contain as much natural gas as Continental Europe used last year.

title: Orioles Get A Quick Jump By Blanking The Indians
description: From Peter Angelos to Davey Johnson to many players to the bat boys, the Orioles were obsessed with playing the Yankees in the American League Championship Series. They sounded forlorn that the Indians, not the Yankees, showed up as their opponents at Camden Yards tonight. The Orioles got over their obsession quickly and simply mugged the Indians in the same manner that they had dreamed of mugging the Yankees.

title: ACHILLE CASTIGLIONI: Furniture for Art's Sake: Tribute to a Master
description: He rules!

title: Revival of '1776' Unlikely To Reach Broadway
description: Efforts to transfer the critically praised revival of ''1776'' from the nonprofit Roundabout Theater to a larger, commercial theater on Broadway have all but fallen through.

title: 60's Payola Is His First Taste of America
description: It wasn't that long ago that the notion of Kevin Bacon, the clean-cut, all-American star of ''Footloose,'' portraying a sleazy early-60's Cleveland disk jockey, would have seemed utterly incongruous. But this gifted young character actor with his chiseled, vulpine features and sneaky, too-easy grin has proved himself a master impersonator of smoothies and shifty-eyed hustlers. In ''Telling Lies in America,'' Mr. Bacon's role as Billy Magic, a hepcat Top 40 disk jockey eluding payola investigators as he bounces from city to city, is one of the juciest of his career. When Billy isn't snapping his fingers and jive-talking in a hybrid lingo of Wolfman Jack and Alan Freed inside the cramped studios of radio station WHK, he is gliding around Cleveland in a bright red Cadillac convertible, promoting sock hops and smirking like a lowlife cock of the walk.

title: Economic Scene; Loading the trade agenda with divisive issues could backfire.
description: THE politics of free trade used to be simple. Exporters and the international-minded political establishment were for it. Unions and industries vulnerable to imports were against it.

title: No-Shows Miss Taste of Last Banner Year
description: The Devils amassed the most points in the Eastern Conference last season, and the Flyers represented the conference in the Stanley Cup finals. But when they met tonight for the first time this season in New Jersey's home opener, a crowd of 16,432 was on hand at Continental Arena, which holds 19,040 for hockey.

title: RENEX RAISES $24 MILLION IN INITIAL OFFERING OF STOCK
description: The Renex Corporation said yesterday that it had sold three million shares for $24 million, or $8 each, in an initial public offering. Renex, based in Coral Gables, Fla., provides dialysis and other services to patients with chronic kidney failure. The company will use $21.8 million in proceeds from the offering to repay debt and make acquisitions. Renex shares closed at $8.25 in their first day of trading.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATIS, DR. JACOB D.
description: MATIS-Dr. Jacob D. died October 6, 1997 at his home in West Palm Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Rosalie. Devoted and adored father of George Matis and Nancy Dreyfuss. Loving grandfather of Jessica Matis and Leah Dreyfuss. Beloved brother of Edith Helsel. Services Thursday 12 pm at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Roosevelt Hospital.

title: Money for Estuaries
description: Three New Jersey lawmakers introduced a bill in Congress yesterday that would pay for conservation plans for 28 estuaries in the United States, including the New York-New Jersey Harbor, Barnegat Bay and the Delaware Estuary.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a lawsuit by Sun Microsystems Inc. against the Microsoft Corporation misstated the purpose of an injunction sought by Sun. It would ask that Microsoft be enjoined from labeling its Internet Explorer 4.0 browser program Java-compatible; it is not seeking to stop Microsoft from shipping the program.

title: Vichy Figure Goes on Trial in Deportation of Jews
description: Maurice Papon, the highest-ranking official of occupied France to face charges of complicity in German crimes against humanity, went on trial today behind a bulletproof plastic shield in a courtroom crowded with lawyers and relatives of some of the 1,560 Jews he is accused of having sent on their way to Auschwitz.

title: Surprising Sequel in the Mideast
description: No one expected the botched Israeli assassination attempt against a Hamas leader in Jordan to help revitalize peace talks with the Palestinians. But that seems to have happened. Yesterday Israel's Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, held their first face-to-face meeting in eight months.

title: Arthur Smith, 56, Who Designed Tailored Yet Relaxed Interiors
description: Arthur E. Smith, an interior designer known for his comfortable yet tailored interiors, died on Friday at New York Hospital. He was 56 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Real 'Ugly American'
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about the involvement of some municipalities in the communications business misspelled the name of a spokesman for one such company, Tacoma City Light. He is Korte Brueckmann, not Court Brickman.

title: Court Weighs Weeding Out Of Candidate in TV Debate
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether a government-owned television station that sponsors debates among candidates violates the Constitution if it makes the editorial judgment that a fringe candidate with little chance of success at the polls should not participate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUNNING, ROSEMARY
description: GUNNING-Rosemary. As an Assemblywoman she was a role model for Women in Politics. As a community leader she was without peer, as a friend she was an inspiration. In sympathy. Catherine Nolan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROME, FLORENCE
description: ROME-Florence, 87, at her home in Manhattan on October 6, 1997. Wife of the late Harold Rome. Mother of Joshua and Rachel. Grandmother of Shoshanna and Leah. Memorial service at 11 A.M. Wednesday, Oct. 15, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81st Street).

title: Casino Plan Moves Forward
description: The City Council yesterday paved the way for MGM Grand Inc. to build a $700 million, 2,000-room casino hotel by unanimously approving the company as the developer of up to 30 acres of land.

title: Gunpei Yokoi, Chief Designer Of Game Boy, Is Dead at 56
description: Gunpei Yokoi, a brilliant tinkerer who designed the Game Boy and other products that helped transform Nintendo from a sleepy manufacturer of playing cards into a worldwide colossus in video games, was killed in a traffic accident in Japan on Saturday, the company said.

title: Incubators of Creativity; Can Japan Inc. Put Corporate Individualism to Work?
description: This is Japan, traditionally the land of consensus and conformity, of finely calibrated bows and maxims like ''The nail that sticks up gets hammered down.'' So what on earth is Toru Uchida up to?

title: S.E.C. Chief Defends Accounting Board
description: On the eve of a Congressional hearing on a proposed accounting rule that has drawn fierce criticism, Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, sharply attacked Congress and the banking industry for intervening in the independent process by which such rules are written.

title: Glavine Provides Calm in a Storm
description: Perhaps it is time to stop trying to create a must-win game that would rattle Tom Glavine. Post-season games certainly don't do it. Witness Glavine's patently efficient stopping action in the National League Championship Series yesterday.

title: Excerpts From Testimony by Ickes on Fund-Raising by the Democrats
description: Following are excerpts from testimony today by Harold M. Ickes, a former White House deputy chief of staff, at a hearing of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee on 1996 campaign finance practices, as transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription company. Questions were from Senators Richard J. Durbin of Illinois and Don Nickles of Oklahoma, who referred to R. Warren Meddoff, a Florida businessman who has testified that Mr. Ickes asked him for a $1.5 million campaign donation.

title: In Her Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLD, MARY JAYNE
description: GOLD-Mary Jayne. The International Rescue Committee mourns the passing of Mary Jayne Gold. In the dark days of 1941-42, she was a genuine heroine who saved many of Europe's leading artists and intellectuals trapped in Marseilles and seemingly destined for Hitler's extermination camps. Her courage, compassion and generosity were critical in their rescue. We honor her memory and her deeds. She was a living example of how one person can truly make a difference. John C. Whitehead, Chairman Leo Cherne, Chairman Emeritus Charles Sternberg, Secretary Reynold Levy, President

title: Promise Keepers Show Anti-Equality Colors; Control vs. Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: City Emerald; Great Lawn Reopens. Will Its Fans Love It to Death?
description: A mix of five varieties of lush bluegrass, Central Park's sweeping new Great Lawn is meant to be a deep green oasis in a concrete city. After a two-year face lift costing $18.2 million, it reopens tomorrow morning.

title: AMERICA ONLINE IN DEAL WITH TRAVEL SERVICE PROVIDER
description: America Online Inc. agreed yesterday to make Preview Travel Inc. its main travel-service provider. Preview will pay America Online $32 million over five years and will provide services that include ticket sales, car rentals and hotel reservations. Users can also customize information and do research. America Online and Preview will share advertising and transaction revenue, though America Online did not disclose how it would be divided. Preview Travel, based in San Francisco, said yesterday that it planned to sell 2.5 million common shares in an initial public offering, raising as much as $24.7 million. America Online, based in Dulles, Va., is the company's largest shareholder and will retain a 11.9 percent stake after the offering. America Online shares rose $3.375, to $83.

title: Stun Gun Attack Reported
description: A 15-year-old student was arrested yesterday and charged with firing a stun gun at three students at Springfield Gardens High School in Queens, the police and school officials said.

title: Longo Renounces Retirement Plans
description: Responding to a clamor that is audible only to her, Jeannie Longo renounced her latest retirement. She owed it to her fans, the French public, to continue.

title: Europeans and Alcohol
description: To the Editor:

title: A Magnifying Glass Could Be Redundant
description: The dire news is that the latest recruit into the ''Mystery'' pantheon of sleuths is a 60-year-old woman with a funny name, a fussy husband and a plucky 17-year-old male pal who accompanies her into ill-lit houses. Going through the motions as Detective Hetty Wainthropp is Patricia Routledge, a veteran British player, especially popular in the old country as the star of ''Keeping Up Appearances,'' a comedy series that is also seen on some PBS stations (WLIW in this neighborhood).

title: No Room in the Grill: Woman Cites Inequality
description: Female golfers at private country clubs often find themselves subject to forms of discrimination unparalleled in almost any other part of their lives. Some accept their lot; tradition, they say, is the price to pay for privilege.

title: Star of 'Ellen' Threatens To Quit Over Advisory
description: Ellen DeGeneres threatened to walk away from her ABC comedy ''Ellen'' yesterday after learning that the network has decided to add an on-screen advisory declaring that the show has adult content and warning parents to use discretion in allowing children to view it.

title: Stores Specializing in Aching Spines
description: New Yorkers have an amazing knack of creating their own problems, then setting up cottage industries to solve them.

title: Look at Lake Powell As Creative Monument
description: To the Editor:

title: In His Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: At Breakfast With Anita Hill; Dealing With Unanswered Questions
description: There are images of Anita Hill that have been burned into the country's collective memory. That royal blue suit. Those large, brimming eyes. The halting voice that seemed always on the verge of breaking.

title: Clinton Goes to New Jersey To Spotlight McGreevey
description: He was not invited to ride in the Presidential limousine, but State Senator James E. McGreevey had little else to complain about today.

title: Y'Alternative Hollywood
description: WHILE dining at the Russian Tea Room during a business trip 10 years ago, I looked around and discovered the Fox Commissary. Wherever I turned I saw a writer I was pursuing, agents whose calls I'd missed, a competitive producer (usually Scott Rudin). In one horrible moment New York had morphed into Los Angeles. At dinner at Elaine's, I was still in Hollywood, with the same polenta. Hollywood had ceased to be a place; it had transmogrified into a beast. No armor could be dropped.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINGAST, IRENE
description: WEINGAST-Irene. Beloved wife of the late Abraham Becker and the late Al Weingast. Dearest mother and mother-in-law of Laurie and Fred Iskowitz, Paul and Cathy Becker. Devoted grandmother of Allison and Aaron Krueger and Aaron and Ross Iskowitz. Beloved sister and sister-in-law of Sandy and Paul Winston and Ethel Small. ''A lady truly loved by all.'' Memorial donations may be made to one's own favorite charity.

title: Sweet Science At the Apollo
description: When boxing historians look back they will find that the first professional card at the Apollo Theater in Harlem was headlined by a pair of heavyweights named Lou Savarese of the Bronx and David Izon of Nigeria.

title: Mets Ponder Olerud
description: The Mets will decide in the coming weeks whether to re-sign first baseman John Olerud, who hit 22 homers and drove in 102 runs this season, his first with the team after being obtained from Toronto in a trade. General Manager Steve Phillips plans to call Olerud's agent by today to explore the player's preferences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ELEANOR (NEE VOLK)
description: GOLDMAN-Eleanor (nee Volk), 59, died in Florida October 8, 1997. Wife and companion of Howard Goldman, daughter of Anne and Irving Volk. Mother of David Ritter. Adam (Sharon) Ritter. Elizabeth (James) Crickey. Michelle Goldman and Adam (Jean) Goldman. Grandmother of Ryan Ritter and Rebecca Ritter. You left us much too soon and we will miss you. We love you, Ellie. Graveside services at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island, 10 A.M., Sunday, October 12th. Memorial gifts to charity of your choice.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SHELBY COFFEY 3d, the editor at The Los Angeles Times for nearly nine years, is said to be on the verge of leaving that job, according to numerous people at the newspaper.

title: Greenspan's Comments Push Dollar Lower Against Mark
description: The dollar fell against the mark yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, roiled financial markets and a report raised concern that the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, might soon raise interest rates.

title: Calendar; Equestrian Farms and Folk Artwork
description: Country Farms

title: Canada to Preserve Vast Pristine Area in West
description: More than 2.5 million acres of nearly untouched wilderness in the Rocky Mountains of British Columbia -- an area larger than Yellowstone National Park -- is to be protected from all development under an agreement announced today between the provincial government, oil and mining companies, environmentalists and Indian groups.

title: Gretzky's Poignant Trip
description: The red and white flag of the maple leaf flapped in the early-autumn snow flurries and the brisk morning breeze. This was hockey weather in the western Canadian city where Wayne Gretzky was a National Hockey League rookie almost two decades ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIMAN, BARBARA
description: KLEIMAN-Barbara. On October 7, 1997. Beloved daughter of Bella Kleiman and the late Murray Kleiman. Sister of Michael and Mark Kleiman and Isabel Byron. Aunt of Molly Kleiman. Cherished of Stan Diglio. Assistant Commissioner, NYC Dept of Homeless Services. Passionate advocate for services to the poor. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St, Mount Vernon, N.Y. Thursday, October 9th, 10AM. Contributions in her name may be made to local services for the homeless.

title: Pataki Promotes an Aide to a Top Advisory Role
description: Gov. George E. Pataki elevated James M. McGuire, the administration's first assistant counsel, to the position of counsel to the Governor today.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We can use fines to protect farmers and ranchers from unfair trading practices. Abuse a circus elephant, sell a cat without a license, market a potato that's too small, keep bad records on watermelons, fail to report to the onion committee -- fine, fine, fine, fine, fine. Yet if you produce unsafe food -- the only one of these items that puts people's lives at stake -- there is no civil penalty.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATHEWSON, VIRGINIA BOSWORTH
description: MATHEWSON - Virginia Bosworth. On October 7, 1997, at the age of 85, in New London, N.H. Widow of W. Glen Mathewson. Mother of William G. Mathewson of Basking Ridge, NJ, and Douglas Mathewson II of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. Grandmother of Hillary M. Moulliet, Bethany M. Conklin, Glenna M. Mathewson and Christina B. Mathewson. Memorial contributions may be made to the William P. Clough Extended Care Center, 270 County Road, New London, NH 03257.

title: Change in Hong Kong Is Slow but Sure
description: One hundred days after China raised its red flag here, ending 156 years of British colonial rule, Hong Kong is feeling a new and uncertain mood.

title: Promise Keepers Show Anti-Equality Colors; Self-Directed Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Similarity Breeds Respect For 2 Coaches
description: When the Dolphins released place-kicker Joe Nedney over the summer, the Jets quickly picked him up.

title: Three Ties in Three Tries for Rangers
description: The Rangers are still undefeated and still without a victory -- after three games of the season. After taking a 2-0 lead in the first period, they settled for a 3-3 tie with the Edmonton Oilers tonight at Edmonton Coliseum.

title: Martial Arts With Literal Sparks
description: One exciting moment followed another when Dance Brazil performed on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. The New York-based company of Brazilian dancers and musicians is marking its 20th-anniversary season, and a festive spirit prevailed throughout the evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPERLING, MORTIMER
description: SPERLING-Mortimer. On October 7, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Mabelle Sperling. Dear father of Peter (Paula) Sperling, and Andrew (Shelley) Sperling. Adored grandfather of Evan and Rebecca. Services were held on Wednesday, October 8th.

title: U.S. Official Assails China On Trade Gap
description: Commerce Secretary William M. Daley, apparently trying his best to sound angry, today attacked China's growing trade imbalance with the United States.

title: A WELL-ROUNDED SOUND: Big Brother Is Listening (Or, the New Look of Speakers)
description: It woofs!

title: Messinger Vows Help for Small Businesses
description: Declaring that ''we have a job crisis in New York City,'' Ruth W. Messinger outlined an economic development strategy yesterday that would direct tax breaks and other municipal assistance to small businesses, which she said were best positioned to generate jobs and put more city residents to work.

title: Greenspan Cautions on Inflation; Change in Tone a Jolt to Investors
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned today that inflation might be on the horizon, jolting investors who had grown used to the ideal economic conditions of the last year and increasing the chances that the central bank might soon raise interest rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, ARCHIBALD A.
description: PATTERSON-Archibald A. On October 6th, 1997, at the age of 81. A graduate of Hobart College and Harvard Law School, he practiced law in NYC and was a fifty year member of the American Bar Association. He was an accomplished bridge player and member of the University Club. He is survived by his wife, Esther; his sister Janet Feeley; a daughter Marcia; four sons, Bruce, James, Roy and Robert; a stepdaughter Noma; and eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held from 6-8 PM, Thursday, October 9th, at Krtil Funeral Home at 70th and 1st.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LACHMAN, LAWRENCE
description: LACHMAN-Lawrence, 81. Passed away in his sleep on October 7, 1997. He will be sorely missed by his family and friends. Beloved husband of Judith for fifty-two years. Devoted father of Robert and Charles. Grandfather of Elizabeth and Peter, Amy and the late Jill Lachman. Father-in-law of Dianna and Emily. Loving brother of Frances. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St, Wednesday, 6-8PM with service Thursday, 11:30AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to The Jill Lachman Memorial Fund, c/o EVAC, P.O. Box 743, Englewood, NJ 07631, or the charity of your choice.

title: Cause of Student's Death Is Not Yet Discovered
description: The death of the 13-year-old boy who collapsed on Tuesday in a Brooklyn classroom remained a mystery yesterday after an autopsy by the Medical Examiner's office proved inconclusive.

title: Look at Lake Powell As Creative Monument
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday tracing trade between Mexico and Canada misstated its growth since the North American Free Trade Agreement went into effect. The increase was 59 percent, not 43.

title: Connecticut's Police Chiefs Seek Guidelines on Sex-Offender Law
description: Faced with a new law that requires the police to provide information about sex offenders living in their community, police chiefs in Connecticut are seeking immunity from any lawsuits that might result.

title: Exercise, Not Gadgets
description: To the Editor:

title: With Partisan Display, Another Panel Begins Hearings on Campaign Finance
description: Members of the House Government Reform and Oversight Committee waxed more rhetorical than revealing today as they opened their campaign finance hearings, with 43 of its 44 members lining up to speak and argue at length.

title: Knicks Still Seem to Be Obsessed by Bulls
description: It is a fixation. And it cannot be helped. Just know that the Knicks are still one pair of binoculars and an unmarked car short of being totally obsessed with the daily comings and goings of the Chicago Bulls.

title: Our Towns; Candidate, 17, Battles More Than Just Age
description: IT was an afternoon as bright as fall could muster and most young people from the James Geddes Houses had escaped to savor October in the park. Dania Vega, not yet 18, was busy campaigning as a Green Party candidate for a seat in the County Legislature. She traipsed through the barracks-style project like a missionary, clipboard in hand and an answer awaiting every skeptical question.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about possible merger discussions between the AT&T Corporation and the GTE Corporation misstated the sources of the information. It came from executives close to the companies, not with the companies.

title: Albany Is Told to Give $450,000 to Yonkers Public Schools
description: A Federal judge today ordered New York State to give the Yonkers public school system $450,000 as a down payment toward the costs of remedying years of school segregation, which could run as high as $300 million.

title: Largest Fine To Be Paid For Donation
description: A Pennsylvania landfill company agreed today to pay an $8 million fine, the highest penalty ever for a campaign-finance violation, in connection with a scheme to funnel $129,000 in illegal campaign contributions to 10 political candidates, a Federal prosecutor said tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUSKY, HELEN M.
description: TAUSKY-Helen M. On October 6, 1997. Loving cousin of Robert Schmeidler. Graveside services on Thursday, October 9, 1997, 2:00 P.M., at Linden Hills Cemetery, Maspeth, Queens.

title: Ogilvy One Worldwide Wins 6 Echo Awards
description: Ogilvy One Worldwide took top honors, winning six awards, at the 68th annual International Echo Awards competition sponsored by the Direct Marketing Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAPIRO, MURRAY H.
description: SCHAPIRO-Murray H. On October 6, 1997. Beloved son of the late Minnie and David. Brother of the late Miriam and Harold. Uncle of Harold and Flora Bofshever. Grand-uncle of Jon and Miriam and great-granduncle of Scott. Devoted friend and companion of Samuel Altman. Graveside services on Thursday, at 11 A.M., at Mount Hebron Cemetery.

title: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
description: Stocks were lower here this morning. At the midday recess in trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 140.06 points, or eight-tenths of 1 percent, at 17,479.12. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rose 107.99 points.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHEL, CARLTON MARK
description: FISHEL-Carlton Mark, age 88, suddenly on October 6th, 1997. Former Chairman of the Board of Trifari, Krussman & Fishel, Inc. until he retired in 1975. A graduate of Phillips Andover ('26) and Yale ('30), he was a founding member and past President of the Advisory Board of St. Vincent's Hospital, Harrison, New York on which he has served for over 40 years. He was a Knight of Malta and a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre. For many years he served as a member of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, Catholic Charities, the Board of the United Hospital's Fund of New York and was affiliated with numerous other religious associations of the Archdiocese of New York. He was also an active parishioner of Resurrection Church in Rye. He was a past President of the ''24 Karat'' Club of New York (a fine jewelers' association). As a member of the Yale Club of New York City and the Apawamis Club of Rye, he enjoyed golf until the time of his death. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 61 years, Helen M. Fishel, and is survived by two daughters, Penelope F. McDermott of Rye and Kathleen F. McCullough of Chatham, MA, son-inlaw William H. McCullough, 7 grandchildren and 9 adored greatgrandchildren. Visiting hours will be at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York, Thursday, October 9th, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass will be held at 10 AM Friday, October 10th at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye. Interment immediately following at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Vincent's Hospital of Westchester, 275 North Street, Harrison, New York 10528 or United Hospital Medical Center, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, New York 10573.

title: Market Place; Marvel returns to the brink as another reorganization fails.
description: YOU may get a chance to buy Spider-Man.

title: Ban on Method of Late Abortion Passes House Despite Veto Threat
description: The House approved by a wide margin today a ban on a form of late-term abortion that opponents see as violent, unnecessary and a political vulnerability of those who defend abortion rights.

title: Residential Resales
description: Big Deal

title: People
description: * David S. Egan, executive vice president and account management director at Ketchum Advertising Pittsburgh, part of Omnicom Group, was promoted to president, succeeding Jim Ficco, who took a medical leave of absence.

title: Promise Keepers Show Anti-Equality Colors
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIMAN MARCUS TO TEST CHAIN OF JEWELRY AND GIFT STORES
description: The Neiman Marcus Group Inc. said yesterday that it planned to open three stores focusing on precious jewelry, gifts and home accessories as a test toward creating a national chain selling those items. Neiman Marcus, based in Dallas, plans to call the stores the Galleries of Neiman Marcus. The first one will open outside Cleveland. If the stores succeed, Neiman Marcus will take the concept nationwide to capture more of the $25 billion precious-jewelry market, its president, Robert Smith, said in a statement. Shares of Neiman Marcus, a unit of Harcourt General Inc., fell 6.25 cents, to $32.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSCELLI, MAUREEN F. MCKENNA
description: ROSCELLI-Maureen F. McKenna. Of Bloomfield, on Oct. 7, 1997, wife of Richard N. Roscelli, mother of Richard K. Roscelli, sister of Kenneth McKenna, daughter of Ruthye Giorgio and the late Michael McKenna, stepdaughter of Eleanor McKenna and Anthony Giorgio. The funeral mass will be celebrated at Sacred Heart Church, Bloomfield, on Sat., Oct. 11th at 10 AM. Interment Glendale Cemetery. Friends may call at the Van Tassel Chickene Funeral Home, 337 Belleville Ave., Bloomfield, NJ Thursday and Friday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Memorial contributions may be made to the St. John's Church Feeding Program, 22 Mulberry St., Newark, NJ 07102.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEAP, J. NEIL
description: HEAP-J. Neil, 76, of Tuxedo Park, NY, died Tuesday, October 7, 1997, at home. Mr. Heap was the founder of World Yachts, New York, New York. Visiting will be at the home in Tuxedo Park, Thursday from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. Funeral services will be held on Friday Oct. 10, 1997 at 11AM at St. Mary's Episcopal Church, Tuxedo Park, NY. He is survived by one sister, Nell Baumann of England and 4 nephews. Memorial contributions may be made to United Hospice of Rockland, Inc., 18 Thiells-Mt. Ivy Road, Pomona, New York 10970.

title: Insurers' Plan to Sell Stock Riles Consumer Advocates
description: Some of the biggest insurance companies in the country squared off against Ralph Nader and a contingent of lesser-known consumer advocates yesterday in a committee hearing of the New York State Assembly on the structure of insurance companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUBLICK, JUDITH S.
description: BUBLICK-Judith S. Peacefully, on Oct 5, 1997. Cherished partner and wife of the late David Bublick, dear mother of Linda, Aaron; truly magical, deeply beloved grandmother of David and Peter. Writer for old-time radio, poet, painter, world traveler; her enthusiasm never waned. Her wit and humor, her unfailing generosity, and her blithe spirit will be forever missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELDIN, JULIAN
description: SELDIN-Julian. Monday, October 6, 1997. Julian of Davis, CA., formerly of Queens, N.Y. & Durham, N.C. Beloved husband of the late Helen Seldin, Devoted father of Dr. Harriett & Dr. Michael Seldin. Dear brother of Elliot Seldin & Edith Gordon, Loving grandfather of Stephen and Helen. Graveside service at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ, Friday, October 10, 1997, 10:00 A.M. Info: Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, New Jersey.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKER, SHIRLEY
description: ZUCKER-Shirley. The law firm of Hawkins, Delafield & Wood extends its deepest sorrow to our partner, Howard Zucker, and family on the loss of his beloved mother.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; A Fertile Field: Experimenting With Early Music
description: The early-music movement has never lacked provocateurs, musicians willing to make points about style by stretching the limits of the style itself. The field is still apparently fertile: Il Giardino Armonico, a band of young musicians from Milan, has found fresh approaches to even the most overly recorded Baroque works. And the Kronos Quartet, playing (partly) against type, mixes old and new.

title: Honorable Fatigue
description: Jane Alexander, head of the National Endowment for the Arts for the past four years, has decided to give up her career as an arts administrator and return to acting. Who can blame her? She has endured four years of lunches, speeches, meetings, arguments, assurances and compromises, just to make sure that Congress dismantles the N.E.A. only a brick at a time. The theater and Hollywood have nothing worse to offer. Last week a Senate-House conference committee agreed to give the N.E.A. $98 million for fiscal year 1998, a reduction of $1.5 million from 1997 and $78 million since 1992. That is the kind of thing Ms. Alexander has been obliged to call a victory, and in this legislative climate, it is. But as part of the settlement, Congress has granted itself added authority over the distribution of arts money and placed its own representatives on the N.E.A.'s grant-making board. That would sting even if Congress had doubled the Endowment's budget.

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES TO ACQUIRE JETLINERS FROM BOMBARDIER
description: The Midway Airlines Corporation said yesterday that it would buy 10 small jetliners from Bombardier Inc. in Montreal for $207 million. Midway now flies 12 98-seat Fokker F100's and one 148-seat Airbus A320 from its hub in Durham, N.C. The Canadair regional jetliners, which have 50 seats, will be delivered over 14 months beginning in November. The company said it would use the new planes to add flights to existing routes and enter new markets. It will partly finance the deal with some of the $30 million it expects to receive from an initial public offering, which was filed yesterday.

title: Sulzer Seeks to Sell A Troubled Unit
description: Sulzer A.G. said yesterday that it was trying to sell its troubled building services unit, Sulzer Infra France, to Belgian Groupe Fabricom, a subsidiary of Tractebel S.A., as it continues to reorganize. Terms were not announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, MILTON
description: HOROWITZ-Milton. We remember your spirit and love of politics, ''La Donne Mobile'', and Chekhov. In lieu of flowers, donations: Democratic Party-Speakers Fund.

title: Cornell Moves to End a Rift Over the Housing of Freshmen
description: After years of debate about the best way to integrate undergraduate housing at Cornell, the university's president announced a plan today that will require all freshmen to live on the same part of campus.

title: Ford Planning To Spin Off Lending Unit
description: Seeking to persuade investors that its stock is undervalued, the Ford Motor Company said late today that it would distribute to shareholders its 80.7 percent stake in its highly profitable consumer and commercial lending unit, handing out shares in the Associates First Capital Corporation worth nearly $18 billion.

title: Manager Is Found Dead in Office in Times Square
description: The New York manager of a company that exports textiles from India was found dead in his Times Square office shortly after noon yesterday, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BIENSTOCK, LARRY
description: BIENSTOCK-Larry. The unveiling of a monument in loving memory of the late Larry Bienstock will take place on Sunday, Oct. 12, 1997 at 12 noon at the Hebrew National Cemetery, 122 Arthur Kill Road, Staten Island, NY. Relatives and friends are invited to attend. We will gather at the main entrance.

title: Baruch President Wants to Bolster Some CUNY Colleges
description: In an unusual public statement of what should be done to restore the City University system, the Bernard M. Baruch College president, who is being mentioned as a possible successor to the former CUNY Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds, called yesterday for a broad revamping of the 21-campus system and higher admissions standards.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 2 about a lawsuit against the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy stemming from its role in a bankruptcy case misstated the given name of a Chicago lawyer representing the law firm. He is William Conlon, not Charles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIFSHEY, SAM
description: LIFSHEY-Sam. National Council of Jewish Women Brooklyn Section Inc., extend heartfelt sympathy to our board member Ruth Lifshey on the loss of her husband Sam. Services at Garlick Funeral Home, 1700 Coney Island Avenue. Co-Presidents Anne Berger and Rita Berger

title: CHRONICLE
description: MICHAEL KELLY, who was dismissed last month as the editor of The New Republic, is on his way back into the inner circle of Washington journalism.

title: Lighter Side Of the Mayor: Can It Last?
description: DURING the summer, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sent over a photo after this column had suggested that he give himself and everyone else a break by taking a few days off, for a change. To show that he does know how to enjoy himself, he had a messenger (not to be confused with a Messinger) deliver a photo of him with his Parks Commissioner at the newly restored Astoria Pool in Queens.

title: A Revenge Plot, With Cross-Dressing
description: ''Lilies'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 11, 1996. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Art in Review
description: Kiki Smith

title: To the Jets' Offensive Line By Way of South Pacific
description: They are two-fifths of the offensive line, playing only a few feet apart. But Lonnie Palelei at left guard and Siupeli Malamala at right tackle each traveled 8,000 miles to come together on the Jets.

title: Bob Dylan Wins The Gish Prize
description: The singer and songwriter Bob Dylan is the recipient of the 1997 Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize. The award consists of a silver medallion and a cash stipend drawn from interest on a trust fund, now worth more than $7 million, that was created after Lillian Gish's death in 1993. Last year's prize of $200,000 went to the composer Robert Wilson.

title: Mercer Tries Charity For Lewis Rematch
description: In a style unusual to professional boxing, Ray Mercer is putting his money where his heart is by using a charity hook as a lure for a rematch with Lennox Lewis, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion.

title: Weekend Warrior; A Squealing Tire Is a Happy Tire
description: I never knew how much fun driving a $12,000 car could be until I went to the Skip Barber Advanced Driving School one weekend this month. Somehow I'd thought that after having driven for the last 30 years or so, I pretty much knew what cars were all about. Sure I was rusty from living in New York, driving rentals a couple of times a year. And maybe I had picked up a few bad habits from New York cabbies. But driving a car? Why you just keep one hand on the steering wheel and the other on the stereo.

title: Campbell to Acquire French Soup Concern
description: Danone S.A., France's largest food company, sold part of its grocery operations today for $850 million, including the $170 million sale of its soup business to the Campbell Soup Company.

title: FINGERHUT SAYS IT WILL SPIN OFF ITS 83% STAKE IN METRIS
description: Fingerhut Companies Inc. said yesterday that it planned to spin off its 83 percent stake in Metris Companies to shareholders. After the spinoff, worth about $615 million at current prices, Metris would be able to raise the capital needed to expand its credit card business without hurting Fingerhut's credit rating, the company said. The move would also allow Fingerhut, based in Minnetonka, Minn., to concentrate on its main catalogue business. The company has asked the Internal Revenue Service to declare the spinoff tax free for shareholders. Fingerhut shares rose 75 cents yesterday, to $22.375 while Metris shares rose $1.625, to $40.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, ROBERT H.
description: O'BRIEN-Robert H. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Robert H. O'Brien, a Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Victor D. Ziminsky, Jr. Pres. Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: The A.B.L. Hopes for a Successful Encore
description: In the pro women's game, the American Basketball League is certainly the poorer sister. But not necessarily the weaker sister, as it proved last year in its first season. It should prove that again when its second season starts Sunday with the Atlanta Glory playing the New England Blizzard in the Hartford Civic Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENKRANTZ, ESSYE
description: ROSENKRANTZ-Essye. Oct. 8, 1997 in her 92nd year, Charlotte, NC. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Maurice C. Rosenkrantz (formerly of Scarsdale, NY and Hollywood, FL). Devoted mother of Edmund and Diane Rosenkrantz and Judith and Milton Tager. Adored and adoring grandmother of Beth Benamy, Bonnie Draluck, Deborah Buchman and Elizabeth Rosenkrantz. Precious great-grandmother of Mark and Ross Draluck, Brittney and Madison Buchman, and Joseph and Sari Benamy. Proud Life Member of Hadassah. Graveside services and interment on Oct. 13, 1997 at 11 AM at Temple Beth-El Cemetery, Davie, FL.

title: In Answer to Whisper Campaign, Castro Talks for 7 Hours
description: It wasn't so much what Fidel Castro had to say. It was how long he took to say it that has turned out to be the biggest surprise so far of the Cuban Communist Party's first congress in six years.

title: Closed School Was Studied as State Superfund Site
description: As city school officials prepared this summer to open a Harlem elementary school for 500 students in a former dry-cleaning plant, state environmental officials were examining whether the building should be added to a state registry of inactive hazardous waste disposal sites, known as Superfund sites.

title: Merit Test Is Divisive in Affirmative Action Case; Flip a Coin
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop and Jazz Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Hilton to Get Country Club
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the Atlantic City Country Club from a private family, making it the only hotel operator in Atlantic City to operate a golf course.

title: On My Mind; Gutless in New York
description: In New York City one battle has been lost, by surrender. But in Washington and around the country, conservatives and liberals of courage continue to fight for the religiously persecuted of the world.

title: When One Door Slams, Patten Unlocks Another
description: After fumbling kickoffs in successive games, David Patten, the Giants' special teams impresario, will be relieved of his duties on kickoff returns against the Arizona Cardinals on Sunday.

title: 'Tis True, 'Tis a Puppet: Hamlet Hangs by a Thread
description: Consider: Czech marionettes performing ''Hamlet'' with Andrew Lloyd Webber-style songs added. Even the ghost sings (''Revenge me, Hamlet, revenge me, Hamlet'').

title: Nissan Sentra From Mexico
description: The Nissan Motor Company said today that it would invest $250 million in its Mexican division this month as part of a plan to shift production of the Sentra from its United States plant in Smyrna, Tenn., to Mexico. Nissan, Japan's second-largest car maker, said it intended to invest a total of $800 million in Mexico through the year 2000. The subcompact Sentra is being shifted to make room for a new sport utility vehicle.

title: Dynastic Politics in North Korea
description: Like everything else in the opaque world of North Korean politics, the formal appointment this week of Kim Jong Il as head of the country's Communist Party is hard to read with any clarity. It suggests there has been orderly passage of power to Mr. Kim, the son of North Korea's longtime dictator, Kim Il Sung, who died three years ago. It may also mean that the country's dogmatic military leaders will take orders from civilian authorities. Neither development augurs any great change in the North's self-imposed isolation.

title: After-School Classes Closed Over Gang Fears
description: After-school classes were suspended yesterday at three Bronx high schools after a police precinct commander warned school officials that October is a particularly active month for Blood gang recruitment, a Board of Education spokesman said yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MCMORAN OIL and GAS CO., New Orleans, said shareholders had approved a shareholder rights plan and a $200 million oil and gas exploration program.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Rallying Against Utilities
description: At least 300 people in the heating, air-conditioning and plumbing industries rallied at the State House yesterday, protesting against a state government they said gave an unfair advantage to major utility companies trying to encroach upon their business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTON, JOHN SPERRY
description: MINTON-John Sperry, on October 7, 1997. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Alison. Loving brother of Stuart Minton Jr., and Sari Berliner. Services were private.

title: The Mayor Cites Past Successes, While Messinger Focuses on Future
description: There was never any doubt that Ruth W. Messinger and Rudolph W. Giuliani would present different visions of the city last night at their first debate, but what was most striking were their differences in how to campaign: Ms. Messinger refused to discuss her past, while Mr. Giuliani refused to discuss the future.

title: Donadoni Is Leaving MetroStars for Italy
description: Roberto Donadoni, the player who helped give Major League Soccer instant credibility and joy when he joined the MetroStars two years ago, created leaguewide disbelief and disappointment yesterday when he announced he was returning to Italy to rejoin AC Milan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 2 about a visit by television forecasters to the White House misidentified the television station in Miami where Bryan Norcross presents the weather. It is WFOR, not WBRY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWER, THOMAS C.
description: POWER-Thomas C., of Fair Haven, NJ, died at home on October 8, 1997. Husband of Joan nee King Power, father of Thomas C. and James King Power. Visitation Saturday 6-8 PM and Sunday 3-7 PM at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, NJ. Relatives and friends may gather at the Funeral Home Monday 12 Noon followed by 1PM Funeral Mass at the St James R.C. Church Red Bank, NJ. Interment to follow in Mt Olivet Cemetery, Middletown, NJ. The Family has requested that no flowers be sent. Please make donations to the Catholic Youth Organization, 499 Bell Grove Drive, Kearney, NJ 07032 or National Center for Learning Disabled, 381 Park Ave. S., Suite 1401, N.Y., NY 10016.

title: Merit Test Is Divisive in Affirmative Action Case
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'ARBELOFF, CATHERINE
description: d'ARBELOFF-Catherine, in Boston, September 29, 1997. Baroness Catherine T. (Tiepolt) d'Arbeloff. Beloved wife of the late Baron Vladimir d'Arbeloff. Loving mother of Alexander V. d'Arbeloff of Brookline, Chairman of Teradyne Inc. and of the M.I.T. Corp, George V. d'Arbeloff of Newton, C.E.O. of Retail Solutions and the late Dimitri V. d'Arbeloff former Chairman of Millipore Corp. Also survived by 7 grandchildren and 4 great grandchildren. A funeral service will be held in the Holy Trinity Orthodox Cathedral, 165 Park Drive, Boston on Saturday, October 11, at 10:00 AM. Relatives and friends respectfully invited. J.S. Waterman & Sons Eastman Waring Funeral Service, 495 Commonwealth Ave. (Kenmore Square) Boston.

title: U.S. Alters Medicaid Rules, But New York Isn't Mollified
description: The Clinton Administration tonight issued new nationwide standards specifying how states may finance their share of Medicaid costs, but Gov. George E. Pataki of New York immediately denounced the rules as unacceptable.

title: Mr. Lott's Arrogance
description: Senator Trent Lott's spin is that campaign finance reform is dead for this year. He cannot, of course, allow a straight-up vote on the McCain-Feingold bill because it enjoys majority support. So he resorted yesterday to arcane parliamentary procedures to try to make his his death prediction into a death sentence. Despite these clumsy tactics, the McCain-Feingold bill, which would outlaw open-ended donations and curb other abuses, will be back when the Senate reconvenes on Oct. 20. Senators John McCain and Russell Feingold and the minority leader, Tom Daschle, intend to keep bringing it up again and again.

title: Real-Life Tableaux, Natural Yet Startling
description: The Dia Center for the Arts gets credit for not just sticking with the golden oldies -- those influential artists of the 60's whose work it owns in depth. Over the last decade or so, it has started going out on limbs with relatively young artists, or filling gaps in local knowledge by showing artists from abroad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTEIN, RICHARD PALAIS
description: EISENSTEIN-Richard Palais. Beloved father of Daniela, Michael, and Benjamin. Dear brother of Nancy and George Strausman and adored uncle. Services private.

title: Second Banana Never Expected Top Billing
description: For 30 years, Bill Guthridge sat loyally beside Dean Smith on the North Carolina bench and blended into his shadow off the court.

title: No, Mr. Ickes, Not Every President
description: Where was Harold Ickes when President Richard Nixon needed him?

title: Inside Art
description: Another Matisse Joins the Modern

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOWARD, CYNTHIA REDDING
description: HOWARD-Cynthia Redding. Happy birthday in heaven. I miss you. George Kowalczyk

title: N.A.S.D. Wants Central Market for Orders
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers today proposed creating a central market for customer orders in an attempt to generate more competition on the Nasdaq market.

title: Theater Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Bad Day for Commandos and a First Lady
description: Showing practically no sign of his customary humor, Keenen Ivory Wayans has written in ''Most Wanted,'' a jackbooted action film punctuated by top-volume special effects. A 20-car collision and a leap off a 45-story building are among its highlights. As directed with bland efficiency by David Glenn Hogan, the film casts Mr. Wayans as a somnolent tough guy. He's so steely that he barely has a speaking role, beyond saying things like: ''Relax. If I was going to kill you, you'd already be dead.''

title: Knicks Finally Get Wish: Dudley
description: Rarely do the movements of a plodding, 32-year-old backup center cause such a stir, but Chris Dudley's agile maneuvering through a loophole in the National Basketball Association's collective-bargaining agreement left the league's lawyers scrambling, all to prevent a sign-and-trade deal that would allow him to become the Knicks' safety net for Patrick Ewing this season.

title: Toshiba Joins Forces With Alcatel Alsthom
description: Alcatel Alsthom S.A. said yesterday that the Toshiba Corporation of Japan would invest in its $3.5 billion multimedia satellite project, giving the venture a key third major partner in the race for global radio licenses. The amount of Toshiba's investment in Alcatel's Skybridge Ltd. Partnership was not disclosed. Loral Space and Communications Ltd. joined the project in June when the two companies agreed to invest an initial $60 million to combine their satellite networks.

title: House Approves School-Voucher Plan for Nation's Capital
description: With Speaker Newt Gingrich providing the deciding vote, the House today approved a spending bill for the District of Columbia that includes a controversial Republican-drafted provision to give public school students vouchers to help pay tuition at private schools.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Want to preserve for future generations the lore of your family, its triumphs and tragedies, funny moments and sad ones?

title: Art in Review
description: Tom Otterness

title: Of Dark Doings in Sunny Colors
description: With solid success, Pedro Almodovar leaves his taste for camp behind to direct a richly detailed tale of passion, perfidy and revenge adapted from a typically tricky Ruth Rendell novel. ''Live Flesh'' (or in Spanish, even better, ''Carne Tremula'') is Mr. Almodovar's stylish, sexy film noir, although in his case film rouge is more like it. Bold, sunny colors saturate this sleek and vibrant-looking film, even in settings like a graveyard and a child care center.

title: Top Aides Urge Clinton to Ease Global Warming Emission Goal
description: To the dismay of environmentalists seeking swift action to toughen the international treaty on climate change, President Clinton's senior economic and environmental advisers are urging him to delay until the year 2010 and beyond the time when the United States and other industrial nations must achieve deep new reductions in the pollution that may cause global warming.

title: Art in Review
description: Roni Horn

title: Finding Plenty of Rest Stops Along the Road to Discovery
description: In ''Love Always,'' a young woman named Julia Bradshaw goes on a journey of self-discovery, and 90 minutes in her company seems like a long time on the road to nowhere.

title: Stocks Tumble in Japan
description: Stocks fell today to their lowest level in eight months, following Wednesday's drop on Wall Street. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 242.26 points, or 1.37 percent, at 17,376.92 -- its lowest since Jan. 27. The Tokyo market is closed on Friday for a national holiday, Sports Day. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rose 107.99 points.

title: Pacificare Names Official
description: Pacificare Health Systems said today that it had named Brad Bowlus as president and chief executive of the Pacificare of California unit, its largest, as the health maintenance company continues to integrate the FHP International Corporation, acquired in February.

title: Florida Backs Out On a Deal
description: A businessman wants to market a product. The risks are great and the investment high. Others have tried and failed, but potential profits are immense. So he and 10 others invest $12 million and work hard for two and a half years with no return. Then a conglomerate buys their company for more than a billion dollars, netting each a profit of $100 million. Rejoicing ends when the government declares the profits excessive and asks arbitrators to determine a fair return.

title: Bertrand Goldberg Dies at 84; Architect Reshaped Chicago
description: Bertrand Goldberg, an architect who literally changed the shape of the Chicago skyline in the 1960's with a pair of cylindrical apartment towers known as Marina City, died Wednesday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 84 and lived in Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLAUSTEIN, MAE
description: BLAUSTEIN-Mae. October 10, 1914. Passed away April 16, 1990. Dearest Mom, we love and miss you very much. Adrienne, Hank, Frank, Miriam, Simcha and Anna

title: 3 Blacks Win $1 Million in Bauer Store Incident
description: A Federal District Court jury in nearby Greenbelt, Md., ordered the Eddie Bauer company today to pay $1 million in damages over an incident in which three young black men were detained on suspicion of shoplifting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LACHMAN, LAWRENCE
description: LACHMAN-Lawrence. The Board of Trustees of New York University and the entire NYU community mark with great sadness the death of Lawrence Lachman: alumnus, trustee of the university from 1974 to 1990, and emeritus member of the Stern School's Board of Overseeers. He embraced every aspect of University life: Top-ranked student, stellar athlete, devoted alumnus. His list of achievements both at NYU and after, his sense of commitment and service, his keen mind and business sense, and his kind spirit and manner serve as an example to all. He will be greatly missed. L. Jay Oliva, President Laurence A. Tisch, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Columbus Day, actually Oct. 12, will be legally observed.

title: Mellon Offers $17.7 Billion For Corestates And Is Spurned
description: In what could be the beginning of a hostile takeover battle, the Mellon Bank Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to buy the Corestates Financial Corporation, but that it had been rebuffed.

title: Rangel Disavows His Vote on Abortion
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, said today that he used his voting card mistakenly on Wednesday when he cast his ballot in favor of banning a late-term abortion procedure.

title: Market Place; The High Hopes Of Investors In Stock Funds
description: Unlike Alan Greenspan, some mutual fund investors seem relatively certain that the stock market will continue to provide them with outsized gains -- and for a long, long time.

title: Merit Test Is Divisive in Affirmative Action Case; More Minority Doctors
description: To the Editor:

title: Meredith F. Burrill, 94, Expert On World Geographic Names
description: Meredith F. Burrill, a toponymist's toponymist who made a name for himself as the world's foremost authority on what people variously -- and sometimes perversely -- call the earth's lakes, rivers, mountains, seas, cities, towns and other physical features and political subdivisions, died on Sunday at a hospital in Washington. He was 94 and had spent 30 years as executive secretary of the United States Board on Geographic Names.

title: Diner's Journal
description: At some restaurants you go to the bar and drink while you're waiting for your table. Tuscan Square has a different tack: this new restaurant in Rockefeller Center offers the opportunity to buy hand-painted plates and pure silk aprons until your table is ready.

title: Holocaust Remembered
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSCELLI, MAUREEN F. MCKENNA
description: ROSCELLI-Maureen F. McKenna. Of Bloomfield, on October 7, 1997, wife of Richard N. Roscelli, mother of Richard K. Roscelli, sister of Kenneth McKenna, daughter of Ruthye Giorgio and the late Michael McKenna, stepdaughter of Eleanor McKenna and Anthony Giorgio. Also survived by her inlaws Edna (Anna De Crescenzo & Stephen J. and Norma Roscelli. The funeral mass will be celebrated at Sacred Heart Church, Bloomfield, Saturday, October 11, at 10 AM. Interment in Glendale Cemetery. Friends may call at the Van Tassel Chickene Funeral Home, 337 Belleville Ave., Bloomfield, NJ Thursday and Friday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Memorial contributions may be made to the St. John's Church Feeding Program, 22 Mulberry Street, Newark, NJ 07102.

title: Family of Slain Man Sues Funeral Home
description: A Long Island family has sued a funeral home for $7 million, contending that it wrapped the corpse of a loved one in plastic rather than dressing it as the family had requested.

title: PECO ENERGY SAYS IT WILL FIGHT ENRON ELECTRICITY PLAN
description: The Peco Energy Company will not accept the Enron Corporation's proposal to take over its customers and will fight the plan in court if regulators approve it, Corbin McNeill, Peco's chairman and chief executive, said yesterday. ''We are treating this as a hostile takeover,'' Mr. McNeill said. ''We will not negotiate with Enron.'' On Tuesday, Enron, based in Houston, proposed taking over service to Peco's 1.5 million electric customers in the Philadelphia area in return for cutting rates by 20 percent and assuming $5.5 billion in Peco costs. The Pennsylvania Public Utilities Commission said yesterday that it would consider the two competing proposals together and vote on Peco's proposal on Dec. 11. The proposals were submitted as part of Pennsylvania's move to deregulate electricity sales to consumers.

title: Sharp Exchanges Pepper Debate Between Giuliani and Messinger
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger battled last night about where New York City has been during the last decade, its current condition, and where the next Mayor should lead it. The 90 minutes of often harsh exchanges gave voters the first opportunity to measure the two candidates on the same stage.

title: Merit Test Is Divisive in Affirmative Action Case; No Equal Candidates
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeing a Doomed Future After War and Hatred
description: In ''Pretty Village, Pretty Flame,'' the Belgrade-trained filmmaker Srdjan Dragojevic unleashes a powerful assault on the insanity of the war that pitted Serb against Muslim in Bosnia.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Students Protest Remarks
description: About 100 Stockton State College students staged a peaceful march yesterday morning, demanding the resignation of a tenured professor who has been accused of making insensitive remarks about African-American students.

title: Idea for Teamster Gift Was Dropped, 2 Testify
description: Two former finance officials of the Democratic National Committee testified today that they had considered arranging for a Filipino businesswoman to donate money to the election campaign of the teamsters president, Ron Carey, but abandoned the plan when they determined that it could not be done legally.

title: Goddess and Composer, Reeling at Love's Wallop
description: Every so often during the humdrum of the New York Philharmonic's weekly programs, its music director, Kurt Masur, steps forward and puts his distinctive mark on the orchestra's repertory. Last season, it was Debussy's ''Martyrdom of St. Sebastian,'' this year the ''Psyche'' of Cesar Franck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUROW, MYRON
description: JUROW-Myron. The Morris family and the staff of I.J. Morris, Inc, mourn the passing of our beloved friend and colleague of almost 40 years. We will miss his kindness and his compassionate dedication to his professional responsibilities. Our deepest sympathy to his wife Hedy and his children, Scott and Allison. Services Friday 9:30 AM, at ''The Dix Hills Chapel'' of I.J. Morris, Inc, 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, Long Island.

title: Dassault Weighs Sale Of Warplanes to China
description: Dassault Aviation S.A., a maker of combat jets and business aircraft, said yesterday that it was talking to China about selling it the company's newest fighter, the Rafale. The talks occurred as the French company began deliveries of Mirage 2000 fighter planes to Taiwan, which China has threatened to attack if it declares independence. Dassault sold Taiwan 30 Mirage jets in 1992.

title: Web Genesis Picks Kirshenbaum Bond
description: Web Genesis Inc. in New York said yesterday that it had named Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York as the first agency of record to handle integrated marketing for the Globe, its community Web site. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $8 million.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: CASCADES AND DOMTAR PLAN A JOINT VENTURE
description: Cascades Inc. and Domtar Inc. said yesterday that they would create a joint venture through a merger of Cascades' containerboard operations and Domtar's packaging division. The Canadian paper and packaging products companies said the venture, which would be 50 percent-owned by Cascades and 50 percent owned by Domtar, would be the largest Canadian producer of linerboard and corrugated materials. Domtar is to receive its stake for $300 million (Canadian), or $218.6 million (United States), in exchange for assets valued at about $580 million (Canadian). Cascades is to receive its stake for $70 million (Canadian), or $51 million (United States), in exchange for assets valued at about $350 million (Canadian).

title: Renewable Love, and Other Fallacies of Youth
description: ''When you travel, your first discovery is that you do not exist,'' Elizabeth Hardwick observed in her book ''Sleepless Nights.'' That sense of acute isolation while in transit is woven into the exhilarated, brooding tango music seeping through the soundtrack of Wong Kar-Wai's powerfully moody film ''Happy Together.''

title: Vegetarian Immortality
description: To the Editor:

title: New Works to Music Composed for Choreography
description: Music written expressly for dance is not a new idea, but rare is the musician nowadays who chooses to compose with choreography in mind.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARSKE, ESTHER
description: BARSKE-Esther, on October 9, 1997, in Fairfield, CT. Widow of Abraham Barske. Survived by her children, Harriet and Howard Peck of Atlanta, Raymond and Rhonda Barske of Bethel, Conn. Grandchildren, Randy and Scott Barske, Steven and Jeffrey Sledkus. Services Friday 10:00 A.M., at Hebrew Sick Benefit Cemetery, Fairfield, CT. Memorial contributions to The American Kidney Foundation.

title: Abroad at Home; 'Accent the Positive'
description: Senator Spencer Abraham of Michigan, elected just three years ago, was quickly made chairman of the Immigration subcommittee. As the grandson of immigrants and a believer in the American story, he used his key role successfully to oppose in last year's legislation a proposed sharp cutback in legal immigration. But he supported stringent new procedures to decide who can enter and remain in this country -- changes that have had some harsh results. Why? I asked him.

title: Bomb Trial Lawyers Focus on Death Penalty
description: A potential juror in the second Oklahoma City bombing trial here seemed at first to be a prosecutor's dream: a business manager who had once helped the Federal Bureau of Investigation find documents for a successful criminal investigation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENSON, ADELAIDE
description: BENSON-Adelaide. On October 7. Devoted sister of Milton and Ruth, loving aunt of Faye, Alfred, Lois and Adrienne and Ellen. She worked in the garment industry for last 35 years. Service 1:30, on Sunday, at the ''Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I was mad.''

title: A Nerd Who Gets a Life (And a Love) in Space
description: To imagine the 1995 film ''Apollo 13'' as a tale told by idiots is to plumb the shallows of the new release called ''Rocketman.''

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Lawsuit Over Diet Drug
description: A woman who claims a recalled prescription diet drug damaged her heart is the latest to file a class-action lawsuit against the manufacturers.

title: Nothing but Net: When Life Is a Hoop Dream
description: On a steamy summer Sunday afternoon several years ago, I sat in the stands at the Holcombe A. Rucker tournament on the outdoor basketball court at West 155th Street in Harlem and watched a game. Hundreds, if not thousands, of others watched, too. They sat on the makeshift wooden bleachers, or peered from behind the chain-link fence, or hung out of curtain-still windows from the nearby projects across Eighth Avenue, or fleetingly caught the action as they rumbled by on the elevated CC local.

title: Two Views of New York
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and his Democratic opponent, Ruth Messinger, defined their basic disagreement last night with perfect clarity. Ms. Messinger sees the glass as half-empty. Mr. Giuliani sees it as pretty much full already. Their debate was a useful portrait of two contrasting analyses of the state of New York City. But it was not the kind of debate likely to drive voters from one candidate to another, and since Mr. Giuliani began in the stronger position, he had more reason to smile at the end.

title: U.S. Expands Its Air Patrols Over Zone In South Iraq
description: With Defense Secretary William S. Cohen warning that Iraq will ''bear the consequences'' of additional violations of an American-enforced no-flight zone in southern Iraq, the Pentagon announced today that air patrols had been expanded over the area.

title: Art in Review
description: Joseph Kosuth

title: Jordan's Passivity Forces Israel to Act
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Movies; Disney Hires Kissinger
description: Henry A. Kissinger once secretly flew to Beijing to help reopen China to the United States. Now he's gone Hollywood -- to keep China open to the Walt Disney Company.

title: WORLD CHAMPIONSHIPS: JALABERT WINS TRIAL
description: Laurent Jalabert surprisingly won the individual time trial yesterday in the world cycling championships in San Sebastian, Spain. The Frenchman is the No. 1-ranked rider in the world, but heretofore he had been only a middling time trialer.

title: Old Problems Plague Knicks
description: The Knicks' training camp slogan ''It's time'' is still a work in progress, which was revealed when the team slipped back into some old sloppy habits in losing its first preseason game to Philadelphia, 104-101, in overtime tonight.

title: Key Keeps Performing Magic; It's Just Not Enough for Orioles
description: The first inning resembled one inning Jimmy Key pitched in a post-season series last year. And just as that inning did, this one demonstrated that age has not withered Key's Houdini-like powers. Escape from an underwater tomb with chains around it and him? Houdini had nothing on 36-year-old Jimmy Key.

title: Forget the Breezy 60's, It's Time for a Tantrum
description: Three albums into its career, Oasis is no longer just slavishly imitating the Beatles. That worked well enough in 1994-95, when pumped-up, retreaded Beatles tunes made Oasis the most popular band at home in England and a Top 10 fixture in the United States. But its show on Tuesday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom suggested that Oasis might be planning to recapitulate the whole time line of British rock, era by era. For the moment, this means that Oasis has adopted the bloat and pretension of rock circa 1969-75: the booming guitars, the drawn-out songs, the unquestioning self-importance. It made for a show that seemed much longer than the two-hour set.

title: Vegetarian Immortality; Diet-Drug Side Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: 'Selections Fall '97'

title: The Inquirer's Top Editor Plans to Step Down
description: Maxwell E. P. King, the editor and executive vice president of The Philadelphia Inquirer since 1990, said yesterday that he would resign those posts at the end of the year to become an editorial writer on regional issues.

title: Descriptions of Concealed Donations to Democrats Cause Bickering on Panel
description: A raucous session of the House committee investigating campaign abuses heard testimony today that two big-money fund-raisers and friends of President Clinton, John Huang and Charles Yah Lin Trie, personally arranged illegal ''straw'' donations for the Democratic re-election campaign last year.

title: Metro Business; Bills Delivered on Line
description: Customers of the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the CheckFree Corporation will be able to receive and pay bills via the Internet next year, as part of a plan to expand the bank's on-line services.

title: Hopeful Syracuse Blasts Hopeless Rutgers
description: Tonight's Big East game pitted hopeful versus hopeless. Hopeless never had a chance.

title: Excerpts From Attorney General's Remarks on Campaign Finance Inquiry
description: Following are excerpts from remarks today by Attorney General Janet Reno defending her inquiry into campaign finance questions and from her response to questions by reporters, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company.

title: A Tourist Expanding His Horizons
description: Monet understood the appeal of an underdog and cultivated the role. The public, which seems never to get enough of him, still tends to romanticize him: he's the impoverished genius unloved by critics, rejected by the official salons, recognized only by posterity.

title: Hevesi Campaign Fined for Taking Excessive Donations
description: The New York City Campaign Finance Board levied a $2,600 fine against the re-election campaign of City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi yesterday for accepting $12,750 in illegal contributions. Some of the money came from companies that were involved in a much larger sanction that the board imposed last month on the re-election campaign of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Home Video
description: A Biography Of Diana

title: Using Puns and Pratfalls to Lob Satirical Grenades
description: Dario Fo, the subversive satirist who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature yesterday, once described his work as a ''preoccupation with ridicule, laughter, sarcasm, irony and the grotesque.''

title: Industry Disputes U.S. Study On Profits in Tobacco Accord
description: Tobacco companies today challenged a Government study that projected soaring industry profits from the proposed settlement of tobacco litigation.

title: Fervidly Drafting The Self And Sex
description: The exhibition titled ''Egon Schiele: The Leopold Collection, Vienna,'' which opens at the Museum of Modern Art on Sunday, couldn't have blown into town at a better moment.

title: Rangers Manage 4th Tie In 4 Games
description: What a strange way to begin a season. After four games, the Rangers have no victories, no defeats, eight goals and four ties. Tonight's verdict was a 1-1 draw with the Calgary Flames at the Saddledome. The four ties to start a season are believed to be a National Hockey League record.

title: TV Weekend; Letting George Eliot's Passion Surface
description: As she glides down the river, an Ophelia-like figure lying in a small boat, Maggie Tulliver passes by ghostly images standing on the bank. ''I'm sorry,'' her disembodied voice says as she moves past those she has loved and hurt: her bankrupt father, the two men who have loved her, the sweet cousin she has betrayed and her adored brother, Tom.

title: Qufu Journal; Not Equal to Confucius, but Friends to His Memory
description: When darkness falls on this quiet town, where crooked old cypress trees hang over aimless roads, the mood becomes as calm and silent as the untended apple orchards that cover the surrounding countryside.

title: Father Denies He Abused Adopted Girls During Flight
description: A man from Arizona who, with his wife, is accused of beating their newly adopted 4-year-old Russian girls on a flight from Moscow to New York in May, said in court yesterday that he believed in corporal punishment. But he added that his contact with his daughters was nothing more than a pat or a tap.

title: Judge Approves Hilton-Bally Pact
description: An agreement by the Hilton Hotels Corporation to settle lawsuits brought by Bally's Grand Inc. shareholders for $97.5 million was approved today by a Delaware judge, over the objection of some shareholders.

title: Foreign Affairs Still Unpopular on Main St.
description: The American public is no more eager to have the United States play a greater global role than it was four years ago, while so-called ''opinion leaders'' have become much more confident about America's place in the world, according to an opinion poll scheduled for release on Friday.

title: Art in Review
description: Kathy Butterly

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BIENSTOCK, LARRY
description: BIENSTOCK-Larry. The unveiling of a monument in loving memory of the late Larry Bienstock will take place on Sunday, Oct. 12, 1997 at 12 noon at the Hebrew National Cemetery, 122 Arthur Kill Road, Staten Island, NY. Relatives and friends are invited to attend. We will gather at the main entrance.

title: Marlins Lose Fernandez To Bad Shoulder Injury
description: Jim Leyland, manager of the Florida Marlins, sensed something was wrong with Alex Fernandez, from his body language, from the diminished velocity of his fastball. But Leyland admitted to being blindsided by the results of Fernandez's shoulder examination today: the star pitcher has a complete tear of his right rotator cuff.

title: Review/Fashion; A Versace Looks Ahead, Through Tears
description: For as long as anyone can remember, just before a Versace show starts, the music surges a bit and the lights dim, so everyone knows to take a seat. The music is always some exclusive selection no one has ever heard before -- this time, Madonna singing ''Candy Perfume Girl,'' from an album to be released next year. There are always laser lights -- this time darting from a huge screen like the moment in ''Star Wars'' when they go for speed.

title: The Buzz in the Capital Brings a Yawn in Peoria
description: As Washington was buzzing this week with talk of campaign finance scandal at the White House, Butch Long was pushing a heavy wheelbarrow on a dusty construction site here along the Illinois River.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Weather Wilts Lyme Disease
description: Thanks to dry weather, New Jersey residents have reported 40 percent fewer cases of Lyme disease so far this year than during the same period last year, according to figures released this week by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: CONTROLLING CASINOS

title: INSIDE
description: Fatal Tanker Explosion Creates Thruway Chaos

title: Movie Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Running times and ratings of films are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 7.

title: Bear Stearns Revises Filing About Baron Investigations
description: The Bear Stearns Companies has filed an amended annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission, after apparently deciding that its original report to the agency, filed just last week, was not correct in every respect.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. A * denotes highly recommended shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLURMAN, MORTON
description: CLURMAN-Morton, age 80, on October 7, 1997. Will be deeply missed by his wife of 57 years, Frances; by his children Michael and Beth; his grandchildren Daniel, Nick, Ha and Anthony; and by his daughter-in-law Barbara and his brother Lawrence. His sense of humor, curiosity, breadth of interests and fund of knowledge will be missed by his family and by his many friends. Memorial services will be held at the James House on the grounds of Phelps Memorial Hospital on Saturday, November 15th at 2:00 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARTELLO, GEORGE
description: MARTELLO-George 1937-1962 Not a day goes by. Nancy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RING, ROSE (NEE LEDDY)
description: RING-Rose (nee Leddy), on October 7, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Thomas F. (FBI). Devoted sister of Anne O'Brien and sisterin-law of James O'Brien. Dear aunt of Maureen Sears, Joseph and James O'Brien. Great-aunt of seven. Friends may call at The Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20th Street), NYC. Thursday and Friday, 2-5 & 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Epiphany RC Church, Saturday 9:45AM. Interment Saint Charles Cemetery.
