In lieu of flowers contributions to: Former Agents of FBI Foundation, POB 1027, Quantico, Virginia 22134-1027.

title: Lawrence Lachman, 81, Leader In Transforming Bloomingdale's
description: Lawrence Lachman, a former chairman of Bloomingdale's, died at his home in Manhattan on Tuesday. He was 81 and died of heart failure, a spokeswoman for the company said.

title: Art in Review
description: Theodore Roszak

title: As It Turns Artistic, A Noirish Enclave Steps Into the Light
description: Chic it isn't.

title: Top Sergeant, Facing Trial, Is Stripped Of His Post
description: The Army said today that it had removed Gene C. McKinney from his post as the service's top enlisted soldier, a day after the announcement that he would be court-martialed on charges of sexual misconduct involving six women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KASTNER, MARGARET NICHOLS
description: KASTNER-Margaret Nichols. On October 7, in NYC. Wife of Alton Kastner, mother of Susan K. Tree of Westtown, PA., and Timothy Kastner of Chicago, IL. Interment was private. A memorial contribution may be made, if you wish, to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ANDEWELT, BELLE
description: ANDEWELT-Belle. Hello again Cookie. Today is your 60th wedding anniversary date. Thanks for the wonderful years you gave us. Love, all of us.

title: Classical Music and Dance Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: Jewish Election Shows Division on Issues
description: American Jews have been barraged for more than six months with campaign mail, calls from the kind of phone banks organized for Congressional races and pleas from their rabbis to vote in an election for an organization that few even knew still existed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARROLD, CLAYTON JR.
description: HARROLD-Clayton Jr. On October 4, 1997, Clayton departed this life. Wed 51 years to Millie. Family and friends will have a memorial service at Brooks Memorial United Methodist Church, Jamaica, NY on October 11, 1997 at 12 noon.

title: Brazil Jet Maker Gets French Order
description: Brazil's Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica S.A. yesterday won a $94.4 million order from France's Flandres Air for eight of the company's newest jet. The contract includes eight firm orders for the 37-seat EMB-135, brought out by Embraer on Sept. 16, and options to buy 12 more jets, said Marcia Benevides, a company spokeswoman.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Germany Raises Rate, Rattling Financial Markets

title: A House (of Worship) Divided; Two Congregations Sharing One Synagogue Wind Up Before a Higher Authority: State Court
description: In the Jewish religion this is the season of forgiveness, but in Brooklyn's leafy, literary Park Slope neighborhood two congregations co-existing in one synagogue can neither forgive nor forget.

title: Sports of The Times; A Coach's Right Sense Of Priority
description: HIS players were listed in alphabetical order. If you wanted to find the total points scored by that precocious freshman, you had to work through the walk-ons and the substitutes and the role players until you found the name ''Jordan'' in the middle of the pack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANENBAUM, MARY MAYER
description: TANENBAUM-Mary Mayer, for 59 years beloved wife of Charles J. Tanenbaum, and loving mother of Ann Tanenbaum King. Born in San Francisco, the greatgranddaughter of Marcus Reyman, a California pioneer, she won the City Girl's Tennis championship and continued her tennis career at Stanford where she was also a junior member of Phi Beta Kappa. Beginning as an assistant book reviewer with the San Francisco Chronicle, she continued as a freelance journalist for various publications, and was an active member of the Overseas Press Club. She was deeply interested in Chinese Art and Culture and wrote over 50 essays in this field for the Christian Science Monitor. She also assembled an important collection of Chinese paintings which will pass to the Stanford Museum of Art, where there will be a seminar room in her name. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81 St), Sunday, October 12, at 1:00 P.M. Contributions may be made in her name to the Stanford Museum of Art, Stanford, CA. 94305-5060.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Body in River Is Identified
description: The body of Don Leventhal, a sports analyst, was pulled from the Delaware River on Wednesday and identified yesterday, officials said, noting that Mr. Leventhal had been missing since Sept. 29.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARTENSTEIN, MORRIS
description: GARTENSTEIN-Morris. The Bnos Yisroel School for Girls family mourns the passing of a respected member of the community and a proud supporter of our Robert Gartenstein Memorial Kindergarten. Our sincere condolences to Mrs. Mollie Gartenstein, children Victor and Gail, grandchildren and great granddaughter. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rebbitzen N.D. Groner, Dean Rabbi B.L. Barnetsky, Administrator Mrs. Judy Feuer, Principal

title: Bosnian Weapons Help Keep the Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Last Day to Register
description: Today is the deadline to register for the Nov. 4 election. Mailed registration forms must be postmarked by midnight tonight and received by the City Board of Elections by Wednesday.

title: Officer Shoots Man During Drug Arrest
description: Police officers conducting an undercover narcotics operation in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, shot and wounded a 23-year-old man while trying to arrest him, the police said.

title: EMERITUS EXPECTS INVESTMENT FROM SOROS-BACKED FUND
description: The Emeritus Corporation said yesterday that an investment fund backed by Soros Fund Management L.L.C. had agreed to invest $25 million in the company. Emeritus, which builds and operates housing for elderly people who need daily assistance, said Northstar Capital Partners L.L.C. would buy 1.37 million newly issued preferred shares, representing about 10 percent ownership in the Seattle-based company. Northstar, based in New York, makes investments on behalf of Quantum Realty Partners, a real estate fund affiliated with the financier George Soros. Emeritus owns and operates about $500 million worth of housing communities for the elderly. Its shares were up 87.5 cents yesterday, to $15.6875.

title: World News Briefs; Court Urged to Halt French War-Crimes Trial
description: The lawyer for Maurice Papon, the 87-year-old former high-ranking French civil servant on trial for complicity in Nazi crimes against humanity for agreeing to arrest Jews in occupied France during World War II, argued today that his client should be set free because too much time had gone by to permit him a fair trial.

title: Storm Hits Acapulco; Scores Die in Workers' Districts
description: A hurricane swept the resort belt along the Pacific Coast overnight with unexpected fury, unleashing flash floods and landslides and drenching Acapulco. A hundred people were reported dead, 40 of them in Acapulco.

title: Teacher's Aide Is Said to Smuggle Blades in Jail
description: A teacher's aide was arrested yesterday after trying to smuggle razor blades into a juvenile center at Rikers Island, jail officials said.

title: Eating Out; For Carnivores
description: New York steakhouses, temples for the most devout carnivores, stand tall once more but are by no means the only option for meat-worshipers. The following restaurants, representing Asia, South America and the Mediterranean as well as the United States, all offer menus rich enough in meat to satisfy any persuasion. (Here are summaries, written by Eric Asimov, taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Art in Review
description: Current Undercurrent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ROSE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Rose. Age 88. Cherished wife of Walter. Caring sister of Benjamin Rosenfeld. Also beloved by all who knew her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ELEANOR (NEE VOLK)
description: GOLDMAN-Eleanor (nee Volk), 59, died in Florida October 8, 1997. Wife and companion of Howard Goldman, daughter of Anne and Irving Volk. Sister of Arthur Volk. Mother of David Ritter, Adam (Sharon) Ritter, Elizabeth (James) Crickey, Michelle Goldman and Adam (Jean) Goldman. Grandmother of Ryan Ritter and Rebecca Ritter. You left us much too soon and we will miss you. We love you, Ellie. Graveside services at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island, 10 A.M., Sunday, October 12th. Memorial gifts to charity of your choice.

title: INVESTMENT GROUP BUYS 9.99% STAKE IN APRIA HEALTHCARE
description: An investment group that includes David Batchelder and Ralph Whitworth acquired a 9.99 percent stake in Apria Healthcare Group Inc. yesterday. The investment group, Relational Investors L.L.C., and its affiliates, which hold 5.14 million common shares, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that they think Apria, a provider of home health care services, is undervalued. Apria, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., hired the investment bank Goldman, Sachs & Company to help the company explore options such as a sale. Company shares closed unchanged yesterday at $14.

title: Markets Shake Off Turmoil But Finish the Day Mixed
description: The stock market shrugged off early worries about rising interest rates yesterday and helped push some broad indexes to record highs, but overall results ended mixed.

title: Vallone Ends Plan to Get Law to Fight Persecution
description: Facing intense opposition from business leaders, Peter F. Vallone, Speaker of the New York City Council, announced yesterday that he would end his effort to seek legislation to bar the city from doing business with companies that operate in 15 countries that he contends persecute Christians.

title: Spare Times
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: EQUITY OFFICE BUYS 19 OFFICE BUILDINGS FOR $1 BILLION
description: Equity Office Properties Trust said yesterday that it had completed the purchase of 19 office buildings, including properties that flank the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, for about $1 billion. The properties are in Chicago, New Orleans, Houston, Dallas and Philadelphia and contain about 6.6 million square feet. In addition to 10 and 30 South Wacker Drive in Chicago, the properties include the LL&E Tower and the Texaco Center in New Orleans and 1700 Market Street in downtown Philadelphia. The purchases were financed with cash, securities and the assumption of debt. Equity Office, based in Chicago, is the nation's largest owner of office properties. It owns and operates 113 buildings with 39.5 million square feet and 16 parking garages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARROW, CONSTANCE L.J.B.
description: BARROW-Constance L.J.B., on 4 October 1997. Beloved wife of the late Donald F. Barrow. Mother of Elizabeth Doering and Constance Hurley. Grandmother of Elizabeth, Dennis and Lily. Sister of the late Alexander J. Bruen, Edward F.L. Bruen and Evelyn B. Trevor. Services on October 10 at 11 AM at St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor. In lieu of flowers, donations to Animal Rescue and Rehabilitation, POB 61, Syosset, New York 11791.

title: Senate Panel Hears Costs and Benefits of Bigger NATO Debated
description: Critics of President Clinton's plan to expand NATO charged today that enlargement of the Western military alliance would create new risks of instability in Europe and cost the United States far more than the Administration has estimated.

title: A Serious-Minded Pianist With a Witty Take on Liszt
description: Arnaldo Cohen ended his program at the 92d Street Y with a work that showed off all his abundant strengths: the ''Fantaisie Dramatique sur les Huguenots de Meyerbeer,'' which was one of Liszt's early operatic paraphrases and which apparently had not been heard in this country before Mr. Cohen's performance.

title: Yankees' First Move: Raines Won't Be Back
description: The Yankees began revising their roster for 1998 yesterday when they declined to exercise Tim Raines's $1.8 million option and paid the 38-year-old left fielder a $200,000 buyout.

title: Gore Visits and Gives Messinger a Low-Key Endorsement
description: Vice President Al Gore came to New York yesterday and delivered a respectable endorsement of Ruth W. Messinger as the education candidate for mayor. But he stopped short of bestowing the full Vice-Presidential treatment. He did not campaign with Ms. Messinger or even provide her with a prized ''photo op.''

title: For Drivers of Perilous Cargo, Crash Crystallizes Worst Fears
description: As investigators pored over the warped wreckage of a Mystic Bulk Carriers gasoline tanker under a charred highway overpass in Yonkers yesterday, 20 miles away, in Astoria, Queens, drivers milled around the company's main truck depot and spoke of the daily worries that come with hauling such a deadly cargo.

title: Muslims Win Vote in Town That Serbs 'Cleansed'
description: In a result from municipal elections last month that could complicate Western peacekeeping efforts, Bosnian Muslims won political control of Srebrenica, the town in eastern Bosnia where thousands of Muslims had been expelled and massacred in one of the darkest episodes of the Balkan war, election monitors announced yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the decision by the Manhattan District Attorney not to seek the death penalty in the slaying of a police officer misstated one aspect of the sentencing procedure in death-penalty cases in New York State. Jurors are given the option of death or life without parole; only if they cannot agree unanimously on either option is the judge required to impose a lesser sentence, of between 20 years to life and 25 years to life. The lesser sentence is not automatically imposed if the jury fails to vote unanimously for a death sentence.

title: Overhaul Bill Stalled Again In Senate In Same Ploys
description: The Senate today defeated a last-ditch effort to advance the campaign-finance bill, leaving the issue deadlocked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WANG, FANG YU
description: WANG-Fang Yu, Professor. On October 6, 1997, of Manhattan, formerly of Short Hills, NJ. Learned scholar with broadly recognized expertise transcending multiple fields of endeavor including teaching, art, and calligraphy. A prolific author and friend and mentor to many. He is survived by two sisters, Wang Shi Fen and Shih Hiang Chu, a daughter, Shan, and three sons, Shen, Lun, and Shao Fang, seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Viewing will take place at Frank Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue on Saturday, October 11 between 1:00 and 4:00PM and 7:00 and 9:00PM and Sunday, October 12, between 1:00 and 4:00PM. Funeral services will take place on Wednesday, October 15 at 9:45 A.M., at the same location.

title: Art Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Fed Vice Chairwoman's Comments Calm Wary Investors
description: Interest rate increases by several European central banks, led by the Germans, sent Treasury securities tumbling early yesterday before they rebounded on remarks by Alice M. Rivlin, vice chairwoman of the Federal Reserve.

title: Retailers Report Sales Gain Of Only 2.1% in September
description: Blaming the sun and the death of a princess, retailers reported some of the weakest monthly sales of the year yesterday, leaving economists and analysts wondering if bullish predictions for the holiday season should be tempered.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVEC, PIERRE
description: LEVEC-Pierre. Kaatsbaan International Dance Center deeply mourns its dear friend, patron, Board member. Dance, art, music, and interior design have lost a valuable friend.

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q&A column of Science Times on Sept. 9, about the nutritional benefits and risks of peanut butter, misstated its caloric value. A tablespoon of crunchy peanut butter has about 94 calories, not 188.

title: Italy's Barbed Political Jester, Dario Fo, Wins Nobel Prize
description: Dario Fo, an iconoclastic Italian playwright-performer known for mixing wacky social farce with sharp political satire, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature today, to the guarded amazement of Italy's literary establishment and the outright dismay of the Vatican.

title: TYLER IN DEAL FOR 2 INFORMATION MANAGEMENT COMPANIES
description: The Tyler Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two companies for about $84.3 million in cash, stock and the assumption of debt, as Tyler moves into information management. Consideration for the acquisition of the two companies, the Business Resources Corporation and Software Group, will consist of 12 million Tyler common shares and about $40 million in cash and debt assumption. Based on Wednesday's price of $3.6875, the stock is valued at about $44.25 million. Tyler stock rose 75 cents yesterday, to $4.4375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKFORT, RENEE
description: FRANKFORT - Renee. Passed away October 8, 1997. Loving mother of David (Joyce), Edward (Tina Suzan), Helene (Larry). Adoring grandmother of nine, cherished great-grandmother of two and caring friend. Her kindness and heartfelt goodness touched the lives of many, all of whom will miss this special lady. In lieu of flowers the family suggests contributions to Gifts of Life Inc, 718-281-0582. Condolences may be mailed to: Dr. Helene Schaeffer, PO Box 16, Oak Bluffs, MA 02557.

title: New York Punishes Swiss Bank Over Nazi Gold
description: New York City quietly administered a major sanction against the Union Bank of Switzerland last week by barring it from participating in a billion-dollar bond offering, a move meant to underline disapproval of the way the bank has responded to the investigations into dealings with Nazi Germany, city officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, G.E. KIDDER
description: SMITH-G.E. Kidder Born October 1, 1913 Birmingham, Alabama; died Oct. 8, 1997 at home. Beloved husband of Dorothea (nee Wilder). Beloved father of Kidder, Jr. and Hopkinson, and beloved grandfather of Zacharias, Samuel, Tatjana, and Alice. Graduate of Princeton (1935), MFA (1938). USNR 1942 to 1946. Architect, author and photographer. Fellow of The American Institute of Architects. Memorial Service November 17, 11 A.M., at the Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Avenue, NYC. Contributions may be sent to the Class of 1935 Fund.

title: RENO STRIKES BACK AT INQUIRY CRITICS
description: Challenged for months over the Justice Department's handling of the campaign finance investigation, Attorney General Janet Reno today offered an unusually aggressive defense of her agency's conduct and said she was ''mad'' at the White House for failing to inform her of videotapes of President Clinton with wealthy supporters.

title: COLLEGES: FOOTBALL NOTEBOOK
description: Columbia

title: Jordan's Passivity Forces Israel to Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Greenspan's Jawing Gets The Job Done For the Fed
description: The economy would seem to be right where Alan Greenspan wants it. Growth, while still robust, shows signs of moderating. Unemployment is low. Inflation is almost nonexistent.

title: Candidates in Mayoral Race Touch on Education, Gangs and Unemployment
description: Following are excerpts from remarks made in a debate last night by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his Democratic challenger, Ruth W. Messinger, as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: Playwright Can't Go On? Let the Audience Help Out
description: Improvisational theater bears comparison to experimental chemistry. Mix the right ingredients and a magic elixir forms, filling the theater with laughter, excitement and applause. Great risk is rewarded with exhilarating success.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Israelis, Arafat and Jordanian King Feuding
description: The aftermath of a bungled assassination attempt in Jordan continued to send shockwaves through Israeli politics today, with Foreign Minister David Levy saying he had considered resigning, and Yasir Arafat complaining that King Hussein was meddling in Israeli-Palestinian affairs.

title: Exploring the Misery Of a Desperate Era
description: When the Yale Center for British Art first opened here in 1977, it presented a view of England and English life that was predominantly Arcadian. The countryside in the 18th century looked idyllic. So did life in English country houses, large and small. Horses and dogs were well bred and well fed. Life in the slow lane in England was no cause for anxiety. Work was work, but very few people died of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUCK, HELEN R.
description: BUCK-Helen R., of Allwood in Far Hills, NJ on Wednesday, October 8, 1997. Wife of the late Leonard J. Buck, mother of C. Auftin Buck II, of Bernardsville, NJ, Martha Buck Bartlett of Washington, D.C., and Nancy Buck Pyne of Far Hills, New Jersey. Also survived by nine grandchildren and twelve greatgrandchildren. Memorial Mass at St. Brigid's Church, Peapack, New Jersey, Friday, October 17, at 5:30 P.M. Private entombment Holy Savior Cemetery, Bethlehem, PA.

title: Editor of Los Angeles Times Quits Amid News Shake-Up
description: The Los Angeles Times announced a big step in its much-debated reorganization today. Its editor, Shelby Coffey 3d, resigned and the newspaper named a new editorial team that will further dismantle the wall that has traditionally separated the news and business sides at most major newspapers.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; A Study of Truckers' Need for Sleep Raises New Alarms
description: EVEN if truck drivers are given as much rest time as regulations require, some of them are not getting enough sleep to keep them from dozing off at the wheel.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: H.M.O. Switches to Flat Fee For Treatment by Specialists
description: One of the country's biggest health maintenance organizations has signed up hundreds of medical specialists to diagnose and treat expensive medical conditions for set fees, rather than piecemeal payments. The move is a sharp departure from industry practice.

title: Sri Lanka Hails Condemning of Tamil Tigers
description: The Sri Lankan Government today hailed a State Department decision to include a group fighting for a separate Tamil state on a list of 30 terrorist organizations that will be barred from raising money or other material support in the United States. The decision came as Sri Lankan troops are booged down in one of the bloodiest battles of a 14-year separatist war.

title: Bossa Nova By a Purist, Stripped Of Excess
description: True to bossa nova's essential subtlety, Vinicius Cantuaria played a quiet set at the Knitting Factory on Monday night. His syncopated guitar chords were bare wisps of harmony; his backup musicians, a percussionist and a trumpeter, were precise yet gentle. Mr. Cantuaria, who has written plenty of Brazilian hits, is confident enough to choose understatement.

title: Confession to '71 Killing Revives Memories
description: It was the summer of 1971 and tremors from the nation's generational earthquake had reached all the way up to this tiny Rocky Mountain village just east of the Continental Divide.

title: White House Proposes I.R.S. Oversight Panel
description: Responding to intense pressure from Congress to take stronger action to rein in the Internal Revenue Service, President Clinton will unveil proposals on Friday to overhaul management of the tax-collection agency, including establishment of an oversight board made up largely of private citizens, Administration officials said today.

title: Residential Real Estate; Deposit Rule in Rent Law Draws Fire
description: One of the most bitterly contested provisions of the new rent regulations passed by the New York State Legislature four months ago -- requiring many tenants facing eviction to deposit rent in an escrow account even before a case is adjudicated -- will go into effect in 10 days.

title: Seeing the Beauty in Things Through Eyes of Wonder
description: As marginal as it may seem nowadays, the cinema that still calls itself avant-garde remains a wellspring of ideas about the purity and integrity of the filmed image when divorced from commerce and (often) from conventional narrative form. If you point a movie camera at any object and seriously explore its texture, shape and iconography, what you come up with is often something as compelling as it is mysterious in its evocation of the spiritual qualities of things. It has everything to do with light projected on a screen whose size monumentalizes and with whatever images are shown.

title: A Japanese Atonement Helps to Heal Wounds
description: KANCHANABURI, Thailand  Nagase Takashi, a retired Japanese school teacher, is not sure if this is his 94th or 95th voyage to Kanchanaburi.

title: Thruway Bridge Is Ruined As Explosive Crash Kills One
description: A gasoline tanker exploded in flames early this morning after colliding with a car beneath the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, leaving one person dead, ruining a bridge supporting an essential thoroughfare and creating traffic chaos in the New York metropolitan region that reverberated as far south as Maryland and as far north as Albany.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLANDER, LILLIAN
description: FRIEDLANDER-Lillian. After a long and fruitful life Lillian (formerly Bieber), wife of the late Maurice, mother of Brent Friedlander, sister of Richard Bieber, died on Wednesday, October 8, 1997. Lillian was born in New York City, July 15, 1896. At the age of 101, she was an active woman. Music was a lifeline for her. Her involvement with the Philharmonic and as a longtime volunteer for the New York City Opera, Lillian spent every Saturday at the New York State Theatre. Devoted to her family and friends, she was loved and admired for her outgoing and life-affirming personality. She is survived by three nieces, two great nieces, and three greatgreat nieces. We will all deeply miss her in our lives. Private burial. Donations may be made in the name of Lillian B. Friedlander to the New York City Opera.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONAGH, BERNARD
description: McDONAGH-Bernard, on October 8, 1997. Joined The New York Times in 1948, retired 1972. Native of Bally Conlaught, County Galway, Ireland. Formerly of Bronxville, NY. Beloved husband of the late Katherine (nee Twoney), devoted father of Thomas, Bernard, Margaret and John. Grandfather of eight. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Friday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Saturday, October 11, at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Villa Marie Claire, 12 West Saddle River Road, Saddle River, New Jersey 07458.

title: From Science to Fiction; Military and Entertainment Industries Swap Expertise
description: From the time he was a boy, Mike O'Neal wanted to ''put something on another planet.'' He earned degrees in aerospace engineering and then worked for eight years at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, helping design the Mars Pathfinder.

title: Art in Review
description: Willard Boepple

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a report providing detailed evidence that troops loyal to President Laurent Kabila of Congo have been killing large numbers of civilian refugees misstated the source of the report in some copies. It was presented by Human Rights Watch and the International Federation of Human Rights Leagues, not the United Nations.

title: Looking Eastward for Patterns and a Quiet Sensuality
description: There was little that unified Monday night's program given by the chamber group Parnassus in Merkin Concert Hall, except the high quality of the performances and an aura of the East, differently expressed in three of the four works. This Orientalism was most explicit in Jonathan Harvey's ''Song Offerings,'' where poetry by Rabindranath Tagore becomes the occasion for a Wagnerian love-death delivered by an ecstatic soprano from out of a humming hive of instruments: string quintet, piano, flute and clarinet. The work was sung beautifully and with characteristic dedication by Susan Narucki, who fulfilled every obligation in creating an extended instant of joy, a marriage of sensuousness and calm. Cyrus Stevens, the first violinist, provided some perfectly tuned whistling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARCHIAPONE, A. ROBERT
description: SARCHIAPONE-A. Robert, of Malverne, on October 8, 1997. Retired advertising executive of Young & Rubicam. Beloved husband of Catherine. Loving father of Marie Ann, Dorothy Kress, Robert, Anthony, and Josephine Zeigler. Dear grandfather of five. Family will receive friends today 2-4PM and 7-10PM at the Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home Inc., 34 Hempstead Ave., Lynbrook. Mass of Christian burial Sat. 9:45AM at Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverne. Entombment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

title: In Vandross, Excellence As a Form Of Rebellion
description: The singer Luther Vandross has never received much critical attention. Wrapped in sequins, a purveyor of luxury, he's hopelessly bourgeois, and critics have disdained him because of it.

title: Indians Go Home on Wings of Grissom Homer
description: Marquis Grissom was so weakened by influenza on Wednesday night that the Indians pumped fluids into him intravenously and wondered if he would be strong enough to play. Grissom played on Wednesday and even crashed into the center-field fence trying to make a catch. His teammates were impressed.

title: Baby Hidden in Closet Is Healthy, Hospital on L.I. Says
description: A baby who was hidden in a bedroom closet for 17 days by his teen-age mother was reported to be ''eating normally and functioning properly'' at Stony Brook University Medical Center today.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 7
description: SUNDAY 1 P.M.

title: METROPOLITAN HEALTH ENDS ITS BID FOR TRIDENT MEDICAL
description: Metropolitan Health Networks Inc. said yesterday that it had ended its bid for Trident Medical Concepts Inc. as a four-month surge in Metropolitan's stock raised the value of the offer to $31 million from $20 million. Metropolitan said on June 5 that it would buy Trident, swapping one of its shares for each of the closely held Trident's 4.9 million shares. Metropolitan's stock has risen 56 percent since June 4, closing unchanged yesterday at $6.25. Metropolitan, a network of physicians based in Boca Raton, Fla., said it ended the bid after Trident failed to meet revenue requirements, which were not disclosed.

title: Spare Times
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Family Fare
description: Boris Karloff, Courtly Monster

title: Three on the Wind
description: The leading yachts in the Whitbread Round the World Race were hard on the wind after rounding the first landmark off the Brazilian coast yesterday and are heading for the second at Ilha de Trinade.

title: On Stage and Off; A Full Season, And Then Some
description: The Broadway season officially begins on Thursday with the opening of ''Side Show,'' a new musical about Siamese twins who become vaudeville performers. And it never lets up, promising to be an exceedingly busy, crowded season.

title: Poland Urges Sobriety on Road
description: Eager to slow a sharp rise in drunken driving, Poland's national police force ran a bold advertisement soon after the death of Diana, Princess of Wales.

title: Some Philosophy Lessons From a Cunning Monk
description: A Tibetan lama, street smart and in exile, drops in on a high-powered Yale economist and stands the modern Western world on its head in Don Thompson's ''Tibet Does Not Exist.'' This monk has little to say about the current suppression of the Tibetans by the Chinese, and he seldom asserts his Buddhist philosophy to change the minds of the economist, several academic colleagues and a couple of students.

title: Metro Business; John Wiley Acquires A Trade Book Unit
description: John Wiley & Sons, the New York publishing company, has acquired a unit of International Thomson Publishing that publishes trade books on architecture, industrial science, culinary arts and technology, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Two marketers of alcoholic drinks inject humor into their campaigns for premium imports.
description: TWO large marketers of alcoholic beverages, seeking ways to pique the interest of pickier tipplers, are pouring generous shots of humor into campaigns getting under way for premium-priced import brands.

title: 879, Then Farewell: It's a Lovefest for Smith
description: Dean Smith, the coach whose basketball lineage traces from James Naismith and the first peach basket, formally ended an era today.

title: Weekend Excursion; Beside the Hudson, The Lure of Art
description: ''You notice that I write in an absent-minded sort of way, crossing out and inserting words,'' the Hudson River landscape painter Frederic Edwin Church wrote in 1891 to a friend from Olana, his home near here. ''Well, it is owing to the magnificent effects this morning. The beautiful clouds, and opalescent atmosphere, and lovely tints in the landscape, distract me everywhere.''

title: GERMANS SURPRISE WORLD ECONOMIES WITH A RATE RISE
description: Germany's central bank sent shivers around the world today by raising an interest rate for the first time in five years, a move that deflated stock markets across Europe and knocked down the value of the American dollar.

title: DIGITAL SAYS IT REMAINS COMMITTED TO ALPHA CHIP
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it was committed to selling products based on its flagship Alpha chip even as it considered settling a patent dispute with the Intel Corporation. Bruce Claflin, the Digital sales and marketing chief, said in a memo to workers that Digital's objectives remained the same ''whether we resolve our differences with Intel in court or through settlement.'' Digital sued Intel, the world's biggest chip maker, in May, contending that Intel stole Alpha technology to help create its Pentium chips. Digital's shares rose earlier this week amid speculation that it may license the Alpha chip to Intel, plus sell some production operations, for $1.5 billion. Shares in Digital rose 50 cents yesterday, to $48.5625.

title: Casino Boats Must Observe 12-Mile Limit
description: Casino boats that sail from New York City must travel at least 12 miles from shore before passengers can start gambling, not just 3 miles, according to the top Federal prosecutor in Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGHBLOOM, SIDNEY
description: HIGHBLOOM-Sidney. The partners and staff of Hecht and Company note with deep sorrow the passing of Sidney Highbloom, who had been associated with the firm in various capacities for over 20 years. Sidney's pride in his work was matched by his great sense of humor and those who worked with him on a daily basis have suffered the loss of a friend. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Hecht and Company PC

title: Italian Government Falls In Fight Over Euro Austerity
description: Italy's coalition Government fell today after a bitter battle in Parliament over how much to cut social programs to qualify for the European common currency, the euro.

title: A 3d Term for Yeltsin?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACHIDA, DOROTHY
description: MACHIDA-Dorothy, of Thiells, NY, on October 8, 1997. Longtime, award-winning artist. Wife of the late Masuro Machida. Loving mother of Robert, William, Marianne Hever, Dorothy Burckardt. Viewing Friday, 2-4 PM, 7-9 PM, at Hannemann Funeral Home, Inc., 88 South Broadway, Nyack, NY. Funeral Mass Saturday, 10:15 AM, St. Gregory Barbarigo Church, Garnerville, NY. Burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Lead Content Is Found High In Plastic Items
description: A wide variety of household objects like children's raincoats, Barbie toys and telephone cords contain dangerously high levels of lead, Greenpeace said in a report today. Greenpeace cited tests it had commissioned by an independent laboratory that frequently works for Government agencies.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about a defamation award that could shut down Barricade Books, a small New York publisher, misidentified the court that issued a restraining order against the publisher. It was a New York State court, not a Nevada court.

title: 'Antics' Annoy Marlins
description: Ryan Klesko finished his swing with his hands high after hitting a home run off Alex Fernandez in the first inning in Game 2, pausing for a couple of seconds and watching the ball fly into the stands. This annoyed some of the Marlins.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Man Gets Life in Stabbing
description: A man who fatally stabbed his ex-girlfriend 82 times was sentenced to life in prison yesterday by a judge who called the crime ''the most brutal'' he had never seen, The Associated Press reported.

title: Overhearing History: Johnson's Secret Tapes
description: TAKING CHARGE

title: Hernandez Back as Starter
description: In the wake -- and shock -- of the news of Alex Fernandez's torn rotator cuff, the Florida Marlins' pitching coach, Larry Rothschild, felt heartened about the attitude of his relief pitchers.

title: Art in Review
description: Joachim Koester

title: Balloon Warfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding Alternatives to Alternate Routes
description: Because a tanker exploded in Yonkers yesterday, picnic areas in Palisades Interstate Park in New Jersey went unpatrolled. Contractors assigned to a half-dozen road projects took their shovels elsewhere. And truckers 300 miles away in Maryland saw flashing signs along Interstate 95 and changed their routes.

title: Antiques; The 'Secrets' Of French Furniture
description: Collectors of 18th-century French furniture behave like members of a secret society. They bat around the names of furniture makers most people have never heard of -- Louis Cresson, Georges Jacob, Nicolas Heurtat, Jean-Baptiste Tilliard. They talk about provenance -- who owned the piece before, whether it is in the Wallace Collection catalogue in London or the Wrightsman rooms at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. They argue whether Regence is better than Louis XV and whether unpainted wood (bois naturel) is more chic than painted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AGATE, ANITA KAUFMAN
description: AGATE-Anita Kaufman, on October 8, 1997. Peacefully at home. Beloved wife of the late Sanford S. Agate. Adored mother of Constance Austin. Loving grandmother of Anita Dann Friedman (Harvey) and Caroline Dann. Adored greatgrandmother of Adam and Jonathan Friedman. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st, Friday at 10AM. Kindly omit flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMBERG, ALBERT E.
description: BLUMBERG-Albert E. The Audubon Reform Democratic Club mourns the passing of our longtime President. A political leader, senior citizens advocate, philosophy professor and an activist in the truest sense, he worked hard to organize people in northern Manhattan to improve their communities and especially to empower the Dominican community. He has left an indelible mark and will be greatly missed by all who worked with him.

title: Toyota Seizes a Title, but Ford's Trucks Stay in the Money
description: The 1997 model year is officially over, and there is a new name at the top of the list of the best-selling cars: the Toyota Camry. The Camry took the title from the Ford Taurus, which had been the top-selling car in America for the prior four years, having stolen the crown from the Honda Accord.

title: ARTS AND CRAFTS COMPANY SELLS 2.7 MILLION SHARES
description: A. C. Moore Arts and Crafts Inc. said yesterday that it had sold 2.7 million shares for $40.5 million, or $15 each, in an initial public offering of its stock. A. C. Moore, based in Blackwood, N.J., operates arts and crafts superstores. Proceeds from the offering are expected to be used for repaying debt, for opening new stores and for working capital. Shares of A. C. Moore opened on the Nasdaq stock market at $16.25 and finished their first day of trading at $16.50.

title: New Video Releases
description: Grosse Pointe Blank

title: Blackstone Raises $4 Billion for Fund
description: The Blackstone Group, a New York investment bank, said yesterday that it had raised a $4 billion fund to finance corporate acquisitions, the second-largest such fund that has been created.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNAPPERMAN, YETTA JOAN
description: SNAPPERMAN-Yetta Joan. On October 10, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Loving mother of Sedra Schiffman and Caryl Avery. Cherished grandmother of Marc, Lauren and the late Caron. Services Friday, 11 AM, at New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Metro Business; Arts-to-Business Databank
description: The Arts and Business Council, a nonprofit arts organization in New York City, has started an Internet database listing services that local arts groups can sell to businesses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEARMAN, SAM
description: BEARMAN-Sam. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services mourn the passing of Sam Bearman, beloved father of Marla Siskind. We extend our deepest sympathies to Marla; her husband, Alan; and their children, Daniel and Tamara Jill. Seymour R. Askin, Jr., President Joseph S. Kaplan, President-Elect Fredric W. Yerman, Chairman Paul Levine, CSW, Associate Executive Vice President

title: Tears for Ataturk
description: To the Editor:

title: A Painter Unafraid to Change Styles
description: Most of us are too young to remember, of course, when terms like beauty, order, even the sublime were used in connection with painting. But in the case of Richard Diebenkorn (1922-1993), these words can be recycled without embarrassment. His contemporary work in the spirit of classical modernism -- now on view in a full-scale retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art -- reaffirms him as a major figure in 20th-century American art.

title: Caraustar Floats an Offer for Britton Group
description: Caraustar Industries said today that it might offer about $270 million in cash for Britton Group P.L.C., a bid that the British carton and packaging maker rejected as inadequate.

title: A Love Affair Kept All in the Family
description: One thing is certain about Mark Waters's film ''The House of Yes'': this contemporary screwball comedy with a leering sensibility doused in the taboo-breaking confessional world of Jerry Springer and Ricki Lake is a one-of-a-kind movie that gives new meaning to that jokey old slogan, ''Vice is nice but incest is best.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FARRICKER, REV. WILLIAM J., S.J.
description: FARRICKER-Rev. William J., S.J. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Wiegel Hall, 515 East Fordham Road. Visitation Sunday 3-5 PM & 7-9 PM. Monday 3-5 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 8 PM at Loyola Chapel. For information contact Farenga Brothers, Directors.

title: Immigration Plan Would Protect Central American Refugees
description: The chairman of the House immigration subcommittee said today that he expected Congress to approve within the next few weeks legislation that would allow as many as 500,000 Nicaraguan, Guatemalan and Salvadoran refugees to avoid deportation.

title: Investigators Work to Determine Cause of Fiery Tanker Explosion
description: Federal and local investigators examined melted wreckage, medical tests and piles of records today, trying to piece together how a fully loaded gasoline tanker and a Chrysler Eagle sedan collided beneath the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in the fog early Thursday morning, producing a pillar of fire that killed the doctor driving the car and closed one of the busiest commuting routes to New York City.

title: Big, Bright Secret
description: The Space Telescope Science Institute made news this week when it found in the heavens a heretofore unobserved star burning with a brightness of 10 million suns. But this surprise discovery did even more than put a new giant on the astronomer's maps.

title: Developer Is Selected For Residence for Elderly
description: The Battery Park City Authority announced yesterday that it had selected Brookdale Living Communities, a company based in Chicago, to develop a 14-story residential rental building that is expected to appeal to the well-to-do elderly.

title: RELIANCE STEEL PLANS TO SELL 3.3 MILLION COMMON SHARES
description: The Reliance Steel and Aluminum Company and shareholders filed for the sale of 3.3 million common shares yesterday to raise money to repay debt associated with recent acquisitions and to finance new acquisitions. The company, a steel and aluminum distributor and processor, plans to sell 3.1 million of the shares, and shareholders will sell the other 200,000, according to an S-3 registration statement filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Reliance, based in Los Angeles, expects to raise $82.7 million in the stock sale if the shares sell for $28.25, their closing price on Thursday. Its shares rose 25 cents yesterday, to $28.50.

title: N.B.A.: NOTES
description: Indiana

title: Declarer Needs an Entry. Defenders Hope He Finds It.
description: Situations that W. S. Gilbert would have called ''a most ingenious paradox'' occur occasionally at the bridge table. An example is the diagramed deal, played in the 1996 Vanderbilt Knockout Team semifinal in Philadelphia.

title: THEME PARK OPERATOR TO MANAGE SIX FLAGS OVER TEXAS
description: The shares of Premier Parks Inc. rose 8 percent yesterday after the company said it had agreed to become managing partner of Texas Flags Ltd., which owns the Six Flags Over Texas theme park. Shares in the company, which is based in Oklahoma City and owns and operates 12 theme parks, rose $3.125, to $42. The proposed $315 million transaction would give Premier 13 theme parks with expected 1998 attendance of 13 million, making it the fourth-largest theme-park chain in the world.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Columbus Day, actually Oct. 12, will be legally observed.

title: 3 Weak Days Trim Week's Gain in Dow
description: Stocks slipped yesterday, their third consecutive decline, leaving the Dow Jones industrial average with little to show for the week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEATING, SR. MARIA LAWRENCE
description: KEATING-Sr. Maria Lawrence. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity and former Head Mistress of the Academy of Mount Saint Vincent on Oct. 9, 1997. Survived by her niece, Joan Marshall, and her nephew, Thomas Marshall. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark St., Yonkers, NY on Sun. and Mon. 1-8PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tues. 9:30 AM at the convent. Interment at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers.

title: Bond Prices Take Steep Fall On Rise in Producer Costs
description: Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday as a surprisingly strong report on producer prices stoked worries over inflation that had been raised by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.

title: A Report on His Suicide Portrays A Deeply Troubled Vince Foster
description: Hoping to refute persistent speculation that the White House aide Vincent W. Foster Jr. was a victim of foul play, the Whitewater independent counsel today made public his report supporting his finding that Mr. Foster killed himself in a suburban Virginia park.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about a White House ceremony honoring police officers misidentified a man sitting between President Clinton and Attorney General Janet Reno. He was Richard Feldman, director of the American Shooting Sports Council, not Thomas J. Scotto, a New York City detective.

title: Robert H. O'Brien, 93, MGM President in 60's
description: Robert H. O'Brien, an early member of the Securities and Exchange Commission who later presided over the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer film studio in the 1960's, died on Monday in Seattle. He was 93.

title: William B. Spong, 77, Senator Who Altered Virginia Politics
description: William B. Spong, a Democrat who successfully challenged Virginia's political establishment to win election to the United States Senate, died on Wednesday at Maryview Medical Center in Portsmouth, Va. He was 77 and lived in Portsmouth.

title: Jones Misplays A Line Drive, And the Braves Are in a Hole
description: The Atlanta Braves conveyed many subliminal messages after blowing Game 3 of the National League Championship Series to the Florida Marlins, 5-2, tonight, and none of what they imparted flattered them.

title: Senate Judiciary Panel's Head Scolds Reno on Her Response
description: The chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, who is considering hearings into Attorney General Janet Reno's handling of the campaign finance investigation, expressed annoyance today with Ms. Reno's failure to respond to questions he posed to her after a Senate hearing five months ago.

title: Mount Faces St. Anthony's
description: Mount St. Michael of the Bronx prevented St. Anthony's of Huntington from capturing its fourth consecutive Catholic High Schools Football League title last season. Today, the Friars (1-2) have a chance to avenge that 21-7 loss and in the process even their season record.

title: CIGARETTE MAKERS REACH SETTLEMENT IN NONSMOKER SUIT
description: The major tobacco companies today settled the first class-action lawsuit over the effects of smoking on nonsmokers by agreeing to spend $300 million for the study of tobacco-related diseases.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Complaint Against Mayor
description: A harassment complaint has been filed against Mayor James Whelan by a man who was among a group of city residents who led an unsuccessful recall effort against the Mayor earlier this year, officials said yesterday.

title: Mail-Well Bid for Graphic
description: The commercial printer Mail-Well Inc. bid today to acquire Graphic Industries for $20 a share, topping an $18.50-a-share offer by Wallace Computer Services, a business forms company based in Hillside, Ill. Based on 12.35 million Graphic shares outstanding, Mail-Well is offering $247 million. Graphic, based in Atlanta, said its board had not determined whether to accept the offer. Graphic shares closed today on the New York Stock Exchange at $21.3125, up $2.8125.

title: Thruway Traffic Is Sparse a Day After a Crash Forced Its Closing
description: The only commuters along the partly closed Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway who seemed really inconvenienced this morning were Bruce Bimbo and Christian Suarez.

title: Lethargic Devils Fall Short
description: Through their first four games since moving from Hartford, the Carolina Hurricanes failed to win or to play particularly impressive hockey. But against visiting New Jersey tonight, they played with the precision of a playoff contender, notching a convincing 2-1 victory against the Devils.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: $96,000 Is Stolen From Bank in Queens
description: Two armed men wearing ski masks stole $96,248 from a Citibank branch in Beechurst, Queens, yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: A Hard Musical Act to Follow: The Spirit of Sidney Bechet
description: Capturing the essence of Sidney Bechet has to be one of the hardest assignments of an institutional jazz program. The clarinetist and saxophonist, who would have turned 100 this year, had one of the greatest individual sounds in jazz. It wasn't just his tone, a little sharp and nearly bursting with a vigorous vibrato; it was a graceful but thoroughly unshowy command of harmony and an ability to hold fast to a continuous logic through successive choruses of a song.

title: Chiappucci Is Out After Blood Test
description: Claudio Chiappucci, an Italian bicycle racer who was hoping to revive his career in the world cycling championships road race tomorrow, was instead dropped from the national team yesterday after he failed a blood test.

title: U.S. Has Training Shortage, Not Labor Shortage; Help Workers Succeed
description: To the Editor:

title: French Court Orders Ex-Vichy Aide Freed During Trial
description: In an unusual decision, a French court today ordered that the former Vichy police official, Maurice Papon, be released from prison, primarily for health reasons, while he stands trial for crimes against humanity during World War II.

title: At the Heels of Bull Elephants; Nimble, Small Stocks Chase Big Blue Chips And Lately That Means Bigger Gains
description: Glenn Fogle could feel his investors' pain early this year. Through several mutual funds that he manages, the investors had loaded up on the shares of smaller companies, only to watch in dismay as their prices sank while those of blue-chip stocks like Coca-Cola and Gillette kept soaring.

title: SPURNED TAKEOVER OFFER LIFTS SHARES OF CORESTATES
description: Shares of the Corestates Financial Corporation traded higher yesterday on speculation that the Mellon Bank Corporation's rebuffed bid could set Corestates in play for a takeover. ''People are speculating that Mellon hasn't gone away,'' said Anthony Davis, a bank analyst at SBC Warburg Dillon Read. Shares of Corestates rose $1.4375 yesterday, to $73.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Mellon's shares went the other direction, slipping $1.9375, to $52.9375. Based on the rejected offer of $88 a share, or $18 billion, a merger between Corestates, based in Philadelphia, and Mellon, based in Pittsburgh, would have been the largest bank merger in history.

title: Acapulco's Workers Dig Out After 120 Die in Hurricane
description: While white-uniformed employees at the elegant Fiesta Americana Condesa hotel mopped up a few troublesome puddles left on the patio by a hurricane, on a hillside across town, Efrain Flores shoveled five feet of mud out of his living room.

title: A False Assumption on African AIDS Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PATTERSON, JOHN T.
description: PATTERSON-John T., 45, died from complications of AIDS on October 9. Beloved son of Mildred R. Patterson, brother of Jeffrey T. Patterson. Reception at StretchEvans Funeral Home in Haddonfield, NJ today 12:30-2:00 PM, followed by graveside ceremony at Harleigh Cemetery in Camden, NJ. Memorial service Friday, October 31, 11 AM, Memorial Church, Harvard Yard, Cambridge, MA.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; 6 Held in Car Theft Ring
description: An auto theft ring stole hundreds of new automobiles from northern New Jersey dealerships by switching real ignition keys with look-alikes after a test drive, and coming back later with the real keys to drive the cars off the lot, the authorities said yesterday.

title: First Step on Gun Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Charles B. Branch, 82, Chief Of Dow Chemical in 1970's
description: Charles B. Branch, a former president and chief executive of the Dow Chemical Company, died last Saturday at Santa Rosa Hospital in San Antonio. He was 82 and lived on a ranch and wildlife refuge in nearby Boerne, Tex.

title: MCI Board Agrees to Closer Look At Worldcom's Unsolicited Bid
description: Worldcom Inc.'s unsolicited bid to acquire the MCI Communications Corporation passed its first major test yesterday when MCI's board directed the company's bankers and lawyers to take a closer look at Worldcom's offer.

title: Kanell's Move Up Has A Trickle-Down Effect
description: There has been a domino effect to Danny Kanell's new position as the Giants' starting quarterback, and today, things were still tumbling into place.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, BARBARA LOUISE BERMAN
description: YOUNG-Barbara Louise Berman. Devoted and adoring wife of Dr. Gilbert H. Young. Loving mother of Laurie and Rabbi Stephen Pearce, Beth and Dr. Joel Rush, and grandmother of Sarah Jean and Michael. Cherished neice of Frieda B. Wohl. Her appreciation of the beauty and goodness in life guide and sustain us. For over one decade, her unparalleled service ennobled the Roebling Society of The Brooklyn Museum. Her wide circle of friends reflects her far reaching interests. She leaves a legacy of enriching the lives of others, of grace, and of joy. Service, Sunday 2 P.M., ''Gutterman's'', 175 North Long Beach Avenue, Rockville Center. In lieu of flowers contributions to The Roebling Society of The Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARBETMAN, DAVID
description: ARBETMAN-David, 86, on October 9th. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Father of Edna Triska and Stephen. Father-in-law of Alacoque Arbetman and Frank Triska. Grandfather of Liam Arbetman & William Triska. Brother of Clara. Graveside services on Sunday, October 12, 1 PM, Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Corrections
description: An article in House & Home on Thursday about ways in which architecture and design firms redefine themselves after the death of a star partner misspelled the last names of two designers who commented. They are Arthur Dunnam, not Dunham, and Barbara Barry, not Berry. The article also misidentified the city in which Ms. Barry practices. It is Los Angeles, not San Francisco.

title: At the Library of Congress, a Little Joke for Profit
description: The Library of Congress has begun the observance of its 200th anniversary with readings from works in its collection by such extraordinary Americans as Thomas Jefferson, Abraham Lincoln and Groucho Marx.

title: YACHT RACING: A SAILOR'S JOURNAL; Coping With Unexpected Challenges
description: Ten yachts, all about 64 feet in length with a maximum crew of 12, began the 31,600-nautical-mile Whitbread Round the World Race on Sept. 21. The competitors are in the midst of the first of nine stages, a monthlong, 7,350-nautical-mile voyage south through the Atlantic to Cape Town. At last report, Innovation Kvaerner led by 18 miles as Merit Cup and EF Language continued to make small gains. Katie Pettibone, an American on the all-women's crew of EF Education, currently ninth, will be filing periodic reports of life on board until the race's scheduled return to Southampton next May. This is her fourth report.

title: Should Marino Get Smart, Jets' Glenn Will Be Wiser
description: Three years ago, the largest home crowd in Jets history watched the team battle Dan Marino and the Miami Dolphins with a share of first place on the line. But Aaron Glenn was all alone, a rookie cornerback, as Marino shouted, ''Clock! Clock!'' Glenn believed, as everyone else did, that Marino was going to spike the ball and stop the clock with 22 seconds left and the Dolphins trailing by 3 points. Glenn relaxed for just a second.

title: Mahathir Suspects Link to Ringgit's Fall : Malaysian Leader Sees Hidden Jewish 'Agenda'
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad said Friday that he suspected there may be a Jewish "agenda" behind recent attacks on his country's currency and stock markets.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Senate hearing on the proposed expansion of the NATO alliance misstated the office formerly held by Zbigniew Brzezinski, a witness. He was national security adviser to President Jimmy Carter, not Secretary of State.

title: Confucian Capitalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Tutoring Anxiety?
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. Acts to Require Big Cut In Air Emissions by 22 States
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today proposed rules that would require 22 states east of the Mississippi River to make deep cuts in their emissions of nitrogen oxides, the main source of the ozone in smog.

title: Kamieniecki Rips Yanks Over Ring
description: Scott Kamieniecki's voice dripped with bitterness and sarcasm today as he answered questions about his career with the Yankees. His words were exploding, his flushed face was twisting, and it almost seemed as if Kamieniecki had been transported back to the Yankee clubhouse instead of being in the Orioles'.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; School Board Is Investigated
description: The State Department of Education is investigating claims of corruption in the Asbury Park Board of Education, officials said yesterday.

title: About New York; A Poet Finds A New Muse In Columbus
description: CALL it cosmic payback in 1992 when Christopher Columbus was recast by revisionists as an imperialist point man. Around the 500th anniversary of his voyage, the namesake of circles and avenues became another Dead European Male whose greatness seemed destined to vanish like the indigenous cultures he ''discovered'' in the New World.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT STOCK FALLS ON EARNINGS PREDICTION
description: Shares of Waste Management Inc. fell sharply yesterday after the company said it expected third-quarter results to come in below analysts' expectations. Shares dropped $3.125, to $30.625, or 9.3 percent, on the New York Stock Exchange. It was one of the most active issues, with more than eight million shares changing hands. Waste Management, based in Oak Brook, Ill., said it expected third-quarter earnings from continuing operations to be 38 cents to 40 cents a share, below analysts' expectations of 44 cents a share and earnings of 49 cents a share in the quarter a year earlier.

title: Postmodernism's Critics
description: To the Editor:

title: PRUDENTIAL TO INVEST $10 MILLION IN WESTAR FINANCIAL
description: Westar Financial Services Inc., an automobile finance company, said yesterday that it would receive a $10 million investment from the Prudential Insurance Company of America that will help it expand into new regions. Westar, based in Olympia, Wash., said it would use the capital to offer the lease-financing services it provides only in the Pacific Northwest in another region in the West by the end of the year and elsewhere in 1998. After its $10 million investment, the insurer, which is based in Newark, will be the company's biggest shareholder. Shares of Westar climbed 62.5 cents, to $5.375, on Wednesday in over-the-counter trading. They have not traded since then and have rebounded about 95 percent from a low of $2.75 on Sept. 9.

title: Devotion to Small Town Is a Way of Life for Mussina
description: Mike Mussina is doing what he has always wanted to do, pitching for the Baltimore Orioles in the playoffs in October, driving his team toward the World Series. But he has mentioned to his younger brother a wistful desire to be in two places at once, for this is football season, too, and Mussina coaches at his former high school in Montoursville, Pa.

title: THE FINE PRINT: Of Arms and Cruise Ships; In a Bill's Shipbuilding Provision, Some See a Floating Pork Barrel
description: Tucked inside a military appropriations bill signed by President Clinton this week was a provision that would give a billionaire investor a 30-year monopoly on the cruise business in the Hawaiian islands.

title: Obituary : Jean Pasqualini, Who Wrote Account of China's Gulag, Dies
description: PARIS  Jean Pasqualini, 71, who wrote a best-seller about his seven years as a prisoner in the Chinese "gulag," died in a hospital in a Paris suburb on Thursday after a long series of illnesses.

title: The Care and Feeding of Digital Behemoths
description: Litigators have been making lots of money this week, thanks to computer companies. Sun Microsystems sued the Microsoft Corporation for violating its exclusive control of the Java software used for the World Wide Web. The Justice Department is considering whether Worldcom's pending acquisition of MCI Communications would create an improper monopoly. The GTE Corporation has sued Netscape Communications and several other companies over an alleged monopoly of access to customers on the Internet.

title: Chrysler Profit Down 35%, A Little Better Than Feared
description: The Chrysler Corporation's earnings fell 35 percent in the third quarter, to $441 million, as the company prepared for the introduction of several new models while running out of the old ones.

title: Patriarch Puts Together A New Defense Team
description: Sifting through television's past for salvageable properties isn't the most admirable creative undertaking, but in ''The Defenders,'' Showtime has found an old show that's especially appropriate for renovation in the late 1990's.

title: Rutgers's Athletic Boss to Quit
description: A day after the Rutgers football team suffered a 50-3 loss to Syracuse and dropped to 0-6, Fred Gruninger, the university's athletic director for the past 25 years, announced yesterday that he would retire at the end of the academic year.

title: How a Pup Named Muffin Proves He's No Pussycat
description: Here's an idea for a children's movie. Name a bird Birdo Lucci and give him a flock of friends named Luchino, Roberto and Federico. Then name two dingo puppies Sid and Nancy. Small children who are film buffs devoted to art-house Italian directors and heroin-addict biographies are sure to howl with laughter.

title: Radiation Leaks at Hanford Threaten River, Experts Say
description: Nuclear waste has leaked out of the giant underground tanks at the Hanford nuclear reservation here and flowed deeply into the soil, and some experts are convinced that it has reached underground water supplies and is flowing toward the Columbia River.

title: Clinton Presents Proposals to Improve I.R.S.
description: Hoping to forestall more radical measures being considered in Congress, President Clinton offered a series of modest proposals today to make the Internal Revenue Service gentler to taxpayers and more efficient.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cutbacks at Westinghouse Eliminating 2,000 Jobs

title: No Party, No Wake, No Racing for Arlington
description: The strains of ''Auld Lang Syne'' accompanied the horses to the post for the last race at Arlington International Racecourse yesterday when the stylishly colonial track outside Chicago presented its final program before closing, perhaps for good.

title: Regional Airline Strike Threat
description: Pilots at Atlantic Southeast Airlines voted in favor of striking if contract talks with the carrier's parent company, ASA Holdings Inc., break down at the end of the month, the pilots' union said yesterday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-6

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Armageddon? Is There a Doctor in the House?
description: For nearly five hours in ''The Kingdom, Part 2,'' the second big chunk of Lars von Trier's supernatural medical soap opera, the forces of Armageddon gird themselves for an ultimate showdown in the corridors of a spankingly immaculate modern hospital in Copenhagen.

title: First Thing We Do, Let's Pay All the Lawyers
description: The $49 million in legal fees and costs resulting from a tobacco litigation settlement today in which the plaintiffs received no money was criticized by some legal scholars.

title: Nomura to Buy British Betting-Shop Chain
description: Nomura International P.L.C., which two weeks ago became Britain's biggest independent pub owner with the purchase of Inntrepreneur P.L.C., said today that it would buy one of the country's biggest betting-shop chains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANENBAUM, MARY MAYER
description: TANENBAUM-Mary Mayer, for 59 years beloved wife of Charles J. Tanenbaum, and loving mother of Ann Tanenbaum King. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81 Street), Sunday, October 12, at 1:00 P.M. Contributions may be made in her name to the Stanford Museum of Art, Stanford, CA. 94305-5060.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on the Theater Guide page of Weekend yesterday, with a caption about ''Mere Mortals,'' the David Ives play at the John Houseman Theater, was published in error. Nancy Opel has been succeeded by Cynthia Darlow in the play.

title: Ex-Official at Social Agency Is Accused of Embezzlement
description: A former business supervisor at a Brooklyn social service agency was indicted yesterday for embezzling more than $800,000 by submitting duplicate sets of petty cash forms and pocketing half of the money he withdrew from the agency's bank, officials said.

title: Hard-Luck Marlins? After Game 3, Hardly
description: The Florida Marlins seemed like the unluckiest first-time post-season participants in recent memory. They had lost their top pitcher and their top run producer. Another pitching ace had joined the manager in battling a debilitating illness. And they still had to face the buzz saw that was the Atlanta Braves rotation.

title: Safety Lessons For the Internet
description: Is the Internet dangerous to children? Parents across the country were asking that question after an 11-year-old New Jersey boy was sexually abused and murdered, allegedly by a 15-year-old neighbor. The teen-ager himself apparently had been the victim of a 43-year-old convicted pedophile whom he met on-line.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He has time to call the winners of the Super Bowl, but the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize he can't call?''

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Teacher Held in Sex Case
description: A Monroe High School science teacher was held on charges of criminal sexual contact after students saw him kissing and touching a 16-year-old girl in his classroom, the police said yesterday.

title: Orlando Agosti, 73, Argentine Junta Member
description: Orlando Ramon Agosti, a member of the military junta that overthrew the Government of Isabel Peron in 1976, opening one of the most violent periods in Argentina's history, died on Monday. He was 73.

title: Clinton Still Firmly Against Land-Mine Treaty
description: The White House said today that President Clinton was ''rock solid'' in his opposition to an international treaty banning all land mines, even though pressure was sure to build on the White House to reconsider after the Nobel Peace Prize was awarded to an American anti-mine activist and her organization.

title: A Legend at Home With Life and Art
description: ''When I was young, life seemed long and endless to me,'' the elderly man says.

title: Prosecutors Get Tough on Donations
description: The $8 million fine assessed this week against a Pennsylvania company for campaign finance violations, the largest such fine in history is just the latest in a string of criminal election law convictions by Federal prosecutors who have succeeded in gaining multimillion-dollar fines and even jail terms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTSCHALK, AUDREY
description: GOTTSCHALK - Audrey. Died peacefully on October 10, 1997, at age 89. Wife of the late Robert F. Gottschalk and cousin of Frances Bolton. She had a keen mind, great wit and fierce loyalties. She will be deeply missed by all those who knew her.

title: Autocratic Kazak Leader Ousts His Reformist Premier
description: The autocratic leader of Kazakstan removed his reformist Prime Minister today, prompting worry about investment in the Central Asian republic, which is rich in oil deposits.

title: Cassell Is Aiming for Victories and Respect
description: There was a time this summer when Sam Cassell nearly decided to return to the Houston Rockets and play for $1 million.

title: Despite Strict Law, Money Talks Loudly in New Jersey Race
description: For the last two decades, New Jersey's campaign finance laws have been held up as a national model for other states seeking to curb the influence of money in politics. But spending in this year's race for governor shows that even strict laws have their limits.

title: Producer Prices Exceed Forecast With 0.5% Rise
description: The Government reported today that producer prices rose at an unexpectedly steep rate in September, but analysts said the increase was mostly a result of temporary factors and did not necessarily portend a resurgence in inflation.

title: Baku Journal; Awash in Oil Wealth, But Just for the Few?
description: If there is such a thing as a sure bet in the turbulent world of oil politics, it is that Azerbaijan is going to become fabulously rich.

title: Peace Prize Goes to Land-Mine Opponents
description: The Nobel Peace Prize was bestowed today on the International Campaign to Ban Landmines and on Jody Williams, an American who coordinates it -- and the newly minted laureate immediately wielded the award to step up political pressure on recalcitrant countries, including the United States.

title: Arriving at Short and Rough From Long and Complicated
description: The heart of the trumpeter Wallace Roney's set at Birdland on Thursday night was a pair of standards, ''I Can't Get Started'' and ''I Didn't Know What Time It Was,'' utterly reimagined. Mr. Roney and his group, who will be performing through tomorrow (315 West 44th Street, Clinton), played just about every variation that could be played, turning the pop songs' simple framework into something ornate and fluid; if the music hadn't been so searching, and fundamentally honest, the process might have seemed condescending to the tunes themselves.

title: L.B.J., From the Inside
description: The publication of Lyndon Johnson's secretly recorded tapes is an important event. Unlike the Watergate tapes, which focused on a Presidency in crisis, the Johnson tapes provide an intimate portrait of a full range of Presidential activities, of matters high and low, public and personal. Covering the period between John Kennedy's assassination in November 1963 and the following August, the tapes are given further and even tragic resonance because of what the reader knows and President Johnson does not -- that Vietnam will in time destroy not only thousands of American lives but Johnson himself.

title: Seeking Unity, the Right Ignores History
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools vs. Gangs
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Problem Solved At Exit 9
description: ON a pleasant Thursday evening in Piscataway, N.J., Fred Gruninger, the 66-year-old Rutgers athletic director, stood outside his suite at beautiful but half-empty Rutgers Stadium. It was a fitting metaphor for a tenure that would end the next day, as Gruninger announced yesterday that he would resign at the end of the academic year.

title: As Ridership Increases, Officials Seek More Buses
description: With New Yorkers riding city buses in surging numbers and the prospect of even greater increases ahead, the Transit Authority next week will propose adding hundreds of new buses to its fleet of 3,800 over the next four years, transit officials and advocates for riders said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EINSON, ALBERT
description: EINSON-Albert. Lovingly and missing you. Love forever. Mina and Family

title: Judge Rules City Hall Must Surrender Records to State Comptroller in an Audit Fight
description: A State Supreme Court Justice ruled yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani must turn over city records that State Comptroller H. Carl McCall had requested in his effort to audit city agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, BERTRAND
description: GOLDBERG-Bertrand, beloved husband of the late Nancy Florsheim Goldberg; devoted father of Lisa, Nan (Nickel Van Cleve), Geoffrey (Lynne Remington) Goldberg; loving grandfather of Lillian Van Cleve and Nathan Goldberg; dear brother of the late Lucille Goldberg Strauss; fond uncle of Peter (Susan) Strauss, Ellen (William) Hunt Jr. and the late Barbara (James) Heller. Memorial services to be announced.

title: Suspect Said to Plan Fraud While in Prison
description: Serving time in the Fort Dix Federal Correctional Institution on two bank fraud charges did not stop Antonio Fasolino from devising a new plan to defraud a lender, the authorities said.

title: Editorial Notebook; 'The Bell Curve,' Revisited by Scholars
description: ''The Bell Curve'' inflamed readers when it was published three years ago by arguing that economic and social success in America had become largely a matter of genes, not education, environment or other factors over which society might exert control. The chilling genes-are-destiny thesis, laced with racial overtones, was greeted with furious criticism. But much of the initial criticism was ill informed and driven by ideology.

title: G.M.'s Check Is in the Mail, No Kidding
description: It usually works the other way, but Detroit has finally started sending customers checks for buying new cars.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a trade dispute between Canada and Mexico misstated the base of operations of Jose Cordoba Montoya, a former Mexican Government official who was linked to the controversy by the Mexican press. Mr. Cordoba, who denied involvement in the case, is based in Mexico City, not in Washington.

title: Bronx Teacher Accused of Buying Heroin During Break
description: A fourth-grade teacher in a Bronx school has been accused of buying heroin during her lunch break and a cafeteria worker in a Brooklyn school has been accused of sexually abusing two third graders, school investigators said yesterday. In a third case, a Brooklyn kindergartner reported being molested by a school custodial worker, the authorities said.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: BOOM IN BUSES -- With ridership surging since the start of free transfers, officials said the Transit Authority would propose adding hundreds of new buses to its fleet. B3.

title: A First Novel's Ambiguities Tantalize the Swiss Literati
description: In the three years since she left school at age 20 without the Swiss equivalent of a high-school diploma, Zoe Jenny has been an occasional cleaner, baby sitter and bookstore clerk in this town where the borders of France, Germany and Switzerland come together.

title: Westinghouse Industry Unit Will Cut Jobs
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, hoping to get its ailing industrial divisions in shape to survive on their own, announced yesterday that it would cut 2,000 industrial jobs, or nearly 13 percent of the industrial group's 16,000 people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ELEANOR (NEE VOLK)
description: GOLDMAN-Eleanor (nee Volk), 59, died in Florida October 8, 1997. Wife and companion of Howard Goldman, daughter of Anne and Irving Volk. Sister of Arthur Volk. Mother of David Ritter, Adam (Sharon) Ritter, Elizabeth (James) Crickey, Michelle Goldman and Adam (Jean) Goldman. Grandmother of Ryan Ritter and Rebecca Ritter. You left us much too soon and we will miss you. We love you, Ellie. Graveside services at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island, 10 A.M., Sunday, October 12th. Memorial gifts to charity of your choice.

title: Ex-Executive Who Exposed Archer Scandal Pleads Guilty
description: Mark E. Whitacre, the former Archer Daniels Midland executive who became a Government informant and exposed a global price-fixing scandal, pleaded guilty today to 37 criminal charges, including theft, money laundering, conspiracy and tax evasion.

title: LEAGUE CHAMPIONSHIP SERIES: YOU CAN GO HOME AGAIN
