description: Mike Mussina is doing what he has always wanted to do, pitching for the Baltimore Orioles in the playoffs in October, driving his team toward the World Series. But he has mentioned to his younger brother a wistful desire to be in two places at once, for this is football season, too, and Mussina coaches at his former high school in Montoursville, Pa.

title: Iranians Warily Await Reforms They Voted For
description: In May, 7 out of 10 Iranian voters cast ballots for Mohammed Khatami to be Iran's new President, with much of that majority coming from the legions of young people born since the Islamic revolution of 1979.

title: The Contagion of Dictators
description: Only seven months after its great triumph, the Serbian democratic opposition coalition Zajedno -- which means ''together'' -- has conclusively forsaken its name. Zajedno, principally led by Vuk Draskovic and Zoran Djindjic, helped organize three months of street protests against Serbia's dictator, Slobodan Milosevic, last winter. But now the two men are tearing the opposition apart. Mr. Draskovic recently helped oust Mr. Djindjic from his post as Mayor of Belgrade, which returned control of the city and Belgrade's only independent television station to Mr. Milosevic.

title: Corrections
description: A subheading yesterday with an article about the aftermath of a bungled assassination attempt in Jordan referred incorrectly to the target of the attack. Khaled Meshal, the leader of the Islamic movement Hamas, is not a sheik.

title: Giuliani and Messinger Keep Slugging on Day After Debate
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger each took time out yesterday to disparage the other's performance in Thursday night's mayoral debate in Harlem.

title: The Rangers Face Messier, With Feelings
description: When the Rangers visited the Canucks last month in the exhibition season, Brian Leetch and Mark Messier dined together the night before the game. The Rangers' current captain and their former captain then participated in an uneventful game. Both players said afterward that the intensity and passion might be different when the teams met in the regular season.

title: Messinger Fights to Stir Women; Tepid Support by Her Base Is Seen as an Ominous Sign
description: When Ruth W. Messinger rose to speak about domestic violence at the Y.W.C.A. in midtown Manhattan the other morning, it marked the fourth time in 24 hours that the Democratic mayoral candidate had campaigned before an audience of women. The room was half-filled, and as Ms. Messinger methodically laid out her program, several women dozed off while a few others slipped out the door.

title: FINANCING ARM OF BOEING PLANS TO SELL DEBT SECURITIES
description: The Boeing Capital Corporation, the commercial financing arm of the Boeing Company, filed a registration yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell as much as $1 billion in debt securities. Boeing Capital, which is based in Long Beach, Calif., and provides commercial aircraft financing and commercial equipment leasing, may decide the terms of the securities later and sell them as it needs financing under the S-3 registration it filed with the S.E.C. Boeing's stock rose 43.75 cents, to $54.3125.

title: Dancing All the Way; From Broadway to the Concert Stage
description: Ballet and modern dance choreographers have moonlighted in musical theater from the late 1920's on, from Agnes de Mille and George Balanchine through Mark Morris, the director and choreographer of the new Paul Simon musical ''The Capeman.'' Crossing over to the concert stage from Broadway is a far less common phenomenon, but Susan Stroman and Ann Reinking are bucking the trend.

title: Spanish Court Seeks 11 Argentine Officers' Arrest
description: A Spanish court issued arrest warrants today for the former chief of the Argentine Navy and 10 aides on charges of genocide during the ''dirty war'' waged by Argentine military governments of the 1970's. It ruled that the only member of the group currently in Spain, a former Argentine Navy captain, must remain in jail.

title: Dispute Over a Parking Space Ends With a Killing in Queens
description: A newspaper deliveryman was stabbed to death in Queens late Thursday night by an assailant who had apparently been beaten to a parking space and returned three hours later to take revenge, the police said.

title: Justice Dept. Gives Consent To New Lines For a District
description: The United States Justice Department announced today that it had approved a recently enacted state law that would redraw the lines of the largely Hispanic 12th Congressional District and five neighboring districts in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMBERG, DR. ALBERT E.
description: BLUMBERG-Dr. Albert E. The Congress of Senior Citizens of Greater NY deeply mourns the loss of our long-time president and friend who died October 8, 1997. Al's dedication, leadership and support for the seniors of our city will continue to remain an inspiration for the Congress of Senior Citizens. Al's commitment to the welfare of children and seniors would have him shouting from the grave, ''Don't privatize Social Security.'' Arrangements for a memorial service are being drafted for a later time. We extend our very sincere condolences to the family.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LICHTMAN, ISIDORE
description: LICHTMAN-Isidore. 9/12/'17-10/11/'94. You are always missed and will be forever loved. Phyllis, Miriam, Beverly, Judy and Paul

title: After 2 Months, Beating Victim Is Out of Hospital
description: Two months after the beating he said he suffered in a Brooklyn precinct station house made him a symbol of complaints about increasing police brutality, Abner Louima left a hospital last night under police escort.

title: Columbia/HCA Will Allow Audits of Some of Its Florida Hospitals
description: In what legal experts call a significant first step toward resolving Government investigations of the company, the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation has reached an agreement with Federal officials to cooperate with a series of financial audits of some of its hospitals in Florida, according to a confidential memorandum distributed yesterday to senior administrative executives in the state.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALEXANDER, ARTHUR
description: ALEXANDER-Arthur. In loving memory of Arthur Alexander. ''Time cannot erase the memories of moments shared.'' Ailene

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HOST MARRIOTT CORP., Bethesda, Md., a real estate company, said it had settled a lawsuit against Trinity Industries and others for $70 million.

title: New Term Seen For S.E.C. Chief
description: President Clinton has decided to renominate Arthur Levitt Jr. to another five-year term as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, a Congressman's office said today.

title: South African Gold Giants to Combine
description: Gold Fields of South Africa Ltd. and Gencor Ltd. agreed today to combine all their gold interests in a new $3.6 billion company called Goldco, which they say will rank first in world gold production.

title: A False Assumption on African AIDS Tests
description: To the Editor:

title: Fred Wang, 84, Artist and Scholar in Chinese
description: Fred Fang Yu Wang, an artist, calligrapher and expert in Chinese art who helped develop the first computer system to teach Chinese, died on Monday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 84 and lived in Manhattan.

title: BASEBALL: NOTES
description: Mets Revamp

title: Student Accused of Abuse
description: A 14-year-old boy was arrested yesterday and charged with sexually abusing a 13-year-old girl in a public school bathroom in Washington Heights last month.

title: Paine Webber Forms Top Panel
description: Paine Webber Inc. has given two of its top executives additional responsibilities and formed a new executive committee, the company said yesterday.

title: Clinton Again Vetoes Measure To Ban a Method of Abortion
description: President Clinton today vetoed legislation that would ban a form of late-term abortion, squaring off for a political fight that Republicans hope will help sustain their Congressional majorities in the 1998 elections.

title: Paterno Fears Ohio State Will Put Big Plays at Big Risk
description: Joe Paterno sounded as if he sensed his team was falling into a trap. As the Penn State coach prepared for his team to play Ohio State on Saturday, in a matchup of undefeated teams that could point the winner in the direction of a Big Ten championship, his team's success was making him nervous.

title: French Premier Proposes Cutting Workweek to Create Jobs
description: Facing an abrupt rise in interest rates that could slow the economy, the French Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, today proposed a law to cut the French workweek to 35 hours from 39 hours as a means to create jobs.

title: White Mountain Journal; A Trying Job, but the Views Are Great
description: Love the outdoors? Here's a dream job: spend the summer and early fall in a hut perched in one of the Northeast's most glorious spots, the heart of the White Mountains.

title: Millard Lampell, 78, Writer And Supporter of Causes, Dies
description: Millard Lampell, a screenwriter, novelist and songwriter who survived blacklisting to become an award-winning television writer, died on Oct. 3 at his home in Ashburn, Va. He was 78.

title: TENNIS: YESTERDAY
description: PORSCHE CUP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ROSE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Rose. Age 88. Cherished wife of Walter. Caring sister of Benjamin Rosenfeld. Also beloved by all who knew her.

title: U.S. Has Training Shortage, Not Labor Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: Op-Art; The Future Belongs to Those Who can See It
TOXIC LEASE: A special report.; How a Laundry in Harlem Became a Tainted School
description: In fall 1995, the Board of Education and Alexander Karten each had something the other desperately needed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINSTEIN, MEL
description: FEINSTEIN-Mel. On October 9, 1997. Beloved husband of Anita. Devoted father of Marc and Jeffrey. Loving son of Pearl. Dear brother of Hal and Howard and many, many friends. We love you. Services Sunday, 10AM, at ''Gutterman's Inc'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Wrangling Is Over: Dudley's A Knick
description: Chris Dudley, sounding exhausted and relieved at the same time, may have summed up the situation best. ''I think I should get an honorary degree for going through all this,'' the veteran center said.

title: Religion Journal; When Responsibility and Repentance Are Mixed
description: For a time like the late 1990's, when popular devotion to self-esteem runs so much higher than any apparent interest in humility, the word repentance has played a remarkably prominent role in public discussions over the last month.

title: JUDGE APPROVES SETTLEMENT OF FOXMEYER DRUG LAWSUITS
description: The Avatex Corporation said yesterday that a judge had approved a $33 million settlement of lawsuits filed by creditors of the Foxmeyer Drug Company over the transfer of assets from the bankrupt company. Unsecured creditors of Foxmeyer sued Avatex, formerly the Foxmeyer Health Corporation, for reportedly transferring assets out of the unit before declaring bankruptcy. The lawsuit, filed in November 1996, contended the transfers were illegal. Avatex, based in Dallas, will pay $25 million in cash and sign a three-year, $8 million interest-bearing note to compensate creditors of Foxmeyer and its former holding company as part of the settlement.

title: Netscape Executive Shift
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation said today that it had named Eric Hahn chief technology officer and executive vice president. The company said Mr. Hahn would replace the co-founder, Marc Andreessen, who was named executive vice president of the products division. Mr. Hahn was most recently senior vice president and general manager of Netscape's server products division.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Atlantic City Tunnel Planned
description: State officials and representatives of Mirage Resorts Inc. completed an agreement yesterday to construct a $330 million tunnel to improve access to a site where Mirage and two other companies plan to build casinos.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: MYRIAD GENETICS EXPECTS TO MAKE $3 MILLION ON OPTION
description: Myriad Genetics Inc. said yesterday that it would buy and sell an option for 400,000 of its own shares, a move it expects could make it as much as $3 million if its stock price rises more than 13 percent in the next 14 months. Myriad, which makes genetic tests to identify those predisposed to breast and ovarian cancer, said the terms for the call option would be established in the next week. Myriad would not disclose which financial institution it was working with. Under the expected agreement, Myriad, which is based in Salt Lake City, will be paid if its shares sell between $32 to $40 when the 14-month option comes due, said Jay Moyes, the vice president of finance for Myriad. Shares of Myriad rose 87.5 cents, to $28.625.

title: Excerpt From Independent Counsel's Report on Foster's Death
description: Following is an excerpt from a ''Summary of Conclusions'' with the report on the death of Vincent W. Foster Jr. unsealed today by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit. The report was prepared by Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel investigating Whitewater matters.

title: FOOTBALL: NOTES
description: St. John's Wins

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Convict Is Accused in Fraud
description: Serving time in the Fort Dix Federal Correctional Institution on two bank fraud charges did not stop Antonio Fasolino from hatching a new scheme to defraud a lender, prosecutors said. Mr. Fasolino, of Bayonne, was charged yesterday with lying about his assets to a Toronto investment firm to obtain a $180 million loan.

title: The N.E.A.'s Fire Hose; No Need of Government
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBEN, JUDY
description: RUBEN-Judy. Daughter of Helen and the late Dr. Samuel Rosen, wife of Albert, mother of David and Nancy, and Julie, grandmother of Hallie and Tessa, good comrade and companion. 10/9/97, aged 65. Memorial to be announced. Contributions to Monthly Review Foundation in lieu of flowers.

title: INSIDE
description: Abortion Measure Vetoed

title: U.S. Has Training Shortage, Not Labor Shortage; Missing Money
description: To the Editor:

title: CD Radio Inc. Pays License Debt to U.S.
description: CD Radio Inc. today paid the full $83.3 million it owed the Federal Government for the satellite license it won at auction April 2, clearing the way for it to begin offering its satellite radio system. The company had already paid the Federal Communications Commission $16.7 million toward its debt in April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, SYLVIA
description: PRICE-Sylvia. On October 9, 1997. Beloved wife & adored companion of the late William. Loving mother and best friend of Leslie Price Hayes. Most cherished & devoted grandmother of Elan Price Kaplan. Dearest mother-in-law of Dr. Dennis Hayes. Treasured sister of Bertram and his wife, Lilyan Weingart, and of the late Claire French. Service Sunday, 12:00 noon at the ''Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Yom Kippur, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: The N.E.A.'s Fire Hose
description: To the Editor:

title: Tory Leader Asks Delegates to Back a Conservatism That Cares
description: The new Tory leader said today that the Conservative Party had to take responsibility for its election defeat in May, and he called on delegates to the annual party conference to follow his leadership to a new conservatism ''determined to show it cares.''

title: SAMSUNG SUES U.S. UNIT OF FUJITSU OVER COMPUTER CHIP
description: The Samsung Electronics Company filed suit yesterday against a unit of Fujitsu Ltd., contending it infringed Samsung's patents covering computer chips that provide memory for personal computers. Samsung, the South Korean electronics giant, said Fujitsu Microelectronics had wrongfully appropriated protected technology behind the synchronous dynamic random-access memory chips, which provide faster access to a computer's memory. Samsung said Fujitsu Microelectronics, based in San Jose, Calif., had been making and selling the chip in the United States even though Samsung holds the exclusive license for it. In the lawsuit, filed in Federal court in Wilmington, Del., Samsung officials asked a judge to order Fujitsu Microelectronics to cease making and selling the chips. Officials of Fujitsu Microelectronics said yesterday that they were not aware of the suit.

title: Jordan's King Still Angry but Netanyahu Gains Support
description: A public opinion poll two weeks after Mossad agents bungled an attempt in Jordan to kill a leader of the militant Islamic movement Hamas suggested today that the affair had not hurt Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu politically at home. But new reports indicated that King Hussein of Jordan remained furious at what he saw as a betrayal of his friendship.

title: When Bad Economic Theory Threatens Good Times
description: Just when we thought Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, had settled into a wise laissez-faire approach to our surging economy, he warned this week that we may soon be tasting some foul medicine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLIN, SISTER FRANCES MAUREEN
description: CARLIN-Sister Frances Maureen, OP, past Superior General of the Sisters of St. Dominic of Amityville, New York, died October 9 at Carlin Hall, an infirmary named in her honor. Sister was head of the congregation from 1967-73. She was also past Academic Dean of Molloy College in Rockville Centre, NY. Sister was a scholar and historian of the Dominican Order, frequently lecturing on St. Dominic. Sister Frances Maureen is survived by her nephews Charles Kee of Rockville Centre, NY, Christopher Carlin of Connecticut, Francis Carlin of California and niece Denise Kee La Flam of New Hampshire. The Mass of Resurrection will be celebrated by Reverend Joseph Payne, O.P., on Monday, October 13, 1997 in St. Albert's Chapel at 10:30 AM. Burial will follow in the Dominican Sister's Cemetery in Amityville.

title: T. G. Klumpp, 94; Was Drug Company And F.D.A. Official
description: Dr. Theodore G. Klumpp, an executive of the pharmaceutical company Winthrop Laboratories for 31 years and a former official of the Food and Drug Administration, died on Sept. 10 at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 94.

title: Elizabeth Voves, Timothy Martin
description: Elizabeth Myra Voves, a daughter of Myra and Joseph Voves of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesterday there to Timothy Andrew Martin, a son of Johanna and Raymond Martin of Coeur d'Alene, Idaho. Msgr. Timothy McDonnell performed the ceremony at the Church of St. John and St. Mary.

title: Where the Rangers Reign and the Fans Score
description: Wait till this year. The fate of the New York Yankees doesn't much matter to Andrew J. Feldman, computer whiz and high-school sophomore. For him, the New York Rangers, whose season has just begun, are king.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, ESTELLE (NEE KIEFER)
description: LEE-Estelle (nee Kiefer), of Boca Raton, Florida, and formerly of Freeport, NY, on October 9, 1997. Beloved wife of the late James. Loving mother of Antonia Ferrucci & Maryann Daly. Loving grandmother of Lee, Michael, Susan and Richard. Dearest friend of Christopher Gilson. Reposing at Flinch & Bruns, 34 Hempstead Av, Lynbrook, NY. Visitation Monday, Oct. 13 from 2:00-4:00pm and 7:009:00pm. Mass of Resurrection at 10:00am on Tuesday, Oct. 14, at St. Joseph's Church, Garden City, NY. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: October 5-11; Shadows of Vichy France
description: With the opening of the trial of Maurice Papon in Bordeaux last week, France revisited the issue of complicity by the Vichy regime in Nazi war crimes.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: BETWEEN EACH LINE

title: Welcome Aboard!
description: It's the company welcome packet: that collection of papers, supplies and so on issued when you start work at a company. It reveals a lot about the place: A certificate for a free lunch (not to exceed $6), a towel for the company gym, a recyclable coffee cup, a 10-year-old policy statement on drug abuse. What was included in your company's package? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: U.S. Experts Suggest India Ease Military Presence in Kashmir
description: India's seven-year military occupation of the Muslim Kashmir Valley should be relaxed as a first step toward ending a guerrilla war in the disputed territory and reducing tensions with Pakistan, a group of American experts said this week.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: To Timbuktu By Mark Jenkins. Morrow, $25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GONZALEZ, MARIO
description: GONZALEZ-Mario. The officers and members of the Parent Assembly of the Society of American Magicians mourn the passing of our esteemed Compeer, devoted contributor to the Art of Magic and respected mentor to young magicians. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to his family. Frank Reyes, President Dr. Bruce Lish, First VP

title: What About The Middle Class?
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Food Stores Expand With Demand
description: TIME was when ''health,'' ''organic'' or ''natural'' in referring to food conjured up visions of flower children mixing granola. But, like the flower children themselves, ''the whole health food industry has changed dramatically since the 70's, and we're very mainstream now,'' said David Robinov, an entrepreneur who owns a half-dozen successful health food stores, including the Katonah Natural Market and Nature's Warehouse in Larchmont.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HAMILTON BEACH -- UPDATE ; Shaky House to 'Nut House' to Rebuilt Home: A Costly Trip
description: Readers of these pages may remember the account of Augustine Barry, a man who was bounced from his home to his car to what he calls ''the nut house'' after the city decided to rebuild an old wooden bridge next to his home in Hamilton Beach.

title: Catcher for Marlins Is Always at the Ready
description: Charles Johnson's Florida Marlins teammates fondly refer to him as ''Big Hungry.'' It's for the catcher's voracious appetite, but they could just as easily be talking about his work ethic.

title: DIARY
description: MARKETS

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEWDELL, CARLTON
description: YEWDELL-Carlton. Beloved husband of Florence. Loving father of Thomas and Suellen. Dear brother of the late Noel and Melvin. Cherished grandfather of Stephanie and Michael. Graveside services today 1 PM Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Fledglings at Play In First Rite of Season
description: BY this time of year, the natural world is slowing down. Bees are slowing down. Turtles are digging into the mud and snakes are crawling into crevices. But if you have an interest in Homo sapiens and its young, especially of the socially prominent variety, there is no better season to observe them. Last Wednesday, for instance, it was possible to observe many elegantly long-legged creatures flocking with their offspring into the American Museum of Natural History for its annual family party. It was the first big party for fledglings on the city's fall social calendar, and they took to it as naturally as birds to the air.

title: Beyond Sex and Violence, Back to a Place Like Home
description: IT'S A LONG WAY FROM THE working-class neighborhood in Cleveland where Joe Eszterhas was reared to the hacienda in Malibu where he now writes his multimillion-dollar screenplays. Yet Mr. Eszterhas has recently gone back to his humble roots in an effort to recharge his creative batteries and resurrect his reputation after a string of big-budget fiascos: ''Sliver,'' ''Showgirls'' and ''Jade,'' three raunchy melodramas that were almost universally derided.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ON HISTORY

title: First U.S. Doctoral Program on Holocaust Is Being Created
description: A Center for Holocaust Studies, offering the first doctoral program in Holocaust history in the United States and an undergraduate program in Holocaust and genocide studies, is being created at Clark University in Worcester, Mass.

title: Memento Mori -- but First, Carpe Diem
description: TOWARD THE END

title: Miss Yellowlees, Mr. Kennedy
description: Elizabeth Heyward Yellowlees, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Yellowlees of Atlanta, was married there last evening to Craig Lawrence Kennedy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence X. Kennedy of Goshen, N.Y. Canon Andy Anderson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of St. Philip. The Rev. Robert Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, took part in the service.

title: Inspecting And Fixing The Roof
description: MOST homeowners give little thought to the roof above their heads, and they rarely venture up to inspect the general condition of the shingles or the flashing. About 80 percent of the homes in the United States have asphalt shingles covering the roofs. Traditionally, asphalt -- also called composition -- shingles were made by saturating a heavy layer of building felt (made from organic fibers) with asphalt. These asphalt-felt shingles have largely been supplanted by fiberglass-based shingles. Instead of building felt, they have a fiberglass base impregnated with the asphalt. These shingles are more durable and will last twice as long as the felt-based shingles.

title: Top Secret Is First
description: Top Secret, a 4-year-old filly, had several strikes on her before she ran the Gallant Bloom Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park. She had not run since June, when she finished eighth in the Hempstead. She was being asked to run six and a half furlongs, her shortest distance in two years. And she was trying to outrun the sprinters Aldiza, Dixie Flag and Song of Africa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEYS, HAROLD C. JR.
description: KEYS-Harold C. Jr. of Hillside, NJ. On October 10, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Maria (Barna) Keys, father of Patrizia Ignorato, Lucio and William Keys, grandfather of Marianna, Nicholas, Paola and Laura. A funeral service will be conducted at Growney Funeral Home, 1070 N. Broad St., Hillside on Tuesday at 10 AM. Interment Evergreen Cemetery. Visiting Monday 6-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to the Pingry School, Martinsville, NJ.

title: In a Darwinian World Of Weight Control
description: ON THURSDAY, BOSTON BALLET will open its 34th season with ''Romeo and Juliet,'' the story of teen-age lovers whose passion, refracted through the prism of the prejudice and heedlessness of their elders, leads them to an early death. The performances will be dedicated to Heidi Noelle Guenther, the 22-year-old member of the corps de ballet who collapsed and died on a family trip to Disneyland last summer.

title: No Pix, No Di
description: Max Frankel overlooks perhaps the most important lesson we might learn from Diana's life and tragic death: Buckle your seat belt.

title: Forget the Lively Past: Window Makes for Uproar
description: Alternately called the Washington Irving House and the Elsie de Wolfe House, 49 Irving Place, at 17th Street, has a storied past. Although there is some question whether Irving ever actually lived in the 1850's house, there is no doubt among historians that Ms. de Wolfe, credited with founding interior design as a profession, lived and worked there, with the literary agent Elisabeth Marbury. They were said to be the most fashionable lesbian couple of Victorian New York, and, for a while, Ms. Marbury's client, Oscar Wilde, lived next door.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSS, MICHAEL
description: ROSS-Michael, October 11, 1954May 23, 1993, in loving and endless memory. Gail Hendler

title: Culture Zone; Heart of Stones
description: There's an amazing moment midway through the Rolling Stones' new ''Bridges to Babylon'' show when time doesn't just stand still but scrolls backward in fast reverse -- to 1964, the year they released their first LP and made their first American recording, in Chicago's famed Chess Studios. For a moment, the band walks away from the show's campy, Brobdingnagian set, strolls down a walkway and performs three songs from a small bandstand perched above the crowd in the very middle of Chicago's Soldier Field. For a moment, the Stones are the way they were three and a half decades ago, their roots and essence revealed: they are five guys on a tiny, spotlighted stage, and they are playing the blues.

title: ART IS DEAD
description: This month, Pam Goldblum and Jeff Kaisershot, husband-and-wife artists in Los Angeles, are showing a series of old-master-style paintings of monkeys and pigs that they ''take absolutely no credit for.'' That's because the paintings are supposedly the work of channeled spirits, a deceased 18th-century duo named Gorsky and Temeles. Pretty gimmicky, but it's working for somebody: several Gorsky and Temeleses are for sale ($2,000 and up) at Patricia Correia Gallery in Santa Monica. Any checks, of course, are made payable to Goldblum and Kaisershot. ''Gorsky and Temeles don't have an active bank account,'' Goldblum explains.

title: Pianist and His Wife Will Introduce a Series
description: TWENTY years ago, Anthony Newman played the inaugural recital on the Dutch Flentrop organ at Purchase College. Now he will be joined by his wife, Mary Jane Newman, at the harpsichord, when he ushers in a new organ series at the Performing Arts Center. Audiences at today's opener at 4 P.M. will have to follow the Newmans around: the first half of the Bach-and-Friends recital takes place in the Organ Room, where the Flentrop is stored; after intermission the music flows from the French Rieger organ in the Recital Hall of the College Conservatory. Since only 140 listeners can be accommodated, readers are advised to call the box office at 251-6200 to make sure places are available.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: From a Piano in Shoreham

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEE, AVON. ALWAYS, GABE
description: LEE-Avon. Always, Gabe

title: Notes From the Eagle's Nest
description: ON a glorious spring day in the Bavarian Alps, only a few snow-capped mountains over from where Julie Andrews sang, our party assembled for a six-hour ''health walk.'' The plan was to ascend the stunning Wimbach gorge and the valley above it, stopping along the way at Wimbachschloss, a hunting lodge built in 1784 for the last local prince.

title: Appearances; The Peace Process
description: I am sitting cross-legged in a purple-and-turquoise room that smells of incense and sweat, admiring my toenails, painted an iridescent slate called Raven (Creative Nail Design). Sharon Gannon, co-director of the Jivamukti Yoga Center on Second Avenue and 10th Street, has given us an exercise: imagine that you are God. Five minutes later, she says, ''That was interesting, and I feel guilty because everyone around me was probably having a profound experience while I was admiring my nail polish.

title: INVESTING WITH: David K. Schafer; Strong Schafer Value
description: DAVID K. SCHAFER, the slender, bespectacled manager of the Strong Schafer Value fund, has loved movies since he was a child. In his late 20's, he teamed up with a fellow money manager, David Dreman, to produce a short animated film based on a Ghanaian myth about the origin of the moon. In more recent years, he opened his Manhattan apartment for the filming of ''Working Girl.'' (Sigourney Weaver's flat in the movie was his.)

title: A Family's Hard-Candy Lessons
description: FOR Jay Tapper, the cocky young president of an upstart local candy company, and John Osher, the wealthy, autocratic stepfather he once worked for, the dynamics of family business became -- like some of the products they sell -- sticky and bittersweet.

title: Former Police Official Is Evasive on His Role
description: To the Editor:

title: October 5-11; Study on Affirmative Action
description: A study of doctors trained at the medical school of the University of California at Davis cheered beleaguered advocates of affirmative action last week.

title: October 5-11; Arrested for Spying
description: Three former student radicals who met at the University of Wisconsin's Milwaukee campus were charged last week with conspiring to commit espionage for Communist intelligence services since the 1970's. Terry Squillacote, 39, a Pentagon lawyer; her husband, Kurt Stand, 42, a international labor union representative, and Jim Clark, 49, a Pentagon paralegal turned private eye, were accused of worming their way into American military and intelligence agencies to steal secrets, primarily for the now-defunct East German spy service. They face life without parole. TIM WEINER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMBLE, THOMAS O. III
description: GAMBLE-Thomas O. III, suddenly at the age of 36 on October 5, 1997. Beloved father of Giacomo FioreGamble, son of Thomas O. Jr. and Amy Gamble of Santa Rosa, CA., husband of Janerae L. Fiore of Baldwin, N.Y., brother of Meg Gamble of San Francisco. Tom grew up in the U.S. and Japan, graduated from the Albany Academy and Pratt Institute. He lived in the NY area for the past 17 years and was working at the NY Zoological Society at the time of his death. He will be missed.

title: VIEWPOINT; Web Commerce: Be Prepared
description: ACCORDING to the cognoscenti, electronic commerce will revolutionize your business, add new revenue sources, improve customer service and enhance productivity, all the while reducing costs. All of this is possible, they say, because of the emergence of ubiquitous communications, low-cost computing, digitized content of all types and a population that is increasingly computer-literate.

title: How to Create a Windowsill Aviary of One's Own
description: House finches may seem as common as house flies to a bird watcher in a rural setting, but if you live in a small East Village apartment with only a couple of window boxes for a garden, they are a natural wonder. Their melodious chirpings are as delightful as their coloration. And they don't seem to mind human companions on the other side of an open window, as long as we stay a few feet away and keep still.

title: A Lot of Quarters: $26 Billion a Year
description: Some facts about parking in the New York City, the country and around the world, courtesy of the International Parking Institute, the City Department of Transportation, Duncan Industries and POM Inc.

title: Jets Are Pleased That Green Is Thinking Like a Safety First
description: Victor Green can stop wondering.

title: So What's Al Sharpton Really Like? Ask These Two Guys
description: Here are five things you may not know about Al Sharpton: he holds business meetings while eating a big plate of food; he lost a lot of weight but has not got around to having his suits altered, so he's swimming in them; he's a social conservative, and preaches against abortion; he's camera shy, in the sense that he will appear on camera only in situations he controls, and throughout the Democratic mayoral primary campaign, he listened exclusively to a tape loop of his favorite song, ''I Believe I Can Fly,'' whenever riding in his car.

title: Welcoming Place for 'Stone Carver'
description: IT is easy to call him a crazy old man. Even his son does.

title: Messier Made the Right Move, and Yet the Bitterness Lingers
description: The employee starts a new job in a new city. For a few years, things go great. The employee is productive, earning praise and pay raises. The company prospers as never before.

title: Federal Budget Raises Airline Ticket Prices
description: The taxes on air tickets have done some jumping around as a result of the compromise reached on the Federal budget over the summer. The net impact will be an extra $18 in the price of every round-trip international ticket. The impact on domestic ticket prices is less clear; the airlines may absorb any net reduction in the domestic tax.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Spec Houses Serve the Impatient With Deep Pockets
description: IT takes 18 months or more to plan and build the kind of house that sells in the multimillion-dollar class. But there are a lot of potential buyers who do not have the time to wait, or who are too busy with their professional lives to deal with an architect and a builder.

title: Pamela Stripay, Michael Iacono
description: Pamela Christine Stripay, the daughter of Judith and Thomas Stripay of Monroe, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Iacono, a son of Maria and Raffaele Iacono of East Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. Richard D. Murphy performed the ceremony at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in East Norwalk.

title: UNPACKING (AND REPACKING) WITH; Life's a Ball: Dress for It
description: THE question was posed: ''What about sweaters?''

title: Cassini Spacecraft Nears Liftoff, but Critics Object to its Risks
description: As NASA prepares to launch the Cassini spacecraft on Monday on a journey to Saturn, opponents continue to argue vociferously that the plutonium on board presents a dangerous risk.

title: Air Force Avoids Upset, Scoring on Blocked Punt
description: A field goal was the margin of victory, and a blocked punt turned into the winning touchdown in Air Force's 10-7 victory over Navy today.

title: The Circle of Faith and Friendship
description: THE rabbi and the pastor are kindred spirits. Their long friendship is based on a vision of a world that imposes no barriers because of religion or skin color.

title: Renee Estevez, Jason Federico
description: Renee Pilar Estevez, the daughter of Janet Sheen and the actor Martin Sheen of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Jason Thomas Federico, a son of Joyce E. McLean and Thomas B. Federico, both of Tucson, Ariz. The Rev. Matthew Faulkner, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Scapular and St. Stephen Church in New York.

title: Why Does Recruiting Post Use Times Sq. Rent-Free?
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecting Hartford and Its Neighbors
description: CONTRACTORS have been chiseling out a new food court in the century-old Richardson Building on Main Street in downtown Hartford. Down the block, Fleet Bank and Aetna have renovated office space. Nearby, Main Street Market hums with vendors, farmers and entertainers, especially in milder weather.

title: For Rabbi, 25 Years of Fitting Ancient Laws to New Ideas
description: SEARCHING for a way to explain the popularity of his Talmud class, Rabbi Arnold S. Turetsky said, ''The Bible is God-obsessed, but the Talmud is people-obsessed.''

title: Jean Lennon, Kevin Weinfurt
description: Jean Mallery Lennon, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Lennon of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kevin Phillip Weinfurt, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Phillip T. Weinfurt of Brookfield, Wis. The Rev. Daniel C. O'Connell performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Small Plane Crashes in New Jersey, Killing All Four on Board
description: Four people were killed yesterday when their single-engine plane crashed in a wooded area in Marlboro, N.J., narrowly missing a housing development, the state police said. They did not identify the pilot and three passengers, pending notification of their families.

title: The High Cost of Owning
description: HOUSING PARTNERSHIPS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RITCHIE, EVELYN JEAN (NEE ORCUTT)
description: RITCHIE-Evelyn Jean (nee Orcutt), 78, Sept. 24, 1997 at Reykjavik, Iceland. Lifelong traveler, writer, broadcaster, international public relations specialist, founder of the Women's International Network of Amsterdam, the Netherlands, dear friend to many on both sides of the Atlantic. For further details contact: 201-854-8270.

title: A Tempting Taste of a Scarce Cuisine
description: AMBASSADOR of India is well named. As an unofficial emissary, this brightly decorated restaurant has introduced many of the delights of Northern Indian cuisine to Glastonbury.

title: The Kind of Sniping That Gives Sustenance
description: MASTER funnymen in duet, Al Lewis and Willie Clark were among vaudeville's top headliners. Lewis without Clark, it was said, was like laughter without joy. Put them together and you had ''the Sunshine Boys.''

title: Frances Nuelle, Daniel Mummery
description: Frances Dorsett Nuelle, the daughter of Frances G. Nuelle of Sanibel, Fla., and the late William J. Nuelle, was married last evening to Daniel Raymond Mummery, the son of Kathleen M. Osborne of New York and Dr. Charles R. Mummery of Coral Gables, Fla. The Rev. Pamela Brownlow-Bakal, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: Charles Di Bona 2d and Penny Bodle
description: Penny Anne Bodle, the daughter of Katherine and James Bodle of Groton, Conn., is to be married today to Charles Joseph Di Bona 2d, the son of Evelyn and Charles Di Bona of Great Falls, Va. The Rev. Preston B. Hannibal, the Episcopal chaplain of St. Mark's School in Southboro, Mass., is to officiate in the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Backtalk; It's Only a Game. It's More Than a Game.
description: It ended softly. The ball left Bernie Williams's bat in the top of the ninth inning and, years later, sighed into Brian Giles's glove. One run down, two outs and a pinch-runner for my brother on second base. And it was over. The Yankees were no longer the defending world champions.

title: Occidental Makes a $95 Million Acquisition: The Boss's Contract
description: SO, it was not a misprint. On Monday, directors of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation announced that they were paying Ray R. Irani, the company's chairman and chief executive, $95 million to buy out his current contract so it could issue a new agreement that linked his pay more closely to the company's performance.

title: Repeal of U.S. Speed Limit Is Found to Raise Highway Deaths
description: In 12 tates that raised their highway speed limits in 1996, the number of deaths from automobile accidents increased by a total of 500 in the last nine months of the year, compared with a similar period in 1995, according to a study by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

title: The Great Lawn, Sown Again
description: After 60 years of service, the Great Lawn -- that 13-acre greensward at the heart of Central Park -- had simply died of abrasion. Day after day, one after another, New Yorkers carried away a few atoms of dirt upon their shoes, until all that was left was a lens-shaped depression, a giant buffalo wallow. But the greensward is green again. After a two-year, $18.2 million restoration by the Central Park Conservancy and the city's Parks and Recreation Department, a ribbon was cut Friday at 11 A.M., the gates were thrown open and the public was readmitted to the sod.

title: Q. & A.
description: Corporate Owner Of a House

title: Some Luminous Surfaces And 2 Asian Survey Shows
description: Joseph Reboli/David Ebner/Richard Newman

title: Correction
description: The quotation printed across the tops of pages 52 and 53 of The Times Magazine today, with an article about the initiation rituals of West Point cadets, misspells the name of the speaker. He is Christopher Plek enpol, not Plenkenpol. A quotation on the contents page, taken from the same article, misstates the Army rank of Daniel W. Christman. He is a lieutenant general, not a lieutenant.

title: Thy Neighbor as Thyself
description: SHTETL The Life and Death of a Small Town and the World of Polish Jews. By Eva Hoffman. Illustrated. 269 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $25.

title: Film Makers Survive a Skirmish With Revolution Buffs
description: At Fraunces Tavern on Pearl Street, where George Washington said farewell to his troops in 1783, there were no tricorner hats, no powdered wigs and, judging by the mostly smiling crowd last week, no wooden teeth. There was, however, not a little nervousness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PANETTIERE, MIRIAM C.
description: PANETTIERE-Miriam C. Of Glen Cove, LI. On October 11, 1997. Age 75. Beloved wife of Bart R. Loving mother of Denise M. Cooke (W. Robert) and Lisa S. Zebrowski (Thomas E.). Dear sister of James C. Apicella. Devoted grandmother of Zachary, Marisa, Katie, Brittany and Brett. Visting Dodge Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove, Sunday 3-5 and 7-9. Mass St. Patrick's RC Church, Monday 10 AM. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; Mother Teresa's Economics Lesson
description: THE life of Mother Teresa was in the service of the poor. And her death helps awaken us to how our own society is becoming disconnected from the plight of the economically marginalized.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 12, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Chafing Faiths in Russia's Onion Dome
description: With its onion-domed churches and imposing walled monastery, this town had long been a symbol of the Russian Orthodox faith. Nestled among quiet streams and woodlands 130 miles east of the hustle and bustle of Moscow, it conveys a quiet serenity.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: HORROR MUSEUM

title: One By One
description: Many moviegoers recall Robert Hamer's KIND HEARTS AND CORONETS (1949) erroneously. No: Alec Guinness wasn't the protagonist of this British comedy gem. Dennis Price was, as a black-sheep heir who polishes off eight legacy-obstacle relatives. Guinness brilliantly mimed all eight. There's also a final ironic twist that the British serve better than anyone else. But the Guinness gallery makes the fun memorable, from a doddering admiral (above) to a bewigged suffragette dropping leaflets from a balloon. Mr. Price calmly tilts a bow and arrow, telling us: ''And Lady Agatha went down in Berkeley Square'' -- FRIDAY at MIDNIGHT on Channel 21. Howard Thompson

title: Half-Marathon Man
description: HARRY POLITES of Ventnor is perfectly content to sleep late. A widower in his 17th year of retirement, Mr. Polites, 87, doesn't need an excuse to goof off.

title: A New Season for the Orchestras
description: FOUR orchestras begin their new seasons on Saturday night.

title: THEATER; Sisters, United: Step Right Up!
description: The musical ''Side Show,'' which opens Thursday at the Richard Rodgers Theater on Broadway, offers more than a glimpse of carnival life in the 1930's. With a score by Henry Krieger (who wrote the music for ''Dreamgirls''), book and lyrics by Bill Russell, and choreography by Robert Longbottom, who also directs, it was inspired by the lives and careers of the Hilton sisters (played by Alice Ripley and Emily Skinner).

title: A Day That Began at the River Ends in the Hot Tub
description: A day -- Tuesday, Oct. 7 -- in the life of Larry Goldman.

title: Have Guitar, Will Picket
description: The awning at Arlene Grocery on Stanton Street in the Bowery advertises ''frutas y vegetales,'' but for the last year, the place has been a thriving night spot, offering live music free. Therein lies the rub. Some musicians who play there say what is good for the patrons is not so good for the bands, which are not paid for performing.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Mercedes-Benz ML320; Star of Sport Utilities Is Suddenly 3-Pointed
description: BEST you think the new ML320 ''all activity vehicle'' is not a true Mercedes-Benz, check out the big, bold three-pointed star embedded in the plastic grille. The badge is a whopping eight inches in diameter, just so no one misses the point: although this is a different kind of vehicle for Mercedes, and it comes from Tuscaloosa, Ala., instead of Stuttgart, Germany, it is a Mercedes nonetheless.

title: When Brando Came to Town
description: Wearing a big white bow on her head and a flower print dress, Nancy Cambria kisses the Godfather on his right cheek, and he kisses her. With her back to the camera, all we see is her tidy hairdo, but Marlon Brando is in full view.

title: Taking a Turn Into Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: New Worshipers Are Bane, Not Balm, for Old Synagogue
description: For years, the approach of Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish New Year, was a marker of a doomed destiny at Congregation Tifereth Israel, the last synagogue in Corona. Each year, old members died and no new ones arrived to take their places. The paint began to peel and the grass grew longer. So each Rosh ha-Shanah, worshipers at the synagogue, near 108th Street and 54th Avenue, prayed for new people to come and save their synagogue.

title: $5,000 on My Credit Card? But Mom, It's for Tuition
description: WHEN Marc Fox's tuition bill came due recently, there was no scramble to drain savings accounts, sell stock or apply for a bank loan. His father, David, simply pulled a Mastercard from his wallet, called the University of Maryland and said ''charge it.''

title: The Case Against Tipping
description: In New York, tipping cabbies, regardless of the service, is a habit so entrenched there is no longer an alternative. However, if I don't get back even some small sign of appreciation -- even a friendly grunt -- I just step out on the curb side and leave the door open. Makes me feel good for the rest of the day.

title: Our Towns; Working Girls Keep Finding A Way Back
description: THE prostitutes keep coming back to Tonnelle Avenue. They get swept up by the police. They disappear. Then here they are all over again.

title: 'Zen and the Beat Way'
description: To the Editor:

description: Rocket Man

description: SAVADSKY-Edna. Loving wife, mother, grandmother. Devoted employee of many years at Park Surgical Company. The Dube Family Park Surgical Company

title: The Nation; Attention The G.O.P. Can't Use
description: AFTER months of tales about how fat-cat donors slept in the Lincoln Bedroom and mingled at (videotaped) coffees at the White House, and how the President and Vice President played central roles in the interminable hunt for donations in the 1996 campaign, it may seem that Republicans have the upper hand on the issue of campaign finance.

title: Comedy Nights At the Thalia? It's No Joke
description: The Thalia, once a beloved Upper West Side institution, has seen the lights dim on its various reincarnations since it closed as an art-film movie house a decade ago. Now the theater on West 95th Street, where moviegoers once went to see the latest pictures starring Bette Davis and Charlie Chaplin, is open again, featuring films from India and comedy acts, mostly on weekends.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE SECRET BOOK OF GRAZIA DEI ROSSI By Jacqueline Park. Simon & Schuster, $25.

title: New Rochelle League Welcomes Agency
description: Regarding the article ''Changes in Parking Plan Could Imperil Health Agency'' on Sept. 7, the League of Women Voters of New Rochelle wants those in New Rochelle and all other readers to know that we heartily welcome the county's Department of Health to New Rochelle.

title: The Forbidden City Gets a Face Lift
description: OF all China's illustrious and history-rich places to visit, perhaps none is quite so stunning in scope and design as the Forbidden City, the palace complex where emperors once lived and ruled.

title: Security Risk
description: BOB THE GAMBLER

title: Bill Kraus and Jennifer Plath
description: Jennifer Lynn Plath, a daughter of Warren J. Plath of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., and the late Margaret W. Plath, is to be married today to Charles William Kraus, a son of Pamela and Robert Kraus of New York. The Rev. Marjorie Bowens-Wheatley, a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to officiate at the Otto Kahn mansion in New York.

title: In the Workplace, Power and Sex
description: SEXUAL harassment is an old story to several women who gather every other week in the office of a psychologist, Dr. Barbara Moynihan, in Branford. They talk about incidents that have left them feeling abused, angry, and, in many cases, unemployed.

title: Julie Semones, David Robb
description: Julie Dee Semones and David Robb were married on Thursday at their house on Shelter Island, N.Y. The Rev. William Grimbol, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Christiane Shipley, Mitchell Wade
description: Christiane Denyse Shipley is to be married today to Mitchell John Wade at the Central Presbyterian Church in Summit, N.J. The Rev. Joel R. Yoss, a Lutheran minister, is to perform the ceremony. The Rev. Thomas Boone, a Presbyterian minister, will take part in the ceremony.

title: Katherine Wilson, Richard Meyer
description: Katherine Newton Wilson, a daughter of Barbara L. and William N. Wilson of Chatham, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Richard Warfield Meyer, a son of Janan and Gary E. Meyer of Salinas, Calif. The Rev. Herbert G. Draesel, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Holy Trinity in New York.

title: Sculpture Biennial at Purchase With Pizazz and Imagination
description: THE Neuberger Museum at Purchase College here has produced its first public sculpture biennial. But visitors beware: Do not leave home without wheels, comfortable shoes and the promise of fine weather. What lies ahead is not just an exhibition of 27 pieces -- more if those drawn from the museum's collection are counted -- but also a tour of the college grounds where most are displayed, and it is quite a haul.

title: Portfolio Prescriptions
description: State Street Global Advisors, which runs the SSgA family of funds, is leading the way for large mutual fund companies into the new world of medical savings accounts.

title: Greenburgh Offers Help To Animal Shelter
description: Thank you for the article about the Elmsford Animal Shelter (Sept. 14).

title: 'Toward the End of Time'
description: FIRST SNOW: it came this year late in November. Gloria and I awoke to see a fragile white inch on the oak branches outside the bathroom windows, and on the curving driveway below, and on the circle of lawn the driveway encloses-the leaves still unraked, the grass still green. I looked into myself for a trace of childhood exhilaration at the sight and found none, just a quickened awareness of being behind in my chores and an unfocused dread of time itself, time that churns the seasons and that had brought me this new offering, this heavy new radiant day like a fresh meal brightly served in a hospital to a patient with a dwindling appetite.

title: On Intellectual Property: A Marxist Brief
description: Groucho Marx was very pleased when the Library of Congress told him it wanted his papers. He would have been especially pleased Tuesday evening when one of his many letters was read aloud, between letters by Jefferson and Lincoln, as the Library began its bicentennial celebration.

title: October 5-11; A Pill and a Pucker
description: Drinking grapefruit juice could affect your health. Some prescription drugs become so potent when taken with it that some scientists have called for specific warning stickers on pill bottles to avoid possible overdoses.

title: How Dinosaurs Found a Home On an Oil Storage Tank
description: NOW drivers on Interstate 95 in New Haven can see what is being billed as the world's largest natural history mural of dinosaurs: ''The Age of Reptiles,'' by Rudolph Zallinger.

Agnew Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Steven Weisse Schelling, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Schelling of Winchester, Mass. The Rev. Gerald F. Greaves, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Holy Family Chapel of the College of St. Elizabeth in Convent Station, N.J.

title: Ms. Karamanos, Dr. Brier
description: Teresa Stephanie Karamanos, a fund-raising consultant in New York, was married on Friday to Dr. Stephen Burnett Brier, a social historian. Edward Hanaberry, a town justice of Shelter Island, N.Y., officiated at the Ram's Head Inn there.

title: How a Daughter's Account Has Divided a Family
description: Q. I'm a 25-year-old starving student in New York. Last year my parents removed $30,000 from my UGMA account because they disapprove of my life style. I got stuck with the tax bill, and a lawyer advised me that it's not worth trying to get the money back. What can I do?

description: When the National and American Leagues play their championship series a year from now and then send their winners against each other in the World Series, the opponents each step of the way will be recognizable to themselves and fans as opponents who represent the units they have always represented.

title: More Choose Creation, Though Cost Can Rival Burial
description: FUNERALS were once mostly simple affairs: a pine coffin, a few friends and family members, a donation to the preacher, a modest bill from the undertaker. Nowadays, a full-service funeral and burial can cost as much as a small wedding.

title: Ms. Castagnoli, David Moore

title: Now, the Anti-Barbie
description: At noon on Oct. 3, as people walked by the Body Shop at Broadway and 76th Street, heads turned. The cause of the stir was a poster of Ruby (as in Rubenesque), the company's new icon designed to make women not built like supermodels appreciate themselves. The image, whose voluptuous body also graces magnets and postcards (detail above), was introduced last year in Europe and Australia, and last month in the United States.

title: Gip Hoppe
description: Hoppe is a playwright who lives on Cape Cod. His comedy ''Jackie: An American Life'' opens in New York next month.

title: Helen Poole and Richard Corroon 2d
description: IN New York City, perhaps more than many places, a heavy snowfall can change everything. City streets suddenly look as quaint as village lanes; parking rules are suspended, and so is the usual reserve between strangers. It seems the more it snows and the chillier it gets, the warmer New Yorkers become.

title: Terence Hosten and Shani Williams
description: Shani Talese Williams, the daughter of Claudette M. Williams of Richmond and Reginald L. Brown of Vienna, Va., was married yesterday to Terence Borah Hosten, a son of Patricia C. Hosten of White Plains and the late E. Borah Hosten. The Rev. Earl L. Bledsoe performed the ceremony at Great Hope Baptist Church in Richmond. The Rev. Robert O. Simpson, a United Methodist minister and the bride's cousin, took part in the service.

title: Special Education Is Not A Scandal
description: I don't have to imagine a classroom where all the children, save one, are nondisabled. My son Jesse is that disabled child -- he uses a wheelchair, sometimes drools and reads and writes less well than many -- but not all -- of his classmates. Yet, I am pleased he's there rather than in a ''self-contained'' special education classroom for children with ''multiple disabilities.'' Life -- and teaching -- is far more complicated than your article suggests. A carefully planned and supported program of inclusion does meet my son's needs, allowing him to progress while he, his classmates and his teachers explore the ways human similarities abrade human differences. And this works for Jesse and, their parents tell me, the other kids.

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: NIM AND THE WAR EFFORT. By Milly Lee. Illustrated by Yangsook Choi. Frances Foster/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16. (Ages 6 and up) It's the last day of the newspaper drive and Nim, a Chinese-American girl in San Francisco during World War II, is determined to win. Her nearest rival has cheated. Undaunted, she leaves Chinatown and walks up Nob Hill after school, determined to find more scrap newspaper. Nim's sweet seriousness and ingenuity are captured in the text and in the luminous, grave illustrations.

title: Turning an Old Silo Into a Wine Cave
description: LAST year, when Carole Winer moved her shop, Country Loft Antiques, into the circa 1706 Samuel Bull Homestead in Woodbury (a 19-acre compound of houses, barns and a silo) she held a decorator show house to benefit Paul Newman's Hole in the Wall Camp and the Michael Bolton Foundation.

Long termed, honored empolyee of Macy's. Service Sunday, 11:45 AM, at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam AVe.

title: Le Humidor
description: When a woman embraces a man wearing the Cigar Jacket, she may find out that she has been deceived. That thick-looking chest? Only inside pockets full of cigars, cigar cutter and lighter.

title: Special Education Is Not A Scandal
description: Special education is a scandal and Brent Staples points to why. When the ''whole language'' craze jettisoned the drill-and practice component that 40 percent of American children need to learn reading,'' the growing ranks of poor readers created a huge pool of learning-disabled ''customers'' that has become increasingly expensive to service. The edu-cational juggernaut now proposes ''mainstreaming'' more severely disabled children to cut costs. Can't we just bring back phonics, and quickly?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, JANE L.
description: BERGER-Jane L. Beloved wife of the late Irwin. Devoted mother of Sherri Rothstein, Meredith, Ruth and Stacey Berger. Loving daughter of Pearl Novak. Cherished grandmother of Ilana and Rachel. Dear sister of Jay Novak. Services Monday, 10AM, at The Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris, Inc., 21 E. Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, L.I.

title: Penn State And Enis Show Resolve In Comeback
description: The preservation of their perfect season required qualities that the Penn State Nittany Lions had not yet shown they possessed. There had been no need to call upon them until today.

title: Six Days to Curtain
description: TEN years ago, it was just a gritty edge of downtown Newark, and a dream. Eight months ago, it was a work in progress, a complex of cold concrete floors, miles of wires and seatless auditoriums resounding with the music of buzz saws where violins and piccolos would be heard someday. On Saturday night, the New Jersey Performing Arts Center becomes a glittering reality, raising the curtain on a new era of possibility for the arts and for the city.

title: Joannes ter Haar and Ann Riposanu
description: Ann Maria Riposanu, a vice president and the deputy general counsel at the K-III Communications Corporation, the New York publishing company, was married yesterday to Joannes ter Haar, a partner in the Frankfurt office of Clifford Chance, a law firm. The Rev. Dr. William M. Johnson performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Southampton, N.Y.

title: Mellowing on a Canadian Isle

I told her I was going to a holistic retreat center called Hollyhock off the coast of British Columbia, where the rule at the beach is clothing optional. They also offer workshops, I said: Green Witch Week and Communicating With Animals.

description: Seven Years in Tibet

Murray, formerly of Yonkers, New York. Brother of Janet. W.W. II veteran of Camp Carson, Colorado. Burial Calverton National Cemetery. For information contact Bryant Funeral Home, Setauket and Committee, Theodore G. Bushell, Northport, New York.

title: 6 Days to Curtain: An Arts Center's Debut; Fine-Tuning the Hall: A Process That Never Ends
description: The New Jersey Performing Arts Center is about complete; all that's left to do is hope. And if you believe that, there's a bridge in Brooklyn you might want to buy. As the countdown to opening night nears zero, teams of stagehands, acousticians, musicians, caterers and movers are among hundreds so busy that they hardly have time for hope. They'll bring it in on time, but it will be close.

title: Thrill-Seekers' Natural Wonder
description: A SUNSET cruise on the Zambezi? Who with $25 to spare could resist? And for the first hour it delivers all the magic the name implies -- a languid ride along a seemingly pristine African river.

title: Funds for Court Design Approved
description: WITH what the lawmakers described as a gun to their heads, the County Board of Legislators has approved the next step in the overhaul and expansion of the County Courthouse, a construction project that could be the most expensive government project in county history.

description: Rick Pitino, the great savior of bad basketball teams, left the University of Kentucky this past May to coach the Boston Celtics of the N.B.A.

title: White House Tape Crews at Eye of Storm
description: The camera crews of the White House Communications Agency are active-duty members of the military services, trained to record combat and high-risk training operations for the Pentagon's archives.

title: Traffic Problems Begin With Us
description: Odd species, we. The articles regarding the widening of Route 25A [''State Plans for Route 25A Meet Opposition'' and ''How the Towns View Changes to Route 25A,'' Oct. 5] highlight our inability to take responsibility for our own actions.

title: Lace Up, Slip On, Step Out
description: GETTING into a tuxedo requires a kind of grin-and-bear-it fortitude, what with those microscopic studs, the always-missing cuff link and the how-in-heck-do-I-tie-a-bow-tie issues. But there is a payoff: Every man looks good in a tux. The one problem is the shoe.

title: Haiku Populi
description: ''THE poet's pen,'' William Shakespeare wrote, ''gives to airy nothing a local habitation and a name.''

title: Bumbling Columbia Is Routed At Home
description: That Columbia fumbled on its first two snaps should have given the Lions a hint of what was to come yesterday. What followed only confirmed the problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANE, ANNE
description: SHANE-Anne. We deeply mourn the untimely death of our dear friend and respected colleague, who has enriched our lives for many years. We shall miss the light she brought to everything, and the daily pleasure of her warmth and caring. Our deepest sympathies go out to her children, Michael, Stephen (Jasmine), Joseph, and her entire family for their irreplaceable loss. Andy and Norman Cohen and everyone at the Mortgage Publishing Group

title: Checking and Repairing the Roof
description: MOST homeowners give little thought to the roof above their heads, and they rarely venture up to inspect the general condition of the shingles or the flashing. About 80 percent of the homes in the United States have asphalt shingles covering the roofs. Traditionally asphalt, also called composition, shingles were made by saturating a heavy layer of building felt (made from organic fibers) with asphalt. These asphalt-felt shingles have largely been supplanted by fiberglass-based shingles. Instead of building felt, they have a fiberglass base impregnated with the asphalt. These shingles are more durable and will last twice as long as the felt-based shingles.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Think of a Walpurgis-Mart For One-Stop Sorcery

description: Jennifer Amato Loveman and Gregory Donald Manthei are to be married this afternoon in Newton, Mass. The Rev. G. Truman Welch, an Episcopal priest, is to perform the ceremony at the Church of the Good Shepherd.

description: LARRY FOX, the owner of a small Brooklyn company that distributes paper products to party-supply stores, grew up in Flatbush but until recently had not been near the waterfront in Sunset Park in 10 years. He had been storing goods in Kearny, N.J., although he garaged his trucks on Neptune Avenue in Brooklyn, and he was looking for a place in which to consolidate operations.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Beauty and Truth in Boston
description: Published to mark the centenary of the founding of Boston's Society of Arts and Crafts, and the earliest American Arts and Crafts exhibition in 1897, INSPIRING REFORM: Boston's Arts and Crafts Movement (Davis Museum and Cultural Center/Abrams, $75) documents what Marilee Boyd Meyer in a foreword calls ''a pattern of New England connections . . . affirming Boston's role as a catalyst in the popularization of the Arts and Crafts movement in America.'' Founded in Britain in the 19th century and spearheaded by luminaries like William Morris and John Ruskin, the Arts and Crafts movement called for esthetic and social reform in reaction to the decline in craftsmanship and dehumanization of labor that accompanied the Industrial Revolution. Boston's primary contribution, Meyer writes, was not style but the transmission of ideas through education; by 1900, for example, Boston area colleges (including Harvard) were offering public enrollment in summer art classes. The Society of Arts and Crafts, Boston, numbered some 1,000 members in its first two decades, and one of the charms of this book is its brief biographies of many of those men and women; among the better-known members whose work is discussed are the painter and printmaker Arthur Wesley Dow and the photographer F. Holland Day. Informative essays explore pottery, woodcarving, furniture and jewelry making, metalworking and bookmaking. This elegant book, with its handsome design and more than 200 photographs, is itself an Arts and Crafts artifact. Robin Lippincott

title: A Moment of Pause Between a Bleak Past and a Hopeful Future
description: What comes next? And how soon?

title: No Pix, No Di
description: Perhaps it is the shared affliction of being male, old and comfortable, but I couldn't agree more with Max Frankel's honest appraisal in ''No Pix, No Di'' (Word & Image, Sept. 21).

title: A Refurbished Van Cortlandt Park Begins Its Comeback
description: Nobody knows whether a $1.5 million renovation has made Van Cortlandt Park's historic cross-country course faster, but it is definitely safer.

title: Dishes That Celebrate the Bounty of the New World
description: COLUMBUS DAY weekend is an appropriate time to celebrate the culinary legacy of the Western Hemisphere. Who does not know that tomatoes, potatoes, corn, beans, squashes and peppers are New World crops unknown in Europe before 1492?

description: To the Editor:

description: Over the next month or so, thousands of area residents -- mostly retired, mostly in pairs -- will migrate from their roosts in the city and fly south in search of warm weather and a winter tan.

description: David Schmitt, a waiter at Broadway Joe's, often gets double takes from baffled customers who think he is Harrison Ford.

description: HIGHBLOOM-Sidney. The partners and staff of Hecht and Company note with deep sorrow the passing of Sidney Highbloom, who had been associated with the firm in various capacities for over 20 years. Sidney's pride in his work was matched by his great sense of humor and those who worked with him on a daily basis have suffered the loss of a friend. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Hecht and Company PC

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, MORRIS
description: SINGER-Morris. Age 89. Beloved husband of the late Thelma Keller Singer. Devoted father of Charles and Peter, grandfather of Mark, Todd, Guy and Samantha. Loving son of Hyman and Fanny. Brother of Ann and the late Molly, Harry, Irving and Leonard. Caring and loyal to countless friends, he inspired affection in all who met him. He will be deeply missed but lovingly remembered.

Mother of David Ritter, Adam (Sharon) Ritter, Elizabeth (James) Crickey, Michelle Goldman and Adam (Jean) Goldman. Grandmother of Ryan Ritter and Rebecca Ritter. You left us much too soon and we will miss you. We love you, Ellie. Graveside services at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island, 10 A.M., Sunday, October 12th. Memorial gifts to charity of your choice.

title: A Vote of Confidence For Mortimer Levitt
