description: UPPER EAST SIDE

title: BOOKEND; The History of a Historical Novel
description: Browsing through a recent birthday present -- the Oxford Companion to the Mind -- one afternoon in the summer of 1988, I read a short essay on the 18th-century physician and showman Anton Mesmer, inventor of ''mesmerism'' and for a time darling of the beau monde, the Timothy Leary of prerevolutionary Europe. Something in the character of this man, his eccentricity and the pathos of his story so impressed me that I wrote to the author of the essay -- a Professor Zangwill -- requesting more information. Six weeks later my letter was returned. Professor Zangwill had become the late Professor Zangwill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENKRANTZ, THEA (NEE SCHWARZ)
description: ROSENKRANTZ - Thea (nee Schwarz) wife of late Ernest on October 10, 1997 six days after her sixty-ninth birthday. She leaves a legacy of love and devotion to eight children: Robert, Gary, Wayne, Clark, Kevin, Deborah, Selma and Cora. Sons-in-law: Steve, Jim and Ronald. Daughtersin-law: Carol and Diane. Grandchildren: Susan, Mark, Jason, Scott, Laura, Douglas, Gregory, Joseph, Jeffry, Benjamin, Heather, Michael, Evan and Rachel. Great grand-children Alissa and Emily. Brothers Cary and Ralph Schwarz, their wives Sarah and Ruth. More than thirty nieces and nephews. She was a beautiful lady with a sweet smile. She will be missed by everyone who knew her. Services: Parkside Chapel, 9860 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, Queens, 10 AM Sunday, October 12.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A surprising version of a best-selling novel, an adroit caper about a Broadway producer, a festive musical and a darkly engrossing melodrama stand out on the television screen this week.

title: Abuse Case Leaves 2 Adopted Girls in Limbo
description: As the case against an Arizona couple accused of abusing their newly adopted Russian daughters on a flight to New York City drags into its fifth month, the girls have been on their own strange odyssey in the United States. They have had to make six moves among four foster homes in two states, staying in two of the homes for only a few days.

title: Behind Bars
description: PRISON JOURNAL

title: The 'Flame of Flamenco' Keeps Alive a Tradition
description: SEVILLE'S BRILLIANT SUN CAN'T penetrate the plain, cavelike building where the renowned flamenco dancer Cristina Hoyos rehearses. It's a dark, intimate space, reminiscent of the Gypsy camps where the art developed here in southern Spain in the early 19th century. Ms. Hoyos, 51, grew up in Seville, weaned on flamenco songs played on the family radio, and later, performing in shows at local restaurants. During that period in Spain, the dictator Francisco Franco forbade everything, Ms. Hoyos recalled. ''He said real flamenco was decadent and only allowed tourist versions. I determined when I was young that I would keep the roots strong.''

title: A Sitcom Is a Sitcom
description: To the Editor:

title: Deborah Norville on the Rebound
description: DEBORAH NORVILLE would like to be a typical Long Island mother. ''I've gone on field trips with my son Niki's class,'' she said. ''But the last time I went on a field trip I went into early labor.''

title: 'Veronica's Closet' Has the Cats on Edge
description: MY cat Antonia is furious. She says, ''How come Kirstie Alley has an ancient bulldog pulling a wagon in her new sitcom and all I get to do is eat scientifically approved Iams Cat Chow and walk on all fours around this house?''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YASSKY, BESSIE
description: YASSKY-Bessie. Oct. 12, 1992. Forever loved, mourned and missed. We always see your beautiful face and smile. Elmer, Peggy and Lauri Ellias

title: Festival to Stress Water as Lifeline
description: IN recognition of the 25th anniversary of the Federal Clean Water Act and to heighten awareness of the fragile nature of the county's watersheds, a free multimedia festival celebrating the Croton watershed will take place next Saturday from 6 to 8 P.M. at Marymount College in Tarrytown.

title: The Innocent Approach to an Adult Opus
description: THERE'S A HISTORICAL BIT OF film that Paul Thomas Anderson has been trying to track down for most of his adult life. He was only 10 years old when this fixation began: while visiting his grandmother, who lived just down the block from his family's home in Studio City, Calif., he noticed that the windows of a house across the street were blacked out and that several light stands stood on the front lawn. The neighbors explained to Mr. Anderson why. ''They told me that a porno movie was being shot,'' he said. ''And I clearly remember thinking, 'Wow! I want to see what's going on in there.' ''

title: Partitioning Bosnia Rewards Ethnic Cleansing; Remember Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Journey to the Center of the Egg
description: Christiane Nusslein-Volhard has a peculiar hobby for a world-renowned biologist: she makes her own jigsaw puzzles. In her apartment in the old millhouse of a 14th-century monastery near Tubingen, Germany, she spreads 173 puzzle pieces out on a table. The room is sparsely furnished: a music stand, bookcases full of art books and in the corner an aquarium with some small striped fish. The jigsawed image is supposed to be a detail from a Bruegel painting, but by cutting the pieces along the picture's lines and colors, eliminating any identifiable connectors, Nusslein-Volhard has made a puzzle so subtle and complex that I can't imagine where to begin.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Can't Steer From the Back Seat of Life
description: Relationships in varying degrees of stress or disintegration are a recurring concern in NOT HER REAL NAME (Anchor, paper, $12), a debut collection of 12 moody short stories by Emily Perkins, a young New Zealander who now lives in London. Kicking off with the title selection, about a financially challenged waitress who ends up sharing her apartment with a man she had an adolescent crush on years before, Perkins goes on to present a variety of disgruntled protagonists amid a variety of settings. Among the more memorable yarns are ''After McDonald's,'' a painfully funny account of two talent-free former employees of the Golden Arches on a quest for fame, and ''A Place Where No One Knows Your Face,'' which perfectly captures the impatient stream-of-consciousness ramble of a child trapped in the back seat of the car on a family vacation. Perkins exhibits a flair for subtle details, deployed in concentrated blasts. Not surprisingly, most of the work in ''Not Her Real Name'' reflects that familiar mid-20's feeling of edgy dissatisfaction with one's personal status quo, often accompanied by a vague sensation of confusion. But while many of Perkins's stories are tinged with a hint of melancholy, they also display strong threads of optimism and humor. And so, in ''The Shared Experience,'' when a discontented secretary finally wakes up and takes charge of her life after a drunken one-night stand with her boss, she vows not only to ''get a life'' but ''a hamburger as well.'' J. D. Biersdorfer

title: Style; Orientation Week
description: Dear Diary: It's the first day back and gosh, are there a lot of new kids. I just met this totally artsy, peace-and-love hippie chick named Stella McCartney. She showed me her sketches for Chloe -- all these swishy bell-bottoms and tunics, in rad colors like aqua and pink! She said her mom used to wear Chloe back in the 70's. She was some peace-and-love hippie chick, too. Later, at lunch, I saw Karl in the cafeteria and he was telling everybody that Stella's dad is some old British rock star, and that's the only reason she got the job. Meeeow!

title: SOAPBOX; After-School Meetings
description: I HAVE a friend, a high school psychologist, who refuses to dine in one of the most popular restaurants in town. He lives in terror of being handed a glass of water by a busboy whom he counsels for a drug problem.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 14 about the No. 63 bus in Paris misidentified one Left Bank street on the route. It is the Boulevard St.-Germain, not the Boulevard St.-Michel.

title: Freight President Arrested Over Shipment of Pesticide
description: Federal prosecutors have arrested the president of a freight forwarding company in Miami and accused him of trying to illegally ship as passenger baggage 500 pounds of a corrosive pesticide on a passenger jet, with the warning labels covered over with black plastic.

title: Editors' Note
description: A review of a biography of Rachel Carson in The Times Book Review last Sunday discussed the reasons her predictions of environmental calamity did not come to pass. It said, at one point, that ''society heeded her warning.''

title: PROPERTY CRIMES STEADILY DECLINE, LED BY BURGLARY
description: With little public notice, property crime in the United States has fallen sharply since 1980, data from the Federal Bureau of Investigation show, with burglary rates down by almost half. That gives New York a lower burglary rate than London, and Los Angeles fewer burglaries than Sydney, Australia.

title: BENEFITS
description: For Cancer Research

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBEN, JUDY
description: RUBEN-Judy. The rarest of treasures and most wonderful, loving friend and human being who brought extraordinary joy into our lives and the lives of so many. We shall miss her infinitely. We embrace and love her soulmate and our dear friend Al and their most special children and grandchildren, Julie, David, Nancy, Hallie and Tessa. Donna Nevel and Alan Levine

title: The Case Against Tipping
description: My employees are polite to everyone -- even the occasional customers who place large, complicated orders, yet feel that it's too much of a burden on their good natures to drop something in the tip jar -- or even to say thank you.

title: After Years on the Fast Track, A Career at a Crossroads
description: IT SEEMS A BIT PERVERSE: ALMOST everyone who talks or writes about the mezzo-soprano Cecilia Bartoli uses the term ''diva,'' but most do so only to suggest what Ms. Bartoli supposedly is not: the flighty, temperamental, impossibly demanding prima donna so beloved of operatic lore. Despite her meteoric rise over the last decade, such commentators insist, the 31-year-old Ms. Bartoli remains utterly unspoiled, down-to-earth, intimately tied to home and hearth.

title: For Best-Selling Author, What's in a Name?
description: TODD STRASSER enjoys a curious kind of fame. An award-winning author of more than 90 books, with 20 million copies in print and translations in 12 languages, Mr. Strasser maintains a ubiquitous presence on bookshelves without quite managing to be a household name. The gap between success and celebrity may be because of the age of his readership, which ranges from about 8 to 16.

title: POP VIEW; Britpop Spiced With Asian Flavor
description: FROM THE BEATLES AND ROLLING STONES IN the 60's to Oasis and Blur in the 90's, America experiences at least one new British invasion per decade. In a time-honored tradition, mop-topped bands with attitude have conquered Britain and then America, using a basic formula -- pilfer ideas from American rockers and bluesmen, throw in a few twists, then spin them back out as a hip new phenomenon.

title: Anne Motta, Robert Yamins
description: Dr. Anne Patricia Motta, the daughter of Josephine Motta of Ozone Park, Queens, and the late Alvaro Motta, is to be married today to Robert Joseph Yamins, the son of Frieda K. Yamins of Freeport, N.Y., and Jacob L. Yamins of Sunderland, Mass. M. Michael Grupp, a leader of the Society for Ethical Culture, is to officiate at the Church Center for the United Nations in New York.

title: Commercial Property/West Chelsea; Ex-Garages Attracting Art Galleries From SoHo
description: THE gritty industrial neighborhood of West Chelsea between 10th and 11th Avenues and from 20th to 26th Streets is sporting a new look these days. New owners are taking unused former garages and warehouses and converting them into art galleries in hopes of luring buyers from more established gallery locations.

title: Dawn Fratangelo, Eric Wishnie
description: Dawn Marie Fratangelo, a correspondent for the television news show ''Dateline NBC'' in New York, and Eric Reed Wishnie, a segment producer for ''NBC Nightly News with Tom Brokaw,'' also in New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Ralph S. Pyle, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony at the Inn at Langley on Whidbey Island, Wash.

title: An Offer She Couldn't Refuse
A Dance Class That Encourages Boys to Be Boys, Exuberantly
description: GROWING up in Paramus, Ronen Murad never thought boys should dance. That kind of stuff was for girls.

title: RACE FOR CITY HALL: The Democratic candidate.; Messinger's Long Road in Pursuit of the Mayoralty
description: The first time Ruth Wyler Messinger ran for elective office, seeking a seat on the local school board for the Upper West Side in 1975, she did not rely on traditional leaflets. She used a chain letter, sending copies to friends and asking them to do the same.

title: Massachusetts Man's Goal Is to Rid Town of Tobacco
description: From this well-worn seaside town beneath the planes roaring into the nearby Boston airport, 74-year-old Ralph Sirianni watched the unveiling of the tobacco industry settlement this summer with mounting discontent.

title: Liz Johnston, Michael Volgende Jr.
description: Mary Elizabeth Johnston and Michael Joseph Volgende Jr. were married yesterday in Chatham, Mass. The Rev. Rene R. Levesque performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church.

title: Essay; White House Tapes
description: After the nation had become disgusted at President Nixon for secretly taping confidential discussions in the White House, I got a call from Cartha (Deke) DeLoach, a longtime top official at the F.B.I.

title: On the Midnight Shift, Target Blue
description: THEY drive into my neighborhood every day, from the cop lands of Staten Island, Suffolk and Orange Counties, officers of the 13th Precinct and the students and teachers of the Police Academy.

title: The Prison That Was Europe
description: THE MYTH OF RESCUE Why the Democracies Could Not Have Saved More Jews From the Nazis. By William D. Rubinstein. 267 pp. New York: Routledge. $25.

title: Special Education Is Not A Scandal
description: As a physician and parent of a child with significant learning disabilities, I would like to applaud Brent Staples's article ''Special Education Is Not a Scandal'' (Sept. 21). There seems to be an aspect of denial in the compulsion to integrate children with special needs into regular classes. I often wonder if we are actually concerned with seeking the best outcome for the child or if we are pandering to parents' fears of their child being viewed as ''different.'' Let there be no mistake -- these children know they are different. Having them sit in a regular class only emphasizes to them how far behind they are intellectually compared with their peers. In my opinion, this is cruel. It also puts impossible expectations on the teacher of that class.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a typographical error, a letter on Sept. 28 about airline clubs misstated the number of years that its author, Paul Malecka, had been a member of United's Red Carpet Club. It was 30, not 13.

title: Search for Libyan's Fate Leaves Wife in Disbelief
description: Libya's leading dissident, Mansour Kikhia, was by all accounts in a pretty good mood on the night he disappeared nearly four years ago.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL; Vietnamese Player Sees No Obstacles
description: Dat Nguyen's silver platter is 100 yards long. His parents, Ho and Tammy Nguyen, showed him its fruits were attainable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, SYLVIA
description: PRICE-Sylvia. On October 9, 1997. Beloved wife & adored companion of the late William. Loving mother and best friend of Leslie Price Hayes. Most cherished & devoted grandmother of Elan Price Kaplan. Dearest mother-in-law of Dr. Dennis Hayes. Treasured sister of Bertram and his wife, Lilyan Weingart, and of the late Claire French. Service Sunday, 12:00 noon at the ''Riverside,'' 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Agencies Using Native Stock In Landscaping Sites on L.I.
description: GOVERNMENT agencies are increasing their use of Long Island native plants in restorations and landscaping, thus entering a new world, with controversies and uncertainties as well as rewards.

title: Rx for Cashmere
description: Pampered people think nothing of flying thousands of miles to a spa. So, why shouldn't a cashmere sweater no longer in its prime be sent to England to be refurbished?

title: Two Ways to Skin a Kat
description: WHY OUR CHILDREN CAN'T READ And What We Can Do About It: A Scientific Revolution in Reading. By Diane McGuinness. 384 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25.

title: Cain in Oklahoma
description: THE MERCY SEAT

title: A Look at Perils The Internet Poses to Children
description: WHEN Carol Ellison, a senior editor at Home PC Magazine in Manhasset, entered a computer chat room and posed as a 14-year-old, she received what she called ''a fair number of interesting overtures.''

title: You May Be off the Hook On Old Parking Tickets
description: Ever hope that if you just ignored those old parking tickets long enough they would somehow go away? Well, if you've waited long enough, you got your wish.

title: Dairy Farmers' Woes Grow by the Gallon; Milk Producers See a Way of Life Threatened by Lagging Prices and Rising Costs
description: As it often does in the fall, the price of milk at the grocery store is going up by as much as 25 cents a gallon in some parts of the New York metropolitan area.

title: Seminar Offers Advice in Starting a Business
description: A SEMINAR for people who are interested in going into business for themselves, ''Starting and Operating a Small Business,'' will be held at the White Plains Library on Oct. 22 from 6 to 8 P.M. The seminar, sponsored by the Service Corps of Retired Executives, is free.

title: October 5-11; Suspects in Ethnic Cleansing Turn Themselves In
description: Ten Bosnian Croats, including one of the most-wanted war-crimes suspects in Bosnia, surrendered to the international tribunal in The Hague last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEICHSELBAUM, WALTER
description: WEICHSELBAUM-Walter. On October 2, 1997. Age 78. Cherished husband of Natalie (Gallin). Beloved father of Wilma and Paul (Elyse Meltz). Loving grandfather of Noah and Emma. Dear uncle, cousin, friend. Cared and gave purpose to David Gallin's life. Philatelic dealer. Loved his stamps and his home. In remembrance forever beyond his forgetting... due to Alzheimer's.

title: Down Memory Lane at a Microbrewery
description: CAN White Plains support two microbreweries? From recent evidence, the answer seems to be a decided yes, especially as the new kid on the block sends out entirely different sparks. No brass and muted wood here. The entrance to this stage is set for a Fourth of July picnic, circa a simpler age, when flags had 48 stars and Robert Preston led bands through the town square. The fare may be a cut above fried chicken and potato salad, but the fizz and the aura of the good will of a town gathering are there.

title: For Family (Tax) Shelter, The Rules Have Changed
description: ACCORDING to estimates by the Department of Housing and Urban Development, there are approximately 65 million homeowners in the United States. For many, the purchase of a home was the most significant investment of a lifetime. For some, that investment has proved fruitful indeed: It is not uncommon for a house bought for $50,000 a quarter century ago to have grown -- through appreciation, a series of sales and purchases, or a combination of both -- into an asset worth several hundred thousand dollars. The equity in the family home often represents a major portion of the total estate to be passed from one generation to another.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: The Geometry of Love

title: Campaign Fact and Fiction
description: In his bravura performance before the Senate committee on campaign finance, Harold Ickes argued that every act of the White House money machine could be excused under an expansive reading of Federal law or by common practice of both parties in years past. Indeed, if Mr. Ickes's certainty had any legal weight, the committee could shut down, and Janet Reno would be justified in her refusal to appoint an independent counsel.

title: Abner Louima Meets Joe Hill
description: JUST over six weeks ago, Stephan Smith, a 29-year-old folk singer, returned to New York from a ''national tour'' of little-known East Coast bars to discover that thousands of the city's residents were marching that very day in protest of what prosecutors say was an attack on a Haitian emigre, Abner Louima, by police officers.

title: Politicians Threaten Accounting Integrity
description: Sixty years ago, an intense battle was waged inside the young Securities and Exchange Commission. There was no consensus about how to fix what all agreed was the deplorable accounting that was showing up in corporate financial reports.

title: The Home-Town Hero and the Home Town That Loved Him
description: Dick Jeffer remembers the game as a special moment in this town's life, one that has reverberated in the communal memory down through the decades to become part of its folklore. And its identity.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I read it and I thought, 'That's terrible.' Believe it or not, there are a few of us who don't take a lot of joy in this.''

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Yale in the Midst of a Mammoth Renovation Program
description: FOR the last two years, Yale has been engaged in what its officials believe is one of the most complex and costly building projects ever attempted by an American university.

title: Critics Say Clinton Panel About Race Lacks Focus
description: Three months after President Clinton appointed a seven-member advisory board to help develop a national dialogue on race, the initiative is being criticized for its slow start and lack of focus. Some critics say the board's desultory beginning even raises the question of whether the White House is using the panel to duck, rather than confront, the country's thorny racial issues.

title: ESPN Host Arrested
description: Gary Miller, a host of ESPN's ''Baseball Tonight,'' was arrested yesterday and charged with urinating out the window of a Cleveland nightclub onto off-duty police officers.

title: Children's Books
description: THIS FOR THAT

title: Dungeons and Witches in Massachusetts
description: In Massachusetts the Halloween spirit prevails year round. This is especially true in Salem, where such reminders of the witch trials of 1692 as the Witch House, the Salem Witch Museum, the Witch Dungeon Museum, and the Salem Wax Museum of Witches and Seafarers, as well as Burying Point, the city's oldest cemetery, can be visited without charge from dawn to dusk every day.

title: No Saints Allowed
description: To the Editor:

title: The World; Recalling Che, the Man, But Not His Revolution
description: CUBAN schoolchildren still begin their day singing the hymn ''We Will Be Like Che,'' and an outsized portrait of the fallen guerrilla warrior looms larger than ever over the Plaza de la Revolucion here. At a Cuban Communist Party congress last week scheduled to coincide with the 30th anniversary of the death of Che Guevara, Fidel Castro paid an emotional tribute to his late comrade.

title: The View From: Armonk; Trekking to a Cider Mill To Taste the Fruit of Fall
description: IT is Columbus Day weekend and that means it is the busiest three days of the year for Schultz's Cider Mill on Old Route 22 here. From points north (vacation homes in Putnam, Dutchess and Columbia Counties) and south (White Plains, Yonkers and Manhattan), they converge on the cider mill-produce stand-snack bar, which has been an institution for more than 40 years.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: BELMONT ; Theater Has Heart, and Sausage, Too
description: ''BRING an artful audience, but have them buy a salami too!'' is what merchants of the Arthur Avenue Retail Market told Annie Lanzillotto, project director of ''A' Schapett!'' (''The Tight Shoe''), when she presented the idea of a theatrical performance in a working market.

title: The Secret Weapon For Early Lettuce
description: HAVE you ever wondered how it is that your neighbor is able to plant lettuce or spinach early in the spring? Or has a friend who lives down the block brought a bunch of fresh lettuce for dinner salad when the outdoor temperature is hovering around 30 degrees? How many times has the old garden adage been proposed that peas should be planted on St. Patrick's Day?

title: Backtalk; Longing for the Browns In a Tale of Two Cities
description: With the baseball season winding into its final days and football about to claim our full attention, it is fitting that the Cleveland Indians would be playing the Baltimore Orioles. The two cities share not only a baseball rivalry, but also a painful legacy from football.

title: Nipping at the Hand That Has Long Fed Him
description: To hear Murray Sabrin tell it, government should limit its role to helping individuals defend themselves from force and fraud.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCDONAGH, BERNARD
description: McDONAGH-Bernard. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Bernard McDonagh, associated with The Times from 1949, until retiring in 1971.

title: PULSE: In the Mail; P.R. Bauble Of the Week
description: To promote the release on Tuesday of ''Medazzaland'' (Capitol), the new Duran Duran album, a shoe box holding a CD, video and compact with four eye-shadow shades, including Trash (gray) and Void (silver).

title: Making a Home Beautiful (Without Beige)
description: ALEXANDRA STODDARD, her bright eyes flashing at the thought of Edith Wharton's turn-of-the-century estate in Massachusetts, said she felt she had a spiritual connection to the novelist. ''She was a writer, she was exceedingly visual,'' said Ms. Stoddard. ''I identify with her on different levels. She invented our profession. She invented my life!''

title: ESPN Host Arrested
description: Gary Miller, a host of ESPN's ''Baseball Tonight,'' was arrested yesterday and charged with urinating out the window of a Cleveland nightclub onto off-duty police officers.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 12, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Foot Frill
description: Forget about ornamenting the face, neck, wrist or fingers. Think about the feet.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAXTER, LORRAINE S.
description: BAXTER-Lorraine S. On Friday, October 10, 1997, of Marlboro, NY, and a former resident of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Q. Baxter, Jr. Loved and loving mother of Barbara L. Baxter, S. Noel and Sandy F., Wayne C. and Sally W. Dear grandmother of Paul V., Sarah Q., Luke B. Winters, and Jennifer N. Conway, Allison L., Elizabeth A., and Thaddeus W., Danford S. and Rebecca B. Baxter. Great-grandmother of Austin T., Lindsay A. Baxter and Madeleine L. Conway. Grandmother by marriage of Nancy F. Baxter and Paul J. Conway. Loved and loving sister of Charles F. Schoenlein, D.D.S., and his wife Lois, and her late sister Gertrude Webster. Also survived by many nieces, nephews and cousins. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 9807 Ascan Avenue (corner Metropolitan Ave), Forest Hills, NY 11375, Sunday, October 12, 1997, 7-9 PM, and Monday, October 13, 1997, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Services St. Luke's Church, 85 Greenway South, Forest Hills, NY, Tuesday, October 14, 1997, at 10 AM. Reposing also at her home, 184 Plattekill Rd, Marlboro, NY, on Tuesday, October 14, 1997, 3-9 PM. Committal service at Cedar Hill Cemetery, Middle Hope, NY, Wednesday morning. Memorials as desired. Donations to Louis Busch Hager Cancer Center, Bassett Health Care, One Atwell Rd, Cooperstown, NY 13326-1394, in mom's memory would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODARD, ROBERT A.
description: WOODARD-Robert A. The family of Robert A. Woodard notes with great sadness his passing on October 9, 1997 in Marietta, GA. After proud service during World War II as an Airforce pilot instructor, Robert began what was ultimately a forty-one year career in the chemical industry, first with Catalin and then with Ashland Chemical Company. Above all, he was a loving and devoted husband, father, and grandfather. His love will be sorely missed by his survivors, Jeanne Woodard, Susan Woodard, Robert and Laura Woodard and their two children, Nicole and Brendan. Services will be held at the Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, New York, Tuesday October 14, 1997 at 1 P.M.

title: Old New Jersey Had Its Farms, and They Are Preserved Here
description: Trucks and cars whiz past on nearby Route 1 and college students move back and forth between classes. But in North Brunswick, the New Jersey Museum of Agriculture, surrounded by the pastures where the Cook College students raise livestock, still looks as if it is in the middle of a farm.

title: Miss Brown, Mr. Correa Bordes
description: Eliza Eleanor Brown, the daughter Sally and Thatcher M. Brown 3d of New York, was married yesterday to Fernando Correa Bordes, a son of Rosario Bordes and Jaime Correa of Las Palmas, the Canary Islands. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Indians Win on a Disputed Passed Ball in the 12th
description: The two starting pitchers who had dominated the game were simply spectators, the two center fielders whose defensive mistakes had helped lead to the only two runs were simply praying and the two managers who had exhausted their benches and bullpens were simply sweating as the tantalizing skirmish between the Orioles and Indians rolled into extra innings. Who would sputter and who would soar in the American League Championship Series? Anyone ready for a wacky ending? Definitely.

title: Workers United?; Debating Union Dues and Political Don'ts
description: REPUBLICANS in Congress often see labor as the enemy. But as they move to restrict unions' political spending, they are trying to unite with a certain type of worker of the world: Americans upset that their union dues go to political causes they disagree with.

title: The People's Raj
description: India

title: Running Hard, Candidates for D.A. Continue to Spar
description: IN politics and horse races, picking a winner can be a tricky business -- which is why no one is placing bets on the outcomes on Election Day, not even in the contest for Westchester District Attorney.

title: Neagle's Steady Pitching Stifles Marlins and Rights the Stumbling Braves
description: For months, Denny Neagle tried forgetting Game 4 of last year's World Series, tried ignoring the memory of helping to blow a 6-0 lead to the Yankees in the pivotal game of the post-season. Lately, however, the Braves' left-hander has been thinking about that game again, for motivational purposes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHTRITT, JACK
description: HIRSCHTRITT-Jack. Beloved husband of Ethel. Devoted father of Carol, Joel and Nancy. Adored grandfather of Evan, Stefanie, Jonathan, Marissa and Alexandra. Loving brother of Ralph. Funeral service Sunday, 1:30 PM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st St. and Amsteram Ave.

title: Streetscapes/Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and 90th Street; Restoring One of Manhattan's Magnificent Churches
description: IN 1991 the vestry of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, at 90th Street and Fifth Avenue, told the architects Gerald Allen and Jeffrey Harbinson to plan for a restoration that would take 20 years -- or longer. The designers were not disappointed. ''You have a lot of time to think about it,'' Mr. Allen said.

title: Report Says Health of Society Lags Behind That of Economy
description: An annual analysis of 16 social indicators shows the nation's social health is improving, but noted that this was only the second time in seven years that such an improvement has been seen.

title: Sitting Pretty Again
description: VLADIMIR KAGAN is back, though he never really went away.

title: World Beats Path to Clinton's Door
description: CHURRASCARIA PLATAFORMA**

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUT, HELEN
description: KRAUT-Helen. Age 75, on Oct. 11, 1997. Beloved wife of Ben. Loving mother of Steven, Larry, Eugene and Sharon. Adored grandmother of Jennifer, Scott Michael, Jonathan, Paulina and Francesca. Funeral services on Sunday, Oct. 12, 1 PM, at Gutterman's Funeral Parlor, 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, NY. Interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Group Says China Is Holding Leader of Underground Church
description: Supporters of the underground Catholic movement in China said today that the authorities had detained Bishop Su Zhimin, a prominent church leader who has repeatedly defied Government attempts to control religious worship.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: A Man Under Authority

title: Love and Heartbreak
description: Pre-industrial England is the setting for Masterpiece Theater's MILL ON THE FLOSS, based on George Eliot's haunting and tragic tale about young love. Emily Watson plays the rebellious heroine Maggie Tulliver, a tradesman's daughter, and James Frain is her childhood sweetheart. The story revolves around a mill that has been in the Tulliver family for more than 300 years. When her father loses the mill to the local barrister, Maggie's brother vows revenge not knowing that his sister has secretly fallen in love with the lawyer's crippled son. But when a climactic flood threatens the mill Maggie must choose between love and duty, and in doing so makes the ultimate sacrifice -- SUNDAY at 9 P.M. on CHANNEL 13. Yolanda A. Andrews

title: Habitats/The Osborne, 205 West 57th Street; In a Stately Old Building, Just a Touch of Karma
description: FOR most of the 24 years Norma Rosenberg lived in a modern Brooklyn Heights building, she dreamed of a home in an old Manhattan apartment, preferably around West 57th Street.

title: Australians Play Rough in Political Dispute Over Travel Perks
description: As with their robust brand of football, where under so-called Aussie rules almost anything goes, Australians are now playing a rough game of politics.

title: Famous Just Doesn't Make It
description: Bill Gregory once gazed at Earth through a window in space. Gary Johnson was running races in New Mexico long before he began running for office. Tim Jacobs makes a living guarding the President's life, and Alexandra Paul spent years roaming a California beach with David Hasselhoff.

title: POSTINGS: Two Floors in Former Flag and Banner Factory on West 26th Street; For Theaterworks, New Places to Rehearse
description: Rob Barron, directing ''The Prince and the Pauper'' for Theaterworks/USA this season, couldn't be happier about the consolidation of the company's offices and its dozen rehearsal studios -- which it also rents to other groups -- on two floors at 151 West 26th Street in Chelsea.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EISENSTEIN, ALVIN GORDON
description: EISENSTEIN-Alvin Gordon. Remembered always by his loving family and friends. 10/12/15 -10/26/87

title: New, Refurbished Hotels In Mexico, Caribbean
description: Visitors heading south for winter vacations have some new choices this year. Among the major resorts that are opening or reopening under new management are two in the Caribbean and one in Baja California.

title: Once Commonplace, Now Elevated to Rarity
description: THE Jersey City Museum presents a continuing series of exhibitions called ''Everything for Industry,'' which celebrates products traditionally made here, one business at a time. Completing the series could take a while, for Jersey City, near both New York City and the ocean, has been a manufacturing hub for many products, including beer, pencils and soap. A major industry of the 19th century is the subject of the current show, ''Jersey City: Shaping America's Pottery Industry.''

title: 'Unaccustomed as I Am to Mudslinging . . . '
description: THE campaign for Governor -- arguably the most important race in the country this year -- has been conducted so far with a reasonable degree of civility.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOODY, RUTH PIERPONT
description: MOODY-Ruth Pierpont. Formerly of Brooklyn and Fort Lauderdale, survived by her children Alfred G. S. Moody, Jr., of Ridgewood, NJ, and Caroline M. Roberts of Sewickley, PA, four grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Interment at Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn.

title: Sports of The Times; Not a Quarterback Controversy. It's Simply a Contest.
description: IT is considered one of pro football's unwritten laws: when a starting player, especially a quarterback, gets hurt, he gets his job back as soon as he's healthy enough to start again.

title: Whip Deflation Now?; Two Cheers for Inflation, Given the Alternative
description: INFLATION made headlines last week. Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned that labor shortages could lead to rising prices. The German central bank raised a key interest rate, citing as a reason the need to prevent inflation. And the Labor Department reported that an index that measures the prices of goods as they leave American factories jumped sharply in September. But for all the focus on inflation as a big threat to the economy, Wall Street analysts, economists and investors talk increasingly about its opposite -- deflation -- as the potential source of the next crisis.

title: At Regatta, L.I. Waters Try Sailors' Wits
description: WHEN the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club Fall Series Regatta begins Saturday in western Long Island Sound, sailors will be hoping for one element that is often missing from Long Island summer racing.

title: Interviewer Builds Life in Katonah
description: WHEN the Fox News Channel interviewer Catherine Crier met her future husband, Christopher Wilson, at a Manhattan dinner party they talked about horses, cattle and the great outdoors. She was raised on a horse farm in Dallas, and he was brought up on a cattle ranch in Australia.

title: Sports of The Times; The Jones Boys' Night: Survival, but Barely
description: Just what alias does a fellow named Jones use when he wants to disappear? Smith, perhaps?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WOLOSOFF, JEANETTE
description: WOLOSOFF-Jeanette. As always you are in our thoughts and in our hearts. We love you. Joy, Jessica and Evan.

title: Gail Arrington, Shannon Richards
description: Gail Susan Arrington, a daughter of Mary Ellen Arrington of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Roscoe D. Arrington, is to be married this afternoon to Shannon Terry Richards, a son of Saundra H. Arrington of Carrollton, Tex., and Terry S. Richards of Brooklyn.

title: Fishermen Face Loss In the Hunt for Shad
description: ONE of the last commercial finfish left for fishermen to take from the Hudson River may be off limits next year.

title: Large Portions at Very Moderate Prices
description: MAX'S in Rockville Centre is my mother-in-law's kind of place. She hates fussy food and is unimpressed by plates of towering au courant creations. Max's menu is loaded with her favorites: meat loaf, brisket, turkey dinner, BLT's and chicken salad sandwiches.

title: The Decade That Won't Go Away
description: PERHAPS one of the hundreds of curses leveled at the beautiful people as they passed through the throngs kept outside the velvet ropes at Studio 54 has come true. Perhaps some crone deemed too grizzled to go inside pointed to the gyrating crowd and doomed them this way: ''Enjoy yourselves tonight. But I curse the beautiful people that they, and others like them, will live inside the 1970's forever!''

title: One Satellite, From One-Man Soviet Union
description: Gregory Green is prone to making statements like, ''It's frightening how simple a nuclear bomb is to produce.'' So it was fitting that on the 40th anniversary of the Sputnik satellite, which sent American self-esteem plummeting when it went aloft, Mr. Green launched, or rather erected, a satellite of his own -- a radio transmitter, carefully modeled on Sputnik -- on a Williamsburg roof.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, AARON S.
description: FRANK-Aaron S., at his home in Vero Beach, Florida on October 8, 1997. Formerly of Phila., PA, Loveladies Harbour, NJ and New Hope, PA. He served in the United States Army from 1941 through 1945. He was associated with the Na-Lor Mfg. Co. of Phila. and the Forum Sportwear Co. of NYC for most of his life, serving as CEO and President of both companies. He is survived by his wife, Susan Wardick Frank; his 3 daughters: Lisa Baladad of Deerfield, Il, Donna Riskin of Eddyville, OR, Marcy Patrick of Valdez, AK; his sister Phyllis Brooks of Vero Beach, FL, and his three grandchildren: Addi, Austin and Jennifer. The family suggests that donations be made to their favorite charitable organization.

title: Orphans
description: THE DANCING GIRL OF IZU

title: INSIDE
description: In Cuba, More of the Same

title: Learning to Live With Arrivederci
description: IT has been exactly six weeks since I closed the door of my small rented apartment in Florence and headed home to New York. I know that because my final memento of the trip -- a majolica jar adorned with a gaily dancing putto -- arrived intact, meticulously packaged, in today's mail. For 25 years, on each visit to Florence, I have been buying china in the same small, utterly reliable shop on the Via Guicciardini. And each time, as if there were no postal, airport or customs snafus on either side of the Atlantic, my purchases have arrived, give or take a day, in six weeks. Now, once again, I must come to terms with the fact that I am truly here and won't see Florence again for a span of time I cannot bear to estimate or contemplate.

title: Correction
description: A table last Sunday with an article in the Mutual Fund Quarterly Report about the performance of five hypothetical retirement portfolios misstated the third-quarter return of the Vanguard Emerging Markets Index fund in the portfolio prepared by Sheldon Jacobs, editor of the No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y. The fund's 9.3 percent change was a drop, not a rise.

title: Those 'Easy' Sonatas
description: To the Editor:

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: Images That Reveal How Atlantic City Got Its Name
description: Atlantic City was a vibrant tourist center long before the current era of casino hotels that turn their back to the beach. It is easy to forget that the Atlantic Ocean gave the city its name and pulled in the crowds. But the many photographs in ''Bettmann on the Boardwalk'' serve as a reminder and, like the sea air, a tonic.

title: Time Was on Their Side
description: The Franchise

title: Michele Kayal, Satu Limaye
description: Michele Kayal, the daughter of Patricia and Joseph Kayal of Huntington Station, N.Y., is to be married this afternoon to Satu Prakash Limaye, a son of Nandini and Prakash Limaye of Seattle. The Rev. John Faraj, an Eastern rite Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony with Ramesh Gangeolli, a Hindu scholar, in the rose garden near the American Immigrants Wall of Honor on Ellis Island.

title: Ms. Henning And Dr. Brock
description: Kimberly Valentin Henning, a daughter of Mrs. James G. Leonard of Madison, Conn., and Robert E. Henning of Woodstock, Vt., was married on Friday to Dr. Jerry Steven Brock, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry W. Brock of Brigham City, Utah. The Rev. Ivan Weiser, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Randall Davey Audubon Center in Santa Fe, N.M.

title: The View From: Norwich; A New Beginning For an Old Port City
description: THE specter of Norwich's 18th- and 19th-century past, when the city bustled with merchant ships bound for the West Indies and hummed with textile mills, dwells in the minds of people eyeing its future.

title: Heady Brew
description: SOME people leave when they discover that the Trap Rock Restaurant and Microbrewery doesn't serve hamburgers for dinner. I feel sorry for them. Bruce Johnson, at 36, is one of the premier chefs in New Jersey. If he suggests Maine mussels and pan-seared salmon with creamy savoy cabbage for dinner, order them. The pumpkin cheesecake produced by his kitchen is an airy dream, and his warm chocolate cake oozes bittersweet pleasure.

title: A Journalist's Nonfiction Reads Like a Novel
description: IN November 1963, Joyce Egginton, a correspondent for The London Observer who was in Dallas covering the assassination of John F. Kennedy, noticed a coincidence. She was interviewing people at The Dallas Morning News about Jack Ruby, who had been at the paper buying an advertisement as the President's motorcade passed by.

title: Lost Innocence
description: AS IF A Crime, a Trial, a Question of Childhood. By Blake Morrison. 209 pp. New York: Picador USA. $21.

title: Rehabilitation in Prison?
description: Should rehabilitation be a goal of imprisonment? What can be done to keep inmates from returning to prison once they are released?

title: Holiday Tomorrow
description: Columbus Day, actually Oct. 12, will be legally observed.

title: October 5-11; Locks on Handguns
description: It was a White House ceremony that brought together two sets of antagonists: Bill Clinton and gun makers; Mr. Clinton and Attorney General Janet Reno.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, WILLIAM
description: ALTMAN-William. Beloved husband of Dorothy Altman, died Wednesday, October 8. He was the brother of Sylvia Wasserman, Ida Kozlowski and Ruth Teitelbaum. The interment was Friday, October 10, at Floral Park Cemetery, Deans, NJ. Rest in peace, Willie.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Jersey City; Now as Then, a Place for New Beginnings
description: FOR nearly two centuries, Jersey City, a short boat ride from Ellis Island and the Statue of Liberty, has served as a first American home for hundreds of thousands of immigrants. More than a fourth of its residents are foreign born, with large numbers from the Arab world, the Philippines, South America and the Dominican Republic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOTKIN, DR. JAY
description: SLOTKIN-Dr. Jay, on Friday, October 10, 1997, of Potomac, MD. Precious husband and best friend of Bonnie. Loved and revered ''Daddy'' of David (Sharon) and John. Adored son of Marjorie and Raymond. Beloved brother of Caryl. Treasured son-in-law of Shayne and Harold Friedman. His name is courage. His integrity, compassion and humor showed us the way. His strength of character and unyielding will to survive was, and always will be, an inspiration to all those whose lives he touched. His synagogue, B'nai Israel Congregation, 6301 Montrose Road, Rockville, MD, will embrace him one last time on Sunday, October 12 at 2:30 PM. Memorial contributions may be made to the Jay Slotkin Fund, Johns Hopkins Hospital, 600 North Wolfe Street, Meyer 5-119, Baltimore, MD 21287. For information call Edward Sagel Funeral Direction 800-217-9403

title: Program Teaches Girls Fitness and Good Health Habits
description: WORKING out to the rhythms of UB40 and Puff Daddy, the teen-age girls could have been at a fitness club or in a music video. But instead they were in Amy Barone's gym class at Sleepy Hollow High School here.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SULLIVAN, RICHARD J.
description: SULLIVAN-Richard J. October 13, 1996. Decorated WWII veteran, retired Chief Counsel, U.S. House of Representatives Public Works Committee. Beloved husband of Julia (nee Monaghan). Father of seven children. Dick, we all love and miss you. Family and Friends

title: Rabbis Still Resist Interfaith Marriage, Study Shows
description: A nationwide survey of 325 rabbis, asked whether they would perform interfaith marriages between Jews and non-Jews, has provided an unusual statistical look at how this contentious question divides the spiritual leaders of the faith's more traditional branches from some of those in Judaism's more liberal branches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, ANNE (BACKUS)
description: ADAMS-Anne (Backus). 75, of Farmington, CT. Beloved wife of Worthington Miner Adams, died suddenly, Wednesday, October 8, 1997, at Hartford Hospital. Besides her husband she is survived by her two daughters, Linn Adams Seidensticker of Cold Spring Harbor, NY, Mary Adams Lines of Bedford Hills, NY; her two sons, Worthington Miner Adams Jr, of Clearwater, FL, Cecil Backus Adams of West Hartford, CT; her two brothers, John W. Backus of San Francisco, CA, Cecil F. Backus Jr., of Easton, MD and nine grandchildren. The memorial service will be held on Monday at 11 AM, in St. James Parish, Mountain Rd, Farmington, CT, with the Rev. Jeffrey S. Dugan officiating. Memorial contributions may be made to Miss Porter's School, 60 Main St, Farmington, CT 06032.

title: Sports of The Times; A Resilient Baltimore Ballplayer Comes to Learn Another Medical Term
description: THE word slips into the news conference, heavier than most of the banal words spoken at these rituals. Chemo. Normally, it is a word for other sections of the paper, or other segments of the television news, but here it is, coming amid talk of third-game starters and three-day rests and other such trivia.

title: David Gill, 69, Dies; A Restorer of Films From the Silent Era
description: David Gill, who with his partner, Kevin Brownlow, restored many classic films of the silent era, including Abel Gance's ''Napoleon,'' died on Sept. 28 at his home in Huntington in Cambridgeshire, England. He was 69.

title: Anonymous Gifts for Art, So Women Creating It Aren't
description: Last summer, when Nancy B. Davidson's phone rang and a caller announced that she had won a $25,000 grant from an anonymous benefactor, Ms. Davidson, a sculptor, thought it was a ruse played by her friend, Heidi. ''I said, 'Now, Heidi, cut it out,' '' Ms. Davidson said.

title: Freight Company President Arrested Over Shipment of Pesticide
description: Federal prosecutors have arrested the president of a freight forwarding company in Miami and accused him of trying to illegally ship 500 pounds of a corrosive pesticide as passenger baggage on an airline jet, with the warning labels covered over with black plastic.

title: Glass Art Predominates At Chicago Fair
description: Studio art glass will be well represented at the international Sculpture, Objects and Functional Art exposition to be held next weekend on Navy Pier in Chicago. Nearly 40 of the art fair's more than 90 participating galleries will specialize in glass objects, ranging from jewelry to vases and sculptures. Furniture, textiles and ceramics are among the non-glass exhibits.

title: Technology Takes Students to New Vistas
description: AS a result of technology, students at Pelham High School are speaking in French, Spanish or Italian by computer to students in other classrooms. Students at Byram Hills High School in Armonk are doing research on the Internet through their school library. Pelham art students are making designs on computers, and middle school students in the Pelham district can design bridges, practice on a keyboard or test car models in an aerodynamic tunnel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATIS, JACOB D., M.D.
description: MATIS-Jacob D., M.D. The entire family of St. Luke'sRoosevelt Hospital Center mourns the passing of Jacob D. Matis, MD, a longtime member of our attending staff who exemplified our finest traditions of excellence. He was devoted to his patients and much beloved by colleagues, and will be sorely missed. To his wife, Rosalie, and his entire family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman of the Board Ronald C. Ablow, MD President Richard P. Fried, MD President of the Medical Board

title: Malling the Amazon
description: AMAZON JOURNAL

title: Westport Loses Its Radio Station
description: MARK GRAHAM looked around a group of 35 people jammed into a small radio studio and an adjacent lobby, smiled and said to the assembled gathering, to the nonstop callers to his morning radio show and to his radio audience, ''Where were all of you when we needed you?''

title: October 5-11; New Regime, New Massacres
description: For months relief organizations and human rights groups have been quietly collecting and filing away evidence of atrocities suffered by Hutu refugees from Rwanda who got in the way of a Tutsi-backed rebel army led by Laurent Kabila, now the President of the Democratic Republic of Congo.

title: Discovery of 44 Tapes Exposes Vulnerabilities of 2 Institutions
description: On the afternoon of Oct. 1, Michael X. Imbroscio, a 29-year-old lawyer in the White House counsel's office, was keystroking his way through a restricted computer database when he stumbled into an electronic cache of videotapes that he said he had been told did not exist.

title: Creating Moods With Gold Drapes and Terry Cloth
description: WHEN THE AUDIENCE ARRIVES AT the Royale Theater on Broadway during the current previews for ''Triumph of Love,'' it finds itself facing what appear to be several acres of tissue-thin gold fabric draping the stage in great curving loops and voluminous folds. At showtime, when the curtain starts to go up . . . and up . . . and up . . . without ever quite clearing the floor, a theatergoer could be forgiven for flipping through the program to learn who designed this visual joke: Heidi Ettinger.

title: Dig You Must for Early Spring Lettuce
description: HAVE you ever wondered how it is that your neighbor is able to plant lettuce or spinach early in the spring? Or has a friend who lives down the block brought a bunch of fresh lettuce for dinner salad when the outdoor temperature is hovering around 30 degrees? How many times has the old garden adage been proposed that peas should be planted on St. Patrick's Day?

title: Chameleons With Conservative Stripes
description: IF you want to stay in the stock market but are worried about its gyrations since August, convertible securities may be the answer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ROSE
description: GOLDSTEIN-Rose. Age 88. Cherished wife of Walter. Caring sister of Benjamin Rosenfeld. Also beloved by all who knew her.

title: 10 Hearts, And the Songs That Speak To Them
description: ASKING A CABARET SINGER to name a favorite song is an impossible question. Who can name just one? On the occasion of the Eighth Annual Cabaret Convention opening tomorrow night at Town Hall in Manhattan, The New York Times asked a few top cabaret singers to do just that. Here are their answers. BARRY SINGER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISHEL, CARLTON MARK
description: FISHEL-Carlton Mark, age 88, suddenly on October 6th, 1997. Former Chairman of the Board of Trifari, Krussman & Fishel, Inc. until he retired in 1975. A graduate of Phillips Andover ('26) and Yale ('30), he was a founding member and past President of the Advisory Board of St. Vincent's Hospital, Harrison, New York on which he has served for over 40 years. He was a Knight of Malta and a Knight of the Holy Sepulchre. For many years he served as a member of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity, Catholic Charities, the Board of the United Hospital's Fund of New York and was affiliated with numerous other religious associations of the Archdiocese of New York. He was also an active parishioner of Resurrection Church in Rye. He was a past President of the ''24 Karat'' Club of New York (a fine jewelers' association). As a member of the Yale Club of New York City and the Apawamis Club of Rye, he enjoyed golf until the time of his death. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 61 years, Helen M. Fishel, and is survived by two daughters, Penelope F. McDermott of Rye and Kathleen F. McCullough of Chatham, MA, son-inlaw William H. McCullough, 7 grandchildren and 9 adored greatgrandchildren. Visiting hours will be at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York, Thursday, October 9th, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass will be held at 10 AM Friday, October 10th at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye. Interment immediately following at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Vincent's Hospital of Westchester, 275 North Street, Harrison, New York 10528 or United Hospital Medical Center, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, New York 10573.

title: Cynthia Carey, A.W. Schwartz Jr.
description: Cynthia Allison Carey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Ward Carey of New York, was married yesterday to Arthur Warton Schwartz Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Schwartz of Stockbridge, Mass. The Rev. John Peter Gerhardt performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: CYCLING: PRESEASON
description: The professional bicycle racing pack, the fellows who competed over the world championships' roads near San Sebastian, Spain, two months ago in the one-day Clasica San Sebastian, complained afterward that the course was too easy, not ''selective'' -- a word that means the field does not break up over tiring climbs.

title: Life's a Ball: Dress for It
description: THE question was posed: ''What about sweaters?''

title: Rickel Home Centers Will Go Out of Business
description: Forty-four years after brothers Mort, Al and Bob Rickel opened their first store on Route 22 in Union, Rickel Home Centers said last week it would go out of business and lay off all 2,700 employees, including 2,000 in New Jersey. Rickel, based in South Plainfield, will close its 38 New Jersey stores and 11 others in New York, Pennsylvania and Delaware by Dec. 31, said Greg Hanselman, vice president for marketing. Rickel overexpanded by acquiring the Channel Home Centers chain in November 1994, Mr. Hanselman said, then fell into bankruptcy 14 months later and failed to attract badly needed investors despite a streamlining plan to boost profits. ''Basically, we just ran out of cash,'' he said.

title: October 5-11; Kindergarten, Now or Later?
description: Maybe your 5-year-old doesn't like sitting still, or doesn't have much of an attention span. If so, you may be advised to delay kindergarten for the child. Many families have done just that.

title: The Cyber Hasid
description: 'If you can read this, then you don't belong here,'' states a Yiddish disclaimer on the ''unofficial'' Satmar Web page, a mostly English site that, oddly, discourages Satmar Jews from reading it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, JULIUS (''POP POP'')
description: HOROWITZ-Julius (''Pop Pop''). Thanks for the wonderful times we shared. We will always be loving, proud members of your team. Andrew, Elizabeth and Stephen

title: L.I. Vines
description: Merlot

title: 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell'
description: To the Editor:

title: Volunteer Heads Gala to Fight Alzheimer's
description: FOR Judith B. Resnick of Harrison, saying no is harder than saying yes. Which is why with an already loaded schedule of volunteer work, she took on another commitment that in itself is a full-time job: being chairwoman of ''The Gilded Age,'' the 13th annual Rita Hayworth Gala to benefit the Alzheimer's Association.

title: The Pictures That Serve a President's Image
description: WHEN IT COMES TO constructing a self-image and bruiting it about, rulers have always had an edge. Rameses II had himself portrayed in stone, 65 feet tall while sitting down, not once but four times on the facade of Abu Simbel. Certain Pharaohs were both more parsimonious and more invidious: they ordered their predecessors' names erased so memories of them would die and sometimes had statues' faces recarved to resemble their own.

title: Parking Meters Picking Up a Few I.Q. Points
description: Attention, beleaguered motorists. The digital, handleless parking meter of the future has arrived. Not to be confused with the 10,000 digital, handleless meters of the future introduced last year (4,000 of which have been installed), the latest model is not designed to take smart cards -- a feature that no one has ever used. But it can tell when a car pulls into and leaves a parking space, a talent unlikely to make drivers rejoice when its liquid-crystal display starts flashing on city streets next month.

title: A Drug Maker Takes on AIDS, Cancer and the Short-Sellers
description: EARLY this year, Agouron Pharmaceuticals received approval for a drug that combats H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. Not surprisingly, shares of Agouron, a biotechnology company, soared.

title: Capturing the Flow of Life In War and in the Depression
description: AN exhibition at the Yale Center for British Art, ''Humphrey Spender's Humanist Landscapes: Photo-Documents 1932-1942,'' charts the inexorable daily grind that can wear people down. Elsewhere in the New Haven museum the three large canvases that encompass the 19th-century painter John Martin's ''Vision of the Biblical Flood'' show humanity's dramatic trial by water.

title: Bill Clinton's Garbage Man
description: For all the analysis in ''Bill Clinton's Garbage Man'' (Sept. 21), Michael Lewis managed to gloss over a most remarkable tidbit of father-son psychodrama. Harold Ickes pere required drugs so that he could fall asleep, yet Harold Ickes fils required drugs so that he could stay awake.

title: Messinger's Long Road in Pursuit of the Mayoralty
description: The first time Ruth Wyler Messinger ran for elective office, seeking a seat on the local school board for the Upper West Side in 1975, she did not rely on traditional leaflets. She used a chain letter, sending copies to friends and asking them to do the same.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Cash Keys for Meters

title: Laura Poling, Paul Santoriello
description: Laura Anne Poling, the daughter of Virginia and John Poling of Cortlandt Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Albert Santoriello, the son of Ann S. Santoriello of Basking Ridge, N.J., and the late Albert Paul Santoriello. The Rev. William L. Winston performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Assumption in Morristown, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDREOLI, PETER D.
description: ANDREOLI-Peter D. Of Pelham, NY, on October 11, 1997. Beloved husband of Catherine McCarthy Andreoli, father of Peter, Jr., Brian, Catherine, Christine and Francine, grandfather of nine, brother of Caesar. Reposing Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham, NY. Mass St. Catharine's Church, Pelham, NY, on Tuesday at 10 AM. Visiting hours on Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Masses preferred.

title: Sports of The Times; Of Owners, Coaches, Promise Keepers and Today's New Sports Order
description: Some of the city's most fervent Yankee fans had mixed feelings last week when their season stopped dead. Up in the Bronx, where the pinstripes (actually chalk stripes, I've been told) are on sacred cloth, it was feared that the short-term joy of seeing the club win another pennant could come at the cost of eventually not seeing them in the borough at all. The momentum of another championship, went the paranoia, could grease the secret deal between George Steinbrenner and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- a Manhattan ball park with enough luxury boxes to make even the Fat Worm in the Big Apple happy at last.

title: Brother Act Is Winner For a Paper
description: Bernard Stein, the 56-year-old editor of The Riverdale Press, pauses when he encounters his younger brother, Richard, on the stairs of the weekly newspaper's homey office on Broadway in Riverdale. ''Anything at all controversial, I run by my brother,'' he said. ''But we always agree.'' Richard Stein, 50, retorts: ''Well, sure! He's the one who taught me what I know.''

title: New Equations in Two Nebraska Political Campaigns
description: In deciding to run for Governor of Nebraska halfway through his second term in Congress, Representative Jon Christensen has not only joined a tight two-way race for the 1998 Republican nomination. Mr. Christensen may also be setting the stage for a Congressional contest between the Democrat he narrowly defeated in 1994 and the wife he divorced soon after moving to Washington.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Street of Easy Virtue

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Taking a Turn Into Teaching
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANENBAUM, MARY MAYER
description: TANENBAUM-Mary Mayer, for 59 years beloved wife of Charles J. Tanenbaum, and loving mother of Ann Tanenbaum King. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81 Street), Sunday, October 12, at 1:00 P.M. Contributions may be made in her name to the Stanford Museum of Art, Stanford, CA. 94305-5060.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: The Ice Storm

title: Thomas Whiteside, 79, Dies; Writer Exposed Agent Orange
description: Thomas Whiteside, a writer who made a career of tackling extraordinarily complex topics -- from toxic chemicals to media conglomeration -- for The New Yorker, died on Friday at his home in West Cornwall, Conn. He was 79.

title: SOAPBOX; Committed to Protect
description: NEW JERSEY, which in 1994 led the nation in community ostracism of sex offenders, is now facing the consequences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALLOCK, MELVIN W.
description: HALLOCK-Melvin W. Born in Kewanee, Illinois, March 26, 1929. Cherished husband of 45 years to Norma Elizabeth Williams. Beloved father to Ward, Mark and Micah. title: A Fresh Round in Bar Wars

Eristoff, a Republican who represents much of the East Side of Manhattan, calls them a ''major community problem.'' And if Mr. Eristoff has his way, noisy bars on residential streets will be prohibited by a zoning measure that he recently introduced and that is also sponsored by Council members A. Gifford Miller and June M. Eisland, both Democrats. Mr. Miller represents the rest of the East Side and Ms. Eisland the northern Bronx.

title: 75 Die in Crash of Argentine Plane in Uruguay
description: An Argentine airliner crashed and exploded in Uruguay, killing all 75 people aboard, the authorities said today. The jet had changed course to try to avoid a fierce rainstorm.

description: Big tippers are usually former service-industry workers who have moved on to better jobs. I doubt that Lewis ever had to support himself at a minimum-wage job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAPIN, HAROLD
description: CHAPIN-Harold. With profound sorrow the Rabbis and Cantor, Officers, Trustees and members of Congregation Emanu-El express to our colleague and friend, Rabbi Richard S. Chapin, deepest sympathies on the occasion of the death of his beloved father, Harold. A man of impeccable integrity who lived his life with unshakeable values, Harold Chapin has left a legacy to be cherished and revered. The hearts of those whose lives he touched will hold precious his rememberance forever. To Richard, his mother, sisters and all the other members of the family, we reach forth with affectionate care and loving concern. May they be comforted among the mourners of our people, knowing that the memory of Harold Chapin will endure as a beautiful blessing. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel Rabbi David M. Posner Rabbi Amy B. Ehrlich Cantor Howard Nevison Dr. Mark W. Weisstuch David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Modern Romance
description: If nothing reveals quite so much about an architect as the house he designs for himself, then Stanley Abercrombie and Paul Vieyra's house in Sonoma, Calif., reveals that they are unapologetic modernists. ''Modern architecture does not pretend to be something it isn't,'' says Abercrombie, who is better known as a writer and the editorial director of the magazine Interior Design. Unlike their wine-country neighbors, who seem to prefer historicist salutes to Tuscany, they ''wanted the feeling of a villa without making it look as if it came from another country or period,'' Vieyra says.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Benefit Events Gained Huge Sums
description: THE dust from the benefit circuit in the Hamptons has finally cleared, and the results are in: the wildest, most successful season ever, proving again that the word nonprofit can be a misnomer.

title: The Case Against Tipping
description: My daughter Sarah, a sophomore at the University of Iowa, has worked in our local ice-cream parlor for the past two summers. Her employer, unlike the one in your article, did not allow a tip cup. But as the summer went on, more and more customers gave her a tip. Each night, arriving home around midnight, she would announce her totals: 25 cents, a dollar, very rarely more than that. She would tell us who gave her the tip, how much they gave and the story surrounding the event. She was happy with any amount, and she saved these tips separately from her paychecks (coins in a jar for laundry at school and the bills in a different jar). I can say that although she didn't make much, she made her tips the old-fashioned way; she earned them.

title: Jane Dick, 91, Social Worker Who Served on U.N. Commission
description: Jane Warner Dick, an early social welfare advocate who later served on a United Nations panel, died on Sept. 29 at her home in Lake Forest, Ill. She was 91.

title: A Star Studies the Stars
description: ONE truly wondrous thing about the universe is the human mind's ability to embrace the idea of a universe full of wondrous things. Especially things unseen and unseeable, like the Big Bang of cosmic creation, the mysterious dark matter that constitutes some 90 percent of everything and the awesome black holes with gravity so powerful that nothing, not even light, can escape their depths.

title: Pitino Rides to the Rescue; Celtics Are the Coach's Latest and Most Difficult Reclamation Project
description: The new and imperfect Boston Celtics were splayed out in their hotel rooms on Monday night, six of them hooked up to intravenous feeders after an especially grueling practice. Rick Pitino surveyed the scene as if he were some morale-building general in a demilitarized zone.

title: Despite Fears, Little Evidence Is Seen of a Rise in Gang Violence

J.A., otherwise known as Reptile, had just stuffed a hot dog into his lanky 15-year-old frame. More of the crew began to appear, bookbags dragging off oversized T-shirts and baggy jeans scraping the sidewalk.

title: Tuscaloosa Meets Detroit, With Class
description: WHAT'S the buzz? If a conversation turns to the oh-so-hot Mercedes M-Class, as many seem to do these days, the same questions come up over and over: (a) How much? (b) Can you get one? And (c) How does it stack up against the Explorer and Grand Cherokee?

title: Using Sage to Flavor The New World's Bounty
description: SAGE is an herb Americans use mainly for stuffings. While I do not particularly like dried sage, which can be very strong (Elizabeth David accused it of deadening food with a musty, dried-blood taste), fresh sage leaves are another thing. And now that the sage bushes in my garden are producing enough leaves to stuff a hundred turkeys, I have taken to frying them as they do in Italy, in olive oil or butter. When cooked this way, sage leaves become subtle instead of overpowering. They are wonderful sprinkled over meat, fish or pasta (recently I bought some porcini ravioli and served them tossed in a little creme fraiche and topped with fried sage leaves and pine nuts).

title: L.S.U. Proves Gators Vulnerable After All
description: It was a monumental, goal-post-felling upset of the defending national champions, a 28-21 outlasting of the Florida Gators, who were thought to be invulnerable. And it signaled that the DiNardeaux Era, as the Cajuns here in southwest Louisiana have dubbed the Italian coach and his program, is for real.

title: Jerusalem's Arabs Can Hardly 'Co-exist'
description: To the Editor:

title: The High Court's 20-Year-Old Mistake
description: The effort to reform campaign finance seemed mired in futility last week. The McCain-Feingold campaign legislation was left for dead on the Senate floor, and Harold Ickes, President Clinton's former aide, made a defiant appearance before the Senate committee investigating fund-raising abuses. Around the country there is a growing cynicism over the mixture of money and politics, and over the chicanery practiced in avoiding the rules.

title: Jeeves, Shred This; Luxury Is a Car You Can Work In
description: BACK in 1923, Rolls-Royce accessorized a stately Silver Ghost with a gun rack, a large spotlight and a Gatling gun so its owner, an Indian prince, could hunt tigers.

title: East End Faces a Growing Abandoned Domestic Cat Problem
description: BY 11 A.M. the other day Gillian Wood, director of the Southold Animal Shelter, had received over 20 calls relating to stray cats. Not atypical, the calls were merely one example of an extensive problem facing the animal shelters. The number of stray domestic animals in eastern Suffolk is so numerous as to be incalculable, according to the Suffolk County S.P.C.A., and the consequences rival that of the overpopulation of deer.

title: Miss Dougherty, Mr. Gulbrandsen

Gulbrandsen of Daytona Beach, Fla., and the late Marjorie Davis Gulbrandsen. The Rev. Edward Dougherty performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: Lives; A Child of Difference
description: At 16 weeks into an uneventful third pregnancy, I insisted on a statistically unwarranted amniocentesis and got the result we all want: normal. The child was the daughter we had hoped to conceive after two sons, and I fantasized about a long-legged creature in a ballet tutu, one more noisy kid scrambling onto the bus.

title: A Massacre in Egypt Renews the Pain of Another Attack
description: Every time Merrill Kramer replays the night in his mind, it comes out the same. He sees the lights of Cairo and the stars over the Nile as he and two colleagues dine on shish kebab, stuffed grape leaves, beer and wine. As they stand to go, a short, slight man with nervous eyes pulls out a revolver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, BARBARA L.
description: YOUNG-Barbara L. The Chairman, the Board of Trustess, the Director and Staff of the Brooklyn Museum of Art record with deep sorrow the passing of their dear friend Barbara L. Young who served as President of the Roebling Society of the Museum for the past twelve years. A tireless and dedicated worker on behalf of the Museum, Mrs. Young was a collector of Asian art. She was also a member of the Museum's Asian Art Council. Her boundless energy, her enthusiasm and her friendship will be greatly missed.

title: ALI AUCTION
description: * Shelly Finkel, Evander Holyfield's former manager and a collector of boxing-ticket stubs, will be among those on hand next Sunday in Los Angeles for Christie's auction of Muhammad Ali memorabilia. * The stuff, 3,000 items in all, is from the collection of Ronnie Paloger, an L.A. businessman. * Among the prizes: ''Muhammad Ali Fight-Worn Shoes vs. Ken Norton'' ($12,000 to $15,000; Ali lost) and ''Muhammad Ali Fight-Worn Trunks vs. George Foreman'' in Zaire ($35,000 to $45,000; Ali won). * Also available: An autographed sealed box of Muhammad Ali D-Con roach traps. * Who'd want roach traps? ''The collector who just wants anything with his picture on it,'' says Simeon Lipman of Christie's. * Only the truest fans will pay for ''The Champ Sings,'' one of several records featuring Ali's raspy vocals.

title: Encounters In the Wild
description: EARLY in June, on a South African winter morning, the sky above the Klaserie Nature Reserve was pale, the air clear and sharp. We walked in loose single file, in an easy, peaceable silence broken only by the pad of boots on hard ground, the swish of legs in dry grass. The path was animal-made, and there was evidence everywhere of the builders: a rhino midden blanketed in dung, tree trunks rubbed shiny by elephant tusks, the golf-ball leavings of hyena, thousands of tracks -- the pinpricks of duiker to the great round splots of rhino.

Motherin-law to Alan and Philip. Left us on October 5, 1997. Her courage and spirit demonstrated by her during her long illness will be remembered and admired by her friends and family. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Arthritis Foundation. Mom, may you enjoy chandeliers above.

title: Wannstedt Enduring Tough Times in Chicago
description: These are brutal times for Chicago's Dave Wannstedt, one of the National Football League's good young coaches. The Bears are 0-6. Everything that could go wrong, has gone wrong, with Wannstedt changing quarterbacks the way people change socks. Over all, he says, the losing has been the toughest thing he has ever gone through -- for him and his family.

title: Lament Of Commuter In 8 Parts
description: True, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority recently decided that its riders were too sensitive to be exposed to risque advertisements and that the transportation system itself was too thin-skinned to run ads critical of itself. But M.T.A. officials and commuters can get a laugh by taking a few seconds to look up and appreciate the dry wit attached to ceiling beams in a long, dingy and arid underground corridor, the one that connects the Eighth Avenue IND station to the IRT Nos. 1, 2 and 9 trains at Times Square.

title: Friend to Horses, Friend to Hoofs
description: ARMED with a box of vanilla wafers, Dennis Sullivan cautiously approached the fence. ''Good boy, Mac,'' he said, patting the horse's head and slipping a wafer in his mouth. As he lead the 19-year-old, 1,500-pound horse past the fence and into the stable, Mr. Sullivan patted Mac's side and talked to him. The horse walked into the stable without a fight and stood quietly as Mr. Sullivan lifted his hoofs and began the job of reshoeing Mac's hooves.

title: Word for Word/Republican Remedies; Speak Less Loudly And Stop Calling the Speaker 'Newt'
description: AFTER the election of 1994, President Clinton sank into despair as Republicans took control of Congress. But ever since a resurgent Mr. Clinton won re-election last year, it is the Republicans who have been suffering through a crisis of confidence.

title: The Case Against Tipping
description: Though I prefer Coke from a machine to Starbucks at a counter, I gladly and amply reward anyone making an effort to transform a mundane retail transaction into something more (The Capitalist: ''The Case Against Tipping,'' by Michael Lewis, Sept. 21). How could I ever forget the New York waitress who, when asked about the soup, answered, ''It won't change your life''? That was 12 years ago. My tip did not change her life, either, but I hope it changed her evening, because she was worth it.
