Catalogues and applications arrive and are perused. Notices appear on school bulletin boards. Meetings are held. Families call other families about their experiences.

title: Word & Image; Why So Foreign?
description: Here is the world around Us, as Brokaw, Jennings, Rather and less mobile anchors have portrayed it for Americans in the autumn of 1997:

title: 'God Created Me To Be a Slave
description: Ask Fatma Mint Mamadou how old she is, and the Mauritanian woman turns her gaze shyly downward; she does not know when she was born. Ask her how many camels and sheep she tended, or how many bags of water she hauled every day, and her face turns to stone; she cannot count.

title: Celebrating the Glory Of Celebrated Lives
description: A CELEBRATION of divas was not on New Haven's cultural agenda this month, but when the gods of publicity smile in the right place at the right time, starry events converge, art is served and the living is easy.

title: 3,000 Miles to Go for Two Women
description: Adventure comes easily to Tori Murden, a 34-year-old lawyer and divinity school graduate from Louisville, Ky., who has climbed mountains on five continents, skied to the South Pole, scaled ice walls and paddled sea kayaks.

title: Backtalk; As a Legend Steps Down, A Big 'Amen'
description: I guess the world didn't end Thursday at 2 P.M., but it sure felt that way to me. That was the moment Dean Smith stepped down after 36 years as coach of the University of North Carolina basketball team. As a Tar Heel expatriate currently doing hard time in exile among the Manhattan literati, I'd dreaded that day for years, and when it finally arrived it felt awful, worse even than losing to Duke, though for the record I am compelled to note that that has happened only once in the last nine games.

title: Flags: New, Used ... Recycled
description: It cost $33,250 to refurbish all 185 United Nations flagpoles in time for the recently convened General Assembly. This assures that the internationally recognized symbols of legitimacy will flap securely for a while. The countries themselves have to take their own chances -- flags often change thanks to the outcome of wars, politics, even fashion. Here's a look.

title: A Tropical Rain Forest Provides the Setting
description: THE Rainforest Cafe is about fun, not food. This ''wild place to shop and eat,'' at the Source, the new Fortunoff Mall on Old Country Road, in Westbury (227-6000), is ''Tarzan,'' ''Planet of the Apes'' and Disneyworld all in one.

title: Writing a Musical, an Offbeat Therapy for H.I.V.
description: Somebody's friend took a trip to Chinatown.

title: INSIDE
description: In Cuba, More of the Same

title: The Beauty of Beast Barracks
description: On a hot summer's night in early july, after dinner, the new cadets were led off to hear a speech by the superintendent of West Point. It was Day 3 of Beast Barracks for the Class of 2001. They were sweating in their new dress white shirts and gray slacks, 1,192 of them marching in formation, fists clenched, eyes forward. As they crossed the stone bridge to South Auditorium, they could glimpse the Hudson River -- so far in the distance that the wakes from the yachts and speed boats were tiny white flecks. At that moment, many new cadets were having trouble remembering why coming to West Point had seemed like such a good idea last winter. Up at 5:20 A.M., they were out for physical training at 6. (''New Cadet Yates, did you throw up?'' an upperclassman asked the morning before, after a three-mile run up a brutal hill. ''Yes, sir!'' answered a pale, green Lisa Yates.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLAVIK, WILLIAM
description: SLAVIK-William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William Slavik associated with The Times from 1947, until retiring in 1987.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; On Safari -- in Great Neck?
description: DEFIANTLY double-parking his Outback on a street already choked by traffic, the Great Neck cowboy was a man on a mission. Were he Crocodile Dundee wandering the wilds Of Australia, he might have been excused. Not here in suburbia.

title: Invisible North Korea; Famine Isn't Always What It Seems
description: NORTH KOREA is like a kaleidoscope.

title: McGreevey's Best Chance Against Whitman: A Strong Message
description: From the outset of his gubernatorial campaign in June, State Senator James E. McGreevey knew he would have to make a powerful impression to defeat the Republican incumbent, Christine Todd Whitman.

title: Adultery's Double Standard
description: The story of the world's most public dysfunctional marriage is over. Even before Diana's death transformed her into a full-fledged saint, her marital troubles, like her bulimia, lent her an air of vulnerability that somehow made us love her more. Both Charles and Diana had affairs. Yet while hers seemed justified, his seemed comic or disgusting or unmanly, depending on how you looked at it. Very few people were willing to see Charles as the hero of a tragic love story. His obvious devotion to Camilla Parker-Bowles didn't count in his favor at all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLADES, WILLIAM B., III
description: BLADES-William B., III, a native of New Bern, NC, died peacefully at his home on October 6, 1997 at the age of 75; he spent most of his adult life in New York. He was a graduate of the University of North Carolina and the American Institute of International Commerce. He was employed by the American Express Co. and subsequently retired from Scandinavian Airlines. Memorial gifts may be made to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Development Office, 1000 Fifth Avenue, New York, New York 10028.

title: Hong Kong's Master of Internal Pyrotechnics
description: IN KOWLOON, UP FROM Boundary Street, the border of the bit of Hong Kong that the British once thought they had secured forever, a bamboo stalk of a man carrying a plastic bag full of comic books loped through the gate of a gray-tile, five-story pile of an apartment building.

title: October 5-11; Center Stage Again
description: Jane Alexander, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, announced last week that the agency's show would go on without her. Discouraged by a four-year struggle with conservatives, who charged that the N.E.A. was spending tax money on pornography, and with the left, which argued that grants were too restrictive, the actress said she was returning to the theater. The agency's budget and staff were cut almost in half during her tenure. JUDITH MILLER

title: Slovak Leader Fans a Region's Old Ethnic Flames
description: In a meeting little noticed at the time, the Prime Minister of Slovakia, Vladimir Meciar, made an explosive offer to his Hungarian counterpart, Gyula Horn, at a tense tete-a-tete in August.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: HOTEL

title: Correction
description: A chart in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about the number of Hispanic elected officials in New York City misstated the number of State Senators from the city who are Hispanic. There are four, not two.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; For Tinton Falls, a Vast Continuing-Care Complex
description: CONSTRUCTION of one of the state's largest retirement communities is to begin later this month in Tinton Falls. It will eventually turn 134 acres into a complex of 1,786 residences that will offer people 62 and older meals, services and health care at each stage of aging.

title: POSTINGS: Walking Tour Next Saturday; Brownstones Of Bed-Stuy
description: Here's a tip for anyone attending the 19th Annual Brownstoners of Bedford-Stuyvesant House Tour: Put on your walking shoes.

title: Secret Service
description: Beyond The Threshold

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, STUART ALAN
description: GREENE-Stuart Alan, died October 9, 1997. He was the cherished husband of his adored and devoted wife, Sherry, for the 33 years of their happy marriage, and the devoted father of Douglas, Stephanie and Bradley. Stuart was the older of the two brilliant sons of Dr. Barnett and Mrs. Lee Greene of Lawrence, Long Island, New York. Stuart was a graduate of NYU and earned a Master's degree in Hospital Administration from George Washington University. He served for several years as an Assistant Administrator at two hospitals in Manhattan until his health required the limitation of his professional activities to an office at his home in Cedarhurst. Stuart will be greatly missed by his younger brother, Dr. William H. Greene, who was devotedly responsible for the superior teamwork and treatment by personnel of the Oncology and Infectious Diseases Departments of the State University Hospital at Stony Brook, Long Island, during the five years of Stuart's unusual illness. Stuart's absence will be grievously felt by William's wife, Beverly, and their children, Ilyssa, David, and Lauren. Stuart's love of music, his sharp intelligence, remarkable memory and great sense of humor were qualities that made him a joy to know.

title: Food; Love, Italian Style
description: In the early 70's, when pasta was still spaghetti and fine dining in America was still French, Johanne Killeen and George Germon would seduce each other with gnocchi in a rabbit ragout.

title: In America; Gangs at School
description: Ruth Messinger can't catch a break. She has been unrelenting in her effort to make the school system her issue, the one major area in which she could demonstrate her credibility while putting Rudolph Giuliani on the defensive.

title: Miss Cazes and Mr. Hachemian
description: Anne-Christine Cazes and Farzine Reza Hachemian were married on Friday at the City Hall in Pauillac, France. Gerard Regimbeau, the bride's uncle who is a Pauillac city councilman, officiated. On Saturday, the Rev. Luc Darcos performed the religious ceremony at St.-Martin Roman Catholic Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMP, JACK
description: CAMP-Jack. Of Old Tappan, New Jersey, formerly of Cranberry, New Jersey and Englewood Cliffs. Beloved husband of Rose (nee Moskowitz); devoted father of Richard and Mitchell; loving grandfather of five grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Services Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramas, New Jersey, Sunday, 11 A.M. For information, call ''Gutterman-Musicant'' 1-800-EST-1892.

title: Sports of The Times; Houston Should Share Top Billing
description: THE story goes that in the aftermath of a season-ending playoff defeat in 1996, Doug Collins and Bill Davidson, coach and owner of the Detroit Pistons, respectively, made heartfelt speeches about how proud they were of their young team, how bright the future certainly seemed.

title: Devils Come Back In Victory
description: The Devils came up with a lethargic start for the second consecutive night, but this time they recovered well and scored more than once, rallying twice from deficits for a 3-2 triumph over the Buffalo Sabres at Continental Arena.

title: '97 BASEBALL PLAYOFFS
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: The Giants Agree: Their New On-Field Leader Is One Cool Customer
description: The veteran players on the Giants still talk about Danny Kanell's first official moment as a National Football League quarterback in the huddle.

title: Marlo Nussbaum, Andrew Klein
description: Marlo Beth Nussbaum, a daughter of Bette and Joel Nussbaum of Roslyn, N.Y., was married on Oct. 4 to Andrew Matthew Klein, the son of Carole and Stanley M. Klein of Manhattan. Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein performed the ceremony in the ballroom at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: New Life for a (Pre-O. J.) Legal Classic
description: WHEN ''THE DEFENDERS'' ran on CBS from 1961 to 1965, it was noteworthy not only for being one of the first of many television series about the legal profession but also because it tackled difficult subjects -- like abortion and Hollywood blacklisting -- at a time when television shied away from most controversy. While many television series of that period favored good-versus-evil scenarios and happy endings, the lead characters in ''The Defenders,'' a father and son lawyer team portrayed by E. G. Marshall and Robert Reed, took on complex, morally ambiguous cases, and sometimes lost.

title: Where Mixing Comes Before Matching
description: Fashion takes a walk on the wild side, with color. Crossing New York City's style divide -- 14th Street -- and heading downtown is like passing under a rainbow. Free spirits are uninhibited with their dress, and their wigs. This is where a teen-ager mixes leopard print and plaid; where a young woman dresses in cotton-candy pink, from head to soles of platform shoes; where a young man, in bleached blond hair, struts in his aqua nylon jeans, and where the outfit includes an exotic bird-print Mary McFadden coat.

title: Out of Pretoria, by Luxury Train
description: WE'VE all known him. The little boy whose devotion to the details of his 1:87 scale model steam train is so obsessive that he paints the microscopic lenses of its tiny lamps just the right shade of amber.

title: Survived By His Book
description: IN the final paragraphs of his life, J. Anthony Lukas faced his editor across the divide of a desk at Simon & Schuster's offices towering over midtown Manhattan on the Avenue of the Americas.

title: Bernard Altshuler, 78, Expert On Effects of Pollutants on Lungs
description: Dr. Bernard Altshuler, a mathematician who helped lay the groundwork for understanding how the lung is damaged by polluting particles and carcinogens, died on Oct. 4 at his country home in Hillsdale, N.Y. A Manhattan resident, he was 78.

title: Ideas & Trends; Maybe a Bankrupt Nation Isn't The Worst Thing in the World
description: WHEN political systems collapse, the United Nations now routinely arrives to glue things together and organize or monitor elections, whether the problem erupts in Cambodia, Angola or Mozambique. When currencies collapse, the International Monetary Fund shows up. Its team of experts parachutes in, often followed by billions in loans to restore the confidence of international investors who suddenly discovered, to their shock, that last week's emerging market is this week's submerging one.

title: The Senate Rules: Cigarettes, No. Snuff, Yes.
description: After months of debate, the United States Senate is scheduled to decide this month whether to allow laptop computers on the Senate floor (No. 1 in the illustration). Among the factors under consideration by the Senate Rules Committee: Would the devices result in on-line lobbying? Or annoying squawks and beeps? The debate may seem tiny, but these fine points matter, and they can be rich with historical lore. For example, flowers were banned in 1905 because so many senators were sending anonymous bouquets to themselves on Congress's opening day that the chamber was described as looking ''more like a garden than a legislative assembly.'' Here's a peek at other yeas and nays in the world's most deliberative deliberative body.

title: A Man of Particular Passions
description: THE president and chief executive of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center is a slender, intense, impeccably dressed, graying 51-year-old who looks as if his name would be something imposing and formal. And it is, on his official biography, the one that says Lawrence P. Goldman has a Ph.D. from Princeton University and notes that his responsibilities include overseeing the design, construction and operation of the imposing new $200 million center.

title: Is It a Musical or Just an Aneurysm?
description: DR. AARON SHUTT IS HAVING A bad day. A very bad day.

title: The Searchers
description: God & the

title: Golf Is Carving a Place in Colorado's Ski Country
description: With a perfect swing, Jack Nicklaus recently sent a golf ball arcing through the thin mountain air, past a sylvan backdrop of golden aspen leaves, a languid trout stream and the granite mass of Mount Sipris.

title: Wildlife in Some Unlikely Places
description: Recently, I was poking around in a desktop chest trying to find that small spool of ''holographic tinsel'' that I had ordered from a fly-fishing catalogue months ago. This was the ''revolutionary'' new material that I absolutely, positively had to receive via overnight mail, for reasons that eventually became just as unfathomable to me as the whereabouts of the unused tinsel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYCROFT, J. DENNIS
description: RYCROFT-J. Dennis, 70, formerly of Gladwyne, PA., died on October 3, 1997 in Scottsdale, AZ. A graduate of Horace Mann School, Princeton University & Columbia Graduate School of Business, he was a retired partner of Arthur Andersen & Co and former faculty member of Villanova University. Survivors include his wife Doris, daughter Leslie Halmi, son David, brother Alan and 4 grandchildren. Memorials may be sent to Hospice of the Valley, 1510 E. Flower Street, Phoenix, AZ. 85014-9297.

title: Half Bond, Half Stock: But Is It Right for You?
description: A stock picker's work is done after comparing a stock's price to its company's prospects. But buyers of convertibles must do some extra number-crunching.

title: New Jersey, Healthy for All, Aiming at Health of the Elderly
description: New Jersey residents lead healthier lives than those in three-fourths of the nation, according to a survey released last week.

title: Braves' Lockhart Takes Long Way to the Majors
description: Keith and Lisa Lockhart waited out the longest week of their lives at a Ramada Inn in Omaha in the spring of 1995. Lockhart was 30 years old, all but 45 days of his baseball career spent in the minor leagues, and Lisa had recently given birth to their second child. He was in jeopardy of losing his job with Kansas City's Class AAA affiliate, Lockhart was sure, because he refused to be a replacement player.

title: Kirstie Saltsman, Jon R. Lorsch
description: Dr. Kirstie Ann Saltsman, a research fellow in biology, and Dr. Jon Reis Lorsch, a research fellow in biochemistry, both at Stanford University, were married yesterday in Williamstown, Mass. The Rev. William Cyr, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Thompson Memorial Chapel at Williams College. The Rev. Robert Buckwalter, a Congregational minister, took part in the service.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE RISK OF HIS MUSIC

title: 'Kalifornia' Dreamin'
description: Thirty-two years after the Mamas and the Papas first sang that all the leaves are brown and the sky is gray, the song that helped to define a generation is popular with a new one -- in the dance clubs of New York.

title: Ice-Cream Jingles Bring Nostalgia, Not Anger
description: To the Editor:

title: Wannstedt Enduring Tough Times in Chicago
description: These are brutal times for Chicago's Dave Wannstedt, one of the National Football League's good young coaches. The Bears are 0-6. Everything that could go wrong, has gone wrong, with Wannstedt changing quarterbacks the way people change socks. Over all, he says, the losing has been the toughest thing he has ever gone through -- for him and his family.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Aimee Vincent, Jeremiah Jamison
description: Aimee Archelle Vincent, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Vincent of Weston, Mass., was married yesterday to Jeremiah Stewart Jamison, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Jamison 2d of Latrobe, Pa. The Rev. James W. Crawford, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Old South Church in Boston.

title: France's Bishops Apologize
description: When societies face their participation in a crime as overwhelming as the Holocaust, it is understandable that their memories sharpen, not dim, as time passes. In the years just after World War II, the nations of Europe created exculpatory myths about their own complicity. Only now, as untainted generations arise and study the past, are those illusions giving way to truth. Earlier this month in France, a myth was felled as France's Roman Catholic bishops gathered in the Paris suburb of Drancy -- once an internment camp from which 76,000 Jews were deported east to their deaths -- and made a full and anguished apology to the Jewish people for the church's silence during French collaboration with the Nazis.

title: Jennifer Jenkins, Morgan Grove
description: Jennifer Caroline Jenkins, the daughter of Dr. Jan Storm of Kansas City, Mo., and John A. Jenkins of Washington, was married yesterday to Dr. Jonathan Morgan Grove, the son of Barbara and David Grove of Swarthmore, Pa. The Quaker ceremony was held at the Friends Meeting in Dover, N.H.

title: HISTORY REWRITTEN: A special report.; Purported Kennedy Writings Attract a Legion of Investors
description: With a flourish suggesting secrets yet to be told, Lawrence X. Cusack 3d waved several folders in the air, only to return them quickly to his satchel. Then he described what he had almost shared: enigmatic jottings on index cards, on torn pieces of White House stationery, in the margins of typewritten contracts, in President John F. Kennedy's hand.

title: Uzbekistan's Move
description: To the Editor:

title: Crime and Politics Make Most Gangs Come and Go
description: More than a generation ago, gangs like the Young Lords, the Ghetto Boys and the Black Spades were a regular presence on New York City streets, some having been born of the political activism of the 1960's, others a byproduct of the increasing criminal activity of the era.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTSCHALK, AUDREY
description: GOTTSCHALK - Audrey. Died peacefully on October 10, 1997, at age 89. Wife of the late Robert F. Gottschalk and cousin of Frances Bolton. She had a keen mind, great wit and fierce loyalties. She will be deeply missed by all those who knew her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, BERTRAND
description: GOLDBERG-Bertrand, beloved husband of the late Nancy Florsheim Goldberg; devoted father of Lisa, Nan (Nickel Van Cleve), Geoffrey (Lynne Remington) Goldberg; loving grandfather of Lillian Van Cleve and Nathan Goldberg; dear brother of the late Lucille Goldberg Strauss; fond uncle of Peter (Susan) Strauss, Ellen (William) Hunt Jr. and the late Barbara (James) Heller. Memorial services to be announced.

title: Tired of London Traffic? Sightsee by Ferry
description: Travelers to London who want to visit sites along the Thames River between London Bridge and St. Katherine's Dock can take a new hop-on, hop-off Thames ferry that started operating this summer. For a single fare of $:2 ($3.50) a passenger can use the ferry, called Pool of London, as often as he likes within a day to visit sites around each of the five piers at which the boat stops: Tower Pier, London Bridge Pier, H.M.S. Belfast, Butlers Wharf and St. Katherine's Dock. A map provided with the ticket lists places of interest along the route, such as the Tower of London, the Tower Bridge Experience, the Tower Bridge Museum and the Tower Hill Pageant, as well as the Design Museum, the London Dungeon and the Bramah Tea and Coffee Museum.

title: The Cranberry Festival Will Go On; So Will the Lawsuit
description: Lynn Giamalis wants nothing to do with cranberries after next weekend. ''I've been working so hard on this, I don't want to even hear the word,'' she said.

title: Hit Parade; The Harsh Logic Of Assassination
description: IN the tumultuous aftermath of a failed Israeli attempt to assassinate a leader of the Islamic movement Hamas in the Jordanian capital, the main conclusion among commentators, experts and politicians was that the operation was mounted in the wrong place, at the wrong time and against the wrong target.

title: Film Festival Widens Scope in 5th Year
description: JUST as the New York Film Festival has projected its last feature, the Hamptons International Film Festival is about to begin its fifth year in East Hampton.

title: Gold Funds: An Exercise In Volatility
description: LUCKY you if you caught the recent gold run-up.

title: Showcasing the Bull Market, One Share at a Time
description: WALL STREET, often associated with trading commodities, is becoming a commodity itself.

title: Jennifer Ragan, Richard Brower Jr.
description: Jennifer Leigh Ragan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Ragan of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Richard Anson Brower Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Brower of Dongan Hills, Staten Island. The Rev. Thomas Chulak, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in Manhattan.

title: Los Angeles
description: Since warm weather and constant sunlight first lured movie makers in the early years of this century, Los Angeles has played a dominant role in shaping consumer culture. From the spinning teacups of Disneyland to the whirring cash registers of Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills, the dream merchants of greater Los Angeles have helped define and market popular taste throughout the world.

title: First Year for Theater: Imported and Popular
description: ''Mandy Patinkin in Concert'' can pass as an evening of theater. And David Copperfield (''Dreams and Nightmares'') promotes that illusion. Although both the singer and the sorcerer performed their acts on Broadway, the brochure for the New Jersey Performing Arts Center lists their shows as ''variety and special events.'' That category also includes a South African take on Shakespeare (''Umabatha: The Zulu Macbeth,'' with English supertitles) and Crossroads Theater Company's production of August Wilson's play ''Jitney'' -- both evenings of genuine theater.

title: Man Is Arrested After Laser Sight Is Aimed at Officers in Brooklyn
description: Plainclothes officers responding to a report of shots fired near an apartment complex in Brooklyn early yesterday morning found themselves marked by the laser sight of the shooter's handgun, the police said.

title: Is It Art? Is It Good? And Who Says So?
description: THE DEBATE CONTINUES about where art is today and what so many people still want it to be. For years, the National Endowment for the Arts has been the target of some members of Congress and their constituents and has sometimes seemed on the brink of extinction, although Congress voted on Sept. 30 to preserve the agency for another year with $98 million, just slightly under the previous year's allocation. Last Sunday on CBS, Morley Safer devoted a segment of ''60 Minutes'' to attacking a selection of contemporary art; the report was a follow-up to a controversial one he presented in 1993 on the same subject. Again, he asked the rhetorical question, Yes, but is it art?

title: Once More, the Baton
description: Quiet, social lions: Carnegie Hall's season opens.

title: All in the Family
description: NEXT OF KIN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMBROZEK, STANISLAV
description: AMBROZEK-Stanislav, formerly of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, and La Jolla, CA. Died October 10, 1997, age 83. Born Prague, Czechoslovakia. Retired U.N. economist. Beloved husband of Gerta. Loving father of Stephanie (David), Janet (Bruce) and Michael (Jenny). Adored grandfather of Charlotte, Sarah, Christopher and Daniel. No flowers, please. Donations to Hudson Valley Music Club, 6 Barbara Lane, Irvington, NY 10533.

title: Islanders' Solid Start Not Enough
description: The Islanders' first priority tonight was to keep the Washington Capitals off of the scoreboard in the opening period. They did that, but the two other periods -- the second, in particular -- did them in.

title: State of Snitch
description: THE FILE A Personal History. By Timothy Garton Ash. 262 pp. New York: Random House. $23.

title: SOAPBOX; Sunset Rides Into the Sunset
description: I REMEMBER the day clearly; it was Friday, Aug. 22. That was the day Donald Trump took away a rare and precious gift from me -- my sunset view.

title: Eye on the Nobel; They Should Give A Prize for Ambition
description: AS a sort of reality check, Dr. J. William Langston, director of the Parkinson's Foundation in Sunnyvale, Calif., periodically asks fellow scientists whether they would rather make a great discovery or win a Nobel prize. Most, he said, have to stop and think.

title: A Lobsterman's View Of Nitrogen Cutting
description: Regarding the article ''Nitrogen-Cutting Plan for Sound Is Attacked,'' [Oct. 5]:

title: On Language; Potus And Flotus
description: Controversy was bestirred by a memorandum dated Nov. 20, 1995, from high officials of the Democratic National Committee to Harold Ickes, then deputy chief of the White House staff, asking for ''18-20 calls by POTUS'' and ''10 calls by VPOTUS.''

title: Goodbye to the Job. Hello to the Shock.
description: AS a regional director for Ross Perot's 1992 Presidential campaign, Tamara Hardy never stopped to think what life would be like without constant travel, 14-hour workdays, cellular phones, pagers and an endless supply of frequent-flier miles. When she finally quit to become a stay-at-home mother, reality hit hard.

title: Lisa Cartafalsa, Thomas Takoudes
description: Lisa Ann Cartafalsa, a lawyer, and Dr. Thomas Gregory Takoudes, a medical resident, were married yesterday in Philadelphia. The Rev. Michael C. DiIorio performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Consolation Roman Catholic Church.

title: Aaron D. Wyner, 58; Helped Speed Data Around the Globe
description: Aaron D. Wyner, an information theorist at Bell Laboratories whose research is central to the way data move through through a modem or satellite network, died on Sept. 29 at Morris Hills Nursing Home in Morristown, N.J. He was 58, and lived in South Orange, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Saturday showing test results for the level of perchloroethylene, a noxious chemical, in a Manhattan building that housed a dry-cleaning plant before it was converted into a public school omitted results for the school's cafeteria. A corrected chart appears today on page B5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ROSE
description: GOLDBERG-Rose. Of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, on October 11, 1997. Beloved wife of Samuel Leon. Loving mother of Helene Marcovici, Harriet Croll and Steven Goldberg. Adored grandmother of Carol, Linda, Diane, Wendy, Andrea, Erica and Jon. Cherished great grandmother of Danielle, Jack, Alex and Eric. Services today, 12 noon at ''Gutterman's'' 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, LI.

title: Collision Kills Grandmother And Child
description: A woman and her 11-month-old granddaughter were killed yesterday morning when a car jumped the median of a highway in Howard Beach, Queens, and struck their car head on, causing it to burst into flames, the authorities said.

title: Spurs Seeing Double
description: The 6-foot-11-inch rookie is in the high post, his 7-foot mentor is on the blocks and college is in the rearview mirror. Tim Duncan admits missing the camaraderie at Wake Forest, but life with David Robinson in the Twin Peaks offense has its upside.

title: Bass Captures Pennsylvania Show
description: Lauren Bass, 17, of Willoughby Hills, Ohio, beat a field of 202 qualifiers from 30 states and Canada when she won the American Horse Shows Association's Equitation Medal Final yesterday at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show in Harrisburg, Pa.

title: Anxiety at The Star Tribune
description: Clusters of visitors began walking through the offices of The Star Tribune in Minneapolis last week, casting acquisitive eyes on the newspaper and taking notes. The paper's newsroom staff had been warned beforehand not to expect introductions, and none were offered.

title: A WAR OF NUMBERS EMERGES OVER COST OF ENLARGING NATO
description: With a warning from Senator Jesse Helms last week that Senate approval of NATO expansion ''may very well succeed or fail'' on what share of the cost Europe is willing to pay, a rancorous and largely hidden debate is now surfacing over just what that cost should be.

title: THIS WEEK
description: EVENTS

title: White House to Release More Tapes
description: With the Justice Department facing another imminent deadline on the appointment of an independent counsel, the White House said today that it would soon release many more videotapes and audio tapes of President Clinton at Democratic Party events that would show no evidence of criminal wrongdoing.

title: Pride and Privacy Are Submerged in Workfare Evaluation
description: The welfare recipients in the overcrowded waiting rooms of H.S. Systems on West 45th Street are called by number, not by name. Ordered to the Manhattan clinic so the city can determine whether they are too sick or disabled to work for their benefits, they sit or stand with their canes, walkers and braces, waiting to be examined. To keep crowding down, the city tells them they must come alone. Some must hold on to urine samples while waiting.

title: Chekhov With Pratfalls, as a Symbol of Russia
description: Ready for another merry round of backstage back stabbing?

title: Before Cuba Crisis, A Not-So-Cool J.F.K.
description: To the Editor:

title: Driver of Runaway Bus Released From Hospital
description: The driver of a city bus that raced out of control on Fifth Avenue earlier this month, killing one man and critically injuring another, was released from the hospital on Saturday, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TATKON, CAROL CLARK
description: TATKON-Carol Clark, 59. In North Egremont, MA, October 11. Services October 13, 2 PM, in West Stockbridge, MA, Congregational Church. Former Sr. Vice President Exxon USA and presently Vice Chairman of Cornell University Board of Trustees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENETOS, STEVE
description: GENETOS-Steve, October 11, 1997. Funeral at St. Barbara Greek Orthodox Church, 480 Race Brook Rd., Orange, CT 06477, Tuesday, 10/14, 10 AM. Donations may be made to Church Building Fund or Connecticut Hospice, Inc., 61 Burban Dr., Branford, CT 06405.

title: Market Place; An investment analyst's battle with Woolworth.
description: CLINICALLY examined, the Woolworth Corporation is not exactly worth obsessing over.

title: Climate Change Imposes Heavy Financial Cost; Mexican Auto Controls
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, ROBERT F.
description: KAUFMAN-Robert F. Died October 11, 1997. Beloved husband of Jan; father of Clayton, Whitley and Douglas; grandfather of Katie, Perry and Harper.

title: Editorial Observer; The Beleaguered Department of Justice
description: The Justice Department can be a deceptive place. From the outside, the imposing gray building on Pennsylvania Avenue looks like a fortress. It is a different story inside. The department is actually a fragile place that needs to be carefully protected from Washington's political gales. When the wind rises and the windows start blowing in, career prosecutors and investigators cannot do their job. These days a hurricane is howling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN RENSSELAER, GEORGINA LAWRENCE WELLS
description: VAN RENSSELAER - Georgina Lawrence Wells. Wife of the late Cortlandt Schuyler Van Rensselaer. Mother of Nina Van Rensselaer and Catherine Townsend. Funeral service to be held at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, New York on October 15 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, a gift to the United Thank Offering or St. Matthew's Church, or the Chapin Alumni Fund would be appreciated.

title: FIGHTING OUTLASTS DEFEAT OF MOBUTU
description: Five months after seizing power in the former Zaire, President Laurent Kabila has yet to gain military control over the eastern province of this vast country, and his rise to power has not brought peace to Central Africa as the regional leaders who sponsored his rebellion hoped.

title: Flying High, From Flamenco to Jazz
description: Better dancers attract better choreographers; or so Tina Ramirez's law holds for Ballet Hispanico, the duckling-turned-swan company that she founded in 1970.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Dolphins Have Style: Nouveau N.F.C. East
description: They won their Super Bowls two apiece -- in the National Football Conference East, Bill Parcells with the Giants and Jimmy Johnson with the Cowboys.

title: Mr. Gates Goes to Moscow
description: Splashing through the wet streets of this chilly capital last week from meetings with bankers and industrialists to meetings with top officials of the Russian Government, the chairman of Microsoft, William H. Gates, was true to form. His diet was unbroken McDonald's, his discussions concerned either deals or his vision of a computer-aided future, and a key item on his agenda was stifling his competition.

title: Albert Blumberg, 91, Philosopher and Communist
description: Albert E. Blumberg, an idealistic philosophy professor who fought for economic and social reforms as an oft-harassed Communist Party official in the 1940's and 50's, then continued the fight with somewhat more success as a Democratic Party district leader in Manhattan, died on Wednesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center near his home in upper Manhattan. He was 91.

title: Chinese Village Swells With Pride as Washington Governor Seeks His Roots on a Pilgrimage
description: This tiny farming hamlet had never seen such a spectacle. Hundreds of villagers rushed in from their work in the fields. Schoolchildren lined the road to town for several miles, waving pompons, Ping-Pong paddles and bouquets of fake flowers, and chanting ''welcome, welcome, warmly welcome,'' in English and Taishanese, the Cantonese dialect spoken here.

title: B.A.T. Industries in Merger Talks With the Zurich Group
description: B.A.T. Industries of Britain said today that it was in serious negotiations to merge its insurance operations with the Zurich Group of Switzerland in a $32 billion deal that would separate them from the shadow of its tobacco business.

title: Money Becomes Electric
description: Can the computer-legible plastic cards that were mailed to some 50,000 bank customers on Manhattan's Upper West Side last week displace bills and coins between 60th and 96th Streets? For the moment perhaps not, but these cards are yet another sign that our relationship with money is changing.

title: Marino Continues Mastery Of the Jets
description: Jimmy Johnson does not usually hand out game balls until Monday afternoon, giving himself a chance to consider the honor carefully.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, ROBERT
description: LERNER-Robert. On Saturday, October 11. Beloved husband of Rose; adored father of Nathan ''Zeke'' (Lenore) and Linda ''Buddy''. Loved and admired by his grandsons Peter, Laurence, Jordan, Daniel and Jordan's fiancee Alana. Bob was in the men's shirt business with Bedford Shirt. He will be missed and forever loved. Services Tuesday, October 14, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Fat Can Be Good
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW ; Discovering There's Color In Shades of Gray on Gray
description: Shakespeare's close contemporary John Dowland did not go in much for variety of tone: from one of his songs to another, the biggest difference is likely to be whether the lamentation takes place in duple time or triple -- whether, in other words, the voice is slowly dancing a pavane or a galliard. The prospect, then, of a full evening of his music was worrying.

title: Wes Gallagher, 86, President And General Manager of A.P.
description: Wes Gallagher, who as president and general manager of The Associated Press oversaw substantial changes in news coverage and in the use of technology, died on Saturday at St. Francis Medical Center in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 86 and lived in Santa Barbara.

title: Game 3 Scorer Makes Change
description: The weird play that ended Game 3 of the American League Championship Series did not quite end Saturday night. The official scorer revised his decision today, giving Marquis Grissom of Cleveland a stolen base and taking a passed ball from Baltimore catcher Lenny Webster on the play, which gave the Indians a 3-2 victory in 12 innings.

title: The New Jets, Rolling Along, Hit an Old Bump: Marino
description: It was all there today for the Jets, in ways most of the players haven't known. A meaningful game in front of an imploring, green-jerseyed crowd. A classy opponent. A chance to move even closer to a first-place showdown in another week.

title: Wave of Bombings Stops in Cuba but Tensions Persist
description: The Cuban authorities are holding a suspect charged with carrying out a half dozen of the recent bomb attacks on hotels and restaurants here that have unnerved Government officials and ordinary Cubans. But the internal tensions caused by the blasts and the mystery of who is behind them remain.

title: Crowded Out of School
description: Imagine enrolling your child in a shiny new school only to see the computer lab ripped out to make way for new classrooms to ease overcrowding. The parents at a grade school in Ozone Park, Queens, do not have to imagine it. Their school opened just a year ago with good facilities and manageable class size, but it is already jammed to the rafters with new students for whom the school must scramble to find space and desks.

title: A Growing Clash of Visions At The Los Angeles Times
description: Anyone trying to understand the deep worries that have suddenly buffeted The Los Angeles Times need only have listened in last Monday as a group of reporters and editors confronted Mark H. Willes, the publisher of the newspaper, objecting to plans for a special section aimed at the Latino population.

title: ICG Reported Near a Deal For Netcom
description: Netcom On-line Communication Services Inc., one of the few remaining big independent Internet service providers, is in the final stage of negotiations to be acquired by ICG Communications Inc. for $250 million in stock, executives close to the talks said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEWART, VIRGINIA M.
description: STEWART-Virginia M., age 65 years, of Bayport, LI and Davis Park, Fire Island, on October 12, 1997. (Graduate of Packer Collegiate Institute, Brooklyn Heights, Class of 1952. Owner of Ethelind S. Realty Co., Davis Park, Fire Island). Beloved wife of Robert. Loving mother of Robert, Jr. Dear sister of Irene Fox, George Dagher and the late William Dagher. Cherished grandmother of Robert III, Lindsay and Brooke. Reposing at The Raynor & D'Andrea Funeral Home, 245 Montauk Hwy., West Sayville, Monday, 2-4:30 PM and 79 PM and Tuesday, 7-9 PM only. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10 AM, Our Lady of The Snow RC Church, Blue Point. Interment St. Ann's Cemetery, Sayville. Contributions in her memory to Sayville Cabinet for the Sick or Davis Park Community Association, appreciated.

title: Butler Passer Sets a Record
description: On a rare Sunday of high school football, quarterback Scott Brown put on a performance worthy of a professional.

title: CHRONICLE
description: VLADIMIR HAENSEL does not have a name that is instantly recognizable, but he is the winner of the country's richest prize for accomplishment in engineering.

title: Sports of The Times; Just More Weird Tales From the Post-Season
description: SOMEHOW or other, poor schnooky baseball comes up with these greatest-longest-weirdest games, leaving people wandering around the next day asking, ''Did you see that?''

title: WPP Unit Shuffles Top Management
description: The Simmons Market Research Bureau, the media research company in New York owned by WPP Group, has made changes in top management as it prepares to compete for a large tobacco industry research project.

title: GPU to Buy Australian State's Electrical Network
description: The American energy company GPU Inc., which has been expanding rapidly overseas, said today that it had bought the high-voltage electricity transmission network of the Australian state of Victoria for $2.72 billion (Australian), or $2 billion (United States).

title: Taking In the Sites; Echoes of Mideast Conflict on Line
description: In the real world of Middle Eastern conflict, the militant Islamic organization Hamas and Israel's intelligence agency Mossad locked horns long ago, exchanging assassinations and other violent attacks in a macabre pursuit of one another. There is nothing quite like this on the World Wide Web, yet, but echoes of the intensity of Islam's confrontation with Zionism and Western culture are mixing on the Web with the joyful sounds of young high-tech Muslims from all around the globe, who are now wandering around the Internet.

title: Transport Project Aims To Alleviate Congestion : A New Way Across Town
description: PARIS  One of the biggest challenges facing urban transport designers is to find ways of moving people around crowded cities quickly, cheaply and with minimal impact on the environment. In France, where certain car owners recently were prevented from driving in central Paris for a day to cut pollution, the need for progress is especially great.

title: She Smoked and He Sued; She Quit and They Both Won
description: For more than 20 years, Richard J. Thomas had begged and pleaded with his wife to stop smoking. Nothing worked.

title: Book jacket blurbs are, by definition, shameless. Want attention? Pan your own author.
description: BREATHLESS blurbs in praise of books are as mechanical as a response to ''How are you?'' Fine. Also delighted, haunted, satisfied, engaged, moved, thrilled and gripped.

title: Utah Is Warming Up To Newest Monument
description: One year ago, President Clinton and Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt were hung in effigy here on the day that President Clinton announced, from the safety of Arizona, the creation of the new Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument.

title: Donations Save Gun Program
description: In April, the Montclair Police Department's program to take guns off the streets by buying them from owners went out of business after running out of money. But on Saturday, the program got a second chance when residents donated $23,000.

title: Libel Typecasting
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Strange Night in Cleveland as the Indians Take Command
description: Once again, the Indians and the Orioles made the game nerve-racking. Once again, the Indians won in dramatic fashion. Once again, Sandy Alomar Jr. laced a game-winning hit, this time a two-out single in the bottom of the ninth inning that vaulted the surging Indians to an 8-7 victory in Game 4 and placed them in an enviable position in the American League Championship Series.

title: Teheran Journal; Who Says There's No Fun in an Islamic Republic?
description: There are people here who remember the New City as Teheran's red-light district, crawling with gamblers, pimps, addicts and the patrons of its several brothels, none of which ever raised a blink from Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: SHARPTON'S SUPPORT -- After a month of uncertainty, the Rev. Al Sharpton endorsed Ruth W. Messinger, urging his supporters to vote for her in November. B3.

title: Sports of The Times; Reconstructed Jets Expose Their Own Weaknesses
description: WHEN the Jets edged the Oakland Raiders, 23-22, three weeks ago, they were suddenly 2-2 on their way to a

title: What Makes a Doctor?
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Union Vote In Mexico Illustrates Abuses
description: For three years, Armando Hernandez belonged to a Government-controlled union he had never heard of, led by labor bosses he had never seen. His 85-cents-an-hour wage was set by a contract negotiated in secret that he was not allowed to read.

title: Trinity Topples Tufts, 13-3
description: In a game that matched the league's best offense against its best defense, the Tufts offense never had a chance yesterday.

title: William Hartman, 78, Influenced Sex Research
description: William E. Hartman, whose teachings and research on sex influenced a generation of sex therapists, died on Sept. 26 in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 78 and lived in Long Beach.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LA PIDUS, GERTRUDE
description: LA PIDUS-Gertrude. Remembered with love on your birthday. Joan and Mike

title: Worldcom Fancies Itself Muffler of the Local Bells
description: When Bernard J. Ebbers, the chairman of Worldcom Inc., wanted to convince MCI Communications shareholders on Friday that his company would be a better mate for MCI than British Telecommunications P.L.C., the main reason he gave was that Worldcom owns local phone networks around the United States, while British Telecom does not.

title: Instant Friendship Wins the Empire
description: It is called New York Showcase Day because it consists of a series of stakes for horses bred in New York State. Sixty-nine of them competed yesterday in the seven showcase races at Belmont Park, and the day's honors went to Leo O'Brien, who trained two of the winners: Irish Daisy in the Ticonderoga and Instant Friendship in the featured Empire Classic.

title: Improvising at the Piano And Creating a Narrative
description: There's a sense when the pianist Gonzalo Rubalcaba plays that pretty much anything can happen. Mr. Rubalcaba knows how to frame his improvisations, to make every silence, every slapping chord sound surprising, and at the Iridium on Thursday night that ability to create a clean narrative, in which one musical event followed the next, made the audience pay attention.

title: Amid Figures, Finest of Feelings
description: Could we please put the numbers aside for a week or two or three? Let's look beyond the strange mechanics of an industry that intends to preserve the bowl tradition by holding next season's championship game on the fourth of January, 1999, and by turning the 2002 Rose Bowl into a night game, which means it will not be the Rose Bowl anymore. Let's crunch numbers and play politics when the season is in sharper focus.

title: Messier Treads Softly on Old Pals
description: Early Saturday evening, before Wayne Gretzky and the Rangers routed the Canucks, there came one of those revealing moments that seem to stand as stark and still as a freeze frame in the kaleidoscopic swirl of a hockey game.

title: Kennametal to Buy Greenfield, the Top Maker of Drill Bits
description: Kennametal Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Greenfield Industries for about $623 million plus the assumption of debt, adding the No. 1 maker of drill bits to its line of industrial metalworking tools.

title: Jean Pasqualini Dies at 71; Told of China's Penal Horrors
description: Jean Pasqualini, whose book about the seven years he spent as a political prisoner in China's labor camps first exposed the hidden world of the penal system here, died in Paris on Thursday after a long illness. He was 71.

title: Before Cuba Crisis, A Not-So-Cool J.F.K.
description: To the Editor:

title: Cause of Plane Crash Sought
description: Investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board are continuing to look for clues to what caused a small plane to crash in Marlboro on Saturday morning, killing the pilot and three passengers.

title: Sorry About the Cannons
description: The city's Parks Commissioner has apologized to veterans for removing two Civil War-era cannons from a park and giving them to a scrap metal dealer, The Associated Press reported.

title: Lott, Champion Money-Raiser, Still Champions Rules of Game
description: After ringing the death knell for a campaign finance overhaul on the floor of the Senate last Tuesday evening, the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, had other pressing business.

title: Love and Lust, the Down-Home Way
description: For nearly 40 years, Delbert McClinton has been on the roadhouse circuit, singing blues, soul, country and rock in places where the floor is wet with spilled beer. He has had fitful pop success: a Top 40 hit in 1980 with ''Giving It Up for Your Love'' and a Grammy-winning duet with Bonnie Raitt in 1991 on ''Good Man, Good Woman.'' He has plenty of fans within the music business; his new album, ''One of the Fortunate Few'' (Rising Tide/Universal), includes guest appearances by B. B. King, John Prine and Lyle Lovett.

title: Bond Issues Scheduled for the Week Ahead
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to tomorrow's auction of three- and six-month bills. The bond market is closed today in observance of Columbus Day, a Federal holiday.

title: New York Harbor Steps Up Share of Cargo Traffic
description: Buoyed by a strong economy and a reduction in shipping fees, New York Harbor handled nearly 12 percent more cargo traffic during the first half of this year, compared with the same period last year, the Port Authority reported yesterday.

title: New England Wins A.B.L. Opener
description: With a slogan of ''We've Got the Players'' to counter the ''We Got Next'' refrain of the competing Women's National Basketball Association, the American Basketball League began its second season tonight before a league-record crowd of 12,683 at the Hartford Civic Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHTRITT, JACK
description: HIRSCHTRITT-Jack. The firm of Newman Tannenbaum Helpern Syracuse & Hirschtritt LLP note with deep sorrow the passing of the beloved father of our Managing Partner, Joel Hirschtritt. Jack was a loving husband, father, and grandfather, who took great pride in his son's achievements and commitment on behalf of many charitable organizations. We extend heartfelt sympathy to Jack's wife Ethel, his daughter Carol, his daughter-in-law Nancy, and his grandchildren Evan, Marissa, Stefanie, Ali and Jon.

title: Suspect Is Arrested After Turning to Police
description: The streets of midtown were raw and windy early yesterday, and Chris Applewhite, who had just been robbed at gunpoint of his leather jacket, was cold, the police said. Mr. Applewhite flagged down two officers on 40th Street near Madison Avenue, to report the crime.

title: Metro Matters; In This Race, Being Pretty Isn't the Point
description: IN last week's mayoral debate, Ruth W. Messinger began with a joke that was certainly her funniest line of the campaign up to this point, and perhaps her most insightful as well. ''When you look at the two of us,'' she said, ''you know this election isn't a beauty contest.''

title: 1997 BASEBALL PLAYOFFS
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Bad Guys, Good Guys: Journalists in the Movies
description: ''Five Star Final,'' made in 1931, the same year as ''The Front Page,'' depicts a thoroughly despicable reporter who lies, steals and pretends he's a clergyman to get a story. The journalist is played by Boris Karloff.

title: Correction: Monitoring the Fumes
description: Below is a corrected chart showing the results of tests for the level of perchloroethylene, a noxious chemical, in the air at the former site of Public School 141, which was once a dry cleaner's plant. The tests were conducted by AKRF Inc., an agent for the building's owner, and Roy F. Weston Inc., consultant to the city's School Construction Authority.

title: Census Bureau Names Five Ad Agencies
description: The United States Census Bureau has named Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York and four other agencies to handle the first paid advertising campaign to persuade Americans to participate in a census. The campaign, for the 2000 census, will receive $100 million in Federal spending, pending Congressional approval.

title: Offerings Set For Equities During Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Abroad at Home; Medicine and Politics
description: The medical use of marijuana remains a poisonous idea in political Washington. Williams Weld's support for it was one of Senator Jesse Helms's stated reasons for blocking his nomination as Ambassador to Mexico, and no one in Washington wanted even to discuss it.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: EXTRA POINTS ; Kicker Pressed Into Extra Duty
description: When Brian Hansen sustained what could be a medial collateral ligament knee injury in the third quarter, place-kicker John Hall suddenly became the Jets' punter.

title: First, Fix Nafta
description: President Clinton shouldn't be surprised about the pale reception his ''fast track'' trade package is receiving on Capitol Hill.

title: More Geek, Less Chic; After a Tryout at Microsoft, the Hip Gives Way to the Really Useful
description: Morale is not running high these days in Building E on Microsoft's Redmond West campus, hangout for the black-clad creative types that the geeky software giant has hired in recent years to build a new, chic kind of media business.

title: A Private Eye; As Writers Despair, Book Chains Can Only Exult
description: When Leonard Riggio, the chief executive of Barnes & Noble, produced a sheet of paper one recent evening that revealed to more than 400 people precisely what modest numbers each of Cynthia Ozick's books sell in a year, this distinguished woman of letters looked embarrassed and shocked. She is a sensitive person for whom the evening -- a panel discussion on book publishing sponsored by The New Yorker magazine at the New York Public Library on 42d Street -- was a strain in any case. Timidly, she assured Mr. Riggio, who said she would probably like to sell more but then so would Stephen King, that she was not complaining. She seemed humbly grateful that so many of her books of fiction, essays and criticism were still in print. But for me, some melancholy lingered after hearing that Mr. Riggio's nationwide empire of nearly a thousand stores had, for instance, sold only a few hundred copies of ''The Shawl,'' Ms. Ozick's masterpiece of Holocaust literature. On reflection, that bullying moment of shattered privacy, that rending of the veil between a literary artist and a businessman armed with numbers that he gave an impression of having casually punched up on his computer as he was on his way out of his office, strike me as a cultural watershed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCAROLA, THERESA T.
description: SCAROLA-Theresa T. On October 10, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Michael F. Loving sister of Aurora Turso, Angelina Turso, Ann Baldino, Vincent, Dominick, Marcello and Mauro Turso. Devoted stepmother of Angela Gray, John and Michael Scarola. Also survived by thirteen grandchildren and six great grandchildren. Reposing at the Conway Funeral Home, Northern Blvd. at 83rd St., Jackson Heights. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joan of Arc Church, Tuesday, 9:30 AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery. Visiting hours 2-5 and 7-9 PM, Sunday and Monday.

title: Columbus Day
description: The holiday, actually Oct. 12, is legally observed today.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : Bottling Moose Drool Can Get You Into Trouble
description: Microbreweries have been busting out all over, proving so popular that one tongue-in-cheek television ad for Miller, one of the nation's biggest brewers, urges viewers to give a "good old macrobrew" a chance.

title: Bonilla Ends Misery, Prolonging Maddux's
description: Throughout the 1990's, Greg Maddux and Bobby Bonilla have been brothers in misery.

title: American Orders For Machine Tools Increased in August
description: American orders for machine tools rose 10.2 percent in August from the month before, lifted by purchases by the auto parts and aerospace industries, according to a survey by two trade groups.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about a memorial service for fallen firefighters at the Firemen's Memorial in Manhattan misstated its location in some editions. The monument is at Riverside Drive and 100th Street, not 110th Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the reopening of the Great Lawn in Central Park after a two-year rehabilitation project misstated the name of one park area. It is the Arthur Ross Pinetum, not Arthur Rice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, SAM
description: FRIEDMAN-Sam, 97. On October 11, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Esther, devoted father of Harry, Marvin, and Sandy Groveman, cherished father-in-law, adored grandfather of nine and great grandfather of fourteen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATOWITZ, HARRY
description: KATOWITZ-Harry. On October 11, 1997. Devoted husband of the late Claire for 47 years. He was a warm and generous man and was most loved by all who knew him. He will be remembered and missed by many. Loving father of Shelley and Jim Hoberman. Dear grandfather of Mara and Anna. Funeral service Tuesday, Oct. 14, 10 AM at Garlick-Hellman Funeral Home, Yonkers, NY. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: Fine-tuning Clarinet Production
description: MANTES-LA-VILLE, France  Of all the wind instruments, Mozart most loved the clarinet. Von Weber used it to express his most sublime passages. Generations of jazz players have adopted it for its velvety low tones and liquid highs. Intimate as the voice and stretching a remarkable four octaves, the tone of the clarinet is for many musicians as close to perfection as human nature can get.

title: Accounts
description: * MacGregor Golf Co., Albany, Ga., to Howard, Merrell & Partners, Raleigh, N.C., to handle its account, which had been handled in-house and by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

description: Below is a corrected chart showing the results of tests for the level of perchloroethylene, a noxious chemical, in the air at the former site of Public School 141, which was once a dry cleaner's plant. The tests were conducted by AKRF Inc., an agent for the building's owner, and Roy F. Weston Inc., consultant to the city's School Construction Authority.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Sept. 24 about the licensing of characters from ''Arthur'' and other PBS children's shows misidentified the licenser for the characters from another such show, ''Thomas the Tank Engine.'' It is the Britt Allcroft Company, not the Itsy Bitsy Entertainment Company.

title: Car Thefts Decline in Newark
description: This city has often been derided as the nation's car theft capital, but according to police statistics, the number of cars reported stolen in the first seven months of 1997 dropped by more than 30 percent over the same period last year.

title: CAMPAIGN STOP: Views From the Neighborhoods; Safe and Satisfied in Whitestone
description: Bessie Aslanidis was in a hurry. She was feeding quarters into the meter, trying to avoid a parking ticket on busy 14th Avenue in Whitestone, Queens. She was rushing to get her nails done in a salon around the corner. But she stopped for a moment to consider the New York City mayoral campaign.

title: Patents; A computer system with an eye (and ear) for crime, or at least for re-enactments thereof.
description: IMAGINE that Central Park were studded with discreetly placed cameras that fed images into computers programmed to keep a watchful eye. This may sound darkly Orwellian, but David G. Aviv, a former aerospace engineer, has patented exactly such a system as a way of combatting crime.

title: Phelps Group Buys Cohen/Johnson
description: Phelps Group in Los Angeles has acquired and absorbed Cohen/Johnson in Los Angeles. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Study Links Drop in Support To Elitist Attitude in the Arts
description: Stunning increases in the numbers of American artists and arts groups over the last 30 years have far outpaced the growth in public and private support and cannot be sustained, a new Federal study says.

description: IT sometimes seems as if a major preoccupation of old media is new media. With nearly suicidal determination, vast quantities of ink, staples and glue are being used to celebrate the on-line world of pixel publishing.

description: In his four years as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Reed E. Hundt has presided over the most tumultuous era in the F.C.C.'s history, a period during which change -- economic, political and technological -- washed over the communications industry like a tidal wave and made this relatively sleepy regulatory agency one of the most powerful forces in Washington.

description: WAIT TILL NEXT YEAR

description: In April, the Montclair Police Department's program to take guns off the streets by buying them from their owners ran out of money. But on Saturday, the program got a second chance when local residents donated $23,000.

title: Where There's Grissom, There's Usually a Rally
description: This time all Marquis Grissom did was stand there. Honestly. He didn't get a hit that won the game, he didn't get a hit that started a rally that won the game, he didn't score the run that won the game. He just happened to be the batter when the game turned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, JOSEPH H.
description: SIMON-Joseph H. Much loved by his family, died October 11, in his 100th year. He was the husband of Bertha, his wife for 57 years, devoted and loving father of John Simon and Patricia Scheines; fatherin-law to Laura Lee and Morton, adored grandfather of Terri, James, and Andrew Simon; Richard and Elizabeth Scheines and their spouses, Eric Levine, Audrey and Nancy Simon, Martha Harty and Ron Elton, and great grandfather of ten. He is also survived by his sister, Dorothy Fisher, and a host of nieces and nephews. Following a small family service, the family will be at the Scheines home in New York from 3 PM Monday and 4 PM Tuesday, and at the Simon home in Connecticut from 7 PM on Tuesday.

title: Fine Levied in Phone Scheme
description: A Texas telecommunications company has been punished for switching the long-distance service of some telephone users in New Jersey without their permission, a crime informally known as ''slamming,'' state investigators said Friday.

title: Bus Door Fails, Throwing Rider Onto Highway
description: A Brooklyn teen-ager leaning against the emergency door of an overcrowded bus chartered by a church, was critically injured yesterday afternoon when she fell onto a highway, the authorities said.

title: High-Tech Eavesdropping Raises New Questions on Personal Privacy
description: ''It's sort of a dodgy business,'' Gilbert Walz told a purported buyer who had expressed an interest in purchasing gear allowing the monitoring of cellular telephone conversations, according to a report later filed by the buyer, who was actually a Federal investigator.

title: Military Is Neutral as Majors Fight Over Children
description: When Maj. Bernice Beckwith of the Defense Intelligence Agency kissed her two sons goodbye in July last year and put them on a plane for Illinois and a summer vacation with their father -- her ex-husband, another Air Force officer -- she expected them home a month later, in time for the start of the school year.

title: A major force in marketing to college students steps up its activities on the Internet.
description: A PROMINENT force in the growing field of marketing to college students is intensifying its involvement in the Internet and helping a giant advertiser do the same.

description: To the Editor:

description: ROSENBAUM-Walter. 75, died Saturday, October 11. Beloved husband of Sylvia, devoted father of Joseph. He was President of Louis Levine Royal Lodge #

title: INSIDE
description: Huge Merger in the Works

title: Wall St. Firms Weigh Video-Web Link
description: Merrill Lynch & Company and two units of Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company are nearing completion of a deal with MSNBC Business Video to have it provide video feeds for the Web sites of the Wall Street firms, according to people close to the negotiations.

title: Struggle Over Gun Control Laws Shifts to States and Tests N.R.A.
description: For the last two weeks, Tanya Metaksa, the chief lobbyist for the National Rifle Association, has forsaken the marble corridors of the other Washington to work the asphalt byways of this one. For the gun lobby, there is no bigger battle in 1997 than a handgun-licensing initiative that will go before voters here next month.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, some copies of SportsSunday omitted the continuation of an article about the Penn State-Ohio State football game. Readers wishing a copy of the article may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or telephone (212) 556-1992. E-mail: quality@nytimes.com. (Include a postal address.)

title: Small Schools Face Limits On Autonomy
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has moved to limit the independence of the scores of small, innovative public academies at the heart of New York City's school reform effort of the last decade, a model that has been copied by school reformers around the nation.

title: New Blend On Offense Gives Giants 3-Game Streak
description: Seven games into their season, the Giants have been reborn. They have a winning streak, a winning record and a host of new faces serving as centerpieces of the revival. In a matter of three weeks, the team that wobbled through a dreadful defeat in St. Louis has recast itself with a new quarterback, a new running back, a new leading receiver and a young, dominating defense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, IRWIN ''SPIKE''
description: STEIN-Irwin ''Spike''. Died Friday, October 10 in Corning, New York. Beloved husband of Ruth; father of Jamie, Michael, and the late Peter Lincoln; grandfather of Julie, Katherine, Liam and Peter Seth. Services on Tuesday, October 14, at 10 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels in Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your local Literacy Volunteers chapter in his name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, BARRY R.
description: ROGERS-Barry R. Beloved husband of Helen; devoted son of David and Lillian; loving brother of Jesse. Services 11:15 AM on Monday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 2 Boats Overtake Whitbread Leader
description: After leading the Whitbread Round the World Race for 14 days, Innovation Kvaerner was overtaken by both EF Language and Merit Cup on Saturday night.

title: Commercial Construction Up
description: Nonresidential construction, which has lagged for several years, increased by 58 percent during the first half of the year in New Jersey, state officials announced last week.

title: Bates Gets Accounts From Carter-Wallace
description: Carter-Wallace Inc. in New York has consolidated its consumer products account, with combined billings estimated at $30 million, at Bates USA in New York. Those duties had been divided for many years between Bates, part of Cordiant P.L.C., and Avrett, Free & Ginsberg in New York.

title: People
description: * Alan Taylor was named to the new position of worldwide corporate marketing director at Diefenbach Elkins, New York, a corporate and brand identity consulting company that is part of McCann-Erickson World Group, owned by the Interpublic Group of Cos. He had been president at Interbrand, Zintzmeyer & Lux, New York, a corporate identity consulting company that is part of the Interbrand Group, a unit of the Omnicom Group.

title: An Irreverent Director Advises Reverent Fans
description: Oliver Stone, class of '71, came back to New York University on Friday night, bringing a pair of mature-looking spectacles, a bushel of books and a few hard-learned lessons.

title: A Shrine to Books Past Clings to Independence
description: Books. Two hundred thousand books. Five floors of them. Books with moire silk endpapers and rich linings, gilt edges and crushed Moroccan leather bindings. First editions and incunabula, old letters and maps and prints for every occasion. The Argosy Book Store stands indomitably, an oasis of calm and mustiness, amid the skyscrapers and bustle of 59th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues.

title: An Outside Chance: Hernandez's 15 Strikeouts Put the Marlins in Control
description: Livan Hernandez, pitching today only because the Marlins' best pitcher could not, spun a curveball to Atlanta's Fred McGriff in the first inning and it plopped into the glove of catcher Charles Johnson six inches to a foot or so outside. A strike, the home plate umpire, Eric Gregg, said.

title: Secrets of a Bit of Fabric on the Floor
description: Nayo Takasaki plays games with her dancers and her audience. She even called a work ''A Game Is'' on the program of three premieres that her group, Nayo and Friends, presented on Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio.

title: Governor's Race Tightens, 2 Polls Suggest
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and State Senator James E. McGreevey, her Democratic challenger, paraded across metropolitan New Jersey today, the same day two polls suggested that the race for governor was narrowing sharply.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Climate Change Imposes Heavy Financial Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: A Stylish Triumph For France's Brochard
description: With his big earrings, blond ponytail and colorful bandanna around his forehead, Laurent Brochard looks more like a mountain-bike racer than a member of the road fraternity, which tends to regard two-day stubble as a daring fashion statement. Yet this afternoon, Brochard, a 29-year-old Frenchman, found himself crowned king of the road.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEVLIN, LEONORE (NEE KEYES)
description: SHEVLIN-Leonore (nee Keyes), 71, on October 10, 1997. Cherished wife of John J. Shevlin. Loving mother of Patricia Shevlin Holmes, Raymond J. Shevlin and Nancy E. Shevlin. Dearest motherin-law of Theodore E. Holmes and beloved grandmother of Sally and Jack Holmes. Much loved sister of Marion Keyes, Robert and Marie Keyes, William and Jeanne Keyes and the late Dorothy Day. Funeral service Tuesday, Oct. 14, 1997 at 10 AM at A.S. Cole Funeral Home, 22 N. Main St., Cranbury, NJ. Burial in Holy Cross Burial Park. Calling hours Monday, 3-5 and 7-8:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAZANECKI, THEODORE
description: KAZANECKI-Theodore. October 10, 1997. Beloved husband of Mary; devoted father of Rev. Thaddeus Kazanecki, Christine Kemp, Paul and Helen. Reposing Bay Ridge Funeral Home, Inc., 6741 5th Ave, Brooklyn, until Tuesday 9 A.M. Mass of Christian Burial 10 A.M., St. Andrew the Apostle Church. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Rose Home appreciated. Visiting on Monday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID RAPPAPORT, 83, a former fashion designer and manufacturer, has never tried to sell a painting, nor has he had an exhibit, but he is making his artistic debut tomorrow in an unusually visible place: the windows of Barneys on Madison Avenue at 61st Street. Sixteen of his canvases will be on view there for two weeks, along with designer men's fashions.

title: Foreign Affairs ; Madeleine & Bill
description: The French oil company Total, the Russian oil company Gazprom and the Malaysian oil company Petronas just signed a $2 billion contract with Iran to jointly explore its South Pars offshore gas field. The deal was strongly endorsed by the French, Malaysian and Russian Governments and is a direct challenge to the U.S. law that orders sanctions on any companies that do big energy business with Iran. Here's my guess at what Secretary of State Madeleine Albright and President Clinton are now saying to each other.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What's happened to public arts funding is in no small measure the fault of the arts institutions and the individuals who run them.''

title: Banks Offer Discount Loans
description: Two New Jersey banks have agreed to provide $78 million in discount loans to low-income and minority applicants in eight counties, the state's largest consumer watchdog group said last week.

title: Sports of The Times; Giant Offensive Line Has Its Way
description: FORTY-FIVE minutes after the Giants' 27-13 victory over the Cardinals yesterday, Bernard Wilson, Arizona's 6-foot-3-inch, 318-pound defensive tackle stood by the locker room door, in a state of uncertainty -- unsure whether to leave or to linger. It had been that kind of stunning afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, JANE L.
description: BERGER-Jane L. Beloved wife of the late Irwin. Devoted mother of Sherri Rothstein, Meredith, Bruce and Stacey Berger. Loving daughter of Pearl Novak. Cherished grandmother of Ilana and Rachel. Dear sister of Jay Novak. Services Monday, 10AM, at The Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris, Inc., 21 E. Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, L.I.

title: Patriots Bounce Back With a Bang or Two
description: BILLS 6

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: GPU Will Buy in Australia And Sell Some U.S. Assets

title: Bridge; Foolish Contract Can Work
description: It is a truth universally acknowledged, as Jane Austen might well have said, that a single bridge player in possession of good high-card strength must be in want of the majority of the trumps. The players on the diagrammed deal, from the 1995 world championships in Beijing, were clearly unaware of this valuable maxim.

title: HSBC Holdings Changes Guard
description: HSBC Holdings P.L.C., Britain's largest bank, said today that its chairman, Sir William Purves, would retire on May 31 and be succeeded by the chief executive, John Bond, as part of a wide-ranging management shake-up.

title: Little Independent Oversight
description: The experience of many welfare recipients inside H.S. Systems has produced skepticism about the motives of the clinic, which determines whether welfare recipients are healthy enough to take part in workfare programs.

title: Sharpton and Messinger Seal Awkward Political Alliance
description: Ruth W. Messinger and the Rev. Al Sharpton campaigned together for the first time yesterday, with Mr. Sharpton publicly urging his supporters at two black churches to turn out in November and help his former opponent oust Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: EXTRA POINTS ; Young's Leaving Is Still a Rumor
description: Giants General Manager George Young declined comment on a NBC-TV report that he planned to retire from his post at the conclusion of this season. ''I have nothing to say about rumors or whispers,'' Young said.

title: DANCE REVIEW ; Two Who Tried Hard But Failed To Connect
description: It was better to look and listen than to count when Mills and Payne Dance presented ''Four Truths: An Evening of Live Music and Dance'' at the Joyce SoHo.

title: Humankind's 3,000 Years Of Prowling the Universe
description: The first hour of ''Stephen Hawking's Universe'' carries us across 3,000 years of astronomy or cosmology, from Eratosthenes to Ptolemy to Copernicus to Galileo to Newton to Einstein up to Edwin Hubble, as our little planet went from being the seeming center of all things to being just another unremarkable inhabitant of a galaxy. For the next five Mondays, the programs prowl outer space, inspecting such phenomena as the big bang, dark matter, quasars, black holes and the concept of a universe that began with an indescribable explosion and has never stopped expanding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALLER, JESS
description: WALLER-Jess. 83, of New Bern, NC, died Saturday at home. Survived by his wife Joyce, three daughters Betsy Shillinglaw of Brewster, MA, Leslie Waller of New York, NY and Peggy Doherty of CT. Also a sister, Miriam Justin of New York; and two grandchildren. Graveside services will be Tuesday, 11 AM, Mount Lebanon, Queens, NY.

title: Queens Council Incumbent, Once Critic, Is Now Criticized
description: Four years ago, Alfonso C. Stabile was a political novice running for the City Council who took on an entrenched incumbent from Queens, depicting him as an ineffective legislator who was woefully out of touch with voters.

title: Climate Change Imposes Heavy Financial Cost; Big Oil Wins Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Car-Pooling Advantage
