description: To the Editor:

title: Slattery Sets Pace
description: Steve Slattery of Mount Olive High School, the New Jersey state champion, had the fastest time among 8,000 runners in 33 races yesterday at the Manhattan College high school cross-country meet at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: Police Identify Victims In Fatal Airplane Crash
description: Investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board are continuing to look for clues to what caused a small plane to crash in Marlboro on Saturday morning, killing the pilot and the three passengers.

title: A Perilous Pause on Nuclear Cuts
description: Nearly a decade after the end of the cold war, some 30,000 nuclear warheads are still available for use around the world, each with devastating destructive power. Future generations may someday look back at the failure to reduce that total more rapidly as the greatest blunder of the 1990's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAXTER, LORRAINE S.
description: BAXTER-Lorraine S. On Friday, October 10, 1997, of Marlboro, NY, and a former resident of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Q. Baxter, Jr. Loved and loving mother of Barbara L. Baxter, S. Noel and Sandy F., Wayne C. and Sally W. Dear grandmother of Paul V., Sarah Q., Luke B. Winters, and Jennifer N. Conway, Allison L., Elizabeth A., and Thaddeus W., Danford S. and Rebecca B. Baxter. Great-grandmother of Austin T., Lindsay A. Baxter and Madeleine L. Conway. Grandmother by marriage of Nancy F. Baxter and Paul J. Conway. Loved and loving sister of Charles F. Schoenlein, D.D.S., and his wife Lois, and her late sister Gertrude Webster. Also survived by many nieces, nephews and cousins. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Inc., 9807 Ascan Avenue (corner Metropolitan Ave), Forest Hills, NY 11375, Sunday, October 12, 1997, 7-9 PM, and Monday, October 13, 1997, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Services St. Luke's Church, 85 Greenway South, Forest Hills, NY, Tuesday, October 14, 1997, at 10 AM. Reposing also at her home, 184 Plattekill Rd, Marlboro, NY, on Tuesday, October 14, 1997, 3-9 PM. Committal service at Cedar Hill Cemetery, Middle Hope, NY, Wednesday morning. Memorials as desired. Donations to Louis Busch Hager Cancer Center, Bassett Health Care, One Atwell Rd, Cooperstown, NY 13326-1394, in mom's memory would be appreciated.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Communist Party Congress in Cuba misidentified two officials in some copies. The party secretary for Havana is Esteban Lazo Hernandez, not Esteban Lazo Cardenas. A new Politburo member is Jorge Luis Sierra, not Jose Luis Sierra.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAUBENBLATT, DEBORAH
description: TAUBENBLATT-Deborah. Congregation Ohab Zedek, Belle Harbor, mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our esteemed member, Ruth Rackman. May the bereaved family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob Reiner, Rabbi Mendy Bauman, Stanley Liker, Presidium

title: In Venezuela, Clinton Promotes Hemisphere Trade Zone
description: Envisioning ''a new world in the making,'' President Clinton arrived here today to begin his first trip to South America, planning to oversee the signing of modest agreements on energy, education and the environment -- and hoping to generate enthusiasm back home for a free-trade zone throughout the hemisphere.

title: Seoul's Mighty, Once Immune, Now Feel the Arm of the Law
description: A son of President Kim Young Sam of South Korea was sentenced to three years in prison today for bribery and tax evasion, in a stunning demonstration of how Korean democracy has come to apply the rule of law even to the nation's most powerful family.

title: Coke's Chairman Is Critically Ill; Some Duties Given to President
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Roberto C. Goizueta, was in critical condition in an intensive-care unit of Emory University Hospital in Atlanta, suffering from a throat infection and fever contracted during treatment for lung cancer.

title: The Disappearance of Mansour Kikhia
description: Mansour Kikhia, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's most prominent Libyan critic, vanished on a visit to Cairo in December 1993. At the time he was an American resident, four months away from citizenship. This summer the C.I.A. concluded that Mr. Kikhia had been kidnapped by Egyptian agents, turned over to Libya and executed. Washington should insist that Egypt identify and punish those responsible for extending the reach of Libyan terrorism to an American national in Cairo.

title: HOSPITALITY TO PURCHASE 9 HOTELS FROM MARRIOTT
description: Hospitality Properties Trust agreed to buy nine hotels, seven of which are still under construction, from Marriott International Inc. for $129 million. Marriott will sell three Residence Inns and six Courtyard hotels with a total of 1,336 rooms, and operate them under long-term leases. The sales will take place as each property opens by the end of next year. The transaction is part of Marriott's strategy to expand its hotel brands, including Marriott, Ritz-Carlton and Fairfield, by operating or franchising hotels owned by other companies. In April, Hospitality Properties, a real estate investment trust, agreed to buy 14 hotels from Marriott for $149 million. Marriott stock rose 18.75 cents, to $73.50, while Hospitality Properties climbed 56.25 cents, to $36.1875.

title: Review/Fashion; Armani as the Real Celebrity
description: After years of courting celebrities, designers finally got one they deserve: Demi Moore. Ms. Moore went to this month's shows in London, Milan and is planning to attend those in Paris, which begin on Monday. In Ms. Moore, designers have a celebrity who came an hour late to the Gucci presentation, which started the minute she hit her seat (although Tom Ford, the house's designer, said he had insisted the show not be held). Then her bodyguards stopped journalists from going backstage afterward, while Ms. Moore offered private congratulations.

title: Observer; Funny as a Root Canal
description: It is tempting to dismiss Washington's political money scandal as just another farce acted by buffoons and hypocrites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROME, FLORENCE
description: ROME-Florence, 87, at her home in Manhattan on October 6, 1997. Wife of the late Harold Rome. Mother of Joshua and Rachel. Grandmother of Shoshanna and Leah. Memorial service at 11 A.M. Wednesday, Oct. 15, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81st Street).

title: Republicans Overlook Reagan's Fund-Raising
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRENCE, RUSSELL C., JR.
description: LAWRENCE-Russell C., Jr., of New York City, on October 11, 1997. Beloved brother of Sheila Aaron and Steve Lawrence, both of Arkansas. A New York celebration of his life will be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAGAN, HILDEGARD (NEE WALLACH)
description: KAGAN-Hildegard (nee Wallach). 93. On October 11, 1997 in Geneva, Switzerland. Devoted wife of the late Illi Kagan. She is survived by her brother, Helmuth Wallach, her two children, Tanya Josefowitz and Vladimir Kagan, six granchildren and ten great-grandchildren. She had a wonderful, long life and will be missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Breast Cancer Research. Services will held in Geneva, Switzerland.

title: LVMH Now Backs Merger Of Grand Met And Guinness
description: Ending a messy war over the future of the European spirits business, Guinness P.L.C. and Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said yesterday that they would forge ahead with their $20 billion merger, this time with the blessing of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., which had said it would try to block the deal.

title: Brooklyn Mother Is Charged With Strangling Her Daughter, 3
description: Latisha McGhee was unusually calm when she walked into a police station on Sunday evening in Brooklyn to file a missing persons report for her 3-year-old daughter, the police said.

title: SOCCER: NOTEBOOK
description: WORLD CUP

title: Jobs Mean Less Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Leaps From Bach Variations
description: Mark Haim, who has been showing his dances publicly since 1984, is a choreographer's choreographer. ''The Goldberg Variations,'' the new solo he created for himself, is one man's view of Bach and it is anything but narrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, MARIE CONSALVI
description: BELL-Marie Consalvi, 99, died Friday in Norwalk, CT. Wife of the late Harry C. Bell, she is survived by a son, Daniel W. Bradley; two daughters, Jean B. Harper, Mimi Bradley Bliss; 12 grandchildren, nine great-grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to Notre Dame Convalescent Home, 76 West Rocks Road, Norwalk, Connecticut 06850.

title: As Election Approaches, City Is Flush With Cash
description: New York City took in $150 million to $200 million more in taxes from July through September than officials had projected, which could allow Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to channel more money into popular programs in the weeks before Election Day.

title: Fighting Back With Goofiness
description: Paco Mir makes tea in his mouth. Joan Gracia impersonates an ice cube. And Carles Sans plays a bored percussionist who has a pizza delivered in the middle of a symphony concert.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MICHAEL JACKSON has a new title to his credit. He was made a member of the Bafokeng Ka Bakwena (People of the Crocodile) tribe in Phokeng, South Africa, on Saturday, The Associated Press reported yesterday. His former wife, LISA MARIE PRESLEY, and her two children were on hand for the ceremony.

title: Lawyers Take Too Much
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAGG, THOMAS H
description: STAGG-Thomas H, of Carlstad on Oct. 12 1997, beloved husband of Maryanne (nee King), dear father of Brian, Luke and Billy. Brother of Helene Martin, son-in-law of Harriet King. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from The Kamienski Funeral Home, 106 Locust Avenue, Wallington, Friday 10 A.M., from Assumption RC Church, Woodridge at 10:30 A.M. Interment St. Michael Cemetery, visitation Wednesday 6-9 and Thursday 2-4 6-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to Fordham University Law School Library would be appreciated.

title: ALLIED SIGNAL AGREES TO BUY ASTOR HOLDINGS
description: Allied Signal Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Astor Holdings Inc., a privately held maker of chemical products. Terms were not disclosed. Allied Signal, based in Morris Township, N.J., makes automotive and aerospace products and engineered materials. It had sales of $14 billion in 1996. Astor Holdings, based in Raleigh, N.C., has 850 employees. Shares of Allied Signal closed at $41.1875, down 6.25 cents.

title: Nike Expands Ties to Thompson
description: Nike Inc. in Beaverton, Ore., has expanded its relationship with the J. Walter Thompson Company by naming that agency's Shanghai and Hong Kong offices to handle creative duties in five Asian nations outside of Japan. Billings have not been determined.

title: A Pivotal Weekend Looms
description: The first half of the college football season is over, leaving at least a dozen pivotal games in the seven major conferences to determine championships and bowl slots.

title: Friday Night Fights: A Welterweight Showdown
description: The Ike Quartey-Jose Luis Lopez and Pernell Whitaker-Andrei Pestriaev welterweight bouts at Foxwoods Casino in Ledyard, Conn., on Friday night could be the beginning of some major showdowns in the welterweight division. It is perhaps the most talent-laden group in boxing now, but getting the top boxers to fight each other has been impossible.

title: Kingfisher Halts Talks On French Retailer Stake
description: Kingfisher P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it had recessed talks with But S.A. over increasing Kingfisher's 26 percent holding in But, a 235-store French retailer of electrical goods and home furnishings. The talks that began in July with But's founding Venturini family were postponed by mutual agreement, Kingfisher said.

title: A Risk Taker Wants to Show She Can Work With Disney; Director of 'The Lion King' says, 'I'm doing what I do.'
description: Julie Taymor leaned against a long, flat table at the side of the stage as the actors began to assemble in full costume.

title: His Doctor Says Louima Is Walking
description: Abner Louima, the Haitian immigrant who the authorities say was tortured in a Brooklyn police station in August, can walk and eat solid foods again, his cousin and his doctor said yesterday.

title: Hot Giants Stay Wary of Own Confidence
description: As the Giants filed into the locker room today, still a bit giddy from their third consecutive victory, there was a hastily scrawled message awaiting them. Written on the board just inside the door was the cautious directive, ''Even if you're on the right track, you'll get run over if you just sit there.''

title: Metro Business; A Sale by Lone Star
description: Lone Star Industries of Stamford, Conn., sold its construction-materials business in New York State yesterday to Ireland's CRH P.L.C. for $40 million.

title: Laureates Against Land Mines
description: The Nobel Peace Prize awarded last week to the International Campaign to Ban Landmines and its coordinator, Jody Williams, is a fitting cap to an extraordinary few years in which the cause of banning land mines has won broad support. In 1994 not a single government would endorse a ban on these mines, which kill or injure 25,000 people each year, almost all of them civilians. Last month about 100 countries agreed on a treaty requiring the removal of mines and a ban on the production and use of new ones. After the Nobel award President Boris Yeltsin said that Russia, one of the few remaining important holdouts, was likely to sign the treaty.

title: Lazard in Forefront in Wave of Deals
description: The half a dozen big European merger bids announced today promise a windfall for investment banks, led by the three Lazard Freres & Company investment houses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASSIN, MAE
description: PASSIN-Mae, 66, of San Diego, CA., formerly of Mill Basin, Brooklyn, NY and El Paso, TX, died on September 30, 1997. She is survived by her husband Frank; son Howard, daughter Sheila; two grandsons Steven and Cliff, all residing in San Diego, CA.; and a sister Sylvia Ness of Teaneck, NJ.

title: What Kind of Israel Do American Jews Want?
description: To the Editor:

title: EMERITUS MAKES AN OFFER FOR ARV ASSISTED LIVING
description: The Emeritus Corporation said yesterday that it had offered to buy ARV Assisted Living Inc. for $16.50 a share, or $210 million. Emeritus, based in Seattle, operates care centers for the elderly. It already owns 8 percent of ARV, which is based in Costa Mesa, Calif. A merger of Emeritus and ARV would create an assisted-living company with 164 residential communities and capacity for 17,200 residents. Emeritus said its bid topped a $135 million offer for 49.9 percent of ARV made earlier this year by an affiliate of Lazard Freres Real Estate, a unit of Lazard Freres & Company. The affiliate, Prometheus Assisted Living L.L.C., had offered to buy 9.6 million ARV shares for $14 each. Lazard already owns a 17 percent stake in ARV. Shares of Emeritus closed down 25 cents, to $16, while shares of ARV rose $1.625, to $16.875.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Caldwell Teachers Walk Out
description: More than 2,000 public school students in Caldwell and West Caldwell were scheduled to attend school on the Columbus Day holiday yesterday. But they got to take the day off because of a one-day walkout by the local teachers' union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASUCCI, MICHAEL V.
description: MASUCCI-Michael V. On Oct. 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Frances & the late Josephine. Dear father of Janette Hourigan, Michael A. Masucci, Marcella Masucci and Sabrina Paolini Stewart. Devoted grandfather of Michael C. and Marc D. Masucci, Loving brother of Claire DelVecchio and Vincent Masucci. Dear father-in-law of Kevin Hourigan and brother-in-law of Alfred DelVecchio. Survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Reposing at Sinatra Memorial Home, 601 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, New York. Visiting today from 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral mass Wednesday 10 A.M., at St. John the Baptist R.C. Church, Yonkers, New York. Entombment follows at Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Executions Spread From South, Become Part of U.S. Landscape
description: Two decades after the United States Supreme Court reinstated the death penalty, states are executing prisoners at a steadily accelerating pace, and executions are spreading out from their traditional Southern base to states around the country.

title: Ellis Island, Yielding, Permits Photos of Armenian Massacre
description: A compromise has been reached in a rancorous dispute over the content of an exhibit at Ellis Island depicting the killing of Armenians by Ottoman Turks eight decades ago.

title: Snapple Maker Buyback
description: The Triarc Companies, the maker of Snapple Beverages, said yesterday that it would buy back up to $20 million of its stock. One purpose of a buyback is to increase earnings per share by cutting the number of shares outstanding. The repurchases will follow completion of Triarc's Cable Car Beverage Corporation purchase.

title: Yellowstone's Microbial Riches Lure Eager Bioprospectors
description: THE temperature of the gin-clear water in the Morning Glory hot pool in the Upper Geyser Basin is near the boiling point, with wisps of steam dancing across its surface and the smell of sulfur hanging in the air.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLER, STANLEY
description: KELLER-Stanley. Temple B'nai Shalom mourns the loss of our past Board of Trustees and long time member. We extend condolences to the family. Services were held at Gutterman's on Monday, October 13. Dr. Martin Greenberg, President Dr. Barry Dov Schwartz, Rabbi

title: A Woman's Tale, Imagined by a Man
description: MEMOIRS OF A GEISHA

title: Kenneth F. Hahn, 77, Is Dead; Political Giant in Los Angeles
description: Kenneth F. Hahn, a giant of Los Angeles politics for 45 years who helped relocate the Dodgers baseball team from Brooklyn, died on Sunday in Inglewood, Calif. He was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNICK, MONYA (MINNIE)
description: RESNICK-Monya (Minnie), 103. Died in Weston, Florida Oct. 12. Beloved wife of the late Julius Resnick. Mother of Irene Resnick and the late Murray M. Resnick. Grandmother to Byron Wright, Leslie Granoff, Jo Ann Small and Ellen Franco and also seven great-grandchildren. She was a very special person to all who knew her. Funeral services at Riverside Gordon, Miami Beach, Fl. on Tues., Oct.14 at 1:30PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, ADELLE
description: LEVY-Adelle. October 13, 1997. Beloved mother, grandmother & sister. Services at Gutterman's Memorial Chapel, Rockville Centre, October 15th, at 10 AM.

title: Goldman, Sachs Invests Time in City Schools
description: Thomas B. Lewis said he had butterflies in his stomach as the chartered bus snailed north from Goldman, Sachs & Company's Broad Street headquarters through Manhattan's traffic-clogged streets. As the bus fell ever further behind schedule, his butterflies started kick-boxing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, SHIRLEY A.
description: HOFFMAN-Shirley A. Of Del Ray Beach, FL., passed away Oct. 12, 1997. Beloved wife of Abraham. Dear sister of Jerry and Veronica Carlin. Loving mother of Carol and Jules Sherwinter, Barbara and Tom Leahy, & Richard and Arlyne Hoffman. Adoring grandmother of Daniel, Jessica, David and Emily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBEY, MATTHEW
description: TOBEY-Matthew. Ski Editor NY Daily News. Host of radio and television show, Skiing with Tobey. Uncle Mac. With love from your sister, Rose, and from all your nephews, nieces, grandnephews, grandnieces, great grandnephews, great grandnieces. You will always be Santa to us. Memorial service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave, Oct 20, 1997, 11am.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWERSKY, RABBI DR. ISADORE
description: TWERSKY-Rabbi Dr. Isadore. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a distinguished scholar and authority on Maimonides and Raavad, an eminent educator whose life embodied the cross-cultural enrichment at the heart of our institution. Erudite and intellectually demanding, he was a gentle and sensitive man. Ordained by our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary and a YU honorary degree recipient, he perpetuated an illustrious family legacy as the Tolner Rebbe and was Nathan Littauer Professor of Hebrew Literature and Philosophy at Harvard University. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Atarah-daughter of the late Rabbi Joseph B. Soloveitchik, whose philosophy is central to YU and profoundly influenced Jewish thought in our age; to his children, Rabbi Mayer E. (and Faige) Twersky, who succeeded Rabbi Soloveitchik as Leib Merkin Distinguished Professor of Talmud and Jewish Philosophy at RIETS, Rabbi Moshe (and Basha) Twersky, and Tziporah (and Rabbi Jonathan) Rosenblatt, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Cone to Have Surgery On Pitching Shoulder
description: David Cone will undergo surgery on his right shoulder after a second doctor concurred yesterday that he apparently needs the operation to reduce or remove a bone spur and relieve inflammation and tendinitis. The problem has hampered the Yankees' Cone since at least August and prevented him from making a second start against Cleveland in the division series.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I call it the therapeutic haves and the therapeutic have-nots. Anybody who walks into a pharmacy in a poor neighborhood and looks at the line of people who are trying to negotiate which drugs they can or cannot get understands this.''

title: Sports of The Times; A Pure Athlete Knows No Barriers
description: THE husband nodded hesitantly to the conversational question of whether he, too, had been an athlete. His wife, lying in obvious discomfort on her stomach on the hotel room bed, said, ''Steve was a relief pitcher up at Dartmouth.''

title: Police Confirm Identities Of Plane Crash Victims
description: The state police confirmed yesterday that a 65-year-old Colts Neck man was piloting the small airplane that crashed in the woods near the Marlboro Township Airport on Saturday, killing all four on board.

title: Clinton Says He'll Win New Powers For Trade
description: President Clinton predicted today that he would ultimately win enhanced authority from Congress to negotiate free trade deals here in Latin America and around the world.

title: 23 Basque Leaders Go on Trial in Spain
description: The 23 top leaders of a leftist Basque political party went on trial today for collaborating with the Basque separatists who are blamed for killing nearly 800 people since 1968 in their fight for an independent homeland.

title: Science Watch; Cutting Poultry Pollution
description: BEFORE they grace America's dinner tables, the nation's chickens and turkeys produce prodigious amounts of manure -- millions and millions of tons that must be disposed of each year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Losing the guest list may well be a party planner's worst nightmare, particularly if the list is 450 names strong.

title: Janet Reno Turns, Just a Little
description: Sunday, Oct. 12, could emerge as a pivotal date in the inquiry into President Clinton's 1996 fund-raising efforts. On that date, Attorney General Janet Reno made the first tentative efforts toward turning the battleship of her own stubbornness. Ms. Reno is still resisting the appropriate step of using her discretionary powers to appoint an independent counsel. But her remarks on NBC's ''Meet the Press'' suggest that she is coming into better contact with the legal and political realities of the Capitol.

title: Lafarge Bids $2.8 Billion for Concern
description: Lafarge S.A., a French building materials company, made a surprise $2.8 billion offer today for a British rival, Redland P.L.C.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Fishermen Rescue Canoeists
description: Three fishermen from Philadelphia helped emergency workers rescue two canoeists over the weekend after their canoe capsized on the Delaware River, fire officials said yesterday.

title: Colleagues Say Young Is Closer to Leaving Giants
description: Giants General Manager George Young has made no overt plans for retirement, or for another job, but he has frequently and plainly hinted that the time for him to leave the Giants is near, according to National Football League officials and colleagues familiar with Young's thinking.

title: Creativity for Profit
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODGER, LEON M.
description: RODGER-Leon M. Of Naples, Florida, Stowe, Vermont and formerly of Greenwich, Connecticut. On October 11, 1997, at Greenwich Hospital. Beloved husband of Joan Rodger; devoted father of Terri, Steven and Wendy Rodger; grandfather of ''Charlie'' Rodger and father-in-law of Lisa Rodger. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, PO Box 3556, Stamford, CT 06905, or to The Phil, Naples, Florida 34108.

title: Arts in America; Despite the Boom, a San Francisco Museum Struggles
description: These are palmy days for art museums. With the economy in a spectacular boom, people have the money and the inclination for culture, and many museums have seized the day, expanding their buildings, their collections, their programs and their publics. What, them worry?

title: Car Goes Supersonic, but Fails to Set a Record
description: With a deafening roar and billowing trail of dust, a British jet car today became the first vehicle to officially exceed the speed of sound on land.

title: Right Time for Leaders to Surface
description: Leadership in professional sports takes many forms and can come from almost anywhere. The tricky part is making sure it emerges at the right time. It popped up several times this past weekend in the National Football League and for some teams facing critical situations the timing could not have been better.

title: Richard Gallagher, 69, University President
description: Richard H. Gallagher, retired president of Clarkson University in Potsdam, N.Y., died on Sept. 30 at Northwest Hospital in Tucson, Ariz. He was 69.

title: Personal Health; After a Back Injury, Exercise Smooths the Road to Recovery
description: TWENTY years ago, I bent over to pack a suitcase and couldn't stand up again. I had done something awful to my back, and I landed in the hospital, where I was put in traction and on morphine for five days. Returning home, I was sentenced to indefinite bed rest. Week after week, when I saw the orthopedist, I asked, ''Shouldn't I be doing exercises for my back?'' And week after week, the doctor replied, ''You're not ready for that yet.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, ISABEL U.
description: BLAKE-Isabel U. Of Bronxville, NY, on Oct. 12, 1997. Wife of the late John A. Mother of Frances M. Blake and Barbara B. Dallas. Grandmother of five and great grandmother of eleven. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Wednesday, October 15 at 10AM.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a tape transcription error, an article yesterday about the Rev. Al Sharpton's campaign appearances in support of Ruth W. Messinger, and an excerpt from a speech by Ms. Messinger, quoted a remark of hers incorrectly. In an appearance at a church in Queens, Ms. Messinger thanked Mr. Sharpton ''for his sensitivity to the people in the city, not only the people whose boats aren't rising with the tide but people who aren't yet even in the boats.'' She did not refer to ''people whose votes aren't rising with the tide'' and ''people who aren't yet even given votes.''

title: Home of 'Cabin' Author Is Reprieved
description: The birthplace and girlhood home of Harriet Beecher Stowe, the author of ''Uncle Tom's Cabin,'' has a new lease on life.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Jazz and New Music CD's; Improvisers Meet the Machines
description: Improvising musicians and electronics: there's something inevitable about their coming together. Beyond melody, harmony and rhythm, improvisers create with texture; electronics -- samplers, synthesizers and devices that manipulate the sound of live instruments -- can be a terrific aid in this. And like any instrumental voice, electronics can expand the range of stimuli for an improviser to react against. Jazz and improvised music as a whole has seen lots of gimmicky or plainly practical uses for electronics. But the musicians on these CD's have gotten beyond using the synthesizer simply as a tricked-up keyboard or a portable orchestra; they're beginning to use these machines for their own inherent properties.

title: Freeman Given N.H.L. Assignment
description: The Fox Sports division of the Fox Broadcasting Company, part of the News Corporation, has named Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York to handle advertising for its broadcast coverage of the National Hockey League games, which had been handled by various agencies on a project basis. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Heat of Ethnic Politics Is Felt In New York Race for Mayor
description: The New York City mayoral contest became entangled in ethnic politics yesterday when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani attacked Ruth W. Messinger for skipping a Columbus Day Mass, while she tried to reassure Jewish voters concerned about her public embrace of the Rev. Al Sharpton.

title: How Globe-Trotting Executives Also Find Time to Study
description: DURHAM, North Carolina  As a Canadian working for an American ad firm in Brazil, Alain Groenendaal knows that his professional success will depend on how well he can operate across cultural boundaries, work in teams and use sophisticated communications technologies. As a graduate business student at Duke University, Mr. Groenendaal is getting practice in all of the above.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Pilot in Crash Is Identified
description: The state police confirmed yesterday that a 65-year-old Colts Neck man was piloting the small airplane that crashed in the woods near the Marlboro Township Airport on Saturday, killing all four people on board.

title: Mir Prompts New Effort to Quench Threat of Fire in Space
description: ONE day last February, an astronaut on the Russian space station Mir was preparing to make a batch of life-giving oxygen when the candle-type generator he was using caught fire. Almost instantly, flames were shooting out one to four feet, and chunks of molten metal were flying through the air, splattering a nearby bulkhead. Sparks erupted like fireworks, and smoke billowed through the station, clouding vision and making the air unbreathable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDNER, LILLIAN
description: LINDNER-Lillian. On October 12, 1997. Peacefully in her 99th year. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Lindner. Loving mother of Jack and Anneliese Lindner and the late Jean Lindner Kass. Generous and adoring grandmother of Benjamin Lindner, Robert Kass and Robyn Lindner. Proud greatgrandmother of Trevor Elliot. Funeral services will be private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DINKOFF, GARY R.
description: DINKOFF-Gary R. Devoted son of Harris and Renae, cherished brother of Allan and Kevin, adored brother-in-law of Pamela and Roseanna, loving uncle of Benjamin and Daniel, and all of his friends' children. Funeral service Tuesday 2 PM, at Gutterman Inc, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Gary R. Dinkoff Memorial Fund, C/O District 13, James A. Dever School, 585 N. Corona Ave, Valley Stream, New York 11580.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Thursday about an agreement by gun manufacturers to provide child safety locks with their firearms by the end of next year misstated the history of the practice at Sturm, Ruger & Company. For most guns, the company began it in 1987; only for a few specialty models did it begin in the spring of this year.

title: AIDS Drugs Elude the Grasp of Many of the Poor
description: The doctor's chicken scratch is barely legible, but to Luis Figueroa the scribbles on the little white slips of paper are precious. They are prescriptions for powerful new AIDS medications that once miraculously revived Mr. Figueroa, who was so close to death last year that his parents brought in a priest in case he needed last rites.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTGARTEN, IRA H.
description: LUSTGARTEN-Ira H. October 12, 1997. Survived by his wife Rhoda, two daughters, Lise Anne Schwartz and Nancy Lustgarten, two sons-in-law, Jeffrey Schwartz and Danny Wessel. Funeral services private. A memorial service will be scheduled for a later date. Contributions may be made to Rockefeller University or American Cancer Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COREN, ARNOLD S.
description: COREN-Arnold S. On Sunday, October 12, of Woodmere, New York. Loving husband and best friend of Miriam. Caring father & father-in-law of Alice and Larry Reichenberg, George and Nancy Coren. Cherished grandfather of Jason, David, Jeffrey and Andrew. Beloved brother of Mildred Rothman. A ''gentle-man.'' His integrity, compassion and charm showed us the way. His strength of character and unyielding will to survive was, and always will be, an inspiration to all those whose lives he touched. He will live on in all of our hearts.

title: Stocks Climb Modestly, With Dow Up 27.01
description: The stock market rose modestly yesterday, after several strong earnings reports gave Wall Street early hope about the direction of third-quarter earnings.

title: Murrell And Line Massage Their Egos
description: Adrian Murrell could not remember a game as a starter in which he did not have at least one carry for more than 4 yards.

title: More Accounts From War Era Are Uncovered By Swiss Banks
description: Swiss banking officials said today that a further search of their archives had turned up 4,000 more unclaimed accounts that belonged to foreigners before and during the Holocaust era, twice the number they had discovered and published in July.

title: A College in Belgium Enlists The EU's Future Technocrats : Forging the Bonds Of a New Europe
description: BRUGES, Belgium  At a time when the European Union faces some of the biggest challenges in its history  the move toward a single currency and its enlargement toward the east  the College of Europe here says it is educating many of the people who will have to control those developments.

title: Adults Need Educating to Acquire Skills Necessary to Work in Global Economy : A Lesson for the World:Too Many Are Illiterate
description: WASHINGTON  Mention the word "education," and most people think of children in school. To Michael Lakin of Unesco, however, such a reflex, while understandable, represents only part of the picture.

title: Sports of The Times; Cleveland Can't Always Come Back
description: IT was the house in the suburbs that put the Indians over the top. Sandy Alomar Jr. said he could not afford it -- with athletes' incomes, everything is relative -- but he was sending a message that he was here for the long haul.

title: Crude Oil Falls as No Crisis Materializes in Persian Gulf
description: Crude oil prices tumbled yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as the uneventful arrival of a United States aircraft carrier in the Persian Gulf prompted heavy selling by traders who had feared the ship's presence would increase tension in the region.

title: Ericsson China Contracts
description: Ericsson A.B., the Swedish telecommunications equipment maker, said today that it had won three network expansion contracts totaling $223 million from China. The contract were from the Guangxi Posts and Telecommunications Administration, the Chongqing Telecom Administration and the Sichuan Posts and Telecommunications Administration.

title: Hostile Bids And Mergers Rise in Europe
description: Europe became the staging ground today for a burst of mergers and hostile takeover bids potentially worth more than $100 billion, as corporate buccaneers from France to Italy to Britain were pitted against each other in at least three different industries.

title: TRANSWORLD HEALTHCARE WILL PURCHASE APRIA
description: Transworld Healthcare Inc. and its largest stockholder, Hyperion Partners, offered yesterday to buy Apria Healthcare Group Inc. for about $950 million in cash and stock plus assumed debt. Transworld, based in Clark, N.J., said it was offering $14 in cash and $4 of stock for each of Apria's 52.5 million shares. It will also assume about $500 million in debt if the transaction is completed. Apria, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., hired the investment bank Goldman, Sachs & Company in June to help the company explore its alternatives, including a sale. Apria also said in June that it would phase out its lower-margin home-health nursing and medical equipment sales businesses. Apria said it would instead focus on its main businesses of respiratory services, home infusion therapy and home medical equipment. Apria's shares rose $1.5625, to $16.25.

title: IN A DEAL, CLINTON MAY BE QUESTIONED OVER FUND-RAISING
description: The White House and the Justice Department are negotiating an agreement under which President Clinton would voluntarily answer questions about his knowledge of Democratic fund-raising efforts in his re-election campaign, Government officials said today.

title: Glasgow Debate: Should Art Go Abroad?
description: This scrappy city owes a great deal to Sir William Burrell, a very rich and somewhat cranky shipping magnate best known for the extraordinary collection of art he amassed with canniness and taste during his long life. In 1944, 14 years before he died at age 96, Burrell donated his eclectic collection ofmore than 8,000 works to Glasgow, no questions asked (well, almost none).

title: History's a Tough Test for Bosnian Teachers
description: SARAJEVO  Bahrija Cehajic is teaching history to a roomful of 8th graders at a Sarajevo public school. She draws a large letter "B" on the blackboard to represent Bosnia; on the right she marks Serbia and on the left Croatia.

title: What Kind of Israel Do American Jews Want?; Spirituality vs. Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Safety Locks Won't Halt Gun Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Blair Meets With Adams, I.R.A. Figure, In Belfast
description: In a highly charged gesture meant to symbolize his commitment to peace talks in Northern Ireland, Prime Minister Tony Blair met today with Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army.

title: FOUNDATION CUTS 6% OF WORKERS AT 9 HOSPITALS
description: Allegheny Health, Education and Research Foundation said yesterday it had dismissed 6 percent of its workers at nine hospitals in the Delaware Valley, cutting about 1,200 jobs as it seeks to reduce costs. The parent of Allegheny University of the Health Sciences and Allegheny University Hospitals also said it had cut compensation for all of its executives by an average of more than 20 percent, as it will seek to reward highly productive faculty and reduce compensation for others. The Philadelphia-based foundation said it employed about 20,000 people at its facilities, which include Hahnemann's Hospital and St. Christopher's Hospital for Children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BYRD, THOMAS HUGH
description: BYRD-Thomas Hugh, 90, former Palisade Interstate Park Commissioner and Treasurer, died October 12, 1997 in Belleair, Florida. Mr. Byrd was born in Hartsville, S.C., but spent most of his life in New York City with his brokerage firm, Byrd Brothers, after his graduation from Harvard in 1930. He was a senior member of the Harvard Club of New York. During World War II he joined the U.S. Navy and was active in many areas, the most notable being the sinking of U Boat 613 on its way to destroy Mayport Naval Base and the surrounding Jacksonville area July 23, 1943. The Navy rewarded him for this by naming its building for Fleet training units, Byrd Hall. After the war Mr. Byrd returned to his Wall Street firm but continued in the U.S. Naval Reserve, Commander of the Third District. In 1969 he was made Rear Admiral of the New York State Navy Militia by Governor Rockefeller. Mr. Byrd is survived by his wife of 67 years, the former Eleanor Deland; two daughters, Caroline Dunjoy of Paris, and Beatrice Myler of Belleair; four grandchildren; and one great-grandchild.

title: A Self-Made Man Takes On Newark; Shy Philanthropist Gives His Time And Money to New Arts Center
description: Few have ever heard of Raymond G. Chambers. That's just the way he wants it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, ROBERT
description: LERNER-Robert. On Saturday, October 11. Beloved husband of Rose; adored father of Nathan ''Zeke'' (Lenore) and Linda ''Buddy''. Loved and admired by his grandsons Peter, Laurence, Jordan, Daniel and Jordan's fiancee Alana. Bob was in the men's shirt business with Bedford Shirt. He will be missed and forever loved. Services Tuesday, October 14, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, LI.

title: Fast Workout For Skip Away
description: Skip Away fired the first salvo of Breeders' Cup Preview week when he shot five furlongs in 58 2/5 seconds yesterday morning at Belmont Park in his final serious workout for Saturday's $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup, a race he won by a head against Cigar last year.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Train Kills Man on Tracks
description: A man walked into the path of a New Jersey Transit train yesterday and was fatally struck in what officials are investigating as a suicide.

title: Americans at Debt's Door
description: American society increasingly is split into two classes: people who own stocks and those who wish they did. While 63 million Americans have money invested in stocks or mutual funds, most of that wealth is concentrated in relatively few hands. Only 50 percent of all households own more than $1,000 in financial assets. Despite an explosion of mutual funds, the average wage earner has only limited participation in the booming stock market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, BARBARA L.
description: YOUNG-Barbara L. The members of the Roebling Society of the Brooklyn Museum of Art mourn the passing of their long-time President Barbara L. Young and extend their deepest condolences to her family. As President of the Roebling Society for the past 12 years she was selfless in her dedication. We all will miss her extraordinary leadership, intelligence, good humor and her friendship. The Roebling Society

title: What Kind of Israel Do American Jews Want?; Fend Off Theocracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by The Associated Press in some copies yesterday about a plane crash on Saturday in Marlboro, N.J., misidentified the agency that named the four victims. It was the New Jersey state police, not the New Hampshire state police, though the plane was headed for New Hampshire.

title: Group Suing U. of Michigan Over Diversity
description: The University of Michigan, which has doubled its minority enrollment over the last decade through a strenuous diversification effort, is the object of a Federal lawsuit to be filed today asserting that its admissions policies are unconstitutional because they discriminate against whites.

title: Building-Supply Chain May Buy British Rival
description: Meyer International P.L.C., a British timber and building materials merchant, said yesterday that it was in talks to buy the Harcros building materials unit of Harrisons & Crosfield P.L.C., for more than $:300 million ($483 million).

title: 9 Police Officers Among 11 Slain in Egypt
description: Nine police officers and two Coptic Christians were shot and killed today by suspected Islamic militants in two separate incidents in southern Egypt.

title: In Europe, a Flurry Of Corporate Deals
description: With mergers and acquisitions slowed in the United States because of Columbus Day, corporate buccaneers from France to Italy to Britain showed that they had discovered the free-wheeling ways of business in America.

title: America Online and Netscape Team Up on Message Service
description: America Online Inc. and the Netscape Communications Corporation plan to announce today an instant-messaging service in a deal that symbolizes the continuing integration of Internet with traditional on-line technology.

title: Rivals for Governor Step Up Campaigning
description: A day after two new polls suggested that their contest was tightening, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman courted Democrats here today while her Democratic challenger, State Senator James E. McGreevey, stepped up the pace of his campaign and his aides exulted in his new-found spotlight.

title: Police and Suspect Trade Shots, and Bystander Dies
description: A 58-year-old porter sweeping a sidewalk outside a Harlem apartment building where he worked was slain yesterday, caught in the crossfire of a gun battle between two police officers and a gunman they were chasing. It was not immediately clear whose bullet struck the victim, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SISKIND, PEARL
description: SISKIND-Pearl. Beloved mother of Barry and daughter-in-law Claire. Loving grandmother of Jeff and Nancy, Stephen and Laura, Jill and Jeff Marks. Dear greatgrandmother of Andrew, Max, Sam, Melanie, Cara, Shelby, Elizabeth and Julia. Cherished sister of Mildred Schneider. Loving aunt of Stephanie Levine and greataunt of Cari and Eric.

title: Baby Walkers May Slow Infants' Development
description: PARENTS and babies seem to love infant walkers, parents for the baby-tending and entertainment value of these wheeled seats and babies for being able to scoot around the house in them long before they can walk and even before they can crawl. Many parents believe that infant walkers foster the development of the motor skills needed for walking and provide mental stimulation by allowing the baby to explore a broader environment.

title: Toddlers Cram For Elite Schools
description: LONDON  The boy's conscientious parents had prepared him for months for his school entrance test and as he proceeded through verbal and other tests all seemed to be going well . . . until he got onto the computer.

title: Chess
description: Despite the presence of super skilled tacticians, this year's United States Championship in Chandler, Ariz., featured the positional style. Overall, the wild-eyed, risk-taking combination players kept their distinguishing weapons out of sight. Virtually everyone chose to go in for the maneuvering game.

title: Many Feasts In the Religion Of Parking
description: AS the tale goes, a reporter looking for a local angle on the annual Rosh ha-Shanah story once began his account something like this: Jews in New York City ushered in the New Year today in traditional style, filling synagogues with prayer and parking on both sides of the street.

title: Patterns
description: Designer Leaves Lanvin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESSER, JOEL
description: LESSER-Joel, on October 12. Internationally known toy and doll company executive. He is survived by his wife and daughters, a brother and four grandchildren. Funeral services in Boston.

title: Finland's Biggest Bank In Swedish Merger
description: Merita Oy, Finland's largest bank, said yesterday that it would merge with Nordbanken A.B. of Sweden to create a company with a market value of $10.7 billion and assets of $103 billion.

title: Kamieniecki And Key Help Orioles Escape Jacobs Field
description: What could have been the final night of the season for the tumbling Orioles turned out to be a splendid night for two former Yankees, as well as 25 current Orioles. Because of Scott Kamieniecki and Jimmy Key, two pitchers the Yankees did not want, Baltimore defeated the Cleveland Indians, 4-2, in Game 5 at Jacobs Field tonight and remained alive and kicking in an intense American League Championship Series.

title: Tragedy And Futility In an Effort To Help
description: Perhaps you've never heard of Fred Cuny, so here's your chance. ''The Lost American,'' tonight's ''Frontline'' travelogue of places tourists avoid, is dedicated to keeping alive the memory of this freelance engineer, adventurer and humanitarian who disappeared in Chechnya in 1995.

title: Parent Sets Spinoff Of British Home Builder
description: The Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company said yesterday that it would sell shares in its British house-building unit, Bovis Homes, in early December. The announcement sets a date for a spinoff the company has been planning since March 1996. Analysts said then that Bovis Homes was worth as much as $:300 million ($480 million).

title: The leading on-line music retailer hopes to popularize electronic commerce as it builds share.
description: THERE used to be a joke in the heyday of Top 40 radio that disk jockeys would introduce the biggest hit tune as ''No. 1 and climbing higher every week!'' Now it's the No. 1 Internet music retailer that's trying to climb higher, by making more consumers more comfortable with the concept of shopping on line.

title: Peter Andreoli, 78, Prosecutor In Corruption and Rackets Cases
description: Peter Donald Andreoli, a retired lawyer who prosecuted racketeering cases in New York City and investigated political corruption in Syracuse, died on Saturday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 78 and lived in Pelham, N.Y.

title: On My Mind; The Amman Story
description: In the 50-year struggle against Arab terrorism, every Israeli prime minister has combined three strategies, in the hope that fewer Jews might be murdered. That seemed to the West to be an acceptable goal, until recently.

title: Opera With Washington and Lenin? Revolutionary!
description: The Kitchen, the proudly alternative performance venue in New York's Chelsea neighborhood, could have safely celebrated its 25th anniversary by revisiting its vibrant past. For a while, this ramshackle space, formerly an actual hotel kitchen, was mission control for the downtown new music scene. Here, Philip Glass, Laurie Anderson and other iconoclasts staged a rebellion against the concert music status quo. To its credit, instead of looking back, the Kitchen acknowledged its birthday by commissioning ''Naked Revolution,'' a multimedia opera by the composer Dave Soldier and the librettist Maita di Niscemi. The work was given its premiere on Thursday night. But if the idea was to show the Kitchen still at the cutting edge, the production was a sad failure.

title: How to Make Big Rubles? Invest in a Comrade's Debt
description: Stanislav Baranov sat in the computer-filled trading room at Rossiisky Kredit Bank, barely able to contain his glee.

title: Cantonese, Mandarin and English Compete for a Place at School : The Language War in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  For years this former British colony has had the dubious distinction of being a place where it was a serious social stigma not to be able to speak a foreign language fluently. For the city's 6 million Cantonese-speaking majority, that language was English.

title: Shuttle Service to Start For Newark Arts Center
description: New Jersey Transit is to begin a new shuttle service today between the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, Newark's two train stations and several other points of interest, agency officials said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Monkey Mia Journal; Like to Meet a Wild Dolphin? This Is the Place
description: ''Don't pat their heads,'' Sherylee Randall, a conservation ranger with the state of Western Australia, advised as dorsal fins emerged below an early morning mist and sliced the ruffled surface of the bay.

title: VULCAN VENTURES TO BUY CONTROLLING STAKE IN METRICOM
description: Vulcan Ventures Inc. said yesterday that it would buy a controlling stake in Metricom Inc., a wireless network and Internet services company. Vulcan, the investment group for the Microsoft Corporation's co-founder, Paul G. Allen, said it would buy 4.65 million shares from Metricom for $56 million. Vulcan said it had agreed in a separate deal to acquire 2.58 million Metricom shares from Lindner Group. The two purchases raise Vulcan's interest in Metricom to 49 percent, a controlling stake. Additionally, Vulcan, based in Bellevue, Wash., said it planned to take a leadership position on Metricom's board. Metricom, based in Los Gatos, Calif., had 1996 revenues of $7.1 million. Shares of Metricom rose $1.875, to $14.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: ICG TO BUY NETCOM ON-LINE FOR $283.5 MILLION
description: ICG Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Netcom On-Line Communications Services Inc. for $283.5 million, or $22.65 a share, in stock. Netcom, based in San Jose, Calif., is an Internet service provider. ICG Communications, based in Englewood, Colo., is a provider of local and long-distance phone and data services in California, Colorado, the Ohio Valley and the Southeastern United States. Shares of Netcom surged on news of the deal, gaining $6.0625, to $21.1875, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of ICG slipped $1.0625, to $25.1875. Under the agreement, expected to close early next year, ICG will issue 0.8628 share for each Netcom share.

title: In New Orleans, the House Loses
description: Back in the early 1990's, when the Louisiana Legislature legalized casino gambling, it seemed to many New Orleanians that their city was the odds-on favorite to become the next Las Vegas or Atlantic City.

title: Networks and N.F.L.: Heading North Again?
description: Pat Bowlen tried not to sound boastful. But you couldn't fault him if he bragged a smidgen thanks to the leverage the National Football League has on its TV ''partners.'' Bowlen, who owns the Denver Broncos and heads the N.F.L.'s broadcasting committee, reckons that very soon, the networks will agree to pay ''somewhere north of 50 percent'' more than they are paying now.

title: People
description: * Ray Gillette, president for integrated services at DDB Needham Chicago, a unit of Omnicom Group, was named to the new post of president of Beyond DDB, a unit of all American DDB Needham offices that will oversee integrated services like direct marketing, promotions and interactive communications. He continues as a managing partner at DDB Needham Chicago.

title: John Denver, 53, Who Sang of Natural Love and Love of Nature, Dies in a Plane Crash
description: John Denver, the singer and songwriter who was the voice of wholesome sincerity and simple country pleasures in the 1970's, died on Sunday afternoon when a light plane he was piloting crashed into Monterey Bay in California. He was 53.

title: Trans-Atlantic Trip Ends Prematurely
description: An apparent bout with food poisoning yesterday forced the American rowing team of Tori Murden and Louise Graff to pull out of a trans-Atlantic rowing race less than 25 hours after its start from Tenerife, the Canary Islands.

title: What Kind of Israel Do American Jews Want?; Religion and Ritual
description: To the Editor:

title: American Home To Sell 2 Units
description: The American Home Products Corporation said yesterday that it was seeking a buyer for its medical device units, which make products like syringes and sutures and are low-profit businesses.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Bus Shuttle to Arts Center
description: New Jersey Transit is to begin a new shuttle service today between the New Jersey Performing Arts Center and Newark's two train stations, agency officials said.

title: Redskins Stymie Toothless Cowboys
description: It used to come so easily for the Dallas Cowboys.

title: MEDIA GENERAL WILL ACQUIRE 3 NEWSPAPERS
description: Media General Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire The Herald-Courier in Bristol, Va., and two affiliated weekly newspapers for about $91.2 million. Media General, based in Richmond, said the acquisition was expected to be completed in the first quarter of 1998. Included in the sale are The Herald-Courier, with a daily circulation of 43,800; The Washington County News of Virginia, with a weekly circulation of 3,300, and The Sullivan County News of Tennessee, with a weekly circulation of 2,600. Media General's class A shares fell $1.125, to $43.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRUNG, SHIRLEY
description: SPRUNG-Shirley. Beloved and cherished wife of the late Jerome. Devoted mother of Sara & Daniel. Dear sister of Robert and Meyer Judd. Adoring grandmother of two cherished granddaughters. Service 12:00 P.M., on Wednesday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Ronald McDonald House of New York would be appreciated.

title: What Kind of Israel Do American Jews Want?; A Friend of Pluralism
description: To the Editor:

title: Hawaiians Angrily Turn on a Fabled Empire
description: It is the fabled legacy of a Polynesian princess, a feudal empire so vast that it could never be assembled in the modern world. It owns 8 percent of all the land in Hawaii, which makes it the largest private property owner in the state. It is worth perhaps $10 billion, with investments from the Pacific Rim to Wall Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOVITZ, TILLIE
description: RABINOVITZ-Tillie. Congregation Shaaray Tefila in Lawrence records with deep sorrow the passing of Tillie Rabinovitz, beloved mother of Naomi Wurzburger, wife of our Rabbi Emeritus Walter S. Wurzburger. We extend heartfelt condolences to the family. David Weinberger, Rabbi Martin Klein, President

title: Trial Testimony Expected Soon in Slaying of 4-Year-Old Girl
description: Testimony could begin this week or next in the trial of a man accused of killing 4-year-old Kali Ann Poulton after kidnapping her while she rode her tricycle outside her home on May 23, 1994.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Restoring a French Antique; New Wave Chief Brings Life to a Creaky Conglomerate
description: When Jean-Marie Messier was tapped 16 months ago to run Compagnie Generale des Eaux, he was taking charge of the top dinosaur in the Jurassic Park of French industry.

title: Color Scans, Now at Bargain Prices
description: COLOR pictures are wonderful. Getting them into your computer is not. Particularly in the Windows world, color scanners can be tricky to install and trickier to master. But prices have been dropping, and decent models are now available for less than $150.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JACOR COMMUNICATIONS INC., Covington, Ky., which owns and operates radio stations, agreed to buy KSJO-FM in San Jose, Calif., from American Radio Systems, for $30 million in cash.

title: High Spirits Amid Hard Times
description: Jubilation had a special reason to be jubilant on Sunday afternoon. The dance company's program at Aaron Davis Hall featured excerpts from Kevin Iega Jeff's ''Flack,'' a suite to songs by Roberta Flack. It's a strong piece. But on this occasion it was stronger than ever, for Ms. Flack herself provided live accompaniment.

title: Pharmacia's Headquarters To Go to U.S. From Britain
description: In a trans-Atlantic variation on a familiar story in which a company moves its headquarters to a suburb near the home of the chief executive, Pharmacia & Upjohn, the big multinational drug maker, announced yesterday that it would move its headquarters to a mid-Atlantic state from Britain.

title: For Jackson and Bulls, One Last Mile Together
description: David Halberstam asked Coach Phil Jackson over the summer about whether he could chronicle the Bulls' season. Jackson listened and said fine, but warned that a book written about Michael and the Miracles might be in direct competition with some of Jackson's memoirs.

title: Chess; Even the Fieriest Tacticians Chill Out for a Championship
description: Despite the presence of super skilled tacticians, this year's United States Championship in Chandler, Ariz., featured the positional style. Overall, the wild-eyed, risk-taking combination players kept their distinguishing weapons out of sight. Virtually everyone chose to go in for the maneuvering game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORSUK, EVELYN FEINSOD
description: BORSUK-Evelyn Feinsod, 87 years old, on Sunday, October 12, of Boca Raton, FL., and a former resident of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved wife of the late Morris R. Feinsod and the late Benjamin Borsuk. Devoted mother of George and Norma, David and Carole, Donald and June. Loving grandmother of Meredith, Matthew, Michael, Amanda, Melissa, Andrew, Randon and Shawna. Much loved sister and sister-in-law of Ehrenreich family. She leaves a legacy of love, devotion & caring and will be missed by everyone who knew her. Funeral Tuesday, October 14, at 11 AM, ''Schwartz Bros-Jeffer, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Financial Giants Report More Strong Earnings

title: Nimble Deal-Maker For Stars Of Science
description: A FEW months ago, a group of authors gathered at a country house in Connecticut for a weekend, taking walks in the meadows and woods, dining alfresco and talking about their work. They did not, however, discuss movie rights, the fate of the novel or the current rash of memoirs. They talked about multiple universes, the philosophy of mathematics and the nature of consciousness.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: TAX REVENUES -- New York City is flush in unexpected tax revenues, largely from Wall Street, which could help the Mayor's re-election campaign. B3.

title: The Aging Eye: Researchers Aim To Stop the Clock
description: AGING Americans expect more from their eyes these days than ever before. People in their 70's and 80's want to be able to drive, play cards, recognize people on the street, travel with their grandchildren, take advantage of senior discounts in the movies and read the books they missed while working full time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISLIN, JULIA
description: KISLIN-Julia. The leadership and staff of UJA-Federation mourn the passing of Julia Kislin, beloved mother of Semyon ''Sam'' Kislin, an outstanding philanthropist in our community, and mother-inlaw of Ludmila Kislin, a member of our Board of Directors and an exemplary leader in our organization. Both are cherished and beloved friends of UJA-Federation. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Crime Is Down All Over
description: Crime rates have declined for the fifth consecutive year. F.B.I. statistics show that violent crimes fell 6 percent in 1996 from 1995, and national murder rates reached the lowest level since 1969. Property crime rates continue to fall steadily, with burglary down by nearly half since 1980. In New York City, Mayor Rudolph Guiliani has taken credit for a reduction in crimes, large and small. This year homicides in the city are projected to drop to 779, fewer than even the 986 killings recorded in 1968.

title: 'Harp Boont': Don't Get Upset If You Understand Every Word
description: BOONVILLE, California  The isolated sheep-ranching community of Boonville in Mendocino County has developed a way of talking that some call a language. And it has even been incorporated into their schools.

title: Essay; Dinosaurs Still Star in Many Human Dramas and Dreams
description: DURING the height of the Korean War, Al Capp introduced America to a delightful cartoon creature called the shmoo. Pear-shaped little shmoos were not only cute and comforting to have around, but they laid eggs, produced prewrapped butter sticks and cheerfully transformed themselves into grilled steak or chicken when confronted by hungry humans. Toy stores sold legions of shmoo dolls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN RENSSELAER, GEORGINA LAWRENCE WELLS
description: VAN RENSSELAER - Georgina Lawrence Wells. Wife of the late Cortlandt Schuyler Van Rensselaer. Mother of Nina Van Rensselaer and Catherine Townsend. Funeral service to be held at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, New York on October 15 at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, a gift to the United Thank Offering or St. Matthew's Church, or the Chapin Alumni Fund would be appreciated.

title: L.A. GEAR SELLS A 42% STAKE AND NAMES NEW CHIEF
description: L.A. Gear Inc. said yesterday that it had named a new chairman and chief executive after PCH Investments L.L.C. purchased a 42 percent stake, as the company tries to turn around its sneaker and clothing business. PCH bought 1.14 million shares of series B convertible stock from Trefoil Capital Investors L.P. Trefoil also granted PCH a six-month option to buy its remaining 20,981 convertible shares and another one million shares of common stock, the company said. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. L.A. Gear, which is based in Santa Monica, Calif., also appointed its executive vice president, David Gatto, as chairman and chief executive. He replaces Stanley Gold, who was also the president of the general partner of Trefoil. Shares of the company closed yesterday down 6.25 cents at $1.8125.

title: Grace Chairman Has Heart Attack
description: W. R. Grace & Company said today that its chairman, president and chief executive, Albert J. Costello, suffered a heart attack on Saturday.

title: Raymond L. Spangler, 93, Former Publisher
description: Raymond L. Spangler, a newspaper publisher and a former president of a national journalist organization, died on Sept. 21 at Sequoia Hospital in Redwood City, Calif. He was 93 and lived in Redwood City.

title: Why All the Self-Doubt in Manila?
description: MANILA  Filipinos are the most overeducated illiterates in the world, a Filipino political organizer commented with a chuckle at a party. It was not meant to be quippy cocktail chatter.

title: Part of Thomson-CSF to Be Sold to French Industry
description: The French Government, moving to consolidate the country's military industry to meet increased global competition, has chosen a group of French companies led by Alcatel Alsthom to relieve the state of a part of its controlling stake in Thomson-CSF, Europe's largest military electronics company.

title: Gelinas Scores a Goal, Then Sprains a Knee
description: Canucks 3 , Oilers 0

title: Islanders Fight Past Penalties
description: Rick Bowness knew he had just seen something special. The Islanders' coach gathered his team in the locker room to acknowledge it.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Hospital Deals Raise Concern On Abortion
description: When Northern Dutchess Hospital and Kingston Medical Center merged last year, they began the kind of streamlining and emphasis on preventive care that keeps hospitals afloat in the era of managed care.

title: A Fractured Eye Socket Sidelines Childs Again
description: It was well before tip-off when Chris Childs disappeared into a dim corridor beneath Madison Square Garden wearing dark sunglasses to hide an injury that left him shaking his head in disbelief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHR, SHIRLEY
description: BEHR-Shirley. Of West Palm Beach, Florida on October 12, 1997. Loving mother of Dr. Roberta Wiener and Harriet Belenker. Cherished grandmother of Chet Wiener, Pam Wiener-Baker, Esther Belenker-Mehlman, Rachel Hombach, and Dr. Stuart Belenker. Great grandmother of Shaina. Funeral service Tuesday 1:30PM I.J. Morris, Inc. 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, New York.

title: INSIDE
description: Ulster Peace Gesture

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUDSON, THOMAS FEAREY
description: JUDSON-Thomas Fearey, on October 5, 1997. He is survived by 3 sons and daughters-in-law, John Pike Judson and Charmaine of Clover, South Carolina; Thomas Fearey Judson, Jr., & Elisabeth of Victor, New York; & Junius Royal Judson, II, and Lauren; grandchildren, John Pike Judson, Jr., Derek Grogan Judson, Rufus Morgan Judson, Elisabeth Judson, Davis Royal Judson and Virginia Pike Judson; also a dear friend, Mrs. H. Percy (Edith) Clark of Bryn Mawr, PA. A memorial service was held in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, East Avenue, Rochester, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, those wishing may contribute to Rochester Institute of Technology in his memory. Care was entrusted to Hedges Memorial Chapel, 770 East Main Street, Rochester, New York 14605.

title: Outcome of Cameroon Vote: Fear of the Future
description: For weeks, citizens of this Central African country were inundated with radio jingles, television testimonials and campaign posters proclaiming the incumbent President, Paul Biya, as the ''best choice'' for the country's future.

title: Brown Definitely Ready Now (Well, Maybe)
description: Kevin Brown, the Florida Marlins' best chance for completing a shocking playoff upset in the face of misfortune, boarded Delta Flight 1168 in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., at 8:45 this morning, looking gaunt and tired after five days of fighting a flu.

title: By Design; Wide-Leg Pants Get the Space
description: Anyone who has shopped for cigarette-leg pants this fall has had a hard time, because wide-leg pants are the style of the season. You can spend as much as $800 for wide-leg pants by a top designer, like Giorgio Armani, Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein or Jil Sander. But there are many less-expensive versions, which is good, because spring may see a return to skinny pants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIKE, SEYMOUR
description: PIKE-Seymour. On October 12, 1997. Husband of the late Lillian; loving companion of Annette Goodrich; dear brother of the late Eugene; uncle of Michael and Andy. Services on Tuesday 12 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUTMAN, JEANETTE E.
description: GUTMAN-Jeanette E., of Fishkill, NY, on Oct. 11, 1997. Sister of the late Selma (Sallie) M. Taylor. Aunt of Henry G. Taylor, Rev. George E. Taylor, Jr., Marian Davis and the late Joan Jaschob. Reposing at Krtil Funeral Home, Wed. 12 noon-1:30 P.M. Service at 1:30 P.M. Burial Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY, by Libby Funeral Home, Inc., Beacon, New York.

title: Q&A
description: Shine On, Harvest Moon

title: Nobel Incivility
description: To the Editor:

title: Orioles Try to Outrun The Ghosts From 1969
description: The Baltimore Orioles faced an arduous task last night in trying to stay alive in the American League Championship Series. Not only did they have to beat the Cleveland Indians, they also had to overcome the ghosts of 1969.

title: Hard-Line Leftists in Italy Back Out of Backing Out
description: Only four days ago Italy's small Communist Refounding Party brought about the collapse of Prime Minister Romano Prodi's center-left Government, arguing that its tight-fisted, pro-Europe policies were a betrayal of the working classes and a sop to globalized capitalism.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: Trans Fatty Acids Tied to Risk of Breast Cancer
description: A CLASS of fats that is widespread in the American diet has been linked to an increased risk of developing breast cancer.

title: What Kind of Israel Do American Jews Want?; World Zionist Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Kool Cigarettes' New Campaign
description: The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation will introduce a campaign that takes a sensual, sultry tack to sell Kool menthol cigarettes, replacing advertisements with outdoorsy themes centered on waterfalls, ski slopes and beaches.

title: Retaliation Works Well For Rangers
description: In separate brawls last Saturday night, Darren Langdon, Mike Keane, Eric Cairns and Adam Graves displayed the team toughness that Rangers Coach Colin Campbell said was so desperately needed in the first four games of the season, all ties.

title: Executive Changes
description: NETSCAPE COMMUNICATIONS CORP., Mountain View, Calif., named Eric Hahn chief technology officer, succeeding a co-founder, Marc Andreessen, who was named to the new position of executive vice president for products.

title: Judge Rules States Can't Cut Welfare For New Residents
description: A Federal judge has ruled that states may not discriminate against new residents by paying them lower welfare benefits than longtime residents. His decision blocks Pennsylvania's use of a tool given to states by the 1996 welfare law.

title: ITT Plans More Reductions In Corporate Work Force
description: Facing a crucial shareholder vote next month, the ITT Corporation announced another round of cost cuts yesterday, a move analysts said could help in its fight to avoid a takeover by the Hilton Hotels Corporation.

title: Riding Merger Prosperity, 3 Wall Street Firms Post Strong Earnings
description: J. P. Morgan & Company and Smith Barney Inc. reported double-digit gains in third-quarter earnings yesterday while Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. said earnings more than doubled to a record.

title: Driver in Fatal Crash Was Not Legally Drunk
description: Prosecutors said yesterday that they would not file drunken driving charges against the driver of a car that jumped a highway median in Queens on Sunday morning, killing a woman and her 11-month-old granddaughter, who were traveling in the opposite direction.

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP
description: European Indoors

title: Metro Business; Big Meals for City Slickers
description: The Golden Corral Corporation, a buffet grill-style restaurant chain that appeals to people with big appetites and small budgets, has set its sights on the New York metropolitan area.

title: Market Place; Will Northeast Utilities survive New Hampshire's rate cutting?
description: UTILITY deregulation, which has many states scrambling to come up with large rate cuts, has put New Hampshire in a nasty bind. Regulators and politicians have raised hopes that residents will soon see big declines in rates, which are the highest in the nation, but now they are struggling to deliver.

title: As Washington's Attention Wanders, Brazil Plays a Quiet Catch-Up Game
description: Three years after he corralled other leaders in the region into charting a Free Trade Area of the Americas, President Clinton stepped off Air Force One tonight to encounter a far more worldly and assertive Brazil, posing the first serious challenge to undisputed American leadership in the hemisphere.

title: 3d-Quarter Profit Off at Hughes Electronics
description: The Hughes Electronics Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter profit fell 4.7 percent, after its Delco unit cut prices for the automotive electronics it supplies to the General Motors Corporation, Hughes's parent company, because of competitive pressures.

title: Neagle Might Relieve
description: When the National League Championship Series resumes in Atlanta tonight with the Braves one defeat from elimination, Denny Neagle may be available for bullpen duty against Florida, according to the pitching coach, Leo Mazzone. And this time it will be for more than a tuneup.

title: Safety Locks Won't Halt Gun Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nets' Top Rookie Enjoys Garden
description: About an hour before his first game as a professional, Keith Van Horn turned to Jayson Williams and asked, ''What do we do now?''

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Whitman Web Site in Spanish
description: Spanish-speaking voters with Internet access can now get the same information on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's re-election campaign as their English-speaking counterparts. Since Saturday, a Spanish translation of Governor Whitman's campaign Web site has been available on the World Wide Web at www.christie97.org, campaign officials said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Ninety-year-old JAMES A. MICHENER has taken himself off life-sustaining kidney dialysis. Linda Milanesi, a spokeswoman for the James A. Michener Art Museum in Doylestown, Pa., said the prolific author opted last week to stop the medical treatment, which he was receiving in Austin, Tex., where he lives. His condition has not changed since he stopped the treatment, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, ORVILLE N.
description: GREENE-Orville N., 88. Of Manhattan. Suddenly, October 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Maxine Greene. Devoted father of Timothy, Elizabeth and the late Jonathan. Father-in-law of JoAnn and Paula. Loving grandfather of Dan and Chris. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81 st. 11:30AM Wednesday, October 15. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Epilepsy Foundation of America, Landover, Md. or the Neurology Department, Mayo Foundation, Scottsdale, Ariz. in memory of Jonathan Greene.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, IRWIN ''SPIKE''
description: STEIN-Irwin ''Spike''. Died Friday, October 10 in Corning, New York. Beloved husband of Ruth; father of Jamie, Michael, and the late Peter Lincoln; grandfather of Julie, Katherine, Liam and Peter Seth. Services on Tuesday, October 14, at 10 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels in Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your local Literacy Volunteers chapter in his name.

title: High Voice, High Profile: Countering Expectation
description: Not so long ago, countertenors were as intimately associated with the early-music world as gut strings and gambas, but even period-instrument productions offered them only intermittent work. As much as early-music listeners admired them for restoring something of the sound that castrati brought to 16th- and 17th-century sacred works and 18th-century operas, audiences raised with 19th-century opera in their ears had trouble taking them seriously. For these listeners, the power and heft of operatic sopranos, altos, tenors and basses were the models of vocal excellence; they considered the countertenor voice a lightweight, reedy variety of falsetto, and not at all in the same league.

title: A Dispute That's Worthy Of the Title 'Battle Royale'
description: James Bond, that suave, all but invincible veteran of secret wars, might have just landed in one of his toughest fights yet.

title: Pianist Explores the Italian Influence
description: Like many people, pianists often have physical quirks. Grunting, foot-stomping, face-squinching and such can be uncontrollable manifestations of a pianist's style. But the physical quirkiness in the playing of the Marseilles-born pianist Cyprien Katsaris, who gave a recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night, seems an affectation, and that is another matter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RISING, ALBERT E., JR.
description: RISING-Albert E., Jr., on October 11, at his home in Brightwaters, New York. Consulting Metallurgist and Geologist, Dr. of Engineering. He graduated Cum Laude from Princeton University, 1939 and Yale University in 1942. Lt. in US Navy, 1942-1946. Member Sigma XI Society. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, four children and their spouses, eight grandchildren, one of which is married. Family & friends are welcome at his home October 17, 1997 from 2 till 5 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the L.I. Maritime Museum, P.O. Box 184, West Sayville, N.Y. 11796, or North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove, St. Andrews Lane, Glen Cove, New York 11542. Care entrusted to the George C. White Funeral Home, Bay Shore, New York.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Critic's Notebook; The Not-So-Accidental Recognition of an Anarchist
