description: When Dario Fo was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature last week, it was the first time the honor had been given to an actor and clown. Mr. Fo is, of course, also a playwright, but it is as a performer of his own comedies that he has achieved his greatest international celebrity. His primary distinction is in combining all his diverse theatrical roles -- he is also a director and designer -- into a single act of comic self-creation.

title: Wine Talk; Taking a Closer Look at Boutique Australian Vintners
description: IN 1993, I flew to Sydney, Australia, to be a judge at the Royal Sydney, the annual wine competition of the Royal Agricultural Society of New South Wales. Over a period of three or four days and in the company of experts from all over Australia, I tasted 300 to 400 of the 1,500 wines entered: reds, whites, sparkling and late-harvest sweet wines.

title: Where Are the Great Braves' Rings?
description: If the Atlanta Braves do not win another World Series before the year 2000, history will lump them into a group of teams that always contended but often lost in the post-season: teams such as the Baltimore Orioles of 1969-74, the Brooklyn Dodgers of 1947-53 and the Oakland Athletics of 1988-92.

title: Why Wait for Congress on Campaign Reform?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAGG, THOMAS H
description: STAGG-Thomas H, of Carlstad on Oct. 12 1997, beloved husband of Maryanne (nee King), dear father of Brian, Luke and Billy. Brother of Helene Martin, son-in-law of Harriet King. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from The Kamienski Funeral Home, 106 Locust Avenue, Wallington, Friday 10 A.M., from Assumption RC Church, Woodridge at 10:30 A.M. Interment St. Michael Cemetery, visitation Wednesday 6-9 and Thursday 2-4 6-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to Fordham University Law School Library would be appreciated.

title: Labor Talks Up British Art While Cutting the Budget
description: Having struggled through 18 years of Tory rule, during which the arts were treated first with hostility by Margaret Thatcher and then with indifference by John Major, the heads of Britain's museums, orchestras, theaters and opera houses were understandably relieved this spring by the election of a Labor Government committed to promoting culture.

title: Class Notes
description: The concept of a new Middle East has taken such a thrashing in the past year or two that, when a glimmer of it appears, the natural tendency for many is a roll of the eyes. Lately, every time there is talk of the children of Abraham joining hands for a better future, someone blows himself up in a crowded market or bulldozers break ground on disputed land. Threats are voiced, guns are raised and hopes fade yet again.

title: Knicks Appear Mired In Not-So-Tender Trap
description: A strip of grass by the parking lot served as a makeshift tee box for Buck Williams. Head down, feet aligned. He was ready to give the dimpled ball a wild ride with his driver. Up went the ball, straight up. And straight down. Plop.

title: Troubled Start For Atlantic Race
description: Teams on three boats experienced difficulties at the start of the 3,000-mile Atlantic Race, which began from Tenerife on Sunday, but two have reserved the right to continue the trans-oceanic voyage.

title: Rituals and Ambiguities of Dreams
description: Sari Nordman appeared to be trying to evoke the mysterious beauty and ambiguity of dreams in the program of dances she offered on Friday night at Context in the East Village. But her choreography was often so wispy that instead of resembling dreams vividly recalled, her works seemed dreams half-forgotten.

title: Why Wait for Congress on Campaign Reform?; Irresistible Returns
description: To the Editor:

title: All Color and Perfume, Rice Steps Out
description: CONFUCIUS, whose writings suggest he was something of a food authority and a purist, the Brillat-Savarin of his day, insisted on the pristine whiteness of polished rice to provide a background for other elements of color in a dish: the emerald of spring vegetables, the golden burnish of perfectly sauteed fish or pork. But now, on the American table, a rainbow of colorful rices have started clamoring for attention.

title: Woods Plans on Answering 'What Have You Done Lately?'
description: Whether he is idolized or criticized, Tiger Woods is learning how to cope.

title: Police Officer on Trial Weeps As He Describes Killing a Man
description: A police officer on trial here for murder put his head in his hands and cried when he testified today that he felt he had to shoot a man three times to save his father's life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVEC, PIERRE HENRI
description: LeVEC-Pierre Henri, co-founder of ''Pierre Deux'', died in Rhinebeck, NY, Sept. 28 of heart failure at 78. His long time associate, Pierre Moulin, was with him. LeVec and Moulin launched a highly acclaimed interior design movement for the French provincial country style started in 1967 with their chain of prestigious shops, Pierre Deux, and now exclusively Pierre Deux Antiques on Bleecker Street in NYC. They collaborated on the publishing of 4 very popular books on the French Country style. LeVec was born in St. Louis on February 16, 1919, the son of Alice Mary Becker and Alfred Ernest Rene LeVec. Graduated from University of Missouri-Sigma Chi Fraternity and earned a degree in journalism at Georgetown University. He served as a paratrooper in W.W. II during the Normandy Invasion and was awarded the Purple Heart. Post-war he worked for the FBI and Treasury Department and in Paris with the Marshall Plan where he met Mr. Moulin. In recent years, Mr. LeVec, and Mr. Moulin have beautifully restored the 200 year old historic Hudson River mansion, Callendar House in Tivoli, NY, a stunning legacy. Mr. LeVec had a great love of horses and dogs. He generously shared his success and resources with cultural and preservation causes. His favorite charities were the Kaatsbaan Int'l Dance Center and the Four Nations Ensemble. In lieu of flowers, donations can be sent to either organization at P.O. Box 482, Tivoli, New York 12583. He is survived by his sister, Mary Alice Newcomer of Kansas City, nephews and nieces. There will be a private tribute at the Callendar House on Saturday, October 18.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BUFFUM, IMBRIE
description: BUFFUM-Imbrie. Former Professor of French at Yale University, died in Penn Yan, New York on July 7. He was eighty-two. There will be a Memorial Service at Christ Church in New Haven, on October 19 at 3 P.M. Contact John Taft, 202-338-5830 or David I. Roe 206-727-0713.

title: The Daring Attack That Blew Up in Israel's Face
description: Over many years, it has been an open secret in the Middle East that Israel and Jordan have quietly cooperated on a host of covert projects. And so, diplomats here say, King Hussein was not surprised on Sept. 25 when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called to ask that he immediately meet Israel's chief spymaster.

title: EF Language Leads Whitbread
description: EF Language, the current leader in the Whitbread Round the World race, hit some of the fastest speeds so far, averaging just over 15 knots yesterday as the 10-yacht fleet continued on its course to Cape Town. EF Language increased its lead over Merit Cup to 42 miles, with Innovation Kvaerner a mile farther back in third. Meanwhile, America's Challenge, the seventh-place yacht, reported slow going caused when a 75-foot length of fishing net became snarled in the propeller shaft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNERAN, SCOTT WILSON
description: FINNERAN-Scott Wilson, 25, of Greenwich CT., on Sept. 25, 1997. Beloved son of Gerard and Judy Finneran. Brother of Mark Finneran & Laurie Calder. Also survived by a niece, a nephew, several uncles, aunts & cousins. Memorial Mass, Saturday, October 18, 1997, 10 AM, at St. Mary RC Church, 178 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers donations to Scott Finneran Scholarship FundGHS, 10 Hillside Drive, Greenwich CT. 06830. Information: Gallagher Funeral Home, Greenwich, CT.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Strict Review Is Sought for Adirondack Prison Plan
description: Four environmental groups said today that the Pataki administration was trying to rush construction of a maximum-security prison in Adirondack Park without adequate environmental review, and they asked the state to consider less ecologically sensitive spots for the 750-cell prison.

title: Old Crime Returns to Haunt an Immigrant; Facing Deportation, Dominican May Become Test Case for New Law
description: For 171 days now, immigration officials have held Jesus Collado, a Bronx restaurant manager and a legal resident of the United States, in a detention center in Pennsylvania for a misdemeanor he committed 23 years ago and for which, until now, he had never spent a day in jail.

title: About New York; Dutch Treat: Hanging Out In 'Breukelen'
description: THE sharp rhythms of Brooklynese broke the silence on Gold Street, where a family lounged on the stoop of their building. The sights and sounds were enough to baffle Ralph Hoetmer and his friend Daniel Gulpers, as they walked along the dimly lighted side street off the Fulton Mall.

title: Women's Event In Washington
description: It is part Olympics, part Goodwill Games, all female. The first Women's Global Challenge, a biennial international competition of seven or eight sports for professional and amateur athletes, has been scheduled for April 28 through May 2, 1999, in the Washington area.

title: Why Wait for Congress on Campaign Reform?; Money Isn't Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Succoth, the Jewish harvest festival, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Friday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHESSIN, MILDRED
description: CHESSIN-Mildred. Beloved sisterin-law, we will always remember you with our love. Lil, Betty, Duke and Midge

title: An Accord With Communists Ends Latest Italian Political Crisis
description: Italy's latest political crisis drew to a close today after Prime Minister Romano Prodi reached a new accord with the same party of Communists who only a few days ago were ready to sacrifice his 17-month-old center-left Government in a fight over spending cuts.

title: Familiarity Breeds Affection for Asian Vegetables
description: FOR thousands of years, Asians have treasured the delicate sweetness of pea shoots, the gentle bite of Chinese broccoli, the zest of Chinese chives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RISING, ALBERT E., JR.
description: RISING-Albert E., Jr., on October 11, at his home in Brightwaters, New York. Consulting Metallurgist and Geologist, Dr. of Engineering. He graduated Cum Laude from Princeton University, 1939 and Yale University in 1942. Lt. in US Navy, 1942-1946. Member Sigma XI Society. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, four children and their spouses, eight grandchildren, one of which is married. Family & friends are welcome at his home October 17, 1997 from 2 till 5 P.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the L.I. Maritime Museum, P.O. Box 184, West Sayville, N.Y. 11796, or North Shore University Hospital at Glen Cove, St. Andrews Lane, Glen Cove, New York 11542. Care entrusted to the George C. White Funeral Home, Bay Shore, New York.

title: 60-Year-Old Woman Is Robbed and Raped
description: Two youths robbed and raped a 60-year-old woman yesterday in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx, the police said. A 16-year-old, Kenny Whitaker of 314 East 143d Street, was arrested and charged with rape, robbery and assault. A second suspect was still being sought.

title: Silversmith Admits He Stored Stolen Torahs
description: A Hasidic silversmith from Monsey, N.Y., pleaded guilty yesterday to possession of stolen goods, ending a three-year investigation of robberies that stripped sacred religious objects from synagogues in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: ARV ASSISTED LIVING REJECTS TAKEOVER BID FROM EMERITUS
description: ARV Assisted Living Inc. said yesterday that it had rejected an unsolicited offer to be acquired by health care provider the Emeritus Corporation for $210 million, or $16.50 a share. The operator of assisted-living facilities called the offer from Emeritus ''unattractive,'' citing conditions including ARV's current stock price. Shares of ARV, which is based in Costa Mesa, Calif., fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $16. It also said the offer was inconsistent with its strategic relationship with Prometheus Assisted Living L.L.C., an affiliate of Lazard Freres Real Estate Investors L.L.C.

title: Food Stuff
description: Following the Chefs To Where They Eat

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, MORTON
description: JACOBS-Morton, Esq. October 13, 1997. Husband of Claire (nee Cohen) of Haddonfield, NJ. Father of Ralph Jacobs, Esq., Anne Jacobs Molofsky and Barbara Jacobs Cohn. Brother of Pearl Bilofsky and Natalie Abrams. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Funeral services Wednesday 11 AM, Platt Memorial Chapels Inc. 2001 Berlin Road, Cherry Hill, New Jersey. Interment Crescent Burial Park.

title: The Mayor Mars Columbus Day
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani hit the worst possible tone for a New York City political campaign on Monday when he charged that his Democratic challenger, Ruth Messinger, ''doesn't care very much'' about Italian-Americans. Ms. Messinger had done nothing to merit the Mayor's rancor except to spend less time than he did at the Columbus Day festivities. But in the end, it was Mr. Giuliani who rained on the parade.

title: U.N. Chief Seeks Peace Force to Dampen the Brazzaville Flames
description: With a sudden intensification of civil war in the Congo Republic threatening to engulf several West African nations in a regional conflict, Secretary General Kofi Annan asked the Security Council tonight to impose sanctions on the country and to prepare to send a peacekeeping force there.

title: INTERRA FINANCIAL PLANS TO MERGE ITS 2 BROKERAGE UNITS
description: Interra Financial Inc. said yesterday that it would merge its Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc. and Dain Bosworth Inc. brokerage units. The combined firm, Dain Rauscher Inc., will have more than 1,200 brokers and institutional salespeople. Interra expects to cut 100 jobs during the next several months as a result of the merger, and took a $9.6 million, or 72-cents-a-share, charge against third-quarter earnings for severance costs. Shares of Interra rose $2.75, to $61.375. As part of the reorganization, Interra's chief financial officer, Louis Fornetti, 47, resigned.

title: A Cry for Humanity in the Carnage of War
description: At the heart of Camus's play ''The Misunderstanding'' is the proposition, which has gained wide currency in this century, that happiness and prosperity can be secured if one can just kill enough other people different from oneself. Under the admirable direction of Francoise Kourilsky, Ubu Repertory has staged a commendable revival of Camus's joint cri de coeur on behalf of humanism and swift kick to the backside of fate.

title: A Rain Forest Imperiled
description: The issue that most Americans identify with Brazil -- the destruction of the Amazon rain forest -- did not occupy a prominent role in the talks between President Clinton and Brazil's President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso. The issue deserved better, though neither man is comfortable with the subject. Washington still subsidizes logging in America's temperate rain forests. Brazil has abandoned some of its worst policies in the Amazon, yet it is not enforcing its laws and seems oblivious to a range of new and insidious threats from timber and agricultural interests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, EDGAR
description: HABER-Edgar, 65, of Salisbury, NH, Weston and New York, Elkan R. Blout Professor of Biological Sciences & Professor of Medicine, Harvard University, former Chief of Cardiology of Massachusetts General Hospital and former President of Bristol-Myers Squibb Pharmaceutical Research Institute, on Monday, October 13th. Husband of Carol Avery Haber, father of Justin A. Haber of Waban, MA, Graham S. Haber of NY & Eben M. Haber of Palo Alto, CA; brother of Dr. Ruth H. Jonas of NY; & son of Dorothy J. Haber of Yonkers, NY. Memorial donations in lieu of flowers should be made to The Edgar Haber Research Award, C/O. M. Mitchell, Center for the Prevention of Cardiovascular Disease, Harvard School of Public Health, 677 Huntington Avenue, Boston, MA 02115. Private burial; memorial service to be held at 1:00 PM on Sunday, November 16, 1997 at The American Academy of Arts and Sciences, 136 Irving St., Cambridge, MA.

title: Restaurants; Spicy Notes From a Sichuan Kitchen
description: THE news arrived in a six-page, single-spaced letter that began, ''I am a Sichuan food lover.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, CAROLEE A. (NEE: WILLIAMS)
description: ROGERS-Carolee A. (nee: Williams), 50, of Glen Rock, NJ, died Monday, October 6, 1997, at home. She worked as a Systems Analyst for Texaco Inc., in Harrison, NY. Beloved wife of Eugene and devoted mother to Thomas and Andrew. She is also survived by her mother Marie and brother Gregory Williams. Predeceased by her father Edward in 1994. A memorial service will be held at 10:00 A.M. Saturday October 18, 1997 at The Glen Rock Community Church, Glen Rock, NJ. Donations to the Valley Hospital Hospice, 15 Essex Street, Paramus, NJ. 07652 or The American Cancer Society, 20 Mercer Street, Hackensack, NJ 07601, would be appreciated. For information, contact C.C. Van Emburgh Inc., Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Fox Is Outplaying NBC at All the Key Positions
description: Two years ago, baseball diehards asked, ''Why can't we watch both League Championship Series?'' Now, viewers should sing hosannas: not only do Fox and NBC show every game -- without any inane regionalization -- but they are also a joy to watch. But not an equal joy. Fox is doing a better job. It should; it does baseball all season, while NBC materializes for the post-season.

title: Oktyabrsky Journal; How to Amuse Rich Russians: Odds on the Horses
description: The way Daud Naloyev sees it, Russia's tycoons will inevitably grow weary of ostentatious jewelry and cars.

title: Temptations; A Sausage With Nothing to Hide
description: Astoria Meat Products is not a name with a lot of poetry to it, but it makes the point. Meat is the theme in this small Ukrainian store at 35-09 Broadway in Astoria, Queens, (718) 726-5663, and it's played with every possible Eastern European variation. Links and loops of jaternice, debrecine and kielbasa hang on racks suspended from the ceiling. Mahogany squares of double-smoked bacon dangle over trays of smoked rib bacon, glistening baked hams and two kinds of slab bacon. The glass display case is packed with krakowska sausage, sweet and hot Hungarian sausages, lasschinken, Westphalian ham and wursts galore.

title: Essay; Pushing Reno Ahead
description: Evidence linking President Clinton to the conspiracy to subvert campaign finance laws came on videotape when an Indonesian gardener, used as a conduit in illegal foreign-based contributions, told Clinton, ''James Riady sent me.''

title: AXA Unit Sells Stake In New Ireland Holdings
description: AXA-UAP S.A. of France said yesterday that its Sun Life and Provincial Holdings unit had agreed to sell its 83 percent stake in New Ireland Holdings to the Bank of Ireland for about $311 million. The main asset of New Ireland Holdings is New Ireland Assurance. Sun Life controls all AXA's insurance and asset management operations in Britain.

title: Settlement by Fujitsu
description: Fujitsu Ltd. agreed today to a $26.8 million settlement of lawsuits that accused the company of underpaying when it bought out public shareholders of the Amdahl Corporation last month. Fujitsu added 40 cents to its $12-a-share takeover offer for the 58 percent of Amdahl that it did not already own -- bringing the total value of the takeover to $910 million, Fujitsu said.

title: N.F.L. Owners Meet With Eyes on New TV Deal
description: Four years ago when the National Football League signed its current $4.3 billion television rights package, eyes bulged. It was the richest television sports contract in history, and it ends early next year, after the Super Bowl and Pro Bowl.

title: 5 Days of Kite Maneuvering
description: Flying everything from the sleekest dual-line sports kite to the simplest delta-winged novice kite, nearly 600 members of the American Kitefliers Association kicked off their 20th annual convention yesterday on the beach in Wildwood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERNER, ROSE
description: WERNER-Rose. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member, and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: Teamsters' Union Staff Members Cite Pressure For Donations
description: Several members of the teamsters' union told a Congressional subcommittee today that union officials engaged in an array of questionable tactics to help re-elect President Ron Carey, including pressuring union staff members to make donations to his campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, NATHANIEL
description: HERMAN-Nathaniel. Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member Nathaniel Herman. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Joan and their beloved family. Morton West, President Leon Fassler, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TATKON, CAROL CLARK
description: TATKON-Carol Clark. Cornell University mourns the loss of a devoted alumna and Trustee, Carol Clark Tatkon, whose leadership, energy and commitment to the University was an inspiration for more than four decades. An involved undergraduate and member of the Class of '59, she went on to a distinguished career in the corporate world at a time when such achievements by women were rare. Despite the demands of her professional life, she remained deeply involved with the University. She became a member of University Council in 1975 and she served with distinction as vice-chair of the College of Arts and Sciences Advisory Council, the Johnson Graduate School of Management's Strategic Task Force, as president of the Board of Cornell Adult University, as a member of the Council's Cultural Endeavors Committee, and on the President's Council of Cornell Women. As a Cornell Trustee since 1981, she had numerous leadership roles including vice-chair, chair of the Buildings and Properties Committee, and a member of both the Executive and the Alumni Affairs and Development Committees. She had an unbounded enthusiasm and love for Cornell and she inspired all who knew her with her determination, wit, keen mind, integrity, and personal warmth. We share with her daughter, Heather, and with her family, the loss of one of Cornell's most beloved alumni. Harold Tanner, Chairman Cornell Univ. Board of Trustees Hunter R. Rawlings III, Pres. Cornell University

title: Metro Business; Hicks, Muse Units Acquiring a Bakery
description: C. Dean Metropoulos & Company of Greenwich, Conn., and Stratford Capital Partners of Dallas signed an agreement yesterday to acquire the operating assets of the Van den Bergh Bakery, which is part of the Lipton division of Unilever P.L.C..

title: Poverty Grows Quietly Along With Wealth : POOR AND RICH IN EUROPE
description: MARSEILLE  [Part 1 of a two-article series]

title: Supreme Court Roundup; ASSISTED SUICIDE CLEARS A HURDLE IN HIGHEST COURT
description: The Supreme Court removed the last legal obstacle today to Oregon's law allowing physician-assisted suicide, clearing the way for the state to put the country's only such law into effect for the first time since Oregon voters adopted it in a statewide referendum three years ago.

title: The Chef
description: MY friend and paesano the late Vince D'Attolico was proud of the organic produce he sold at the Union Square Greenmarket, and he introduced me to things like salsify, burdock and his beautiful Jerusalem artichokes.

title: Topics of The Times; Historic Handshake In Belfast
description: Britain's Prime Minister, Tony Blair, was right Monday to confer the legitimacy of a meeting and a handshake on Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein leader, despite complaints from Ulster Protestant Unionist politicians. Though Mr. Adams and Sinn Fein have a history of condoning I.R.A. terrorism, they have met the reasonable conditions set by the British and Irish Governments and the American mediator, George Mitchell, for full participation in the Northern Ireland peace talks.

title: Unions Flexing Muscles For McGreevey Campaign
description: Hundreds of union members rallied at the foot of the State House steps today, cheering as their leaders vowed to unseat Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in what they say will be their largest political effort in decades.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe for Basic Meatloaf in an article on Oct. 1 about meatloaf misstated the number of grams of fat per serving. It is 21, not 6.

title: A Dissertation on Mr. Ed?; New Scholarly Center to Study Pop Television Culture
description: As a typically compulsive undergraduate at the University of Chicago, Bob Thompson used to allow himself just one half-hour of television viewing a week, on Sunday night. And no matter how hard he tried to watch PBS, he always succumbed to ''CHiPS,'' the drama about California motorcycle cops starring Larry Wilcox and Erik Estrada.

title: Hawaiian Empire
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; Laying Mr. Foster To Rest
description: Some people will never be convinced that Vincent Foster Jr. killed himself, and there is no doubt that the White House Counsel's office meddled improperly with the initial investigation. But for most citizens, Kenneth Starr's newly released findings on the death should end credence in the theory that the Deputy White House Counsel was murdered as part of a Whitewater-related plot.

title: Steeler Receiving Corps Is Battered and Bruised
description: Kordell Stewart suddenly has a new problem to deal with in his first season as the Pittsburgh Steelers' quarterback -- finding somebody healthy enough to catch his passes.

title: COMPANY REPORTS: Market Place; Sprint and Frontier are forgiven their performance sins.
description: FORBEARANCE is generally as difficult to find on Wall Street as pity.

title: Foreign and Fed Buying Aids Bond Prices
description: Treasury securities advanced yesterday as investors returned from a long holiday weekend to find that overseas bargain hunters had pushed up prices.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe for quince butter in the Food Chain column last Wednesday misstated the type of pot to use. It is a Crock-Pot or slow cooker, not a heavy two-quart pot.

title: Calendar
description: Wine and Rauschenberg

title: Harold Robbins, 81, Dies; Wrote Best Sellers Brimming With Sex, Money and Power
description: Harold Robbins, a writer whose formula of sex, money and power made him one of the best-selling authors of his day, died yesterday at Desert Hospital in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 81 and lived in Palm Springs.

title: UNOCAL WINS GASOLINE PATENT SUIT IN CALIFORNIA
description: The Unocal Corporation said yesterday that it had won a court case over a gasoline patent that could provide licensing fees for the oil company and higher fuel prices for California drivers. The Federal District Court in Los Angeles ruled against six major oil companies that had challenged a patent Unocal has on a clean-burning type of gasoline that California requires. Unocal won the patent in 1994 and wants to collect a fee for every gallon sold. The patent was challenged by ARCO, the Chevron Corporation, the Exxon Corporation, the Mobil Corporation, the Shell Oil unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Texaco Inc. Neither damages nor royalty fees were set.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDREOLI, PETER
description: ANDREOLI-Peter. The City Club Trustees and Staff express their condolences to the family of Peter Andreoli, a long term member of the Board of Trustees. His advice and council will be missed. Norma Munn, Board Chair

title: In War Against No-Shows, Restaurants Get Tougher
description: THEY call. They reserve. They don't come.

title: Jail Officer Held in Robberies
description: A Mercer County correctional officer was accused of using a fake pipe bomb to commit 17 bank robberies in New Jersey and four other states and was ordered held without bail yesterday, Federal agents said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWERSKY, RABBI DR. YITZHAK
description: TWERSKY-Rabbi Dr. Yitzhak. The Students, Faculty and Directors of Maimonides School of Brookline, Ma., mourn the passing of Rabbi Dr. Yitzhak Twersky, zt''l, teacher, Rebbe and role model. Rabbi Twersky's scholarship and righteousness, his devotion to Jewish learning and the Jewish people, inspired and uplifted our community. He guided and enriched our school, fostering the teachings and philosphy of his father-in-law, Rabbi Dr. Joseph Soloveitchik, zt''l, revered Founder of Maimonides School. We extend our deepest condolences to Rabbi Twersky's beloved wife Atarah, Chair of the Maimonides School Committee, and their children and grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Jets Join The Others In Search Of a Punter
description: The Jets, looking for a temporary or permanent replacement for their injured punter, Brian Hansen, tried out one candidate yesterday. They will try out one or two more kickers today, then sign one to a minimum salary and hope he holds up Sunday against the New England Patriots.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Evening Hours column on Sunday with a report about the opening of Carnegie Hall's season misspelled the surname of the president of the Alliance for the Arts and chairman of New York City's advisory commission for cultural affairs, who attended. He is Randall Bourscheidt, not Bourcheidt.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINREW, JANET (NEE TUCK)
description: LEVINREW-Janet (nee Tuck). Of Edgewater, MD, formerly of NYC, October 13, 1997. Sister of Eugene Tuck. She is also survived by a niece Martha T. Rozett and nephews Jonathan and Daniel Tuck. Funeral services will be private.

title: Toy Makers To Sponsor Design Lab At M.I.T.
description: Whether the children of tomorrow will be brighter than today's is anyone's guess. But thanks to ever-cheaper microprocessors, their toys will be smarter -- at least in the view of researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Women Don't Undermine Military Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Not Ready for Golden Oldies
description: David Bowie, science-fiction fan, transported himself into an alternate reality on Monday night at the Supper Club, emerging as the leader of a dance band at the edge of time. Pop's master of artifice pulled a grand illusion by mixing his classics with material from his modestly successful new album, ''Earthling'' (Virgin), and refusing to make the slightest distinctions. Mr. Bowie, who hasn't had a genuine hit in over a decade, might be expected to rest on his plastic laurels, but instead he mocked that role, erasing history's ups and downs by acting as if every song he performed were a chart-topping smash right now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, CHARLOTTE (NEE KAUFMAN)
description: ADLER-Charlotte (nee Kaufman). Formerly of New York City and Yonkers, on October 13, 1997 in San Francisco, CA. Beloved wife of the late Samuel (Hershi), devoted mother of Preeva and Leonard Tramiel, dear sister of Pauline Kaufman, Chaim Kaufman, Laurie Weinberg and the late Abner Kaufman. Devoted grandmother of Alex and Michael. Graveside services Wednesday, October 15, 1997, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, Long Island.

title: Military Court Reviews Trial in Which Prosecutor Switched Sides to Defense
description: Military law specialists say they will be closely watching judicial hearings this week in a case that raises a fundamental question about the fairness of military justice: Can the accused be assigned a defense lawyer who was previously the prosecutor in the very same case?

title: The Minimalist; A Pumpkin Soup for Fall: It's Almost Too Easy
description: TO most people, pumpkin means pie, a limited role for a large vegetable that is nearly ubiquitous from Labor Day through Christmas. But to Debra Ponzek, the chef and owner of Aux Delices, a take-out shop and caterer in Greenwich, Conn., pumpkin means soup. And soup based on pumpkin -- or other winter squash like acorn or butternut -- is a minimalist's dream, a luxuriously creamy dish that requires only two main ingredients, a blender and a stove.

title: Stocks Are Mixed on Earnings That Mostly Top Expectations
description: A new batch of third-quarter earnings reports left stocks mixed yesterday. Although many of the reports were positive, analysts said, investors seemed to focus on any negatives that they could find.

title: With Afro-Peruvian Songs Old and New
description: Slavery scattered African music across the Americas -- even as far as Peru, where Spaniards imported African workers more than 400 years ago. Susana Baca, who performed at the New School auditorium on Thursday night, is both a historian and popularizer of Afro-Peruvian music.

title: STRATEGIC HOTEL AGREES TO BUY HOTELS FROM PRUDENTIAL
description: Strategic Hotel Capital Inc., a private investment company, said yesterday that it had acquired five luxury hotels from the Prudential Insurance Company of America for $549 million. Prudential has also committed to investing as much as $225 million for an equity stake in Strategic Hotel. The deal is part of a plan announced last year by Prudential, the nation's largest life insurer, based in Newark, to reorganize its $5 billion real estate portfolio by swapping properties for shares in public and private real estate companies and partnerships. Strategic Hotel is a newly formed joint venture between Goldman, Sachs & Company and Security Capital Group.

title: From Grief and Rebellion to Serenity
description: On the calendar in her tiny dorm room at Manhattan College, the space marked Oct. 23 is filled with a drawing of an angel spreading her wings, a beacon of light emanating from her halo. The angel's heart, surrounded by flowers and stained by a teardrop that was not a part of the original art work, bears a one-word inscription: ''Mom.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, SARA
description: COHEN-Sara. On October 13, 1997. Beloved wife of Sam, dear sister and sister-in-law, loving aunt, great aunt, and great great aunt. Services today, 1 P.M., at Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEICH, ''JULIE'' JULIUS R.
description: TEICH-''Julie'' Julius R., Oct. 10. Retired advertising executive. Beloved husband of Esther M. (Cosindas) Teich. Devoted father of Julius R. Teich Jr., Norman P. Teich (deceased), his wife Ruth H. Teich, Pamela J. Teich (deceased), & Phyllis T. Litman. Loving grandfather of 11. Cherished great grandfather of 5. If desired, sympathy may be expressed by donating to National Alzheimer's Disease & Related Disorders, 919 Michigan Ave., Chicago, IL 60611.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, SYLVIA
description: WEISS-Sylvia. Formerly of Pembroke Pines and Levittown. The family of Sylvia Sue Weiss notes with great sadness her passing on October 13, 1997. Beloved mother to Karyn and Lisa and devoted grandmother to Quinn. We will miss her always. Donations can be sent to the New York Women's Foundation.

title: Surge in Growth Predicted for Europe
description: European economic growth will surge in 1998 to the fastest pace in nearly a decade, putting most European Union countries on course to adopt the planned common currency, the European Commission said yesterday. The forecast showed the economy of the 15-nation union expanding 3 percent next year, beating the 2.6 percent pace of the United States, according to its own predictions, for the first time since 1991.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Television section on Sunday about Dwight Gooden of the New York Yankees, with an article about a film on Joe Torre, referred incorrectly to Gooden's 1996 no-hitter. He pitched it in a regular-season game in May of that year, not during the World Series.

title: Robert M. Rogers, Cable Television Executive, 71
description: Robert M. Rogers, founder, chairman and chief executive of TCA Cable TV in Tyler, Tex., died on Sept. 18 at his home in Tyler. He was 71.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: GUILTY PLEA -- A man accused of exploiting deaf Mexican immigrants pleaded guilty, and appeared to be cooperating with prosecutors. B3.

title: SIX EXAMINED ITT'S WORLD DIRECTORIES BUSINESS
description: The ITT Corporation attracted at least six companies that were interested in buying its telephone book business, which ITT was keeping as part of a proposal to separate into three companies, court records show. The GTE Corporation, the BellSouth Corporation, the Dutch publisher VNU, the Danish phone company Tele Danmark A/S and the German Deutsche Telecom all approached ITT earlier this year, according to depositions of the ITT chairman, Rand Araskog, and chief financial officer, Ann Reese. Ms. Reese also cited interest from a company called Telefonica, although she did not specify which one. ITT wanted at least $2.4 billion for World Directories, one of the largest international publishers of telephone books, according to the depositions.

title: Grim Details Emerge in Teen-Age Slaying Case
description: Providing the first chilling details about the purported plot behind the Oct. 1 massacre at Pearl High School, a sheriff's investigator testified today that an 18-year-old student had served as the leader of a cult of teen-agers known as the Kroth and had masterminded a plan to assassinate enemies in a takeover of the school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIETZ, LYNNE
description: DIETZ-Lynne. Beloved wife of Hal for 50 years. Devoted mother of Ken and Debbie and Laurie Dietz, Marcie and Stuart Lipsett. Adoring ninny of Matthew, Max and Jake. Loved by all her friends. Lynn, you left us much too quickly. Your spirit, humor and strength inspired everyone who knew you. Lynn and Hal . . . together again. Services on Monday, October 20, at 9:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Business Travel; T.W.A. and Royal Jordanian Airlines are set to begin their code-sharing alliance on Nov. 1.
description: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES and Royal Jordanian Airlines will begin their code-share alliance on Nov. 1, which will enable T.W.A. passengers to fly to Amsterdam and Amman, Jordan, with a connection in New York, and will allow Royal Jordanian passengers to connect in New York to T.W.A.'s domestic flights. Passengers on both carriers will receive boarding passes and seat assignments at their originating city and their bags will be checked straight through.

title: U.S. Investigating Sale of Supposed Kennedy Papers
description: Federal prosecutors opened a criminal investigation yesterday into the sale of hundreds of documents supposedly written by John F. Kennedy, which some forensic specialists now say are fake.

title: Off the Menu
description: Leaving the Green

title: CHRONICLE
description: Over the years when HEATHER WATTS, the former principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, and JOCK SOTO, still a principal there, danced together, they developed the profound affinity of partnership and friendship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRILL, MARTIN
description: BRILL-Martin, on October 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Betty. Loving father of Walter and Gerrilyn, Peter and Krista, and Steven and Elaine. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Natalie, David and Lauren. Dear brother of Frank. A memorial gathering of family and friends will be held on Thursday, October 16, at 1:30 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: On the Wrong Side of a Revolution
description: In the Revolutionary War, some Americans lost, of course, and for some of them it was a vicious, bloody business. In ''Pledge of Allegiance,'' Mark R. Giesser makes the war intensely personal as one woman whose farm was burned by patriots after her husband was hanged as a British spy and another who was driven mad when her fiance was executed by court-martial seek compensation for their losses from an agent of the British crown in a refugee camp in Canada.

title: Maurice Braunstein, 83; Ran Bridge Events
description: Maurice Braunstein of Schenectady, N.Y., a leading director of bridge tournaments, died on Sept. 20 at his home.

title: Appellate Court Blocks Referendum on State Takeover of Lilco
description: For the second time, a court has ruled that Suffolk County cannot proceed with plans for a referendum next month on the partial state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROME, FLORENCE
description: ROME-Florence, 87, at her home in Manhattan on October 6, 1997. Wife of the late Harold Rome. Mother of Joshua and Rachel. Grandmother of Shoshanna and Leah. Memorial service at 11 A.M. Wednesday, Oct. 15, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. (at 81st Street).

title: Sports of The Times; Bench's Peers Are in Awe Of Johnson
description: THE Atlanta Braves, the team of the 1990's, wanted dearly to avenge their World Series loss last year to the spendthrift Yankees and fulfill their destiny. But they were ambushed by the deep-pocketed Florida Marlins. The five-year-old franchise, boosted by an $89 million off-season free-agent binge, threw lots of green money and seasoned veterans at the Braves' dreams, and won.

title: Murder Charge Filed In Killing of Bystander
description: A gunman has been charged with murder after a Monday morning shootout with the police that ended in the death of a bystander, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: Restrain Inflation Genie
description: To the Editor:

title: Once More the Mushroom Cloud
description: Atrocity is one of the least elastic of dramatic subjects. So it should come as no surprise that ''Hiroshima,'' a new play by Ron Destro with music by Yoko Ono, is unfailingly sober, mournful and respectful of the victims of the atomic bomb dropped on the Japanese city in August 1945.

title: Kodak Sales and Earnings Continue to Show Declines
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, whose digital photography business continues to bleed profusely, said yesterday that its sales and earnings had declined for a second consecutive quarter.

title: Commercial Real Estate; 50's Tower to Be Fitted for 90's Retail
description: The building with the sixes is shedding the 50's.

title: Suspect in Peddling Ring Is Said to Aid Prosecution
description: One of the suspects charged with holding deaf Mexicans in servitude in the United States and forcing them to sell trinkets pleaded guilty yesterday to involvement in the conspiracy, and the judge indicated that the man was cooperating with prosecutors.

title: Jersey City Aesthetics Query
description: Officials in Jersey City are taking an unusual approach to city planning by asking their own residents to decide how they want the city to look.

title: 5 Arrested in Drug Sweep In Washington Heights
description: Eighty narcotics officers converged on a Washington Heights neighborhood yesterday, arresting suspected drug dealers, padlocking buildings and barricading the street, the police said. The raid on 152d Street between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenues followed two similar sweeps in the neighborhood and completed a seven-month investigation of activities on the block.

title: Starting At Twilight Puts Hitters In the Dark
description: The shadows. Yes, the shadows that everyone knows had such a significant impact on Game 3 of the American League Championship Series in Cleveland last Saturday might become the story again in Game 6 at Camden Yards here on Wednesday, when the Orioles attempt to keep their season alive and the Indians attempt to roll into the World Series.

title: Immigration by the Numbers
description: As a demographer, I study population trends using the most complete and accurate data available. Usually, this work isn't controversial -- but not when it comes to studying the impact of immigration.

title: Curious Cook; That First-Flapjack Slip-Up: Case Solved
description: MANY of life's firsts are flops, but they are flops we can leave behind. First pancakes are irksome because they are recurring flops. I make pancakes often, and the first batch off the griddle is always an embarrassment. You'd think that pancakes would come out best at the start, when the freshly oiled griddle is at its shiniest, the batter at its liveliest. But no. First pancakes are blotchy disks, part brown and part pasty white, which I slip surreptitiously into the stacks of subsequent, uniformly golden pancakes.

title: TV Notes; Comedy Shuffle Isn't Paying Off
description: Is NBC coming back to the pack?

title: Updating the Jewish Image of Poles
description: SHTETL

title: Indian's First Novel Wins Booker Prize in Britain
description: An Indian writer, Arundhati Roy, was awarded England's prestigious Booker Prize this evening for her first novel, ''The God of Small Things,'' a soaring story about a set of twins struggling to make sense of the world, themselves and their strange and difficult family in southern India.

title: Israel Demolishes 2 Palestinian Houses in the West Bank
description: Despite calls by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright for a ''time out'' from actions that might provoke the Palestinians, the Israeli authorities today resumed the demolition of Palestinian homes in the West Bank, razing two houses near this refugee camp.

title: Once Back, Brown Wasn't Leaving
description: Apparently the only true measure of Kevin Brown, besides minuscule earned run averages, is orneriness. So when the Marlins' right-hander was seen scowling tonight while lobbying against being extracted from his team's clincher against the Atlanta Braves, all of Florida had to exhale with relief.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANCKTON, CATHERINE
description: LANCKTON-Catherine. Formerly of New York and Fairfield County, on October 13th in Sarasota, FL. Beloved wife of Arthur Lanckton; mother of Alison Lankenau of New York City, Van Lanckton of Boston, MA. and Barbara Connors of Boulder, CO; grandmother of Benjamin and Samuel Lanckton, Matthew Connors, Catherine and Christine Lankenau, Amy McPherson; great-grandmother of Noah Lanckton. Memorial at 3PM, Saturday at Plymouth Harbor in Sarasota. In lieu of flowers a gift to the Fresh Air Fund, 1040 Avenue of Americas, New York, New York 10018, would be appreciated.

title: NBC Sports Decides Olympic Assignment
description: The NBC Sports division of NBC, owned by the General Electric Company, has named Fallon McElligott Berlin in New York to advertise and promote coverage of the Olympics in 2000, 2002, 2004, 2006 and 2008. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Drivers in Thruway Crash Cleared of Fault in Inquiry
description: The police investigating last Thursday's collision and fatal fire under the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in Yonkers said yesterday that neither of the two drivers involved appeared to be at fault in the crash and that the driver of the gasoline truck that burned tried to assist the other driver but was prevented by mounting flames.

title: Israel's Orthodox Rabbis Reject Deal on Role of Other Branches
description: The increasingly bitter struggle between Orthodox and non-Orthodox branches of Judaism broke back into the open today after Orthodox rabbis rejected a reported compromise under which the non-Orthodox would gain a limited role in Israeli religious affairs.

title: U.S. Respects Brazil, Clinton Assures Latin Giant
description: President Clinton had a simple message for Brazil today, and he delivered it over and over, in several different ways: The United States takes this country seriously. Really. It doesn't want to dictate relations in the hemisphere, but just to do more business.

title: INSIDE
description: Counter-Protest on AIDS

title: TV Notes; The News Race
description: While NBC News continues to be the clear leader in the Nielsen ratings race among the three major evening news broadcasts, there was good news for CBS last week. ''The CBS Evening News'' with Dan Rather finished second in total viewers and almost tied ABC's ''World News Tonight'' in households.

title: Give Judges a Raise
description: To the Editor:

title: Council Votes to Increase Fines Sharply for Excessive Noise
description: For New Yorkers who have long complained about noisy nightclubs, jackhammers on overtime, shrieking car alarms and howling dogs, the City Council offered a remedy yesterday that members said they hoped would provide more relief than even a good set of earplugs.

title: Two Magazines Name Agencies
description: Two magazines have named agencies to handle their accounts.

title: AIDS Experts Leave Journal After Studies Are Criticized
description: Two internationally recognized AIDS experts are resigning from The New England Journal of Medicine's editorial board over the content and handling of articles criticizing the ethics of Federally financed studies of AIDS treatments in third-world countries.

title: In Umbria, Tradition Confronts Convenience
description: JUST a few miles from the center of this picture-perfect Umbrian hill town sits a symbol of 20th-century progress and a threat to tradition: a supermarket.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID KOREVAAR is a concert pianist who is performing on more than one kind of stage these days. He is running for mayor of Norwalk, Conn., on the Democratic ticket, hoping to unseat Frank J. Esposito, the five-term Republican incumbent.

title: HASBRO AND GALOOB ARE GRANTED 'STAR WARS' RIGHTS
description: Hasbro Inc. and Galoob Toys Inc. said yesterday that they had been granted the right to make certain ''Star Wars'' toys and games for the three new ''Star Wars'' movies. Hasbro said it won worldwide rights from Lucas Licensing Ltd. for core action figures, vehicles and games, plus additional ''Star Wars'' categories -- including electronic hand-held games, die- cast vehicles and creative play products. In a separate agreement, Hasbro said it had also acquired long-term preferential negotiation rights from Lucasfilm Ltd. for the same categories of toys based on new Lucasfilm movies. Galoob Toys said it had won a license from Lucasfilm to make small-scale figures, vehicles, play sets and accessories based on the second ''Star Wars'' trilogy. Shares of Hasbro fell 12.5 cents, to $26.6875, while shares of Galoob rose $1.9375, to $17.50.

title: Clinton Gently Vetoes $144 Million in Military Budget Items
description: President Clinton today again exercised his new power to veto individual items in newly enacted spending measures, but this time he did so gingerly, slicing 13 projects worth $144 million from the Defense Department budget for the current fiscal year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, ANITA FIRESTONE
description: ROSS-Anita Firestone. On October 12, 1997. Beloved aunt of Dr. Stephen and Doreen Klass, Dr. Robert and Carolyn Klass, Warren West, Wendy West and Judy West Cohen. Great aunt to Elizabeth Klass, Mark Klass, Jeremy Klass, Justin Octavi, Amaris Octavi, Daniel Cohen and Emily Cohen. Loving sister-in-law to Sandra West. Her love of her family and of life will leave a legacy to her surviving family members. Services are on Wednesday, 10 A.M., at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAMAGNI, RAYMOND J.
description: TAMAGNI-Raymond J., a New York investment banker died at his home in Summit, NJ, Sunday, after a long illness. Mr. Tamagni was born in Brooklyn, NY in 1910. He joined the investment banking firm of F.S. Moseley in 1928. Starting as a runner just a year before the stock market crashed in 1929, he rose through the ranks to become a General Partner of the Boston Firm. He was married for 52 years to Laura Searle Tamagni, who died in 1986. He is survived by a son, John S. Tamagni of Summit, a partner of Lazard Freres & Co., four grandchildren, Susan Kulick, Lisa Jordan Tamagni, John S. Tamagni, Jr. and Christina Fastert and one great grandchild, Natasha Kulick. A memorial service will be held at Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit, New Jersey, Thursday, October 16, 1997 at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Overlook Hospital Foundation or Calvary Episcopal Church would be appreciated by the family. For information, contact Brough Funeral Home, 535 Springfield Avenue, Summit, New Jersey.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: WESTERN WIRELESS TO SELL 19.9% STAKE TO HUTCHISON
description: The Western Wireless Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 19.9 percent stake in its Western PCS Corporation unit to Hutchison Telecommunications Ltd. for $248 million. Western Wireless said Hutchison would also buy a 5 percent interest in the parent company for about $74 million. Western Wireless, based in Issaquah, Wash., provides wireless communications services. Western PCS is the holding company for all of the Western Wireless investments in PCS, a new generation of wireless communication. Hutchison operates mobile telephone and paging services in Hong Kong. It is a unit of Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. of Hong Kong. Shares of Western Wireless gained $1.25, to $21.375.

title: Food Chain
description: Leftover Herbs

title: Judge Declines To Return Boy Hidden Away By His Mother
description: A 17-year-old girl who hid her newborn son in her bedroom closet for 17 days until the infant was found by his grandmother went to court today hoping to regain custody of the baby, but she had to settle for temporary visitation rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMM, EDWARD JACOB
description: LAMM-Edward Jacob, who retired as President and Owner of Pathescope Company of America, died in Palm Beach, Florida on Monday, October 13. He was 96. As President of Pathescope, Mr. Lamm produced television commercials, industrial films, training films for the Navy during World War II, and educational filmstrips to be used in high schools and colleges. Many of the filmstrips were made in conjunction with the Berlitz School of Languages. Others covered such subjects as American and English literature, the history of Israel, psychosomatic disorders, the Metric System, and ''Jam Sessions''-made conjointly with General Foods. Mr. Lamm was born in New York City, the son of Lillian and William Lamm. After attending the Fieldston School and Columbia University, Mr. Lamm began working for such companies as Bambergers, the Plexiglass Company and W.R. Grace, before founding Pathescope. At the age of 81, he sold the company and relocated to Florida. Mr. Lamm married the late Ruth Heyman Lamm in 1934. They had two daughters, Barbara Lamm Goldbenberg of Orangeburg, NY, and Margaret (Peggy) Lamm Nibblett of Easton, Maine. In 1980, Mr. Lamm married the former Paula Kastner Pragerson who survives him. In addition to his wife and daughters, Mr. Lamm leaves four grandchildren, Alice, Dan, Karen and Ted. Funeral Services were private. Donations in Mr. Lamm's memory may be made to The Leukemia Society of America.

title: In His Own Words
description: JAMES E. McGREEVEY

title: I.B.M. Plans to Reorganize Its PC Operations
description: I.B.M. said yesterday that it was restructuring its personal computer operations and that it expected to dismiss some employees as part of an effort to halt the sales decline of its Aptiva brand.

title: Roche Sales Increase, But Less Than Expected
description: Roche Holding A.G., the Swiss pharmaceutical company, said yesterday that third-quarter sales rose 18.2 percent, at the lower end of expectations, as weaker drug sales held back an advance powered by the weakening Swiss franc.

title: 2 Get Nobel for a Formula at the Heart of Options Trading
description: Two North American scholars won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science yesterday for work that enables investors to price accurately their bets on the future, a breakthrough that has helped power the explosive growth in financial markets since the 1970's and plays a profound role in the economics of everyday life.

title: Local Bells Win Another Victory To Block Rivals
description: The plans of long-distance telephone companies to get into local telephone markets were dealt a major blow yesterday as a Federal appeals court threw out regulations that were intended to foster competition with local telephone incumbents.

title: 2 Accused of Murder and Arson
description: Two men were charged with second-degree murder and arson yesterday, accused of setting a fire in 1994 that killed an 81-year-old Coney Island woman, prosecutors said.

title: In India, Queen Bows Her Head Over a Massacre in 1919
description: In an act of contrition for Britain's colonial past, Queen Elizabeth came to this Punjab city today and paid 30 seconds of silent homage at the site of the Amritsar massacre of April 13, 1919, one of the British Empire's darkest days.

title: Bankruptcy Filing Off 4%
description: Personal bankruptcies fell in the third quarter as the result of an expanding economy and steady job growth.

title: Vatican Spoke Out On Plight of Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Stock Slides Despite Solid Earnings
description: The General Motors Corporation reported today that third-quarter earnings were better than expected, but its stock fell as analysts focused on the deterioration in profitability at its auto parts division, Delphi Automotive Systems, and concluded that the division was less likely to be partly spun off anytime soon.

title: University for Working Adults Shatters Mold
description: Just off the shimmering asphalt ribbons of Interstate 10, minutes from the Phoenix airport, in a zone of windshield and transport companies, sits a set of brick office buildings that contains what many view as the biggest challenge to higher education in the United States today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTGARTEN, IRA H.
description: LUSTGARTEN-Ira H. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend, Ira H. Lustgarten, an esteemed member of The Rockefeller University Council, as well as The Committee on Trust and Estate Gift Plans for over ten years. His friendship to The Rockefeller University, and his advocacy of its mission of biomedical research and education, will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Rhoda and his daughters, Nancy Lustgarten and Lise Schwartz. Torsten N. Wiesel, President Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman Board of Trustees, and David Rockefeller Honorary Chairman and Life Trustee, Board of Trustees

title: In Her Own Words
description: CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN

title: Saudi Buys $50 Million Stake in Daewoo
description: Prince Walid bin Talal, the Saudi billionaire, said he had made a $50.5 million investment in the Daewoo Corporation of South Korea, convertible into a 5.9 percent stake in the company.

title: Hunter Has Edge Over the Hunted
description: Maybe a well-needed day off, as Charles Nagy phrased it yesterday, will restore to the Cleveland Indians the attitude of a team one victory away from the World Series. The Indians sure didn't look and act like that team after their fifth-game loss to the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Nobel in Economics For Pricing Pioneers
description: Two North American scholars who helped devise a formula for accurately pricing financial market options have won the Nobel Memorial Price for Economic Science.

title: Caught On Film. Or Was He?
description: He reiterated his belief that failure to turn the tapes over in a timely fashion . . . was a result of a simple mistake, not deliberate defiance.

title: Continental to Reduce Flights
description: Continental Airlines is reducing its number of daily flights between Newark and Atlantic City beginning Dec. 1, a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: British Airways Aims at Gay Market
description: British Airways, in its first consumer advertising and promotion aimed at the gay and lesbian market, has signed a multiyear deal to sponsor the Rainbow Card, a Visa affinity credit card, and the annual Rainbow Card Leadership Award presented by Do Tell Inc. in Conshohocken, Pa., which operates the Rainbow Card. Terms were not disclosed.

title: EQUITABLE RESOURCES IN $80.6 MILLION DEAL WITH CHEVRON
description: Equitable Resources Inc. said yesterday that it had bought two offshore oil and gas fields from the Chevron Corporation for $80.6 million and sold five properties in the Western United States and Canada for $175 million. The Pittsburgh-based Equitable, an integrated oil and gas marketer and exploration company, bought from Chevron two fields already in production in waters off the Louisiana Gulf Coast. The company said it had sold the five Western properties, including fields in production and undeveloped acreage, to focus on production from the Appalachian Basin and the Gulf of Mexico. Shares of Equitable Resources stock fell 31.25 cents, to $31.375. Shares of the San Francisco-based Chevron fell 12.5 cents, to $85.375.

title: Metro Business; Sprint PCS Is Expanding
description: Sprint PCS, a digital wireless telephone service, is expanding its services to include parts of Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester County.

title: Dollar Gains on Yen as Tokyo Hints Current Rate Is All Right
description: The dollar rose against the yen yesterday after a senior Japanese official suggested that he was content with current exchange rates, despite the yen's declines this year. The dollar was also helped by a rally in United States Treasury bonds.

title: National News Briefs; Lawyers Seek Details Of Clinton's Sex Life
description: Lawyers for Paula Corbin Jones filed legal papers today in a Federal court in Little Rock, Ark., asking President Clinton whether he ever had sexual relations with women other than his wife while he was Governor of Arkansas and whether anyone was rewarded with a state job in exchange for sex.

title: A Bit of Daring: Braised Pigeon to Salmon Jelly
description: FROM the creation of its name to the choice of dishes and their fanciful descriptions on the menu, Camaje never takes the easy way out. That is part of its attraction, and if you take the time to try to understand the restaurant, it all begins to make sense.

title: ARENA FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK
description: The New York CityHawks, after a disastrous first season in the Arena Football League, gave Chuck Shelton a two-year contract yesterday as head coach.

title: It's a Made for Television Controversy; Hollywood's Vitriol Rises Over Promotion of New Videodisk
description: How on earth did Circuit City Stores, the nation's largest retailer of televisions, stereos and other consumer-electronics products, manage to make so many people in the entertainment industry so angry so quickly?

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a government crisis in Italy misstated the length of the legal workweek, which was one area of dispute. It is 40 hours, not 39.

title: Products intended to evoke the exotic world of Picasso, Hemingway -- and Max Morgan.
description: REMEMBER Max Morgan, the free-spirited aviator, and Aerobleu, the jazz club he ran in Paris after World War II? Remember those all-night jam sessions in Morgan's DC-3 en route to London, New Orleans and New York? Remember his mysterious disappearance in Havana as Castro was coming to power?

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Of Surprises and Standards on the Guitar
description: Slava Grigoryan's guitar recital on Thursday evening at Weill Recital Hall was his North American debut, but he was by no means unknown. At 21, he has already made two recordings for Sony Classical, the first, ''Spirit of Spain,'' devoted mostly to standard repertory in the Spanish style, but with a few twists (transcriptions of Chick Corea pieces, for example), and the second, ''Dance of the Angel,'' given over to tangos and other works in a Latin popular style.

title: For Wine Lovers, a Distant Paradise; New Zealand's vines yield a voluptuous harvest.
description: Some pictures may lie, but not the one on the Cloudy Bay label. When you stand in New Zealand's most acclaimed vineyard and look north, you see the same romantic view you see when you pick up a bottle of the sauvignon blanc that made the nation's name among wine lovers -- the Richmond Ranges in silhouette, their jagged peaks softened by the mist, rising above a line of evergreens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, DANIEL JOSEPH
description: RICHMAN-Daniel Joseph. Beloved son of Sheldon and Amelia Richman and beloved brother of Beth Ann Richman. Died October 11, 1997. Grandson of Herman and Dorothy Richman of Hudson, N.Y. a d Joseph and Mary Setteducati of Albany, N.Y. He graduated Fieldston Lower School and Elizabeth Irwin H.S. His music and laughter will be missed by all. Funeral services Friday, October 17, 1 PM, at the Riverdale Temple, Bronx, New York. For information call Weinstein Memorial Chapel, at 1-800-468-3232.

title: Paul D. Bartlett, 90, Expert On Reactions of Chemicals
description: Paul Doughty Bartlett, a chemist known for his insights into the mechanics of organic reactions, died on Saturday at a retirement community in Lexington, Mass. A former resident of Weston, Mass., and Fort Worth, he was 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YILMAZ, FLORENCE
description: YILMAZ-Florence, 51 years old. Suddenly on October 13. Beloved wife of Osman. Enjoyed and admired by her colleagues at Workbench, Inc., where for 18 years she was assistant to the chairman and corporate secretary. Service on Thursday, 7:30 P.M., at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWERSKY, RABBI ISADORE
description: TWERSKY-Rabbi Isadore. The Board and staff of the Council for initiatives in Jewish Education mourn the loss of an incomparable leader of spirit and scholarship. We grieve with his family and with the Jewish people. May his memory be a blessing. Lester Pollack, Chair Karen Barth, Executive Director

title: West Coast Shifts At Saatchi & Saatchi
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide has changed top executives at its West Coast operations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWERSKY, PROF. ISADORE
description: TWERSKY-Prof. Isadore. The American Friends of the Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the loss of Professor Isadore Twersky, an esteemed member of the University's Board of Governors and a 1996 recipient of an Honorary Doctorate. A renowned scholar in Jewish thought and literature, Professor Twersky served The Hebrew University as a member of the academic committee of the Institute for Advanced Studies and Director of its Summer School for Jewish Studies. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Menachem Magidor, President Alex Grass, Chairman of the Board The American Friends of The Hebrew University Keith Sachs, President Lawrence Newman, Chairman of the Board Adam D. Kahan, Executive Vice President

title: Low-Tech Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: Kemp to Join Highest Paid
description: Shawn Kemp may be close to joining the $100 million club. The Cleveland Cavaliers are said to have re-worked Kemp's contract and signed him to a seven-year deal that would vault him into the same tax bracket as the National Basketball Association's highest-paid stars.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL EXTENDING INQUIRY ON CLINTON'S CALLS
description: On the eve of her testimony before a House committee that has demanded appointment of an independent counsel, Attorney General Janet Reno today ordered an extension of a Justice Department inquiry to determine whether an outside prosecutor should examine President Clinton's fund-raising phone calls.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: A Question Of Responsibility; Injured Player's Case Could Shake Up N.C.A.A.
description: Twenty-three years ago, on an October afternoon at Birmingham's Legion field, the Texas Christian University coaching staff sent in a play from the sideline designed to take advantage of a weakness in Alabama's outside pursuit. They called ''Red Right, Power 28'' and told their running back not to turn the sweep inside.

title: Devils Confront a Weak Spot Head On
description: The Devils may have won the Eastern Conference regular-season championship last season, but an ineffective power play was a major factor in their surprising early exit from the playoffs.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ANNETT CO., Arlington, Va., the publisher of USA Today and other newspapers, said it had entered into an agreement to buy the Maine Broadcasting System's television stations in Portland and Bangor. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Armstrong Finds Team
description: The 1993 world cycling champion Lance Armstrong joined the United States Postal Service team yesterday, three days after being dropped by his French team, Cofidis.

title: Caught in Law Not Meant to Bend
description: President Nixon was investigated for obstruction of justice. President Reagan was investigated for not telling investigators what he knew of the Iran-contra scandal. President Clinton is being investigated for making telephone calls from the wrong room in the White House.

title: Electrolux Confirms British Plant Closings
description: Electrolux A.B., Europe's largest household-appliance maker, confirmed yesterday that it was closing two plants in Britain and dismissing 1,300 employees. The closings are part of a 2.5 billion kronor ($330 million) cost-cutting program at the Swedish company, aimed at eliminating 12,000 jobs by closing 25 plants and 50 warehouses in the next two years.

title: Former Judge Who Fled Law Is Captured
description: A former Tennessee judge convicted of sexual assault who has been a fugitive for nearly two months, was arrested at a post office in Mexico on Monday where he was picking up a package containing a blank birth certificate and blank personal identification cards, Federal authorities said.

title: Crude Oil Prices Drop Again; Corn and Soybeans Are Lower
description: Crude oil prices fell sharply for a second day yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as worries about tensions in the Persian Gulf continued to ease.

title: Nafta and Vegetables
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, LOUISE (NEE ANUSKIEWICZ)
description: HELLER-Louise (nee Anuskiewicz) on October 13. Beloved wife of Jerome. Sister of Jeanne Mabey. Survived by many nieces and nephews. Visitation at Dimiceli & Sons Funeral Home, 182 Lexington Avenue, New York City, on Friday 10 A.M. Mass of Christian burial, Friday at 11 A.M, Church of Our Saviour, Park Avenue and 38th Street, NYC. Interment at Calvary Cemetery, Long Island City.

title: Mob Figure Sentenced For Role in Extortion
description: The man described by Federal prosecutors as the acting underboss and second-ranking member of the Genovese organized crime family was sentenced yesterday to 21 months in prison for his role in extorting money from a construction union.

title: State Studies School Control
description: State education officials are working on a plan to determine the best way to return local control to three New Jersey school districts that are now run by the state, a Department of Education spokesman said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORSUK, EVELYN FEINSOD
description: BORSUK-Evelyn Feinsod. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of our beloved colleague Evelyn Feinsod Borsuk. Our deepest condolences to her family. May her memory be for a blessing. Marlene E. Post National President Beth Wohlgelernter National Executive Director

title: Islanders
description: Left wing Ken Belanger returned to New York yesterday after sustaining a concussion during a first-period brawl with Panthers defenseman Paul Laus in Monday night's 2-2 tie with Florida in Miami.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENVER, JOHN
description: DENVER-John. The Trustees and Advisors of the Wildlife Conservation Society express their deep sorrow at the death of John Denver. As a member of the Society's Board of Advisors, Mr. Denver gave of his time and talents to raise public awareness of the Society's works in saving wildlife. He was a true advocate for wild creatures and wild places. David T. Schiff, Chairman William G. Conway, President Wildlife Conservation Society

title: Moody's Warns That New York State's Budget Could Spawn Gigantic Deficits
description: A major Wall Street rating agency is warning that New York State's budget, with its commitments to deep tax cuts and big increases in school spending -- and what the agency sees as a risky reliance on a continued bull market -- is a prescription for enormous budget deficits in a few years.

title: Rangers' Offense Shifts Into Gear, but Barrasso Throws It Off Track
description: They outshot the Penguins by nearly 2-1. They held the Penguins scoreless on the power play. They did mostly everything right. But there was little consolation for the Rangers last night.

title: Test Kitchen; Tea and Crumpets, Madame? Let Me Plug In the Machine
description: THE ancient art of making tea recently acquired a new ritual: plugging in the pot. But this is not the end of gracious civilization as we know it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, ORVILLE N.
description: GREENE-Orville N., 88. Of Manhattan. Suddenly, October 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Maxine Greene. Devoted father of Timothy, Elizabeth and the late Jonathan. Father-in-law of JoAnn and Paula. Loving grandfather of Dan and Chris. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81 st. 11:30AM Wednesday, October 15. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Epilepsy Foundation of America, Landover, Md. or the Neurology Department, Mayo Foundation, Scottsdale, Ariz. in memory of Jonathan Greene.

title: Sunshine Supermen: Florida Advances to the Series
description: Jim Leyland stirred the Florida Marlins with a rousing speech last weekend, telling them that adversity had given them every reason to quit against the Atlanta Braves, telling them that he was sure they would never quit. He punctuated his inspiring oratory by telling the Marlins that they would win, with one heartbeat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERBER, MICHAEL A.
description: GERBER-Michael A. The Department of Pathology at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine grieves deeply for Dr. Michael A. Gerber and his wife, Minda, who died on Sunday in an automobile accident. Dr. Gerber was a loyal alumnus and devoted friend of this department. He was an internationally renowned liver pathologist, scholar and researcher. He will be deeply missed.

title: Behind the Killings, an Unbending Briton
description: In his autobiography, Jawaharlal Nehru, India's first Prime Minister, gave a chilling description of a chance encounter with Brig. Reginald Dyer, the British officer who ordered troops to fire on protesters at Jallianwala Bagh. The occasion was a train journey that Nehru, then a rising figure in India's freedom movement, took from Amritsar to New Delhi in the weeks after the massacre on April 13, 1919.

title: Ex-Counsel to Cuomo Seeks Statewide Office
description: Evan A. Davis, who served as counsel to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, added his name yesterday to the growing list of Democrats who plan to challenge Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco next year.

title: Giuliani Apologizes for Faulting Messinger About Missing a Mass
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani apologized yesterday for sharply criticizing Ruth W. Messinger because she missed a Columbus Day Mass, saying he was wrong to suggest that political candidates should be judged by whether they attend a religious service.

title: White House Surrenders Fund-Raising Tapes to Investigators
description: White House officials tonight began to turn over to Congressional and Federal investigators scores of videotapes that capture President Clinton mingling with many of the central figures in the campaign fund-raising investigations.

title: TV Notes; 25th Opening Night
description: New Yorkers who could not make it to Carnegie Hall last Wednesday will be able to watch the opening night performance of Yo-Yo Ma in concert with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra tonight. They and classical music lovers around the country can see it on PBS, because tonight at 9 is opening night for ''Great Performances.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORN, JANET
description: HORN-Janet. Beloved wife of the late Joseph; dear sister of Pauline Frankel, Rene Wansker, Sam Fener and the late Minerva Bober, Phoebe Riesnburger and Sarah Buchler. Service will be held on Tuesday, 11 A.M., at Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Wooten Finally Bolsters Giants' Defense
description: It was mentioned to Tito Wooten as a possibility, just a thought thrown out there for him to consider. After swiping his third interception in the last two games, keying a defense that was turning the Giants around, the question posed to Wooten was: Might he be having a Pro Bowl season?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODGER, LEON M.
description: RODGER-Leon M. Of Naples, Florida, Stowe, Vermont and formerly of Greenwich, Connecticut. On October 11, 1997, at Greenwich Hospital. Beloved husband of Joan Rodger; devoted father of Terri, Steven and Wendy Rodger; grandfather of ''Charlie'' Rodger and father-in-law of Lisa Rodger. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, PO Box 3556, Stamford, CT 06905, or to The Phil, Naples, Florida 34108.

title: No New Jury in Murder Case
description: A Superior Court judge ruled yesterday against empaneling a new jury to decide the fate of a Brick Township man who was convicted of murder last summer but never sentenced. The judge, Edward J. Turnbach, ruled that he, rather than a jury, will sentence the man, Scott L. Baker.

title: Better Shooters This Time Around
description: John Calipari knows it will take time to install a pressing, trapping defensive scheme with the Nets. One thing that will make the job easier for the Nets' coach is knowing that, while he works on the defense, at the other end of the floor he has a better-shooting team than the one that shot a franchise-low 42.2 percent last season.

title: Spies Just Wouldn't Come In From Cold War, F.B.I. Says
description: Terry Squillacote was a Pentagon lawyer who hated her job. Kurt Stand, her husband, was a union leader with an aging beatnik's slouch. Their friend Jim Clark was a lonely private investigator who spent too many nights mumbling into his drink.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVEE, FRANCES
description: LEVEE-Frances. Happy 4th Birthday in Heaven, Grandma. Love, Michael

title: Amid Mixed Profit Reports, Intel Talks of Its Fastest Chip
description: Top chip designers from Intel and Hewlett-Packard gave the first public briefing today on the ultrafast microprocessor chip that the companies hope can dominate computing in the next decade the way Intel chips have held sway in the 1980's and 90's.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''This is the big idea: to change the way people think about Newark. It's not the place where you get your car stolen; it's where you go to concerts.''
