title: Hamptons Film Festival Just Keeps On Growing
description: Off season, the Hamptons go to the movies. Today, the Hamptons International Film Festival begins its new expanded version, with 60 features and 28 shorts being shown during a five-day period. One sign of the growth of the Long Island festival is that in its fifth year, it will spread from East Hampton to Sag Harbor and Westhampton Beach, with screenings held in theaters in all three places.

title: New Orchestral Painting From a French Colorist
description: Henri Dutilleux is to French music pretty much what Elliott Carter is to American.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRUNG, SHIRLEY
description: SPRUNG-Shirley. Beloved and cherished wife of the late Jerome. Devoted mother of Sara & Daniel. Dear sister of Robert and Meyer Judd. Adoring grandmother of two cherished granddaughters. Service 12:00 P.M., on Wednesday, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Ronald McDonald House of New York would be appreciated.

title: Why Wait for Congress on Campaign Reform?; A.C.L.U.'s Role
description: To the Editor:

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: G.M. Has Strong Profit, But Parts Unit Suffers

title: Pan-Caribbean Approach With Politics Thrown In
description: The singer and producer Willy Chirino put in a rare appearance on Friday night at the Beacon Theater to promote his new album, ''Baila Conmigo'' (Sony), in a concert that was part politics, part social gathering and part music. Mr. Chirino, from Cuba by way of Miami, has had a string of hits over the last decade, both as a bandleader and as a producer, but he's also known for his strong anti-Castro stand. The concert, which never quite got going musically, had its share of pronouncements.

title: Brewers Could Make Switch
description: Baseball club owners are scheduled to hold a conference call Wednesday to adopt a mini-version of realignment: the move of one American League team to the National League. Which team, however, may not be immediately determined.

title: Honor, and a Cool Car!
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ORFINGER, MARVIN
description: ORFINGER-Marvin. Loving husband of Sandi, dear father of Anne Joy and Stephen Grollman and Alex. Cherished brother of Harriette Dule. Services on Wednesday, 1:30PM, ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Dallas Has Problems, But Where to Begin?
description: Age has caught up with the Dallas Cowboys.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Reagan's Fund-Raiser
description: To the Editor:

title: Newark Hopes for Revival Far Beyond Arts Center
description: Gloria F. Cohn, a widow from Middlesex County, N.J., has not ventured into this battle-scarred city for years. But she recently sent in $108 for tickets for herself and her granddaughter to a series of Sunday afternoon family dance programs and plays in the heart of downtown.

title: Cruise Line Monopoly Survives A Presidential Line-Item Veto
description: A provision in the military appropriations bill giving a 30-year monopoly on the cruise business in the Hawaiian islands to a company controlled by Sam Zell, the billionaire investor, survived a line-item veto by President Clinton yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLATTSKY, BESSIE KLATT
description: KLATTSKY-Bessie Klatt. The Yeshiva University family is saddened by the passing of a respected member of the Jewish community, beloved sister of the late Sidney Weisner, a YU Benefactor. We extend heartfelt condolences to her son, Robert Klatt; grandchildren, Brad Klatt and Bambi Goode; great-grandchildren, and the entire Weisner/Klatt family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Director of Ban on Chemical Arms Warns Russia to Ratify Pact
description: The director general of a new organization monitoring the destruction of chemical weapons said today that unless Russia ratified the treaty banning their use within two weeks, Moscow will be cut out of critical decisions on the inspection system, weakening the accord significantly. Russia has the largest stockpile of chemical arms.

title: Bond Prices Falter a Bit On Sales Data
description: Treasury securities slipped yesterday after a Commerce Department report indicated that retail sales last month were stronger than expected. The prospect of new corporate supply later this week also weighed a bit on the market.

title: Noisy Fans, Quiet Bats, Early Exit
description: The Orioles' players wanted scoreboard gimmicks, so the scoreboard operator gave them gimmicks. They wanted noise, so the fans made noise. They wanted fans to stand, so the fans stood.

title: $89 Million Provides Instant Gratification
description: With a giddy entourage surrounding him, H. Wayne Huizenga, owner of the Florida Marlins, tumbled out of the visitors' dugout at Turner Field almost an hour after the Marlins had eliminated the Atlanta Braves on Tuesday night.

title: Aghalee Journal; The Story of Bernadette: Ulster's Ultimate Victim?
description: Drive up and over the bowed stone bridge, pass by Ballycairn Road on the left and the Lock-Keeper's Inn on the right, and you are in a blink's bend in the lane called Aghalee.

title: World News Briefs; Japan Hints It Will Sign Pact to Ban Land Mines
description: Japanese officials are dropping broad hints that they may reverse course and join the worldwide ban on anti-personnel land mines, putting further pressure on the White House to forsake the use of mines as well.

title: Lockheed-Hewlett Pact
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation agreed to buy Hewlett-Packard Company work stations and servers in a two-year agreement valued at $60 million. Hewlett-Packard said today that the deal also included support services. Hewlett-Packard said the work stations would support Lockheed Martin's Engineering Process Improvement program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELDOW, LEONA
description: SELDOW-Leona, October 14, 1997. Mother of Carol (Walter) Irvine. Aunt of Scott Armstrong. Funeral service to be held Thursday, 10AM at Goldsteins' Rosenberg's Raphael-Sacks, Philadelphia. Interment, Mt. Hope Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to Albert Einstein Cancer Center, 5501 Old York Road, Philadelphia PA 19141.

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: NEWS

title: TV Pursuing Ads From Drug Makers
description: Television executives have begun efforts to attract more advertising dollars from pharmaceutical marketers to take advantage of less stringent Federal regulations for prescription-drug commercials. But the print media, particularly magazines, are striving to keep their drug ad business.

title: Artists' Elitism May Really Be Survival Reflex; Society Should Back Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents; ARTIST AS DECORATOR -- Interior Design A la Gauguin
description: Wherever he lived, whether in Paris, Brittany or the South Seas, Paul Gauguin (left in a self-portrait) tinkered in the decorative arts. Starting in the 1880's, when he was in Paris, he started making his own pots, including the green-glazed wine jug embellished with flowers and leaves (left). In 1889, when he was living in a village in Brittany, he and other artists decorated the inn (Gauguin painted some of the dining room panels). He also made furniture.

title: Public Advocate Wins a Look At Suspected Officers' Files
description: The New York Police Department must allow the city's Public Advocate to review the case files of hundreds of police officers whom the Civilian Complaint Review Board suspects of misconduct or brutality, a State Supreme Court judge has ruled.

title: Mercedes-Benz Grows By Adding Smallness
description: THE three-pointed star of Daimler-Benz stood for land, air and sea when it was introduced in 1909, a symbol of the German company's interests in cars, planes and ships. Since then, it has become an emblem for other things: riches, refinement, reliability and the steep price tag on a secondhand Mercedes. Of course, the star has adorned taxis and trucks as well as the contemporary conveyances of popes, kings, playboys and Balkan strongmen. But a belching Mercedes cab in Istanbul never impinged much on the image. Mercedes is to cars what Cartier is to jewelry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, LAURA ALISON
description: WARD-Laura Alison. On Oct. 14, 1997, after a long illness. Survived by her mother, Frances, sisters, Claudia and Susan, as well as their families who all loved her very dearly. There will be a short service at the Greenwood Cemetery and Crematory, Fifth Avenue and 25 Street in Brooklyn, Thursday, October 16, 11 AM for family and friends wishing to attend. In lieu of flowers donations to the Breast Cancer Fund or Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Medical Center would be appreciated.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: GTE Joins Chase for MCI With $28 Billion Cash Bid

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBERSTEIN, LOUIS E.
description: DUBERSTEIN-Louis E., 83, formerly of Brooklyn, died October 15, 1997 in Kingston, NY. Husband of Sylvie Baim Duberstein, father of Dr. Ned (Lucy) Goldfarb and the late Seth, brother of Robert. Funeral Friday at noon at Temple Emanuel, Kingston, NY. Burial in Montrepose Cemetery. Donations to A.R.C.S., 2269 Saw Mill River Rd., Elmsford, NY 10523. SimpsonGaus F.H. Kingston, New York.

title: Lehman Hoping Disney Will Pick Up His Game
description: No matter what happens on the golf course this week, Tom Lehman will be No. 1 in his household. Lehman promised his three children a trip to Walt Disney World. So by playing in the Walt Disney World-Oldsmobile Golf Classic, which begins Thursday, Lehman can give his family a present, even if his golf game is giving him fits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, DORIS VERCOE
description: SOLOMON-Doris Vercoe, 77, of Hillsboro, New Hampshire and Brookline, Mass., on October 12, 1997, at Brigham and Women's Hospital, Boston, of complications following surgery. Beloved wife of Joseph L. Solomon, mother of Magen Solomon of Menlo Park, Calif., Mara Solomon-Auger of Scituate, Mass., and Meli Solomon of Seattle, Wash. Grandmother of Noa and Tobey Solomon Auger, sister of Jean Vercoe Mulligan of Waukegen, IL. & Vester V. Vercoe, Jr. of Newark, Ohio. Originally from Kingston, Penn. She graduate from Syracuse University and made music her life. After moving to New York City her professional singing career included many years with the Robert Shaw Chorale, Collegiate Chorale and the Bach Aria Group. In addition to working as a vocal soloist and accompanist she conducted choruses at the Berkley Institute in Brooklyn. After moving to Brookline with her family, Mrs. Solomon taught chorale music at Windsor School, Buckingham Browne and Nichols, and The New England Conservatory Extension Division. She also served for fifteen years on the Board of Young Audiences of Mass, Inc and as head of the Program Committee developing special in-school programs in opera, jazz and chamber music. Funeral services are private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Young Audiences of Mass., Inc., 1 Kendall Square, Building 200, Cambridge, MA. 02142 or to another charity.

title: Nouvelle Detroit? Global Growth Brings Changes at Home
description: PEOPLE around the world think they know what Detroit is like. The common mental picture is of a huge, dirty city of factories where burly men labor on assembly lines, turning steel skeletons into gigantic cars and trucks. This industrial reputation has spread so widely that some street vendors in Europe do a brisk business in T-shirts with scenes of machinery and the city's name in huge letters on them.

title: Malaysian Premier Sees Jews Behind Nation's Money Crisis
description: Confronted with an economic crisis that has taken this rapidly developing nation by surprise, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has unleashed a series of verbal attacks on everyone from Jews to currency traders to unidentified ''sinister powers.''

title: F.B.I. and Encryption
description: To the Editor:

title: With Cool Energy, Ex-Vichy Official Defends His Past
description: Maurice Papon, the elderly ex-Vichy functionary accused of aiding in the deportation of more than 1,600 Jews from wartime Bordeaux, defended himself with vigor and cool precision today in his first extended testimony at his trial on charges of complicity in crimes against humanity.

title: A Coastal War Flares Over a Supertrawler
description: It has been nigh on a generation, some in this salt-scented town say, since so many fishing folk from Maine to New Jersey were last so united in a single cause.

title: INSIDE
description: Warning Given on Tankers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKER, CHRISTIAN F., JR.
description: BECKER-Christian F., Jr. On Oct. 15, 1997, of Hampton Bays, LI (retired NYC Board of Ed). Beloved husband of Adele. Loving father of Christine May and Kathryn Werlein, and five grandchildren.

title: Garden Notebook; A Perfect Season for Roses
description: IT was Oct. 9, and Mike Ruggiero, the head horticulturist at the New York Botanical Garden, was surveying the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden.

title: SYNOPSYS TO BUY VIEWLOGIC FOR $512 MILLION
description: Synopsys Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Viewlogic Systems Inc., a rival maker of software for designing computer chips, for more than $512 million. News of the deal drove up shares of Viewlogic $2.6875, or 12 percent, to $25.1875, on the Nasdaq market. Under the agreement, Synopsys, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., would pay 0.6521 share, or $28, for each of Viewlogic's 18.3 million shares outstanding. Synopsys earned $23.7 million, or 57 cents a share, on revenue of $353.5 million last year. Viewlogic, of Marlboro, Mass., had earnings of $11.3 million, or 66 cents a share, on sales of $132.9 million. Synopsys shares sank $3.125, to $39.8125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRILL, MARTIN
description: BRILL-Martin, on October 12, 1997. Beloved husband of Betty. Loving father of Walter and Gerrilyn, Peter and Krista, and Steven and Elaine. Cherished grandfather of Rachel, Natalie, David and Lauren. Dear brother of Frank. A memorial gathering of family and friends will be held on Thursday, October 16, at 1:30 PM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, New York.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the last asking price before the sale. ''Weeks on market'' refers only to the listing by the most recent broker.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, EVELYN M.
description: PHILLIPS-Evelyn M. On 10/9/97. A memorial service will be held at Bates College Chapel Sunday, Oct. 19 at 3 P.M. Private burial services will be at Gracelawn Memorial Park in Auburn. In lieu of flowers the family suggests memorials be made to Bates College Lewiston, The United Baptist Church of Lewiston, or The American Cancer Society. The Fortin Group-Teague Funeral Homes of Lewiston & Auburn, 207-782-5631.

title: Likely Cause of Yonkers Tanker Fire Was Pointed Out in '89
description: The deadly inferno that closed one of the busiest highway links to New York City a week ago after a car hit a gasoline tanker appears to have been caused by a preventable problem pinpointed in 1989 by Federal transportation officials and warned of by the New York City Fire Department in 1994.

title: Philip L. Ravenhill, 52, Expert On the Art and Culture of Africa
description: Philip L. Ravenhill, chief curator of the National Museum of African Art, part of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, died on Monday at his home in Washington. He was 52.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBEN, JUDY
description: RUBEN-Judy. She was our inspiration, our pride, and above all our joy. All who met her were touched by her warmth and humor. She combined a lifetime commitment to human liberation with pure, irrepressible love. We grieve with Al, her family and the huge extended family of friends and comrades. Monthly Review Foundation

title: Tamil Tigers Are Linked To Fatal Blast In Sri Lanka
description: A truck bomb that exploded early Wednesday in the central business district of Colombo, the capital of Sri Lanka, killing 18 people and wounding more than 100 others, including foreigners, appeared to end the 15-month lull in a bombing campaign by the separatist Tamil Tigers, Sri Lankan officials and Western diplomats said.

title: Amtrak Prepares for Strike That Might Affect Commuter Lines
description: The workers who maintain the tracks, bridges and electrical systems for Amtrak could go on strike next Wednesday, shutting down the already weakened railroad and possibly the major commuter operations in New York, Boston, Philadelphia and Washington.

title: Stocks Lower, With the Dow Falling 38.31
description: Stock prices moved modestly lower yesterday in light trading on weak demand for technology issues and rising interest rates in the bond market.

title: Glitter-Gulch From Givenchy As McQueen Goes Wild West : A Stellar Start for Chloe's Light-hearted Little Nothings
description: PARIS  Paul McCartney jumped to his feet to lead the standing ovation at his daughter Stella's first fashion show for Chloe.

title: Big, Bigger, Biggest: Rolling Reports From Across the Country; A Mini-Van With a Checkered Future
description: EVER SINCE their beloved Checker cabs began heading for the scrapheap, New Yorkers have grumbled about the lack of room in the rest of the city's taxis, which can turn rides into Big Apple moments of torture.

title: A Survey of Bach Opens at a Trot
description: Can it be that simple? One of the things the New York music scene has needed most desperately in recent years is an excellent Bach harpsichordist, and there was every reason to believe, on Tuesday evening, that it has found one. Just like that.

title: Lucent to Buy Internet Servicer
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Livingston Enterprises Inc. for $650 million in stock, adding a new arm to its aggressive move into computer networking.

title: Jets' Simple Game Plan: Get on Bledsoe's Nerves
description: The one Jet who can apparently rattle Patriots quarterback Drew Bledsoe the most will not suit up Sunday, but Coach Bill Parcells's game plan for the rematch could include mind games.

title: NCR TO CUT 1,000 JOBS IN LATEST REVAMPING
description: The NCR Corporation said it would eliminate 1,000 jobs, or 2.6 percent of its work force, next year and give sales teams more authority in the latest effort to increase sales at the money-losing computer and data-machine maker. NCR also said its third-quarter loss narrowed to $9 million, or 9 cents a share, from $33 million, or 32 cents, a year earlier. NCR, the world's largest maker of automated teller machines, is struggling to repair damage done when the AT&T Corporation owned it, although analysts say it may never fully recover. The effort to improve operations is the second in two years for the Dayton, Ohio, company, which was spun off by AT&T in December. Shares of NCR declined $2.3125 yesterday, to $35.625.

title: In His Own Words
description: JAMES E. McGREEVEY

title: Apple Reports Quarterly Loss That Is Larger Than Expected
description: Apple Computer reported a loss for the fourth fiscal quarter today that was wider than expected, as its revenue was badly hurt by a sharp decline in Japanese business.

title: Metro Business; Finance Deal Luring Company to Bronx
description: In a small victory in New York City's efforts to stem the decline of manufacturing jobs, a food processing company that fled Queens for New Jersey in 1993 is expected to accept a package of financial incentives to move back to the city, this time to the Bronx.

title: Little Travel Agency That Could; Rosenbluth's Key to Growth Is Corporate Business
description: When Rosenbluth International opened an office in Atlanta 12 years ago, it heralded its arrival with a billboard proclaiming, ''Rosenbluth has landed!''

title: Tracking Hip:Blink and It's Gone
description: PARIS  "Hipness is bigger than General Motors," claimed a Time magazine cover story four years ago titled "Everybody's Hip (And That's Not Cool)." Clever marketing, the piece stated, had made hipness "a special condition almost everyone" in America "seems to aspire to."

title: Executive Changes
description: APPLE COMPUTER INC., Cupertino, Calif., said that two senior executives had left to pursue other interests: Dave Manovich, senior vice president for international sales, and James McCluney, senior vice president for worldwide operations.

title: Foreign Affairs; Cover Story
description: Well, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had good news and bad news this week. The good news was that he made the worldwide cover of The Economist magazine. The bad news was that The Economist labeled him ''Israel's Serial Bungler'' and said he should resign immediately.

title: Accounting Board Asked to Alter Inflation-Indexed Bond Rule
description: The Treasury Department has asked the Financial Accounting Standards Board to change the way that inflation-indexed bonds would be treated under a proposed accounting rule for derivative securities. Board officials said they expected that the rule would be changed to accommodate the concerns.

title: At Rutgers, Fresh Start With a New Quarterback
description: The season starts Saturday. That is the only way for the Scarlet Knights of Rutgers to look at it. They have little to gain from looking back at the six losses in six games, or comparing indignities nearly a century old.

title: Officer Charged in Parking-Spot Killing Says He Did Not Warn Before Firing
description: A police officer on trial for killing a man in a fight over a parking space testified today that he never identified himself as an officer, told the man to freeze or warned him that he had a gun.

title: Review/Fashion; A Mentor and Her Followers
description: Imagine seeing the two toughest Bergman films imaginable back to back, and that was the way the woozy audience felt after getting fashion's heavy double feature: Martin Margiela sharing the same space and time as the woman who has influenced him most, Rei Kawakubo of Commes des Garcons.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KLEIN, BARRY
description: KLEIN-Barry. October 16, 1996. Dearest Barry, We love you and we miss you so very much. We're not having fun anymore. Love and kisses always, Sherry and the kids.

title: Orchestras Welcome Corporate Overtures; Concerts Raise Funds, and Questions
description: Usually, when shareholders leave the annual meeting of RPM Inc. in Cleveland, they are clutching five-gallon buckets filled with samples of Rust-Oleum, Mar-Hyde windshield cleaner, Chemspec carpet cleaner and other products from the company's industrial repertory.

title: On the Road, the Menace Is Always the Other Guy
description: DRIVERS are feeling jittery these days. What's setting them on edge? The bad habits of other drivers -- talking on the phone, drinking coffee, even putting on makeup, and traveling too fast.

title: In Brazil, Clinton Urges the Rich to Share Gains of Free Trade
description: Trying to reassure the poor in Brazil and the Democrats in Congress about his hopes for free trade, President Clinton visited a school and sports complex in a slum here today to issue a stark warning about the potential social damage of open markets.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; A Shelter for Lead Victims
description: Families in Newark with children who are suffering from lead poisoning now have a place to go while the city removes lead from their homes. Yesterday, city officials opened the first shelter in the state for victims who have contracted lead poisoning from living in a tainted home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HICKEY, ROBERT J.
description: HICKEY-Robert J., 80. Of Keene, N.H. In Keene on October 13. Formerly of New York City. Was Regional Chief Inspector, Eastern Division of U.S. Postal Service. He was a bridge life master. Father of Delina Hickey, Keene, Elizabeth M. Hickey, Denver, brother of Joseph Hickey, Fort Lauderdale, FL., two grandsons. A mass of Christian burial Friday 10AM at St. Bernard Church, Keene. Donations to Thorne-Sagendorph Art Gallery, Keene State College, 222 Main Street, Keene, NH. 03431.

title: Correction
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Monday about an analyst's battle with the Woolworth Corporation referred incorrectly to an investment in the company by Fidelity Investments. While Fidelity has sold some of its stake, it remains a shareholder.

title: Giuliani Plans To Challenge Line-Item Veto
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said today that he and an alliance of hospitals and labor unions would file a lawsuit on Thursday challenging the constitutionality of the Presidential line-item veto, contending that President Clinton did not have the right to strike down a Medicaid financing measure that benefited New York.

title: Officer Wounded in Shootout Near Schools
description: A police officer and two suspected drug dealers were shot and wounded yesterday afternoon when an undercover drug arrest went awry and ignited a pitched gun battle on a crowded Bronx street corner, as children were pouring out of two nearby schools.

title: World News Briefs; Swiss Freeze Funds In Bhutto Accounts
description: The Swiss Government said today that it had frozen $13.7 million in bank accounts belonging to the former Prime Minister of Pakistan, Benazir Bhutto, and her family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COREN, ROSE B.
description: COREN-Rose B. Age 92 of Eastchester, NY on October 14, 1997. Beloved wife of the late M. Mailloux, devoted mother of Michael and Mary Lou Coren and Susanne and David Katzman, cherished sister of Etta and Milt Zelickman, adored grandmother of Dana and Randy Wiston, Stephen and Shawn Katzman and Sharon and Michael Katz, most loving greatgrandmother of Mia Wiston and Cooper Katz. Services private. Friends who wish may contribute to a charity of their choice.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Rules on Releasing Sewage
description: Public and private sanitation agencies in New Jersey, Connecticut and New York must warn each other before they release untreated sewage into waterways in the metropolitan area, according to a regulation passed yesterday by water pollution control authorities.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Getting Hydrangeas to Bloom

title: Newest Bre-X Suit Will Seek $101 Million
description: A court here today permitted a shareholder lawsuit to proceed against officials of Bre-X Minerals Ltd. to reclaim profits they made by selling shares before the company collapsed in a gold-discovery fraud earlier this year.

title: Departing Polish Officials Sign Israeli Arms Deal
description: Poland's departing Government has signed an agreement to buy Israeli armaments in preference to an offer by Boeing, despite warnings that the deal would tarnish the country's image as it seeks approval in the United States Senate for joining NATO.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUN, GLADYS (SCHREIBER)
description: BRAUN-Gladys (Schreiber), 97 years young, Tuesday, October 14. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Leo Braun. Treasured Mother of Phyllis Braun Leventhal and son-in-law Bernard. Adored and adoring Grammy of Lionel, Alexander and Evan Leventhal. Cherished darling big sister of Celia Levine, Sidney Schreiber and the late Shirley Seiler. Early graduate of Hunter College and admired German and Spanish teacher in NYC high schools. Funeral services Sunday, October 19 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street at 10:30 AM, burial to follow in East Hampton at Gates of the Grove Cemetery. Memorial contributions in honor of her beautiful life may be made to Friends of Israel Sports Center for the Disabled, Independence Mall East, Phila., PA 19106. You will truly live forever.

title: A Bold Move to Play Big in a New Game
description: For nearly a year, Charles R. Lee, the chairman of the GTE Corporation, has declared that his once-stodgy company has adopted a new motto and a new strategy. ''We've decided we are going to be a growth company,'' he has said repeatedly.

title: 6 Men Share Nobels In Chemistry and Physics
description: The Nobel Prizes in Physics and Chemistry were awarded yesterday to six scientists in the United States and Europe for advances in manipulating atoms and in understanding the basic chemistry of life.

title: Democrats Seeking $1 Million for New Jersey Races
description: Saying they were encouraged by James E. McGreevey's showing in recent polls on New Jersey's governor's race, officials of the Democratic National Committee decided this week to help raise as much as $1 million for a final spurt of television advertising for Democratic candidates across the state.

title: ARV CHAIRMAN RESIGNS AFTER BOARD REJECTS BID
description: ARV Assisted Living Inc. said Gary L. Davidson, its chairman and chief executive, resigned a day after ARV had rejected the Emeritus Corporation's $286 million offer to buy 92 percent of ARV. Mr. Davidson, who is 63, also resigned his board seat. ARV said Mr. Davidson still planned to vote his ARV shares in support of an alternative proposal by Lazard Freres & Company to buy 49.9 percent of ARV for $135 million by paying $14 each for about 9.6 million newly issued shares. Emeritus, which owns 8 percent of ARV, is offering $16.50 a share. John Booty, the company's co-founder and former president, will become interim chief executive. ARV, based in Costa Mesa, Calif., has 49 assisted-living communities. Seattle-based Emeritus operates 115 communities in 19 states.

title: Metro Business; Real Estate Units Combine
description: W. P. Carey & Company of New York said yesterday that it would combine nine real estate partnerships it manages into a publicly traded company with about $750 million in assets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODS, HELEN F.
description: WOODS-Helen F., of Bronxville, N.Y., on October 15th, 1997. Wife of Michael F. Woods. Mother of Teresa Woods Daley, Michael and Stephen Woods. Sister of John Brennan. Grandmother of Anthony and Maxwell Woods. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 7-9 P.M., Thursday; 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Friday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Saturday, October 18th at 10 A.M.

title: Eligibility Suit Over Phillip Is Dropped
description: A lawsuit over the eligibility of Darren Phillip, a 6-foot-6-inch Fairfield University forward, was settled yesterday with concessions by all three parties.

title: From Baffling to Familiar to Startling Anew
description: As a choreographer, Merce Cunningham needs no introduction; for most of his career, he did. But nowadays, an audience made up of the overdressed and the deliberately underdressed at the Brooklyn Academy of Music can turn an opening night by the superb Merce Cunningham Dance Company into a celebration. Once-revolutionary concepts about how dances could be composed and perceived hold no terrors.

title: WINSTAR PURCHASE OF U.S. ONE ASSETS IS APPROVED
description: Winstar Communications Inc. won approval yesterday from a Federal bankruptcy judge to buy virtually all the assets of the U.S. One Communications Corporation for $100 million. Winstar would pay $80 million in cash and $20 million in stock for the assets, officials said at a hearing in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del. Dallas-based U.S. One and its two units, U.S. One Communications Services Corporation and U.S. One Communications of New York, have been in bankruptcy reorganization proceedings since late July. The companies offered local and long-distance phone service. New York-based Winstar is a provider of local communications services.

title: Of the N.F.L. and Real Estate
description: Better stadiums improving those that exist and building others -- have been on the minds of National Football League owners in recent years, and it was a topic again today as the league's owners ended two days of meetings.

title: Profits Rise Sharply at Ford On Strong Sales
description: The Ford Motor Company reported sharply higher third-quarter earnings today, as improved results in Europe and South America and strong sales of big sport utility vehicles more than offset weaker car loan profits and big discounts on car sales.

title: Newborn Is Abandoned On Doorstep in Queens
description: A newborn baby boy was left on a doorstep in South Jamaica, Queens, on Tuesday night with a note asking the house's occupant to care for him, officials said yesterday.

title: Giants Hoping to Flunk Another Fassel Student: Mitchell
description: For a second successive week, it will be the mentor's job to dismantle the pupil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERWOOD, SAMUEL S.
description: SHERWOOD-Samuel S. Beloved of Eva Wartels; dearest father of Nancy Ticktin; devoted husband of the late Minnie K. Sherwood; adored grandfather of Karen Ticktin and Dani and Peter Koplik; cherished great grandfather of Laura and Matthew Koplik; revered uncle of Arnold and Barry Sherwood; honored brother in-law of Rose Sherwood. Memorial services will be held at the LevittWeinstein Memorial Chapel, 1921 Pembroke Road, Hollywood, Florida, on Friday, October 17th, 1997 at 2 P.M. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions in his name to B'Nai B'Rith Foundation.

title: Home Mortgage Defaults Are Still Rising in Region
description: Signals abound in the New York metropolitan region that the economy has heated up, especially in the last year. One indicator, however, still looks like the bad old days of the recession and appears to be getting worse: more homeowners in the region are defaulting on their mortgages than at any time since at least the late 1970's, and in higher numbers than in the rest of the nation.

title: Currents; THE ULTIMATE MAKEOVER -- 70,000 Faces of Eve (or Adam)
description: High-tech, slightly schlocky fun abounds at Liquid Image, a new shop and photo studio at 390 West Broadway (Spring Street). You can have your face digitally blended into one of 70,000 images, anything from a sphinx to Gainsborough's ''Blue Boy'' (right, disguised as the shop's owner, Bob Malkin). Santa Claus or the Venus de Milo (or both!) could be you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, HYMAN
description: GROSSMAN-Hyman. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Lucille, Nancy and Ken Orr and the entire family. Stanley Plonchak, President

title: Jordan Is a Popular Figure in Paris
description: The first time Michael Jordan came to play basketball in this fair city, he could sit outside at a cafe of his choosing and watch the world go by without it watching him.

title: Pollution Record Is Far From Black
description: JUST AS every car has a tailpipe, the internal combustion engine under every hood is a pollution machine. But in some ways the American car has been getting strikingly cleaner over the years, while in other ways its environmental record remains troublesome.

title: Airborne Dust In Radar Center Disrupts Travel
description: Airborne dust from a ceiling renovation project in a Long Island air traffic control center forced dozens of controllers to abandon their work stations for almost 10 hours today, setting off cascading delays that disrupted air travel around the country.

title: Lease or Buy? It's More Than a Matter of Money
description: IN THE 1990's, it is the car shopper's twist on the Shakespearean question: to lease or not to lease? Or is it better to suffer higher monthly payments and nerve-racking service hassles, and buy?

title: Literary Women With Roots In Africa
description: In her 1992 novel, ''Possessing the Secret Joy,'' Alice Walker, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of ''The Color Purple,'' helped expose to the Western world the practice of female genital mutilation in Africa. Ms. Walker's disturbing tale of the tribal initiation touched off an international debate on the issue.

title: For First Time, U.S. Discloses Spying Budget
description: Abruptly abandoning 50 years of secrecy, the Central Intelligence Agency disclosed today how much money the United States spends annually for intelligence: $26.6 billion.

title: FINISHMASTER SET TO ACQUIRE RIVAL FOR $68.8 MILLION
description: Finishmaster Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a rival automotive paint and coatings distributor, Thompson PBE Inc. for about $68.8 million in cash. Finishmaster, based in Kentwood, Mich., will pay $8 a share for Thompson's 8.6 million shares outstanding. The combined company will have annual sales of about $320 million. Finishmaster serves customers in Mid-Atlantic, Southeastern and Midwestern states, while Thompson, of Marina del Rey, Calif., supplies automotive collision repair shops throughout Southern California and the Northeastern, Southeastern, Southwestern and Rocky Mountain regions of the United States. Thompson BPE stock rose $1.3438, to $7.7188. Finishmaster stock was unchanged at $6.50.

title: Marijuana as Medicine: Risks Outweigh Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * William Common was named to the new post of senior vice president for business development for the Americas at 141 USA, New York, the sales promotion unit of the Bates Worldwide division of Cordiant P.L.C. He had been vice president for business development at the Marketing Corporation of America, Westport, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, FELLOWES
description: DAVIS-Fellowes, of Hamilton, MA, October 14, 77 years, husband of Alice (Plummer) Davis. Father of Morgan F. of Ontario, Susannah L. Adams of NH, C. Cary Gallaudet of N.Y., and Rose G. Mendoza of Washington, DC. Also survived by seven grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Saturday in St. John's Episcopal Church, 705 Hale St., Beverly at 2 PM. A graveside service will be held Friday in the Swan Point Cemetery, Providence, RI at noon. Relatives and friends are invited to attend. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the St. John's Episcopal Church or to the Pingree School, Highland St., So. Hamilton, MA 01982. Information: the Lee, Moody & Russell Funeral Home, 9 Dane Street, Beverly, MA.

title: Vichy on Trial
description: Fifty years is a long time to wait to bring a World War II collaborator to justice. But France has finally put Maurice Papon, Secretary General of the Gironde Prefecture in Bordeaux during the Vichy regime, on trial. He is charged with crimes against humanity for organizing the arrest of nearly 1,600 Jews during World War II and arranging for their transport to a transit camp in Drancy, a Paris suburb. From there, the Nazis took them to Auschwitz.

title: Retail Sales Increased 0.3% in September
description: Shoppers increased spending for the fourth straight month in September, but much of the gain appeared to reflect higher automobile prices and masked sales declines at clothing and department stores, Government figures showed today.

title: For Russians, to Own a Car Is to Fix a Car, Again and Again
description: AFTER a year in which American correspondents, including this one, have written endlessly and obsessively about the many horrifying flaws of the Russian space station Mir, we ought to be fair and also tell you this: Nobody in this country pays the slightest attention to the troubles of the Mir.

title: Accidentally on Purpose
description: Hamiet Bluiett's show at Sweet Basil on Tuesday night was all about his sound on baritone saxophone, and his presence. Mr. Bluiett wants things to happen onstage. He wants energy and excitement, and the looseness that allows accidents to be creative.

title: Three Guesses: The Fuel of the Future Will be Gas, Gas or Gas
description: NEARLY 20 years after the last gas crisis, auto makers are finally confident that they can produce cars that are durable, reliable and powered by something cleaner than gasoline.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLASER, MORRIS
description: BLASER-Morris. October 16, 1966. Cherished father, we shall never forget you. Love, Blaser Family.

title: Brown Meggs, 66, a Recording Executive Who Signed the Beatles
description: Brown Meggs, a record company executive who was chief operating officer of Capitol Records in the 1960's and 70's, and who returned to the company as president of its classical division in 1984 after an eight-year hiatus in which he published several novels, died on Oct. 8 at his home in San Francisco. He was 66.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTGARTEN, IRA H.
description: LUSTGARTEN-Ira H. The Advisory Committee to the Legislature on EPTL and SCPA sadly notes the passing of member Ira H. Lustgarten Esq., Dean of the Trusts and Estates Bar. He contributed greatly in making revisions in the trusts and estates law. He will be greatly missed. Our condolences to his family. C. Raymond Radigan, Chair

title: Anatomy of a Bid: Less From GTE May Mean More
description: Never has there been a takeover battle like the one for MCI Communications, the second-largest long-distance telephone company. In your normal takeover battle, the price only goes up. In this one, the price gyrates in both directions.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HANOVER COMPRESSOR CO., Houston, a provider of natural gas compressors, acquired three natural gas compression stations from a subsidiary of Enron Corp. for $26 million.

title: How Not to Handle Prosperity
description: From Frankfurt to Washington, talk of higher interest rates suddenly fills the air as central bankers sense wisps of increased inflation.

title: In America; Get This Election Over With
description: Get this thing over with, this worst ever of mayoral campaigns. Nothing about it is appealing, least of all the candidates. There is no fun, no excitement, no charm, no charisma and nothing in the way of new ideas. If this were a prizefight the referee would stop it amid a cascade of boos. There should be a way to spare the voters this exercise in sustained dreariness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, CLAIRE (TOOTS WERLEMANN)
description: HALL-Claire (Toots Werlemann). At South Lake Tahoe, California, on October 15, 1997. Survived by husband Frank H. Hall, son Dorn Hall, daughter Hilary McDonnell, sister Terry Pero, cousin Louise Crane, and four grandchildren. In lieu of flowers donations to The American Cancer Society.

title: Everetts Will Let Court Rule On Custody
description: An agreement that would have reunited Mets outfielder Carl Everett with his two children now in custody of the city's child welfare agency fell through yesterday, setting the stage for a Family Court trial to determine if the children have been abused, lawyers involved in the case said.

title: Sports of The Times; Fernandez Did Damage Both Ways
description: THE starting lineup was already made out. Bip Roberts was leading off and playing second base for the Cleveland Indians. Tony Fernandez was not in the lineup at all.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PALEN, DAVID S.
description: PALEN-David S. It is with the greatest sorrow and regret that we note the death of David S. Palen, a Managing Director of The Chase Manhattan Bank and our Senior Country Officer for Korea. David died tragically September 30, 1997 in a car accident in Poland, along with a fellow Chase Officer, K.Y. Lee, a Vice President and head of Chase's Korea Desk in London. David had been our dear friend and loyal colleague since joining the bank in 1981. We will miss him. Our expressions of heartfelt sympathy go to David's wife, Betty, and his three children. We will remember David at a memorial service on Friday, October 17, at 1 PM, at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and 50th Street, New York City. In Lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Palen-Lee Education Fund, which has been established to benefit the children. Contributions may be sent to Julian Bub, US Trust Administration, The Chase Manhattan Bank, 1211 Avenue of The Americas, 34th Floor, New York, New York, 10036.

title: Giuliani Proposes $70 Million in Tax Cuts
description: With less than three weeks to go before the election, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed $70 million in tax cuts yesterday for small corporations and families who pay for child care, declaring that his efforts to lessen the local tax burden had helped stimulate an economic recovery in New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUSSMAN, IDA MARGOLIES
description: SUSSMAN-Ida Margolies, born on October 14, 1907 in New York City, passed away on October 13, 1997. Ida was the wife of the late Dr. Bernard A. Sussman and mother of Dr. Howard Sussman and wife Pat; grandchildren, Laura Sussman and John Sussman; sister, Pearl Diamond; sister-in-law, Bessie Sussman.

title: Currents; REAL AND IMAGINED -- For the Youngest Do-It-Yourselfers
description: This fall, there are two fresh sources of inspiration for children who like to build things.

title: Big, Bigger, Biggest: Rolling Reports From Across the Country; Git Along, Not-So-Little Sport-Ute
description: ACROSS the nation, the Suburban is enjoying some of the hottest sales years in its history, and six decades after its creation, this nearly 18 1/2-foot behemoth has recently inspired a bunch of mammoth knockoffs, including the Ford Expedition and the Lincoln Navigator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, JEROME JAY, M.D.
description: HOFFMAN-Jerome Jay, M.D. Died October 14, 1997. Beloved husband of Joan (Osias) Hoffman. Loving father of Elizabeth and Patricia. Adoring grandfather of Jeffrey and Rachel Rothberg, and devoted brother of Elliot. Dr. Hoffman, an obstetrician and gynecologist, was a member of the Beth Israel Hospital Staff since 1950 and was much loved by all his patients. Funeral service 10:45 A.M., Friday October 17, ''The Riverside'', 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue. Interment to follow at King David Cemetery, Putnam Valley, N.Y.

title: Schubert on a Large Scale (No Musicales)
description: The 19th-century practice of transcribing music is greatly misunderstood today. When Liszt, for example, did transcriptions for solo piano of Beethoven's nine symphonies, this was not some gimmicky display of virtuosity, nor some act of defacement. Liszt simply wanted to give listeners a fresh way to experience these ingenious symphonies without the distraction, in a sense, of orchestration.

title: School Aide Charged In Abuse of Boy, 14
description: A 30-year-old teacher's aide from Long Island has been charged with sexually abusing a 14-year-old New Jersey boy he met in an on-line chat room, the Suffolk County police said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANE, THERESA (NEE MARCHETTI)
description: KANE-Theresa (nee Marchetti), 51, of New York City, formerly of Jeannette, PA., died Sunday, October 12, 1997 at her residence. She was born May 8, 1946 in Jeannette. A daughter of William J. Marchetti and the late Lena Tressa Caserio Marchetti. In addition to her mother she was predeceased by her husband Joseph Kane earlier this year. In addition to her father she is survived by her brother, William J. Marchetti and his wife Annette, of Powell, Ohio; a sister Carol Ann Marchetti, of Hong Kong, and a niece, Alexandra Marchetti. She is also survived by her husband Joseph's children, Steven Kane, of Miami, FL. and Patricia Wilson, of California. Friends will be received at the John V. Graziano Funeral Home, Inc., 228 North 2nd St., Jeannette, PA., Thursday from 79PM, Friday from 2-4 and 7-9PM. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated Saturday at 10AM in Sacred Heart Church, Jeannette. Entombment will follow in Twin Valley Memorial Park, Delmont, PA.

title: More French Twists; Asia de Cuba, a Fusion by Starck
description: JEFFREY CHODOROW's new restaurant, Asia de Cuba, which opens tomorrow, was born in another of Mr. Chodorow's restaurants, the China Grill in Miami.

title: Johnson Becomes Knicks' Radio Voice
description: Gus Johnson became the radio voice of the Knicks yesterday, replacing Mike Breen, who was elevated to the TV side on the MSG Network when Marv Albert resigned following his guilty plea for assault.

title: A Bucolic Nightmare: Gridlock in Suburbia
description: AT 7:20 on a misty workday morning, like soldiers mustering at dawn reveille, commuters in this suburb 45 miles north of New York City assembled in long snaking lines leading to a Y-shaped intersection.

title: When Sex Is Just a Matter of Fact; To High School Students, Free Condoms Seem Normal, Not Debatable
description: On some days, Kelly Bunkley, a prim 17-year-old, slips into the health-resource room at Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn, where she quietly asks for a free condom.

title: Get Ready for the Past: Beetles, Hot Rods and Fins
description: A DECADE after trying to persuade the world that their cars were not your father's Oldsmobile, auto makers from around the world have decided that the past is way cool.

title: Reno Confronts Republicans On Demands for Prosecutor
description: Attorney General Janet Reno withstood eight hours of often antagonistic questioning today by Republican lawmakers, rebuffing their assault by saying that she had not uncovered enough evidence to step aside to let an independent prosecutor pursue Democratic campaign finance abuses.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The jurors for the Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize, given by Columbia University for excellence in biological or biomedical science, are barred from awarding the prestigious award to anyone who has already received a Nobel Prize. So why will Dr. STANLEY B. PRUSINER, the newly anointed winner of this year's Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, be the recipient of the Horwitz Prize?

title: Not the Driver's Ed Class Your Parents Remember
description: FOR SO many adults, the words driver education -- or, more colloquially, driver's ed -- conjure images of a high-school course that was taught, in all likelihood, by a gym teacher droning on about the merits of a three-point turn.

title: Federal Financing for Teamster Election Draws Opposition
description: Republican lawmakers attacked the Clinton Administration today for planning to spend $7.4 million to conduct a new teamsters' election, after last year's federally financed teamsters race was overturned because of a fund-raising scandal.

title: Currents; A MUSEUM BRANCHES OUT -- For Jewish Family Rituals
description: The Jewish Museum has one of the most extensive Judaica collections in the world. And it has just opened a new Judaica shop next door, at 1 East 92d Street.

title: CNB BANCSHARES TO MERGE WITH PINNACLE FINANCIAL
description: CNB Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Pinnacle Financial Services Inc., a bank holding company with 47 offices in the Midwest, for $583 million, or $46.32 a share. The acquisition will create a bank with assets of $6.6 billion and 142 branches in Michigan, Indiana, Kentucky and Illinois. CNB, based in Evansville, Ind., is a bank holding company with 95 offices and assets of $4.4 billion. Pinnacle, based in St. Joseph, Mich., has assets of $2.2 billion. Under the agreement, CNB, which is offering 1.0365 share for each Pinnacle share, will have a 61 percent interest in the combined entity. Shares of Pinnacle rose $2.125, to $42.25, while CNB's shares fell $2.5625, to $42.1875.

title: WHAT ABOUT MISSISSIPPI?: A special report.; Welfare Law Weighs Heavy In Delta, Where Jobs Are Few
description: While President Clinton has flatly declared ''the debate is over -- we know now that welfare reform works,'' the hard-luck counties of the Mississippi Delta show the difficulties that can emerge when tough laws collide with a weak economy.

title: Personal Shopper; Still Lifes, With Fruit and Bowls
description: FRUIT has one advantage over flowers as a table centerpiece: if the arrangement obscures the view, you can just munch it down to size. Even empty, some bowls are worthy of a place of honor.

title: Two Advertisers Switch Agencies
description: Two consumer advertisers have changed agencies on their accounts.

title: No Longer In Love, Not Ready To Walk
description: MORE Americans own cars than pay income taxes. Cars have become such an inescapable fact of American life that everyone has a car story -- tales, say, of near-death experiences, malevolent mechanics or post-warranty breakdowns.

title: The Dollar Is Weaker on Hint Of Another German Rate Rise
description: The dollar fell against the mark on speculation that German interest rates might rise sooner than rates in the United States.

title: On Tape: Clinton and Yesterday's Old Friends
description: There was President Clinton with his ''good friend'' John Huang at the Hay Adams Hotel here saying he was overwhelmed by the outpouring of Asian-American support for his campaign.

title: Cynical, Sincere, Brash, Corny. They're Car Ads, What Else?
description: THERE ARE as many milestones along the road of automotive advertising as there are distinctive cars. Sometimes the two converge, with an outstanding product receiving outstanding advertising. Sometimes a great car sells despite bad ads. Sometimes a bad car is the subject of superior ads. And even the best ads have not kept smaller companies from disappearing as the industry has relentlessly consolidated.

title: A Self-Assured Mixture of Lyrical and Muscular
description: Wendy Chen, a pianist from California, made her New York City debut in 1990, when she was 17 and had just won the National Chopin Competition. Since then, she continued her studies with Leon Fleisher, earned bachelor's and master's degrees from the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore, won several more competitions and awards, made her first recording (all-Chopin, on the RCD label) and played lots of concerts. This year she was a winner of the Young Concert Artists auditions, and on Tuesday evening she opened that organization's annual series at the 92d Street Y.

title: Harlem Woman, 70, Dies In Suspicious Fire
description: A 70-year-old woman was killed last night in a suspicious fire in a Harlem apartment building, fire officials said. The victim, whom officials did not identify, was pronounced dead on arrival at Metropolitan Hospital Center.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Teacher Force Among Oldest
description: New Jersey has the highest percentage of older teachers in the nation, state education officials said yesterday.

title: Honey, I Spun the Porsche: Hairpin Tales From a 911 Lover
description: A CONFESSION. I am a recovering sports car aficionado. The recent revival of interest in the roadster has caught me by surprise: I sold my last two-seater three years ago, shortly before becoming a father. After an MG, an Austin Healey, two Porsches, a couple of dozen speeding tickets and several brushes with mortality, I reasoned that the time had come to put aside some of the vices of youth.

title: Finalists for Book Award Named
description: ''Underworld,'' Don DeLillo's enormous rumination on baseball, waste and the cold war, joins ''Cold Mountain,'' Charles Frazier's first novel about a Civil War soldier's journey home, as finalists for this year's National Book Award for fiction.

title: Accounts
description: * The Good Guys, Brisbane, Calif., to Citron Haligman Bedecarre, San Francisco, to handle radio advertising for the consumer electronics retailer, which had been handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $12 million. The print portion of the account remains in-house. Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, a unit of Omnicom Group, handles television campaigns; Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, handles media buying.

title: Big, Bigger, Biggest: Rolling Reports From Across the Country; Hollywood Fades to Black
description: IN THE entertainment business your clothes, your shoes, your hair style and, above all, your vehicle convey not-too-subtle messages about your wealth and social class and, most important, the kind of person you think you are.

title: Movies Were Better, and So Were the Skid Marks
description: FOR a 13-year-old American boy riding around town in a poorly carbureted Volkswagen Squareback, the chase scene in ''Bullitt'' was an epiphany, a worshipful awakening to the glorious transcendence of speed and anarchy and appetite. Its potboiler complications and existential antiheroism were lost on me, but the glass-packed V8 exhaust obbligato of genuine Detroit iron was like music. I remember liking the turtlenecks, too.

title: Big, Bigger, Biggest: Rolling Reports From Across the Country; Four-Wheel Ice Follies
description: ''IT could snow any time'' an electronic message board has blinked since late September on Interstate 70, at the point where the plains meet the mountains.

title: Excerpts From Remarks at Hearing of House Judiciary Committee
description: Following are excerpts from comments by Attorney General Janet Reno today as she testified before the House Judiciary Committee, by Representative Henry J. Hyde, the Illinois Republican who is the committee chairman, and by Representative Maxine Waters, a California Democrat who is a committee member, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private company:

title: Pakistan Central Bank Devalues Currency 8%
description: The State Bank of Pakistan yesterday devalued the rupee 8 percent, adjusting the currency's buying rate to 44.05 from 40.52 against the dollar, while setting the selling rate at 44.2703 from 40.7226.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHAPIRO, HYMAN R.
description: SHAPIRO-Hyman R. You are with me every moment-in my heart and in my thoughts. Your Ruth

title: CORNING LOWERS OUTLOOK FOR GAIN FROM SALE OF UNIT
description: Corning Inc. said yesterday that it would amend the terms of its sale of a controlling stake in its housewares unit, reducing its value to $825 million from $975 million amid weaker sales and an outlook for low earnings growth in 1998 for the unit. As a result, Corning's after-tax gain from the transaction will be $125 million, instead of $250 million under the terms proposed in August. Corning could also be required to return as much as $50 million, based on the unit's 1998 performance. The Corning, N.Y., glass maker is selling the stake to a company formed by AEA Investors Inc. It plans to retain an 11 percent interest in it. Corning's shares rose $1, to $46.1875.

title: Man Accused of Delivering a Bomb Said He Believed It Was Soap
description: The man accused of driving a rental van packed with explosives into the World Trade Center garage in 1993 believed he was ferrying boxes of soap, he later told the authorities.

title: Auto Makers See Nothing but Trouble in a Warmer World
description: FOR more than a decade, the auto industry has pretty much got what it wanted in this town. Tighter fuel standards? Forget about it. New safety standards? Small potatoes only, please.

title: Messages of Devotion From Singer and Fans
description: In Sarah McLachlan's songs, love is overpowering: greater than affection or passion, more like a force of nature or a holy quest. She gives herself over to it absolutely and unquestioningly, promising her lover selfless devotion; she would sacrifice everything to keep love or to get it back when it's gone. ''Sweet surrender,'' she sings in her latest single, ''is all that I have to give.''

title: Edgar Haber, 65, Immunologist And Expert in Protein Chemistry
description: Dr. Edgar Haber, a specialist in immunology and cardiovascular diseases noted for his work in protein chemistry and biotechnology, died on Monday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 65 and lived in Weston, Mass.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Paralegal Sentenced in Fraud
description: When the owner of a Livingston law firm suffered a debilitating stroke in 1991, his paralegal posed as a lawyer and, over the next four years, cheated clients, businesses and the Federal Government out of as much as $800,000, prosecutors said.

title: U.S. Team to Go to Kinshasa to Try to Restart Massacre Inquiry
description: The Clinton Administration announced today that it would send a senior delegation to Congo next week to try to revive the United Nations' investigation into massacres and other atrocities during the civil war that toppled Mobutu Sese Seko earlier this year.

title: Pride Goeth Before the Car Glut
description: THE best way to see Malaysia's natural treasures, the Malaysians always tell visitors, is from the front seat of the national car, the Proton.

title: Wheels and the Man: A Moving Melodrama
description: THERE ARE seven ages of a man and his cars. First, there is the object of lust, and smells never to be forgotten. Then, in rough order: the wounded models and constant repairs; the one true love; the first new car; the image cars, those rolling advertisements for oneself, followed by the best ones money can buy. Then ends this strange eventful history, sans lust, sans everything but getting there.

title: Detroit May Not Like Him, but He's the Crash Dummy's Friend
description: While Clarence M. Ditlow has never achieved the public recognition of Ralph Nader, there aren't many people in the automobile industry who don't know who he is. As the executive director of the Center for Auto Safety, which Mr. Nader founded 27 years ago, Mr. Ditlow is the splinter the industry cannot remove from its thumb.

title: Currents; JEFFERSON GOT THERE FIRST -- Standing Room Only (Not for Comedians)
description: Chronic back pain was the mother of invention for Martin Burns.

title: Starks Works Overtime
description: Practice had been over for an hour, with most of the other Knicks players already gone, but the gym door remained shut. Behind it could be heard the sound of a basketball bouncing and the squeak of one pair of sneakers on the floor.

title: Milestones and Potholes on a Well-Traveled Road
description: Today, there are $60,000 off-road vehicles that never leave the pavement, pop-up cup holders and eight-way power seats with electric lumbar supports. Japanese cars are made in Kentucky; German trucks are built in Alabama, and American vehicles are assembled in Mexico. But before there were hideaway headlamps, tailfins and push-button transmissions, before even the electric starter, there were mechanically inclined folks who tinkered with motors and gears in out-of-the-way barns. Few died rich and fewer left their names to posterity in chrome script on trunk lids. Here are some highlights, lowlights and sidelights - by no means a comprehensive history - of what they have wrought.

title: Showdown Is Averted, for Now, in Battle Over Laws Barring Cuba and Iran Trade : EU and U.S. Step Back In Clash on Sanctions
description: BRUSSELS  European and U.S. negotiators stepped back Wednesday from imminent confrontation in their dispute over American attempts to penalize countries that trade with Cuba and Iran.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The simple fact is that the average American wants an independent prosecutor.''

title: Metro Business; Have M.D., Will Travel
description: In a city where personal shoppers, body builders and dog walkers visit customers in their homes, now comes something revolutionary for the 1990's: doctors who will make house calls.

title: From the Land of Private Freeways Comes Car Culture Shock
description: ON most of the perfect California mornings when he arrived at the preschool to drop off his children, he was turned out just as the mood had struck him. Sometimes he would wear something formal -- a European luxury sedan, perhaps -- and on other days, he would slip into something less dressy, perhaps vented on the sides in case he felt like letting his biceps ripple in the sun. On those days, Arnold Schwarzenegger wore the Humvee. For sure, there was nothing like 3.4 tons of military muscle-car to make the Mr. Moms in their Volvos go taupe with envy.

title: Isadore Twersky, of Harvard and the Hasidim, Dies at 67
description: Isadore Twersky, who bridged two worlds, making the study and practice of ancient Jewish traditions the common thread of a life as a Harvard scholar and Hasidic rabbi, died on Sunday at a hospital in Boston. He was 67 and had been the Nathan Littauer Professor of Hebrew Literature and Philosophy and the founding director of the New Harvard Center for Jewish Studies.

title: BANKAMERICA TO SEEK BIDS FOR SPECIALIZED LENDING UNIT
description: The BankAmerica Corporation expects to solicit bids for its manufactured housing finance business. San Francisco-based BankAmerica said yesterday that it hoped to conclude a deal in the first half of 1998 and had retained Goldman, Sachs & Company to assist with the sale. The unit, which operates a network of 45 offices in 31 states, maintains a portfolio of more than $9 billion of loans and originated $3 billion of loans in 1996. It is the second-largest manufactured housing lender in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, WILLIAM T.
description: RYAN-William T. The entire family of the Greater Metropolitan Health Systems, Inc. (GMHS), comprising Beth Israel Medical Center (BIMC) and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center (SLR), acknowledges with great sadness the passing of William Ryan, father of our beloved friend & colleague, Lorraine Ryan-Kelly, and father-in-law of our esteemed co-worker, Peter A. Kelly. To his wife, Eleanor Ryan, his two sons, William and John Ryan, his two daughters, Lorraine RyanKelly and Virginia Hodge, his daughters-in-law, Joanne and Jackie Ryan, his sons-in-law, Peter A. Kelly and Ronald Hodge, his grandchildren and friends, and to all who loved him, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman Boards of Trustees, GMHS and BIMC Lawrence S. Huntington, Chairman Board of Trustees, SLR Vice Chairman, GMHS Robert G. Newman, M.D., President, GMHS Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President, BIMC Ronald C. Ablow, M.D., President, SLR Ralph Zalusky, M.D., Chief, The Rachel Sussman Division of Hematology/Oncology, Department of Medicine, BIMC

title: Metro Matters; Bond Act Has Unsafe School As a Backdrop
description: THERE are few better arguments for spending more on school construction than the brief, unhappy life of Public School 141.

title: Bye-Bye, Birds: Indians Head to World Series
description: When the Baltimore Orioles reminisce about their underachieving season and how Tony Fernandez ended it with a surprising home run in the 11th inning of a memorable 1-0 victory by Cleveland today, their pile of regrets should not focus on the one pitch from Armando Benitez that destroyed them.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Impersonating a Dentist
description: Working mostly at night in the living room and kitchen of his own home, a Parsippany denture maker performed dental work on about 100 people without a license, state investigators said. The denture maker, Fernando Velasquez, was released from custody on $10,000 bail after being arrested Tuesday by the Parsippany police.

title: He's Good, He's Golden, And Fans Can't Stand It
description: IF there was any concern for the well-being of the driver, even for an instant, it never registered on the faces in the grandstand as Jeff Gordon's rainbow-painted Chevrolet Monte Carlo slammed into a backstretch retaining wall at the Goody's Headache Powder 500 here in August.

title: It's Dark. It's Scary. It's Your Garage.
description: THERE are no second stories in American houses. Not, at least, in the classic postwar suburban ranch house, the prototype of modern living that millions have called home. For who among us is willing to place ourselves above our cars? As the French critic Roland Barthes observed, cars today are the exact equivalent of great Gothic cathedrals: ''I mean the supreme creation of an era, conceived with passion by unknown artists, and consumed in image if not in usage by a whole population, which appropriates them as purely magical objects.'' It would be sacrilegious, in other words, to tower over the antenna.

title: How Many Passengers Can Cram Into a Rickety Bread Loaf?
description: SHAO BING is a man on the move.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAFFE, BENJAMIN
description: JAFFE-Benjamin. On October 15, 1997, in his 98th year. Beloved husband of the late Nan Jaffe. Father of Vivian (Joseph) Goldreich and Morton (Lois) Jaffe. Respected grandfather and greatgrandfather. Graveside services on Friday, October 17, 1 P.M., at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENVER, JOHN
description: DENVER-John. The members, Board of Directors and staff of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers join the world in mourning the tragic death of our member, John Denver, on October 12. John was a prolific and gifted songwriter, a world renowned and beloved entertainer and recording star, and a committed and giving humanitarian. The loss to ASCAP and American music is impossible to calculate, but John Denver's heartfelt songs will live on. We express our most sincere condolences to his family. Marilyn Bergman, President & Chairman, ASCAP

title: Artists' Elitism May Really Be Survival Reflex; The Irish Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIGGINS, JAMES D.
description: HIGGINS-James D. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of James D. Higgins, a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Victor D. Ziminsky, Jr., Pres. Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: COMPANY REPORTS: Market Place; Behind Time Warner's strong earnings was evidence of a closer eye on the bottom line.
description: TIME WARNER INC. reported third-quarter earnings yesterday that not only told investors that its core businesses were healthy but also went a long way toward reassuring them that the company had gotten religion and was rigorously monitoring its spending.

title: Ford or Honda, New or Used, He Wants to Sell It
description: IF every car salesman, especially every used-car salesman, were honest, sensitive, patient, fair, tactful and caring, then Wayne Huizenga's whole plan to revolutionize the $700 billion business of buying cars wouldn't stand a chance.

title: A Defense Lawyer Who Doesn't Lose
description: THE DEFENSE

title: Pain, Suffering and Cash: A Primer on Car Insurance
description: TO MOST consumers, buying automobile insurance ranks right up there with tossing money out the window. ''We sell a product that everyone in this country must have and that everyone believes they're paying too high a price for,'' said Steven Goldstein of the Insurance Information Institute, a New York trade organization.

title: On Russian-Iranian Oil Deal, U.S. Sanctions May Backfire
description: In the next few weeks the Clinton Administration will face the first test of its willingness to make good on a threat to punish foreign companies that invest in Iran.

title: Stranded Travelers Deal With Delays
description: It was Janet Foster's first trip to the United States, and Newark was not on her itinerary. But after a series of bungled connections on the way from her native England to Houston, a bedraggled Ms. Foster found herself stranded at Newark International Airport yesterday afternoon, only to discover that her flight to Houston would be delayed for at least an hour and a half more.

title: Bethpage Black Getting A Face Lift
description: Although it will be almost five years until Bethpage Black becomes the first truly municipal golf course to be the host for the United States Open, the renovations to elevate the course into a high-caliber facility are well under way.

title: State Censures Judge For Campaign Activities
description: The New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct has censured Arthur Birnbaum, a Civil Court judge in Manhattan, for improper campaign activities in September of last year.

title: Rostenkowski, 69 and Free, Is Feeling Lighter
description: Rosty is looking good. He has lost 60 pounds and had his hernia fixed. At the age of 69, he has cut down on the sirloins and the gin, and he walks as much as seven miles a day.

title: Editorial Observer; Imagining the Consequences of Cassini
description: Children of my generation grew up pinioned between two technological tensions: the patriotic optimism of President Kennedy's manned-space program and fear of nuclear war -- epitomized, when I was too young to understand it, by the Cuban missile crisis. Nuclear fear was, perhaps, the more realistic of these two emotions. It conjured up a terrible post-conflict America that wasn't actual, but that could become actual at any moment. With a few stunning exceptions -- Alan Shepard's flight, John Glenn's orbit, the moon landing -- the optimism evoked by the space program was always being deferred. Even its long-range rationale -- the future colonization of space -- was a deferral of sorts. The future that NASA envisioned had to be imagined to be believed, as did the future envisioned by the most persuasive of anti-nuclear activists. But for some reason it is nearly always easier to imagine your fears than your hopes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIER, DEAN
description: GRIER-Dean, 58, of Chicago, on Sunday, Oct. 12. Beloved husband of Lita, devoted father of Paul, Mark, Scott & Thomas; stepfather of Jonathan Dubman, grandfather of Elizabeth, Dore, Shannon and Kathryn. He was President of Inter-Continental Media, Inc. which produced and syndicated classical music radio programming worldwide. Service on Friday 12:00 P.M., at Blake-Lamb Funeral Home, 1035 North Dearborn Street, Chicago, Illinois 60610. Contributions may be made in his name to the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, 220 South Michigan Avenue, Chicago, Illinois 60604.

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: When It Comes to Harleys, Arlen Ness Is One Very Cool Customizer
description: WE are heading south on California 580, screaming past cars and semis. I am riding with Arlen Ness on one of his newest creations, the Ness Patrol, a takeoff on the black-and-white California Highway Patrol bike. Save for the airbrushed flashing lights, the custom Dynaframe looks real enough to attract worried stares.

title: Review/Fashion; When Rock Meets Romance
description: ''These British designers,'' said Maria Luisa Pomaillou, owner of the chic Paris boutique Maria Luisa, after Stella McCartney's first show for Chloe. ''It always comes down to rock-and-roll and royalty.''

title: Yeltsin Wins a Delay in No-Confidence Vote
description: Averting a political crisis, President Boris N. Yeltsin tonight staved off a parliamentary vote of no confidence in his Cabinet that could have severely undercut his economic reform effort.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WEINTRAUB, SHEILA
description: WEINTRAUB-Sheila 10/16/40-10/20/90 Cherished mother, loving you... still. Allison

title: A Fairway of Dreams
description: HAVING had three years to mature and develop, the back nine of the 18-hole golf course known as the Putnam Country Club looks more polished than the newly opened front nine, which still has some rough edges, literally and figuratively. ''We'll be picking up rocks for years,'' said Sally Donovan, who built the 6,131-yard-long, 18-hole golf course with her husband, Mike.

title: Computers Take a Byte Out of the Design Process
description: SLAM the hood. Slam the hood. Slam the hood. Silently.

title: Currents; GAETANO PESCE -- Somewhere Over the Rainbow
description: It is a mystery that Gaetano Pesce, 69, is a design superstar in Europe (a Pesce retrospective filled the Pompidou Center this year), but he is little known here (he lives in New York). Mr. Pesce is known for adding explosive color to architectural spaces, inspired by today's mutant materials that allow designers to spark up places that are usually not colorful or textural.

title: Quartey Fighting for High Profile in U.S.
description: Ike Quartey, the hard-hitting welterweight champion of the World Boxing Association, was asked yesterday to rank the toughest opponents in the division. He put Pernell Whitaker first, because of Whitaker's ducking, peek-a-boo style. He ranked Felix Trinidad, the International Boxing Federation champion, second.

title: Public Eye
description: ''WHEN you hear the word 'titanium,' '' said Bernie Wire, a sculptor in Marina del Rey, Calif., who uses the shimmering metal extensively in furniture and vases, ''you kind of think 'space.' ''

title: Honors
description: * Wendy Riches, chairwoman for North America at Ogilvy One Worldwide, New York, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group, was named general chairwoman of the 33d annual Direct Marketing Days in New York, to be held June 1-3, 1998.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In his first official tour since the death of his mother, Diana, Princess of Wales, 13-year-old PRINCE HARRY will accompany his father on a trip to South Africa at the end of the month and will attend a Spice Girls concert, The Evening Standard of London reported yesterday.

description: BASEBALL

description: In percent

description: Hazel N. Dukes, the president of the New York State chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and a former president of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, pleaded guilty yesterday to stealing $13,000 from an OTB employee who was suffering from cancer.

title: Money Cards Create Paperwork Nightmare
description: To the Editor:

title: Artists' Elitism May Really Be Survival Reflex; P.C. Backfires
description: To the Editor:
