description: To the Editor:

title: New Complaints Are Added To Suit Against Microsoft
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. raised additional accusations today in its lawsuit against the Microsoft Corporation over the Java programming language, and both sides made public the contract that they are disputing.

title: Economic Scene; A new look at why the U.S. outdoes Europe in job creation.
description: IN 1994, Paul Krugman, an economist at M.I.T., concluded that ''growing U.S. inequality and growing European unemployment are different sides of the same coin.''

title: A Show House That Smiles? Eh Bien!
description: IT is impossible to climb the stairs of the 1997 French Designer Showhouse and not imagine that you have stepped into a three-dimensional version of a brain-teaser cartoon for Sunday-bored children.

title: People Buy the Cars He Says They Like
description: IN 1973, Mazda gave J. D. Power 3d his first dose of fame by denouncing his report, based on a customer survey, that the Japanese auto maker's highly praised rotary engine tended to die after 30,000 miles. Not long afterward, the auto industry decided that Mr. Power was right, and the Wankel engine headed into history.

title: Judge Says Couple Used Excessive Force on Adopted Girls
description: A Queens judge ruled yesterday that an Arizona couple who had been accused of beating their newly adopted Russian children on a flight from Moscow to New York had used excessive force, and he ordered the girls moved to yet another foster home -- their fifth in four months. The judge, who dismissed more serious abuse charges against the adoptive parents, also delayed for at least a month and possibly much longer a decision on the custody of the girls.

title: Fear Is Increasing on the Roads, But That May Not Be a Bad Thing
description: THE stories are familiar, almost part of highway lore by now: the mild-mannered retiree who shoots a teen-ager for taking his parking spot; the lawyer who rams another car because it's blocking her way and kills a passenger; the student who knifes another driver after a fender-bender.

title: Must-Have Label
description: BUYERS of handmade imported rugs are used to petting the plush, appraising the pattern and checking the dimensions. But not until now have so many buyers been inspecting a rug's flip side, searching out a little tag that says the rug was made without child labor.

title: The NATO Debate Begins, Badly
description: Though the Senate has barely begun consideration of NATO's eastward expansion plans, the discussion has already drifted into troubling territory. Because the Clinton Administration has offered no compelling security justification for enlargement, a variety of dubious rationales are being advanced. The confusion should be a warning that the Administration's scheme for NATO lacks a core organizing principle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRETZ, ALFRED F., M.D.
description: FRETZ-Alfred F., M.D. The entire family of St. Luke'sRoosevelt Hospital Center mourns the passing of Alfred F. Fretz, M.D., a former Senior Attending Physician in Urology who first joined our staff in 1946. He was dedicated to his patients and beloved and revered by colleagues, and will be greatly missed. To his wife, Kathleen, a longtime member of the St. Luke's auxiliary, and to his entire family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Lawrence S. Huntington Chairman of the Board Ronald C. Ablow, MD President Richard P. Fried, MD President of the Medical Board

title: INSIDE METRO
description: GUILTY PLEA -- Hazel N. Dukes, a former president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, pleaded guilty to stealing $13,000 from an ailing OTB employee. B3.

title: Messinger And Sharpton Show Warmth At a Rally
description: Ruth W. Messinger and the Rev. Al Sharpton campaigned together enthusiastically last night at a rally at a Democratic clubhouse in Queens. Mr. Sharpton gave Ms. Messinger a rousing endorsement and she praised him in return, saying that because of Mr. Sharpton, ''We are able to create a unified Democratic party.''

title: PACIFICORP SELLING UNIT TO NRG FOR $133 MILLION
description: Pacificorp, a Portland, Ore., utility holding company, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Pacific Generation Company unit to NRG Energy Inc. for $133 million. NRG is a unit of the Northern States Power Company, a utility holding company in Minneapolis. Pacific Generation owns stakes in 12 power plants in California, Washington, Maine, Massachusetts and Ontario, with a total generating capacity of 795 megawatts. Pacificorp fell 12.5 cents, to $22.3125. Northern States rose 31.25 cents, to $50.6875.

title: Moods of 5 Decades, Color by Color
description: HENRY Ford wouldn't get away with telling customers today what he did in the early days of the Model T: they could buy any color -- as long as it was black.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWERSKY, PROFESSOR ISADORE
description: TWERSKY - Professor Isadore. The Department of Near Eastern Languages and Civilizations at Harvard University & the Harvard Center for Jewish Studies mourn the passing of our distinguished colleague and friend, founding Director of the Center and internationally renowned authority on Jewish intellectual history in all its aspects. As Nathan Littauer Professor of Hebrew Literature and Philosophy he inherited the mantle of his teacher, Professor Harry A. Wolfson, and brought Jewish studies to the very center of university life. He guided the establishment of the Center for Jewish Studies, and by the force of his example as well as through his teaching inspired generations of Harvard students. His own scholarly writings on Maimonides and other crucial figures from the Jewish Middle Ages set a standard of scholarship for the world to follow. His energetic sponsorship of international conferences and publications helped turn Harvard into a center for Jewish studies known and respected throughout the world. We extend our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife, Atarah, and to his children, grandchildren and the entire family. May they be comforted from Heaven. Department of Near Eastern Languages and Civiliations Center for Jewish Studies Harvard University

title: Court Weighs Whether One State Must Obey Another's Courts
description: The Supreme Court has spent considerable energy recently examining the relationship between the states and the Federal Government. Today, the Justices shifted their focus to a much less explored side of federalism: the relationship among the states themselves.

title: U.N. Names Slovenia To Security Council
description: Slovenia has become the first former Yugoslav republic to be elected to a rotating seat on the Security Council. Slovenia, which joined the United Nations in 1992, will be one of three nations getting Security Council seats for the first time; the others are Bahrain and Gambia.

title: Bridge; The Liberating Side Effects Of Having Cards in Prison
description: The Russian novelist Ivan Turgenev had an unusual use for playing cards. He wrote: ''I was once in prison, in solitary confinement, for more than a month. The room was small, the heat stifling. Twice a day I carried 104 cards, two packs, one by one from one end of the room to the other. That made 208 round trips, nearly two kilometers! The day I didn't take my walk, all the blood went to my head!''

title: Oval Office Fund-Raising
description: To the Editor:

title: From a Coltrane, a Quiet Exploration of Soft Melodies
description: The chemical composition of a jazz group is so fragile that the change of one musician can completely change a group's sound. So it was for the saxophonist Ravi Coltrane's two nights at the Zinc Bar on Monday and Tuesday. Mr. Coltrane was preparing for a recording session; the drummer Jeff Watts worked the first night, and on Tuesday his place was taken by Steve Haas.

title: Tylenol Overdoses Linked To Acute Failure of Liver
description: Overdoses of Tylenol or other medications containing its active ingredient, acetaminophen, were the leading cause of hospitalization for acute liver failure at a large medical center in Dallas from 1992 to 1995, researchers are reporting in the first study in the United States to measure the incidence of the problem. Although uncommon, the condition is serious and potentially fatal.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; A Different Spin on Resurrection
description: No, the Cologne Chamber of Commerce has offered no booty here, or even done any lobbying. It's just that the German city's musicians keep issuing recordings of early music that are enterprisingly conceived and superlatively executed, more impressive on both counts than most of the releases that kept London so tiresomely in the spotlight a decade ago.

title: Arts Abroad; Why Painters Have Made Revolutionary Sculptors
description: David Smith, no mean sculptor himself, said that much of the best sculpture of this century had been made by painters. Perhaps it took a sculptor to point this out, but how easy it is to confirm: Picasso and Matisse influenced not just individual sculptors but entire movements as well, and Miro and Max Ernst are critical figures in any history of the period. Others made brilliant contributions.

title: Owners' Vote Allows One Team to Move to National League
description: For the first time in Major League Baseball history, club owners voted today to move a team from one league to the other. The team was not determined, but it will be from the American League's Central Division and will move to the National League's Central Division.

title: Through Trial by Tape, Reno Is Unperturbable
description: Let's go to the videotape, the chairman ruled, even before Attorney General Janet Reno could get an opening word in edgewise before the House Judiciary Committee.

title: GTE JOINS BIDDING FOR MCI, OFFERING $28 BILLION IN CASH
description: Adding yet another combatant to the richest corporate takeover battle in American history, the GTE Corporation, the nation's third-largest local telephone company, made an unsolicited offer yesterday to acquire the MCI Communications Corporation, the nation's No. 2 long-distance carrier, for $28 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLISKIN, DANIEL
description: PLISKIN-Daniel. On October 15, 1997, in Boca Raton, FL. A former resident of Teaneck, NJ. Husband of Martha. Father of Deborah, Helen and Janet. Grandfather of Suzanna, Matthew, Rebekah, Jeremy and James. Brother of Sara, Robert, Irving and Ralph. Chairman and Professor of Marketing and Management at Fairleigh Dickinson University and head of the Golf Team, Teaneck Campus. Graveside services on Friday, October 17, at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island at 11:15AM. Remembered and loved by family and students.

title: If 6 Million Jews Moved Back to Germany?
description: President Clinton is really sorry about slavery. The Swiss are sorry about banking practices during World War II. So a future German Chancellor in the early 21st century might conceivably wake up one morning and decide to apologize for the Holocaust by inviting six million Jews to return to Germany to live.

title: How G.I. Joe's Little Jeep Grew Into a Yuppie Hunk
description: IN THE beginning, there was the jeep: Spartan transportation based on the tough ''general purpose'' vehicles that jarred and jolted the Allies to victory in World War II. But like some alien life form introduced into a poorly defended environment, sport utility vehicles have evolved and multiplied, crowding out indigenous species.

description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: In Her Own Words
description: CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN

description: To the Editor:

title: It May Not Be Camelot, But Pitino Knows Way
description: Rick Pitino stepped into Rupp Arena this morning after a long time away and quietly said, ''Home, sweet home.''

title: Rangers Still Waiting for Some Offense
description: With a payroll pushing $45 million and four former 50-goal scorers in the lineup, it figured production would be the least of the Rangers' problems this season.

title: Click and Clack Q & A: How Not to be a Jamoke
description: Tom and Ray Magliozzi, better known as Click and Clack, have been the hosts of the National Public Radio call-in program ''Car Talk'' for two decades. They are loud, cynical, smart and very funny. Neither one, apparently, has ever heard a joke he didn't like -- especially if it was his own.

title: An Arts Center for New Jersey
description: The New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark will open on Saturday to expectations that will be a challenge to meet. No development can single-handedly restore life to Newark's downtown, but this $180 million facility -- financed with state and Federal money and more than $50 million in private contributions -- offers more promise than many past urban renewal efforts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, MAX
description: GROSSMAN-Max, 98, in Clifton, New Jersey on October 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Mollie Grossman for 70 years. Devoted father of Gloria, Bernard, and Sarah, and father-in-law of Elliott, Lenore, and Michael. He is also survived by seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. He was founder in 1933 of M. Grossman & Son Inc. and Betmar Hats, and was active in the Millinery Manufacturers Association of New Jersey. His love and counsel will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORN, JANET
description: HORN-Janet. Beloved wife of the late Joseph; dear sister of Pauline Frankel, Rene Wansker, Sam Fener and the late Minerva Bober, Phoebe Riesnburger and Sarah Buchler. Service will be held on Friday, 11 A.M., at Evergreen Cemetery, Brooklyn, New York.

title: Belgrade and Moscow Stall Bosnia Vote Desired by U.S.
description: Washington's desire for an election in the Serbian-controlled region of Bosnia in order to shore up the position of relative moderates there is facing continuing resistance from Moscow and Belgrade, diplomats here said today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; A Meeting on Aircraft Noise
description: Federal aviation regulators agreed during a private meeting yesterday to sit down with a group of New Jersey elected officials to negotiate a solution to the longstanding problem of air traffic noise.

title: TONIGHT'S N.F.L. MATCHUP
description: San Diego (3-3) at Kansas City (4-2) -- 8 P.M. Eastern TV: TNT

title: Rebels, Backed by Angola, Take Brazzaville and Oil Port
description: Rebel forces gained full control of Brazzaville, the capital of the Congo Republic, today and were on the verge of ending the country's four-month civil war with a clear victory. President Pascal Lissouba has fled the capital and his whereabouts were not immediately known.

title: Currents; A DARKROOM THAT FITS IN -- When Bigger Isn't Better
description: Shlomo Ben-Yaacov, a TriBeCa photographer, learned the hard way how to cram sophisticated equipment into a tiny space: he spent three years as an Israeli Army tank crewman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, PARKER THOMPSON
description: HART-Parker Thompson. On Wednesday, October 15, 1997 Parker Thompson Hart of Washington, D.C. Beloved husband of Jane S. Hart. Father of Margaret Hart Espey of Lafayette, CA and Judith Hart Halsema of Karachi, Pakisan. Grandfather of John and Audrey Espey and Petra and Rachael Halsema. He is also survived by 1 nephew, 4 nieces and many grandnephews and nieces. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Interment private. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made in his name to the Middle East Institute or Bread for the City. Joseph Gawler's Sons, Inc.

title: Gun Locks May Help, but Education Is Key
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUIDA, BETTY JANE
description: GUIDA-Betty Jane, formerly of Great Neck, died suddenly on October 14 at Hillsboro Beach, Florida. Beloved wife of Andrew Guida, mother of Grace and Joanne Schrank, grandmother of Debra and Nicoll, sister of Mary Ellen Straus. In lieu of flowers, contact St. Gabriel's Church, Pompano Beach, FL. 33060 in her memory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBAUM, JAMES
description: BIRNBAUM-James. October 9, 1997, suddenly, in an accident in Calgary, Canada. Beloved son of Rosalie Birnbaum and cherished brother of Paul D. Birnbaum, Eve Tetaz, and Esther Ann Barnet. A memorial service will be held at Church in the Garden, Ascan and Greenway North, Forest Hills, November 1 at 3 P.M.

title: Tests for Golota
description: Andrew Golota, the heavyweight Lennox Lewis knocked out 95 seconds into the first round of a championship fight Oct. 4, underwent a battery of neurological tests at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan yesterday to determine why he had a seizure in his dressing room 20 minutes after the bout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, EDGAR
description: HABER-Edgar, 65, of Salisbury, NH, Weston and New York, Elkan R. Blout Professor of Biological Sciences & Professor of Medicine, Harvard University, former Chief of Cardiology of Massachusetts General Hospital and former President of Bristol-Myers Squibb Pharmaceutical Research Institute, on Monday, October 13th. Husband of Carol Avery Haber, father of Justin A. Haber of Waban, MA, Graham S. Haber of NY & Eben M. Haber of Palo Alto, CA; brother of Dr. Ruth H. Jonas of NY; & son of Dorothy J. Haber of Yonkers, NY. Memorial donations in lieu of flowers should be made to The Edgar Haber Research Award, C/O. M. Mitchell, Center for the Prevention of Cardiovascular Disease, Harvard School of Public Health, 677 Huntington Avenue, Boston, MA 02115. Private burial; memorial service to be held at 1:00 PM on Sunday, November 16, 1997 at The American Academy of Arts and Sciences, 136 Irving St., Cambridge, MA.

title: Agencies just aren't interested in the ad executive crying to get out of every consumer.
description: THE next time you think you may have a better idea for an advertisement than a Madison Avenue hotshot, know that even if you do, no one will likely pay attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DINSTMAN, HARVEY S.
description: DINSTMAN-Harvey S., on October 14, 1997. Former president of I.D. Watch Case Company and affiliates. Devoted husband of Ethel. Loving father of Carole and Nancy. Services were held privately.

title: Few Buy Autos on the Web, but Many Start Their Research There
description: WHEN Rod Bowles and his wife, Mary Terwiske, of New Market, N.H., decided it was time to replace their 1982 Pontiac Bonneville station wagon with 140,000 miles, they sat right down and logged onto the Internet.

title: Home Chic Home:When Designers Dress Up Interiors
description: PARIS  Now that fashion has turned life into a lifestyle, designers are no longer content just to dress the body, they want to break into your home. The message is: You wear the Gucci steel-heeled stiletto? You'll love the Gucci steel and ebony cutlery. So you bought Ann Demeulemeester's slouch tweed pantsuit? Well, actually it looks great teamed with her white canvas table.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARTMAN, ANN
description: HARTMAN-Ann, died on October 3, 1997, three weeks before her 95th birthday. She was loved and revered by her children, Kathlyn and Jerard, her daughter-in-law, Dorothy, her seven grandchildren, and her 7 great grandchildren. For over forty years she was active in fashion and design circles and was nominated as a ''Woman of Achievement.'' In her early career she appeared as a model in Peugot advertising, and for thirty years she and her late husband, Emil Alvin Hartman, directed Fashion Academy, a prestigious school of design and illustration founded by Mr. Hartman in 1920. Author and lecturer on fashion and design, her eloquent writings and speeches were frequently drawn on in the literature of a variety of companies. She continued to enjoy these activities, speaking and writing, especially poetry, until her death. A private service was conducted on October 14, 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMONSON, JONAS J.
description: SIMONSON-Jonas J., on Oct. 14, of Brooklyn. Beloved husband of Florence. Devoted father of Norman (Stacey) Simonson & Judith (Robert) Rosenkranz. Dear grandfather of Robin Rosenkranz Leon (Matthew Leon) and Kari Rosenkranz. Loving brother of Gertrude Rosen of Brooklyn. Services are at the Stanetsky-Hymanson Chapel, Salem, MA., Friday, 1:30 P.M.

title: Havana's Day-Glo Dreams of Old Glory
description: AS A CLASH of cultures and ideologies, few experiences compare with that of rounding a corner in the heart of Old Havana, its crumbling baroque buildings adorned with the exhortations of Fidel Castro or Che Guevara, and coming face to face with a gleaming 1955 Thunderbird that looks as if it had just been driven off the lot. Chevrolets, Buicks, Cadillacs, Fords, Chryslers -- all the automotive relics of the Eisenhower era seem to have found a lasting home in the most resolutely anti-American society in the Western Hemisphere.

title: Review/Fashion; Belgians Cover Some Familiar Ground
description: Dries van Noten has boldly and prophetically staked his career on fashion that melds Eastern and Western inspirations, but to push his influence forward he must do more than show long dresses over pants season after season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PINSKER, ELLA N.
description: PINSKER-Ella N. Loving wife of the late Martin. Devoted sister of Harry Neufeld and the late Ruth Klebanow, Philip Newfield, Nettie Bain & Selma Farkas. Adored aunt & great aunt. We loved her dearly. Services were held privately.

title: Ex-Guard Pleads Guilty to Killing 4-Year-Old
description: With jury selection under way, a former security guard pleaded guilty today to strangling a 4-year-old girl whose disappearance in 1994 shocked people in the Rochester area and led to months of futile searching.

title: Former Top Enlisted Man Asserts Innocence
description: The former highest-ranking enlisted soldier in the Army stood in uniform before a military judge today and said that he was innocent of sexual misconduct charges involving six female soldiers.

title: Price No Object at Armory Show
description: A white glazed Viennese stove adorned with the sort of blooming roses you'd expect to see on an over-decorated wedding cake swirls upward 10 feet in the air in the center of the Frederick B. Victoria & Son booth at this year's International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show. The $75,000 early 19th-century stove isn't the typical offering at one of New York City's most serious art and antiques events, but then dealers this season have gone a bit over the top in their effort to exhibit only the unusual. ''I wanted to show something you couldn't find anywhere else,'' Anthony G. Victoria said.

title: Inside Art
description: A New Balance For Calder

title: And Now, The Sin Police
description: Virtuocracy which may be defined as the bureaucratization of personal morality -- is on the move again. We have just seen public hatred of tobacco companies whipped to a fever pitch with some dubious arguments.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Alexandre broke my heart. At 8:30 on a Tuesday evening, my friend and I walked down the stairs to find only one table in the entire restaurant occupied. ''Should we leave?'' she whispered.

title: Spare Times
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLDERNESS, MILDRED K.
description: HOLDERNESS-Mildred K., of Bronxville, New York on October 16, 1997. Wife of the late George S. Holderness. Mother of G. Malcolm Holderness. Service at The Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, on Saturday, October 18, at 12:30 P.M.

title: Restaurant Retribution
description: To the Editor:

title: Joining Evil, Esq., At Satan & Satan
description: Meet Faust in fancy cowboy boots: Kevin Lomax, the lawyer played by Keanu Reeves in Taylor Hackford's unexpectedly seductive ''Devil's Advocate.'' Kevin is at the heart of a high-concept sentence (''Slick yuppie is co-opted by slicker New York Satan'') that has been spun into a lavish-looking, cleverly entertaining morality play with shades of ''Rosemary's Baby,'' ''Wall Street'' and countless other tales of selling out to Manhattan's temptations.

title: Garment Shops Found to Break Wage Laws
description: Federal investigators have found that almost two-thirds of the companies in New York City's garment industry violate overtime or minimum-wage laws, Labor Secretary Alexis Herman said yesterday.

title: Pilot Wins $875,000 In Sex Harassment Case
description: Continental Airlines was ordered yesterday to pay $875,000 to a former pilot who had charged that the airline tolerated sexual harassment in its cockpits.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article in the special Cars section yesterday about Mercedes-Benz omitted a final passage. The last sentence, about the maker's subcompact, should have read: ''To drive it, however, is to feel perched in the midst of a raised fishbowl, one that accelerates niftily and holds the road well, but whose claim to that three-pointed star on the grille seems more than a little tenuous.''

title: Toronto, a City That Works, Offers Varied Places to Play
description: Toronto the Good, people used to call it, with a sneer; it was so proper that a man had trouble buying an aspirin on Sunday. It was a plain vanilla town, ''a nest of British-thinking, British-acting people,'' as a local writer said, who threw up their hands in horror at anything exotic.

title: Art in Review
description: 'The New Objectivity'

title: PHILLIPS PETROLEUM TO BUY STAKE IN CANADIAN PROPERTIES
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company agreed yesterday to buy Gulf Canada Resources Ltd.'s stake in some oil- and gas-producing properties in western Canada for $230 million (Canadian), or $165 million (United States). Phillips will give Gulf Canada its 100 percent interest in the Coleville field in western Saskatchewan as part of the transaction. The agreement allows Phillips to add low-cost reserves and production while increasing Gulf Canada's portfolio of heavy-oil reserves. Phillips will acquire an interest in properties in the Zama/Virgo Basin of northwestern Alberta that produce 7,500 barrels of oil and 35 million cubic feet of gas a day. Phillips will hold a more than 90 percent stake in the oil properties and 50 percent in the gas properties. Phillips will gain reserves equal to about 58 million barrels of oil. The Coleville field to be acquired by Gulf Canada holds the equivalent of 22 million barrels of heavy oil and produces 3,100 barrels of oil daily.

title: On Stage and Off
description: Roman Polanski And Broadway

title: PRO BASKETBALL: Holding Class on the Court; Larry Brown Takes On Task of Teaching the Young 76ers 'What the Game Is About'
description: It is a special day in Larry Brown's class. Jimmy Jackson is celebrating a birthday. A humongous, two-layer frosted cake is wheeled onto the court after practice. Jackson's teammate, Jerry Stackhouse, plays maestro and everyone sings along.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, JEROME JAY, M.D.
description: HOFFMAN-Jerome Jay, M.D. Died October 14, 1997. Beloved husband of Joan (Osias) Hoffman. Loving father of Elizabeth and Patricia. Adoring grandfather of Jeffrey and Rachel Rothberg, and devoted brother of Elliot. Dr. Hoffman, an obstetrician and gynecologist, was a member of the Beth Israel Hospital Staff since 1950 and was much loved by all his patients. Funeral service 10:45 A.M., Friday October 17, ''The Riverside'', 76th Street at Amsterdam Avenue. Interment to follow at King David Cemetery, Putnam Valley, N.Y. In lieu of flowers please contact family for memorial trust address.

title: A Crash Course at Center Is 'Just Weird' for the Jets
description: Forty-five minutes before the offensive line gathered at the Jets' complex this morning, center J. R. Conrad was in a serious discussion with his coach Bill Muir.

title: A Connoisseur's African Choices
description: The French artist Arman has always gloried in carefully arranged profusion. In the late 1950's, when his close friend Yves Klein mounted an exhibition that consisted of an empty art gallery, he countered by filling the same gallery with trash.

title: Police Arrest 24 Accused In Drug Gang Violence
description: Prosecutors said yesterday that 24 suspects from three Manhattan drug gangs had been arrested on charges related to shootings, slayings and the torture of a witness.

title: James Michener, Author of Novels That Sweep Through the History of Places, Is Dead
description: James A. Michener, who survived a Dickensian childhood to win the Pulitzer Prize with his very first book, published when he was about 40, and then became one of America's favorite storytellers with grand-scale novels like ''Hawaii,'' ''The Source'' and ''Texas,'' died in his home in Austin, Texas yesterday. He was about 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEYMANN, SEYMOUR CHARLES
description: HEYMANN - Seymour Charles. Beloved husband of Friedl (Neumann). Died peacefully Wednesday, October 15, in Mill Valley, CA, after a long, happy and productive life. Born in Pretoria, South Africa, in 1902, he graduated with a medical degree from the University of the Witwatersrand and was the Chief Pediatrician and Head of Department at the Transvaal Memorial Hospital for Children for nearly two decades. He was physician to many generations of South Africa's children until he came to the US in 1968, where he continued his second mission-training young doctors at The Children's Hospital Medical Center of Northern California, Oakland, CA. Lovingly remembered by his wife Friedl, his son, Michael Heymann, of San Francisco, his daughter, Jennifer Davis, of New York, his grandchildren, Sandra, Mark and Simone, and his great-grandchildren. Donations in his memory may be made to The Children's Hospital Foundation, 747 52nd St, San Francisco, CA. 94609.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLER, MIRIAM A.
description: HANDLER-Miriam A. Age 82. Died on October 16, 1997 after a long illness. Cherished wife of Professor Milton Handler; devoted mother of Carole E. Handler; adored grandmother of Lisi and Lani Schoenbach; beloved sister of Milton Adler & Avivah Benamy; beloved aunt of Dr. Daniel Adler, Denise Jaffe, Elan Benamy; dedicated grand-aunt of numerous nieces and nephews. Her rare beauty was matched by her charm and dedicated service to the various philanthropies in which she played a leading role. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, on Saturday, October 18th between the hours of 7 and 9 PM. Funeral services will be held at the Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th Street & Madison Ave, Sunday, October 19th at 10:30 AM. Burial private.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Jerusalem Journal; Who in Israel Loves the Orthodox? Their Grocers
description: There's a synagogue for shoppers at the Birkat Rahel supermarket here, and kosher pints of Ben and Jerry's ice cream in the dairy section carry the seal of strict rabbinical supervision.

title: Op-Art
Pop and Jazz Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Rallies Mark 1995 March Organized By Farrakhan
description: On the second anniversary of the Million Man March, black men and women observed the occasion yesterday at scattered rallies around the country with some of the spirit but nowhere near the multitudes of the original gathering.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Benefits column last Sunday about Town Hall's annual fund-raising gala misstated the scheduled day. The event at the hall, 123 West 43d Street, is at 3 P.M. next Sunday, not Saturday.

title: Wordplay's the Thing Wherein the Actors Sing
description: Three young women wearing identical lime-green slit skirts and bathed in eerie half-light stand shoulder to shoulder onstage, an ethereal trio of dream girls.

title: Atlanta Broadcaster Seen in Bid for Lin Television
description: The Alabama state pension fund, acting through an Atlanta broadcaster it has backed, is bidding at least $1.6 billion in cash for the Lin Television Corporation, topping a $1.45 billion offer Lin accepted in August from a Dallas buyout firm, people close to the discussions said today.

title: From Merce Cunningham, an Esthetic Summary
description: In Merce Cunningham's eye-filling ''Installations,'' a 1996 piece that received its New York City premiere on Wednesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, dancers in gray stand still in front of a huge drape whose folds curve upward. Three screens, divided into squares, are positioned onstage and above the cast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCARTHY, WILLIAM J.
description: McCARTHY-William J. The family of William J. McCarthy notes with sadness his passing October 14, 1997 in New York, NY. Beloved husband of Maureen. Cherished father, 2 sons Brian and Matthew and daughters-in-law Catherine and Monica and devoted grandfather to Eoin and Anneliese. He will be much missed by all who knew him. A memorial mass at 11AM, Saturday, October 18, 1997 at Mother Cabrini Church, 701 Fort Washington Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to: Friends of Incarnation Children's Center, 142 Audubon Avenue, New York, New York 10032.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAMBERG, BARBARA B.
description: STAMBERG - Barbara B., of Greenwich, CT., and Palm City, FL. on October 15 in Greenwich. She is survived by her husband, Frank L. Stamberg; her children Amie D. Stamberg of Ridgefield, CT, Susan Schnoor of Hurlock, MD, Frank L. Stamberg, Jr. of Riverside, CT, and Bebe McCarthy of Port Chester, NY; 2 grandsons; and her siblings Amie B. Knox of Greenwich, CT., Thomas D. Bushman of Dover, MA., and Janet Spencer of Carlisle, PA. A private memorial service will be held by her family. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Greenwich Library Development Fund, Greenwich, CT. 06830.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He was just a piece of space junk that happened to get us. It was our turn.''

title: Federal Death Penalty Sought For Man Charged in 8 Killings
description: For the second time in four months, Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have decided to seek the death penalty -- again in the case of a man accused of committing several murders while a member of a violent drug gang.

title: Labor Holds Rally to Oppose Wide Trade Power for Clinton
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. brought its campaign against giving President Clinton wide authority to negotiate trade agreements to New York yesterday afternoon but could muster only a few hundred people at a downtown rally.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; Expanding their range, infomercials push charitable donations rather than sales.
description: AN unusual infomercial that is scheduled to begin a test run today will seek charitable contributions from viewers rather than beseech them to buy cookware, cosmetics or car wax.

title: From a Wimp to a Kingmaker in Battle for MCI
description: Ever since Worldcom trumped British Telecommunications' offer to acquire MCI Communications by about $11 billion two weeks ago, the British phone company has been looking like an impotent giant. In fact, until GTE waded into the battle for MCI with an unsolicited $28 billion bid on Wednesday, the prevailing wisdom on Wall Street was that British Telecom had little choice but to cut a deal with Worldcom.

title: TV Weekend; The Boys of October, 1996
description: Whoever arranged for Showtime's ''Joe Torre: Curveballs Along the Way'' to be shown tonight must not be a New York Yankee fan, or at least must have a strange sense of timing. If the team had managed to defeat the Cleveland Indians and advance to the 1997 American League Championship Series, the Yankee faithful would be concentrating on the real thing this evening. As it is, this appealing, if slightly superficial, dramatization of the team's glorious 1996 season and its manager's particular triumph serves less as proof that magic happens than it does as a reminder that magic is fleeting.

title: Bonilla Could Be The Latest Casualty
description: That Bobby Bonilla is using words like ''hope'' and ''wish'' about his chances of playing the first game of the World Series against Cleveland on Saturday does not bode well for Florida. But then, the Marlins are becoming experts at hurdling obstacles like the hamstring pull that is troubling their cleanup hitter.

title: Distinction Without a Difference
description: The Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, and his Republican colleagues are not able to offer their biggest donors coffees with the President or Lincoln Bedroom sleepovers. But they are hardly slouches when it comes to selling access to key lawmakers in exchange for fat contributions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLADES, WILLIAM B. III.
description: BLADES-William B. III. Friends of Bill will gather for a memorial service on Monday, October 20th, at 5 P.M., in the chapel of All Souls Church, 1157 Lexington Avenue.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's the question of the moment at the Frankfurt Book Fair: who will publish ELTON JOHN'S memoirs and how high will the bidding go?

title: A Grieving Little Town Unites, and Moves On
description: It had been scarcely six weeks since Earl and Irene Bunnell's only daughter, Vickie Bunnell, a 45-year-old lawyer and part-time judge, was gunned down, one of four leading townspeople murdered by a local recluse nursing a twisted grudge over his property rights.

title: Working Less in France
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG INSURERS PLAN TO INCREASE RATES ON LARGE VEHICLES
description: Alarmed by research showing that sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks are inflicting unusually costly harm to cars and their occupants in collisions, some big insurers are raising liability rates on the oversize vehicles in what could amount to the largest overhaul of liability coverage since the rise of no-fault laws a quarter-century ago.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes highly recommended shows.

title: Art in Review
description: Josiah McElheny

title: Companies Get Second Helping Of Tax Breaks
description: New York City's use of corporate tax breaks has become so pervasive that some of the city's most powerful and profitable companies are getting a second helping of incentives and subsidies at a time when New York's economy appears to be thriving.

title: A Perplexing Schedule Awaits the N.L. Central
description: The creation of a 16-team National League will produce a far more different -- and possibly confusing -- schedule than either league has ever had, according to the format for the 1998 schedule. The addition of a sixth team to the N.L.'s Central Division is the biggest reason for the new look.

title: Cramped in the Vastness of Outer Space
description: If you have the tiniest inkling of claustrophobia, don't even think about attempting space travel, at least not the way it is done now, in its early pioneering phase. ''Mission to Mir,'' a visually sweeping 40-minute documentary, much of which was shot inside the Russian Mir space station, doesn't talk much about the anxieties and discomforts of space travel, but its close-up pictures of astronauts crammed into tiny spaces certainly let you sense them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANTWERK, SAMUEL
description: GANTWERK-Samuel. Beloved husband of Belle. Devoted father of Lewis and Barbara, Carol and Bob, Roslyn, Ellen. Adored grandfather of Heidi and Andy, Rebecca and David, Adam and Lara, Jason, Eric and Tracy, Amy, Jonathan. Cherished great grandfather of Isaac. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre.

title: Zurich Group-B.A.T. Deal Is Made Firm
description: The Zurich Group of Switzerland announced a firm agreement today to take control of B.A.T. Industries' insurance businesses in a complex merger that would create one of the world's biggest financial-services companies and a major new player in the United States.

title: Home Video; Animal Grousing and Capitalist Greed
description: For many videophiles, ''Batman and Robin,'' to be released next week, not to mention the prospect of other large action films to follow on tape from now through the holidays, only intensifies the hunt for items far from the mainstream.

title: A Puzzle Whose Pieces Are Bass, Banjo and Mandolin
description: ''The last time I heard banjo was in summer camp,'' one middle-aged classical-music fan was overheard saying at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night. That element of surprise was all in the name of good business: Edgar Meyer, the regular bassist of Lincoln Center's Chamber Music Society and a musician with equal experience in classical and bluegrass, has teamed up with the banjoist Bela Fleck and the mandolin player Mike Marshall for a new classical-crossover album, ''Uncommon Ritual'' (Sony Classical). The Chamber Music Society's opening concert this season came mostly from the recording.

title: French Insurer Rejects A Takeover Bid
description: The board of Assurances Generales de France S.A., France's second-largest insurer after AXA-UAP, rejected an unsolicited 55 billion franc ($9.3 billion) takeover bid by Italy's Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A., saying it was too low and could lead to the dismantling of AGF. In a statement, the company said its board considered the Italian insurer's bid, pitched at a 28 percent premium above AGF's stock price, as ''unacceptable'' and ''hostile.''

title: On My Mind; The Chosen Weapon
description: This is a mystery story without a mystery. Everybody involved knows the key -- terrorists, antiterrorists, U.S. officials, America's allies, enemies and sunshine friends. But they do not want to utter it. Before this column ends you will know it too, and be afraid.

title: Refocused Whitaker Has Something to Prove
description: Pernell Whitaker's self-described ''dipsy-do'' style has frustrated many opponents and angered fans who would rather see a boxer throw big punches than dodge them. Whitaker is definitely an acquired taste.

title: Indians Went From Team in Disarray to Team of Destiny
description: The Cleveland Indians were sputtering after setbacks to Pat Hentgen and Roger Clemens in Toronto in early August, their confidence was dissipating because they wondered if they were worthy of the post-season and their lead over the ravaged Chicago White Sox was crumbling to three and a half games. It was definitely time to discuss the deteriorating season.

title: A Bad Patent Bill
description: The Senate is considering a misguided bill to recast the patent laws in ways that would threaten small inventors and dampen the innovative spirit that helps sustain America's economy. The bill is so mischievous that it has attracted an unusual coalition of opponents -- including the icon of liberal economists, Paul Samuelson, the icon of conservative economists, Milton Friedman, and 26 other Nobel Prize-winning scientists and economists.

title: Seagate Posts Huge Loss On Charges
description: Seagate Technology Inc., a major maker of computer disk drives, reported an unexpected and large fiscal first-quarter loss yesterday, including charges for foreign currency losses, as revenues fell as a result of pricing pressures and aggressive competition.

title: Palffy Has Hat Trick In Victory
description: Zigmund Palffy knew his scoring slump would not last. It simply was a matter of how soon he would break out of it.

title: Teen-Age Girl in Chicago Embarks on New Experience: School
description: The caller to the Chicago schools' special truancy line wanted to ask a hypothetical question. What would happen to a parent if her 15-year-old daughter were not in school? In several days of coaxing conversations, the mother acknowledged the truth: Her daughter had never been to school. In fact, the girl hardly went out of the house.

title: The Indians Must Slay The Wild-Card Beast
description: The Cleveland Indians have already performed a yeoman-like job this post-season. Is it fair to ask them to perform one more critical task in the 10 days ahead?

title: China Telecom Shares Prove a Hot Seller
description: China Telecom (H.K.) Ltd., the mobile telephone arm of China's Telecommunications Ministry, was valued at $140.2 billion (Hong Kong), or $18.1 billion (United States), in the biggest stock sale ever held in Asia outside Japan. The company priced its shares at $11.68 (Hong Kong) each, the middle of its target range. Hundreds of thousands of people stood in lines at Hong Kong banks this week to buy China Telecom, which has a near-monopoly on the nation's growing mobile phone market.

title: Creepy Guys, Ghost Stories, Teen-Age Sex: Uh-Oh.
description: Murder victims are piling up faster than the aptly named croakers in the picturesque little fishing village of Southport, N.C., but what's really brain dead there is the police force.

title: Two Plead Guilty in Case Involving Deaf Mexicans
description: Two of 20 people charged with holding deaf Mexicans in servitude in Queens and Chicago and forcing them to peddle trinkets in the subways and streets pleaded guilty yesterday to criminal conspiracy in deals through which other charges against them were to be dismissed.

title: With Restraint, Illuminating The Freak In Everyone
description: It's something to marvel at, all right, that strange connection between otherwise separate human beings. It is what's being so improbably celebrated in ''Side Show,'' the new musical about the Siamese twins Violet and Daisy Hilton. No, not the ligature of flesh that joins the heroines of this daring, enthralling production, although as played by Alice Ripley and Emily Skinner, they set a new standard for crackerjack Broadway teamwork.

title: MERGER TO CREATE LARGE CREDIT-RATING AGENCY
description: Fitch Investors Service L.P. said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with IBCA Ltd. in a $175 million deal that will create the world's third-largest credit-rating agency. It will compete with the Standard & Poor's Corporation, a unit of the McGraw-Hill Companies, and Moody's Investors Service Inc., a unit of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation. Fimalac of France, which controls IBCA, will buy Fitch from the Van Kampen Group, based in Grand Haven, Mich. The new company, to be called Fitch IBCA Inc., will have combined revenue of $105 million and more than 550 employees. Fitch, based in New York, focuses on rating bonds and borrowers in the United States public finance, taxable debt and structured finance markets. IBCA, based in London, specializes in rating banks and financial institutions worldwide.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERON, EVA DUARTE.
description: PERON-Eva Duarte. October 17, 1945. We will love and adore you forever and you will never be forgotten. We will take up your name and wave it aloft like a victory flag, Mother Eva. Your Descamisados Children

title: Marlins May Add a D.H.
description: Cliff Floyd will most likely replace John Wehner on the Marlins' post-season roster, and may get a start as a designated hitter in the middle three games of the World Series, in Cleveland.

title: Skip Away vs. Siphon In Jockey Club Gold Cup
description: Almost three dozen horses were entered yesterday in the four stakes that make up tomorrow's Breeders' Cup Preview at Belmont Park, which stars Skip Away and Siphon, who have combined earnings of $7 million but almost no chance of going on to the Breeders' Cup three weeks later.

title: Classical Music and Dance Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: A Shipping Dispute Flares With Japanese
description: A long-running trade dispute with Japan, over American access to its ports, worsened suddenly yesterday.

title: QUAKER STATE TO SELL LIGHTING UNIT TO PENSKE VENTURE
description: The Quaker State Corporation plans to sell its vehicular lighting unit to Penske Capital Partners L.L.C. for an undisclosed amount of cash. Quaker State said it would use proceeds from the sale of the Truck-Lite Company to pursue growth opportunities and to reduce debt. Truck-Lite had revenue of $86.7 million in 1996 and employs about 1,000 people. Penske Capital Partners is a venture formed by the Penske Corporation and Chase Capital Partners. Quaker State makes motor oils and lubricants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEYER, EDWARD
description: BEYER-Edward. Film editor. On October 12th in Los Angeles. Beloved father of Matthew Beyer and Leslie Flom. Grandfather of Gabriel. Brother of Lila Sobel. He will live forever in the hearts of his family and friends. Memorial services to be announced.

title: Black Ministers Rate the Gubernatorial Candidates
description: The association of black ministers in New Jersey -- a constituency courted heavily by both candidates for Governor -- gave Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and her Democratic challenger, James E. McGreevey, roughly equal grades yesterday in a report card on issues of importance to black voters.

title: DEVILS
description: The Devils left for Ottawa yesterday for tonight's game against the Senators without defenseman Vlastimil Kroupa and forward Patrik Elias. They were sent to Albany, the team's top minor league affiliate, leaving the Devils with 22 healthy players.

title: School System Can Be Held Liable in Rape of Girl on Field Trip, Court of Appeals Says
description: New York City's school system can be held liable for the rape of a 12-year-old girl who was separated from her class on a field trip, the state's highest court ruled today.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about a Harlem elementary school that opened in a former dry-cleaning plant misidentified the company that tested for a toxic solvent in the soil beneath the building. It was Riverpoint Inc. of New Rochelle, N.Y. (AKRF Inc. of Manhattan was the company that reported the test results to the state.)

title: At the Movies; Beatty's Latest Is on the Way
description: For months it was known as ''The Untitled Warren Beatty Project.'' Then it was known as ''Untitled Bullworth.'' Now it's just ''The Untitled. . .''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AULTMAN, DICK
description: AULTMAN-Dick. Of Charlotte, North Carolina. On October 15, 1997. Survived by his wife Marjorie (Nee Kirk), daughters, Katie and Kim and son Michael.

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Beck

title: Rogues in Cahoots With the F.B.I.
description: You probably never expected to see Ice-T, the rapper and underrated actor, wearing a purple sequined jacket and a cowboy hat, or rapping out ''Folsom Prison Blues.'' Then again his character, a streetwise ex-convict called Ice Gregory, never expected to go undercover for the F.B.I., as he does in the slick and sometimes jokey new drama ''Players.''

title: At Home Abroad; Grounds for Hope
description: ''The situation is better,'' President Alia Izetbegovic said. ''There is hope for the future in Bosnia.''

title: Voyage Round the Female Body for Fashion's New Blood
description: PARIS  Two stories are dominating the new fashion season: a fresh take on the female body and the regeneration game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFMANN, REGINA
description: HOFMANN-Regina. On October 15, 1997 at the age of 85. Wife of the late Max Hofmann, M.D. Mother of Peter Hofmann, M.D. Services at the Hebrew Tabernacle, 551 Fort Washington Avenue, NYC, Sunday, October 19, 11 AM. She will be missed by her many friends and her family in whose hearts she will remain. Her wit, integrity and loving kindness endeared her to all who had the privilege of knowing her.

title: Yankees Sign A Quarterback
description: The Yankees have signed Gus Ornstein, a backup quarterback for Michigan State, to a minor league contract. Ornstein, a switch-hitting first baseman from Tenafly, N.J., who batted .286 with 4 homers and 11 runs batted in for the Spartans last spring, will be permitted to maintain his football eligibility while he plays in the minors.

title: No Extra Guns Are Recovered In Shootout
description: A day after an undercover police officer was wounded and a suspected drug dealer was killed when an attempted drug bust went awry and more than 40 shots were fired on a crowded street in the Bronx, the police said yesterday that they had not recovered any weapons from the men whom they arrested.

title: Put J.F.K. Tapes in Perspective
description: To the Editor:

title: Drag Queens, A Cleaver And a Raven
description: ''Tell-Tale,'' initially produced at Performance Space 122, has reopened at the Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street, Manhattan. Following are excerpts from Peter Marks's review, which appeared in The New York Times on June 25.

title: INSIDE
description: James A. Michener Dies

title: Future Showrooms: Museum, Mall or Resort?
description: WHILE some analysts suggest that the Internet spells doom for dealerships, auto makers are hedging their bets by exploring new ways to lure shoppers into showrooms.

title: President Vetoes Item On Pensions
description: President Clinton today vetoed a spending bill provision that would have permitted hundreds of thousands of Federal workers to switch retirement systems.

title: Prying Open the Spy Budget
description: The tenacity of Washington's secrecy keepers has never been doubted, but this week they recorded another milestone in minimal disclosure. Cornered by a lawsuit brought by the Federation of American Scientists and President Clinton's own words allowing for disclosure of Washington's annual bill for intelligence activities, the Central Intelligence Agency announced that last year's spy budget was $26.6 billion. It was a bit like calendar makers declaring with great solemnity that Christmas this year will fall on Dec. 25.

title: N.F.L. MATCHUPS: WEEK 8
description: GAME WEEK OF THE WEEK

title: Market Place; Standard & Poor's buys a fund-research firm, the better to compete with Morningstar and Lipper.
description: SEEKING to tap deeper into the vast worldwide market for mutual fund data, the McGraw-Hill Companies said yesterday that it would buy the Micropal Group, a British mutual fund research company that has been expanding in the United States.

title: Coca-Cola Profits Climbed By 4.4% in Third Quarter
description: The Coca-Cola Company reported a 4.4 percent increase in third-quarter earnings yesterday. Although the company posted higher-than-expected beverage volumes, earnings were suppressed by a reduction in income from divested bottlers and the negative impact of the strong dollar on international revenues.

title: Of Craft, or Cheating
description: Bobby Bonilla grinned wryly when asked if Orel Hershiser throws a spitball, as Manager Davey Johnson of the Orioles suggested last week.

title: Social Security Benefits to Increase 2.1%
description: The tens of millions of Americans who get Social Security and other Federal benefits will get an increase of 2.1 percent in their checks in January, the second-smallest raise since automatic cost-of-living adjustments began in 1975, the Government said today.

title: Edison A. Price, Lighting Designer, Dies at 79
description: Edison Avery Price, the inventive lighting master whose innovative fixture designs give minimalist modern interiors their unobtrusive glow and shed new hidden light on old masters and other museum art, died on Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 79 and widely recognized as the originator of the entire modern lighting consulting industry

title: Art in Review
description: Willie Cole

title: Bombing's Fallout Adds to the Gloom Hanging Over Sri Lanka
description: Vijay Gunawardene stood silently for a long time today, staring at the acres of rubble and twisted steel left by a huge truck bomb that devastated several showpiece buildings here on Wednesday morning and left 18 people dead, more than 110 wounded and Sri Lanka's 18 million people in a renewed state of shock.

title: A Relaxed Tour Through the Early Ephemera
description: A blurry photograph of four Nubian children in sunlight is the first picture in the inaugural exhibition of the Howard Gilman Gallery, the Metropolitan Museum's new suite devoted exclusively to photography. Taken in 1852 by Ernest Benecke, this picture shows one boy with his hand playfully resting on another's head, while a third looks on. The fourth boy sits on the ground fiddling with his toes.

title: CONCORD SHARES RISE 47.3% IN INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING
description: Shares of Concord Communications Inc. rose 47.3 percent above its initial public offering price of $14 a share yesterday. Concord, which is based in Marlboro, Mass., and makes software for managing computer networks, raised $40.6 million in the offering. The shares opened at $20 and finished the day at $20.625 on trading of nearly 3.5 million shares. Analysts said Concord was well positioned within the growing computer-network trouble-shooting industry because it is one of the few companies that specializes exclusively in that niche. The company is still losing money, however, having reported 1996 losses of $5.1 million on revenue of $9 million, compared with a 1995 loss of $3.8 million on revenue of $4.4 million. Concord attributed the losses to the company's complete make-over in 1991.

title: Girl Reports Assault at School
description: A 15-year-old girl reported yesterday that she had been sexually assaulted in the stairwell of a high school in Jamaica, Queens, the police said. The victim, who was not identified by the police, said that two teen-age boys had assaulted her on Tuesday while two others stood guard. All four suspects are students at the school, the police said, but no arrests have been made.

title: New Video Releases
description: Batman and Robin

title: Encore Media Adds Richards to Roster
description: Two marketers named new agencies yesterday.

title: A Group That Plays Around With Harmonic Bareness
description: For his new group, Down Home, the drummer Joey Baron has brought together some of the best musicians in jazz and improvised music, including Arthur Blythe on alto saxophone, Bill Frisell on guitar and Ron Carter on bass. But Down Home, which appeared at the Knitting Factory on Wednesday night, doesn't take advantage of their collective strengths.

title: Theater Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Vacco Report Seeks New Safety Program at Brookhaven Lab
description: A report from State Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco recommends a major new safety program at the troubled Brookhaven National Laboratory and demands that the lab contribute to local health and environmental programs as a show of good faith.

title: Residential Real Estate; New Housing Planned Near Wall St.
description: Following the trend of recycling older office buildings in the downtown financial district, a Manhattan developer is planning to convert the upper floors of the three-building complex known as 17 Battery Place into a Ritz-Carlton hotel topped by luxury condominiums, while keeping the lower floors as commercial space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, MARIAN
description: BERMAN-Marian. Beloved wife of Harry, devoted mother of Cindy and Martin Rowe, loving daughter of Meyer Sacks. Services Sunday, 10 AM at Garlick-Riverside Chapels, 1439 Unionport Rd, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to Educational Jewish Center, 801 Astor Ave, Bronx, NY 10467 would be appreciated.

title: Accounts
description: -- Proscape Technologies Inc., Fort Washington, Pa., to Lois/EJL, New York, part of Lois/USA, as the first agency to handle advertising for Salesgod, a customized software program. Billings were estimated at more than $3 million.

title: Six Marines Are Charged With Selling Stolen Arms
description: Six marines based in North Carolina, including a captain, were arrested today on Federal charges of trying to sell machine guns, antipersonnel mines, rocket grenades, plastic explosives and other weaponry stolen from military stocks, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Spare Times
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTGARTEN, IRA H.
description: LUSTGARTEN-Ira H. A Memorial Service will be held Saturday, Oct. 25, 1997 at 12:30 PM at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University Campus, 1160 Amsterdam Avenue, off Broadway. Please omit flowers. The Lustgarten Family

title: 'Red Scrub' Enjoys a Revival
description: TOKYO  Beauty treatment fads come and go in Japan like the seasons: with heady fanfare when they arrive and barely a whisper when the next one overtakes them. This decade alone, Indian and Thai massage, and a plethora of other treatments have come and been and slipped away.

title: Art in Review
description: Karen Carson

title: Flamenco That Smiles, More Playful Than Fiery
description: Cristina Hoyos has been called the ''flame of flamenco.'' But those who expect fire and smoke from her Flamenco Cristina Hoyos company, which opened on Tuesday night at City Center, are in for a surprise. There are fleeting moments of white-hot passion in ''Caminos Andaluces'' (''Andalusian Roads''), one of two programs in this two-week American debut season. Still, the accent here is less on theatricality than on beautiful staging and stylish, fluid performing.

title: BTR TO ACQUIRE EXIDE ELECTRONICS FOR $352 MILLION
description: BTR P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Exide Electronics Group Inc. for $352 million in cash in a bid to extend its growth into the power supply components market. BTR, based in London, will pay $29 a share for Exide, based in Raleigh, N.C., and assume about $233 million in debt. The cash element represents a 30 percent premium to Exide's closing price of $22.25 on Wednesday and counters a bid by the Danaher Corporation, based in Washington, for $20 a share, which Exide rejected in July. Shares of Exide rose $6.328125 yesterday, to $28.578125. Exide, which makes equipment to allow uninterrupted power supply for computers and other equipment, would be combined with BTR's control systems division.

title: Eating Out; Asian Noodle Spots
description: Even if you don't include pasta, noodles are everywhere in New York. At these 12 restaurants, Asian-style noodles come in a spectrum of flavors and textures, from clear chapchae noodles made from yams to earthy soba noodles made from buckwheat. (Here are summaries, written by Eric Asimov, taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: In Brazzaville, a Triumphant Rebel Mocks His Ousted Enemy
description: Declaring himself victorious in a five-month civil war, the Congo Republic's new de facto leader today quickly took to mocking the President whom he had just defeated.

title: Kittles Is Injured in the Nets' First Preseason Loss
description: The Nets posted their first loss of the preseason here tonight in agonizing fashion, squandering an 11-point fourth-quarter lead in a 117-109 overtime defeat to the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Where Affirmative Action Ranks in Importance With the Architecture
description: Etched on the plaques around the rotunda of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center are the names of governors, million-dollar-plus donors and Gus Heningburg, the affirmative-action consultant for the project.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, LUISE SCHEINER
description: DAVIDSON-Luise Scheiner, 90, died Wednesday, October 15, 1997, at the Chester County Hospital in West Chester, PA. Born in Rochester, NY, she was the widow of Robert M. Davidson who died in 1984. She was the former Director of Volunteers at Bellevue Hospital in New York City. She held various personnel administrative positions. She was a member of the Womens City Club and the Citizens Union of New York. Survivors: Son, Bruce R. Davidson of Branchburg, New Jersey. Daughter, Marcia D. Horn of Ferrum, Virginia. Grandchildren: Alan, Lisa, David and Michael. Preceded in death by brothers, Paul & Bobby Scheiner. A memorial service date and time will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests that memorial contributions be made in her name to: Bailey House, 275 7th Avenue, 12th Floor, New York, New York 10001. Funeral information contact the Kuzo & Gofus Funeral Home, Inc. of Kennett Square, PA.

title: From Alberta, a Troupe Both Lyrical and Dramatic
description: Dancegoers who love to discover unfamiliar ballet companies will have a fine time at the Joyce Theater, where the Alberta Ballet opened a week's engagement on Tuesday night.

title: FOOTBALL REPORT
description: MIAMI

title: O'Neal to Cover Logo on Uniform
description: Shaquille O'Neal, the Los Angeles Lakers center and Reebok International Ltd. endorser, will tape over the Nike Inc. logo on his uniform, the team said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELMAN, REGINA R. ESQ.
description: SELMAN-Regina R. Esq., 10/15/97. Hollywood, FL/Spring Valley, NY. Wife of the late Dr. A.N. Selman. Dearly loved & respected by all of her relatives and friends. We will remember you forever.....Ted. Burial Sunday. Details: 914-356-8600

title: Mideast in Flux: Fiasco in Jordan Strains Old Links
description: To King Hussein of Jordan, balancing has always been the most crucial skill. Scion of a centuries-old dynasty, he rules a small country, now two-thirds Palestinian, that is surrounded by powerful neighbors whose epic conflicts constantly threaten to draw him in.

title: Halfway to Being a Playoff Contender
description: The Giants are at a crossroads this weekend, and waiting in their path is a team so much like themselves. The Detroit Lions, with several offensive stars, play a far racier brand of football than the balanced, methodical Giants. But, like the Giants, the Lions have a 4-3 record, and, like the Giants, they are one of the surprises of the season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, ZEV K, DHL, DD
description: NELSON-Zev K, DHL, DD. Died after a long illness in Riverdale, NY. He was 86. Spiritual leader of Temple Emeth, Brookline, MA for 30 years. Rabbi Nelson founded and chaired the Board of Directors of the Solomon Schechter Day School of Greater Boston. He received two doctoral degrees from the Jewish Theological Seminary, NY. Past president of Massachusetts Board of Rabbis and National Conference of Christians and Jews in Boston. Fellow Lehman Institute of Jewish Ethics and Rabbinic Cabinet Jewish Theological Seminary. Author and weekly columnist, visiting lecturer at Hebrew College of Boston. Survived by Avi Nelson of Boston, Dr. Yona Nelson-Shulman of NJ, Dr. Deena Nelson of NY and grandchildren Serena and Larissa Shulman. Funeral services Temple Emeth, South Brookline, MA, on Sunday, October 19, 2:30PM. Donations to Solomon Schechter Day School, 125 Wells Ave., Newton, MA.

title: A Kind of Education
description: To the Editor:

title: No Talks, Just Faxes, in Amtrak Dispute
description: Amtrak and the union that may strike over wages next week did not meet today but traded unfriendly faxes, each making statements that threaten the continued operation of Amtrak and commuter lines across the country.

title: Baghdad Threatens to Withdraw Cooperation From U.N. on Arms
description: Iraq has warned the United Nations that if the Security Council imposes any further sanctions on the country it will stop cooperating with inspectors monitoring the destruction of prohibited weapons, the chief of the inspection system said today.

title: A Soaring Dow Masks Inflation
description: To the Editor:

title: Defense in Louima Case Refuses a Longer Break
description: The state prosecution of four police officers accused of torturing Abner Louima in a Brooklyn station house resumed yesterday with a flurry of motions and promises of motions by defense lawyers -- despite a possible takeover of the case by Federal authorities.

title: Federal-Mogul to Buy T & N of Britain
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation said yesterday that as expected it had agreed to buy T & N P.L.C. of Britain for about $2.4 billion, in a move that would place the company among the world's largest makers of engine parts for cars and trucks.

title: Modernize Medicaid to Cover H.I.V.-Positive
description: To the Editor:

title: As Workers Strike at Columbia, Classes Meet in Pizza Shops and Bars
description: Columbia University's clerical workers union declared a strike over job security and pay issues yesterday, prompting professors to move ''Apocalypse in the Medieval Tradition,'' ''Introduction to British Literature'' and dozens of other classes off campus yesterday to pizza parlors, churches, bars and neighboring schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, DAVID
description: GROSSMAN-David. Beloved husband of Irene. Father, grandfather, brother-in-law, uncle and friend to so many, died October 6. He retired in 1974 from the Federal Gov't after 34 years with HUD and HEW. He will be forever missed.

title: Stocks Tumble As Earnings Disappoint
description: The stock market suffered its worst drop in more than a month yesterday, hurt by a handful of disappointing corporate earnings reports that dragged down a wide range of blue-chip and technology issues.

title: Aid From Rich Nations to Poor Fell in 1996
description: Foreign aid to the world's poorest countries has fallen to its lowest point in half a century, a report by private relief groups said this week.

title: With Transit Surplus Comes Subway Fare-Cut Proposal
description: Bus and subway ridership are up by about 10 percent since July, far beyond the Transit Authority's expectations. The taxes that subsidize the authority have brought in much more money, thanks to the city's booming economy. The Transit Authority is, relatively speaking, awash in money in 1997, its balance sheet about $110 million healthier than projected.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Water Testing Is Praised
description: City water officials have made great strides in the last year in protecting people infected with the AIDS virus from waterborne parasites, an AIDS victims' advocacy group said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLOTT, EVE B.
description: CLOTT-Eve B., of Kearney, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, devoted mother of Jay, Mitchell, Gordon and the late Roger, dear sister of Min Starr, loving grandmother of Jeffrey, Mathew, Melissa, Jonathan. Services ''Wien & Wien'', Hackensack, NJ Sunday, 12:30 P.M., 1-800-522-0588.

title: HBO Show Preserves DiMaggio Mystique
description: If you try to figure out Joe DiMaggio, he will offer you no help. He has glowed in America's spotlight since 1936 as a luminary long before a star's privacy and innermost thoughts were virtually deemed public property.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Workers' Compensation
description: State officials announced yesterday that they would reduce employers' fees for workers' compensation insurance by 9.3 percent next year, a move that will save New Jersey employers an estimated $113 million.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Owning and Leasing; Daewoo's British Trick: Making Dealers Vanish
description: CD-ROM no-dicker stickers to mega-car marts to digital deals on the Internet, car sellers are experimenting with techniques that may hold promise for a future where only one thing seems certain: the traditional dealership will be forced to make big changes. An approach that has proved successful in Britain may soon be adapted for the United States as the Daewoo Motor Company sets up shop.

title: Family Fare
description: Lore and Lure Of Circuses

title: Art in Review
description: Antonio Martorell

title: Spencer, Loyal To His Every Obsession
description: The English painter Stanley Spencer (1891-1959) is best known to Americans through Pam Gems's play ''Stanley,'' which had a well-received run on Broadway last season and was based on the batty, seriocomic saga of spiritual yearnings and sexual preoccupations that constituted the artist's life.

title: One Chief Leaving Pagano, Schenck
description: Robert Pagano, co-chairman and managing partner at Pagano, Schenck & Kay in Boston, said yesterday that he would leave that agency at the end of the month ''to try some other things.''

title: Sulzberger Passes Leadership of Times Co. to Son
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, who steered The New York Times through 34 years of expansion and enormous changes in the way it delivers the news to its readers, retired yesterday as chairman and chief executive of The New York Times Company, the newspaper's parent company.

title: CANADIAN SOFT DRINK MAKER EVALUATING SALE OF COMPANY
description: The Cott Corporation, a Canadian soft drink producer, said yesterday that it had hired an investment bank to help it evaluate a possible sale of the company. Cott, based in Toronto, said it had hired Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company to assist in evaluating options, including a possible sale. Cott also confirmed that the Pencer family was considering selling its 29 percent interest in the company. Last month, Cott officials played down rumors that the Pencer family was planning to sell its interest. Shares of Cott rose 81.25 cents, to $12.75.

title: For Giuliani, Ethnic Tone Is Emerging Despite Vow
description: When Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani stumbled into one of New York City's many chasms of ethnic and racial division this week, he quickly pulled himself up with an immediate and uncharacteristic apology. But in doing so, he illuminated a truth little seen over the last four years: that while ethnic appeals may have gone underground during the Giuliani administration and are less forceful than in past administrations, they remain very much alive.

title: Scrubbing the Air, Buffing the Cleaners; Belated E.P.A. War on Pollutants May Infuse Value Into Companies
description: A few years ago, Nina Bergan French started Sky+ to perfect and sell a still rough but promising new method for analyzing toxic metals that she had licensed from a Federal research laboratory. She was certain that the Clean Air Act of 1990 would provide a ready-made market. But the years passed and the Environmental Protection Agency still did not crack down on the metallic contaminants. Ms. French lost her license, and switched Sky+ to government consulting to pay her bills.

title: Cats, Grandma and Other Disposables
description: October is early, but not too early to acknowledge Harmony Korine's ''Gummo'' as the worst film of the year. No conceivable competition will match the sourness, cynicism and pretension of Mr. Korine's debut feature. Turned loose with a camera and the Emperor's new clothes, the writer of the vastly better ''Kids'' creates an aimless vision of Midwestern teen-age anomie, complete with drugs, garbage, dead cats and neat tricks like turning off Granny's respirator. When it comes to boy wonders exploring the cutting edge of independent cinema, the buck stops cold right here.

title: Arkansas Rebel Bucks G.O.P. on Campaign Bill
description: On his visits home here lately, Representative Asa Hutchinson looks out at an attentive crowd of constituents and has to wonder: Dare he raise the arcane issue that haunts him most in Washington? Can the words ''soft money'' pass his lips without inviting the mass numbing of his audience at the issue of campaign finances.

title: N.A.S.D. Cites Stratton Staff
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said today that the president of Stratton Oakmont Inc. and 32 employees had defrauded at least 70 customers through aggressive telemarketing and other sales practice violations.

title: Defying NATO, Hard-Line Serbs Resume Broadcasting in Bosnia
description: In a slap at the international officials who had declared their broadcasts a danger to peace, hard-line Bosnian Serbs returned to the airwaves tonight, managing to circumvent the NATO troops who had seized their transmitters.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: European Merger Deal To Form Financial Giant

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, MILDRED
description: ROSS-Mildred. The Sternberg family notes with great sorrow the passing of Mildred Ross. She was a friend in the fullest to us for decades and her loss will be deeply felt. Our sincerest condolences to the Ross family on their bereavement. The Sternberg Family

title: A Kind of Education
description: To the Editor:

title: The Sprint to Opening Night in Newark
description: The violins in Beethoven's Ninth Symphony were warring with the keening of power saws slicing through copper tubing, so much so that Zdenek Macal, director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, halted the rehearsal in frustration.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption yesterday about renovation of the Bethpage Black golf course on Long Island misstated the name of the United States Golf Association official aiding the project. He is Tim Moraghan, not Jim Morafhan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SATO, ANNA TURID
description: SATO-Anna Turid, Wednesday, October 15, 1997, Turid Sato of Washington, D.C and Flesberg, Norway. She is survived by her son, Thomas Sato Danforth, her partner, William E. Smith, her mother, Tora Hoimyr, her sister, Solveig Sato, and many other close friends and family in the United States, Norway and many other countries. Memorial service will be held at St. Margaret's Episcopal Church, 1820 Connecticut Avenue., N.W., Sunday, Oct. 19, 1997 at 2 P.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Organizing for Development, an International Institute (ODII), for the Turid Sato Trust.

title: J. R., You're No Iago
description: To the Editor:

title: A Purist Who Makes Simplicity Seductive
description: Don't worry if you missed the Columbus Day parade. The Museum of Modern Art will be hanging out the red, white and green straight through the new year with a wonderful arrival from Italy: ''Achille Castiglioni: Design!'' One of the great Italian explorers, a tireless discoverer of beauty in the commonplace, Mr. Castiglioni, along with his brothers, Livio and Pier Giacomo, helped pioneer the 20th century's most vibrant movement in design. This beautiful retrospective of his work should stimulate fresh thinking about a time and a place and the artists who captured them in designs for living.

title: Hanson to Sing Game 1 Anthem
description: The pop group Hanson will sing the national anthem before the opening game of the World Series tomorrow night at Pro Player Stadium in Miami. The group of brothers Isaac, Taylor and Zachary Hanson reached the charts this year with their song ''MMMBop'' from their album ''Middle of Nowhere.''

title: Close-Knit and Proud, Quebec Town Mourns Crash Victims
description: The choir that sang at the community memorial service came from a neighboring town. St.-Bernard's own choir, mourning members killed in the worst bus crash in Canada's history, was unable to perform at the ceremony today in the town's Roman Catholic church, Saint Bernard's.

title: Sports of The Times; One Coach Is Nearing Recognition
description: WE needed this week. That is, those of us who recognize Bill Parcells as an excellent football coach but who are withholding sainthood, like the Vatican on Mother Teresa.

title: Bosnian Serb Leader Is Reported to Balk at Imposing Peace Pact
