description: The Bosnian Serb President, who has been championed by the West as an alternative to defiant nationalism, has not delivered on her promises to carry out the Dayton peace agreement, Western diplomats and United Nations officials contend.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Airport Back on Schedule
description: Newark International Airport was back to normal yesterday morning, hours after an air traffic control center on Long Island shut down, causing 150 canceled flights and dozens of delays overnight.

title: High Heels and American Blues
description: WASHINGTON  The shoes looked positively threatening on the Gucci runway. The toe-box came to a sharp, unforgiving point. If it weren't for the pounding soundtrack that accompanied the models and those shoes down the catwalk, one suspected it would be possible to hear bones being crushed inside those evil pumps.

title: A New Organ in an Old Style Gets a Chromatic Workout
description: Paradoxically, at a time when many churches are abandoning much of their traditional music and even their traditional instrument, the organ, others are installing new organs made in an old style.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGOR, ARTHUR S.
description: GREGOR-Arthur S., on October 14, 1997. Beloved husband of Margot. Devoted father of Laurie and Thomas and brother of Lester, and six grandchildren. Educator, Writer and Thinker.

title: Racing to Be First With a Harmless Substitute for a Cleaning Solvent
description: For the last six weeks, Jeffrey L. Battiston, the owner of a dry cleaning chain in West Hartford, Conn., has secretly been testing what could be the Holy Grail of his industry: a substitute for the toxic but commonly used cleaning solvent perchlorethylene that he said is harmless to the environment, nonflammable and cleans just as well as perc.

title: Modernize Medicaid to Cover H.I.V.-Positive
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: There is something about a close friendship that can transcend even the most scathing of literary reviews. At least that is the experience of the poet JOHN HOLLANDER in his 50-year association with Allen Ginsberg, who died in April.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Continental to Pay in Lawsuit
description: Continental Airlines was ordered yesterday to pay $875,000 to a former pilot who had charged that the airline tolerated sexual harassment in its cockpits.

title: The Man Of Her Dreams? Hardly
description: Except for an overlay of portentous religious symbolism, every detail of ''Eye of God,'' Tim Blake Nelson's bleak, haunting study of a brutal murder in Oklahoma, feels absolutely right. Set in a parched, fading little oil town named Kingfisher in the heart of the Bible Belt, the film tells the story of Ainsley Dupree (Martha Plimpton), a spunky, self-confident short-order cook in a local burger joint who makes a scary leap of faith by impulsively marrying the handsome ex-convict with whom she has been conducting a prison correspondence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUN, GLADYS (SCHREIBER)
description: BRAUN-Gladys (Schreiber), 97 years young, Tuesday, October 14. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Leo Braun. Treasured Mother of Phyllis Braun Leventhal and son-in-law Bernard. Adored and adoring Grammy of Lionel, Alexander and Evan Leventhal. Cherished darling big sister of Celia Levine, Sidney Schreiber and the late Shirley Seiler. Early graduate of Hunter College and admired German and Spanish teacher in NYC high schools. Funeral services Sunday, October 19 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street at 10:30 AM, burial to follow in East Hampton at Gates of the Grove Cemetery. Memorial contributions in honor of her beautiful life may be made to Friends of Israel Sports Center for the Disabled, Independence Mall East, Phila., PA 19106. You will truly live forever.

title: ARGENTINA CABLEVISION PLANS TO ACQUIRE A RIVAL SYSTEM
description: Argentina's Cablevision S.A. agreed yesterday to buy its smaller rival, Mandeville Cable Partners, for $515 million. The purchase includes 430,000 subscribers served by Mandeville. The acquisition will increase Cablevision's subscriber base to more than one million, moving it ahead of Argentina's No. 2 cable operator, Video Cable Comunicaciones S.A. Mandeville is 85 percent-owned by the United States investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst. Cablevision is a unit of Tele-Communications Inc., based in Englewood, Colo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COREN, ARNOLD
description: COREN-Arnold. Beloved husband of Miriam. Beloved cousin, we will always remember you Gladstone Family Circle

title: INSIDE METRO
description: DEATH PENALTY SOUGHT -- Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have decided to seek the death penalty for the second time in four months. B3.

title: The Moment for New York Court Reform
description: A bipartisan consensus seems to be emerging on a plan to consolidate and simplify New York state's archaic court system. But Gov. George Pataki and the legislative leadership need to move quickly to translate this consensus into concrete change.

title: Ready-to-Wear Labels From Spain Quietly Infiltrate Paris
description: PARIS  "Without trumpets or drum rolls"  as the French say  Spanish ready-to-wear has quietly and quickly become a fashion force here with, in the vanguard, the Zara boutiques.

title: Clintons Present Their Act To an Admiring Argentina
description: One was perhaps more homey, the other a bit more cool; one improvised wildly, the other stayed pretty true to the text.

title: CIRCON SHAREHOLDERS VOTE TO BACK U.S. SURGICAL'S BID
description: The U.S. Surgical Corporation said yesterday that the shareholders of the Circon Corporation had voted to support its hostile bid to acquire Circon for $254 million. At a recent meeting of shareholders, they voted by almost 70 percent to elect U.S. Surgical's nominees to Circon's board and to promptly sell Circon, U.S. Surgical said. U.S. Surgical has been fighting to acquire the rival surgical-products maker for more than a year. Circon, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., had 1996 revenue of $153.8 million. U.S. Surgical, based in Norwalk, Conn., had 1996 sales of $1.11 billion.

title: Let the Madness Begin
description: At colleges all across the nation, basketballs will be pulled out of the closets and teams will unveil new recruits, old coaches and the same dream: to be the last team standing when the clock strikes the end to the season in less than six months.

title: Adam Opel to Cut 1,900 Jobs in Belgium
description: Adam Opel A.G., the German unit of the General Motors Corporation, said it was cutting 1,900 jobs at its plant in Antwerp, Belgium, almost a quarter of the work force, to offset sluggish sales in Europe. Opel, Europe's second-largest car maker after Volkswagen A.G., is seeking ways to trim costs to increase profitability, as sales flag in Europe's sluggish car market.

title: Lots of Gore, Tantrums, Leather And Bleach
description: ''Playing God'' is so fond of showing bloody hands digging into bullet-punctured bodies that after its third or fourth close-up of an emergency surgical procedure, you might as well be watching a children's finger-painting class for all the impact it has. Those dripping red hands belong to Eugene Sands (David Duchovny), a down-and-out Los Angeles surgeon who becomes the pet miracle worker of a big-time counterfeiter and smuggler named Raymond Blossom (Timothy Hutton).

title: The New York Times Co. Reports Improved Results for 3d Quarter
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it earned $46.2 million, or 46 cents a share, in the third quarter, compared with a loss of $47.7 million in the quarter a year earlier.

title: Campbell Is Fed Up With Rangers' Slump
description: There is never really a good time for a slump, but the start of the season is one of the worst times. The Rangers, with two consecutive defeats and only one victory in their first seven games, got the message today at Playland Ice Casino.

title: Contemplating the Sorrows And Perils of Time Passing
description: Henri Dutilleux's latest orchestral work, ''The Shadows of Time,'' has much to recommend it on its own terms, but when Seiji Ozawa and the Boston Symphony gave the work its New York premiere at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, the piece also carried a provocative question for the start of a new concert season. It challenged listeners to remember the last time they had left a concert by a major American orchestra convinced that a freshly minted work was the highlight of the program, and to wonder why the experience was so rare.

title: Successful Births Reported With Frozen Human Eggs
description: In an advance that promises to make it vastly easier for older women to remain fertile, researchers at a private clinic in Atlanta said yesterday that they had frozen human eggs, thawed them, fertilized them and created a successful twin pregnancy.

title: Saving That Dollar; Free Bus Transfers Mean Fewer Fares for Vans
description: Phil Myers emerged from the Jamaica Center subway station into a chilly drizzle Wednesday morning, 50 feet from where a row of dollar-a-ride vans waited to whisk him home to Laurelton, Queens.

title: Art in Review
description: William L. Hawkins

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWE, CAROLE M.
description: LOWE-Carole M., of Grand Cayman Islands and Boston, October 15, 1997, Mrs. Carole (Myers), wife of Philip Lowe, aged 79 years. Lovingly survived by her husband Philip, a son and daughter-in-law Prof. Perry Lowe and Delphine Lowe of Belmont, 2 grandchildren Todd Lowe of New York City and Alexandra Lowe of Belmont and numerous relatives. Funeral services Friday, October 17, 1997 at 10:30 AM in Temple Israel, The Riverway, Boston followed by interment in Temple Israel Cemetery, Wakefield, MA. Relatives and friends invited to attend. For information J.S. Waterman and SonsEastman Waring Funeral Service, 495 Commonwealth Avenue, (at Intersection of Beacon) Boston. Memorial observance will be held on Saturday and Sunday from 1-3 PM at the family residence, 330 Beacon Street, Boston.

title: Ward Sets Tone as Knicks Get Aggressive
description: It was as if Charlie Ward was tailing the Philadelphia 76ers' version of a sporty, maneuverable Matchbox car. When the sprite-sized Allen Iverson stopped and spun, Ward stopped and spun. When Iverson floored it, so did Ward.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OCEAN ENERGY INC., Baton Rouge, La., an independent energy company, agreed to form a joint venture with Shell Offshore Inc. for oil and gas exploration in Louisiana.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, FRANCIS P., M.D.
description: MARTIN-Francis P., M.D., prominent physician, track champion and official member of the Smith Barney Board of Directors. On October 15, 1997 of Rockville Centre. Beloved husband of Barbara (nee Kelsey). Loving father of Katherine Pangaro, Therese Martin, Francis Jr. M.D., Jeanne Bolton, Deborah Martin, James, Thomas, Lawrence, Kenneth, Margaret Votta and Daniel. Dear brother of John, Walter and William. Cherished grandfather of 14. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre today 2-4 7-9 PM. Funeral mass St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre Saturday 9 AM. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Cross, Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers friends may send donations to the Francis P. Martin M.D. Memorial Fund, University of Notre Dame, 230 Park Avenue Suite 520, N.Y., N.Y. 10169

title: Jewish Intermarriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Synthetic Ingredients Increasingly Part of the Mix : In Search of the Perfect Perfume
description: PARIS  The most neglected sense, the sense of smell, is also the most intriguing. Smells can trigger very remote, sometimes forgotten, memories buried in the unconscious. Each person's sense of smell and taste in perfume is unique. Creating a "universal" perfume which resonates in the "collective unconscious" remains a marketing dream.

title: U.S. Maritime Agency Moves to Bar Most Japanese Cargo Ships From American Ports
description: In an unexpected intensification of a trade dispute with Japan, the Federal Maritime Commission ordered the Coast Guard today to bar most Japanese cargo ships from American ports and to detain any Japanese ships currently in port.

title: Ciba SC Sales Beat Analysts' Estimates
description: Ciba Specialty Chemicals A.G., a Swiss chemicals company, said nine-month sales rose a higher-than-expected 20.4 percent, fueled by the weak Swiss franc and growth in Europe, Asia and the United States.

title: Harry D. Gotwals, Swarthmore Official, 50
description: Harry D. Gotwals, vice president of development and public and alumni relations at Swarthmore College for the past seven years, died on Oct. 2 at Taylor Hospital in Ridley Park, Pa. Mr. Gotwals, a resident of Swarthmore, was 50.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Night column last Sunday about a party for the photographer Francesco Scavullo referred incorrectly to a photograph he took for Cosmopolitan magazine. His photograph of the models Cindy Crawford and Marcus Schenkenberg was never used; he later photographed Ms. Crawford alone, and that image appeared on the magazine's cover.

title: Movie Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Running times and ratings of films are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: Landscapes That Are Steeped in Time
description: The children grew up, or anyway edged toward adolescence, and were no longer amenable to being photographed nude. And so she turned to the land. You could see the turn coming. The final photograph in Sally Mann's 1992 book, ''Immediate Family,'' was titled ''The Last Time Emmett Modeled Nude'' (1987). The boy in the picture looked a bit reproachful, or maybe it was just that he looked at least as sulky as many a boy his age.

title: Leo Burnett Quits Fruit of the Loom
description: The Toronto office of the Leo Burnett Company said yesterday that it had resigned the North American Fruit of the Loom account, with billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million, rather than participate in a review.

title: Wonders Of Patagonia Await Clintons
description: Patagonia, the vast expanse of opulent wilderness in southern Argentina, is a long, long way from Hollywood and the Hamptons. Still, its endless snow-capped peaks, virgin forests and crystalline waters have become the latest haunt of the rich and famous.

title: Messinger Opposes Helping Yankees Move to Manhattan
description: Ruth W. Messinger said yesterday that she opposed spending city funds to build a new stadium for the Yankees in Manhattan and would support only a relatively limited effort to improve Yankee Stadium in the Bronx and prevent George M. Steinbrenner 3d from acting on a threat to move his team to New Jersey.

title: Admiring an American Hero, From a Distance
description: JACKIE ROBINSON

title: An Ambitious Symbol Of Newark's Pride
description: As the diva protested to the camera-toting tourist, ''We are not a building!'' Darn right. And neither is the New Jersey Performing Arts Center. Don't let those sturdy walls of brick and glass fool you. Newark's new center is much more than a work of architecture. It is an uproar. A commotion. A melee of civic hope.

title: MARSH & MCLENNAN TO BUY MEXICAN INSURANCE BROKER
description: The Marsh & McLennan Companies said yesterday that it would buy Brockman y Schuh Group, a Mexican insurance broker, for an undisclosed price to bolster its Latin American insurance brokerage business. The acquisition would give Marsh & McLennan additional revenue of $50 million. Marsh & McLennan, based in New York, is the world's largest insurance broker. It had 1996 revenue of $4.15 billion. Brockman y Schuh has 600 employees in 15 offices in Mexico, making it the nation's biggest broker. It also has an office in Miami and does business in Colombia and Guatemala. Shares of Marsh & McLennan fell 18.75 cents, to $74.0625, on trading of 323,800 shares, more than the three-month daily average of 299,100.

title: Debunking 'Bell Curve'
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; Census Report Shows Suburban Growth
description: In 1995, the economic expansion in the New York region was strongest in some of the wealthiest suburban counties surrounding New York City -- Bergen in New Jersey, Fairfield in Connecticut and Putnam in New York -- according to an analysis released yesterday by the Federal Bureau of the Census.

title: Art in Review
description: Bob Thompson

title: A Quiet City at Last?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An illustration with the Metropolitan Diary column on Wednesday carried an incorrect credit. It was by Phil Marden.

title: Nostalgia, Song and Angst
description: There's plenty of rhythm and even more blues (of the psychological kind) in ''Thank God! The Beat Goes On,'' but this generous backstage musical never manages more than intermittently to flirt with the kind of rousing, hand-clapping, head-bobbing audience rapport that it obviously aspires to.

title: Police Added on Subways as Thefts Rise
description: Trying to combat the steady work of pickpockets and robbers in New York City's subway system, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that he would send 300 new police academy graduates into the tunnels to strengthen the Police Department's transit division.

title: As MCI Fight Grows, the Wall St. Entourage Builds
description: The growing multibillion-dollar struggle to acquire the MCI Communications Corporation highlights the feeding frenzy in the telecommunications industry for investment bankers and lawyers, those profit-hungry pilot fish who counsel both predator and quarry in big acquisitions and mergers.

title: Wonderful World for Stewart With One-Shot Lead in Disney
description: Nobody had to twist Payne Stewart's arm to persuade him to enter the Walt Disney World-Oldsmobile Golf Classic.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Plan Made for Rail Strike
description: As Amtrak workers dig in for a strike that could cripple New Jersey's commuter and commercial rail lines, state officials announced a plan yesterday to relieve the huge traffic problems a strike could cause.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LILLIEN, BERNARD
description: LILLIEN-Bernard. Bernie left us October 13. Much beloved husband, father, grandfather, friend. His warmth, wit and humor were legendary. Heaven will be a livelier place.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Park Construction Begins
description: Work began yesterday on the first waterfront park to be built in Atlantic City in more than 100 years.

title: Regimes That Persecute
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Keybank to Sell Health Coverage To Businesses
description: In a departure for banks, Keybank plans to announce today that it will begin selling health insurance to small businesses, many of whose employees now have no coverage.

title: Chiefs Overwhelm Chargers
description: The San Diego Chargers were embarrassed, and not just by the final score.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SONENBLICK, GRACE OSLER (NEE BROWN)
description: SONENBLICK-Grace Osler (nee Brown). October 17, 1987. Forever amazing Grace, always an inspiration to her daughters and granddaughters. Susan, Amy, Julie, Dana, Abby, Lydia and Joanna

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELMAN, REGINA R. ESQ.
description: SELMAN-Regina R. Esq., 10/15/97. Hollywood, FL/Spring Valley, NY. Wife of the late Dr. A.N. Selman. Dearly loved & respected by all of her relatives and friends. We will remember you forever.....Ted. Burial Sunday. Details: 914-356-8600

title: CLOSINGS IN EUROPE AND WORKER DISMISSALS PLANNED
description: The Kellogg Company, based in Battle Creek, Mich., said yesterday that it would close three European factories and dismiss 400 workers, about 10 percent of Kellogg's European work force, resulting in a pretax charge in the fourth quarter of as much as $150 million. Factories in Riga, Latvia; Svendborg, Denmark, and Verola, Italy, will close by the end of the year. Production will be moved to other European plants in Bremen, Germany; Manchester and Wrexham, Britain, and Valls, Spain. The moves will result in annual pretax savings of $60 million to $70 million when complete, the company said. Kellogg shares fell in midafternoon trading.

title: Henry Holt, 63, Music Educator, Conductor and Festival Founder
description: Henry Holt, a conductor and music educator, died on Oct. 4 at the University of Virginia Medical Center in Charlottesville. He was 63 and lived in Warrenton, Va.

title: On the Stump, Whitman Touts Record Employment
description: With less than three weeks to go before Election Day, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday that New Jersey had regained all the jobs that were lost in the last recession, and announced that the state had reached a new high in the number of employed residents, surpassing the record set at the height of the last boom in 1989.

title: Reporter's Notebook; No Borders for Fund-Raising Queries
description: Over and over on his trip through Latin America this week, President Clinton has labored to conjure visions of a future in which goods and ideas flow freely throughout the hemisphere.

title: HARTFORD FINANCIAL TO BUY OMNI INSURANCE GROUP
description: The Hartford Financial Services Group Inc. said it would pay $187 million in cash for Omni Insurance Group, entering the business of insuring drivers viewed as higher-than-average risks. The all-cash offer is about $31.75 a share for the Atlanta-based Omni Insurance, the nation's 22d-largest provider of ''nonstandard'' auto insurance. Omni sells its insurance through 3,500 independent agents in 11 states. At present, Hartford Financial only sells nonstandard insurance written by the Progressive Corporation of Mayfield Village, Ohio, the No. 2 provider of such coverage. Hartford Financial is the fifth-largest publicly traded United States insurer.

title: Review/Fashion; 3 With Just the Touch To Inherit the Crown
description: Which of today's hit songs will be the standards of tomorrow, sung by children at campfires, whistled tunelessly by every worker, piped without words into elevators? What new stories will be returned to, and updated, in generations to come? And what contemporary designers will build a core of classics under their names that, years after their deaths, another designer can take on, modernize but still make instantly recognizable? Who, in effect, can build the next generation's Chanel?

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Acid Spills at High School
description: About 300 students were evacuated from St. Mary's High School yesterday, including 89 who were taken to hospitals for observation, after a chemistry teacher dropped a six-ounce bottle of hydrochloric acid, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BEHRMAN, QUEENIE
description: BEHRMAN-Queenie,. Mom, your little darlings miss you. Much Love

title: Quartey, Whitaker Capture Decisions
description: Ike Quartey never doubted the outcome, even though Jose Luis Lopez dropped him to the canvas twice in their action-packed thriller of a fight tonight -- including once in the next-to-last round.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISTLER, BETSY
description: DISTLER-Betsy, an extraordinary human being. The President, a Fellow, a Training Analyst and a Supervisor of the Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research. A creative person who was a source of love, a pillar of strength, and a well of understanding for her husband David, her sons Daniel and Josh, & countless friends, colleagues, patients and students, even through her ten year private battle with breast cancer. Her life will be a continuing inspiration. She will be dearly missed. Funeral service will be held Sunday at 1:45 P.M., at the Plaza Memorial Chapel, at 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. No flowers, please.

title: Youth Violence Decline
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LILLIEN, BERNARD
description: LILLIEN-Bernard. Bernie left us October 13. Much beloved husband, father, grandfather, friend. His warmth, wit and humor were legendary. Heaven will be a livelier place.

title: Cone Has Shoulder Surgery
description: Seventeen days after David Cone pitched valiantly but poorly in Game 1 of the division series, he underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday to remove frayed and inflamed tissue from his right shoulder. The Yankees said the one-hour procedure was successful, and said they believe Cone will be in their rotation for opening day next season.

title: N.F.L.: NOTES
description: MIAMI

title: In Marlins vs. Indians, a Clash of Young and Old
description: The last time a Cuban native was the starting pitcher in a World Series, the game became one of the most memorable in World Series history. The game, however, was memorable for Carlton Fisk's 12th-inning home run, not for Luis Tiant's pitching.

title: Pennzoil to Buy 2 Car Products Companies
description: The Pennzoil Company said today that it had agreed to buy two auto products companies for about $40 million to expand its consumer product lines.

title: Pivotal Upstate Democrat Backs Schumer for Senate
description: Almost since the day he declared his candidacy for the Senate last April, Representative Charles E. Schumer has faced nagging questions on two issues: Could he overcome a lack of support outside New York City? Would he stay in the race?

title: Security Guard Arrested In Sale of Marijuana
description: A security guard for a construction company renovating a public high school in the Prospect Heights section of Brooklyn was arrested yesterday and charged with selling marijuana to undercover investigators posing as students, the police said.

title: An Old Letter Backs a Claim of Helping Kennedy Write 'Profiles'
description: A recently discovered 40-year-old letter written by a well-respected history professor appears to support his claim that he wrote major portions of John F. Kennedy's Pulitzer Prize-winning book, ''Profiles in Courage.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, BEATRICE (BEA)
description: SIMON-Beatrice (Bea). On October 15, 1997, of Belle Harbor, NY. Beloved and cherished wife of the late Nicky. Devoted and loving mother of Joan and son-in-law Jerry Goldfarb. Adoring Nana of Jane, Jim and Andrew. We will love and cherish your memory always. Graveside service 2:00 PM, Sunday at Hungarian Union Fields.

title: Cuba Buries Che, the Man, but Keeps the Myth Alive
description: After 30 years of mystery and intrigue, the remains of Che Guevara, the doctor-turned-guerrilla who inspired a generation of would-be revolutionaries around the world, were laid to rest today in this elegantly faded provincial capital where he achieved the military victory that first established his reputation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in SportsThursday about the pennant-clinching victory by the Cleveland Indians misstated the number of World Series they have won. It is two, not one.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PORTEC INC., Lake Forest, Ill, a manufacturer of railroad, materials handling and construction machinery, said Astec Industries would buy its construction equipment division for an undisclosed amount to strengthen its business.

title: In Melting Pot of Parisian Art World, Designers Gain Inspiration : Young Upstarts Reinvent French Style
description: PARIS  Thanks more to a kick in the pants than a monetary upturn, the Paris fashion scene is pulling out of its sleeping beauty mode at last.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; An Oil Change (of Venue)
description: Assemblyman Kenneth C. LeFevre drove to a Jiffy Lube here yesterday for an oil change. As his gold 1997 Nissan Maxima waited, keys in the ignition, a man at a nearby railway station was apparently tempted to take a quicker route to Philadelphia, the Assemblyman said.

title: PHOTRONICS TO ADD SOME MOTOROLA OPERATIONS
description: Photronics Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Motorola Inc.'s photomask manufacturing operations in Mesa, Ariz. Financial terms were not disclosed. Photomasks are plates that transfer patterns during the manufacture of integrated circuits. The companies will enter an agreement in which Photronics will supply all photomask requirements previously provided by Motorola's operations. Motorola, a Schaumburg, Ill., maker of electronic equipment, had 1996 sales of $28 billion. Photronics, a photomask supplier based in Brookfield Center, Conn., had 1996 sales of $160 million.

title: The Bulls (Oui, Les Bulls) Almost Lose One in Paris
description: Michael Jordan often looked very much like Michael Jordan, but the rest of the Chicago Bulls often looked very much like the Vancouver Grizzlies tonight.

title: Princeton Wins IC4A
description: Tony Barroco kept looking over his shoulder as he neared the finish line yesterday, confident that he was about to lead Princeton to its first team title in the Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: In Westchester, Race Tight but Rivals Miles Apart
description: They represent the two faces of Westchester.

title: The Many Sad Voices Of Longing
description: K. D. Lang, torch singer extraordinaire, turned her torch into a cigarette lighter for ''Drag'' (Warner Brothers), an album of songs about smoking. In her concert on Thursday night at Radio City Music Hall, Ms. Lang, a nonsmoker, soon made it obvious that she had found a new analogy for her perennial subject: yearning. In Ms. Lang's songs, lovers and addicts are creatures of desire, and whether they need a cigarette or a romance -- or, in a song like ''Smoke Dreams,'' both -- they are humbled and purified by that need.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCULLY, LEONARD TYSON
description: SCULLY-Leonard Tyson, Colonel, U.S.A. Died October 17, 1997 at his home in Pound Ridge, New York. He is survived by his wife Jean Scully. Colonel Scully was formerly President of Excelsior Income Shares, Inc. and a retired Officer of United States Trust Company of New York. He served on the Boards of a number of charitable organizations. Funeral services are private. Burial will be at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Schoolyard Sex Assault Investigated
description: School officials and the police last night were investigating reports that two 9-year-old girls were sexually assaulted by groups of boys in a Bronx elementary school playground yesterday afternoon. The attacks, at Public School 44 in the East Tremont section, were the third reported sexual assault in public schools in the last two weeks.

title: 10 Years After the Crash, Fall Is Not in the Air; Talking the Talk, Walking the Walk On Main Street
description: It was not the corn prices or the baseball playoffs, or even the weather that had the regulars buzzing at the Muddy Waters coffee shop on Main Street. It was the stock market.

title: At Syracuse, Ivory Tower Gets Wired for Cable; From Caesar to Seinfeld
description: To the Editor:

title: Prisoner Saved From Tight Squeeze in Courthouse
description: An apparently distraught female prisoner arriving for a hearing at Staten Island Criminal Court leaped over a third-floor railing yesterday, but did not hit the ground. Instead, after a two-story plunge, she slithered down and became tightly wedged in a narrow space between the bars of a cellblock and the base of a stairwell.

title: Electric Car Efficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Said He Was 'Glad' He Shot Man, Nurse Testifies
description: An emergency room nurse testified today that a police officer charged with killing a man in a dispute over a parking space told her ''he was glad he did it.''

title: Jets' Hall Doubling Up As Kicker and Punter
description: John Hall, the rookie with the strong leg, stony expression and no-excuses attitude that has endeared him to Coach Bill Parcells, once again is likely to be a pivotal player in the Jets' intense rivalry with the Patriots.

title: A Little-Known Solidarity Figure Is Chosen as Poland's Prime Minister
description: A former anti-Communist underground activist, Jerzy Buzek, was named Poland's Prime Minister today, marking a distinct change in the complexion of government after four years of rule by former Communists.

title: SUNGARD DATA TO ACQUIRE INFINITY FINANCIAL
description: Sungard Data Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Infinity Financial Technology, a designer of trading and risk-management software, for about $313 million in stock. Sungard, of Wayne, Pa., provides computer disaster recovery services. It also makes software for investment managers and health care providers. News of the deal drove up shares of Infinity $2.25, to $16. Sungard shares rose 5/16 , to $24.375 on the New York Stock Exchange. Under the accord, Sungard will issue 0.68 share for each share of Infinity, or about 15 percent of Sungard's shares outstanding. Infinity, of Mountain View, Calif., had 20.8 million shares on average as of Sept. 30.

title: Madrid's Opera House Regains Its Past Luxury, But Borrows the Music
description: Grand opera houses have a way of competing as much with their offstage dramas as they do with their lavish productions. Yet few have matched the tortured history of Madrid's 19th-century opera house, the Teatro Real, which has finally been reinaugurated by King Juan Carlos II all of 72 years after the last opera was performed on its stage.

title: Bradford Journal; Women Marked for Death, by Their Own Families
description: She has had to move 19 times over the last five years. She steps outside her suburban home only after checking the street for strange cars and rehearsing the nearby footpath escapes. Once back inside, she shoves heavy furniture under the front door handle and places a knife within quick reach.

title: Motorola Plans Bigger Investment in China
description: Motorola Inc. will double its investments in China to $2.5 billion over the next three years to match fast-rising sales, said Shelagh Lester-Smith, director of Motorola's communications in Asia.

title: James Michener Dies at 90
description: At readings and book-signings all across the country, American writers are commonly asked, ''What do you think of James Michener?'' It isn't a trick question, but phrasing the answer does require a little diplomacy, the ability, at least, to gauge the audience accurately. Whatever writers may think of Mr. Michener -- and they think many different things -- he was a touchstone for several generations of American readers, the standard by which they judged literature, a reason, above all, for them to keep reading. In the perpetual battle between highbrow and lowbrow, Mr. Michener was neither: he was simply brow. He wrote millions of words and made millions of dollars and gave millions of readers pleasure.

title: Treasury Prices Are Hurt By Strong Econonic Data
description: Prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday after strong housing and manufacturing data again raised investors' worries about growth, inflation and interest rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, ESSIE COHEN
description: GOLDBERG-Essie Cohen. Devoted wife of the late Harry A. Beloved mother of Sondra and Murray Stoller, Sharon and Irwin Parker, Enid and Donald Hillman. Adored grandmother of Rhonda and Michael, Leslie and Walter, Laurie and Peter, Glenn and Elise, Mark and Adrianne, and Jennifer. Cherished great-grandmother of 6. She left us all too quickly. Services Sunday, 12:45 P.M., ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Japan Nears Pact With U.S. On Threat to Bar Its Ships
description: The United States and Japan said today that they were on the verge of a shipping agreement that appeared to defuse a looming confrontation between the Coast Guard and Japanese vessels entering and leaving American harbors.

title: The Leader Who Led
description: While reading the newly published transcripts of the deliberations of President John F. Kennedy and his advisers during the Cuban missile crisis of 1962, I recalled the chilling question from the floor of a religious convocation that I addressed some months after the crisis ended: ''By what authority, Mr. Sorensen, did President Kennedy last October threaten the incineration of 180 million Americans?''

title: STATES PASS LAWS TO REGULATE USES OF GENETIC TESTING
description: Concerned that the Federal Government is acting too slowly to protect the confidentiality of genetic information, states are passing their own laws to regulate the use of genetic test results to prevent discrimination by insurers and employers.

title: Dollar Strengthens vs. Mark As German Rate Fears Ease
description: The dollar surged against the mark yesterday after officials of the Bundesbank eased concerns that German interest rates would soon rise, while talk of a rise in United States rates mounted.

title: Something in Common; To Bridge a Gap, Korean Grocers Try a Little Creole
description: Gazing at his customers suspiciously, Mun Chae paced along the rows of eggplants, green plantains, bell peppers and other vegetables stacked neatly on the shelves of Chae Fruit and Vegetable Market.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Mayor Seeks Commuter Tax
description: Mayor Martin G. Barnes wants to impose a commuter tax on the city's 650,000 nonresidential employees similar to taxes in Newark and New York City. The proposed tax, one-tenth of 1 percent of commuters' incomes, could generate $6 million to $8 million a year for Paterson, which is plagued by a low tax base, Mr. Barnes said yesterday.

title: Vitamins for Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: The Keys for the Indians to Win
description: 1. How Do You Spell Relief?

title: Federal Election Commission Drops Some Prominent Cases
description: The Federal Election Commission today closed several prominent election law cases, including one involving Speaker Newt Gingrich, because of actions already taken by the courts.

title: Malaysia Tightens Rules For Bad Loan Provisions
description: In an attempt to avoid the financial ills in other Southeast Asian countries, Malaysian banks will increase provisions for bad loans and take other measures to shore up the financial industry, the Government said yesterday in the 1998 budget report.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, MARY (NEE KAISER)
description: SCHWARTZ-Mary (nee Kaiser). 1906-1997. Precious and adored wife of the late Harry of over 71 years, who died nine months ago. An Eishes Chayil to her daughters Sylvia Rombom, Suzanne Knobel and all of her family and friends who knew her. A woman whose participation in every sphere of synagogue life was an example of what it means to be a ''ShulMentch''. Mary was a member of the Jewish Center of Jackson Heights & Crown Heights Yeshiva. She is survived by her grandchildren, great-grandchildren, nieces, nephews, sister-in-law and son-inlaw. Funeral services Sunday, October 19, 1997, Schwartz BrothersJeffer Memorial Chapel, at 9 AM. Interment Montefiore Cemetery on Springfield Boulevard.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about finalists for the National Book Awards misspelled the surname of a finalist in the nonfiction category. He is Sam Tanenhaus, not Tenenhaus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINER, SOLON L.
description: WEINER-Solon L., 75, of West Hartford, CT., died suddenly October 16, 1997. Beloved husband of Frances Weiner. Loving father of Andrew and Debra Weiner, Howard and Patti Weiner, and Lori Weiner Rosenthal and David Rosenthal. Dear brother of Herbert Weiner. Adored grandfather of Joshua, Hannah, Ross, Elizabeth, Stephanie, Emma and Rebecca. Funeral at the Emanuel Synagogue, West Hartford, on Sunday, 1 PM. Shiva in West Hartford through Tuesday and on Tuesday evening at the home of Debra and Andrew Weiner.

title: Fumble Return Lifts Elizabeth
description: Ketwan Graham, a 6-foot-4-inch, 275-pound defensive end, picked up a fumble by Union's Nygiem Calhoun in the third quarter and returned it 17 yards to break a scoreless battle and lead Elizabeth over host Union, 21-7, last night before a Cooke Field crowd of 3,500 in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPAISMAN, JOSEPH
description: SPAISMAN-Joseph. Beloved husband of Zyporah. Devoted father and father-in-law of Ben and Sally. Cherished grandfather of Erica and Elliot. Services on Sunday at 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOSK, JEAN
description: WOSK-Jean, of Smithtown, NY, beloved mother of Shari and Robert, and daughter of Florence Wanes, died of cancer on October 16, 1997. She will be dearly missed by all who knew and loved her. Services to be held on Sunday, October 19, at 12 Noon, at Sunset Chapel in Manhasset, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NANNI, ETHEL
description: NANNI-Ethel. October 17, 1997. Beloved wife of Louis F. Nanni. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call on Saturday 7-9 PM and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: Too Polite in Argentina
description: President Clinton's three-day visit to Argentina was designed to celebrate the dramatic improvement in that country's relations with the United States, an achievement of President Carlos Saul Menem's eight years in office. Those warmer ties are a welcome change coming from a country that tilted toward the Axis powers in World War II, sheltered Nazis after the war and denounced American policies under the postwar dictator Juan Peron and several of his successors.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about international sanctions against Iraq misstated the status of further sanctions, which would prevent travel by Iraqi officials to other United Nations member nations. Debate on the new sanctions, not the imposition of the sanctions, is expected to begin next week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALTER, GRACE WARING
description: WALTER-Grace Waring. Sister of Henry G. Walter, Jr.; aunt of H. Glen Walter, III. Retired teacher, age 85. B.A., College of New Rochelle, Masters, Teachers College. Services private. Suggest Catholic Charities in lieu of flowers.

title: Bartoli Gives a Lesson in Voice Projection
description: There is one reason only that the Metropolitan Opera decided to present its first-ever production of Rossini's ''Cenerentola'' and that James Levine, who has not previously demonstrated much interest in the bel canto repertory, chose to conduct it: Cecilia Bartoli.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: An Unhappy Stewart Still Leads by Two
description: Payne Stewart was disappointed after today's round, but he was still in first place.

title: Picture This: Big Smiles After Surgery
description: Scott Caldwell's face is right out of a Norman Rockwell painting, with blue eyes, freckles, tousled brown hair and an infectious grin.

title: Investigators Suspect Large National Market for Illicit Arms
description: Federal and military investigators said today that they were looking into the possibility that the six marines arrested on Thursday in connection with the theft and sale of large quantities of military explosives and ammunition from Camp Lejeune might not have been the only military personnel in the country involved in munitions and weapons thievery.

title: Touchy-Feely Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Official:Shopping Can Be Good for You
description: LONDON  Whoever said money can't buy happiness didn't know where to shop  a sentiment close to the heart of every fashion professional.

title: Palffy and Reichel Add Punch
description: It is no accident that Zigmund Palffy and Robert Reichel ended up together on the Islanders' scoring line. It is a finesse game they learned in their homeland, which was once Czechoslovakia, one of precise passing and skillful skating. So there was little question in Coach Rick Bowness's mind that they would complement one another.

title: Sports of The Times; Nike Says, 'Jump, Man.' How High?
description: FRAN Fraschilla was driving to work yesterday morning thinking about the first day of his second season as head basketball coach at St. John's University. With a strong recruiting class anchored by a pair of outstanding seniors in Zendon Hamilton and Felipe Lopez, this might actually be a whip of a team. Then Fraschilla thought about the dreaded ritual of the glitzy, televised prelude to practice known as Midnight Madness. He groaned. ''I'm not a big Midnight Madness proponent,'' he said, speaking on his cell phone. ''I like to get down and dirty and get to work right away.''

title: 10 Years After the Crash, Fall Is Not in the Air; Taking the Pulse Of Wall Street From Bottom Up
description: When Wall Street laid an egg 10 years ago -- to borrow from Variety's classic headline in 1929, another time of sudden plunges on the stock market -- Tony Psaroudis did not even blink. He deals in eggs.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Corrections
description: A front-page table of contents in the special Cars section on Thursday misspelled the surname of the author of an interview with the hosts of the radio program ''Car Talk.'' He is Jim McCraw, not McGraw.

title: Japan Sentences Killer, 15, to Treatment
description: A family court today handed down the toughest sentence possible to a 15-year-old boy who has admitted killing two children, including the beheading of a boy that transfixed the nation. The court sent him for medical treatment to a special juvenile reformatory where he can be held until he is 26.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; 41 Get State Military Award
description: Forty-one New Jersey war veterans, each of whom had at least one medal for valor or meritorious service, have another one: the Distinguished Service Medal, the state's top military award.

title: Beliefs
description: The familiar charge that the news media ignore religion looks a little unconvincing right now. Barely had the press recorded the final prayer for Mother Teresa than the Promise Keepers swarmed over every front page. One week later, Buddhism was the cover story on Time and the guru Deepak Chopra on Newsweek. Bunched just behind these big stories were Pope John Paul II's visit to Brazil, the new law regulating religious groups in Russia and the shifting stances of militant Muslim leaders in Iran and Afghanistan.

title: Little Panel That Could, Did, Posing Threat of Trade War
description: During the budget battle two years ago, Republicans in Congress proposed abolishing the Federal Maritime Commission, arguing that the regulatory agency had outlived its purpose. For most of the day today, the Administration sounded as if it wished it had gone along with the idea.

title: Biggest Merger Is Said to Be Set For Accounting
description: Two of the world's biggest accounting and consulting firms, KPMG Peat Marwick and Ernst & Young, are expected to announce as soon as next week that they will merge.

title: '97 WORLD SERIES: A Rookie Who Knows About Pressure; After His Problems Adapting to the U.S., Livan Hernandez Takes the World Series in Stride
description: Livan Hernandez pitched in big games for the Cuban national team before defecting in 1995. He felt tremendous pressure to succeed.

title: SPIEGEL CATALOGUE UNIT PLANNING EMPLOYEE REDUCTIONS
description: Spiegel Inc.'s catalogue division said yesterday that it would dismiss 775 full- and part-time employees in Pennsylvania and Nevada by December as it moves to cut costs amid declining sales. Spiegel Catalogue said the dismissals would represent about 3 percent of its 13,400 full-time equivalent employees when it closes its Bensalem, Pa., and Reno sales centers in late December. The company plans to take an unspecified charge in the fourth quarter for severance costs, said a company spokeswoman, Allison Scherer. The move comes as Spiegel struggles to revive its catalogue business.

title: Kittles to Sit Out After Injury
description: Kerry Kittles will probably miss the next two exhibition games because of a pulled left groin he sustained Thursday night against the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ZELDA
description: MILLER-Zelda, October 17, 1997. She is survived by her daughter Stacey Dumain, her son Jeffrey Miller, her dear and devoted friend Julius Wittman, her granddaughters Emma and Rebecca Dumain, and by her niece Sandra Ball. She will be missed by them and by her many friends. Service Sunday, 11:15 AM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIMOWITZ, DR. LILLIAN L.
description: HEIMOWITZ-Dr. Lillian L., of Greenwich, CT., on October 16th, 1997. Beloved sister of Bert Margolies, mother of Carl and Edna Heimowitz, grandmother of Donald Heimowitz. Services Monday, October 20th, at 1 P.M., Temple Sholom, 300 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT. 06830. Contributions may be made to Hadassah or Temple Sholom.

title: At Syracuse, Ivory Tower Gets Wired for Cable
description: To the Editor:

title: Tape Links Clinton to Man Tied to Crime
description: In the fall of 1995, President Clinton was introduced to a Macau businessman and told he had been ''very helpful'' in arranging a Hong Kong reception for Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, according to a newly released White House videotape of Democratic Party events.

title: Challenging the Line Item Veto
description: The Supreme Court avoided dealing with the merits of the case when it ruled last summer that members of Congress do not have standing to challenge the constitutionality of the Line Item Veto Act. The justices ruled that the lawmaker plaintiffs, including Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, could not sue because they had not been personally injured. The ruling left it up to parties outside of the Federal Government who have been directly harmed by the line item veto to raise the constitutional question.

title: Excite to Acquire Netbot for $35 Million
description: Excite Inc. has agreed to buy Netbot Inc., which makes software for finding and buying products on the Internet, for $35 million in stock, to attract more shoppers to the directory's site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, GLADYS I.
description: BROWN-Gladys I. Loving wife of the late Joseph. Beloved mother of Joseph K., Bernadette Carragher, Gladys Staats, Linda, Sharon Schuler, Donna Zevens, Janice Harvey and the late Coranne Bertrand. Also survived by 26 grandchildren & 23 great grandchildren. Reposing at the Martin A. Gleason FH, 10-25 150th Street, Whitestone, N.Y., Saturday 7-9 PM and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass St. Luke's R.C. Church, Monday at 9:30 AM. Interment Kensico Cemetery.

title: Dinosaur Evolution
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Inmates Allege Retaliation
description: Inmates at Bayside State Prison in Leesburg say they have been stripped, beaten, fed rotten food and denied clean linen in retaliation for the killing of a guard. Yesterday, Judge Stephen M. Orlovsky of Federal District Court in Camden permitted lawyers to begin interviewing inmates at the Cumberland County prison on Monday to investigate their claims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, FRANCES MARY (PORCELLI)
description: GINSBERG-Frances Mary (Porcelli). Died at 80 years of age. Beloved wife of the late Robert Ginsberg, President of the Fur Association of America and devoted mother of Roger Ginsberg; PGA Touring professional and current Golf Director of Muttontown Country Club, and Frank C. Ginsberg, Chairman, CEO & Creative Director of Avrett, Free & Ginsberg Advertising. She was also the proud grandmother of 3 granddaughters as well as 3 greatgrandchildren. Frances and Robert were one of the first families to move to the Woodlands in 1968 and members of the Woodlands Golf Club. Frances Ginsberg was devoted in her younger years to many charities in the Riverdale, Fieldston, New York area.

title: Corrections
description: The final paragraph of a review yesterday about ''Gummo,'' a film about teen-agers in the Midwest, misstated its rating. As the accompanying list of credits declared correctly, the film is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian), not NC-17 (No one under 17 admitted).

title: GUESS TO CUT ABOUT 6% OF ITS WORK FORCE
description: Guess Inc. said yesterday that it would cut 170 jobs, or about 6 percent of its work force, as part of an effort to reduce costs by $8 million in 1998. The casual-apparel maker said the layoffs in management, support departments and at a distribution center were expected to save $4.5 million. Reduction of other general and administrative costs will result in additional cost savings of about $3.5 million, the company said. Guess Inc., based in Los Angeles, also makes accessories and related consumer products.

title: A Rare Chance for State Schools
description: Voting for a $2.4 billion school construction bond authorization on November's ballot will require a leap of faith for New York State residents. But the potential gains are too large not to take the chance.

title: INVESTORS TO TAKE OVER STARRETT FOR $80 MILLION
description: The Starrett Corporation, which built the Empire State Building in Manhattan and Starrett City in Brooklyn, agreed to be acquired for about $80 million in cash by a group of investors. The investor group will begin a cash tender offer of $12.25 a share starting Oct. 23, said Jonathan Mayblum, vice president of the real estate developer the Lawrence Ruben Company, one of the investors. The investment firms Blackacre Capital Group, Amroc Investments and Argent Ventures are also part of the investor group making the latest offer, Mr. Mayblum said. Starrett owns the HRH Construction Corporation, the Grenadier Realty Corporation and the Levitt Corporation. In January, Paul Mistein, Starrett chairman, and other shareholders agreed to sell about 52 percent of the company to the Related Capital Company for $12 a share, an offer Starrett ended in March.

title: YACHTING: A SAILOR'S JOURNAL; Tempers Wearing Thin
description: Ten yachts, all about 64 feet in length with a maximum crew of 12, began the 31,600-nautical mile Whitbread Round the World Race from Southampton, England, on Sept. 21. The competitors are on the first of nine legs, a 30-day, 7,350-nautical mile voyage south through the Atlantic to Cape Town. With 1,400 nautical miles to go to Cape Town, EF Language has a 116-nautical mile lead over Merit Cup. Katie Pettibone, an American on the all-women's crew of EF Education, currently ninth, will be filing periodic reports on life on board until the race's scheduled return to Southampton next May. This is her fifth report.

title: McDonald's Profit Up 1.9%, But U.S. Sales Are Still Slow
description: The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that earnings rose 1.9 percent in the third quarter, less than expected, as sales remained sluggish and the strong dollar hurt results overseas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, MILDRED
description: ROSS-Mildred. With profound sorrow the Officers, Board and staff of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations mourn the death of a cherished friend and devoted collegue. A truly elegant and gentle woman, she lovingly served our sacred cause for many years with quiet dedication and caring concern. We extend heartfelt condolences to her beloved life's mate, Matt, her bereaved children, grandchildren and loved ones. Jerome H. Somers, Chairman Rabbi Eric H. Yoffie, President Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, President Emeritus

title: Miami Journal; A Frequently Divided City Rallies Around Its Marlins, a Team of the Rainbow
description: Armando Vidal, the Dade County Manager, was so thrilled the Florida Marlins had made it to the World Series that in a departure from the employee dress code, he told the county's 28,000 workers they could wear the team's color, teal, to work today.

title: Devils Lose 2-Goal Lead
description: A 2-0 lead on the road with Martin Brodeur in goal. That is usually a winning script for the Devils.

title: Messinger Vows to Ease CUNY Students' Tax Bill
description: Proclaiming that she would make the city's public colleges a top priority, Ruth W. Messinger said yesterday that as mayor she would seek to give a tax break to City University of New York students by allowing them to deduct their tuition from city income taxes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUN, GLADYS (SCHREIBER)
description: BRAUN-Gladys (Schreiber), 97 years young, Tuesday, October 14. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Leo Braun. Treasured Mother of Phyllis Braun Leventhal and son-in-law Bernard. Adored and adoring Grammy of Lionel, Alexander and Evan Leventhal. Cherished darling big sister of Celia Levine, Sidney Schreiber and the late Shirley Seiler. Early graduate of Hunter College and admired German and Spanish teacher in NYC high schools. Funeral services Sunday, October 19 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street at 10:30 AM, burial to follow in East Hampton at Gates of the Grove Cemetery. Memorial contributions in honor of her beautiful life may be made to Friends of Israel Sports Center for the Disabled, Independence Mall East, Phila., PA 19106. You will truly live forever.

title: No Enrollment Minimums Set for Small Schools
description: Top aides to Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that he has rejected the idea of dictating minimum enrollments for small schools.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSANO, LOUIS A.
description: ROSSANO-Louis A., on October 16, 1997, of Great Neck, NY. Beloved husband of Margaret. Dear father of Geoffrey, George, Mark and Lynette. Loving grandfather of Margaret and Chloe. Brother of Paul. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Sunday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service Monday 10 AM, at the Funeral Home. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLER, MIRIAM A.
description: HANDLER-Miriam A. Age 82. Died on October 16, 1997 after a long illness. Cherished wife of Professor Milton Handler; devoted mother of Carole E. Handler; adored grandmother of Lisi and Lani Schoenbach; beloved sister of Milton Adler & Avivah Benamy; beloved aunt of Dr. Daniel Adler, Denise Jaffe, Elan Benamy; dedicated grand-aunt of numerous nieces and nephews. Her rare beauty was matched by her charm and dedicated service to the various philanthropies in which she played a leading role. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, on Saturday, October 18th between the hours of 7 and 9 PM. Funeral services will be held at the Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th Street & Madison Ave, Sunday, October 19th at 10:30 AM. Burial private.

title: As Crash Date Nears, Few Still Fear Stocks
description: From Wall Street to Main Street, the stock market crash 10 years ago, when the Dow Jones industrial average fell 508 points, is a distant memory for many.

title: As Ever the Stones, Rocking, Rolling and Ruling
description: In the middle of entertaining 50,000 people at Giants Stadium on Thursday night, Mick Jagger paused to enjoy a semi-private joke. He had just dispatched the last falsetto whoop in the disco-era chestnut ''Miss You'' when he muttered, ''Hit me one time!'' Charlie Watts, the drummer, responded with a quick one-two: Ba-dum-bum! ''Thank you!'' proclaimed Mr. Jagger, and the Rolling Stones' latest rock-and-roll circus proceeded toward the inevitable fireworks of its encore.

title: Reining In a Plot While the Performers Run Free
description: Hope is the name of a racially divided Southern town where a 13-year-old named Lilly Kate Burns comes of age morally during the very week of the Cuban missile crisis, in October 1962. It is hard to imagine a more heavy-handed concept, but as the TNT movie ''Hope'' unfolds, that portent turns out to be a false alarm. This charmingly deft film is shaped by two perfectly pitched performances, one in front of the camera and one behind it.

title: Stocks Tumble, With Dow Falling 91.85
description: Stocks dropped sharply yesterday for the second consecutive day, hurt by bad news on corporate earnings, rising oil prices, fears of a United States-Japanese trade war and Government data that suggested renewed inflation.

title: CPC INTERNATIONAL PLANNING TO CHANGE ITS NAME
description: CPC International Inc. said it would change its name to Bestfoods, after it spins off its corn-refining business in January, as it seeks to emphasize its stable of brand-name packaged foods. The company, which makes Best Foods dressings, Knorr soups and Hellmann's mayonnaise, said it wanted to highlight its brands and their quality, while removing a link to its past as a corn-refining business. CPC International was once named the Corn Products Refining Company. CPC, which is based in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., decided to spin off the corn-refining unit because of its volatility as a commodity-type business. Its remaining business of packaged foods had an annual growth rate of 11 percent in both sales and earnings over the last 10 years.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: FACES OF JOY AND PAIN -- Life-changing plastic surgery for children is being celebrated in a display of the young patients' artwork at a Long Island museum. B5.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Ethnic Change Tests Mettle Of Minneapolis Liberalism
description: The Stockholm of America, this city of lutefisk and liberals has long boasted a tradition of generous social programs and enlightened views on American race relations. But for all the proudly progressive attitudes, only a tiny percentage of blacks actually lived in Minnesota, a place where a mixed-marriage once meant the union of a Swede and a Norwegian.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Plunge in Stocks Puts Worldcom's Offer for MCI at Risk
description: In what is fast becoming one of the biggest battles in Wall Street's history, Worldcom Inc. yesterday defended its $34 billion bid for the MCI Communications Corporation, as Worldcom's stock price briefly dipped below $34, a level that affects the value of its offer.

title: Touchy-Feely Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVI, DAVID
description: LEVI-David. Suddenly on October 15th. Be loved father of Jeffrey. Funeral services Sunday 9:30AM, at ''Schwartz Brothers'', Queens Blvd. and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Need a New Designer?First, Call a Talent Scout
description: PARIS  When Lanvin announced its new designer, Christina Ortiz, on Friday, and when applause rang out for Alber Elbaz and the renaissance of Guy Laroche, one powerful woman deserved the credit for pulling the strings: Floriane de Saint Pierre.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Another Big Marriage In the Accounting Industry

title: Off-Duty Police Officer Is Shot at a Nightclub
description: An off-duty police officer was shot last night in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, after a dispute broke out in a nightclub, the police said. The officer, whom the police did not identify, was shot once in the hip and was listed in stable condition at Kings County Hospital Center.

title: Of John Denver, the Man and Musician
description: John Denver was remembered today not only for his music, but also for his many humanitarian passions in life, including music, flying, children and the environment.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about final preparations at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark misstated the day of the opening. It is tonight, not last night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWE, JAMES JENKINS
description: LOWE-James Jenkins, 82. A long time resident of Bedford, New York died at his home on Friday, October 17, after a long illness. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, the former Tatiana (Tanya) Litchfield, a son James Lowe, Jr of Waterville, Maine, and two daughters, Jennifer Lowe Noble of New York, and Penelope Lowe of Danville, Vermont; a brother, Dr. William Carter Lowe of Richland, Michigan and a sister, Elizabeth Cnobloch McLean of Sarasota, Florida. Loving grandfather of Christina and Heather Lowe, Katharine and Penelope Noble. He graduated from The Kent School in 1933 and was a member of the class of 1937 at Williams College. He volunteered for service in the Navy during World War II, and served overseas. In 1959 he founded J.J. Lowe Associates, Inc, an international marketing firm dealing with the wire and cable field. He was involved in many community activities. Services will be held at Saint Matthew's Church, Bedford, New York, Monday, October 20, at 2:00PM. In lieu of flowers, you may send contributions to Saint Matthew's Church, Bedford, New York, or the James J. Lowe Scholarship Fund at Williams College, Williamstown, Massachusetts.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Being liberal in Minnesota didn't cost anything. Like being for the rain forest. It's not going to affect me.''

title: Dow Jones Is Said to Discuss Deal for Data Services Unit
description: Executives at Dow Jones & Company have met with potential partners or buyers of its troubled financial information services company, a person close to the company said yesterday.

title: L'Oreal Says Profit From Operations Rose
description: L'Oreal S.A. said yesterday that operating profit in the first half rose to 3.87 billion French francs ($66 million) from 3.44 billion a year earlier, helped by the dollar and international growth. For the full-year, L'Oreal said net profit should increase from 1996 despite about 100 million francs in additional taxes because of a 15 percent increase in corporate taxes. In 1996, L'Oreal's net profit was 3.73 billion francs.

title: Trial of Vichy Official Lifts Veil on Killing of Algerians
description: The French Government announced today that it would open secret archives relating to the killing of dozens of Algerians in Paris in 1961 after Maurice Papon, a senior functionary under both the wartime Vichy government and the postwar Republic, denied that the police he then commanded were responsible.

title: Calgary Posts First Victory
description: Flames 6, Avalanche 5

title: Ciba Specialty Chemicals Buys Mallinckrodt Unit
description: Ciba Specialty Chemicals of Switzerland said yesterday that it had bought the pre-blend additives business of Mallinckrodt Inc. of St. Louis. The Swiss company did not disclose terms of the transaction.

title: INSIDE
description: Poland Turns to Solidarity

title: BASEBALL: NOTES
description: OAKLAND

title: Clinton Vetoes Eight Projects, Two in States Of Leadership
description: President Clinton found a new use for his line item veto today, excising several of what he called ''unwarranted corporate subsidies'' from the traditionally pork-laden spending bill for energy and water development projects.

title: Africa Finds Old Borders Are Eroding
description: With the spread of war across a band of countries that spans the breadth of Central Africa, a tide of democratic change begun on the continent at the turn of the decade has been blunted by a new model: change by the gun.

title: Deal Is Close On Keeping L.I.R.R. Going
description: With the deadline for an Amtrak strike that could also cripple local commuter railroads just five days away, union leaders and Amtrak reached a tentative agreement yesterday to keep the Long Island Rail Road running into Manhattan even if a strike occurs.

title: Tourists Can Be a Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge; Teams Descend on Tunisia For Bermuda Bowl Matches
description: Two world championships, the Bermuda Bowl for Open Teams and the Venice Cup for Women's Teams, begin this weekend in Hammamet, Tunisia. The defending Bermuda Bowl champions are the United States players captained by Nick Nickell, who won two years ago in Beijing. Germany is defending its Venice Trophy title.

title: The Keys for the Marlins to Win
description: 1. Mound Character

title: NBC Official Disdains Series
description: With NBC about to begin its telecasts of the World Series tonight, an NBC entertainment executive said yesterday that he hoped one team would win in four straight games so the network could return to its entertainment programming as quickly as possible.

title: Strength in Economic Data Renews Fear of Fed Tightening
description: Just when it seemed the economy had begun slowing to a safer speed, two Government reports today renewed fears that it still was running too fast for the anti-inflation police at the Federal Reserve.

title: Arts Abroad; Less Than the Royal Treatment for Louis XIV's Music
description: William Christie is as American and as patrician as Henry James, and he is almost single-handedly responsible for the revival of French Baroque music in the land of Louis XIV. But even he has had to take a back seat within the official state-supported structure that carries the Paris Opera, the Orchestra of Paris and other heavily subsidized pillars of the French musical establishment.

title: Liberties; Murder of an Anatomy
description: It's getting more and more difficult to put out a family newspaper.

title: A Much-Recorded Maestro With Encyclopedic Taste
description: So is it now ''Neeme Jarvi: The Middle Years''? It is a heady venture on which the music world is embarked, to judge from a series of six Melodiya CD's just issued by BMG under the grand title ''Neeme Jarvi: The Early Recordings.''

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Worker Killed at Casino Site
description: A construction worker helping to expand a casino parking garage was crushed to death yesterday morning when part of the concrete foundation left from a building that had been demolished fell on him, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRENIK, HELEN (NEE HEILING)
description: KRENIK-Helen (nee Heiling). Died at age 94 in Boynton Beach, FL. Devoted wife to the late Charles Krenik. Beloved mother to Paul, Betty and the late Henri. She is survived by her grandchildren Martine, Catherine, Corinne, Gordon, Gabrielle and Giselle and caring step-grandchildren Gerard and Marc. She is also survived by her great-grandchildren Josse, Zachary, Bella and little Jeremy. She will be sorely missed. Services Sunday, Oct. 19, 10 AM, Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, LI.

title: U.S. SAYS CHINESE WILL STOP SENDING MISSILES TO IRAN
description: China has promised the Clinton Administration that it will no longer send anti-ship cruise missiles to Iran, senior American officials said today, 10 days before a state visit by China's President, Jiang Zemin.

title: Improving Giants Defense Faces a Stiff Test in Lions
description: Statistically, the Giants' defense ranks only 17th in the National Football League in yards allowed. But the defensive players insist they are a victim of statistical circumstance.

title: The Tax Agency's Layered Look
description: Before Congress and President Clinton create an oversight board to monitor the Internal Revenue Service and end taxpayer abuse at the agency, they should take another look at what made that abuse possible.

title: McCarty's Energy Adds Life To Knicks
description: Walter McCarty is the guy next to you in a traffic jam, the one tapping his fingers on the steering wheel and bobbing his head like a fishing cork. The world can put on the brakes, come to a complete standstill, but McCarty just keeps on moving.

title: Crude Oil Prices Move Lower; Cocoa Is Up and Coffee Down
description: Crude oil prices reversed early gains in late trading yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange after the State Department said that warring Kurdish factions in northern Iraq had agreed to a cease-fire, easing concern that the conflict might widen and disrupt exports from the Middle East.

title: I.B.M. Offering Voluntary Buyouts to Some
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it was offering many of its 241,000 employees a voluntary buyout plan.

title: With a Snip of Scissors, Stylists Make Their Mark : The Hands That Mold the Hair
description: PARIS  As every designer knows, it's not just the clothes that make or break a show. The hairdos are just as much a part of the fashion message, and their creators  the little known hairstylists working behind the scenes  are increasingly gaining recognition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPROW, MIRIAM LEE, PH.D.
description: KAPROW-Miriam Lee, Ph.D., Anthropologist, Scholar. Wednesday, October 15, 1997. Beloved sister of Allan Kaprow. Devoted and loving aunt of Anton & Marisa Kaprow and Amy Kaprow Mezey. Loving niece of Ida Josefson and Esther Schwartz. Cherished friend. Graveside services Sun., October 19, 11 AM, Mt. Golda Cemetery, Huntington, N.Y. A memorial service will be held Sunday, December 7, 1:45 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations to congregation Shaare Zedek, 212 West 93rd Street, NYC, 10025 or Cabrini Hospice, 227 East 19 Street, New York City 10003.

title: Lotte Goslar, Dancer and Mime, Is Dead at 90
description: Lotte Goslar, a dancer and mime known for her eccentric and whimsical comedy, died on Thursday at the Willowood Nursing Home in Great Barrington, Mass. She was 90 and lived in West Cornwall, Conn.

title: Church Has Apologized for Holocaust Inaction
description: To the Editor:

title: Runway Colors Jump Onto the Store Shelves : Makeup:Now It's for Show, Not Just for Shows
description: PARIS  A lightening bolt of blue across the eyes at Jil Sander's spring show in Milan last week was one more sign that the pale face that has dominated runways lately is on its way out.

title: Reform Family Court
description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Fits In; He's Back In the Series
description: The last time David Justice was seen or heard in a World Series in which he had a chance to effect change, the outfielder did so twice.

title: J. Crew Caught in Messy World of Finance as It Sells Majority Stake
description: The carefree models in lemon-colored turtlenecks who dot the J. Crew catalogue are far removed from the messy world of junk bonds and leveraged buyouts facing the retailer.

title: Paris Breaks Out in Fin-de-Recession Burst of New Clubs and Shops
description: PARIS  Just over a year ago, Frank Besegher was working as an undertaker at the Pere Lachaise cemetery. Now he owns a tiny and kooky cafe, Le Denicheur, where you can buy not only a goat's cheese and basil omelette, but the chair you're sitting on or the plate you're eating off.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Convict Is Held in Stalking
description: A man convicted of raping a young woman at knifepoint in 1983 was charged with stalking a 15-year-old Closter girl while carrying a knife and a woman's slip in his car, officials said yesterday.

title: At Syracuse, Ivory Tower Gets Wired for Cable; Not 'Lured Away'
description: To the Editor:

title: 1,000 Pictures Of 1 County In Kentucky
description: Forty-five photographers from around the country gathered in Logan County, Ky., last week to try to capture a glimpse of small-town America.

title: Review/Fashion; Embracing Tradition And Moving Forward
description: At Guy Laroche, Alber Elbaz has become the first of the young revivalists to indicate how an old couture house with a new designer might move forward without doing a demolition number on its history. Every chief executive who ever signed a contract with a young designer wishes to see a collection like that designed by Mr. Elbaz, one that comfortably serves tradition while appealing to a new generation.

title: About New York; Ex-Gangster On New Path, With Advice
description: FELIPE MERCADO slowly got up from the sofa -- he was tired after working all day as a building superintendent -- and ducked into the bedroom. He reappeared holding a denim jacket with cutoff sleeves, the kind that used to be seen in his Hunts Point neighborhood more often than intact ones. An arc-shaped patch on its back read ''Savage Skulls.''

title: Whitman's Husband Has Behind-the-Scenes Role
description: John R. Whitman, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's husband, said today that his wife has asked him several times to work as an ambassador with businesses or other parties with whom the state has had disputes. It was one of the first indications that Mr. Whitman plays a broader behind-the-scenes role than the public has known.

title: Church Has Apologized for Holocaust Inaction
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Ouster for Hingis
description: European Indoor

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORLIN, RICHARD, M.D.
description: GORLIN-Richard, M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital, the entire Mount Sinai community, and physicians everywhere mourn the death of our esteemed colleague Richard Gorlin, MD. An internationally renowned physician, his extraordinary intelligence and energy propelled him to major achievements in ever-widening arenas of Medicine: from basic laboratory cardiologic research, to bedside Cardiology, to medical education and most recently to health care networking. He served Mount Sinai as Chair of Medicine and Physician-in-Chief, Dr. George Baehr Professor of Clinical Medicine, President of the Medical Board, member of the AAS Board of Directors, Senior Vice President of the Mount Sinai Medical Center and Medical Director of the Mount Sinai Health System. This gentleman-scholar excelled as brilliant scientist, astute and caring clinician, inspiring teacher and role model to generations of medical students and trainees. We miss him fondly and extend our sympathy to his devoted wife Florence, his children and family. Peter H. Rubin, MD, President Lynda Mandell MD, Secretary Amy J. Weinstein, Administrator

title: Richard Gorlin, 71, Cardiologist; Devised Diagnostic Method
description: Dr. Richard Gorlin, a cardiologist who developed a method of diagnosing critical blockage of a heart valve without using surgery, died on Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 71, and had homes in Manhattan and Bedford Hills, N.Y.

title: Editor of New Woman Quits, Owner Says
description: Betsy Carter has resigned as editor of New Woman magazine, the publication's owner, the Rodale Press, said yesterday.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Chardonnay

title: English Channel Ferries Try to One-Up the Tunnel
description: STILL suffering from the increased competition occasioned by the opening of the Channel Tunnel in 1994, the ferry companies that cross the Channel are introducing faster boats, better service and more alluring special offers in an effort to keep the passengers coming.

title: QUICK BITE/Union City; From Argentina, a Cake Worth Celebrating
description: Bring on the birthdays. The anniversaries. The class reunions. I've discovered a cake worthy of a place of honor at ceremonies marking the passage of time. And it's not even chocolate.

title: VIEWPOINT; When Victimhood Runs the System
