description: THE ink was barely dry on the tobacco settlement last June, when Richard Scruggs, a Mississippi trial lawyer who represented 25 states in talks with the industry, acknowledged in The Wall Street Journal that the fees he and his colleagues would end up collecting might seem ''a little obscene.''

title: Itinerant Subversive
description: SPEAKING FREELY A Memoir. By Nat Hentoff. 303 pages. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: Do Guards Need a Guard?
description: Rodolfo A. Altieri recently paid $215,000 for a two-story house in Astoria Heights. ''It seemed like a good deal,'' he said. The price was right, the local grade school is among the best in Astoria and the house is on a quiet residential block, or so Mr. Altieri thought.

title: Spotlighting Two Shows: A Medley, and Drawings
description: TWO group exhibitions, one with a message and one without. The first is a medley of assemblages, paintings and works on paper by 24 Latin American women, occupying the Castle Gallery at the College of New Rochelle. This is an appropriate setting, for while the college now admits men, it began its career in 1904 as the state's first Roman Catholic institution of higher learning for women, one oriented to the needs of immigrants. The other show, at the Pelham Art Center, is of drawings by 15 artists, most of them women, and, it would seem, most home grown.

title: Q. & A.
description: Renovating Rental Unit In a Co-op

title: St. Louis Sights
description: To the Editor: Your otherwise informative article ''What's Doing in St. Louis'' (Sept. 7) missed two very interesting places.

title: VIEWPOINT; Clinical Trials as Inside Information
description: THE Securities and Exchange Commission recently served notice that it intends to go after individuals who trade on a unique form of inside information -- clinical trial results. Just last month, the S.E.C. filed insider-trading charges against a Columbia University neurologist who had helped Cephalon Inc. evaluate its new drug to treat Lou Gehrig's disease. The S.E.C. contended that the neurologist illegally bought Cephalon stock after getting advance knowledge of the drug's promising performance in a clinical trial.

title: Suzanne Meadow, Peter Glaser
description: Suzanne Meadow, a daughter of Marla W. Frankel of Larchmont, N.Y., and David Meadow of Victor, Mont., is to be married this afternoon to Peter Michael Glaser, a son of Carole Glaser of Southbury, Conn., and Dr. Howard S. Glaser of Newtown, Conn. Town Justice Harold S. Klein of Greenburg, N.Y., is to officiate at Estherwood, a historic house on the grounds of the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: Hall of Fame Honors Cars and Their Creators
description: A new automotive museum has just opened next to the Motor City.

title: Laura Eisenberg, Todd Balestro
description: Laura Lyn Eisenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Eisenberg of Rumson, N.J., was married at her parents' house last evening to Todd Anthony Balestro, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Balestro of Ada, Mich., and Bedminster, N.J. Rabbi Joseph Goldman performed the ceremony with the Rev. Joseph Hughes, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPLOWITZ, GERTRUDE ZELDA ROBINSON GOLD
description: KOPLOWITZ-Gertrude Zelda Robinson Gold, January 16, 1914October 12, 1997, of River Vale, New Jersey, has passed on. Beloved wife to the late Harry Gold, then to the late Sol Koplowitz. She is survived by her loving daughter, Diane Gold Levitt, and grandchildren, Jaden and Janna Levitt. She was a loving and devoted mother and proud and joyous grandmother. Mother by marriage to Herb and the late Rita, and their spouses, grandmother of same to Isabel, Juliet, Matthew, Jesse, great-grandmother of same, with special pride, to Zel. Special friend to Mildred and Selma. Ex-motherin-law to Jaren. Gertrude loved you all easily and completely. Your love in return sustained her. Gertrude, avid patron of the arts, lived for sharing smiles, helping people and spreading joy.

title: '87 Crash: The Other News
description: Where were you when the lights went out on Wall Street?

title: The World; The 21st Century Belongs to . . .
description: LISTENING to President Clinton's speeches in Latin America last week, audiences might have concluded that Washington's economic hopes and preoccupations lay to the south. But wait a week. Next Sunday, China's President, Jiang Zemin, arrives in the United States for an official visit. And chances are that visions of a vast Chinese market with a bottomless appetite for consumer goods -- or of a repressive and militaristic China -- will relegate every other place to the sidelines again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCULLY, LEONARD TYSON, COLONEL, U.S.A.
description: SCULLY-Leonard Tyson, Colonel, U.S.A. Died October 17, 1997 at his home in Pound Ridge, New York. He is survived by his wife Jean Scully. Colonel Scully was formerly President of Excelsior Income Shares, Inc. and a retired Officer of United States Trust Company of New York. He served on the Boards of a number of charitable organizations. Funeral services are private. Burial will be at Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Baby Found Dead in Brooklyn Apartment
description: A 2-month-old baby boy was found dead yesterday in an apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, and seven other children found at the scene were placed in protective custody, city officials said. The child, whom the police did not identify, was pronounced dead on arrival at Interfaith Medical Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULMAN, HARRY
description: SHULMAN-Harry. Born September 3, 1924. Died October 17, 1997. He was loved dearly by his wife and best friend of 47 years Bernice (Saloshin); his children Howard, and Lori Miller (Philip) and his many friends, students, colleagues in the NYC School System where he taught with dedication for 32 years. Services Sunday, 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The View From: Milford Point; Lessons From the Shore On What's Out There
description: SARAH VAN DINE, 9 years old, looked up excitedly through the light mist as dozens of songbirds suddenly appeared overhead, noisily flying in a flock across the gray-blue sky toward Long Island Sound.

title: Farmers Say Sunny Days Improved Crop Quality
description: DRY and sunny weather in the summer and fall have browned suburban lawns but stimulated the agricultural industry on the East End, where a good year for farmers increases farm and field preservation.

title: Vvt-vvvvvt! Let the LP's Rip and Roll
description: ''TWO TURNTABLES AND A MICROPHONE'' may be a refrain to a Beck hit, but on a recent night at a club in lower Manhattan, it's a reality. Stepping onto the stage, a man takes his place behind two record players. He sets up a beat with a drum machine, places an LP onto each turntable, plops down the stylus and begins manually rotating the LP's back and forth.

title: A Portrait of the Artist as an Orphan
description: The World is

title: A Chip of Things to Come?
description: WHEN Citibank, Chase, Mastercard and Visa introduced a new money chip on the Upper West Side, they called it a convenient way to do without coins and paper cash. They are passing out scads of free cards and electronic reading devices so customers and merchants can try out the new technology. They're even giving out free money: the first time you load up with electronic cash, you get either $5 or $25 extra loaded onto the chip that is embedded in your bank card.

title: The Case Against Tipping
description: Michael Lewis's article ''The Case Against Tipping'' (Sept. 21) brought me a warm feeling on a cool last day of summer: I am not alone! Tip-o-phobia is a common human trait.

title: How to Judge Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: In New Jersey Governor's Debate, Focus on Taxes and Car Rates
description: Locked in a tight ace, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and State Senator James E. McGreevey used their first televised debate to draw sharp contrasts today between their approaches to the two biggest campaign issues: property taxes and auto insurance.

title: SOAPBOX; Lots of Luck
description: RESERVED parking places for the handicapped have been around so long that they've faded into the landscape. Now, some new signs have sprung up in supermarket parking lots in Monmouth County: ''Reserved Parking for Customers Accompanied by Infants or Toddlers.'' ''Reserved for Expectant Mothers.''

title: Take Only as Directed
description: THE SPIRIT CATCHES YOU AND YOU FALL DOWN A Hmong Child, Her American Doctors, and the Collision of Two Cultures. By Anne Fadiman. 339 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24.

title: Penn State's Late Heroics Nip Minnesota
description: This time, Curtis Enis's fourth-quarter heroics spared Penn State humiliation, instead of earning it respect.

title: Ideas & Trends; Modern Creed For Ancient Church
description: SOME have called it ''the greening of the Bible.'' In Europe they talk about ''eco-missionaries.'' In the United States, a recent magazine headline asked, ''Science and God: A Warming Trend?''

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; Becoming American 101
description: When Kyra Voss, a teacher at the Riverside Language School, walks into English-only class every day, she encounters a pained silence. In the small yellow room, prim as a kindergarten, 25 students from the Ukraine, Nepal, Taiwan, Colombia, Uzbekistan, Bosnia, Croatia, Latvia, Russia and the Ivory Coast avoid one another's glances. They look wrong in their chairs -- too big, tired, old or anxious for school, adults thrust back into the world of early childhood, struggling for speech.

title: Guggenheim Built in Spain Opens Under Militant Cloud
description: When the new Guggenheim Museum Bilbao opens to the public on Sunday, visitors entering the strikingly unusual titanium and stone-covered building will walk past bouquets of flowers marking the spot where a Basque policeman was shot and fatally wounded this week while foiling a terrorist attack.

title: They Want To Live
description: I was captivated by your series of articles on what technology is doing to us. Employing adjectives like ''better,'' ''faster'' and ''daring'' seemed appropriate as subheads. Under ''optimistic,'' Alex Heard (''They Want to Live,'' Sept. 28) writes about a fascinating group of ''scientists'' and health buffs who are manipulating their bodies through the use of calorie-restricted diets, antioxidant supplements and cryonics in the hope that they will somehow achieve superlongevity. Although George Lange captured in his subtly conceptual photographs some of the more bizarre and ghoulish figures in this strange subculture, only in passing did Heard mention the possibly disastrous social implications that life spans of 200 to 500 years would deliver. I would not call that optimistic. I'd call it scary.

title: Technology Makes Us ...
description: Who put the ''nano'' in the Nanosecond Nineties? The New York Times Magazine, that's who! Thanks for your way cool issue ''Technology Makes Us ...'' (Sept. 28).

title: Addicted to Speed
description: In ''Addicted to Speed'' (Sept. 28), James Gleick notes that NBC is trying to squeeze an additional 15 to 20 seconds into an evening's programming (read: advertising) by excising the imperceptible periods when the screen actually goes black between programming and commercial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPAISMAN, JOSEPH
description: SPAISMAN-Joseph. Beloved husband of Zyporah. Devoted father and father-in-law of Ben and Sally. Cherished grandfather of Erica and Elliot. Services today 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76th and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: The Series Attracts A Big Crowd of Yore
description: Not since the days of Mickey Mantle had such a large crowd witnessed a World Series: Game 1 tonight at Pro Player Stadium drew 67,245 fans, the largest gathering in the World Series since Oct. 2, 1963, in a game at Yankee Stadium between the Dodgers and Yankees that drew 69,000.

title: BOOKEND; The Morning After the Night Before
description: Based on the calendar year, ''A Book of Days for the Literary Year'' (Thames and Hudson, 1984) informs readers about dates and events in the lives of literary figures throughout history. Here are some things that might have happened on the mornings after some of the events therein described.

title: Breast Cancer on TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Praising the Power of Intel
description: THE Intel Corporation's ubiquitous slogan -- ''Intel Inside'' -- could just as well apply to the November batch of personal-finance magazines as it does to personal computers.

title: Black Women With Cancer Find Support in Their Own Group
description: Like other black women who have battled breast cancer, Karen Jackson found the odds stacked against her when she learned the fearsome diagnosis three years ago.

title: Next Stop, Carnegie Hall
description: ANTHONY PICCOLO'S Imaginary Symphony No. 1 was being rehearsed in the Norwalk Concert Hall by 261 youngsters recently, in preparation for performing at Carnegie Hall on Thursday.

title: Disinflation, Anyone? Prices of New Cars Are Declining, for a Change
description: CAR and truck prices are falling, for the first time since the nation entered its current period of economic expansion in 1991.

title: For the Tapes of a Master, It's Worth the Wait
description: THEY MAY HAVE HAD THEIR differences, but now that the tapes are available, everybody involved with the project agrees that home video has stepped forward to do one of the jobs it is intended to do: acquaint people with a great filmmaker who is relatively unknown in this country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, IDA
description: SILVERMAN-Ida. Beloved sister, sister-in-law, aunt and great aunt. She was loved by all who knew her. Died on October 9, 1997.

title: Finance Debate Spans the Political Spectrum
description: Many Americans may think that the debate over how political campaigns are financed is simply an inside-the-Beltway battle between a Republican-controlled Congress and a Democrat in the White House.

title: Crying Is Best Done In Public
description: IT was her party and she was going to cry if she wanted to, but first Fiona Apple did the right thing. The tiny pop star followed the orders of her publicity agent, a young woman named Luke Burland, as obediently as a cadet in boot camp, posing for the requisite photo ops and pouting for posterity. She looked like a Keane child -- big sad eyes in an oval face, the Gen-X version of a Salinger whiz kid.

title: Who's Fairest? For Tots, an Early Lesson
description: Parents said they scrimped and saved so everybody could see how beautiful their babies were. They coached them to wave to the judges, though the babies apparently could not have cared less. Many of the young ones sucked bottles, the boys with red cummerbunds over their diapers and the girls in earrings and real leather shoes.

title: Miss Mesologites, Mr. Keslonsky
description: Melanie Mesologites, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Mesologites of Kings Point, N.Y., was married in Manhattan yesterday to David Keslonsky, a son of Stanley Keslonsky of Commack, N.Y., and the late Sylvia Keslonsky. Justice Harold Tompkins of State Supreme Court in Queens officiated at the Metropolitan Club.

title: October 12-18; Insurers Even the Odds Between Cars and Trucks
description: It might seem self-evident: sport utility vehicles and pickups cause more damage to other vehicles and their occupants in collisions than passenger cars, which weigh much less. But insurers have long charged the same liability rates for all, using the profits from cars to cover losses from the bigger, higher-riding sport utilities.

title: Technology Makes Us ...
description: I always look forward to settling in with the Magazine, picking and choosing stuff that interests me. This time, nothing. I was at first depressed. My mood shifted to one of hostility combined with feelings of techno-inadequacy. I worry that all I know is obsolete or will be when I awaken tomorrow. Go back, please, to the format that helps us know a little bit about a lot of things. Massage our egos.

title: Tight Is Right
description: It might seem that all one needs to get rich fast is a good logo. Not so, said John Flynn, the managing director of Fred Perry Ltd. in London. The Perry laurel, familiar to tennis fans, was licensed in the United States in 1992 to the Action Sports Group, a clothing company. After a poor showing, it was given up last year. ''The kind of thing they were making had a very traditional American fit, big and baggy,'' he said. Not the way to the body-conscious heart.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: PLAIN SEEING

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 5 about investing in blue-chip Russian companies misstated the market position of one such concern, Vimpelcom, in cellular phone service in Russia. It is No. 1, not No. 2.

title: Masters Of an Art Keep Busy
description: The City section's plea for urban haiku, offered two weeks ago, continues to draw an enormous response. Some writers offered their reaction to the dozens of haikus that were published last Sunday, all in three unrhymed lines with five syllables, seven and five. One writer published last week, Jeanne Marie Monaghan, wrote another haiku reflecting on her new fame: ''Thanks for the mention/Will this be deducted from/my fifteen minutes?'' Here are some others:

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; Kimchi Alley
description: Korean food is so exhilarating that from my very first bite, all I have wanted is more. Asia's most robust cuisine combines everyone's favorite flavors: sugar, salt, spice and peppers. It is fresh, healthy and low in cholesterol. Koreans graze through every meal, cooking at the table and eating with their fingers. Yet even in New York, this fascinating food remains a mystery. Why? A midnight stroll across 32d Street, in Manhattan's Koreatown, offers a couple of answers.

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; Vinnie From Queens, You're on the Fan!
description: Ten years ago, a struggling New York AM country music station known mostly as the radio home of the New York Mets made an abrupt and risky format change: WHN became WFAN, the nation's first all-sports talk radio station. After a slow start, the concept exploded, making WFAN one of the leading stations in the market and spawning more than 150 sports-talk imitators across the country.

title: Q and A
description: Renting a Yacht

title: Runners Go to Dublin to Aid Leukemia Cause
description: VICKIE FOULKE, Karen Colin and 26 others will be doing some long-distance running a long distance from here on Oct. 27. Ms. Foulke, from Larchmont, and Ms. Colan, who lives in Mamaroneck, and the 26 other runners will be in the Dublin Marathon in Ireland, raising money to battle leukemia here in Westchester.

title: Katherine Oettinger, 94, Expert on Retardation
description: Katherine B. Oettinger, an authority on the care and upbringing of children, who was head of the Federal agency for the care of handicapped and underprivileged children, died on Monday in Carmel, Calif. She was 94.

title: The Nation; Drip, Drip, Drip
description: It has become a familiar refrain of frustration among investigators who have scrutinized the Clinton Administration: important evidence requested in subpoenas pops up months, even years, after it is first sought. The White House has maintained that in each instance the delays were inadvertent, though critics have found them to be too numerous to be attributed to mere coincidence.

title: The Wonders of Day 1
description: It's the company welcome packet: that collection of papers, supplies and so on, issued when you start work. It reveals a lot about the place: A certificate for a free lunch (not to exceed $6), a towel for the company gym, a recyclable coffee cup, a 10-year-old policy statement on drug abuse. What was included in your company's package? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: The Nation; Becoming Unstuck On the Suburbs
description: PLYWOOD has a lifespan of 40 years. Over time, the glue that holds plywood together dries up. Then, walls buckle, split and peel. Panels pop loose. Rooms, doors and windows morph into trick-or-treat versions of themselves. Suburban America, this is to say, is becoming unstuck.

title: Designer Houses For the Poor
description: My compliments to Samuel Mockbee (Designer Houses for the Poor,'' by Amy Virshup, Sept. 21). I've worked for Habitat over the last three years and have been bothered by the houses I'm asked to build -- they have little or no architectural merit. While I'm afraid the same can be said for the vast majority of commercially built homes, at least I'm not contributing to them. With Mockbee's work as proof that low cost does not preclude good design, I hope I can convert the local chapter -- or else get them to stick to rehab.

title: Miniatures That Make a Diary
description: BY 1910 Arthur Dove was referring to his paintings as abstractions. He was the first American painter to use the term, and only the Russian-born Wassily Kandinsky, whose work Dove knew, could challenge him for the title of first abstract painter in Western culture. Dove (1880-1946) is also seen as a decisive influence on the Abstract Expressionists, but for all his influence, his work itself isn't as well known as it should be.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLER, MIRIAM A.
description: HANDLER-Miriam A. Age 82. Died on October 16, 1997 after a long illness. Cherished wife of Professor Milton Handler; devoted mother of Carole E. Handler; adored grandmother of Lisi and Lani Schoenbach; beloved sister of Milton Adler & Avivah Benamy; beloved aunt of Dr. Daniel Adler, Denise Jaffe, Elan Benamy; dedicated grand-aunt of numerous nieces and nephews. Her rare beauty was matched by her charm and dedicated service to the various philanthropies in which she played a leading role. The family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, on Saturday, October 18th between the hours of 7 and 9 PM. Funeral services will be held at the Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th Street & Madison Ave, Sunday, October 19th at 10:30 AM. Burial private.

title: Public Defender
description: ARCHIBALD COX

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYSZKIEWICZ, ALICIA. COUNTESS TYSZKIEWICZ
description: TYSZKIEWICZ-Alicia. Countess Tyszkiewicz. Born May 28, 1912, died October 8, 1997 at her home in New York City. Full of courage and true to her own high standards to the end. Mourned by her friends, Isabelle Cazeaux, Ruth M. Collins, Fernando Demarquet, Robert Hickey.

title: The Nation; How Washington Remembers, and Forgets
description: ALMOST everyone who's anyone here seems to take copious notes. But tape recordings are rare nowadays, and no one keeps a diary any more.

title: Big, Bold Effort Revives the Danube Wetlands
description: Marius Condac, a wildlife warden in the immense delta of the Danube River, remembers when a sudden frenzy rippled through this quiet, waterlogged world, one where change is normally measured by the rising and falling of the seasonal floods, by the reed harvest or the nesting of pelicans.

title: Park vs. Putting: Chelsea Disputes A Plan for Pier 62
description: For Chelsea residents who have long dreamed of a riverfront public park, Pier 62 seems like the perfect site for a small public green. And for once, the owners of Chelsea Piers, which holds the lease on the slip, agree with the locals.

title: Another Line Is Drawn in Pedestrian War Against Sidewalk Cyclists
description: Hurtling through crowds, they are the nemesis of many a New Yorker, and a menace the city has long tried to curtail. But while many strategies have been tried of late to stop bicyclists from riding illegally on sidewalks, none of those measures -- regulations, fines and even the seizure of bikes -- is as concrete, so to speak, as the one to be announced tomorrow by the city's Department of Transportation.

title: Castles in the Air
description: PFITZ By Andrew Crumey. 164 pp. New York: Picador USA. $20.

title: Investing With Religious Principle Will Often Yield Fewer Loaves
description: SHOULD faith be a factor when it comes to managing your money?

title: Laurel Hollow And Route 25A
description: Once again you have broached the issue of Route 25A and once again, despite the title ''How the Towns View Changes to Route 25A'' (Oct. 5), no attempt was made to get input from our village, although the project is located almost entirely in Laurel Hollow, not in Cold Spring Harbor.

title: Hospital Workers Say McDonald's Means Unhappy Meals
description: Many employees at Elmhurst Hospital Center are as fired up as a spicy beef patty. The reason: a decision by the hospital to contract out the operation of its cafeteria to the McDonald's Corporation.

title: Killing Sets Stage for Fight Over E-Mail to California Newspaper
description: A murder trial in California is turning into a first test of a newspaper's right to shield its readers' E-mail and Internet use from a defense lawyer's claim that electronic coverage of a case can taint a jury pool.

title: October 12-18; Even Spies Have Budgets
description: The Central Intelligence Agency let fall a pillar of cold-war policy, revealing for the first time how much the United States spends annually for intelligence: $26.6 billion for the C.I.A. and a dozen other intelligence services.

title: So Far, Just 1929 and 1987 Are Under His Belt
description: ROY R. NEUBERGER, a founder of the money management firm of Neuberger & Berman, started work on Wall Street in 1929 and is still managing money. His autobiography, ''So Far, So Good -- the First 94 Years,'' has just been published by John Wiley & Sons. He was asked about the two crashes he has seen. FLOYD NORRIS

title: C. W. Gottschalk, 75, Doctor Who Studied Kidneys, Dies
description: Dr. Carl W. Gottschalk, whose work rewrote the textbooks on how the kidney sorts and conserves water, and who played an important role in the extending of Medicare to cover dialysis for patients in the final stages of renal failure, died on Wednesday in Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: Premium Shock
description: ON a gloomy day in April, Paul Pugliese strapped a wooden barrel around his nearly naked body, glued an auto inspection sticker to his chest and headed to a protest rally at the foot of the State House steps.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDER, JAMES
description: EDER-James, 85, of San Diego, October 12, 1997. Beloved father of Martin and Nancy Maria; grandfather of Ana Maria and Daniel. Devoted brother of Linda Storrow and uncle of Margot Witty and Fran Jamieson-Unger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN EYRE, PAUL
description: VAN EYRE-Paul. Of Red Hook, NY on October 13, 1997. Son, brother, uncle, friend. Mourned and missed by so many, leaving a legacy of everlasting love. Interment private. Memorial contributions to charity of choice.

title: Books Unbound
description: One afternoon in 1939, Jorge Luis Borges and a couple of fellow writers plotted a story (never written) in which the young admirer of a mysterious and famous author traveled to his hero's castle and discovered among the master's papers a list of ''Things to Avoid in Literature.''

title: 29 of 80 Potential Jurors Have Qualified to Serve in Bomb Trial
description: A potential juror at the Oklahoma City bombing trial today recalled his own encounter with explosives, when on a January afternoon as a 15-year-old, he had gone outdoors to play with black powder and blown off his right hand.

title: In Merger, Catholic Hospital Can Compromise; Community Protests
description: To the Editor:

title: J.F.K. Tape Transcripts Weren't Sanitized
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Makes Me Mad
description: The only page of your Sept. 28 issue I was able to understand was the one written by Patricia Volk. Her Lives column ''Technology Makes Me Mad'' made me laugh out loud. I am 80, and I find my one shield against the great cyber onslaught is my sense of humor.

title: Stateside Lingo Gives Japan Its Own Valley Girls
description: With the forces of globalization gaining ground every day, perhaps it is not surprising that 15-year-old Japanese girls like Kaori Hasegawa use English expressions like ''chekaraccho.''

title: Orie M. Wittek, Howard J. Mass
description: Dr. Orie Marie Wittek and Dr. Howard Jeffrey Mass are to be married this afternoon at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan. The Rev. Eugene Prior will perform the ceremony in which Rabbi Charles Lippman will take part.

title: Keeping Vacation Homes in the Family
description: ON these fleeting fall days, Angelica and Luke Emery-Fertitta, ages 6 and 2 respectively, can still capture some of the joys of summer. With a 360-degree view from the family vacation house on majestic Madaket Beach here, they stroll the shore some 50 feet from their front door with their parents and grandparents, or meet up with their cousins, Vanessa, 9, and Kelly, 6, for a game of tag.

title: INSIDE
description: MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 8/ Funds operated by or for religious believers offer a way to put your money where your heart is. By Nick Ravo.

title: Mythology Is Taught
description: To the Editor:

title: A Curious Voyage Into Uncharted O'Neill
description: THE VAGUELY deconstructionist production of ''More Stately Mansions,'' now at New York Theater Workshop (through next Sunday), has its isolated, sometimes quite arresting rewards. Yet it is less a presentation of an essentially realistic play than a stylized analysis of it, performed as if it were a religious rite so familiar that much of its language need not be understood but heard only as the drone of remembered cadences. If you don't know the catechism, you often won't have a clue as to what's going on.

title: ART REVIEW ; A Native Son, At Home and Abroad
description: BRIDGING Trenton and New Hope,'' an exhibition of paintings and watercolors plus some ephemera by Graham Holmes (1908-1981) at the Trenton City Museum, presents an artist who painted from here to Shanghai, Venice and Havana. Although some of his foreign pictures dot the exhibition, his strongest and steadiest work was local.

title: Accounting Magic Erases Big Loss
description: For a corporate executive who must meet Wall Street expectations every quarter, a dream come true would be to have a couple of months that would pass unnoticed. There would be no need to pump up sales, and every reason to take all possible expenses.

title: The Case Against Tipping
description: Michael Lewis has me trying to figure out why we tip anybody. And that includes waiters, bartenders, cabdrivers, hairdressers, moving men, delivery boys, supers -- the list is endless. I'm waiting for those tipping cups to start appearing in banks.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Cynthia McIntyre; Helping People Learn to Save Money
description: CYNTHIA MCINTYRE of Newtown spends her days learning how to save money, and then passing her tips on to other people. Though it isn't exactly how the Kansas-born wife and mother of two envisioned her career niche, Mrs. McIntyre is determined to see her family not only survive but prosper on her husband's salary.

title: BENEFITS
description: Dining Afloat

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; The Demonization Of the Upper West Side
description: Ruth W. Messinger seemed startled by the question. It was a Sunday evening, at the last television debate before the Democratic primary for Mayor in New York, and the moderator was pressing her to explain her ideology: How does she define herself politically? Is Ruth Messinger a progressive? An old-style Democrat? A new-style Democrat? A liberal? A reformer? Messinger is unquestionably a living symbol of the Upper West Side, the intellectual and ideological stamping ground for a generation of district leaders, activists, state legislators, city council leaders and members of Congress, most of whom would have a quick answer to the question. But Messinger hedged her way through the exchange. ''I define myself as someone who, in a long 20-year history of public service, and before that, has always fought for what I believe is right, having been willing to stand up against special interests,'' she said. ''I don't find the labels useful.''

title: Essay; Leaky Boat to China
description: Could a Jewish merchant have preceded Marco Polo to China and returned to tell his tale in full and pungent detail? The thought is intriguing. Why not, one might ask? We know that there were communities of Jews in China for many centuries before Polo traveled there. Many centuries before Polo, also, Arab merchants opened up regular trade routes by sea with China, with networks of commercial entrepots stretching from the Persian Gulf and the western coast of India through southeast Asia to Fujian province. Jewish merchants certainly explored part of this route, and communities of Jews were scattered along it. The Spanish Jew known to us as Benjamin of Tudela traveled in the years 1169 and 1170 from Barcelona to Constantinople and thence to Baghdad and Basra, leaving a brief report of what he saw and of the Jewish communities he encountered along the way. He mentions some of the ports on the Indian coast, notes that it took 23 days by sea to get from southern India to Ceylon and, in an aside that has tantalized readers ever since, adds that from Ceylon ''to cross over to the land of Zin is a voyage of 40 days. Zin is in the uttermost East.''

title: FILM; A Fanciful, Haunting Tale of Influence
description: IMAGINE THAT SOMEWHERE IN heaven there is a bar, a luminous, fashionable place with a sparkling clientele and an endless supply of the best cocktails. Membership is limited, though; its doors are open only to a few. This is the bar where dead authors go to brag about their earthly legacies. F. Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald are there, bickering and boozing but safe in the knowledge that they are immortalized as literature's golden couple. P. G. Wodehouse orders a stiff Scotch and gazes down upon a world where his name is well known and his works well respected. Somebody buys James Thurber a drink because, after all, he has had his face on a postage stamp.

title: For a Newcomer, the Screen Is Its Signature
description: TIRED of the ''if it bleeds, it leads'' school of television news? Since June 30, viewers in the New York region have been able to tune out the gore, at least between the hours of 6 A.M. and 6 P.M., by tuning in to the all-news programming of Bloomberg Television, carried on WPXN, Channel 31.

title: Marlins Star Is a Hero Cuba Ignores
description: Orlando Hernandez was relaxing in his living room last Sunday evening when a neighbor burst into his small house near the airport here, excited and agitated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISTLER, BETSY
description: DISTLER-Betsy, an extraordinary human being. The President, a Fellow, a Training Analyst and a Supervisor of the Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research. A creative person who was a source of love, a pillar of strength, and a well of understanding for her husband David, her sons Daniel and Josh, and countless friends, colleagues, patients and students, even through her ten year private battle with breast cancer. Her life will be a continuing inspiration. She will be dearly missed. Funeral service will be held Sunday at 1:45 PM, at the Plaza Memorial Chapel, at 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations to Betsy Distler Memorial Fund, at IPTAR.

title: Skip Away Again Captures Gold Cup
description: For the second year in a row, Skip Away won the $1 million Jockey Club Gold Cup yesterday, and for the second year in a row he won it with fanfare. Last year, he nudged the great Cigar by the length of his head. This time, he won by 6 1/2 lengths over Instant Friendship.

title: STAGE VIEW; Of Henrik Pontoppidan and Other Literary Laureates
description: I REMEMBER WONDERING aloud years ago why the Neapolitan playwright Eduardo De Filippo, who died in 1984, never seemed to get the Nobel Prize for literature, and being told by colleagues it was because he was an actor and stage director.

title: In the Region/Long Island; In Low-Cost Housing, the Key Is Selling Fast
description: BUILDING moderately priced houses for mostly first-time buyers may not be as lucrative as targeting a higher-income market. But builders say the payoff comes in generating faster sales, thus greatly lowering carrying costs.

title: Gail V. Benson, Scott Berkenblit
description: Gail Valerie Benson, the daughter of Patricia and Alan L. Benson of Oetrange, Luxembourg, is to be married this afternoon to Dr. Scott Ira Berkenblit, a son of Sarita and Ronald H. Berkenblit of Long Beach, N.Y. Rabbi Beverly Lerner is to officiate and the Rev. Dean Wolfe, an Episcopal priest, is to take part in the ceremony at Stillington Hall, a historic house in Gloucester, Mass.

title: Investigating a Rash of SIDS Deaths, Exposing Infanticide
description: ''FIRST, do no harm'' is a basic tenet of the medical profession. A new book, ''The Death of Innocents: A True Story of Murder, Medicine and High-Stakes Science'' by a husband-and-wife team of journalists, Richard Firstman and Jamie Talan, details case histories where physicians, blinded by ambition and dogma, colluded in the worst kind of harm -- the deaths of helpless, healthy babies.

title: Clearance Sale
description: ONE POINT SAFE

title: The Festival Man
description: JUST off Fieldcrest Avenue in the vast, anonymous patchwork of grass and asphalt of the Raritan Center industrial park is a huge tent that glows white in the night. At 11 P.M. on a Friday, the streams of cars and vans entering the parking lot haven't yet congealed into a mini-jam, and the lines of people at the ticket windows inside are equally smooth.

title: Cornell Outlasts Lafayette to End Streak
description: Cornell 41, Lafayette 34

title: Amy Koppelman, Kenneth Kahn
description: Amy Beth Koppelman, the daughter of Lewis B. Koppelman of New York and the late Roberta Koppelman, is to be married this evening to Kenneth Franklin Kahn, a son of Sheila and Ezra Kahn of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Andrew N. Bachman is to perform the ceremony at the Essex House in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INGBER, ANNA HARRIS
description: INGBER-Anna Harris passed away on Wednesday, October 15, 1997 in Los Angeles, California. She was 93 years old and the wife of the late Nathan Ingber. She will be remembered by those she left behind for her unselfishness, her caring, her sense of humor, and her deep and passionate love for her children, grandchildren, and great grandchildren. She was loved by all who knew her, her family and friends from New York to Los Angeles. Her generous spirit will far outlive her life on this earth. We will miss her deeply and remember her for the way that she touched all of our hearts. Services and interment are private. Forever, Fran and Alfie, Jamie, Laurie and Paul, Sara and Ben

title: Bill Clinton's Smoking Tape
description: There is no telling what it takes to meet Janet Reno's ever-shifting definition of ''specific and credible evidence'' of an intent to break the campaign laws. But the White House's latest fund-raising videotape is smoking with evidence that would interest a less blinkered Attorney General. On Dec. 7, 1995, President Clinton told a group of contributors that the Democratic National Committee's so-called issue ads on television were, in fact, being used to drive his poll numbers in states where he had failed to get electoral votes in 1992. He also confirmed that the White House was using the D.N.C. as a shield to avoid the $1,000 limit on individual contributions to candidate advertising. Taken with Dick Morris's revelation that Mr. Clinton designed the television ads, this videotape shows that the White House had a thoroughgoing plan to operate outside the Federal Election Campaign Act's spending limits.

title: Harry Chapin: All His Life Was a Circle
description: ''HARRY was a jack-of-all-trades with the soul of a salesman,'' the singer Pete Seeger said of his friend, Harry Chapin. ''That's nothing to be ashamed of, if the product is good. His legacy goes on, not just in his music but in his public spirit.''

title: Secrets and Lies
description: THE HIDDEN WRITER

title: Stacey M. Boyd, Scott W. Hamilton
description: Stacey Maureen Boyd, a daughter of Loretta R. Boyd of Essex Fells, N.J., and John A. Boyd of Cape May, N.J., was married yesterday to Scott Weston Hamilton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight A. Hamilton of Denver. The Rev. David A. Westcott, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Warren United Church in Warren, Vt.

title: Two Omitted Villages On the North Shore
description: It was surprising to note that the Village of Sands Point was omitted from the map and article on North Shore homes, wealth and people in the Long Island section (Oct. 5).

title: SHOPPING WITH: Anna Sui; Still a Mod, Mod, Mod, Mod World
description: NEW YORK is slowly losing its cloistered corners untouched by the trendy march of time. Now that even Le Cirque has gone mod, it is certainly time to sit back on a zebra-striped banquette in Pucci leggings with a tomato-red Kelly bag and reflect.

title: Spalding Gray Finds Solace in Sag Harbor
description: IT is autumn in Sag Harbor. Pumpkins lie in fields longside the road. Main Street is quiet, the crowds having all gone back to the city. A New England-like aura, a Puritan calm, has descended upon this seaside village. So too has Spalding Gray.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: New Dimension for WNET: A Store of Knowledge

title: American Originals From 2 Different Worlds
description: PAUL ROBESON and Lou Harrison, to be honored in age-related tributes at Rutgers University next week, are 20th-century American men of music. Next April 9 is the centenary of the birth of Robeson, 1919 valedictorian at Rutgers, member of Phi Beta Kappa and All-American college football player. Mr. Harrison's tribute observes the California composer's 80th birthday last May 14. Thereabouts, the similarity ends: one sang; the other doesn't.

title: In Era of Short Allegiances, Leyland and Bonilla Enjoy Longstanding Bond
description: The Marlins' practice here on Thursday was like any of the hundreds Jim Leyland and Bobby Bonilla have shared in, as manager and player, except that nearby, some guy was painting a World Series logo next to the Florida dugout. Leyland wielded a fungo bat and hit grounders to infielders, as Bonilla took batting practice.

title: Finn Paces Quakers Past Lions
description: When Penn's Jim Finn fumbled the ball away on the 2-yard line early in the game yesterday, he did not have time to sulk or worry about his mistake.

title: Gail Goldman And Craig Tifford
description: Gail Brooke Goldman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Goldman of Westport, Conn., was married last evening to Dr. Craig Daniel Tifford, the son of Lois A. Turner of Dix Hills, N.Y., and Alan S. Tifford of North Miami Beach, Fla. Rabbi Jonah Pesner performed the ceremony at the Birchwood Country Club in Westport.

title: DIARY
description: MERGERS

title: Giants' Way Leads Team In Respect
description: Charles Way's college teammates at Virginia called him ''teacher's pet'' because he was never late for a meeting and seldom scolded by a coach for missing an assignment. But his Virginia teammates voted him their captain.

title: Heidi Petelinz, Matthew Benson
description: Heidi Katherina Petelinz, an editor and writer at Martha Stewart Living magazine in New York, was married yesterday to Matthew Edward Benson, an editorial and fine-art photographer in New York. The Rev. Dr. James David Ford, a Lutheran pastor who is the chaplain of the United States House of Representatives, performed the ceremony at the Chapel of Our Lady Restoration in Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: Crime
description: Some retirees do not go gentle into that good night, and Donald E. Westlake's career criminal known as Parker is obviously one of them. After a 23-year snooze, the master thief is back on the game in COMEBACK (Mysterious Press/Warner, $18), along with Richard Stark, the nom de plume Westlake chose for this gritty series, which he began in 1962. The standards and practices of criminal enterprise may have changed, but Parker has not lost his touch -- or his nerve.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Violin

title: The South Has Risen Again. Everywhere.
description: THE BLUES HAVE COME TO CARNEGIE HALL, there's an Off Broadway revival of Patsy Cline, and Garth Brooks has taken over Central Park. John Grisham, the best-selling novelist from Mississippi, keeps turning out movie-friendly thrillers on a yearly basis. In the art scene, folk objects like McArthur Chism's bottle-cap art from the rural South are selling faster than hotcakes -- or rather biscuits, which the Acme Bar and Grill in Manhattan features for weekend brunches, along with red-eye gravy. Upscale floral decorators now include cotton bolls in their arrangements, and the plantation look is big in furniture.

title: October 12-18; Hospitals Keep the Faith
description: Hospital mergers and affiliations increasingly involve more than sharing assets. In the fast growing area of partnerships between Roman Catholic and secular hospitals, the newly joined institutions are shedding reproductive services deemed immoral by the Church.

title: Cristine B. Singer, Camp Shropshire
description: Cristine Beth Singer, the daughter of Sue and Steven Singer of Cortlandt Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Donald Camp Shropshire 3d, a son of Jean and Donald Shropshire Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Michael R. Moynihan performed the ceremony at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich.

title: Murder Most Fogbound
description: MOST people tend to lose track of time when they travel. Me, I keep forgetting which century it is. This lapsus mentis strikes with peculiar force in London, which I attribute to the mystery stories I make my guidebooks.

title: Our Oldest Computer,Upgraded
description: A common refrain in articles about the impact of technology on humans seems to be ''Whew, George Orwell. Did he get it wrong!'' (''Our Oldest Computer, Upgraded,'' by John Tierney, Sept. 28). This is the sound of techno-boosters whistling past the graveyard of privacy.

title: Jennifer Nejame, Douglas Scherr
description: Dr. Jennifer Ann Nejame, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Franklin F. Nejame of Middlebury, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Douglas Scott Scherr, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Scherr of Dix Hills, N.Y. Yolanda D. Bosman, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Lewisboro; Desirable Schools Amid the Horse Trails
description: IN the small hamlet of South Salem, the geographic center of the town of Lewisboro, there is a tiny commercial center that provides a tableau of small-town Americana, just an hour's drive from Manhattan.

title: Trying to Put a Little Soul Back Into Silicon Alley
description: THE Thai food still had not arrived at the monthly meeting of the Whatever Group, but it was not just because there was plenty of beer to go around that no one seemed to notice. With the hypnotic whir of computer fans and the bleeping of cellular phones serving as background music, the dozen or so attendees were busy catching up on life.

title: Miss Schierenbeck, Mr. Manganaro
description: Lynne Dexter Schierenbeck and Nicholas Waln Morris Manganaro were married yesterday in Fort Washington, Pa. The Rev. Marek P. Zabriskie performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HULL, KENNETH JR.
description: HULL-Kenneth Jr., of Chevy Chase, Maryland, on Wednesday, October 15, 1997. Beloved father of Catharine Hull Fleming, Edward Luckenbach Hull, and Dorothy Hull Osgood; brother of Shirley Huntington; and grandfather of four. Memorial service will be held at All Saints Church in Chevy Chase, MD., Tuesday, October 21, at 4:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Chesapeake Bay Foundation (410-268-8816) or American Oceans Campaign (202-544-3526).

title: Elderly Wield Their Might in Florida; In the Silver-Haired Legislature, Building a Political Powerhouse
description: For a week, the corridors of power in the State Capitol were devoid of campaign finance troubles, sex scandals or hovering lobbyists. Even more strikingly, agreement to pass or reject bills came swiftly as the Florida Silver-Haired Legislature, where the average age is 80, showed little patience for posturing, meandering speeches or tardiness.

title: Dvorak Memorial Coverage Slighted the Conductor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; The Jets Have Found Another Real Rival in the Patriots
description: ALL the Jets had to do was kick a 29-yard field goal, then hold the Patriots for 20 seconds, and they would have won in a stunner that Sunday night in Foxboro Stadium five weeks ago. But a split-second after the rookie John Hall booted the football, Bill Parcells heard the sound he had dreaded.

title: Forgoing the Sponsors But Retaining the Fun
description: Corporate sponsorship has become a desirable addition to most sports, and yacht racing is no exception. But some regatta organizers are managing without the comforts of corporate largesse, and even liking it.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report last Sunday about the New York American Revolution Round Table misstated the address of the group's Web site. It is http://samson.kean.edu/leew/arrt/index.html.

title: The Great Divide: East Side, West Side, Does It Matter Anymore? (Yep!); O.K. An East Side Mayor May Win Again. But Broadway Nationalism Still Reigns.
description: WHEN I was growing up in a vintage brick building overlooking the dignified curve of the Hudson River, the New York I knew was divided between west and east. The West Side was my home. It was where I relaxed with a bunch of guys I had known since my playground days. The East Side was foreign turf. It was where I ran with the crowd from my blue-blazer prep school. Some of my best friends were East Siders, but I always knew which side was better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTGER, CARMEN
description: ROTGER-Carmen, AIDS activist, co-founder of the Women's Center, died on Wednesday, October 15, 1997. Carmen spoke out on behalf of PWAs in both the U.S. and abroad. The Women's Center, the international AIDS community, family and friends mourn the loss of a valiant colleague.

title: Candidates Against the Odds
description: SOME might just consider them warm bodies coming to the aid of a political party in need of candidates for the County Board of Legislators. But they insist they are in the race for real.

title: Dr. Buchkova And Dr. Bresch
description: Dr. Dessislava Dimitrova Buchkova and Dr. David Bresch are to be married today by Cantor Elliot Levine at the Village Temple in New York.

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; Floyd Flake's Middle America
description: The congregants of the Allen African Methodist Episcopalian Church started lining up early for the 8:30 service one morning in July. It was a momentous occasion: the unveiling of the church's $23 million cathedral at the edge of the St. Albans neighborhood in Queens. The older women wore hats -- raspberry-colored straw numbers with the brims rolled up, bluebird confections decorated with lace and little pearly beads. Many of the men were in suits; the ushers had on white dinner jackets and white gloves. In their daytime lives, these men and women were bus drivers and police officers and electricians and small businessmen -- members of the vast black middle-class community that stretches eastward from St. Albans to the Nassau County line. And the soaring new cathedral, with its burgundy carpet and oak pews and its great balcony suspended way up in the air, held an almost allegorical power for them. It spoke of prosperity and permanence and shared sacrifice. Last year, the congregation had coughed up $5.3 million, or close to $1,000 per adult. Allen takes in more in a week than many black churches do in a year.

title: In Merger, Catholic Hospital Can Compromise; Endangering Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Head of Charles Is Bigger and Better
description: For the first time in its 33-year history, this year's Head of the Charles Regatta has expanded to two days of competition. ''We reached our saturation point,'' said Fred Schoch, the regatta's director, referring to past years' single day of racing. ''Entry demand exceeded daylight racing time. By going to two days we have been able to accept 20 percent more entries this year than last.''

title: AT&T Is Expected to Pick Chief From Hughes
description: The AT&T Corporation plans to wrap up its three-month search for a chairman and chief executive on Monday by selecting C. Michael Armstrong, the chairman and chief executive of the Hughes Electronics Corporation, an executive close to the one of the companies said yesterday.

title: 2 Candidates, Different Plans
description: IN most states, voters consider a politician's position on education, taxes or the economy when they go to the polls. But not in New Jersey this year. According to recent polls, voters have auto insurance on their minds.

title: The Subtle Flavor of Fried Sage
description: SAGE is an herb Americans use mainly for stuffings. While I do not particularly like dried sage, which can be very strong (Elizabeth David, the British food writer, accused it of deadening food with a musty, dried-blood taste), fresh sage leaves are another thing. And now that the sage bushes in my garden are producing enough leaves to stuff a hundred turkeys, I have taken to frying them as they do in Italy, in olive oil or butter. When cooked this way, sage leaves lose their pungent, harsh taste entirely and become subtle instead of overpowering. They are wonderful sprinkled over meat, fish or pasta (recently I bought some porcini ravioli and served them tossed in a little creme fraiche and topped with fried sage leaves and pine nuts).

title: India and England Beg to Differ; Tiptoeing Through the Time of the Raj
description: BEFORE Queen Elizabeth began her tour marking the 50th anniversary of the independence of India and Pakistan, British officials preparing her way saw the journey as a healing experience.

description: WE have a World Series. Take a good look. It could be one of the last World Series as we have known them in this century.

title: Surf City Seeks to Discipline Its Police Officer in Bosnia
description: Charles Senior's parents are proud their son was selected to spend a year helping the United Nations train a newly installed police force in Bosnia. ''The kid's got guts,'' said Mary Senior, whose husband, Ernest Senior Sr., is a retired police captain.

The $180 million complex, after all, holds tremendous promise for the continued revitalization of this city, which is only now recovering from the racial strife of the 1960's.

title: Commission May Allow Some to Hunt Whales Again
description: The international body that regulates whale hunting will debate proposals at its annual meeting in Monaco next week to allow some commercial whaling in coastal waters around the world and to let an American Indian tribe resume small-scale subsistence hunting.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE ARCHITECT OF DESIRE: Beauty and Danger

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; Let Them Eat Elsewhere
description: I don't need a name over the door, Philippe Delgrange, the owner of Le Bilboquet, was musing aloud not long ago. This place is here. If you want to come, you come. If you don't want to come, don't come.

title: Citizens; France Confronts Its Jews, And Itself
description: AS a bloody century wanes, repentance is in vogue, a sort of global purging of the soul before the millennium. A world relatively becalmed, perhaps moderately bored, is confronting the upheavals of the past hundred years as a form of atonement. British colonialism, Nazism, Communist totalitarianism, apartheid: the candidates for expiatory examination are rich and varied. But nowhere, perhaps, is the process more fraught or obsessive than in France's contemplation of its treatment of the Jews during World War II.

title: The Next Crash Foretold, or Maybe Not
description: When will the next crash come, and why? Here, from a game group of financial professionals and one layman, are some answers, including several that dispute the premise.

title: Designer Houses For the Poor
description: I am an architect who has felt a great deal of disgust for my profession and its fixation on architecture for the elite. Year after year, I watch the American Institute of Architects honor its own for designing enormous houses on breathtaking sites for clients with unlimited resources. Each time I attend another such ceremony I sink into my seat, ashamed. And then there is Samuel Mockbee, whom I had the pleasure of hearing speak last spring. When he began his lecture with the words ''architecture is not about passion...it is about compassion,'' I sat up and thought, yes! Thank you for acknowledging his work.

title: The Polish Pope
description: Man of the Century

title: Where Flavors of the Subcontinent Reign
description: THE building at 766 Route 25A in East Setauket is a weirdly shaped hodgepodge with a railroad dining car attached. It is also the scene of many a failed restaurant, including the Crocodile Cafe and the 1890 Dining Car. The new tenant is the Curry Club, a bare-bones Indian outpost that fills a niche for lovers of the flavors of the subcontinent.

title: Another Fine Mess
description: To the Editor:

title: I Have a Case of Water on the Brain
description: THE carwash is an almost religious experience for me. I love to see my old clunker transformed from a 4,000-pound muddy duckling into a shining white swan. As the car is scrubbed, I feel cleansed myself. It's like one of those 12-step programs, every stage visible through the glass windows: the lather goes on, the great brushes revolve, then water, hot wax, more water, underbody wash (why not?) and, finally, the blow-dry. I always choose the super-deluxe full service, which includes vaccuming up all the small change, paper clips and cat fleas in the interior, emptying the spotless ashtrays, polishing the windows and blackening the tire walls to make the car look new. This doesn't deceive anybody, but it pleases me. A free bonus air freshener gives the whole interior a sharp, sweet chemical smell, like those whiffs you get along I-95 in New Jersey. It's better than a new car: it's a purified car.

title: The Case Against Tipping
description: Lewis is obviously someone who has never had to work at a job in public service. If he had, he would understand the realities of a near-minimum-wage job and the need for a little extra money that comes packaged in the form of a tip.

title: Winter Whale-Watching Off Baja
description: Late winter is a good time to watch whales off Baja California in Mexico -- in the Pacific Ocean and the Gulf of California -- sometimes at such close range that passengers in skiffs can reach out and touch them.

description: The Florida Marlins, the youngest franchise to reach the World Series, defeated the Cleveland Indians, 7-4, last night in Game 1 in Miami.

description: GARDEN cleanup marks the end of the growing season, for this year anyway, and affords a brief time to take stock. Gardeners often like to grade themselves on just how well they did.

description: HE may be about to lose the title of County Executive, but Andrew P. O'Rourke was given a new title last week -- vice admiral -- and a new medal to wear on his military clothes -- New York State's Conspicuous Service Cross.

description: My west windows look across a parking lot and a narrow, picturesque, much-photographed street into the windows of another loft building, where I am used to seeing certain people I think of as neighbors. I can just make out on a floor higher than mine the ceiling-high slots where a painter stores canvas stretchers. I don't know her name. Sometimes I see her dinner guests by candlelight, at a table longer than two of her windows. Very early in the morning, on another floor, a muscular man in glasses works bare-chested at his kitchen sink. Out on the street once, my arms full of groceries,

description: Whites Move to the Country

description: California Fish and Game officials have declared victory over a game fish that invaded a Sierra Nevada reservoir and threatened the state's fisheries, but it may take months to make peace with outraged residents.

description: Television brims this week with provocative films, led by two comedy classics, a dramatic allegory and a whodunit steeped in racial overtones.

description: TRAUM-Maxine R. October 12, 1997. Beloved wife of Stanley, devoted mother of Elaine Gosman, loving grandmother of Amy and David in Tucson, Arizona.

description: LIKE Davids fending off advancing giants, many small merchandisers are waging a battle for survival. Mom-and-pop businesses, in Westchester and the rest of the United States, are digging in their heels despite the onslaught of mammoth retailers.

description: To the Editor: When Amy Engeler was on the Long Path, one wonders if she thought that she might be following the footsteps of President Theodore Roosevelt, who spent much time in the Catskills.

The Rev. Lane J. Davenport officiated at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension and St. Agnes.

title: Traditions of East and West Gather at the River
description: WESTERN OPERA AND Japanese Noh drama might seem to be incompatible. The word ''operatic'' has come to be synonymous with ''flamboyant.'' Noh connoisseurs, on the other hand, prize subtlety and restraint. Yet one work, at once powerful and exquisite, successfully unites the two traditions: Benjamin Britten's one-act opera ''Curlew River.''

title: Signs of the Times: Bike Billboards
description: There are ads on the back of Metrocards and commercials at the movies. There are ads on phone booths and bus shelters, and billboards on construction site fences. There are even ads in traffic, on top of taxis and on the sides of buses. In this city of sensory overload, where commercial intrusions into daily life seem never-ending, what could be next?

title: Seeing Spots And Fuzzy Furbelows
description: Fur trim around the clock, fake or real, is the embellishment on fall sweaters, coats and evening wraps. A fake-fur collar on a short leopard-print chiffon coat was seen in SoHo, top left. Another leopard print in a long dress, top, was worn with a coat with a fake-fur collar. Among the sweaters that pick up on the theme are those at far left center and in the inset above, trimmed with real fur collars. For evening, the possibilities include a purple fox collar on an openwork knit coat, left, and a brocade evening coat dress with a Peter Pan fake-fur collar, right. Another more voluptuous possibility for evening is (at far left bottom) a leather jacket deeply trimmed in lamb.

title: Alou Makes Sure That the Series' First Night Belongs All to Miami
description: With one swing in the first World Series game the Florida Marlins ever played, Moises Alou outperformed his father and two uncles tonight.

title: Open the Files at City Hall
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani lost twice in the courts recently for refusing to turn over New York City agency records to other elected officials. One case involves requests for information by State Comptroller H. Carl McCall. The Mayor's office claims that the Comptroller has no authority to do ''performance'' audits, as opposed to more limited reviews of financial accounts. The court disagreed, and ruled that state law grants the Comptroller broad powers to investigate how effectively city money is spent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLEWETT, EVELYN
description: SLEWETT-Evelyn. The National Parkinson Foundation is deeply saddened by the recent passing of Evelyn Slewett, the beloved wife of our Chairman of the Board. Evelyn Slewett passed away on Tuesday, October 14, leaving behind her husband, Nathan and two beloved children, Alan and Robert, her daughter-in-law, Sheila and four grandchildren, Philip, Karen, Gregory and Danielle. Evelyn Slewett came from an intensely philanthropic background. Her father the late Andrew Miller of New York, founded Boys Town of Jerusalem and raised millions of dollars for Jewish charities throughout the world. Evelyn followed in her father's altruistic footsteps and encouraged her family to do the same. Her children and grandchildren are deeply involved in the charities she believed in and represent the fourth generation involved in the Boys Town of Jerusalem. She was a Founder of the National Parkinson Foundation, the University of Miami, Girls Town in Jerusalem, Mount Sinai Medical Center, the Miami Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in Douglas Gardens, and the Miami Project to Cure Paralysis. In addition, she created and endowed the Slewett Free Loan Society in Israel. As the wife of the Chairman and one of the founding members of the National Parkinson Foundation, Evelyn traveled with her husband all over the world raising money for Parkinson's disease. Her dedication and commitment helped further the growth of the Foundation which encompasses offices in Miami, New York, Washington, DC and 50 Centers of Excellence throughout the world. The National Parkinson Foundation will greatly miss our sweet, courageous Evelyn. Donations in her honor may be sent to the Evelyn Slewett Parkinson's Research Fund, C/O NPF, 1501 N.W. 9th Avenue, Miami, Florida 33136. Nat'l Parkinson Foundation Staff Board of Directors Board of Governors Paul Oreffice Harold Kravitz Herbert Zemel Emilio Alonso-Mendoza

One may as well criticize him by noting that barnyard animals have yet to take control of any farm.

title: October 12-18; Frozen Eggs, For Later
description: Fertility clinics have long been able to freeze sperm and embryos, but freezing eggs proved more difficult. Efforts were largely abandoned when research with mice suggested that freezing could damage chromosomes.

description: FRANCE TELECOM is not the only foreign company going public this year with the help of investors in the United States.

description: Other people's money has long had a way of fogging the vision of Louisiana politicians, but maybe the city of New Orleans should take heart from its dream of casino riches going bust.

description: To the Editor: I was interested to read the answer in Q & A about touring the haunts of Inspector Morse in Oxford (''On the Case,'' Sept. 7).

Rand of Sugar Grove, N.C., and Richard Naville Rand Jr. of Hickory, N.C. The Rev. Lewis H. Mills performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Holding Listeners Hostage in the Name of Art
description: MUSIC LOVERS BREATHED a sigh of relief when the musicians of the Chicago Symphony voted to accept a new contract this month. Listeners were thus assured that the Chicago would keep on blowing them away with its musical might. It was also nice to know that players wouldn't be rooting around in garbage cans for their next meal.

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; Why New York Taco Stands Are Chinese
description: Ever since the days when New York was New Amsterdam, newcomers from far-off lands have been arriving in search of a fresh start, and have been met with the tender greeting, Get a job! And they have. From Irish policemen to Korean grocers to Jewish jewelers on 47th Street, immigrants have followed their cousins and countrymen into ready-made professions -- forging ethnic toeholds that have become part of the New York landscape. Known to urban planners as niche labor, the phenomenon is as visible today as it was a century ago. According to ''The Newest New Yorkers,'' a report issued by New York's city planning department, on average more than 100,000 documented immigrants settle in New York every year, one-third more than a decade ago. ''No matter how large a distance they have crossed, immigrants still go by word of mouth,'' says Saskia Sassen, professor of urban planning at Columbia University. ''They build up a niche through their ethnic network. They see an opportunity, and move into it.'' Sassen should know: she herself immigrated to New York, where she worked as a nanny in the early 70's.

title: Out of the Loop, Small-Town Charm
description: FIRST-TIME visitors to rural and small-town northeastern Illinois often are surprised to find that the terrain shares the bucolic charm of southern Wisconsin: a glacial landscape of prairies and rolling hills cut by lovely wooded river valleys. But it has much better restaurants. A major reason is the culinary influence of nearby Chicago and its prosperous suburbs, including a burgeoning high-tech belt known as Silicon Prairie.

title: Dunham's Rare Start Lifts Devils
description: Mike Dunham made his first start of the season in goal for the Devils tonight and looked sharper than Martin Brodeur, the team's No. 1 goaltender. Dunham stood on his feet, controlled the puck well behind his goal, put the rebounds in the right places and came off his line when necessary.

title: Playing Cops and Robbers a New Way
description: IN the second episode of the new police show ''Brooklyn South,'' an investigator from the internal affairs division of the New York City Police Department is prodding Officer Nona Valentine, a black woman, on her reticence to discuss the death of a suspect in custody. Her loyalty to her partner and colleagues, most of them white men, is duly noted. But is it it well placed? ''I haven't noticed the welcome mat out for African-American females around here,'' the investigator says.

title: Elise Rosenblum, Bruce Perlmutter
description: Elise Beth Rosenblum, a daughter of Carol and Norman Rosenblum of Danbury, Conn., was married last evening to Bruce Steven Perlmutter, the son of Evelyn and Jerome H. Perlmutter of Silver Spring, Md. Rabbi Bradd Boxman performed the ceremony at the Rolling Hills Country Club in Wilton, Conn.

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; I Was A Member of the Kung Fu Crew
description: Chinatown is ghetto, my friends are ghetto, I am ghetto. I went away to college last year, but I still have a long strand of hair that reaches past my chin. I need it when I go back home to hang with the K.F.C. -- for Kung Fu Crew, not Kentucky Fried Chicken. We all met in a Northern Shaolin kung fu class years ago. Our si-fu was Rocky. He told us: ''In the early 1900's in China, your grand master was walking in the streets when a foreigner riding on a horse disrespected him. So then he felt the belly of the horse with his palms and left. Shortly thereafter, the horse buckled and died because our grand master had used qi-gong to mess up the horse's internal organs.'' Everyone said, ''Cool, I would like to do that.'' Rocky emphasized, ''You've got to practice really hard for a long time to reach that level.''

title: Excerpts From Remarks by Whitman and McGreevey
description: Following are excerpts from the remarks of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and State Senator James E. McGreevey during a debate yesterday in Glassboro, N.J.
