description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: A Decade and a Bull Ride Later, Complacency Reigns
description: AS trading moved toward a close on the worst day in stock market history, a crowd of young investment bankers gathered around the fringes of the trading floor at one of Wall Street's premier firms.

title: In Florida, Hernandez Hits the Right Spots
description: Livan Hernandez will forever be remembered for outpitching the great Greg Maddux in the 1997 National League Championship Series, when he had every pitch working, owned the black portion of the plate and was a master of his environment, much like a raw Sandy Koufax.

title: The Paper-Bag Revolution
description: Paul Krugman makes good points about ''dubious improvements'' in personal computing (The Paper-Bag Revolution,'' Sept. 28). Of course, this doesn't prevent Microsoft and its rivals from continually cramming more features into their office applications. Some are mildly helpful, others absurdly overaggressive. Last week my wife was exasperated when she typed ''Dear Manager'' and Word 97 tried to change it to ''Dear Mom and Dad.

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; 'Oh My God, It's Taylor Dayne!'
description: The night is already half-over, and Jared Paul Stern, a 26-year-old up-and-comer in the gossip field -- an up-and-comer given to wearing fedoras without irony -- is still working the crowd at the opening of Marc Jacobs's designer boutique in SoHo. One of five reporters for The New York Post's Page Six, Stern doesn't have to fill a daily quota, but the column requires no less than eight items a day, 365 days a year, and the beast must be fed. Items placed by publicists are never enough: shoe leather must be expended, conversational promiscuity encouraged.

title: Near Theater District, Showy Spots
description: CHEZ JOSEPHINE** [rating: two stars]

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The More You Watch,

title: RACE FOR CITY HALL: The Republican Candidate; A Mercurial Mayor's Confident Journey
description: There he is in the photos, aflame with conviction and heady with success: class president, editor on the law review, bold young prosecutor, No. 3 man at the Justice Department, crime-fighting United States Attorney, archenemy of the Mafia, the 107th Mayor of the City of New York. Quite a run!

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; Where The Boys Went
description: He called himself -- right there in the Yellow Pages -- the Legend of the Village, and I suppose it was part of his legendary status that, on the Sunday night of Labor Day weekend, 1980, in the middle of the kind of heat wave that makes even the brownstones weep, he alone among air-conditioner merchants answered the phone. The unit that ended up in my window that midnight lasted only one season, and the tag dangling from its chassis provided instructions on the use of a hand grenade (''remove pin . . . ''), but it was my first night in Greenwich Village and I was overjoyed because my neighborhood offered everything in the world, or something like it, and I was now part of the legend, too.

title: Albanians Inside Serbia Set to Fight For Autonomy
description: The shadowy ethnic Albanian guerrilla force that overran 11 Serbian police stations last month in its first large coordinated attack appears not only flush with newly acquired weapons but ready to wage a secessionist war that could plunge this country into a crisis rivaling the conflict in Bosnia.

title: Hershiser Falters, But Fields The Blame
description: Orel Hershiser tilted his head, and stared at the upper deck in left field at Pro Player Stadium and watched Charles Johnson's flyball keep soaring and soaring. Hershiser squinted once, closed his eyes and then squinted again to see just how far the baseball had traveled. Very far.

title: Four Times the Fun
description: Honoring a human-rights leader, and celebrating African art, a contemporary-art organization and fashion from Christian Dior to the present.

title: Aliza S. Levine, Eric D. Brown
description: Aliza Sara Levine, a daughter of Tobie Goldman Levine and Dr. Robert Aaron Levine of Brookline, Mass., was married on Monday to Eric Daniel Brown, a son of Francine H. Brown and Michael O. Brown, both of Germantown, Tenn. Rabbi Yosef D. Hollander performed the ceremony at the Harvard-Radcliffe Hillel in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIMOWITZ, DR. LILLIAN L.
description: HEIMOWITZ-Dr. Lillian L., of Greenwich, CT., on October 16th, 1997. Beloved sister of Bert Margolies, mother of Carl and Edna Heimowitz, grandmother of Donald Heimowitz. Services Monday, October 20th, at 1 P.M., Temple Sholom, 300 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT. 06830. Contributions may be made to Hadassah or Temple Sholom.

title: Mushrooms Can Draw A Crowd In Seattle
description: In a damp climate, the mushroom becomes a matter of civic pride. The 34th annual mushroom exhibition here this weekend has evolved into a major event, attracting 1,300 people with cooking demonstrations, slide shows and more than 300 species of mushrooms gathered over two days.

title: Never-Ending Saga
description: Thanks to Michiko Kakutani for a lucid, balanced analysis of hypertext (Culture Zone: ''Never-Ending Saga,'' Sept. 28). She writes that since all elements of the novel become building blocks assembled according to the reader's choice, the ''domination by the author'' is undermined. And in its place? A ''group consciousness would prevail.'' Is this liberation, or the Orwellian world of ''1984?

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; The Last Smoke-Filled Room
description: City Councilman Antonio Pagan walked into Gallagher's Steak House on West 52d Street at the end of a Tuesday afternoon looking for the newspaper columnist Sidney Zion. ''Sidney called and said he was running late,'' the bartender said. ''He'll be here. He's always here.'' Everybody who was bellied up to the bar, from the fat man nursing a beer to the two young suits slugging bourbon, could have told Pagan the same thing. For 35 years Zion has worked for a succession of New York City newspapers large and small, and whenever he wants to talk with someone -- or someone wants to talk with him -- Zion always says the same thing: ''Meet me at Gallagher's.''

title: October 12-18; Fake Kennedys, or Not?
description: A Federal grand jury in Manhattan is investigating the sale of letters and other documents that were said to be written by John F. Kennedy, but which several forensic specialists say are fake.

title: Ghouls Seek Blood to Curdle
description: THINGS may go bump in the park on Saturday as Halloween, and the ghosts that haunt it, arrive a little early in Prospect Park. Walkers will encounter the headless horseman, the grim reaper and other scary visages (last year's walk is shown at right). Blood curdled by the walk can be warmed afterward with hot cider as terrorized park visitors are entertained by magicians, clowns and jugglers at a Halloween Carnival that follows.

title: Rolling Stone, Venerable at 30. Still, No Moss.
description: WHEN Rolling Stone magazine turns 30 this month, it will be in the same situation as many of its early readers: once a 1960's rebel and iconoclast, now a comfortable, businesslike part of the mainstream.

title: Memorial For Women In Military Is Dedicated
description: Visitors swarmed across Memorial Bridge toward the somber gateway to Arlington National Cemetery, the vast resting ground for American military heroes. It was not an unusual sight for a Saturday in the nation's capital, but today, for the first time, the heroes being honored and memorialized were the 1.8 million women who have served in the United States armed services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KISTER, HANNA
description: KISTER-Hanna. Died on October 16, 1997 after a brief illness. She was the widow of Marian Kister, founder of Roj Publishers in Warsaw, Poland, and Roy Publishers in New York City, which they ran together. She is mourned by her daughters Mrs. Irene Lombroso of Cambridge and Mrs. Elizabeth Clark of New York City; and her five grandchildren and her five great grandchildren.

title: Kathryn Reimann, William Thomas
description: Kathryn Susan Reimann, a daughter of Mrs. Ferdinand J. Moebus of Baywood, N.J., and Kenneth N. Reimann Sr. of Indian Harbor Beach, Fla., was married last evening to William Michael Thomas, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Thomas of Buffalo. The Rev Thomas A. O'Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Christ the King Chapel at Canisius College in Buffalo.

title: A Rugged Pilgrim's Progress
description: YEARS ago, on a back street in Katmandu, I happened on Heinrich Harrer's autobiographical ''Seven Years in Tibet.'' It's the kind of book you read in a single sitting; then, if you're like me, you set out for Tibet yourself.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Yonkers School Ruling

title: My Life as a Token
description: TRESPASSING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LITTMAN, SYLVIA
description: LITTMAN-Sylvia. Of Yonkers, on October 16, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Herbert Littman. Survived by children Judy and Howard Ellison, Robert and Ruth Littman, grandsons Daniel and Eric Ellison and sister Lillian (Monroe) Gutner. Services Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon, noon, Sunday.

title: 'Civil' Death Penalty Demeans All Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: A 12-Meter Yacht Race Of 'Dreamy Quietude'
description: TO envision what 12-Meter yacht racing looks like, visit Conservatory Water, or the Boat Pond, in Central Park off Fifth Avenue at 74th Street, where model boat enthusiasts sail their precisely scaled creations. Now squint tightly and imagine that the pond is Long Island Sound and that the boats have real people on them.

title: Browning of Hope for Village Gardens
description: Supporters of community gardens suffered a setback last week when a State Supreme Court justice ruled against an environmental group that wants to prevent the construction of housing on four garden sites in the East Village. Though the decision directly affects only a handful of the city's 400 or so makeshift urban greens, advocates of community gardens say they are worried about the message it sends at a time when city officials are increasingly reclaiming the long-abandoned -- and now cultivated -- lots for housing.

title: TENNIS: YESTERDAY
description: CZECH INDOOR

title: BEST SELLERS: October 19, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Westbury Closing by Venerable Firm Angers Its Workers
description: PHIL KLAUS of Hicksville rode a forklift and worked in receiving at the King Kullen grocery warehouse in Westbury for 21 1/2 years. His late father, Felix, also worked in the warehouse, moving his family from Brooklyn to Hicksville in 1960 to be near his job when the warehouse moved from Jamaica, Queens.

title: Casting Not Complete
description: To the Editor:

title: Time Bomb
description: PERFIDIA

title: The Capitalist; The $700,000-a-Year Drone
description: On the 8th of august, the bond market fell nearly 2 points. In the bond market this amounts to a collapse, and the day was faintly reminiscent of the delightful chaos that reigned during much of the 1980's. I watched the sell-off from a trading desk in midtown Manhattan, sitting beside a bond salesman who was a friend from the old days.

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; Seinfeld Masala
description: The actors are part of a vibrant cross-cultural scene of young South Asian students, artists and professionals in the city. Jaffrey is played by Sameer Butt, a 28-year-old Pakistani with a struggling actor's dream day job -- trading options on the floor of the American Stock Exchange. The 24-year-old Chhaya Bhanti (Neha) left Udaipur, India, to attend college in Iowa and now works for a photo-processing company. Rizwan Ahmad plays Shaukeen; his hair grows down, not up, but he has Kramer's height and goofy stage presence. Ahmad grew up in the Bronx and fronts a heavy-metal band called Taj.

title: Grand, Not Excessive
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Makes Us ...
description: Congratulations on your comprehensive coverage of technology circa 1997. Unfortunately, I was unable to muster the patience to read most of the masterful prose carefully crafted by your writers. As a computer scientist engaged in moving the financial-services industry onto the Internet, I get virtually all of my news and information from the Web. Reading content that consumes multiple paragraphs, like books, now strikes me as quaint, an activity that I enjoy strictly on vacation.

title: On Our Best Behavior?
description: The Appearance of Impropriety How the Ethics Wars Have Undermined American Government, Business, and Society. By Peter W. Morgan and Glenn H. Reynolds. 272 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25.

title: In Merger, Catholic Hospital Can Compromise
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIED, NAN LEVINE
description: FRIED-Nan Levine. In memory of Nan Levine Fried. Ten years we still miss you. Your loving daughters, granddaughters and sisters.

title: IN BRIEF; For Acme Sign, the Smithsonian Or the Trash Heap
description: Unless someone claims it soon, a piece of architectural advertising history in Lambertville may be junked, city officials say. The blue enamel tile Acme supermarket sign and facade appeared with the store in 1951. The store, one of the oldest Acmes in the country, closed in January.

title: October 12-18; Adult Education Marketing 401
description: The past decade wasn't easy for colleges and universities. Flat enrollments and reduced state subsidies led scores to close, while hundreds of others engaged in downsizing and soul-searching. Public and corporate disillusionment with the academic world put scholars on the defensive. But the University of Phoenix not only swelled its enrollment, but with 40,000 students in 12 states made itself the nation's largest private university.

title: Elizabeth Cohen and Paul Giamatti
description: Elizabeth Ora Cohen, the daughter of Dr. Fern W. Cohen and Daniel B. Cohen of New York, was married on Monday at her parents' apartment to Paul Edward Valentine Giamatti, a son of Toni S. Giamatti of Hamden, Conn., and the late A. Bartlett Giamatti, the former president of Yale University. Judge John G. Koeltl of Federal District Court in New York performed the ceremony.

title: Reclaiming a Long-Lost Loner
description: IT'S ALWAYS EXCITING WHEN the simple, streamlined narratives of art history start unraveling, when the stage framing an era's most prominent artists or art movements begins to fill with competing characters and conflicting styles.

title: Night Shades
description: When Ray-Ban first introduced its yellow Kalichrome glasses in the mid-1960's, it probably didn't foresee that they might one day need instructions for proper use. But for all those hipsters recently spotted wearing the glasses in broad daylight as a statement of ''Easy Rider'' cool, that day has arrived.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  STEEL, COURTNEY
description: STEEL-Courtney. Not one day passes that we don't think of you and miss you. We can never forget your gentleness and beauty. Our lives are incomplete without you and Robby. We love you forever. Eric, Mom and Charles

title: A Change in the Chemistry in Purchase
description: ON a woodsy back road near a handful of corporate parks as well as the busy Performing Arts Center at Purchase College, Cobble Creek Cafe would be a serious destination even if it did not have a captive audience. Hearing that a new chef has been revitalizing the kitchen, we went to see, or eat, for ourselves, and found the information to be more than rumor. For the most part, Jose Oliver, the chef, appears to have such an understanding of food chemistry that his best efforts seem more like alchemy.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: Richard Mason, 78, 'Suzie Wong' Author
description: Richard Mason, a British author best known for ''The World of Suzie Wong,'' a novel about a Hong Kong prostitute, died on Monday in a hospital here. He was 78 and had lived in Rome for nearly 40 years.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MARINE PARK -- UPDATE ; Mariners Are Still Riding High
description: Last Saturday, under Coach Pudgie Walsh's careful tutelage, Brooklyn's semiprofessional but fully dedicated football team, the Mariners, won their first playoff game this season, against the Long Island Seahawks, 17-0.

title: POSTINGS: 145 Rentals, From $2,500 to $20,000; Pied-a-Terre On E. 57th Street
description: Bernard Spitzer had his heart set on a site for a luxury rental building at 150 East 57th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, six years ago. He finally secured it from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for $1.2 million in May, and his 34-story tower is now rising on it.

title: Wild Blue Wonders
description: TERRESTRIALS By Paul West. 380 pages. New York: Scribner. $24.

title: Magaly Diaz, Timothy Oliver
description: Magaly Diaz, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernesto Diaz of Shelton, Conn., was married yesterday to Timothy Patrick Oliver, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Oliver of Trumbull, Conn. The Rev. Michael J. Bachman performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: 3 Outsiders Move To Center Stage
description: THEY'RE CONSIDERED UNKNOWNS IN the world of Broadway musicals. But this season three choreographers renowned in the world of contemporary dance -- Garth Fagan, Doug Varone and Mark Morris -- have been invited to work in commercial musical theater.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: 10 LB. PENALTY

title: October 12-18; An Irish Handshake
description: Britain's Prime Minister, Tony Blair, made a bold gesture in Northern Ireland, where peace talks are seeking a way forward for the troubled province. He met -- and shook hands with -- Gerry Adams, the president of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army.

title: Accusation of I.R.A. Support Jolts a Sleepy Election in Ireland
description: The presidential election campaign here has erupted in a national debate over the outlawed Irish Republican Army and its political wing, Sinn Fein.

title: A Financial Capital? Yes. A Model Economy? No.
description: MAYBE it isn't the economy, after all.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: New British Dance (and Nary a Toe Shoe in Sight)
description: IN ''QUINTET,'' A LANKY FIGURE softly strikes four tubular chimes, posing gnomic questions for the audience to ponder while watching the dance. The questions -- Is the music more complex than the silence? Do the dancers move differently in the silence? Does the choreography? -- are a gentle tease.

title: Fordham Homecoming With a Big Heart Missing
description: The fifth captain was not introduced. Four Fordham Rams walked in the sunshine to the center of Jack Coffey Field, their names announced to the crowd on homecoming day, an event that could not happen a year ago. The fifth captain's name, and the circumstances of that day, did not have to be mentioned. The people in the stands who had been there last October for a football game that never took place could not forget how they watched after safety Bill Tierney fell during the warm-ups, or how they heard that he had died.

title: Neversink Bridge
description: To the Editor: Hikers on the Catskill Mountain section of the Long Path, described by Amy Engeler in ''A Trail Carved by Persistence'' (Aug. 24), will be pleased to learn that the bridge in Denning crossing the East Branch of the Neversink has been replaced. A team of horses dragged the original double hemlock logs into place in 1990. The bridge failed to withstand the great rush of water following the heavy rains and melting snow of January 1996.

title: Argentina Backs U.S. In Restricting Global Gases
description: Framed by the ancient Patagonian wilderness, President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina appeared with President Clinton here today to endorse Mr. Clinton's call for developing nations to join developed ones in restricting gases that contribute to global warming.

title: New Headsets Improve In-Flight Sound
description: When the in-flight movie features Michelle Pfeiffer whispering softly into her co-star's ear, most passengers strain to pick out the words from the rumble of the jet engines. But starting this month, every subtle sound should be heard clearly by international passengers in the first- and business-class sections of United Airlines. United is the first airline to buy headsets with anti-noise technology, which creates sound waves that cancel out the engines' soundwaves, making higher-pitched frequencies bright and clear. Military pilots and owners of small planes have long used such headsets, paying up to $1,000 to block engine sounds. Bose Corporation, the audio-products company that produces such headsets for the military, says its research shows pilots stay more alert when engine noise is silenced. The company's chairman wears a headset when he flies to reduce fatigue.

title: For Gay Voters, It Could Be a Win-Win Election Year
description: The longtime equation of gay rights with the Democratic Party and anti-gay sentiment with the Republican Party no longer applies in New Jersey, a state that has more safeguards than most for gay residents.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: On the Edge

title: From Rags to Riches and Back, Laughing Along the Way
description: WHAT WOULD YOU DO for $1,000? How about $100,000? The screenwriter and director Jeremiah Bosgang answers these questions in his autobiographical film ''Good Money,'' which will be shown on Saturday night as a centerpiece of the first New York Comedy Film Festival.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Technology Makes Us ...
description: Home PC users who do not have the benefit of a corporate systems department have to spend hours on hold waiting for a tech-support person (now always an expensive toll call). They have to decipher user manuals incomprehensible even to experts and are obliged to buy a brand-new system on average every two years. For the moment, it is the computer industry that sets the rules, and consumers have taken what would be an unacceptable level of service in any other sector for granted.

title: Editorial Notebook; Gauging the Gasbag Generalissimos
description: No matter how Fidel Castro phrased his latest defiance of democracy in his speech opening the recent Cuban Communist Party Congress, he sent his real message in taking 6 hours and 43 minutes to say it. Mr. Castro so dominates the global verbosity championships that his number should probably be retired, but he is not the only competitor. Another, Heydar Aliyev, Azerbaijan's President, came to America this summer advertising Azerbaijan as home not only to petroleum but also to democracy. At one lunch he took 33 minutes to respond to a question, counting time for translation, thus undercutting his message.

title: Baseball in Black and White
description: Jackie Robinson

title: Technology Makes Us ...
description: Why is it, I often wonder, that Luddites, so few in number and passive in manner, are so threatening to those who beat the drum for technological determinism? The naysayers perform a valuable service in their opposition. Though they may fight a lost cause, they also may just broaden the discussion, which has been narrowed by technology boosterism. In the realm of technology, we always hear the benefits first and learn the real costs too late.

title: David Bowie Fills In At the Capitol Theater
description: BEFORE David Bowie broke into his first song here at the Capitol Theater Tuesday night, he looked out at his frenzied audience and asked, ''Anyone here from New Jersey?''

title: 'Hero' Label Lifts a Life
description: Just back from an extended alcoholiday, John Byrnes is rebuilding his life from the bottom.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Condo Market in Fairfield Is on the Upswing Again
description: WHEN Jennifer and Carl Ruspini came to Stamford in 1989, they bought a one-bedroom, 750-square-foot condominium at Harbor House for $205,000. Still in immaculate condition, it has a 24-foot living-dining room, marble fireplace, a small den or breakfast room, top-of-the-line appliances, powder room, and a 25-foot deck overlooking the harbor and 100 boat slips that rent for $72 per foot.

title: Welfare's State
description: NEW AMERICAN BLUES A Journey Through Poverty to Democracy. By Earl Shorris. 432 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $29.95.

title: Michele Evans, Darryll Arrindell
description: Michele Elizabeth Evans, a daughter of Elizabeth E. Evans of Upper Marlboro, Md., and Michael D. Evans Sr. of Brockton, Mass., was married yesterday to Darryll Jeffery Arrindell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Arrindell of New Brighton, Staten Island. The Rev. Elgin Watkins, a Congregational minister, officiated at Bethany Baptist Church in Brooklyn.

title: Coming-of-Age
description: HOPE, Goldie Hawn's directorial debut, takes place in a sleepy southern town of that name during the tumultuous early 60's. Jena Malone plays Lilly Kate Burns, the movie's pubescent protaganist, who lives with her paralyzed mother, fearful aunt and duplicitous uncle (J.T. Walsh, above) amidst a gentile facade that conceals tragedy and scandal. When Lilly meets a black preacher from up north with a past that turns out to be tightly intertwined with her own, she must absorb a number of shocking revelations that turns her world into a dark and frightening place -- SUNDAY at 8 P.M. on TNT. Caitlin Lovinger

title: Along the Old Silk Road, a New Effort to Shine
description: Historians say that no one knows when this ancient Silk Road town was founded, but that has not prevented President Islam Karimov from declaring October as its 2,500th anniversary.

title: Betting on Sector Funds to Cash In on Deals
description: INVESTORS looking for a way to participate in the consolidation wave that keeps sweeping over vast sections of the economy might consider industry-specific sector funds.

title: Our Towns; In Audit Blitz, Merchants See Death in Taxes
description: TWENTY-THREE years running a neighborhood bar and Terry Monaghan still puts in the crazy hours, seven days a week, 13, 14 hours a day. Every night, Monaghan's has the same handful of regulars. Maybe a couple more handfuls drop by on the weekend. It adds up to barely getting by.

title: Our Oldest Computer,Upgraded
description: Tierney begins by lauding the Mars landing, mostly because of its accessibility on the Internet: ''With a few clicks of the mouse, you could read a treatise on Martian geology, check out the latest weather conditions on the planet, sit in on a news conference or watch scientists issuing commands from the mission-control room. One Web site provided a recipe for throwing a Mars Madness Celebration -- red and brown M&M's were recommended.

title: All in the Wrist
description: In the 1950's, a young man would buy an ID bracelet in hopes of seeing it, if briefly, on the wrist of a steady girlfriend. Now, modern guys are reviving the accessory but keeping it for themselves, like the silver one from Tiffany & Company, below ($175). In turn, women are cutting out the middlemen. ''We've seen a lot of women buying them,'' said Melvyn Kirtley, a vice president of Tiffany, which now makes a shorter one ($250), with women in mind. The manly links stayed, for that loved-one look.

title: Airport Remedies
description: To the Editor: It is good news that the managers of the Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam are taking on the task of overhauling one of the world's worst airports, Kennedy International in New York (Marlise Simons, ''An Airport With a Sauna and a Supermarket,'' Aug. 24). Schiphol is indeed superb.

title: Computers and the Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LILLIEN, BERNARD
description: LILLIEN-Bernard. Bernie left us October 13. Much beloved husband, father, grandfather, friend. His warmth, wit and humor were legendary. Heaven will be a livelier place.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GUY, GEORGES
description: GUY-Georges. A celebration of the life of Georges Guy of Lentilly, France and beloved Bennington College professor for three decades who died August 3, 1997. Service Sunday October 26, 1 PM, Duane Methodist, 7th Avenue and 13th Street, NYC. All Welcome.

title: Sensitivity to Holocaust
description: The growing incidence of reports of hate crimes on Long Island was one reason Michael H. Gerber became involved in a project related to the Holocaust. Mr. Gerber, of Kings Point, a film producer and a former executive at Viacom, said he wanted to help sensitize people to Holocaust issues.

title: Follow-up: A Local Five-and-Dime Succumbs
description: An institution here is fading away. The Atlas 5 & 10, an old-fashioned dime store with wood floors and high tin ceilings on Main Street where you could get everything from the trendy (Tickle Me Elmo) to the obscure (a potato baker) for more than 45 years, is going out of business, a victim of changing shopping tastes. (The store was featured in an article on July 27 after the closing of the Woolworth chain.)

title: Backtalk; When Army Was Caught By Surprise In Lions' Den
description: As the cadets from West Point marched crisply down 218th Street and into Baker Field, it was a little like watching the arrival of an invading army. With good reason. It was Oct. 25, 1947, and the cadets had come to town to see their Army football team try to extend its 32-game unbeaten streak by defeating a Columbia team with a 2-2 record.

title: While England Sinks
description: THE WITCH OF EXMOOR

title: Best-Paid College Leader Is at Northeastern U.
description: When John A. Curry resigned as president of Northeastern University last year, he received $711,358 in an early-retirement and severance package in addition to his base salary of $284,000. The total of $995,358 made him the most highly paid college president in the nation in the 1995-1996 academic year, according to an annual survey of private colleges and universities conducted by The Chronicle of Higher Education.

title: Seeking the Sacred Mountain
description: THE Himalayas are to other mountains what wild animals are to those kept penned in a zoo. Vast and solid though they are, they have a curious insubstantiality, the ability to lose themselves behind clouds, to appear, then disappear again in seconds before a person has time to take the lens cap off a camera. These are peaks you need to go on a kind of safari to see.

title: Not Coming 2 a Scrabble Board Near U
description: IF you N2K (need to know), get the Four11 (information). But the answer may not be up K2 (a Himalayan mountain) -- it may be right @Home.

title: Thinking Small, but Acting Globally
description: WITH small-company stocks rallying in the United States, can the rest of the world be far behind?

title: The Case Against Tipping
description: I enjoyed Michael Lewis's article. I think I can go him one better. We have a bagel bakery in town with a drive-through window. Yes, there is a cup soliciting tips at the drive-through!

title: In Norwalk, a Mansion Aglow in the Patina of the Past
description: THE Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum's 21st annual antiques show has reinvented itself. With new manager, chairwomen, more volunteers and many new dealers, the players and concept have changed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAUN, GLADYS (SCHREIBER)
description: BRAUN-Gladys (Schreiber), 97 years young, Tuesday, October 14. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Leo Braun. Treasured Mother of Phyllis Braun Leventhal and son-in-law Bernard. Adored and adoring Grammy of Lionel, Alexander and Evan Leventhal. Cherished darling big sister of Celia Levine, Sidney Schreiber and the late Shirley Seiler. Early graduate of Hunter College and admired German and Spanish teacher in NYC high schools. Funeral services Sunday, October 19 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 Street at 10:30 AM, burial to follow in East Hampton at Gates of the Grove Cemetery. Memorial contributions in honor of her beautiful life may be made to Friends of Israel Sports Center for the Disabled, Independence Mall East, Phila., PA 19106. You will truly live forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMON, BEATRICE (BEA)
description: SIMON-Beatrice (Bea). On October 15, 1997, of Belle Harbor, NY. Beloved and cherished wife of the late Nicky. Devoted and loving mother of Joan and son-in-law Jerry Goldfarb. Adoring Nana of Jane, Jim and Andrew. We will love and cherish your memory always. Graveside service 2:00 PM, Sunday at Hungarian Union Fields.

title: October 12-18; Welcome Welfare
description: In writing the 1996 welfare law, Congress did not worry much about constitutional problems. But a Federal judge has found one provision severely flawed.

title: When You're a Jets Fan
description: Are the chronically hapless Jets really coming back? Do you think New Jersey will finally adopt the team?

title: Dos and Don'ts For Park Safety
description: LAST month I spent an hour or so at the park clinic at Lake Yellowstone, where a friend who had cut herself with a jackknife had stitches taken in a finger. A T-shirt was displayed in the waiting room.

title: A Zoo (and Much More) That Would Overwhelm Noah's Ark
description: Imagine a vast petting zoo with some man-eating beasts thrown in, combined with a kind of homespun Smithsonian Institution, and that still wouldn't begin to describe Space Farms Zoo and Museum. What started as Ralph and Elizabeth Space's general store in the remote reaches of Sussex County now attracts 100,000 visitors a year to the hamlet of Beemerville in Wantage Township. (The season ends Oct. 31.) Fred Space took over for his father, Ralph, who died in 1986; Elizabeth Space died in August. Now Fred's youngest son, Parker, 28, is in charge.

title: POSTINGS: Possible Slogan: Don't Buy Home Without It?; Using Plastic for a Broker's Fee
description: Last week, a Manhattan real estate broker completed what would otherwise have been a routine closing on a one-bedroom condominium at Manhattan Place, 630 First Avenue, at 36th Street. The only difference was that the seller put the broker's commission on an American Express card.

title: A Comedy Of Merry Pranks
description: HE goes by the name of Tony Lumpkin, plunking himself onto the stage for a New Age prologue to which attention must be paid and offense allowably taken.

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; To the Fund-Raiser Born
description: On the night Ted Turner gave $1 billion to the United Nations, Robin Chandler Duke was among the first to arrive at the private reception in his honor at the Marriott Marquis Hotel. As she entered, he sprang to attention like a schoolboy smitten with his first-grade teacher.

title: The Case Against Tipping
description: In a place like Starbucks, where the customers are almost invariably better off than the staff, giving the patrons an unobtru-sive opportunity to redistribute a bit of the wealth is not inappropriate. Contributions are entirely voluntary and any amount should be considered an act of generosity. Thus, Lewis should feel no qualms about giving nothing if that is what he chooses.

title: The Crash Effect: Going, Going and Almost Gone
description: The long term is getting a lot brighter

title: Arts Center Opens With High Hopes
description: The New Jersey Performing Arts Center opened here tonight with a gala fund-raising performance and a vow from its president that it would become not only a great cultural institution, but also ''a healing force in a divided world.''

title: So Eat
description: MIRIAM'S KITCHEN

title: In Search of a Meal in Terra Incognita
description: JUST south of the Massachusetts line is the small town of Granby. And less than a block from Route 20 in Granby is the Bank Street Bistro, a small restaurant in a strip mall. To a traveler in search of a decent meal in terra incognita, this cheerful, amiable cafe is a little jewel waiting to be discovered.

title: Jonathan Keep, Marie Szurszewski
description: Marie Cecelia Szurszewski, the daughter of Cecelia and Dr. Joseph H. Szurszewski of Rochester, Minn., was married on Wednesday to Jonathan Davis Keep, a son of Nancy and C. Russell Keep Jr. of Solebury, Pa. Jack Economou, a retired judge of the Poughkeepsie (N.Y.) City Court, officiated at the Innisfree Garden in Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Profile in Caution
description: THE KENNEDY TAPES

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Books From The Times
description: Some of the most approachable subjects in science journalism are animals -- everybody likes some kind of animal -- and two collections of articles from Science Times, the Tuesday science section of The New York Times, are now here to prove it: THE SCIENCE TIMES BOOK OF BIRDS and THE SCIENCE TIMES BOOK OF FISH (both edited by Nicholas Wade and published by the Lyons Press, $25 each). Articles in both cover such territories as evolution, migration, strange metabolisms and kinky reproductive behaviors, but there is also recent information on such perennials as the probability of being eaten by sharks (very low) and the intelligence of parrots (amazing, considering that they are birds).

title: What Did Fred Thompson Say and Why Did He Say It?
description: FRED D. THOMPSON has had a frustrating time digging up actionable dirt on the Clinton White House's creative campaign fund-raising. As chairman of the Senate panel that is investigating abuses, he has wrangled with the former White House aide Harold M. Ickes, castigated President Clinton and excoriated the Justice Department.

title: The View From: Katonah; For Costume Fanciers, Regal Fantasy Fashions
description: IF the costumes in the stores this season seem a bit tacky, come to Caramoor to see ''Primavera.'' While not created for Halloween, the gown made by Henri Bendel for Lucie Bigelow Rosen is the epitome of fantasy. Fashioned after ''The Flora,'' a figure in a Botticelli painting, it is a hand-stitched confection of pastel gold, pink and green organza garlanded with silk leaves and flowers. Mrs. Rosen, who, with her husband, Walter, founded the Caramoor Music Festival, wore it to the 1930 Beaux-Arts Ball in Manhattan.

title: Debra Mowrey, Henry Druker
description: Debra Lynne Mowrey, a daughter of Wendi and John Mowrey of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., was married yesterday to Henry Druker, a son of Dorothy Vogel of San Mateo, Calif., and B. B. Druker of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Dr. George Koury, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the Maidstone Club in East Hampton, N.Y.

title: On Language; New Yorkese
description: ''If we hurry, we can make the light.''

title: 1,057 Calls? A Telephone Bill Is on Hold
description: JONATHAN BERMAN will never forget the phone bill he received in November 1995. Not only did he owe a lofty $221.20, but more than one-third of it was for 1,057 local calls in New York City.

title: Symbolism Marks Three Exhibitions
description: Yolanda Daliz/Wendy Young

title: Filling the Nest
description: AN EMPTY LAP

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWE, JAMES JENKINS
description: LOWE-James Jenkins, 82. A long time resident of Bedford, New York died at his home on Friday, October 17, after a long illness. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, the former Tatiana (Tanya) Litchfield, a son James Lowe, Jr of Waterville, Maine, and two daughters, Jennifer Lowe Noble of New York, and Penelope Lowe of Danville, Vermont; a brother, Dr. William Carter Lowe of Richland, Michigan and a sister, Elizabeth Cnobloch McLean of Sarasota, Florida. Loving grandfather of Christina and Heather Lowe, Katharine and Penelope Noble. He graduated from The Kent School in 1933 and was a member of the class of 1937 at Williams College. He volunteered for service in the Navy during World War II, and served overseas. In 1959 he founded J.J. Lowe Associates, Inc, an international marketing firm dealing with the wire and cable field. He was involved in many community activities. Services will be held at Saint Matthew's Church, Bedford, New York, Monday, October 20, at 2:00PM. In lieu of flowers, you may send contributions to Saint Matthew's Church, Bedford, New York, or the James J. Lowe Scholarship Fund at Williams College, Williamstown, Massachusetts.

title: Technology Makes Us ...
description: Computer technology may be making people richer and life faster, but I'm not sure it's making us smarter. Is it smart to become more alienated from one another, to exchange human relationships for frenetic speed and isolation? Keep this up and psychiatrists will reap untold profits.

title: Goizueta's Rich Years at Coke
description: The wealth created by Roberto C. Goizueta during his 16 years as chairman and chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company, is shared by millions of shareholders, whose stock value multiplied 65-fold during his tenure.

title: Backtalk; And Justice for All
description: While in Ireland recently, I witnessed a purse snatching. Although the man ran down a deserted street in Dublin, the woman's yells signaled store owners and onlookers, who pursued him and then detained him until the authorities arrived. I was impressed.

title: Ready for My Close-Up
description: HOW does one prepare for one's 15 minutes of fame?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOBSON, ELIZABETH S.
description: HOBSON-Elizabeth S. Died on October 1 in San Diego, at ninety. Following WW II, she left Hungary to join her mother and brothers in America. Throughout life, she had a thirst for knowledge: reading voraciously, traveling extensively, studying until recently at the New School. She marveled at the world around her and observed the distinguishing details of a fine fabric, a well-stitched garment, a porcelain figurine. She's remembered lovingly by many friends, the families of nephew Gary Sternberg of Texas, cousin Ron Meisels of Montreal and niece Marika Gordon of Los Angeles. The family requests that contributions in her memory be made to the Arthritis Foundation.

title: Ira H. Lustgarten, Lawyer, 86
description: Ira Howard Lustgarten, a Manhattan lawyer and an authority on trusts and estates law, died last Sunday at his East Side home. He was 86.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ZELDA
description: MILLER-Zelda, October 17, 1997. She is survived by her daughter Stacey Dumain, her son Jeffrey Miller, her dear and devoted friend Julius Wittman, her granddaughters Emma and Rebecca Dumain, and by her niece Sandra Ball. She will be missed by them and by her many friends. Service Sunday, 11:15 AM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Miami
description: After a tumultuous summer, Miami seems to be settling into a promising autumn. Crime -- after the Versace murder and a manhunt that held the world's attention in July -- appears to be under control, and last month voters defeated a proposal to essentially abolish Miami and merge it with Dade County.

title: Time to Press Redial?
description: WHEN France Telecom arrives on world stock exchanges Monday with a $7.3 billion initial public offering, the highly sought-after issue will have a specter looming behind it: the German telephone company.

title: Just How Does the Killer Klown Get Through the Winter?
description: On a chilly Columbus Day, Coney Island is a shadow of its summer self. Rubbish piles up on sidewalks and streets. Most stands and stores are shuttered, and scream-inducing rides are shut down. A lone couple rides the carousel on Surf Avenue; on the boardwalk, one child bounces on a caterpillar ride.

title: Cromwell Slept Here, Louis XVIII Slept There
description: THE bounteous summers of the English countryside have attracted me since my days as a youth-hosteler on a bicycle, so I have returned to the Cotswolds and Midlands twice in recent years -- once two summers ago and again in the spring of this year, on short trips from London. On both occasions, my companion, Rosalie, and I visited two very different but equally classic country hotels: the vicaragelike Lygon Arms, in the heart of the Cotswolds village of Broadway, and the palatial Hartwell House, some 20 miles northeast of Oxford in the rolling Midlands of Buckinghamshire.

title: Pauline Purcell, Scott F. Akers
description: Pauline Dawson Purcell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Purcell Jr. of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Scott F. Akers, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Akers, also of Westport. The Rev. Richard M. Simpson performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

title: Leaving the Suburbs for Rural Areas
description: Four years ago, Richard and Sherrie Glover decided they had had enough of life in Upland, a suburb of Los Angeles. They were fed up with the traffic, fed up with the smog, and frightened by what they believed was increased activity by Hispanic gangs.

title: Man Among Men
description: Brian Clemens's CAPTAIN KRONOS: VAMPIRE HUNTER (1974), an atmospheric-chiller from Britain's Hammer Productions, has already gained a large, appreciative cult following. Why? Because it will knock your sox off. Settle back somewhere and savor this stunning embroidery of the vampire theme as a sword-wielding stranger (Horst Janson) scouts medieval Europe for bloodthirsty prowlers. He is great, too. Dig his reply when his companion, a sweet-natured hunchback, asks why his deformity? Surprises abound and the pacing is electric. Hang on. WEDNESDAY at 9 P.M. on the Sci-Fi Channel. Howard Thompson

title: Where Pollution Hampers New Uses for Old Buildings
description: THEY used to make hats in Danbury, so many hats that it was nicknamed the Hat City. They used mercury to make the hats. Today, the hat makers are gone but the mercury remains, scaring away investors from redeveloping the properties where the hats were made.

title: Why Unrest Isn't Unsettling For the Israeli Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, THOMAS TUNNY
description: HARRIS-Thomas Tunny. Of Dix Hills, NY, on Oct. 15, 1997, at the age of 66. Beloved husband of Miriam. Devoted father of Amy and Michael. Cherished grandfather of Robert and Gregory. Loving brother of Maria Harris. Reposing Sunday 2-5 and 7-10 PM, at Commack Abbey Inc., 96 Commack Rd., Commack, NY. Funeral mass Monday, 9:45 AM, at St. Matthew's R.C. Church, Dix Hills, NY. Interment Long Island National Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Alzheimer's Association, 66 South St., Patchouge, NY 11772.

title: Crystal Ball: The Eastwest Side?
description: THERE will always be an East Side and a West Side. Thank Central Park and a lack of good crosstown transportation for that. But lately there is concern in some quarters that these two distinct cultures, if you can call them that, are being watered down.

title: Food; The Day The Chefs Ate Lunch
description: The world of new york chefs is rarely punctured by daylight. In the gray before dawn, some can be found at the Fulton Fish Market sniffing, poking and gazing into the eyes of a yellowtail snapper. After midnight, usually in jeans and leather jackets, they might observe the sky while hailing a taxi home. But in between, their world is a professional kitchen as brightly lighted as a surgical theater, as hot as an ironworks and as frantic as a Wall Street trading floor.

title: Needle Exchange Programs Fail to Deliver Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rangers' Slump Gets a Little Uglier
description: The Rangers' losing streak reached three tonight and the Blues' winning streak reached seven when St. Louis beat New York by 5-3 in raucous Kiel Center. The defeat, which left the Rangers with a 1-3-4 record, was the first of seven games in 13 nights in what could be a portentous fortnight for the Blue Shirts.

title: Privacy Preservation in Gramercy Park
description: THOSE busybodies from Gramercy Park, as Carol Roberto calls them, are at it again. Four years ago, she received a flier in the mail from the Gramercy Neighborhood Associates Inc. inviting her to a hearing in which landmark designations would be discussed. Her address, 136 East 16th Street, was on the list. She allowed herself an hysterical moment, then said, ''This democratic fighter says no.''

title: Essay; Clinton's Campaign Conspiring
description: ''Soft money'' which may be donated in large chunks to a political party -- must not be used to directly assist the campaign of a candidate for Federal office. Nor may such a candidate direct its use to aid his own election. That's the law.

title: Deaf, Not Disabled
description: MARGIE GLENDENNING was among the first to buy tickets for tonight's performance of the Gallaudet Dance Company at Trump Plaza. Since 1988, Mrs. Glendenning has worked for Trump Casino Services, the administrative organization that operates three casinos here. Mrs. Glendenning, a native of Atlantic City, and her husband, Gordon, an upholsterer, are both deaf.

title: Patriarch's Visit Bolsters Orthodox Church
description: Six years ago, the Rev. David Hovik said, his nondenominational congregation in Arlington, Wash., reached a turning point, deciding that ''there has to be more to worship'' than the hymns and prayers of evangelical Protestantism.

title: D.C. Confidential
description: TAKING CHARGE

title: Backtalk; Violence, Redemption and the Cost of Sports
description: The trial balloon with Marv Albert's toupee on top has long since returned to ground. The broadcaster politely declined even discussing an offered radio job until after his sentencing this week and then presumably more time for jail or psychological counseling. But the brief flurry 10 days ago accomplished the mission of preparing us for his return. Most people polled seemed to think that after a decent interval (after the bite marks fade?), Albert should resume what has been a notable career. Sports, after all, is about second chances, coming back from all the bad bounces of life, from knee injuries to rape convictions.

title: Glamorous Internships With a Catch: There's No Pay
description: HOPE WAGNER, a sports administration major, scored a dream summer job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES LESSER, ETHEL
description: MOSES LESSER-Ethel, on October 13, 1997, who triumphed over all of life's battles except the last one. She will be missed by her loving family, Harry, Judith, and Anne, and by her many wonderful friends.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on Sept. 28, about Paris, referred incorrectly to the vineyard opposite the Lapin Agile bistro in Montmartre. It is not the last working vineyard in the city; there are several others.

title: Rift Widens for Pastor and Restive Parishioners
description: Over the last 20 years, the Church of St. Francis Xavier on West 16th Street has established itself as one of the city's most progressive parishes, openly accepting gay men and women, divorced people and others often alienated from the Catholic Church. But in the last year, after the arrival of a new pastor and the subsequent dismissal of several popular staff members, the church has found itself embroiled in an increasingly nasty dispute.

title: Once-Forgotten Dali Returns to a Shrine
description: Thirty-five years ago, Salvador Dali completed what until now has been a little-known painting that was meant to depict ''A Vision of Hell.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; A Stomach Full of Needles
description: The Chinese writer Can Xue's latest collection of stories is a book for readers who have grown tired of minimalist fiction. THE EMBROIDERED SHOES (Holt, $20) offers fanciful language and plenty of action, much of it bizarre: an old woman ransacks her neighbor's bedroom each night in search of a pair of shoes she lost years before; a man wakes up with his stomach full of needles, which appear on X-rays but do him no harm. The best of these tales have the compression of dark fables. Others sound like surreal poetry or a paranoiac's mutterings, veering here and there without a unifying thread. Reading Can Xue's fiction is like running downhill in the dark; you've got momentum, but you don't know where you're headed. At times, her characters adopt a formal speech that seems to parody the rhetoric of the Chinese Communist state: bureaucracy with a lunatic ring. Then the narrative shifts gears and comments on itself: ''Deep inside they hoped to find some trace of something related to present matters that could provide a new passion to the stories they made up. But they also knew that its arrival would be for the most part accidental.'' Translated by Ronald R. Janssen and Jian Zhang, the stories in ''The Embroidered Shoes'' describe strange, disordered worlds where people speak in riddles and time and setting are as fickle as the wind. Lisa Michaels

title: They Want To Live
description: As I read about those who anticipate the indefinite extension of the human life span, two thoughts nagged me. The first was Jonathan Swift's warning that ''every man desires to live long; but no man would be old.'' The second was an image of a world overpopulated by such narcissists and crackpots as your article features.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DREW, ROBERT A.
description: DREW-Robert A. 1947-1997. In loving memory on your birthday. Loving and missing you always, Mom and the family

title: Many Voices Raised in Song
description: SINGING is the focus today, with opera at 3 and choral music at 5. Ellen Chickering takes the title role in the Connecticut Concert Opera production of Donizetti's ''Lucrezia Borgia,'' with artistic director Wayne Rivera appearing as her son and Kyle Swann conducting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASTERNAK, HENRIETTA
description: PASTERNAK-Henrietta. On October 16, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Milton Pasternak. Cherished aunt and great aunt. Services on Sunday, October 19, at 1 P.M. at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: What You See Is Deconstruction
description: BURNING WITH DESIRE

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; New York's Parallel Lives
description: The worlds of New York have inspired many collective metaphors -- melting pot, a boiling pot, a rainbow, a patchwork quilt, a gorgeous mosaic -- and none of them really work. Seven million people do not resemble an inanimate object. The best image of the city's diversity is not an abstraction. It is alive in Central Park and called the Skate Circle.

title: Westchester Q&A: John W. Reavis Jr.; Leveling the Field for Young Black Skiers
description: OUT there somewhere perhaps is a black American who can do for skiing what Tiger Woods did for golf. And John W. Reavis Jr. is determined to see that he (or she) is properly nurtured and trained.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORLIN, RICHARD, M.D.
description: GORLIN-Richard, M.D. The Trustees, Faculty and Staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center deeply mourn the passing of our most cherished friend and esteemed colleague Richard Gorlin, M.D., Senior Vice President of The Mount Sinai Medical Center, The Dr. George Baehr Professor of Clinical Medicine, Mount Sinai School of Medicine, Medical Director of The Mount Sinai Health System, and internationally-renowned cardiologist in whose honor the Richard Gorlin, M.D./Heart Research Foundation Professorship in Cardiology was established last month for the Director of The Cardiovascular Institute of The Mount Sinai Medical Center. Born in Jersey City, NJ, Dr. Gorlin earned his undergraduate and medical degrees at Harvard, and was associated for more than two decades with Harvard Medical School and Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston, where he rose to the position of Chief of the Cardiovascular Division, before joining Mount Sinai in 1974 as Murray M. Rosenberg Professor and Chairman of the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine, a post he held for 18 years. He played a pivotal role in strengthening the capacity of Mount Sinai School of Medicine during its critical, formative years, developing programs of excellence in numerous medical disciplines, recruiting outstanding faculty, setting and achieving ambitious research goals, establishing a Division of Molecular Medicine to help Mount Sinai realize the potential of modern biomedical research, and transmitting his vast knowledge and skill to medical students. He also served Mount Sinai in numerous additional capacities, ranging from membership in the President's Advisory Group and President of the Medical Board of The Mount Sinai Hospital, to Dean for Clinical Affairs of Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Dr. Gorlin was known for his compassionate as well as expert care of patients, and he was recognized worldwide for his numerous outstanding contributions to the diagnosis and management of cardiovascular disease. He authored more than 400 published papers and over 100 invited articles, delivered no less than 75 honorary lectures, served on the editorial boards of prestigious journals, and was Editor-inChief of the journal Primary Cardiology for 20 years. He held countless appointments on task forces and memberships in professional societies, and his numerous awards included the Scientific Achievement Award from the American Heart Association, The New York Academy of Medicine's Glorney-Raisebeck Award and Medal for distinguished lifetime achievement in cardiovascular disease, and the Jacobi Medallion, highest award of The Mount Sinai Alumni. He will be remembered most fondly for his compassion, dedication, wisdom and personal warmth, and he will be sorely missed. We extend our sincerest condolences to his wife, Florence, his children, Douglas, William, and Wendy Tayer, his son-in-law Marc Tayer, daughter-in-law Natalie Gorlin, grandchildren Madeleine and Melanie Tayer, and the entire family. Stephen M. Peck, Chairman John W. Rowe, M.D., President Arthur H. Rubenstein, MBBCh, Dean Barry R. Freedman, Executive Vice President Wendy Z. Goldstein, Director Alan L. Schiller, M.D., President, Medical Board

description: Emily Alejos, the daughter of Rosalia A. Alejos of Santa Monica, Calif., and the late Dr. Juan E. Alejos, is to be married today to Aaron Wimpfheimer Finkel, a son of Doris and David Finkel of Manhattan. The Rev. R. John Nelson is to officiate with Rabbi Ari Fridkis at the Water's Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: High Cuisine
description: DURING my first visit, on my husband's birthday nine years ago, Highlawn Pavilion took my breath away. Never mind the view, which reminded me how much I missed Manhattan. (We had only recently arrived in New Jersey.) It was the salmon that turned my head, a large pink fillet, as juicy as it was delicate.

description: TWO months ago in Federal court in East St. Louis, Ill., Michael Blucker, 28, a paroled thief, sued Illinois state prison guards and other employees whom he accused of ignoring his requests for help when he was allegedly raped and treated as a ''sex slave'' by gang members while behind bars. Mr. Blucker, who is HIV-positive, says he was infected as a result of the sexual abuse.

description: TOUGH? Giuliani tough? Our Mayor Giuliani? Pretty hard-nosed, sure. No pussycat, that ex-prosecutor. Some New Yorkers like that, some don't, and we'll find out who likes what on Election Day.

description: Nancy Dickerson, who in the 1950's and 60's combined network television reporting with her role as a sought-after Washington partygiver and insider, died yesterday in New York Hospital in Manhattan. She was 70 years old and maintained homes for many years both in Washington and New York.

title: Norman Beck, Elizabeth Rowntree
description: Elizabeth Rowntree, the daughter of Dr. Ellen B. Rowntree and Peter D. Rowntree of White Plains, was married yesterday to Norman Kenneth Beck, a son of Frances L. Beck and Kenneth D. Beck of Westerville, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. Richard Murdoch performed the ceremony at the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Charles Stacy, an Episcopal priest, took part in the service.

title: Never-Ending Saga
description: Hypertext, far from inspiring a ''group consciousness,'' merely gives a reader the same freedoms available to consumers of other art forms. For example, in viewing a sculpture installation, although the artist may prescribe a particular order in which to view the objects, the consumer makes choices continually -- which way to look, how long to spend, what to focus on and when to leave or ignore.

description: THREE events compete today at 3 P.M.: a piano recital in Katonah, a recital for viola and piano in Peekskill and orchestral favorites in Valhalla.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Banners for Ballots
description: At the turn of the century, English and American women took to the streets to demand the right to vote. Suffragist movements mounted propaganda campaigns using the tools of publicity -- banners, placards, floats and ribbons -- that were equal, if not superior, to any conventional electioneering. This visual agitation had an indelible effect on the public and ultimately helped the suffragists achieve their goals early in the long history of the use of fine art and applied art in the service of women's issues. However, until recently these documents received curiously little scholarly recognition. In SUFFRAGETTES TO SHE-DEVILS: Women's Liberation and Beyond (Phaidon, $59.95), Liz McQuiston, a graphic designer who has also written a history of protest graphics, traces in word and image an impressive legacy, from the earliest public demonstrations to contemporary street art and advertising, of advocating equal rights, abortion rights, AIDS research, rape law reform and protection against domestic violence. This exhaustive study reveals that little has actually changed in feminist protest art since the earliest handmade signs hit the streets. A portion of the book surveys how women's health and other issues are visually represented in the third world. Another addresses the ways sexist advertising is satirized and parodied. This book rejects issues of esthetics in favor of the contexts in which art is made and the constituencies that it serves. Steven Heller

title: Not Big Men on Campus, But Big in the Ivy League
description: Dartmouth extended college football's longest unbeaten streak to 22 games today with a 21-7 victory over Yale that was nothing to boast about. Take away three big plays in the first half of this tedious contest and it came out almost even.
