title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, MILDRED BERGER
description: ROSS-Mildred Berger. Beloved wife of Matthew H. Ross. Mother of Jane Ross, Alan and Eleanor Ross. Loving grandmother and adoring great-grandmother. A life filled with good works; among other activities she was the first woman President of Central Synangogue, Founder and first Director of Central Synangogue Nursery School and Synagogue Seniors Group. Member of Council to the Dean of Hebrew Union College, member of the Board and the Executive Committee of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, and she served on the Board of the Scholarship and Welfare Fund of Hunter College. Elected to the Hunter College Alumni Hall of Fame. Services will be at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and East 55th Street, Monday, 10:00AM. Interment for family members only. Memorial contributions may be made to The Scholarship and Welfare Fund of Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, New York, New York 10021.

title: Forget Washington; Social Issues Shift to the States
description: REPUBLICAN and Democratic candidates alike declared, ''Power to the People!'' in the 1996 campaign. They were not invoking 1960's radicalism but expressing their enthusiasm for returning power from Washington to state and local governments.

title: A Gang of Hustlers Turns a Dime Bank Into a Cash Cow
description: One economic postulate of the streets holds that where there is cash, there is crime. But even hard-boiled police officers are marveling at the ingenuity of the latest low-end scam to hit the East Village. Beat cops from the Ninth Precinct report that a gang of ragtag hustlers are picking off bank card codes of unsuspecting customers at the Dime Savings Bank branch at Eighth Street and Second Avenue and taking thousands of dollars from their accounts.

title: Portraits Of an Economy
description: While highly dependent on Wall Street, left, New York also dominates high-profile businesses like the theater. Its liabilities include chronic poverty and a widening gap between the rich and the poor. The paradoxes of the city's economy are city's economy are evident in the people who work it it. Articles, pages 14 and 15.

title: Tomorrowrama!
description: Visions

title: Anne Giovaniello, Thomas Zafian
description: Anne Therese Giovaniello and Thomas Edward Zafian are to be married today in New York. The Rev. George Kelly, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bride, is to perform the ceremony at Holy Trinity Chapel at New York University.

title: A Beautiful Guy
description: Since the dawn of time, or so some might say, women were meant to be models and men were meant to admire them and be content with being handsome. But judging from a new book, all that has changed with the coming of one man: Marcus Schenkenberg.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Sept. 14 about tours of the Vasari Corridor in Florence has become outdated. The tours were scheduled to run through Oct. 31, but were canceled late last month because of a lack of qualified guides from the Uffizi Gallery, a spokeswoman for the gallery said.

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; Seinfeld Masala
description: The star is a slim, wisecracking actor named Jaffrey. His modest Manhattan apartment is an open house for the wild-haired, eccentric Shaukeen, the balding underachiever Ashiq and the solipsistic brunette Neha. All four are neurotic, cynical New Yorkers; the show chronicles the minutiae of their daily lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, SARA ROSE
description: LEWIS-Sara Rose, died peacefully in Virginia Beach, VA., on October 17, 1997. Affectionately known as ''Rose'' to all who knew her, she was the loving wife of the late Harry Lewis. Rose is survived by her devoted daughter Margie Brotman, Margie's husband Bob, two grandsons David and Ira, their wives Lynnda and Amy, and nieces and nephews, all of whom loved her dearly. Rose served as the executive secretary to the various chairmen of the New York State Athletic Commission from 1937 to her retirement in 1983. A graveside service will be held at the Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island, New York on Monday, October 20 at 11 AM.

title: Two Republican Rivals, One Purpose on Taxes
description: The House Republicans' antitax road show came rolling through Newt Gingrich territory on Friday night, playing a tune that might well have been called ''50 Ways to Loathe Your Tax Code.''

title: In America; Days of Terror
description: The bonfire was symbolic, as was the noose that dangled from a lower limb of the willow oak outside 29 East Fourth Street in the East Village. The film maker Ric Burns was shooting a scene for his 10-hour PBS documentary history of New York City. The events symbolized by the fire and the noose, collectively known as the draft riots, took place in July 1863. It was a period of panic and terror that is difficult to imagine today.

title: Stephanie Siegel, Michael Weiner
description: Stephanie Joy Siegel, a daughter of Marilyn and Howard Siegel of Park Ridge, N.J., was married last evening to Michael Hal Weiner, a son of Francine C. Weiner of Nanuet, N.Y., and the late Leonard Weiner. Rabbi Mark W. Kiel officiated at Bridgewaters in New York.

title: Not So Fast; Speed Has Hit the Wall
description: ON an ancient, dry lake bed in Nevada last week, a British team broke the sound barrier on land, 50 years after Chuck Yeager first did it in a plane. Just for fun, General Yeager reprised his performance again last week, this time making a routine flight in an Air Force jet. Also last week, more than 100 million Americans got to work by car and more than 10 million others took airplane flights. But they didn't get there any faster than the week before, the year before or the decade before.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Conversions Step Up Pace in Stronger Office Market
description: WHILE new commercial construction plods along in the state, conversions of older buildings as well as industrial properties to Class A offices continue at a brisk pace.

title: ANALYSTS EXPECT HEALTH PREMIUMS TO RISE SHARPLY
description: After four years of near stability brought about by the spread of managed care, the premiums that most Americans pay for their health insurance are poised to rise significantly next year, industry groups and health care consultants report.

title: Carol Bakinowski, John McCormick
description: Carol Ann Bakinowski and John William McCormick were married yesterday in Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Gill C. Babeu performed the ceremony at St. Bridget of Ireland Roman Catholic Church.

title: At Times, Confidence Could Be Ill Advised
description: A coach loves a player to be brash and confident, but quarterback Stoney Case may have gone too far. What he did this week has some of his teammates feeling that Case crossed the line from brazen to arrogant. Case's situation is one of several problems facing the Arizona Cardinals, the National Football League's hard-luck team.

title: A Place for Everything and . . . Then What?
description: MY wife describes the decor of my home office as Crack House Revival. The women from the cleaning service won't touch it.

title: An Ancient Tragedy Told as a More Recent One
description: IN stunning prologue to ''The Darker Face of the Earth,'' a celebratory rush of resplendent theatrical effects spills over the stage of the Crossroads Theater Company: choral chants, grand gesture, masks and movement everywhere. Slaves and conspirators, among a company of 20 are momentarily conjoined in an invocation of life. The ritual ends in a moment of exultation. A newborn child is lifted high, as if favored by the gods.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of hotels on Sept. 14 with an article about Maastricht, the Netherlands, misstated the name of the square on which the Hotel du Casque is situated. A fax from the Maastricht Visitors and Convention Bureau received on Oct. 6 pointed out that it is the Vrijthof, not the Onze Lieve Vrouweplein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALAZZO, THOMAS
description: PALAZZO-Thomas. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Thomas Palazzo, associated with The Times from 1974, until retiring in 1993.

title: The Restoration That Failed: Rutgers Royalty Still in Exile
description: After several losing football seasons and sagging attendance at games, homecoming spirit at Rutgers University needed a boost, and one dean thought she had the answer.

title: Easy Reading
description: To the Editor:

title: Habitats/248 West 22d Street; Long-Leaking Crash Pad Turned Into Dream House
description: NESTLED on the couch in her comfortable (and dry) living room, Judy Kreston remembered her mother's reaction 28 years ago when she saw the four-story brick building in Chelsea that her daughter had just bought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEIN, EVA
description: SHEIN-Eva. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Eva Shein, beloved mother of our esteemed colleague Shelia Lebowitz. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marlene E. Post Nat'l President Beth Wohlgelernter National Executive Director

title: BATTLE EMERGING ON HOW TO REVISE BANKRUPTCY LAW
description: Even before sending it to Congress, the authors of a proposed revision to the Federal bankruptcy law have begun squabbling over its conclusions. As a result, some lawmakers are already moving to draft bills that would take a much tougher line with debtors than what is recommended in the 1,300-page report they commissioned.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PHOTOGRAPHS ON VIEW

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TWERSKY, YITZCHAK, RABBI
description: TWERSKY-Yitzchak, Rabbi. The leadership and staff of UJAFederation mourn the passing of Rabbi Yitzchak Twersky, cherished father, beloved husband, renowned scholar, eminent educator. His life enriched those around him with his gentleness and knowledge. To his beloved wife, Atarah, to his daughter, Rebbitzin Tzipporah Rosenblatt, his son-in-law, Jonathan Rosenblatt, rabbi of the Riverdale Jewish Center, and his grandchildren, Yehuda, Tonya, Shmuel and Rivka, and the entire Twersky/Rosenblatt families, we send our deepest sympathies. May you be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Nancy Berkeley, Frank Bynum Jr.
description: Nancy Ellen Berkeley, the daughter of Marilyn B. Snyder of New York and Herbert Berkeley of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Frank Kitchell Bynum Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bynum of Birmingham, Ala. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the home of John Poster in Southampton, N.Y. The Rev. Martin R. Tilson, an Episcopal priest, took part in the service.

title: Filling Out the Picture of an Autocratic Maestro
description: THE JACKET PHOTOS ON George Szell's old LP's showed two very different men. In formal portraits, Szell looked grandfatherly, bald and bespectacled and often gently smiling. But pictures of him in concerts, rehearsals or recording sessions captured the severity of focus the musicians who played under his direction knew, and went a long way toward explaining why they considered him a tyrant.

title: Here Comes the Bride, In October and Ivory
description: LIKE many women today, Liz First refused to be a June bride. Just refused. A producer for National Public Radio in Boston, she was married yesterday, partly to avoid any association with June. That month, she says, is when princess brides get married.

title: Golf; Mattiace's Hot Streak Continues
description: He turned 30 years old on Wednesday. He became a father on the Fourth of July. But while 1997 has already been a milestone year for Len Mattiace, he is still looking for his first victory on the PGA Tour.

title: With Her Family in Need, a Star Athlete Walks Off the Field
description: Emily Stauffer remembers vividly the moment when she raced downfield on that beautiful, crisp afternoon last fall in Cambridge, Mass., the center midfielder on the Harvard women's soccer team. She ran with the wind at her face and the game on the line to collect a pass from a teammate. She had a clear shot at the goal 20 yards away. This was against the University of Massachusetts in the third and sudden-death overtime of the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships, with the score 1-1 at Ohiri Field.

title: Ms. Vartanian And Mr. Harris
description: Margaret Vartanian, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vartan Vartanian of Barrington, R.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Andrew Harris, a son of Dr. and Mrs. A. Brooks Harris of Berwyn, Pa. The Quaker service was held at the Providence Friends Meeting House in Providence, R.I.

title: Libya Is Reported to Lobby to Settle Pan Am Explosion Case
description: Apparently encouraged by African and Asian support for its campaign to have United Nations sanctions lifted, Libya is lobbying the families of people killed in the explosion of a Pan Am jet over Scotland in 1988 in the hope of persuading them to settle the case, the mother of one victim says.

title: Leila Burger, Richard Mansouri
description: Leila Evans Burger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Van Vechten Burger Jr. of New York, was married yesterday to Richard Paul Mansouri, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Karim Mansouri of Frederick, Md. The Rev. Leslie Merlin performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: Corrections
description: A credit last Sunday with a picture of John Osher, founder of Cap Toys Inc., cited in an article about disagreements within family-run companies, misspelled the given name of the photographer. She is Courtney Kealy, not Cortney.

title: Fight Doesn't Add Up
description: The two welterweight matches at the Foxwoods Resort Casino here Friday night were supposed to add some clarity to the muddled picture in the division. It didn't quite do that, but it did prove that the ability to add is an important skill, particularly if you are scoring a fight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAKOFF, REBECCA
description: RAKOFF-Rebecca, age 95, on 10/ 13/97. Widow of Dr. Morris, dear mother of Dr. Stanley, and Dr. Saul, adored grandmother of Amy, Joanna, Martin and Joseph. Also survived by sisters, Julia Merlis, Lillie Levy and brothers Edward, Simon, and Hy Avrut and five great-grandchildren.

title: How That Free Social Security Card Can Still Cost You $15
description: TWO weeks after the birth of her son, Connor, Irene M. O'Brien received a letter, amid mounds of advertisements for baby products, that angered her.

title: Life Styles of Rich and Ailing; In Luxury Hospitals, High Tea to Fresh Goat
description: The patient, a Saudi prince, wanted roasted goat, and insisted that only the most freshly slaughtered would do. The staff of 11 West, Mount Sinai Medical Center's luxury wing, was eager to make him happy. But how?

title: A Key Figure Of Apartheid Denies Intent Was Murder
description: A top apartheid-era official told South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission this week that thousands of cases of torture and murder under the National Party Government were really a result of a misunderstanding -- a semantics problem.

title: Wayne Smith and Shelley Anderson
description: Shelley Hoyt Anderson, the daughter of Eloise H. Anderson of New York and the late Vernon Hoyt, was married yesterday to Wayne Elliot Smith, a son of Alma V. Young and a stepson of Keith R. Young of Chicago. The Rev. Dr. James A. Forbes Jr., a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Cosmopolitan Club in New York.

title: Tom Hanks Solo in Central Park? Celebrity Sightings, Real or Not
description: In other cities, gushing over celebrities is expected, even anticipated, especially by the celebrities themselves. But in New York, celebrity fawning is frowned on by the natives as touristy and uncool.

title: Choose the Right Hammer for the Job
description: THE first hammer was probably a hand-held stone used to crush bone, nuts and hard roots for food. Archeologists say that around 7,000 B.C., primitive tool makers lashed a branch to the stone head -- a technique known as hafting -- and created the ancestor to the modern hammer.

title: Bulls Show The World Who's Best
description: For most of the 1990's, the Chicago Bulls have been calling themselves ''world champions.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENNETT, WILLIAM
description: BENNETT-William August, 80, died October 16, 1997, in Houston, Texas. Mr. Bennett was born on April 17, 1917, in Brooklyn, New York, attended New York University, where he was a member of Beta Gamma Sigma and graduated in 1939. He married Doreen May Snoddy in 1943, and they were together for over fifty-two years. Mr. Bennett was Senior Vice President of Frank B. Hall & Company of New York. He retired in 1982, to Fripp Island, South Carolina. He was a member and Elder in the Presbyterian Church. Mr. Bennett was preceded in death by his wife, Doreen May Bennett and is survived by his daughter, Barbara Bennett Collier and son-in-law, Timothy J. Collier of Houston, Texas; two granddaughters, Heather Carlisle Collier and Erin Leigh Collier of New York City, New York. Memorial services will be held in Beaufort, South Carolina. For those desiring, memorial contributions may be given to The Hospice at the Texas Medical Center, 1905 Holcombe Boulevard, Houston, Texas 77030 or the Friends of Caroline Hospice, Beaufort, South Carolina.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: A Long Dash Into History; Instead of Running Down, Sanders Is Still Outrunning His Pursuers
description: His reputation for evasion precedes him. Want to talk to Barry Sanders, stay close. Seeking an audience with the elusive running back requires a combination of ESP and athletic skill. He is like a whisper. You think he is there, then he is gone. Sanders speaks when he is ready, and when he finally does, he is so courteous that anyone standing near him tucks his shirt in.

title: Indians' General Manager, for One, Doesn't Believe the Braves Are a Failure
description: If the outcome of the playoffs were determined by regular-season performance, the World Series would have started in Atlanta, not here, last night. The Braves compiled the best record in the National League, and they won a division championship for an unprecedented sixth successive season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRONSON, EMERICK R.
description: BRONSON-Emerick R. Died on Oct. 15, at home, in Sag Harbor, NY, of a heart attack. Graduate of the Merchant Marine Academy, served in WW II. His career as an internatinal fashion photographer was based in Paris and NY. Predeceased by his wife Arden Catlin. Survived by his sisters Frances Fulton, Anna Luciana and Mary Schafer. Also survived by a number of nieces and nephews. Remembered with much affection by his many friends who shared his wide interests. Services were held and his ashes will be buried in the family plot in Pittsburgh, PA.

title: Tambi in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; Me Too
description: Religious sects, Boy Scouts and debutantes all dress alike for the same reasons. However, the people who agreed to pose on these pages (plucked from their habitats around town) dress alike for reasons as varied as designer lettuces. They do it to seduce, to flaunt a status symbol, to protect themselves from trends or to announce their membership in an informal community. Sometimes they even do it to rebel. Individuality, it seems, loves company.

title: Faces of the New York Economy; Immigrants Providing a Global Link
description: IN 1994, Zan Ng, a commercial photographer, persuaded Joseph Liu, an advertising executive, to join his fledgling ad agency, which Mr. Ng hoped would attract business from American companies trying to sell products to Asian consumers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NANNI, ETHEL
description: NANNI-Ethel. October 17, 1997. Beloved wife of Louis F. Nanni. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call on Saturday 7-9 PM and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

title: The Great Divide: East Side, West Side, Does It Matter Anymore? (Yep!); Say What You Like but It's Still Really Nice Over Here
description: THE place where God made man, according to Genesis, was in the east. The three Wise Men, the New Testament says, came bearing gifts from the east. And in Judaism, prayers are directed to the east.

title: No Decor, Lots of Shellfish
description: Certain names invoke certain associations. Newton and apples. Duke Ellington and pianos. And in central Harlem, the name Robert Lee means only one thing: shellfish. Tasty, lip-smacking-good crabs and mussels that customers swear they cannot find anywhere else.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAMBLE, THOMAS O. III
description: GAMBLE-Thomas O. III, suddenly at the age of 36 on October 5, 1997. Beloved father of Giacomo FioreGamble, son of Thomas O. Jr. and Amy Gamble of Santa Rosa, CA., husband of Janerae L. Fiore of Baldwin, N.Y., brother of Meg Gamble of San Francisco. Tom grew up in the U.S. and Japan, graduated from the Albany Academy and Pratt Institute. He lived in the NY area for the past 17 years and was working at the NY Zoological Society at the time of his death. He will be missed.

title: Van Cortlandt Debate Marks Its 300th Year
description: THE farcist Oliver Goldsmith wrote the above in ''She Stoops to Conquer'' about the time Pierre Van Cortlandt and his family were settling into their Westchester manor, which has a tavern on the premises.

title: When Westchester Had Slaves: A Catalogue of Unseen Faces
description: SOMETIMES when it is quiet, Barbara Bush-James takes a warm cup of tea, kicks off her shoes and settles into the oversize couch in the living room of her Yonkers home. With her glasses on, she can look out the window and see Yonkers Avenue. But she does not need her glasses to see beyond the avenue. She does not even need to open her eyes.

title: The Teacher as Star of the Class
description: ''THIS isn't about me,'' Maria Callas insists. ''You are here to observe the students. Not me. Forget all about me. Poof! I'm invisible.''

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; Surf Dudes Of Beach 89
description: The Dodge van is making good time along the Belt Parkway. It should, because it's 8 A.M. on a Labor Day Sunday. Three Brooklyn Surfers are in the van. They all live in Manhattan, every one of them. Adam Mergan is driving. By day he delivers for a New Jersey pharmaceuticals company. He's 27. Beside him is his girlfriend, Casey M., 24, who's in real estate, and in back is Eric Watson, 41, a hairdresser from the salon at Bergdorf's, sharing the hard van floor with a bag of soda and six or seven surfboards.

title: Meryl Poster, Daniel Levinson
description: Meryl Ivy Poster, a film producer, and Daniel Smith Levinson, a director of television commercials, are to be married this evening in New York. Rabbi Meir Berger is to perform the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: BENEATH MULHOLLAND

title: Corrections
description: A report in the F.Y.I. column last Sunday about the cover of the record album ''The Freewheelin' Bob Dylan'' misstated the location in the photograph. It is Jones Street in Greenwich Village, between Bleecker Street and West Fourth Street, not on West Fourth Street.

title: Another Columbus Day Parade Offers More Cause for Sniping by Mayoral Candidates
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger marched separately yesterday through the heart of one of New York City's sturdiest Italian-American neighborhoods, Bensonhurst, encountering starkly different receptions as they joined thousands of people in celebrating the Brooklyn Columbus Day parade.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 19, 1997
description: Weeks

title: Money's No Object in This Council Race
description: It took a staggering $900,000 -- most of it his own money -- for Andrew S. Eristoff to win and keep his City Council seat in two elections four years ago as a Republican representing the heavily Democratic East Side of Manhattan.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We come up with ideas on the cutting edge. We don't expect the priorities to be adopted right off the bat. We figure it's going to take some educating of the legislators.''

title: Buying the House and Fixing It Up With One Loan
description: A YEAR ago Kim and Robert McBratney bought their neighbor's house, at 131 Elizabeth Street in the West Brighton section of Staten Island. Mrs. McBratney explained how it happened.

title: Iran Sees Pistachio Ban As Foul Play by Enemies
description: It is not often that something as small as a pistachio can create so much stir, but remember this: in Iran, pistachios are big business.

title: The Class of '57 Gets Together Again
description: THE pages of East Haven High School's 1957 yearbook sprang to life on a recent Saturday evening in the middle-class community on the Connecticut shoreline.

title: Faces of the New York Economy; Big Earner, Big Spender, Little Burden
description: PHILIP G. POTTER, who develops investment products for high-net-worth clients of Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, likes to think of himself as an ''uberconsumer.''

title: Beerbohm on Bennett
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLAGHER, EILEEN (NEE BOEHM)
description: GALLAGHER - Eileen (nee Boehm), on October 16th, 1997 at Chapel Hill, NC. Wife of Nathaniel. Formerly of Darien, CT. Sister of Elise Haas. Funeral services private. Interment at West Point, NY.

title: Warhorse
description: Captured

title: When Old Movies Land a Part in the New
description: IN OUR CONSERVATION CONSCIOUS times Hollywood often pursues its own recycling program. As if determined to waste little of its legacy, the film industry dusts off and finds new uses for movie concepts from the past, not only in official remakes but also in uncredited rehashes and inspired variations on a theme.

title: A Latinist Lover and a Hero Who's Lacking in Tact
description: BACK IN 1962 RICHARD EYRE played the tiny part of Seyton in a Cambridge University production of ''Macbeth'' directed by his fellow-undergraduate Trevor Nunn. For those of us who were there that night -- and yours truly was reviewing the play for a student rag called Broadsheet -- it wasn't a very auspicious occasion.

title: Di Suvero, At Home Abroad
description: AT THE MOMENT FOUR GIANT STEEL sculptures by Mark di Suvero are parked on the lawns in front of the Hotel des Invalides here. The other day, an unseasonably hot Sunday, I watched the ubiquitious art students with sketch pads, who remain one of this city's more endearing cliches, along with the people who didn't seem to be taking special notice of the works at all but who interacted with them: the soccer players, for instance, who as a point of urban pride ignored the signs posted everywhere forbidding soccer on the lawns and used adjacent I-beams of one of the sculptures for goal posts.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: LOWER MANHATTAN

title: End the Divide, Trump Says
description: DONALD J. TRUMP says he may think more about the East-West issue than anyone else in the city. And he says he is on a mission: he wants to merge the two sides.

title: TELEVISION; Now It's All Bronte, All the Time
description: THE WRITER ANNE BRONTE has long remained in the shadow of her elder sisters, Charlotte and Emily. A ''literary Cinderella,'' the esteemed critic George Moore wrote of Miss Bronte in 1924. Indeed, the parsonage in Haworth, where all three women lived and wrote, was as cramped and drafty as any fairy-tale cottage so it seems an apt analogy. But no pumpkin ever turned into a horse-drawn carriage for her.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YASSKY, BESSIE
description: YASSKY-Bessie. Oct. 12, 1992. Forever loved, mourned and missed. We always see your beautiful face and smile. Elmer, Peggy and Lauri Ellias

title: At Disney World, 9 Nighttime Rides
description: Guests at Walt Disney World resort hotels in Orlando, Fla., can party with Mickey until the wee hours, thanks to the E-Ticket Express, $10 plus tax, which allows visitors with day passes to the parks to ride the nine most popular attractions at the Magic Kingdom after hours, avoiding the lines. Space Mountain, Pirates of the Caribbean, the Haunted Mansion and Alien Encounter are among the rides to be open until 11 P.M.

title: Boards Reviewing Liability
description: LAWYERS who represent New York City co-ops and condominiums are being bombarded with calls from anxious clients after a Criminal Court judge declined last month to dismiss criminal complaints against three members of a Brooklyn co-op board charged with violating the city's Window Guard Law. The charges were filed after an inspection of the building -- Premier House, a 185-unit co-op in Midwood -- found that nine apartments had faulty window guards. The inspection was made after a child fell out of a window in the building and died.

title: Roberto C. Goizueta, Coca-Cola Chairman Noted for Company Turnaround, Dies at 65
description: Roberto C. Goizueta, a Cuban refugee who became chairman and chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company, strengthening its global dominance in soft drinks and building one of the greatest generators of shareholder wealth in corporate history, died early today at Emory University Hospital in Atlanta. He was 65 and lived in Atlanta.

title: A School Needing Help Takes Lessons From Down Under
description: To the untrained eye, all hell has broken loose in Doreen Patchen's third-grade class at Public School 7. She sits on the floor reading with 10 children. Two others wriggle under headphones at a listening station. Others sprawl, reading and writing, on a rug. A few sit at tables, laboring on reports. A few don't sit at all.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the restoration of the Church of the Heavenly Rest included an outdated name for a school founded by the church and now long independent. The school changed its name in January from The Day School to Trevor Day School.

title: Faces of the New York Economy; A Laborer At Hard Jobs For Low Pay
description: ''IF you can survive the New York economy,'' Jennifer Fields said, ''you can survive anywhere.''

title: While Jets Are Winning, Johnson Isn't Grumbling
description: Here is why Keyshawn Johnson, who feels he can do more if only they ask him, is not complaining:

title: Parachute to Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Texan Smarting Over Jewel Theft at Airport
description: Stung by the recent loss of $590,000 in jewelry to thieves at Newark International Airport, the wife of Mayor Bob Lanier of Houston took a jab at the Port Authority police yesterday, suggesting that they could learn something from Houston's police force.

title: Miss Steinberg, Mr. Schachter
description: Stephanie Ruth Steinberg, the daughter of Natalie and Isaac Steinberg of Sarasota, Fla., was married last evening to Daniel Eben Schachter, the son of Drs. Judith and Joseph Schachter of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Linda H. Goodman performed the ceremony at the Picnic House in Prospect Park in Brooklyn.

title: CYBERSCOUT
description: PLOTTING A ROAD TRIP

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Oct. 5 about Madrid's recently reopened opera house, the Teatro Real, misstated the fax number for ordering tickets. It is (34-1) 516 0651.

title: With Empty Seats at 'Godspell,' an Organizer Cries Bias
description: To the producers of a current revival of ''Godspell'' in Harlem, it must have seemed they had all the elements for a potential hit.

title: Oxygen in Flight
description: To the Editor: I was upset by how my neurologically impaired son was treated by Air France on a recent trip to Paris.

title: Contract Extended For Symphony Director
description: Zdenek Macal, artistic director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, has signed a contract to remain in his post through the 2000-2001 season. In the 1993-1994 season, before assuming his present position, Mr. Macal was the orchestra's artistic adviser.

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; Seinfeld Masala
description: The star is a slim, wisecracking actor named Jaffrey. His modest Manhattan apartment is an open house for the wild-haired, eccentric Shaukeen, the balding underachiever Ashiq and the solipsistic brunette Neha. All four are neurotic, cynical New Yorkers; the show chronicles the minutiae of their daily lives.

title: Same Subjects, More Verbs in New P.S.A.T.
description: Nearly two million teen-agers who took the standardized tests used to qualify for the coveted National Merit Scholarships last week were quizzed for the first time on their understanding of English grammar.

title: Growing Sweater Business Stays at Home
description: AS far as Peri Basel is concerned, the phrase ''quality time'' as it relates to her two young daughters is meaningless.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: Up & Coming: Samantha Morton; Actress Against The Odds
description: WHEN THE DIRECTOR Robert Young describes the 20-year-old actress Samantha Morton -- ''She's tenacious, willful; she has an enduring character about her -- he could easily be describing the character she so memorably plays: Jane Eyre.

title: When Causes Spring From Grassroots
description: TWO grassroots environmental festivals in greater New Haven were blessed with perfect fall weather on a recent Saturday and hundreds of people took full advantage of the opportunities offered.

title: Offering a Choice Between East and West
description: JAPANESE Continental? What's that, rack of lamb in a tempura crust?'' The question, voiced by two people peeking through the window of Chez Kama in Great Neck, is understandable. The answer is no. Chez Kama is not about fusion food. Diners can choose rack of lamb or tempura, but East and West generally do not meet on the same plate.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the growing use of cremation in funeral services misstated the affiliation of Wilson H. Beebe Jr., who noted the percentage of bodies cremated annually in the New York area. He is executive director of the Metropolitan Funeral Directors Association, not the Cremation Association of North America.

title: For Bridgeport Campus, A New Kind of College
description: A NATUROPATHIC college has been established at the University of Bridgeport and school officials said they believed the university's association with the Unification Church would not discredit the program.

title: Lynette Blevins, Douglas Hettrick
description: Lynnette Lavonne Blevins, the daughter of Vonnie M. Nelson of Minneapolis and Richard L. Blevins of West Paterson, N.J., was married yesterday to Douglas Tyrrell Hettrick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey L. Hettrick of Meriden, Conn. Deborah O. Stiewing, a justice of the peace in Newtown, Conn., officiated at the McLaughlin Winery in Sandy Hook, Conn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANTWERK, SAM
description: GANTWERK-Sam. It is with profound sorrow that we extend our sincere condolences to Belle, Lewis, Carol, Roz and Ellen on the loss of their beloved husband and father. He will be sorely missed and dearly remembered by all. Arthur and Laura Dennis and Andrea Jay and Felice

title: Katherine Wilson and Richard Meyer
description: ACCORDING to friends, Katherine Newton Wilson loves carrots, cappuccino, going out for brunch, eating cereal for dinner and telling funny stories, something she excels at.

title: Streetscapes/The East 50's; 1871 Panorama Offers a View on the Cusp of History
description: ONLY in the last generation have the East 50's around Madison and Park Avenues been extinguished as a residential area, as commercial development replaced the vestiges of Victorian brownstones and Edwardian apartment houses. An unusual two-part panorama from 1871 shows the area at the start of residential development, but research cannot explain who made the photograph, or why.

title: Lynn R. Drasin And Ron Hazelton
description: Lynn Robin Drasin, a segment producer in New York of ''Good Morning America'' on ABC-TV, and Ron Hazelton, that show's home improvement editor, were married last evening at the Plaza in New York. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated with the Rev. David Lothrop, a United Methodist minister.

title: Commercial Property/The Flatiron District; A Transformation From Off-Price Retail to $100 Socks
description: THE Flatiron shopping district -- the section of Fifth Avenue between the signature building at 23d Street and the beginning of the Union Square area at 17th Street -- has undergone a transformation in the last decade, retail specialists say.

title: Technology Makes Me Mad
description: It was good to read Volk's anti-technology article. But, hey, I don't have to fake having a rotary phone; I still have one. The best part is when people who are completely familiar with computers come over and have to ask for help using the phone. I love it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRENIK, HELEN (NEE HEILING)
description: KRENIK-Helen (nee Heiling). Died at age 94 in Boynton Beach, FL. Devoted wife to the late Charles Krenik. Beloved mother to Paul, Betty and the late Henri. She is survived by her grandchildren Martine, Catherine, Corinne, Gordon, Gabrielle and Giselle and caring step-grandchildren Gerard and Marc. She is also survived by her great-grandchildren Josse, Zachary, Bella and little Jeremy. She will be sorely missed. Services Sunday, Oct. 19, 10 AM, Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, MARION EDWARDS
description: MILLER-Marion Edwards, 81. Loving wife of Professor Neal E. Miller, died of pneumonia in the Yale/New Haven Hospital on October 13. To us former students of Professor Miller at Yale and Rockefeller University (many of whom are now famous psychologists and neuroscientists), Marion was a great source of comfort and encouragement in times of the stress connected with our training. To her husband, her two children, York and Sara Mauch, and her five grandchildren, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Others wishing to join us can express themselves to Professor Miller care of The New Haven Funeral Service (203-777-2309). A memorial service will be held on October 24, 3:30 P.M., at the Unitarian Society of New Haven, 700 Hartford Tpk., Hamden, CT. (203-288-1807). In lieu of flowers, send donations to either the Unitarian Society or the American Indian College Fund, 21 W. 68th St, NYC 10023, 212-787-6312.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Bus Signs in the Sky

title: Roosevelt-Yonkers Rebounds With Victory Over Arlington
description: Raheem Allen, a 5-foot-10-inch senior tailback and defensive back, scored all of Roosevelt-Yonkers' points in its 39-14 victory over Arlington (3-3). Allen had 17 carries for 267 yards and 5 touchdowns, returned a fumble 30 yards for another touchdown, and kicked 3 extra points. Roosevelt (5-1), the state's defending champion, rebounded nicely from last week's 45-12 loss to Gorton, which snapped the school's 16-game winning streak.

title: Faces of the New York Economy; A Professional Celebrating Differences
description: ROWING up in rural Ohio, the son of a farm equipment dealer, Jim Streacker had a simple dream: to live in a place where Sears was not the arbiter of style.

title: Class-Conscious
description: Benilde Little worked for a Newark newspaper and a Manhattan-based fashion magazine (The Star-Ledger and Essence.)

title: Karen Pasquale And Robert Hoch
description: Karen Marie Pasquale, the daughter of Rosemary and Louis W. Pasquale of Harrison, N.Y., is to be married today to Robert Lawrence Hoch, a son of Sandra W. Hoch of White Plains and the late Sheldon Hoch. Rabbi Albert L. Sturmer is to officiate, and Msgr. Guy Vinci is to take part in the ceremony at the Orienta Beach Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Vowing Not to Blink
description: The best way to weather market breaks is to build a long-term diversified portfolio and sit tight.

title: Assessing The Role of Mutual Fund Investors
description: A DECADE after the stock market crash of 1987, two of its biggest contributors -- portfolio insurance and index arbitrage -- either no longer exist or operate under severe constraints.

title: Sprucing Up a Slain Teacher's School
description: The name of a slain teacher was not invoked as 200 volunteers from Time Warner showed up yesterday to spruce up William Howard Taft High School in the Bronx.

title: In Merger, Catholic Hospital Can Compromise; Doctrine vs. Care
description: To the Editor:

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Volkswagen Passat GLS; A Cure for the Common Car
description: SOME cars leave me wondering, ''Whatever were they thinking when they came up with that?'' Even after the marketing people make their presentations, I still don't see the point.

title: The Cult Of the Mind
description: Mark Dery's ''Cult of the Mind'' (Sept. 28) once again picks on the Heaven's Gate cult, whose members were going to escape to a promised paradise.

title: Two Omitted Villages On the North Shore
description: Re ''On North Shore, the Rich Thrive on Anonymity'' (Long Island Weekly, Oct. 5): I was saddened and shocked to see that my community, the incorporated Village of Laurel Hollow, does not exist. While you mentioned that Lattingtown is No. 44 on Worth's list, you fail to mention that Laurel Hollow is No. 49.

title: In Search of Black Voters For a Republican Governor
description: Leroy I. Robinson is Governor Whitman's great black hope this campaign season. As recent statewide elections have shown, black voters make up a segment of the voting population that alone could make the difference in returning Mrs. Whitman to the Governor's mansion or sending her back to her Hunterdon County estate. And as the state Republican Party's campaign coordinator for African-American affairs, Mr. Robinson is the man the Governor is counting on to deliver black voters to the polls on her behalf. ''My job,'' he said, ''is to get the African-American vote.''

title: The Past Is Another Country
description: MY BROTHER By Jamaica Kincaid. 198 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.

title: Approaches To Tibet
description: THERE are three ways of entering Tibet legally, and on each of three trips I have made there as a budget traveler, I have used a different route.

title: Hopefuls, Street Toughs; Power Brokers; Networkers; Strivers; Grande Dames; Musclemen; Exiles; Reformers; Purists; Clones; Big Mouths; Outsiders; Air Kissers; Fanatics; Gossips; Nightclubbers; Babes in Toe Shoes
description: Though she has been living in New York for a year, she has never been above 96th Street or below 18th. She hasn't seen SoHo or Greenwich Village -- which she refers to as ''Greenwich'' -- or the Metropolitan Museum of Art. She doesn't attend high school. But no, Jessica Kusak is not a culturally deprived youngster yearning to escape the confines of the inner city. She is, in fact, part of the city's cultural elite.

title: Italy Sets Price Parameters For Phone-Company Offering
description: Italy's Treasury said this weekend that it had set the share price of Telecom Italia S.p.A. in this week's public offering at a maximum of 11,200 lire ($6.50) a share, or just above Friday's closing price of 11,161 lire.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We are working to strengthen taxpayers' procedural and substantive rights in cases of I.R.S.

title: Brown's Fastball Lets Him Down
description: Kevin Brown, who absorbs defeat in the same genteel manner as the basketball coach Bobby Knight, was in his final, frustrating inning of work in Game 2 of the World Series tonight when a paper airplane dropped onto the front part of the mound.

title: Pro Bono Accounts
description: * Juvenile Diabetes Foundation International/The Diabetes Research Foundation, based in New York, to Foote, Cone & Belding, New York, a division of True North Communications.

title: Shift in Focus Is Expected At Coca-Cola
description: With the death of Roberto C. Goizueta, its chairman and chief executive, the Coca-Cola Company is expected to focus more attention on developing the enormous global network that he built up during his 16-year reign.

title: In Prison, Free to Get Information; Inmates Abuse a Law to Obtain Personal Data, Critics Say
description: Last month, Maria Molina received a letter from the New York City Board of Elections that both bewildered and petrified her. In dry legal language, the Sept. 10 letter informed the 27-year-old mother of three that Hector Rivera, ''who is currently incarcerated at the Woodbourne Correctional facility,'' is ''seeking to determine your current address.''

title: City Son vs. Inside Outsider In Atlanta's Mayoral Race
description: Even Mayor Bill Campbell's most ardent supporters acknowledge that he is a lucky man. He is lucky, they say, because after four years of managerial misadventures, he is running for re-election against an opponent, City Council President Marvin S. Arrington, whose record may be just as vulnerable as his own.

title: U.S. Envoy In Jerusalem To Try to Spur Peace Talks
description: The American mediator in the Middle East, Dennis B. Ross, returned to Jerusalem today to start another round of shuttle diplomacy aimed at finding a way to get substantive negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians moving again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEAGUE, MARY A. (NEE MCCORMACK)
description: TEAGUE-Mary A. (nee McCormack) Beloved wife of the late Edward, devoted mother of Bernadette, Michael and the late John. Cherished grandmother of Christopher and Eduardo. Loving daughter of the late Michael McCormack and the late Bridget (nee Carey). Dear sister of James, Ann Gaffney, Michael and the late Margaret, Agnes and Sister Rose de Lima, O.P. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., NY, Monday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 11 AM, St. Ignatius Loyola Church.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

description: LEAF-Ethel V. Loving wife of George. Devoted mother of Suzanne and Harold Greenberg, and adoring grandmother of Deena and Robert Mandel. She will be sorely missed. Services Monday, October 20, 10 AM, at Riverside Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Taking In the Sites; A Renewed Focus on the Crash of '87
description: What's the difference between a pigeon and a stockbroker? The pigeon can still make a deposit on a BMW.

title: Duval Wins Again, Dramatically, Again
description: For three years, people wondered when David Duval would win.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HULL, KENNETH JR.
description: HULL-Kenneth Jr., of Chevy Chase, Maryland, on Wednesday, October 15, 1997. Beloved father of Catharine Hull Fleming, Edward Luckenbach Hull, and Dorothy Hull Osgood; brother of Shirley Huntington; and grandfather of four. Memorial service will be held at All Saints Church in Chevy Chase, MD., Tuesday, October 21, at 4:30 P.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Chesapeake Bay Foundation (410-268-8816) or American Oceans Campaign (202-544-3526).

title: Overpass Taken Down At F.D.R. Drive
description: Drivers commuting into midtown Manhattan on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive this morning might notice the disappearance of the Washburn overpass at East 117th Street.

title: Tajong's Burst Leads Mount St. Michael's
description: NcHendia Tajong ran 58 yards for a score on his first carry and finished with 101 rushing yards as Mount St. Michael's of the Bronx (5-0) defeated Iona Prep of New Rochelle (3-3) yesterday, 49-8. Tajong, a senior, has 2,115 career all-purpose yards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICH, SOLOMON
description: REICH-Solomon. Beloved husband of Gizella. Devoted father of Barbara and Simon Gluck. Adored grandfather of Stephanie Witkin, Sabrina and Effie Gluck. Services and interment were held Sunday, October 19, 1997.

title: Leo Burnett Resigns As Ameritech Agency
description: The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago said that it had ended its relationship with the Ameritech Corporation by resigning as its media agency of record. Billings were estimated at $100 million.

title: Treasury Issues Set For Sale This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: U.S. Alliance Brings Prestige To Argentines
description: For many Argentines, President Clinton's decision last week to name their country a non-NATO ally of the United States was the latest proof that Argentina is finally returning to prominence in the industrialized world after decades of social and economic ruin.

title: Charisma and Bravura From Houston via Cuba
description: It is debatable whether the world at large needs still another production of ''Don Quixote.'' But Ben Stevenson, the Houston Ballet's artistic director, reckoned correctly that this not-so-venerable 19th-century comic ballet would be the right dancing machine for his two dazzling stars, Lauren Anderson and Carlos Acosta.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, DR. MENEK
description: GOLDSTEIN-Dr. Menek, died suddenly on October 18, 1997. Professor at NYU Medical Center. Beloved nephew of Frania Gitterman and Maria Rosenbloom. Loving cousin of Dr. Alex Gitterman and Dr. Hana Savir and their families. Devoted to dear friend Dr. Mira Dziatelowski and her family. Funeral on Tuesday at 1:15 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street.

title: Tarnished Dreams Hold Painful Lessons
description: The brute will to survive that keeps a country ticking in ''The American Clock,'' Arthur's Miller dramatic vaudeville about the Great Depression now at the Signature Theater Company, is shared, it seems, by the play itself. Although it was hailed as a work full of promise when seen at the Spoleto Festival in Charleston, S.C., in 1980, critics felt it had been altered to the point of sabotage when it arrived on Broadway only months later. It died the sort of quick and brutal death that seemed to harbor no hope of resurrection.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Thai Official Is Ready to Quit
description: Thailand's Finance Minister, Thanong Bidaya, said today that he would quit, probably within the week, as part of a planned Cabinet reshuffle by Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh.

title: Harsh Immigration Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAKE, ESTHER
description: BLAKE-Esther. Born 7/12/1898, died 10/11/97. Loving wife of the late George Blake, she lived in Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn until 1985, when she moved to Pound Ridge. She is survived by her children Olive Colon of VT, Marshall Blake of CT, Steven Blake of Pound Ridge, NY, eight grandchildren and five great-grandchildren, as well as her sisters Lola Farer and Grace Cooper. Donations in her name can be made to Habitat for Humanity, PO Box 351, White Plains, NY 10603.

title: Accounts
description: * Play by Play Toys and Novelties Inc., San Antonio, to Anda & Scotti Advertising, New York, to handle its account, previously handled by Ziccardi & Partners, New York. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Parcells Has Method Behind His Madness
description: As Jets Coach Bill Parcells is apt to do, at the beginning of last week he gave a speech to his players that left them stunned. Parcells read some quotes from Miami Dolphins players who had said after last week's game that the Jets had played flat. He spoke of how, if the Jets were going to beat the New England Patriots, it would be up to the players, and he was going to do something that gave them no excuses.

title: Virginia Banking Deal
description: First Citizens Banc Shares Inc. said last week that it had agreed to acquire 15 branches in Virginia from the Signet Banking Corporation. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENTHAL, I.J.
description: ROSENTHAL-I.J. The passage of time has not eased our sadness. Mac and Renee Kashdan

title: Inflation? Where?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Steps Up Campaign As Messinger Presses On
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani capped his first full weekend of campaigning last night by visiting two Brooklyn rabbis celebrating the harvest festival of Succoth, while his challenger, Ruth W. Messinger, sought yesterday to shore up support from blacks, Jews and women, traditionally three of the Democratic Party's most reliable constituencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POTOFSKY, SYLVIA
description: POTOFSKY-Sylvia. On October 17. Beloved sister of Julius and Hyman, cherished aunt of Richard, Allan, Judy Finch and Donna Ritter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKERSON, NANCY
description: DICKERSON-Nancy. The Board of Trustees, faculty, and staff of The Rockefeller University are profoundly saddened by the loss of our beloved friend, Nancy Dickerson Whitehead, an esteeemd member of The Rockefeller University Council since 1989. Her loyal friendship to the university and her advocacy of its medical research programs will be greatly missed. We admired her tremendous professional accomplishments as a television news correspondent, author, lecturer and president of her own independent televison production company. Her keen intelligence and astute insight into the world of government and politics have inspired succeeding generations of journalists. The Rockefeller University community will also treasure the memory of her warm and gracious nature, and the generous way in which she embraced those around her. With heartfelt sympathy, we extend our deepest condolences to her husband, John C. Whitehead, Trustee of the University, and to her family. Torsten N. Wiesel, President Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman Board of Trustees David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman and Life Trustee Board of Trustees

title: Corrections
description: An obituary and headline yesterday about Ira H. Lustgarten, a Manhattan lawyer and authority on trusts and estates, misstated his age. He was 68, not 86.

title: Michael E. Burt, 49, Surgeon; Researched Ways to Halt Tumors
description: Dr. Michael E. Burt, a thoracic surgeon who was president of the medical staff at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan, died on Oct. 4 in Southampton, N.Y. He was 49 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Fire Burns 200 Cars at Yard
description: Fire officials and insurance investigators were continuing to look into a blaze that swept through an auto yard in Carteret on Saturday morning, destroying about 200 cars, the town's Fire Chief said yesterday.

title: Stranglehold in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: As Yale Moves Away From Apple Computer, Cries (Nay, Shouts) of Conflict of Interest
description: Last June, students preparing for their freshman year at Yale received a letter from the university's director of information technology, Daniel A. Updegrove, steering them toward the purchase of personal computers using the Windows operating system from Microsoft, equipped with microprocessors from Intel.

title: Last Unbeaten Tumbles
description: BRONCOS 25

title: Patents; A system that effortlessly switches telephone calls between cellular and land-line networks.
description: IN a step toward a world where people are assigned a personal telephone number they can carry everywhere, Bell Atlantic Network Services Inc. has won a patent for a personal communication system that switches calls between land lines and cellular networks.

title: 'Soft Money' Talks
description: With the battle over campaign finance reform legislation resuming in Washington today, opponents of reform are again arguing that Americans do not much care. Many citizens may not be able to see how their lives are affected by all those coffees, receptions, telephone calls, fund-raising letters and other campaign rites. But any suggestion that hustling for dollars has no bearing on ordinary Americans is dispelled by a new report from Common Cause outlining how the open-ended donations at the center of recent scandals have had a far-reaching effect on government.

title: The Ultimate Obsession; What Will People Pay to Enter His World?
description: Entering the three-story foyer of Richard Garriot's hilltop estate is a short trip into another dimension. The high walls are covered with crossbows and other menacing medieval weapons, overhead is an imposing astronomical observatory. At eye level, there is a bullet hole in the staircase.

title: Investing In Integrity Pays
description: Journalists last week criticized a reorganization of The Los Angeles Times, which appears to be the most important merger ever of the business side and news side of a major American newspaper.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: For Rowers, It's the Getting There, First or Not
description: The lean, muscled young men began powering their racing shells toward the starting line this morning as the announcer called out the competitors in the second event of the final day of the Head of the Charles Regatta, the country's largest rowing event.

title: People
description: * V. Lance Tarrance Jr. was named to the new position of managing director in the public affairs practice at Burson-Marsteller, Washington, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc. He had been a senior executive at Gallup Inc., Princeton, N.J. Also, John Smith, a senior partner at Mead Point Group, Greenwich, Conn., a consulting company owned by Burson-Marsteller, was promoted to chairman of the Burson-Marsteller global health care practice, succeeding Edna Kissmann, who was named chief knowledge officer. Mr. Smith and Ms. Kissmann will be based in London.

title: Bumper Crop of Apples Seen
description: New Jersey apple farmers are in the middle of a bumper crop that should reap five million pounds more than last year's harvest, agricultural experts said.

title: Metro Matters; In New Jersey, An Electorate Of Discontent
description: AT the beginning of the decade, before the rest of the country realized just how thoroughly disgusted it was with politics as usual, voters in New Jersey were way ahead of the curve.

title: A Change in Thinking at Ernst & Young
description: What a difference a few weeks makes. Philip A. Laskawy, the chairman and chief executive of Ernst & Young, predicted in early September that the nation's accounting profession, which now consists of six major firms, would not see further consolidation. ''I do not expect any more mergers among the Big Six,'' he said.

title: In a Democratic Bastion, Giuliani Looks Good
description: In John's Barber Shop on Linden Boulevard in St. Albans, Queens, the walls are plastered with posters of black politicians, the Bible is open to Psalms, and there are hints of a possible Election Day surprise.

description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRABEL, SYLVIA
description: GRABEL-Sylvia. Wife of the late Lester Grabel. At age 80, on October 18, 1997. Loving mother of Barbara, Miriam, Maury, and Lillian. Grandmother of Michele, Marc, Alan, Jonathan, Aliza, Eliezer and Joshua.

title: Health Concerns Mounting Over Bacteria in Chickens
description: The nation's health authorities are increasingly concerned about a poultry contaminant that can be as debilitating, if not as deadly, as salmonella. Researchers say that the contaminant, the campylobacter bacterium, infects a larger percentage of chickens than they had realized and that antibiotics used to treat people sickened by infected poultry appear to be losing their effectiveness.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Nancy Dickerson referred incorrectly to Lyndon B. Johnson, who was a host at a party for her when she was married in 1962. Johnson was Vice President, not President, at the time.

title: The Twists in the Road To Happily Ever After
description: Among the propositions advanced tomorrow night on ''Love, Lust and Marriage: Why We Stray, Why We Stay'' are these: Romance is an evolutionary side effect. When it comes to love, the conscious brain might as well be asleep. Sexual appeal may seem just skin deep (men with symmetrical features report having more sex), but looks are often indicators of healthy genes. Nature demands that a man enjoy sex ''with as many women as will let him.'' The seven-year itch usually begins around the fourth year of marriage, but only about half as many women as men scratch. (Beavers are monogamous for life, so what is all this about being busy as a beaver?) And there is a lot to be said in favor of arranged matings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROTT, TIMOTHY
description: TROTT-Timothy. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Naomi Master, Jonathan and the late Michael. Cherished grandfather of Howard, Jeremy, Leah, Melissa and Matthew. Funeral services Monday, 12 noon at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, NY.

title: Honors
description: * Betty Anne Cooper, managing partner and strategic services director at Gillespie, Princeton, N.J., was named Woman of the Year by the New York Chapter of the Women in Direct Marketing International.

title: Program to Protect the Elderly
description: Hoping to discourage crimes against the elderly, police officials in Westampton Township are to announce a special program today to prevent crimes often committed against the elderly, a sheriff's official said.

title: Alomar (Who Else?) Lift Indians Into a Tie
description: Because the Florida Marlins reached the World Series faster than any expansion team ever had, and because they were the first wild-card team to make it, the Fish, as they are colloquially known, might have thought they were charmed enough to make this World Series theirs.

title: Adil Carcani, 75, a Leader In Albania's Stalinist Twilight
description: Adil Carcani, the last Prime Minister in Albania's Stalinist era, died last Monday, according to press reports from Tirana, the capital. He was 75.

title: Cuba's Unwanted Refugees: Squatters in Havana's Teeming Shantytowns
description: Seven years ago, Jorge, a sugarcane cutter from the eastern province of Guantanamo, arrived here with his wife and three children hoping, he said, for a better life. Though he eventually found a job that paid double his old salary, he was able to get housing only by building a one-room wooden shack on the outskirts of the Cuban capital.

title: Goals Clash in Shielding Privacy
description: Senator Dianne Feinstein was dismayed last year when it took only three minutes to get her confidential Social Security number, like millions of others, from an on-line look-up service available to Internet users around the world.

title: Tokyo Says Global Trade Surplus Rose 37%
description: Japan said today that its merchandise trade surplus in September rose 37.1 percent from a year earlier, to $8.81 billion. The increase, though significant, was smaller than economists had expected.

title: Even Without N.E.A., Art Will Misbehave
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The occasion may be a party, but that does not mean that Dr. DAVID A. KESSLER, the former Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration who is now dean of the Yale University School of Medicine, won't have a serious message when he addresses 500 guests in the Puck Building in SoHo next Monday.

title: Patriots Doubt A Crucial Call
description: It was an official's call that left the Patriots shaking their heads: a fourth-and-18 pass from Drew Bledsoe to Shawn Jefferson that was ruled incomplete.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GENDAL, KEITH BARRY
description: GENDAL-Keith Barry. Three years gone, forever mourned.

title: What History Leaves Out
description: In 1983, Charles Hamilton Jr., a Manhattan dealer of autograph manuscripts, was asked to comment on the so-called Hitler diaries supposedly found in an East German hayloft and purchased by the magazine Stern for $3.3 million. Mr. Hamilton, a white-haired, elf-like man who died last year, called the diaries -- in a wonderfully pleonastic phrase -- ''a misbegotten prevarication.'' The same phrase may well turn out to apply to a cache of index cards and scraps of White House stationery with jottings allegedly in John F. Kennedy's handwriting. These documents, some apparently legitimate and some purportedly authenticated by Mr. Hamilton himself, come from Lawrence X. Cusack 3d. He claims they belonged to his father, a lawyer often employed by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

title: The Yellow Pages Are Caught Up in an Aaaarms Race
description: Patrick McPhilomy thought he had come up with a perfect name for the new business he wanted to start last spring in Phoenix. Mr. McPhilomy, who already owned one locksmith service, wanted to open up another, to cater specifically to people in emergencies.

title: Ex-Yankee Pitcher Is Arrested
description: A former New York Yankees pitcher remained in custody in the Monmouth County Jail yesterday, facing charges that he sexually assaulted and threatened his ex-wife, The Associated Press reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, JULIAN
description: HOFFMAN-Julian of East Hampton on October 18, 1997. Beloved husband of Margaret; loving father of Peter Hoffman and stepfather of Gail Reisin-Goldstein and Ronald Frank. Dear brother of Elizabeth Lily Frenkel; devoted uncle of Steven and Irving Frenkel; cherished grandfather of seven grandchildren. Reposing Monday 12 noon at the Brockett Funeral Home, Inc, 203 Hampton Road, Southampton, New York, where a service will begin at 1 PM. Interment to follow Cedar Lawn Cemetery, East Hampton. In lieu of flowers, donations to Apple, Inc., P.O. Box 1270, Wainscott, New York 11975 would be appreciated.

title: Foley Inspires the Jets After O'Donnell Gets the Hook
description: Glenn Foley was the backup quarterback who had never led the Jets to victory. And this was a Jets franchise that was trying to make a statement against the division-leading New England Patriots, who had beaten them six straight times.

title: Frenetic, With French Fries, Or Calm, With Cranberries

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOIZUETA, ROBERTO C.
description: GOIZUETA-Roberto C. The Board of Governors of Boys & Girls Clubs of America mourns the passing of long-time member and wonderful friend, Roberto Goizueta. His deep commitment to the young people of our nation, demonstrated consistently throughout his Chairmanship of The CocaCola Company, as well as by his great personal generosity and spirit, will be greatly missed by all. Rick Goings, Chairman and Roxanne Spillett, President Boys & Girls Clubs of America

Greatuncle of Sean, Alexa, Brendan, Hayley and Erica. Services Tuesday, 11:30 AM, at Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd at 76th Rd, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Foley Catches Patriots Unawares
description: Maybe it was because Bill Parcells had switched quarterbacks long before the fans at Giants Stadium had a chance to chant for the backup. Maybe it was because Glenn Foley was not even an afterthought in the Patriots' game plan. Whatever the reason, when Parcells made the switch, the Patriots' defenders did not even notice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENBERG, HARRIET
description: GOLDENBERG - Harriet. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of the sister of its esteemed Trustee, Jules Cohen, and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Dr. Sol Roth, Rabbi Hermann Merkin, Founding Pres. David Yagoda, Chairman Dr. William Schwartz, President

title: Guest Shot and Killed At a Wedding Reception
description: A wedding reception in Queens ended in bloodshed early yesterday when a guest was shot and killed as he tried to break up a fight between two other guests, the police said.

title: The Giants Ride Overtime Gamble to First Place
description: As the Giants were about to take the field today against the Detroit Lions, Coach Jim Fassel told his players that their division rivals, the Washington Redskins, had lost their game with the Tennessee Oilers.

title: '97 WORLD SERIES
description: CLEVELAND -- 6

title: Run of Zeros Ends, And Ogea Gets Victory
description: Poor Chad Ogea. Make that, poor, dubious Chad Ogea. He was known as the pitcher who had received absolutely no run support over 19 1/3 innings in the post-season, who was the only Indian who lost games in the American League Championship Series and whose changeup was whacked for a grand slam by the Yankees' Paul O'Neill when Cleveland was wobbling in the division series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANTSOUDES, JAMES GEORGE
description: GANTSOUDES-James George. 55, died October 17, 1997, at his home in Redding, CT after courageously fighting cancer for more than a year. Jim adored and was adored by his wife, Martha, their children Sarah, Spencer and Nicholas, and his two children by a previous marriage, Geordy and Alexis. He will also be deeply missed by his mother, Helen, his sister, Betsy Robeson, his brother, Peter, and his other relatives and many dear friends. Jim was a patriot who graduated with honors from West Point and served with distinction in Vietnam. A graduate of Harvard Business School, he became an esteemed member of the investment banking community who at his death was Managing Director and Global Head of Equity Capital Markets at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Co. A memorial service will be held October 25, 1 PM, at the Gantsoudes home, Poverty Hollow Road, Redding, CT 06876. Contributions may be made to: The New Building Fund, Redding Boys and Girls Club, Redding, CT 06896

title: O Smach Journal; On Its Last Legs, the Saddest Cambodian Army
description: At this base camp near the Thai border, just south of the Chong Chom pass, what is left of Cambodia's most successful non-Communist movement has taken refuge among piles of debris and collapsed huts.

title: Russia Fails to Block Bosnian Serb Vote
description: With a combination of deft diplomacy and superpower might, the Clinton Administration has vanquished Russia's attempt to block parliamentary elections in the Serbian region of Bosnia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKOFF, GAIL
description: ROCKOFF-Gail. The membership and Board of Governors of the Boca Rio Golf Club, Boca Raton, FL announce with deep regret and sorrow the passing of our dear friend and member, Gail Rockoff, and extend our sincerest condolences to her husband, Clyde and their family. Norman Ricken, President

description: A LAST KNISH -- Most of the regulars were at the Grand Luncheonette for its last day on the Deuce. B3.

title: Foreign Affairs; Have I Got a Deal for You
description: So I was thinking about buying an office building in Shanghai. You know, something with lots of glass and steel to impress my friends. To do it right, I thumbed through the latest Jones Lang Wootton research on the state of the Asian-Pacific real estate market. I was surprised. There was a lot to choose from. The vacancy rate for Shanghai office buildings was 32 percent, and many more new buildings were coming up. I checked out Beijing; the vacancy rate there was 33 percent. So I checked out Bangkok, Thailand. Same story as China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSMAN, BARBARA
description: HAUSMAN-Barbara. In loving memory of Barbara Hausman, who is survived by husband Arthur, children Kenneth and Wendy, grandchildren Michele and Mark, and sisters Sheila and Roseanne. Funeral at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Jericho Trnpk, Woodbury, NY, on Tuesday, Oct 21, 1997, at 10 AM. Shiva period begins Saturday evening, Oct 25, until Thursday, Oct 30, at the home of Arthur Hausman.
