description: GAFFNEY-Sr. Walburga R.S.H.M. On October 18, 1997, of Marymount, Tarrytown, NY. Wake Monday, 3-7 PM, at Marymount Convent, Vigil Service 7:30 PM, Funeral Mass, Tuesday, 10:30 AM. Interment Mt Calvary Cemetery.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about children looking at a red-tailed hawk in Central Park referred incorrectly to the children's school. It is Public School 234, not 243.

title: Chase Is On: Everybody Is After Nebraska
description: Playoff advocates, pay attention: The playoffs have already started, and these are the rules. You cannot look ahead. You had better not look back. Not in the Big Ten, not anywhere anymore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLER, MIRIAM
description: HANDLER-Miriam. The Officers and the Board of Directors of the American Friends of the Hebrew University, deeply mourn the passing of Miriam Handler, wife of Professor Milton Handler, former Chairman of the Board and longtime leader of our organization. We extend to Professor Handler and the entire family our deepest condolences. Lawrence Newman, Chairman Keith L. Sachs, President Adam B. Kahan, Exec VP

title: CHRONICLE
description: Not many parties draw the kind of rave reviews that were awarded to the celebration of ARTHUR M. SCHLESINGER Jr.'s 80th birthday last week at the Century Association on West 43d Street.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, LILLIAN P.
description: POSNER-Lillian P. On October 17, 1997. Loving wife of Alan H. Posner. Beloved mother of Dr. Marshall R. Posner, Jeffrey P. Posner, Matthew A. Posner and Claudia A. Posner. Loving grandmother of M. Bowen Posner and Lily G. Posner. Service Tuesday, 12 noon, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Contributions to the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies would be appreciated.

title: A Late Starter, AT&T Is at Sea In Global Race
description: The AT&T Corporation, readying itself for its third change of top management in the last two years, remains conspicuously adrift in global waters.

title: PBS Makes Digital Plans
description: While the nation's commercial television networks ponder, equivocate and complain as they confront the impending transition to digital broadcasting, the Public Broadcasting System is plunging forward with a clearly articulated plan and obvious enthusiasm.

title: Bridge; Discarding a Blocking Ace When a Deuce Is the Key
description: This year the world of bridge has lost two of its leading citizens: Edgar Kaplan, who died last month, and Alfred Sheinwold, who died in March. Together, with their Kaplan-Sheinwold system, they introduced the bridge public to many ideas that have become popular in tournament play. Most notable was the inverted minor raise, in which one club, two clubs is strong, and one club, three clubs is weak.

title: Updates/Media and Technology; Microsoft Repairs Glitches That Vexed Its On-Line Service
description: The Microsoft Network has worked out some glitches that prevented prospective members from signing up last week, and deterred existing members from upgrading their on-line service and checking their accounts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELZ, WILLIAM R.
description: DELZ-William R. On October 18, 1997, of White Plains, New York, formerly of Rye. Devoted husband of Joan, beloved son of Mona Delz of Florida, adored father of Nicole Lynch of Bronxville, New York, Pamela Hissey of Avon, CT, dear brother of Marilyn Seeley of Florida. Grandfather of Teddy, Tyler, Brittany and Sara. The family will receive friends Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, October 21 at 10 AM at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY. Entombment is private.

title: The Books That Sell
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYSZKIEWICZ, ALICIA, COUNTESS TYSZKIEWICZ
description: TYSZKIEWICZ-Alicia, Countess Tyszkiewicz. Born May 28, 1912, died October 8, 1997 at her home in New York City. Full of courage and true to her own high standards to the end. Mourned by her friends, Isabelle Cazeaux, Ruth M. Collins, Fernando Demarquet, Robert Hickey.

title: Museums Finding Money In Aristocratic Rooms
description: Three prominent American museums sold antique doorways, fireplaces, paneling and lots of furniture from old English houses, most of it unseen by the public for decades, at Sotheby's Manhattan auction room on Saturday. The sale left the museums -- the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Art Institute of Chicago and the Denver Art Museum -- some $460,000 better off. But the sale also illustrated a trend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORLIN, RICHARD, M.D.
description: GORLIN-Richard, M.D. The Physicians of the Medical Service of the Veterans Affairs Medical Center, Bronx, New York, note with great sorrow the loss of Richard Gorlin, M.D., a colleague who was also a friend and mentor to many of us. As well as his many great achievements in cardiology and in the senior administration of the Mt. Sinai Medical Center, he was also an enthusiastic supporter of the educational, research and clinical missions of the Medical Service at the Bronx VA. His example as a caring and compassionate doctor will always be remembered. Our deepest condolences to his wife Florence and to his entire family. Clive Rosendorff, M.D., Ph D, Professor of Medicine, Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, and Chief, Medical Service Bronx VAMC

title: Amazon Rain Forest Is Global Responsibility; Fast-Track Destruction
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Killed in Parkway Crash
description: Two people were killed and three others injured Saturday afternoon on the Garden State Parkway after a van apparently struck the rear of a compact car, driving the vehicle off the road, the New Jersey state police said.

title: Autopsy Is Inconclusive In 2-Month-Old's Death
description: An autopsy performed yesterday did not determine the cause of death of a 2-month-old boy who was found dead Saturday in his family's Brooklyn apartment, officials said.

title: Daniel E. Provost Dies at 78; Was Tobacco Industry Leader
description: Daniel E. Provost 3d, the tobacco executive who got Arthur Godfrey and Ronald Reagan to endorse Chesterfield cigarettes, led the the Liggett & Myers campaign against claims that tobacco is harmful and never abandoned his bedrock position that there is no evidence that smoking causes cancer, heart problems or other illnesses, died on Oct. 13 at his home in Ranchero Mirage, Calif. He was 78.

title: Updates/Media and Technology; Infoseek Revises Its Internet Search Engine
description: By providing a natural leaping-off point for the World Wide Web, the so-called search engines -- Yahoo, Infoseek, Excite, Lycos and the like -- attract more people to the Web than any other category of sites. No wonder these companies are eager to establish brand-name identities in hopes of attracting a loyal audience they can sell to advertisers.

title: Amazon Rain Forest Is Global Responsibility; Florida Isn't Hurting
description: To the Editor

title: A Private Eye ; Seeing the Bearded Lady as Statement, Not Sideshow
description: ''Come look at the freaks! Come gape at the geeks!'' ''Side Show'' was singing at full throttle. In the dark of the audience, I turned surreptitiously to look at my companion, Jennifer Miller. Because she is a woman with a beard -- thick, dark, elegantly trimmed -- her profile differed from all the faces in the row, all the strangers' eyes and cheeks gleaming red or blue in the changing lights from the stage.

title: Priscilla Told Miles, I Won't, But Two Descendants Say, I Do
description: It was just a romantic legend, based on real people who landed aboard the Mayflower at Plymouth, Mass., in 1620. But as generations of Americans have learned, Miles Standish, a captain who could brave cannon fire but not the eyes of a woman, sent his trusted lieutenant, John Alden, with his marriage proposal to Priscilla Mullens, who answered, ''Why don't you speak for yourself, John?''

title: Once AT&T Names New Leader, Climb Back to Top Will Be Tough
description: When the AT&T Corporation names a new leader, it will be a long-awaited move in the company's effort to regain unquestioned leadership of one of America's fastest-growing industries.

title: Ethics in Office
description: To the Editor,

title: Roy Rappaport, 71, Expert on Religion and Society
description: Roy A. Rappaport, an innkeeper turned scholar, anthropologist and director of the program of religion studies at the University of Michigan, died on Oct. 9 at his home in Ann Arbor. He was 71.

title: Why the U.S. Fell Short of Ambitious Goals for Reducing Greenhouse Gases
description: Four years ago, President Clinton stood in the Rose Garden and declared that by the end of the decade his Administration would reverse the increase in the nation's emissions of pollutants that threaten to warm the planet's climate.

title: Amazon Rain Forest Is Global Responsibility; What City Can Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Amazon Rain Forest Is Global Responsibility

title: American Men Set Course Record
description: The United States men's national team set a course record yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., while winning the Championship Eight, the final race of the Head of the Charles Regatta.

title: Engineers Faulted on Signals
description: New Jersey Transit engineers have run their trains through red lights four times this year, the most since 1993, with three of the incidents occurring in a 15-day stretch in September, the Record of Hackensack reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JEWETT, RICHARD WILLIAM DICKINSON
description: JEWETT-Richard William Dickinson. Of Upper Nyack, NY, a recognized civic leader for over 70 years, died on October 16, 1997. He was 98. Mr. Jewett was a former Mayor of the Village of Upper Nyack, NY, President of the Nyack YMCA, founding member of the Rockland County Historical Society, and Board member for Grace Church. Visiting hours will be on Monday, October 20, 1997, at the Hannemann Funeral Home, Nyack, NY. Funeral services will be held at Grace Church, Nyack, NY, on Tuesday, Oct 21, 1997, and interment will follow at Oak Hill Cemetery.

title: The Museum as Work of Art
description: It is, by the way, an art museum.

title: Ban Latin Arms Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: Starks Is Latest Addition to the Knicks' Injury List
description: John Starks had returned from a local hospital and was on the training table after the game, lying on his back while reading a Bible. Maybe he was searching for comfort in the Scripture after experiencing the pain of a sprained left ankle.

title: Calloway Makes The Correct Call
description: Giants wide receiver Chris Calloway not only caught the game-winning touchdown, but, as one of the game captains, also made the right call on the coin flip that decided which team got the football first in overtime.

title: Rangers Recall Sweeney
description: The Rangers' roster is starting to look like a Boston College mini-reunion: New York now has three Boston College stars from the 1986-87 season. The latest is Tim Sweeney, called up from the Hartford farm club last night and expected to be available when the Rangers play host to Carolina at Madison Square Garden tonight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIETZ, SARAH (FLANDERS), MD
description: DIETZ-Sarah (Flanders), MD, 84, of West Main St., Chester, CT. Widow of Dr. J. Herbert Dietz Jr., passed away Tuesday, Oct. 14, 1997, Essex, CT. Memorial services will be Thursday, Oct. 23, 10:30 AM at Christ Episcopal Church, Rt. 151, Middle Haddam, CT. Interment will be at the convenience of the family. There are no calling hours. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The J. Herbert Dietz Jr. Memorial Fund, c/o Mrs. Lois Weinstein, Dept. of Social Work, Memorial Hospital, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021. For further information contact the Spencer Funeral Home, 112 Main St., East Hampton, CT.

title: Pair Leave Devon To Form Agency
description: Two executives at Devon Direct Marketing and Advertising in Berwyn, Pa., have left to open their own agency in Wayne, Pa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURKEL, GAZELLA
description: TURKEL-Gazella. Three sons, Harold, Joseph, and David, sadly announce the death of our beloved mother on October 16, 1997. Her 98 years were blessed with a loving husband, children, and grandchildren. She has earned her rest in the arms of God.

title: Soros to Donate Millions More to Help Russia
description: George Soros, the Hungarian-born American financier and philanthropist, said yesterday that he would donate as much as $500 million in the next three years in Russia trying to improve health care, expand educational opportunities and help retrain the military for civilian jobs.

title: Authors Wrestling With God (if They Can Find Him)
description: GOD AND THE AMERICAN WRITER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLONSKY, MURRAY
description: POLONSKY - Murray. Beloved father of Leonard, Ivan and Maxine, and Jay. Cherished brother of Robert Polon and Ruth Heller. Loving grandfather of Alan, Marc, Nicole, Jonathan, Linda, Amy, Andrea, Elizabeth, Sara and Alexander. Loving great grandfather of ten. His love and good humor will be greatly missed. Services were held Sunday, October 19th, 1997.

title: Sports of The Times; Chants of 'Fo-ley, Fo-ley' Force a Decision by Parcells
description: AS the Jets' 24-19 punishment of the Patriots wound down yesterday, many of the 71,061 voices in Giants Stadium were chanting, ''Fo-ley, Fo-ley.'' And even now, as Glenn Foley stood on the stool at his locker to answer questions, an unidentified teammate's deep voice was heard across the room chanting, ''Fo-ley, Fo-ley.''

title: Offerings Set For Equities During Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: G.O.P. CHIEF AIMS TO SHIFT BURDEN IN I.R.S. DISPUTES
description: The chief Republican tax writer in Congress will push this week to curtail the legal presumption that the taxpayer is always guilty in Federal tax disputes, introducing a powerful but divisive new issue into fast-moving efforts to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Joanne A. Moonan, 84, Designer Of Whimsical Costume Jewelry
description: Joanne A. Moonan, a costume jewelry designer in the 1930's, 40's, 50's and 60's, died last Monday at Southampton Hospital in Southampton, N.Y. She was 84 and lived in Manhattan and Westport, Conn.

title: Man in the News; 'Quintessential Salesman' Is Poised to Take the Helm at AT&T
description: When C. Michael Armstrong became the chief executive of the Hughes Electronics Corporation in 1992, he wasted no time. He and his lieutenants labored night and day for three months on a plan to restructure the bloated military contractor and cut thousands of jobs.

title: McGreevey Is Running on Record as Mayor
description: The day after James E. McGreevey took over as Mayor of this sprawling suburban town on Jan. 1, 1992, two Federal agents arrived at his office unannounced to investigate the disappearance of $650,000 in health insurance funds during the previous administration.

title: Jogger Raped In Quiet Park Near Cloisters
description: A 45-year-old woman jogging in the woods behind the Cloisters, the replica of a medieval monastery tucked inside Fort Tryon Park in upper Manhattan, was raped shortly before dawn yesterday, the police said.

title: Neil Young and Friends Gather to Have Fun For a Serious Purpose
description: The benefit concert has developed into one of the great charades of popular music over the last few decades. There is a worthwhile investigation to be done on how much of the ticket proceeds actually reaches an intended charity. Standing in contrast to sham benefits for unspecified causes was Neil Young's Bridge concert this weekend at the Shoreline Amphitheater here.

title: Bleak Study On the Arts Stirs Outcry
description: Federal reports are not usually known as page-turners. But the National Endowment for the Arts, having supported a list of what became artistic hits and best sellers in its 32 years, now has one of its own, along with a controversy.

title: National advertisers strive to brand their product names on the minds of the consumer.
description: IF, as they say, the future is where we will spend the rest of our lives, America's biggest and most persistent consumer marketers are striving to insure that we will spend that future, well, spending.

title: At Home Abroad; Heartbreak House
description: The Mufti of Banja Luka, Ibrahim Halilovic, is a young-looking man, clean-shaven, who wore a suit and tie when we met. The only sign of his religious vocation was his headgear: a white ahmedija, like a modified turban.

title: Roberts Fills a Void And Ignites Indians
description: When the Cleveland Indians acquired Marquis Grissom before the season, they solved a lot of questions about their outfield, their offense, their personality.

title: Plan to Delay Amtrak Strike Is Accepted
description: Amtrak management and track workers agreed yesterday on a cooling-off period of at least one week, averting a possible strike on Wednesday that could have wrought havoc on hundreds of thousands of commuters in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALK, SHELDON
description: FALK-Sheldon. Beloved husband of Sheila. Devoted father of Robert and Judy, and David. Loving grandfather of Barry. Services Gutterman-Musicant, 402 Park St, Hackensack, NJ, Monday, 11 AM.

title: Immigration Law's Fine Print Emerges, Setting Off a Debate About Welfare Provisions
description: On Dec. 19, the Government will begin enforcing a new law that will make it more difficult for poor and working-class immigrants living legally in the United States to have members of their families immigrate to join them.

title: Malaysians Rally Around Mahathir
description: KUALA LUMPUR  Amid prospects of rising prices and slower economic growth, Malaysians have taken to the streets. But far from demanding a change in government, these demonstrators are proclaiming their support for their prime minister, Mahathir bin Mohamad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AIZENBERG, RYWKA
description: AIZENBERG-Rywka. The Conservative Synagogue of Jamaica Estates records with profound sorrow the passing of Rywka Aizenberg, mother of our esteemed Rabbi Isidoro Aizenberg. May he be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Paul Diamond, President

title: Hard-Driving Salsa, With a Sense of Humor Added
description: Marc Anthony's sprawling, sold-out Madison Square Garden show on Saturday night found him and salsa on the cusp of change. He's salsa's biggest international star, the leader of a new crop of extraordinarily gifted singers that, in a just world, would have audiences outside of their own cultures.

title: Electronic 'Branding' Receives Accolades at the Frankfurt Book Fair
description: The first international rally to tame the freewheeling sprawl of cyberspace was a civil, rather sedate affair, a lounge party -- as one publisher termed it -- with contented revelers.

title: A Quiet Roar Of a Swinging Octogenarian
description: It was like a Zen master bowling over a student with a one-sentence revelation. When Harry (Sweets) Edison played ''Lester Leaps In'' at the Pace Downtown Theater on Thursday night, he jumped into his first solo chorus with a roaring, high-register trumpet squeal, which then tailed off abruptly into a melodic improvisation.

title: Ode to the Artistic Moment From a Confident Pianist
description: There are remarkable moments in the experience of music when time seems to stop. Furious activity appears motionless. Expressions of pain or exuberance arrive at the ear somehow in a state of peace. We hear how fast the music is playing, but the impression it leaves is very different.

title: Piper Jaffray to Settle Suit
description: The Piper Jaffray Companies said last week that it would pay $6.6 million to settle a derivatives-related class-action lawsuit and other claims brought by First Commercial Trust. The suit was brought by shareholders of the Managers Intermediate Mortgage Fund, which was managed by Managers Funds. Piper's subsidiary, Piper Capital Management, was the fund's subadviser and the case involves investors who acquired shares in Managers Intermediate from May 1, 1992, through June 13, 1994.

title: Sports of The Times ; Way Beats Sanders at His Own Game
description: THE Giants keep winning, and no one quite knows why.

title: Harsh Immigration Law
description: To the Editor:

title: France vs. U.S.: Warring Versions of Capitalism
description: Anti-Americanism is an old theme here, almost a ritual, one that Prime Minister Lionel Jospin rehearsed recently when he declared that America could not impose its laws on the world and that ''ultra-capitalism'' was unacceptable.

title: Luncheonette's Grill Turns Off for Good
description: Most of the regulars could be found at the Grand Luncheonette yesterday, parked on the stools or bellied up to the counter.

title: Miscellany
description: * Lowe McAdams Health Care USA, New York, part of the Lowe & Partners/SMS division of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., acquired Health Tech Communications Corp., New York. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Ayer Direct Buys Deare Marketing
description: Ayer Direct in New York, the direct marketing agency of N. W. Ayer & Partners, has acquired Deare Marketing Inc., a promotional and direct marketing agency in New York. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Major Recipients of Gifts From a $350 Million List
description: George Soros's network of nonprofit foundations now spends about $350 million a year promoting ''the open society,'' a concept developed by his former professor, the philosopher Karl Popper.

title: The U.N. and Human Rights
description: When the human rights lawyer Mary Robinson was elected President of Ireland in 1990, she inherited a ceremonial post with virtually no budget or staff. Yet through her forceful speeches on human rights, civil rights and feminist issues, and by opening her official residence to groups such as the homeless, she redefined the office and helped modernize her country.

description: Failure on Climate Goals

description: WEINTRAUB-Sheila 10/16/40-10/20/90 Cherished mother, missing you so. Allison

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, THOMAS TUNNY
description: HARRIS-Thomas Tunny. Of Dix Hills, NY, on Oct 15, 1997, at the age of 66. Beloved husband of Miriam. Devoted father of Amy and Michael. Cherished grandfather of Robert and Gregory. Loving brother of Maria Harris. Funeral mass today, 9:45 AM, at St. Matthew's R.C. Church, Dix Hills, NY. Interment Long Island Natinal Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Alzheimer's Association, 66 South St., Patchouge, NY 11771. For more information contact Commack Abbey Inc., 96 Commack Rd., Commack, NY.

title: Updates/Media and Technology; British Cable Companies Reach Deal With Warner On Rights to Movies
description: Four British cable companies have signed contracts to show Warner Brothers films on a pay-per-view basis and are close to signing two more Hollywood studios, three people with knowledge of the situation said yesterday.

title: 'Old Man' Walker Rambles for Victory
description: JAGUARS 22

title: Campaign Lobbies Voters On State School Bond Act
description: With just two weeks left until Election Day, a diverse coalition of educators, union organizers and business leaders is kicking off a vigorous campaign to persuade voters, particularly New York City Democrats, to approve a proposed $2.4 billion bond act to repair the state's crumbling schools.

title: The National Enquirer turns to a consultant to improve its sales at supermarkets.
description: MOST magazines would kill for the circulation of The National Enquirer. The supermarket tabloid sells 2.2 million copies on the newsstand and more than 490,000 to subscribers.

title: Virtual Satisfaction
description: Booming ''Can't get no satisfaction,'' beneath the blank gaze of two vaguely sphinx-like and unambiguously suggestive statues, Mick Jagger strutted and pranced onto the stage in front of more than 55,000 fans at Giants stadium late last week.

title: Many users of commercial on-line services are getting a steady diet of 'spam.'
description: Make Money Fast By Sending Unsolicited Commercial Advertisements on the Internet!

title: Good Small Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Inner-City Troubles Won't Respond to Nostalgia; History's Slippery Slope
description: To the Editor:

title: Meadowlands Magic
description: One of the convenient things about being a sports fan in New York is that there are so many professional teams in the area there is bound to be a winner somewhere -- and if not a winner, at least a pleasant surprise. That is just what the New York Jets and the New York Giants have turned out to be, much to the delight of New Yorkers who were disappointed by the Yankees' early exit from the baseball playoffs.

title: REXEL S.A. SWEETENS ITS BID FOR REXEL INC.
description: Rexel S.A. sweetened its offer yesterday to acquire the remaining shares of its United States electrical supplies distributor, Rexel Inc., by 15 percent. The new offer of $22.50 a share, up from $19.50 a share, is being made directly to Rexel Inc. shareholders. In August, Rexel S.A. of France offered to pay $265 million, or $19.50 a share, for the 49.4 percent of Rexel Inc. not already held by Rexel S.A. or its affiliates. Rexel Inc., based in Coral Gables, Fla., has annual sales of $1.16 billion. Its shares rose $1 yesterday, to $22.3125.

title: Success of Chinese Visit May Turn on Prisoner Release
description: In the puzzle of how to make a China-United States summit meeting successful, the release of a political prisoner may be a central piece.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREUTEL, EDWARD
description: TREUTEL-Edward. The Juilliard School mourns the loss of Edward Treutel, who served the Juilliard trumpet faculty with great distinction for close to 50 years until his retirement in 1995. Many of his students hold prominent positions in orchestras throughout the country today. As a dedicated teacher and musician, he will be missed by his colleagues and students alike. Mary Rodgers Guettel Chairman, Board of Trustees Joseph W. Polisi President

title: I.B.M. Earnings Rise 6%, Beating Analysts' Estimates by 4
description: Sailing slowly but smoothly through the stormy seas that have buffeted other technology companies recently, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its earnings increased more than 6 percent in the third quarter.

title: The Bacterium and the Chicken
description: ''Biosecurity'' is a word that appears with increasing frequency in farm journals and the literature of animal pharmaceutical manufacturers. A farmer who buys new cattle for his herd or new chickens for his flock worries about biosecurity -- protecting his isolated population of animals from diseases to which they may not be immune. But the history of life on earth, and human history as well, suggests that biosecurity is largely an unattainable condition. So do recent findings that report the widespread occurrence of the campylobacter bacterium in supermarket chickens. The very circumstances in which poultry is raised -- so intensely crowded that disease is always a risk -- create a parable of bioinsecurity.

title: Bonds Climb As Inflation Concerns Ease
description: Treasury securities ended mostly higher yesterday, partly rebounding from a sharp selloff Friday, as renewed anxiety over growing inflationary pressure eased a bit.

title: Science Watch; Doctor vs. Laptop
description: PATIENTS have long complained of doctors who seem mechanistic, lacking the human touch. Now researchers in Wisconsin have found that in some circumstances at least, machines may actually do a better job.

title: Sports of The Times; Yanks Ignore The Hispanic Influence
description: THE folly of George Steinbrenner's distancing of his baseball team from the borough in which it plays has never been more obvious than during this post-season, this World Series, when the images of success have been the very ones he apparently wishes to run from.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAUSMAN, BARBARA
description: HAUSMAN-Barbara. Employees, managers and partners of Combined Container Industries note with sorrow the passing of Barbara Hausman, wife of retired partner Arthur Sidney Hausman. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Combined Container Industries

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, DOROTHY E.
description: COOK-Dorothy E. On October 18, 1997. Beloved aunt of Patrick Reynolds and Maureen Montagne. Dearest friend of John Bates. Funeral mass today at 10 AM, St. John the Evangelist Church, 348 East 55th St, NYC. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Queens, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, DR. MENEK
description: GOLDSTEIN-Dr. Menek, died suddenly on October 18, 1997. Professor at NYU Medical Center. Beloved nephew of Frania Gitterman, Maria Rosenbloom, and Frieda Hirsch. Loving cousin of Dr. Alex Gitterman and Dr. Hana Savir and their families. Devoted to dear friend Dr. Mira Dziatelowski and her family. Funeral on Tuesday at 1:15 PM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street.

title: A Broken Pipe Shoots Water, Gravel and Mud Into Co-Op City Apartments
description: A water pipe burst in Co-op City early yesterday morning, shooting a stream of water into an adjacent building, breaking windows and damaging 15 apartments on three floors, officials said.

title: On the Ballot, Evil Twins: Fear and Hope
description: IF you want your friends to do the Full MEGO -- that's the acronym for My Eyes Glaze Over -- just mention the Nov. 4 referendum that will ask New Yorkers if they wish to hold a convention in 1999 to rewrite the State Constitution. Watch those eyelids come down. By comparison, the mayoral race really is a beauty contest, no matter what Ruth W. Messinger says.

title: ITT Accepts $9.8 Billion Bid, Forming Biggest Hotel Chain
description: The ITT Corporation yesterday accepted a friendly $9.8 billion purchase offer from Starwood Lodging Trust, a deal that apparently ends the Hilton Hotels Corporation's 10-month-old hostile quest to buy its rival in the hotel and gaming industry for $8 billion.

title: Hoffa Is Faulted for Past Ties
description: Ron Carey, whose election as teamsters' president has been overturned because of a fund-raising scandal, today accused his election opponent, James P. Hoffa, of being connected to organized crime.

title: End County Government
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Boys Charged in Lodi Arson
description: Two Maywood teen-agers were arrested and charged yesterday with setting a fire that gutted a discount warehouse in Lodi in April, prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKOFF, GAIL
description: ROCKOFF-Gail. You left us way too soon. Our hearts go out to Clyde and Michael, Chi, David, Lauren and Alison. We love you. Myrna and Norman

title: Planting Trees and Not Crops to Fight Water Pollution
description: Government began a new approach to battling water pollution today: planting trees to control runoff from farm fields.

title: Metro Business Briefs; Bankers Trust Unit Is Sold to Met Life
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it would buy a unit of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation that administers retirement saving plans.

title: A Sheepish Nagy Will Try To Lead the Indians Again
description: The setting was a bustling Indians clubhouse after Cleveland had mauled the Marlins, 6-1, in Game 2 to even the World Series. The focus shifted to Charles Nagy, who will pitch Game 3 for the Indians on Tuesday night. The swarm of reporters surrounding Nagy seemed to make the shy pitcher uncomfortable.

title: Italy, Too, Was Pressured to Persecute Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Messinger Presses Giuliani On Child Welfare Report
description: Ruth W. Messinger urged Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday to drop his administration's opposition to releasing the second part of a court-ordered report that is expected to be highly critical of the city's Administration for Children's Services.

title: Gatling Returns to Fill Nets' Need in the Middle
description: The weary Nets received some good news on the final day of a seven-day road trip: Chris Gatling played in his first preseason game here tonight.

title: Woe Is Me: Rewards And Perils of Memoirs
description: CLOSE TO THE BONE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERSON, C. ROBERT
description: WERSON-C. Robert. On October 11, 1997 in Stowe, VT. Loving husband of Evelyn Dyhr Werson. Loving father of Suzanne Werson and Robin Boucher.

title: French Insurer's Shares Rise on Bid Speculation
description: Shares of Assurances Generales de France S.A., France's second-largest insurer, surged as much as 36.2 percent yesterday amid expectations that another company would make a bid higher than the one from Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A. Assurances Generales de France's shares rose as high as 320 francs ($53.78), from 235 francs ($39.50) on Oct. 10, the last time they traded, and higher than Generali's unsolicited offer of 300 francs ($50.42) a share. They were suspended on Oct. 13, when Italy's biggest insurer made its bid of 55 billion francs ($9.24 billion). They closed at 318.4 francs ($53.51).

title: Union Carbide Plans To Reduce Costs
description: The Union Carbide Corporation has set a goal to reduce costs by $1.1 billion annually by the year 2000, almost double the target of $637 million for that deadline originally set in 1995.

title: Women's Team Won't Give Up
description: Tori Murden and Louise Graff, the two Americans who recently withdrew from a trans-Atlantic rowing race, announced late yesterday that they planned to re-enter the competition sometime this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMSON, SARA
description: ABRAMSON-Sara. 98-1/2. Mother of Robert and Joan, grandmother of Dianita, Jane, Steven, Laura, Evan and Lauren. Great grandmother of Yesica, Sally, Kathleen, Jessica, Jill, Samuel and Jacob. Legendary teacher of ''fours'' at Little Red Schoolhouse. She dedicated her life to teaching and tolerance and was loved by many.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''When you're the single spokesman for the intelligence community you get shot at from a lot of directions, and you get tired of it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDERER, FRIEDA
description: LEDERER-Frieda. Beloved wife of the late Philip; devoted mother of Irwin and Martha; cherished grandmother of Philip and Jodi, Jonathan and Yesenia, and Ellen Lederer. Great grandmother of Starr and Harley; dear sister of Al Schoenhertz. Services ''Boulevand-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, 10 AM today.

title: Ratings Slide Aside, Series Is Winner
description: Once upon a time before ''must see TV,'' NBC adored baseball. Baseball was the center of its sports universe. When it lost baseball to CBS in 1988, NBC mourned publicly about the loss of its heirloom and beloved tradition.

title: Banc One to Pay $3 Billion In Stock for First Commerce
description: The Banc One Corporation has agreed to buy the First Commerce Corporation of New Orleans for $3 billion in stock.

title: G.O.P. Recasts Public Debate Over Abortion
description: For more than a decade, Democrats seemed to hold the winning argument in the contentious debate over abortion by framing it as a matter of a woman's right to choose and by posing this simple question: ''Who decides?''

title: Consortium to Buy Oilfield
description: Enterprise Oil P.L.C. of Britain said today that it was part of a group that will buy a North Sea oilfield from Conoco Inc. for $92 million. Enterprise Oil is making the acquisition on behalf of the Beryl field partners consortium. The consortium consists of the Mobil Corporation with a 50 percent interest, Enterprise Oil with a 22.8 percent, the Amerada Hess Corporation with 22.2 percent and OMV A.G. with 5 percent. Conoco, a unit of DuPont, is based in Houston.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Refuse to Review Texas Death Penalty Case
description: With an unusual public statement by four Justices, the Supreme Court today refused to hear a case challenging a provision of the Texas death penalty law. The law prohibits telling jurors that if they choose a life sentence instead of the death penalty, the defendant will not be released on parole for at least 40 years.

title: Scientists Cry Politics
description: Scientists are criticizing the United States Government for saying that a seismic event in the Russian wilds two months ago might have been an underground nuclear blast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLER, MIRIAM A.
description: HANDLER-Miriam A. Yeshiva University and its Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law mourns the passing of a highly respected member of the community, a stalwart advocate of Jewish education and the State of Israel; beloved wife of Professor Milton Handler, honorary member of the CSL Board of Directors and CSL Fellow through Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays, and Handler. We extend our heartfelt condolences to daughter, Carole E. Handler; brother, Milton Adler; sister, Avivah Benamy; grandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Italy, Too, Was Pressured to Persecute Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFFLER, BLANCHE
description: LEFFLER-Blanche. On Oct 19, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Irving. Devoted mother of Steven and Robert. Loving mother-in-law to Carolann and Susan. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Her presence will be deeply missed.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Guarantee Life Acts to Acquire Insurer
description: The Guarantee Life Companies agreed today to pay $37.25 million in cash to acquire PFG Inc., a closely held life insurer, in a move to increase its life insurance sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, ARTHUR
description: STEIN-Arthur. Devoted husband of Evalyn for 56 years. Loving father, brother, grandfather and friend. He was a good man and will be missed by those who knew and loved him. Funeral at Union Field Cemetery, Ridgewood, Queens on October 21 at 10:45am.

title: Wider Mental Health Benefits Threatened by Exemption Plan
description: New rules being drafted by the Clinton Administration could allow many employers to exempt themselves from a landmark law intended to expand health insurance benefits for millions of Americans with mental illnesses, Federal officials and mental health advocates said today.

title: Hughes Won't Be Hurt by Chairman's Exit, G.M. Says
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had no intention of selling the Hughes Electronics Corporation and that the subsidiary would not be hurt by the departure of its chairman and chief executive, C. Michael Armstrong, to head the AT&T Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBLATT, JACOB AARON
description: GOLDBLATT-Jacob Aaron, 71, of Manasota Key, Florida, died Sunday, October 19 in Englewood Community Hospital. He was the most adored and loved husband, father and grandfather. He is survived by his wife Barbara Goldblatt; children Paul Goldblatt, Laura Goldblatt, Tracy Edwards, and Seth Katz; seven grandchildren, all from Mahopac, New York. There will be no services. For information Farley Funeral Home and Crematory, Englewood, FL. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Association, 122 East 42nd St, New York City, NY 10168.

title: Justice Dept. to Seek $1 Million-a-Day Fine In Antitrust Dispute : U.S. Fires Legal Salvo At Microsoft For 'Abuses'
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department said Monday it was seeking a $1 million-a-day fine against Microsoft Corp. until the software giant stopped requiring makers of personal computers to license and distribute its software for its Internet Explorer browser.

title: Keller Will Miss Next Game
description: Kasey Keller, the top American goalkeeper, will miss the crucial qualifying game in Mexico City Nov. 2. Keller suffered a compound dislocated right thumb while practicing with his English club, Leicester City. He is scheduled to return to the United States today to be examined by Dr. Bert Mandelbaum, the team physician for the United States World Cup team. Keller is expected to miss as many as four weeks.

title: Finding 'Typos' in Scriptures; On Lower East Side, Scribe Devotes Life to Standards
description: As much as anything, it is life's obstinate parade of angst and grief that brings customers to 11 Essex Street on the Lower East Side. Family squabbles. Illness. Problems with the pet. Or just plain rotten luck. And so people do what their rabbis always advise them to do. They get their mezuzas checked.

title: Kravis-Led Fund Is Backing Internet Lab
description: An investment fund established by Henry R. Kravis is collaborating with Ericsson, the Swedish telecommunications company, to open a high-technology business center in lower Manhattan to help Internet entrepreneurs tinker with new ideas.

title: Observer; Idea for a Sitcom
description: Here is a vision of Hell grim enough to make you swear off all seven of the Deadly Sins and send burnt offerings twice weekly to the Rev. Pat Robertson. I refer to the new Center for the Study of Popular Television being established at Syracuse University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRATZ, SYLVIA
description: GRATZ-Sylvia On October 19, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Michael. Devoted mother of Sandra and Louis. Loving sister of Helen Perlmutter. Cherished grandmother of Elana, Michael and Donovan and great grandmother of David and Danielle. Services Tuesday, 12:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street, and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: No Caesarean Risk Is Found For a Labor Pain Medication
description: CONTRADICTING highly influential reports, four new studies of more than 20,000 women conclude that the use of epidural anesthesia for labor pain does not increase a woman's risk of having a Caesarean section.

title: Inner-City Troubles Won't Respond to Nostalgia; Who's a Virtucrat?
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; New Housing in Atlantic City
description: Nearly 20 years after the first casino opened here, the gambling industry is beginning to make good on one of its promises -- to rebuild ramshackle urban neighborhoods, The Associated Press reported.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: A Slap and an Old Man's Shame Amid All the Mischief-Making
description: ''Don Pasquale'' is to Donizetti's career what ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' was to Mozart's. Both operas came toward the end of composing lives. Timeworn models notwithstanding, both achieved a theatrical momentum unusual to opera then and now. In both, stories are told by means of duets, trios and quartets. The arias are there, and they are beautiful. But they exist as breathing points, eloquent clearings of the throat that allow otherwise continuous narrative to catch its breath.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; When Songs Cross the Atlantic
description: The Verve's 'Urban Hymns'

title: NATO's True Mission
description: Fifty years ago Secretary of State George Marshall called upon the people of the United States to contribute to the building of a new Europe ''united in freedom, peace, and prosperity.'' Succeeding generations of Americans rallied in support of Marshall's vision, electing leaders who were committed to fostering and maintaining the strongest possible ties between America and Europe's democracies, both old and new.

title: Union Pacific Says Service Is Less Ragged
description: The Union Pacific Railroad told Federal regulators today that service had improved in the last week, suggesting that the worst of the traffic jams that may have cost customers hundreds of millions of dollars are behind it.

title: Rift With Whitman Turns Trump From Ally to Adversary
description: From the moment Christine Todd Whitman was elected Governor of New Jersey, Donald J. Trump was a man she could count on.

title: In Tunisia, The Scores At Bridge
description: Before a card was played in the World Team Championships here, world politics had made an impact. When Israel sought permission to send an armed guard to protect its women's team, the Tunisian organizers refused, saying they would provide security. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu then decreed that the team should stay home.

title: NATO Says It Shut Serb Radio to Silence Propaganda
description: NATO peacekeepers and other international officials in Bosnia said today that they were satisfied they had taken a step toward bringing about responsible news coverage in Bosnia by shutting down a hard-line Bosnian Serb broadcast network.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITEHEAD, NANCY DICKERSON
description: WHITEHEAD-Nancy Dickerson. October 18,1997. Beloved wife of John C. Whitehead, devoted mother of Elizabeth Earls, Ann Pillion, Jane Dickerson, Michael Dickerson, John Dickerson, Anne Whitehead, Gregory Whitehead, Robert Chartener and Sarah Whitehead. Loving sister of Mary Ellen Phillip. Cherished grandmother of eleven. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, October 22 at 10am at St. Patrick's Cathedral, NYC. A reception will follow. A service will be held later in the week at the Fort Myer Chapel at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington Va. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Covenant House, 346 West 17th St, NY, NY 10011 Attn: Sister Mary Rose McGeady.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, ARTHUR JAMES
description: LYONS-Arthur James, attorneyat-law, of Somers, NY, formerly of Mahopac, NY, on October 18, 1997. Husband of Aileen P. Lyons. Brother of Stephen, William and Charles Lyons and Ann McGinnis. Visiting today 2:00-4:00pm and 7:009:00pm at Joseph J. Smith Funeral Home, 862 Route 6, Mahopac. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10:00am at St. John the Evangelist Church, Mahopac. Interment St. Joseph's Cemetery, Somers.

title: When Death Hits a Corner Office; Coping With Loss of a Top Executive Requires Planning
description: As soon as Michael H. Walsh, the Tenneco Corporation's former chief executive, began feeling ill in 1993, he told Dana G. Mead, his close friend and handpicked successor. Three months later, when his doctors suggested a biopsy, he told Dr. Peter Flawn, a senior board member. Only when the biopsy showed brain cancer did he and Mr. Mead tell the rest of the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, DR. BERTRAM A.N.
description: COLLINS-Dr. Bertram A.N. Retired U.N. diplomat, on October 17th, 1997. Beloved husband of Claire, brother of Rudolph and Joan. Funeral service at Frank E. Campbell, 81st and Madison, 6 PM, October 21st. Memorial service 1 PM, October 22nd, United Nations Chapel, 44th and 1st Ave.

title: William McGill, 75, President Who Led Columbia After Years of Distress, Dies
description: Dr. William James McGill, a psychologist and teacher who led Columbia University in the 1970's as it recovered from years of student rebellion and financial distress, died on Sunday at the University of California-San Diego Thornton Hospital in La Jolla, Calif. He was 75 and had lived in La Jolla since retiring from Columbia in 1980.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Seeks Changes In Microsoft Browser Policy

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, ALEXANDER
description: SIEGEL-Alexander. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Ronald and Laurie Havassy. Dear brother of Erma Raflowitz. Adoring grandfather of Selene, Randy, Joshua and Amy. Service Wednesday, 12 Noon, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st & Amsterdam Ave.

title: AT&T Introduces Executive Who'll Take Over Company
description: It was three days shy of a year ago that the AT&T Corporation introduced a man meant to guide the nation's largest communications company into the next century. Investors reacted to the choice that day by sending the company's stock down almost 5 percent, and the executive, John R. Walter, left the company barely nine months later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONCANNON, CHARLOTTE
description: CONCANNON-Charlotte. On October 20, 1997. Beloved mother of Robert T. Concannon of East Stroudsburg, PA and Richard J. Concannon of Larchmont, NY. Caring sister of George Schreck of East Islip, NY. Also survived by eight grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. Family will receive friends at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY on Wednesday 6-9PM. Mass of Christian burial on Thursday 10AM at Sts. John and Paul Church, Larchmont, NY. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: Whitman Acts To Minimize Train Trouble Before Nov. 4
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman turned the focus of her re-election campaign today to a problem that is not hers but could still cost her votes with cranky New Jersey commuters: a possible Amtrak strike the week before the election.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPITZER, SAM
description: SPITZER-Sam. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member, Sam Spitzer. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Starks Back in a Flash, Childs Back in a Mask
description: John Starks and Chris Childs went down on the court at two different but equally queasy moments this preseason. Both grimaced and winced as they left the floor, looking as if they would not reappear in Knicks uniforms for some time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, JULIAN
description: HOFFMAN-Julian of East Hampton on October 18, 1997. Beloved husband of Margaret; loving father of Peter Hoffman and stepfather of Gail Reisin-Goldstein, Jeffrey Kronemeyer and Ronald Frank. Dear brother of Elizabeth Lily Frenkel; devoted uncle of Steven and Irving Frenkel; cherished grandfather of seven grandchildren. Services and interment were held Monday. Donations in his memory may be made to Apple, Inc., P.O. Box 1270, Wainscott, New York 11975.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, MILDRED
description: ROSS-Mildred. The Board of Directors of 16 Sutton Place Corp. mourns the loss of an advisor whose attentive eye added beauty to our gardens and to our lives. Gerald Keller, President

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; March for Needle Exchanges
description: Hundreds of people plan to march in Trenton today to show support for the legalization of needle-exchange programs, organizers of the march said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, CHESTER
description: FRANK-Chester. On October 19, 1997. Beloved son of the late Sidney and the late Ruth Frank. Service Wednesday, October 22 at 11:30 am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street

title: Patterns
description: Opening in America

title: Pataki Cancels Project to Build Car Pool Lane In Westchester
description: In the mid-1980's, New York State proposed what was then considered an environmentally progressive solution to traffic jams on the Cross Westchester Expressway, a major conduit for east-west travel north of New York City. It would build a new car pool lane on the median, which officials said would mean fewer vehicles, less pollution and fewer tie-ups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANNING, WILLIAM MACLEOD
description: MANNING-William MacLeod, age 4, on Oct 19, 1997. Survived by parents Robin Baxendale and James W. Manning. Brother of Jesse B., maternal grandparents David and Janet Baxendale and Barbara and Arthur Morgan all of Princeton, NJ and paternal grandparents Ferdinand and Kathryn Manning of Canaan, NY and Jean and David Williams of Clearwater, FL. Visitation Wed Oct 22 at the Mather-Hodge Funeral Home, 40 Vandeventer Ave, Princeton. Burial private. Memorial service Saturday Oct 25, 2pm at the Princeton University Chapel. Memorial contributions may be made to Make-a-Wish Foundation of NJ, PO Box 4028, 1034 Salem Rd, Union, NJ 07083 and Give Kids the World, 210 South Bass Rd, Kissimmee, FL 34746.

title: Pope's Trip to Cuba Pulls at Exiles
description: Elisa Flanigan-Chovel says she initially hesitated after hearing that the Archdiocese of Miami planned to take a cruise ship with American Catholics to Cuba for the Pope's visit in January. What would people say if she went? Would she be ostracized?

title: Levi Strauss Planning Review Of Ad Agency Handling Jeans
description: In an unexpected unraveling of one of the longest relationships in advertising, Levi Strauss & Company announced late yesterday that it had placed in review its Levi's brand account, with billings estimated at $87 million, after 67 years at Foote, Cone & Belding and a predecessor, Honig-Cooper in San Francisco.

title: Mapping the Beach, One Grain at a Time
description: JUST before a recent, rosy dawn on the Outer Banks of North Carolina, a few men crossed the dunes and walked across the beach toward the waterline, where a strange contraption squatted in the sand. A metal-pipe framework seven feet square at the base and about as high, it was hung with dozens of sensors, meters and other devices.

title: Poll Finds Most Voters Have No Opinion About Messinger
description: Two weeks before Election Day, Ruth W. Messinger remains an essentially unknown figure to a vast segment of New Yorkers, suggesting that the Democratic challenger to Rudolph W. Giuliani -- and indeed the mayoral race itself -- has not captured the attention of the city, according to the latest New York Times poll.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Woman Freed in Jersey City
description: A Jersey City man held his girlfriend hostage for 36 hours, beat her, and shot at police officers before finally surrendering yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Rights Panel Is Accused In Bias Case
description: The agency that enforces New York City's laws against discrimination may itself have discriminated against two female staff lawyers when it rejected their applications for a supervisory position and promoted a man who had less seniority and litigation experience, a Federal agency has found.

title: For Hoffa, Nearly Everything Is in a Name
description: Up in the grandstands, his back to a 30-foot-tall window overlooking the racetrack, James P. Hoffa was whipping up a crowd of 1,000 truckers and their wives the way his legendary father did, telling them that last year's election for the teamsters' presidency was stolen from him.

title: QUANDARY FOR U.S.: ADVISER ON TIBET
description: With only a week to go before the visit of China's President to the United States, the Clinton Administration finds itself in a diplomatic predicament of its own making over its pledge to appoint a ''special coordinator'' to oversee American policy toward Tibet.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EDWARD VILLELLA, the former star of the New York City Ballet who is the founder and artistic director of the Miami City Ballet, will be teaching a class today to an unusual assembly of students: the hockey team at Union College in Schenectady, N.Y. His son, Rodney Villella, graduated from Union College in 1994 and Mr. Villella received an honorary doctorate from the college, ''So I have a personal relationship there,'' he said yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Festering Fruit Flies

title: 2 Teams, 4 Passers, 1 Question: Who Plays?
description: He is a Pro Bowl quarterback in the National Football League, and he says he thinks he knows exactly what Dave Brown is up against.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, ALVIN
description: WARREN-Alvin, 84, of Montrose, NY, on Oct. 18. Beloved husband of Anna; father of Frederick, Constancia and David; grandfather of Josie Dollar; brother of Vivian Munday. Veteran of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade and the 29th Infantry Div. (WWII). Cabinetmaker and lifelong peace and justice activist. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Abraham Lincoln Brigade Archive at Brandeis Univ., c/o VALB, 799 Broadway, NY, NY 10003.

title: Inner-City Troubles Won't Respond to Nostalgia; Preaching to Faithless
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefs; Car-Rental Suits Planned
description: New York's Attorney General said he planned to sue 14 car-rental offices, including franchises of the Chrysler Corporation's Thrifty Rent-A-Car System Inc. and Budget Group Inc., which owns Budget Rent-a-Car, for refusing to rent to drivers younger than 25.

title: In a Step Toward a Better Electric Car, Company Uses Fuel Cell to Get Energy From Gasoline
description: The Energy Department and an engineering company plan to announce on Tuesday that they have produced electricity from gasoline through a new method that yields twice as much useful energy per gallon as a car engine does, and with pollution 90 percent lower.

title: On My Mind; Shatter the Silence
description: On Sunday afternoon, after I had seen the two videos, I thought that if only God had a sense of packaging He would put them back to back on one cassette. Then He would drop them on the heads of all people who can worship in freedom but are indifferent to the suffering of those who cannot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGRIFF, VERN H.
description: McGRIFF-Vern H. Retired Professor, Jersey City State College. On October 19, 1997. Beloved husband of Erline (Nee Perkins). Devoted son of Verna Holt. Loving brother of Warren, Philip, Hershel, Norman and Eris Nielsen. Funeral service Wednesday, October 22 at 1PM at Grace Episcopal Church of New York in the Chantry. Interment will follow in Blandford Cemetery, Petersburg, Va. For more information call Nucciarone Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, NYC. 212-254-3007. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Erline McGriff Scholarship Fund, Division of Nursing, New York University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, LEONARD
description: PRICE-Leonard. On October 20, 1997. Son of Jeanette and Isaac, husband of the late Lorraine, father of Robert and daughter-in-law Frances, grandfather of Arnold and step granddaughters Frances and Eileen and step great granddaughters Teri and Andrea and Many friends. Lieutenant colonel in the U.S. Army, past president New York State Society of CPAs, senior partner at Grant Thornton. Burial private. In lieu of flowers, donate to your favorite charity.

title: A Matisse Looted in '41 Turns Up
description: A 1927 painting by Henri Matisse that was confiscated by the Nazis during World War II from a prominent Jewish art dealer in Paris and had been missing ever since has turned up in the Seattle Art Museum. Owen Pell, a lawyer for the family of the dealer, Paul Rosenberg, notified the museum by phone on Friday and has since sent a letter seeking the return of the painting, ''Oriental Woman Seated on Floor.''

title: Inner-City Troubles Won't Respond to Nostalgia
description: To the Editor:

title: By Design; Sweat-Shirt Chic
description: Whether they are physically active themselves or not, designers have long been inspired by athletic garb. Right now, hip young designers, from Marc Jacobs to Daryl K, are turning the sweat shirt into high fashion.

title: U.S. Urging Identification Of Patients With H.I.V.
description: In deliberate but cautious steps, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is urging states to require that people infected with H.I.V. be reported to state health departments, following the same practice used for infectious diseases like tuberculosis and syphilis.

title: Calpers to Join Suits Against Columbia
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System said today that it would join other American public pension funds suing directors of the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation over a Government investigation that has sent shares plunging.

title: GENERAL BINDING TO ADD SWISS BINDING COMPANY
description: The General Binding Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Ibico A.G., a Swiss maker of document binding and laminating products. Financial terms were not disclosed. General Binding, which also makes binding and laminating products, said Ibico would continue to market its products under its own name. The closely held Ibico is expected to have 1997 revenues of $110 million. General Binding, based in Northbrook, Ill., had 1996 sales of $536.8 million.

title: Lafarge to Buy Stake In Cementos Molins
description: The French building materials company Lafarge S.A. said yesterday that it would buy a 39 percent stake in Cementos Molins S.A. of Spain for about 800 million francs, or $134.5 million. Lafarge's Spanish subsidiary, Asland S.A., will acquire the stake from a rival French building materials company, Ciments Francais S.A.

title: 40 Years and No Swan Song, Vows Pavarotti
description: Luciano Pavarotti, in a blue painter's smock, sat at his window overlooking Central Park, envisioning a milestone on the distant horizon. ''The 29th of April, 2001, it will be 40 years,'' he said. ''And 40 years in the profession for a tenor who is singing these kind of notes is quite something.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEARSON, HARRIET G.
description: LEARSON-Harriet G., on October 19, age 91, of Lansdale, PA, formerly of Cincinnati, OH, Scarsdale, NY and Greenwich, CT. Wife of the late Richard J. Learson. Mother of Katherine L. Sullivan, S. Hamilton, MA; Margaret I. Grosso, Westport, CT; Richard J. Learson, Port Chester, NY; and Harriet A. Learson, Rosemont, PA. Relatives and friends are invited to a Memorial Mass on Saturday, Oct. 25 at 11 AM in St. Paul's Church, King St., Greenwich, CT. Interment private. Care entrusted to Longenecker, North Wales, PA.

title: BellSouth Profit Increases 11.7%
description: The BellSouth Corporation said today that its third-quarter earnings rose 1l.7 percent as revenue surged in its wireless telecommunications business.

title: FOUNDATION HEALTH REDUCES PRICE FOR PHYSICIANS HEALTH
description: Foundation Health Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had cut the price of its acquisition of Physicians Health Services to $271 million from $280 million. Foundation said Physicians Health, a health-plan provider, had agreed to the revision, which will reduce the per-share price to $28.25 from $29.25. Foundation, a managed health care company in Los Angeles, said the move came after Physicians Health did not amend certain joint venture agreements. If the company does amend its joint venture agreements before the closing, the purchase price will return to the original $29.25 a share. Shares of Physicians Health rose $1.6875, to $27.3125, on the Nasdaq. Shares of Foundation rose 93.75 cents, to $33.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOVENTHAL, DANIEL J.
description: LOVENTHAL-Daniel J. On Oct 18, 1997. Former President of Temple Judea of Manhasset. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Robert (Debbie) and Amy (Ricky) Gordon. Loving brother of Lawrence (Renee) and Gloria (Murray) Silver. Cherished grandfather of Lesley, David, Kenneth and Lisa. Services Tuesday, 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: San Francisco Museum Forgets Its Duty to Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Khannouchi Took Shortcut to Long Race
description: Last July, in the middle of a superb road racing season, Khalid Khannouchi of Brooklyn received an unsettling suggestion from his wife, Sandra, who is also his coach and manager. You should run a marathon, she said.

title: Taiwan, Korea and Thailand Suffer Domino-Like Losses
description: Correction Appended

title: Explosions of Intense Passion and Fiery Footwork
description: Some dancegoers refuse to read program notes, wishing actions onstage to speak louder than words on a page. But anyone who did not read the note for ''Arsa y Toma'' might have been perplexed by Ballet Cristina Hoyos Flamenco on Sunday afternoon.

title: Congress, but Not Judiciary, Receives an Increase in Pay
description: The nation's Federal judges, already feeling beset by criticism from many in Congress, have found a new reason to be uneasy. Earlier this month, for the first time, Congress approved a pay raise for itself without including the judges.

title: Parcells Aims to Settle Quarterback Situation
description: Coach Bill Parcells once said, ''You don't bench a veteran lightly because once you do, you can't go back.''

title: Chess; Despite the Huge Databases, It's Still Possible to Innovate
description: Serendipity has been almost entirely replaced by days, even weeks of study at a computer delving into gigantic chess databases. Producing a new opening move at the chessboard is regarded as primitive, risky and -- by coaches -- irresponsible. Nevertheless, every once in a while an untried, uncertified move shows up in the first 10 moves of a game.

title: DEN AMERICA REJECTS OFFER FOR BLACK EYED PEA UNIT
description: The Den America Corporation rejected a $69 million takeover offer yesterday for its Black Eyed Pea restaurants unit and settled its lawsuit over issues arising after its purchase of the chain. WAM Acquisitions L.L.C. made the cash offer on Friday and said it would in turn sell the chain to Tech Electro Industries for $75 million in cash. Den America called the offer ''totally inadequate and unsubstantial.'' Den America, also the largest Denny's restaurant franchiser, said it would stick with its plan to expand the 100-restaurant Black Eyed Pea chain and sell some of its Denny's restaurants. Shares of Den America rose 43.75 cents, to $3.0625.

title: DISCOUNT AUTO PARTS TO ACQUIRE HI-LO AUTOMOTIVE
description: Discount Auto Parts Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Hi-Lo Automotive Inc. for $37.2 million in stock to expand its reach in the Southern United States and California. Discount Auto, which is based in Lakeland, Fla., sells automotive replacement parts and accessories at 411 stores in five Southern states. The Hi-Lo purchase, valued at $3.44 a share at yesterday's close, will add 187 stores in Texas, Louisiana and California. Hi-Lo holders will receive 0.1485 Discount Auto share for each Hi-Lo share if Discount Auto stock trades between $22.73 and $26.15 during a specified 10-day period. Discount Auto will issue 0.15 share if its stock averages between $20.78 and $22.73 a share. Shares of Discount Auto Parts rose 68.75 cents yesterday at $23.1875. Hi-Lo's shares declined 50 cents yesterday, to $3.0625.

title: Hot Bats, Not Chill, Of Concern To Leiter
description: Mike Hargrove had the best take on the weather that suddenly has eclipsed Marquis Grissom and Moises Alou as topics of World Series conversation.

title: Youngest Giants Prove to Be Precocious
description: When the 1997 season dawned, the Giants' status as the youngest team in the National Football League hardly seemed a strength. In pro football's rough-and-tumble world, youth is a code word for mistake prone.

title: MANAGEMENT GROUP OFFERS TO BUY SYBRON CHEMICALS
description: Sybron Chemicals Inc. said yesterday that a group of its major shareholders and management had offered to buy the shares it does not own already, for $32 to $33 each, or as much as $103 million. The company, a specialty chemicals maker based in Birmingham, N.J., said the investor group is led by its president and chief executive, Richard M. Klein, and John H. Schroeder, an executive vice president, and includes Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd., Sybron's largest shareholder. The investor group already owns about 45 percent of the shares outstanding. Sybron's shares rose $6.25, or 23 percent, to $32.50, on the American Stock Exchange. The company's products include chemicals used in water treatment, textile dyes and printing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLEWETT, EVELYN
description: SLEWETT-Evelyn. AMIT is deeply saddened by the passing of the devoted sister of our dedicated benefactors, Minnie Lieberman and Leon Miller and beloved aunt of our AMIT Scholarship Dinner Honorees Mindy and Howard Miller. A woman of noble spirit and character, Evelyn Slewett exemplified her family's tradition of magnanimous philanthropy. Heartfelt condolences to her entire family. Evelyn Blachor, Nat'l Pres. Marvin Leff, Executive Dir.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREWER, LOUISE H.
description: BREWER-Louise H., died on October 19, 1997 in Hamden, CT. A longtime resident of New York City, she lived at 235 E. 22nd Street. Through her acquaintance with Eleanor Roosevelt in the late 1940's, she was inspired to a lifelong commitment to politics and activism. She worked for numerous Democratic party candidates on both local and national campaigns. She marched down Fifth Avenue in the front line of the National Organization of Women's first demonstration. She worked in the Peace Movement and was deeply concerned with issues of the elderly. She served on the Senior Citizen Council of New York City and was an early instigator of the Meals on Wheels Program. In 1986 she moved to the Whitney Center in Hamden.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNAM, JAYNE M. (NEE HUNOLD)
description: LYNAM-Jayne M. (Nee Hunold) of Forest Hills on October 18, 1997. Former teacher Lexington School for the Deaf. Beloved wife of William. Devoted mother of Kathryn and Mark. Loving daughter of Dorothy and Niles Hunold. Dear brother of Ken. Fond granddaughter of Martha Hillmann. Reposing Glascott Funeral Home, 102-03 Metropolitan Ave., Forest Hills. Religious service Wednesday, 10 A.M. at Grace Lutheran Church. Interment Mt. Olivet Cemetery.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, LILLIAN P.
description: POSNER-Lillian P. On October 17, 1997. Loving wife of Alan H. Posner. Beloved mother of Dr. Marshall R. Posner, Jeffrey P. Posner, Matthew A. Posner and Claudia A. Posner. Loving grandmother of M. Bowen Posner and Lily G. Posner. Service Tuesday, 12 noon, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Contributions to the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies would be appreciated.

title: A More Modest Man of October
description: Mr. October.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAXIN, ARNOLD
description: MAXIN-Arnold. October 19, 1997, Arnold, husband of Elaine (nee Cohen) of Marlton, New Jersey. Father of Amy (Dan) Heitzer and Marjorie Maxin Ellis. Brother of Jack Maxin and Anne Gould. Grandfather of Matthew, Alissa, and Rebecca. Relatives and friends are invited to graveside services Tuesday, 10:30am, Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, N.Y. The family will return to the home of Dan and Amy Heitzer and respectfully request in lieu of flowers contributions in his memory be made to the American Cancer Society. Platt Memorial Chapels Inc. Cherry Hill, New Jersey.

title: Foster's Brewing Buys Breweries in Vietnam
description: Foster's Brewing Group Ltd. of Australia said yesterday that it had bought two breweries in Vietnam from the French company Brasserie et Glacieres Internationales for about $57 million. ''Market potential is excellent, with growing beer consumption and acceptable margins,'' Foster's said.

title: Like TV Come to Life, Outlaw Lovers' Escapade Rivets Brazil
description: With 17 people in the hands of kidnappers here just this month, the parents of Carla Coelho feared the worst, soon after their daughter took off to meet the rich stranger who had been courting her through her computer screen.

title: Data Every 2 Minutes Are Fast Dispelling Mystery of Giant Tuna
description: LATE last winter, in eight-foot seas 20 miles off Cape Hatteras, N.C., Dr. Barbara Block, a Stanford University marine biologist, and two teams of sometimes seasick researchers undertook a bold experiment. They spent five weeks wrestling more than 200 fish in the 300- to 500-pound class to the lurching decks of tiny charter fishing boats.

title: Beyond Browsers
description: In taking action against the Microsoft Corporation, the Justice Department is trying to seize control of the computer industry's competitive ground rules that the software giant has increasingly dictated in the 1990's.

title: Playing Politics With Taxes
description: In their continuing search for salable political issues for the next campaign, the Republicans have hit upon the income tax code and the agency that enforces it, the Internal Revenue Service. Tax collectors are, of course, inviting targets, and Congress, inspired by the Republicans, certainly made some useful points when it identified abusive tax-collection practices and revenue agents who terrorized innocent taxpayers. The G.O.P. has also rounded up bipartisan support -- including the expected endorsement today by the House minority leader, Richard Gephardt -- for a taxpayer ''bill of rights.''

title: Crying for Argentina
description: To the Editor:

title: Salo and Fichaud Combine in Solving Isles' Goalie Woes
description: Goaltending was a big question for the Islanders entering this season.

title: Review/Fashion; Dressing Them Like Artists
description: Way, way before there were designers plotting to have their names known around the world, there were women who had personal style. Before designers made deals to dress celebrities for free, a woman could be famous, and dress herself.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Legislative Fund-Raising Up
description: The most recent campaign spending filings show that candidates for the New Jersey Legislature have raised 55 percent more than they did at this time four years ago, The Associated Press reported.

title: Anonymous Donations
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a new digital marking system that was demonstrated at the Frankfurt Book Fair misidentified a German publishing house whose chief executive, Dietrich Gotze, was quoted praising the system. It is Springer-Verlag, not Axel Springer Verlag A.G.

title: U.S. TELLS COURT MICROSOFT BREAKS ANTITRUST ACCORD
description: The Federal Government asked a judge today to order the Microsoft Corporation to stop forcing makers of personal computers to include its Internet browser when they install its Windows 95 operating system.

title: In Big Corporate Accounting, Will 4 Be Sufficient?
description: The question facing regulators over the coming months as they review two mergers being pursued by the nation's largest accountants is simple: are four major firms, responsible for looking over the books of nearly every large corporation in America, enough?

title: CHRONICLE
description: JEANNETTE WATSON did not go happily into the fall season. The bookshop she founded and owned on Madison Avenue for 20 years, the venerated Books & Company, went out of business in June after a dispute with the landlord, the Whitney Museum of American Art, over a proposed rent increase.

title: No Piano-Slamming But Still Intimidating
description: Jerry Lee Lewis, looking like a lawyer in his dark suit and vest, glowering without blinking through thick, buglike glasses, was using one of his old tricks to intimidate the audience at Tramps on Friday night. Not any of the exciting ones -- setting a piano on fire, jumping on top of it or using it to create a discernible musical excitement -- but something far more subtle. During his 1 A.M. set, he played with undisguised indifference.

title: Diller's HSN In $4.1 Billion TV Asset Deal
description: In a deal that thrusts Barry Diller once again into the thick of entertainment programming, his company, HSN Inc., agreed yesterday to acquire the Seagram Corporation's USA and Sci-Fi cable channels as well as almost all of Seagram's Universal Studios television production company for $4.1 billion in cash and stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKMANN, ALLAN G.
description: BECKMANN-Allan G., 81, of Boca Raton, FL and formerly of Park Slope, Brooklyn, NY, passed away on Saturday, October 18, 1997. Mr. Beckmann was a customs house broker with Daniel F. Young, Inc., for many years. He was preceded in death by his wife, C. Florence Beckmann, and second wife, Mary Beckmann. He is survived by his son, Allan G. Beckmann, Jr.; daughter-in-law Kathleen; and beloved grandchildren, Allan III, Carolyn and Melinda. Friends will be received on Tuesday and Wednesday from 2-4 pm and 6-8 pm at Babione Funeral Home. Funeral services will be held on Thursday at 10:00 am at Babione Funeral Home. Memorial remembrances in his name may be made to The American Cancer Society of Boca Raton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, RABBI ZEV K.
description: NELSON-Rabbi Zev K. We record with sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. Ordained in 1939, he served Beth Jacob Congregation in Norwich, CT, and in 1947 assumed the pulpit of Temple Emeth in Newton, MA, becoming rabbi emeritus in 1977. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children Avi, and Dr. Yona NelsonShulman and Dr. Deena Nelson, and all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi David L. Lieber, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. VP, The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Rival's Victory in Montenegro Weakens Milosevic
description: The Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, who has dominated the political life in this country since it broke apart, saw another key support knocked out from under him today with the election of a staunch political opponent to the Presidency of Montenegro.

title: Norsk Hydro Profits Rise 43% in Quarter
description: Norsk Hydro A.S.A., a Norwegian oil, fertilizer and metals company, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 43 percent, less than expected, as higher oil and gas earnings more than offset a drop in fertilizer prices. Profit rose to 1.304 billion kroner ($183.4 million), from 909 million ($127.8 million) in the third quarter last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUESTONE, BEATRICE
description: BLUESTONE - Beatrice. The Board members and entire staff of the Mosholu Montefiore Community Center extend their deepest sympathy to our esteemed Executive Director, Donald Bluestone; his brother, Barry, and their entire family for their loss. She dedicated her heart to family and community. They are her legacy. Arline Rubel, President Board of Trustees

title: New Offer Confirmed for Lin Television
description: Raycom Media Inc. confirmed yesterday that it had offered to buy the Lin Television Corporation for more than $1.7 billion, topping an earlier bid from Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc.

title: Fan Charged in Stabbings
description: A Massachusetts teen-ager who had watched the New England Patriots lose to the Jets on Sunday drew a five-inch folding knife and stabbed two New York men after an argument outside Giants Stadium, officials said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Electricity From Gasoline

title: Two Hospital Employees Charged in Bribe Scheme
description: Two workers at the United States Department of Veterans' Affairs Medical Center in East Orange were arrested yesterday and charged with taking bribes in exchange for steering contracts to a Wantage businessman and his wife, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BILLING, CLAIRE
description: BILLING-Claire, of Great Neck, NY, on October 19, 1997 at the age of 74. Beloved wife of Harold Billing. Loving mother of Jonathan, Mitchell, Lee. Adoring grandmother of Julie, Melissa, Jennifer, Amy. She will be missed by all of her family and friends. Graveside service Tues., Oct. 21, at 1 PM, at Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the ALS Assoc. 40 Wall St, #

title: From Welcome Visitor To Occupying Enemy
description: In two hours tonight, ''Frontline'' delivers 30 years of explosions and negotiations over the fate of Northern Ireland.
