At the moment, the long and bloody conflict between the British Government and the Irish Republican Army shows signs of becoming resolved, but as this history reminds us, hopes of peace have often been reduced to rubble in that beset land.

title: The challenge of getting shoppers to try the untried is the final focus of an ad conference.
description: THE daunting challenge posed by getting skeptical shoppers to try the untried -- particularly in the continuously changing technology market -- was the focus of the final sessions of the 88th annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers.

title: Out of the Basement and Onto a Disk
description: UNTIL now, back issues of National Geographic inevitably called to mind doctors' waiting rooms and musty storage boxes. But soon those stacks moldering beneath the cobwebs in America's garages and basements may be destined for recycling bins. The Complete National Geographic (for Windows or Macintosh, from Mindscape Inc., at about $200), a collection of 30 CD-ROM's, contains a digitized version of every page of the magazine from the first issue in 1888 through the December 1996 edition.

title: I-80 Is Closed After Truck Catches Fire
description: A tractor-trailer loaded with chemicals caught fire yesterday on Interstate 80 in Paterson, N.J., sending rocketlike bursts of flame and a cloud of gray smoke into the air and creating a 10-mile traffic jam after the highway was closed in both directions.

title: Judge Decrees 6-District Plan For Hempstead Town Board
description: A Federal judge who had ruled that Hempstead's at-large system of electing members to the Town Board discriminated against black residents accepted a plan yesterday that would divide the township into six voting districts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, HELEN
description: STEIN-Helen. Of Teaneck N.J. (25 year volunteer at Englewood Hospital). Beloved wife of the late Kurt J. Devoted mother of Lorraine and Roger Gordon and the late Allan. Loving grandmother of Jeffrey. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'' Hackensack N.J., Tuesday, 1:30PM. 1-800 522 0588

title: Change of Heart About Joining the Euro Hands Blair a Setback
description: The Labor Government of Prime Minister Tony Blair appeared to have suffered its first major setback tonight over contradictory statements about how soon it would abandon the pound to join the unified European currency, the euro.

title: Tim Curry Returns, With a Flourish
description: If ever a situation comedy was appropriately named, it's ABC's ''Over the Top.'' The new show, which has its premiere tonight, stars the ebullient British actor Tim Curry as the ebullient British actor Simon Ferguson, who is down on his luck and tends to spill his emotional baggage straight into the laps of everyone around him.

title: New Candidate Is Named in Dietary Fight Against Cancer
description: THE buzzword of a few years ago was beta carotene, a substance found in fruits and vegetables that was supposed to protect against cancer. Then scientific studies showed no particular benefit from taking beta carotene in pill form. In fact, questions were raised about potential harm, especially to smokers. Now it seems another substance in fruits and vegetables may account for the health protection long associated with eating carotene-rich foods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIROUX, JOHN
description: GIROUX-John. Lawyer, actor, lover of life. On October 19, 1997, at home in Manhattan. Husband of Vera Giroux. Also survived by his daughter Noelle and sons Paul and Leigh. Cherished grandfather of James, Hilary, Alexandra and Charlotte. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Central Park Conservancy, The National Psoriasis Foundation or the Actors Fund of America. The family will receive friends on Thursday and Friday, October 23 and 24, from 6-8 PM at the home of Mrs. Giroux.

title: Crew Threatens Removal Of School Board Member
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has threatened to dismiss a community school board member in Manhattan unless she resigns from a Brooklyn-based community organizing group that sometimes deals with the Board of Education, school officials said yesterday.

title: Clinton's Comments On Ads and Money
description: Following are excerpts from comments by President Clinton recorded on a videotape of a luncheon for Democratic donors and Democratic Party officials on Dec. 7, 1995, at the Hay Adams Hotel in Washington:

title: Prospecting In the Jumble Of Pollock's Earliest Work
description: ''My drawing, I will tell you frankly, is rotten,'' wrote a glum 18-year-old Jackson Pollock to his brother in 1930. ''It seems to lack freedom and rhythm. It is cold and lifeless. It isn't worth the postage to send it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOIZUETA, ROBERTO
description: GOIZUETA-Roberto. The Board of Directors, volunteers and staff of the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation (JDFI) International extend their deepest sympathies to the family of Roberto Goizueta on the sad occasion of his passing. His leadership, loyalty, warmth and kindness will be missed by his family, his friends, his company and the world. We, along with so many others, honor his memory. Robert Wood Johnson, IV, Chairman, JDFI Willard J. Overlock, Jr., Chairman of the Board James E. Mulvihill, D.M.D., President and CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DISTLER, BETSY
description: DISTLER-Betsy. IPTAR, the Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, mourns the untimely death of our President. She was a strong, committed advocate for psychoanalysis and especially for the understanding of female identity conflicts. We will miss her warmth and her steadfast voice. Contributions to the IPTAR Betsy Distler Memorial Fund. Our condolences to her husband David and her sons Daniel and Joshua.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENBERG, HARRIET
description: GOLDENBERG-Harriet. Hineni expresses heartfelt sympathy to our distinguished member, Ellen Fawer on the passing of her dearly beloved mother, Harriet Goldenberg, a true Aishes Chayil. Our condolences to her grandchildren, her son Stuart Sloame and her brother Jules Cohen. May they be comforted among the morners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rebbetzin Esther Jungreis, Pres. Barbara Janov, Exec. Director

title: Market Place; An Analysis By Goldman Can Be Used Against It
description: Allegiances are shifting so quickly among telecommunications investment bankers that an analyst who befriends a stock may soon find himself providing ammunition to his firm's foes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRONHEIM, DAVID
description: BRONHEIM-David. A life of passionate commitment to democracy and democratic reform will be honored and remembered by all who knew him. His loved and loving children, his sister, his family and friends mourn his tragic and untimely death. Memorial service, Friday, Oct. 23, 11AM, ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Nine Years After Pan Am Flight 103
description: Libya is pressing hard to free itself from the United Nations sanctions imposed on it for refusing to extradite two suspects in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, nine years ago. It has persuaded Arab and African leaders to begin ignoring restrictions on Libyan flights and it is trying to persuade the Lockerbie victims' families to accept financial settlements so that it can avoid a criminal trial altogether. Tripoli has also revived its 1994 offer to let the suspects be tried by Scottish judges under Scottish law, but in a country other than Britain or the United States.

title: How to Expand NATO
description: To the Editor:

title: Jury Pool Is Whittled Down In Bomb Trial's Fourth Week
description: Jury selection in the second Oklahoma City bombing trial passed the halfway mark here this morning.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GOURAUD SHEILA MARGUERITE
description: GOURAUD Sheila Marguerite, 21 October 1994 Irma Schlesinger, 21 October 1955 In loving memory. Jackson, Meg, George, Charles Steven, Tracey

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUEGER, PEARL
description: KRUEGER-Pearl. On October 20. Beloved wife of Philip. Loving mother of Nadine Oppenheimer and Donald (Mindy) Krueger. Grandmother of Jessica and Adam Oppenheimer and Jeremy Krueger. Sister of Bernard and Robert Feller. Funeral services are to be private and family requests that donations be made to the Leukemia Society of America, 600 Third Avenue, N.Y., N.Y. 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, SIDNEY
description: BERMAN-Sidney. 79. Of Laurelton and Lynbrook, N.Y. Died in Tamarac, FL. on October 18, 1997 after a long illness. He was the loving and cherished husband of 56 years to Helen Denowitz Berman; beloved father and father-in-law of Madelynn Berman Heintz and Nick Davy, Robert and Susan Berman and Mark and Donna Berman Saks; the adored grandfather of Jarrad, Ryan, Matthew and Sam and the devoted brother of Laura Gottlieb, Frieda Handelman and Dorothy Fried. Funeral service 2PM Tuesday, October 21, Gutterman's, Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I. Contributions may be made to The Crohn's and Colitis Foundation, 585 Stuart Ave., Garden City, N.Y. 11530 or the United Jewish Appeal.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Prosecutor Tells Court Of Kickbacks In Union Case
description: Beginning with the story of a cash bribe divided in a Brooklyn basement, a Federal prosecutor sketched his case yesterday against three lawyers and a former union president charged with stealing from the union that once represented city transit police officers.

title: Visions of Music Like Wheels In Space; Electronic Challenges Posed By Berio's New Composition
description: Centro Tempo Reale, Luciano Berio's center for research, production and training in new music technology, occupies the top floor of the Villa Strozzi, on the west side of the city, the lower stories being tenanted by a fashion institute. Walking up the stairs, in a building without elevators, Mr. Berio pointed out how the steps to the second and third floors are low, to improve access by ladies and cardinals in long robes from a period considerably before the time of the fashion school, whereas the final flight to Mr. Berio's own premises is steeper. Tempo Reale -- Real Time in Italian -- is perched in the servants' quarters.

title: National G.O.P. Bankrolls Ads in Race for Seat Molinari Left
description: Raising the stakes in the battle to fill Susan Molinari's House seat, the Republican National Committee is spending about $750,000 on a television advertising campaign to begin this week to help City Councilman Vito J. Fossella Jr., the Republican candidate.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CROSS-CONTINENT AUTO RETAILERS INC., Amarillo, Tex., agreed to acquire Chaisson Motor Cars and Chaisson BMW in Las Vegas, Nev., for about $18 million in cash, notes and stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIBBO, MICHAEL ALLEN
description: BIBBO-Michael Allen. On October 18, 1997. Beloved husband of Martha M. Gagne. Devoted father of Nicholas. Loving son of Domenico and Julie, and the late Gloria. Adored brother of Nancy, Nick, Greg, Eileen, Debbie, Michael and Steven. Memorial service Friday, 1:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory can be made to the American Council for Drug Education, 164 W. 74th Street, NYC 10023.

title: Gephardt Will Join Republicans on Overhaul of I.R.S., Aides Say
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, has tentatively decided to support legislation that would bring sweeping changes to the way the Internal Revenue Service is run, giving the bill broad bipartisan backing despite objections from the Clinton Administration.

title: Ah, to Freeze in Cleveland in Autumn
description: A wall of frigid air-conditioning greeted the Florida Marlins on Sunday night when they boarded their team plane shortly after midnight. ''What, are they trying to prepare us for Cleveland?'' a player said.

title: Paralyzed Athlete Loses Workers Compensation Appeal
description: A jury in state District Court ruled today that a former Texas Christian University running back who was paralyzed during a football game was not an employee of the school at the time and therefore was not entitled to workers compensation benefits for his injury.

title: Inner-City Troubles Won't Respond to Nostalgia; Profiteer Restraint
description: To the Editor:

title: $2.4 Billion Bond Act For Schools Draws Notice
description: The battle over whether voters should authorize New York State to borrow $2.4 billion to build and renovate schools began in earnest yesterday, as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the State Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, described passage of the bond referendum as a moral obligation, while an independent fiscal monitor derided its terms as too vague to insure that the money would be used properly.

title: C.I.A. Official Quits Nonproliferation Post
description: The director of the C.I.A.'s Nonproliferation Center, who provided Congress with detailed briefings on some of the most diplomatically sensitive instances of illicit technology sales to Iran from Russia and China, is taking early retirement.

title: Kinder Morgan In Pipeline Deal
description: Kinder Morgan Energy Partners said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Santa Fe Pacific Pipeline Partners for about $1.1 billion in cash and stock.

title: In Case of Art Thievery, A Guilty Plea and Help
description: A Japanese man arrested last month and charged with trying to sell more than $10 million worth of drawings, including works by Rembrandt and Albrecht Durer, has pleaded guilty and has agreed to cooperate with Federal prosecutors, according to court documents.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUSTGARTEN, IRA H.
description: LUSTGARTEN-Ira H. A memorial service will be held Sat., Oct. 25, 1997 at 12:30 PM at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University Campus, Amsterdam Avenue and 116th Street. No flowers by request.

title: Pilar Miro Romero, 57, Film and TV Director Who Served in Spain's Culture Ministry
description: Pilar Miro Romero, a pioneering female director of movies and television who also fostered Spain's film industry by introducing state aid for promising young filmmakers when she served in the Socialist Government of the 1980's, died at her home here on Sunday. She was 57.

title: Executive Jet Venture Is Set
description: Boeing, General Electric and Executive Jet Inc. are forming a joint venture that will allow businesses and individuals to buy partial shares of new $40 million Boeing business jets to be introduced late next year.

title: 2 Styles In Pakistan: For Lovers And Sufis
description: Love songs from the mountains and devotional songs inspired by the desert made for a fascinating double bill of Pakistani folk music at the Asia Society on Saturday night.

title: Prices for Natural Gas Reach 9-Month High
description: Natural gas rose to a nine-month high yesterday on expectations that an early cold snap this week would raise demand.

title: U.S. Says Its Greenhouse Gas Emissions Are at Highest Rate in Years
description: As negotiations resume in Bonn on a new treaty to save the planet from global warming, the United States said today that its emissions of heat-trapping gases into the atmosphere grew last year at the highest rate since the nation pledged to cut them back.

title: Review/Fashion; For New Talent, No Safety Nets
description: For some time to come, fashion's eyes will be focused on how new designers fare at old houses. Whether these companies live or die will depend on it, and the survival of fresh design talent is increasingly tied to it as well, as there is little money around for them to build their own houses. Veronique Leroy's show was a river of emotion for the French fashion power brokers in attendance. Not because of the collection she showed, which was strong, but because she managed to have a show at all. Ms. Leroy recently lost her backer.

title: Personal Health; When Eyes Betray Color Vision
description: BACK in the late 1950's, when men's ties were usually selected to match the color of their suits, Marty arrived for a date in a handsome new brown suit. When I asked about his unusual choice of a green tie, he exclaimed, ''It's not green, it's brown.'' And thus he discovered a previously unrecognized defect in his color vision.

title: How Cells Unwind Tangled Skein of Life
description: EVERYONE knows the innate propensity of hoses and pieces of string to weave themselves into inextricable tangles just as soon as one's back is turned. So consider the problem faced by each cell in the human body: it must manage more than two yards worth of computing tape in the form of delicate ribbons of DNA, the genetic material.

title: Awoken by Gretzky, Rangers End Their Skid
description: After one period last night against the Carolina Hurricanes, the Rangers trailed by 1-0 on a goal that accidentally went into the Ranger net off the foot of a New York defenseman.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Petroleum Geo-Services In Awilco Shipping Deal
description: Petroleum Geo-Services A.S.A. agreed yesterday to acquire the floating oil production and storage business of Awilco Shipping A.S. of Norway for $860 million in stock. Petroleum Geo-Services is a Norwegian oilfield services company that buys and sells marine seismic data. It said the deal would help it increase the amount of its income that comes from oil production.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Two Arrested in Bribery Case
description: Two workers at the United States Department of Veterans' Affairs Medical Center in East Orange were arrested yesterday and charged with taking bribes in exchange for steering government contracts to a Wantage businessman and his wife, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKERSON, NANCY
description: DICKERSON-Nancy. The Board of Directors, staff and national membership of the United Nations Association of the United States of America (UNA-USA) are deeply saddened by the passing of Nancy Dickerson, beloved wife of our esteemed Chairman, the Hon. John C. Whitehead. We are grateful for her activity on behalf of the Association and her valuable participation in our peacekeeping trips, and we are inspired by her grace, compassion and commitment to those less fortunate. She will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to John and all her family. Michael W. Sonnenfeldt, Chair, Executive Committee of the Board Ruth J. Hinerfeld, Vice Chair, Board of Directors Estelle Linzer, Vice Chair, Board of Directors Arthur Ross, Vice Chair, Board of Directors William J. Rouhana, Jr., Vice Chair, Board of Directors Christopher W. Brody, Treasurer Shirley Quisenberry, Secretary Alvin P. Adams, Jr., President and CEO

title: Powlus Will Share His Duties
description: When Notre Dame plays host to Boston College on Saturday, a quarterback other than Ron Powlus will see considerable action for the Irish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WENDER, MATTHEW GEORGE
description: WENDER-Matthew George. Born August 13, 1952. Died October 19, 1997. Beloved son of Angelica M. Wender and Ira Wender. Beloved stepson of Phyllis Wender, beloved brother of Abigail Wender Weerasinghe and John, Theodore, Justin and Sarah Wender. Funeral will be held Wednesday, October 22, 11am at Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64 Street. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Mary Lea Johnson Richards Organ Transplant Center at NYU Medical Center, 530 1st Avenue, Suite 6A, NY, NY 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMBRIA, BARBARA JEAN (SCHMIDT)
description: CAMBRIA - Barbara Jean (Schmidt), 44, died on October 16, 1997 at home in Green Brook, NJ. Beloved wife of 14 years of John. Loving mother of Catherine P., Jean J.P. and Lucia R.A. Devoted daughter of Robert and Patricia Schmidt. Dear sister of R. Mark Schmidt, Laurel Taylor and Catherine Wolfe. Services 9 AM, Wednesday, at Higgins Home for Funerals, 752 Mountain Blvd., Watchung, NJ followed by a mass at 10 AM at St. Vincent de Paul R.C. Church in Stirling, NJ. Visiting 2-4 and 7-9 Monday and Tuesday.

title: Undisclosed School Board Session Said to Violate Open Meetings Law
description: The Board of Education held a secret meeting with Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew last summer to discuss his goals and objectives for the school system, in apparent violation of the state's open-meetings law, a state monitor said yesterday.

title: Hints of a Nuclear Test In Russia Are Disputed
description: Civilian scientists are strongly criticizing the Federal Government for saying that a seismic event that rocked the Russian wilds two months ago might have been an underground nuclear blast.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: CHILD WELFARE -- On the campaign trail, Ruth W. Messinger pressed Mayor Giuliani to drop his opposition to the release of a report on the city's child welfare agency. B2.

title: G.M. Division Shifting Account
description: The Pontiac-GMC division of the General Motors Corporation is shifting the GMC trucks account, with billings estimated at $70 million, between agencies owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, according to executives close to the agencies involved. G.M. is dismissing the Troy, Mich., office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising and hiring Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York.

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: Stocks were higher here this morning. At the midday recess, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 233.16 points, or 1.35 percent, at 17,527.67. On Monday, the Nikkei fell 189.91 points.

title: GENERAL ACCIDENT TO ACQUIRE A CANADIAN INSURER
description: General Accident P.L.C. of Britain agreed yesterday to acquire Canada's General Insurance Group Ltd. for $600 million (Canadian), or $432 million. General Accident, based in Perth, Scotland, is Britain's second-largest publicly listed insurer in terms of premium income, after Commercial Union P.L.C. General Insurance, based in Toronto, is a property and casualty insurer owned by the New York-based investment firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company. General Accident's chief executive, Bob Scott, hinted the company might make further acquisitions in Canada. It already owns the Pilot Insurance Company in Ontario, which will continue to operate separately.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about affirmative action efforts at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark misstated the residence of Gus Heningburg, the affirmative action consultant for the construction of the center. He has long worked in Newark, but he lives in in Secaucus, N.J.

title: Stocks Rebound, With Dow Rising 74.41
description: Quarterly earnings reports that were better than expected lifted stocks out of their slump yesterday, with broad market indexes posting their first sizable gains in a week.

title: Tape Shows Clinton Involvement in Party-Paid Ads; Legal Line Is Unclear
description: When President Clinton sat down to lunch at the Hay Adams Hotel with a group of wealthy Democratic donors and party officials in December 1995, he could not have expected that a videotape of the gathering would now be at the center of a heated debate over the legality of how he conducted his re-election campaign.

title: Gunter Grass Touches a Nerve in Germany Over 'Closet Racism'
description: Senior German Government officials engaged in a public fight today with Gunter Grass, one of the country's best-known writers, over remarks he made criticizing his compatriots as ''closet racists'' in their behavior toward would-be immigrants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EILEN, ADELE
description: EILEN-Adele. Died Sunday, October 19, 1997. Adele valiantly fought Parkinson's Disease for 31 years and finally lost. She will be greatly missed by her husband, Arthur; daughter and son-in-law, Sherry and Henry Krostich, and grandchildren, Seth and Wendy, and sister, Evelyn Gold, and many, many friends and relatives who loved beautiful Adele. Services will be held at Riverside Nassau North Chapel at 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, at 2 PM, Wednesday, October 22nd.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORLIN, RICHARD, M.D.
description: GORLIN-Richard, M.D. The members of the Department of Cardiothoracic Surgery of the Mt. Sinai Medical Center note with sorrow the loss of Dr. Richard Gorlin. His deep commitment to the welfare of his patients, to the growth of his proteges, and to the art of medicine were and continue to be an inspiration to those who knew him. His contributions to the science of medicine live on as a legacy to our profession. We will not soon see his like again. Randall B. Griepp, M.D., Professor and Chairman M. Arisan Ergin, M.D. Robert S. Litwak, M.D. Paul A. Kirschner, M.D. Steven L. Lansman, M.D. Jorge L. Camunas, M.D. Jan D. Galla, M.D. Khanh H. Nguyen, M.D. Jock N. McCullough, M.D.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, LEONARD
description: GOLDBERG-Leonard. The Lido Beach Synagogue mourns the passing of its Founding President. May God console the family in their hour of bereavement. Dr. Daniel Mehlman, Rabbi Herman Berger, President

title: Foumban Journal; Inheritors of an African Kingdom, Come and Gone
description: Surrounded by praise-singers who strive to outdo one another in chanting his virtues, court attendants who wave fans to preserve him from the heat and musicians who blow shrill six-foot-long trumpets toward an incandescent sky, Sultan Ibrahim Mbombo Njoya takes half an hour to walk the stone's throw from the central mosque to his imposing palace.

title: FIGURE SKATING: Growing Up in the Spotlight; Lipinski Concentrates More on Artistry Than Athleticism
description: Figure skating is in such a state of vertigo that, at 15, Tara Lipinski is old enough to be called the women's world champion, old enough to have an autobiography and a Web site and young enough to open a new kids' department at Macy's.

title: The Shaping of Oboe Reeds: Maybe It Is Rocket Science
description: HE invents statistical methods for helping missiles hit their targets more precisely, and she plays the oboe in symphony orchestras. Together, they hope to achieve a synthesis of techniques.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, HAROLD
description: RATNER-Harold. To our dear friend Andrew Ratner, expressing our heartfelt condolences to you and your family on the loss of your beloved father. Lee and Jeffrey Feil Susan and Jay Anderson

title: When Giant Squids Mate, It's a Stab in the Dark
description: LITTLE is known of what lives in the depths of the sea, much less how the creatures of darkness live and die, hunt and eat, play and reproduce. Nevertheless, two scientists in Australia have managed to shed light on the sex life of the giant squid, the most famous of legendary sea monsters.

title: Review/Fashion; 3 Eminences Sense Youth's Hot Breath
description: The longest-running acts in fashion are not about to cede their hard-earned place to the many designers jockeying for position and the fashion observers ready to dismiss them. Valentino, Emanuel Ungaro and Vivienne Westwood must look at the pages in their fashion book and wonder whether it's time to turn to a new leaf or to set their fashion esthetic in stone for posterity.

title: Seles's Year to Forget Still Has 72 Days to Go
description: This disturbing year is not quite over for Monica Seles. She has events in Moscow and Chicago to brush up on her indoor game before making her first appearance in four years at the Chase Championships next month at Madison Square Garden, the year-end event she dominated before her career was derailed by a stabbing in 1993.

title: France Telecom Shares Gain in Initial Trading
description: The shares of France Telecom S.A. surged as much as 18 percent yesterday on the first day of trading, after a record number of investors subscribed to the $7.1 billion initial public offering of the concern, Europe's second-biggest telephone company. The shares opened at 215 French francs ($36.13), up from the 182 francs ($30.59) a share paid by individual investors. They slipped back to close at 206.5 francs ($34.71). That gives France Telecom a market capitalization of 206.5 billion francs ($34.71 billion), dethroning the oil company Elf Aquitaine S.A. as the biggest French company.

title: Chevron Plans to Sell British Gas Stations
description: The Chevron Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell 450 filling stations in Britain to the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, completing its plans to withdraw from the retail gasoline business in Britain.

title: Armstrong-Domco Deal Cleared by F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission has cleared Armstrong World Industries' proposed $354 million acquisition of Domco Inc., Armstrong said today.

title: Whitman and McGreevey Disagree Over the High Cost of Car Insurance
description: Following are excerpts from last night's second debate between Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, her Democratic opponent, State Senator James E. McGreevey, and Murray Sabrin, the Libertarian candidate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORIARTY, PATRICK J.
description: MORIARTY-Patrick J., CSW. The NYC Chapter, National Assoc. of Social Workers mourns the loss of our long-time member, colleague, & friend. He was the consummate social worker, with an exquisite sense of principle, purpose and spirituality: he touched people at their deepest level. The core of his existence was to serve others, and in doing so, he made a difference to so many. As an older person living with AIDS, he confronted and lived his life with courage & grace. We are grateful for his example and privileged to have known him. Memorial service Wed., November 19, 6:15 PM, Holy Trinity RC Church, 213 West 82 Street, NYC. Robert Schachter, DSW, Exec. Dir. Carmen Hendricks, DSW, Pres.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Jury Is Split in Doctor Case
description: After five days of deliberations, a jury said it was deadlocked in the trial of a doctor charged with tampering with evidence while examining the body of a man that had been found hanging in a cell in the Essex County jail.

title: Citicorp Plans To Cut Payroll By 7,500 Jobs
description: Citicorp said yesterday that it would eliminate a total of 7,500 jobs as it moves to cut costs and streamline operations in nearly 100 countries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSBERG, SYLVIA
description: WEISSBERG-Sylvia. Congregation Ohab Zedek, Belle Harbor, mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our esteemed member, Rosalie Rothenberg. May the bereaved family be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Jacob Reiner, Rabbi Mendy Bauman, Stanley Liker, Presidium

title: Corrections
description: A News Summary on Monday about the marriage of descendants of Miles Standish and Priscilla Mullens referred incorrectly to Standish's role aboard the Mayflower in some copies. Captain Standish was a military officer hired as the military leader of the colonists. He was not the captain of the ship, whose master was Christopher Jones.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The sheer number of these young star clusters is amazing.''

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES TO BUY NEW ENGLAND BAKER'S ASSETS
description: The Interstate Bakeries Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the assets of the John J. Nissen Baking Companies, a baker and distributor of bread in New England. Terms were not disclosed. Interstate, based in Kansas City, Mo., whose brands include Wonder bread and Twinkies, had $3.2 billion in sales for the year ended May, 31. It said sales of Nissen-branded products exceed $115 million annually.

title: Medical Research Saves Money, Too; Doctors Strike Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Inter Milan and Liverpool Are Sent to Early Exits
description: UEFA CUP

title: Class Notes; The life of the child actor: First the math, then some ball, and finally the big scene.
description: ''You're going to be going down a bumpy hill in a car,'' Jacqueline Figueroa was telling her 6-year-old son Jean-Luke on a recent morning, preparing him for his afternoon's activity. ''A bad guy is going to be chasing you. If he catches you, he's going to put a bullet in your head.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLAN, PATRICK D.
description: BOLAN-Patrick D., on October 20, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Yolanda. Loving father of Daniel, John and Thomas. Dear brothter of Thomas and the late Alfred. Reposing Neufeld Funeral Home, 8804 43rd Avenue, Elmhurst. Funeral mass St. Mary's Church, on Friday at 9:30 A.M. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, HAROLD
description: RATNER-Harold. The Employees of Sunny Day Enterprises mourn the loss of Harold Ratner, our beloved friend, associate and mentor. His loss has left an irreplaceable void in our organization and in our hearts. His memory is an inspiration to all who knew him. Our deepest sympathy to the entire Ratner family. Sonny Gordon Kenny Gordon

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MCDOUGALD, CORNELIUS
description: McDOUGALD-Cornelius. Memorial service will be held Nov. 1 at 1:30 at Community Church of New York at 40 East 35 Street.

title: '97 WORLD SERIES: GAME 3
description: The Marlins scored seven runs in the ninth inning last night to break open a tie game and defeated the Indians, 14-11, in Cleveland to take a lead of two games to one in the World Series. Florida tied a Series record for most runs in the ninth.

title: Chicago's Scandal Resume Lengthens
description: Sometimes regarded as a finishing school for the penitentiary, the City Council recently passed a strict ethics code, a man-bites-dog case for Chicago politicians better known for sneering at good-government reformers, who are known here as ''goo-goos.''

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Islanders Fall to .500 on Road Trip After Loss to Kings
description: Eleven days ago, when their five-game road trip began, the Islanders would have probably been satisfied with a .500 record. But somewhere between Miami and San Jose, those expectations were raised.

title: Adventurous Chefs Pour the Glory Back Into the Ketchup Bottle
description: KETCHUP, believe it or not, was once elegant, diversely flavored and in vogue. Nearly a century ago, ketchup was proudly offered in the nation's finest restaurants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNOCK, DANIEL B.
description: KNOCK-Daniel B. On October 20, 1997, of Harrison, NY. Beloved husband of Helen (nee Olson). Loving father of the late Peter B. Knock and father-in-law of Signe S. Gates. Dear brother of Esther Knock Borden. The family will receive friends Thursday, 7:00PM9:00PM, at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Services Friday 11:00AM, at the Presbyterian Church of Rye. Interment to follow, Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the Peter B. Knock Memorial Music Fund, C/O the Presbyterian Church, 882 Boston Post Road, Rye, N.Y. 10580.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: European Engineering Giant Is Cutting 10,000 Jobs

title: Alone at the Top? Not Shakespeare; Mendel's 'Tedious' Peas
description: To the Editor:

title: An Ugly Night Turns Even Uglier for the Indians
description: They had a wild and crazy no, make that ugly -- time in the third game of the World Series. If it had been a beauty contest, observers would have booed the contestants. If it had been a concert, listeners would have run out of the hall. If it had been an art exhibit, viewers would have covered their eyes.

title: Cast Iron: It Just Gets Better With Time
description: HOMELY and definitely old-fashioned, cast-iron skillets have fallen out of favor with many modern cooks because they are rather clunky and look out of place in a streamlined, high-tech kitchen. Before they fade away completely, some of us who admire them need to take a stand, band together in some kind of iron-pot protection society and sing their praises. These skillets have more than enough virtues to overpower their drawbacks. Plus, they cost about $20, and can last forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUEGER, PEARL
description: KRUEGER-Pearl. The Auxiliary of Montefiore Medical Center mourns the loss of our friend and colleague, Pearl Krueger, a devoted member and dedicated volunteer of the Information & Referral Service. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved family. Ruth Saporta, President Mary Goldsmith, Secretary

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about an agreement by Starwood Lodging Trust, a hotelier, to buy the ITT Corporation misidentified the owner of the Aristocrat Hotel in Dallas. It is Patriot American Hospitality Inc., not Starwood Lodging.

title: Draft Riots of 1863
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGLONE, ROBERT J. (BOB)
description: MCGLONE-Robert J. (Bob), of 212 Carolina Sands Drive, Carolina Beach, NC, died October 21, 1997 at his residence. He is survived by his wife, Margaret (Peggy) Hassett McGlone of the home. He retired from Slattery Associates, Queens, New York. Also surviving are his three daughters, Teresa M. Day of Wake Forest, North Carolina, Patricia M. Gasparello of Burlington, NC, Barbara M. Keyes of Mount Pleasant, SC; and 3 grandchildren. For information, the Andrews Mortuary Valley Chapel, 4108 South College Road, Wilmington, N.C. 28412 (910-791-7055).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VASILE, LUCY RUSSO, M.D.
description: VASILE-Lucy Russo, M.D., on Oct. 20, 1997, of Tomkins Cove, NY (formerly of Jackson Heights). Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 11 A.M., Immaculate Conception Church, Stony Point, NY. Burial, Mount Repose Cemetery, Haverstraw NY. Visiting Higgins Funeral Home, Rte 9W, Stony Point, NY, Thursday and Friday 2-4, 7-9PM.

title: Slippery, Sweet and Strange
description: THERE is an odd fruit lurking on stands around New York. Fruit sellers cannot seem to agree on a spelling for it. Variously called canepes, geneps and gineps, the specimens look like baby limes grown in clusters like grapes.

title: Senators Hear Welcome News on Cost of NATO's Expansion
description: Two of the Clinton Administration's top foreign policy officials went to Capitol Hill today to assert that the Pentagon's initial estimates of the cost of expanding NATO were too high, and to assure wary Senators that the project would not become a financial morass for the United States.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Panel Weighs Casino License
description: The State Casino Control Commission is set to decide today whether to grant a casino license to Sol Kerzner, a South African developer who was accused of bribery in 1986, state officials said.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Rise On Big Board and Amex
description: A wave of takeover announcements helped drive the open positions of short sales on the New York Stock Exchange up 2.2 percent this month to 3.42 billion shares, just short of the record 3.44 billion in June, figures released by the exchange showed yesterday. The American Stock Exchange reported short interest rose 1.1 percent, to a record 181.7 million shares. The figures reflect trades through Oct. 9.

title: Insignia in British Deal
description: The Insignia Financial Group has agreed to acquire the Richard Ellis Group, a British real estate services and investment firm. Financial terms were not disclosed. The closely held Richard Ellis has annual revenues of about $85 million, Insignia said. Insignia, also a real estate services company, had 1996 revenues of $221.1 million.

title: $25 and Under; On an Odd Menu, Russian Classics Survive
description: A REVOLUTION has come to Vanechka, a small restaurant in Riverdale that until recently specialized in old-fashioned Russian cuisine. Around Labor Day, Vanechka closed for a few days, and when it reopened the Russian menu had gone the way of the czars. Replacing it was something Vanechka calls ''Euro-seafood.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORLIN, RICHARD, M.D.
description: GORLIN-Richard, M.D. We are saddened about his passing. He was a friend and a mentor-a brilliant teacher. He still had so much to offer. Arnold and Sylvia Schonfeld

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the popularity of New York City's mayoral candidates in St. Albans, Queens, misstated the given name of one resident. He is Richard Walden, not John.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; United Parcel Depot Robbed
description: Nearly 30 police officers from Pleasantville and surrounding towns sealed off a section of wooded swampland yesterday in an effort to catch an armed fugitive who had robbed a United Parcel Service depot, the police said.

title: THE FINE PRINT: A closer look at the Amtrak bill.; Rail Bill Would Benefit Private Freight Companies in Lawsuits
description: As the House this week considers a measure to reauthorize Amtrak, the national passenger rail system, among the most interested onlookers will be the private freight rail companies, which could benefit greatly from an obscure provision in the bill.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Two Shot on Bus in Newark
description: The Newark police were searching last night for a teen-ager who shot two passengers on a city bus after the passengers complained that he was playing his radio too loudly, the police said.

title: Thousands of Thais Protest Bangkok's Inaction in Crisis
description: Thousands of people rallied in the streets of Bangkok for a second day today, furious at their Government's vacillation in the face of a severe economic crisis.

title: Hush Those Helicopters
description: To the Editor:

title: Waste Industry Deal
description: Eastern Environmental Services Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Pine Grove Landfill Inc., a 174-acre municipal solid-waste landfill, and the Pine Grove Hauling Company for $46 million. The landfill and hauling companies, which are in Pennsylvania, are units of the Delmarva Power and Light Company, an electric utility.

title: Critic's Notebook; A Call to Action: Save the Real Deli
description: A COUNTERMAN at a corner deli gets the order, a hot corned beef sandwich. He knows what that means: heat up the meat. He grabs the corned beef, presliced, of course, and hurls it onto the hot grill alongside the sizzling bacon and eggs. Soon, the corned beef is warm, but it is now a pathetic specimen, all dry and leathery. What does he do next? He slaps it between two slices of supermarket rye, and there you have it: a hot corned beef sandwich.

title: ABB Will Cut 10,000 Jobs And Switch Focus to Asia
description: In one of the most striking examples yet of shifting global allegiances in business, the Swiss-Swedish engineering company ABB Asea Brown Boveri announced today that it would cut 10,000 jobs in Western Europe and the United States and invest in Asia instead.

title: To Repay G.I.'s and Rebuild America
description: The millions of men and women who returned to civilian life at the end of World War II have sometime since gone to gray, but memories of their reception remain green. Instead of being shrugged off like veterans of earlier wars, they were given generous unemployment checks, low-interest loans for houses and businesses and, most significantly, free education at colleges and trade schools.

title: WELLS FARGO PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO 8.6 MILLION SHARES
description: Wells Fargo & Company said yesterday that it would buy back up to 8.6 million additional shares, or about 10 percent, of its outstanding common stock. The planned repurchases are a continuation of a buyback program that began in 1994. The stock of Wells Fargo, a San Francisco-based banking company, rose $22.3125 a share yesterday, or 7 percent, to $314.

title: Lawmakers Are Confident a Court-Reform Plan Will Pass Next Year
description: The 35-year-old schoolteacher thought she could finally get on with her life when she won custody of her children two years ago after protracted and bitter divorce hearings in State Supreme Court in White Plains.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, SOPHIE
description: WEISS-Sophie, on October 20, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Albert Weiss. Beloved mother of Murray and Robert. Loving grandmother of David, Amy, Elizabeth and Marian. Also survived by four great-grandchildren. A private graveside service at the Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. For information contact the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, STANLEY. PETER MARTINS
description: WILLIAMS-Stanley. Peter Martins, Ballet Master in Chief, Eugene P. Grisanti, Chairman of The Board, Howard Solomon, President of The Board Directors and everyone at New York City Ballet deeply mourn the passing of Stanley Williams, legendary teacher, colleague, mentor and dear friend. We shall remember fondly his gentle and patient spirit and his life long dedication to his craft and to his beloved students. Our heartfelt sympathy goes to his family. We have lost a cherished and irreplaceable member of the NYCB family, but his enduring legacy to generations of dancers will never be forgotten.

title: South Korean Government to Operate Kia
description: The South Korean Government said today that it would take over the troubled Kia Motors Corporation in an effort to stem a crisis.

title: William S. Ogden, 69, Executive Of Chase and a Banking Rescuer
description: William S. Ogden, a banker credited with helping save the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company from insolvency after its collapse in 1984, died on Saturday. He was 69 and lived in Stamford, Conn.

title: Democrat Leads Race For County Executive
description: The Democratic candidate for Westchester County Executive, Andrew J. Spano, continues to maintain a lead over his Republican opponent, Ted Dunn, despite an aggressive advertising campaign by Mr. Dunn, according to a poll released yesterday by Manhattanville College.

title: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN TO SELL 60% STAKE IN RAILROAD UNIT
description: Kansas City Southern Industries said yesterday that it planned to sell about 60 percent of its equity stake in the company's railroad business. Kansas City Southern declined to say how much it expected to raise in the stock sale, scheduled for next year. Analysts estimated the company would raise about $250 million in the offering. Last month, Kansas City Southern said it would split its railroad and mutual fund businesses to concentrate on the faster-growing financial services unit. The company manages about $71.3 billion in assets through its Denver-based mutual fund groups: the Janus Capital Corporation and Berger Associates Inc. Kansas City Southern has said it could make more purchases in the money management business.

title: Business and Politics Merge To Mourn Coke's Chairman
description: Roberto C. Goizueta, the chairman and chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company who died on Saturday, was remembered today in a funeral service attended by prominent executives and politicians.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIROUX, JOHN
description: GIROUX-John. Lawyer, actor, lover of life. On October 19, 1997, at home in Manhattan. Husband of Vera Giroux. Also survived by his daughter Noelle and sons Paul and Leigh. Cherished grandfather of James, Hilary, Alexandra and Charlotte. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Central Park Conservancy, The National Psoriasis Foundation or the Actors Fund of America. The family will receive friends on Thursday and Friday, October 23 and 24, from 6-8 PM at the home of Mrs. Giroux.

title: In His Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Russia and France Balk at U.S. Plan to Punish Iraq Even More
description: Despite the personal intervention of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, the United States is meeting sustained resistance in the Security Council to its plan for imposing new sanctions on Iraq, diplomats on the Council said today.

title: Justice Moves Against Microsoft
description: The complaint filed this week by the Justice Department against Microsoft poses little threat to the software company that provides the operating system, Windows 95, for about 90 percent of the personal computers in America. Even if the courts force Microsoft to comply, it will lose few sales. But the Justice decision sends a welcome signal that the department is ready to act whenever Microsoft's business practices unfairly threaten its rivals.

title: Alone at the Top? Not Shakespeare
description: To the Editor:

title: Lockheed's Net in 3d Quarter Up 6.4%
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation reported a 6.4 percent gain in third-quarter earnings yesterday on improved results from its space, missile and airplane businesses.

title: Despite the Bad News, The Fishing Is Good
description: MAYBE there will always be plenty of fish in the sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANTSOUDES, JIM
description: GANTSOUDES-Jim. A best friend and confidant for over 23 years. Courageous, stoic and always a constant in our lives. A man among men. His affectionate embraces, warm and engaging smile and eternal sense of optimism created his own special aura. ''JG'' truly made a difference in our lives and his essence will always remain with us. Deepest condolencences to his loving family; his adored wife Martha and beloved children: Geordy, Alexis, Sarah, Spencer and Nicholas and his treasured mother, Helen. The Behrman's: Darryl, Janine, Greg, Amanda and Grant

title: Leyland Is Forced to Play by Different Rules
description: Maybe Jim Leyland was prescient. Maybe he was just worried.

title: Repose at the Frick
description: Perhaps the subtlest art exhibition in New York City at the moment is the single painting by Nicholas Poussin hanging, on loan from the Louvre, in the Frick Collection. The painting, completed around 1638, is called ''The Arcadian Shepherds.'' It depicts three shepherds and a shepherdess contemplating a tomb built of stone blocks and bearing the Latin phrase ''Et in Arcadia ego.'' The words translate to ''Even in Arcadia am I,'' and they are the words of death himself, present even in that mythic, pastoral golden age when the most pressing concern of men and women was the welfare of their sheep.

title: Defense Assails Main Witness In Union Trial
description: Defense lawyers for the men accused of stealing from the union that once represented transit police officers attacked the Government's case yesterday in their opening statements, saying it was built on testimony from witnesses who had clear motives to lie.

title: SAN DIEGO
description: The Padres will name Dave Stewart pitching coach at the end of the World Series, General Manager Kevin Towers said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, CHESTER
description: FRANK-Chester. On October 19, 1997. Beloved son of the late Sidney and the late Ruth Frank. Service Wednesday, October 22 at 11:30 am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY PLANS TO BUY DAIRY QUEEN
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., headed by Warren E. Buffett, agreed yesterday to buy International Dairy Queen Inc. for $585 million in cash and stock. Berkshire will pay $27 a share in cash or $26 in either of its two classes of stock for each class A and class B share of Dairy Queen. No more than 55 percent of the purchase price will be made in cash. Dairy Queen's board, headed by John W. Mooty, the chairman, approved the acquisition. The Mooty family controls 35 percent of Dairy Queen and chose to exchange its entire holding for Berkshire stock. Although those who take stock will be getting a lower price, they will be able to defer paying capital gains taxes on their profit. Dairy Queen's class A shares climbed $2.625, to $26.75, and the class B rose $2.125, to $27.375.

title: Are Teachers of Teachers Out of Touch?
description: Education professors are ''out of sync'' with public school teachers and the public on fundamental issues like what and how teachers should teach, according to a survey by a nonpartisan research group, Public Agenda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDENBERG, HARRIET
description: GOLDENBERG-Harriet. Bar-Ilan University in Israel and its American Friends mourn the passing of Harriet Goldenberg, the beloved sister of our dear friend and benefactor, Jules Cohen. May Jules and the entire family derive solace from inspiring memories and their devotion to the Jewish community and the people of Israel. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor Prof. Moshe Kaveh, President Jane Stern Lebell, President, American Friends Brig. Gen. (Res.) Yehuda Halevy, Executive Vice President Gary Baskind, NY Regional Dir.

title: Undermining Local Government
description: The House is scheduled to vote today on a bill that is ostensibly aimed at protecting private property rights from intrusion by local governments. The bill has 236 co-sponsors, few of whom could have read it with any care. It is a dangerous piece of work that would threaten local zoning laws, reshape time-honored principles of federalism and make Federal judges the arbiters of land-use decisions everywhere. It would be a dream come true for developers but a nightmare for rational community planning.

title: 2 Men Ask for Help, Then Rob Man and Child
description: A 70-year-old man and his 5-year-old granddaughter were tied up and robbed at gunpoint in their home here yesterday by two men who said they were looking for a lost dog, the Nassau County police said.

title: Chill in the Air Means It's Time for Aqueduct
description: Thoroughbred racing in New York switches to its winter quarters today when Aqueduct in Queens opens for the next six and a half months, replacing the more scenic venues at Belmont Park and Saratoga.

title: Lucent Earnings Exceed Estimates
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. reported fourth-quarter earnings yesterday that sharply exceeded estimates.

description: HARTLEY-Lena Elizabeth Boykin. Beloved mother of Pat and grandmother of Smokey D. Fontaine who lived a fearless life of joy, struggle, and love without compromise. She will be missed by a family who lived to make her proud. A memorial service will be held at the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, Thursday, October 23nd at 5:00 P.M.

title: Fireworks in Deep Space as Two Galaxies Collide
description: New pictures from the Hubble Space Telescope have given astronomers striking views of stellar birth triggered by the collision of two nearby galaxies -- and perhaps a glimpse of what could be in store for the Milky Way galaxy in about five billion years.

title: The Minimalist; Getting Chicken Right: Just Add Bricks
description: IT isn't easy to cook chicken so that its skin is crisp and its interior juicy. Grilling, roasting and sauteing all have their problems.

Levenson, former Associate Director of the Center. Her intelligence and energy encouraged in countless ways the work done there, and she will be sorely missed. Wm. Theodore de Bary Carl F. Hovde,

title: Accidental Starter: Gordon Is Ready
description: On June 3, when Dwayne Gordon agreed to a two-year contract with the Jets, his agent, Harold Lewis, was happy.

title: Brother James Bonilla Dies at 60; Headed Bishop Loughlin High
description: Brother James Bonilla, principal of Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School in Brooklyn for the last 12 years, died on Friday at Brooklyn Hospital Center. He was 60.

title: 30-Year Bond Extends Gain; Others Mixed
description: Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday as comments from four Federal Reserve officials did little to ease investor uncertainty over whether the central bank would raise interest rates at its November policy-making meeting.

title: Northwest Reports a 14% Gain in Earnings
description: The Northwest Airlines Corporation posted quarterly earnings today that were stronger than expected, aided by growth in domestic travel and cost-cutting efforts.

title: New Test Finds 2 in 3 Know Basics of Science
description: In what education officials hailed as progress toward meeting national goals in science, a test of fourth, eighth and 12th graders from across the country showed that 2 in 3 have a basic understanding of the subject.

title: Closing Arguments Delivered in Dobbs Ferry Killing Over Parking
description: A police officer charged with killing a man in a dispute over a parking space was described in closing arguments today both as a dutiful son trying to protect his father and as a vengeful killer who ignored years of police training and shot a man three times without giving him a warning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOIZUETA, ROBERTO C.
description: GOIZUETA-Roberto C. The leadership and Entertainment, Media & Communications division of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Roberto C. Goizueta, chairman and chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company. His fierce dedication to the company strengthened its global dominance, making it one of the most successful firms in corporate history. Less known are his many educational and philanthropic contributions. His wit, warmth, loyalty and kindness will be missed by his employees, friends, and family. To his wife, Olga, his two children and his eight grandchildren, we send our heartfelt condolences. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Edward Bleier & Marty Pompadur, Co-Chairs, Entertainment, Media & Communications Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Duvall's Battle to Confound a Religious Stereotype
description: Midway through Robert Duvall's acclaimed new film, ''The Apostle,'' the Pentecostal minister whom he portrays takes a secretary out on a dinner date. When their food arrives and the woman lifts her fork, Mr. Duvall stills her hand. Then he thanks God. And as he does, the woman tightens her face and rolls her eyes, emitting a muffled ''Amen.''

description: AUTO RACING

title: Backpacks: The Full Story
description: Are children's backpacks getting heavier, or does it only seem that way? Reliable statistics are hard to find, but a recent sampling at three public schools around the New York area made one thing clear: those packs are packed.

title: Pataki's Right to Remove District Attorney Is Weighed
description: Taking on one of the most politically charged cases of recent years, New York's highest court heard arguments today on whether Gov. George E. Pataki had the right to remove the Bronx District Attorney from the case of a police officer's slaying because he believed the prosecutor would not seek the death penalty.

title: Citizen Soros
description: In a season of grand philanthropic gestures, George Soros has now joined Ted Turner in announcing a munificent international gift. Mr. Soros will increase his Open Society Institute's activities in Russia by $300 million to $500 million over the next three years. That will more than double his current programs in Russia and easily exceed Washington's $95 million annual donation to Russia's civilian sector. The contribution adds to the $1.5 billion Mr. Soros has already given away overseas, the bulk of it to build civil society and independent media in formerly Communist countries.

title: Bull Market's Glitter May Be Blinding Investors
description: It was less than a week ago that stock investors fretted about the possibility of a huge decline as the 10th anniversary of the Oct. 19, 1987, crash approached. But the real concern may be whether investors have become too giddy.

title: From the Faraway Deep: A Glossary
description: THE fish market is full of strangers these days. New immigrants like North African rouget are nudging their way onto the ice, along with under-appreciated locals like herring. It's time to make a few introductions.

title: Hilton Decides Not to Match Starwood's Offer for ITT
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said today that it would not raise its offer for the ITT Corporation in an attempt to match a bid by the Starwood Lodging Trust, which agreed on Monday to acquire ITT in a friendly $9.8 billion deal.

title: Two Convicted as Leaders Of New York Trash Cartel
description: Two men accused of being the Mafia masters of the cartel that plundered New York City's private garbage-removal industry were convicted yesterday on state racketeering charges that could imprison them for 25 years.

title: New Jersey Debate: Clashes on Pocketbook Issues
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and State Senator James E. McGreevey clashed over property taxes and automobile insurance rates tonight during their second televised debate as they each sought to portray themselves as the champions of homeowners and drivers.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Commuter Concierge Service
description: Maplewood rail commuters may seem somewhat less frazzled this spring when a private company begins to offer concierge service to nearly 1,500 New Jersey Transit commuters who pass through Maplewood's station every day.

title: Drug Makers Post Stronger 3d-Quarter Results
description: Four drug makers -- Bristol-Myers Squibb, American Home Products, Schering-Plough and SmithKline Beecham -- yesterday reported stronger third-quarter results.

title: CEDAR FAIR PLANS TO BUY KNOTT'S BERRY FARM THEME PARK
description: Cedar Fair L.P. said yesterday that it would buy Knott's Berry Farm for an undisclosed amount of cash and units, giving the company its first year-round theme park and added protection from the impact of bad weather on earnings. Knott's Berry Farm, the closely held theme park in Buena Vista, Calif., would become the fifth theme park of Cedar Fair, based in Sandusky, Ohio. With the addition, Cedar Fair expects to generate annual revenue approaching $400 million and annual attendance of more than 10 million people. Cedar Fair's stock rose $1.75, to $48.50. Cedar Fair will also acquire the Knott's Camp Snoopy store, which Knott's Berry Farm manages at the Mall of America in Minnesota.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARASCH, BETTY GADAS
description: BARASCH-Betty Gadas, 104, of West Palm Beach, FL and formerly of the Bronx. She was preceded in death by Abe Barasch, her first husband of 50 years, and Abe Gadas, her second husband of 12 years. Beloved mother of Phyllis and Marvin Barasch, Helen and the late Norman Barasch. Loving grandmother of Jane and Lowen Hankin, Claudia and Shelly Hirshon, Renee and Richard Barasch, Candy and Michael Barasch. She adored her great grandchildren Matt and Alex, Ariel, Yaniv and Jessica, Emily and Ben, and Robert Norman. She is survived by her sister Millie Herman and sister-in-law Lillie Klapholz. Funeral Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Ave at 76th St, Wednesday 9:30 AM. The family will gather at the Hirshon home, 290 West End Ave on Wednesday and Thursday to be surrounded by the people whose lives this spirited matriarch touched. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to The Friends of South Bronx Academy (Norman Barasch Scholarship Fund), C/O Richard Barasch.

title: By the Book; A Treasury of Turkish Delights
description: SOME of Turkey's opulent yet rustic cuisine is as familiar as the eggplant dip and hummus in the neighborhood deli case. But a browse through ''Classic Turkish Cooking'' by Ghillie Basan (St. Martin's Press, $29.95) shows how alluring and diverse Turkish cooking can be. The book's well-written recipes convey the complexity of food that is frequently fueled with a good pinch of oiled ground chili (kirmizi biber) and smoothed with the rich tang of whole milk yogurt.

title: A New Kind of Veto Brings a New Way of Doing Business
description: Heaven knows how many dams have been built, research grants awarded and Federal office buildings constructed over the years because lobbyists and Congressional staff managed to stick them into giant spending bills and because the projects were not so expensive that the President felt obliged to veto the entire legislation.

title: Girl Reports School Attack
description: A 13-year-old girl told the police yesterday that she was sodomized at knifepoint in a bathroom of a Bronx junior high school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKERSON, NANCY
description: DICKERSON-Nancy. The members of the board of trustees and staff of Carnegie Corporation of New York express their profound sorrow over the loss of Nancy Dickerson, beloved wife of our former trustee John C. Whitehead. An extraordinarily gifted journalist, with a vibrant intelligence and acute insight, Nancy broke new ground in her coverage of national & world affairs. She was a fervent supporter of numerous important causes all her life and a devoted friend to many. All New Yorkers are grateful for her contributions to the cultural life of the City. We shall miss her deeply and offer our most heartfelt condolences to John, on whom we continue to rely for his astute counsel. Vartan Gregorian, President Thomas Kean, Chairman of the Board

title: Rich Acapulco Cleaned Up From Storm but Poor Still Wait
description: The emergency that began when a hurricane ravaged the city above the beaches of Acapulco was officially declared to be over on Monday, but residents are still wearing surgical masks against a cloud of brown dust rising from caked, drying mud, and many thousands still have urgent basic needs.

title: Essay; Worldthink Inc.
description: Why should professional opinion-mongers be the last to cash in on globalization?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSNER, LILLIAN
description: POSNER-Lillian. The Board of Directors and Shareholders of 911 Park Avenue extend our deepest sympathy to our President and family on the passing of Lillian, beloved wife and mother.

title: Temptations; From a Small Bakery, a Virtual Mountain of a Cookie
description: AS you descend into the tiny basement space at Levain Bakery, you are quickly consumed by wafts of chocolate and yeast, the hum of refrigerators, the intensity of bakers going about their solitary trade. Dressed in aprons and sneakers, with flour-dusted hair, the bakers pause only to take your order and dutifully ignore you when the cookies are ready to come out of the oven. You are a guest in their sublime, unpretentious work space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARENGI, HENRY A.

Friends may call at the McLaughlin Kramer Megiel Funeral Home, Inc., 220 Glen Street, Glen Cove, on Friday, 3 to 5 and 7 tp 9. Funeral Mass Church of St. Patrick's, on Saturday, 10 AM. Board of Governors Richard A. Horowitz, Pres.

title: Sports of The Times; Amateurism: The Myth Is Upheld
description: AFTER Mike Utley broke his neck playing for the Detroit Lions in a National Football League game in November 1991, he received workers' compensation for his injuries, which have rendered him a paraplegic confined to a wheelchair. He gets $533 a month, nurse's care five days a week, and rehabilitation paid for.

description: I can dig it. The 70's are back. It was an ineffably happening time.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DURA PHARMACEUTICALS, San Diego, a marketer of prescription drugs, agreed to acquire Scandipharm Inc. of Alabama, a distributor of cystic fibrosis treatments, for $93 million to $139 million in stock.

title: South Korean Banks To Create Bailout Fund
description: A group of 23 South Korean banks agreed yesterday to create a fund to assist companies that show signs of cash-flow problems. Under the accord reached at a meeting of the Minister of Finance and Economy, Kang Kyong Shik, with the bank presidents, each bank will contribute to a pool of funds to be used to bail out financially troubled companies.

title: F.B.I. Names An Outsider As New Head Of Crime Lab
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced the appointment today of a nuclear-weapons physicist with no forensic experience to head the law-enforcement agency's crime laboratory, which was harshly criticized for substandard performance in a recent Justice Department report.

title: Top Guns Quitting for Life at Cruising Altitude
description: As a boy in Texas, Maj. Ernie Brown knew he was destined for the cockpit.

title: A College Reunion Helps Lift Rangers
description: A victory over Carolina on Monday night was a reunion for three members of the Rangers who were teammates at Boston College a decade ago. They followed the same path after college, playing for the United States national and Olympic teams. And all three contributed to the first victory at home for the Rangers and hope that more good days are ahead.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Chemicals Added to Risk List
description: Two chemicals that were mixed improperly at a Lodi plant in 1995, causing an explosion that killed five people, were singled out yesterday by Federal officials for special handling.

title: 3 Buildings Are Declared Landmarks
description: One has just turned 30. Another is slightly older, and the third is comfortably middle-aged. All are old enough to have the last laugh, winning recognition in circles that once maintained they had ruined the skyline.

title: Modernist Twist to Macho Mythology
description: To describe Matthew Barney's ''Cremaster'' film cycle as a series of bogus allegories with a vaguely prurient subtext is not to say that these elaborate cinematic rituals involving androgynous nymphs, satyrs and other quasi-mythical figures aren't both pretty to look at and symbolically provocative.

title: Finally in Series Spotlight, Sheffield Is Slugging Away
description: The Cleveland Indians are trying to pitch around Gary Sheffield, Florida's explosive hitter, trying to prevent him from being a factor in the World Series. But any time the Indians' pitchers threw the ball near the plate Tuesday night, in Game 3, Sheffield hurt them.

Wife of Joel for 55 years, mother of Loraine Wilson, Peter and David Cohen, sister of Russell, Donald and Lee Quaintance, grandmother of Peter, Jr., Natasha and Sarah Cohen and Thomas and Kathryn Wilson, great-grandmother of Vanya Cohen. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, N.Y., Thurs. 2-4 and 7-9PM. Services and interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to The American Cancer Society.

title: At 48, Foreman Says He Has No Reason to Quit Fighting
description: For those wondering when George Foreman, the 48-year-old heavyweight, is going to give up boxing, join George Foreman.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Saturday about President Clinton's visit to Argentina mistakenly said that Mr. Clinton failed to stress the importance of a free press in his meetings with President Carlos Menem and other Argentine leaders. The record shows that he raised the issue privately and publicly during his visit, including at his meeting with Mr. Menem.

title: About New York; The Politics Of Battling Persecution
description: WHENEVER the Rev. Jim Geist visits the Interchurch Center on Riverside Drive, he remembers some of his heroes who walked those streets decades ago. His thoughts often settle on Dietrich Bonhoeffer, the German theologian who was briefly at the nearby Union Theological Seminary before returning to Nazi Germany, where he was hanged for his role in plotting against Hitler.

title: Special-Teams No-Names Give Giants a Special Glow
description: Before the Giants' unexpected ascension to the top of the National Football Conference East standings, one of the glaring flaws in the organization was the lack of impact players. While the offense and the defense have thrived with a workmanlike effort, the impact has come from an unexpected source.

title: A Debut With Both Youthful Energy and Maturity
description: The three German musicians of the Clemente Trio started working together 11 years ago when they were students in a chamber music course. Since then, they have performed throughout Europe, in Australia and Japan, and even, last season, on a tour of Vietnam. Carnegie Hall introduced the ensemble locally at Weill Recital Hall on Friday night to open its Distinctive Debuts series. And the concert lived up to its billing, for it was a most distinctive debut.

title: Calendar
description: Adam and Eve's Revenge

title: Metro Business Briefs; Praxair to Cut 800 Jobs
description: Praxair Inc. of Danbury, Conn., said yesterday that it would dismiss about 800 workers to cut costs, as a rising dollar and falling prices erode its profit growth.

title: WORLD SERIES RATINGS
description: Game 1 of the World Series produced an 11.3 national Nielsen rating, the lowest ever for the Series, replacing the previous low, a 14.0 for Game 2 last season. The game was played Saturday night, which usually has the lowest viewership. Each rating point represents 980,000 television households.

title: U.S. Bridge Teams Start Near the Top
description: All four United States bridge teams competing in the World Team Championships here have made a good start. With two of six days of preliminary play over, both the open teams are in qualifying positions in the Bermuda Bowl. One is the defending champion team headed by Nick Nickell of Manhattan, while the other team, their great rivals in American championships, has Seymon Deutsch of Laredo, Tex., as captain.

description: BART-Melvin. Beloved husband of Sondra. Devoted father of Robin Allen and Adam Bart. Cherished grandfather & devoted father-in-law and uncle. Services today 11:30 AM, the Parkside Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, opposite Kings Plaza, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PERRY, EDWARD
description: PERRY-Edward. June 27, 1908October 22, 1993. Dear Edward, 4 years have passed but you are always with me. There are no words to say how much I miss you. My love for you will never die. It is forever. Fito

title: Labor Department Focuses on 401(k)'s
description: The Labor Department wants to know what employers are doing to keep down the costs to their workers of 401(k) plans, Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman said today.

title: Metro Business Briefs; Lower Earnings for Arrow
description: Arrow Electronics Inc. of Melville, N.Y., said yesterday that costs associated with a revamping of its North American operations had lowered its third-quarter earnings by more than $40 million.

title: Office Depot Names Wyse Advertising
description: Office Depot, the office-supply retail chain in Delray Beach, Fla., said yesterday that it had selected Wyse Advertising in Cleveland to handle its account, with billings estimated at $30 million. Office Depot had parted ways in July with the Chicago office of the J. Walter Thompson Company unit of WPP Group, after a merger with Staples Inc. was called off.

title: Educational Testing Service Opens a Security Review
description: Educational Testing Service officials said yesterday that the company would hire an international corporate investigations concern to conduct the first outside review of its security procedures for tests.

title: Another Victim, 14, in Serbia's War Against Gypsies
description: On a hill above the curves of the Danube, 3,000 mourners, many dressed in shabby overcoats and clutching limp bouquets of flowers, listened this afternoon to a mother's plaintive wails of grief as she bade farewell to her young son.

title: Mawgan Journal; Forgive Us Our Trespasses? Not Here in England!
description: Sir Ferrers Vyvyan's family has lived in this wild and lovely corner of Cornwall for more than 900 years -- its estate, Trelowarren, was mentioned in the Domesday Book -- so he thinks he should know by now what is his property and what isn't.

title: N.F.L.: ROUNDUP
description: Indianapolis

title: Fidelity to Pay $10 Million To Settle Suit On Statements
description: Fidelity Investments said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $10 million to settle a class-action lawsuit filed in late 1995 against the company and Jeffrey N. Vinik, former manager of the Magellan Fund, over statements by Mr. Vinik in the fund's September 1995 report to shareholders.

title: Mastercard hopes to become the credit card of choice for ordinary, middle-class consumers.
description: MASTERCARD is trying to carve out a niche in the crowded field of credit and charge card marketers, with an emotional campaign, starting tonight, that emphasizes its image as the card for ordinary, middle-class consumers.

title: TV Notes; A Hot Topic And Hot Water
description: It isn't even November -- one of those sweeps months when Nielsen ratings matter most to the networks -- but this week the Big Three networks' news divisions are showing great fascination with sex. And, in an intra-journalistic sideshow, NBC News's president got himself into a bit of hot water on the subject.

title: Settlements Cut Deeply Into Tobacco Profits
description: Legal settlements with Mississippi and Florida took a heavy toll on the third-quarter earnings of the nation's two largest cigarette makers, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Moorer Ready for Holyfield
description: Michael Moorer has no idea what his strategy will be in his Nov. 8 rematch against Evander Holyfield, does not know if Holyfield's style has changed since they fought in 1994, and insists his style is the same with a new trainer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDLEY, AUDRA
description: LINDLEY-Audra. Died from complications of leukemia October 16, Cedar Sinai Hospital, Los Angeles, CA. Survived by 2 daughters, Dr. Elizabeth Blalock of California and Alice Ulm of New York, one son, William Ulm of California, and 7 grand children. Two children preceded her in death. The family asks that donations be made to The American Red Cross.

title: METS
description: The Brewers, searching for a center fielder, are interested in the Mets' Carl Everett, the subject of one of many discussions Mets General Manager Steve Phillips has been having during the winter meetings. Everett hit 14 homers and drove in 57 runs last season, compiling a .248 batting average. The Mets are searching for a left-handed reliever, and the Brewers could dangle the hard-throwing Ron Villone, who had a 3.42 earned run average in 50 games last season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRANE, LOUISE
description: CRANE-Louise. On October 20, 1997, at the Lenox Hill Hospital. Beloved aunt of Winnie Mackey and Davis Greene. Service and burial will be private.

title: Eating Well; Endorsements Raise Money and Questions
description: SINCE the American Heart Association changed its charter in 1988 to permit product endorsements, an arrangement it had prohibited from its founding in 1924, it has raised millions of dollars from such sources as the National Cattlemen's Beef Association, the Kellogg Company and Conagra.

title: Two Booksellers Settle Lawsuits
description: Barnes & Noble and Amazon.com have settled lawsuits against each other concerning sales of books on the Internet, the companies said yesterday.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS IT SUPPORTS A BILL TO OVERHAUL I.R.S.
description: The Clinton Administration reversed itself today and said it would support legislation to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service by creating an outside board with broad authority over the tax-collection agency and strengthening the rights of taxpayers who think they are being treated unfairly.

title: Renoir Portraits Show an Artist In Two Lights
description: ''Great painters paint in order to learn to paint.'' The words of the French pedagogue and painter Andre Lohte apply with particular accuracy to the career of Pierre-Auguste Renoir. The great Impressionist spent his life moving restlessly from style to style, working under the spell of various contemporaries or masters from the past, loosening, then tightening his famously fluttery brushwork.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARAN, WIENER, CHARLOTTE, D.H.S.
