description: BARAN - WIENER - Charlotte, D.H.S. On October 21, 1997. Beloved wife of Dr. Harry Wiener. Devoted sister of Jane Staminski, Irene Watrobski and Edward Watrobski. Reposing Krtil Funeral Home, Inc., 1297 1st Avenue, NYC on Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10:30AM at St. John the Evangelist RC Church, 55th Street and 1st Avenue, NYC. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park, Long Island.

title: Communist Leader Drops Move to Oust Yeltsin Government
description: After years of ideological intransigence and increasing political irrelevance, all it really took today was a huff and a puff to bring the party of Lenin and Stalin to its knees.

title: New Offshore Gambling Limit Halved Income, Cruise Line Says
description: Citing a ''dire'' drop in income, lawyers for a Brooklyn company that operates gambling trips at sea asked a judge yesterday to overturn a Federal prosecutor's ruling that a casino boat must travel at least 12 miles from shore, not just 3 miles, before passengers can gamble.

title: Japanese Economic Package Comes Up Short of Specifics
description: The ruling Liberal Democratic Party disclosed a widely anticipated package of proposals to jump-start Japan's moribund economy today, but economists and investors declared them short on substance and long on political expediency.

title: A Mini-War of Gay Newspapers; A New Weekly Draws Fire Even Before Its First Issue
description: The first copy of The New York Blade News, a gay weekly, has yet to hit the streets, and already the criticism is stinging.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEFFIELD, REUBEN
description: SHEFFIELD-Reuben. Peacefully, at home, on October 19, aged 91. Beloved and loving husband, father, father-in-law, grandfather, brother, brother-in-law and uncle. Cremation in London, October 22.

title: EXPERTS DENOUNCE CHILDREN'S AGENCY
description: Offering a bleak portrayal of New York City's efforts to protect its most vulnerable children, a court-appointed panel of child welfare experts has found that more than 40 percent of the abused and neglected children left in their homes under the supposedly watchful eyes of city caseworkers were mistreated again.

title: Nagy Does Better Than the Bullpen
description: Charles Nagy was so sluggish for the Cleveland Indians on Tuesday night that Manager Mike Hargrove dialed the bullpen telephone for the first time in the fourth inning. Like virtually everyone else at Jacobs Field, Hargrove realized that his pitcher was in serious trouble and that he would probably be calling the bullpen all night. He might as well have applied for frequent-caller rates.

title: Monsanto Earnings Fall 3.7% in Quarter
description: The Monsanto Company said today that earnings from continuing operations fell 3.7 percent in the third quarter as increased spending for research and development undercut rising sales of its Roundup herbicide and of pharmaceutical products.

title: Anti-Defamation League Warns of Web Hate Sites
description: From a Web site on the Internet called Nazism Now, it is only a mouse click to reach I Hate Jews -- The Anti-Semetic Homepage, Knights of the Ku Klux Klan and the White Nationalist Resource Page.

title: Needed: Planet Insurance
description: An American team in Bonn is deep in negotiations that, it is hoped, will lead to the signing of an international treaty on global warming in Kyoto, Japan, in December. Such a treaty would define the responsibilities of roughly 170 nations for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. President Clinton, who is scheduled to outline his policy on global warming today, must walk a fine line, balancing the concerns of environmentalists who worry about the fate of the earth and those of business and labor constituencies who worry about the fate of their companies and jobs.

title: Childs Returns To Practice
description: While a football practice may be harder hitting than the workouts that Jeff Van Gundy guides the Knicks through, his sessions on the hardwood do not bring with them the hands-off policy that football quarterbacks enjoy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, LEONARD
description: PRICE-Leonard. On October 20, 1997. Son of Jeanette and Isaac, husband of the late Lorraine, father of Robert and daughter-in-law Frances, grandfather of Arnold and step granddaughters Frances and Eileen and step great granddaughters Teri and Andrea and Many friends. Lieutenant colonel in the U.S. Army, past president New York State Society of CPAs, senior partner at Grant Thornton. Burial private. In lieu of flowers, donate to your favorite charity.

title: Nikko Raided Again By Japanese Prosecutors
description: For the second time in a month, Tokyo prosecutors raided the headquarters of the Nikko Securities Company today over a widening payoff scandal.

title: Hong Kong Stocks Plunge but Then Recover
description: Hong Kong stocks plummeted again this morning as concern grew that higher interest rates and an oversupply of land and housing would hurt developers' earnings, but they rallied in the afternoon. The index fell as much as 658.9 points, or 5.3 percent, to 11,744.12 -- the lowest since Sept. 26, 1996. But by the afternoon, the index was down 149.92 points, or 1.2 percent, at 12,253.18.

title: Accounts
description: * W. J. Deutsch & Sons Ltd., Armonk, N.Y., to North Castle Partners, Stamford, Conn., as the first agency to handle advertising for its George Duboeuf Wines brand. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: A map and a list of sites on Friday with an article about places to visit in Toronto included a zoo different from the zoo referred to in the accompanying article. The Metropolitan Toronto Zoo, not named in the article, but identified as having a Komodo dragon from Indonesia, is on Meadowvale Road; the Riverdale Farm zoo, shown on the map and included in the list, was not mentioned in the article.

title: Review by Levi Strauss To Include Foote, Cone
description: The San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding announced yesterday that it would take part in an unexpected review of its oldest account, the domestic Levi's brand of the Levi Strauss & Company, with billings estimated at $87 million. The decision came a day after Levi Strauss stunned the agency by placing in review the account, which Foote, Cone and a predecessor have handled since 1930.

title: An 'Asian Miracle' Now Seems Like a Mirage
description: A businessman pays for a home-remodeling job with his Mercedes. A chauffeur says imported milk powder for his two children now costs more. A real estate agent spends his afternoons sipping iced tea in an upscale mall: nobody is buying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEUER, ELIOT
description: STEUER-Eliot. After several years of ill health. Survived by his beloved wife Eleanor, nephew Dr. Richard Gilbert and wife Shirley and three great-nieces Ellen, Lori and Randi. A former Senior VP of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Eliot will be remembered most for his warmth, wit and integrity.

title: Wine Talk; In Bordeaux Rating, Economist Considers Price First
description: FOR the first time in almost a decade, Orley Ashenfelter, a Princeton University economist and an implacable foe of wine orthodoxy, has produced a new ranking of the chateaus of Bordeaux. No matter how big your pocketbook -- whether you buy in quantity at wine auctions or by the bottle at your local store -- his method could help you ferret out bargains.

title: Power Politics and the Kurds: A Tale of Betrayal
description: AFTER SUCH KNOWLEDGE, WHAT FORGIVENESS?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, RALPH
description: PETERSON-Ralph. Passed away Monday, October 20, 1997 after a brief illness. Ralph was a dear husband to his wife, Patricia; a loving father to his 3 children, Jeffrey, Stacey and Beth; an adoring grandfather to Jami, Scott, David and Brian. His professional life as Chief Finance Officer of Warner Brothers spanned three decades. A memorial service will be held Thursday, 4 P.M., October 30, at Temple Emeth, 1666 Windsor Road, Teaneck, New Jersey. Services under the direction of Gutterman - Musicant, Hackensack, New Jersey (1-800-522-0588).

title: A Cupful of Ginger to Help Soothe Winter's Ills
description: THE flu season's first call about the hot ginger lemonade came last week.

title: Apologies on Holocaust
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LUSTGARTEN, IRA H.
description: LUSTGARTEN-Ira H. A memorial service will be held Sat., Oct. 25, 1997 at 12:30 PM at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University Campus, Amsterdam Avenue and 116th Street. No flowers by request.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: 2 FOUND GUILTY -- Two men were convicted of being the Mafia masters of a garbage-removal cartel in New York City. B3.

title: Priming for '98, Congress Pares '97 Agenda
description: Driving toward the session's end, Congressional leaders are honing their final agenda, postponing controversial issues like a promised effort to exempt workfare recipients from Federal protections and putting off other measures for maximum political advantage in the election year.

title: Generosity's Next Wave
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKMANN, ALLAN G.
description: BECKMANN-Allan G., 81, of Boca Raton, FL and formerly of Park Slope, Brooklyn, NY, passed away on Saturday, October 18, 1997. Mr. Beckmann was a customs house broker with Daniel F. Young, Inc., for many years. He was preceded in death by his wife, C. Florence Beckmann, and second wife, Mary Beckmann. He is survived by his son, Allan G. Beckmann, Jr.; daughter-in-law Kathleen; and beloved grandchildren, Allan III, Carolyn and Melinda. Friends will be received on Tuesday and Wednesday from 2-4 pm and 6-8 pm at Babione Funeral Home. Funeral services will be held on Thursday at 10:00 am at Babione Funeral Home. Memorial remembrances in his name may be made to The American Cancer Society of Boca Raton.

title: School Officials Skeptical Of Sexual Assault Charges
description: A day after the police arrested four third-graders in the Bronx and charged them with sexually attacking two young girls during recess, district school officials are defending their actions in the case and questioning whether the attacks even took place.

title: Market Place; Cheap crude oil and heavy summer driving ignite quarter's profits.
description: THIS summer, the living was easy for the oil industry.

title: Officer Charged in Sting Using Child Pornography
description: A New York City police officer was arrested Monday night for stealing a videotape of child pornography during an Internal Affairs Bureau sting operation, the police said yesterday.

title: Schwab Unit Agrees to Pay $200,000 Fine
description: Mayer & Schweitzer Inc., one of the largest wholesale dealers on the Nasdaq stock market, agreed today to pay a $200,000 fine to settle charges that it failed to arrange the best possible trades for several customers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOSWEIN, DAVID J.
description: YOSWEIN-David J. Devoted husband of Martha. Beloved father of Jery, Rick and Joni. Cherished grandfather and brother. Funeral service Wednesday, 1 PM at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THORNER, PHYLLIS
description: THORNER-Phyllis. Founder and Director of ''New Beginnings'' for widows and widowers. Wife of the late Hayman. Beloved mother of Joel, Scott and the late Martin, and Martin's wife Pat. Adoring grandmother of Michael and James. Dear sister of William Klein and his wife Marilyn. Service Wednesday, October 22, 1 PM, at Temple Beth Sholom, Northern Blvd. at 172nd Street, Flushing, NY.

title: Business Travel; The American Airlines pact with Asiana is part of a strategy to increase a Pacific Rim presence.
description: AMERICAN AIRLINES' new code-sharing and frequent-flier partnership with Asiana Airlines -- which is based in Seoul, South Korea -- is part of a long-range strategy by the Dallas-based carrier to heighten its presence in the Pacific Rim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, MITCHELL
description: GORDON-Mitchell. To a loving cousin, we will miss you. Richard, Caren, Adam, Matthew, Sami; Jerry, Nancy, Ben Liebman.

title: In Her Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: Film, the Snubbed Art
description: The Pulitzer Prize is the most important award given to the arts in America. But movies, the most important art form in America, aren't eligible. It is time to change that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITEMAN, HERBERT WELLS, JR.
description: WHITEMAN-Herbert Wells, Jr., of Brooklyn, died Sat., Oct. 18 at age 61. He spent twenty years as a VP at the Federal Reserve Bank of NY, and made significant contributions to the Bank's Information and Bank Security Operations. Herb earned a civil engineering BS from Columbia U. and an MS from NYU. He was a very active member of the professional and civic community, including serving as past President of the National Association of Urban Bankers. A warm, energetic and well-respected man, he will be greatly missed by all who knew him. He is survived by his beloved wife of 36 years, Nola Lancaster Whiteman, devoted daughter, Cheryl Whiteman Brooks and husband Baron and their two children; and a host of other relatives and friends. Services Wed., Oct., 22, 7PM, St. James Cathedral, Jay St., Brooklyn. Contributions in his memory to Colony South Brooklyn Houses.

title: Six-Year Prison Term In Daughter's Burning
description: A woman whose 7-year-old daughter was severely burned when she forced the girl to sit on a radiator as punishment for fighting with her brother and sister was sentenced yesterday to six years in prison.

title: Through the Tunnel Of Dating Cliches With an Unlikely Pair
description: Consider Marcia, the platinum blond bombshell of the Adobe Theater Company's stiletto-sharp new spoof ''Duet! A Romantic Fable.'' Like Tammy Wynette and Lady Thiang before her, she has found a man and she is standing by him, even if he isn't God's gift. Strike that. Even if he's profoundly off-putting.

title: Candidates Clash on Issue Of Job Loss and Creation
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani defended his job creation record yesterday as Ruth W. Messinger, joined by the former United States Labor Secretary, Robert B. Reich, said the Mayor's administration had awarded tax breaks to corporations that have failed to keep jobs in the city.

title: Clinton Alters His Approach Over Warming
description: Stung by complaints that it is moving too slowly against global warming, the Clinton Administration has devised a set of rewards for companies that cut emissions of heat-trapping gases faster than the Government would require under a pending international treaty.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, ALEXANDER
description: SIEGEL-Alexander. Beloved husband of Shirley. Devoted father of Ronald and Laurie Havassy. Dear brother of Erma Raflowitz. Adoring grandfather of Selene, Randy, Joshua and Amy. Service Wednesday, 12 Noon, at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRONHEIM, DAVID
description: BRONHEIM-David. A life of passionate commitment to democracy and democratic reform will be honored and remembered by all who knew him. His loved and loving children, his sister, his family and friends mourn his tragic and untimely death. Memorial service, Friday, Oct. 24, 11AM, ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Celebrating Writers Who Defy All the Odds
description: From the realms she calls ''the outposts of the Empire,'' Ama Ata Aidoo, the Ghanaian poet and novelist, has reached a far larger world.

title: CADENCE DESIGN SHARES FALL ON RESIGNATION OF CHIEF
description: Shares of Cadence Design Systems Inc. fell yesterday in the wake of the unexpected resignation of its chief executive, Joseph B. Costello, to run a company founded by the financier Michael R. Milken. Cadence, which supplies software used to design semiconductor chips, said late on Monday that Mr. Costello had quit and was succeeded by Jack Harding, who joined the company earlier this year. Its shares fell $3.75, to $52.125. Mr. Costello, 43, had worked at Cadence for more than 13 years. He accepted a position at Knowledge Universe, a closely held educational-technology company founded by Mr. Milken and Lawrence J. Ellison, chairman of the Oracle Corporation.

title: Critic's Notebook; Intense, Artistic, All the Rage? Must Be Disgusting
description: It is almost impossible to write about disgust without being disgusting. Words like squishy, sticky, squirmy and slimy can hardly be used without hints of a grimace. Others, like pus and phlegm, bring on anticipations of full-scale offense.

title: Gates Is Defensive on U.S. Antitrust Action
description: A mostly dispassionate but occasionally testy William H. Gates faced a sometimes skeptical computer industry audience here today and declared that no magic antitrust line divided the Microsoft Corporation's market-dominating Windows 95 software operating system from competitors' programs.

title: Dolph Camilli, Who Led Dodgers to '41 Pennant, Dies at 90
description: Dolph Camilli, a slugging first baseman who propelled the Brooklyn Dodgers to a long-awaited pennant in 1941 and became one of the most popular players in Flatbush, died yesterday in San Mateo, Calif. He was 90. Noted for his muscular physique and soft hands, Camilli hit 34 home runs, drove in 120 runs (both National League highs) and fielded superbly to win the league's most valuable player award in '41 as the Dodgers won a pennant for the first time in 21 seasons.

title: Restaurants; Where the Show Goes On and On and . . .
description: FOR his first trick, your waiter will ignore your wine request and urge you to have the 1993 Chianti Classico Riserva from Antinori. ''It is,'' he will assure you, ''the best wine on our list.'' Presenting the bottle with a flourish, he will decant it into an enormous stenciled glass pitcher. Later, if you are lucky, he may even confide that he has already sold 30 bottles tonight (at $50 each).

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of two Jewish holidays, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow, for Shemini Atzereth, which concludes Succoth, the Feast of Tabernacles, and Friday, for Simhath Torah, which ends the annual cycle of the public reading of the Torah. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUTZER, SEYMOUR, MD.
description: SCHUTZER-Seymour, MD. The medical staff of North Shore University Hospital expresses its deep sorrow on the death of its distinguished colleague. A dedicated and compassionate individual, Dr. Schutzer served his patients and his community at the highest level as a personal physician and through his expertise in diabetes. His integrity and desire for excellence always earned for him the utmost respect from his patients and peers. Throughout his 42-year tenure at this institution, he contributed immensely to our clinical and academic programs. We extend our sincere condolences to his family and friends. Lawrence Scherr, MD, MACP Chairman, Dept. of Medicine Peter R. Walker, MD, Chairman, Medical Board Paul E. Karafiol, MD President, Medical Staff North Shore University Hospital

title: PRUDENTIAL REAL ESTATE TO BUY $100 MILLION OF BRE STOCK
description: Prudential Real Estate Investors agreed yesterday to buy $100 million in BRE Properties Inc. stock at $26.93 a share. The private deal is partly in exchange for BRE's $600 million acquisition of certain assets and operations owned by the closely held Trammell Crow Residential, a joint-venture partner of Prudential Real Estate. Prudential Real Estate is the real estate investment unit of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the Newark-based insurer. BRE, a San Francisco-based real estate investment trust, had 1996 revenues of $101.6 million. Shares of BRE slipped 6.25 cents yesterday, to $28 a share.

title: World News Briefs; Japan Says It Will Sign Treaty on Land Mines
description: Breaking ranks with the United States, Japan says it will sign a worldwide ban on antipersonnel land mines that was endorsed by almost 100 other countries in Oslo last month.

title: Brazil Utilities Sold in Bidding
description: The AES Corporation and a group led by Public Service Enterprise Group Inc. were the winners in bidding for two Brazilian energy companies in the latest round of utility sales.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Buildings Are Reshaped After Big Tenants Leave
description: There was a tenancy slip between cup and lip a few years ago at 1251 Avenue of the Americas, the 54-story Rockefeller Center skyscraper between 49th and 50th Streets. Executives of Morgan Stanley had been so sure that they would sign a five-year renewal of their lease, which was expiring in 1998, that they were photographed with Mayor David N. Dinkins to celebrate the decision.

title: Sips; Home-Brewers Who Are Winners Must Face Up to Fame
description: WITH a bit of success comes a bit of celebrity. Six home-brewers now find that their personal recipes are on store shelves, next to the Amstel.

title: Alone at the Top? Not Shakespeare; Social Barometer
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAELIAN, MARY A.
description: MICHAELIAN-Mary A. Died on October 16, 1997 at the age of 97. Beloved aunt of George L. King and great aunt of George L. King III, Pamela Parmenter, the late Victoria King, Jason Sumner, William T. Sumner, Katherine Sumner Bacon, and their children. Her parents John and Tevrez Michaelian emigrated from Armenia in 1896. Donations can be made to The Armenian Evangelical Church of New York, 152 East 34th Street, New York, New York 10016.

title: The Chef
description: SOMETIMES food ideas just knock around in my head like ingredients stirred into a soup pot. Let the ideas simmer long enough and eventually a recipe comes bubbling up to the surface.

title: Imaginary Truths in Song
description: In today's pop landscape of manufactured stars and sounds, folk music has long stood as the realm of the real: the indigenous rather than the commercial, the heartfelt rather than the calculated. Yet as the celebrated English songstress June Tabor reminded her audience at the Bottom Line on Sunday night, folk music has another function. It furthers a culture's imaginary life, preserving its legends and invigorating its fantasies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITEHEAD, NANCY DICKERSON
description: WHITEHEAD-Nancy Dickerson. October 18,1997. Beloved wife of John C. Whitehead, devoted mother of Elizabeth Earls, Ann Pillion, Jane Dickerson, Michael Dickerson, John Dickerson, Anne Whitehead, Gregory Whitehead, Robert Chartener and Sarah Whitehead. Loving sister of Mary Ellen Phillip. Cherished grandmother of eleven. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday, October 22 at 10am at St. Patrick's Cathedral, NYC. A reception will follow. A service will be held Friday October 24 11AM at the Memorial Chapel Ft. Myer, VA. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Covenant House, 346 West 17th St, NY, NY 10011 Attn: Sister Mary Rose McGeady.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: OLYMPICS: ROUNDUP
description: Nagano Games

title: Vacco Seeks Curbs on Information for Inmates
description: Responding to complaints that inmates are using the state's Freedom of Information Law to harass their victims or members of the public, Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco has proposed a requirement that a judge grant permission before any public information is released to prisoners.

title: EASTMAN CHEMICAL MAY SPIN OFF OR SELL PET PLASTIC UNIT
description: The Eastman Chemical Company said yesterday that it was looking at ways to improve returns on its PET plastic packaging business, including selling it or spinning it off, as overcapacity had put pressure on prices. The company, a chemical and plastics maker in Kingsport, Tenn., told analysts it was considering various options for the unit that makes polyethylene terephthalate, or PET, the plastic used to make soda bottles and other packaging. Eastman's shares fell 31.25 cents yesterday, to $63.6875. The PET business generated revenue of $1 billion, or almost 20 percent of Eastman's 1996 sales of $4.78 billion, said Martha Lawson, a company spokeswoman.

title: Salomon Reports an Increase in 3d-Quarter Profit
description: Salomon Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose in the third quarter as gains from bond trading and investment banking offset losses from an arbitrage position related to British Telecommunications P.L.C.'s takeover bid for the MCI Communications Corporation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINARD, ESTHER L. (NEE LANDES)
description: WINARD-Esther L. (nee Landes). On October 21, 1997. Beloved wife of Arthur I. Winard. Loving mother of Sue H. Winard, M.D. and Rosalie F. Winard. Devoted grandmother of Shari Lillian Winard and adoring great-grandmother of Emily Janet Badillo Winard. Loving sister of Augusta L. Packer and Mae Fisher. Funeral services Friday at 10 AM, at the Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, New York. Interment at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings on Hudson, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to Emergency Room, Sound Shore Medical Center, 16 Guion Place, New Rochelle, NY 10801. For further information contact John J. Fox Funeral Home (914-834-0144).

title: Metro Business Briefs; Fall in Jobless Rate For New York City
description: The unemployment rate in New York City fell last month to 9.3 percent from 9.5 percent in August, the State Department of Labor said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of Klea Scott, who is in the CBS series ''Brooklyn South,'' on the cover of the Television section on Sunday carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Abbot Genser of CBS.

title: BAUSCH & LOMB IN $300 MILLION DEAL FOR CHIRON VISION
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Chiron Vision Care for $300 million in cash to expand in the $25 billion global eye-care market. The eye-products unit of the Chiron Corporation makes products for improving cataract and refractive surgery and for treating progressive eye diseases. The unit had sales of $211 million in 1996, Bausch & Lomb said. This deal comes in the midst of a major restructuring at Bausch & Lomb, which is based in Rochester, as it seeks to trim $100 million in costs in 1999 and return its lagging sunglasses unit to profitability. Chiron is a biotechnology company based in Emeryville, Calif., which develops products to treat neurological disorders. Shares of Bausch & Lomb rose 12.5 cents, to $42.125. Chiron stock rose 25 cents, to $22.0625.

title: Whitman Aide Said to Expect Endorsement
description: Two leaders of a statewide Hispanic group said today that a senior Whitman administration official asked them to endorse Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's re-election campaign because $500,000 had been added to the state budget for Hispanic community organizations.

title: Corrections
description: A caption about rice in Dining In, Dining Out last Wednesday misidentifed a selection of dishes from Rice, a cafe in Manhattan. A corrected caption appears on page F2, along with the photograph.

title: Making Books; Can't Anybody Play This Game?
description: It comes down to talent, or the lack of same. So the real question among book publishers is not whether there are Grishams and Updikes to be discovered, but whether publishers can find the people who are going to find the new Grishams and Updikes. And sign them up and publish them well.

title: Romanian Luxury Goods? Yes. Its Caviar Arrives in New York.
description: MOST caviar experts know nothing about Romanian caviar. They know about Russian caviar from the Caspian Sea, and some may even know about caviar from Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and China. But Romania?

title: CHRONICLE
description: When JAMIE GORELICK, the former United States Deputy Attorney General, graduated from Harvard Law School in 1975, 18 percent of the school's student body were women. This year, the figure is 42 percent.

title: Fordham Offers a Discount for Commuters
description: Seeking to attract more students from the metropolitan region and to ''renew its commitment to New York,'' Fordham University announced yesterday that it would offer a $4,000 tuition discount to all new freshmen who continue to live at home with their families and commute to the college beginning next September.

title: Walk of Fame At Garden Adds 2
description: Dave DeBusschere was a model power forward when the Knicks won the National Basketball Association championship in 1970 and 1973, a career that led to his induction into the Basketball Hall of Fame. Phil Esposito, who played for the Chicago Blackhawks, the Boston Bruins and the Rangers, is the National Hockey League's fourth-highest career scorer (1,590 points) and goal scorer (717), and a member of the Hockey Hall of Fame. Later, they became general managers of their teams -- DeBusschere for the Knicks and Esposito for the Rangers.

title: Goldman, Sachs to Give 126 New Titles
description: Goldman, Sachs Group has rewarded 126 employees who do not have ownership stakes in the firm by naming them nonpartner managing directors, according to an internal memo.

title: For 2 Republican Senators, Signs of an Early Frost Over Finance Hearings
description: When the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, campaigned for Fred Thompson in his home state last year, Mr. Lott paid the Tennessee Republican a glowing compliment: ''I call him the E. F. Hutton of politics. When Fred talks, people listen.''

title: Senate Patent Bill Helps Small Inventors
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
description: Stocks were trading higher here today. At the end of the morning session, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 leading issues was up 173.43 points, or 1.01 percent, at 17,383.52. On Tuesday, the Nikkei fell 84.42 points, or one-half of 1 percent, to a level just six points short of a two-year low.

title: A Banking Powerhouse of Cards; MBNA Continues to Build on Its Foundation of Plastic
description: Charles M. Cawley has long seen gold where others see lead, mining the overlooked business opportunity to the hilt and making it pay off handsomely. Take, appropriately enough, the gold credit card, which despite its hue left many bankers cold.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL: Starting Over In New Jersey; New Coaches at Seton Hall and Rutgers Rebuild
description: Tommy Amaker's newly renovated office in Walsh Gym at Seton Hall University is as bare as a bachelor's apartment. It is furnished with a desk, two chairs and a couch. There are a few pictures of past Seton Hall players on the wall, and a photo showing a panoramic view of the Kingdome in Seattle during the Pirates' loss to Michigan in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game in 1989.

title: An Irish Classic, Alive and Well
description: ON a cold winter night in 1948 at Shannon Airport in Ireland, a plane was delayed, passengers shivered, a bartender had an idea -- and Irish coffee was born.

title: CLAIRE'S STORES PLANS TO ACQUIRE SPECIALTY RETAILER LUX
description: Claire's Stores Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Lux Corporation and its 51 specialty retail stores for about $46 million to expand in the Western United States. The closely held Lux operates its stores under the name Mr. Rags, mostly in 11 Western states, specializing in teen-age unisex clothing and accessories. Lux, which is based in Renton, Wash., had sales of more than $27 million in the first nine months ended on Aug. 31. Claire's Stores, with almost 1,700 stores throughout the United States, Canada, the Caribbean, Japan and Britain, has agreements to open 13 more Mr. Rags stores in California, Washington, Colorado and Illinois next year, and expects to increase that number significantly.

title: Trade Deficit Rose as China Swelled Gap During August
description: The nation's trade deficit widened in August to $10.4 billion, driven substantially by a record imbalance with China, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDAE, SHIRLEY
description: GOLDAE-Shirley on October 21st. Beloved mother of Jacqueline and son-in-law Ronald Goldberg. Cherished grandmother of Robert and Sanford Goldberg. Loving greatgrandmother of David and Alissa. Shiva will be observed in Florida.

title: Let It Snow: Indians Fans Earned the Chance to Shiver
description: THE rain came whipping out of the west, very cold and very wet, slashing at a low angle designed to get under ball caps and blow away umbrellas. Thunder and lightning bombarded the ball park. In other words, it was late October in Cleveland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGILL, WILLIAM J.
description: MCGILL-William J. On behalf of the entire University community, the President and Trustees of Columbia University express deep sorrow at the passing of President Emeritus William J. McGill. Dr. McGill assumed the responsibilities of President and Trustee at a time of student unrest and severe fiscal crisis. During the next decade, he won the confidence of students and faculty, brought calm to the campus and financial stability to the University, and engendered in the academic community a forward-looking and optimistic attitude for the future of the University. The dedication, stamina and administrative genius that characterized Dr. McGill's tenure earned the respect and admiration of the academic world. Columbia University extends profound sympathy to his beloved wife Ann and family. George Rupp, President Stephen Friedman, Chair of the Trustees

title: Former New Yorker Executive Sues Magazine
description: A former senior vice president and publisher of The New Yorker has accused the magazine of sex discrimination, alleging that she was dismissed several months after she told her boss that she was expecting her second child.

title: In Her Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'AURIA, GLORIA G.
description: D'AURIA-Gloria G. (of Flushing New York and Shelter Island), on October 21, 1997. Beloved wife of Paul A. Loving mother of Paul, Charles and Cynthia. Dear sister of Anna Vivenzio, Jenny Criazzo, Eedee McMurry and the late Ralph and Michael Sabatino. Cherished Grammie of seven. Visiting Friday 3-5 and 7-9PM, John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue, NYC. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10AM, St Ignatius Loyola Church. Donations may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Avenue, Bronx, New York.

title: Such Deceit on 'Washington Square'
description: AGNIESZKA HOLLAND'S ''Washington Square,'' which opened on Oct. 5, is to flowers what Martin Scorsese's ''Age of Innocence'' is to food -- a movie full of signifiers.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLAN, PATRICK D.
description: BOLAN-Patrick D., on October 20, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Yolanda. Loving father of Daniel, John and Thomas. Dear brothter of Thomas and the late Alfred. Reposing Neufeld Funeral Home, 8804 43rd Avenue, Elmhurst. Funeral mass at St. Mary's Church, 70-31 48 Avenue, Woodside, New York, on Friday at 9:30 A.M. Interment St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Pataki Signs 2 Bills for Penalties On Switching Telephone Service
description: Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation today that imposes new penalties on telephone companies that switch the long-distance service of telephone users without their permission.

title: Nets Limp To Start Of Season
description: Over the off season, the Nets revamped their offense to feature an up-tempo game. Today, Coach John Calipari's squad is limping its way into the regular season.

title: Pepsico's Profits Climbed By 42.7% in Third Quarter
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that third-quarter profit from continuing operations rose 42.7 percent as sales of salty snacks and soft drinks soared in its first quarter since spinning off its restaurant business.

title: Hankook to Build Plant
description: Hankook Synthetics Inc., a South Korean polyester maker, will spend $1.2 billion to build its first United States plant in Augusta, Ga. The project would create more than 1,800 jobs in the next decade, a Hankook Synthetics vice president, Nochul Park, said. There will be 500 immediate job openings at the polyester fiber plant. Building costs will initially total $350 million.

title: New Jolt to Belgium: Police Role in '87 Deaths
description: BRUSSELS  A parliamentary report made public Wednesday on a series of mysterious killings in Belgium 10 years ago focused new criticism on the nation's police, already under heavy fire on charges of mishandling a widespread pedophile case.

title: Voter Registrations Examined
description: Jimmy Tarlau, the union's treasurer, said that Chuck Haytaian, the chairman of the Republican State Committee, asked for the investigation to discredit the efforts of the union, which has endorsed the Democratic candidate for governor, State Senator James E. McGreevey.

title: Conrail Proposal Raises Concerns
description: A proposed division of Conrail by two other railroads poses ''significant competitive problems'' for some electric utilities, the Justice Department said in newly filed documents.

title: Whitman Seen Gaining Favor Of Black Clergy
description: To get the critical support of New Jersey's black clergy, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in recent weeks has broken bread with ministers at the Governor's mansion, offered them tickets to the opening of Newark's new performing arts center and even sent them a $10,000 check to finance a grade-school tutoring program.

title: The President Bets on Technology
description: The most important thing to understand about President Clinton's speech on global warming yesterday is that he has asked the United States, a hungry producer and consumer of energy, to reverse course. He has publicly committed the country to a plan to reduce emissions of carbon dioxide, the gas mainly responsible for what could be a calamitous increase in atmospheric temperatures. He has agreed to binding targets and a timetable -- the stabilization of greenhouse gas emissions at 1990 levels between 2008 and 2012. He has proposed a system for doing so, relying largely on market mechanisms, energy efficiency and technology.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, SARAH
description: GLUCK-Sarah. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Dr. Joel and Stephanie. Dear sister of Joseph Biegen. Adored grandmother of Eric and Robin. Graveside services Friday, 1 PM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing. For information, call RiversideNassau North: 516-487-9600.

title: Eldredge Plans to Fill His Olympic Void
description: It has been a figure skating career that has vaulted as high as a triple axel and sunk as low as a sit spin. Todd Eldredge has been a world champion, but never an Olympic champion, or even an Olympic medalist. His previous two Olympic seasons have begun with great anticipation and ended with bitter disappointment. Now he has a third chance to close his Olympic book with a final, uplifting chapter.

title: Residential Resales
description: Manhattan

title: New-Media Industry Becoming Juggernaut
description: With breathtaking speed, Manhattan's new-media industry has become one of the biggest players in the city's media business, doubling in jobs and companies in just the last 18 months to become a $2.8 billion-a-year juggernaut, according to a study to be released today.

title: Our Towns; A Student Takes On Her Academy
description: ON the last Saturday of September, when the grueling first quarter courses at the United States Merchant Marine Academy were over, Stephanie Vincent, a junior midshipman and top engineering student, turned in early to spend Sunday studying for her thermodynamics final.

title: Hebron Journal; On This Street, It's All Painted Over but the Hatred
description: Perched high on a ladder on a recent afternoon, a workman dusted off a Spanish street light gracing the new brick sidewalks of Shuhada Street, a bitterly contested road here where Palestinians and Jewish settlers are uneasy neighbors.

title: I.B.M. Gives More to Put Technology In Schools
description: Two years after challenging the nation's governors and corporate leaders to propose fresh solutions to education's most vexing problems, Louis V. Gerstner Jr., the chief executive of I.B.M., is seeking to illustrate what he meant.

title: 3M Profit Rises 8% As Sales Are Strong
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that earnings grew in line with estimates during the third quarter, lifted by strong sales and cost controls.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: LEXMARK INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC., Lexington, Ky., will repurchase three million class A common shares for as much as $105 million from the Clayton & Dubilier Private Equity Fund IV L.P. and other shareholders.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When BARBARA COOK sings ''Time Heals Everything'' at a celebration of the opening of the new Gay Men's Health Crisis center this evening, the song will have a meaning she could not have anticipated in August when she agreed to appear.

title: Personal Shopper
description: LITTLE sheets may spend more time with your baby than you do. And fitted crib linens are no longer plain white -- or out-of-favor pink or light blue. This season, babies' beds can be as offbeat or designer as their parents'. (For classic minimalist babies, Calvin Klein's store sells his pale parchment-colored percale baby sheets at $30.)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I came to carry out the struggle, not to kill people. Even now, and you can look at me: am I a savage person? My conscience is clear.'' POL POT, in his first interview in nearly 20 years. [A12]

title: In Boise, Manhattan Kvetching Is Familiar as a Bagel
description: It's probably safe to say that in Murphy, population 65, a dusty remote town in Owyhee County, in the desert about 40 miles south of here, there isn't a great deal to do at night. Still, Dick Freund, the Chief Deputy Sheriff, finds time for only a few hours of television a week. He's discerning; everything he watches takes place a world away, in New York City.

title: In Their Own Words
description: CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, STANLEY
description: WILLIAMS-Stanley. Peter Martins, Ballet Master in Chief, Eugene P. Grisanti, Chairman of The Board, Howard Solomon, President of The Board Directors and everyone at New York City Ballet deeply mourn the passing of Stanley Williams, legendary teacher, colleague, mentor and dear friend. We shall remember fondly his gentle and patient spirit and his lifelong dedication to his craft and to his beloved students. Our heartfelt sympathy goes to his family. We have lost a cherished and irreplaceable member of the NYCB family, but his enduring legacy to generations of dancers will never be forgotten.

title: Advertisers are shuffling accounts that add up to more than $210 million in billings.
description: SEVERAL big national advertisers made changes on their accounts this week involving billings estimated at more than $210 million.

title: Corrections
description: A picture with an article yesterday about the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission's designation of three new landmark buildings was published in error. The bank building designated a landmark was the Chase Manhattan branch at 510 Fifth Avenue, at 43d Street, not the building shown, which was the former Chase headquarters in lower Manhattan.

title: Polygram Posts 21.4% Rise in Net
description: Polygram N.V. said yesterday that its net income rose 21.4 percent in the third quarter, as strong releases from Elton John and Boyz II Men in its music division outweighed losses in the film division. Net income at Polygram rose to 85 million guilders, or $42.2 million, from 70 million guilders a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ERNST, MINAROSE G.
description: ERNST-Minarose G., in Tucson, Arizona, formerly of Bergenfield, New Jersey, and New York City. Beloved wife of Leonard and loving mother of the late Margaret.

title: Metaphor Monopoly
description: The Justice Department doesn't usually deal with existential matters -- at least until last Monday, when Attorney General Janet Reno asked a Federal judge to impose a $1 million-a-day fine on Microsoft Corporation.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: DIFFICULT RIDE -- Rail service from Connecticut to New York City came to a jarring halt when two commuter trains pulled down a milelong stretch of power lines. B6.

title: And the Wires Came Tumbling Down
description: Rail service from Connecticut to New York City came to a jarring halt yesterday morning when two commuter trains pulled down a milelong stretch of 90-year-old power lines in Greenwich, delaying as many as 40,000 riders, many of whom gave up their travels and went home.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Messinger Turns Up Heat, But Mayor Reacts Coolly
description: Ruth W. Messinger stepped up her attacks on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday, accusing him of running a secretive administration that has tried to suppress negative information. But the Mayor, appearing calm and confident as he cut a campaign swath through the Democratic heart of Queens, refrained from responding to his Democratic rival's criticisms.

title: Out-Twigging the Neighbors; In the Adirondacks, Great Camps Are Sprouting Again
description: A CENTURY ago, a generation of monied urban sportsmen, dressed in velveteen of approved cut and fortified by creme de menthe served in tin cups by their butlers, took to the mossy wilds and trouty streams of the Adirondacks, momentarily leaving their marble piles and Old Masters behind to build sprawling rustic retreats in the woods.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GRABER, SHIRLEY U.
description: GRABER-Shirley U. Remembering you on our birthdays and every day before and every day after. Judith

title: O'Donnell Given The Call Over Foley
description: Bill Parcells's odd game of spin the quarterback today landed precisely where almost everybody on the team thought it would: back on Neil O'Donnell.

title: In Manhattan, a Quixotic Abe Hirschfeld Chases at Elected Office Again
description: Reaching for an oyster at lunch, Abe Hirschfeld had just finished discussing the need ''for a builder to rebuild the city's schools,'' when he was asked to present another platform plank in his campaign for Manhattan Borough President.

title: Teacher Who Assigned Graphic Poem Says He Made Mistake
description: A Manhattan high school teacher who is being disciplined for distributing what school officials describe as a sexually explicit poem to an English class said yesterday that he had erred but noted that many of his students are exposed to much more provocative materials in their daily lives.

title: Driver in Fatal Runaway Bus Incident Dies 20 Days Later
description: The driver of a city bus that careered down Fifth Avenue on Oct. 2, killing a messenger and critically injuring a bicyclist, died in his home in the Bronx last night, the police said.

title: 'Camelot' Papers
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Repression Makes Arab Terror Inevitable
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Pitching Enduring An Ice Age
description: LAST night the World Series looked like one of those pretty glass balls turned upside down, with the snow falling in a pristine artificial universe. While the Indians and Marlins practiced, the public address system was booming ''Walking in a Winter Wonderland.''

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Court Plan Endangers Legal Services for Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Walter W. Curtis, 84, Bishop Of Bridgeport for 27 Years
description: Bishop Walter W. Curtis, the former head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Bridgeport, died on Saturday at St. Joseph Manor, a nursing home in Trumbull, Conn. He was 84.

title: Time Change Not Likely
description: Baseball officials will consider starting World Series and other post-season games earlier at night, Bud Selig said today, but he did not seem to hold out much promise.

title: Redevelopment Plans May Hem In Skid Row
description: Every night on the edge of downtown, a couple of dozen men and women hustle cardboard boxes from the trash and arrange them, like a row of coffins, behind a red line painted on the sidewalk at the corner of Fourth and Los Angeles Streets.

title: An Esiason Revival? Not on Blake's Life
description: The Giants have a new quarterback and the Jets at least have a quarterback debate, but don't suggest to Jeff Blake that the 1-6 Cincinnati Bengals need a quarterback change.

title: Currents; INSTALLATION -- A Dressing Room For an Absent Friend
description: Decorators can be their own worst enemies at show houses -- giving away their best trade secrets as they stage their most stylish tricks. Here are the names, addresses and numbers behind ideas at the French Designer Showhouse, 49 East 67th Street (through Nov. 16).

title: Union Monitor Seeking to Oust Laborers' Chief
description: A former Federal prosecutor hired to clean up the laborers' union plans to bring internal charges of associating with members of organized crime that could oust the union's president, Arthur A. Coia, Government officials said.

title: Dyslexic Law Graduate Sues on Exam's Time Limit
description: In the newest legal battleground over what assistance must be given to learning-disabled students, a dyslexic 1996 law school graduate has sued the California committee of bar examiners, saying that its refusal to allow him to double the normal time to take the bar examination violated Federal anti-discrimination laws.

title: Garden Notebook; Out of the Shrubs, a Green Menagerie
description: I STOOD among the Green Animals made of privet and yew, feeling an odd disappointment. There was no movie camera set at an impossibly low angle to make the giraffe, silhouetted against the clouds, look as tall as an Egyptian pyramid. In broad daylight, it was just a 15-foot green giraffe, made of privet, standing over a flower bed full of zinnias edged with boxwood.

title: Accounts
description: * Centex Homes, Dallas, to Temerlin McClain, Irving, Tex., a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, as the first agency to handle advertising for the builder. Billings were not disclosed.

title: SUMMIT CARE HIRES FIRM TO EXPLORE 'ALTERNATIVES'
description: The Summit Care Corporation said yesterday that it had hired the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation, the investment banking firm, to help it evaluate ''strategic alternatives'' and ''maximize shareholder value.'' Summit, a nursing home operator based in Burbank, Calif., did not elaborate. Its shares rose $1.25, to $17.875, giving the company a market capitalization of $121 million. Summit Care operates 35 nursing homes and five assisted-living centers in California, Texas and Arizona. The company also operates three pharmacies and manages subacute units in acute hospitals.

title: Mr. Sinatra Spoils Concerto's Comeback
description: George Steinbrenner heard a voice from the past yesterday when Aqueduct opened its fall racing season. No, it wasn't the voice of the Yankees. It was Concerto, his 3-year-old racing star, who won five straight stakes last spring before running ninth in the Kentucky Derby and sixth in the Preakness.

title: Kimberly-Clark Awards Options
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said today that it was marking its 125th anniversary by awarding stock options to 56,000 of its 60,000 employees worldwide in an unusual move that one employment expert said would build a link with investors.

title: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL IN DEAL WITH PINNACLE RESOURCES
description: Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd. said yesterday that it would sell part of its Wascana Energy unit to Pinnacle Resources Ltd. for $308 million (Canadian), or $221.5 million (United States). Canadian Occidental said the sale included properties in southwest Saskatchewan that produce 11,200 barrels of oil equivalent a day and generate an annual cash flow of about $32 million (Canadian). The deal also includes about 788,000 acres of undeveloped land. Canadian Occidental acquired Wascana earlier this year for $1.7 billion (Canadian) after a bidding war with a rival, Talisman Energy Inc. Canadian Occidental, which is 30 percent owned by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, and Pinnacle are both based in Calgary, Alberta.

title: Briefcase Shields Man From Attacker's Arrow
description: Quick reflexes and a briefcase saved a Housing Authority manager in Brooklyn from an arrow yesterday, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTEIN, RUTH RICHARDS
description: EISENSTEIN-Ruth Richards, 91, at home Tuesday, October 21, 1997. Senior Editor at Harry N. Abrams, Inc., founding member Manhattan Reconstructionist Havurah and West End Synagogue. Remembered with love by children and their spouses, Paula Eisenstein Baker & Stephen D. Baker, Hester Eisenstein and Michael Tanzer, & Jethro M. Eisenstein and Stefany Gordon; grandchildren, Hannah Baker Hitzhusen, Sarah Baker Topper, Max Gordon Eisenstein, and Leo Gordon Eisenstein; greatgrandchildren, Leah Malka Topper and Rachel Batya Topper. Services Friday, October 24, 12:30PM, The Riverside, Amsterdam at 76th. Minyan at 419 East 57th, Saturday, Sunday, Monday, 7:30PM. Contributions to West End Synagogue or National Yiddish Book Center, Amherst, MA. 01002-3375.

title: Currents; FLOORING -- Boulevardier at Home
description: Decorators can be their own worst enemies at show houses -- giving away their best trade secrets as they stage their most stylish tricks. Here are the names, addresses and numbers behind ideas at the French Designer Showhouse, 49 East 67th Street (through Nov. 16).

title: Sheik Vows to Continue the Hamas Holy War Against Israel
description: Delivering his most militant and impassioned speech since his return to Gaza three weeks ago, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, the guiding symbol of the militant Islamic movement Hamas, vowed today not to abandon holy war against Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CANTOR, MIMI
description: CANTOR-Mimi. We will always love you and will never stop missing you. Eddie, Barry, Mary Ann and Adam

title: Pope's Visit Sets Off Bickering In Cuba
description: Less than three months before Pope John Paul II is to make his first visit here, the Cuban Government and the Roman Catholic hierarchy are still jockeying over crucial organizational details of the trip as well as the scope of activity that the Cuban church will be permitted.

title: Guilty Plea in Baby's Death
description: A Paterson woman charged in January with killing her newborn baby by throwing her from a third-story window pleaded guilty yesterday to aggravated manslaughter, prosecutors said.

title: Hard Times Weaken a Malaysian Powerbroker
description: Bumper stickers have appeared here bearing a portrait of Malaysia's leader and the words, ''We support Dr. Mahathir.''

title: Crenshaw's New Task: Regaining Ryder Cup
description: Ben Crenshaw was thrilled today after being named captain of the 1999 United States Ryder Cup team.

title: Currents; MATERIALISM -- Magic Made on Slender Means
description: Decorators can be their own worst enemies at show houses -- giving away their best trade secrets as they stage their most stylish tricks. Here are the names, addresses and numbers behind ideas at the French Designer Showhouse, 49 East 67th Street (through Nov. 16).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SINCLAIR, MARION
description: SINCLAIR-Marion, February 10, 1923-October 23, 1995. In loving memory. Cynthia & Tom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERCOVITCH, HANNA M.
description: BERCOVITCH-Hanna M. The officers, directors, and staff of The Library of America are deeply saddened by the death of their colleague, Hanna M. Bercovitch, who served as editor-in-chief for many years and contributed greatly to the organization's mission. Her devotion to books and to American writing, her learning and enthusiasm, and her commitment to the highest levels of scholarship inspired everyone who came to know her. We extend our condolences to her family and friends. Cheryl Hurley, President Richard Poirier, Chairman, Board of Directors The Library of America

title: TRAVELERS TO SPLIT STOCK AND BUY BACK $1 BILLION WORTH
description: Travelers Group Inc. said yesterday that it would split its common stock 3 for 2 and buy back up to $1 billion worth of shares. Travelers said the stock split would be distributed on Nov. 19 to shareholders of record as of Nov. 3. The concern, a financial services and insurance company, said the buyback would finance employee benefit plans. As of Sept. 30, the company had 647 million shares outstanding. Travelers also announced a dividend of 10 cents a share on a post-split basis, to be paid Nov. 26 to shareholders of record as of Nov. 3. In the following quarter, Travelers will raise its dividend 25 percent, to 12.5 cents a share. Travelers shares closed at $76.375, up $1.1875.

title: KELLEY OIL TO PURCHASE SCANA UNIT FOR $110 MILLION
description: The Kelley Oil and Gas Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Scana Petroleum Resources Inc. for $110 million from its parent company, the Scana Corporation. Scana, which also owns South Carolina Electric and Gas, said it would use proceeds from the sale to buy back its stock and perhaps to pay off debt. The assets to be acquired include more than 70 billion cubic feet of gas equivalent in shallow waters of the Gulf of Mexico and in East Texas. Kelley, based in Houston, had 1996 revenues of $62.2 million. The Scana Corporation, based in Columbia, S.C., had 1996 revenues of $1.51 billion. Scana's shares slipped 18.75 cents, to $25.1875, while Kelley was up 12.5 cents, to $3.6875.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOLNESS, ELSA
description: HOLNESS-Elsa. October 23, 1985. In God always loving; in God forever loved. Nieces, Shirley and Lorraine; Brother, Archibald

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, FRANCES
description: KAYE-Frances. Of Miami Beach and Saratoga Springs, New York. An elegant and gracious woman of valor, compassionate and held with great love by her children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Loved by countless friends and family. Burial Sunday, 3 PM, Saratoga Springs, NY. Shiva at the home of her brother, Harry Walker, 122 Central Avenue, Lawrence, New York (516-371-1400).

title: Newark Tries Out Its Space
description: The timing worked out nicely for the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra. The orchestra is celebrating its 75th anniversary this season, and that would normally have been good reason for it to call attention to itself. But the anniversary has been overshadowed, understandably, by the orchestra's move to its new home, the 2,750-seat Prudential Hall in the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark.

title: South African Gets Approval For a Casino In New Jersey
description: Sol Kerzner, a flamboyant casino magnate who has been described as South Africa's answer to Donald J. Trump, won approval today from the New Jersey Casino Control Commission to operate a casino here despite evidence that he helped bribe a government official in Africa more than a decade ago.

title: The Grit & the Glory; Help From The Home Doctor
description: Is wood the new porcelain?

title: The Islanders Get Even
description: The Islanders were satisfied to come home from their first extended road trip this season with a .500 record. Considering their poor road record last year, average is good.

title: First Car in U.S. Was Truly a Sport Utility
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Indians Tie the Series on a Snow Shower of Power
description: Less than a year ago, Jaret Wright, pitching for the Scottsdale Scorpions, and Tony Saunders, pitching for the Tempe Rafters, were the opposing starters in an Arizona Fall League game. Saunders emerged as the winning pitcher.

title: State Says Man Has Rabies
description: The man, whose name was withheld, was not expected to survive; the disease is untreatable once symptoms have appeared, Dr. Sorhage said.

title: Caution on Infant Doses
description: To the Editor:

title: Child Care Talks Return First Lady to Spotlight
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton convenes a White House conference on Thursday to highlight what she and the President see as an urgent need for safe, affordable child care. But conservative Republicans say they fear that the conference will lay the groundwork for plans to increase Government spending or regulation.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of two Jewish holidays, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today, for Shemini Atzereth, which concludes Succoth, the Feast of Tabernacles, and tomorrow, for Simhath Torah, which ends the annual cycle of the public reading of the Torah. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Israeli Repression Makes Arab Terror Inevitable; No More Concessions
description: To the Editor:

title: At High Point, Revivals and the 'Pottery Barn Look'
description: IN a tailored chalk-stripe suit, Bill Blass looked out of place in the brightly lighted Pennsylvania House showroom. He was at the opening day of the International Home Furnishings Market to introduce a line of furnishings -- tables, chairs and beds, most under $3,000 -- that bear his name. Almost all were inspired by pieces from his own much-photographed home.

title: Jurors Deciding Case Of Parking-Place Murder
description: Jurors began deliberations here yesterday in the murder trial of a New York City police officer accused of shooting a man to death in a dispute over a parking space.

title: Subpoenas May Be Out In Louima Case
description: The first Federal grand jury subpoenas have apparently been issued to some of the witnesses in the case of Abner Louima, the Haitian immigrant who prosecutors say was tortured by police officers at a Brooklyn station house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MENEK
description: GOLDSTEIN - Menek. Caring friend leaves an irreplaceable void in our lives. Tuchman family.

title: The Mold Scare: Overblown or Not?
description: EVEN the ancients had trouble coping with mold. In the worst case, the Book of Leviticus instructs, move out of the house. And a recent study published in Caduceus, a medical journal, theorizes that the last of the 10 plagues of Egypt was actually poisonous mold.

title: Hong Kong Stocks Plunge as Rates Soar
description: Stocks in Hong Kong plunged, as the financial forces wreaking havoc across Southeast Asia have now turned full force on that market.

title: Personal Shopper; Not Just Pink and Blue
description: LITTLE sheets may spend more time with your baby than you do. And fitted crib linens are no longer plain white -- or out-of-favor pink or light blue. This season, babies' beds can be as offbeat or designer as their parents'. (For classic minimalist babies, Calvin Klein's store sells his pale parchment-colored percale baby sheets at $30.)

title: A Golden Alley On Wall Street; Merchant Banking's Midas Touch Reaches Even Mundane Enterprises
description: Golf, fly-fishing -- polo, perhaps. These are the recreations (aside from making money) that one associates with Wall Street's elite. But bowling? Investment bankers do not go bowling.

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES TO ACQUIRE GEORGIA DEALERSHIPS
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it would buy Sutherlin Automotive Management, a closely held company in Marietta, Ga., that owns six auto dealerships. Terms were not disclosed. Sutherlin's dealerships, including four in the Atlanta area, had $367 million in revenue in 1996, ranking it as the 39th-largest new-car group in the nation, according to Automotive News, which reported the acquisition last week. The acquisition also adds single dealerships in Pinellas Park, Fla., and Pell City, Ala. Republic, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and run by the billionaire H. Wayne Huizenga, plans to announce the acquisition formally later this month, a spokesman said. He declined to specify a price. Republic's shares rose $1.125, to $34.1875.

title: In America; A Revolution Subsides
description: It's not more than a stirring at the moment, like a soft breeze that heralds a change of seasons. But it's there. It's happening.

title: Market Place; Fidelity Critic Gets Tougher As a Deal Fails
description: In the three years since he left Fidelity Investments, David J. O'Leary of Alpha Equity Research has made himself the mutual fund giant's most strident critic.

title: Currents; LIGHTING -- The Soft Glow Of the 40's Casts Its Spell
description: Decorators can be their own worst enemies at show houses -- giving away their best trade secrets as they stage their most stylish tricks. Here are the names, addresses and numbers behind ideas at the French Designer Showhouse, 49 East 67th Street (through Nov. 16).

title: Frenchwomen's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Question in Messinger Camp: Where's the Party Support?
description: When Ruth W. Messinger wanted a Democrat of stature to campaign with her the other day, she reached out halfway across the country, enlisting Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota to fly in for a day of appearances at her side.

title: Economic Scene; Clinton may soon tackle the devilish Social Security issue.
description: WITH trade liberalization and global warming already on the menu, one might expect President Clinton to take a break before heaping another difficult-to-digest economic issue on his plate. In fact, the White House is close to making a decision on whether to add Social Security to his agenda. There is reason for the haste: while the President has three years left in office, the political window of opportunity for tackling this most sensitive of issues is narrow.

title: Harold Rothwax, Stern Criminal Courts Judge, Dies at 67
description: Judge Harold J. Rothwax, who began his legal career as a combative defense lawyer and civil rights advocate in New York but who later gained wide attention in a campaign to limit the rights of defendants, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 67.

title: U.S. Fails to Get U.N. Backing To Widen Sanctions on Iraq
description: The United States lost its battle to impose new sanctions on Iraq today and settled for a Security Council resolution that would keep only a strong threat of added restrictions.

title: Boeing Startles Market With Delays Costing $2.6 Billion
description: The Boeing Company stunned Wall Street yesterday by announcing that unexpected production delays in the booming market for its commercial planes will cost $2.6 billion and erase a good portion of the company's profits.

title: Dangerous Sparks in Kosovo
description: Events in Kosovo are proving the adage that those who make peaceful revolutions impossible make violent ones inevitable. Kosovo is a region of Serbia where a tiny Serbian minority has governed the Albanian majority in brutal apartheid style since Slobodan Milosevic revoked the region's autonomy in 1989. Recently some Albanians, frustrated that politics is getting them nowhere, have turned to attacks on police stations and other symbols of Serbian power. Serbian authorities respond with indiscriminate repression. To keep the peace in Kosovo, the United States and its European allies must do more to help restore the rights of the Albanians there. A peaceful Kosovo is crucial because violence could spread to neighboring areas.

title: What Smoke? New Device Keeps Cigarettes in a 'Box'
description: The Philip Morris Companies is planning to test a microelectronic cigarette holder that eliminates the smoke and ashes from the end of a cigarette.

title: Stock Rally Stalls on Corporate Earnings
description: A two-day rally in stocks was stalled yesterday as investors chose to focus on the latest spate of corporate earnings disappointments to drive their investment strategies.

title: 2 Die as Military Jets Collide in California
description: An Air Force training jet collided today with an F-16 fighter over Edwards Air Force Base in California and crashed in the Mojave Desert, killing the two airmen aboard the trainer, one American and one British.

title: Advertising and Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Turkish Court Yields to Police Officers Accused of Torturing 14
description: In one of Turkey's most closely watched human rights cases, a court backed down today when police officers accused of torturing 14 young people refused to appear in court to face their accusers.

title: Davis Gets Clemente Award
description: Eric Davis, the player credited with inspiring the Baltimore Orioles this season with his courageous battle against colon cancer, was named the Roberto Clemente man of the year today by Major League Baseball.

title: As Trade Center Smoldered, Suspect Watched, Jury Hears
description: As smoke billowed from the towers of the World Trade Center on Feb. 26, 1993, after a huge blast had torn through the center's garage, a man watched intently from the Jersey City waterfront.

title: Clinton's Use Of Soft Money Is Denounced By Thompson
description: Seizing on the newly released White House videotapes, the chairman of the Senate inquiry into campaign abuses accused President Clinton today of perpetrating a ''ruse'' on the taxpayers by accepting public financing for his re-election campaign in exchange for voluntary spending limits while also directing an expensive round of additional television advertisements to bolster his standing in the polls.

title: Million Women March Is Set With High Hopes
description: Two years after hundreds of thousands of men came to Washington for a day of speeches and prayers at the Million Man March, a large group of women is expected here on Saturday for an event called the Million Woman March.

title: Hong Kong Stocks Fall Steeply, New Victim of Region's Ills
description: The financial forces wreaking havoc across Southeast Asia have turned on Hong Kong, hammering stocks nearly 30 percent this month and putting pressure on the Hong Kong dollar, the last currency in the region to escape devaluation.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks were lower this morning. At the midday recess, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 79.12 points, or one-half of 1 percent, at 17,608.49. On Wednesday, the Nikkei surged 477.52 points, or 2.77 percent.

title: U.S. Leads in Bermuda Bowl
description: The two United States squads, both loaded with former world titleholders, surged to the top in the Bermuda Bowl at the world team championships here today. With half the qualifying play completed, they seem sure to reach the playoffs, which begin Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, SOPHIE
description: WEISS-Sophie, on October 20, 1997. Devoted wife of the late Albert Weiss. Beloved mother of Murray and Robert. Loving grandmother of David, Amy, Elizabeth and Marian. Also survived by four great-grandchildren. A private graveside service at the Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. For information contact the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle.

title: Israeli Repression Makes Arab Terror Inevitable; Jordan Isn't Palestine
description: To the Editor:

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; New Clues From the Met's Permanent Guest
description: The Russian conductor Valery Gergiyev should be well known to New York opera fans. He has conducted acclaimed performances at the Metropolitan Opera. For the Lincoln Center Festival last summer, he arrived with the Kirov Opera, the St. Petersburg company he has built into a Russian national treasure. They will be back for a special, post-season run at the Met this spring. Still, now that Mr. Gergiyev's appointment as permanent guest conductor at the Met has been announced, it is natural to wonder how he will fare. Are there special qualities he will bring to standard repertory? How does his approach differ from James Levine's? What is in store in terms of the Russian opera he champions? The two latest additions to Mr. Gergiyev's substantial discography from the Kirov Opera on the Philips label offer some answers.

title: The Martinez Watch
description: Steve Phillips, the Mets general manager, planned to meet tonight or tomorrow with club officials from Montreal to continue discussions about pitcher Pedro Martinez; the Yankees, too, are interested in Martinez. But neither the Mets nor Yankees seem to have the sort of players the Expos are seeking.

title: Antidepressant Is Found to Help Smokers Quit
description: An antidepressant drug can help people quit smoking, even those who are not depressed and would not normally take such a medication, researchers say.

title: Devils Lose Andreychuk
description: The line of Bobby Holik as the center to Dave Andreychuk on the left and Randy McKay on the right has been the most productive threesome for the Devils this season with 10 of the team's 20 goals. But Andreychuk will be missing when the Devils play the visiting Montreal Canadiens on Thursday night.

title: Corrections
description: The crossword puzzle yesterday contained an erroneous clue for 59 Across: ''Winningest N.C.A.A. basketball coach.'' The answer being sought was ''RUPP,'' a reference to Adolph Rupp, who coached at Kentucky. But Rupp no longer holds the record for victories; he was surpassed last March by Dean Smith of North Carolina.

title: A Dramatist's How-To Guide for the Stage-Struck
description: TRUE AND FALSE

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Shades of Astilbe

title: Fuji Bank Plans to Cut Assets by 4 Trillion Yen
description: Fuji Bank Ltd., one of Japan's 10 biggest commercial banks, said it would cut its assets by 4 trillion yen, or about $33 billion, in the next two years to improve its return on equity.

title: Sweeping Changes for I.R.S. Win House Panel's Approval
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today overwhelmingly passed legislation intended to bring sweeping changes to the Internal Revenue Service, with members of both parties saying the bill would protect taxpayers and impose new management standards on the tax-collection agency.

title: Pol Pot Unapologetic
description: Pol Pot, who as leader of the Khmer Rouge was responsible for the deaths of at least a million Cambodians in the 1970's, said in his first interview in 18 years that his conscience is clear. ''I came to carry out the struggle, not to kill people,'' he told the Far Eastern Economic Review in a report published this week.

title: Treasuries Nearly Flat In Dull Day
description: Treasury prices were little changed yesterday in a lackluster trading session.

title: Hicks, Muse, Aided by NBC, Sweetens Lin Television Bid
description: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, an investment firm that has been amassing broadcast properties, agreed today to pay a sweetened price of $1.7 billion in cash for the Lin Television Corporation, using the backing of NBC to beat an offer financed by the Alabama state pension fund.

title: 'On the Town' Is Broadway Bound
description: Only the selection of a new choreographer is needed to finalize plans to reopen the revival of the musical ''On the Town'' at the St. James Theater on Broadway in April, and that decision is expected in the next few days.

title: Calendar; Architecture, Even Doghouses
description: Artists' Open House

title: The Big City, With an Even Bigger Cast; A Great Place to Visit (At Least on Television)
description: New York City is the place of big breaks: broken legs (''So many punks, so little time,'' says Danny Aiello's private investigator in ''Dellaventura''); broken hearts (the heroine of ''Caroline in the City'' found and lost her true love without ever leaving her apartment); broken grammar (almost anyone on ''N.Y.P.D. Blue''). And of course it is the place of big show-biz breaks or at least steady work, the kind that Jerry Seinfeld's sitcom alter ego gets. These are New York stereotypes, yet they have been hauled out with a distinct air of rediscovery lately, along with a few fresher images.

title: Metro Business Briefs; Chubb Computer School
description: Chubb Computer Services, a division of the Chubb Corporation, is opening a career-training school for programmers, network engineers, data center operators and other computer specialists at 22 Cortlandt Street in lower Manhattan, a building better known as the home of the Century 21 department store.

title: Emotions That Spring From Form
description: Humanism is back, the Limon Dance Company will remind us during its 50th-anniversary season, which got off on a high note with a superb performance on Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Suspect to Remain in Custody
description: The Jackson Township teen-ager charged with sexually assaulting and killing an 11-year-old boy who was going door-to-door to raise money for his school was ordered yesterday to remain in custody and continue psychiatric counseling, his lawyer said.

title: Bankers' Discipline
description: Less than 15 months from the creation of a single currency, Europe's central bankers have sent a sobering message to its politicians: You can no longer use monetary policy to cushion economic shocks of your own making. Whether politicians take the hint is another question altogether.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bailout of Auto Maker Lifts South Korean Market

title: Court Lets Two Gay Men Jointly Adopt Child
description: In a decision hailed by gay rights advocates, a state court judge today allowed two gay men to jointly adopt a 2-year-old boy they had cared for as foster parents since he was 3 months old.

title: A Pivotal Vote on Campaign Reform
description: The effort to reform the nation's corrupt campaign finance system, which ran into Trent Lott's parliamentary blockade earlier this month, faces a minefield this week. In a cynical attempt to thwart the will of the majority, Mr. Lott plans to bar any attempt today to offer the McCain-Feingold campaign bill as an amendment to a highway spending bill now before the Senate. The majority leader hopes that so many senators want the highway bill that they will not challenge his obstructionism. This is precisely the moment, then, for reformers to stand firm and demand the right to present campaign reform to the Senate and get an up-or-down vote.

title: Montenegrins Land in Game Of Geopolitics
description: PARIS  Western governments are hoping that Montenegro's change of leaders will make the country a heavier geopolitical domino in the Balkans than its tiny size might suggest, according to U.S. and European diplomats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUTZER, SEYMOUR, M.D.
description: SCHUTZER-Seymour, M.D. He will be deeply missed and remembered always by family, friends and all those who knew and loved him. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 Station Plaza North, Great Neck, L.I. Friday, October 24th, 12 Noon. Contributions may be made to your favorite medical charity.

title: Today Is the Day
description: I do apologize for intruding upon a perfectly pleasant morning with the potentially unwelcome news that the world will end today -- precisely at noon. I base these tidings on the most famous and widely accepted chronology built by a method that the greatest Western scholars once viewed as beyond reproach.

title: China's Trade Status
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts in America; In a Transformed Concert Hall, Hearing Is Believing
