description: At the Kennedy Center Concert Hall a month ago, Leonard Slatkin, the music director of the National Symphony Orchestra, was running through the repertory it would play during its European tour.

title: Failing to Protect Children
description: A court-appointed panel of experts has shown in devastating detail how wretchedly New York City's child welfare system has been performing. The city's Administration for Children's Services, charged with protecting abused and neglected children, has routinely left them to languish in dangerous homes where many are abused again.

title: The Bliss and the Battles Of Ballroom Romance
description: Romance was back again when the New York Ballroom Company performed on Saturday afternoon at the Theater of the Riverside Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORLIN, RICHARD, M.D.
description: GORLIN-Richard, M.D. The Department of Pathology of Mount Sinai School of Medicine deeply mourns the death of Richard Gorlin, M.D. He was a pioneer in cardiology, a leader and innovative scholar, a true friend of this department and a Mount Sinai ''giant''. We will miss him. We wish his wife Florence and the family our sincere condolences.

title: Currents; FABRICS -- A Dash Of Honey And Gold
description: Decorators can be their own worst enemies at show houses -- giving away their best trade secrets as they stage their most stylish tricks. Here are the names, addresses and numbers behind ideas at the French Designer Showhouse, 49 East 67th Street (through Nov. 16).

title: McCall Comeback
description: Oliver McCall, the heavyweight who suffered a bizarre mental breakdown in a bout against Lennox Lewis last February, is returning to the ring to fight Bryan Yates on Nov. 4 in Nashville.

title: Anything but a Cad
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Attacked on Impropriety Claim
description: The Democratic candidate for New Jersey governor, James E. McGreevey, demanded today that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's chief of staff be suspended without pay over allegations that she bluntly told a Hispanic group that they were expected to endorse the Governor because the state had agreed to provide $500,000 for various Hispanic causes.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Where do the authors of a book aimed at women titled ''The Money Club: How We Taught Ourselves the Secret to a Secure Financial Future -- and How You Can, Too,'' go to celebrate the fact that it has gone into its third printing?

title: Crew Attacks School Investigator, Calling His Reports Exaggerated
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew complained yesterday that the independent investigator set up to investigate corruption and misconduct in the New York City schools had produced exaggerated reports that were damaging to the schools and the people in them, and said that he was going to begin his own investigation of the investigator.

title: An Award Liberates Two More Conductors
description: The classical music world has had a love-hate relationship with competitions for most of this century: much as professionals decry the blood sport aspect of setting young musicians against one another, there is enough interest in them to keep dozens of contests alive and well financed, with new ones joining the list every year. As a backlash to the mano a mano nature of the contests, a new kind of non-gladiatorial competition has taken form.

title: Crude Oil Climbs as U.S. Inventories Shrink
description: Crude oil prices climbed yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, in part on data showing unexpected declines last week in United States oil inventories.

title: Foreign Affairs; A Crude Story
description: Follow the oil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARAVANI, VILLANI, WANDA
description: GARAVANI-VILLANI-Wanda, beloved sister of Valentino Garavani, passed away suddenly in Paris on October 20, 1997. She played an important role in the organization that benefits children with AIDS called L.I.F.E., which was founded by Valentino Garavani and Giancarlo Giammetti. In addition to her brother, she is survived by two sons, Piero and Mauro Villani. The funeral will take place on Friday, October 24, at 11:00 A.M., at the San-Lorenzo-in-Lucina Church in Rome.

title: In an Interview, Pol Pot Declares His Conscience Is Clear
description: Pol Pot, the man responsible for the deaths of at least a million Cambodians in the 1970's, says that he never intended to kill anybody and that ''my conscience is clear,'' according to a report to be published this week.

title: Corrections
description: At article on Oct. 10 about efforts by Reform and Conservative Jewish leaders in the United States to challenge control of the Orthodox on religious and civic life in Israel mischaracterized the financing of religious schools in Israel. While Orthodox schools receive most government money that is given to religious schools, non-Orthodox schools do receive some public money.

title: Team One Names Co-Chairman
description: Leonard Pearlstein, a longtime automotive advertising executive, has been named co-chairman and chief executive at Team One Advertising in El Segundo, Calif., as Team One absorbs his agency, the Pearlstein Group in Los Angeles. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANDLER, MIRIAM A.
description: HANDLER-Miriam A. The Officers and Board of the Jewish Campus Life mourn the passing of the beloved wife of our esteemed board member, Professor Milton Handler. Our deepest sympathy to Milton, his daughter Carole and entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Prof Robert Pollack, President Earle W. Kazis, Chairman of the Board Rabbi Charles H. Sheer, Chaplain Jewish Campus Life Fund, Inc. at Columbia University

title: Currents; PAINT -- Celadon and Silk
description: Decorators can be their own worst enemies at show houses -- giving away their best trade secrets as they stage their most stylish tricks. Here are the names, addresses and numbers behind ideas at the French Designer Showhouse, 49 East 67th Street (through Nov. 16).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSE, CHARLOTTE
description: ROSE-Charlotte. October 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Leon. Devoted Mom and friend of Stephen Rose and Linda Iennaco. Cherished grandmother of Lisa and Laurie, and great grandmother of Harry. Loving mother-in-law of Domenick Iennaco. Services Friday, 12 noon at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Hospice Care Network.

title: Ordonez and Williams Are Voted Gold Gloves
description: As executives from both New York baseball teams probed for trade possibilities, Rey Ordonez, the shortstop for the Mets, and Bernie Williams, the Yankee center fielder, each won his first Gold Glove for fielding today.

title: Stocks Soar in Seoul on Kia Takeover Plan
description: The South Korean Government's decision to take over the Kia Motors Corporation, the nation's third-largest auto manufacturer after Hyundai and Daewoo, sent stock prices to a record gain today and halted a decline in the nation's currency.

title: Turf; Co-op Boards Twist The Screws
description: IN mid-September, a Wall Street trader and his stockbroker fiancee plunked down a hefty deposit to buy a co-op apartment on West End Avenue. In early October, the two were married, six months before they had planned, because their real estate broker said it would help them pass the building's co-op board -- for financial, not moral, reasons. The agent even suggested the minister: the Episcopal priest who was selling the apartment.

title: Knicks Send Four Players To the Celtics for Mills
description: The Knicks reasserted their urgent need to win a title now by unloading their future today, sending the last of their MTV generation players to Boston for the veteran forward Chris Mills in a four-for-one trade.

title: Recess in Trial of Ex-Coroner
description: The trial of a former coroner accused of tampering with evidence while examining the body of a man found dead in the Essex County jail was recessed until Monday.

title: People
description: * Spence Kramer was named senior vice president and general manager of a new Los Angeles office of Grey Entertainment, part of Grey Advertising. He was previously vice president for client services at Seiniger Advertising, Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: A sports headline yesterday about soccer's UEFA Cup in Europe misstated the status of two teams, Inter Milan and Liverpool. They are still playing in the tournament, and have not been eliminated.

title: Dean Foods to Buy Dairy
description: The Dean Foods Company agreed today to buy the closely held H. Meyer Dairy, expanding distribution of its dairy products into southern Ohio and northeastern Kentucky. Terms were not disclosed. The Cincinnati-based H. Meyer has annual sales of almost $70 million. ''This is the first of what should be a series of acquisitions,'' John McMillin, an analyst at Prudential Securities, said. He estimated the H. Meyer acquisition would cost Dean Foods $35 million to $40 million.

title: The French Memory and the War
description: Like a gale sweeping across the land, the trial of Maurice Papon, an 87-year-old ex-Vichy functionary accused of complicity in the Holocaust, is buffeting France's image of itself and pushing the post-war Gaullist political movement into a deep crisis.

title: Young and in Fear of the Police; Parents Teach Children How to Deal With Officers' Bias
description: Dwight Raiford, a black Citibank banker, has the usual parental misgivings about buying his 17-year-old son a nice car eventually after he gets his driver's license. His son has his own concerns.

title: Jordan, McGrath Picks Heir Apparent
description: Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor in New York has promoted Stephen Badenhop, 50, its executive vice president and group director on the SmithKline Beecham account, to the new position of client services director. In addition, the agency identified him as the heir apparent to Pat McGrath, the agency's president.

title: A Dialogue Between Then and Now
description: Pop nostalgia has never been just one thing. For some singers, the resurrection of vintage pop songs is an excuse to wallow in memories of the good old days, while for others it entails mounting museum-perfect re-creations of bygone sounds and styles. But for Mary Cleere Haran, whose brilliant new cabaret act at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel focuses on movie songs from the Depression, nostalgia is more than a backward glance through rose-colored glasses or an imitation gramophone sound.

title: Nike Swoops In and Pays United States $120 Million
description: Tom Clarke, Nike's president, prefers not to think that his company dominates world soccer, with the Brazilian, Dutch, Italian, South Korean, Russian, Polish, Portuguese and Nigerian national federations under swoosh control.

title: Lally, McFarland Revamps Leadership
description: Lally, McFarland & Pantello Euro RSCG, a leading medical agency in New York, said yesterday that it had reorganized its top-level management. The decision comes a month after three of its top executives unexpectedly left the shop to form an agency specializing in health care advertising under the aegis of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Saunders Lacks Experience And the Indians Exploit It
description: Thinking too much, Tony Saunders admitted before pitching Game 4 of the World Series, only gets him into trouble. ''I guess I'm stupid in a way,'' he said. ''I just grab the ball and throw it.''

title: Success in Balkans, as All Sides Destroy Heavy Weapons
description: In the political gloom that hangs over the tenuous peace in the Balkans, with war criminals at large and refugees unable to return home, there is a glimmer of good news: The enemies who were at war two years ago have been destroying their weapons in large numbers.

title: CULLIGAN WATER OFFERS $172 MILLION FOR PROTEAN P.L.C.
description: Culligan Water Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had offered to acquire Protean P.L.C. of Britain for $:105 million, or $172 million. Culligan, a water-purification company based in Northbrook, Ill., offered 240 pence a share, or $3.92, for the shares outstanding of Protean. It already owns 2.96 percent of Protean's stock. Protean is a holding company for businesses that supply water-cleansing, analysis and temperature equipment mainly for scientific, medical and industrial users. Analysts said the deal would help Culligan's industrial operations move into Britain. Protean also recently acquired FTS Systems Inc., a United States maker of freeze-drying equipment.

title: Nap Over, Indians Wake Up And Win
description: Marquis Grissom made his comments so quickly and so casually after a forgettable Tuesday evening at the World Series that the words took a moment or two to digest.

title: Public Eye
description: IT was 40 years ago that Jack Kerouac came out with his beat epic ''On the Road,'' a novel that was inspired as much by the temptations of the American highway system as by rebellion and methamphetamine. The novel's protagonist was eager to follow that ''one long red line called Route 6 that led from the tip of Cape Cod clear to Ely, Nev., and there dipped down to Los Angeles.''

title: Fire on Bus Causes Delays
description: A New Jersey Transit bus to New York City burst into flames on Interstate 80 yesterday, closing the eastbound express lanes for two hours, the state police said. It was the second time this week that a vehicle had caught fire on the highway, creating delays.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLERSBERG, ZINA
description: ADLERSBERG-Zina, died peacefully on October 21, 1997. Singer and voice teacher, known professionally as Zinaida Alvers. Beloved wife of the late Dr. David Adlersberg. Loving mother of Margaret and Mark Berger. Devoted grandmother of Josh and David Berger (Tracey Altman). Dear great grandmother of Tashi. Service on Friday, 1:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to your favorite charity.

title: Metro Business Briefs; New-Century Telecast
description: Dick Clark, move over. To ring in the new year 1998, the Times Square Business Improvement District will offer a live satellite broadcast of all the festivities in Times Square to countries around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YOUNG, CELIA
description: YOUNG-Celia. 10/23/64. Adored mother, dearest friend. Loved, mourned, missed unto eternity. Ida

title: Battle Stage Is Set
description: After two years of struggle over what to do about global warming, the Clinton Administration and the developing countries in the global game of greenhouse politics have put their cards on the table, and negotiations have at last begun in earnest.

title: PANEL OF EXPERTS URGES BROADENING OF PATIENT RIGHTS
description: A Presidential advisory commission decided today to recommend a wide range of new rights for patients, including the right to appeal denials of care or coverage by insurance companies and health maintenance organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, RICHARD N.
description: JONES-Richard N. On October 19, 1997, at age 92, in Hanover, N.H. Husband of Leila Elizabeth Jones (deceased). He is survived by two loving children, Elizabeth Thorne, of Manchester, Mass., and Gerard E. Jones of Greenwich, Conn., six loving grandchildren and two stepgrandchildren and one greatgrandchild. He devoted over 35 years of his professional life to his work in sales and as a publisher with Time Inc. In addition, he participated actively in community life in Cleveland, OH, Winetka, IL, and Greenwich, CT. We will all miss his character, intellect and devotion to his family and friends. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Greenwich, Conn., at 2 P.M., on December 20, 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELAHI, CYRUS
description: ELAHI-Cyrus. One with love in his heart never dies.

title: Jays Talk to Randolph
description: Willie Randolph, the Yankees' third-base coach, interviewed with the Blue Jays in Cleveland for their vacant managerial position on Tuesday. Randolph is one of at least 12 candidates for the position that opened when Toronto dismissed Cito Gaston last month. JACK CURRY

title: In His Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Meaning in a Mezuza
description: To the Editor:

title: Sidelining Candidates Is Seen as Risky : Dane Sounds Warning Over EU Enlargement
description: BRUSSELS  Foreign Minister Niels Helveg Petersen of Denmark has warned that the European Union risks creating dangerous divisions by inviting only selected East and Central European countries to become members.

title: Panel to Consider New Rules For Digital TV Broadcasters
description: Vice President Al Gore today convened an advisory panel charged with determining what public-interest obligations broadcasters must fulfill to borrow a second channel for digital broadcasts.

title: A Night of Fumbles In Football Weather
description: The Cleveland Indians and Florida Marlins played one of the sloppiest games in World Series history Tuesday, then weakly agreed that the weather was not a factor.

title: DAVCO ACQUISITION TO BUY REST OF DAVCO RESTAURANTS
description: Davco Acquisition Holding Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the shares it does not already own in Davco Restaurants Inc. for $20 each, or about $110 million. The shares of the restaurant operation, based in Crofton, Md., rose $1.0625, to $19.125. Davco Acquisition, which is closely held, already owns about 55 percent of the outstanding shares of Davco Restaurants. Davco Acquisition is owned by an investor group headed by the chairman of Davco Restaurants, Ronald D. Kirstien; the executive vice president, Harvey Rothstein, and its top shareholder, Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Tuesday in the Footlights column misstated the time of Sunday's student talent performance at La Guardia High School of Music and Art and Performing Arts in Manhattan. It is at 3 P.M., not 6; performances on Friday and Saturday are at 8 P.M., as the article reported.

title: 60 Trainees Protest Late Child-Care Money
description: About 60 welfare recipients taking an educational training program in Brooklyn walked out of their classrooms yesterday, saying they had not been getting child-care payments from the city. The money, from the Human Resources Administration, is intended to let them pay for child care so they can attend classes in literacy to earn high school diplomas, alternating with assignments to municipal tasks like working in parks.

title: Surprise, an Adventurous Counterpoint
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center seems intent on shaking up its audience's expectations. Instead of a conventional season opener last week, it presented a crossover collaboration that fused elements of jazz, country and classical music. It is to depart from its regular mission again this weekend, when it presents the New York debut recital of Hilary Hahn, a promising young violinist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERNAN, LESLIE HADDEN
description: KERNAN-Leslie Hadden on October 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Walter Avery Kernan; mother of Anita Halton, Mary Rutherfurd, Emily Rafferty, Nancy Chamberlain, Beatrice and Charles; grandmother of Anita Halton; Leslie Coleman, Lily and Emily Rutherfurd, Nicholas and Sara Rafferty, and Katherine Chamberlain; and sister of Anita Hadden Page and the late Hamilton Hadden Jr. Funeral Mass, 10:30 A.M., Friday, October 24th, at Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Interfaith Neighbors, Inc., 247 East 82nd Street, New York, New York 10028.

title: All the Wisdom a Team Can Handle
description: It was bad enough that Chuck Mills had been away from coaching for eight years. But when he came back as head coach at the Coast Guard Academy last spring, he was without a staff to help prepare for the 1997 season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, THEODORE F.
description: FELDMAN-Theodore F., 62, of 42 Mill Stone Drive, formerly of Woodbridge, CT., died Tuesday, October 21, 1997 at Middlesex Hospital. He is the husband of Diane G. Feldman. Mr. Feldman was born in New Haven, CT., on June 22, 1935 to the late Nathan Feldman & Evelyn Goldstein Feldman of Medford, OR. Mr. Feldman was an Insurance Executive for Mutual of Omaha for many years. He attended Norwich University, was a former Naval Aviator, a member and President-Elect for the Bridgeport Rotary, Past President for the GAMA, a member of the Brideport Life Underwriters and was the Founder of the CT Chapter of AAHU. Besides his wife he is survived by two sons; Neal Feldman of Salem, OR., and Sean Griffin of Danbury, CT.; two daughters Lori Scott of Deltona, FL., and Leslie Siraco of Wakefield, MA.; and a brother Nikos Mikalis of Ashland, OR; also survived by seven grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Friday morning at 11 o'clock at the Guilford Funeral Home, 115 Church St. Burial Services will be private. There will be calling hours on Thursday (Today) from 6 to 8 PM. Memorial contributions may be made to Norwich University, Northfield, Vermont 05663.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, LEONARD
description: PRICE-Leonard. October 20, 1997. The New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants mourns the loss of its Past President. A member since 1936, he received the Society's Distinguished Service Award in 1962 for a lifetime of dedicated service to the CPA profession. We extend deepest sympathy to his family.

title: Strikers at Columbia Meet With Officials
description: Columbia University officials held an impromptu meeting yesterday with representatives of striking clerical workers, a move that is expected to lead to new negotiations, possibly as early as today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BYRNE, MARGARET M.
description: O'BYRNE-Margaret M., of West Long Branch, NJ, Oct. 22, 1997. Wife of the late John P. O'Byrne. Mother of Reverend Charles J. O'Byrne, Dr. Margaret G. O'Byrne, Deidre O'Byrne, and Patricia O'Byrne. Sister of Elizabeth T. Koch and Mary Ann Fortunato. Grandmother of Melina & Mariah Mastrodimos. Visitation Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM, at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Ave., Red Bank, New Jersey. Funeral mass Sat., 9:30AM, at St. Michael's R.C. Church, West End, N.J. Interment to follow in Mount Olivet Cemetery, Middletown, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Vincent de Paul Society, c/o St. Michael's RC Church, 960 Ocean Ave., West End, NJ 07740.

title: Gretzky's Wife Hurt As Glass Breaks Out
description: Wayne Gretzky's wife, Janet Jones, was taken by ambulance to a Manhattan hospital last night with a concussion and a cut lower lip after being struck by a pane of heavy, treated glass that fell from the boards around the rink during the Rangers' game against Chicago at Madison Square Garden.

title: President Plans Energy Savings In a Moderate Step on Warming
description: President Clinton today outlined a moderate program to fight global warming, saying that it would be painless and even economically beneficial but that it must be carried out quickly to be effective.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, ANITA
description: ROSENBLATT-Anita. Of Westwood, New Jersey. Left us October 22, 1997. Beloved wife of Harry, devoted mother of Rachel Shipman and Deborah Rosenblatt, adored mother-in-law of Dr. Barry Shipman, dear sister of Helen Weissman, Maxine Siegel and Marcia Kaplan, loving grandmother of Dr. David Shipman and Lana Shipman. Services ''GuttermanMusicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey, Friday, 1 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REGAN, OPAL A.
description: REGAN-Opal A., 89, of NYC and Baldwin, beloved mother of MaryPat Hennelly, Linda Regan Basedow and Anne Milke; loving grandmother of Childre Felicetta, Erin DeStefano, Lisa Edick, John Basedow, Jennifer and Lauren Milke; devoted great grandmother of Tabitha and Stephen Foster. Funeral services at Weigand's Funeral Home, 2283 Grand Ave, Baldwin, NY, Friday, October 24 from 2-5PM and 7-10PM. A funeral mass will be offered at St. Christopher's Church, 11 Gale Avenue, Baldwin, 9:45AM, on Saturday. Interment at St. Charles Cemetery.

title: Israeli Repression Makes Arab Terror Inevitable; Europe Analogy Misses
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAXTER, THEODORA TUOMEY
description: BAXTER - Theodora Tuomey, Lady of The Holy Sepulchre, on October 21, 1997 in Princeton, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Robert Byrne Baxter and dear mother of Anne B. Humes, Elaine B. Tracy, brother Robert B. Baxter OFM, Conv, Julie Baxter, William E. Baxter, Clare Baxter, Margaret B. Helmig and James E. Baxter. Also surviving are 14 grandchildren and her brother Robert N. Tuomey. Mass of Christian Burial, will be celebrated 11 AM, Friday, October 24, at Saint Paul's Church, Princeton, NJ. Interment will follow at Princeton Cemetery. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to The Baxter Pavilion of Good Samaritan Hospital, West Islip, New York 11795.

title: Metro Matters; City Hall's Fragile Babies Seem to Be Caseworkers
description: SARCASM from the bench is almost always a discouraging sign. After all, if the judges found your arguments compelling, why would they be making fun of them?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARZON, JULIO M.
description: GARZON-Julio M., 92, newspaper editor and USIA official, died on October 19. Born in Bogota, from 1925 to 1958 Mr. Garzon was Sports Editor & Managing Editor of the Spanish daily ''La Prensa'' of New York. From 1958 to 1971 he was Director of the Latin American Branch of the Press and Publications Service at the United States Information Agency. He was a founder of the InterAmerican Press Association. He retired to Florida in 1971 and was active in inter-American activities. Mr. Garzon was awarded the Maria Moors Cabot Gold Medal of the Columbia University School of Journalism, and was named a life member of the American Society of Newspaper Editors. Mr. Garzon is survived by his wife of sixtythree years, Manuela; two daughters, Maria Garzon of Los Angeles and Laura Wyman of Washington, D.C; three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. For further information: All Care Cremation and Funeral Service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGSOHN, MAX. MIGDAL OHR
description: SELIGSOHN-Max. Migdal Ohr Institutions in Israel and American Friends of Migdal Ohr deeply mourn the passing of Max Seligsohn, father of Gerald Seligsohn, Board Member of American Friends of Migdal Ohr. We express our condolences to wife, Selma, and grandchildren, Lisa and Danny. May the A-lmighty comfort the family in their time of deep bereavement and may they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Yitzchok Dovid Grossman Dean and Founder, Migdal Ohr Morris Talansky Chairman of the Board Max Thurm, President Shalom Siegfried, Exec. Director

title: 3 Big Oil Companies Register Increases in Operating Profits
description: Three big American oil companies -- Mobil, Chevron, and Phillips Petroleum -- reported increases in their operating results for the third quarter yesterday that exceeded analysts' expectations, following solid reports by other energy giants earlier this week.

title: The Pop Life; 96 Tears? Still Flowing
description: ''Tell Tom Hanks to get a hold of me and I'll give him a really good story about an American rock-and-roll group that had a No. 1 hit when nobody believed in them,'' said ? (pronounced Question Mark), the leader of ? and the Mysterians, a band that in 1966 had an even bigger hit than the fictitious group in the Tom Hanks movie ''That Thing You Do.'' It was called ''96 Tears,'' and not only is it still played on the radio today but it is also an important precursor of punk rock, a garage-rock classic and an oft-cited example of the use of Farfisa organ in rock.

title: Excerpt From Clinton Comments on Global Warming
description: Following is an excerpt from remarks by President Clinton today to the National Geographic Society on the proposal for stabilizing industrialized nations' release of gases that may cause global warming, as recorded by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company:

title: Currents; TILES -- Tough, Suave Glass
description: Decorators can be their own worst enemies at show houses -- giving away their best trade secrets as they stage their most stylish tricks. Here are the names, addresses and numbers behind ideas at the French Designer Showhouse, 49 East 67th Street (through Nov. 16).

title: KEVCO TO BUY SHELTER COMPONENTS FOR $136.5 MILLION
description: Kevco Inc. of Fort Worth agreed to buy the Shelter Components Corporation of Elkhart, Ind., for $17.50 a share, or $136.5 million. Kevco said the deal would make it the top United States supplier of hardware, fasteners, doors, plumbing and wood components used in manufactured homes and recreational vehicles. Shelter's shares jumped $2.3125, to $17.25. Kevco's rose $2.25, to $14.75.

title: Law Publishing Merger Planned
description: American Lawyer Group, now owned by U.S. Equity Partners L.P., an equity fund managed and partly financed by Wasserstein Perella Group, the investment banking firm, said yesterday it would acquire the National Law Publishing Company, creating the country's leading publisher of legal news.

title: Do You Believe In Magic? Yes and No
description: The legendary escape artist Harry Houdini, who delighted in exposing fraudulent spiritualists, is a significant character in ''Fairy Tale: A True Story,'' but he's not the only magician connected with this enchanting family film. The director Charles Sturridge and the screenwriter Ernie Contreras, who collaborated on ''Fairy Tale,'' have executed a deft feat of spiritual sleight of hand by making a film that asserts a belief in magic, then gently refutes that belief and ends up having it both ways.

title: Scratch That Power Shower
description: BE honest. Do you sincerely need an enormous room with a walk-in power shower and a galaxy of designer toiletries, a king-size bed, a club lounge with complimentary cocktails? Would it be a great hardship to forgo having your bed turned down with a good-night chocolate on the pillow? How often do you use the hotel pool, fitness center or 24-hour butler service?

title: Excerpts From Missing Logs Of Gulf War Are Discovered
description: The Defense Department, which announced last year that classified chemical-detection logs from the 1991 Persian Gulf war were missing, has found lengthy excerpts from the logs in the home of an Army officer, officials said today. A criminal investigation of the officer is now under way.

title: Privacy in H.I.V. Reporting
description: The Centers for Disease Control makes a good case for mandatory reporting of all cases of H.I.V. infection. But any reporting plan must protect the privacy of infected individuals.

title: OMNIQUIP ASKS TO RENEGOTIATE PURCHASE OF FIGGIE UNIT
description: Figgie International Inc. said yesterday that Omniquip International Inc. had asked it to lower the sale price of $150 million for an aerial-platform business after the unit's third-quarter earnings fell. Omniquip agreed in July to buy Figgie's Snorkel unit, which makes aerial fire equipment and work platforms, for $150 million and assumed debt. Figgie said soft sales of platforms contributed to a decline in third-quarter earnings. Shares of Figgie, which is based in Willoughby, Ohio, fell $1, to $13.6875, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Omniquip, based in Port Washington, Wis., fell 62.5 cents, to $18.875.

title: At Toyota, 10% Share Is Viewed As a Start
description: HIROSHI OKUDA is talking ''Global 10'' again, which means trouble for the world's auto manufacturers. Global 10 was the 1980's battle cry of the Toyota Motor Corporation, which aimed for a 10 percent share of the global market. But in the early 90's, as trade tensions with the United States flared and Toyota floundered, the slogan was quietly abandoned.

title: House Again Delays Vote on Money for Amtrak
description: The House of Representatives failed for a second day in a row to vote on a bill that is needed to release $2.3 billion that is supposed to pay for new high-speed Amtrak trains.

title: An Elaborate Parade of Double-Entendres
description: Something shocking happens toward the end of the endless-seeming first act of ''Triumph of Love,'' the new musical that opened last night at the Royale Theater. By that time, if you're lucky, your feelings have graduated from irritation to numbness before the flat-footed parade of raunchy double-entendres and double takes that give new meaning to the phrase ''low comedy.'' How many botanical puns about sex organs can you take, after all, before your theatergoer's response system shuts down in self-defense?

title: GOLF: ROUNDUP -- Las Vegas Invitational; Waldorf Sinks 8 Birdies
description: Wine collecting is one of Duffy Waldorf's hobbies, but he spent today collecting birdies.

title: Art in Review
description: John Marin

title: A Plunge in Hong Kong Shakes Markets
description: A plunge in the Hong Kong stock market, touched off by an attack on the local currency, shook financial markets around the world yesterday.

title: The Small-Schools Battle
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has been warned before that advocates of the small-school movement suspected him of planning to undermine them. Those suspicions intensified when it was disclosed that New York City's Board of Education had secretly considered a plan to diminish small schools' autonomy, set strict limits on school size and undercut creative staffing arrangements that many of the schools have found helpful. Foundations and community groups were thrown into panic, worried that the Chancellor was about to shut off an education experiment that many communities have found fruitful.

title: A Murder Trial About More Than a Nanny
description: Every working parent's deepest fear has a new face: one with a milkmaid's wholesome roundness, clear blue eyes and a broad, serene brow.

title: Herbert W. Whiteman Jr., 61; Banker Aided Social Causes
description: Herbert W. Whiteman Jr., who began his professional life as a civil engineer and in 1977 became the first black to be named a vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died Saturday at Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 61 years old.

title: Family Fare
description: A Weekend Of Haunting

title: A Bitter Rivalry That Shaped History
description: MUTUAL CONTEMPT

title: Politics at Separate Schools For Whitman and McGreevey
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman basked in the political star power of her fellow moderate Republican, Gen. Colin Powell, today, appearing at Nottingham High School here in an event billed as completely nonpolitical even though the heat of the gubernatorial race managed to seep through.

title: It's a Boy But There's Um, a Hitch
description: ''Twilight of the Golds'' was broadcast on the Showtime cable channel this year. Following are excerpts from John J. O'Connor's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 21. The film opens today in Manhattan.

title: Two 24-6 Victories in Bridge Keep the Americans Ahead
description: All four United States teams stayed among the leaders in the qualifying stage of the world team championships here today and are likely to reach the playoffs Sunday.

title: Classroom Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Living Beside Water Really Means Life on the Edge
description: Anne Galjour, the writer and performer of ''Alligator Tales,'' is like a pitcher with a painfully slow windup. She eventually throws some interesting curves. But you have to spend an awfully long time waiting for the delivery.

title: Photo Helps in Arrest Of Suspect in Rapes
description: A rapist struck twice last month, using the same method, the police said: following victims from subway stations and attacking them at knifepoint in desolate areas of Queens and Brooklyn. When the two women looked through police photographs and identified the same man as their assailant, the police distributed the suspect's picture widely.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Hong Kong Stock Drop Unnerves Global Markets

title: Hong Kong Jitters Send Dollar To 2-Week High Against Yen
description: The dollar climbed to a two-week high against the yen yesterday as currency dealers grew nervous about investing in Asia after the Hong Kong stock index plunged overnight.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; PATH Is Busier on Weekends
description: Weekend PATH ridership increased 6 percent in 1996 and is growing at the same rate this year, mainly because of new residential development along the Jersey City and Hoboken waterfronts, officials said yesterday. Starting this weekend, there will be one more train per hour on the line that runs from Journal Square in Jersey City to 33d Street in Manhattan, said Michael P. DePallo, director of PATH service for the Port Authority. Those trains will also no longer stop in Hoboken, he said, shaving 8 to 10 minutes off the trip.

title: Residential Real Estate; Luxury Assisted Living On the Upper West Side
description: Hoping to capture a segment of Manhattan's growing elderly population, developers are converting an apartment hotel on the Upper West Side into luxury rental housing that will provide tenants with services and help with daily chores.

title: HOUSE APPROVES TAX-FREE SAVINGS FOR SCHOOL COSTS
description: Moving on a Republican showcase proposal, the House today approved tax-free savings accounts that supporters say will give parents more control over their children's education by helping them pay for private school tuition, tutoring and home computers.

title: Levittown, Cut Down By Ridicule
description: ''Wonderland,'' a satirical documentary about Levittown, the Long Island planned community that is just now celebrating its 50th anniversary, has some amusing moments, but the kind of laughter it provokes has a queasy edge.

title: Dallas Tower to Be Sold
description: The Crescent Real Estate Equities Company and the Trizec Hahn Corporation said today that they had agreed to acquire Bank One Center, a 10-year-old, 60-story Dallas office tower, from affiliates of the Teacher Retirement System of Texas and the Cigna Corporation for about $238 million. Crescent, based in Fort Worth, is a real estate investment trust. Trizec Hahn is based in Toronto.

title: Overruling Justice Dept., Judge Clears Path for Long Island Hospital Systems' Merger
description: Over the objections of the Justice Department, a Federal judge has cleared the way for the merger of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore Health Systems, hospital officials said tonight.

title: A More Petulant Than Headstrong Hedda
description: Ever since Ibsen wrote it in 1890, the role of Hedda Gabler has been a great lure for actresses in much the same way Hamlet has been for actors. Whatever else Ibsenism did for the feminist cause, it certainly gave women some of the best parts in dramatic literature since Shakespeare, and none is more complicated than the pistol-packing daughter of General Gabler.

title: EASTERN BANK IN DEAL TO BUY EMERALD ISLE BANCORP
description: The Eastern Bank Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a rival Massachusetts bank, Emerald Isle Bancorp Inc., for $33 a share, or $80 million. Emerald Isle's shares surged 25 percent, gaining $6.375, to $31.875. Emerald Isle, based in Quincy, Mass., is the holding company for Hibernia Savings Bank, which operates nine branches with total assets of $444 million. Eastern Bank, based in Lynn, Mass., operates 32 branches with total assets of $2 billion.

title: Giuliani Campaign Pays Penalty Again Over Contributions
description: For the second time in two months, the staff of the city's Campaign Finance Board has accused the re-election campaign of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of accepting contributions larger than city law permits.

title: A Walk in the Woods Explores the Layers of Love
description: With ''Woud'' (forest), an astonishing and dream-like meditation on the ordeal of love, Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker proves again to be one of the few truly experimental choreographers around.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISS, WILMER
description: WEISS - Wilmer. East Coast friends, colleagues and admirers of Wilmer Weiss: Wilmer Weiss Memorial Evening Zoom Studio, 632 Broadway, 8th floor, 7-9PM Monday, October 27.

title: One-Woman Standoff at 'Roby Ridge'
description: Shirley Ann Allen peers occasionally through the back window of her green farmhouse. The camouflaged state troopers, hiding in her woods for more than a month now, hope she cannot see them. If she steps onto her deck for even a few seconds, without her shotgun, they plan to take her away for a court-ordered psychiatric exam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLAZER, GUSTAVE
description: GLAZER-Gustave. Beloved husband of the late Dora. Loving father of Janet Glazer of Manhattan and Fred D. Glazer of Minneapolis, MN. Services Friday, 11AM, Riverside Chapels, 76 Street at Amsterdam Avenue, N.Y.C.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLERSBERG, ZINA
description: ADLERSBERG-Zina, died peacefully on October 21, 1997. Singer and voice teacher, known professionally as Zinaida Alvers. Beloved wife of the late Dr. David Adlersberg. Loving mother of Margaret and Mark Berger. Devoted grandmother of Josh and David Berger (Tracey Altman). Dear great grandmother of Tashi. Service on Friday, 1:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to your favorite charity.

title: For Strangers in Brazil, A Sense of Endless Loss
description: Recent political history in Brazil, expatriation, timeless human frailty and the inevitability of fate -- captured in the melancholy music of the Portuguese fado -- color ''Foreign Land,'' a small, taut drama that opens today at Anthology Film Archives in the East Village.

title: King Njoya's Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Jewish holiday of Simhath Torah, which ends the annual cycle of the public reading of the Torah, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Backs Are the Basics In Giants' Passing Game
description: The little swing pass to a running back who has drifted out of the backfield to the right or left of the quarterback is a part of every pro football team's playbook. With many teams, it is no more than a safety valve, a last option when all the receivers downfield are covered.

title: Stanley Williams, 72, Teacher Of Top Male Ballet Dancers
description: Stanley Williams, an internationally renowned teacher of male ballet dancers, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Confined, Pol Pot Tells Of Feeling 'Bit Bored'
description: Confined to a wooden hut with nothing to read and nothing to do, Pol Pot, the man who created the Khmer Rouge ''killing fields'' in Cambodia in the 1970's, says he is getting bored.

title: Loughlin vs. Stuyvesant
description: To the Editor:

title: Firm Got Pact After It Aided Mayor in Race
description: A small law firm that had tried unsuccessfully to win a valuable contract to represent the city hospitals was awarded two such contracts by the Giuliani administration after the firm and its partners gave heavily to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaigns, records show.

title: Dominoes in Asia's Financial Crisis
description: Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines, Indonesia all these strong economies suffered significant currency devaluations and bear markets in the last six months. With the collapse of Hong Kong's stock market yesterday, have the last economic dominoes fallen in Asia?

title: At Home Abroad; A Conversation With Milosevic
description: ''We Serbs have a national characteristic,'' Slobodan Milosevic said. ''We resent being pushed.''

title: Art in Review
description: 'The Hansa Gallery (1952-1959) Revisited'

title: South Africa Panel Recommends Aid for Apartheid-Era Victims
description: After listening to 2,000 victims of apartheid-era abuses tell their stories and studying the written submission of 10,000 others, South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission recommended today that the Government spend about $650 million on reparations.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Optimism From Whitman
description: Expressing cautious optimism about her re-election bid, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today played down recent polls showing her locked in a close race with her Democratic opponent. But she acknowledged that voters were sending her a strong message to address their concerns over property taxes and auto insurance.

title: John W. Hall, Historian of Japan, Dies at 81
description: John Whitney Hall, the missionaries' child who became a pioneer in the field of Japanese studies and one of the most respected historians of Japan of his generation, died on Tuesday at his home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 81.

title: Use of Placebo Is Ended for H.I.V. Study in Africa
description: A team of researchers at Johns Hopkins University has abandoned plans to use dummy pills in an experiment on Ethiopian women who are pregnant and infected with the AIDS virus. The use of the dummy pills as a placebo has renewed intense debate over the ethics of a series of federally financed studies in the third world.

title: Lot Owner's Dispute With Transportation Chief Widens
description: A dispute between a Bronx parking lot owner and city transportation officials, which began three weeks ago over a sign in the street, grew nastier and more tangled yesterday as the city accused the owner of operating without a permit and the owner accused officials of abusing their powers and trying to cover up their misdeeds.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Public Notice'

title: Trading on the Pollution Exchange; Global Warming Plan Would Make Emissions a Commodity
description: If President Clinton has his way, rights to spew carbon dioxide into the atmosphere will eventually be traded by energy producers, utilities and even investors on exchanges the way pork bellies, German marks and interest rate futures change hands today.

title: Metro Business; Company Settles Suit Alleging Health Bias
description: The Heisei Minerals Corporation has agreed to pay $170,000 to a former secretary who contended that she was dismissed after doctors discovered she had a brain tumor, according to documents filed yesterday by the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BOEING CO., Seattle, received a $475 million order from Australia's Qantas Airways Ltd. for three of its 747 passenger planes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRONHEIM, DAVID
description: BRONHEIM-David. The lawyers and staff of Rosen & Reade, LLP are deeply saddened by the sudden death of David Bronheim, loving father of Elizabeth Bronheim Semler, one of our associates. We send our heartfelt sympathy to Elizabeth, her brother Jeffry and all the members of their family.

title: Report Confirms Decay In New York Schools
description: H. Carl McCall, the State Comptroller, issued a study yesterday that tries to tie together many findings on the state of the schools in an effort to persuade voters to approve a $2.4 billion bond act on Election Day intended to repair schools around the state.

title: Delta Reports 6.8% Increase In Earnings
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. said today that its earnings rose 6.8 percent in the fiscal first quarter, beating estimates, on higher air fares and increased traffic.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We live between two terrors: one of the armed groups and the other the

title: Memorial for Gallagher
description: A memorial service for Wes Gallagher, former general manager and president of The Associated Press, will be held Nov. 7 at 11 A.M. at the Associated Press Building, 50 Rockefeller Plaza. Mr. Gallagher died Oct. 11 in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 86.

title: Portraits That Conceal Identity
description: Sometimes what you don't see in a painting matters as much as what you do.

title: Movie Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Running times and ratings of films are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLISS, PHILIP
description: BLISS-Philip. Age 82. Formerly of Brooklyn, died on October 21, 1997, in Los Angeles. Beloved husband of Rose. Loving father of Elaine and David Levy, Susan and Richard Levine and the late David. Devoted grandfather of Lori, Dana, Wendy, Jonas and Robin. Great grandfather of six. Brother of Sylvia Cohen, Mac and Jules Bliss. Private services were held October 22 at Hillside Cemetery in Los Angeles.

title: Sex, Graft and Asbestos: School Investigator's Biggest Cases
description: Following are some cases Edward F. Stancik has pursued as the school system's chief investigator.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Neurologist Says He Tentatively Diagnosed Epilepsy in Driver of Bus in Fatal Accident
description: The bus driver involved in a fatal runaway crash on Fifth Avenue, who died on Wednesday, had been given a tentative diagnosis of epilepsy after the crash and was put on medication to control epileptic seizures, his neurologist said yesterday.

title: Daly Trying Again to Remold a Franchise
description: When Chuck Daly was with the Nets, he liked to refer to himself as ''the oldest coach in captivity.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPERSTEIN, WALTER M.
description: COOPERSTEIN-Walter M. Of Boca Raton, FL., on October 22, 1997. Beloved husband of Pennie. Loving father of Chuck Cooperstein and Karen Lieberman. Adored son of Yetta Garfield. Cherished grandfather of four. Dear brother of Jane Wyker. Services held in Boca Raton, FL. For information Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, FL.

title: Microsoft Is Being Punished for Its Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Both Parties Were Assisted By Nonprofit Groups in 1996
description: Despite the mountain of documents and videotapes that the Clinton White House has surrendered to investigators looking into campaign finance abuses in the 1996 election, a touch of mystery still surrounds a dinner held in the Blue Room of the White House on July 12, 1996.

title: The Visit of Jiang Zemin
description: As Jiang Zemin travels across the United States next week, he cannot expect the enthusiastic reception that greeted the last Chinese leader to make such a public passage through America. When Deng Xiaoping barnstormed through Washington, Houston, Atlanta and Seattle in early 1979, it was just months after Washington had established full diplomatic relations with Beijing for the first time since 1949, and the mood was one of almost euphoric curiosity. Deng's easy spontaneity, identification with market reform and pithy comments charmed American audiences.

title: The Next Bigotry: Privilege by Genetic Perfection
description: Imagine an Orwellian story presented with a cool, eerie precision like Peter Greenaway's and you have some sense of ''Gattaca,'' a handsome and fully imagined work of cautionary futuristic fiction. Its subject is bigotry, though the races and sexes appear to enjoy equal freedom, which is to say not much. The film's world revolves around strict conformity at places like the Gattaca Corporation, where employees wear somber uniforms and stern, serious expressions -- except for one man with a discreetly worried look: Vincent Freeman (Ethan Hawke), Gattaca's house imposter.

title: Microsoft Is Being Punished for Its Success; The Browser's Ascent
description: To the Editor:

title: Developer Buys Blue Cross Tower on Third Ave.
description: Playing an ace in the hole, a real estate developer, Charles S. Cohen, yesterday snatched the midtown Manhattan headquarters of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, setting into motion a series of large-scale shifts that could well raise the fortunes of other property owners.

title: Kinder, Gentler Aliens From Space (A Tip: Be Wary)
description: For a while there, space aliens were benevolent, advanced and gentle as kittens (''E.T.,'' ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind''). More recently, they've been almost inconceivably evil, and humans who think otherwise are shown to be fools (the skyscraper-roof New Age partygoers in ''Independence Day,'' just about everybody in ''Mars Attacks!''). Now ''Earth: Final Conflict,'' a syndicated series that presents its third episode tonight (at 9 on Channel 11 in New York), makes the question of the true nature of aliens its theme. The characters and original story are by none other than Gene Roddenberry, the creator of ''Star Trek,'' who died six years ago today.

title: Whitman Plays Down the Polls That Show Her in a Tight Race
description: Expressing cautious optimism about her re-election bid, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today played down recent polls showing her locked in a close race with her Democratic opponent. But she acknowledged that voters were sending her a strong message to address their concerns over property taxes and auto insurance.

title: Seeking Glint Of Urban Gold In the Shadows; At Self-Storage Auctions, Treasure Is a Used TV Set
description: One by one, they thrust their flashlights into the darkness of a cluttered self-storage room, angling cones of light onto a mobile IV pole near the front, a pair of mattresses propped against the right wall, an electric fan way in the back.

title: Johnson Promises To Strut His Stuff
description: He was preening like a movie star awaiting a close-up, staring at the crowd as if they were his mirror. He folded his arms and mugged on the court.

title: Art in Review
description: Francis Alys

title: Thailand's Currency Flutters, And Wind Is Felt in the U.S.
description: Can the economic troubles of Thailand, a small country in Southeast Asia, really have begun the processes now causing currency turmoil through much of Asia and producing selloffs in nearly every stock market in the world?

title: Chairside With Scully, For Maybe a Final Call
description: Vin Scully is calling the World Series on radio, so turn your television set off. What are you going to miss? Replays? Sitcom promos? Charts? Pictures?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RISKIN, JACK
description: RISKIN-Jack. Jack, I will miss you, a great friend that I trusted impeccably. Andrew

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CIRKER, MINETTE
description: CIRKER-Minette October 24, 1986. In loving memory of my dear Minette, forever in my mind. Sadly missed. ''Rest My Sweet Darling'' Stanley

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Newark Bay Pit to Be Finished
description: Digging will be completed today for a 65-foot-deep pit in Newark Bay, which will be able to begin receiving mud dredged from nearby shipping channels as soon as Nov. 1, the Port Authority said yesterday. The pit will hold 1.5 million cubic yards of toxic sediments taken from the bay, the Kill Van Kull and the Arthur Kill, said Allen Morrison, a spokesman for the agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTICA, STEVAN
description: LUSTICA-Stevan of NYC on October 20, 1997 at the age of 39, after 15 years of endless battles against AIDS. His unending courage, outlook and optimism will always remain an inspiration to all who knew him. He is survived by his loving mother Edeltraud and step father Anthony Deorato, Lakewood, N.J. Devoted brothers Klaus of Seattle, Wash., Tee, Middletown, N.J., sisters Lori of Red Bank, N.J., Sharon Bachi and Deborah of S.I., NY and Susan Black of Merrick, L.I. Adored uncle of eight nephews and two nieces. He will be missed by all. Contributions can be made to the Bailey House, 180 Christopher St., N.Y.C. 10014.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Fort Dix to Process Recruits
description: The Army's processing center for new recruits will be moving from Philadelphia to Fort Dix next spring, taking along about 40 full-time employees, officials said yesterday. The move is expected to add at least $4 million a year to Burlington County's economy, according to figures supplied by the Military Entrance Processing Command.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, HERMAN ALFRED
description: PHILLIPS-Herman Alfred, 95, Physician of Miami Beach and formerly of Brooklyn, New York, died in his sleep on October 20, 1997. A graduate of CCNY and NYU-Bellevue (1928) he served his patients with skill, compassion, enormous energy and good humor for more than 50 years in NYC and Miami Beach. An avid swimmer, he realized the benefits of daily exercise and a low-fat diet in the 1930's, long before this concept was popularized, and recommended it to his patients-film stars and statesmen included. He is survived by his devoted wife Hana Giniger ''Ginny'' Phillips of Coconut Creek, Florida, a daughter, Judith Phillips Lichtenstein of NYC, two sons, Charles of Stuart, Florida and Edward of Boca Raton, Florida and five grandchildren.

title: Junichi Ueno, 87, Owner of Japanese Newspaper
description: Junichi Ueno, co-owner of Japan's second-largest daily newspaper, Asahi Shimbun, died of pneumonia at a Tokyo hospital on Sunday. He was 87 years old.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERNAN, LESLIE HADDEN
description: KERNAN-Leslie Hadden on October 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Walter Avery Kernan; mother of Anita Halton, Mary Rutherfurd, Emily Rafferty, Nancy Chamberlain, Beatrice and Charles; grandmother of Anita Halton; Leslie Coleman, Lily and Emily Rutherfurd, Nicholas and Sara Rafferty, and Katherine Chamberlain; and sister of Anita Hadden Page and the late Hamilton Hadden Jr. Funeral Mass, 10:30 A.M., Friday, October 24th, at Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Interfaith Neighbors, Inc., 247 East 82nd Street, New York, New York 10028.

title: GROUP OF MANAGERS AGREES TO BUY ECHLIN'S ACE ELECTRIC
description: The auto parts maker Echlin Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Ace Electric Company unit to a group led by the unit's managers. Terms were not disclosed. Ace Electric, based in Columbus, Kan., makes engine starting and charging system products. It has annual sales of $60 million. Its products are sold under the Ace, Mega and Accurate brand names. Proceeds from the sale will be used to pay down debt. Shares of Echlin, which is based in Branford, Conn., fell 68.75 cents yesterday, to $34.1875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Palestinians Confront Israel On Representation at U.N.
description: Reopening a diplomatic front against Israel that has been quiet for nearly five years, Palestinians are planning to challenge the Israeli Government's right to represent the people of the West Bank, Gaza and Jerusalem in the United Nations.

title: With Luck And Pluck, Devils Win In Overtime
description: The Devils had all the luck in overtime. The Canadiens had too many men on the ice, and the Devils had a man in Montreal's crease. The referee caught the Canadiens but didn't see the guilty Devil.

title: The Risks to America in Asia's Plummeting Markets
description: Correction Appended

title: Home Video
description: When small, independently produced films like ''Shine'' and ''Breaking the Waves'' earned myriad Oscar nominations last spring, appreciation shot up for the good little movie that most people miss in theaters but often discover on tape. This month there are at least three new examples on videocassette, as well as a fourth film that may miss the mark from a critic's point of view but certainly can't be faulted for a lack of independence.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Sentence in Baby's Death
description: A 17-year-old who pleaded guilty in August to causing the death of her newborn daughter was sentenced yesterday to four years in prison.

title: Classical Music and Dance Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: As Cameras Whir, The Bronte Novels Come Into Focus
description: Just four months after ''Jane Eyre'' appeared in print, Charlotte Bronte's publisher wrote her with news of a London stage version, which added the lurid subtitle ''The Secrets of Thornfield Manor.'' Charlotte replied that she had no interest in seeing what she guessed would be ''a rather afflicting spectacle to the author of that work.''

title: G.M. Sales Hurt by Shortage of Rail Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation said this week that its United States sales would decline this month and perhaps the rest of the year because of a shortage of rail cars.

title: >New York And Its Wealth Of Nature (Really!)
description: Follow Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn with enough persistence, and eventually you wind up at Floyd Bennett Field. This is the end of the line, an abandoned airport where the wind swirls and whips, disturbing the ghosts of Amelia Earhart, Howard Hughes and Wiley Post, the fliers who helped make Floyd Bennett Field a symbol of the romance of aviation. Now it sits on the far corner of New York City's map, a highly unlikely candidate to pop up on a short list of natural wonders.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Novartis Sales Jump 25.6% in Quarter
description: Novartis A.G., the world's largest drug maker, reported a 25.6 percent rise in third-quarter sales, helped by rising drug revenue and a weaker Swiss franc. Sales rose to 7.289 billion Swiss francs ($4.88 billion) from a pro forma 5.802 billion francs, as pharmaceutical sales rose 32.4 percent.

title: Microsoft Is Being Punished for Its Success; Competitor or Bully?
description: To the Editor:

title: Saga With Tight Corsets And a Loose Structure
description: Pierre Augustin Caron de Beaumarchais, the 18th-century rake, playwright and secret agent famous for accomplishments as varied as inventing a durable watch movement and writing ''The Barber of Seville'' and ''The Marriage of Figaro,'' was undoubtedly a more compelling figure than the conniving aristocrat at the heart of Edouard Molinaro's lavish new costume drama. The director of ''La Cage Aux Folles'' brings broadly conventional strokes to the convoluted story of Beaumarchais's adventures.

title: In Fury, Hamas Leader Masks His Intentions
description: In Gaza, the walls are still the major distributor of news, and the dominant message now is Sheik Ahmad Yassin. His stenciled visage looks down from every plastered wall, alongside slogans like ''Fatah Greets Yassin!''

title: '97 WORLD SERIES: GAME 5
description: FLORIDA 8

title: Pay, Then Pray: The Cavs Have Bought a Whirlwind
description: Shawn Kemp was suspended this week by the National Basketball Association for leaving the bench during a recent preseason game fight, which should make make the Cleveland Cavaliers feel mighty secure about their $107 million investment in a player they have banked on leading them deep into the playoffs the next seven years.

title: Brazil to Break Up and Sell Phone Giant
description: Brazil will privatize and split its giant telecommunications holding company, Telcomunicacoes Brasileiras S.A., or Telebras, in the first half of 1998, the Communications Minister, Sergio Motta, said today.

title: Antiques; Ephemera That Still Work Magic
description: ''A poster has got to be able to make you see, do and feel -- all in a second,'' says Richard Barclay, one of the authors of the new book ''Collecting Prints and Posters'' (Reed International, London). Mr. Barclay should know: he has been a poster consultant to Christie's in London for 11 years. He is currently in Manhattan, readying the 221 lots in Christie's first New York sale devoted entirely to 19th and 20th-century posters, scheduled for Dec. 10 at Christie's East.

title: Xerox Earnings Jump 28% As Digital Copiers Sell Well
description: The Xerox Corporation said today that earnings rose 28 percent in the third quarter as higher sales of newer digital copiers and printers, as well as a reorganized sales force, more than offset the rising dollar's effect on foreign results.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; E-Z Pass Comes to Tunnels
description: After the E-Z Pass system makes its debut at the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels on Tuesday, all six Hudson River crossings between New Jersey and New York will be equipped with the popular electronic fare collection system that lets drivers roll through the toll booth without stopping.

title: Senators Move To Override Item Vetoes
description: A Senate committee approved a bill today that would override President Clinton's line item veto of dozens of military construction projects.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: ELECTRIC CAR'S JOURNEY -- For two decades, electric cars have been seen as a ''someday'' kind of technology. But yesterday, a pioneer of electric car design drove a consumer-ready model from Boston to Manhattan. B3.

title: In the Land Of Lawsuits, No Apologies
description: THIS hardly qualifies as a world-shaking brainstorm, but it is startling sometimes to see how leaden bureaucracy, coupled perhaps with America's passion for lawsuits, can get in the way of human instincts for decent behavior.

title: Holders Approve Cordiant Split
description: Cordiant P.L.C. said yesterday that its shareholders had approved its planned split, which will create separate operating companies centered on Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide and Bates Worldwide.

title: Lisbon, Enchanted City Of Memories and Dreams
description: With its fey characters, its keen sense of place, its suggestion of some poetic insight into life with a capital L, ''Taxi Lisboa'' is one of those movies that aspire to captivate with sentimental charm.

title: Accounts
description: -- Ecomat Inc., Mamaroneck, N.Y., to the GFS/Levinson Group, New York, as the first agency to handle advertising for the cleaner and laundromat franchiser. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: Deaf Peddlers Were Tortured With Stun Guns, Enforcer Says
description: A brother and sister, said by officials to be two leaders of a ring that forced deaf Mexican immigrants to peddle trinkets in the subways and streets, used an electric stun gun to torture some who did not sell enough or who had tried to escape, an admitted ring enforcer said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the treaty-mandated destruction of heavy weapons in Yugoslavia, Croatia and Bosnia misstated the value of an American-financed program to rearm Bosnia's Muslim-Croat federation. It is $400 million, not $10 million

title: The Case That Haunts Sharpton
description: It has been nine years since the Rev. Al Sharpton and other advisers of a black teen-ager named Tawana Brawley helped make a national cause out of her allegations that a group of white men had abducted and raped her in Wappingers Falls, N.Y., and then left her covered in feces with racial slurs scrawled on her skin.

title: Spare Times
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUBKOFF, DOROTHEA BARY
description: SUBKOFF-Dorothea Bary. On October 21, 1997 at home. Beloved sister of Leona, James and Jeanne. Devoted aunt of Richard and Clair, Michael, David and Reva, Jeffrey and Margaret, Andrew and Karen, and great-aunt. A New York City school teacher for many years, Dot was bright, spirited and had a wonderful sense of humor. Her family and friends will miss her dearly. A memorial service is planned for late November.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When the reconstructed concert hall at the John F. Kennedy Center opened last night, with new acoustics and new provisions for the handicapped, the National Symphony Orchestra's music director, LEONARD SLATKIN, was joined at the podium by the brother of the hall's namesake, Senator EDWARD M. KENNEDY of Massachusetts, who conducted John Philip Sousa's ''Washington Post March.'' NADINE BROZAN

title: Correction; Correction: Put-Call Ratio
NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISCHLER, ESTHER
description: TISCHLER-Esther. Of Somerset, New Jersey, formerly of NYC, died October 22, 1997. She retired from the U.S. Corps. of Engineers after 35 years. She is survived by her sisters Ann Newman and Ruth Piltz Bell and many nieces and nephews. Graveside services are Friday, King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ. The family will receive friends on Saturday and Sunday at the home of Arlyne and Barry Zalaznick, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Blame Monetarists for Asia's Boom and Bust
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 9
description: Game Of The Week

title: CHRONICLE
description: To say that this is a memorable time in the life of VALERIE SOLTI, the widow of Sir Georg Solti, the conductor who died last month, would surely be an understatement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUTZER, SEYMOUR, M.D.
description: SCHUTZER-Seymour, M.D. A most compassionate man, dedicated and caring physician, a true friend. Thank you for taking such good care of us all. Our thoughts are with those for whom you cared. The Schur Family

title: Algeria Votes, Recalling Fateful Election of 1992
description: Twelve-year-old Fawzi Bouchmecham appeared unsure how to react today as he described watching his father die. His awkward smile sent one message, while his pleading eyes sent another.

title: Nukus Journal; In Plain English, These Uzbeks Are Going Places
description: Eager students at the Progress Center here told a recent visitor that their favorite authors include Mark Twain, Charles Dickens and Robert Louis Stevenson. Had they ever read anything by Shakespeare?

title: Metro Business; Moving to One Penn Plaza
description: Buck Consultants, a financial planning and consulting firm, has signed a 10-year lease worth $25 million to move into a 66,210-square-foot space that covers two floors of One Penn Plaza, the brokers of the deal said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRASK, FREDERICK K., JR.
description: TRASK-Frederick K., Jr. Ninetyone, of Carmel Valley Manor, Carmel, CA., and Underhill, VT, died Thursday, Oct. 16 of heart failure. He was the husband of Sarah W. Trask and the late Margaret P. Trask. Mr. Trask was a founder and partner of Payson & Trask (NYC) venture capital with Joan Whitney Payson. He was also a founding director of the New York Mets (baseball). He graduated from Groton School and Harvard University in 1930. During World War II Mr. Trask was a Lt. Col. in the U.S. Army in Washington, D.C. with the Office of Contract Settlement. Mr. Trask was a longstanding trustee of U.S. Trust Co. of New York and a director of General Reinsurance Corp., the former Great Northern Nekoosa Corp., and New York Hospital-Cornell. He was instrumental in forming the New York-Cornell Medical Center. Besides his wife he is survived by one son, Frederick K. Trask III of Denver, CO, and three daughters, Jacquelin T. Duffek of Eastham, MA., Jane T. Rosen of Stillriver, MA., and Frances T. Wozencraft of Sun River, OR. He is also survived by 13 grandchildren. A memorial service will be held for Mr. Trask in the summer of 1998 in Vermont. Contributions may be sent to the Deborah Rawson Memorial Library, C/O Dee Dee Jameson, RR 3, Box 439, Jericho, Vermont 05465, or to a charity of the donor's choice.

title: INSIDE
description: Taxpayers' Advocate

title: Report Faults Energy Dept. On Managing Nuclear Site
description: The Energy Department spent $50 million on a nuclear waste processing plant in Ohio that was supposed to cost only $16 million, but even before it could handle radioactive materials, the heart of the plant was destroyed in an accident because of poor planning, according to an independent report on widespread mismanagement at the department.

title: Britain Reviews Iraqi Request to Free Millions in Frozen Funds
description: The British Government says it is weighing a request by Iraq to release some of the $760 million in assets frozen in 1990 so that Baghdad can pay for a legal defense against billions of dollars of claims stemming from the Persian Gulf war.

title: Russia and Brazil Caught in Selling Surge
description: What had been an Asian problem looks more and more like an emerging markets problem, as even the most buoyant of these markets, like Russia and Brazil, succumbed to a tidal wave of selling yesterday.

title: Clinton Pledges $300 Million Toward Improving Child Care
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton invited the President to her conference on child care today, and he obliged by offering a few modest proposals to alleviate parents' concerns about the cost and quality of day care centers.

title: At the Movies
description: Mel Gibson As Bad Guy

title: Sports of The Times; Jim Leyland Speaks Up For Series
description: HERE'S what's really wrong with baseball: No game in this World Series has been as compelling as the taut and pungent rage expressed by Jim Leyland before last night's latest marathon, an 8-7 victory by his Florida team over Cleveland.

title: Dismissal Leads to Protest at St. Regis Hotel
description: Workers at the St. Regis Hotel held a spontaneous protest yesterday morning after a hostess who had filed a sexual harassment complaint against a maitre d'hotel at the hotel restaurant was dismissed. The woman was rehired later yesterday.

title: Limon Troupe Draws on Both Ends of a 50-Year Run
description: The Limon Dance Company celebrated the past and the present on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater. A revival of Jose Limon's ''Orfeo,'' created in 1972, was part of the company's 50th anniversary retrospective of his work. And Donald McKayle's recent ''Heartbeats'' was both a departure from and a restating of the Limon canon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREVETTI, FRANK A.
description: PREVETTI-Frank A. Passed away on October 20, 1997 in San Jose, CA. Survived by long time companion, Janice Prevetti; sister, Petranilla Prevetti; daughters, Laurel Prevetti & Lynn Bushman; and a granddaughter, Katherine Hawn. Born June 13, 1937 and raised in Milwaukee, WI. Regional editor of T.V. Guide Magazine for 37 years in San Francisco, Seattle, Los Angeles, Merced and San Jose. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Thomas of Canterbury Catholic Church, 1522 McCoy Ave, San Jose, CA., Sunday, October 26, 1997 at 6:45 PM. In lieu of floral tributes the family prefers donations to Polycystic Kidney Research Foundation, 800-753-2873. Info: Darling & Fischer Chapel of the Hills, Los Gatos, California.

title: The Tax Man's Burden
description: Bashing the Internal Revenue Service is popular. First, Congress held one-sided hearings, with hooded witnesses serving up horror stories of being abused by the agency. Then, on Wednesday, an initially reluctant Clinton Administration agreed to a sweeping overhaul of the agency -- which includes bringing in an outside board and switching the burden of proof in tax disputes from the taxpayer to the agency.

title: 1998 Race Too Flat For Virenque's Tastes
description: The organizers of the Tour de France unveiled next year's course here today and ruined the cyclist Richard Virenque's day, even his 1998, to hear him tell it.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; Clearing up an urban misperception to attract audiences to a new performing arts center.
description: AS advertising challenges go, it would hardly seem difficult to attract audiences to a much ballyhooed, architecturally praised new $180 million performing arts center in the region where culture vultures spend more on the arts than anywhere else in America.

title: On My Mind; Saddam's Triumph
description: Mark the date: Saddam Hussein returned to Mideast political glory on Oct. 23, 1997, in a chamber of the United Nations Security Council.

title: Treasuries Soar as Investors Seek Safety in Stock Plunge
description: The prices of Treasuries rose sharply yesterday, largely because of a ''flight to quality'' by investors seeking safety in United States Government securities after the selloff on stock markets.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Chemical Maker to Be Sold
description: The International Paper Company agreed today to sell its Anchor pressroom chemicals business to Fuji Hunt Photographic Chemicals Inc. Financial terms were not disclosed. International Paper said Anchor, based in Orange Park, Fla., is part of its imaging products subsidiary. Fuji Hunt, a film chemistry unit of Japan's Fuji Photo Film Company, said it would keep Anchor management in place and operate the company as one of its subsidiaries. International Paper said it was in talks to sell the rest of its imaging operations by the end of the year.

title: Evading a Famous Father's Shadow, in New York
description: Two things are inevitably linked with the photographer Brett Weston: that he labored under the shadow of his father, the great modernist photographer Edward Weston, and that he burned all but a dozen of his own negatives near the end of his life to prevent anyone from printing from them. These are dramatic markers, and both have everything to do with artistic identity and originality. Was Brett Weston just his father's son? Or was there something in his prints that only he could do? These are the questions raised by his work.

title: Metro Business; Insurance Suit Dismissed
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice has dismissed a class action suit against the Mutual of New York insurance company, saying that several hundred thousand policyholders failed to demonstrate that losses they suffered were attributable to deception by the company.

title: Spare Times
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Diamond Merchant Found Murdered With 2 Others
description: A wholesale diamond dealer and two other men were murdered today in the merchant's modest home on a quiet street in this small middle-class suburb a few miles west of the George Washington Bridge.

title: Three Men Arrested In Bodega Killing
description: Three men were arrested yesterday in the killing of a customer on Oct. 20 at a Brooklyn bodega they were trying to rob, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Science Watch column on Oct. 14 about a molecule that appears to mimic an effect of marijuana misstated an affiliation of Dr. Daniele Piomelli, an author of the study. He works at the Neurosciences Institute in San Diego, not the Scripps Research Institute.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday showing the put-call ratio -- the daily relationship of ''put'' options to ''call'' options on the Standard & Poor's 100-issue index -- inverted the figures for Wednesday. A corrected version appears today on page D10.

title: Heaven-Sent Love With a Mean Streak
description: The third and most ordinary film from the triumvirate behind ''Shallow Grave'' and ''Trainspotting'' is a madcap romance, complete with spoiled heiress, guardian angels and hapless nice-guy hero. It melds the buoyant energy of Danny Boyle's previous direction with a plot that is pure, vintage fluff. And if that sounds too good to be true, it is: Mr. Boyle's brand of heaven-sent love story comes with a strange and whimsical mean streak. Tender thoughts and ha-ha shootings don't automatically mix.
