title: AMGEN SAYS IT WILL BUY BACK UP TO $1 BILLION IN STOCK
description: Amgen Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy back as much as $1 billion of its stock under a new repurchase program amid strong cash flow. Amgen, the world's largest independent biotechnology company, said it would conduct the program through the end of 1998. Amgen completed its last buyback program, repurchasing $450 million of stock, in the third quarter. Shares in the company, which is based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., closed at $48, up $2.0625, in Nasdaq trading of 14.2 million shares after recording a 52-week low of $44.875 early in the day.

title: SHARES OF FIRST DATA FALL 16% ON EARNINGS NEWS
description: The stock of the First Data Corporation skidded 16 percent yesterday after the company, a payment-services provider, lowered its full-year earnings expectations. First Data, based in Hackensack, N.J., said Wednesday after the financial markets closed that it expected earnings for the year to be $1.51 to $1.56 a share. Analysts had predicted $1.58 a share. First Data attributed the decline to lower-than-expected revenue growth, slow growth in noncore businesses and big investments to develop new services. The company has been spending heavily to develop electronic check acceptance and bill payment services. Shares of First Data dropped $6 yesterday, to $30.125.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICKERSON, NANCY
description: DICKERSON-Nancy. The members of the Board of Trustees of the Center for the Study of the Presidency mourn the passing of Nancy Dickerson, beloved wife of our former trustee, John C. Whitehead. This Center has long recognized Nancy's brilliant contributions to public policy, beginning as a reserach associate for the Sente Foreign Relations Committee in Washington. Thereafter, for more than three decades, she contributed significantly to public affairs in our nation's capital, pioneering as the first woman producer for CBS News, subsequently serving with NBC and founding her own television producing company. Every President of the United Sates from Eisenhower to the present has viewed Nancy Dickerson as a respected counselor. Washington's loss eight years ago was New York's gain when John Whitehead brought her here as his wife. She contributed so much to so many New York institutions. Her counsel, her grace, her understanding will long be remembered in our community, and we offer our condolences to John, whose friendship the Center continues to appreciate. Richard G. Kelley, Chairman R. Gordon Hoxie, Founder President Emeritus

title: Sunbeam Chief Says Company, Now Stable, Is Ready for Deal
description: After a tumultuous 15-month overhaul that the Sunbeam Corporation says is complete, the consumer products maker threw open its doors yesterday to ''any and all types of transactions,'' including acquisitions, or a sale or merger.

title: No Magic for Hershiser, Much Misery for Indians
description: The post-season mastery was a post-season myth. Orel Hershiser has been one of the premier post-season pitchers of his generation, but he has been far from sparkling in this World Series. That is why the Cleveland Indians are one loss away from being eliminated by the Florida Marlins. Hershiser lost his magic, and the Indians might be next.

title: Japan Securities Firms Report Lower Results
description: Japan's Big Four securities firms -- Daiwa Securities, Yamaichi Securities, Nikko Securities and Nomura Securities -- reported lower results for the first half of the 1997-98 fiscal year amid payoff scandals and falling commission rates. Of the group, Nomura reported the smallest fall in current profit. Daiwa, Yamaichi and Nikko cited sharp falls in commission rates on stock trading as well as decreased underwriting opportunities amid receding issuances.

title: Two Catchers Caught In Battle for Limelight
description: Charles Johnson and Sandy Alomar Jr. did not enter the World Series wanting to be cast in baseball's version of ''The Prince and the Pauper.''

title: Quiet Rivals Battling For a Shared Dream
description: Michelle Kwan trailed a few steps behind as Nancy Kerrigan left a practice rink here on Jan. 6, 1994, disappeared through a curtain and was clubbed on the knee by an associate of Tonya Harding. In that instant -- with Kerrigan screaming, ''Why me?'' -- figure skating changed forever. While its ice queen image reached a tawdry low, its popularity soared to an unprecedented high.

title: Nominee for I.R.S. Vows to Serve Taxpayers
description: The management consultant poised to head the Internal Revenue Service pledged today to transform the culture of the beleaguered agency to make taxpayer interests pre-eminent and to root out abusive collection methods like those disclosed in Congressional hearings this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMB, SUSAN
description: LAMB-Susan, LCSW, 61, a psychotherapist in private practice and with Jewish Family Service of Union County, died on October 22nd at her home in Plainfield, New Jersey, after a long illness. Mrs. Lamb was a licensed clinical social worker and a graduate of Hunter College, Columbia University School of Social Work, and the Institute for the Study of Psychotherapy. The Lambs maintain a second residence in Cape Elizabeth, ME. Her husband Rick Lamb, her mother Helen Frank, her brother David Freund, her sister Elizabeth Fideler, and her golden retriever, Bear survive her, along with beloved sisters-in-law, nieces and nephews. A memorial service is planned for 3 PM, on Sunday, November 2nd, at the Friends Meeting House in Plainfield, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Cancer Institute of New Jersey.

title: From Boston to 63d Street, On Single Battery Charge
description: For two decades, builders of electric cars have battled an image problem. Even their sleekest, most pollution-free offerings have been deemed too sluggish, too burdened with bulky batteries or too limited in range to ever be useful in the real world of traffic jams and superhighways.

title: Ericsson Says Profits More Than Doubled
description: Ericsson A.B. said yesterday that its third-quarter profits more than doubled as strong sales of mobile phones offset weaker growth in traditional telecommunications equipment. The company earned 2.91 billion kronor in the quarter ended on Sept. 30, or $380 million, compared with 1.38 billion kronor a year earlier. Sales rose to 40.41 billion kronor from 28.17 billion, while operating profit rose to 4.67 billion kronor from 2.11 billion.

title: Weekend Excursion; Storybook Places And Scenic Byways
description: Interstate 684 leads through northern Westchester County toward the Berkshires and beyond, a wide swath with views of distant hillsides. Autumn becomes dazzling once you reach Exit 4; by Exit 6, the itch to explore takes over. Woodlands beckon; the signs point to museums and scenic byways.

title: The Chinese Horse, A Symbol of Power
description: One of the most appealing animals in Chinese art is Night-Shining White, a well-fed hunk of a horse with a powerfully muscular chest. His name came from his luminous moon-white coat, and he was a favorite in the stable maintained by the Emperor Xuanzong, the most powerful ruler of the Tang dynasty (A.D. 618 to 907).

title: Microsoft Is Being Punished for Its Success; Marketing Prowess
description: To the Editor:

title: Tiny Objects, Grandiose Statements
description: Tom Friedman, sculptor extraordinaire, continues to endanger his eyesight by making objects of mind-boggling refinement and tininess. His fourth exhibition at the Feature gallery in SoHo contains a dozen sculptures and three works on paper -- the most pieces this 32-year-old artist, who lives in Conway, Mass., has exhibited at one time. It represents several years of his eccentrically herculean labors, often expended on the most ephemeral of materials.

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP
description: Eurocard Open

title: Inside Art
description: Rembrandt At Frick Passes

title: Records Show Clinton Made White House Calls to Donors
description: The Clinton Administration has turned over to Federal investigators telephone records showing that President Clinton made telephone calls about campaign fund-raising from the White House, including one from the Oval Office and others from his residence, White House officials said today.

title: Analysts Mixed on Philip Morris's Smoking System
description: Wall Street analysts had mixed reactions yesterday to a new battery-powered smoking system that the Philip Morris Companies plans to test soon in the United States and Japan.

title: Investigator Has Many Foes, But Crew's Attack Is Risky
description: In taking on the powerful independent investigator assigned to root out corruption in the New York City schools, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew caught many in the system and the city by surprise.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, SAMUEL M.
description: FRIEDMAN-Samuel M. 87, retired partner of A.L. Eolis & Associates, Certified Public Accountants, on October 22, 1997. Beloved husband of Lucille T. Friedman, loving father of Jerold, Nina, and Karen, father-in-law of Linda, grandfather of Brett and Jennifer, brother of Pauline Slotnick. Funeral services Sunday at 10:30 AM at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, NY, 718-445-0300.

title: Hats Off to Soulful Lee Konitz
description: lee konitz "DiG DuG DoG" (Columbia): Hats off to "Subconscious Lee" (the name of an early album), who turned 70 last week. The name fits. He wears a soulful shroud. Remindful of Stan Getz, Chet Baker and Paul Desmond, all deceased, he is perhaps the only original white sound remaining from the formative years. Konitz came out of Lennie Tristano, Claude Thornhill and Miles Davis ("Birth of the Cool") in the '40s, and Stan Kenton in the '50s. Recently, he's been mostly under his own flag, mostly abroad, often with locals, sometimes in duo and even solo. This album was recorded live in Tokyo with the French pianist Laurent de Wilde and the purry Japanese singer Keiko Lee.

title: Cabaret Guide
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes highly recommended shows.

title: Marlins Rally, Then Leave the Indians Just Short
description: In a game that was emblematic of the changing of the post-season guard, Livan Hernandez overcame his early pitching problems tonight and Orel Hershiser self-destructed for the second time in this World Series.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHORR, ROBERT
description: SCHORR-Robert. Of Delray Beach, FL., died peacefully on October 22, 1997. Beloved husband of Joan. Devoted father of Steven Schorr, Andrea Kadin and Melissa Lubliner. Dear brother of Morton Schorr. Adored grandfather of Jourdann, Brittany and Justin. He will be sorely missed. Graveside services Sunday 1 PM, Mt. Ararat Cemetery, E. Farmingdale, L.I.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about pending privacy bills in Congress referred incorrectly to Equifax, a credit-checking company. It disbanded its health care information unit last year and is no longer in the medical records business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHWAX, HAROLD J.
description: ROTHWAX-Harold J. Beloved husband of Yona. Adoring father of Julia and Louis. Darling brother of Judy and Helen. Cherished friend of so many. Service on Sunday, 11 A.M., at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory to VISTA, 1356 Old Clinton road, Westbrook, CT., would be appreciated.

title: MOVIE REVIEW : Rien ne va plus
description: Directed by Claude Chabrol. France.

title: New Video Releases
description: Addicted to Love

title: Microsoft Is Being Punished for Its Success; Endless Revisions
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, STANLEY
description: WILLIAMS-Stanley. The entire School of American Ballet family notes with greatest sorrow the death of faculty member Stanley Williams. The entire faculty, all the stdents and staff join Chairman Albert C. Bellas, Faculty Chairman Peter Martins, and President Larry Alan Smith in mourning the loss of this extraordinary teacher. In his quiet, unpretentious way, he was one of the most influential ballet academicians of his era, and left his indelible mark on generations of American dancers.

title: Prosecutors Won't Retry Former Prison Guard
description: Prosecutors said yesterday that they would not retry a former prison guard who spent 12 years in prison before a judge threw out his convictions in two vicious beatings.

title: Ann Devroy, 49, White House Reporter
description: Ann Devroy, the White House correspondent for The Washington Post who was known for her assertiveness and digging, died today. She was 49 and lived in Washington.

title: Pointcast Names Chief Executive
description: David Dorman, the former chairman and chief executive of Pacific Bell, has agreed to become the chief executive of Pointcast Inc., the Silicon Valley start-up company that delivers news and information to more than one million personal computers.

title: Youthful Hernandez Pouts, Postures and Wins
description: Every so often Livan Hernandez issues a reminder that he hasn't been long on this Earth, as he pouts and sulks, flinging his cap and glove like many infuriated pitchers ages 8 to 38.

title: Art in Review
description: Peter Halley

title: Misguided Court Merger
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIE REVIEW : Live Flesh
description: Directed by Pedro Almodovar. Spain.

title: Theater Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show. + means discounted tickets were available at the TKTS booth last weekend for last Friday and Saturday nights' performances. ++ means discounted tickets were available only for last Friday night. +++ means discounted tickets were available only for last Saturday night.

title: Plurality of Workfare Recipients Said to Vote in Favor of a Union
description: Slightly less than half the 35,000 workfare participants in New York City have voted in favor of union representation, officials of an organizing group announced yesterday.

title: SCOPUS PLANS TO BUY SOFTWARE COMPANY FOR $92 MILLION
description: Scopus Technology Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy Clear With Computers Inc. for $92.1 million in stock to bolster its customer service software systems. Scopus said it would issue about 5.67 million shares in exchange for Clear With Computers' shares and options. Scopus's shares closed at $16.25, unchanged in Nasdaq trading. Clear With Computers, a closely held company in Mankato, Minn., develops interactive selling systems for such companies as General Motors and Ingersoll-Rand. Its shareholders include General Atlantic Partners, which is also Scopus's leading shareholder. Scopus, based in Emeryville, Calif., provides client-server software systems for the customer information management market.

title: Jets Spend the Week Off Trying to Pull Out of Stall
description: They are smiling in the locker room in late October. Jets teams just are not accustomed to that. But now that he has defused the minor quarterback debate (which he himself ignited), Coach Bill Parcells turned his attention today to a real issue: getting the running game going again -- especially inside the red zone.

title: On Stage and Off
description: No Sinking Ship, Despite Waves

title: Three New Voices in the Met's Familiar 'Barbiere di Siviglia'
description: This seems to be Rossini mezzo-soprano month at the Metropolitan Opera. Last week Cecilia Bartoli sang her first Met performances of Cinderella in a new production of ''La Cenerentola.'' And on Wednesday night, the Italian mezzo-soprano Sonia Ganassi made her Met debut as Rosina in the company's familiar 1982 John Cox production of ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia,'' which will be repeated tomorrow afternoon and through January.

title: Danube's Other Delta Needs Help, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Phone Calls Reported
description: The Administration has turned over telephone records showing that President Clinton made telephone calls about campaign fund-raising from the White House. Page A28.

title: Art in Review
description: Luca Pancrazzi and Yoshihiro Suda

title: Excerpts From an Interview With the Governor
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman conducted today by editors and reporters from The New York Times.

title: Mannesmann to Buy A Philips Unit
description: Mannesmann A.G. said yesterday that it would pay 1.5 billion guilders ($750 million) for a Philips Electronics unit. Mannesmann said acquiring Philips Car Systems would make it the world's largest provider of information to motorists that lets them map routes while driving.

title: This Realm of Newcomers, This England
description: The art world in England has been emitting a steady, excited buzz throughout the 1990's, and one by one, young British artists have been making carefully timed New York debuts. Some look good; some disappoint. But with a hefty number of Turner Prize winners and short-listers among them, there's no question that they represent the institutional choice for the New British Art.

title: Tough Talk About the Mob and Charges About Its Money
description: Seeking to promote his image as an arch-foe of organized crime, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani declared yesterday that his drive to oust the mob from the garbage hauling industry and the Fulton Fish Market had saved companies hundreds of millions of dollars. He vowed that in a second term, he would deploy similar tactics in other sectors of New York City's economy, including the air cargo business at Kennedy International Airport.

title: Viewership Keeps Falling
description: The Nielsen rating for Game 4 of the World Series declined 13 percent from last year to a 15.5 Wednesday, the third time in four games the ratings have fallen from 1996. Each rating point represents 980,000 television households.

title: Great Chocolate War Reveals Dark Side of Europe
description: The European Parliament erupted in angry recriminations today after voting on an issue that has split western Europe for more than two decades: the Two Chocolates Policy.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Oct. 15 with a front-page article about the growth of the profit-making University of Phoenix, comparing its enrollment with that of the largest private nonprofit universities, omitted two institutions. They are Harvard, with 24,409 students in the fall of 1996, and Long Island University, with 20,615. (Phoenix lists its fall 1996 enrollment as 40,158.)

title: EU Upholds State Monopoly on Alcohol Sales : Sweden Keeps Its License
description: BRUSSELS  The European Court of Justice on Thursday upheld Sweden's state monopoly on the sale of alcohol, accepting the argument that it was justified on public-health grounds but warning that aspects of it were an impediment to free trade within the European Union.

title: Eating Out; Late Nights
description: New York may be the city that never sleeps, but most restaurants turn in by midnight. Not surprisingly, those restaurants that do thrive late at night are largely downtown, with a few exceptions. Crowds tend to be arty and young, the kind of people who don't use an alarm in the morning. (Here are summaries, written by Eric Asimov, taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Charles Busch Plays It Straight, So to Speak
description: Sometimes, being glamorous, witty and divinely attired just isn't enough for a woman, or, for that matter, a man dressed as a woman. Even if the restless soul happens to be as absurdly glamorous and sublimely witty as Charles Busch has been in the succession of Hollywood-inspired drag performances that have made his name on the New York stage.

title: Republican Prestidigitation
description: This year's single Congressional election, selecting a successor to Susan Molinari on Staten Island, has turned into a prime example of campaign finance abuse. A Democratic State Assemblyman, Eric Vitaliano, is running against Vito Fossella, a Republican member of the New York City Council, for the seat vacated by Ms. Molinari when she signed on as a Saturday morning anchor for CBS television. Though Federal election law limits each party to spending no more than $63,000 to support its candidate, the Republican National Committee has invested some $800,000 in television ads promoting Mr. Fossella.

title: Savoring a Cool Clarity
description: Peter Serkin's piano recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon was not only beautifully played but beautifully planned.

title: Without Frenzy, Sprint Outdoes Its Competitors
description: As his competitors anoint new chieftains and approach a deal-making frenzy, William T. Esrey is smiling.

title: HARBINGER AGREES TO $214 MILLION DEAL FOR PREMENOS
description: The Harbinger Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Premenos Corporation for about $214.4 million in stock to expand its position in the electronic commerce software market. Harbinger plans to issue 0.45 of a share for each share of Premenos common stock. Harbinger last traded at $40.375, down $1.875, before trading was halted yesterday. The acquisition of Premenos, based in Concord, Calif., would make Harbinger one of the largest suppliers of electronic data interchange software, which enables companies to make financial transactions over the Internet. Harbinger, based in Atlanta, expects to take a charge of $20 million to $30 million in the fourth quarter for the acquisition.

title: Art in Review
description: Diti Almog

title: Microsoft Is Being Punished for Its Success; 'Download the Patch'
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Appreciation of the Cahors wines of southwestern France is said to go back some 2,000 years, and the line was continued on Wednesday evening when some aficionados of the country red wine were formally recognized in New York.

title: Defending Fixed Exchange Rate at Further Cost to Stocks
description: How much longer can the bloodletting in stock markets go on?

title: Ivester Is Named to Top Posts at Coca-Cola
description: As expected, the board of the Coca-Cola Company elected M. Douglas Ivester chairman and chief executive yesterday, replacing Roberto C. Goizueta, who died on Saturday at the age of 65.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: FIDELITY INVESTMENTS, Boston, a unit of the FMR Corp., hired Matthew Sadler from the rival Charles Schwab Corp. to manage the company's Funds Network mutual fund service as a senior vice president.

title: Art Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Villanova Quarterback Has His Team On Top
description: Because Youngstown State lost to Northern Iowa and Montana to Eastern Washington, Villanova (6-0, 5-0 Atlantic 10) is the No. 1 team in Division I-AA, according to the Sports Network poll. Unexpected status? Definitely.

title: Gretzky Defends Returning to Play After Wife Was Hurt
description: One day after he watched his injured wife leave Madison Square Garden on a stretcher while he remained behind to finish the game, the Rangers' Wayne Gretzky said he was torn by what he called ''a can't-win situation.''

title: Diner's Journal
description: When the hostess tries to seat us at the long, high communal table that runs down the middle of Asia de Cuba, the new restaurant in Morgans Hotel, we demur. She frowns a bit and

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEEP, ANTHONY PETER
description: DEEP-Anthony Peter, 73. Died in Myrtle Beach, SC. Services will be in SC. Memorials may be made to Grand Strand Humane Society, PO Box 621, Myrtle Beach, South Carolina or charity of one's choice.

title: Agencies Honored For Health Spots
description: Four agencies have taken top honors at the fourth annual Grand Global Awards competition for health care communications, sponsored by the New York Festivals. The agencies are: New.Comm Comunicacao Total Ltda. in Sao Paulo, Brazil, for campaigns aimed at health care professionals, for a multimedia campaign for the decongestant Transpulmin marketed by Asta Medica; Young & Rubicam Buenos Aires, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., for campaigns aimed at consumers, for a television commercial for Tulipan lubricating gel marketed by Kopelco; Marr Associates in Edinburgh, for copywriting for posters, for Scottish Cot Death Trust, and Ammirati Puris Lintas in Copenhagen, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, in the social commitment category, for a public service television announcement for the National Board of Health.

title: Los Angeles Journal; A Sushi Bar Brings Hollywood to Its Knees
description: Here on the eastern edge of the Pacific Rim, where power is mystic and nothing is quite so attractive as whatever is just out of reach, a peculiar phenomenon thrives: a restaurant in which even Hollywood's high and mighty must take whatever they are given, including stern lectures from the chef.

title: China Vows Not to Overrule Hong Kong Officials
description: Faced with their first major crisis since resuming sovereignty over Hong Kong, where the stock market went into free fall and lost 10.4 percent of its value today, Chinese officials responded calmly with promises not to intervene or overrule Hong Kong authorities.

title: In His Own Words
description: JAMES E. McGREEVEY

title: Engaging the Listener In a Bold Conversation
description: Theatricality in its happiest meaning describes intense communication from stage to audience. Luciano Berio writes theatrical music. It aggressively co-opts the attention; it seeks to arrest, surprise, if not amaze. It enlists the eye by arranging musicians and singers in severe groupings and bathing them in provocative light (in ''Ofanim,'' for example, which Mr. Berio conducted at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night). It raises biblical or classical texts to an operatic pitch (again, ''Ofanim'').

title: 3 Mitsubishi Executives Arrested in Payoffs
description: Three executives of the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation were arrested yesterday on charges of paying off gangsters, as scandals that have tainted Japan's financial and retail industries spread to a major exporter. The president of Mitsubishi Motors, Takemune Kimura, said he regretted the executives' arrests. He said that the three paid 23.5 million yen ($194,000) to the gangsters but that top executives at the auto maker were unaware of the transactions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLIKOFF, HY
description: POLIKOFF-Hy. On October 22, 1997 (Simcha Torah). Age 85. He died after a long goodbye. Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Phyllis and Steve Opochinsky and Rhoda P. and Joseph Traum. Proud ''Papa'' of Laurie, Juliet, Jillian and Seth. A man for all seasons. Services on Sunday, 10:30 AM, at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, New York.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the absence of active support among some leading New York Democrats for Ruth W. Messinger, the Democratic mayoral candidate, misstated the title of Judith Hope. She is chairwoman, not executive director, of the state Democratic Party.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, DONALD J.
description: COOPER-Donald J., 79. Of South Orange, New Jersey, Thursday, October 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Fay. Cherished father of Arlene and Richard. Adored grandfather of Jonathan, Ariane and Gregory Brainin. Devoted brother to Arnold, Burton and Raymond. Funeral service will be held at 12:30 p.m. on Sunday, October 26, 1997 in the Bernheim-Apter-Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the UJA-Federation or the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168 Street, NYC, 10032.

title: 2 Scientists Say New Data Disprove Dinosaur-Bird Theory
description: Studying embryos of modern birds and reptiles, biologists think they have found evidence disputing the prevailing theory that birds descended from dinosaurs. The evidence is digital, as in fingers.

title: Pop and Jazz Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Police Say Boy, 12, Attacked Girl, 11, in a Brooklyn School
description: An 11-year-old girl was sodomized yesterday by a 12-year-old classmate in the stairwell of her Brooklyn junior high school, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EBERT BROWN, JOYCE
description: EBERT BROWN-Joyce. A memorial Monday, Oct. 27 for Joyce Ebert Brown at Long Wharf Theatre, New Haven, CT at 4 PM. Donations in memoriam to Long Wharf Theatre. No flowers please.

title: Blame Monetarists for Asia's Boom and Bust; Thai Bank Rumors
description: To the Editor:

title: Clear Channel Buying Company
description: Clear Channel Communications, a San Antonio-based media company, announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy Universal Outdoor Holdings Inc., an operator of billboards, for $1.7 billion in stock.

title: Art in Review
description: Roy De Forest

title: Rikers Island Teacher Arrested for Smuggling
description: A social studies teacher at Rikers Island was arrested on Wednesday and charged with smuggling a razor blade into the prison between the leaves of a book, jail officials said. It was the second time this month that a school employee there was arrested for smuggling razor blades inside.

title: Dow Profit Down In Latest Quarter
description: The Dow Chemical Company said today that its third-quarter profit fell 10 percent, as increased shipments of some chemicals failed to offset falling chemical prices and the strong dollar's erosion of gains in foreign sales.

title: Man Freed After a DNA Test Is Sentenced in a Second Rape
description: Kerry Kotler, the Long Island fisherman who spent 11 years in prison for a 1981 rape before he was cleared by DNA evidence, was ordered back to jail today because of a second rape conviction, also based on DNA evidence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAELS, CHARLES, SR.
description: MICHAELS-Charles, Sr. On Tuesday, October 21, 1997. Charles Michaels, Sr. of Rockville, MD and formally NYC. Beloved husband of the late Helen L. and the late Dorothy G. Michaels. Devoted father of Charles Michaels, Jr. and the late Bea Jacobs. Loving brother of the late Allen and the late Sally Michaels. Dear grandfather of Kay Katz, Jerry Jacobs, Charles F. Michaels and Susan Tussy. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Memorial contributions may be made to the National Capital TaySachs Foundation, 5511 Thornbush Ct, Bethesda, MD 20902. For information call Edward Sagel Funeral Direction, 800-217-9403.

title: Blackout in San Francisco; Sabotage Is Seen
description: Switches in a utility substation in San Francisco were turned off in an apparently deliberate act on Thursday, causing a power failure that knocked out traffic lights, caused home computers to crash and disrupted the morning for much of the city, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about a lawsuit filed by a former Texas Christian University football player who was paralyzed in a 1974 game, misidentified the defendant. It was the Texas Employers Insurance Association in Receivership, not the university.

title: A Premiere From Silesia With a Signature Style
description: No doubt about it: Jacek Luminski, the Polish founder and director of the Silesian Dance Theater, does not choreograph like anyone else. His is contemporary dance with a difference.

title: G.O.P. Dispute Delays Amtrak Bill in House
description: Split by a regional division among Republicans, the House of Representatives failed for a third day today to take action on an Amtrak bill that would release $2.3 billion in new capital and change the railroad's labor rules.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLZMAN, DORIS (NEE HODKIN)
description: HOLZMAN-Doris (nee Hodkin). October 22, 1997 at age 96. Beloved wife of the late Meyer Fishman. Adored mother of Martin (Ann) and Charles Fishman. Cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Sunday 12 noon ''Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapels'', 76th Road and Queens Boulevard in Forest Hills.

title: Is He on Second Base or Not?
description: This week, watching the World Series, I've learned that the Cleveland Indians have a potent offense, that the Florida Marlins have a porous defense and that the Indians' pitcher Jaret Wright has great velocity while Orel Hershiser has great location. I'm also told that the Marlins' Gary Sheffield is dangerous with runners in scoring position and that both teams made it this far because of significant role players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILES, FREDA
description: MILES-Freda, 80. Of Allendale, NJ, on October 22, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Michael Miles, deceased July 1997; adored mother of Carol Bleifer, Joseph and Alex Miles; dear grandmother of Craig and Sean Bleifer, Grant and Anthony Miles; great-grandmother of Dimitri and Samuel Bleifer. To my dearest Mom, I give you all my love as you always gave your love to me. Thank you for having shared this special time. You will always be part of me and our family. You have shown just how strong love can be and because of our great love you will be part of me and all who are yet to come for all eternity. You will always be missed. The bond we have shared can never be broken. Your daughter, Carol. Services at 2 PM, Sunday, October 26, 1997, at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, Route 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Lustful Ardor, Fresh From England
description: One could not have asked for a more enjoyable opening of the ambitious Dancing in the Isles: British Invasion '97 festival of new English modern dance than that provided by the Ricochet Dance Company in its American debut Thursday night at St. Mark's Church.

title: S.& P. Lowers Ratings On South Korean Debt
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its long-term and short-term ratings yesterday of the foreign currency debt of South Korea. The move reflects the escalating cost to the Government of supporting the country's ailing corporate and financial sectors, S.& P. said.

title: Fixed-Rate Mortgages Rise
description: Rates on 30-year fixed-rate home mortgages edged up this week, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage rose to 7.35 percent, from 7.34 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgage rates averaged 6.90 percent, up from 6.89. The average adjustable-rate mortgage stayed at 5.55 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, PARKER T.
description: HART-Parker T. A retired career minister of the Foreign Service of the United States and former Assistant Secretary of State for Near East and South Asian Affairs died October 15 in Washington, DC at the age of 87. He served as U.S. Ambassador to Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Turkey, Minister to the Yemen and as Director of the Foreign Service Institute. From 1969 to 1973, he was president of the Middle East Institute. His book, ''Two NATO Allies at the Threshold of War'' was published in 1990 by Duke University Press. Born in Medford, MA., Mr. Hart graduated from Dartmouth College, received a Master's Degree from Harvard in 1935, and studied at the Graduate Institute of International Studies in Geneva. In 1952 he also graduated from the National War College. After his foreign service career he retired in Washington, DC and served as a consultant to Bechtel Corporation for a number of years. He is survived by his wife Jane Smiley Hart and his two daughters, Margaret Hart Espey and Judith Hart Halsema.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, DONALD J.
description: COOPER-Donald J., 79. Of South Orange, New Jersey, Thursday, October 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Fay. Cherished father of Arlene and Richard. Adored grandfather of Jonathan, Ariane and Gregory Brainin. Devoted brother to Arnold, Burton and Raymond. Funeral service will be held at 12:30 p.m. on Sunday, October 26, 1997 in the Bernheim-Apter-Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the UJA-Federation or the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168 Street, NYC, 10032.

title: Music in Review: ROCK
description: A Roche Sister Expands To a Full Band

title: LEARNING AGREES TO ACQUIRE CREATIVE WONDERS
description: The Learning Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Creative Wonders L.L.C., a children's-software venture of ABC Inc. and the game-maker Electronic Arts Inc., for $40 million in cash and stock options. Learning, based in Cambridge, Mass., is an education-software company. It said it would maintain Creative Wonders, a company with estimated full-year revenue of $22 million, as a group in Redwood City, Calif. ABC is a unit of the Walt Disney Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALITAN, MIRIAM G.
description: SALITAN-Miriam G. On October 24, 1997, age 98. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Mark, Adele and Lucille. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Laurie, Jim, Diane, Geoffrey, David, Marc, Marta and Mish. Adoring great-grandmother of Emily and Gabriel. Devoted aunt of Lenore and Arthur, Morton and Marcia, Richard and Minna, Howard and Phyllis. Sister-in-law of Jean Mahler and Henry Salitan. Services, Sunday, October 26, 9:45AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SONNETT, CARL
description: SONNETT-Carl. Missing you on your birthday and everyday. Love, Meri, Stacy, Tony, Larry, Avram, Alex, Richard, Evan, Joshua, Jacob and Princess Anna

title: I.R.S. Reform May Not Benefit the Taxpayers; All-Powerful Agency
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Hong Kong Rebounds, But Not U.S. Stocks

title: Volkswagen to Divert State Aid to Plant
description: Germany and the European Commission reached a preliminary accord yesterday for Volkswagen A.G. to divert 90.7 million marks, or $51 million, in state aid to a plant in the state of Hesse. Karel van Miert, the European Union competition commissioner, has agreed to the accord and will seek approval from his European Commission colleagues, according to the German Economics Ministry. The commission is the European Union's executive arm.

title: Assisi Holds Its Breath, and Rebuilds Treasures
description: It has been weeks since a devastating earthquake struck central Italy on Sept. 26, killing four people inside the St. Francis basilica here and reducing large swatches of its magnificent ceiling frescoes to rubble.

title: The Pain-and-Suffering Lotto
description: There may be a lot of reasons to vote for James McGreevey in the race for New Jersey governor. After all, he's a Democrat, as, most of the time -- and with considerable enthusiasm -- am I. (Yes, I have been to a coffee. No, it wasn't a fund-raiser.) But when it comes to auto insurance reform, a topic I have spent all too much of the last 17 years studying, I'm sorry to say that Mr. McGreevey has either turned demagogue or, as I prefer to think, simply been poorly advised.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Daniel E. Provost 3d, a former Liggett & Myers executive, misstated the name of his wife. She is Carol, not Laura.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAGG, ROSE LUCAS
description: BRAGG-Rose Lucas. On Thursday, October 23, 1997. Lifelong resident of New York. Mother of Lucas (Patricia) Bragg and Jane Bragg. Sister of Benjamin and Herbert Lucas and Dorothy Delbaum. Also survived by two grandchildren.

title: Candidates Sharpen Attacks and Defend Records in Final Debate
description: In their third and final televised debate, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and State Senator James E. McGreevey sharpened their attacks on each other and aggressively defended their own records last night, focusing on the two issues that New Jersey voters cite as their biggest concerns: taxes and automobile insurance rates.

title: INSIDE
description: Senate Moves on Nominees

title: State Panel Removes Judge From Bench
description: A state commission voted yesterday to remove Judge Lorin Duckman from the bench, saying the judge, who sparked a furor when a domestic violence case he handled in Brooklyn ended in murder, had shown a ''mean-spirited, bullying'' bias against prosecutors and made disparaging or inappropriate remarks about blacks and women.

title: Others Have Won on the Road
description: The Cleveland Indians will attempt this weekend to become the seventh team to win the World Series by winning the sixth and seventh games on the road. The last team to do it was the 1979 Pittsburgh Pirates, who erased a 3-2 deficit by winning in Baltimore.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPTAY, JOHN
description: LIPTAY-John, on Oct 25, 1996. One year in heaven. Not one day passes that we don't think of you. We miss your gentleness, your smile and your laughter. Love you forever, Joan, Christina & Bruno

title: The Wrong Fight for Rudy Crew
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew blundered this week when he attacked Edward Stancik, the New York City school system's special investigator. Mr. Stancik is a bit of a showboat, but he has done a solid job of exposing corruption in a system where criminal inquiries were virtually nonexistent before his arrival in 1991. In criticizing a successful investigator, Dr. Crew has picked a fight that he is unlikely to win -- and has given the impression that he views tough law enforcement as a threat to his authority.

title: Clinton Defends China Policy
description: The President insisted that engagement with China was fundamental to America's economic and security interests. He meets with China's president next week. Page A6.

title: Golf: U.S. Mid-Amateur; New Yorker Wins on Birdie on 18
description: Ken Bakst, a real estate developer from New York City, birdied the 18th hole yesterday after hitting a 7-iron shot to within four feet of the cup and defeated Rick Stimmel to win the 1997 United States Mid-Amateur championship at the Dallas Athletic Club in Dallas.

title: AVON SHARES SURGE ON COST-CUTTING NEWS
description: The stock of Avon Products Inc. surged yesterday after the company announced measures intended to cut costs by up to $400 million a year by 2000. Late on Thursday, Avon said re-engineering costs, including the elimination of 30 percent of its beauty-products line, would reduce earnings in the next two years by $150 million to $200 million. Avon, based in New York, is also studying whether to open new Avon stores and next year it will open an Avon spa in New York. About half of the charges related to the reorganization will be recorded in the first quarter of 1998. Shares of Avon were up $6.875, at $73.75, on the Big Board

title: Late-Term Abortion Debate Miscasts the Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Oilers On Verge Of Sale
description: The Edmonton Oilers are close to a sale that will keep the National Hockey League team in the Alberta capital, principals of the deal said last night.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption on Wednesday about arguments before the New York State Court of Appeals on whether Gov. George E. Pataki had the right to remove the Bronx District Attorney from the case of a police officer's slaying misspelled one lawyer's surname. He is Richard J. Holwell, not Howell.

title: Taliban Agree to Enforce World Ban on Opium Trade
description: The director of the United Nations anti-narcotics organization said today that the militant Islamic movement that controls most of Afghanistan had agreed to enforce a ban on opium poppy production and smuggling with the help of international crime-fighting organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE ATAMANOFF)
description: HENRY-Josephine M. (nee Atamanoff). Of Greenwich Village and Woodstock, N.Y. Died suddenly October 23, 1997. Loving mother of Christopher. Beloved wife of Thomas O'Malley. Dear sister of Thomas Atamanoff. Noted Local 829 Costume Designer for the TV commerical industry. Reposing at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, NY, Saturday 79:30PM, Sunday 2-5 and 7-9:30PM. Funeral Mass Monday 9:30AM, Our Lady of Pompei Church. Burial Woodstock Cemetery.

title: Suspicions Large and Small Bedevil Jiang's Visit to U.S.
description: For months, American and Chinese negotiators have gone head to head on China's weapons sales, human rights record and unfair trade practices in preparation for the most important summit meeting of the Clinton Presidency.

title: City's Troubles Are Hidden, Messinger Says
description: In a direct challenge to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's portrayal of a city on the upswing, Ruth W. Messinger says that New York's schools, economy and budget are threatened by dangerous if unrecognized problems. She said she would devote her first months as Mayor to uncovering and explaining the depth of the city's woes.

title: Short Positions Not Yet Covered Are Up 7.1% on Nasdaq Market
description: The increase between September and October 1993 was 7.4 percent.

title: 4 Charged in Killings of 2 and Gem Dealer
description: Four New Jersey men were arrested and charged yesterday with murdering a diamond wholesaler and two other men during a robbery on Thursday at the merchant's home on a quiet residential street in Bogota.

title: Clinton Withdraws Nomination For Secretary of Veterans Affairs
description: President Clinton today withdrew the nomination of Hershel Gober, the Deputy Secretary of Veterans Affairs, to be the department's Secretary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURTIN, CLAIRE M.
description: CURTIN-Claire M. Of Bronxville, N.Y. on October 24, 1997. Devoted wife of Brian J. Curtin, M.D. Beloved mother of Edward, James, Thomas Curtin and Deirdre Hommel. Dear sister of Joan Snyder, Dorothy Flynn, M.D., Eileen Ronan and Ann McSherry. Treasured grandmother of Brian Hommel. She brightened every life that she touched. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 24 and 7-9 P.M. Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial Saint Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Monday, October 27, 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to College of Saint Elizabeth, Convent Station, New Jersey.

title: AMERICAN BUILDINGS IS ADDING UNITED DOMINION UNIT
description: The American Buildings Company agreed yesterday to buy United Dominion Industries' Windsor Door division for $60 million in cash to expand its construction products business. Windsor Door, based in Little Rock, Ark., is the nation's fourth-largest maker of steel garage doors for homes and businesses. Windsor Door's other products, which include rolling steel doors for industrial uses and a metal stamping business, complement American Buildings' product lines. Windsor Door operates two plants in Little Rock and one in Marysville, Calif., and owns 29 distribution centers. The unit had sales of $94 million in the 12 months ended Sept. 30. American Buildings, based in Eufaula, Ala., had sales of $274 million last year.

title: Historic Series Pitching, and All of It Ugly
description: So maybe Jim Leyland and Mike Hargrove have no need to apologize for their teams' being in the World Series. But would they like to apologize for their starting pitchers?

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Race Track Plan Advances
description: Plans to add a 105,000-seat automobile race track to the Atlantic City Race Course drew closer to reality on Thursday when the Township Committee unanimously endorsed the $100 million project.

title: WALL STREET FAILS TO BUILD ON RALLY SEEN IN HONG KONG
description: Hong Kong paved the way yesterday for a recovery from Thursday's global stock market rout, but Wall Street would not cooperate.

title: Hanna Bercovitch, 63, Who Rescued Texts
description: Hanna M. Bercovitch, the founding editor of the Library of America, died on Monday at her son's home in Madison, Wis. She was 63.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; School Shaken by Violence
description: Capping a week of violence at an Atlantic City public middle school, students fought in the halls, set off fire alarms and walked out of their classes yesterday, a police spokesman said. About 20 teachers at the Albany Avenue Prep School did not show up for work, he said.

title: Corrections
description: Two parts of a diagram in Science Times on Tuesday illustrating the organization of DNA in the cell nucleus depicted double-helix strands of DNA incorrectly. In a vertical depiction of DNA, the closer of the two strands rises to the right (as the main part of the diagram showed), not to the left.

title: This Comeback Will Be Harder for Indians
description: The Cleveland Indians are speaking boldly of how they have been in this kind of situation before. How they have faced elimination. How they have always survived. How they can do it again.

title: Crew Removes Principal After Inquiry On Sex Attack
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew last night ordered the removal of the principal of a Bronx elementary school where five third-grade boys have been charged with sexually assaulting two girls during recess last week.

title: Late-Term Abortion Debate Miscasts the Issues; States Shouldn't Decide
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties; Yakkety-Yak
description: I ran into a friend in New York the other day who looked rattled.

title: French Grocery Concern Buys Retailer in Portugal
description: Promodes S.A. announced yesterday that it had made its second purchase in a week as it expands outside of France. Promodes, France's No. 2 publicly traded supermarket company, agreed to buy the discount retailer Portuguesa de Lojas de Desconto from Auchan for an undisclosed sum. Promodes said the purchase strengthened its position in Portugal. Earlier, it announced the purchase of Simago, a Spanish supermarket operator.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL MOTORS CORP., Detroit, said it planned to begin construction of a $150 million auto parts plant in Brazil by the end of the year.

title: Payoff Scandal Widens For Mitsubishi Units
description: The payoff scandal involving the Mitsubishi conglomerate in Japan widened yesterday as another company admitted to transferring money to a man arrested on suspicion of corporate extortion. Mitsubishi Electric said it had transferred money to the same man who was arrested on Wednesday for reportedly taking payoffs from Mitsubishi Motors. Three Mitsubishi Motors executives were also arrested.

title: Milken Probation Is Extended Yet Again
description: A Federal judge in New York extended the probation of Michael R. Milken yesterday for a sixth time while regulators consider whether he is complying with a court-ordered ban from the securities industry.

title: Child Welfare Agency Needs More Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: Great Substitution Game Generates High Stakes and Huge Profits
description: LONDON  Slowly but irresistibly, a gigantic substitution game is being played on the art market. As the total of available paintings from the Renaissance to the outbreak of World War II dwindles by the year, interest shifts from categories no longer available to others that still are.

title: In Final Round, Arguments Over Guns, Condoms and Cars
description: Following are excerpts from last night's debate among Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, State Senator James E. McGreevey, a Democrat, and Murray Sabrin, a Libertarian.

title: Republicans Begin Clearing Backlog of Nominees
description: After being pummeled for weeks by the White House over their pace in approving nominations, Senate Republicans have started moving quickly to confirm a backlog of sub-Cabinet-level officers, ambassadors and judges.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Hunt for Civil War Cannons
description: Federal investigators are trying to determine how two Civil War cannons disappeared from a Union City park during the summer while the park was undergoing renovations, the city's corporation counsel said yesterday.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: TODAY'S KEY GAMES

title: Eastern Orthodox Head Welcomed to New York
description: Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew I of Constantinople, spiritual leader of more than 250 million Eastern Orthodox Christians worldwide, began his first visit to New York yesterday by saluting a city -- ''the capital of the world,'' he said -- that, in turn, welcomed him with excited children, clicking cameras of the faithful, and receptions with some of its most eminent figures.

title: In His Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Edward Treutel, 84, a Trumpet Instructor
description: Edward Treutel, a trumpeter who taught at the Juilliard School for nearly 60 years, died on Friday at the Englewood Medical Center in New Jersey. He was 84 and lived in Leonia, N.J.

title: Hilton Hotels Extends Hostile Offer for ITT
description: Despite its apparent defeat in a hostile takeover battle for the ITT Corporation, the Hilton Hotels Corporation extended its cash tender offer yesterday to buy the company for $8 billion. In a press release, Hilton said the $70-a-share offer, which had an expiration date of Oct. 24, was now scheduled to expire at midnight Oct. 31, unless again extended.

title: Coach of the Year? Here's a Top 10 List
description: The one thing that the National Football League should perhaps be most proud of at the halfway point of the season is that there are numerous coaches -- some of them new to the ranks -- who are turning their teams into winners.

title: Van Horn Sprains Ankle
description: NETS 101, CAVALIERS 100

title: Audra Lindley, 79, Actress; Played a Sex-Starved Wife
description: Audra Lindley, who starred on Broadway, in films and in more than 100 live television dramas but who gained her greatest fame playing a sex-starved wife in the television series ''Three's Company'' and its spinoff, ''The Ropers,'' died on Oct. 16 at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. She was 79 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Keane's Goal Lifts Rangers, But Graves Injures a Knee
description: When the Rangers acquired the veteran Mike Keane as a free agent last summer, they knew his history and what to expect. Keane would kill penalties, check opposing wings, rough up people occasionally and provide vocal leadership both on the bench and behind the scenes.

title: Success and the Black Magazine; As Readers Prosper, Advertising Still Eludes Publishers
description: As Edward Lewis tells the story, his wife was approached at a 1992 party by the cosmetics executive Leonard A. Lauder, chairman of the Estee Lauder Companies, who joked, ''Ed Lewis never smiles.''

title: Police Officer Convicted of Killing Man Over Parking
description: A New York City police officer was found guilty of murder today for shooting a man to death in a dispute over a delicatessen parking space in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: DETROIT
description: Pistons forward Grant Hill will miss the rest of the preseason after undergoing toe surgery yesterday. He will likely be ready to play in Friday's season opener against Washington.

title: Health Care's Weird Geography
description: In medicine, as in real estate, location turns out to be everything. That disturbing message emerges from an extensive survey by Dr. John Wennberg and colleagues at the Dartmouth Medical School, which shows that hospitalization rates, surgical choices and other medical practices vary across regions for reasons that appear unrelated to patient desires or medical needs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLIN, HYMAN S., M.D.
description: GELLIN-Hyman S., M.D., 90. On October 23, 1997 in Lauderhill, Florida. He was a graduate of New York Medical College, and practiced family medicine in Brooklyn from 1931 to 1980. His children, Dr. Gerald Gellin and Harriet Selverstone and their spouses Lucille Gellin and Dr. Robert Selverstone, and grandchildren, Dr. Erica Jonlin, Gary Gellin, Marc Selvertone and Amy Silberfein and their spouses Duane Jonlin and Andrew Silberfein and three great-grandchildren honor his memory. Predeceased by his wife of 61 years, Irma Gellin. Missed by his dear friend, Freda Lefton. Funeral services at Riverside-Gordon Chapel in Tamarac, Florida, at 10:00AM, October 26. Interment at Beth-El Memorial Park in Davie, Florida.

title: I.R.S. Reform May Not Benefit the Taxpayers
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; Campaigns Hit Youth Center, But Not Cash
description: THE folks who live near the corner of Mapes Avenue and East 178th Street in Crotona can make something from nothing. During the 1970's, when flames and fear hit this Bronx neighborhood like a slow-motion atomic fireball, Mary Mitchell took an abandoned supermarket and turned it into a youth center. She did this through will, not wealth, digging into her own pockets for the games and art supplies the children used.

title: Clinton Defends Engagement With China
description: Declaring the isolation of China to be ''unworkable, counterproductive and potentially dangerous,'' President Clinton today defended his policy of engagement with China as fundamental to America's economic and security interests.

title: State Trooper Killed In Burglary Shooting
description: A state trooper was shot and killed yesterday afternoon while investigating a burglary in Warren County, according to law enforcement officials who spoke on condition of anonymity. The name of the trooper, who was killed in Independence Township, was not released pending notification of the family, the officials said.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Women's Caucus Endorses 66
description: The Women's Political Caucus of New Jersey endorsed 66 legislative candidates yesterday, splitting its support between Democrats and Republicans and women and men.

title: Sports of The Times; Sacrificing, On the Court And Off It
description: The edict has been given: the watchword of this season's Knicks is ''sacrifice,'' though it is not clear whether that means sacrifice, as in helping the team win, or sacrifice, as in being led to the corporate altar for the sake of pleasing customers in the box seats.

title: Aide Calls IMF Rules For Bailout Too Strict : Thai Leader Reshuffles His Cabinet
description: BANGKOK  After a week of intense political negotiations, Prime Minister Chaovalit Yongchaiyut appointed a new cabinet Friday and made clear his intention to call elections in Thailand as early as possible.

title: A Jesuit Takes the Heat For a Gritty TV Series About a Doubting Priest
description: Bill Cain is an earnest man of the cloth, an intense Jesuit priest in a plaid shirt, khaki trousers and running shoes, saving souls. But it is hard to miss the mischievous glint in his eye as he interrupts some brooding comments about God's love and harmony to make clear that he actually relishes a good theological scrap.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Thomas Hunter, 84, Medical Dean Who Helped Poor Countries
description: Dr. Thomas H. Hunter, who sought to improve medical care in poor countries as dean of the University of Virginia School of Medicine and later was the university's chancellor and vice president for medical affairs, died on Thursday at his home in Cismont, Va. He was 84.

title: Hong Kong Investors Look (Hard) for the Silver Lining
description: Along Des Voeux Road, in front of dozens and dozens of flickering market monitors, a sustained sigh of relief issued from anxious Hong Kong investors today.

title: 4 Men Are Charged With Murders of 2 and a Gem Dealer
description: Four New Jersey men were arrested and charged yesterday with murdering a diamond wholesaler and two other men during a robbery on Thursday at the merchant's home on a quiet residential street in Bogota.

title: In a Policy Shift, More Parents Are Arrested for Child Neglect
description: The mothers in handcuffs shuffled into the police stations in Brooklyn, blinking nervously under the white fluorescent lights.

title: While Markets Toss and Turn, Japan Enjoys Relative Calm
description: For the last few years, Japan has sat on the sidelines while the rest of the world enjoyed the financial and economic equivalent of a giddy New Year's Eve party.

title: U.S. Is to Help Army in Colombia Fight Drugs but Skeptics Abound
description: Deepening its involvement in a country that it has held at arm's length for years, the United States has approved sending more than $50 million in equipment to help Colombia's military fight guerrillas involved in drug trafficking in the south.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article and another in Business Day yesterday, and a chart showing the performance of stock markets around the world, misstated the German DAX 30 index. It closed on Thursday at 3,977.26 points, not 3,976.38. It was down 4.66 percent for the day, not 3.60 percent, and down 9.79 percent since Aug. 1, not 8.31 percent.

title: Pigeon Case Comes Home to Roost; Accused by A.S.P.C.A. in '92, Professor Gets Her Day in Court
description: All Renee Solomon wanted was a little quiet, a little cleanliness. She wanted to sleep past 5 A.M. without bolting upright to a winged ruckus outside her window. She wanted a view unsullied by the stool of pigeons.

title: Insilco Seeks F.T.C. Approval for Mill Deal
description: The Insilco Corporation has asked the Federal Trade Commission for approval of its sale of two aluminum tubing mills, potentially clearing the way for resolution of an unusual legal fight with antitrust officials.

title: China's Dissident Game
description: To the Editor:

title: KLM Forms an Alliance With Japan Air System
description: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, the Dutch flag carrier, said yesterday that it had agreed to team up with the Japan Air System Company, Japan's third-largest airline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, JULIUS
description: VOGEL-Julius. On October 22. Beloved husband of Annette. Services Sunday 12:00 noon at ''Boulevard-Riverside Chapels'', 312 Coney Island Ave., at Prospect Park.

title: While Not a Natural, Giuliani Has Learned to Work a Crowd
description: Nobody would call Rudolph W. Giuliani a natural.

title: Late-Term Abortion Debate Miscasts the Issues; Politically Defensible
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAIDENBERG, DAVID
description: SAIDENBERG-David, concert pianist and teacher, died in Taipei, Taiwan following a long illness at age 52. Beloved husband of Maria. Devoted father of Sasha, Sergei, Demetri and Nikolai, all of Taipei. Fond brother of Nini Abbott of Hollywood, Florida.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, ESTELLE RAE SKLOWER
description: GINSBERG-Estelle Rae Sklower. Widow of Samuel Ginsberg, died Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital, Passaic, at the age of 104. Beloved mother of Miles David and Dulcie Freeman; grandmother of Steven, Amelia and Heidi David, and Sheila Freeman Fung, Eve Freeman Kogan, Bill Freeman and Joel Freeman; great grandmother of Julia, Lesley and Lea Fung, Rebecca and Josh Kogan, Alan and Emily Freeman, Samantha Freeman; she was ''Aunt Rae'' to scores of nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grand-nephews. Funeral services on Sunday, October 26, 10 AM, Robert Schoem Menorah Chapel, Rte. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: Kwan Wins Battle of Teens With a Fluid Short Program
description: The most eagerly anticipated rivalry of this figure-skating season renewed itself tonight as Michelle Kwan defeated Tara Lipinski in the short program at Skate America. It was the first in a series of head-to-head meetings that is expected to culminate with one of the precocious teen-agers wearing an Olympic gold medal around her neck.

title: What an 1890's Music Lover Loved
description: A New Yorker a century ago could have strolled from a matinee performance of a Victor Herbert operetta to hear Edward MacDowell play one of his piano concertos. Wednesday evening's concert by the American Symphony Orchestra, under its conductor, Leon Botstein, was an effort to recreate that historical moment, more or less. MacDowell's Second Piano Concerto and the Third Symphony of his contemporary George Chadwick were paired with some Herbert numbers and, from a generation later, Charles Miller's adaptation of Jerome Kern's ''Showboat'' music, to make a symphonic ''scenario.''

title: State Trooper Shot and Killed In Chase of Robbery Suspect
description: A New Jersey state trooper was shot and killed yesterday afternoon by a shotgun-wielding robbery suspect on a deserted road in Warren County, the state police said.

title: South Africans to Stay With 'The Lion King'
description: The producers ''The Lion King,'' the Broadway musical now in previews at the New Amsterdam Theater, have reached an accord with Actors Equity allowing five South African performers to remain with the show at least through June.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: J. Robert Lackey, 71, an Expert In the Financing of Health Care
description: J. Robert Lackey, a health-planning executive and former head of the New Jersey Health Care Facilities Financing Authority, which he helped organize, died on Tuesday at his home in Pennington, N.J. He was 71 and also had a home in Venice, Fla.

title: Air Force Says Pilot Committed Suicide
description: The Air Force will issue a report next week that concludes, largely by process of elimination, that the pilot who flew his A-10 Thunderbolt 800 miles off course on April 2 and crashed into a mountain in Colorado had made a sudden decision to commit suicide, a senior officer confirmed this evening.

title: Trying Something New, Something Mellow
description: Fiona Apple is this season's It Girl, her pale blue eyes drawing the viewer's gaze to magazine covers and MTV videos, her offhand comments regularly quoted by the press. She is also something else: an Id Girl, an undomesticated spirit who follows her impulses and presents an unedited account of what she finds.

title: SHARES OF SPECTRIAN PLUMMET BY 37%
description: The stock of the Spectrian Corporation plummeted 37 percent yesterday after the company said it expected lower sales to its most important customer. The maker of radio frequency power amplifiers said late Thursday that sales to Northern Telecom Ltd., would dip lower than expected for this fiscal year and the next. Spectrian said sales to the telecommunications-equipment maker could be as much as 10 percent below those in the first half of the year. In the first half of the year, Spectrian derived 59 percent of its revenue from Northern Telecom and 20 percent from a joint venture between Northern Telecom and the French company Matra. Shares of Spectrian fell $15.875 yesterday, to $26,25, on the Nasdaq.

title: LORAL SPACE SEEKS STAKE IN MEXICO CONCERN
description: Loral Space and Communications Ltd. has offered to pay $692 million for a 75 percent stake in Mexico's state-owned satellite company, Satellites Mexicanos S.A. The company, which submitted the only bid, hopes to use Satmex's three satellites, whose signals cover Mexico, Central America and parts of North and South America, to increase its presence in the region. Satellite services, including television, radio, telephone and data transmission, are expected to boom in Latin America. Mexico's Communications and Transport Ministry is expected to take five working days before declaring a winner. Loral is based in New York.

title: When a Rally's Strength Is Seen as Its Weakness
description: However many thousands attend the Million Woman March here on Saturday, its organizers expect to achieve an unusual goal, staging a mass rally without help from any national organization or even major local leaders.

title: Mets Sign Pitcher From South Korea
description: When Chan Ho Park, the Korean-born pitcher of the Los Angeles Dodgers, started a game at Shea Stadium in August, the Mets had one of their largest walk-up crowds of the season, generated by the large Korean population in Queens. That phenomenon probably contributed to the Mets' aggressiveness in agreeing to terms this week with Jae Weong Seo, a 20-year-old right-hander from South Korea who is likely to start out in Class A.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHWAX, HAROLD J.
description: ROTHWAX-Harold J. Beloved husband of Yona. Adoring father of Julia and Louis. Darling brother of Judy and Helen. Cherished friend of so many. Service on Sunday, 11 A.M., at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory to VISTA, 1356 Old Clinton road, Westbrook, CT., would be appreciated.

title: Police Dismiss Officers Acquitted in Rape Case
description: Two police officers in New Rochelle have been dismissed 15 months after they were acquitted of charges that they raped a female police dispatcher in 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TESSLER, JACK JOSEPH
description: TESSLER-Jack Joseph. On October 24, 1997. Beloved son of Dorothy. Devoted father of Gabrielle and Michelle. Services Sunday 12:15 PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment in Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Arts in America; An Orchestra for a Town That Can't Accept Failure
description: As the final strains of Beethoven's Symphony No. 1 in C faded and the near sellout crowd of 400 inside the Frank Creative Arts Center began a long and warm applause, Leo Driehuys gave his musicians an enthusiastic two thumbs up, his smile nearly 44 piano keys wide.

title: 2 KEY POSTS FILLED AND REORGANIZATION PLANNED
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. has named two new chief operating officers and will reorganize itself into smaller business units, the company announced this week. The telecommunications products maker named Dan Stanzione, 51, executive vice president and chief operating officer. He will remain president of the company's Bell Labs unit. It also named Ben Verwaayen, 45, executive vice president and chief operating officer. The company said the reorganization would allow it to focus on such growth areas as wireless, semiconductors, data networking and optical networking. The changes take effect next Saturday. Lucent was spun off from the AT&T Corporation in 1996.

title: California Blackout Is Seen as Intentional
description: San Francisco was struck by a blackout on Thursday morning that cut off power to about 126,000 customers. While power was restored within hours, utility officials are now saying the power failure was probably caused by a deliberate act.

title: P.&G. to Increase Stake in China Venture
description: The Procter & Gamble Company is planning to increase its stake in a Chinese joint venture with Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. to 80 percent from 69 percent for $650 million.

title: Music in Review: JAZZ
description: A Musician Who Does Not Keep His Thoughts to Himself

title: Chinese Aesthetic Taking Hold in U.S.
description: NEW YORK  Like a rising tide, Chinese taste is refashioning the art scene in New York and, more importantly, coloring the whole American perception of Chinese art.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Court Ruling on Blue Cross
description: A state appellate court ruled unanimously yesterday that Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey is a charitable institution. The three-judge panel upheld a lower court finding that the health insurance company had been receiving substantial tax benefits as a charitable organization since its inception.

title: Internet's Value In U.S. Schools Still in Question
description: With today being the second annual Net Day, a volunteer effort to wire the nation's schools for Internet access, attention turns to network experiments around the country like the one at McClymonds High School in Oakland, Calif.

title: Child Welfare Agency Needs More Workers; Try Higher Salaries
description: To the Editor:

title: John Kennedy Jr., One Step Ahead of the Pack, Quietly Travels to Cuba
description: John F. Kennedy Jr., the editor of George magazine, has quietly traveled to Cuba on the 35th anniversary of the Cuban missile crisis, in which his father, the President, faced down the Soviet Premier, Nikita S. Khrushchev, in a nuclear confrontation. But the purpose of his visit was a mystery yesterday.

title: Judge Gives Marv Albert Option to Avoid Jail
description: The sportscaster Marv Albert will not have to serve any jail time for assaulting a woman in a hotel room tryst last February.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Whitman Debates McGreevey
description: In their third and final televised debate, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and State Senator James E. McGreevey sharpened their attacks on each other and aggressively defended their own records last night, focusing on two issues that voters cite as their biggest concerns: taxes and automobile insurance rates. [Page A1.]

title: Religion Journal; Orthodox Patriarch Reaches Out to U.S. and the World
description: Almost since the moment his plane landed in the United States last Sunday, Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew I, spiritual leader of the world's Eastern Orthodox Christians, has received a high measure of official acclaim.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Everyone is so sad at its closing. There's something about that round room, the blue leather and the marvelous, courteous service that's really wonderful. To sit there at those desks and have people bring books to you . . . .''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILKER, MARGARET G.
description: WILKER-Margaret G. On Thursday, October 23, 1997 of Chevy Chase, Maryland. Wife of the late Philip John Wilker. Mother of Mary I. O'Herron, Silver Spring, Maryland, Philip Jay Wilker, NYC and Christopher Paul WIlker, San Marino, CA. Sister of William Legler, Tucson, AZ. Grandmother of John, Margaret, Felicity and Sarah O'Herron and Anne Wilker. Friends will be received at Pumphrey's Bethesda-Chevy Chase Funeral Home, 7557 Wisconsin Avenue, Bethesda, MD on Sunday from 3-5PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic Church, 7500 Pearl Street, Bethesda, MD, on Monday, October 27 at 10 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Covenant House, 460 West 41st Street, New York, NY 10036.

title: Arts Center Wins a Vow Of Support By Gingrich
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich has promised to support a complete renovation of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, an effort that he said would cost $170 million over the next 10 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOYNO, SHIRLEY PEISER.
description: DOYNO-Shirley Peiser. After a brave struggle with cancer, on October 23, 1997. Beloved mother of Barry and the late Donna. Cherished mother-in-law of Ruthy. Adored Nana of Stefan and Justin. We will always love her with all our hearts and were all blessed to have been loved by her. She was intelligent, witty, selfless and ultimately totally courageous. She will remain in our hearts forever. Funeral on Sunday, 11:45 A.M., Riverside Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Now This Is a Superhighway
description: Just a few months ago, if you were trying to get from, say, Gerlach, Nev., to Jungo, Nev., you would have had to endure an arduous crossing of the 50 miles of scorching desert in between. By conventional car, that would have taken nearly an hour. Bring your canteen! But now, thanks to the new supersonic jet-powered car, which on Oct. 15 set a land speed record of 763.035 miles an hour, that trip will take a scant 3 minutes and 56 seconds. Go ahead, check the math. You'd be a fool to waste time crossing ancient dry lake beds by any other means.

title: Car Crash Kills Officer, Injures Another on S.I.
description: An off-duty New York City Police officer was killed and his passenger, also a city police officer, was seriously injured early yesterday on Staten Island when the car they were in hit a tree, the police said.

title: LABOR
description: A show of solidarity yesterday between the National Basketball Players Association and 12 of the game's most influential agents sent Commissioner David Stern a message: if the owners exercise their right to open the collective bargaining agreement next April, they will face tougher negotiations than they did in 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MURPHY, PATRICK G.
description: MURPHY-Patrick G. October 25. 1944 to October 12, 1962. Happy Birthday. We still miss you. All our love. Mom, Peggy, John & Joe.

title: Don't Censor Voices of Teen-Age Poets
description: To the Editor:

title: National News Briefs; Alumnus Pledges to Give $30 Million to Bowdoin
description: Bowdoin College announced yesterday that an alumnus, Stanley F. Druckenmiller, a New York international investor, would give it at least $30 million, the largest gift in the college's 203-year history and the largest ever from an individual to an institution in Maine.

title: Defense Propels Giants' Turnabout
description: Coach Jim Fassel has divided the Giants' season into four quadrants, and the goal for each one is a 3-1 record. ''If that happens, then we're 12-4,'' Fassel said. ''That might be the best anyone could expect.''

title: I.R.S. Reform May Not Benefit the Taxpayers; Un-American Rule?
description: To the Editor:

title: Childs Steps Out of Lineup for Ward
description: Someone had to say it. And the person who finally stepped forward and admitted that Charlie Ward was the better starting point guard for the Knicks right now was none other than Chris Childs.

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP
description: EUROCARD OPEN

title: New Heart Drug Wins Approval of F.D.A. Panel
description: Plavix, a new heart drug that its manufacturers say is superior to aspirin, today won the backing of a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel.

title: Bank Account Looks Bleak For Messinger In Final Days
description: Ruth W. Messinger is running low on money with just more than a week to go in the mayoral race, throwing into question whether her underdog campaign will able to mount what could be a critical operation to get her supporters to the polls on Election Day.

title: Bridge; U.S. Squads Sure to Qualify For Championship Playoffs
description: With two rounds of qualifying play remaining in the world team championships here, all four United States teams are sure to qualify for playoffs beginning on Sunday. But two dramatic battles are in progress for the lesser placings that will determine the other qualifiers.

title: Lute Olson Adjusts To Life at the Top
description: Arizona fans from across the country were eager to tell Lute Olson where they were and how they celebrated after the Wildcats unexpectedly won the national basketball championship last spring. It was a steady barrage -- in airports, restaurants, gas stations -- and the importance of being No. 1 began to transform the coach's life.

title: Impasse Over Campaign Finance Creates Logjam in the Senate
description: As the Senate failed again today to end an impasse over campaign finance legislation that is blocking several other bills, House Democrats sought to force the full House to address the same issue.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Jimmy Herbert, Track and Field Star at the Garden, Dies at 82
