description: Jimmy Herbert of New Rochelle, N.Y., who won more races than any other runner at Madison Square Garden, died Thursday night in Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 82 years old.

title: Rock's 1998 Hall of Fame Inductees
description: The Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame's inductees next year will include four rock groups -- the Eagles, Fleetwood Mac, the Mamas and Papas, and Santana -- and the performers Lloyd Price and Gene Vincent, it was announced yesterday.

title: HIBERNIA TO BUY TEXAS BANK FOR $66.4 MILLION
description: The Hibernia Corporation announced late yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Firstshares of Texas Inc. for $66.4 million in stock. The transaction will allow Hibernia to expand its coverage to four more counties in northeast Texas. Firstshares of Texas has assets of $292 million. After the merger, the name of the bank will be changed to Hibernia National Bank of Texas in mid-1998. After completion of this merger and others, Hibernia, which is based in New Orleans, will be an $11.4-billion-asset organization.

title: Boeing Loss Is Worse Than Expected Despite Sales Boom
description: The Boeing Company, struggling to keep up with the demand for its commercial airplanes, reported a 26.2 percent rise in quarterly revenue yesterday but suffered a larger-than-expected loss.

title: Prize in Hand, a Young Singer Takes Flight
description: As a prize title, the Alice Tully Vocal Arts Debut Recital Award is a mouthful. Its purpose is specific and worthy: to sponsor a current or recent Juilliard voice student in a New York debut. The first recipient of this new award is Stephanie Houtzeel, a mezzo-soprano born in Germany and raised in the United States, whose debut recital, with the pianist Kyle Nobles, took place on Thursday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Excerpts From Interview With Democratic Mayoral Candidate
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Ruth W. Messinger conducted on Thursday by editors and reporters from The New York Times.

title: Fears of a Sale By Swiss Send Gold Plunging
description: Gold prices plunged to the lowest level in more than 12 years yesterday after a Swiss Government panel recommended that the country sell about half its gold reserves, raising fears that other countries would do the same and inundate the market.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: OFFICER GUILTY OF MURDER -- A New York City police officer was found guilty of murder for shooting a man to death in a dispute over a parking space. B2.

title: London Journal; In Hallowed Reading Room, Last Page Is Turned
description: To Virginia Woolf, it was like a domed brain that loomed overhead ''as if one was a thought in the huge bald forehead.'' To Louis MacNeice it was a beehive full of ''stooping haunted readers.'' To Karl Marx, destitute but aflame with radical ideas, it was the refuge that enabled him to produce ''Das Kapital.''

title: Those Primary Colors
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Frees Immigrant Jailed for 1974 Misdemeanor
description: Facing a barrage of criticism from members of Congress and advocacy groups, Federal officials reversed their interpretation of a strict new immigration law and released a Brooklyn resident yesterday after he had spent 201 days in a Pennsylvania prison for a 23-year-old misdemeanor.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MORDETSKY, HARVEY
description: MORDETSKY-Harvey. On your birthday we miss you still. We always will. Russell

title: Man Dies Despite Attempt At Rescue
description: An off-duty New York City firefighter leapt into the East River yesterday afternoon in a vain attempt to save a man whose car had plunged into the frigid waters, the police said.

title: Ex-MCA Holders Win Right to Sue
description: A group of former shareholders of MCA Inc. won the right today to pursue a trial to collect as much as $1.4 billion in damages from the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company.

title: Justice Dept. Looks Into Babbitt's Role in Killing Casino
description: The Justice Department has opened an inquiry into Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's role in the rejection of an Indian casino opposed by a rival group that lobbied against the project and gave money to the Democrats, officials said today.

title: Safety Alert
description: Standard time resumes at 2 A.M. tomorrow; clocks should be set back an hour.

title: PIONEER HI-BRED BUYBACK PUT AT $92.50 TO $94 A SHARE
description: Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. said yesterday that the prices at which it would buy back 16.4 million shares, or 20 percent of its total outstanding, would be somewhere in the range of $92.50 to $94 a share, under the Dutch auction that expired on Thursday. The auction was part of a transaction announced in August under which E.I du Pont de Nemours & Company agreed to acquire a 20 percent stake in Pioneer, the world's largest seed company, for $1.7 billion, or $104 a share. In a Dutch auction the company gives a range of prices it is willing to pay and buys the lowest-priced shares tendered within that range. The orginal range set by Pioneer was $88 to $104 a share.

title: Here It Is Again, Folks
description: During the World Series, NBC has displayed the full range of its technological tools. To standard, slow-motion, super-slo-mo and reverse-angle replays from each of the dozens of cameras in the ball park, it has added strobe-like pitch-by-pitch sequences and computer simulations that track the flight of the pitched ball and deviations in its trajectory. Graphics flash across the screen like tracer fire. The first-base coach is miked but has nothing to say. We must be just a season away from a mini-cam mounted in the barrel of the bat, where the cork goes. When it comes to calling pitches, there is no longer any doubt in the viewer's mind where the ball crossed the plate. The only remaining question is, what was the umpire thinking?

title: Did Mr. Babbitt Buckle?
description: The excavation of President Clinton's fund-raising practices has now unearthed what could be one of the most serious abuses of the 1996 campaign. Janet Reno, the Attorney General, has begun a preliminary inquiry into allegations that White House pressure influenced Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's decision to deny a gambling casino proposed by three Chippewa Indian tribes in Wisconsin. The casino had been bitterly contested by rival tribes that later made substantial contributions to the Democratic campaign apparatus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTEIN, RUTH RICHARDS
description: EISENSTEIN-Ruth Richards 91, at home Tuesday, October 21, 1997. Senior Editor at Harry N. Abrams, Inc., founding member Manhattan Reconstructionist Havurah and West End Synagogue. Cherished wife of Myron (z''l). Remembered with love by children and their spouses, Paula Eisenstein Baker & Stephen D. Baker, Hester Eisenstein and Michael Tanzer, & Jethro M. Eisenstein and Stefany Gordon; grandchildren, Hannah Baker Hitzhusen, Sarah Baker Topper, Max Gordon Eisenstein, and Leo Gordon Eisenstein; great-grandchildren, Leah Malka Topper and Rachel Batya Topper. Serviceswere held Friday, October 24. Minyan at 419 East 57th, Saturday, Sunday, Monday, 7:30PM. Contributions to West End Synagogue or National Yiddish Book Center, Amherst, MA. 01002-3375.

title: Polaroid in Stock Buyback
description: The Polaroid Corporation is planning to buy back as much as 11 percent of its stock, or as many as 5 million of 45.6 million shares outstanding, in the next three years. At current prices, the entire purchase would cost about $240 million, which Polaroid will pay with cash generated from its day-to-day business and the sale of real estate, a spokesman said. Polaroid's stock gained $1.5625 today, to $47.9375.

title: Preservation Group Honors Canadian
description: The World Monuments Fund presented its annual Hadrian Award for preservation of world art and architecture yesterday to Phyllis Lambert, founder and director of the Canadian Center for Architecture in Montreal.

title: Ailing Alou Rises Up To Power Marlins
description: Moises Alou spent all of Game 5 shaking off one malady or another.

title: Deciding Best Team In a State, And More
description: The Paul Bunyan Trophy is just the beginning. The issue has become far greater than a local difference of opinion, the annual football clash between green and blue when Michigan State meets Michigan for a trophy first awarded 44 years ago.

title: Limon's Craggy Grandeur
description: Just why Jose Limon was considered choreographically important in his time was made clear when the Limon Dance Company performed on Thursday night at the Joyce Theater. The program included four well-danced works by Limon, who died in 1972. All revealed his ability to set people moving with craggy grandeur and emotional fervor. Their power remains undiminished.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  EBERT BROWN, JOYCE
description: EBERT BROWN-Joyce. A memorial Monday, Oct. 27 for Joyce Ebert Brown at Long Wharf Theatre, New Haven, CT at 4 PM. Donations in memoriam to Long Wharf Theatre. No flowers please.

title: I.R.S. Reform May Not Benefit the Taxpayers; Protect the Honest
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A list of travel directions in Weekend yesterday with an article about wilderness areas of New York City included outdated information about a bus to Alley Pond Park in Douglaston, Queens. The bus, connecting the Union Turnpike/Kew Gardens subway station on the E and F lines with Winchester Boulevard, is the Q46, not the Q44A.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, BABETTE ROSMOND
description: STONE-Babette Rosmond. Novelist. Died October 23, 1997. Beloved wife of Henry Stone. Loving mother of James Stone and Gene Stone, and grandmother of Curtis Henry Stone and Lauren Kelly Stone. Devoted mother-in-law of Cathleen W. Douglas Stone.

title: I.R.S. Reform May Not Benefit the Taxpayers; Bully Tactics
description: To the Editor:

title: High Stakes in Las Vegas For Those on the Bubble
description: When today's round was over, a nervous Neal Lancaster hugged his wife, Lou Ann, thankful that she had agreed to become his caddie two weeks ago.

title: St. John's Has a Future, But Seniors Won't See It
description: St. John's freshmen were galloping up and down the court at Alumni Hall, leaving Felipe Lopez, Zendon Hamilton and Tarik Turner one thought: what took so long?

title: Whitman Raises Badge Incident of '88
description: James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate for governor, answered a question in tonight's debate about impersonating police officers the unsurprising way his two opponents did. He said he was against it.

title: Sublime Sadness of the Portuguese
description: Across their former empire, the Portuguese carried the idea of saudade, a wistful, nostalgic sadness and longing that imbue poetry and songs. Portuguese fado, Brazilian bossa nova and Cape Verdean morna are all permeated by saudade. And that mood, as much as the Portuguese language, linked the double bill of Cesaria Evora, from Cape Verde, and Madredeus, from Portugal, at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center on Thursday night.

title: Series Ratings Are Still Down
description: Thursday's Game 5 of the World Series between the Cleveland Indians and the Florida Marlins got a 17.2 rating and a 30 percent share, Nielsen Media research said yesterday. The rating was down 14 percent from the 20.0 for last year's Game 5 between the Atlanta Braves and the Yankees and down 20 percent from Game 5 of the 1995 Series between the Indians and Atlanta Braves.

title: A Path Clears for Skip Away
description: Gentlemen, widely considered the best race horse in the country and the leading candidate for Horse of the Year, came down with a fever at Hollywood Park yesterday and almost certainly will not run in the Breeders' Cup in two weeks.

title: Man Convicted of Murder In 5 Killings in Shoe Store
description: A man who killed five people and maimed three others in a shooting rampage in a Bronx shoe store was convicted yesterday on five counts of first-degree murder and four of attempted murder.

title: As Turmoil Builds, Thai Leader Shuffles Cabinet
description: Thailand's political turmoil widened today, with the Prime Minister shuffling his Cabinet, naming a new Finance Minister and pledging to hold early elections.

title: Futurism Returns but Its Bad Image Lingers
description: VENICE  Filippo Tommaso Marinetti, poet, publicist, rabble-rouser and founder of Futurism, glorified speed, machines, mass culture, modern warfare and Benito Mussolini, to whom Marinetti remained faithful until the dictator's death in December 1944.

title: VISION TWENTY-ONE IN DEAL TO ADD BLOCK VISION
description: Vision Twenty-One Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the eye-care services company Block Vision for $37.5 million in cash, stock and assumed debt. Vision Twenty-One, based in Largo, Fla., provides management services to eye-care providers and networks. Block Vision, based in Boca Raton, Fla. operates a managed-care division and a buying-group division. It had revenue of $23.8 million for the four months ended Aug. 31. Vision Twenty-One's stock fell $1.25 a share yesterday, to $13.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Twins Onstage and Individuals Off; A Show in Which Everything Is the Opposite of What It Seems
description: One of the first questions almost everyone asks upon meeting Alice Ripley and Emily Skinner, who play Siamese twins in the Broadway musical ''Side Show,'' is whether they are glued together during tricky production numbers that require them to seem joined at the hip. Although Ms. Ripley and Ms. Skinner make separate entrances at the beginning of the show, and Ms. Skinner appears by herself in a dream sequence, for the rest of the show, they seem physically connected, moving with an easy synchronized perfection that suggests their costumes have been sewn together.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, MAX, M.D.
description: SINGER-Max, M.D. On October 24, 1997 of Stamford, CT. Formerly of New Rochelle and White Plains, NY. Beloved husband of the late Belle P. Singer and Norma Monoson Singer. Devoted father of Elliot Roy Singer, M.D. of Chappaqua, NY, Marcia Rogull of Rye Brook, NY and Roberta Aviram of Kings Point, NY. Dear grandfather of Elan and Kai Singer, Joshua and Sarah Rogull and Jesse, Simona and Armond Aviram. He was a life member of the Medical Society State of New York, a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons, and attending Opthalmologist Emeritus of New York Eye and Ear Infirmary. Services will be held Sunday October 26, 11:30 AM at Temple Israel of New Rochelle, 1000 Pinebrook Blvd. Interment West Ridge Lawn Cemetery, Clifton, NJ. Contributions may be made to UJA-Federation.

title: YACHT RACING: A SAILOR'S JOURNAL; A Cramped Home Away From Home
description: Ten yachts, all about 64 feet long with a crew of up to 12, began the 31,600-nautical mile Whitbread Round the World Race on Sept. 21. EF Language, skippered by Paul Cayard, won the first of nine stages, the 7,350-mile voyage through the Atlantic, arriving in Cape Town last Tuesday. Two yachts remain to finish: EF Education, the Swedish entry with an all-women's crew, which is expected today, and Brunel Sunergy, which should arrive Monday. Katie Pettibone, an American on EF Education, is filing periodic reports from sea until the race's scheduled return to Southampton next May. This is her sixth report.

title: David Lang and Debra Ellenoff
description: Debra Susan Ellenoff, the daughter of Lois C. Ellenoff of New York and the late Theodore Ellenoff, was married last evening to David Gary Lang, the son of Elaine L. Ockner of Tiburon, Calif., and Dr. Howard L. Lang of Greenbrae, Calif. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein officiated at Central Synagogue in New York.

title: GRAND NATIONAL
description: Rowdy Irishman, who had not won in his last 11 starts over hurdles, became a contender for steeplechaser of the year honors when he galloped to a 1 1/4-length victory yesterday in the Breeders' Cup Grand National at the Far Hills Races in Far Hills, N.J.

title: Rapping As Good Business
description: RAPPERS DON'T JUST RAP ANY MORE. THEY plug clothing lines, star in sitcoms, pitch products, scout talent, form alliances, write books. All that activity reflects hard-nosed strategy, because rappers face the fastest obsolescence of any performers in pop.

title: Exploiting the Living
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWE, VIOLET LUCILLE SMITH
description: LOWE-Violet Lucille Smith. Beloved sister of Shirley Cooke and Hortense Thompson. Passed away October 19, 1997. She was a graduate of Hunter College, a Girl Scout leader, choir member, member of the Lions, St. Fathaith Guild, Cursillo and the Episcopal Church Women. She was a former health inspector supervisor for the New York City Department of Health. Services at the Church of St. James the Less, 107-61 166th St, Jamaica, NY 11433, Sunday, October 26, 1997, at 7 PM.

title: Nancy Obler, Joseph Kaufman
description: Nancy Lynn Obler, the daughter of Geri and Arnold Obler of Great Neck, N.Y., was married last night to Joseph Andrew Kaufman, the son of Gloria and Herbert F. Kaufman of West Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Yaacov Rone performed the ceremony at the Parker Meridien Hotel in New York.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE; Lessons Long Remembered
description: After serving in Asia during World War II, Art D'Lugoff returned to New York, where he enrolled at New York University as a political science major. There he met Rita Nealon Cooley, who taught American government and related courses and who, Mr. D'Lugoff said, changed his life and the lives of many other N.Y.U. students over four decades.

title: Step by Step to Glory: Faith and Worship Through Dance
description: The choreographer Martha Graham said that ''Wherever a dancer stands ready, that spot is holy ground.''

title: MARIJUANA AND PRO BASKETBALL -- A special report.; N.B.A.'s Uncontrolled Substance.
description: Contrary to the wholesome image marketed by the National Basketball Association, 60 to 70 percent of its 350-plus players smoke marijuana and drink excessively, according to conversations with more than two dozen players, former players, agents and basketball executives.

title: University Presses; Starting Over
description: Ghetto Schooling A Political Economy of Urban Educational Reform. By Jean Anyon. 216 pp. New York: Teachers College Press. Cloth, $45. Paper, $18.95.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: October 26, 1997
description: Weeks

title: October 19-25; A Push for Patient Rights
description: A Presidential commission proposed major new protections for patients buffeted by changes in the health care industry.

title: Word & Image; Money: Hard, Soft and Dirty
description: The movement to clean up campaign financing is going nowhere for the simple reason that the reformers are aiming at the wrong target. They are laboring to limit the flow of money into politics when they should be looking to limit the candidates' need for money to pay for television time. It is the staggering price of addressing the voters that drives the unseemly money chase.

title: Ideas & Trends; Brave New Power Grid
description: WOULD offering a bird-feeder coax people into dumping the electric company they've known all their lives for one they've never heard of? How about a spruce sapling? Or a claim that the new company's power is ''greener''?

title: The High Priestess of P.S. 1
description: ALANNA HEISS WAS ON AN adrenaline high. She was standing in a space where coal was once stored at P.S. 1 in Long Island City, Queens, holding a little Robert Ryman painting against a crumbling stone wall. As light from a tiny skylight bathed the acrylic-on-aluminum work, everyone around her gasped. The painting had suddenly shimmered to life.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: GARDEN

title: Opening Night and Beyond as the Arts Center Comes Alive
description: AFTER years of laborious planning and fund-raising, Newark has defied reports of its demise, bringing forth a structure of inviting elegance. The $180 million New Jersey Performing Arts Center is being greeted as a miracle to rival Christmas.

title: A Schoolhouse Revival of 'Betrayal'
description: THINK of world-class playwrights with instantly recognizable styles. Surely, Harold Pinter, who fortified English reserve with menace, leaps to mind. So does David Mamet, American drama's pitchman for the eloquence of the expletive.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Edgewater Is Catching Up on Developing Riverfront
description: THE stage is being set for a second wave of development along the Hudson River waterfront in Edgewater, where nearly 100 gritty acres of former industrial land are to give way over the next five years to a collection of houses and retail stores overlooking the river.

title: University Presses; Police Story
description: WILD COWBOYS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASCH, ESTHER
description: ASCH-Esther. Devoted wife of the late Alexander. Beloved mother of Arthur and Anita, Jerry and Marianne. Adoring grandmother to Lisa, Michael and Toni, Jonathan, Michelle and Larry Diamond, Jenny and Michael Fenton. Greatgrandmother of Alexis, David, Sarah, Noah and Jake. Loving sister of Roz Pimsler and sister-in-law Florrie Willner. Always in our hearts and minds, she has found the peace she deserved.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHMELKA, JEAN
description: SHMELKA-Jean. In our thoughts every single day for 1827 days. Rob & Dee

title: Ogea's Hits Surprise Even His Teammates
description: The last time Chad Ogea tried flailing at Kevin Brown's awesome fastballs, his teammates teased him and congratulated him for simply fouling off some pitches. But tonight, the Indians were no longer teasing Ogea about his rusty swings. They were thanking him for keeping their season alive.

title: Where a Democracy and Its Money Have No Place
description: EARLIER THIS YEAR, JANE ALEXANDER, THE departing chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, wearily spoke of recurring Congressional attempts to ''drive a stake in the heart of Federal funding for the arts.'' She called these exorcistic rites a ''nearly debilitating annual Sturm und Drang that threatens to suck the life out of all arts advocates.''

title: That Unwritten Code Against Fraternization
description: IN the 1980's it was rumors -- repeatedly denied -- of an office affair between the then Bendix Corporation chairman, William Agee, and his aide, Mary Cunningham, that resulted in headlines and led to the resignation of Ms. Cunningham. Last week, the scandal involved Martin E. Hanaka, the president of Staples Inc., who resigned after a subordinate accused him of assaulting her during an argument after what the company described as a ''personal relationship'' between the two.

title: NATO Expansion Shows West's Global Ambition; 'Original Mission'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ca Change
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to see the Hotel de la Sorbonne (''What's Doing in Paris,'' Sept. 28) as a budget inn ($66 to $84), but wistful as to the change in the meaning of budget. When I stayed there in 1934 the budget price was 8 francs, or 56 cents.

title: ON THE MAP; Chenille May Be Fluff, but Here It's Taken Seriously
description: Suddenly, fluffily, it's chenille. Or rather, chenille again.

title: Meet the Occasionally Gentle Giants: The Two Sides of Four Linebackers
description: Jessie Armstead says football almost gave him an identity crisis. Writing is one of his hobbies.

title: Wild And Woolly
description: Call it mod. Call it classic. Even call it trendy. It's the cashmere tie, the antithesis of the boldly patterned, shiny 1980's power tie.

title: Two's the Number in Two Shows With Two Artists in Each Show
description: THIS week, it is a pair of pairs -- John Pindyck Miller and Robert Spinazzola, showing at the Sound Shore Gallery in the Yellow Monkey Village in Cross River and Joy Moser and Joan Lewis at Westchester Community College's Fine Arts Gallery in Valhalla.

title: Miss Thompson And Mr. Terral
description: Jennifer Thompson, a daughter of Theresa Pringle of Silver Springs, N.Y., and William Thompson of Hilton, N.Y., was married on Friday to Adam Terral, the son of Carolyn Rathbun of Morgan City, La., and Kenneth Terral of Ruston, La. The Rev. Fred Hunter, a United Methodist chaplain, performed the ceremony at the Old State House in Little Rock, Ark.

title: Thick Maze Of Objections Slows Down U.N. Reforms
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan's plans to make major changes in the way the United Nations works have run into serious trouble in General Assembly committees, where they are being buried in a blizzard of questions and objections.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Venice Pizza Owner Cheered By Return to Familiar Faces

title: A REMINDER
description: Standard time resumed at 2 A.M. today. Clocks were set back one hour.

title: Cynthia O'Neill, Douglas Pollack
description: Cynthia Elizabeth O'Neill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. O'Neill of Redding, Conn., was married yesterday to Dr. Douglas Fraser Pollack, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Pollack of Delray Beach, Fla. The Rev. Dean C. Ahlberg, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Fairfield County Hunt Club in Westport, Conn.

title: Guns in Israel
description: To the Editor: I'm pleased to learn that Edith Pearlman became comfortable over time with young Israeli soldiers carrying rifles.

title: Susan Schoenfeld, A. P. Harrington
description: Susan Jane Schoenfeld, the daughter of Ileen and Norman P. Schoenfeld of New York, is to be married today to Dr. Andrew Philip Harrington, a son of Alma and John Harrington of London. Rabbi Sarah Reinas is to perform the ceremony at the Central Synagogue in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEG, FRANK A.
description: WEG-Frank A. 5 years ago today. To our friend and mentor, your legacy lives on in everyone you touched, however brief your time. We miss you. Weg and Myers, P.C.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE ASSAILS PENTAGON ON GULF WAR ILLS
description: After a 20-month investigation, the panel that has led the chief Congressional inquiry into the illnesses of Persian Gulf war veterans will ask that the Defense Department and the Department of Veterans Affairs be stripped of their authority over the issue.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rachel Shapiro and Robert Green
description: Rachel Tamar Shapiro, the daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Howard Shapiro of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., was married last evening to Dr. Robert Jeffrey Green, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Green of Palm Beach. Rabbi Shapiro, the leader of Temple Israel in West Palm Beach, officiated at his synagogue.

title: Meaning In a Suit From Mali
description: AN aura of the faraway clung to the thick, still air in a dimly lighted shop in Harlem smelling of incense and curry. Stereo speakers blasted the rhythms of Senegal and Mali. Near the center of the shop, Baobad Imports, an outlet for African wares on Lenox Avenue near 127th Street, I stood in my stocking feet, checking the fit and meaning of my mud cloth.

title: October 19-25; Roll Over, Bing Crosby
description: Elton John's ''Candle in the Wind '97,'' the song he sang at the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, has become the best-selling single of all time: 35 million copies and counting.

title: Off-Year Elections Handicap Challengers
description: TAD SCHARFENBERG, Democratic candidate for Suffolk County District Attorney, called a news conference this month to outline his 10-point plan to change the prosecutor's office.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE NEW COLORED PEOPLE

title: Democrats Defecting On Lower East Side
description: Carmine Morales should be Ruth W. Messinger's last, best hope. Busily sweeping the sidewalk in front of his Lower East Side coffee shop, Mr. Morales, a 46-year-old lifelong Democrat, is emblematic of a diverse neighborhood and group of swing voters that Ms. Messinger must carry to upset Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: The Needle Trade
description: In ''The Needle Trade'' (The Big City, Oct. 5), John Tierney mistakenly describes the Lower East Side Needle Exchange as a drug hub and asserts that the community deserves better. In fact, the exchange was created by that community.

title: PULSE: In the Mail; P.R. Bauble Of the Week
description: Rubik's Cube-like invitation to a party on Wednesday for 50 years of Ford Models.

title: Joline Leibowitz, David Stemerman
description: Joline Faye Leibowitz, the daughter of Shawn and Peter Leibowitz of New York, was married last evening to David Israel Stemerman, the son of Dr. Michael Stemerman of Riverside, Calif., and the late Judith Stemerman. Rabbi Renni S. Altman performed the ceremony at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: Teresa Enriquez, Scott Wornow
description: Teresa Louise Enriquez, the daughter of Patricia L. Land of Potomac, Md., was married on Friday evening to Scott Mitchel Wornow, a son of Alvin and Bernice Wornow of Nesconset, N.Y. The Rev. Delbridge Narron, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Harvard Club in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESSER, LEON
description: DESSER-Leon. On October 21, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Lillian, loving father of Stuart and dear brother of Maxwell. His wisdom, guidance and love will be greatly missed.

title: Lives; A Handwritten Life
description: It is an old brown notebook, its virgin vinyl cover not looking its age, as indicated by the imprimatur Made in U.S.A. Yet within the 6-by-4-inch confines of its six-ringed, loose-leaf ambit lies the record of my life. Not my whole life by any means, but my life as a newspaperman that lasted nearly a half-century. It is the sort of life that true New Historians, like Fernand Braudel, would appreciate. No sloppy, suspect ruminations, no faulty memories. It is a business life told in telephone numbers, the calls I made, most of them to produce news. It is handwritten.

title: University Presses; Roll Over, Beethoven
description: AMERICAN BANDSTAND

title: Teaching Reading
description: To the Editor:

title: New Type of Psychotherapy Seen as Boon to Traumatic Disorders
description: SEXUALLY abused by a relative from the ages of 5 to 11, Deirdre, a 29-year-old nurse living on the South Shore, spent much of her life in a rage until she tried a new type of psychotherapy. The memory of her abuse was repressed until she was about 19, she said, then the flashbacks began and she was consumed with anger and a feeling that she was suffocating. At 21, her impending marriage encouraged her to seek help.

title: They Want the Beat to Go On
description: They were banging the drums loudly in the dank basement of the Fareta School of Dance and Drum, filling the air with the rhythms of Senegal and Guinea, Cuba, Brazil and the Bronx, and the eternal beat of life and hope, sadness and loss.

title: Lonely Planet Guides Take On New York
description: This fall marks a milepost for Lonely Planet Publications, begun in 1973 at a kitchen table in Sydney, Australia. There the company's founders, Tony and Maureen Wheeler, ended a long honeymoon to the Orient from England by putting together the first Lonely Planet guidebook, ''Across Asia on the Cheap.'' Guides to Southeast Asia, Africa and India followed, providing the backpacking crowd with detailed information on dirt-cheap trips to exotic places. Lately, though, the books have begun to address travelers with somewhat deeper pockets, and in the early 90's Lonely Planet marched across the third world and reached Europe and the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JANOVER, DAVID EDWARD
description: JANOVER-David Edward. On October 12, 1997. Of East Bruswick, New Jersey. Beloved father and grandfather. In our hearts you will live forever.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SENORA RODRIGUEZ AND OTHER WORLDS By Martha Cerda. Duke University, cloth, $35; paper, $12.95.

title: Can Brooklyn Keep Its Maestro While He's Hot?
description: LAST SEASON, THERE WAS MUCH talk among music critics and concertgoers in New York about what Robert Spano was accomplishing in his first year as music director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic. The orchestra, essentially a part-time ensemble, was playing with new vigor and striking technical command.

title: Patricia Burns, Sanford Ross
description: Patricia Pearson Burns and Sanford R. Ross were married last evening at the Box Tree restaurant in New York. The Rev. Jon Mundy of the Interfaith Fellowship performed the ceremony.

title: Haute-Tech Couture
description: Before picking up the newspaper, chances are you put in your plastic polymer contact lenses and strapped on your quartz watch.

title: For Reluctant Shoppers, A Turn Toward Tailors
description: IT'S an anything-goes fashion season, with retailers promoting everything from reptile prints and leather wrap dresses to pointy-breasted bustiers paired with pinstriped suits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REES, MINA S.
description: REES-Mina S. October 25, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Leopold Brahdy. Devoted aunt of Dorothy Halpin. Cherished great-aunt of Suzanne Schmitz, James, Kevin and Paul Halpin. A memorial service will be held at a later date at the City University of NY Graduate School.

title: POSTINGS: Seminars on Historic Preservation; Renovating Landmarks
description: Renovating historic buildings is the subject of two panel discussions this week. On Wednesday, the New York City Bar Association will bring together lawyers and preservationists ''to give a blow-by-blow account of the renovation process,'' said Mindy H. Stern, head of the Bar Association's Real Property Law Committee. The committee is sponsoring the free seminar, ''Bringing Landmarked Buildings and Historic Structures Into the 21st Century Without Going Broke.''

title: Stripes And the Man
description: THE real tragedy of so-called dress-down Friday is that so few men have any idea what to wear. Men have long been accustomed to dressing for either professional or casual duties, but bridging the two has not proved a particularly stylish undertaking.

title: A Funny Man Earns It The 2,000-Year-Old Way
description: HERE is Mel Brooks, the director of the sidesplitting classics ''Blazing Saddles'' and ''Young Frankenstein,'' as he dons the persona of the 2,000-Year-Old Man to talk money with Carl Reiner, his 40-year sidekick.

title: October 19-25; Birds Do It. So Do Squid, But Violently.
description: Female praying mantises and black widow spiders eat their lovers during or after sex. Female angler fish keep their mates captive as tiny parasites attached to their bodies, the male diminished in size to little more than a reproductive organ.

title: Lauren Bauer, Daniel Zinman
description: Lauren Michelle Bauer, a daughter of Marian J. Bauer of Stamford, Conn., and Stephen B. Bauer of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married last evening to Daniel Charles Zinman, the son of Sara and David H. Zinman of Point Lookout, N.Y. Judge Harold Baer Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated at the Rockrimmon Country Club in Stamford.

title: Bringing to Life That Legend That Was Diaghilev
description: IN A DIM GALLERY FILLED WITH life-size dolls, a faceless puppet leaps high in a flutter of rose petals, modeling the costume made famous by Vaslav Nijinsky in the ballet ''Le Spectre de la Rose.'' Nearby, a female doll wearing a dress of silver lame and appliqued satin lifts her right foot to begin the mazurka from ''The Sleeping Princess.'' Rarely have mannequins had this much fun.

title: Dissing Newark
description: To the Editor: While waiting for the departure of Continental Flight 726 from Fort Myers to Newark on Sept. 19, I heard a male voice announce over the loudspeaker: ''Continental Flight 726 now boarding for romantic Newark, N.J.'' This was greeted by guffaws and snide comments by the waiting.

title: Correction
description: A caption last Sunday about gay politics incorrectly described Gina Reiss of the New Jersey Lesbian and Gay Coalition in a picture of a voter registration drive. She was seated at far right in the picture, not standing in the center.

title: Intergalactic Interviewer Flies Again
description: REMEMBER Arsenio, Chevy, Dennis? All gone. But not Space Ghost. No, Space Ghost, now starting his fourth season, has succeeded in capturing a segment of the late-night talk show market that even Jay and Dave can't hope to reach: viewers aged 8 to 11 whose parents let them stay up till 11 on Friday nights. (Also teen-agers and a chunk of the demographically significant trend-setters in the 18-to-25 category, who obviously don't watch the 11 o'clock news.)

title: Bradley, in Retirement, Remains Coy on Presidency
description: Bill Bradley, the former three-term Senator from New Jersey, has relocated to Stanford University for a year, and he professes not to be thinking these days about politics or about his own designs on the Presidency.

title: Sharks and Others Who Work on Stage
description: SOME theatergoers will look upon Moss Hart's ''Light Up the Sky'' with wistful remembrances of the way theater was. Others will talk dismissively of the play as time-warped trivia. Written in 1948, when the theater of the spoken word meant Broadway exclusively, Mr. Hart was eulogizing its mad, mad pace, knowing a slow dance at death's door was imminent.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-15

title: New York Retreating On Special Education
description: ''Fiscal Woes Turn Special Education Upside Down'' (Oct. 5) points to some of the problems faced by parents of preschoolers who are disabled. As the director of an early intervention program for children from birth to age 3 with developmental delays and disabilities, I am well aware of the difficulties facing the families of these children. I am particularly concerned with the decrease of options available to parents when their child turns 3 and becomes eligible for preschool services. Including children with special needs in classes designed for their typically developing peers may work for some. However, many children with disabilities need the small classes, high adults to child ratio and continuity of five day a week programming that has traditionally been provided in special education preschool settings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, RALPH
description: PETERSON-Ralph. Passed away Monday, October 20, 1997 after a brief illness. Ralph was a dear husband to his wife, Patricia; a loving father to his 3 children, Jeffrey, Stacey and Beth; an adoring grandfather to Jami, Scott, David and Brian; and a devoted brother to Phyllis Makransky. His professional life as Chief Finance Officer of Warner Brothers spanned three decades. A memorial service will be held Thursday, 4 P.M., October 30, at Temple Emeth, 1666 Windsor Road, Teaneck, New Jersey. Services under the direction of Gutterman - Musicant, Hacken sack, New Jersey (1-800-522-0588).

title: Scientocracy
description: ENDLESS FRONTIER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLORIN, PAULINE
description: FLORIN-Pauline. Wife of Irving, mother of Alan, Stanley and Phyllis; grandmother of Toni, Mark, Gale, Nancy, Andrew; great grandmother of Jenna, Cassie, Jessica, Michael, Lara, Savannah, Taylor, Brendan and Jordan. Loved by all. We will miss you.

title: A Town's Tax Bill Goes To the Highest Bidder
description: Last Monday, North Brunswick brought the possibility of a new world of New Jersey municipal finance a giant step closer, when it picked Angram Business Services as the top bidder on its tax levy. The sale of the levy -- the town's entire projected property tax collection -- depends on the final approval of the Township Council, scheduled to vote on it Nov. 17, and the state, which will review the measure in the meantime.

title: Oxford and All That Jazz
description: Byron is said to have presented his publisher with a generously inscribed Bible that the recipient proudly exhibited for many years, until a visitor pointed out an alteration at John 18:40. Byron had edited the sentence ''Now Barabbas was a robber'' by changing the last word to ''publisher.'' If publishers are not universally admired by the writers they usher into print, neither can they be much exalted by a public inured to tales of conglomerate-owned houses that offer book advances of seven figures to celebrity girlfriends, talk show hosts and dishonored or traumatized memoirists while eradicating professional midlist authors. (''Midlist'' is an industry euphemism for those writers who do not scale best-seller lists.)

title: Tentative Global Profile; China Exports Its Own Uncertainty
description: CHINA exports so much to the United States that at times it can be hard to find a pair of shoes, a toy or an electrical appliance in an American department store that does not say ''Made in China.''

title: ATOMIC PLATES
description: In the early 1960's, Michael Thomas, a resident of Hinsdale, Ill., was deployed to the Johnston Atoll in the South Pacific, where as a naval airman he was exposed to radiation during a test of a plutonium-armed Thor rocket. People like Thomas -- the so-called Atomic Veterans, servicemen who were irradiated during tests or accidents -- haven't always received sufficient recognition, so Illinois is making amends by becoming the first state to offer official Atomic Veteran license plates. Not much, but Thomas, whose fellow squad members have claimed various exposure-related afflictions over the years, will take it. ''It's the only citation we ever had,'' he says.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALITAN, MIRIAM G.
description: SALITAN-Miriam G. On October 24, 1997, age 98. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Mark, Adele and Lucille. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Laurie, Jim, Diane, Geoffrey, David, Marc, Marta and Mish. Adoring great-grandmother of Emily and Gabriel. Devoted aunt of Lenore and Arthur, Morton and Marcia, Richard and Minna, Howard and Phyllis. Sister-in-law of Jean Mahler and Henry Salitan. Services, Sunday, October 26, 9:45AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Polly Fitz; Taking Food and Nutrition More Seriously
description: POLLY FITZ enjoys cooking one-dish suppers, and she's great at soupy stews, fish chowder and warm salads. She's careful to cut the fat and add lots of vegetables. But when she puts her favorite chicken dish on the table, she never tells guests, ''This is a really healthy casserole,'' she says, ''It's coq au vin.'' They have no idea that the bacon bits floating in it amount to two slices chopped into pieces.

title: Westchester Q&A: Noam Bramson; Councilman Strives to Make Service Fun
description: WHEN the call went out last month in New Rochelle for volunteers of all types, about 300 people answered. They painted park benches and cleaned up parks, scrubbed fire trucks and blazed trails, planted gardens and potted plants. It was part of the kick-off of New Rochelle Cares, a collaborative effort of dozens of New Rochelle community groups, aimed at encouraging volunteerism in the city.

title: Making the Holocaust Relevant to Students
description: SHELDON N. GREBSTEIN stood at the blackboard, discussing Holocaust humor with Manhattanville College students here. No, the term was not an oxymoron but a device, he said, involving the use of incongruous juxtaposition. ''You always find this element in a comic work,'' he told the class in Literature of the Holocaust. ''It results from the combination of unlike opposites, of mismatched, ill-fitting components. It produces the one essential element of comedy: surprise.''

title: In the Region/Westchester; In County's North, a Land Rush for Building Lots
description: THE booming economy, combined with low interest rates and a pent-up demand for new construction, has created a land rush in Westchester, with some areas experiencing strong double-digit increases in sales in the last year.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: KEW GARDENS

title: An Ideal Weight
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Koltko-Rivera And Ms. Orr
description: Kristin Leah Orr, a daughter of Catherine and James F. Orr of Cincinnati, was married there last evening to Mark Edward Koltko-Rivera, the son of Sophie Koltko of New York and the late Odilio Rivera. The Rev. Paul S. Hammer performed the ceremony at the Mount Washington Presbyterian Church.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: DARK BLUE SUIT

title: The Doctor Is In
description: JOHN P. BELISLE'S school-age daughters have yet to ask him for tickets to his casino's rock-and-roll shows, but he thinks it's only a matter of time.

title: Testing the Limits of Punishment; Unusually Severe Life Sentence vs. Society's Need for Safety
description: In a Manhattan Federal courtroom filled with his followers and their families last winter, the defendant addressed the judge. His English halting, his voice choked with tears, Luis Felipe, a Cuban immigrant who calls himself King Blood, said, ''You sentenced me to die day by day.''

title: Ms. Tarkenton And Mr. Allen
description: Melissa Merrell Tarkenton, a daughter of Mrs. Richard Delyn Jackson and Francis Asbury Tarkenton, the former football quarterback, both of Atlanta, was married there yesterday to Craig Murfee Allen, a son of Charles Emmett Allen of Atlanta and the late Mary Turner Murfee Allen. Canon Louis C. Shueddig performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. Philip.

title: Clean Car's Wrong Turn
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'New' Kennedy Airport Takes Wing
description: THE INTERNATIONAL ARRIVALS BUILDING, heart of the Terminal City complex at John F. Kennedy International Airport, whose swooping entry arch ushered New York into the jet age, is about to turn 40. And a special event is planned for its anniversary year.

title: Art and Anti-Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Terry McClenahan, Kara Kelly
description: Dr. Kara Maureen Kelly, a pediatric oncologist in New York, was married yesterday to Richard Lee McClenahan 3d, an architectural designer in New York. The Rev. Louis Sogliuzzo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony with the Rev. Barbara Crafton, an Episcopal priest, in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Stifling Michigan Defense Sparks Victory Over Spartans
description: He first came here as a freshman two years ago, with the promise of a rapidly growing reputation. Charles Woodson's first trip to Michigan State as a cornerback for the University of Michigan ended in embarrassment, with a potential interception that got away in a painful defeat.

title: A Saint-Gaudens Goes to the National Gallery
description: A version of Augustus Saint-Gaudens's colossal Shaw Memorial, one of the finest and most moving of Civil War monuments, has recently been installed in the West Wing of the National Gallery of Art in Washington. It depicts Col. Robert Gould Shaw, the Boston Brahmin commander, and his all-black 54th Massachusetts Regiment marching into battle. Shaw and many of his troops died in a heroic assault on Fort Wagner, S.C., in 1863.

title: When the Brew Has a Headier Flavor
description: IN Fairfield, they take the edge off the journey home with mugs of a dark brew called the Bitter Commuter. In Hartford, they pledge allegiance to the state with a few rounds of Praying Mantis Porter (patriotically named for Connecticut's state insect). In Stamford, they toast to romance with Turn On Your Love Light Ale. In New Haven, also known as the Elm City, they hoist frosty mugs of Elmweiser.

title: October 19-25; U.S. Cites Microsoft In Antitrust Case
description: The Justice Department has decided to enter the Internet browser war. Moving aggressively against the Microsoft Corporation, antitrust prosecutors sought a court order to block the company from forcing computer makers that use its popular Windows 95 operating system to also use its less popular, but steadily growing, browser software.

title: Terror Reigns in Uganda Border Zone
description: It was midnight. She was in bed when she heard the angry voices outside the one-room apartment she and her husband shared on the outskirts of this defunct mining town near the border with Congo. Then machine-gun fire hammered, and there were screams.

title: New Search for a Principal Is Needless, Parents Say
description: Public and Intermediate School 176, which comprises three alternative schools at Broadway and 204th Street, has been searching for a permanent principal since it opened in September 1996. Now many parents, who support the promotion of the interim principal, say they have lost patience with the district superintendent, Anthony Amato, who is in the midst of a second systemwide search for someone to lead the school.

title: No Turn Signal Required
description: Of all the ways to leave town in a hurry, maybe the most spectacular is by kayak. From Manhattan's roof decks, you can see the flinty little crafts being tossed by the current. In the last few years, encouraged by cleaner water and development from the Hudson River Park to Chelsea Piers, ever more windsurfers and sailors have been casting off. But the kayakers are the real pioneers.

title: Assurances For Southbury
description: ''Found, a Final Resting Place'' (Sept. 7) stated that urns containing the cremated remains of five residents of the Southbury Training School had been found on the shelves of two local funeral homes. This occurred because there were no surviving family members and the state's funeral allowance did not cover burial costs,

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, ANN C.
description: CASEY-Ann C. On October 24, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Walter J., Sr. Loving mother of Walter J., Jr. Dear sister of Mary M. O'Leary and the late Catherine Casey, Margaret Walsh, Dennis and Daniel O'Leary. Dearest mother-in-law of Veronica K. Dear sister-in-law of Dorothy O'Leary. Cherished grandmother of Karen Marie and Suzanne Catherine Casey. Reposing at the Conway Funeral Home, Inc., 82-19 Northern Boulevard, Jackson Heights, Sunday, 7-10PM and Monday 2-5 and 7-10PM. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 9:30AM at Saint Joan of Arc R.C. Church. Interment Long Island National Cemetery, Pinelawn, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Saint Camillus Health Center, 494 Elm Street, Stamford, CT. 06902.

title: A Storm From Hong Kong
description: A gale-force buffetting of the Hong Kong stock market, which began with an attack on the local currency, shook financial markets around the world on Thursday. Stocks lost 10.4 percent of their value in Hong Kong, causing a frantic selloff first in Japan, where the Nikkei index dropped 3 percent, and then in Europe. London's leading stock index plunged 3.1 percent and Germany's DAX index dropped 3.6 percent. Hours later, Wall Street was engulfed as well, and the Dow Jones industrial average finished the day down 2.3 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGATY, HARRY
description: BOGATY-Harry. Long a resident of Englewood, New Jersey, on October 18, 1997, at his home in Westborough, MA. Dear husband of Helene Marer Bogaty for fifty years, cherished father of Lewis and his wife Lissa, and Daniel and his wife Fran, beloved brother of Beck Bogaty, dear grandfather of David, Tanya, Louie, and Michael, he will be sorely missed. He was a man of high principle and great optimism, who was always concerned for others. His presence enriched the world.

title: GAME 6
description: CLEVELAND -- 4

title: These Frogs Have a Story To Tell (And It's a Mystery)
description: AT the northern end of Pachaug State Forest, on Porter Pond, Indian summer stretched the leaping antics of the frogs later this year than usual. As Joey Gerst led the way to the water's edge, a dozen small green frogs jumped in unison like an amphibian dance troupe, while fat tadpoles wiggled out of the boy's reach into the shallows.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAMUELS, HOWARD J.
description: SAMUELS-Howard J. October 26, 1984. The heart shall not forgetmy man for all seasons. See you, pal. B.B.F.

title: Couture Voyeur
description: Nothing could be richer, more exquisite or more over the top than this fall's couture, which, thanks to an infusion of fresh talent and younger clientele, is once again a hot ticket.

title: Two Dogs Need Behavior Modification, Neighbors Say
description: About 60 people marched on the 112th Precinct station house Tuesday night, demanding that the police arrest their neighbor, Ramon Yosupov, and confiscate his two German shepherds, Mufasa and Nala.

title: On the Record
description: Newark will soon be able to boast that it's the home of several new record labels.

title: The View From: White Plains; Down Syndrome Proves No Match for Volunteer
description: JANET MARCHESE said that at least half the people she speaks to on the phone are surprised when they meet her in person.

title: Ward Is the Knicks' Square Peg With a Round Ball
description: Charlie Ward has this stare. It is as blank and detached as a subway passenger's, an often disconcerting blend of sinister and eerie. At times, you cannot tell if he is peering past you or into you with his unnerving, Mona Lisa eyes. It is quite a look. And it is quite a disguise.

title: POSTINGS: 100 Years on Morningside Heights; Columbia Past, Columbia Not
description: The 13-by-20-foot copy of the 1915 McKim, Mead & White master plan of Columbia University that has been reproduced onto a plastic floor covering in a campus art gallery occupies an appropriately central part in the show, for the blueprint remains the center point of future campus design and debate. The exhibition in the Miriam and Ira D. Wallach Art Gallery on the eighth floor of Schermerhorn Hall is called ''Mastering McKim's Plan: Columbia's First Century on Morningside Heights,'' and is at the gallery through Jan. 17. The exhibition includes plans that were realized, and those that were not.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAPOUNAKIS, PAUL S.
description: SAPOUNAKIS-Paul S. October 26, 1996. In remembrance. Steven J. Fellouris. Georgia Sambazis

title: The Test of Skill
description: To the Editor:

title: Stacey Navin, Darron Weinstein
description: Stacey Gannon Navin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Navin Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., was married on Thursday to Darron Erle Weinstein, the son of Mrs. Franco Vazzana and the stepson of Mr. Vazzano of the Algarve, Portugal. Msgr. William P. Devine performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Church in Short Hills.

title: No Rest for the Eerie
description: WHETHER chilling us or charming us, ghost stories and tales of haunted places capture our imagination, especially at Halloween.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIGLER, LOUIS H., MD.
description: SIGLER-Louis H., MD. October 16, 1978. Dear Grandpa Lou, we remember you with love and pride. Your Children and Grandchildren

title: Army Wins Final Colgate Game
description: Because Bobby Williams's twisted ankle remained twisted on Thursday, the Army coaches told Brendan Rooney to get ready because he would play against Colgate today.

title: Assisted Suicide Comes Full Circle, to Oregon
description: When the Supreme Court ruled in June that there was no constitutional protection for ''the right to die,'' that was not the last word on assisted suicide. The states were free to pursue ''the earnest and profound debate about the morality, legality and practicality'' of the issue, the Court wrote.

title: New Inspection Stickers Planned to Foil Fraud
description: Fraudulent and stolen motor inspection stickers long been a problem for motor vehicle officials for years. But next year when enhanced emissions tests are started, it is going to become more difficult to pass inspection, and officials anticipate that the demand for fake or stolen stickers will increase, according to C. Richard Kamin, director of the Division of Motor Vehicles.

title: Finding Halloween Fright and Fun
description: Here is a trick-or-treat list of places to help kindle the spirit of Halloween:

title: Kate Tattelbaum, Howard Gun
description: Kate Jorge Tattelbaum, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Harvey M. Tattelbaum of New York, is to be married today to Howard Neal Gun, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton J. Gun of Newton, Mass. The bride's father, who is the senior rabbi at Temple Shaaray Tefila in New York, is to perform the ceremony at the Mohawk Mountain Lodge in Cornwall, Conn.

title: A Feminist Victory Despite It All
description: Poor Rosalie Osias. She is yet another woman who just doesn't get it. Her article, ''A Disastrous Loss for Feminists,'' [Opinion, Oct. 19] laments that Brenda Barnes, president of Pepsi-Cola, quit her job to spend more time with her children. In fact, Ms. Osias sees only two means of women having it all: science enabling men to give birth, and women learning ''to be as driven in their careers as men.''

title: Henry Gourdine Dies at 94; Master of Fishing Skills and Lore
description: Henry L. Gourdine, who spent his life messing about in boats, becoming a Hudson River legend for his passionate, lifelong love of the river, his skills as a commercial fisherman and the delight he took in passing on his lore, died on Oct. 17 at Phelps Memorial Hospital Center in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y. He was 94 and lived in Ossining, N.Y.

title: Wheelies In a Kit
description: Packs of teen-agers have been seen all over New York, popping wheelies and pedaling fast on home-built, low-rider bicycles. The bikes, long popular among Hispanic teen-agers in Los Angeles, are picking up speed in New York. With high handlebars and banana-shape seats, they stir up memories of bikes of the 60's and 70's. But it's not just about the look. As Frank Arroyo, the owner of Frank's Bike Shop on Grand Street in SoHo, says, ''It's about building it and making it the best on the block.''

title: Mold Forces 2 More Branches Of the Public Library to Close
description: Two months after a toxic mold forced the closing of a newly renovated public library on Staten Island, officials at the New York Public Library say they have shut down two more branches there because of the same problem.

title: On Language; Tracking The Fast Track
description: To be revealed before your very eyes this morning is the anatomy of an On Language column. You will discover its impetus, its motive, its little research tricks, its blinding flashes of lexicographic insight and the way the writer, straining to show how language illuminates The Meaning of Life, settles for the meaning of a word.

Products for sale purport to offer cancer protection, a hardier heart, extra energy, enhanced immunity, less stress, a longer life, an antidote to pollution, stronger bones, less body fat, relief from premenstrual syndrome, athletic prowess and heightened sexual powers.

description: FOR THE FIRST TIME IN HIS 20-year career, the celebrated British comic Rowan Atkinson has a shot at American stardom. He is underwhelmed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, LOUIS
description: GOLDBERG-Louis, age 89. AO, M. Com, Litt. D, Professor Emeritus, Melbourne University, Australia, died peacefully at home in Melbourne on October 18, 1997. Beloved father of Loretta, New York, cherished husband of Jean, widower of Myrtle. A scholar and gentleman, he influenced several generations of accountants in Australia and internationally by his published theoretical writings and devoted teaching. In the U.S. his visiting academic positions included Baruch School of Business in New York and the University of Florida. His kindness, humor, and empathetic curiosity will be deeply missed.

title: Small-Schools Conference Lands Crew in a Dispute
description: New York City Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew went to a small-schools conference yesterday to raise the flag of peace. But by starting an attack on a small school in the Bronx, he instead became embroiled in a heated dispute with one of the city's most prominent small-schools advocates.

title: October 19-25; Democracy Lessons in Bosnia
description: As part of a campaign to increase appreciation for democratic institutions in Bosnia, American soldiers have been distributing leaflets quoting Thomas Jefferson, John Locke, Plato and others. About 43,000 leaflets were dropped on Serb towns recently by American helicopters.

title: A Writer At Work: Winter Games
description: WESTPORT will be adequately represented at this year's Winter Olympics.

title: Blend of Sculpture and Technology In the Abstract and Real World
description: DAVID SMALLEY has stuck close to New London during his career. Since 1995 he has taught sculpture at Connecticut College. But his work and its associations are exceptionally wide-ranging. His absorbing retrospective at the Lyman Allyn Museum, through Nov. 16, consists of 68 sculptures, opening with work from 1959. It clearly traces the path of his art ever since.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUTZER, SEYMOUR, M.D.
description: SCHUTZER-Seymour, M.D. The American Diabetes Association, New York State Affiliate, Inc., notes with sorrow the passing of Dr. Seymour Schutzer, a member of the New York City Chapter Board. Dr. Schutzer was devoted to caring for people with diabetes and spent time during his retirement volunteering with the Diabetes Information Program. He will be missed by all who knew him. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Margaret Spencer, Chair of the Board Harvey Katzeff, M.D., President of the Board Staff, NY Downstate Region

title: Six Dobbs Ferry High Classes Mingle at a Super Reunion
description: IN the late 1940's, Dobbs Ferry was a quiet blue-collar river town, with a population about half of its current 10,000. Teen-agers went to Friday movies at the Embassy Theater on Cedar Street and held bonfires before important football games against Hastings-on-Hudson and Irvington, their southern and northern rivals. They danced on Wednesday evenings at Gould Park to ''String of Pearls'' and ''Racing With the Moon.''

title: Germany
description: To the Editor: The article about the Schlosshotel Kronberg near Frankfurt (''The Bargains and the Blowouts,'' Sept. 14) carried me back to early 1950, when I was quartered in the schloss, which had been taken over as an officers' club. My wife, two-month-old son and I occupied Princess Sophie's suite -- actually three rather small rooms that had served as bedroom and nursery for the Princess. In one room we found a book inscribed, ''To my granddaughter Sophie. Victoria R.''

title: An East Village Magazine: No Salaries but Lots of Attitude
description: James Golden and Ann Shoket, both 25, love the East Village. But when they looked at existing print publications aimed at downtown, they felt they could do a better job on the World Wide Web. So Mr. Golden, a computer programmer, and Ms. Shocket, an associate editor at React magazine, a national pbulication for teen-agers, last October put together a new magazine aimed at East Village habitues and about-to-be habitues.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; In Search of the Prime Primeval
description: The Bushmen of Africa occupied a peculiar place in the American imagination of the 1920's. Glimpsed only rarely in circus sideshows or in the written accounts of adventurers, the Bushmen (of what is now called Namibia) symbolized the ultimately primeval, the ''missing link,'' the anthropologist Robert J. Gordon writes in PICTURING BUSHMEN: The Denver African Expedition of 1925 (Ohio University Press, cloth, $44.95; paper, $24.95). Interest in these ''human curiosities'' was avid. Hence, it was with great fanfare that two Denver residents with dubious credentials -- C. Ernest Cadle, a disillusioned Methodist minister, and Paul Hoefler, a former Hollywood cameraman -- set off on a lavishly funded expedition to the Kalahari. Their ''scientific'' goal was not to study the customs of these traditional peoples, but to bring back photographic evidence of what they called the ''lowest race on earth.'' That was, after all, what Americans in the throes of a Tarzan craze wanted. When the expedition encountered the Bushmen, they proved to be good actors, Hoefler wrote, ''and to do just what they are told.'' In return for tobacco and other gifts, the Bushmen were asked to be accomplices in posed shots; many illustrate the contrast between Western notions of ''primitive'' and ''civilized.'' Several feature Hoefler and Cadle as swashbuckling, rifle-toting types, accompanied by one or more sparsely clothed Bushmen, ''childlike'' in contrived comparison. Largely in response to these popular photographs, the Bushmen became tourist attractions. Eventually, when their traditional way of life interfered with game park operations, many were expelled or settled in fringe communities. ''Picturing Bushmen'' is the account of how a stereotype is created, packaged, delivered and consumed. Suzanne MacNeille

title: Why 'Nowhere' Might Be A Good Direction For Now
description: After all the outrage about White House coffees, Lincoln bedroom sleep overs and Buddhist nuns apparently corrupted by the American political system, and perhaps vice versa, campaign finance reform has gone exactly nowhere during this session of Congress. And while both the Senate hearings and the ''they did it too'' arguments continue, Senator Robert G. Torricelli, for one, suggests that maybe that's all for the best.

title: A Composer for the Masses Scales Down His Ambitions
description: THE AMERICAN classical-music mainstream has long considered politics and music incompatible. Classical music, it is argued, stands atop Parnassus, removed from the world around it. It is a refuge from the problems of everyday life, not a forum in which to discuss them.

Wear them around your neck, on your head, on your wrists or dangling from a shoulder, and it won't matter what else you're wearing.

description: FASHION PEOPLE KNOW THAT God is in the details. Beau Brummell's legend was built on the way he handled a snuffbox. The Duchess of Windsor wore necklaces so well she could make cork look like a crown jewel. ''All my friends know that I'd rather shop than eat,'' she said.

Outside the concert, rows of white, stretch limousines idle as their passengers -- including many corporate executives in expensive box seats -- enjoy the show. Up on the lawn, nearly 13,000 younger fans sway and holler exclamations of joy with the band's every song.

title: The Nation; Weather at 11, and More or Less All Winter
description: A RICH man this winter may be the one who purchased futures in sand, roofing material and Midwestern grain last summer. Not that there are looming shortages. But enough people think El Nino, the perfectly normal but obsessively observed warming of the Pacific Ocean, will cause such an epic unsettling of winter weather this year that there is already a run on all sorts of things usually taken for granted.

description: JUST off Jericho Turnpike in Cold Spring Hills, past a development of ranch houses, the medieval turrets of the Oheka Castle spring into view. That a 123-room chateau stands blocks from the shopping centers on Route 25 may be unusual.

title: SOAPBOX; The Witch Next Door
description: SHE rides her broomstick beneath a full moon, mixes potions in a large black caldron, casts spells with her evil eye. Her history is as old as humankind. And on Friday, Halloween, in her honor thousands of folks throughout New Jersey will paint their faces green, don tall black hats and drape swirling capes over their shoulders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGBERG, HOLGER LAESSOE
description: ENGBERG-Holger Laessoe. Born in Denmark, died in New York on October 23, 1997. Survived by his wife Lillemor, his son Niels Peter, his daughter Lisbet and her husband Stuart. We shall miss him. Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: The New Look Of Liberalism on The Court
description: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg presents a somewhat revisionist view of Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' (''The New Look of Liberalism on the Court,'' by Jeffrey Rosen, Oct. 5). She is correct that the opera's title can be translated to ''They are all like that'' (or, more literally, ''So do they all''), but in this case, the Italian ''tutte'' does indeed refer to all women. Had the librettist, Lorenzo Da Ponte, meant all men or all mankind, he would have written the mascu-line form ''tutti.''

According to a poll released by Manhattanville College earlier this week, the Republican incumbent, Leonard N. Spano, has 35 percent of voter support, and the Democratic challenger, Kathie Davidson, has 29 percent in her first bid for elective office. The Right to Life Party candidate, Terrence Dwyer, has 5 percent.

title: Managing Managed Care
description: Why did Debra Shapiro view as a joke the notion that '' ... a doctor seeing a particular patient would have no idea whether there was a financial incentive to do more tests, or a financial incentive to do as little as possible ...''? This is how many of us practiced medicine, treating patients with the same level of care, regardless of insurance coverage. H.M.O. incentives are perverse. Would Shapiro take on other H.I.V.-positive patients if there was no centralization of financial risk in her system? Can we not assume that doctors and H.M.O.'s are engaging in cherry picking to reduce their financial risks?

title: Managing Managed Care
description: I have been a member of an H.M.O. for three years. In that time, I have been hospitalized on three occasions -- twice for congestive heart failure and once for back spasms. There was never a problem in being admitted to the hospital. Even though I felt much better after two to three hours of treatment in the emergency room, the doctors insisted I stay in the hospital several days for observation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, JAMES
description: GINSBERG-James. Died peacefully after a courageous battle with mesothelioma. Jimmy will be rememberd by his family, many longtime friends, close business associates and loving companion Ceil Berman. He is survived by his adored wife Sylvia, beloved children Peter, Ronna and Edward Goldstein; devoted grandchildren Elizabeth and Stephanie; and dear sister Cecile Friedlander. Contributions to the James Ginsberg Fund, New York Public Library for Performing Arts at Lincoln Center, attention: Robert Marx, would be appreciated. title: Backtalk; Yifter, Always Running for Ethiopia, Now Runs Far Away From It
description: A hero's welcome awaited the double gold medal winner Miruts Yifter when he returned home to Ethiopia from the 1980 Moscow Olympics. Thousands lined the streets and he was given a car, a luxury villa and a Government position promoting athletics. Yifter, who came from humble beginnings, should have had a storybook ending to his athletic success. Life, however, is not so cut and dried.

description: After a shaky start in windy conditions, Duffy Waldorf hung onto his hat, his composure and the lead.

description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Re-elect Mayor Giuliani
description: This year's mayoral campaign has been, by any standards, a disappointment. The Democratic nominee, Ruth Messinger, has criticized Mayor Rudolph Giuliani endlessly, but failed to give the voters a sharp sense of her own political philosophy. Ms. Messinger, who has a long and distinguished career in local politics, deserves to be remembered for her previous service to the city rather than for this uninspiring race. But even if she had run a model campaign, it is hard to imagine how she could have made a convincing argument for getting rid of Mr. Giuliani. Despite the many disagreements we have had with the Mayor over the last four years, we endorse his re-election enthusiastically.

title: R & R on Antigua
description: TWENTY minutes from the Antigua airport, bouncing around in the back of a taxi whose shock absorbers had seen better days, my wife, Carole, and I admired the lush countryside whizzing by, already feeling revitalized by the warm air we'd come so far to enjoy. But where was the ocean?

title: Grant Helps to Ready Primary Care Doctors

title: Managing Managed Care
description: Your article states that David, the patient with AIDS, ''sees specialists in mental health, infectious diseases, ophthalmology and dermatology.'' When a patient is sent to a specialist in mental health, this is generally a euphemism for a nonmedically trained, subdoctoral-level practitioner. My suspicion is that the other specialists are all doctors, but the mental health specialist is not. In addition, Shapiro notes that ''the visit doesn't get paid if I write depression'' as the diagnosis, and therefore she substitutes the term ''fatigue.'' While this may seem like a white lie to Shapiro, it is demeaning to patients and, ultimately, reinforces stigmatization of mental illness.

Diamond of Todt Hill, Staten Island, is to be married this evening in Manhattan to Laurent Charles Levasseur, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Levasseur of Paris. Justice Thomas R.
