title: Efforts Mount to Keep Part of Estate as Park
description: LEAVES crunched underfoot, while overhead a canopy of interlacing tree branches created a delicate filigree of light and shadows on the narrow trail, which meandered past a stream and pond before emerging into a clear meadow. A distinctive chorus of migrating Canada geese echoed through the trees, muffled by the dense woods.

title: In the Region/Long Island; In Mt. Sinai Project, a Little Something for Everyone
description: IT has taken 12 years for a controversial development plan for a 404-acre tract in Mt. Sinai to evolve.

title: Jennifer Meyer And Eric Jaso
description: Jennifer Anne Meyer and Eric Hector Jaso, lawyers in New York, were married last evening. The Rev. Patrick O'Donovan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHENBERG, M.
description: ROTHENBERG-M. Officially Milton, known as Mark to his friends and associates at the New York State Dept of Labor, Mendie to boyhood pals and relatives, called by assorted affecionate names by his wife Judy, his daughter Tamar and his son Peter. Died October 21, 1997 after an interminable illness. Memorial service to be arranged. He will be missed.

title: Italian Cuisine, With a Warm Embrace
description: DARIO'S is classic Italian, a restaurant of white tablecloths and roses, where tuxedoed waiters deftly debone fish, mix Caesar salads and whip up zabaglione at tableside. Few restaurants of this stripe have opened on the Island in the 90's. Although Dario's has only been at its Rockville Centre site for six months, one might argue that it is not really new, but a transplant from its 13-year home in West Hempstead.

title: The Loyalists
description: Stephen S. Hall's praise of baseball players who have remained loyal to one team is based on a flawed premise (''The Loyalists,'' Oct. 5). Players can be -- and usually are -- traded without their consent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHULMAN, HOWARD
description: SCHULMAN-Howard. A labor lawyer who served two terms as Commissioner of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and who was a past chairman of the American Bar Association's Labor Law Section, died Thursday in Sharon, CT. He was 79. Mr. Schulman, born in Brooklyn, lived in Millbrook, NY, and Boca Raton, FL. He was chief counsel to various trade unions, including the Seafarers International Union from the 1950's to the 1980's, and to the AFL-CIO's Maritime Trades Department. He founded the New York law firm Schulman & Abarbanel and argued three labor-related cases before the U.S. Supreme Court. He is survived by his wife Paula Schulman, three daughters Ann Milbank of Merrick, NY, Judith Lederer of New York, NY, and Janet Dicker, of Livingston, NJ, two sons-in-law Jeffrey Lederer and Marshall Dicker, and six grandchildren Dana Milbank, Aaron Milbank, Megan Milbank, Cecilia Lederer, Joshua Lederer, and Claire Dicker. Funeral services are at noon today at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Rockville Centre, NY, with burial to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: The Magic Word for Italians: Europe (Pain and All)
description: There is a magic word in Italian politics, and it is Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARK, ELAINE C.
description: MARK-Elaine C., 83. Of West Palm Beach, FL, formerly of New York City, passed away October 23, 1997. Lovng mother of Terry Ernst. Cherished grandmother of Marci, Michael and Howard. Adored great-grandmother of Alexandria and Michael. Services were held in Florida.

title: Crashing in Asia; Paper Tigers, Paper Miracles
description: WHEN the history of the Asian crash of 1997 is written years from now, people will probably have long since forgotten the accusation by Malaysia's paranoid-sounding premier, Mahathir Mohamad, that the source of the problem was a Jewish conspiracy to level Asia's booming economies. By then it should be clear whether Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican and chairman of the Banking Committee, was accurate or blowing smoke when he declared that the dramatic fall of the Hong Kong market Thursday was a ''lesson for all freedom-loving people around the world'' of the dangers ''now that the Communist Chinese have taken over'' Asia's most vibrant center of capitalism.

title: Ms. Rosenberg And Mr. Rubins
description: Meredith Amy Rosenberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Rosenberg of New York, was married last evening to Matthew Jonathan Rubins, a son of Dr. Walter H. Rubins of Manhasset, N.Y., and the late Adele S. Rubins. Rabbi David H. Lincoln officiated at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Cool Stuff for Less
description: When fashion editors, with closets full of Gucci and Prada, want a little something extra, a pair of gray pants, say, or a leather miniskirt, they can often be found checking out Club Monaco. A recent addition to the New York shopping scene, Club Monaco is a chain that competes in price with J. Crew and Banana Republic, but outranks them in fashion sensibility. It may have started in Canada, but the look is international cool.

title: Dispelling Myths
description: They are shadow creatures whose world lies beyond the edge of ours. Their name evokes a sense of dread and their cries embody the call of the wild. In WOLVES AT OUR DOOR, Jim Dutcher and his crew spent six years living, observing and bonding with a pack of gray wolves in the rugged Sawtooth Mountains of Idaho, led by the alpha male Kamots. Their film captures the wolves' natural behavior. The animals are affectionate and playful with one another. They have a strong social structure and devotion to their pack and an intimate language. The documentary goes far beyond images of wolves in relentless attack, suggesting they are more than merely strong and savage predators - MON. and SAT. at 8 P.M. on DSC.

title: Park to Grow on the Ashes of the Riverwalk Plan
description: Efforts to revive a desolate stretch of shore on the East River, between 18th and 23d Streets, have themselves been revived.

title: The Loyalists
description: Players from the era before free agency had no choice but to stay with their original team, since they were prevented from seeking employment elsewhere by the now-discarded reserve clause, which bound a player to his employer in perpetuity. Loyalty to a team was not an attribute of the players of that bygone era because it was never an option.

title: October 19-25; But Good News for Yeltsin
description: George Soros, the Hungarian-born financier who has already given away almost $1.5 billion promoting what he calls ''open societies'' at home and abroad, made another startling pledge.

title: New Gay Newspaper Is Cause for Optimism
description: To the Editor:

title: Style; Ghouls Rush In
description: It's going to be the drop-dead party of the year, and you're invited! That's right, the 1997 Ghoulies, celebrating individual achievement in ghoulishness and the masquerading arts, coming to you live from Fresh Kills, Staten Island, on Halloween night! Join us in honoring the men and women who make every day seem like Halloween, those talented individuals who made 1997 the best year ever for ear biting, backbiting, tawdry sex, memoir writing and other vulgar displays.

title: Grape Juice That's Ripe for Cooking
description: SOME wineries in California produce their own olive oil. The climate on the East End of Long Island makes that impossible. Here, they are are starting to make verjus.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: A Wilderness Within

title: Exploring A Shy Island
description: AS we loaded scuba gear onto a tiny fishing boat, wispy clouds obscured the sun, turning the emerald green sea into a deep and foreboding indigo. My stomach tightened trying to imagine the conditions below the ocean's seemingly calm surface.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZMAN, BESS
description: KATZMAN-Bess. Of Forest Hills, NY, and Lake Sunapee, NH, on Saturday, October 25, 1997, at age 101. Beloved wife of the late Selig Katzman. Loving mother of Barbara Marks and Suzanne Ekman. Beloved mother-in-law of the late Lawrence Marks. Grandmother of Scott and Gershon Ekman and Sheila and Nancy Marks. Greatgrandmother of Jason, Sarah and Emmet Van Driesche, Hallie Jay and Larry Pope, and Kate, Laura and Sally Ekman. Beloved aunt, great-aunt and friend to so many. Services 10 AM, Monday, October 27, Schwartz Bros-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 76th Road and Queens Boulevard, in Forest Hills.

title: Music That Moves the Arena Home
description: THE year was 1993. The New York Knicks were slam-dunking an opponent. Madison Square Garden, home of the Knicks and the New York Rangers, was raucous and rocking. And Monica Lynch, a Knicks devotee and president of Tommy Boy Music, a Manhattan-based record label, was in her courtside seat grooving to the beat when the idea came to her: Why not put out an anthology of the songs heard at sports stadiums and arenas across the nation?

title: Trial and Error
description: To the Editor:

title: Unhappy Returns; Pity the I.R.S., the Tax Code's Whipping Boy
description: TO many members of Congress, as to working stiffs and millionaires alike who dread contact with tax collectors, the Internal Revenue Service too often lives up to its caricature as an unresponsive, intrusive and vindictive bureaucracy.

title: Sure-Footed On Saba
description: AS the 15-seat Twin Otter began its approach to the Caribbean island of Saba, it appeared to be heading straight into a rock that rises abruptly out of the sea. I was in a front row seat, having moved from the back, at the pilot's request, to help balance the aircraft.

title: Establishing Linkage
description: The Monkey's Bridge Mysteries of Evolution in Central America. By David Rains Wallace. 277 pp. San Francisco: Sierra Club Books. $25.

title: A Florida Comeback to 'Are We There Yet?'
description: For people living or vacationing in South Florida, the Florida Fun-Train now offers an alternative to those exhausting four-hour car trips to the Magic Kingdom and other Orlando attractions. The multicolored blue, pink, green and yellow trains consist of four double-decker entertainment cars and eight glass-domed coach cars, with a capacity of 600 passengers. The trains have a wide-open view of the scenery as well as video arcade, thematic dining areas and souvenir shops.

title: Hong Kong Wonders, Where Are the Tourists?
description: SUDDENLY an unwanted, unneed ed and until now -- never-asked question is, like a summer storm gathering on the horizon, hovering on many lips here: In the wake of China's resumption of sovereignty on July 1, has Hong Kong died as one of Asia's premier tourist destinations?

title: The Contemporary Collector's Art
description: After Victor Ganz died in 1987, his widow, Sally, spent much of her time in the room they had painted Picasso-red to set off the five paintings from Picasso's variations on Delacroix's ''Women of Algiers'' that hung there. Sally Ganz would curl up near a table piled high with books by Virginia Woolf and Nabokov, fondle a diminutive bronze Picasso bull and light another cigarette. ''Art isn't just buying that picture on the wall,'' she told me one afternoon. ''It adds a measure of grace to one's life.''

title: Fashion Week Is Coming and Club-Land Is Abuzz
description: AH, November, when the frost is on the grass, russet leaves are heaped in piles and the fashion flock wings in from Europe to add a frisson to the city's night life.

title: With It
description: Heretic's Heart

title: 80 Advisers Quit at American Express Unit
description: The money management subsidiary of the American Express Company said on Friday that it had suffered mass defections of financial advisers from its Detroit regional offices, the company's top sales area in the country.

title: Susan Daggett, Michael Bennet
description: Susan Diane Daggett, a daughter of Patricia B. Palmer of Little Rock, Ark., and Jesse B. Daggett of Marianna, Ark., was married yesterday to Michael Farrand Bennet, a son of Douglas J. Bennet Jr. of Middletown, Conn., and Susanne K. Bennet of Washington. The Rev. Arnold W. Hearn, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Crystal Lake in Marianna.

title: Co-op Cases Are Getting Own Court
description: IF all goes as planned, co-op and condominium boards will soon get something they have been seeking for a long time: a housing court of their very own. Or at least part of one.

title: For Hillary Clinton at 50, Yet Another Beginning
description: There was a certain unintended twist in the setting for Hillary Rodham Clinton's meeting with journalists and child care experts this week. She gathered the group in the White House Map Room, a locale immortalized in the recently discovered videotapes of her husband's glad-handing coffees with big-money Democratic donors.

title: Children's Books
description: WHUPPITY STOORIE A Scottish Folktale. By Carolyn White. Illustrated by S. D. Schindler. Unpaged. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $15.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: The Loyalists
description: Of all the problems in baseball, and there are many, the lack of loyalty bothers me the most. Why should I attach my allegiance to some young star when I know he'll soon be gone? It's become too hard to keep track of who plays for whom anymore. This, more than anything else, is what changed me from being a diehard baseball fan to someone who, except for an occasional lapse, ignores the game.

title: David Haut, Meredith Miller
description: Meredith Leigh Miller, the daughter of Jayne and Michael L. Miller of White Plains, was married last evening to David Jonathan Haut, the son of Anita and Bernard W. Haut of Jericho, N.Y. Cantor Theodore Aronson performed the ceremony at the Hampshire Country Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Talking Back
description: Speaking Truth

title: Barring a Cold Snap, Keep Putting in Plants
description: KEEP PLANTING'' really is the answer to ''Is it safe to plant now,'' a question frequently asked at this time of year.

title: Hard-Luck Outing Has Brown Frustrated
description: Perhaps something is broken in the back rooms of the Florida clubhouse tonight. Kevin Brown had that look of destruction about him after losing Game 6 of the World Series.

title: Fear and Loathing in the White House
description: Mutual Contempt

title: Hoop Dream for an Owner
description: Steven M. Schwartz, the owner of the Brooklyn Bounce, which is being billed as the borough's only professional basketball team, watched his players dash around the ragged gym at Gershwin Junior High in East New York. It was 9:30 P.M. on Wednesday, just days before the Bounce's first home game, and Mr. Schwartz, a 51-year-old former lawyer, was hoping for some absolution.

title: 'Ugly Duckling To Swan'
description: To the Editor:

title: Help for the Hairless
description: Bald at 18? Not good. ''I spent every penny on any cure anyone would offer me,'' recalls Dr. Gary Hitzig, a New York cosmetic surgeon. ''One guy had me plug my drain and bring the hairs to him in a plastic bag. It would be funny if it weren't so tragic. I wound up $50,000 later with no hair -- and very upset.''

title: Four Injured Children, but Still No School Crossing Guard
description: At 3 P.M., 930 students from Charles O. Dewey Middle School spill out to freedom and Fourth Avenue. Most are too old to be picked up by parents, and too young to heed their mortality. Talking and laughing, they wander onto the six-lane avenue, paying little mind to crosswalks and ''Don't Walk'' signs. And many drivers gunning to make the light at 41st Street pay little mind to them.

title: The New Look Of Liberalism on The Court
description: Rosen's article confirms why many of us feel uneasy about Ginsburg's apparent tendency to settle for something less than eloquent advocacy of social justice in favor of finding a procedural way to avoid meeting issues head on.

title: Managing Managed Care
description: Hats off to Debra Shapiro, a dedicated doctor who has learned to practice good medicine within a system that I believe will be with us permanently (''Managing Managed Care,'' by Perri Klass, Oct. 5). Unfortunately, many doctors of the fee-for-service generations have been reluctant to adapt to the realities of the 21st century; both they and their patients will lose.

title: On Asian Currencies, Markets Don't Know Best
description: To the Editor:

title: Guns in Israel
description: To the Editor: After reading Edith Pearlman's article ''Learning to Live With the Guns'' (Oct. 5), I was reminded of an incident that occurred several years ago while my husband and I were on a tour in the Upper Galilee.

title: Chasing Sir Ralph, A Biographer's Reluctant Quarry
description: OVER THE YEARS, A NUMBER of books have been written about three great knights of the British theater in this century -- John Gielgud, Laurence Olivier and Ralph Richardson. Next week, in a trifecta of publishing, Applause Books in New York is bringing out volumes on all three: ''The Real Life of Laurence Olivier'' by Roger Lewis, a new biography published in England last year; ''An Actor and His Time,'' an updated memoir by John Gielgud, and a new edition of ''Ralph Richardson: An Actor's Life,'' by Garry O'Connor, a biography published in England in 1982 that has been revised since the actor's death in 1983 at the age of 80.

title: Giuliani, in Harlem, and Messinger, in Brownsville, Court Black Voters
description: There is always a current of amazement when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, in full campaign mode, bursts into a store or a restaurant surrounded by his entourage and begins shaking hands and signing autographs. But the surprise was even greater yesterday when the Mayor decided to make a brief visit to 125th Street, the commercial heart of Harlem.

title: Coach of the Year? Here's a Top 10 list
description: The one thing that the National Football League should perhaps be most proud of at the halfway point of the season is that there are numerous coaches -- some of them new to the ranks -- who are turning their teams into winners.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, HOWARD I.
description: GOLDBERG-Howard I. October 21, 1997. Dear father of Marion, Carol and Victor and father-in-law to Debra Sue. Beloved husband of the late Belle Goldberg. Cherished grandfather of Debra and Barry. Brother of Mildred. A veteran of W.W. II. He will be remembered by all who knew him. Memorial donations should be sent to VFW National Headquarters, TC Selman Fund, Attention: Quartermaster General, 406 West 34th Street, Kansas City, MO 64111.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: AGE AND ART

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAZ, GLORIA
description: DIAZ-Gloria. On October 25, 1997. Beloved mother of Coco Morris, Ketty Pelaez and Tina Ramirez. Devoted grandmother of four and great-grandmother of three. For over fifty years, Gloria was dedicated to improving the quality of life for New York's Puerto Rican community. Her family will miss her dearly. Friends may call at Walter B. Cooke, 117 W. 72nd St, NYC, Sunday, October 26, 2-9 PM. Funeral Monday, October 27, at 10:30 AM. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx, NY. Donations in her memory may be made to The Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged, care of Liz Friedman, 120 W. 106th St, NYC, 10025-3797.

title: Chicken Delight
description: ONE night in September, I watched a woman steal 30 minutes at the California Pizza Kitchen in the Garden State Plaza while her 6-week-old slept in his carriage beside her.

title: From Nickels and Dimes, 14-Karat Gold Leaf
description: THE low-budget dime-store empire of F. W. Woolworth may be crumbling. But his marble manor house in Glen Cove, designed in 1916 by Charles P. H. Gilbert, continues to prevail.

title: The Thrill of Being Scared Keeps Fright Industry Going
description: THIS month, Americans will spend more than $1 billion on eerie Halloween costumes, theme parks and creepy home decorating. Anyone who believes people naturally avoid their fears would be dead wrong by this count. Horror is big business because it taps a basic human need: People like to be scared.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about a conference on the environment attended by leaders of Eastern Orthodox churches misidentified the clergyman shown on the Black Sea. He was a Ukrainian not further identified; he was not Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew I of Constantinople.

title: Prozac Nation?
description: To the Editor:

title: Victoria Glickman and John Hodgkins
description: Victoria Glickman, a daughter of Gretchen Long Glickman and Donald Glickman, both of New York, was married yesterday to John Thomas Hodgkins, a son of Elizabeth and John E. Hodgkins of Yarmouth, Me. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson officiated at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. James W. Crawford, a Congregationalist minister, took part in the service.

title: October 19-25; Seeking the Cause Of a California Blackout
description: A power failure that knocked out traffic lights and disrupted the morning for much of San Francisco on Thursday appeared to have been caused by an intentional act, the authorities said Friday. There were no injuries, and backup power was used to keep office buildings and hospitals functioning. But by the weekend, the outage was being described by utility officials as the worst act of sabotage of a power system nationwide in at least a decade.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: In the Gulf, Thank Allah It's Wednesday
description: GROGGY?

title: Amy Berns, Adam Leibner
description: Amy Lynn Berns, the daughter of Sondra and Dr. Jack Berns of New Haven, was married last evening in Tarrytown, N.Y., to Adam Howard Leibner, a son of Carole Cooper Leibner and Richard Leibner of New York. Rabbi Alvin Wainhaus performed the ceremony at the Castle at Tarrytown.

title: Ninth Inning Wins
description: Jimmy Jerkens, the son of the Hall of Fame horse trainer Allen Jerkens, left the shelter of his father's barn last month and hung out his own shingle as a trainer. When his 2-year-old filly Ninth Inning won the Astarita Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday by 7 1/2 lengths, it was the trainer's fifth success in 15 races.

title: A Higher Level: Expansion Teams Are Seeking a Rapid Rise to the Top
description: ''When are you going to get to the World Series?'' a caller asked Jerry Colangelo one day last week.

title: For a Charter School in Its First Term, the Early Assessment Is 'A' for Effort
description: The turnout was remarkable, by almost any school's standards.

title: When Is Art?
description: To the Editor:

title: Welcome to the Club
description: It's the company welcome packet: that collection of papers, supplies and so on, issued when you start work. It reveals a lot about the place: A certificate for a free lunch (not to exceed $6), a towel for the company gym, a recyclable coffee cup, a 10-year-old policy statement on drug abuse. What was included in your company's package? Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LITTMAN, SYLVIA
description: LITTMAN - Sylvia. Musician, teacher, inspiration, joyous companion, exquisite friend. We miss you. The E.T.C. Club

title: G. E. Kidder Smith, 83, Historian Who Wrote About Architecture
description: G.E. Kidder Smith, an architectural historian and photographer, died on Oct. 8 at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

title: Suzanne Alley, Frank Franzino 3d
description: Suzanne Victoria Alley, a daughter of Judge Edwin R. Alley and Mrs. Alley of Berkeley Heights, N.J., was married yesterday to Frank John Franzino 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Franzino Jr. of Cresskill, N.J. The Rev. Edward M. Halldorson officiated at the Presbyterian Church of Chatham Township in Chatham, N.J.

title: Paying for Advice, if Not for Load Funds
description: FINALLY, mutual fund investors are buying more no-load than load funds.

title: Q. & A.
description: Destroying A Signed Contract

title: Lynn Connors, Stephen Smith
description: Lynn Nancy Connors, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Nason Connors of Portsmouth, R.I., was married yesterday to Stephen Montgomery Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubbards Montgomery Smith of Amherst, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Deene D. Clark, a Congregational minister, who is the religious coordinator at Amherst College, performed the service at the United Congregational Church in Little Compton, R.I.

title: Mary Beth Janson, Victor D'Angelo
description: Mary Beth Janson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick H. Janson of Manhasset, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Victor D'Angelo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D'Angelo of Bethpage, N.Y. Msgr. John J. Wiest performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Mary.

title: Managing Managed Care
description: Your article did not mention the real culprit in cost containment: the medical-supply houses and pharmaceutical companies whose inflationary economies far outstrip the price-to-value score of human-care providers in H.M.O.'s.

title: A Block Digs Back
description: When residents of First Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues in Park Slope began researching the block's past, they learned that their street was once a path that played a major role in the Revolutionary War. The discovery inspired them to look deeper. The result, ''If Stoops Could Speak: A History of First Street,'' may be among the most exhaustive histories ever of a single block. Published first in the 1970's, it was recently updated and contains a wealth of information about the block (like who bought each original brownstore) and Park Slope's history. Some highlights:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOHNENKAMP, LESLIE G.
description: BOHNENKAMP-Leslie G. Age 54. Died on October 16, 1997, at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan after a long illness. He will be remembered by friends and family for his kind and gentle spirit and for his ability to make us laugh. His vitality and sureness of touch is visible to us in all of his extraordinary artwork. A memorial service to be announced.

title: Warm Murals, Lively Menu, Wine Bar
description: MORE than the name has changed at the restaurant called V (formerly the Pompano Grille) in Westport. Further described as a restaurant and wine bar, V is still part of the Gates-Centro-Tequila Mockingbird axis. But the decor, with murals that unfurl warm, glowing Italian landscapes, and a menu of current American and Italian favorites are both stimulating and down-home comfortable. Even the waitstaff has changed (no more attitude); the serving mode now is gracious and, for the most part, helpful.

title: A Recalled Diet Drug and Autism
description: FOR the last 11 years, Joshua Frome has been taking fenfluramine, a prescription drug sold as Pondimin. But unlike the millions of other users who have taken this drug to lose weight, Joshua, a 19-year-old Glen Cove resident, has relied on fenfluramine to be able to function in his daily life.

title: Rutgers (0-8) Smells Victory but That's All
description: Nothing has come easy for the Rutgers football team this season, so why should its best chance for its first victory? It took two overtime sessions, but the Scarlet Knights fell short again, losing by 55-48 to Pittsburgh after a 7-yard, fourth-and-goal pass by the backup quarterback Brian Edmonds sailed incomplete out of the back of the end zone.

title: Foes of Brooklyn Junction Mall Get 2 Earfuls of Good News
description: For residents of Bay Ridge, Dyker Heights and Borough Park who have vigorously fought a large shopping mall proposed for their area, the recent good news flowed like a champagne fountain. On Oct. 17, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Giuliani issued statements opposing the complex, tentatively known as Brooklyn Junction, that a developer, Charles Katz, wants to build between Eighth and 14th Avenues from 61st to 62d Street.

title: Small Purchase Is a Way To Get Around the Boot
description: To the Editor:

title: God's Mailman
description: ON THE ROAD WITH

title: Editorial Notebook; India Wrestles With the Raj
description: The novelist Paul Scott described India and Britain in the last days of the raj as ''locked in an imperial embrace of such long standing and subtlety it was no longer possible for them to know whether they hated or loved one another.'' Earlier this month, those ambivalent emotions flared again as Queen Elizabeth tried her best to celebrate the 50th anniversary of Indian independence. There was the Queen venturing to the northern Indian city of Amritsar, where she reflected sorrowfully on one of the great atrocities of British rule, kicking up clouds of nostalgia, resentment and hurt feelings.

title: Club, It Seems, Isn't Dead Yet
description: When Club Edelweiss, a nightclub popular with transvestites and transsexuals, was closed by a judge in April, Clinton residents, who had lobbied strongly against the club for two years, thought the closing was the beginning of the end of a neighborhood outrage. Now they express fear that because of a legal technicality, the club will reopen as early as Friday.

title: Graves's Injury Puts Focus on Sweeney
description: If they defeat the Mighty Ducks of Anaheim at Madison Square Garden tonight, the Rangers will square their record at 4-4-4, an impressively mediocre mark for a team that has been unimpressively sloppy, inconsistent and short of goals through the first three weeks of the season.

title: James Schachtel, Debra Schupper
description: Debra Beth Schupper, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Schupper of Livingston, N.J., was married last evening to James Craig Schachtel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Schachtel, also of Livingston. Cantor Josee Wolff officiated at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Battling Demons (and Ratings) at the Pulpit
description: IN ''A Place to Fall,'' a 1996 comic novel by the television writer and producer Roger Director, a 30-ish actor named Tony Paris is plucked from obscurity and given the leading role in a series called ''Father Joey.'' The television drama about a crusading Roman Catholic priest strikes a responsive chord in a spiritually parched nation and becomes a monster hit. All goes swimmingly until Paris -- whose ego expands exponentially with each ratings rise -- grows dissatisfied with the limits of his prime-time alter ego.

title: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS
description: Domestic Violence Law

title: In Thornwood, Familiar Japanese Fare
description: ABIS in Thornwood is the second in a chain that came to the county when Abis in Mamaroneck opened its doors 12 years ago. The Thornwood sister establishment took over the site last occupied by Cho Cho San, and after a long period of renovation involving cross-beam additions and restructuring inside and out, this now-imposing corner restaurant opened last summer.

title: Irish Take Heart as Peace Takes Hold
description: After 28 years of sectarian violence in Northern Ireland, peace is quietly settling across this British province.

title: Anne Dickinson, Graham Barber
description: Anne Woodward Dickinson, a daughter of Jeanne R. Dickinson of New York and the late Dr. Selden J. Dickinson, was married yesterday in Jackson, N.H., to Graham Lansing Barber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Barber of Salem, Mass. Pamela L. Smillie, a justice of the peace, officiated at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Temple.

title: A New Approach to Bigger, Juicier Apples
description: Unseen behind the piles of juicy red and green apples now on New Jersey's roadside stands are the forces that create them, from the basic physical components of soil and water to the market-driven science that hones apple husbandry.

title: Evelyn Slewett, 87, Parkinson's Advocate
description: Evelyn Slewett, a founder of the National Parkinson Foundation and supporter of numerous charitable organizations, died Oct. 14 at Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami. She was 87 and lived in Miami.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENSTEIN, JANET U.
description: LOWENSTEIN-Janet U. Died on October 22 in southern Florida. Mother of Joseph H. and Jane E. Michaels. Grandmother of James, Billy, John Sherman and Jane Adler and great-grandmother of 5.

title: In America; 3:00, Nowhere to Go
description: The peak hours for juvenile crime are 3 P.M. to 8 P.M., with the biggest, most dangerous burst coming in the very first hour after school.

title: Dad, the Marines and the Drill at the Diner
description: TUESDAY night, during the second joint television appearance by the candidates for governor -- it insults the language to apply the word ''debate'' to these glorified spelling bees -- the Democratic candidate, Jim McGreevey, tightened his jaw and began his final statement. And you knew what was coming next:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the attitude of East Side residents toward the West Side included an erroneous middle initial, L, for the lawyer Floyd Abrams. Mr. Abrams has no middle name. A chart with the article also misstated his residence. He lives on Fifth Avenue between 94th and 95th Streets, not at Fifth Avenue and 96th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, DONALD J.
description: COOPER-Donald J., 79. Of South Orange, N.J., Thursday, October 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Fay. Cherished father of Arlene and Richard. Adored grandfather of Jonathan, Ariane and Gregory Brainin. Devoted brother to Arnold, Burton and Raymond. Funeral service will be held at 12:30 p.m. on Sunday, October 26, 1997 in the Bernheim-Apter-Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the UJA-Federation or the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168 Street, NYC 10032.

title: Turning Mom and Dad Into Managing Partners
description: To the Editor:

title: Contested Election May Stall House Work
description: The partisan clash over Representative Loretta Sanchez's contested election victory in California, already roiling in allegations of vengeance and impugned motives, shows no signs of abating and threatens to create legislative gridlock on the House floor.

title: Doing Right by B.A.T. Bondholders
description: WHEN B.A.T. Industries of Britain announced recently that it was merging its insurance businesses with those of the Zurich Group of Switzerland, helping B.A.T.'s shareholders was a major goal. Because of B.A.T's extensive cigarette interests, company executives thought, its insurance operations have long been given short shrift by the stock market.

title: Jimmy Carter
description: The former President, who has taught Sunday school since age 18, now runs the Carter Center in Atlanta, which promotes human rights. He has collected 52 of his favorite lessons in a new book, ''Sources of Strength.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Memories Of Times At Yaddo
description: ''ONE of the key literary experiences is to be rejected by Yaddo,'' Susan Cheever said during one of the seven simultaneous benefit parties thrown for the famous artists' colony on Thursday. The small gatherings, as rarefied as the colony itself, took place in venues from an Upper East Side town house to TriBeCa Grill.

title: Virtue by Other Means
description: The issue of human rights always figures prominently in American foreign policy discourse. This year, the sustained focus on China -- now culminating with the visit of President Jiang Zemin -- has given it a particular salience and intensity.

title: Sports of The Times; Leyland Might Take His Title Ring and Go Home
description: SOMEONE who knows Jim Leyland quite well from his years in Pittsburgh remarked the other day that he and others would not be surprised if Leyland walked away from the Florida Marlins, especially if he could carry off championship memories with him.

title: Massachusetts Reconsiders Death Penalty; A Spate of Killings Challenges the Ideals of a Left-Leaning State
description: This has been a ghastly autumn of murder in Massachusetts.

title: Cornettos Resounding In Danbury Recital
description: CHAMBER music, ancient and modern, is high on the list of attractions this week. At 2 o'clock today the Jewish Historical Society of Greater New Haven presents a concert at Temple Beth Sholom, with Sayard Stone conducting the Connecticut Chamber Orchestra in works of Mozart, Mendelssohn and Copland, while the Klezical Tradition explores Jewish songs and dances from Eastern Europe.

title: Ogea Has the Arm and the Swing to Push the Indians to Game 7
description: Just when the Yankees thought they were on their way to the second step of the defense of their World Series championship, the Cleveland Indians knocked them off their feet and out of the playoffs.

title: Halloween Memories
description: What are your memories of Halloween spent in New Jersey as a child or a child at heart?

title: Lions Roll Smoothly Over Eli
description: Even if it lasted a mere 15 minutes, Columbia's first quarter against Yale yesterday has given the Lions hope of turning around their season. They streaked to a 21-0 lead in the opening period, then hung on for a 21-10 victory before a homecoming crowd of 4,665 at Baker Field.

title: Scorn for Albany Unites Forces Urging a New Constitution
description: A few years ago, a state budget two months late would have been a disaster; now it would be an improvement. The struggle over rent regulation laws held millions of tenants' emotions and financial futures hostage for half a year. Money, delivered in political contributions and embodied by powerful lobbyists, seems to rule the Capitol.

title: Will Huskies Embrace Big Time Football?
description: CAN a state that has embraced the University of Connecticut's successful men's and women's basketball teams with a passion develop a similar mania for a bigtime football team on a campus football crowds of 10,000 are a struggle?

title: Maplewood Commuters To Get Concierge Service
description: It may seem like a dream come true for the busy commuter: after a long day at work in New York, picking up dinner, the dry cleaning and a gift-wrapped toy for a son's birthday at the train station on the way home. And someone would have put snow tires on the car and returned it to the commuter parking lot.

title: Will Barbecue Emerge From the Ashes?
description: BARBECUE has been a bust on Long Island. There are a few exceptions: Turtle Crossing in East Hampton and Spicy's in Bellport and Riverhead come to mind.

title: Samantha Greene And Nils Brous

title: An Initial Public Decanting For a Top California Vintner
description: WHOSE not rendered punch-drunk by last week's plunge in stock prices may want to cast an eye on a new equity offering from Beringer Wine Estates, one of California's most acclaimed vintners.

title: Philip Marsden, 64, Tropical Illness Expert
description: Dr. Philip D. Marsden, a specialist in tropical medicine who trained doctors in Uganda and Brazil and became a world expert on parasites, died on Oct. 4 in his home in Brasilia, where he had lived since 1974. He was 64.

description: BIG TROUBLE

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about combining rehabilitation loans with mortgages misstated the minimum down payment required for some houses by one program. Fannie Mae requirements for minimum down payments on three- and four-family homes under its program are 10 percent, not 5 percent.

title: The Brave New World of General Motors
description: SPIN the steering wheel of a Chevrolet Lumina and the car is slow to turn. Press hard on the gas, and there's a long pause before it accelerates. And, somehow, the Lumina manages to look large on the outside and feel small on the inside.

title: Royal Tutor
description: PHILIPPE, DUC D'ORLEANS Regent of France. By Christine Pevitt. Illustrated. 366 pp. New York: Atlantic Monthly Press. $30.

title: From a Vanished Country, a Viewable Cold-War Archive
description: THESE MEN WERE decidedly not the victors. Instead of striding, they shuffled into an auditorium on the campus of the University of Massachusetts as if they were the bewildered colonels of a vanquished army. In fact, they were producers, directors, actors and screenwriters who, as employees of Deutsche Film AG, the East German state film studio, had become virtually obsolete seven years ago with the unification of Germany.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 16 of the Travel section today about the Caribbean island of Saba misstates the height of a cliff where the airport was built. It is 400 feet, not 4,000.

title: October 19-25; Pol Pot Is Unapologetic
description: ''You don't know what I have suffered,'' said Pol Pot, the former Khmer Rouge leader who was responsible for the deaths of at least a million Cambodians in the 1970's. He was talking about his ailments, particularly an apparent minor stroke two years ago.

title: Essay; The Interior Decorator
description: Gambling tends to corrupt; political power purchased by gambling money corrupts absolutely.

title: Streetscapes/East 82d Street; A Tale of 2 Town Houses, All But Empty for Years
description: SPACE is tight in New York, especially on the Upper East Side. So why have two Beaux-Arts town houses just off Fifth Avenue on East 82d Street been all but empty for years? At 2 East 82d, it's a complicated zoning deal from the 1970's; at 3 East 82d, the architect says ''God only knows.'' But with both buildings there is change ahead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENMAN, DANIEL M.

Survivors include: his wife Bernice, daughter Dr. Amy and husband Bill Rogers, son Judge David and wife Patty, grandchildren in CA., brother Robert and Rhoda of Wantagh, NY, brother Richard and Rhoda of Orlando, FL, nieces and nephews.

description: Most Americans no longer spend their entire careers working for one company. Why would you expect baseball players to be different?

title: The World; Come On Down To Sunny Libya!
description: TAKE a country that has languished under a quixotic colonel for about three decades, building up a reputation for terrorism along the way. Put this fair land under international sanctions, spiked by even tougher restrictions imposed by the United States, which has proved capable of enforcing them with bombs. No planes from the outside world can land there legally. Internal flights, with aircraft patched together in the absence of new spare parts, are risky. Isolation has faded the grand old hotels.

title: Sandra Galvis, David Park
description: Sandra Jordan Galvis and David Keith Park, associates at New York law firms, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Montecito, Calif. The Rev. Maurice O'Mahony performed the ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ROSE R
description: SCHWARTZ-Rose R, 88. Suddenly on Oct. 19, 1997. A native of New York City, graduate of Hunter College and The Columbia University School of Social Work. Her thesis at Columbia was titled ''Working Mothers.'' She was Director of Professional Services for both The Family and Children Society of Yonkers, N.Y., and The Marriage Counseling and Education for Family Life Society in Montclair, New Jersey. She served for ten years as Associate Professor in The New York University Graduate School of Social Work. After moving to Florida in 1970 she was in private practice as a marriage and family counselor and served as acting Director of The Center for Family Services of Palm Beach County and as President of The Jewish Family and Childrens Society in 1979-1980. She is survived by Julius Schwartz, her husband for fifty-four years, her sons Michael and Erick, grandsons Jean-Paul and Ariel and brothers Norman and Gilbert Rubinstein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERWOOD, WILLIAM
description: HERWOOD-William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William Herwood, associated with The Times from 1960, until retiring in 1974.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Record Train, Bridal Div.

title: Humoral Sap; Ancient Cures for Open Minds
description: ONE of the surest ways to bring a luncheon conversation to a halt at the National Institute of Mental Health in Bethesda, Md., is to suggest that phlegm, bile and wind are neurotransmitters. So why then did the institute recently send biomedical scientists to India to confer with Ayurvedic physicians, who still believe that ill-sorted humors of the body cause unbalanced minds?

title: 'Side Show' Asks, What Is Normal?
description: IF YOU HAVE EVER SEEN ''Freaks,'' Tod Browning's macabre 1932 horror-film classic, you have seen the Hilton sisters -- Daisy and Violet, Siamese twins. With their unexceptional features, carefully waved hair and eyebrows fashionably plucked, they are almost pretty in the low-key way of two girls next door. Yet their heads are a little too large for their compact bodies and, more important, they are joined at the hip.

title: Besides Salad, Plum Tomatoes Round Out Casserole and a Tart
description: CLINGING to the last vestiges of Indian summer, the shopper picks up ripe plum tomatoes. A salad, perhaps, will satisfy the die-hards. But a casserole or a savory tart may be better. Whatever the recipe, those versatile, late-season, egg-shaped tomatoes are still available in abundance.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Fassbinder's Germany

title: Crediting the County On the Environment
description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s commentary on the environment (''The Environment: Worth Fighting For,'' Oct. 5) highlighted Westchester's ''extraordinary tradition of environmental advocacy.'' Mr. Kennedy is right to attribute many of Westchester's environmental successes to the grass-roots efforts of dedicated activists who have engaged in battles with powerful special interests for the sake of our future.

title: New Gay Newspaper Is Cause for Optimism; Creative Support
description: To the Editor:

title: A Fine Madness
description: DAUGHTER OF THE QUEEN OF SHEBA By Jacki Lyden. 257 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $24.

title: Jets Contemplate a Rosy Second Half and the Possibility of the Playoffs
description: Increasingly in recent weeks, the Jets' season has seemed less a fluke and more a genuine surprise. And the second half of the season, which begins at the Meadowlands next Sunday against Baltimore, holds the potential to be just as successful.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Pressing Against the Thorns
description: ''Portuguese fatalism gravitates to the absolute,'' observes the son of an immigrant from the Azores early in Katherine Vaz's first collection of short fiction. Fittingly, each story in FADO & OTHER STORIES (University of Pittsburgh, $22.50) becomes a fado, the literary equivalent of a Portuguese song ''of fate,'' an evocation of ''a kind of possession by love and sadness.'' Fierce desire -- be it for revenge, love or quietude -- impels Vaz's characters, all of whom share Portuguese ancestry. ''Listen for the nightingale that presses its breast against the thorns of the rose, that the song might be more beautiful,'' a professor writes in one story. Like him, all of Vaz's characters press willingly, painfully, against the thorns, first to realize and then to accept their fates. Throughout the collection, Vaz succeeds in creating unusual protagonists: an ungainly healer whose hands grow larger and smaller as the plot demands; a young woman who rises into the air and whose much older lover waits for the rain ''until he could feel her pouring over him.'' In another story, a man's eyeball completes an obsessive pilgrimage to the house of his married lover -- only to confront the unwanted knowledge that his love permits her to live contentedly with her husband. ''Fado and Other Stories,'' which won this year's Drue Heinz Literature Prize, is a celebration of the drama of individual lives. With inventive lyricism, it explores the notion of a ''grand event allotted to each person -- only one, with every other major event a consequence of that.'' Janet Kaye

title: Backtalk; Jordan, DiMaggio And That Cool Superstardom
description: Will anyone ever wonder, ''Where have you gone, Michael Jordan?'' When the nation finally raises its lonely eyes from home plate to the hoop for the opening this week of the National Basketball Association's regular season, we may also be watching the start of Jordan's really last season.

title: When a Doll Is More Than Pinafores and Lace
description: WHILE Barbie dolls dominate today's market, ''Dolls, Walking the Edge with Spirit,'' an exhibition at the Lynn Tendler Bignell Gallery of the Brookfield Craft Center through next Sunday, opens new doors. It stretches the imagination and redefines just what a doll can be.

title: Major Questions Facing Candidates In Top County Race
description: WITH Election Day just over a week away, the race for the first open seat for Westchester county executive since 1973 has grown increasingly negative, but the outcome seems to have come down to a few key questions:

title: A Feminist Victory Despite It All
description: I think of Brenda Barnes as a person who had the courage, tenacity and vision to compete and succeed in the corporate world. In my view, it was the same set of qualities which led her to make a decision to put her business career behind her and respond to her children's needs.

title: In Living Color, the Gray Areas of Science
description: THE JOYS OF CHILDBIRTH, 21st-century style: a wailing baby is carried to a counter top and unceremoniously pricked. While the parents look on, a drop of blood is fed into a machine, and a nurse reads impassively from the printout: ''Neurological condition probability, 60 percent. Manic-depression probability, 42 percent. Attention-deficit disorder probability, 89 percent.'' Then, after a pause and a sideways glance at the father: ''Heart disorder probability, 99 percent. Early fatal potential. Life expectancy, 30.2 years.'' Dad is devastated. Only 30 years? On second thought, maybe he'll make the next boy his namesake.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Toyota Corolla and Chevrolet Prizm; A Pair of Sensible Shoes for the Road
description: AFTER I pulled up to the public library and locked the doors of the 1998 Toyota Corolla I was test-driving, a friend approached to ask how I liked the car. She has run up 120,000 miles on her 1990 Geo Prizm, the Corolla's twin, with her commute from the suburbs to downtown Detroit.

title: Barring a Cold Snap, Continue Putting In Plants
description: ''KEEP PLANTING'' really is the answer to a question frequently asked at this time of year: ''Is it safe to plant now?''

title: Pop Culture
description: THE PLEASURES

title: Art of 9 to 5: Street Objects With a Twist
description: THE commons area at Metrotech will be transformed into a site-specific art show on Tuesday as six artists investigate the corporate environment. Titled ''9 to 5,'' the exhibition at the office-retail complex is sponsored by the Public Art Fund and aims to invite viewers to reconsider their perspectives on everyday objects.

title: Childs Says He Yielded For Team
description: It might require a cereal-box decoder ring to decipher what caused a proud, $24 million starter to remove himself voluntarily from the Knicks' starting lineup.

title: For the Homeless, A Dismal Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: Food; Three Heads Are Better Than One
description: Garlic was once a lodestar in America. A dish that smelled of it said ''ethnic''; a neighborhood that reeked of it was, uh, exotic. Ambling through Gilroy, Calif. (self-proclaimed garlic capital of the world), Will Rogers took one whiff of the ambient aroma and declared Gilroy the only town in America where you could marinate a steak by hanging it on a clothesline. This was not a compliment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAWSON, MILDRED BOYT
description: DAWSON-Mildred Boyt. Of Plainfield, NJ. Wife of the late Leslie Davis Dawson, founding Partner of Davidson, Dawson & Clark. Mother of Barbara D. Peek and Peter Lindsay Dawson. Sister of Helen Thompson, Florence Farnham and Harriet B. Corbin. Also survived by four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the Crescent Ave Presbyterian Church, Plainfield, November 8, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The King's Daughters Day School, 502 West Front St, Plainfield, NJ 07060, or the Auxiliary of Muhlenberg Regional Medical Center, Park and Randolph, Plainfield, NJ 07061. For further information, contact the Memorial Funeral Home, Fanwood, NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSES, JULIAN MORTON
description: MOSES-Julian Morton. On October 16, 1997. Record historian author of ''American Celebrity Recordings 1900-1925'', Fellow of the National Endowment for the Humanities, critic and teacher. Survived by his life long friend and companion Christopher Bruno. Julian will be deeply missed by those who loved him and influenced by his work. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Sarah Linkie, Scott Gorenstein

description: President Jiang Zemin, on the eve of his visit to the United States, said today that America's efforts to impose its political principles on China were unfair.

title: Protecting Precious Memories
description: IT seems that no family event -- birthday, graduation wedding or vacation -- is complete without photographs that capture the moment. Unfortunately, as important as these pictures are, we rarely give them the care they deserve. Only when it's too late do we realize that some of our most cherished snapshots are faded or damaged because of years of neglect. What can be done to preserve new pictures, and can anything be done to restore the damaged ones?

title: Women and Battle To Achieve Success
description: Women really have to work harder than men to prove themselves. Kay Gilman and Tina Flaherty, ''Helping Women Overcome Barriers and Achieve Success'' (Oct. 5), project a very positive image of what women can accomplish in a male-dominated society.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, a picture on page 44 of The Times Magazine today, with an article about notable art collectors, is printed upside down and in mirror image. In the painting by David Hammons, called ''Bag Lady in Flight,'' the handles seen on the top left should appear at the bottom left.

description: In 1992, when the Volunteers of America proposed renovating a West 20th Street building to house homeless people with AIDS, no one in Chelsea, where many liberals and gay people live, seemed to object. Now some in the neighborhood want to halt the project.

title: Kathleen Allard, Robert Chartener
description: Kathleen King Allard, a daughter of Kathleen K. Madaus of Worcester, Mass., and O. R. J. Allard of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Robert Victor Chartener, the son of the late Evelyn and William Chartener. The Rev. Thomas F. Pike performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church in New York.

title: VIEWPOINT; Failing To Grab A Tiger By the Tail
description: THOSE who see an impending Asian Century also believe that the economic tigers of East Asia can provide the leadership necessary to guide the world into the next millennium. The failure of Southeast Asia's leaders to respond effectively to the current financial and environmental crises sweeping the region, however, shows that they are not up to the task. Rigidity in the region's political and cultural institutions will prevent the emergence of world-class leaders anytime soon.

description: IT'S not enough that tiny Cymer Inc. holds the progress of the entire semiconductor and computer industries in its hands. Now, it also has short-sellers and rumor mongers on its tail.

description: The network did not want this. Nor did the East Coast corridor purists who were apparently mourning the departure of the Yankees, Orioles and Braves from the playoffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULMAN, ROY, SUNSHINE
description: ULMAN-ROY-Sunshine, August 3, 1997, 101. Beloved wife of Robert C., sister of David, Jane, and Samuel. Best friend of Ida. Lawyer for the needy; integrity her religion, compassion her philosophy. She will be missed. Her ashes rest beside her husband on Mount Hope, Hastings-on-Hudson.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENSTEIN, RUTH RICHARDS
description: EISENSTEIN-Ruth Richards, 91, at home Tuesday, October 21, 1997. Senior Editor at Harry N. Abrams, Inc., founding member Manhattan Reconstructionist Havurah and West End Synagogue. Cherished wife of Myron (z''l). Remembered with love by children and their spouses, Paula Eisenstein Baker & Stephen D. Baker, Hester Eisenstein and Michael Tanzer, & Jethro M. Eisenstein and Stefany Gordon; grandchildren, Hannah Baker Hitzhusen, Sarah Baker Topper, Max Gordon Eisenstein, and Leo Gordon Eisenstein; great-grandchildren, Leah Malka Topper and Rachel Batya Topper. Serviceswere held Friday, October 24. Minyan at 419 East 57th, Saturday, Sunday, Monday, 7:30PM. Contributions to West End Synagogue or National Yiddish Book Center, Amherst, MA. 01002-3375.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

In fact, Leonard Slatkin, when he turned over the baton for the second encore of the National Symphony Orchestra's concert at the Kennedy Center on Friday evening, introduced President Clinton merely as ''guest conductor and perhaps new assistant.''

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in the New Jersey section today with an article about ghosts and haunted houses misstates the location of Ringwood Manor. It is in Ringwood, not Saddle Brook.

title: A Glimpse Inside Our 'Crackhouse'
description: THE demon box squats at 125 East 15th Street, just waiting to disturb the peace, lure the local children into addiction and devalue the adjoining properties. It is merely another ugly four-story tenement with a street-level Irish bar, but it is an object of legend and law in my neighborhood. It is erroneously called ''the crackhouse.'' It is a single-room-occupancy building of a kind disappearing in the city because the only people who want and need to live in S.R.O.'s tend to be old, poor, voiceless.

title: For One Rider, at Least, Seat Belt Warnings Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Pacific Overtures
description: FLOWER NET

title: Pregnant With Complications
description: Sophia sits in a booth in a dimly lighted Chinese restaurant, reluctantly talking about the details of her life. She is beyond tired, as she has been for several months, and as she is likely to be for several more. The weathered brown of her hair, the weary brown shadows under her eyes, even the muted brown of her maternity dress over her very pregnant lap, all of these things somehow magnify her exhaustion.

title: A Nobel Winner Wears Several Fund Hats
description: MYRON SCHOLES, the Stanford professor emeritus who recently won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science for research into pricing options, is also a mutual fund investor. In fact, he sits on the boards of three fund complexes, helping them cut costs and improve operations. Along with his fellow Nobel winner, Robert C. Merton of the Harvard Business School, he is also a principal of Long Term Capital Management, a $6 billion hedge fund that invests principally in fixed-income securities and derivatives on them. He spoke last week from his office in Connecticut. TIMOTHY MIDDLETON

title: Harvard Tops Princeton Thanks to 4 Field Goals
description: Coming into today's game between Princeton and Harvard, the consensus was that if the Tigers could keep the Crimson's formidable offense in check, they would win. After all, Harvard ranked fourth in Division I-AA with an average of 479 yards in total offense and 37 points a game.

title: Rebel With Many Causes
description: COMPANERO The Life and Death of Che Guevara. By Jorge G. Castaneda. Translated by Marina Castaneda. Illustrated. 456 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Fast Forward; Lost In Space
description: The United States, having lofted a fleet of satellites to create the modern miracle of navigation technology known as the global-positioning system, now has a choice of methods for making G.P .S. many times more accurate.

title: Cali Leibowitz, Gregg Goldman
description: Cali Paige Leibowitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen G. Leibowitz of Brooklyn, was married last evening to Gregg Louis Goldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan S. Goldman of Commack, N.Y. Rabbi William Berman officiated at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck in King's Point, N.Y.

title: How to Keep the Best Workers Working at Their Best
description: ALMOST every office has one: the recent M.B.A. with fire in her belly, the weekend-working overachiever who regularly finishes his daily list of things to do, the people who take on the workplace equivalent of ironing boxer shorts. Managers love them, unions distrust them and co-workers merely roll their eyes, knowing that on an island of perfectionists, the average Joe is doomed.

title: Word for Word / Drinking Etiquette Abroad; How to Succeed in Business By Getting Really Bombed
description: WITH apologies to the life-style police, there's a downside to the decline of the American three-martini lunch. For it seems that the nation's global economic competitiveness depends in part on the ability of its representatives to knock 'em back with some serious boozers abroad.

title: When a Room Is Not Enough
description: SOON after the 600-room Westin Rio Mar Beach hotel opened in northeast Puerto Rico, the tinkering began. The hotel began poking holes in the walls of some guest rooms. Why? To create more doors and adjoining quarters for the larger than expected number of families with children who had visited the hotel since it opened in August 1996, in a beautiful setting between mountains and sea.

title: University Presses; Against Appropriation
description: RACECHANGES

title: QUICK BITE/Belmar; Vegetables Work Their Magic on a Meat Lover
description: Andrew, a musician in his 30's, has been known to eat cheeseburgers for breakfast, meatball sandwiches for lunch and a sirloin steak for dinner. So when he was invited to dine at Veggie Works, a vegetarian cafe in Belmar, he had a pained expression on his face, as if someone had just interrupted an Eric Clapton guitar solo.

title: Ellerbe Moves In for Wolverines
description: Brian Ellerbe sat in his office at the University of Michigan Athletic complex early last week, doing what most college basketball coaches do at this time of year: study basketball and work the recruiting phones. On this bright, crisp afternoon Ellerbe leaned back in his chair and watched a television showing tapes of last year's Wolverines games.

title: Man Killed on Bridge, as Cars Are No Match for Slick Roads
description: A rare day of rain in what has been an unusually dry autumn created problems on New York City's streets yesterday, with police radios buzzing about fender benders and at least two serious weather-related traffic accidents that left one motorist dead and another in critical condition.

title: The Few. The Proud. The Very Nervous.
description: The Armed Forces School of Music, a converted barracks in Norfolk,Va., is the Pentagon's boot camp for troops who are also musicians. Every year, about 300 freshly scrubbed recruits sign up to perfect their skills on an instrument, learn a little music theory and, of course, practice marching. Lots and lots of marching. The students have to gain proficiency in swing, jazz, classical, Latin, country and rock-and-roll. If they pass an audition at the end of the 26-week course, they ship out to 1 of 76 military bands worldwide to perform in parades, promotion ceremonies and recruitment tours. If they wash out, and some do, they end up driving a tank or shooting a rifle somewhere. With those stakes, wouldn't your lips and fingers be trembling a little? Here's a look.

title: A Feminist Victory Despite It All
description: Ms. Osias is oblivious to an important fact, running a major corporation has nothing to do with having it all. Having it all means three things: nurturing a family, a fulfilling career and time to pursue personal interests. The goal of every feminist manifesto is not ''real power, real wealth and a real job.'' Feminism is about personal power, not corporate power. It has nothing to do with an accumulation of material possessions. Women want to feel complete as individuals and as women. If the ''corrosive environment of the business world'' does not meet feminine needs, then fulfilling these needs elsewhere is growth.

title: Some Foresee Revival, Some Ruin Along a Proposed Light-Rail Line
description: Twice a day, from the front window of his dry cleaning shop, Louis Fisher can see Conrail freight trains moving slowly down a single track through downtown Riverside.

title: An Apt Replacement
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Protect Your Photographs
description: IT seems that no family event, a birthday, graduation wedding, or vacation is complete without photographs that capture the moment. Unfortunately, as important as these pictures are, we rarely give them the care that they deserve. Only when it's too late do we realize that some of our most cherished snapshots are faded or damaged because of years of neglect. What can be done to preserve new pictures and can anything be done to restore the damaged ones?

title: Tracy Altman, Gregory Warner
description: Tracy Frances Altman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Altman of New York, was married there yesterday to Gregory Herbert Warner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Allyn Warner of Lafayette, Calif. Justice Walter B. Tolub of the State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the Metropolitan Club.

title: Race Taking Its Toll On Boats, and Sailors
description: It was a gaunt Paul Cayard who stepped ashore in Cape Town last Tuesday. His wife, Icka, asked him to shave off the full beard he had grown during his 30 days at sea. But with the facial hair gone, his usual hardy good looks gave way to a bony jaw and sunken cheeks.

title: John Cook and Jennifer Davidoff
description: Jennifer Ann Davidoff and John Scott Cook were married last evening at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: WITHIN THE LIGHTED CITY

title: A Good Month for Hedging on Currency Risk
description: WITH Asian currency markets in turmoil, a natural question for mutual fund investors is whether the portfolio managers of their emerging-market funds hedge currency risk.

title: Buoyant McGreevey Stumps in His Hometown
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey shouted, jumped in front of cars and slapped the backs of total strangers today, hoping to solidify support for his gubernatorial campaign in this city's heavily Democratic neighborhoods.

title: Wright Lives Dream: He's Starting Game 7
description: Jaret Wright had a huge smile on his face as he strutted into an interview room tonight to talk about being designated as Cleveland's starter for Game 7 of the World Series. As expected, Manager Mike Hargrove selected the poised 21-year-old Wright over the unpredictable Charles Nagy. As expected, Wright was psyched.

title: BEST SELLERS: October 26, 1997
description: Weeks

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Red Bank, N.J.; Reborn Downtown, Century-Old Homes
description: BETTY THOMPSON is a member of Red Bank's Borough Council, the charter school committee and the school superintendent's partnership committee. ''This is a positive, engagement-type community,'' she said.

title: Whitman Fights Without Her Party's Right Arm
description: After four years as one of the most prominent members of the Republican Party's moderate wing, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is finding that her brand of politics threatens to cost her some badly needed votes from more conservative members of her own party.

title: Better Bankruptcy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WADLER, DR. IRWIN
description: WADLER-Dr. Irwin. The Board of Governors and Members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved member, Irwin. On behalf of all Fairview members, we express our deepest condolences to his family. Andrew J. Frankel, Pres Stephen A. Leber, Secy

title: Kimberly Miller, John Karanik Jr.
description: Kimberly Kay Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Robinson Miller 3d of Asharoken, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Alexander Karanik Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Karanik of Phoenix, Md. The Very Rev. Robert V. Wilshire performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation in Garden City, N.Y.

title: Helping Smokers Quit
description: To the Editor:

title: October 19-25; Secondhand, Meet Firsthand
description: Picture the Marlboro Man, moseying over the mesa on horseback, sucking in microelectronically measured puffs of low-tar smoke from his rechargeable four-ounce cigarette holder. Such is the possibility, at least, if the Philip Morris Companies introduces its new battery-powered ''smoking system,'' tentatively called Accord, which the company will test in the United States and Japan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLDEN, WILLIAM H.
description: POLDEN-William H., 76. Died on Saturday, Oct. 18, 1997 at home in Manhattan, New York. He retired from Hearst Publications Corp. He was of Protestant faith. He will be remembered for his great humor and magic. He is survived by his current wife Anna Mae, and his first wife Caroline, the mother of his six children: Carole Ann Isom, Jan Cheryl Orchard-Hedstrom, William Frederick Polden, Laurie Honor Polden, Vincent Ives Polden, and Tara Ora Lewis. He had sixteen grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. A Memorial Service was held at his eldest daughter's house on Oct. 21, 1997. All children were in attendance.

title: Our Town
description: Henry Hathaway's HOUSE ON 92ND STREET (1945) is a fact-based semi-documentary that bristles with tension and suspense as a patriotic young American, played by William Eythe (above), infiltrates a nest of Nazi spies prowling Manhattan on the eve of World War II. The look and feel of the city are superbly evoked. There is one great, vicious scene at a table in a waterfront saloon. The city itself steals the show, but the runner-up is a Broadway transplant named Lydia St. Clair as a bedraggled spy, with eyes like live coals and the drabbest looking trenchcoat ever to haunt Columbus Circle. Lloyd Nolan, Signe Hasso and Gene Lockhart round out the cast -- WEDNESDAY at 11:30 A.M. on AMC. Howard Thompson

title: Sharks Surprise Devils
description: The Devils entered tonight's game with a 4-0 record at home, and they sent out goalie Mike Dunham, who had recorded a shutout last Saturday in his only start of the season. The opponent was the struggling San Jose Sharks, without a victory on the road in two attempts this season. On paper at least, it appeared to be an easy night for the Devils.

title: Border Crossings
description: THE CRYSTAL FRONTIER

title: Disability Insurance for Your 401(k)
description: FRANK VALENTINE wishes he'd had the chance to use a new kind of insurance that makes contributions to retirement plans if a person becomes disabled.

title: So Long, Amtrak
description: To the Editor: So ''Amtrak Courts Riders'' (Travel Advisory, Sept. 21)? Well, this gal's been jilted one time too often. Sorry, Amtrak, the romance has ended.

title: At Midcareer, an Artist Switches Gears
description: BETWEEN 1995 AND 1996, SUSAN Rothenberg threw away a dozen paintings she had started. She would outline shapes in dirty turpentine as usual, brush on paint squeezed straight from the tube, rework it with a palette knife. She began a series of quilted cats and spiral-coiled mice; she painted apples and oranges. ''Not like Cezanne,'' she remembers. ''I was painting them like what the hell should I paint?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOGEL, CONSTANTINE CHESTER
description: VOGEL-Constantine Chester. Of East Hampton, N.Y., formerly of Manhattan, on October 17th. Retired teacher, Brandeis High School. Beloved husband of D.H. Melhem Vogel; adored father of Dana Marie Vogel and Gregory Melhem Vogel; brother of the late Helen Kiamie and the late William B. Vogel. Interment private. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to East Hampton Meals On Wheels, 33 Newtown Lane, East Hampton, N.Y. 11937.

title: The World; Reversing Roles in a South African Dilemma
description: THE arguments have been fierce and familiar: Affirmative action is only the smallest step toward redressing terrible injustice. Affirmative action is irredeemably divisive. Without the force of quotas, racism won't be dislodged. Quotas are anathema. And so on, in a debate that is not even close to resolution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANSON, BERNARD
description: MANSON-Bernard. 90 of Margate, FL. On October 24, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Syd. Devoted father of Michael Manson of Coram, NY. Father-in-law of Zita. Grandfather of Mara, Steven and Hilary Manson. Great-grandfather of Adam, Emma and Kate Manson. Cherished brother and uncle. Services at Riverside NassauNorth, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, on Monday at 11 AM.

title: University Presses; Not Pretty Enough
description: SKIN DEEP

title: A Good Grip on Creation
description: The Life Of Poetry

title: Adams Family Values
description: JOHN QUINCY ADAMS

title: Chris Rock Has No Time for Your Ignorance
description: As a longtime fan of Eric Bogosian, I was curious to see how he would handle an interview with Chris Rock, whom I have been only moderately impressed by (''Chris Rock Has No Time for Your Ignorance,'' Oct. 5). Bogosian's questions were astute and offered refreshing insights into just who Chris Rock is and why I should care about him. What I read revealed him to be a perceptive, truthful and funny man whose only shortcoming is his foul mouth. The world needs more people like him who tell it like it is. As soon as Rock cleans up his act, he will be ready to kick some serious [expletive].

title: The Piecing Of Her Past
description: SHE handed me the shopping list. This is how it read the first week and, with few exceptions, for hundreds of weeks after that.

title: Michele Evans and Darryll Arrindell
description: A WOMAN with endless interests and plans, and opinions as strong as northeasters, Michele Elizabeth Evans does nothing halfheartedly.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: I Know What You Did Last Summer

title: Performers to Honor Survivors
description: IT is up to the arts to carry on the legacy of Holocaust survivors,'' Donna Cohen, president of the Westchester Holocaust Commission, said. ''Music, art and literature are the most lasting elements of education. They give us a picture of what people are saying, thinking and feeling at any given time in history.''

title: Joy in Mudville: The Resale Value of Minor League Teams
description: THE Quad City River Bandits, a minor league baseball team in Davenport Iowa, are not exactly the stuff of legend. The clubhouse is so small that players have to take turns dressing. The stadium, which seats 5,100, has one men's and one women's restroom (and a 50-cent beer night). And in April the team had among the worst records in baseball -- 3 wins, 15 losses.

title: If It Sings, Wear It; Tommy Hilfiger dresses the stars in hopes that they will strut his stuff.
description: WHEN Mick Jagger dropped in on a party being given by his next-door neighbor Tommy Hilfiger on the Caribbean island of Mustique, Mr. Hilfiger saw the opportunity to ask Mr. Jagger a question: Who was dressing him for his coming world tour?

title: Las Vegas on a Small Stake
description: WHILE waiting for my suitcase at McCarran International Airport in Las Vegas, I got to talking with three little old ladies from Long Island.

title: Giving Commercials Their Best Shot
description: TO David Fitzgerald, New Jersey suburbia essentially breaks down into two basic types: Norman Rockwell and Edward Scissorhands.

title: A Nod to an Independent Streak
description: A Fertile Fellowship

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEENEY, WILLIAM J. III, M.D.
description: SWEENEY-William J. III, M.D. Dedicated physician, pioneer in the field of reproductive medicine. He touched thousands with his humor, skill and kindness. He is survived by his wife Frances, his children and their spouses William, David, James, Brett, Michele, Cindy, Amy and Peter, and his grandchildren William, Nathaniel, Matthew, Hannah, Clifford and Rose.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEIL, ELSE
description: WEIL-Else. Always in our hearts. Bob & Fred

title: NATO Expansion Shows West's Global Ambition; Beware Russia's Reaction
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Look Of Liberalism on The Court
description: The ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' anecdote with which Rosen begins his article may tell us something about Justice Ginsburg's approach to interpreting 18th-century texts.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: MONDAY

title: Colombian Insurgents Undermine Election by Scaring Voters
description: When the bomb blew up the local prosecutor's office Wednesday night, James Canas, a mayoral candidate, sat bolt upright in bed. As windows shattered all along the street, the Rev. Jaime Velasquez, a City Council candidate, figured the public school with its ballot boxes had been destroyed, and stayed put. After the roof tore open, the poll watchers, one by one, decided to quit.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: PICKFORD

title: What's in a Name? Power. Sometimes Trouble.
description: I HAD A CAT FOR EIGHT YEARS AND NEVER named him. I assumed that his animal colleagues knew precisely who he was and that some Fluffy or Tiger appended by me would be superfluous if not condescending. I liked the small mystery of not knowing his name; it added to his dignity. We were close, but he had his friends and I mine.

title: Eve Gallaudet, Timothy Donovan
description: Eve Carter Gallaudet, a daughter of Billie J. Paddock of Cinnaminson, N.J., and Richard L. Gallaudet of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Timothy John Donovan, a son of Jane and John P. Donovan of Norwell, Mass. The Rev. Milton Eggerling, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Church in Boston.

title: Ms. Tinklepaugh, Mr. Fernandez
description: Naomi Mary Tinklepaugh, the daughter of Linda Eggleston Tyree of Holyoke, Mass., and the Rev. Dr. John Nunamaker Tinklepaugh of Northeast, Md., was married yesterday to Prof. David Glenn Fernandez, a son of Concepcion Gochoco Fernandez of Erie, Pa., and the late Dr. Oscar V. Fernandez. The Rev. Dr. Ronald P. Conner, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Christ Church Georgetown in Washington. Msgr. Russell L. Dillard took part in the ceremony.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Mission to Mir

title: Exploring Physical Beauty As a Psychological Weapon
