description: ''FORGET homilies like 'Beauty is as beauty does,' '' Nancy Friday, the author of several pop psychology books, said. ''Believe me, beauty is a player, stalking the streets bare-breasted, stiletto heeled, fly unzipped. Its power is luminous and monumental.''

title: Jail Chief Vows to Stop Sick Leave Abuse
description: CLAIMING that a record number of injury claims and sick calls from corrections officers is undermining operations and breaking the budget at the County Jail here, Commissioner Joseph M. Stancari recently threatened layoffs and other get-tough measures to bring the situation under control.

title: Anybody Home?
description: Planet Quest The Epic Discovery of Alien Solar Systems. By Ken Croswell. Illustrated. 324 pp. New York: The Free Press. $25.

title: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CHALLENGER -- Campaign Journal; Heroic, or Just Quixotic, Messinger Tilts in Populist Tradition
description: Quiet heroism was in the air the other night at Holy Apostles Church in Chelsea. Its congregation has not only fed 3.3 million meals to homeless people in the last 15 years, with the help of thousands of contributors and volunteers, but it rebuilt the 154-year-old Episcopal church after a ruinous fire in 1990.

title: Option Craze Extends to Mutual Funds
description: FOR better or for worse, investors will soon be able to buy options contracts based on mutual fund performance.

title: Prosecutors Widen Inquiry Into Campaign By Teamsters
description: Federal prosecutors have widened their inquiry into teamsters wrongdoing by looking into a $65,000 campaign donation that a teamsters' official made to the union's president, Ron Carey, and by investigating whether union officials were pressured to contribute to his campaign, said lawyers and witnesses who met with the prosecutors.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the state of campaign finances in New York City's mayoral race misstated the amount of money raised in the first three weeks of October, according to disclosure records filed by both campaigns. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign raised $437,398, not $286,732. Ruth W. Messinger's campaign raised $243,488, not $39,643.

title: Beyond 50 and Blazing Trails on the Frontier
description: ONE afternoon Carole Bobruff and Dale Callahan were at their kitchen table, talking about health care, money, entertainment, relationships and a sprightly fellow named Otto. Most mornings they're in a studio at radio station WSUB-AM in Groton, talking about such matters -- and more -- with listeners in a dozen states.

title: Actress, Known for Her Voice, Is Now Getting Meatier Parts
description: ''LINDA LARKIN played the leading female role in ''Aladdin,'' but passers-by on the streets of Manhattan, where she lives, never recognize her.

title: FRIGHT-NIGHT BAROQUE
description: * Halloween's national-blowout status continues -- commercially, it's the second largest holiday after Christmas. * According to a poll by the National Retail Federation, 65 percent of adults say they'll participate in Halloween activities this year. * The two most popular non-mask costumes for 1997 are expected to be Harem Girl and Dracula. * At Headless Horseman Hayrides and Haunted House in Ulster Park, N.Y., Michael and Nancy Jubie, the owners, are using 100 actors and crew to scare some 10,000 people this fall. * Sun Microsystems threw a Halloween ball at Versailles earlier this month for 3,000 guests who wore Louis XVI duds. * Dwayne Ibsen, with the National Costumers Association, says the three most popular Presidential masks are Nixon, Reagan and Kennedy. * What about Bill? ''You can't give those away,'' he says.

title: For the Homeless, A Dismal Equality
description: To the Editor:

title: Bar Is a Borderline Case
description: One summer night 15 years ago, an overheated salesman desperate for a drink blew into the Yellow Rose, a roomy, homey bar a block from the Queens border. ''Thank God, you're the last bar in Brooklyn,'' he said to Addie, the bar's owner, tender, keep and bouncer. (''I'm Addie to the whole world,'' she says, resolutely refusing to give a last name but recalling that at the time she also thought, ''I'm the first bar, for those coming from Queens.'') New signs went up almost immediately.

title: Mount St. Michael Romps
description: NcHendia Tajong scored four touchdowns in leading Mount St. Michael (6-0) to its 11th straight victory in the C.H.S.F.L., a 41-7 rout over St. Francis Prep (3-4). Tajong returned a punt 55 yards, caught a 20-yard pass and scored on runs of 43 and 9 yards. . . . Andre Anderson and Eric Hudson each rushed for touchdowns as Xaverian (3-3) defeated Kellenberg (2-4), 17-12.

title: VIEWPOINT; Making the Giants Nimbler
description: THE tremendous opportunities in telecommunications and information technology continue to spawn a world of megacarriers, created through mergers and large alliances, all born of a need to grow quickly and compete globally. The brisk bidding for MCI Communications by British Telecommunications, Worldcom and GTE is a direct result of this need. But is the business model being pursued the right one for the fast-paced, still entrepreneurial industry these companies hope to dominate?

title: The View From: Waterbury ; Giving Younger Folks A Taste for Rail Travel
description: TRAINS and railroads have played a big part in Edgar Robinson's life ever since he was a boy growing up in Southington during the Depression.

title: University Presses; Barflies
description: SHE LOVED ME ONCE

title: Excuse Me While I Dominate
description: The boy ate crawfish etouffee down on the bayou, played on the lap of the Secretary of the Army, did somersaults in the Court of St. James in London and vacationed along the Nile. The young man helped win two national basketball championships at Duke, played ''Tender Love'' on the piano for David Letterman, reversed the fortunes of an international corporation and would, if his advertising campaign were accurate, ''change the game.'' The professional superstar has a personal assistant, a personal chef and a personal Web site. Tiger Woods is at the locker room door and Muhammed Ali wants an autograph for his son.

title: Joan Alper, William Becker
description: Joan Annette Alper and William Watters Becker are to be married today in Washington. Rabbi Shelley Kovar Becker, a cousin of the bridegroom, is to officiate at the Roof Terrace Restaurant of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Habitats/536 McDonough Street, Bedford-Stuyvesant; Adding 1990's Function To Exquisite 1890's Details
description: JUSTICE LARRY D. MARTIN of State Supreme Court had competition when he bid on the stately old brownstone at 536 McDonough Street in Bedford-Stuyvesant. In fact, the executor of Maybelle Dane's estate said his $124,000 bid wasn't even the highest. Still, he got the home and the antique furnishings with it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEMLER, GEORGE HERBERT, JR.
description: SEMLER-George Herbert, Jr. Age 72, on October 20, 1997, of NYC. Beloved husband of Evelyn Williams Semler. Son of the late George Herbert Semler and Grace Parker Semler. Brother of Gay Semler Estin and Peter Semler. Cherished uncle and cousin to many. Step-brother of the late Joan Achelis Hamilton. Grandson of the late Horatio and Anna Parker. The funeral and burial were held in New Hartford, NY, on October 25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRASK, FREDERICK K., JR.
description: TRASK-Frederick K., Jr. The boards, faculty and staff of The New York Hospital and Cornell University Medical College are deeply saddened by the passing of esteemed New York Hospital Life Governor Frederick K. Trask, Jr. Mr. Trask joined the Board of Governors of The Society of the New York Hospital in 1954, and rendered distinguished service as president from 1961 to 1965. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his wife and family. John T. McGillicuddy Chairman, Board of Governors The New York Hospital David B. Skinner, MD President and CEO The New York Hospital Sanford I. Weill Chairman, Board of Overseers Cornell University Medical College Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., MD Stephen and Suzanne Weiss Dean Cornell University Medical College

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: BALLET IN HARTFORD

title: Van Horn Out at Least 3 Weeks As Nets' Bad Luck Continues
description: Cursed. Jinxed. Snakebit. Call it what you like. The Nets are out of luck again.

title: Correction
description: A listing on Oct. 5 of cruise ships and their itineraries misstated the number of restaurants on the Queen Elizabeth 2. It is 6, not 4.

title: Will Asia's Malady Infect the World?
description: Risk, the four-letter word investors forgot, is back. And so is the business cycle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUBINER, ARTHUR
description: KRUBINER-Arthur. Of Hallandale, FL. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Loving father of Paul (Margie) Krubiner of Fairfield, CT, and Madeline (Warren) Balinsky of Setauket, NY. Cherished grandfather of Sharon, Adam, Marc, Steven and Carleigh. Devoted brother of Buddy. His legacy of love and devotion will live on in our hearts and minds forever.

title: October 19-25; Top Guns Fleeing the Fold
description: For a certain type of pilot, could there be a better job? Supersonic speed. Daring maneuvers. Those nifty military-issue leather jackets.

title: Three Who Dare Not to Fly In Formation
description: At the Paris fashion shows last week, three women in the audience who have raised their exotic vision of dress into an art form caused other spectators to stand on chairs for a better look. The pictures at left and above show Isabella Blow, a London stylist famous for her phantasmic hats. The pictures at right and top right show Marthe Des Moulins, owner of a charming Paris boutique called Absinthe, renowned for her mixes of 1940's plaids, men's smoking coats, ostrich feather collars and signature marceled hair. At top from left are four self-creations of Anna Piaggi, an editor at Italian Vogue, known for her whimsical blends of the old, the new and the patterned, as in the stockings and mules (inset). Three free spirits fly in a minimalist fashion world.

title: On the Sidewalk, a Patch of Mexico
description: When evening falls on the Garment District, workers stream out of the sweatshops, clothing wholesalers and retail stores along Eighth Avenue and the nearby side streets. The Americans and Europeans are the first to leave, starting around 5 P.M. But as it nears 6 o'clock, the the crowd begins to change. Most are Mexicans, who claim the sidewalks as their own. Workers gather at makeshift food stands, sharing gossip and catching up with cousins and friends.

title: Color Me Sarah Jessica Parker
description: Sarah Jessica Parker likes Mercury and Venus. Kate Capshaw prefers Chili. Alfre Woodard's favorite is Jamaica. Annette Bening's choice is Natural Valli.

title: The Heads of Chinatown: Blue, Red, Blond
description: ON most weekday afternoons, the Styling House is no different than any of the 10 other hair salons on tiny Pell Street in Manhattan's Chinatown, attracting a sparse crowd of middle-aged men and women looking for a trim or, perhaps in a fit of whimsy, a perm.

title: SOAPBOX; Double Park
description: THIS summer, a newly renovated children's park reopened its gates to our Lower East Side community on the corners of Houston, First Avenue and First Street.

title: University Presses; The Dark Side
description: NIGHTMARE ON

title: Memories Of Dachau Still Hold A Survivor
description: Except for Mondays, when it is closed to the public, Martin Zaidenstadt returns each day to the concentration camp here where he was once imprisoned to tell the world what he believes to be the hidden truth about the place.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 5 about the director Terrence Malick and the making of the movie ''The Thin Red Line'' referred incorrectly to its financing. Mike Medavoy, former chairman of Tri-Star Pictures and now chairman of Phoenix Pictures, was the first person approached by the producers Robert Geisler and John Roberdeau about such financing, and he agreed to help them. Mr. Geisler and Mr. Roberdeau did not fail in attempts to attract financing.

title: Regina Kreischer, Toby Wyles
description: Regina Mary Kreischer, the daughter of Margaret E. Kreischer of New York and the late Joseph M. Kreischer, was married yesterday to Andrew Tobias Michael Wyles, a son of Patricia M. Kettle of Devon, England, and Michael R. V. Wyles of Sao Paulo, Brazil. The Rev. George Koury, an interfaith minister, performed the ceremony in the Pavillion at the Rainbow Room in New York.

title: For Garlic Fans, Festival Is a Breath of Fresh Air
description: IT is difficult to think of a vegetable as prized, pungent and mysteriously powerful as the humble-looking garlic bulb. In ancient Egypt, 15 pounds of the so-called scented pearl would buy a healthy male slave. Medics in World War I used it to heal soldiers' wounds. And more recently, researchers have confirmed that garlic compounds can prevent, and possibly even cure, certain types of cancer.

title: Reversing Course on I.R.S., Clinton Takes the Wind Out of Republican Sails
description: Only a few weeks ago, Gene Sperling, the White House economic policy director, left no doubt that President Clinton vociferously opposed a Congressional plan to overhaul the Internal Revenue Service, assailing it as ''a recipe for conflicts of interest'' that would be ''a serious step backwards.''

title: Ms. Lowenberg And Mr. Feldman
description: Heather Lynne Lowenberg, a daughter of Cynthia Wane and a stepdaughter of Sy Wane of Short Hills, N.J., is to be married today to Mark Saul Feldman, the son of Karen and Paul Feldman of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Barry H. Greene is to perform the ceremony at the Pleasantdale Chateau in West Orange, N.J.

title: Managing Managed Care
description: Debra Shapiro seems to have lost something important while becoming adept at working the H.M.O. system for the benefit of her patients and herself. What is missing is any sense of moral outrage toward the financial pressures to minimize care and toward the soaring administrative costs and profits of H.M.O.'s.

title: Phineas Indritz, 81, Counsel To Several House Committees
description: Phineas Indritz, a New Deal liberal and civil-rights lawyer who served as counsel to several committees of the House of Representatives, died on Oct. 15 at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was 81 and lived in Silver Spring.

title: October 19-25; More Bad News For Russia's Communists
description: The Communist Party of Russia has been sliding into oblivion for quite a while. It was disbanded briefly after the failed coup attempt in 1991, and was literally shelled into submission by President Boris N. Yeltsin in 1993. But times have never been tougher for the backward-looking leaders of Russia's biggest political party.

title: Managing Managed Care
description: In the narrow sense, the alternative to H.M.O. incentives is how Klass herself is paid: a flat salary that helps doctors focus on care rather than on money -- no piecework, no bonuses, no carrot-and-stick controls.

title: Endgame
description: THE GRAND CHESSBOARD

title: Zina Berthiaume, Michael Bereck
description: Zina Eva Berthiaume, a daughter of Sharon and Frank Berthiaume of Huguenot, Staten Island, is to be married today to Michael Scott Bereck, a son of Susan Mirabel and a stepson of Gary Mirabel of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Barry Dov Schwartz is to officiate at the Westbury Hotel in New York.

title: For Now: 215 Blocks Without Graffiti
description: Scoff if you want, but property owners swear this is true: Lower Manhattan is graffiti free.

title: Commercial Property/Jamaica, Queens; F.D.A. Project Taps Unusual Public-Private Alliance
description: WHEN it is completed in the fall of 1999, the new laboratory and office building for the Food and Drug Administration will look much like the others on the campus of York College in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Gambling on Ghosts
description: Death is perpetually underfoot in Colma, Calif. For decades, thanks to relatively cheap land, the tiny San Francisco suburb has served as a major burial ground for the entire Bay Area. The place takes its role seriously enough that signs in town warn, ''Unlawful to Drive Through Any Funeral Procession.''

title: Hot or Not, Garlic for Every Taste
description: In July 1993, Paul Bertolli, who is the acclaimed chef and owner of Oliveto, a restaurant in Oakland, Calif., brought together a group including six other prominent chefs and five food writers to taste and compare garlics.

title: It Makes a Great Story, but Who Would Believe It?
description: Fairytale: A True Story

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARRUZA, MARIA E.A. DE
description: ARRUZA-Maria E.A. de. March 19, 1916-October 22, 1996. We will always miss you and love you. Minina, Lara, George, Christianne

title: An Enigma Wrapped in Songs
description: IT WAS SO OFTEN REPEATED that it became pop music legend: Laura Nyro, early in her precocious career, bombed at the 1967 Monterey Pop Festival, booed off the stage by a stoned audience that couldn't follow her meandering lyricism.

title: Possession of the Body, Disease of the Spirit
description: AN old, old English country house with 35 rooms (32 of them locked), 140 windows and, well, one doesn't count gardens; the point is, we're talking plural. Everything in the gardens invites the walks and games of the day, the mysteries of the night, and solitude whenever. Two orphans, 12-year-old Miles and 8-year-old Flora, live in the house, and they walk and play in the garden, day and night.

title: Eldredge Overcomes Injury to Win; Kwan Beats Lipinski
description: Almost four years after Nancy Kerrigan was clubbed here by an associate of Tonya Harding, another gold medal favorite from the United States sustained a bizarre injury today when Todd Eldredge fell and partially dislocated his right shoulder while warming up for the long program at Skate America.

title: Glory Jones, Kenneth Flowers
description: Glory Jones and Kenneth Fischle Flowers were married yesterday in New York. Judge Doris Ling-Cohan of the New York City Civil Court officiated at Marylou's Restaurant.

title: Nike Supports Women in Its Ads but Not Its Factories, Groups Say
description: A coalition of women's groups has attacked Nike as hypocritical for its new television commercials that feature female athletes, asserting that something is wrong when the company calls for empowering American women but pays its largely female overseas work force poorly.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm not letting the weather deter anything. It makes me more fired up. We'll all be wet and cold together. That will help us bond more.''

title: Americans Are Out
description: American Pearl, the 32-foot boat being rowed trans-Atlantic by two American women, retired from racing altogether late Friday when it became clear that an electrical problem would cost too much time and money to fix.

title: Economic Analysis; Can America Buy Time for Asia?
description: The financial shakeout in Southeast Asia raises an urgent question: Are American consumers willing to buy more goods from places like Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia to help revive their economies?

title: Children's Books; Bookshelf
description: DAY OF THE DEAD. By Tony Johnston. Illustrated by Jeanette Winter. Harcourt Brace. $14. (Ages 5 and up) This small but neon-bright book, with a wide black decorated border around each illustration, tells how one family in a small Mexican town goes about observing the rituals of the Day of the Dead.

title: Q and A
description: Farm Stays in Italy

title: Gay Prosecutor Reluctantly Goes Public
description: For more than a year, rumors spread through this proud old port city and the marshy hamlets of the surrounding Low Country that the local prosecutor was gay.

title: Peronists Face Likely Upset As Argentines Go to Polls
description: The political opposition is poised to upset the governing Peronist Party in a Congressional election here on Sunday, and at the heart of the movement is a former schoolteacher whose son was killed along with thousands of other dissidents during the military dictatorship that ruled Argentina from 1976 to 1983.

title: The City Airport Raises Its Profile
description: I CAN'T think of many airports where I would welcome news of a record increase in passengers -- 65 percent more in the first half of this year than in the first half of 1996. The thought conjures up a nightmare of crowds, congestion and terminal misery.

title: An Island Where Less Is More
description: MY wife, Jane, and I had wanted a warm place for a one-week vacation, an island without huge hotels, without casinos, without crowds. Dominica has none of these and more: no shopping to speak of, hardly any road signs, little in the way of sandy beaches. Even the many natural wonders of Dominica, taken one by one, were less wondrous than advertised -- and yet the island itself insinuated itself into our hearts, luring us over the next mountain, into the next valley, and across every bridge we came to.

title: Thousands of Women Share Wounds, and Celebrate
description: For LaChanda Bartell, as for many of the other women here this weekend, the Million Woman March was about something larger and more elusive than issues like education and political empowerment on the 12-point program developed by march organizers. More than that, it was both about healing the wounds that come with being a black woman and about celebrating the special joys that come with that as well.

title: Endless Piano Lessons As Theatrical Inspiration
description: ''TWO PIANOS, FOUR HANDS'' -- A two-man, two-piano memory play made up entirely of skits and musical interludes -- doesn't sound like it has the makings of a hit. But don't tell that to the thousands of Canadians who have embraced this show like no other in recent years.

title: Shelter's Closing Has Left Homeless Women in the Lurch
description: It has been more than three months since the homeless shelter at the former United Nations School on First Avenue and 51st Street closed. Many of the mentally ill and substance-abusing women who lived there are expected to become residents of a new shelter that is scheduled to open in January in a former convent on 45th Street between Second and Third Avenues.

title: Editorial Notebook; The Season of Literary Honors
description: This is the season of literary honors, the month in which the committees that award the Nobel Prize for literature, the Booker Prize, the National Book Awards, the Whiting Foundation Awards and the Lannan Foundation Prizes announce their short lists or final decisions. At a rough estimate, something like $1.5 million will be distributed to the winning authors this month, or slightly less than the publishing advances paid to Arundhati Roy, whose first novel, ''The God of Small Things,'' won the Booker Prize recently, earning $30,000 that Ms. Roy doesn't exactly need. The bulk of the autumnal award money goes, of course, to the winner of the Nobel Prize, who this year is Dario Fo, the author of what the Vatican newspaper Osservatore Romano cheerfully called ''questionable works.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, EDWARD N.
description: HERMAN-Edward N., Esq. Died on October 25. He was a longtime practitioner of law in Queens, where he had also served as Assistant District Attorney. He is survived by his wife Phyllis and his beloved children David and Laura, his son-in-law Donald Einsidler and his cherished grandchildren Matthew and Justin. He will be remembered by his many good friends, associates and clients. Funeral services will be at the Nassau North Chapel in Great Neck, on Tuesday, at 4:30 PM. For further information call 516487-9600.

title: Patents; An algae food rich in omega-3 fatty acids is fed to chickens so they pass it up the food chain.
description: THE nutritional content of beef and chicken has changed in subtle ways since the mid-19th century, when agriculture first started to become industrialized, according to William Barclay, a scientist in Boulder, Colo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, MARGARET V.
description: SULLIVAN-Margaret V., on October 25, 1997. Formerly a resident of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Loving sister of Etheldreda Deering and the late Marion E. Sullivan and Alice D. Sullivan. Cherished aunt of Raymond M. Deering, Jr., Laura Deering-Mayclin, Sr. Joan Marie Deering, C.S.J., David A. Deering, Mary Alice Deering and the late Michael J. Deering. Wake at the Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, Monday, 10:15 AM, St. Patrick's Church.

title: Woman, 72, Is Killed By a Fire Truck
description: A 72-year-old woman was struck and killed by a New York Fire Department vehicle last night in Greenwich Village, officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EASTMENT, GRACE A.
description: EASTMENT-Grace A. On October 25, 1997, in Fairfax, VA, at the age of 91. Loving wife of the late George Eastment (retired Manhattan College Dean and Track Coach). Dear mother of George Eastment III and Thomas Eastment. Cherished grandmother of Scott. Reposing Wednesday, 9-11 AM, at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 11 AM, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

title: Smart Rules for Health Plans
description: The ''bill of rights'' for patients that was tentatively approved last week by a Presidential commission would, if adopted by Congress, build in sensible consumer protections without strangling health plans with innovation-killing rules. There are important holes in the commission's work, but on the whole its draft is promising.

title: Baseball Youth and a Big Payroll Are Served as Marlins Take Title
description: Just when the Cleveland Indians thought they had ended a half-century without a World Series championship, they had it snatched out of their grasp early this morning. The World Series trophy instead will reside in South Florida for the next year. The Marlins, the team that brought major league baseball to Florida and teal to major league baseball, snatched the championship from the Indians with a 3-2 victory in the seventh and final game. They built it on a ninth-inning run that Craig Counsell drove in with a sacrifice fly and an unearned 11th-inning run on a two-out, bases-loaded single to center field by Edgar Renteria.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Deficit Falls to $22.6 Billion As Tax Revenues Surge

title: Ewing Fights Off Age Issue
description: Patrick Ewing can see almost anything coming, from defenders looking to strip him from behind to pretenders wanting to buddy-up to his wealth and fame.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEURAD, ELSIE (NEE STUTZ)
description: NEURAD-Elsie (nee Stutz). On October 25, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Milton. Loving mother of Ellen Licker and Roslyn Kesten. Grandmother of Dee-Ann Milne, Alice Licker, David Licker, Alan Kesten and Theodore Kesten. Great-grandmother of Robbie, Evan, Samantha, Adam, Matthew, Dov, Abbey, Ryan and Cari. Services today, Campbell's, 82nd and Madison, 11:30 AM.

title: Hollywood Anticipates A Literary Bottom Line
description: Books are back in Hollywood.

title: Chinese and U.S. Teams Meet At the World Championship
description: Only one of the four American teams was able to establish a clear advantage in the quarterfinal stage of the world championships here today. The defending champions in the Bermuda Bowl contest, headed by Nick Nickell, were 48 imps ahead of Taiwan after 48 deals of a scheduled 96. His teammates are Dick Freeman, Bob Wolff, Bob Hamman, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell.

title: Commissioner, Under Fire, Cites Child-Agency Gains
description: Nicholas Scoppetta took over New York City's child welfare agency in February 1996 and vowed to make reforms in the beleaguered agency, a promise often made but rarely kept in his new line of work.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: THE GREAT PUMPKIN -- The question at Cornell University: how did a big pumpkin end up atop the 173-foot-tall bell tower? B6.

title: Games People Play
description: When is a computer program that hits the market more than a year behind schedule not necessarily a fiasco? One, when it is made by the Microsoft Corporation? Or two, when it is the sequel to the best-selling computer game in history?

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: With a Chance to Tie, Bengals Come Up Short
description: Jeff Blake stood in front of his locker, shaking his head. He was trying to understand how the final opportunity the Cincinnati Bengals had today to pull themselves out of their losing streak -- now at seven games -- had gone awry.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with a brief review of the singing group Moodswings misspelled the given name of the group's leader. She is Terre Roche, not Terry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FONES, MAYNARD L.
description: FONES-Maynard L. 69, died Friday, October 24, 1997, in Greenwich, CT. He was a 1952 graduate of Western Maryland College in Westminster, MD. Survived by wife Betty Steadman Fones, two daughters, Mary Lee Weber and Nancy Dearing, two sons, Lawrence and John, five grandchildren and a brother, J. Lawrence Fones. He was President and owner of Fones & Mann, Inc., with offices in New York City and Raleigh, NC. Memorial service is scheduled for 4 PM Tuesday at St. Clement's Church, 535 Fairfield Avenue, Stamford, CT.

title: Early to Rise, D'Amato Places a TV Ad Criticizing Ferraro
description: The election is still a year away and his potential rival has not even said whether she will run, but Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato plans to begin broadcasting a television commercial this week attacking Geraldine A. Ferraro for her Congressional votes more than a decade ago on taxes, welfare and a balanced budget amendment.

title: A Blizzard Moves Eastward After Hitting East Colorado
description: The freak snowstorm that blanketed eastern Colorado this weekend moved eastward today as snow fell from eastern Kansas through Missouri and Iowa and into Wisconsin and eastern Michigan.

title: Ex-Major League Pitcher Is Arrested in Assault
description: Hours after he was released on bail following domestic violence charges, the former major-league pitcher John Montefusco violated a restraining order and again assaulted his ex-wife, The Associated Press reported the police as saying.

title: Takings Bill Is Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: At Mass Events, Americans Looking to One Another
description: A rally that attracted several hundred thousand black women to Philadelphia on Saturday, the Million Woman March, was the latest in several recent large events that reflect how Americans are turning to one another, rather than officials, to solve personal and community problems.

title: McGreevey Lists Priorities: Schools, a Master Plan and Economic Development
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with James E. McGreevey conducted today by editors and reporters from The New York Times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEENEY, WILLIAM J. III., M.D.
description: SWEENEY-William J. III., M.D. We acknowledge with deep sorrow the loss of our dear friend and colleague and express our deepest sympathy to his family. New York Lying-In Hospital Alumni Association

title: For Leyland, a Game 7 to Remember
description: At the moment Craig Counsell leaped across home plate with the winning run, the burden of unfulfilled expectations fell off the shoulders of Florida Manager Jim Leyland. Seemingly fated to excruciating defeat, Leyland had his championship, and oh, did he celebrate.

title: Deal Near to Keep Commuter Trains Running
description: The Long Island Rail Road and New Jersey Transit are near agreements with Amtrak and its track workers union that would keep the commuter trains running even if there was an Amtrak strike on Wednesday. But the plans await a final review by all sides at a meeting in Washington today, and officials of the commuter railroads urged riders to prepare for the possibility, slim though it may be, of service disruptions.

title: Shaping Totalitarian Reality, With an Airbrush
description: THE COMMISSAR VANISHES

title: Michigan Spells It Dee-fense
description: Two months ago they were overlooked by a system that forgets to separate one college football season from another. The perception of the Michigan Wolverines was of a program wobbling toward mediocrity, with the baggage of four consecutive four-loss seasons and accusations that it was too rooted in the past. They were good enough to be ranked in preseason polls, but not any higher than the flotsam and jetsam of post-season candidates. If they were lucky, the Wolverines would end their season in a considerably warmer place than Ann Arbor. They would have to be very lucky to wind up in a bowl game that meant anything.

title: Corrections
description: A listing on Thursday of proposals to limit emissions of gases that cause global warming misstated the one offered by Japan. It would cut yearly average emissions from 2008 to 2012 by 5 percent below 1990 levels, not return them to 1990 levels.

title: Sihanouk Sadly Leaves Cambodia as Mediation Bid Fails
description: Saying he did not know when he would ever return, King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia left his homeland for China this weekend, defeated in his attempts to mediate its conflicts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VICAS, GEORGE A.
description: VICAS-George A. On Saturday, October 25, 1997, at his residence. George A. Vicas of Arlington, VA, father of Robert and Leslie Vicas; grandfather of Natalie, Alexander and Jeremy. Companion of Sophie Kempf. Friends may pay their respects at the Arlington Funeral Home, 3901 North Fairfax Drive, Arlington, VA, on Friday, October 31, from 2-4 and 6-8 PM. A memorial service will be held in December, the date to be announced. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society or UNICEF

title: Marketers of cars and communications and cleaning products choose new agencies.
description: CONTINUING weeks of brisk account activity, marketers of everything from cars to cleaning products made changes to their accounts on Friday, involving billings estimated at more than $196 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERMAN, SELMA JEANNE
description: KERMAN-Selma Jeanne. Age 76, on October 25, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Irving Kerman. Treasured mother of Sherri Segall Kerman and Anne Helene Kerman. Sweet loving grandmother of Alexandra and Dana. Loving mother-in-law of Laurence Segall. Dear sister of Martin Schwartz, George Schwartz, Shirley Aronowitz, Beatrice Siegel and Marilyn Neuman. Cherished and much loved friend of Arlene Burke and Myra Bentz. You have touched us all so deeply with your humor and love and compassion. Your unique wonderful spirit will be in our hearts forever. Graveside ceremony today at 11 AM, Mt. Eden Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBERMAN, GEORGE, M.D.
description: LIBERMAN-George, M.D., 91, passed away Friday, October 24, 1997, in Bal Harbour, FL. A dedicated physician, he practiced family medicine in Brooklyn from 1930 to 1989. He was elected ''Family Doctor of the Year'' in 1985. He was the beloved husband of Pearl. Cherished father of Ellen (David) Goldschild and Dr. David (Marie) Liberman. Loving grandfather of Michael and Noah Liberman. ''We will miss you always.'' Expressions of sympathy may be made in Dr. Liberman's name to the Wein Center at Mount Sinai Miami Beach, FL, or Catholic Hospice, Miami, FL. There will be a visitation at Riverside Memorial Chapel (Brooklyn) on Monday, October 27, 1997, from 7-9 PM. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, October 28, 1997, at 12 noon (at the chapel). Interment will follow at the family plot in Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. For further information contact Riverside Memorial Chapels, 312 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn, NY, 718-633-0400.

title: Bitter Fight Among Brothers, Bitterly Recalled
description: It is the summer of 1944 in ''Father of the Angels,'' when lethal tensions are rising between Zionists bent on establishing a Jewish state in Palestine and several Orthodox groups there who for religious reasons resist this movement. One day, a leading Orthodox rabbi, Jacob Israel de Haan, is assassinated, apparently by an agent of the military wing of the Zionist coalition.

title: Foreign Affairs; R.S.V.P.
description: There is a vicious, and I mean vicious, diplomatic war going on here over who will -- and will not -- attend the Nov. 16 Middle East economic summit, which for the last three years has brought Arab and Israeli business elites together. This year's summit is being hosted by Qatar, the gutsy, progressive little gulf oil state, located off the east coast of Saudi Arabia. Israel's coming. The U.S. Secretary of State is coming, but virtually every Arab leader is wavering. Here are my predictions for who will show.

title: Wright Was a Well-Taken Risk
description: Mike Hargrove didn't ask for much for his birthday.

title: People
description: * Kent Aitchison was named executive vice president and executive creative director at McCann-Erickson Detroit, Troy, Mich., part of the McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising division of McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. He succeeds John Mead, who retired. Mr. Aitchison had been senior vice president and creative director for the Ford Motor Company's corporate and customer service accounts at Ogilvy & Mather Detroit, part of WPP Group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRATMAN, BEVERLY
description: BRATMAN-Beverly. In San Francisco on October 23, 1997 at age 85. Beloved wife of the late Carroll C. Bratman; loving mother of Garry Bratman; dear sister of Max Kolman. For further information contact Sinai Memorial Chapel, San Francisco, CA. Contributions to the Alzheimer's Foundation preferred.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LELAIDIER, FRANCIS A
description: LeLAIDIER-Francis A. Of Baldwin, on October 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Margaret J. (nee Callahan). Devoted father of Adrienne Leahy and Francis M. Also survived by seven loving grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Retired representative of Asiel & Co., and US Navy veteran of WW II, serving in both the Atlantic and Pacific theaters. Reposing at Fullerton Funeral Home, Inc., 769 Merrick Rd., Baldwin. Mass of Christian Burial St. Anthony's R.C. Church, Oceanside, Tuesday, 9:45 AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. Visiting 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRAUSS, PAUL
description: STRAUSS-Paul. Founding partner of Gersony Strauss Co., Inc., international commodity trading and brokerage firm, which he was active in for over 50 years. Director of American Fats and Oils Association, Inc. Friend and business associate to many around the world. The partners and staff of Gersony Strauss Co., Inc., deeply mourn his passing and extend sincere condolences to his family. Mr. and Mrs. Lonnie E. James Mr. and Mrs. Rick Hegenberger

title: Angola Plans Pullout Of Troops In Brazzaville
description: Angola promised today to pull its troops out of the Congo Republic, where a civil war has been raging, after the United States representative to the United Nations, Bill Richardson, met with the Angolan Foreign Minister and threatened to cut off aid, diplomats said.

title: Largest Bank In Australia Plans to Buy U.S. Lender
description: National Australia Bank Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Homeside Inc., one of the largest home mortgage companies in the United States, for $1.23 billion in cash.

title: For Rap, Double Becoming Standard
description: Rising from the streets, and from the singles that provided its underpinnings, rap music is moving further into the marketing mainstream with an increasing number of double albums from its more famous performers.

title: Who's to Blame for Tainting American Poultry?; Regulators vs. Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Predicts Food Gap for Poor Countries
description: A survey of what people will be eating -- and feeding their animals -- into the first two decades of the next century finds that problems from rising consumer demands to falling water tables could create huge food gaps in the poorest countries despite their economic growth.

title: Pilot Unhurt After Plane Flips
description: An Oak Ridge woman narrowly escaped injury yesterday when the plane she was flying blew a tire on landing and flipped over at the Lincoln Park Airport, the local police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, JAMES
description: GINSBERG-James. The staff of Paper Enterprises, Inc, Consolidated Paper Co and Peter Pak express our intense grief at the passing of our beloved and esteemed associate, friend, mentor and father of our Director of Customer Services, Ronna Goldstein. He shared our dreams. Herb and Jordan Sedler

title: Edwin O. Kennedy, 97, Pastor And a Professor at a Seminary
description: The Rev. Dr. Edwin O. Kennedy, who had been a professor and administrator at Union Theological Seminary and the pastor of Presbyterian churches in New Jersey, died on Oct. 3 at Heath Village, a retirement community in Washington Township, N.J., where he lived. He was 97.

title: Teams Plagued By Interference
description: There were six defensive pass-interference calls yesterday in the Giants' 29-27 victory over visiting Cincinnati, four on the Bengals that led to 23 points for the Giants. There were also two defensive holding calls on cornerbacks in the game, one on each team. And there was an offensive pass-interference call on Giants receiver Amani Toomer.

title: Metro Matters; Labor Backing For Giuliani: It's Pragmatic
description: FOR Ruth W. Messinger, it must have seemed like one of those you-know-you're-really-in-trouble-when jokes come horribly to life.

title: With Nagano Looming, A Worry for Eldredge
description: As the adrenaline of victory at Skate America wore off and was replaced by the soreness of the morning after, Todd Eldredge today began what he hoped would be an uncomplicated recovery from the partially dislocated shoulder he sustained in a freakish accident Saturday afternoon.

title: Chinese Dissident Is Dying in Jail, Sister Says
description: The sister of Wei Jingsheng, China's most prominent dissident, has come to the United States to tell senior State Department and White House officials that he is dying in jail, and that the United States-China summit meeting this week may be his last chance of emerging from detention alive.

title: Drop in Homicide Rate Linked to Crack's Decline
description: At a time when many politicians and law-enforcement officials are saying their innovative police tactics are responsible for the sharp drop in homicide rates over the past five years, a new Justice Department study has found that the most important reason for the decline may be the waning of the crack cocaine epidemic.

title: Buddy Hirsch, 88, a Trainer Of Hundreds of Winning Horses
description: Buddy Hirsch, a Hall of Fame horse trainer and the son of the renowned trainer Max Hirsch, died Saturday in Bal Harbour, Fla., after a long illness. He was 88.

title: In a Cafe, a New Inspiration For Every Rainbow Color
description: ''Rainbow Cafe,'' a new piece by Eun Me Ahn, a young Korean-born avant-garde dancer and choreographer now based in New York City, started off promisingly on Saturday night at Dance Theater Workshop with some charming antics by a tiny, pregnant young Minnie Mouse look alike dressed in red. She was followed by a woman with a shaved head and red tights and skirtlike fringe, her bare chest painted red, a hammer in each hand and a red plastic spoon in her mouth, who took over the stage with an impudent solo danced within a ring of red lights.

title: This Week
description: EVENTS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNEGAN, KATHERINE K.
description: FINNEGAN-Katherine K. Of Howell, NJ, age 90, on October 24, 1997. Beloved brother of John; devoted grandmother of five and great-grandmother of three. Relatives and friends may call Sunday and Monday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Lakewood Funeral Home, 6250 Hwy. #

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: A Race to Catch A Japanese Star On Blue Lasers
description: Racing to catch a lone Japanese pioneer, a trio of American research laboratories are reporting advances in a new class of solid-state lasers promising a range of products including high-resolution color printers and a new generation of compact disks of immense capacity.

title: After Halftime Hollering, Giants Come Back
description: In the Giants' locker room at halftime of games, a floor-to-ceiling partition divides the area where the team meets. The offensive players gather on one side, the defense on the other.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICE, JAMES P.
description: RICE-James P. Of Chicago, IL. Beloved husband of the late Paula (nee Yasgour). Loving father of William ''Bill'' (Myrna Sislen) and Michael (Jane). Dear grandfather of Joel and Nathan. Fond brother of the late Elizabeth (David) Carson. Services Tuesday, 1:30 PM, at Anshe Emet Synagogue, 3760 North Pine Grove Ave., Chicago. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to James & Paula Rice Immigrant and Refugee Fund, c/o JUF, 1 South Franklin St., Chicago, IL 60606. For information, Piser Chapel, 773-561-4740.

title: McGreevey Says Education Plan Would Be His Legacy as Governor
description: Detailing how he would spend much of his time as governor, James E. McGreevey, the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, said today that his focus in a first term would be on public education, economic development and carrying out a master plan for growth in the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HO, BETTY JANE
description: HO-Betty Jane, died October 24, 1997, at Mary Manning Walsh, Manhattan, age 73, following a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Norman Ho, she is survived by her daughter Dr. Ann Ho of Manhattan, her granddaughter Cheryl Andrews of Tarrytown; her brother Russell F. Anderson of Manhattan; her nephew Jon R. Anderson of Gettysburg, PA., and niece Bonnie R. Anderson of Delavan, WI.

title: Long Wait for Water Ending on Texas Border
description: Esperanza Vallejo will never forget the day. ''I turned on the faucet, and there it was,'' said Mrs. Vallejo, 63, who lives in a small cinderblock home in a patch of desert scrubland west of El Paso. ''Water, just like that. I started to cry. I felt overcome by joy.''

title: An Indefensible Treaty
description: Imagine a nuclear arms reduction treaty in which three nuclear powers -- say, Russia, France and China -- committed to no specific reductions while other nations disarmed. It seems absurd.

title: A Private Eye; Art Flourishes on a Grimy Brooklyn Waterfront
description: The few blocks of Brooklyn waterfront between the Brooklyn and the Manhattan Bridges is a strangely powerful place. It's enough to make you believe in Feng-shui or in the existence of ley lines. In itself, the area of cobbled streets and former warehouses, where in recent years hundreds of artists have set up their studios, is unassuming. Disused tramlines converge and lead to nowhere. There is no supermarket, laundromat or other sign of domesticity.

title: United Takes Lead, Then Holds On to Retain Its Title
description: Playing in the rain, just as it had in last year's inaugural championship game of Major League Soccer, D.C. United repeated as champions today with a 2-1 triumph over the Colorado Rapids before a sellout crowd of 57,431 at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: In Her Own Words
description: CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN

title: Sports of The Times; Story Lines Abound: The Game Still Lives
description: ALL of a sudden, baseball was alive with drama, definition and even a touch of political intrigue. Another World Series game ended after midnight early this morning, but not in numbing cold, not with the emptiness of a game gone bad. For a fairly memorable Game 7, the Florida Marlins and the Cleveland Indians put some Classic back in Fall.

title: Hong Kong Market's Descent Resumes as Its Index Drops 6 Percent by Midday
description: Still shellshocked from last week's stock-market mayhem, a week that saw the market here lose 25 percent of its value before mounting a modest recovery on Friday, investors today began fleeing the market again.

title: A Bitter Ending Frustrates Fernandez
description: Tony Fernandez actually smiled, a smallish smile, and invited reporters into his lonely corner of the somber clubhouse. Moments earlier, his flubbing of a grounder helped lead to the decisive run this morning as the Florida Marlins defeated the Cleveland Indians, 3-2, in 11 innings in a dramatic finish to Game 7 of the World Series.

title: New Voices From Jazz's Emerging Generation
description: By the end of Thursday afternoon, jazz, its body spread out on the floor of the practice room of the Eisenhower Theater at the Kennedy Center here, had come close to death. The 11th annual competition of the Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz, this year featuring the trumpet, had just finished its semifinals, and the consensus in the room was that the 15 young trumpeters taking part had collectively fallen off the stage, bumping their foreheads on the potted plants.

title: Whitman and McGreevey Reach Out to Voters
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey took to the pulpit at three of this city's largest churches today, seeking support from black voters, while Gov. Christine Todd Whitman stopped by football games and farm stands in small, heavily Republican towns.

title: CHRONICLE
description: One of Jake's clients, BETTE MIDLER, will be making something of a splash herself this week. She is giving a Halloween party on Friday at the Waldorf-Astoria with an unlikely theme: Hawaii. Proceeds will benefit the New York Restoration Project, which she started two years ago to clean up and restore parks and public spaces in the city.

title: Market Place; Technology Stocks Hit By Variety Of Problems
description: Technology stocks, the perennial leaders of the current bull market, are under fire.

title: U.S. Lowers Goals on China After Glitches in Early Talks
description: When President Jiang Zemin meets President Clinton on Wednesday in the first state visit of a Chinese leader in a dozen years, there is likely to be a nuclear agreement and possibly one to provide American assistance to clear China's air pollution from its coal-fired power plants.

title: Coronado's Quest Rolls
description: The trainer Shug McGaughey said the other day that it was too early to tell whether his 2-year-old colt Coronado's Quest is a Kentucky Derby horse. But the chestnut son of Forty Niner did a lot of things yesterday to suggest that he is: he won the Cowdin Stakes by five and a half lengths, he won for the third time in four starts and he broke the Aqueduct record for six and a half furlongs.

title: Experts Call Giuliani's Term One of Modest Achievement
description: The most devastating charge Rudolph W. Giuliani made against David N. Dinkins in 1993 was that Mr. Dinkins had allowed city government to slip from his control. Mr. Giuliani then spent about 18 hours a day for the next four years making sure that no one ever accused him of the same thing. And no one has.

title: Hollywood's Pulitzer
description: To the Editor:

title: Silencing a Teacher Is Same As Firing Him
description: To the Editor:

title: Figuring It All Out, 350 Years Later
description: Many years ago, I learned, along with the rest of my junior high school geometry class and countless other adolescents, to recite that the square of the hypotenuse is equal to the sums of the squares of the other two sides. But if you expect much more information -- such as, how come? or so what? -- you are at the wrong shop. I cannot begin to explain ''The Proof,'' tomorrow night's offering from ''Nova,'' yet found it absorbing in an incomprehensible way.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, DAVID
description: SAVAGE-David, October 27, 1989. Remembered always with love by your family.

title: More Police on Halloween
description: In an effort to prevent violence on a day that has often been marred by ghoulish crimes, the Police Department will send 1,200 newly graduated officers to patrol the streets and potential trouble spots on Halloween.

title: In Colombia, Rebels Mar Rural Vote With Threats
description: Faced with a violent campaign by Marxist rebels to impose an election boycott, Colombians in well-protected cities turned out to vote today while those in remote villages under guerrilla domination stayed home.

title: Harmonica Maker Battles the Blues
description: Even before musicians from 22 nations began arriving in the German village of Trossingen two weeks ago for the World Harmonica Festival, held every four years, the town already found itself tangled up in blues.

title: Marlins Win World Series
description: The Florida Marlins, a mere babe in the century-old history of major league baseball, won the World Series in their first attempt early this morning, defeating the Cleveland Indians, 3-2, in the 11th inning of the seventh and final game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, LAWRENCE S.
description: SNYDER-Lawrence S. On October 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Shirley Snyder. Dear father of Theodore and father-in-law of Beth. Cherished brother of Stanley and Frederick. Services were held on Sunday, October 26. Contributions can be made in Lawrence's name to: Gilda's Club, 195 W. Houston St., NYC 10014.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERWOOD, WILLIAM JAMES
description: HERWOOD-William James. On October 18, 1997, at the age of 94. A native of NYC, he lived for some years in the San Francisco Bay area. He is survived by brother Fran, sisters Marion and Claudia, son Michael, daughter Beth, and grandson Bill. He retired from International Advertising Sales for The New York Times, and will be long remembered by his friends around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOHNSON, NORMAN DUDLEY
description: JOHNSON-Norman Dudley. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 30th, Saint James' Church 875 Madison Ave, NYC at 11AM. Gifts in his memory may be sent to The Episcopal School 35 East 69th Street, NY, NY 10021, the N.Y. Historical Society 170 Central Park West, New York 10024 or The Martha's Vineyard Hospital Oak Bluffs, MA 02557.

title: When the world doesn't work, try moving to the Web.
description: DEEP in the desert wastes of Partenia, where Saharan sand dunes bake under 120-degree sun and shade is scarce, Bishop Jacques Gaillot presides over his church. There are no buildings, no collection plates, no parishioners, no Communion and no Mass. And undoubtedly, that is just the way the Vatican wanted things when it transferred the dissenting, leftist Bishop from the French diocese of Evreux in 1995 to this ancient see that dates back to the fourth century.

title: After Clinton, Acoustics Star in Renovated Hall
description: There is just one problem with having President Clinton conduct an encore, as Leonard Slatkin and the National Symphony Orchestra did on Friday evening at their concert in the Kennedy Center Concert Hall: What do you do for an encore?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PRINZ, NANCY
description: PRINZ-Nancy. John Wiley & Sons stands out as an extraordinary caring company that kept its faith with Nancy during seven years of illness. It wasn't merely securing the job she loved despite frequent absences for treatment, but giving her support and hope. The company and her loving colleagues extended their hands and their hearts in a manner that sets a standard for corporate responsibility and decency. It's something of which all should take note and which her family will never forget.

title: Finalists Are Selected For Two Accounts
description: Two marketers are entering the final round in the competitions for their accounts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINER, MARVIN
description: STEINER-Marvin. The Officers and members of the Parent Assembly of The Society of American Magicians mourn the passing of our esteemed compeer and past President. Frank Reyes, President Dr. Bruce Lish, First V.P.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BUXBAUM, ETTA
description: BUXBAUM-Etta. Died peacefully on October 25, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Jack Buxbaum. Loving mother of Mark and Howard Buxbaum. Cherished sister of the late Pauline Millman, the late Sam Bernstein, Reuben Bernstein, Jack Bernstein, David Bernstein and Eileen Labrys. Loving grandmother of Jacob, Joseph, Shoshannah and Samuel. Funeral will be held at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY, Monday at 10:30 AM. Contributions can be made in her honor to The Community Hospice of Schenectady, 1411 Union Street, Schenectady, NY 12304.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Thursday about Nike's sponsorship arrangement with the United States Soccer Federation misidentified the reigning women's World Cup soccer champion. It is Norway, not the United States.

title: Slurs Deface Campaign Signs
description: Scores of campaign signs for a candidate for Town Council in Bergenfield were defaced with anti-Semitic epithets early yesterday, the police said.

title: Gingrich Emerging From Self-Exile, Humbler, Wary and Thinner
description: No longer in self-imposed exile, the field marshal of the Republican revolution is once again out on the House floor. Here is Newt Gingrich personally holding open a key roll call so his lieutenants can round up votes. There he is -- leaner but not meaner -- milling in the back of the chamber with his troops.

title: Time-Limit Suit
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOHMAN, DR. HERMAN
description: LOHMAN-Dr. Herman. Of West Orange, NJ, on Sunday, October 26, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Lillian (nee Brody). Devoted father of Mrs. Jane (John) Jellinek and Mrs. Amy (Dr. William) Lieberman. Beloved grandfather of Jill, James, Jordan and Kate. Dear brother of Max and the late Judge Samuel, Nate and George. Funeral service promptly at 12 noon, Tuesday, in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Ave., Short Hills, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the St. Barnabas Development Foundation, Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, NJ 07039. The family will receive visitors at the temple on Tuesday beginning at 11:15 AM.

title: New Jet Eases Travel Hassles For Bill Gates
description: Conspicuous consumption has never come easy to William H. Gates, the chairman and chief executive of the Microsoft Corporation. But these days the mantle of world's richest man seems to be resting easier on his shoulders. Earlier this month, Mr. Gates broke down and bought himself a $21 million private jet.

title: Perseverence Pays Off For Glasson in Victory
description: Each time Bill Glasson suffered another health setback, he wondered if his professional golf career was in jeopardy. He has endured four knee operations, elbow surgery, forearm surgery, debilitating back problems and four sinus operations.

title: Mount Athos Monasteries Unveil Hidden Treasures; Byzantine Works Displayed for the First Time
description: The Western world has no other realm quite like Mount Athos, a rugged tongue of land in northern Greece where 20 Orthodox monasteries rise in crescendo from the rocks and the forests. For the past millennium, the whole peninsula has been a site for monastic settlements, a secret chain of sprawling compounds and hundreds of smaller houses and hermits' hideaways.

title: North Italy Votes for 'Parliament' Without a Ghost of a Chance
description: Last fall, with much pomp and a great deal of publicity, Italy's secessionist Northern League staged an independence day party for Padania, a country that does not exist.

title: Treasury Bills and Notes Scheduled for Auction During the Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two-year and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.

title: Doctors Get Rated
description: To the Editor:

title: FEDERAL DEFICIT AT LOWEST POINT IN TWO DECADES
description: President Clinton will announce on Monday that the Federal budget deficit has fallen to $22.6 billion, the lowest since the early 1970's, largely because of strong economic growth that brought a surge in tax revenue, Administration officials said today.

title: Nagano Journal; Winter Games? El Nino? No Snow? No Problem
description: What if they held a Winter Olympics, and it never snowed?

title: Equity Sale Set For This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHN, URSULE FELIX
description: CAHN-Ursule Felix. Of Delray Beach, FL, died Saturday, October 25, 1997 at Harbour's Edge Nursing Home. Beloved wife of Charles A. Cahn; beloved mother of Patricia (Edward) C. Schwartz of Glencoe, IL; beloved grandmother of David (Renee) A. Schwartz of Hamden, CT, and Donald E. Schwartz of Minneapolis, MN; beloved great grandmother of Sarah L. Schwartz. For information, Robert J. Babione Funeral Home, Boca Raton, FL.

title: Taking In the Sites; Environmental Issues Are Clarified
description: The growing debate over global warming, as well as the El Nino phenomenon and the intense smog over Southeast Asia, has pushed environmental issues to the forefront of the news. Beyond the immediate headlines, though, there is plenty of information available about the environment on the World Wide Web.

title: M.T.A. Seeks To Automate Subway Lines
description: Moving to bring New York City's subways into the 21st century, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to buy a communications system that would allow computers, rather than people, to drive and dispatch the trains.

title: McGreevey's Education Ideas
description: Detailing how he would spend much of his time if he were elected governor, James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate, said that his focus would be on public education, economic development and carrying out a master plan for growth in the state. In an interview with reporters and editors at The New York Times's printing plant in Edison, Mr. McGreevey offered his most specific breakdown of what his priorities would be if he were to win the election on Nov. 4, and said that the state's schools would consume a great deal of his time. [Page A1.]

title: Who's to Blame for Tainting American Poultry?; The Market Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Goes After Voters In Messinger's Stronghold
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began the last week of campaigning yesterday with a foray into the heart of Ruth W. Messinger's base on the Upper West Side, even as he warned his supporters across the city not to grow overconfident. Meanwhile, Ms. Messinger, trailing in the polls and short on money, insisted that the mayoral race was not over and pleaded for votes in four boroughs.

title: Villeneuve Captures Formula One Title
description: Jacques Villeneuve, the son of a driver killed in a Formula One crash, survived a midrace collision with his chief rival yesterday and became the first Canadian to win a Formula One world championship by finishing third in the European Grand Prix in Jerez de la Frontera, Spain, the season's final race.

title: S.I. Democrat Hopes Party Doesn't Matter Most
description: In an overwhelmingly Democratic city, the neighborhoods on the South Shore of Staten Island, with their tree-lined streets and suburban feel, have the distinction of making up the city's most Republican City Council district.

title: Rankin Smith, 72, the Owner Of the Falcons
description: Rankin M. Smith Sr., the owner and chairman of the board of the Atlanta Falcons, died at Piedmont Hospital in Atlanta yesterday afternoon, just hours before the team kicked off the eighth game of a lackluster season. He was 72.

title: Air Couriers Face Changes In Regulations
description: The Transportation Department has announced a review of controls over baggage shipped via air courier services after an incident earlier this month in which pesticide shipped as passenger baggage leaked aboard a jetliner.

title: Who's to Blame for Tainting American Poultry?; Pig-Organ Transplants
description: To the Editor:

title: Station Weighs Local Appeal Against Ready-Made Programs
description: Maybe it is the barking of the ownerless dogs penned in the county humane society across the street. Maybe it is the lingering scare from the explosion at the neighboring gas processing plant, which sent a brick through the station manager's window.

title: Fight Tests Boundaries On Software Operations
description: At the heart of the Justice Department's latest beef with the Microsoft Corporation is a question that constantly plagues the software industry: Just what features do belong in a computer operating system?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REES, MINA S.
description: REES-Mina S. October 25, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Leopold Brahdy. Devoted aunt of Dorothy Halpin. Cherished great-aunt of Suzanne Schmitz, James, Kevin and Paul Halpin. A memorial service will be held at a later date at the City University of NY Graduate School.

title: Great, Greater, Greatest, Gretzky
description: The Great One added yet another milestone to his ever-growing list last night.

title: A Mother's Grief, in Two Traditions
description: On a tour of the Far East in 1956, Benjamin Britten saw a Noh play called ''Sumidagawa'' in Tokyo. For the first 20 minutes, he found the whole thing, with its absurd groaning voices and static pacing, just too silly, as he later recalled. But when the central character took the stage, a crazed woman played by a tall man in a white mask, he was transfixed, as was his companion, the tenor Peter Pears. Eventually, Britten composed his own quasi-operatic version of the tale, ''Curlew River,'' one of his strangest works, which had its premiere at Orford Church in Suffolk, England, in June 1964, with Pears as the woman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MESSINA, BENJAMIN J.
description: MESSINA-Benjamin J. (Retired fireman NYC Fire Department.) Of Mineola, NY, and formerly of Richmond Hill, NY. On October 26, 1997. Beloved husband of Anita. Devoted father of John Messina and Barbara Val. Loving father-inlaw of Anne. Adored grandfather of Susan Messina, Cynthia Luongo and Christopher Messina. Dear brother of Josephine Girardi, Jennie Pugliese and Mary Casella. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday, 25 and 7-10 PM, at Weigand Bros. Funeral Home, 49 Hillside Ave, Williston Park, NY. Funeral Mass Thursday, 10 AM, at St. Aidan's R.C. Church. Entombment Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: E-Z Pass to Start at Hudson River Tunnels
description: Just after midnight tonight, an electronic cordon around New York City will be complete when the E-Z Pass system is switched on at the toll plazas of the Holland and Lincoln Tunnels. For the first time, commuters will be able to drive to and from the city by any route without having to dig for dollar bills, scrounge for coins or hold up traffic asking for a receipt.

title: Hernandez Reunited With Mother
description: The door to Suite 251 at Pro Player Stadium swung open today, and Florida Marlins pitcher Livan Hernandez, a Cuban defector, made eye contact with his mother for the first time in almost two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLGERSEN, ULRIK
description: HOLGERSEN-Ulrik. 90, on October 23, 1997, of Mt. Vernon, NY. Beloved father of Dr. Lief Holgersen and Rev. Arnold Holgersen and brother of Raghnild Holgersen. Friends may visit the Davis and Hepplewhite Funeral Home, Inc., 96 Main Street, Succasunna, NJ, on Sunday, November 2, from 3-5 and 7-9 PM. The service will be held on Monday, 11 AM, at the Hillside Lutheran Brethren Church. Interment will follow at the Pleasant Hill Cemetery in Chester.

title: Who's to Blame for Tainting American Poultry?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hollywood's Pulitzer
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERMAN, STEPHEN FREDERICK
description: HERMAN-Stephen Frederick. On October 24, 1997, at the age of 56. A resident of Riverdale, NY. Senior Vice President at Arab American Bank, NYC, and a member of the Board of Directors. Son of the late Dr. William A. and Marion Herman. Survived by his wife Jean and their children Jeanmarie Sanders, Edward and Stephen, Jr., and by his sister Marion Wedell and brother William Herman. Reposing Monday, 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-5 PM, at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave. (West 261st St., Bronx). Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 10 AM, at St. Gabriel's Church. Interment Poughkeepsie Rural Cemetery, Poughkeepsie, NY. In memory of Stephen, donations to the American Cancer Society, 19 West 56th St., NY, NY 10019 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIRO, EMANUEL
description: SPIRO-Emanuel. Of Brick, NJ, on Saturday, October 25, 1997. Age 86. Beloved husband of Dorothy (nee Dormont). Devoted father of Matthew Jon and the late Richard. The graveside funeral service will be held Tuesday, October 28 at 11:30 AM at the Beth Olam Memorial Park, Lakewood, NJ. For those desiring, donations may be made to a charity of choice. For more information, call Belkoff Goldstein Funeral Chapel, Lakewood, NJ 908-364-0900.

title: Outside Magazine Succeeds by Defying Categories
description: One could say Outside magazine just got lucky.

title: Eagles Save Best for Very Last Minute
description: This was a windy and wet game in which only one offense could survive, only one starting quarterback could exit standing and only one team could claim it was back on track in the shocking, upside-down National Football Conference East.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, RETA
description: RAPPAPORT-Reta. On October 25, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Meyer. Devoted daughter of Doreen Rappaport. She was a talented, powerful woman. Graveside services Tuesday, 11 AM, at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale, New York. For information, call Riverside-Nassau North Chapels 516-487-9600.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RISKIN, JEFFREY JACK
description: RISKIN-Jeffrey Jack. Memorial service Tuesday, 8 PM, Hawthorne Gospel Church, Route 208, Hawthorne, NJ.

title: Conundrum at Cornell: Pumpkin's Lofty Perch
description: At this point in the fall semester, with midterm exams under way, students at Cornell University typically buckle down in the library to ponder the meaning of everything from Picasso's ''Guernica'' to Einstein's theory of relativity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALDACCINI, RENZO
description: BALDACCINI-Renzo. Paintings conservator, art historian, friend to art of all centuries. Born Florence, 1912. New York Journal American, 1963, said of his own paintings, ''a striving to extract from life's incongruities a sense of order and beauty.'' Loyal husband to Louisa. Beloved godfather of Christopher Berry. Dear mentor and friend to Gloria and Eliot. Service St. Ignatius Loyola, 84th St. and Park Ave., 9 AM, Tuesday.

title: INSIDE
description: Blizzard Stuns Colorado And Sweeps Eastward

title: Ex-Pitcher Is Arrested Again
description: Hours after making bail on domestic violence charges, the police said, John Montefusco, the former major league pitcher, violated a restraining order and again assaulted his ex-wife, The Associated Press reported.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: Shaking Off Snow, Broncos Hang On
description: BRONCOS 23

title: TESTING THE LIMITS -- A special report.; Despite U.S. Ban, Russia Buys I.B.M. Computers for Atom Lab
description: Defying the United States, a Russian nuclear weapons laboratory secretly acquired 16 advanced I.B.M. computers late last year, using Moscow-based middlemen to evade American export rules, Russian and American officials say.

title: On First Stop of U.S. Trip, Jiang Visits Pearl Harbor
description: President Jiang Zemin of China began his state visit to the United States today with a simple gesture laden with historical significance, dropping a necklace of Hawaiian flowers at one of the sites in Pearl Harbor where American sailors were killed in the Japanese attack of Dec. 7, 1941.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPKIN, GEORGE
description: POPKIN-George. On October 26, 1997. Attorney at law. Adored husband of Anne. Loving father of Susan Wadsworth and Lenny Popkin. Beloved grandfather of Rebecca Diallo. Cherished brother of Goldie Warren and Joseph Popkin. Beloved of Charles Wadsworth, Joseph Warren, Penny Popkin, Ibrahima Diallo and Carol Tristano. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday 6-8 PM, with service Wednesday, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Anti-Defamation League, 823 United Nations Plaza, NYC 10017, or the organizations with which his children are associated: The Lennie Tristano Jazz Foundaton, PO Box 30273, NYC 10011 and Young Concert Artists, Inc., 250 W. 57 St., NYC 10107.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Who Can Afford Him?; Stephen King Goes in Search of a New Publisher
description: The horror. The horror. Superstar storyteller and scaremeister Stephen King is abandoning Viking, his publisher of 18 years, fleeing what seemed like a contented and placid literary relationship that spanned 44 titles from ''The Dead Zone'' to ''Desperation.''

title: A Rivalry Is Born: Steelers Beat the Jaguars in Overtime
description: The Cleveland Browns were once the despised rivals of the Pittsburgh Steelers. But they have changed ZIP codes, so the Steelers and their fans have been looking for a team to fill the void. It seems the Jacksonville Jaguars will do just fine, and now the Steelers and Jaguars are building one of the more passionate rivalries in the National Football League.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 12 about the history of gangs in New York City incorrectly stated the views of Prof. David Brotherton of John Jay College of Criminal Justice, an expert on gangs. Mr. Brotherton said that the street organizations currently dominant in the city, including the Latin Kings, Netas, and Zulu Nation, do not engage in territorial struggles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUNTER, DR. THOMAS HARRISON
description: HUNTER-Dr. Thomas Harrison. Former Dean of the University of Virginia Medical School, died at his home October 23, 1997. For information, Hill & Wood Funeral Home, Charlottesville, VA.

title: Spanish Passion Swirls With Modern Expression
description: Fred Darsow surely believes that variety is the spice of dance, for he loves to mix styles. On Saturday night at the Kitchen, his company, Fred Darsow Dance, blended American modern dance and Spanish flamenco with fascinating results.

title: Man With a Badge Robs a Token Booth
description: A man who flashed a badge and persuaded a subway token booth clerk in Brooklyn to let him inside the booth hit the unsuspecting clerk on the head with a gun and fled with cash and subway tokens yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Carl Feiss, a Pioneer of Urban Preservation, Dies at 90
description: Carl Feiss, a visionary architect and pioneering urban planner who helped transform the science of clearing slums into the art of historic preservation, died on Oct. 10 at a retirement home in Gainesville, Fla. He was 90 and had played an important role in historic restorations in Charleston, S.C., Savannah, Ga.. Annapolis, Md., Alexandria, Va., and scores of other cities in the United States and abroad.

title: Haute Cheekbones And a Cheeky Spoof
description: The culture of celebrity and the anorexic look of supermodels are overripe as subjects for parody. But the immensely popular A&E ''Biography'' series, prancing through the lives of everyone from Moses to Shirley Temple: there's a subject that's just ripe enough.

title: Trooper's Death Investigated
description: The New Jersey State Police were still trying yesterday to determine what happened in the final moments of the life of Trooper Scott M. Gonzalez, who officials say was shot to death Friday afternoon after he chased a burglary suspect in rural Warren County.

title: Silencing a Teacher Is Same As Firing Him
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS News wants to pay newspaper reporters for tips on stories.
description: IT is not surprising that television news teams comb the daily newspapers for story ideas or that they even call newspaper reporters about their articles. Television news gathering is an expensive proposition, and producers do not like to put their news crews on planes until they know what they will get.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If this were a natural disaster and people were living without water, everyone would expect the government to move in right away with help. There has never been that urgency here. A lot of people were promised by developers that they would have water within one or two years. For many, that one or two years has turned into 20 years.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: JAKE STEINFELD, who is best known for his Body by Jake fitness ventures, will be teaching graduate students to stretch their minds this afternoon at New York University's Stern School of Business. On Nov. 6, he will do a guest lecture at another august institution, the Columbia Business School.

title: Soot Covers Neighborhood
description: Residents in a half-block area in East Rutherford awoke yesterday morning to find their houses covered in black soot, courtesy of a leak at a neighboring printing ink plant, the A.P. reported.

title: Abroad at Home; The War On the Courts
description: It gets little public attention, but it is as important as any political effort in this country today: the campaign by the far right to block President Clinton's appointments to the Federal courts.

title: Smart Savings
description: For reasons that mystify me, there is opposition to a Republican bill that would allow parents to create tax-free savings accounts for education. Opponents claim that this legislation would threaten public schools. In reality, however, it does nothing more than help parents give their children a leg up.

title: Not Your Father's Art Museum; Brooklyn's Got Monet, but Also Karaoke, Poetry and Disco
description: With its immense classical dome and acre upon acre of marble, the Brooklyn Museum of Art bespeaks elegance. Its collections, from ancient Egyptian coffins to looming Rodin sculptures, are renowned.

title: Legal Bills Soar in Fund-Raising Inquiries
description: When Dan Denning went to work for the National Policy Forum, a defunct Republican think tank, little did he imagine that three years later he would be hauled before two Congressional investigative committees and a grand jury. After all, he was just a mid-level financial officer, he said, who did nothing more than persuade lawyers to approve bank loans for the organization.

title: An African Blueprint
description: To the Editor:

title: Who's to Blame for Tainting American Poultry?; Recipe for Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Martinez Could Return to L.A.
description: Pedro Martinez, the hottest trade commodity on the current market, could return to the Los Angeles Dodgers for a reunion with his older brother, Ramon.
