An executive of another club said the Dodgers are aggressively pursuing Martinez, whom the Expos have decided to trade rather than pay the going rate for outstanding pitchers. The executive said it was possible the Dodgers would also acquire second baseman Mike Lansing. One player who would most likely be included in a package for Martinez and Lansing would be Wilton Guerrero, the rookie second baseman for the Dodgers. MURRAY CHASS

title: Correction Officer Charged in Fatal Crash
description: A Queens man was killed yesterday when his car was hit on the Cross Island Parkway by a car driven by a drunken New York City correction officer, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SEVIN, MALVIN PEACE
description: SEVIN-Malvin Peace. Today is your seventy-ninth Birthday. You were always here to understand and guide us, and in times of uncertainty your strength and words of wisdom were our pillar of comfort. We miss you every minute of every day. Love you, Audrey, Irik and Jaar-mel

title: The Justice Department v. Microsoft: The Evidence and the Answers
description: Last week, the Justice Department renewed its antitrust scrutiny of the nation's largest software manufacturer. It asked a Federal judge to order the Microsoft Corporation to stop forcing makers of personal computers to include its Internet browser software in every machine they sell. The Attorney General, Janet Reno, said the company had violated its 1995 agreement not to tie the licensing of one of its products, like its ubiquitous operating system, to another, like the browser software that allows customers to find their way around the World Wide Web.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHN, BERNARD J.
description: CAHN-Bernard J. Lawyer, died October 25, 1997, in Brooklyn, NY, after a long illness at age 89. Beloved husband of Rose Cahn. Devoted father of Meta and Richard Cahn. His integrity, his compassion, his sense of humor and his devotion to family and friends was exceptional. A contribution to the Association for the Help of Retarded Children would be appreciated.

title: Parker T. Hart, U.S. Diplomat And a Mideast Specialist, 87
description: Parker T. Hart, an American career diplomat who was prominent in Middle East matters in the 1960's, serving as Ambassador to Kuwait, Saudi Arabia and Turkey and Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, died on Oct. 15 at his home in Washington. He was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALONEY, CLAIRE M.
description: MALONEY-Claire M. October 23, 1997. Mother of Owen Smigelski. Survived also by her sisters Patricia Maloney and Eileen Jones, her brother William and six nieces and nephews. Interment will be private, a memorial gathering will be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKLIN, CELIA
description: FRANKLIN-Celia. On October 25, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Jay (Jack). Devoted mother of David and Mark and daughter-in-law Fran. Cherished grandmother of Linda, Andrew, Matthew, Jonathan and Laura, and great-grandmother of Pierson and Meg. Services Monday, 3 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: World News Briefs; U.S.-Born Killer Is Freed by Israel
description: The Israeli authorities tonight freed an American-born Israeli who had been sentenced to life in prison for killing a Palestinian mosque guard during a shooting incident 15 years ago on the Temple Mount here.

title: THE AD CAMPAIGN ; A Potential Rival Is Depicted as 'From the Left'
description: PRODUCER -- Russo, Marsh and Raper, Sacramento, Calif.

title: A Passionate Promoter Of Hip-Hop
description: The concert by Wyclef Jean and the Refugee All-Stars on Friday night at the Hammerstein Ballroom was a jumble of mixed agendas: a club show and a live MTV show, a political forum and a rappers' showcase, a history lesson and a promotion for his album, ''The Carnival'' (Columbia). The hourlong extravaganza had guest stars, costume changes, a carnival-mask stage set and even a mini-orchestra for one song. During commercials, a disk jockey played songs, and Mr. Jean tossed T-shirts to the crowd while letting loose the four-letter words MTV had forbidden.

title: Sports of The Times; After Four Victories, the Jury on Kanell Is Still Out
description: IT'S as if a jury of 12 games, not 12 people, were voting on Danny Kanell's future as the Giants' quarterback. Four ''yes'' votes are in; eight others are yet to be counted.

title: Christine Whitman for Governor
description: For most of this year, the New Jersey gubernatorial race sputtered along with little drama. Early surveys showed Gov. Christine Todd Whitman ahead, helped by the state's improved economy, the drop in crime and welfare rolls and, not least, her record of cutting taxes as she promised four years ago. Lately, James McGreevey, a State Senator and the Mayor of Woodbridge, has gained, hammering the Governor over school standards, soaring property taxes and auto insurance rates. Mrs. Whitman, a rising star in the Republican firmament a few years ago, is fighting back hard in a tight race that is drawing national attention.

title: State Street Acquires Stake
description: The State Street Corporation said today that it had acquired a majority interest in Advanced Investments Technology, a developer of investment strategies based on artificial intelligence techniques. Terms were not disclosed. State Street manages $379 billion for clients. Advanced Investments Technology of Clearwater, Fla., said it managed $160 million in assets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLANT, GEORGE
description: BERLANT-George. 83. Died at home Oct. 25th, 1997. He will be remembered by his friends and family as an outstanding ''Mentsch'', and humanitarian, committed to the betterment of society. He was a righteous man in a secular context and will be sorely missed by us all. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Tillie Fogelbaum Berlant, his sister Rose Berlant, his children Karen, Jackie, Mark, Pat and her husband Mel, as well as his ten grandchildren, Trevor, Rebecca, Michele, Libby, Alex, Jason, Erika, Sean, Mac and Tony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIN, FRANCES
description: WEIN-Frances. Devoted wife of the late Abraham. Adored mother of Richard and Lawrence Wein and Carole Ostfeld. Dear sister of Berdie Kleinstein. Cherished grandmother of Bonnie, Felicia, Wendy, Barry, Michael, Stefanie, Jacqueline and Keith. Loving great grandmother of Sandra, Alexander, Valerie and Gabrielle. Services today at 1 P.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEIER, SUSAN (NEE MARGOLIS)
description: MEIER-Susan (Nee Margolis), of Short Hills, on Sunday, October 26, 1997. Beloved wife of Tom. Devoted mother of Jody and James Reitzes, Cathy and Gidion Asher and Amy Meier. Dear sister of Samuel Margolis. Also survived by three grandchildren. Funeral service Wednesday, October 29, at 12 noon in Temple B'Nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Ave., Short Hills. Interment B'Nai Jeshurun Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Jewish Committee or The American Cancer Society.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Plunges 554 Points; Exchanges Close Early

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN HEUKULOM, CAREL
description: VAN HEUKULOM-Carel. Known as a pioneer in the investment company business, died after a long illness. He was an executive of Technology Fund, a management and distribution company, now part of the Kemper Group. Mr. Van Heukulom was known to have been responsible for the first introduction of a U.S. mutual fund on the continent of Europe in 1951. During WWII he took part in the re-conquest of Sicily and was later Military Commander of an area of that island. He next served on General Eisenhower's staff as a Finance and Liaison Officer during the liberation of the Netherlands. He was decorated with Military Order of Oranje Nassau for his dedicated service. Born in New York City in 1908, he is survived by two nephews, Jean Pierre and Michael Guepin of the Netherlands. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday, October 28, 7-9 PM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to Blind Veterans Association, 477 H St, N.W., Washington, DC 20001.

title: Try a Global Warming Compromise; Less Heat, Less Waste
description: To the Editor:

title: In His Own Words
description: JAMES E. McGREEVEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, RUTH PEDOLSKY
description: STEIN-Ruth Pedolsky. Died on Sunday, October 26, 1997 in Corning, New York. Beloved wife of the late Spike Stein, mother of Jamie, Michael, and the late Peter Lincoln; grandmother of Julie, Katherine, Liam and Peter Seth. Services on Tuesday, October 28, at 10 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels in Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society in her memory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARTER, JUDITH (NEE TARR)
description: CARTER-Judith (nee Tarr), 60. Of Howard Beach, N.Y. Survived by two daughters, Susan Isabel Carter, 34, of Costa Mesa, CA., and Julie Hope Carter, 28, of Buffalo, New York. Also survived by sister, Marjorie Glasser of Hollywood, FL., and brother, William Tarr of NYC. Memorial Wednesday, 6 PM. For info: call (716) 882-8104.

title: Soapbox Is Crowded, And Lather Is Richer
description: A group calling itself Project Democracy in China had hoped to assemble Chinese dissidents in Lafayette Park across from the White House to protest the visit this week of China's President, Jiang Zemin. The problem was that so many people were applying at the park to protest the visit that the Parks Service had to turn the group away.

title: Four U.S. Teams Make It to Semifinals
description: All four United States teams won desperately close matches here today at the world bridge championships, and will have to try to eliminate each other in the semifinal stage tomorrow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOKOLOFF, VLADIMIR
description: SOKOLOFF-Vladimir. The faculty, staff, and students of The Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia mourn the loss of Vladimir Sokoloff, our beloved alumnus and emeritus faculty member. Our thoughts and deepest sympathy are with his family. Gary Graffman, President

title: Corrections
description: The Critic's Choice column on Thursday, about compact disks of operas conducted by Valery Gergiyev, alluded to the composer of ''Boris Godunov'' without identifying him. The opera is by Mussorgsky.

title: Arthur S. Lane, 86; Former Federal Judge
description: Arthur Stephen Lane, a lawyer and a former United States District judge, and a former chairman of the New Jersey State Commission of Investigation, died on Thursday at his home in Princeton. He was 86.

title: Owner of Rolls-Royce Plans Sale of Luxury Auto Maker
description: Rolls-Royce Motor Cars P.L.C., a quintessentially British emblem of quality craftsmanship, purring performance and class, was put up for sale today and will almost certainly pass into foreign hands.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBLATT, LEONARD
description: GOLDBLATT-Leonard, 82. Died October 26 in Kingston, New York. A well-known teacher and lecturer on art, he was the originator of the lecture series ''Art on Rye'' at Nassau Community College. Surviving are his wife Evelyn and sons, Stephen, Paul and David. A memorial service will be held Tuesday 1 PM at the Dapson-Chestney Funeral Home, Rhinebeck, New York.

title: Risky Business
description: Was it a case of Asian flu that caused the market to fall 554 points yesterday? I think not. This was, in the language of market technicians, the start of a classic correction, a healthy checking of investor expectations, not unlike the 1987 crash.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BANK OF NEW YORK CO., New York, agreed to purchase the corporate trust business of First American Corp., Nashville, as the bank develops its fee-based businesses. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Microsoft Defends Its Web Browser in Filing
description: The Microsoft Corporation, in a court filing, contends that the Justice Department has long known about the company's plan to incorporate its Web browser software into the Windows operating system and, as a result, should not be allowed to censure Microsoft now.

title: 2 More Companies Linked to Japan Scandal
description: Ten employees of the Hitachi industrial conglomerate and the Asahi Bank paid money into an account held by racketeers, the two companies disclosed yesterday, as an expanding gangster-payoff scandal involved yet more of the best-known names in corporate Japan. Hitachi Ltd., a leading electronics makers and the leader of the Hitachi group, said police were questioning some of its executives about 950,000 yen ($8,000) it paid last year to Honma International, a company linked to a racketeer, Teiji Nakamoto.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINFELD, JOSEPH LEHMAN
description: STEINFELD-Joseph Lehman. On October 26, 1997. Beloved husband of Phyllis Frank Steinfeld. Loving father of JoEllen Snowman, Suzanne Weisman, Gay Benison, Ethelyn Steinfeld and Joseph L. Steinfeld, Jr. Devoted grandfather of ten and great-grandfather of three. Dear brother of Jane Zuckerwar. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, today, Tuesday, 11:30 AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Cancer Care.

title: Featherweight Has Fortune, but Seeks Fame in America
description: He wears leopard-skin trunks and dances in the ring -- before, during and after fights. His elaborate ring entrances, which are taped and sold as stand-alone shows, have lasted longer than some of his bouts. Think of Mick Jagger with a mean left hook and the image of Prince Naseem Hamed begins to come into focus.

title: Official Outlook Pessimistic in Japan
description: The economic recovery in Japan is on shaky ground, with spending continuing to falter as consumers earn smaller paychecks and pay more in taxes, the Bank of Japan said yesterday. The central bank's latest assessment of the economy, part of its quarterly outlook, was more pessimistic than the report in July and offered the latest evidence that the bank would not be raising interest rates from their record lows until late 1998, analysts said.

title: In New Jersey, Rivals Stump At Schools And a Stable
description: Slogging along the edge of a muddy pasture today, in cowboy boots and jeans, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman waved her baseball cap to cajole a stubborn herd of 88 Holstein cattle into their daily ritual of moving down the middle of the road and crossing over into their milking stables.

title: In Chinese Politics, Too, All Photo Ops Are Local
description: When President Nixon went to China in 1972, one of his main goals was to be photographed in the country's most illustrious settings: on the Great Wall, at the Forbidden City, even in Mao Zedong's private bedroom.

title: Boo! Two Studies Uncover Genetic Bases of Fear, in Mice
description: NEUROTIC mice may seem a far cry from anxious people, but two scientific papers being published today provide intriguing clues about the genetic underpinnings of fear in rodents that researchers say may apply to humans as well.

title: Accounts
description: * Vendome Group, Paris, to Ammirati Puris Lintas, Hamburg, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle advertising for its Montblanc pens account, which had been handled by KNSK/BBDO, Hamburg, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $25 million.

title: Giuliani Tailors Ads to Fit Each Borough; Messinger Takes Campaign to School
description: In a media strategy that campaign operatives in both major parties say is a first in New York mayoral politics, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's re-election campaign has bought time on local cable television systems for campaign ads that are tailored to residents of each borough.

title: Down to the sea in marketing: three big new campaigns for the cruise line industry.
description: CRUISE line advertising is still a long way from reaching saturation levels, but it has been growing steadily for several years and shows every sign of continuing to set records.

title: When the Marriage Penalty Is Marriage
description: Recent census figures highlighting dramatic differences in poverty rates between married-couple and single-parent families have lent new ammunition to the ''family values'' crusade. Differences of race, class and neighborhood are no longer the main source of inequality in the United States, asserts David Blankenhorn, president of the Institute for American Values. The problem is simply ''a lack of family formation.'' And the solution to poverty, in this view, is to increase marriage rates.

title: U.S. Charges Liberal Party Council Candidate in Election Inquiry
description: Ernest Emmanuel, a Liberal Party candidate for a Brooklyn seat on the City Council, was charged yesterday with obstruction of justice in connection with a Federal investigation into whether he falsified election documents to qualify for matching public money.

title: Don't Offer Libya Pan Am 103 Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: A. E. HOTCHNER, the writer, was not exactly delighted when he was first asked if he would be willing to have a theater at his alma mater, Washington University in St. Louis, named for him. ''I tried to stop it for three years,'' he said yesterday as he returned from St. Louis for the dedication of the A. E. Hotchner Theater.

title: Squab Control Squabble Ends In Settlement Of a Lawsuit
description: A pigeon-fearing Manhattan woman whose efforts at pest control landed her in jail for several hours settled her $4 million lawsuit against the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals and one of its officers yesterday for an undisclosed amount.

title: Mina S. Rees, Mathematician And CUNY Leader, Dies at 95
description: Dr. Mina S. Rees, a mathematician who broke new ground for women as a university administrator and a leader in the sciences, died on Saturday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home in Manhattan. She was 95 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Amtrak Gets An Extension In Deadline
description: Amtrak and the union representing track maintenance workers agreed tonight to extend a cooling-off period for another eight days, until Nov. 6, averting the threat of a strike at 12:01 A.M. on Wednesday.

title: Inquiry Into G.O.P. Stalls as Donors Are Named
description: Secret bank documents containing the names of donors to two conservative nonprofit groups that helped elect Republican candidates in 1996 have inadvertently fallen into the hands of Democratic members of the Senate Governmental Affairs committee -- and the Democrats are refusing to surrender them.

title: 2 Paper Products Companies To Sell Assets and Pay Debts
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation and the Stone Container Corporation each announced plans today to sell assets and to use the cash raised to pay off debt and focus on their more profitable forest-products businesses.

title: Treasuries Thrive as a Haven From Stocks
description: Supported by a flight to safety from plunging stocks around the world and the first trading halt on Wall Street since the 1987 crash, Treasury securities surged yesterday and pushed yields down to 20-month lows.

title: Here Come the Ink-Jet Printers, Again
description: THE best ink-jet printers seemed remarkable even a couple of years ago, but improvements just keep on coming. Today's top models are more versatile than ever, handling text and graphics with aplomb and even doing a presentable job with photographic images. But plenty of blots remain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VICAS, GEORGE
description: VICAS-George. A life-long close friend. A man of many talents and intelligence, died suddenly, unexpectedly last Saturday, leaving a big hole in our lives. Louis and Maria Kaftal

title: Soft Money Finds Its Way Into 2 Hard-Fought Races
description: Anyone befuddled by the morass of campaign finance charges swirling about Washington these days need only tune in to the races for governor in New Jersey and for Congress on Staten Island for an object lesson in the uses, and possible abuses, of what every C-Span addict now knows as soft money.

title: A Playwright's Tribute To His Power Broker Father
description: The play is about Democratic politics in Manhattan. It was written by the county party leader's son.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBERMAN, GEORGE, M.D.
description: LIBERMAN-George, M.D. The Board of Regents, Medical Board and employees of The Long Island College Hospital join with family and friends in mourning the loss of our longtime colleague. Graduate of the LICH School of Medicine in 1930 and alumni association president, leader in establishing family practice and beloved physician at LICH for 30 years. Personal physican to Eubie Blake, who performed for hospital employees in appreciation. We extend our condolences to his wife Pearl, their children and grandchildren. John Wren, Chairman, Board of Regents Daniel D. Ricciardi, M.D., Medical Board President Donald F. Snell, President and CEO

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Jury Deadlocked on Doctor
description: The jury in the evidence-tampering trial of Dr. Klaus P. Speth remained deadlocked yesterday after a seventh day of deliberations in State Superior Court.

title: In Latin America, Exchanges Follow the Dow Down, Down, Down
description: Stock prices plummeted on exchanges all across Latin America today as global investors, panicked by tumbling markets on Wall Street and in Asia, withdrew funds and local investors followed suit.

title: Marathon Is Staged As Outdoor Theater
description: AS SHE entered Central Park for a training run before the 1996 New York City Marathon, Tegla Loroupe of Kenya was spotted by a homeless man, who sat up from a bench and called out to the two-time winner, ''Are you that runner, that Tegla?''

title: Peronists Lose Congress Election
description: The political landscape in Argentina has undergone a major transformation with the defeat of the governing Peronist Party by an alliance of opposition parties in congressional elections on Sunday.

title: Girl Who Hid Infant Gains Limited Custody
description: A 17-year-old who hid her newborn in her bedroom closet for nearly three weeks gained restricted custody of the baby today, after pleading guilty to neglect.

title: Scientology Rally in Germany Sparsely Attended
description: The Scientology movement, which the authorities here call mercenary and undemocratic, staged a demonstration through the heart of Berlin today intended to depict modern Germany as being just as intolerant toward Scientology as Hitler was toward Jews.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERIN, DANIEL
description: HALPERIN-Daniel, age 85, of Boynton Beach, FL., and formerly of Merrick, NY, on Sunday, Oct 26th in Miami, FL. Beloved husband of Grace Goldberg Halperin. Devoted father of Jane and Jerry Pressman of CT, Gary Halperin and Vicki Markussen. Father-inlaw of Susan Halperin of WA. Grandfather of Karen and Kenneth Ferleger, Steven and Julie Pressman, Jeffrey Pressman of NYC, Mikel, Jory and Devin Halperin of WA. Great grandfather of Samantha Ferleger. Brother of Bernice Adams of Great Neck and Mae Wiesen of NYC. Services Wednesday 12 noon from Abraham L. Green and Son, 88 Beach Rd., Fairfield, CT.

title: Blue Ribbons and Black In Times Sq. Celebration
description: In the latest effort to cast Times Square as a mecca of bright lights and family entertainment, the Municipal Arts Society will preside over a promotion today that might even suggest a county fair baking competition. It will award oversized blue ribbons to what it calls the square's best huge neon signs.

title: First Lady's Hometown Birthday Bash
description: Back in her hometown to celebrate her 50th birthday, Hillary Rodham Clinton sat in her old grammar school today, surrounded by old chums and teachers, reminiscing about the innocence of their childhoods.

title: Old Tensions Threaten India's Governing Coalition
description: After a week of turmoil that was remarkable even by the turbulent standards of Indian democracy, the coalition Government headed by Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral has ordered party leaders to prepare for a possible general election, one many Indians believe could be won by Hindu nationalists with a history of exacerbating Hindu-Muslim tensions.

title: Patriots Falter From the 1, And Packers Punish Them
description: Trailing by 4 points halfway through the third quarter tonight, the New England Patriots had a first-and-goal at the Green Bay 1-yard line. It looked like an easy touchdown, like the emotional lift they needed to recover from what had been a flat performance. Then came disaster.

title: Sometimes a Peaceful Game Is the Most Dangerous Game
description: In chess, nothing can be taken for granted.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I'm just holding tight here. I've been in it long enough not to panic. The economy's doing well and the companies are doing well, so I just have the faith.''

title: For Some Marlins, Rings Are Priceless
description: The Florida Marlins are mercenary champions, a team merged with a spending spree. But from their manager to their stars to their role players, the hired guns for this five-year-old franchise came here with something to prove, bearing very different histories.

title: Metro Business; Morgan Buying O'Connor
description: J.P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy O'Connor Realty Advisors Inc. from the O'Connor Group of New York, making it the largest manager of real estate assets on behalf of pension funds in the nation.

title: Next Asian 'Domino' Won't Be China
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLOGOWER, CHARLES
description: GLOGOWER-Charles. In his 92nd year, on October 25, 1997. Devoted husband of the late Sylvia. Loving father to Ralph and Cynthia Glogower, Susan and Arthur Peisner. Cherished grandfather of Michael and Terri Glogower, Stephanie and Fred Solomon, Nancy, David, Beth, and Ian Peisner. Beloved brother of Jules and Janet Glogower and Iva Tregub. Dear brother-in-law of Irving Cohen. Wonderful uncle to the Glogower, Eckland, Rosen and Cohen families. Services Tuesday, October 28, 1997, 1 PM, at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, New York.

title: Elias Scores Twice to Help Devils Humble Flyers
description: While Eric Lindros and the Philadelphia Flyers may throw a scare into the rest of the National Hockey League, the Devils appear to have little to fear from their Atlantic Division rivals.

title: For Seniors, A Group Walk In the Park
description: For all the people it has touched through the New York City Marathon, the New York Road Runners Club had overlooked a huge segment that would never run a block but wanted to stay fit: walkers, especially older ones. So when club members told Allan Steinfeld, the club's president, about the lack of outlets for their elderly parents, he knew it was time to reach out.

title: A Virtuoso For Whom Perfection Is the Rule
description: A good rule of thumb for music lovers is that concerts ought to be about music first and performers second. Martha Argerich, who played three concertos at two events with the Montreal Symphony over the weekend at Carnegie Hall, clouds this otherwise straightforward thought. She, in other words, is a pianist who brings along a free-standing musicality of her own regardless of the repertory; the ferociousness of her technique and its stupefying accuracy become legitimate attractions in and of themselves.

title: A Soaring Aretha Franklin Ignites an Evening of Tributes
description: Jazz is so relegated to the margins of popular culture that it is seldom permitted to make itself visible in a big way without plenty of compromises. That made the second annual ''A Celebration of America's Music'' an exception; it rounded up some of the biggest names in jazz and jazz-related pop, and put them all in front of the television camera for ABC at the Kennedy Center here on Sunday night. And let them play, or sing, with only a bit of meddling; at last year's gala, jazz came draped in kitsch, singers and dancers.

title: To Study Climate, Freeze Into Arctic Ice
description: HOPING to eliminate some major uncertainties in global climate forecasting, scientists from five nations have allowed an icebreaker to be frozen into a floe drifting in the Arctic Ocean, where they will gather a gigantic treasury of data during the coming year.

title: 36 Players Are Filing For Dollars
description: Some players just could not wait. Thirty-six to be precise.

title: Nutrition, From Angel Hair to Ziti (Ice Cream in Between)
description: In 1981, two days before the New York City Marathon, Alberto Salazar blew the lid off carbohydrate-loading mania. Having lunch at the Carnegie Deli, Salazar devoured a pastrami sandwich as high as an elephant's eye. Then, less than 48 hours later, he proceeded to win the second of his three straight titles in world-record time.

title: Spy Tools Let Civilians Eavesdrop On Earth
description: DURING the cold war, small groups of officials in Washington and Moscow held a monopoly on secret intelligence and often clashed publicly on whether the data indicated that arms treaties were being obeyed or broken. The discord more than once left ordinary people on both sides in the dark about what to believe.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Union Tries to Enroll Doctors
description: A Pennsauken labor union asked Federal officials yesterday to let about 400 New Jersey and Pennsylvania doctors join it as a bargaining unit in negotiations with a Philadelphia health maintenance organization.

title: Intel and Digital Settle Lawsuit And Make Deal
description: Ending five months of bitter legal wrangling, the Intel Corporation has agreed to buy the semiconductor manufacturing operations of the Digital Equipment Corporation for $700 million and to pay royalties to the computer maker as part of a broad settlement of a patent infringement suit brought by Digital.

title: PANTRY BUYS LIL' CHAMP FOOD STORES FOR $133 MILLION
description: Pantry Inc. said yesterday that it had bought Lil' Champ Food Stores Inc. for $133 million in cash, making it the third-largest convenience-store chain not owned by a gasoline company. Pantry, which is based in Sanford, N.C., also assumed $10 million of its debt. Lil' Champ, based in Jacksonville, Fla., was owned by Docks U.S.A. Inc., a unit of theFrench retailer Auchan S.A. The purchase will create a chain of 880 stores with annual revenue of about $970 million. Pantry's owners -- Freeman Spogli & Company, Chase Manhattan Capital L.P. and management -- said they would use the northern Florida chain as a base to expand in the Southeast.

title: Sumitomo Bank to Post Full-Year Pretax Loss
description: The Sumitomo Bank Ltd., a major Japanese commercial bank, said yesterday that it would post a full-year pretax loss of 470 billion yen, or $3.8 billion, to write off bad debts. Sumitomo will close 30 of its bank branches and cut 700 jobs by the fiscal year that ends in March 1999. The actions are a result of problems with nonperforming loans and losses in the stock market, it said.

title: 2d Season Ended on Up Note
description: Major League Soccer attendance was down by 16 percent, but the quality of play improved substantially in the league's second year, which culminated Sunday with D.C. United repeating as champion.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Parent Opposes Devil Mascot
description: A little red devil that appears on everything from stationery to the gym floor in the Penns Grove-Carneys Point Regional School District has set off a controversy in this small Salem County community. Donna McCracken, who has four children in the district, wrote to the local newspaper objecting to the devil image that is the district's mascot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, HOWARD WILLIAM
description: HALL-Howard William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Howard William Hall, associated with The Times from 1959, until retiring in 1974.

title: PIONEER NATURAL RESOURCES BUYS GAS PROPERTIES
description: The Pioneer Natural Resources Company agreed yesterday to buy natural gas properties in east Texas from American Cometra Inc. and the Rockland Pipeline Company for $157 million in cash and stock. Pioneer, based in Dallas, was formed recently by the merger of the Parker & Parsley Petroleum Company and Mesa Inc. American Cometra and Rockland Pipeline are units of Electrafina S.A. of Belgium. Under the agreement, Pioneer will pay $85 million in cash and 1.75 million shares, based on Friday's closing price. Pioneer's stock slipped 75 cents, to $40.3125.

title: Losses for Courier And Martin
description: The Americans Jim Courier and Todd Martin lost in the first round of the Paris Open yesterday. Bohdan Uhlirach beat Courier, 7-6 (7-5), 6-1, and Jan Siemerink topped Martin, 4-6, 7-6 (8-6), 6-2.

title: Billing Problem Leads to Losses For Big H.M.O.
description: Oxford Health Plans, the big New York area health plan that has been invoked as an industry model for its ability to keep costs down while satisfying patients, said yesterday that it had been losing money because it fell behind in sending bills to customers and underestimated how much it owed doctors and hospitals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAZIANO, FRANK JOSEPH
description: GRAZIANO-Frank Joseph, corporation executive, 79. The entire community of Webb Institute, Board Chairman Charles G. Visconti, President James J. Conti, Trustees, Faculty, Staff, and Students mourn the passing of Frank Joseph Graziano. Mr. Graziano, who lived in Short Hills, NJ, died of cancer on Monday, October 27. A former top executive of Crompton and Knolls Corporation, Mr. Graziano began his distinguished career with the U.S. Navy after graduating from the Naval Academy in 1940. After serving for the Navy in World War II and as an Engineering Duty Officer until 1955, he resigned as Commander in 1955. In 1956 Mr. Graziano became a Vice President for Monarch Machine and Tool Co. of Sidney, OH; in 1963 he began a six year career with American Can Co., NY during which time he progressed from the General Manager of the Machinery Division to the position of Corporate Senior Vice President. In 1969 he joined Crompton and Knolls Corporation as President, and he retired from the company as Chairman in 1986. In addition to leadership roles with many business and civic organizations, Mr. Graziano was a treasured member of the Webb Institute community, serving as Chairman of the Board of Trustees for Webb from 1978-84 and later as Chairman Emeritus. Webb Institute will forever remain grateful for both his wisdom and his guidance. Surviving are his wife, Anne, and five children, Gayle, James, Joseph, David and Elisabeth.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Death Penalty Is Considered
description: The authorities may seek the death penalty against a man accused of planning a robbery that led to the slayings of three men in Bogota last week, an assistant prosecutor in Bergen County said yesterday. Dimpy Patel, 31, of Gloucester, who is being held without bail at the Bergen County Jail, recruited the three other men charged in the Oct. 23 slayings at the home of Rajesh Kalsaria, said the assistant prosecutor, James Santulli. Mr. Santulli declined to say how Mr. Patel recruited the men, who are being held in $3 million bail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IOGHA, ELIZABETH
description: IOGHA-Elizabeth. On October 23, 1997. Loving daughter of Mary; devoted sister of Don and Frank. She was in the publishing and editing business.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column of House & Home on Thursday about a designer who placed a portfolio reprint of an 18th-century map of Paris under plexiglass as a floor covering misstated the price of the portfolio. It is $700, not $900.

title: CUNY to Use Teaching Jobs As Incentives
description: Introducing an incentive plan to tie educational performance to budgetary rewards, the trustees of the City University of New York agreed yesterday to parcel out teaching positions to campuses based in part on their graduation rates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPKIN, GEORGE
description: POPKIN-George. On October 26, 1997. Attorney at law. Adored husband of Anne. Loving father of Susan Wadsworth and Lenny Popkin. Beloved grandfather of Rebecca Diallo. Cherished brother of Goldie Warren and Joseph Popkin. Beloved of Charles Wadsworth, Joseph Warren, Penny Popkin, Ibrahima Diallo and Carol Tristano. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St., Tuesday 6-8 PM, with service Wednesday, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Anti-Defamation League, 823 United Nations Plaza, NYC 10017, or the organizations with which his children are associated: The Lennie Tristano Jazz Foundaton, PO Box 30273, NYC 10011 and Young Concert Artists, Inc., 250 W. 57 St., NYC 10107.

title: NEW YORK CITY MARATHON: SPECIAL PREVIEW SECTION: Sports of The Times; ... If James Joyce Had Put on Sweats For Marathon Day
description: The editor called in the middle of the endless baseball playoffs and asked me to write a column about the New York City Marathon, and I groaned and said, ''Mercy, I'm stuck in a motel room somewhere out in America, and it's hard to believe I'll ever get home to cover the marathon,'' but she replied, ''Look, you've often written that the Marathon is the best single sports day of the year in New York, so why don't you just write something off the top of your head about why you love the Marathon?'' and immediately all these images starting forming of these elite runners and gallant plodders roaming through the neighborhoods of New York, and I could hear Mel Torme crooning, ''New York on Sunday,'' and I got all nostalgic, remembering the first New York City Marathon I covered in 1981, when I wangled a spot in Fred Lebow's open pace car, and there we were in Staten Island and the best runners started over the bridge, and Fred spotted some schleppers on the bridge, ahead of the start line, and he yelled at them through his bullhorn, ''I know who you are, you hot-doggers, vee haff your numbers!'' New York gamesmanship from them and New York aggression from Fred, and then we raced through the city, 26 miles and 385 yards, until Fred personally congratulated the American Alberto Salazar and the New Zealander Allison Roe, and I learned to admire the great runners, with their infuriatingly lean bodies, but then I stayed around for the normal clunky people built like me who had somehow willed themselves into running the marathon, and these four-hour runners became my heroes. Fanfare for the common runner. When I finally left the park that year, I just happened to be walking behind Roe as she walked down Central Park West wrapped in a silver heat-holding cape with a garland in her hair, still remarkably spry, and hardly anybody on that hazy November afternoon -- in their sport jackets and leather coats, on their way to dinner or Lincoln Center -- even recognized her, just a vibrant young woman with her boyfriend, ambling down toward Columbus Circle. From that day, I was hooked on the marathon and always volunteered to cover it, starting with observing runners all over the region, in city parks, on suburban roads, doing their roadwork in the snappy fall weather, pushing themselves into better shape, and slugs like me, doing a few silly miles, would mutter, ''next year, next year.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARR, RAY A. BEDFORD
description: BARR-Ray A. Bedford, NY. Died Sunday, October 26 at home. Beloved of Honey and his children, Michael and Korin. Services October 29 at 9:30 AM, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 W. Broad St, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GINSBERG, JAMES
description: GINSBERG-James. To a dear friend and a wonderful human being, we will miss you. Alan and Ardus

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOICHIS, HAYIM, M.D.
description: BOICHIS-Hayim, M.D. After an illness, in Tel Aviv, October 27, 1997. Deputy Minister of the Dept. of Health in the State of Israel, Professor and past Dean of the Tel Aviv University School of Medicine, elected to Honorary Membership of the European Society of Pedatric Nephrology, member of the Council of the European Society of Pediatric Nephrology, Counselor of the International Nephrology Association, visiting professor of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, past Director of the Children's Hospital of the Chaim Sheba Medical Center, Tel Hshomer, Israel. We join his wife Yola, his sons Eli and Ron, their wives Hadar and Iris, and their children in remembering his love and caring for all who came to know him and work with him. Matilda Gevirman, Executive VP Friends of Sheba Medical Center-Tel Hashomer, Inc.

description: MORIARTY-Edmond N., Jr., on October 26, 1997. Beloved husband of Virginia Hyde Moriarty. Moriarty, Jr. Charitable Foundation, c/o Gallagher, Briody & Butler, 212 Carnegie Center, Suite 402, Princeton, NJ 08540.

title: CHRONICLE
description: How many new titles can one acquire in a matter of weeks? VARTAN GREGORIAN, who has been a professor, a provost, a university president, a board member and a doctor many times over thanks to his honorary degrees, has a few new ones to add to his portfolio.

title: WEBSTER FINANCIAL AND EAGLE FINANCIAL SET MERGER
description: The Webster Financial Corporation, the holding company for Webster Bank, agreed yesterday to buy the Eagle Financial Corporation, a Connecticut savings and loan holding company, for $362 million in stock. Shares of Eagle Financial rose $4.50, or 10 percent, to $47.50. Webster Financial, based in Waterbury, Conn., said the acquisition would give it $8.9 billion in assets and more than 110 branches. Eagle, based in Bristol, Conn., has assets of $2.1 billion and operates 30 branches in Hartford and Litchfield Counties. Under the terms of the agreement, Webster will swap 0.84 share for each Eagle share, or $55.44 a share based on Webster's closing price on Friday. Webster's shares dropped $7.25 a share, to $58.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSNER, BERTHA (NEE JUCEAM)
description: ROSNER-Bertha (nee Juceam) on Oct. 25, 1997, age 93. Wife of the late Max Rosner, also wife of the late Edward Levin and wife of the late Joseph Gable. Devoted mother of Barbara Levin Cohen, of Boynton Beach, FL and Janet Levin Pykon of West Orange, NJ. Dear cousin of Leonard Stark of NYC. Beloved grandmother and great-grandmother. Services were held.

title: Adults' Bus Tour Searches for School Bond Votes, and Pizza
description: As the yellow school bus pulled away from the curb and headed off on a field trip yesterday morning, the passengers immediately stirred in their green vinyl seats.

title: Knicks Maintain That All Is Well
description: The Knicks are about to find out if they have attitude on call, and desire ready to pull out from behind their backs.

title: Trial Ordered in Italian Tobacco-Tax Case
description: An Italian judge today ordered the head of the Philip Morris Companies' European operations and 10 officials of an Italian company that Philip Morris does business with to stand trial on charges that they illegally evaded corporate taxes.

title: Netanyahu Comes Under Fire At New Parliament Session
description: The rancorous state of Israeli politics burst back into public view tonight as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu came under a renewed barrage of criticism at the opening of Parliament's winter term, which turned into a bitter shouting match.

title: For Many Market Players, Panic Is for the Other Guy
description: When the great bull market began to teeter yesterday, Esther Curtis was out shopping for groceries.

title: Achilles Track Club Presents Its Own Mosaic
description: Spectators think of them as wheelchair runners. But only about 100 of the 260 disabled athletes scheduled to compete in the New York City Marathon next week use those sleek, racing wheelchairs.

title: PEOPLES HERITAGE TO ACQUIRE CFX IN STOCK DEAL
description: Peoples Heritage Financial Group Inc. of Portland, Me., agreed yesterday to buy the CFX Corporation for $703 million in stock, creating New England's fourth-largest bank. Shareholders of CFX, which is based in Keene, N.H., will receive 0.667 share of Peoples for each CFX share. Based on the closing price of Peoples' stock on Friday, that values CFX at $28.76 a share. CFX's stock was one of the rare gainers yesterday, rising $1.9375, to $24.625. Peoples fell $4 a share, to $39.125. Peoples will issue 16 million shares of stock in connection with the merger, which will be accounted for as a pooling of interest. Peoples Heritage has $6.5 billion in assets, and CFX has $2.8 billion.

title: A New Standard to Govern PC's With Multiple Chips
description: A group of developers of the fastest hardware and software for scientific and engineering computing will announce a new technical standard, perhaps as early as Tuesday, that is intended to make it easier for complex programs to operate on different types of computers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZ, RICHARD E.
description: METZ-Richard E. On October 26, 1997, in New York, age 85. Beloved husband of Gurdon (Howells), dear brother of Eugene and devoted grandfather of Vittorio Cottafavi. Services to be at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, 11 A.M., Friday, October 31. Please, no flowers.

title: Satellite Broadcasters Face Higher Programming Fees
description: The rates that satellite broadcast companies pay to transmit network television signals will quadruple under a United States Copyright Office ruling issued today.

title: The Pianist and Beethoven Refine a Workaday Waltz
description: Yes, Ignat Solzhenitsyn is the son of the Russian author Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, but it seems likely that this 23-year-old pianist will become well-enough known on his own merits that the family identification will become superfluous. He has performed several times in New York City in recent years, both as an accompanist (with the violinist Pamela Frank) and as a concerto soloist.

title: PRI AUTOMATION TO PAY $172 MILLION FOR EQUIPE
description: PRI Automation Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the closely held Equipe Technologies Inc. for $172 million, adding robots to its line of semiconductor equipment. PRI will issue 4.4 million shares, valued at $161.7 million based on Friday's closing price, for Equipe. PRI will pay an additional $10.3 million to cover options held by Equipe employees. PRI, based in Billerica, Mass., makes hardware and software used to automate the transfer of silicon wafers between steps in the chip-making process. Equipe, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., makes robots used to handle the wafers within those individual steps. PRI's stock fell $3.25 a share, to $33.50.

title: Jets Share A.F.C. East Lead
description: The Jets moved into a three-way tie for first place in the A.F.C. East when the New England Patriots and the Miami Dolphins lost their games last night.

title: Metro Business; Office Merger Raises Trade Tower Rentals
description: Aon Risk Services, an insurance brokerage and risk-management consulting company whose parent company has been growing rapidly in recent years, will consolidate its New York offices with those of two of its recent acquisitions in 396,000 square feet at 2 World Trade Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUSCH, HERMANN G.
description: RUSCH-Hermann G. The Members and Officers of the Societe Culinaire Philanthropique deeply mourn the passing of their beloved, Honorary President and Honorary Chairman of the Salon of Culinary Art of New York in Lewisburg, W. Va. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Jean-Pierre Stoehr, President

title: By Design; A Revolution in Pants
description: Not so long ago, a good blazer and blue jeans could take you almost anywhere. But denim jeans are no longer cool. They've been replaced by straight-leg sleek black leather pants that fit flat across the front. The choices range from Ralph Lauren's $1,695 beauties at Neiman Marcus to Sienna Studio's $242 version at Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: Officials Link Man to 11 Teen-Agers With H.I.V.
description: A 20-year-old man with H.I.V. has apparently infected at least 11 teen-age girls in western New York with the virus that causes AIDS, officials said yesterday, adding that the man -- or his sex partners -- may have infected up to 50 other people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAEFFER, ROSE
description: SCHAEFFER-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Loving mother, grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: Westinghouse Moves to Sell Its Power-Generation Units
description: The Westinghouse Corporation is in talks to sell its power-generation units, its last industrial manufacturing businesses, people associated with the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Gem Twist, U.S. Star, To Take His Final Bows
description: Because he hated his heels to touch the fences he was bred to scale, he gained a reputation as a perfectionist who did not suffer human fools lightly, no small feat for a mere horse.

title: Horror and Pain, but Oddly, Some Relief
description: Many emotions swept over Wall Street yesterday: horror, panic, pain. But for a lot of market gurus, the strongest feeling was of relief.

title: Corrections
description: The Theater Guide listing in Weekend on Friday omitted credit for a picture of Steve Mellor and Welker White in the play ''Fnu Lnu,'' at SoHo Repertory Theater. The photographer was Tom Brazil.

title: Helio Beltrao, 81, Official In Brazil Who Cut Red Tape
description: Helio Beltrao, who served in the cabinets of three governments during Brazil's 21-year military dictatorship, died on Sunday morning here. He was 81 years old.

title: Sports of The Times; At Its Best, Baseball Is the Best
description: FOR all the irritants of the industry, for all the overpaid players and all the bottom-line owners and all the arrogant agents, at its best the game of baseball is still the best game.

title: Bulk Discount Approved For Buses and Subways
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority gave final approval yesterday to a bulk discount that will effectively cut the bus and subway fare to $1.36, from $1.50, in January.

title: Male Chromosome Is Not a Genetic Wasteland, After All
description: WHY the Y chromosome? The question can now be answered, after the discovery of almost all of its genes and the emergence of a pattern that explains how the Y chromosome evolved.

title: Romance Must Have Its Fling
description: Many a marriage therapist has prescribed a little romance as the quickest route to rekindling a relationship, and style doctors could not have ordered a better fix for fashion, which many women have held at arm's length for several seasons. The kind of mellifluous clothes that wended their way down European runways the last three weeks are already reigniting women's interest and designers' innovation. For the first time in almost five years, there is a clear and exaggerated shift away from the emotional barrenness of unadorned style.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Jazz CD's; Little Albums, Big Sounds
description: For whatever reason, the following four albums aren't destined to receive the sort of push that greets bigger stars. Some give the pleasure of eccentricity, some of a genre well played; they are all beyond the average, and deserve better.

description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Health; When Eyes Have That Sandpaper Grit Feeling
description: TEARS may seem like simple, salty little drops produced naturally in great profusion when provoked by intense emotion or an irritant in the eye. But tears are neither simple nor simply produced. And for more than 10 million Americans who suffer from dry eye syndrome, tear production is so inadequate or the tears evaporate so quickly that their eyes constantly feel gritty and irritated, as if scratched by sand with every blink.

title: In Mourning, Traditions Mingle; Cultural Exchange in the 'Neighborhoods of the Dead'
description: In a darkened funeral parlor in Chinatown, heavy with the scent of incense and chrysanthemums, an Italian brass band plays ''My Jesus I Love Thee'' at a Buddhist service as family members, illuminated by flickering candles, bow ceremoniously to the deceased, an elderly man lying in an open coffin.

title: Muynak Journal; Only Water, Maybe, but It Was a People's Lifeblood
description: The life of Kubeisin Ikmitulayev has been just long enough for him to watch the death of one of the world's largest inland seas.

title: Science in the Rough: Bears, Winter Dark and Bitter Winds
description: ONE blast on the Des Groseilliers' powerful horn announces meal time and brings scientists in from the surrounding ice camp for a tasty French Canadian meal. But five short blasts warn that a polar bear has been sighted from the icebreaker's bridge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNES, ARTHUR HART
description: BARNES-Arthur Hart. Age 63, of Ithaca, N.Y. Formerly of Garden City, N.Y. Died unexpectedly on October 25, 1997. Graduated Downers Grove (IL) High School '52, Cornell University College of Arts and Sciences '56, School of Law '60, NYU Advanced Degree in Tax Law. Served as President, Board Member, and Treasurer of Cornell Club of Long Island. Board of Directors, Legal Aid Society of Nassau County. Member, MineolaGarden City Rotary Club for 20 years. Survived by wife Joan, mother Rosemary, brothers Frederick and Peter, and children Arthur, Christopher, and Amanda. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated to the Cornell University Office of Student Aid Development, 55 Brown Road, Ithaca, NY 14850. Visitation Wednesday 10/29/ 97, 9:00 AM to 10:30 AM at The Williams Funeral Home, 99 Newtown Lane, East Hampton, N.Y. Funeral Wednesday at 11 A.M., Most Holy Trinity RC Church. Interment to follow in the Parish Cemetery.

description: It could be an Abbott and Costello routine:

description: STRAUSS-Paul O. On October 26, 1997. Beloved husband of Ursula (Teddy). Dear brother of Martin and his wife Barbara. Dear brother-in-law of Greta Leven. Devoted uncle of Denise and Mark Straus, Ronald and Andrew Leven and Sandra Fishman. Great uncle of Jamie, Scott, Erica, Matthew and Alex. His love, intelligence, wit and loyalty will be sorely missed by his family and many friends. Services are on Tuesday at 10 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIVINGSTON, JAMES BACHER
description: LIVINGSTON-James Bacher. Artist, musician, filmmaker and remarkable friend, Jamie died of cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital on Saturday, October 25, 1997, his forty-first birthday. In addition to countless friends, films, images, hand-made instruments, tchochtkas, circus memorabilia and comic books, Jamie leaves behind his most inspired life-work: 6572 Polaroid ''Photos of the Day'', representing every day of the last 18-1/2 years. A memorial to celebrate Jamie's extroadinary spirit, life and work will be announced at a later date. Precious Jamie, we love you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, IDA KALLET
description: CANTOR-Ida Kallet. Age 94. Ida was the most adored person we have ever known. Loved and admired for her gentle disposition and good heart. She went through life helping others with her wise advice and kind smile. She thought of others first and last. Ida, grandma, mother, mother by marriage, we will miss you more than words can possibly express. So dearly loved. So deeply mourned, Ida Kallet Cantor died peacefully at her home, surrounded by her family, on October 26, 1997. Ida was born in New York City, January 23, 1903, and married Louis Harry Cantor (her pharmacist) in 1927. She leaves an empty space forever in the hearts of her grandchildren, Jessica and Douglas, and son by marriage, Ivan. Mommy, I miss you already. Nina.

title: On My Mind; Clinton's Nuclear Deception
description: Craftily, ever so craftily, President Clinton is deceiving the American public about a critical danger to world security: China's international sales of the materiel and technology of nuclear warfare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, CHARLOTTE
description: FEINBERG-Charlotte. Age 82. Died October 26 after suffering from Alzheimer's Disease for several years. She lived for many years in Des Moines, Chicago, New York City and Florida. She is survived by her devoted husband Milton, loving daughters Susan Farber Ganz and Linda Graev and three grandchildren Adam Graev, Nicole Graev and Samantha Ganz Panzier. Her love and caring will always be missed. She has found the peace she deserved. Funeral services will be held at 10AM Tuesday at Lillis Funeral Home, 58 Bridge Street, New Milford, CT.

title: Historic Halt On Wall St. As Market Loses 7.2% : Dow's 554-Point Plunge Suspends U.S. Trading;Hong Kong Sell-Off Alarms Markets Worldwide
description: NEW YORK  U.S. stock trading was halted twice Monday after the Dow Jones industrial average recorded its largest point loss ever as the collapse in Asian equity markets spread fear to investors around the world.
