description: To the Editor:

title: Like It or Not, Marlins Found the Way to Win
description: No one should feel sorry for the Cleveland Indians, who have guaranteed they will not win another World Series for at least an even half century. A year from now, whether or not the Indians play in the World Series again, they can observe the 50th anniversary of their last Series championship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, BERNARD
description: SCHWARTZ-Bernard. Congregation Kneseth Israel, Far Rockaway, NY, mourns with heartfelt sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, beloved husband of Ruth Schwartz, and beloved brother of our member, Addie Zucker. Tzvi Flaum, Rabbi Ralph Pelcovitz, Rabbi Emeritus Sheldon Steinmetz, President

title: JACOR BUYING 17 RADIO STATIONS FOR $620 MILLION
description: Jacor Communications Inc. of Covington, Ky., said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company's 17 radio stations for $620 million, expanding the broadcaster into new markets. Jacor, the nation's third-largest radio broadcaster, is getting stations in eight markets, five of which are new, including Dallas, Houston and Minneapolis. The agreement comes a few weeks after Nationwide Mutual, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, said it planned to sell the stations to focus on its insurance and financial services businesses. Jacor has been a leading buyer of stations the last year to take advantage of looser limits on the number of stations a company can own in individual markets. Jacor owns, operates or represents 172 stations in 36 markets, excluding the latest purchase agreement.

title: The Plunging Dow
description: There are three salient facts to keep in mind before sizing up yesterday's scary 554-point drop of the Dow Jones industrial stock average. Its drop of 7 percent was much smaller than the 22 percent, 508-point drop on Oct. 19, 1987. The economy can absorb shocks better today than 10 years ago, because inflation is lower, employment is higher and, most important, banks are financially sturdier. The Federal Reserve Board, under its current chairman, Alan Greenspan, reacted correctly in 1987 to keep the economy rolling on an even keel, and will have to do so again today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Fire Guts a Strip Mall
description: A fire gutted an aging strip mall in Pompton Lakes yesterday, after spreading easily from one store to the next because the stores lacked fire walls between them, The Associated Press reported. The blaze began shortly after 7 A.M. in the Acme grocery store that anchors the Klugtown Shopping Mall. Nine firefighters suffered minor injuries, the A.P. reported. The cause was under investigation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Kimberly-Clark Initiates a Review
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said yesterday that it had placed in review its worldwide feminine hygiene products account, with billings estimated at $25 million to $30 million. In the United States, the account, for products like Kotex and New Freedom, has been handled by the Chicago and New York offices of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group.

title: Ankle Injury May Sideline Van Horn Only 2-3 Weeks
description: A second look at the magnetic resonance imaging test of Keith Van Horn's lower right leg provided the Nets with their first real good news in some time in what has been an injury-filled preseason.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about plans to move the Public Theater's revival of ''On the Town'' to Broadway in April misspelled the surname of a lawyer for the company. He is John Breglio, not Bralio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, MORRIS
description: SCHNEIDER-Morris. On October 27, 1997. Beloved husband of Miriam. Devoted father of Elias Stephen Schneider and Carol S. Fotenos. Brother of Bill and Irving Schneider. Brother-in-law to Louis Rudnick, father-in-law of James Frank Fotenos, grandfather to Anthony Frank Fotenos, Jill and Bill Sussman, Gigi and Anthony Botti, David and Hanna Diamond. Survived by six great-grandchildren, many nieces and nephews, fond neighbors and good friends. Services on Tuesday, at 1:30 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Christmas Fades As Retail's Rescuer; Stores Look to Rest of Year As December Sales Flatten
description: For weeks, retail executives have been making grand predictions about the imminent holiday. It is going to be smashing, they say, citing all the new toys, themed baby clothes, home decorations and eager shoppers dying to buy it all.

title: Britain Delays Early Entry Into the Euro
description: Seeking to end weeks of damaging political and financial uncertainties, Prime Minister Tony Blair's Government today ruled out early British entry into a European single currency but said that signing up for monetary union is a long-range ambition.

title: Baseball's Free-Market Champs
description: There was something unsettling about this year's World Series, and it arises from the nagging thought that the Florida Marlins, who seemed to come from nowhere to win the championship in a riveting seventh game, may dissolve as quickly as they were put together.

title: Washington Tries to Reassure Investors After Plunge: A Muted Response Is Coordinated by Officials
description: The Clinton Administration sought today to reassure investors after the stock market's plunge, but shied away from addressing the challenges that economic policy makers will face if the market decline continues.

title: Labor Embarrassment
description: At a time when labor's effort to improve its image seemed to paying off with organizing victories, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has been embarrassed by the corruption charges against the teamsters and other unions. While the episodes may be pale in comparison to the abuses of the past, many labor leaders say it will hurt them.

title: No More Tax Deductions; Marketing the I.R.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: When (and Why) Dad Has the Babies
description: MANY working mothers will attest to this: When a woman does the laundry and cooking, she gets clean clothes and food on the table. When a man does the housework, he gets a standing ovation. A good mother is natural, a good father divine.

title: Saving the Salt Flats to Make Utah Safe for Drag Racers
description: FROM the ground, this salty desert seems to stretch in an endless white plain to the foot of a sterile mountain range off in the haze. Historically, the surface has been so smooth, so barren and so hard that marbles roll almost as if on a table top, and the jet-powered cars that race back and forth can burn rubber.

title: Don't Offer Libya Pan Am 103 Deal
description: To the Editor:

title: More Than 30,000 Reasons to Watch
description: Correction Appended

title: Teachers Strike in Ontario, Closing Thousands of Schools
description: Most of the 126,000 public and Catholic school teachers in Ontario went on strike today in the largest teachers' strike ever in North America.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Casino Taxes to Go to Clinic
description: Taxes collected from casinos have long been used to pay for parks, housing and highway projects in and around Atlantic City. But for the first time, state officials said, casino taxes will be used to help finance the cost of a major health care center.

title: Being So Close to a Title Makes the Indians Feel Worse
description: The Cleveland Indians were about one hour into their off season during the wee hours this morning, and the sting of their 3-2 setback in Game 7 of the World Series was still pricking them. The ache will surely linger for a very long time, especially because of the vexing way they lost following Tony Fernandez's inexplicable error in the 11th inning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOHMAN, DR. HERMAN
description: LOHMAN-Dr. Herman. Of West Orange, NJ, on Sunday, October 26, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Lillian (nee Brody). Devoted father of Mrs. Jane (John) Jellinek and Mrs. Amy (Dr. William) Lieberman. Beloved grandfather of Jill, James, Jordan and Kate. Dear brother of Max and the late Judge Samuel, Nate and George. Funeral service promptly at 12 noon, on Tuesday, in Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Avenue, Short Hills, N.J. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the St. Barnabas Development Foundation, Old Short Hills Road, Livingston, N.J. 07039. The family will receive visitors at the temple on Tuesday beginning at 11:15 AM.

title: Science Watch; Succumbing to 'Seinfeld'
description: LAUGHTER may not always be the best medicine. According to a brief letter in Catheterization and Cardiovascular Diagnosis, a journal not widely known for its sense of humor, a 62-year-old man fainted at least three times while watching ''Seinfeld.''

title: No Halloween Shutdown For Schools, Crew Says
description: The rumors were circulating throughout several New York City high schools yesterday: because of recent reports of a rise in gang activity in the city's public schools, school would be canceled or let out early on Halloween.

title: 4 L.I. Catholic Hospitals Unite for Efficiency
description: Bishop John R. McGann, the head of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre, has decided to unify four Long Island acute-care hospitals into a single system with the aim of making them more efficient while maintaining their commitment to the poor.

title: Hardee's Account Is Placed in Review
description: Hardee's Food Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had placed in review the creative portion of its account, with billings estimated at $80 million. Team One Advertising in El Segundo, Calif., part of Cordiant P.L.C., temporarily picked up those duties last week when Leonard Pearlstein joined that agency as co-chairman and chief executive and took the Hardee's assignment with him from Pearlstein Group in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESTER, ROBERTA GELLER
description: HESTER-Roberta Geller. On October 26, 1997, of Coconut Creek, FL. Beloved wife of Joseph. Devoted daughter of the late Eleanor and Milton. Loving sister of Emily, Alan, Diane and Ashley. Loving aunt of Ben, Adam and Talia. Services and interment were conducted on October 27. Roberta will be sorely missed. Contributions to: Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

title: Crisis Over Conversions to Judaism Flares Anew in Israel
description: Leaders of the Conservative and Reform movements of Judaism in Israel said today that they would press ahead with legal action, renewing a confrontation with the Israeli Orthodox rabbinate over the much-debated issue of who is a Jew under religious law.

title: 2 Former Federal Officials Acquitted in Drug Cartel Case
description: A Federal jury today acquitted a former Justice Department official and a former Federal prosecutor of a racketeering charge and deadlocked on four other drug-related charges arising from the men's roles as lawyers for leaders of a Colombian drug cartel.

title: Washington Tries to Reassure Investors After Plunge: Price Gyrations Imperil Mergers Based on Stocks
description: Much of the recent rush among companies to merge, acquire and combine has been fueled by the enormous buying power of stock as the overall market soared. Companies whose names were barely recognizable a few months ago -- like Worldcom Inc. and Starwood Lodging Trust -- have been able to bid billions of dollars to buy huge corporations like MCI Communications and ITT.

title: Q&A
description: Salt-Loving Plants

title: Sharks Win It in Last Minute
description: For the third time in three games, the Islanders surrendered the first goal of the game tonight. And again they were made to pay.

title: Prices of Heating Fuels Soar After Season's First Big Storm
description: Natural gas futures surged to a 10-month high and heating oil also rose on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as an unusual autumn snowstorm in the central United States lifted demand for heating fuels.

title: Oklahoma Case Highlights How Economic Burden of Jury Duty Affects Panel's Makeup
description: An auto mechanic told Judge Richard P. Matsch of Federal District Court here that he did not think he could make ends meet if he was chosen to sit on the jury for the second Oklahoma City bombing trial.

title: A Not-So-Innocent Tax Exemption
description: Last week, the House of Representatives took time out from beating up the Internal Revenue Service to approve a fresh tax loophole. The proposal would authorize households to use up to $2,500 of after-tax money to establish ''school'' accounts, whose earnings would be tax free if used for certain education-related purposes.

title: Microsoft Monopoly
description: To the Editor:

title: The Court Would Have Been Pleased
description: AS timing would have it, the weekend brought a lawyers' seminar in Brooklyn on jury selection and a memorial service in Manhattan for Judge Harold J. Rothwax, who had a lot to say about juries, not much of it good.

title: MEDICARE NOMINEE IS CAUGHT IN FIGHT OVER RULE ON FEES
description: Senate Republicans are holding up action on President Clinton's nominee to run the Medicare program in an effort to force Mr. Clinton to let doctors sign private contracts with affluent elderly patients willing to pay more than the fees set by Medicare.

title: INSIDE
description: Touring in a school bus. It must be election time.

title: Try a Global Warming Compromise
description: To the Editor:

title: High School Running Stars Get the Jump On Finish Line
description: For the first time, two of the most powerful forces in running -- the New York Road Runners Club and the high school track and cross-country community -- have joined forces to bridge the generation gap. As a result, some of the top teen-age distance runners in the region will have their day in the sun as a prelude to Sunday's New York City Marathon.

title: N.J. Insurance Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: For Jews, Rift Widens

title: U.S. Business Ties to China Are Far Richer Than Any Diplomatic Links
description: Early this summer, the president of Intel Corporation, Craig Barrett, went to see the former mechanical engineer who now runs China, Jiang Zemin.

title: Microsoft Monopoly
description: To the Editor:

title: East for 2002
description: Officials said yesterday that the 2002 Goodwill Games would be in Asia or Oceania, ending a partnership that has kept the games in the United States or Russia since they started in 1986.

title: An Art Lover Who Awakened a Generation
description: Earl A. Powell 3d, director of the National Gallery of Art in Washington, was there. Glenn D. Lowry, director of the Museum of Modern Art in New York, was there. James N. Wood, director of the Art Institute of Chicago, was there. And so were the heads of many more of the nation's art museums, as well as a few dozen assorted curators and museum trustees, art history professors and gallery owners, all graduates of Williams College and all gathered for a gala evening at the school's faculty club.

title: Special Today: A Marathon Preview
description: A guide to the New York City marathon. What to eat, what to wear and where to watch. Section G.

title: Oxford Says It Will Shield Patients
description: Oxford Health Plans said that its financial problems, which sent its stock price into a tailspin yesterday, would not be felt by consumers.

title: 'Peer Gynt,' With Sound and Without
description: ''Peer Gynt,'' presented by the National Theater of the Deaf, tells its well-known tale in an original fusion of sign language, voice and physical movement. The basic Ibsen text, translated and adapted with a dose of American slang by J. Ranelli, is discernible, but high stylization is paramount.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GATES, ANDREW
description: GATES-Andrew. Of Teaneck, NJ. Beloved husband of Gloria. Devoted father of Susan Chaikin, and Michael Gates, and the late Peter. Dear brother of Robert Goldman, Shirley Greenwald, and Belle Shapiro. Loving grandfather of six. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', corner of Passaic and Park Sts., Hackensack, N.J., today at 1 PM. Contributions Holy Name Hosp., Hemo-Dialysis Unit appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, GEORGE
description: GORDON-George. Beloved husband of Trudy; loving father of Adam and Donna, Alan and Fuji; cherished grandfather of Rachel and Michael; loving brother of the late Moe, Henry, Bernard, Leon and Howard; devoted uncle of Ned, Alan, Rosylan, Barbara, Natalie, Richard and the late Steven and Andrew. Services today 12 noon at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue (Avenue J), Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANDALL, LOUISE (HARMAN)
description: RANDALL-Louise (Harman), October 25, 1997, in Smithfield, RI. Wife of the late Henry T. Randall, MD. A memorial gathering will be held at Monahan-Kelly DrabbleSherman Funeral Home, 230 Waterman Street, Providence, RI, on Sunday at noon. In place of flowers a contribution may be sent to Family Service, Inc., 55 Hope St., Providence, R.I. 02906.

title: Flaunting a Breast Stroke at Waikiki
description: President Jiang Zemin of China surprised many afternoon strollers on Waikiki Beach by turning up unexpectedly for a swim late Sunday afternoon.

title: Series of New Corruption Cases Hampers Labor's Efforts to Improve Its Tainted Image
description: The wave of corruption charges involving the teamsters and other unions has badly embarrassed the labor movement just as John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, was boasting that efforts to improve labor's image were finally paying off with some major organizing victories.

title: In Their Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Mayor Gets Credit for Safer City, but Wider Trends Play a Role
description: Not long after taking office, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani cautioned New Yorkers not to judge his Police Department solely by the crime statistics it produced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YORKOWITZ, ISAAC
description: YORKOWITZ-Isaac. On October 24, 1997. Interment was held on October 26. Beloved companion of Rita Wernick and dearly loved by all of her family. Warm, caring and a good friend to so many. Loving brother of Geri Singerman and Millie York. A wonderful uncle to all of his nieces and nephews. Everyone who knew him will miss him. Remembrances may be sent to Temple Beth Abraham, Tarrytown, New York 10591. Family sitting shiva at Singerman home in NYC through October 30.

title: SHOLODGE AND HOSPITALITY PROPERTIES IN SALE-LEASE DEAL
description: Sholodge Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 14 Sumner Suites hotels to Hospitality Properties Trust for $140 million. Sholodge, based in Gallatin, Tenn., owns and franchises Shoney's Inns, a no-frills chain. It also owns Sumner Suites, a medium-priced chain that opened its first sites in 1995. Hospitality Properties Trust of Newton, Mass., is a real estate investment trust. Under the agreement, Sholodge will lease back the 14 hotels from Hospitality Properties for an initial term of 10 years. The agreement includes five 10-year renewal options. Hospitality also could make additional investments of $150 million in Sumner Suites hotels, the companies said.

title: Call a Constitutional Convention
description: Next Tuesday, New York voters will have a once-in-a-generation opportunity to take control of their own political future by voting for a state constitutional convention. The system under which the convention would be organized is far from perfect. But we urge a ''yes'' vote because in New York politics the chances for reform are so rare, the price of inaction is so great and the status quo is so wretched. Despite New York's wealth and rich political heritage, its state government is a paralytic wreck. The constitutional convention offers voters a way out.

title: Observer; Of Paula, Pols and The Queen
description: Have sociologists lately noted the growing lust for insincerity that is now rampant in the English-speaking world? We are at this very moment, all over the United States, awash in political advertising, those floods of insincerity that pass for political discourse in America.

title: Training Tips And Psych Jobs
description: The 1997 New York City Marathon is my midlife crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHENKER, LUCILLE
description: SCHENKER-Lucille. On October 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Hyman. Devoted mother of Susan and Martin. Dear mother-in-law of James Monaco and Sonja. Loving grandmother of Andrew, Charles, Margaret, Cathy and Henry. Services Tuesday, 11 A.M., at Village Temple, 33 East 12th Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory may be made to P.S. 41, 116 West 11th Street, New York City, 10011.

title: J. Alfred Guest, Alumni Secretary, 86
description: J. Alfred Guest, who developed many programs in his 25 years as alumni secretary of Amherst College and was active in alumni affairs nationally, died on Oct. 6 at Baystate Medical Center in Springfield, Mass. He was 86 and lived in Amherst and Martha's Vineyard.

title: World Series Sellout; Jumble of Jargon
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZASLOFSKY, RUTH
description: ZASLOFSKY-Ruth. On Friday, October 24, 1997. Wife of the late Samuel. Mother of Andy, Judy and Mary. Adoring grandmother of Samara. Friend, teacher, student, lover of life, she will be greatly missed. Memorial on November 2, 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNGLASS, EDWARD N.
description: BRENNGLASS-Edward N. The Officers, Board of Trustees and Staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) deeply mourn the passing of our devoted Board member, who provided outstanding leadership in guiding JDC's rescue operations; relief efforts to hundreds of thousands in need; and the reconstruction of Jewish life in former Communist countries. We will all deeply miss this extraordinary man and we extend condolences to his bereaved family. Jonathan W. Kolker, President Ambassador Milton A. Wolf, Chairman of the Board Michael Schneider, Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEENEY, WILLIAM J. III, M.D.
description: SWEENEY-William J. III, M.D. The boards, faculty and staff of The New York Hospital and Cornell University Medical College mourn the passing of their beloved and esteemed colleague Dr. William J. Sweeney III. A dedicated physician and researcher, Dr. Sweeney was, at the time of his death, Clinical Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at Cornell University Medical College and Attending Obstetrician and Gynecologist at The New York Hospital. Dr. Sweeney received his medical degree from Cornell in 1949 and was a generous supporter of the Cornell University Medical College Alumni Fund. He authored over 50 publications and was recognized for his extensive work in gynecological cancer. Dr. Sweeney's commitment and contributions greatly advanced the field of obstetrics and gynecology. He was much loved and will be greatly missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to the Sweeney family. John T. McGillicuddy Chairman, Board of Governors The New York Hospital David B. Skinner, M.D. President and CEO The New York Hospital Sanford I. Weill Chairman, Board of Overseers Cornell University Medical College Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D. Stephen and Suzanne Weiss Dean Cornell University Medical College William J. Ledger, M.D. Chairman Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology The New York Hospital

title: Market Place; Two regional Bells take different paths to growth
description: IN moves that highlight the increasingly divergent strategies of the regional Bell companies amid exploding demand for telecommunications services, U S West Inc. announced a plan yesterday to split into separate telephone and cable television companies, while the Ameritech Corporation said it had agreed to buy control of a European telephone carrier for more than $3 billion.

title: Somewhere to Run, Somewhere to Buy
description: In 1978, the organizers of the New York City Marathon had an idea. The runners had to go to the Huntington Hartford Museum at Columbus Circle to pick up their race numbers, so why not have a few stands there so they could buy running shoes and accessories? Five companies bought booths, and the marathon expo was born. It has been held every year since and attracts runners and their families and outsiders who walk in to peruse and perhaps buy.

title: Accusations Are False, Laborers' Leader Says
description: Arthur A. Coia, president of the Laborers' International Union of North America, notified his union's executive board yesterday that the laborers' in-house prosecutor had decided to bring charges against him, but he said he was innocent of all accusations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIENER, RUTH
description: DIENER-Ruth. Eighty-four of Hollywood, FL., passed away October 26, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Maurice Diener; loving mother of Mark Diener and Stephen Diener; cherished grandmother of Hollis, Sharon, James and Scott. Graveside services Wednesday, October 29, 11 AM at King Solomon, Clifton, NJ. For information, call Levitt Weinstein 800-274-2566.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, ROSE E.
description: REISS-Rose E. On October 27, 1997. Beloved wife of Alfred. Dear mother of Robert Reiss and Adrienne McCormick and mother-inlaw of Brian McCormick. Adored grandmother of Carly Jaye McCormick. Sister of Helen Nesson. Services Wednesday, 10 A.M., at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Long Island.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the popularity of New York-based television shows in cities like Boise, Idaho, around the country misstated the location of Minot. It is in North Dakota, not South Dakota.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICE, JAMES P.
description: RICE-James P. Of Chicago, IL. Beloved husband of the late Paula (nee Yasgour). Loving father of William ''Bill'' (Myrna Sislen) and Michael (Jane). Dear grandfather of Joel and Nathan. Fond brother of the late Elizabeth (David) Carson. Services Tuesday, 1:30 PM, at Anshe Emet Synagogue, 3760 North Pine Grove Avenue, Chicago. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to James and Paula Rice Immigrant and Refugee Fund, C/O JUF, 1 South Franklin Street, Chicago, IL 60606. For information, Piser Chapel, 773-561-4740.

title: Cyberspace and You: The Golden Rules of Order
description: RELEASE 2.0

title: KPMG Says S.E.C. Will Bring Charges
description: KPMG Peat Marwick said today that it would be charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission with failing to insure its independence from Porta Systems Inc. when auditing the company in 1995.

title: New Technique Offers Promise in Treating Parkinson's Disease
description: AFTER five years of worsening symptoms of Parkinson's disease, Nicole Stedman, a 58-year-old piano teacher in Palo Alto, Calif., was rapidly losing mobility.

title: Learning to Waffle on Tibet's Precipice
description: The news that some movie actors are into Buddhism may not cause you to sign up, but you don't have to live in Southern California to subscribe to Hollywood's current interest in China and Tibet. As Orville Schell, a veteran China watcher, reports on ''Dreams of Tibet,'' Western movies have become the most powerful way to bring Chinese repression, particularly with regard to Tibet, to the world's attention.

title: In Miami, a Romance, However Brief, With the Marlins
description: The home of the new World Series champions woke up today giddy from celebrations that did not even begin until the early morning hours, its euphoria tempered neither by the workday nor the uncertainty over the possible sale of its winning team.

title: Article on His Drinking Stirs Ex-Mayor's Wrath
description: It used to be that this was the kind of town where all good pols were expected to take a few drinks, mayhap even more than a few, with the boys. From here on in, though, all good pols will most likely be looking over their shoulders as they bend their elbows.

title: Patterns
description: New Windows on Fashion

title: Panthers Making Progress
description: Pittsburgh will have much to say about which team takes the Big East championship. They will play the league leaders -- Syracuse, Virginia Tech and West Virginia -- after playing Boston College on Saturday.

title: Restraint, Eloquence and Some Insight From NBC
description: A moment of prayer now for any West Coast NBC executive who would have preferred showing ''Men Behaving Badly'' (in which Jamie dated a basketball player) and ''Jenny'' (in which Jenny flirted with a bridegroom) to Game 7 of the World Series on Sunday night. Thank you for your silence. Now, to our review.

title: Horse of a Different Color, Literally
description: She is untested as a race horse and comes from a line of also-rans, but Patchen Beauty's place in history is secure.

title: Tale of 2 Colombias: Rebels Disrupt Vote
description: The results of regional elections read tonight like the X-ray of a fractured country, and exposed the declining health of the Government's control over rural areas threatened by Marxist rebels.

title: Recalling the Musical Matriarchs Who Gave Birth to the Blues
description: All-women anthologies of any sort tend to make some people think: ''Oh, yes, women's studies. I don't really have to pay any attention unless I happen to have a special interest in the subject.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Schools Under Giuliani: Raging at System, Then Nurturing It
description: When it comes to New York City's public schools, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's term can be divided into two parts.

title: G.O.P. and Democrats Differ on Implications of the Plunge
description: Republican leaders in New Jersey, New York State and New York City, where G.O.P. administrations have benefited handsomely from the bull market in recent years, sought to reassure constituents and voters yesterday that the plunge on Wall Street would not in itself undo budgets, pension funds or tax revenues.

title: Bye Week Gives Giants Time to Ponder Playoffs
description: It was bound to come up in conversation sooner or later. Today, a Giants head coach was asked to discuss his team's chances of qualifying for the National Football League playoffs. Used to be, the playoffs only came up when the Giants were about to be mathematically eliminated from them.

description: CHRISTINE TODD WHITMAN

title: Town Finds AIDS Is No Longer Someone Else's Illness
description: There is an urge to blame it on someone else, or, more precisely, on somewhere else. It's New York City. It's Buffalo. It's Pittsburgh.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOHNSON, NORMAN DUDLEY
description: JOHNSON-Norman Dudley. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 30th, Saint James' Church 875 Madison Ave, NYC at 11AM. Gifts in his memory may be sent to The Episcopal School 35 East 69th Street, NY, NY 10021, the N.Y. Historical Society 170 Central Park West, New York 10024 or The Martha's Vineyard Hospital Oak Bluffs, MA 02557.

title: Hong Kong's Slide Goes Deeper
description: Hong Kong stocks plunged further today, with the benchmark Hang Seng index ending the morning trading session down 1,621.8 points, or 15.45 percent.

title: Arts in America; Marching Off to Glory, Armed With Electric Guitars
description: Lieut. Col. Roger Kaplan is having another of what he calls those ''band madness'' days. The absolute worst, the killer, Colonel Kaplan says, is the Fourth of July. A close second is Veterans Day, just two weeks away on Nov. 11. ''There are more than 250 million Americans,'' he says, ''and every one of them seems to want bands on those days.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINDLE, FLORENCE
description: PRINDLE-Florence. The Board of Trustees, and faculty past and present, of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School note with sorrow the passing of Florence Prindle, teacher of art in the Fieldston Lower School from 1962-1987. Her thoughtful involvement in the life of the school was immense. Children, parents, and colleagues will remember her with deep affection. A memorial service will be held in the Student/Faculty Center of the Fieldston School, November 22 at 2 PM. Ethical Culture Fieldston School

title: Consumers Likely to Keep On Spending Unless . . .
description: Judging by the initial reaction, yesterday's 554-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average, despite all the scary reminders of 1987, seems unlikely to have much impact on people's spending -- as long as stock prices do not plunge much further.

title: MORE ON MARKETS
description: THREAT TO MERGERS -- Many huge merger deals financed by stock are now faced with the possibility of unraveling because of the sharp market drop. Page D1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYLAND, FRANCINE MILES
description: HYLAND-Francine Miles. On October 27, 1997. Beloved wife of Thomas. Devoted mother of Jennifer and Thomas. Dear daughter of Frances Miles. Loving sister of Mary Theresa Jackson, Edward Miles, Michele Dunn and Christine Miles. Reposing at Fairchild Sons, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, New York. Funeral mass Thursday 9:45AM, St. Mary's RC Church, Manhasset. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting on Tuesday 7-9 P.M., and Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTIGLIO, ISABELLE (NEE MAHONEY)
description: COSTIGLIO-Isabelle (nee Mahoney). On October 25, 1997. Beloved wife of Lawrence; devoted mother of Christina Bernard, Peter Costiglio, Eugene Costiglio and Teresa Cantwell; loving mother-in-law of Edward Bernard, Barbara Costiglio and Thomas Cantwell; cherished grandmother of nine. Visitation at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84 St, NYC, Wednesday 11 AM. Interment at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, NY.

title: Clinton Moves to Help Improve Schools That Perform Poorly
description: President Clinton will order the Department of Education to help cities and states find ways to deal with failing schools, using existing programs to improve them or, as a last resort, shutting them down, Administration officials said today.

title: To Compete for a Gold, Street Must Be Patient
description: Picabo Street has skied the Olympic downhill course in Nagano, Japan, but she happened to be riding on her coach's back at the time.

title: Tanker Accident Spills Gasoline and Shuts Road
description: A gasoline tanker overturned on Interstate 280 westbound late last night in this Essex County town, spilling its load, injuring the driver and partially shutting down the highway.

title: STOCKS FALL 554 POINTS, OFF 7%, FORCING SUSPENSION IN TRADING
description: A worldwide plunge in stock prices erased more than 7 percent from the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday and forced the New York Stock Exchange to halt trading. The only other interruptions like this came after the wounding of President Ronald Reagan and the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HESSEL, ALLEN W.
description: HESSEL-Allen W. Died on Oct 26, 1997, of Great Neck, NY. Devoted and loyal husband and best friend of Renee for 36 years. Proud, loving father of Howard (Betheny), and Brian. Grandfather of Morgan. Brother of Joseph. Loved by all who called him brother and friend, and whose lives he touched. Civic-minded, former Mayor of the village of Great Neck. Employed in health industry, devoted supporter of Israel. Memorial service Tuesday 10/28 at Riverside North Chapel, Great Neck, NY. Donations may be made to The U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington, DC.

title: Correction
description: Anthony Lewis's column yesterday misspelled the name of a Federal District Court judge. He is Stewart R. Dalzell, not Balzell.

title: George A. Vicas, 71; Made Documentaries For TV Networks
description: George A. Vicas, a producer and director of television documentaries on politics and culture, died on Saturday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 71.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIENENFELD, TESSIE
description: BIENENFELD-Tessie. October 24, 1997. Loving wife of the late Julius Bienenfeld. Adored mother of Stanley and Evelyn, Audrey and Max Wagner, Marilyn and Jack Roth. Devoted sister of Mildred Needle of Del Ray Beach, Florida. A gracious lady devoted to her children, her 11 grandchildren, 37 great grandchildren and her great great grandson. She will be missed by her nieces and nephews, her extended family, friends, the Jewish organizations she so generously supported and the State of Israel she loved so dearly.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: RON STETSON was standing near the subway token booth at the 59th Street station on Lexington Avenue, beneath Bloomingdale's, when a couple, obviously visitors and obviously lost, went up to the booth to ask directions. The clerk was counting money with Zenlike concentration and ignoring the world.

title: Britain Is No Model On Job Creation
description: To the Editor:

title: Amid Day-After Jitters, Opportunity Beckons
description: Yesterday morning, shortly before the stock exchanges' 9:30 start of trading, Daniel K. Cantor seemed remarkably assured for a man who had lost millions of dollars the previous day.

title: Drug Use by Young Teen-Agers Is Found Up
description: While the popularity of marijuana and other drugs appears to be leveling off among older high school students, more of their younger brothers and sisters are experimenting with illicit drugs, according to the country's largest survey of adolescent drug use.

description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Caviar by the Mother-of-Pearl Spoonful
description: EVERY time I eat caviar I think of M. F. K. Fisher.

description: Church & Dwight, the marketer of Arm & Hammer baking soda products, will move its account in-house, effective on Jan. 1, after 13 years at Partners & Shevack in New York and a predecessor shop, Kornhauser & Calene. Billings were estimated at $18 million to $20 million.

title: Disappearing Fish

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of two performances by the Montreal Symphony with the pianist Martha Argerich misstated the day of the concert shown. It was Saturday, not Friday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Bounce Back In Record Trading Volume

title: INSIDE
description: A preservation group is hoping to use shame to get emergency repairs for Ellis Island.

title: Japan Suspends Daiwa From Bond Dealings
description: The Finance Ministry suspended the Daiwa Securities Company yesterday from bidding and underwriting Japanese Government bonds. The ministry's punishment for the big brokerage house came after four of its officials were arrested yesterday on suspicion of paying about 100 million yen to a reputed racketeer through illegal stock transactions.

title: New HarperCollins Head
description: Jane Friedman, a longtime publishing executive and vice president at Knopf, has been named to head HarperCollins. She was named president and chief executive of HarperCollins by News America Publishing Group, the newly created publishing arm of the News Corporation. Ms. Friedman, whose appointment is effective on Nov. 10, replaces Anthea Disney, who was earlier named to head the News America Publishing Group.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARETT, HELEN GROBIN
description: SARETT-Helen Grobin. On October 18, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Morton R. Sarett. Mother of Allen W. Grobin, Joan Goodman and Gwynneth F. Weiss. Grandmother and great-grandmother. Services private.

title: Hyundai Plans to Build Its Own Steel Mill
description: The Hyundai Group said yesterday that it planned to build a $5.79 billion steel plant in a bid to break the grip on the industry held by the state-run Pohang Iron and Steel Company. Hyundai, South Korea's biggest conglomerate, said it would build the plant, defying Government opposition, to insure low-cost supplies for its own car making, shipbuilding and electronics businesses.

title: Tunnels Get E-Z Pass; Drivers Get Hang of It
description: Drivers at the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels did not take long to catch on to E-Z Pass. During the morning rush yesterday, the first day of electronic fare collection at the tunnels, 32 percent of drivers at the Lincoln and 24 percent at the Holland used the pass, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

title: Am I a Little Tipsy, or Did That Martini Glass Just Grow?
description: THE martini has just been supersized. In one fell swoop, the standard 6-ounce glass has ballooned to 10 ounces at restaurants like Ben Benson's and Smith & Wollensky in Manhattan, where the steaks used to be the biggest thing on the menu. The king of drinks now joins the one-pound muffin, the triple bacon cheeseburger and the Lincoln Town Car as a potent symbol of America the Huge.

title: More on Markets
description: A WEAK LINK -- When Hong Kong stumbles, must Wall Street fall? Page D1.

title: A California Congressman Dies After a Collapse
description: Representative Walter Capps, a freshman Democrat from California, died today after he was apparently stricken by a heart attack, his Congressional office announced this evening.

title: Trail of Arrests, H.I.V. Fears And a Woman's Tale of Love
description: Long after she had her blood drawn for an AIDS test today, Amber Arnold loitered outside the County Health Department clinic here, smoking, shivering and watching a parade of other teen-agers come and go on their terrified errand.

title: Vitamins Alone Aren't Nutrition
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZ, RICHARD E.
description: METZ-Richard E. On October 26, 1997, in New York, age 85. Beloved husband of Gurdon (Howells), dear brother of Eugene and devoted grandfather of Vittorio Cottafavi. Services to be at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, 11 A.M., Friday, October 31. Please, no flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, GEORGE
description: SILVER-George. The American Committee for Shenkar College and Shenkar College, Ramat Gan, Israel mourn the loss of George Silver, beloved father of our Board Member Howard Silver. A devoted Vice-President of the American Committee and dedicated member of the Board of Governors of the college, George Silver established the Mollie Silver Knitting Workshop to enrich Shenkar's educational program. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Howard, Maida and the grandchildren. Steven Boxer, President American Committee Charlotte A. Fainblatt, Exec Dir David Pernick, Chairman Board of Governors Prof Amotz Weinberg, President Shenkar College

title: W. B. Doner, which has long coveted an auto maker's brand account, wins the Mazda review.
description: IN a surprise conclusion to a closely followed automotive review, a dark-horse contender, W. B. Doner & Company, was selected yesterday to handle the Mazda North American Operations account, with billings estimated at $240 million.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Bus Strike Strands Commuters
description: About 7,000 commuters in Morris, Sussex, Somerset and Passaic Counties were stranded at their stops during the morning rush yesterday when employees of Lakeland Bus Lines went on strike.

title: Shakespeare and TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Hong Kong Follows U.S., Staging a Strong Rebound
description: Stocks rebounded early here today on relief after Wall Street's explosive rally on Tuesday.

title: Metro Business; Restaurant Planned For Delmonico Site
description: After months of flirting with nearly every major restaurateur in the city, Time Equities has leased the historic Delmonico's space at 55 Beaver Street in lower Manhattan to the Bice Organization, which runs 3 Tuscan-style restaurants in Manhattan and 26 worldwide.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEROUNY, JANET LITTLE
description: CHEROUNY-Janet Little. 88. Died in Chatham, MA., on October 25. She was the widow of Arthur Stratton Cherouny who died in 1995. She is survived by two sons; Robert S. Cherouny of Round Hill, VA., Richard M. Cherouny of Canton, CT., a daughter, Cynthia C. Yeaw of Chatham, MA., a brother Robert F. Little of Laurel Hollow, NY, eight grandchildren and nine great grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at The Battel Chapel in Norfolk, CT, 10 AM, Nov. 1. Memorial contributions may be made to: Norfolk Public Library, Box 605 Norfolk, CT. 06058.

title: Albert to Discuss Case on Television
description: Marv Albert will discuss his side of the assault case that led to his dismissal by NBC and the MSG Network in televised interviews with Barbara Walters and Larry King, according to several associates of Albert.

title: Volatility Attracts Investors To New Chicago Contracts
description: The plunge and sharp rebound of stock prices in the last two days has not scared individual investors away from the high-stakes world of futures and options trading, officials at the three Chicago exchanges that specialize in such investments said today.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: EVERY time I eat caviar I think of M. F. K. Fisher.

title: Critic's Notebook; Sin City: What Kind of Priest Is This Anyway?
description: For as long as anyone can remember, there have been calls for more religion on television. Not more preachers -- there's a glut of those -- but religion as prime-time entertainment. With 90 percent or so of the nation professing a belief in God, where was He from 8 to 11 P.M.? Suspicions were advanced that a coven of bicoastal agnostics was holding Him hostage off screen.

title: U.S. Bridge Champions Lead by Wide Margin
description: The defending champions in the world bridge team championships seem headed for another Bermuda Bowl final here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPKIN, GEORGE
description: POPKIN-George. The AntiDefamation League mourns the passing of George Popkin, a long time ADL supporter. George was an Honorary Life Member of our National Commission and a leader on our Palm Beach Board. We will greatly miss his counsel and active participation with the League. We extend our heart felt sympathies to his wife Ann and the entire family. Howard P. Berkowitz, National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WILSON, LUCILE MCCAULEY
description: WILSON-Lucile McCauley. October 29, 1995. Remembered by her family.

title: Alexandria Journal; Down Among the Sewage, Cleopatra's Storied City
description: The poet called it a wine-dark sea, but here the Mediterranean is obscured by something less poetic.

title: For Crystal, A Giant of a Man
description: One movie, and he is already a giant in the industry.

title: Ruling Could Return Children to Everett
description: Mets outfielder Carl Everett and his wife, Linda, reached an agreement in Family Court yesterday that could reunite them within a year with their two children, who have been in custody of the city's child welfare agency after the couple were accused of abuse.

title: Matsushita Says Profit Rose 24% in 6 Months
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company said yesterday that its net income rose 24 percent over a year earlier in the first half of its fiscal year, thanks to growth in exports of digital video cameras, mobile telephones and fax machines. Matsushita, the world's largest maker of home electronics goods, said half-year net profit at its parent company rose to 36.7 billion yen ($306 million). That exceeded analysts' predictions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETTINATO, SISTER EMILY
description: PETTINATO-Sister Emily, M.S.C. Missionary Sister of the Sacred Heart of Jesus. Cherished sister of Marie Mussari, Frances Geraci, Helen Falls, Albert, Vincent, Edward, Richard, the late Joseph, Charles and Louise Levite. In repose Mother Cabrini High School, 701 Fort Washington Avenue, NYC. Mass Thurs., 11 AM, Mother Cabrini H.S. (Shrine). For information Raccuglia & Son 718-855-7737.

title: At a Benefit, Every Kind of Step
description: Virtually every dance company nowadays stages a gala benefit for a worthy cause: itself. A broader view came from ''The Next Step,'' the third annual gala presented on Monday night by Career Transition for Dancers, an aptly named organization.

title: Gang-Free School
description: To the Editor:

title: A Way to Tastier Pork: Less Time and More Heat
description: COME fall, my thoughts turn to the richness of pork. This traditional cold-weather meat has a full, warm flavor, and when properly cooked is exceptionally juicy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SARCEVICH, LOUIS
description: SARCEVICH-Louis. On Oct. 27 1997. Beloved husband of Maria. Dear brother of Teresa and Pero. Resposing at Hess-Miller Funeral Home, 64-19 Metropolitan Avenue, Middle Village, NY. Visiting Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 PM and 7-9pm. Burial will be in Yugoslavia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAY, JOHN
description: GRAY-John, M.D. THe New York Medical Group P.C., the Board of Directors and the entire medical and administrative staff mourn the loss of John Gray, M.D. on Tuesday, October 28, 1997. Dr. Gray was affiliated with the New York Medical Group P.C. since October, 1982. He was a member of the Board of Directors until his untimely passing. His numerous friends and admirers within the health care community also join in sympathy with his beloved family. He won the respect and admiration of all those who came within his circle, and will be greatly missed. Moshe Labi, M.D., Medical Director New York Medical Group PC

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FRIENDLY HOTELS P.L.C., Britain, agreed to buy European hotels owned by Choice Hotels International Inc. for more than $26 million in stock and cash.

title: Johnson Again Jousts With Orioles
description: The successful but stormy managerial career of Davey Johnson has produced yet two more tempests.

title: Sports of The Times; An Olympic Mystery: U.S. Hockey Roster
description: A skilled and charismatic hockey team came to town the other day. The players embody the traditional spirit of the Winter Games -- Americans like Lisa Brown-Miller, who gave up a job and a honeymoon to play hockey, and Cammi Granato, who grew up playing with her brothers and male cousins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICE, JAMES P.
description: RICE-James P. The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) notes with sadness the passing of an outstanding Jewish Civil Servant who, for a decade after World War II, played a major role in JDC assisting Holocaust survivors in a variety of postings: in Salzburg, Paris, Geneva and Frankfurt. He served as JDC liaison with the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, International Red Cross, International Council of Voluntary Agencies, as well as the U.S. Army. We extend condolences to his sons, Michael and Bill Rice, and grandsons. Jonathan W. Kolker President Michael Schneider Executive Vice President Ambassador Milton A. Wolf Chairman of the Board

title: Highsmith Is Making Mark As a Fledgling Heavyweight
description: Alonzo Highsmith, a former National Football League running back turned heavyweight boxer, can't understand why he is held to such an exacting double standard when he steps into the ring.

title: Pataki Plans Fund-Raising Trip to 7 States
description: After spending most of the fall sitting quietly in the shadows of political races in New Jersey and New York City, Gov. George E. Pataki will push his own 1998 re-election campaign machinery into higher gear next month with a weeklong fund-raising trip through seven western and southern states.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVITT, MARVIN, HAZZAN
description: SAVITT-Marvin, Hazzan. The Cantors Assembly records with sorrow the passing of a respected colleague for over four decades. Quietly and gently, he served the spiritual needs of his congregants with great dignity, warmth and care. We extend our sympathy to his wife Harriet, his children and all his loved ones. May his memory abide as a blessing. Hazzan Henry Rosenblum, Pres. Hazzan Abraham B. Shapiro, Executive Administrator

title: $77,600 Raise Proposed For SUNY's Chancellor
description: The trustees of the State University of New York have proposed giving the Chancellor a hefty pay raise, which would make the Chancellor's salary nearly twice as high as the Governor's.

title: Rise in Pass Interference Is Giving the Giants a Lift
description: It is hard to know whether defensive backs in the National Football League are growing more lawless or teams are just getting better at drawing pass interference penalties. Whatever the reason, penalties for defensive pass interference in the first eight weeks of the 1997 season have increased 15 percent over the same period last season.

title: Jets Emerge In Unusual Position: First Place
description: The last time the Jets found themselves in first place this late in the season, the stock market nose-dived. That was 10 years ago. But these new, unpredictable Jets woke up this morning tied for first, and their portfolios soared.

title: Superpower Stats
description: It seems that many people in Washington consider China the next great security threat. For example, Representative Jim Bunning, a Kentucky Republican, complained in June that ''the Chinese Government is engaged in a massive expansion of its own military machine, taking up where the Soviet Union left off, using the profits from trade with us to pay for it.'' As the oratory heats up it may be useful to compare the military strength of China and the United States.

title: In Israeli Dispute Over Who Is a Jew, a Grace Period on Lawsuit
description: Leaders of the Conservative and Reform Jewish movements agreed today to a grace period to mediate a dispute with the Orthodox establishment that has threatened to divide Jews here from those abroad.

title: STOCKS RALLY ON RECORD VOLUME AS SMALL INVESTORS TAKE LEAD
description: Main Street rode in yesterday to rescue Wall Street -- and stock markets around the world -- as America's amateur investors, as well as some professionals, rushed to buy stocks, halting a global financial free fall.

description: BASEBALL

title: Frontier Insurance Deal
description: Frontier Insurance Group will pay $40.5 million for units of the Accel International Corporation, more than doubling its sales of insurance through car dealers. The units that Frontier is buying provide insurance to pay off car loans in the event of death or disability. It is also acquiring a warranty business. Accel, based in Dublin, Ohio, is selling the units to focus on its commercial auto insurance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANNEY, THOMAS F.
description: HANNEY-Thomas F., 86. Mill Rift, PA., October 27, 1997 in Goshen, NY. Past President of N.Y. Oil Heating Assoc., he was founder and President of Hanney Fuel Oil Co., Brooklyn. Survived by wife, Margaret (Bergman) Hanney, daughters, Carol Hafstad, Oslo, Norway and Elaine Romero, Tuxedo Park and Manhattan; a son, Raymond T. Hanney, Floral Park, L.I. and seven grandchildren. Friends call Thursday 2-4, 7-9, Gray-Parker Funeral Home, 100 E. Main St., Port Jervis, NY. Funeral Friday, 10:30 AM, at Funeral Home; 11:00 AM Funeral Mass in St. Joseph's RC Church, Matamoras, Pa. Burial Mill Rift, Pa.

title: The Creme Brulee Crisis, And a Foolproof Solution
description: POPULARITY has not been good to creme brulee.

title: In Colonial America, Jiang Dresses the Part
description: When Deng Xiaoping came to America, he got a cowboy hat. Today Jiang Zemin got a three-cornered one.

title: Making Books; Second String Gets Its Chance
description: It's not that they had a conclave and reached an agreement. But John Grisham, Tom Clancy, Michael Crichton and Stephen King are giving a jumbo Christmas gift to some very popular but not quite as successful fellow novelists. None of the four megastars is publishing a new book this season.

title: Liberties; The Actor And the Tyrant
description: Whoever thought the American Gigolo would become a light unto America?

title: FLEET TO ACQUIRE ADVANTA'S CREDIT CARD OPERATIONS
description: Fleet Financial Group Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the credit card operations of the Advanta Corporation for $500 million. The deal catapults Fleet from 26th place in the credit card business as of June 30, with receivables of $2.8 billion, to ninth place, with $14 billion in receivables and more than eight million customers. Fleet, based in Boston, will combine its card business with Advanta's, with the combined operations to be managed in Horsham, Pa., where Advanta has its operational headquarters. Fleet will pay Advanta a cash premium of about 4.4 percent on Advanta's credit card receivables, which currently total about $10.5 billion. The exact price of the deal depends on Advanta's receivables at the end of the year.

title: Zambia Says a Coup Is Over In 3 Hours, Without Injury
description: The Zambian Government announced today that a coup attempt that lasted a mere three hours had been suppressed without bloodshed and that a handful of military officers had been arrested.

title: A Politician's Comeback May Take Him Only So Far
description: When City Councilman Mike Hernandez was arrested on cocaine possession charges two months ago, his colleagues and constituents were shocked by a seamy tale worthy of ''L.A. Confidential'' -- police surveillance of the councilman buying drugs, cocaine residue found on his desk at City Hall, a cache of pornographic videotapes in his office.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Center for Medical Research
description: With Election Day a week away, state officials yesterday promised $60 million toward establishing a medical research center in Newark to track, treat and prevent the spread of infectious diseases from tuberculosis to AIDS.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-18

title: Former Bronx Detective Admits to Corruption
description: A former Bronx detective pleaded guilty yesterday to a Federal charge of conspiracy to violate civil rights after he was accused of illegally searching a Washington Heights apartment last year and of stealing several kilograms of cocaine.

title: A Russian for Baltimore
description: The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra announced yesterday that it had appointed the Russian conductor Yuri Temirkanov as music director beginning in 1999. He will succeed David Zinman, who is to end a 13-year tenure as music director in June. Mr. Temirkanov, 58, has been the music director of the St. Petersburg Philharmonic since 1988. He is also the principal conductor of the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra in London. He is to retain both positions.

title: Prisoner's Isolation Is Extreme Punishment
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Say 11-Year-Old Boy Was Sexually Assaulted by Classmate
description: An 11-year-old boy was forced into a closet during a class at a junior high school in the South Bronx last week and sexually assaulted by a male classmate while three others held him down, the police said yesterday.

title: Debating Whether Crisis Had to Be
description: The financial tumult that built speed in Southeast Asia and then repeatedly raced around the globe raises a question that few finance ministries around the world want to address: Could someone -- maybe the United States, maybe Japan -- have taken the lead early enough to stop a selloff from becoming a crisis?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, LEA
description: KLEIN-Lea. On October 26, 1997. Beloved wife of Sidney. Mother of Virginia Klein and Richard Kline. Sister of Emma, Shirley and Jackie. Grandmother of Colby. Services were held on Tuesday, October 28.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLODFELTER, CONSTANCE J.
description: CLODFELTER-Constance J. Suddenly, October 24, 1997. Beloved cousin of Gail Irvine and aunt of Katharine Sullivan, Elizabeth Smith, Patricia Irvine and Christine VanLeer. Also dear friend of Sally J. Kuhn. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Museum of Modern Art, New York. A memorial gathering of friends and relatives will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, on Thursday, October 30, at 6:30 PM.

title: New Ad Themes Come With Tumult in Market
description: There has been frenzied activity in the last two days at the intersection of Wall Street and Madison Avenue as financial services advertisers reassess their sales pitches after the stock market's wild swings. Some are changing how they talk to customers and potential customers, while others are sticking with their campaigns.

title: Banks Facing a Cash Squeeze: Asian Troubles Spark Fears of Credit Crunch
description: BANGKOK  Global Market Turmoil / U.S. Stocks Claw Their Way Back

title: Wine Talk; New Guides Point the Way to the Vineyard's Gate
description: IN the 1970's, when Alexis Lichine began to think about a third edition of ''The Wines of France,'' his magisterial book, he decided to change the format. To his descriptions of the wines and the people who made them, he appended precise information on visiting France's winegrowing regions. He changed the book's title to ''The Wines and Vineyards of France.''

title: Ministers Back McGreevey; Whitman Stumps With Kemp
description: More than two dozen black ministers gathered here today to announce their endorsement of the Democratic gubernatorial candidate, James E. McGreevey, a week after the head of the Black Ministers Council threw his support behind Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's re-election bid.

title: A Chief for Civil Rights
description: The important post of Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights has been vacant for nearly a year, sending the wrong message about the nation's commitment to enforce anti-discrimination laws. President Clinton deserves much of the blame. After the last rights chief resigned, he waited seven months before nominating Bill Lann Lee in July. But the Senate, too, has been slow to move.
