description: What to Eat When in Peru

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Clinton's Goal: Inching Toward a Little Rapport and Some Candid Talk
description: President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China agreed tonight to establish a round-the-clock telephone line between Washington and Beijing as a concrete sign of warming relations between the two powers.

title: Jordan and the Bulls Are Finally Vulnerable, Leaving a Scrum for the Title
description: Behind Michael Jordan and Scottie Pippen, Chicago has won five of the last seven championships and the last two in a row. But with the Lakers maturing, Miami and the Knicks adding more ammunition and the Jazz determined not to blow another finals opportunity, the Bulls' dynasty is in serious jeopardy. Here is a quick look at the N.B.A. division races listed in projected order of finish.

title: Fund Managers Feel Stocks May Again Turn Lower
description: As stock prices roared back yesterday, mutual fund managers resisted rushing in to make big purchases, believing that they might have the chance to buy their favorite stocks at even lower prices.

title: Silva to Run for Himself and for Charity
description: German Silva, who won the New York City Marathon in 1994 and 1995, was driving through poor areas of Mexico City last week. He was stunned by what he saw.

title: $25 and Under; Blending the Classic With the Not-So-Classic
description: THE GLOBE is a baffling restaurant from the moment you enter. You are confronted by a large circular stainless-steel counter that is an oyster bar by night, a breakfast bar by morning, a takeout counter at lunch.

title: Messinger Opposes Constitutional Convention
description: Ruth W. Messinger yesterday urged defeat of a ballot proposal that could lead to revision of the State Constitution, asserting that the proposal threatened to undermine abortion rights, tenant protections and the future of state forests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGSOHN, MAX
description: SELIGSOHN-Max. The Ramaz School Family mourns the passing of the beloved father of its esteemed parent and benefactor Gerald Seligsohn and extends heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the bereaved family. David N. Kahn, Chairman Board of Trustees Rabbi Haskel Lookstein, Princ

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, excerpts on Saturday from an interview with Ruth W. Messinger on what she would do if elected mayor misstated part of a quotation. Her comment was: ''What changes are needed? And if you decide that, if you have a vision, which I do, if you really believe that it's worth everything, it's worth a second term to start turning the schools of this city around.'' She did not say ''worth a second time.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITZMAN, SHIRLEY
description: MITZMAN-Shirley. Of Hopewell Junction. Died October 28, 1997. Mother of Steven Mitzman and grandmother of Joshua Mitzman. Funeral service on Wednesday at 11 AM at McHoul Funeral Home, Hopewell Junction followed by a graveside service at 1:15PM at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale.

title: Steady Retirement Money Is Foundation for Rebound
description: Monday's stock market plunge may have unnerved some investors, but it did not spook people who save for retirement in 401(k) plans. At least that was what large employers, mutual funds and plan administrators said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOICHIS, HAVIM
description: BOICHIS-Havim, M.D. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University is profoundly saddened by the passing of Havim Boichis, Professor and Past Dean of the Tel Aviv University Sackler School of Medicine and the incumbent of the University's Lea & Arie PickelPaamoni Chair in Pediatric Nephrology. His colleagues, friends & students, world-wide, will cherish the memory of this remarkable man of great warmth and compassion. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Yola, sons Eli and Ron, and their families. The American Friends of Tel Aviv University Bernard Rapoport, Chairman, Board of Directors Melvin S. Taub, Chairman Emeritus Robert J. Topchik, Pres. Jules Love, Exec. Vice Pres.

title: Iraq's Secret Weapons Programs
description: For months, Iraq has actively misled United Nations inspectors about its continuing germ warfare program and blocked entry to military bases where prohibited materials may be stored. Now it is threatening to suspend all cooperation with U.N. monitors. But the U.N. Security Council seems reluctant to pressure Baghdad to back down.

title: Food Stuff
description: Semidried Tomatoes With Something Extra

title: President Signs Measure Saving Housing Program
description: More than four million people living in subsidized housing were assured of keeping their homes Monday night when President Clinton signed legislation that provides enough money for the government to renew contracts with their landlords.

title: A Road Map Through the Racial Divide in America
description: A COUNTRY OF STRANGERS

title: Gilding Jazz With Class, 70 Years of Cleo Laine
description: Late in Cleo Laine's 70th-birthday concert at Town Hall on Sunday, the jazz pianist and educator Billy Taylor offered the evening's most telling remarks about the English jazz contralto being honored and her husband, the band leader, arranger and saxophonist John Dankworth, who led an eight-piece band. Ms. Laine's and Mr. Dankworth's music, he said, was an example of an American export (jazz) that ''came back in better shape than when we sent it over.''

title: What to Make of Wave That Started Over There; U.S. Businesses Can Shrug Off Asian Tumult
description: When currencies and stocks in Hong Kong -- or Thailand or Indonesia -- take a tumble, must America feel their pain?

title: INSIDE
description: Consensus on U.S. in Bosnia

title: Wall Street Sets the Tone
description: Panic on Wall Street spread around the world, but was halted yesterday where it had been the most intense just a day earlier -- in America. For better or worse, the United States is now setting the tone for world stock markets.

title: Microsoft's Illogic
description: To the Editor:

title: Lest Russians Forget, a Museum of the Gulag
description: The only sign of life amid the cluster of blackened, rotting wooden shacks is one that portends death: a freshly painted green guard tower that once loomed above the inmates of Perm 36, the most notorious labor camp for political prisoners in the Soviet Union.

title: DYLEX ABANDONS $71 MILLION TAKEOVER BID FOR MARK'S
description: Dylex Ltd. said yesterday that it had dropped its $71 million takeover bid for Mark's Work Wearhouse Ltd. because it was not given full access to the company's financial data. Dylex's cash-and-share bid, which was worth the equivalent of about $71 million, expired yesterday. Mark's, which runs 290 stores that sell work wear and casual wear, repeatedly said the bid from the Toronto-based Dylex was too low. Dylex said it was not given access to Mark's confidential financial data, which the Toronto-based company said might have allowed it to raise its offer. Dylex, which owns 638 clothing stores across Canada, wanted to add Mark's because it complements its five retail chains, which include Tip Top, Biway and Fairweather.

title: Accounts
description: * Decibel Instruments Inc., Hayward, Calif., to Lois/EJL, New York, part of Lois/U.S.A., to introduce a hearing aid. Billings were estimated at $12 million.

title: The Rangers Are Detecting Some Unpleasant Patterns
description: After falling behind by 3-0 to the Dallas Stars last night at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers responded by playing well against a good National Hockey League team for the final, robust 40 minutes. Mike Keane scored two goals, and several other Rangers could have scored several other times.

title: ACC TO BUY U S WATS FOR $46 MILLION
description: The ACC Corporation, a Rochester-based telecommunications company, agreed yesterday to buy U S Wats Inc., a long-distance telephone company, for $2.48 a share in stock, or about $46 million. ACC said U S Wats shareholders would receive 0.077 ACC common shares for each U S Wats common share. The purchase price may fluctuate depending on ACC's stock price but will not exceed $50.6 million. ACC's stock was down $3.50 a share yesterday, to $26.125. The stock dropped despite the company's report Tuesday that its third-quarter earnings met Wall Street expectations. U S Wats, based in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., had 1996 revenues of $40.3 million.

title: John Stevenson, 76, Delegate To Law of the Sea Conference
description: John Reese Stevenson, an international lawyer who represented the United States at the Law of the Sea Conference in the 1970's and served as board president of the National Gallery of Art until 1993, died on Saturday at his home in Fort Worth, Tex. He was 76.

title: Impasse Remaining, Senate Ends Effort on Highway Bill
description: The Senate today abandoned its efforts to pass a six-year highway financing bill after supporters of a campaign finance overhaul once again blocked the popular $145 billion highway measure from being brought toward a final vote.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, HENRY L.
description: BROWN-Henry L., on October 21, 1997. A memorial service will be held 2 PM, Saturday, November 1, at St. Agnes Episcopal Church, 65 Union Ave., Little Falls, NJ. Memorial donations may be made to Williams College, Williamstown, MA., or The Mountainside Hospital, Montclair, NJ 07042-9976.

title: Proffitt's Expected to Buy Carson Pirie Scott Chain
description: Proffitt's Inc., a regional department store company that has been on a buying spree in recent years, is expected to reach an agreement to acquire Carson Pirie Scott & Company, a retailer with 56 stores in the Midwest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIAMOND, BERNARD
description: DIAMOND-Bernard. On October 28, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Sara. Devoted father of Paul and loving father-in-law of Vivian. Dear brother of Ethel Doberman, Muriel Gold and brother-in-law of Fred Gold. Cherished grandfather of Randi, Meredith, Andrew and Charlotte. Loving great grandfather of Allison and Zachary. Services Thursday, 1:30 PM, ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Skipper Resigns From Conner Boat
description: Chris Dickson resigned Monday as skipper of Toshiba, Dennis Conner's entry in the Whitbread Round the World Race.

title: Panel on Aviation Disasters Calls for Emergency Data
description: A study group on how to assist families of plane crash victims will recommend on Wednesday that airlines and travel agents be required to ask people who buy tickets for the name and telephone number of someone to call in an emergency.

title: TENNIS: ROUNDUP
description: PARIS OPEN

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; E-Z Pass Exceeds Expectation
description: Exceeding expectations, 32 percent of drivers at the Lincoln Tunnel and 24 percent of the drivers at the Holland Tunnel rolled through the tollbooths with E-Z Pass transponders on the first day of the program at the tunnels yesterday, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REES, MINA S.
description: REES-Mina S. The faculty, staff, students and alumni of Hunter College mourn the passing of Dr. Mina S. Rees, a 1923 Hunter alumna who became an internationally known mathematician and nationally prominent educator. A member of the Hall of Fame of our Alumni Association, Dr. Rees served the College for many years, first as a mathematics instructor and, after WWII, as dean of students. During the war and in the immediate post war years, she worked for the Government, where she helped to direct research in modern mathematics for the war effort, and later headed the mathematics branch of the Office of Naval Research, and served as deputy director of the ONR's Division of Science and Mathematics. In 1961, she became the first dean of graduate studies at CUNY and she was the founding president of the CUNY Graduate School and University Center. An innovative thinker whose ideas had a profound influence on mathematics education and the development of computer technology, she was the first woman to be elected president of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. We are proud of our association with Dr. Rees and we send sincerest condolences to her family. David A. Caputo, President

title: Fed Is Expected to Postpone Discussion of Higher Rates
description: Even after the sharp rebound today in stock prices, analysts said that turmoil in the markets would force the Federal Reserve Board to postpone consideration of raising interest rates until next year, and that it could diminish any risk of the economy's overheating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANEK, BESSIE
description: GANEK-Bessie, 95. Miami Beach, FL. Died October 28, 1997. Beloved mother of Howard and Judie Ganek. Loving grandmother of Tori, Danielle and David. Great-grandmother of Harrison and Nicholas. She will be missed by her whole family who loved her dearly.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption in some copies yesterday about the visit of President Jiang Zemin of China referred incorrectly to the dinner he attended in Honolulu on Sunday. It was not a state dinner; that event is scheduled for tonight in Washington.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARON, PHYLLIS HOFFMAN
description: BARON-Phyllis Hoffman. October 27, 1997. Beloved mother of Carol Taylor Gray, Jennifer Brandt and her husband Gary and Robert Hoffman Taylor. Cherished grandmother of Eliza Lindsay Gray and Ally Hoffman Taylor. Loving sister of Lindley Hoffman. She will be deeply missed by all who knew her. Mass of Christian Burial on Friday, October 31, at 10 A.M., St. Ignatius Loyola Church, New York City. Interment will take place on Saturday, November 1 at St. Ann's Cemetery, Lenox, MA.

title: Is America Ready for Bunny Ragout?
description: IT is the perfect meat. It's low in cholesterol yet high in protein, mild tasting yet rich, matchable with red or white wine, depending on how you cook it, and so easy to digest that doctors recommend it to patients with stomach troubles. It's a meat that does just about everything, in fact, except jump into the frying pan and cook itself, like the self-sacrificing shmoos in ''Li'l Abner.''

title: Business Travel
description: BACK in the late 1980's, travel by stretch limousine was a flashy symbol of executive success. Today, with chauffeured service democratized, the glitz is gone. The corporate car of choice is a commodious sedan equipped with a phone and reading light, according to the 1,500-member National Limousine Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVEY, MINNIE
description: LEVEY-Minnie. Beloved friend passed away peacefully October 27, after a wonderful life with her late husband Jeffrey. Funeral at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey, Wednesday, 2:30 PM. Deeply mourned by her friends, Hillel and Madeline Jaffe and Michael and Audrey Norwich.

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about a performance by the pianist Ignat Solzhenitsyn at the 92d Street Y in Manhattan misstated his age. He is 25, not 23.

title: The Minimalist; What's the Best Clam Chowder? One Made With the Proper Clams
description: CLAM chowder takes many guises: it can be complicated with bacon or other strong flavors or thickened with flour or loads of cream. But the best clam chowder is a simple affair that has as its flavorful essence the juice of the clams themselves.

title: A Garden Institution Is Back in Town
description: Unless they're looking to travel by pony express, those New Yorkers accustomed to hailing cabs in the taxiway between Penn Station and Madison Square Garden will have to look elsewhere, and step carefully, for the rest of the week. The National Horse Show, one of just a trio of enduring Big Apple sporting events that have called all four incarnations of the Garden home, is back in town to present its 114th rendition.

title: Critic's Notebook; In Napa Valley, A Restaurant Scales the Peak
description: IMAGINE a restaurant hidden in the middle of the vineyards. It is an old stone house filled with the golden light of many candles. There is a courtyard in the center, and on fine nights tables are set in the fragrant garden beneath a starry sky.

title: COMMUNITY BANKS TO BUY PEOPLES STATE IN STOCK SWAP
description: Community Banks Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Peoples State Bank in a stock swap valued at $37.56 a share, or about $55.9 million. Community Banks said the transaction would be accounted for as a pooling of interests. Community Banks will exchange 0.889 shares of of its own common stock for each share of Peoples' common stock outstanding. Peoples also granted Community an option to buy up to 19.9 percent of Peoples' outstanding common shares. Community Banks is a bank holding company based in Millersburg, Pa. Peoples State, based in East Berlin, Pa., has operations in Adams and York Counties in Pennsylvania.

title: Public Health Cited in Breaching H.I.V. Confidentiality
description: In publicly identifying a 20-year-old man with H.I.V. who is accused of infecting at least nine young women in western New York with the virus that causes AIDS, public health officials invoked for the first time a provision of state law that allows an infected person's name to be widely disclosed in cases of ''clear and imminent danger to the public health.''

title: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: PROFILE -- Born With Politics in Her Veins; Behind Whitman's Earnest Talk, a Fierce Spirit Lies
description: When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's Labor Commissioner, Peter J. Calderone, tried to muster opposition to her plan to privatize the state's temporary disability insurance fund, he was asked to resign. When one of her spokesmen, Robert Thompson, publicly stated that her privatization of the Department of Motor Vehicles was not working as well as she had claimed, he was dismissed. And during her 1993 campaign, when polls indicated that Mrs. Whitman needed to do something drastic to jump-start her candidacy, she tossed her own brother, Webster (Dan) Todd Jr., from his job as campaign manager.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOUTROSS, MATILDA (NEE COURI)
description: BOUTROSS-Matilda (nee Couri). On October 28, 1997. Loving aunt of George, Ronald, Robert, Steven, John and James Couri, Nick Meena, Yvonne Mena, and greataunt of many. Visiting Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, McLaughlin & Sons, Third Avenue at 97 Street, Bklyn. Religious service Friday, 10 AM, St. Mary's Church.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOHNSON, NORMAN DUDLEY
description: JOHNSON-Norman Dudley. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, October 30th, Saint James' Church 875 Madison Ave, NYC at 11AM. Gifts in his memory may be sent to The Episcopal School 35 East 69th Street, NY, NY 10021, the N.Y. Historical Society 170 Central Park West, New York 10024 or The Martha's Vineyard Hospital Oak Bluffs, MA 02557.

title: Insider Trader Ordered to Serve Sentence
description: James O'Hagan, a convicted insider trader, has been ordered to begin serving his 18-month prison term even as appeals of his conviction are pending.

title: New York Citywide Elections
description: Besides the mayor, New York has two public officials who are elected citywide. Here are our endorsements.

title: G.O.P. Hopes Are Buoyed In Bronx Race For Council
description: For decades, the northeastern Bronx has been among the stablest of political terrains, at least when it came to the City Council. The area, which includes the neighborhoods of Pelham Parkway, Morris Park and City Island, has been represented by Councilman Michael DeMarco since 1970.

title: Britain Is No Model On Job Creation; A War Over Chocolate
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEFLIESE, PHILIP
description: DEFLIESE-Philip. A leader in the accounting profession who served in the 1960's and 1970's as the Chairman and CEO of Coopers & Lybrand, the world-wide accounting, auditing and consulting firm, as Chairman of the American of the American Institute of Public Accountants (AICPA) & as Chairman of the AICPA's Accounting Principles Board, the rule-making body that preceded today's Financial Accounting Standards Board, died in New York, Monday, after a brief illness. He was 82. Mr. Defliese combined his deep interest for teaching with a commanding knowledge of accountancy and auditing throughout his career. He co-authored with other partners from Coopers & Lybrand several editions of ''Montgomery's Auditing'', an authoritative text and reference on accountancy and audit practice. Following his retirement from Coopers & Lybrand in 1977, he was Professor at Columbia University's Graduate School of Business until 1986 and served as a founding member of the Government Accounting Standards Board from 1984 to 1990. Mr. Defliese also served on a number of corporate boards, most notably the board of ARAMARK Corporation. Born in Queens, N.Y. to a family of modest means, he earned a Bachelor's degree in Business Administration at city College of NY at night while working full time. Following service as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy in World War II, he married the former Pauline Harnisch, his beloved wife of fifty years, who died earlier this year. Together they raised their family in Garden City, N.Y., and were parishoners at St. Anne's Roman Catholic Church. Mr. Defliese is survived by his sons Philip Jr. of Mercer Island, WA., and Robert of Garden City, NY, as well as his daughter Jeanne of New York, NY and seven grandchildren. Friends may call at Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 29 Atlantic Avenue, Floral Park, New York from 7 to 10 P.M. on Thursday, and from 2 until 5 P.M. on Friday. A mass of Christian burial will be held 9:15AM, Saturday, November 1, 1997, St. Anne's Catholic Church in Garden City, New York. Burial will follow in St. John's Cemetery in Queens, NY. Memorial donations may be sent to the Baruch College Fund, 17 Lexington Ave., Box D901, New York, N.Y. 10010.

title: Routine Flight Information Is Sought for Study on Safety
description: The Federal Aviation Administration will soon propose a rule under which airlines that voluntarily provide detailed data on routine operations will be given immunity from prosecution for minor violations that data reveal, the Administrator of the agency, Jane Garvey, said today.

title: TV Notes
description: Rolling out Guns For the Sweeps

title: The Bulls Stand Corrected
description: Now that the post-1991 bull stock market has suffered its first major setback (defined in the trade as a drop of 10 percent or more), the time has come to ask, What does a Wall Street ''correction'' correct?

title: Reform Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: REPUBLIC TO BUY DENVER AREA AUTO DEALERSHIPS
description: Republic Industries agreed yesterday to buy auto dealerships owned by the Denver Broncos quarterback John Elway for stock valued at $82.5 million. Mr. Elway owns six Denver-area dealerships that generated $280 million in revenue last year. Republic, the world's largest car retailer, said it planned to include the Elway group of dealers in a cluster of new- and used-car dealerships in Denver. Since December, Republic has agreed to buy 205 dealerships with a combined 1996 revenue of more than $6 billion.

title: Luis Aguilar Manzo, 79, Star Of Many Films of Old Mexico
description: Luis Aguilar Manzo, a shark fisherman turned actor whose debonair mustache, arching eyebrows and splendid singing voice made him one of Mexico's most durable movie stars, died on Friday at his home here. He was 79.

title: Borrowing Country Colors
description: Like Charles Ives and Albert Ayler, the guitarist Bill Frisell draws on the jumble sale of the American subconscious for his music: hymns, lullabies and children's songs, the blues. In Saturday night's late set at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights, Mr. Frisell played songs from his newest record, ''Nashville'' (Nonesuch), with two musicians who mostly work in country and bluegrass music: the dobro player Jerry Douglas and the bassist Viktor Krauss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIEMCZYK, REV. JOSEPH W.
description: NIEMCZYK-Rev. Joseph W. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the retired pastor of Our Lady of Czenstochowa-St. Casimir Church, Brooklyn, October 26. Reposing in Jurek-Park Slope Funeral Home, 728 4th Avenue, Wednesday, October 29, 2-5 PM. Mass of Transferral Wednesday, October 29 at 7:30 PM in Our Lady of Czenstochowa-St. Casimir Church, 183 25th Street, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass, Thursday, October 30, at 10:30 A.M. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Coke's New Chairman Sees No Major Shifts in Strategy
description: In his first public appearance since his appointment as chairman and chief executive of the Coca-Cola Company last week, M. Douglas Ivester announced no major changes yesterday in the strategy of the company.

title: Class Notes; At a Long Island high school, students accept the challenge of seeing differences and looking beyond them.
description: ''I'm Mike,'' said one of the visitors, introducing himself to the 11th-grade health class at North Shore High School. ''I was born with holes in my nose and my forehead. I've had 35 surgeries.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, RALPH
description: PETERSON-Ralph. Passed away Monday, October 20, 1997 after a brief illness. Ralph was a dear husband to his wife, Patricia; a loving father to his 3 children, Jeffrey, Stacey and Beth; an adoring grandfather to Jami, Scott, David and Brian; and a devoted brother to Phyllis Makransky. His professional life as Chief Finance Officer of Warner Brothers spanned three decades. A memorial service will be held Thursday, 4 P.M., October 30, at Temple Emeth, 1666 Windsor Road, Teaneck, New Jersey. Services under the direction of Gutterman - Musicant, Hacken sack, New Jersey (1-800-522-0588).

title: This Time, a Market Slump Would Differ in Its Effects
description: For a long string of years, most New Yorkers did not need to think much about Wall Street and the stock market as prices climbed with seemingly inexorable stability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAZARUS, ELINOR
description: LAZARUS-Elinor. The Board of Governors and Members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved member, Elinor. On behalf of all Fairview members, we express our deepest condolences to her family. Andrew J. Frankel, President Judith Weil, Secretary

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Investors are like those cattle. Maybe they heard a cricket. Maybe they heard thunder. Maybe a mountain lion. Maybe they thought they saw a mountain lion. Maybe they heard something about the Thai baht. One of them starts moving. Then the others start moving. They stampede. Then they stop.''

title: A Cleaner Environmental Bill
description: The legislative process in this country is inherently messy, meaning that one side or the other sometimes has to swallow unpalatable ideas in order to achieve a larger good. That is the situation with the Interior Department appropriations bill, which Congress has now passed and sent to the President's desk. It is full of mischievous, self-serving measures designed to benefit a few Western members of Congress. Nevertheless, we recommend that the President sign the bill and then use a tool we dislike, the line item veto, to strike its most objectionable provisions.

title: Crisis Ahead In East Asia Over Prices Of Property : Wall Street Claws Its Way Back
description: SINGAPORE  East Asia's property values will be the next victim of the region's financial turmoil and slowing growth, economists predicted Tuesday.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Bus-Attack Suspect Arrested
description: Digitally enhanced photographs made from footage taken from a bus security camera helped the Newark police arrest an 18-year-old man who they say shot two people on a city bus after passengers complained that he was playing his radio too loudly, officials said yesterday.

title: Intense Eavesdropping On Violent Behavior
description: At its most explosive, ''It Ain't Love'' hits viewers like the slap in the face that Carlos aims at Catie, re-enacting a moment from her past in which she asked her jealous boyfriend to hit her, ''to get it over with,'' she explains. This tightly focused documentary follows a Brooklyn-based theater group called Faces, in which young adults re-enact their experiences in violent relationships, some as victims and some as abusers.

title: It's Official: Two Women Are Referees
description: Michael Cage of the Nets disagreed with the non-call of the official last Friday during a preseason game. He wanted a foul. The referee didn't see it that way. The two went back and forth, explaining their points to one another without yelling. Cage lost the argument but didn't seem to mind.

title: Houston Finds Groove, Despite Trade Rumors
description: Allan Houston spends hours in front of the television set many nights, squeezing tennis balls and a range of gadgets, everything but a rubber ducky.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Vitamins Alone Aren't Nutrition; Dietitians Can Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Juilliard Quartet's Musical Chairs; Sounding Board for the New, Strings Attached to the Old
description: Change a player or two in an orchestra or on a baseball team, and chances are you still have pretty much the same orchestra or baseball team. But change a player or two in a string quartet, and it may not be entirely clear what you have.

title: Five New Rules Are Likely To Give Pros a Face Lift
description: Blame Pat Riley's no-layup rule that forbids players passage to the basket. Or Charles Oakley's massive forearms that stop penetrating point guards in their tracks. Or point your finger at a bunch of unimaginative offenses that seem to generate points.

title: A Marriage Gone Bad Struggles for Redemption
description: Shutting herself inside the master bedroom of her elegant new home in this Boulder suburb, Lyndi McCartney spent the spring of 1993 weak from bulimia and considering suicide.

title: Cone Says He Will Be Ready For 1998
description: David Cone spoke so enthusiastically yesterday about his surgically repaired right shoulder that he could have been auditioning for an infomercial. The Yankee pitcher said he no longer felt pain in the shoulder, that he could uncork a baseball today, that he might be even better after the surgery and that the Yankees should consider him a lock for 1998. He neglected to give an 800 number.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FISCHER, KARL
description: FISCHER-Karl. On October 28, 1997, of Island Park, N.Y. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury.

description: GORDON-George. The entire family of the the East Midwood Jewish Center profoundly mourns the passing of our Trustee and Chief Usher. He was a man filled with the joy of life and the love of all people. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Trudy and his children. Dr. Alvin Kass, Rabbi Marsha Shlefstein, President

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAVAGE, MARILYN
description: SAVAGE-Marilyn. 10/29/45-2/9/94. Wish we could celebrate todayyour birthday and a 10-year cure. It's so unfair that you're not here. And yet, the fact that you were alive, and ever will be in the hearts of those who loved you, remains cause for rejoicing. Miss you. Vicki

title: More People May Be Linked To Man Who Has H.I.V.
description: The man accused of infecting nine women and girls in Chautauqua County with H.I.V. has told the authorities that he had sex with dozens of women in New York City this year, state health officials said today, raising the possibility that he has, directly or indirectly, exposed hundreds of people to the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, RYWA
description: KAPLAN-Rywa. On October 28, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Loving mother of Martin, cherished mother-in-law of Janet, adoring grandmother of Alexandra, dear aunt of Felix, Gary, Shirley and Fred. Service Thursday, 12 noon at the ''Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Bits and Bytes
description: Now for Something Useful

title: A Friendly Witness Is Invited to Dinner
description: Politics does not just make strange bedfellows. It also makes for some interesting dinner companions.

description: BERKOWITZ-James C. 6/29/60-10/29/84. Thirteen years, a second Bar Mitzvah-we were there with you. Not a day goes by that you are not in our hearts. Love 'til we are together again. Mom, Dad, Steve, Ella, Marian

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FILLMAN, SUSAN
description: FILLMAN-Susan. We extend our deepest sympathy to the family of Susan Fillman, our friend and longtime Board member. Her ideas and action were always inspiring. Her dedication to the community, especially to its youngest members, gave us focus. Although she is gone, her spirit will live on, encouraging us to follow her example. We shall miss her deeply. Berkshire Taconic Community Foundation Salisbury, CT

title: FIRST EMPIRE TO BUY ONBANCORP FOR $872 MILLION
description: The First Empire State Corporation, based in Buffalo, agreed yesterday to acquire an upstate New York rival, Onbancorp Inc., for about $872 million in cash and stock. The merger will create the largest banking franchise in central and western New York, with total assets of $19.2 billion. The combined company will have 76 branches in greater Buffalo, 46 in greater Rochester, 39 in greater Syracuse, 38 in the Albany area, 15 in metropolitan New York and 19 in Pennsylvania. Onbancorp shares fell $2.875, to $61.75, in Nasdaq trading. First Empire slipped $4.75, to $412.25, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Miller Consolidates Promotions Account
description: The Miller Brewing Company in Milwaukee, a unit of the Philip Morris Cos., has consolidated its promotions account, with combined billings estimated at $50 million to $60 million, at the Zipatoni Company in St. Louis and GMR Marketing in Brookfield, Wis.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERKING, MAX
description: BERKING-Max. A memorial service Sunday, November 2, 1997, 3 PM, Wainwright House, 260 Stuyvesant Avenue, Rye, NY. Donations in memoriam to Amnesty International, 322 8th Avenue, NY, New York 10001. No flowers please.

title: If Truffles Seem Out of Reach
description: FRESH white truffles, a precious commodity in any year, are even more of a luxury this fall. A dearth caused by dry weather in the Piedmont in Italy and a growth in demand around the world have pushed the price to $70 to $80 an ounce in shops. Cheaper ones can be had, but they are very small.

title: Student Sponsor Program Regroups
description: As she struggles with three children, a job as a nurse's aide, part-time college classes and credit problems, Maria Escarsega often wonders why she let things go so wrong after a rich man offered her the chance of a lifetime: to finish high school and have her way paid through college.

title: For Wounds of the Mind, The Healer's Art Is Art
description: On paper, with paint and pencil, Ibrahima Sory Bah says what he has not been able to say in words, the pictures unleashing long-unspeakable memories of his arrest and torture in Guinea a dozen years ago. An artist and graphic designer who fled his West African homeland and landed in the Bronx in 1990, Mr. Bah, a 47-year-old worker at a Long Island window shade factory, is only now coming to grips with his ordeal -- another example of the growing use of art therapy to treat victims of extreme abuse.

title: U.S. Judge, Criticizing Delay, Dismisses Case Against Man
description: A Federal district judge, sharply criticizing the lengthy delays that defendants in some criminal cases in United States District Court in Manhattan face before formal charges are filed, dismissed a charge against a man who was held for 14 months before he was indicted on a charge of conspiring to distribute at least 50 grams of crack cocaine.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of Madonna's Manhattan apartment in House & Home on Sept. 18, with an article about the impact of celebrities' names on the selling prices of homes, carried an erroneous credit. The photographer was Durston Saylor for Architectural Digest.

title: Rescue Plan for Neglected South Side of Ellis Island
description: Preservationists worried that Congress is ignoring the accelerating decay of the long-neglected south side of Ellis Island have raised $50,000 to shore up one of the 24 buildings. They say that they hope the work, which began yesterday, will shame the Federal Government into paying for emergency repairs to the rest of the site.

title: Daffiness and Daring In Every Last Ring
description: The Big Apple Circus has something to celebrate. And it's celebrating it in fine style.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWEIGER, ERIC G.
description: SCHWEIGER-Eric G., M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumni records with sorrow the passing of their longtime colleague and friend. He will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Wayne S. Fuchs, M.D., President Avi Barbasch, M.D., Vice Pres. Maria Padilla, M.D. Secretary William G. Stein, M.D., Treas.

title: GOLF: IN THE NEWS
description: L.P.G.A. Schedule Is Set for 1998

title: About New York; Mercy Mission Finds a Storm At Wrong Port
description: A HODGEPODGE of hand-me-downs filled Etienne Victorin's storefront office on Church Avenue -- blue barrels crammed with scuffed shoes and wrinkled clothes, a refrigerator whose door was taped shut, mattresses, bed frames and dozens of cans of tomato paste. All of this stuff probably wouldn't fetch a cent at the Salvation Army, but it might provide some succor to the people of Haiti.

title: Big Game 7 Rating Lifts Series Nielsens
description: With a 24.5 Nielsen rating for Game 7 of the Florida-Cleveland World Series, NBC avoided having the lowest-rated fall classic in history.

title: Test Kitchen; Can Openers for Klutzes, Lefties and Others
description: EVERYBODY needs one, but which one?

title: Metro Business; Black Monthly Is Begun
description: One year after The City Sun ceased publication, a former editor of the black weekly newspaper has started a monthly publication, called The Black Star News, aimed largely at African-American readers in New York City.

title: Majority Ownership Shifts at Comcast
description: In a widely expected move, the Comcast Corporation said yesterday that its chairman, Ralph J. Roberts, had transferred control of his family stock, which represents 82 percent of the votes in the company, to his son, Brian L. Roberts, the company's president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGED, GERTRUDE M.
description: MAGED-Gertrude M., 91. Died on October 8, 1997 in Suffern, N.Y., after a short illness. Graduated from Teachers College in 1925, became music teacher and supervisor in Nyack schools. Wife of Allen J. Maged. Very active in Rockland County community organizations. Returned to teaching in Ramapo School District from 1960 to 1976. In retirement she initiated music programs in Suffern day care centers. Last year she wrote original songs and compiled a multicultural songbook. She discovered and nurtured musical talent in generations of children. A truly creative person, artist, musician, writer, traveler, and inspiration to family, colleagues and many friends. Survived by daughters Eve and Judith of NYC, brother Leonard Goldstein of Nyack. Graveside service was October 10. A memorial is being planned for 1998.

title: CHRONICLE
description: You never can tell what inspiration you may find in a basement. That lesson was learned by MOSES PENDLETON, the director and founder of Momix, the dance company that uses sculpture and other props to stretch the boundaries of movement.

title: Mayor Unveils Sting Strategy Against Drugs
description: New York City police officers have begun posing as drug dealers, selling packets of marijuana to unsuspecting buyers and then arresting them, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEESON, LAURA
description: LEESON-Laura. On October 28, 1997. Aunt Laura to three generations of Schrader, Levkov and Kaufman children. Beloved and tolerated for her independence and outspokeness. A woman and artist, much ahead of her time. Still youthful and flirtatious at 99. Things will not be the same without her. Services on Wednesday 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYLAND, FRANCINE MILES
description: HYLAND-Francine Miles. On October 27, 1997. Beloved wife of Thomas. Devoted mother of Jennifer and Thomas. Dear daughter of Frances Miles. Funeral mass Thursday 9:45AM, St. Mary's RC Church, Manhasset. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting on Tuesday 7-9 P.M., and Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9 P.M.

description: SCHEINER-Samuel (Sonny). Beloved husband to Royce, adored and devoted father to Randy and Tami, caring brother to Bea Schoedes. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside,'' 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 10 A.M., Wednesday.

title: Essay; Non-Panic of '97
description: This was not It.

description: SHAMES-Leonard. October 25, 1997. Husband of Helene (nee Weisman) of NY, brother of Gertrude Schiffer and Isadore Shames of Monticello. Funeral services were held Monday. Interment was in Montefiore Cemetery, Philadelphia, PA. Family will be at the home of Norman Pessin. Contributions in his memory may be made to Volunteer Services for Children.

title: Trust Suit Reinstated Against College's Curbs on Fraternities
description: In a novel case that could affect colleges trying to close fraternity houses, a Federal appeals court has reinstated an antitrust action charging Hamilton College with monopolizing the market for student housing in Clinton, N.Y., by requiring all students to live on campus.

title: Pride and Censure Mix With a Dash of Apathy
description: If President Jiang Zemin of China studies the official receptions here this week and the disparate throngs protesting or quietly watching beyond, he will be able to sample a range of Chinese-American concerns as wide as China itself.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Exploiting the Fame of Times Square
description: On the fringes of Times Square, at 48th Street and Seventh Avenue, there is a rooftop billboard that most passers-by find more confusing than promotional. It displays the number 999 in large figures; below that is the word ''pharmaceutical'' and four Chinese characters across the bottom.

title: Sports of The Times; The Price Of Liberty: A Punch
description: A SLIGHT may be dealt with in a variety of ways. Once upon a time there were duels at 10 paces, but in our supposedly more civilized time one might administer a piercing barb or witticism.

title: Another Attack on Insurance
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate for governor, recently released a 30-second television advertisement criticizing Gov. Christine Todd Whitman for her policies on auto insurance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, DAVID H.
description: LIEBERMAN-David H. On October 27, 1997. Beloved husband of Louella. Services Wednesday 11:00 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory can be made to The Center for ChristianJewish Understanding, Sacred Heart University, 5151 Park Avenue, Fairfield, CT. 06432 or the Infectious Disease Research Foundation, 31 Washington Square West, New York City 10011.

title: U.S. Officials Said to See Need to Extend Bosnia Mission
description: The Clinton Administration's top foreign policy makers have reached a broad consensus on the need to keep some American troops in Bosnia after their current mission ends in June of next year, senior Administration officials and Western diplomats said today.

title: Japanese Stocks Bounce Back Day After Trading Was Curbed
description: Japan's long-suffering stock market enjoyed a rebound this morning, sharing in some of the relief Wall Street experienced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAER, ALBERT M.
description: BAER-Albert M. On October 26, 1997, at his home in Rapidan, Va. Age 92. Beloved husband of Karla. Father of Margery Irish and the late Betsy Kaufman. Grandfather of five and great-grandfather of five. Memorial services will be held Thursday at 11:30 a.m., Frank E. Campbell, 81st Street at Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Rapidan Virginia Volunteer Fire Department, P.O. Box 96, Rapidan, VA 22733

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Tram Considered for Camden
description: State and local officials are considering a plan to build a $15 million aerial tram to connect the waterfront entertainment complexes being developed on both sides of the Delaware River in Camden and Philadelphia.

title: John Peters, Indian Advocate In Massachusetts, Dies at 67
description: John Peters, who gained an international reputation for spiritual leadership as the supreme medicine man of the Wampanoag nation while making secular waves across the nation as the executive director of the Massachusetts Commission on Indian Affairs, died on Monday at a hospital near his home in Boston. He was 67 and known also as Cjegktoonuppa, or Slow Turtle.

title: After First Sinking With Asia, Europe Recovers With U.S.
description: European stock markets recovered in part from early selloffs today, lifted at the end of their trading sessions by an upturn on Wall Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHANOWITCH, FANNIE
description: KAHANOWITCH-Fannie. The officers, trustees and members of Temple Sinai of Roslyn extend their deepest condolences to our Rabbi Emeritus, Norman Kahan on the loss of his beloved mother, Fannie Kahanowitch. We pray that our former spiritual leader's memories of his mother will serve as a source of comfort and strength. Michael A. White, Senior Rabbi Daniel S. Reich, President

title: Advance for Bill to Restrict Computer Exports
description: Congress is moving to tighten controls over the export of high performance American computers to Russia and China, prompting strong opposition from the White House and computer manufacturers and talk of a possible veto.

title: Jury Convicts an Ex-Coroner of Tampering With a Witness
description: A tangled criminal case built around a cracked neck bone and old grudges among some New Jersey coroners ended today with the conviction of a doctor on one charge against him and mistrials on two other charges.

title: O, Forgotten Pioneer: Black Coach Recalled
description: On a frigid day in Pittsburgh in 1956, a talented rookie wide receiver for the Steelers named Lowell Perry took a handoff on a reverse against the New York Giants. The Giants' defensive tackle, Rosey Grier, hit Perry so hard that Perry fractured his pelvis and dislocated his hip. He was rushed to Mercy Hospital.

title: Machismo, Then Relief, for Commuters
description: The commuters who rode the Hoboken ferry to Wall Street yesterday morning repeated the word ''correction'' like a mantra, careful to keep the other C-word -- ''crash'' -- from crossing their lips. Never mind, they said, that the market dived more than 550 points the day before. They stepped off the boat, headed to work and hoped they would be right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEUER, MARVIN
description: FEUER-Marvin. On October 28, 1997, of Orlando, FL., formerly of Massapequa, L.I. Loving husband of Blanche; devoted father of Dr. Kenneth and Pascale and Dr. Randall; adored grandfather of Jessica, Tamara, Sarah, Alexandra and Grant. Services Thursday, 11:30 AM at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Temptation; An Ice Cream for One Season: Autumn
description: You might think twice before bothering to bake a pumpkin pie for Thanksgiving if you could get all its goodness in a bowl of ice cream. Berkshire Ice Cream has delivered a pumpkin flavor for the season that is so marvelous that the idea is indeed tempting. Flavored with pumpkin puree, cinnamon, cloves, ginger and nutmeg, the ice cream is intensely buttery, creamy and sweet as pumpkin pie.

title: So Far, a New Crop of Investors Refuse to Budge
description: Nearly panicking as the stock market dived after today's opening bell, Jan Balou, a saleswoman in her 40's, dashed to the Michigan Avenue bus, and headed for her Charles Schwab brokerage office, ready to unload her investments.

title: UAL and T.W.A. Report Improvements in Earnings
description: The UAL Corporation and Trans World Airlines Inc. reported improved third-quarter earnings today, capping a robust quarter for the airline industry as more travelers paid higher fares and the companies cut costs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAUL NEWMAN and JOANNE WOODWARD having a public disagreement? The unthinkable occurred yesterday in the Pegasus Suite of the Rainbow Room when they simply could not get together on deciding the winner of a recipe contest they were judging.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; $11 Million for Park Project
description: Amid the truck routes and brown fields of Jersey City's western flank lies a 123-acre patch of wilderness named Lincoln Park West.

title: Hamm and Keller Are Athletes of Year
description: The national team goalkeeper Kasey Keller and the women's national team striker Mia Hamm, a key member in the United States' drive to last year's Olympic title, were selected as the United States Soccer Federation's athletes of the year yesterday.

title: Treasuries Lose Their Haven Status as Stocks Recover
description: Prices of Treasury securities declined sharply yesterday, once again zigging as the stock market zagged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, CHARLES A.
description: GREENFIELD-Charles A. On October 27, 1997. Beloved husband of Evelyn. Loving father of Charles A. Jr. and the late Jackie Smerling. Also survived by 3 grandchildren and 6 great grandchildren and his brother Percy. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday 24 PM. Mass of Christian burial at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue, at 66 Street, Thursday at 11:00 A.M. Mr. Greenfield was a member of the New York Stock Exchange, senior partner of J.B. Mabon and Company, a Knight of Malta, Knight of the Holy Sepulchre and a renowned collector of Japanese art.

title: 320,000 Have Left Welfare, but Where Do They Go From Here?
description: In the bleak days of the recession, when Rudolph W. Giuliani first seized the reins of New York City, hundreds of grizzled men nested on the busy streets, dozens of homeless families slept in government offices and 1.1 million people eked out a living on welfare, the highest number since the Great Depression.

title: Rolls Rise, Especially in McGreevey Country
description: For the first time in more than 45 years, New Jersey's voter registration rolls jumped in the year after a Presidential election, with the county of the Democratic gubernatorial candidate having the most new voters, according to state figures released today.

title: Delays, Glitches, Unanswered Calls, but Nothing Like 1987
description: On the first day in history that the New York Stock Exchange handled more than one billion shares, small investors bumped up against agonizing delays in getting through to their brokers. But it sure beat banging their heads against the unbreachable wall of silence that greeted desperate sellers in the crash of 1987.

title: Paribas Quits Bidding For Units of Barclays
description: Compagnie Financiere de Paribas said yesterday that it had dropped out of the bidding for the equity and corporate finance businesses of BZW, the investment company owned by Barclays. The Paribas withdrawal comes as Barclays prepares to consider bids from a number of potential buyers, including Credit Suisse First Boston; Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. and Bankers Trust New York. Barclays has said it would choose a buyer by the end of the week.

title: Kenny Smith, a Poor Fit With Nets, Is Cut
description: The basketball journey of Kenny Smith from Archbishop Molloy High School in Queens to the University of North Carolina to a high point of back-to-back National Basketball Association championships with the Houston Rockets -- may have come to an end this morning, when Nets Coach John Calipari told the 32-year-old guard that he had been waived.

title: By the Book; The Dance of the Vegetables
description: Joost Elffers may not stand convention on its head, but he comes close. Just look at his sideways take on the jack-o'-lantern, below: by letting the pumpkin stem be the nose, he transforms the traditional, simple-minded smiling face into one filled with expressive possibilities -- funny, threatening, worried, guilty. Mr. Elffers, a creator of illustrated books, applies the same sensibility to the rest of the produce section in ''Play With Your Food'' (Stewart Tabori & Chang, $19.95). With 109 pages of color photographs, the book first amuses, then challenges the imagination and gives the how-to's for green-pepper goblins, navel orange cats, pear dogs and mice, bell pepper rabbits, yam pigs and mushroom men, to name a few creatures in this irresistibly whimsical menagerie. FLORENCE FABRICANT

title: Nationwide Considers a Shift
description: Nationwide Insurance Enterprise has placed in review its Nationwide insurance account, which has been handled by Ketchum Advertising Pittsburgh since 1991. Billings were estimated at $22 million.

title: Britain Opens Trial Process in Libya Case to U.N.
description: In an effort to defuse Arab and African criticism that two Libyans wanted for trial in the bombing of a Pan Am jet over Scotland would not get a fair trial there, the British Government today opened the Scottish legal system to inspection by three international organizations.

title: Candidates' Own Taxes Tell a Story in Nassau Race
description: Nassau County residents pay what critics say is among the heaviest local tax burdens in the nation, and as the current campaign for county executive enters its finale, taxes loom as the paramount issue.

title: Wall Street Sneezes and the Russians Catch a Chill
description: During Soviet days, a stock-market plunge in the West would have been cause for rejoicing in the Kremlin.

title: As Casino Inquiry Intensifies, A Friendship Is Ripped Apart
description: In the fall of 1962, Bruce Babbitt met Paul Eckstein. They were first-year students at Harvard Law School and had much in common. Both were from Arizona, and both were stellar students. Mr. Babbitt had graduated from Notre Dame University and spent two years studying in England on a prestigious scholarship. Mr. Eckstein had been Phi Beta Kappa at Pomona College in California.

title: MONSANTO AND MILLENNIUM IN RESEARCH PACT
description: The Monsanto Company will pay Millennium Pharmaceuticals Inc. at least $118 million under a five-year deal that was announced yesterday. Monsanto, based in St. Louis, makes agricultural and pharmaceutical products. Millennium, based in Cambridge, Mass., is a biotechnology company. The companies will work together to discover and develop genetically engineered treatments for plants and agriculture products. Shares of Millennium rose 50 cents, to $20.3125, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Monsanto rose $4.3125, to $42.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: J. P. Morgan Ate Here

title: Candidates for Executive Argue on Integrity Issue
description: For weeks, the Republican candidate for Westchester county executive, Ted Dunn, has been questioning the integrity of his Democratic opponent, Andrew J. Spano.

title: N.B.A. PREVIEW '97-'98: End of Line for Dynasty?; Aging Bulls to Face Challenge From Several Teams
description: Maybe it's heresy. He has made every clutch shot he has taken in the 1990's, so what's to stop him now? Maybe it's crazy. They are still the most mature, savvy and championship-tested team.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESLER, JAY KNIGHT
description: ESLER-Jay Knight. On October 24, 1997 in Tucson, Arizona. Born in New Yirk City in 1922, he attended Hamilton College and was a graduate of Northwestern University. He is survived by his wife Miriam, daughter Lee Rhodes, son Jay Esler, sister Jura Hill, step daughters, Claudia Martens, Merrill Wheaton, Sarah Wheaton and four grandchildren.

title: Prisoner's Isolation Is Extreme Punishment; Literary Cause Celebre?
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Chain
description: Fine Finnan Haddie?

title: CAMERON ASHLEY WON'T PROCEED WITH BRADCO PURCHASE
description: Cameron Ashley Building Products Inc. said yesterday that it would not proceed with its proposed $140 million purchase of the closely held Bradco Supply Corporation after the building-products companies failed to reach a definitive accord. The agreement, disclosed on Oct. 3, would have made Dallas-based Cameron Ashley the third-largest building-products distributor in North America behind the Georgia-Pacific Corporation and the Weyerhaeuser Company. Cameron Ashley sells its products to builders, contractors and retailers in the United States and Canada. Cameron Ashley shares were unchanged, at $17.875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Design for Folk Museum Points to the Future by Honoring the Past
description: The Museum of American Folk Art has commissioned the New York architectural firm Tod Williams, Billie Tsien & Associates to design its long-awaited new building on West 53d Street in Manhattan, next door to the Museum of Modern Art. The new museum, which is expected to open in the spring of 2000, will contain 12,500 square feet of gallery space. The museum will continue to present shows at the Eva and Morris Feld Gallery, its current home near Lincoln Center.

title: Composer and Orchestra Play to a Draw
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra played a peculiarly frustrating concert at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening. With Franz Welser-Most on the podium, the orchestra sometimes played stunningly and sometimes was so lackluster that it was difficult to believe this was the Philadelphia.

title: Of Madness and the Absence of Music
description: The Limon Dance Company has revived ''Carlota,'' Jose Limon's last work. Created shortly before his death in 1972, it depicts the fantasies of the Empress Carlota, who went insane after her husband Maximilian, Emperor of Mexico, was assassinated in 1867.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VOLPE, LINDA
description: VOLPE-Linda. My dearest daughter, I miss you so much. Love Mommy

title: A Post-Punk Band a Decade Later
description: The latest wave of British bands is known for stealing from its 1960's predecessors, but the other night at Roseland, a more immediate mother lode was revealed. Echo and the Bunnymen, leaders in the early-80's romanticization of punk that became New Wave, returned after a decadelong sabbatical to claim their legacy.

title: Lordly Library Serves Commoners, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chef
description: WHEN I set out to roast a turkey in the fall, especially at Thanksgiving, I'll often choose a wild turkey. It's actually a separate species from the domestic bird we know, and it's not terribly wild: the birds available to us are free-range and farm-raised, not hunted. Wild turkeys are smaller, leaner, with denser flesh and an enticingly sweet gaminess. The leanness means they cook faster and can be dry if overdone. I like to rub a great deal of butter on the bird before roasting and baste it often during cooking to keep it moist and tender.

title: Moe Is Ready For Comeback
description: Tommy Moe, the gold medalist in the men's downhill at the 1994 Winter Olympics, was finishing his shift as a celebrity bartender in Kitzbuhel, Austria, last January when he vaulted over the bar with one hand, just as Tom Cruise did in the movie ''Cocktail.''

title: Daily News Picks First Woman Top Editor
description: Debby Krenek, a 41-year-old Texas native who came to The Daily News a decade ago and rose steadily through the ranks, was named editor in chief of the newspaper yesterday. She is the first woman in its 77-year history to be given the top newsroom position.

title: Further Swiss Bank Lists Fail to Calm Uproar
description: It is now well over a year since the ghosts of Switzerland's wartime dealings with Nazi Germany rose up to strip this land of an image that mixed financial probity and political neutrality, chocolate-box landscapes and ingenious watchmakers.

title: Personal Shopper; Fanciful Fabrics To Drape, Sew or Scrunch
description: WHAT would happen if the New York decorator Mario Buatta, famous for his way with chintz, found himself with a handful of some of this season's new fabrics -- leather lace, iridescent draperies stiffened with shimmering metallic threads, and sheers with intriguing bits and pieces hanging off them?

title: Senate Nears Debate in a Fight Over 'Activism' and the Judiciary
description: Conservative Republican senators who complain that President Clinton has been trying to fill the bench with liberal activists opened the way today for a full floor debate on the issue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICE, JAMES P.
description: RICE-James P. of Chicago, Illinois. It is with deep sadness that the Jewish Federation/Jewish United Fund of Metropolitan Chicago mourns the passing of James P. Rice, who died on October 25, 1997. He was an internationally renowned authority on immigration whose critical work had a profound impact on the lives of Jewish refugees after World War II and beyond. From 1966 to 1979, he served as Executive Vice President of the Jewish Federation. Under his leadership, the Federation underwent a major merger and reorganization to expand and more effectively serve people in need. In 1985, Mr. Rice received the Julius Rosenwald Memorial Award, the Jewish Federation's highest honor. His entire professional career was devoted to assisting the less fortunate. His wisdom, leadership, dedication and friendship will be missed. Barbara Hochberg, Chairman of the Board Steven B. Nasatir, President

title: Uncool Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Oct. 21 and Oct. 24 about the Thai economy misstated one effect of the recent downturn there. Many Thai finance companies, but none of its banks, have collapsed recently.

title: Giants Run Deep in the Backfield
description: The player who began the season as the Giants' starting running back, Tiki Barber, was again carrying the football with the first unit in practice today. Also on the field was Charles Way, who is officially the team's fullback but who has filled a variety of backfield roles and is the team's top rusher after nine games.

title: Female Refs Say They Owe Their Jobs to Their Ability
description: First, there was Commissioner David Stern sending accusations at the players association's executive director, Billy Hunter. Then there were two female officials on the cusp of making history.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-21

title: PNC Bank to Buy 4.9% of a Brokerage Firm
description: The PNC Bank Corporation is buying 4.9 percent of an institutional brokerage firm for about $45 million, people involved with the negotiations said yesterday.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Man Who Shot Trooper Dies
description: A 29-year-old man who killed a state trooper Friday and then shot himself died from his wounds yesterday at Morristown Memorial Hospital, the state police said.

title: Three Aphorism Shows Are Better Than One
description: It looks like Santa is getting a full body wax.

title: Residential Resales
description: Manhattan

title: The Short Sweet Life Of Peanut the Elephant
description: AT Jewell and David Brain's booth at the 1997 Atlantique City Holiday Fair, the talk wasn't cheap.

title: National News Briefs; 2 Lawyers to Be Retried In Drug-Related Case
description: Federal prosecutors said today that they planned to retry a former Justice Department official and a former Federal prosecutor after a jury deadlocked on four drug-related charges stemming from the former officials' representation of the leaders of a Colombian drug cartel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDERSON, JAMES W. JR.
description: ANDERSON-James W. Jr. Of N.Y.C., on September 25, 1997. Dear brother of Violet Murray. Funeral mass 9:45AM Friday, October 31, 1997, Our Lady of Mt. Carmel R.C. Church, Patchogue, L.I. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. For information: the Massapequa Funeral Home Inc.

title: Study Discounts DDT Role in Breast Cancer
description: Challenging the convictions of many advocates for patients, a large study has found no evidence that exposure to the chemicals DDT and PCB's increases the risk of breast cancer.

title: Public Eye; Screens swarm with logos, crawls and tickers as TV chases the Internet
description: ''JUST surf until you find the screen with all the stuff on it,'' trumpet the ads on Bloomberg Radio to promote Bloomberg Television. On Bloomberg's television news channel, the words and numbers fairly hum.

title: Metro Business; Capstar Plans to Sell 11 Radio Stations
description: Capstar Broadcasting Partners said yesterday that it was putting 11 radio stations in Connecticut and New York up for sale to comply with Federal ownership limits.

title: At Home With; A Hardy Perennial, Her Passions Still Blooming
description: WHEN Henry Kravis and Carolyne Roehm separated in 1993, her mother said, ''Now you'll know who your friends are.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDEGGER, CARL M.
description: LANDEGGER-Carl M., 44. Of New York City, died at his home Tuesday of a heart attack. Born in Manila, Philippines, on May 17, 1953, he resided in New York City most of his life. Mr. Landegger was the president of The Black Clawson Company, a global supplier of capital machinery for the paper and converting industry. Through his work Mr. Landegger travelled throughout the world, including South America, Europe and Asia. Surviving him are his children Carl F. and Camila of Edison, NJ, his wife Sandra Landegger of Edison, New Jersey and his parents Carl C. Landegger and Cecilia Elizalde Landegger, both of New York City. Services will be Saturday, November 1, at 10 AM at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave. and 84th St. In lieu of flowers donations should be made to The Heart Association, 122 East 42nd St, NYC.

title: A Feel for Siberia And Walden Pond; A Russian at Home in Hollywood
description: The film director who dared to bring Homer's ''Odyssey'' to television has another epic project in mind: Henry David Thoreau.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIDESTRI, DR. JOSEPH C.
description: LIDESTRI-Dr. Joseph C. Suddenly on Oct. 25, 1997, age 69, of Bayville, LI. Beloved husband of Paula I. Loving father of Marybeth Tully (Gerard), Joseph P., and Paula A. Cherished grandfather of Kristin, Gerard, Brendan and Claire. Dear brother of Sylvia Cafaro (Nicholas). Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Visiting Oyster Bay Funeral Home, 261 South Street, Oyster Bay, Long Island; Friday 3-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass, St. Gertrude R.C. Church, Bayville, Long Island, Saturday 10AM. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Pediatric Diabetes Education Center at North Shore University Hospital, 300 Community Dr., Manhasset, NY 11030, Attn: J. Corrigan would be appreciated.

title: Uncool Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Three Arrested in Death
description: Three gang members were charged Tuesday in the fatal stabbing of a man whose body was found Sunday morning in a wooded area of a Jersey City park, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: When Collaboration Weaves Its Own Magic
description: Some singers in recital prefer pianists who can accurately be called accompanists. But the singers who are the most interesting musicians want pianists who are full partners with strong profiles of their own.

title: A Cleopatra More Rowdy Than Regal
description: Let it not be forgotten that Cleopatra, that temptress of infinite variety, had her athletic side. In the famous passage describing the Queen of the Nile on her gilded barge in Shakespeare's ''Antony and Cleopatra,'' the usually cynical soldier Enobarbus may rhapsodize about her Venus-like presence. But he also observes, with equal astonishment, that he has seen this regal creature ''hop forty paces through the public street.''

title: Nets: Stay Tuned for Excitement
description: No matter how the Nets fare this season, they are a different team than the one John Calipari inherited a year ago in his first season as a professional coach.

title: In America; China's Missing Girls
description: There has never been the kind of international outcry that there should be over the girls who are missing from the population of China. The world has largely closed its eyes to this immense tragedy.

title: Fidelity Records Incorrect Prices For 18 Funds
description: After being whipsawed by two days of market turmoil, millions of mutual fund investors picked up their daily newspapers yesterday to check the value of their holdings. They found no prices for hundreds of mutual funds managed by more than a dozen companies. And, even more troubling, they saw incorrect prices for 18 funds managed by Fidelity Investments.

title: Search Expands for the Sex Partners of a Man Accused of Spreading H.I.V.
description: As health investigators in New York City and upstate Chautauqua County searched yesterday for the sex partners of a man accused of infecting at least 10 people with H.I.V., officials here conceded that he almost certainly had sex with more women -- and perhaps dozens more -- than the 28 they were aware of in western New York.

title: Turf; Cleaning Out Those Pesky Old Poltergeists in the Closets
description: SUNSHINE EAGLE, her face as strong as Georgia O'Keeffe's, gently shook her waist-length black hair and demonstrated how to exorcise evil spirits from a client's apartment, a ritual that she says she has performed dozens of times.

title: Bridge; A U.S. Team Beats Another In Event's Biggest Swing
description: The defending champions scored a big victory in the semifinal of the Bermuda Bowl world team championship here today. Nick Nickell of Manhattan; Dick Freeman of Atlanta; Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla.; Eric Rodwell of Naperville, Fla., and Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman, both of Dallas, won by 119 against a rival American team led by Seymon Deutsch of Laredo, Tex.

title: Investigation of Americorps Head Is Kept Secret
description: Government officials said today that an independent prosecutor had been secretly appointed last fall, at Attorney General Janet Reno's request, to investigate Eli J. Segal, the former head of President Clinton's national service organization.

title: In Apocalypse Myth, Devil Is in the Details; Death and Arcadia
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Have a yen to see a building designed by JUAN PABLO MOLYNEUX, the Chilean-born interior designer who has done a number of New York's more luxurious residences? Stroll by Revillon, the fur shop on Fifth Avenue at 56th Street. In the front window sits a miniature Palladian hall with a dome and columns that could, if augmented with living wings, be transformed into a palatial home, Mr. Molyneux said this week.

title: A Too-Powerful I.R.S.
description: Congress has made a commendable start to reform the Internal Revenue Service, but it hasn't addressed one of the real problems: the fact that I.R.S. agents have the power to seize property without due process. No courts, no judges, no lawyers.

title: Excerpts From Greenspan's Testimony
description: Following are excerpts from testimony yesterday by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress:

title: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: PROFILE -- Politics as Lifelong Passion; McGreevey of New Jersey Is a Relentless Competitor
description: He used to shed his suits on weekends, strap a canoe to his car and head to the Delaware River, where a gentle landscape and the company of friends distracted James Edward McGreevey, ever so briefly, from his ambitions.

title: One Woman Takes on the Music of Miles
description: THE SINGER CASSANDRA WILSON STANDS in a darkened recording booth, cigarette in one hand, charts strewn at her feet. A photo of her late father nestles among a few votive candles. Their flickering light illuminates her face, which is framed by her golden brown dredlocks and halo-like headphones. After a run-through of one of her new compositions, she addresses the drummer. ''I dont want you to mark time so much as I want you to mark groove,'' she says. The band launches into the song again, a typically spare arrangement, and when it is finished, the drummer stands up and thanks Ms. Wilson for her direction.

title: Market Place: Cultivating Conagra; Agribusiness Giant Seeks Balance Between Freedom And Cooperation for Units
description: Five years ago, soon after Philip B. Fletcher took over the reins at Conagra Inc., he brought the purchasing managers of about 20 divisions together at the agribusiness empire's headquarters in Omaha. Your assignment, he told them, is to figure out how to cooperate in ordering packaging materials so that Conagra can buy in bulk.

title: Baseball's Success Depends on Free Agency
description: To the Editor:

title: Council Votes To Continue Curb on Vans
description: Drivers of private commuter vans -- and their champion, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- were dealt a setback yesterday when the City Council narrowly voted to continue a ban on new licenses for the vans. The ban, which the Mayor had vetoed on Oct. 10, will remain in effect for up to a year or until the administration submits a citywide study to the Council on where the vans should be allowed to operate.

title: Baby Dies After Birth At Home of Mother, 18
description: A baby girl died shortly after she was born on Tuesday in the home of her 18-year-old mother in Jackson Heights, Queens, the police said.

title: Metro Business; Interactive Data to Move
description: The Interactive Data Corporation, a unit of Pearson P.L.C., which publishes The Financial Times newspaper, has agreed to lease three floors encompassing 58,000 square feet of space at 100 William Street, at the intersection of John Street.

title: In Apocalypse Myth, Devil Is in the Details
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENE, RICHARD
description: GREENE-Richard. Oct. 30, 1992. ''From quiet houses and first beginning/Out to the undiscovered ends/There's nothing worth the wear of winning/But laughter and the love of friends.'' I miss you. Rene

title: Olivetti and Wang in Talks on Unit Merger
description: Olivetti S.p.A., the Italian office products and telecommunications company, and Wang Laboratories Inc., the American computer services company, said today that they were talking about merging Olivetti's Olsy computer systems and services unit with Wang's operations.

title: Both Sides Manipulate Data to Fit
description: In last night's final debate of the mayoral campaign, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger showed off the wiles of political oratory, the timeless art of trying to pummel an opponent with facts that have been stripped of their contexts, nuances and caveats.

title: Mercedes-Benz to Correct Design Problem in New Small Cars
description: Mercedes-Benz said today that it would spend 100 million marks, or $57 million, a year to install electronic equipment on its new A-class subcompact cars to correct a design problem that caused one car to flip in a test.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In our country I think it would amaze many of our Chinese guests to see some of the things that have been written and said about me - my family - our government, our policies. And yet after all this time I'm still standing here, and our country is stronger than it was before those words were uttered six years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEENEY, WILLIAM J., III
description: SWEENEY-William J., III. The Council and Fellows of the New York Obstetrical Society record with profound regret the death of their Life Fellow, Dr. William J. Sweeney, III, on October 23, 1997. David Rosenfeld, MD, President Richard L. Berkowitz, MD, Secretary

title: Sports of The Times; The Bronx Could Calm These Egos
description: AH, the Yankees, the island of peace -- for today's baseball managers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, CAROL S.
description: LEVY-Carol S. On October 29, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Edgar I. Levy. Devoted mother of Liza Levy, Angela Carroll and Kristin Lizotte. Cherished grandmother of Jacklyn, Jennifer and Adam. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 2 at 4 PM at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81st St. Contributions may be made in her name to The Education Action Fund, C/O Jonathan Kozol, POB 145, Byfield, MA. 01922 or a charity of your choice.

title: World's Best Players Will Meet More Often
description: In a development that will dramatically change the worldwide landscape of men's professional golf, three new international tournaments will debut in 1999, featuring the world's top players competing in match play and stroke play for multimillion-dollar purses.

title: U.S. Drug Chief Tells Senators Mexico Merits Help, Not Criticism
description: The White House's drug policy director, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, argued today before sometimes skeptical Senators that the best hope of stopping illegal drugs from crossing the southwestern border lies in helping Mexico reform its corrupt police and weak legal systems, rather than merely criticizing their flaws.

title: White House Is Cooperating, Committee Is Told
description: White House lawyers insisted to skeptical Senate investigators today that they had cooperated fully with the campaign finance inquiry and had turned over all documents and videotapes as soon as they had been found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENSON, JOHN R.
description: STEVENSON-John R. The Council on Ocean Law notes with sadness the death of its longtime Board Member, John R. Stevenson, on October 25, in Fort Worth, Texas. Ambassador Stevenson was the first Chairman of the American delegation to The Law of the Sea Conference and will be missed by professional colleagues in that endeavor around the world who respected his leadership and dedication. We extend our sympathy to his wife, Ruth, and to his children and grandchildren. Elliot L. Richardson, Chairman Christian A. Herter, Jr. Margaret L. Tomlinson, Vice-Chairmen

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK
description: ORIOLES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABINOWITZ, MARGARET
description: RABINOWITZ-Margaret. October 26, of Woodland Hills, CA, formerly Riverdale, NY. Beloved wife of the late Samuel Rabinowitz, devoted mother of Joshua Rabinowitz and Racquel Skolnik, loving grandmother, great-grandmother. Committed and active member of the Brotherhood Synagogue of Gramercy Park, and the Eastern Star. Funeral Oct. 30, 10 AM, Mt. Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: CCL INDUSTRIES OF TORONTO TO BUY TELEDYNE PACKAGING
description: Allegheny Teledyne Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its packaging unit to CCL Industries Inc., a Canadian supplier of packaging materials and services, for about $31 million. Allegheny Teledyne, based in Pittsburgh, is a group of technology-based manufacturing companies concentrating in metals, aerospace and electronics, industrial and consumer products.
