The unit, Teledyne Packaging, is one of eight nonstrategic businesses Allegheny Teledyne said earlier this year it planned to sell. Teledyne Packaging, with annual revenue of $40 million, makes collapsible metal and laminate tubes. CCL Industries is based in Toronto.

title: Stocks Mixed As Volatility Seems to Ease
description: A day after one of the biggest stock market rallies in history, and two days after one of the biggest selloffs, Wall Street calmed down a bit yesterday, ending with mixed results despite continued heavy trading volume.

title: Robert Cahn, 80, Leading Writer And U.S. Aide on Environment
description: Robert Cahn, a prominent environmental journalist whose influence spanned more than three decades, died last Friday at his home in Boulder, Colo. He was 80.

title: INSIDE
description: The City Council has continued its ban on new licenses for commuter vans.

title: Humor in a McGreevey Attack
description: James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate for governor, recently released the following 30-second television advertisement criticizing his opponent, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: CHRONICLE
description: IRENE SAEZ, Miss Universe 1981 and Mayor of Chacao, a wealthy borough in Caracas, Venezuela, has issued a ban on passionate kissing in public, Agence France-Presse reported yesterday.

title: Giuliani Shrugs Off Messinger's Attacks in Debate
description: Ruth W. Messinger used her final joint television appearance with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani last night to repeatedly bludgeon his first-term record, blaming him for a ''crisis'' in city schools and for high unemployment that she warned signaled dark times ahead.

title: Child Welfare Doesn't Belong in Police Hands; Prosecutions Are Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Has Helped Stabilize the Budget, but Avoided a Promised Overhaul
description: When Rudolph W. Giuliani was a candidate in 1993, he pledged to take a scalpel to New York City's budget, cutting spending, taxes and the work force, all in a crusade to end chronic deficits and rouse a local economy that had been thrashed by the recession. He vowed, in short, to administer a dose of hard-nosed fiscal conservatism to one of the most expansive governments in the nation.

title: Silicon Graphics Will Look for New Chief
description: Silicon Graphics Inc., which has been struggling to deliver consistent profitability, said today that Edward R. McCracken, its chairman and chief executive, would step down as chief executive as soon as a successor could be found.

title: Glass Maker Is Cutting 6,000 Jobs
description: Pilkington P.L.C., the maker of flat and safety glass, said yesterday that it would cut 6,000 jobs by March 1999 and take a charge of about $:200 million ($335 million) for a reorganization intended to make the company more competitive.

title: Male Chromosome Finds Work
description: In each of her cells, a woman has 22 pairs of chromosomes, plus two X chromosomes, while a man has 22 pairs plus an X and a Y. Until recently it was thought that the Y chromosome, which determines maleness, was, by the hard-working standards of the X chromosome, a loutish underachiever, with a mere eight genes. Certainly, in a karyotype -- a kind of chromosomal family portrait -- the Y chromosome looks sullen and uncommunicative, a dab of DNA resembling a two-legged bowling pin. But now, the journal Science reports, two biologists at the Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, Mass., have discovered that the male or Y chromosome has 20 genes, not 8 -- a far cry from the thousands on other chromosomes but more enterprising than once supposed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEDGE, SONIA R.
description: WEDGE-Sonia R. Longtime member of the New York Botanical Garden library staff, in her 96th year. Widow of the late New York Sun writer, Will Wedge. Loving mother of Eleanor and Nicholas Wedge; grandmother of Catherine Miranker, Elizabeth Wedge, and William T. Wedge; great grandmother of Emily and Mollie Miranker. Graveside service Monday, November 3, at 2PM, Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Contributions to the NY Botanical Garden Library in her memory welcome.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; The Latest Interpretations of Berio
description: Luciano Berio's visit to New York City last week coincided more or less with the release of several new recordings of his music. There are still important gaps. None of his operas, for instance, have ever come out on record, and some older recordings, often made by the performers for whom the works were written, are out of print.

title: CARIBINER AGREES TO ACQUIRE VISUAL ACTION OF LONDON
description: Caribiner International Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Visual Action Holdings P.L.C. for $:148 million ($247 million) in cash to expand its business of renting audio-visual equipment into overseas markets for the first time. New York-based Caribiner, which will pay $:2.95 ($4.89) a share for Visual Action, organizes corporate meetings, events and training programs. The company said the acquisition would allow it to broaden its audio-visual business in the United States and gets the company into the British market. London-based Visual Action had revenue of $157.5 million last year. Shares of Caribiner rose $4, to a 52-week high of $45.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZ, RICHARD E.
description: METZ-Richard E. On October 26, 1997, in New York, age 85. Beloved husband of Gurdon (Howells), dear brother of Eugene and devoted grandfather of Vittorio Cottafavi. Services to be at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, 11 A.M., Friday, October 31. Please, no flowers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TALLER, STEPHEN LEE, M.D.
description: TALLER-Stephen Lee, M.D. Died Oct. 27, 1997 of pancreatic cancer. Dr. Taller was born May 4, 1933, son of Gladys and Alex Taller. Raised in Manhattan, he graduated from Bronx High School of Science, Oberlin College, and received his M.D. at N.Y.U. In 1963 Dr. Taller moved with his family to Berkeley, California. In 1965 he joined the Kaiser Permanente Medical Group in Oakland where he practiced Internal Medicine until retirement in February 1995. He was a driving force behind several groundbreaking programs developing innovative solutions for the delivery of health care. Dr. Taller was actively involved in the social and political life of the community, supporting a wide array of progressive, Jewish and civil libertarian causes. Dr. Taller's passion for the last 16 years was his work on the Stephen Lee Taller Ben Shahn Archive, a unique collection of graphic works, printed materials, and data base of the American social realist artist Ben Shahn. Beginning in 1999 the Archive will be housed at Harvard University. Dr. Taller is survived by Dolores Shedroff Taller his wife of 41 years, two sons, Eric and Michael, daughter-in-law, Julie Saxe, and sister Ruth Taller. Memorial gifts may be made to the American Civil Liberties Union, 132 West 43rd St., New York, NY 10036 or to Action on Smoking and Health, 2013 H St., Washington, D.C. 20006.

title: S.E.C. Schedules a Meeting As Small-Stock Fraud Soars
description: Federal regulators are turning up the heat on some of Wall Street's biggest firms in an effort to prevent some small brokerage operations from defrauding investors who trade in the stocks of tiny companies.

title: Marian Koshland, 76, Expert On How Antibodies Fight Ills
description: Marian E. Koshland, an immunologist and professor of molecular and cell biology at the University of California at Berkeley who studied the ways antibodies fight off disease, died on Tuesday at Alta Bates Medical Center in Berkeley. She was 76 and lived in Lafayette, Calif.

title: Democrats' Big Debt Hurts Effort In 3 Races
description: The Democratic National Committee's huge debt stemming from the 1996 campaign is taking a toll on its ability to help state and local candidates compete with Republicans in three big races that will be decided next Tuesday.

title: SHARES OF COMSTOCK RISE ON GULF OF MEXICO INVESTMENT
description: The stock of Comstock Resources Inc. rose 22 percent yesterday after the company said its $205 million purchase of interests in Gulf of Mexico oil operations would increase oil and natural gas reserves, production and earnings. Shares of the Dallas-based energy company rose $2.9375, to $15.75. Comstock agreed on Tuesday to buy wells and properties in the Gulf of Mexico from closely held Bois d'Arc Resources, based in Seattle and Houston, for $205 million in cash. The purchase, its largest ever, is expected to increase Comstock's per share earnings 20 percent to 25 percent and its revenue and cash flow by about 70 percent each in 1998, said Roland Burns, Comstock chief financial officer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANEK, BESSIE
description: GANEK-Bessie. The leadership and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Bessie Ganek, a beloved mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother. Her son, Howard Ganek, is a dedicated leader and generous supporter of our Wall Street Division as a member of the Neuberger & Berman UJA-Federation Campaign Committee, and as an officer of the Educational Alliance and the Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care and Rehabilitation, both UJA-Federation beneficiaries. The entire Jewish community is indebted to the family for its dedication and support, and extends its sincerest condolences. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: Rethinking Circuit Breakers After Monday's Big Plunge
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Arthur Levitt Jr., said today that trading may have been needlessly halted during Monday's market slide and that changes may be needed in the braking devices, known as circuit breakers.

title: U.S. and China Reach Trade Pacts but Clash on Rights
description: President Clinton and the Chinese President, Jiang Zemin, engaged in a day of unexpectedly contentious talks today that produced several significant commercial agreements but appeared to broaden the gulf between the two powers on human rights.

title: For the American Astronaut, One Bad Moment Aboard Mir
description: The American astronaut Michael Foale said today that most of his stay aboard the troubled Russian space station Mir was worthwhile and enjoyable, but that for a brief moment he feared for his life when a runaway cargo vessel struck the orbiting outpost.

title: For China's Visiting President, Forecast in New York Is Chilly
description: Instead of the 21-gun salutes and warm official handshakes that have greeted him so far on his state visit, President Jiang Zemin of China can expect a chilly reception in New York this evening. Neither Governor George E. Pataki nor Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to greet him on his arrival or to attend a reception for him at the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow evening.

title: Education Report Faults Tenure For Principals of Failing Schools
description: Reading scores at Junior High School 275 in Brooklyn plummeted 21.5 points from 1991 to 1996 -- 8.3 points in 1996 alone. Yet last spring, the principal, Priscilla Williams, was granted tenure by the local superintendent, over the objections of parents and the local school board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSON, MARTHA
description: GERSON-Martha. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Martha Gerson, beloved Mother of our devoted Members Marcelle and Sam Faust. Sincere condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Figs Show Toughness

title: 94 Names on the Board
description: A total of 94 horses were pre-entered yesterday in the seven races of the 14th Breeders' Cup championships, which will be run two weeks from Saturday at Hollywood Park in California with $11 million in purses and the title Horse of the Year at stake.

title: Paul Jarrico, 82, Blacklisted Screenwriter
description: Paul Jarrico, a screenwriter and producer whose blacklisted status in the 1950's limited the distribution of the film ''Salt of the Earth'' until its release on videocassette three decades later, died on Tuesday in a car accident in California. He was 82 and lived in Ojai, Calif.

title: Board Finds $70 Million and Plans to Spend It on Schools
description: The Board of Education has discovered $70 million left over from last year's schools budget and officials said yesterday that they intended to pass on almost all of the money to the city's schools to help reduce class sizes, buy supplies and hire reading tutors.

title: Senate Approves New F.C.C. Chairman
description: The Senate gave approval today to President Clinton's choice to fill the top post at the Federal Communications Commission, but lawmakers vowed to keep a close eye on the agency as it continues pressing for competition in the telecommunications industry.

title: Fresh and Familiar Faces in Poland's New Center-Right Cabinet
description: Combining some familiar old faces and some unknown new ones, Prime Minister Jerzy Buzek announced the new Cabinet of his center-right Polish Government today, more than a month after elections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, BERTHA
description: COHEN-Bertha. Beloved wife of David. Cherished mother of Barbara and Richard. Devoted grandmother of Donna, Jill, Stephen and Cristina. Services Friday, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SREBNIK, MARTIN
description: SREBNIK-Martin. On October 27, 1997. Beloved husband of Marcia, loving father of Patricia Towbin and father-in-law of Jeffrey Towbin, cherished grandfather to Jennifer and Sara. Services Thursday 11 A.M., at Cedar Park Cemetery.

title: From Gleeful to Motherly and Back Again
description: ''This is a life experience,'' one Patti Smith fan enthused as the queen of New York rock began the first of four performances at CBGB's Tuesday night. Three hours later, Ms. Smith conceded, ''I've tried my best to make this night a living hell -- of Dante-esque proportions.'' Her return to the cramped East Village club where she first surfaced 20 years ago veered between those two extremes, traveling the seven circles of Ms. Smith's exasperating, inspirational art.

title: 2 U.S. Reports Add to Evidence of Minimal Inflation
description: Orders for long-lasting goods fell in September for the first time in three months, the Commerce Department said today in a report that suggested that American industrial activity might be slowing.

title: E.D.S. Earnings Decline 7.4%
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said today that third-quarter earnings fell 7.4 percent as costs rose 5 percent and revenue growth slowed. It was the third consecutive quarter of lower profit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVER, GEORGE
description: SILVER-George. Co-Founder of Jasco Fabrics, Inc. He will be remembered as a man of innovation and integrity who was a leader in business and in his community. His generosity of spirit and enthusiasm for new creative talent made a lasting impact on the history of the American fashion industry. In his lifetime he was honored by UJA Federation of New York, Riverdale Jewish Center and the American Committee for Shenkar College. Devoted, loving and adoring husband, father and grandfather, he was married for 51 years to the late Mollie Silver and is survived by his son and daughter-in-law Howard and Maida Silver and his grandsons Daniel and Rafi. He will be sorely missed. Services Thursday, 12 PM, Plaza Funeral Home, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: McGreevey Visits Factories, Stressing Working Class Roots
description: State Senator James E. McGreevey spent today visiting factories and diners in his home territory of northern New Jersey, asking working class voters to help spread his message in the final days of his campaign for governor.

title: GARTNER ACQUIRES 32% STAKE IN JUPITER COMMUNICATIONS
description: The Gartner Group Inc. said yesterday that it had bought a 32 percent stake in the privately held Internet market research firm Jupiter Communications L.L.C. for $8 million. Founded in 1986, New York-based Jupiter Communications provides analysis and strategic planning consulting to the consumer Internet market. The companies said there would be no changes to Jupiter's management. Gartner Group, based in Stamford, Conn., provides information technology advisory services, measurement, research, consulting and training.

title: After Childhood of Violence, A One-Man H.I.V. Epidemic
description: Nushawn J. Williams, a Brooklyn neighbor put it with plain-spoken certainty, was ''running wild from Day 1.''

title: Corrections
description: The mutual fund table yesterday included erroneous data for some funds managed by Fidelity Investments. A corrected chart appears today on page D2, and a related article appears on page 1 of Business Day.

title: Merrill Chief Calls for Change
description: David H. Komansky, the chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch & Company, said in an interview yesterday that this week's unprecedented volatility and volume in stock trading was ''a wake up call'' to his firm and Wall Street to pay more attention to trading and settlement systems.

title: Merchants Sell Alcohol To Teen-Agers in Sting
description: Teen-agers who did not disguise their age and presented driver's licenses clearly bearing the stamp ''Under 21'' were sold alcohol by nearly half of the merchants selected in an undercover operation, the Westchester District Attorney announced yesterday.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Corps to Keep Deadline
description: Army Corps of Engineers officials assured members of the New Jersey Congressional delegation yesterday that they would be able to meet -- and possibly beat -- a deadline for cleaning up radioactive thorium waste in Wayne and Maywood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEESON, LAURA
description: LEESON-Laura. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center (BIMC) family joins with the leadership of its parent corporation Greater Metropolitan Health Systems (GMHS), Inc., in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Laura Leeson, beloved sister of our dear friend and benefactor Abe Schrader, a member of the Beth Israel Board of Trustees for more than twentyfive years. To Abe, the Schrader and Leeson families and all who loved her, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, GMHS and BIMC Robert G. Newman, M.D., President, GMHS Matthew E. Sink, M.D., President BIMC

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an agreement to settle a lawsuit filed against the The New York Times by a former Philadelphia prosecutor misspelled the name of a Times spokeswoman who commented. She is Heidi Pokorny, not Pokorney.

title: Orioles' Angelos Parries, As Davey Johnson Thrusts
description: The chances of Davey Johnson's remaining manager of the Baltimore Orioles seem to diminish every time he or the owner Peter Angelos comments on their differences. Yesterday, each man had a lot to say.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONE MILLS CORP., Greensboro, N.C., said it was considering the sale of its John Wolf fabrics division as part of a plan to expand its position as the biggest denim maker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIENENFELD, TESSIE
description: BIENENFELD-Tessie. Young Israel of Fifth Avenue mourns the death of the mother of our esteemed member, Audrey Wagner, and extends to her and the bereaved family our heartfelt condolences.

title: The Pop Life
description: Alternative And Long-Lived

title: It's Early, But Rangers Are Taking On Water
description: The level of local hockey drama intensifies on two fronts tonight when Mark Messier and his slumping Vancouver Canucks visit the Devils while Wayne Gretzky and his slumping Rangers visit the Islanders. It is the hockey equivalent of a stock market gyration or being hit in the noggin by a falling pane of heavy glass.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Tyson Breaks Ribs In Cycle Accident
description: Mike Tyson, the former world heavyweight boxing champion, fractured his ribs in a motorcycle accident last night on Interstate 84 in Manchester, Conn., and was listed in stable condition at Hartford Hospital, a hospital spokesman said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Remarks by Greenspan Soothe Shaken Markets

title: A Bittersweet Opening for a Jumper From New Jersey
description: With a jazzy trill of the ringmaster's horn, the National Horse Show unveiled its 114th edition last night at Madison Square Garden and Nona Garson, a New Jersey-born horsewoman who owns, rides and trains jumpers, got down to business.

title: Two Candidates Debate Schools, Crime and Yankee Stadium
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Ruth W. Messinger, the Democratic candidate for mayor, met for their second and final debate televised by WABC-TV last night. Following are excerpts from that debate.

title: Two commercials, meant only for Connecticut, run nationally and win praise for a small agency.
description: A SMALL agency is getting a big break as two of its commercials, originally intended to appear only in Connecticut, were seen nationally by the viewers of last night's episode of the CBS sitcom ''Murphy Brown.''

title: 24 Members of Crips Gang Are Arrested in a Sweep by Police
description: They were known for their blue bandannas and the crack they sold in little blue bags, and the police say the scores of young members of the Rollin' 30's Crips gang in Harlem threatened neighbors who wore red on the street and shot those who interfered in their drug trade.

title: California Auto Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Williams Rates Best in the A.L. For Outfielders
description: While the Yankees' center fielder emerged yesterday as the top-ranked outfielder in the American League, the center fielder of the archrival Baltimore Orioles emerged as one of the top rank of free agents the Yankees covet.

title: Design Notebook; Call It the 'E Pluribus Unum' Floor Plan
description: NEW YORK's trophy apartments -- the Village charmers with front-and-back fireplaces, the TriBeCa lofts with three exposures, the prewar dowagers with haughty architectural bones -- probably inspire more action-packed dinner party tales than big-game safaris ever did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTVILA, HALINA, DR.
description: MONTVILA-Halina, Dr. Dr. Halina Montvila of Manhattan who had been Vice President of Bradford Computer Systems and McDonald Douglass Corporation died on October 26, 1997 in Danbury, CT. She was 79. Dr. Halina Montvila was born in Panevezys, Lithuania and graduated from Vilnius University in 1938. She married George Montvila in 1939 and after the end of World War II immigrated to NY in 1949. She attended NYU and received a Master's Degree in mathematics in 1954. She received a Doctorate of Mathematics, Magna Cum Laude in 1959; specializing in numerical anaylsis and the application of computer systems in the solution of scientific endeavors. Her doctoral thesis involved the prediction of hurricanes at high altitudes. She was awarded the Founder's Day Award by NYU for outstanding and exemplary scholastic achievements. During her doctoral studies at NYU, she was one of the pioneering women to work with computer systems, notably the ENIAC series. She joined RCA Laboratories in 1958 and focused on the applications of computer systems for national defense efforts. She left RCA as a Chief Scientist in 1967. She joined Tracor Systems in 1967 and pursued the application of numerical anaylsis methods for various national defense efforts until 1969. She joined Bradford Computer Systems in 1969 and was elected Vice President in September 1973. While at Bradford she was involved in the application of computer systems for commercial and business applications. Principally, she oversaw activities to computerize NY Municipal and State Departments for Health and Human Services. Bradford Computer Systems was acquired by McDonald Douglass Corporation in 1981, where she continued as Vice President responsible for the application of computer systems for Puerto Rico's Health and Hospital Services. She retired in 1988. From 1988 to 1990 she continued as consultant for the McDonald Douglass Corporation. She is survived by her son Stephen of Brookfield, CT and grandchildren Darius and Andrius, of Cambridge, MA.

title: Princeton Favored For Ivy Title Again
description: Princeton will be the team to beat again, the Ivy League coaches agreed, one by one, yesterday at the league's preseason news conference at the Penn Club in Manhattan. Even the Tigers' coach, Bill Carmody, agreed.

title: Problems With Blockbuster Drag Viacom Profit Down
description: Viacom Inc. posted an 83 percent decline in profit from continuing operations for the third quarter yesterday as problems at its Blockbuster video chain offset higher earnings at its MTV and Nickelodeon cable channels.

title: A Chinese Visitor Comes Between Longtime California Allies
description: One woos. The other attacks.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Fifth Graders to Be Moved
description: Citing fears for the safety of 500 fifth graders at a troubled middle school, state officials yesterday ordered them removed from the school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINS, S. PETER
description: KAMINS-S. Peter. October 28, 1997 of Delray Beach, FL. Loving husband and best friend of Barbara. Adored father of Susan Seligman and Bobby (Ruth Anne) Kamins. Cherished grandfather of Andrew, Alex and Michael. Beloved brother of Elayne Haves and Rita Robert. Services Friday, 12:30PM at Boulevard Riverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett. For further information ''Gutterman-Warheit Mem. Chapel'', 800-992-9262.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GREENBERG, HERBERT
description: GREENBERG-Herbert. 10/30/89. We love you and miss you. Sylvia, Susan, Gwen

title: Interpublic Unit To Change Name
description: Draft Direct Worldwide, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, said yesterday that it would change its name to Draft Worldwide to reflect its recent expansion beyond direct marketing and into services like advertising and promotions.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Some Bus Service to Resume
description: Partial service will resume Monday for 4,000 commuters using Lakeland Bus Lines, company officials said yesterday. The bus line will hire temporary drivers to replace union workers who went on strike Tuesday, said Maureen Leo, a company vice president.

title: A Star's Sore Throat Suspends 'Side Show'
description: Tuesday evening's performance of ''Side Show,'' the new Broadway musical about Siamese-twin vaudeville performers, had to be canceled by producers when one of its stars became ill and further rehearsal was needed for the understudy and the show's co-star to practice its unusual and precisely choreographed dance sequences.

title: SEED GIANT PIONEER HI-BRED BUYS BACK 20% OF ITS STOCK
description: The seed giant Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. said yesterday that it had bought back 16.4 million shares, or about 20 percent of its stock, for $92.50 each. The purchases were made through a Dutch auction tender offer, under which shareholders of Pioneer specified the prices between $88 and $104 at which they were willing to sell shares; $92.50 was the price at which the company could acquire all the shares it wanted. The buyback followed Pioneer's sale last month of a 20 percent stake to DuPont for $1.7 billion. The company used proceeds from that sale for the buyback. Pioneer, based in Des Moines, had sales of $1.78 billion for the year that ended on Aug. 31. Its stock closed yesterday at $90.625, down $2.9375.

title: Inside the Heart of an Earth Mother
description: Certain songwriters demand of a performer nothing less than a go-for-broke immersion in the composer's private emotional world. And Laura Nyro, whose music was celebrated in a three-and-a-half-hour memorial concert at the Beacon Theater on Monday evening, would have to lead the list. Ms. Nyro, who died of ovarian cancer this year at 49, virtually invented a ripped-from-the-soul, stream-of-conscious streetwise style that has inspired countless songwriters, from Rickie Lee Jones to Suzanne Vega to Tori Amos.

title: Jets, on a Roll, Confront Resurging Ravens
description: As the tied-for-first Jets gird for the start of the second half of the season on Sunday, the Baltimore Ravens are the opening obstacle.

title: The American Standard-Bearer Is Mark Coogan
description: Mark Coogan's final weekend of training before Sunday's New York City Marathon was complicated by the small interruption of 30 inches of snow dropping on the running trails of Boulder, Colo.

title: House Proud; To Get the Doorway, Buy the House
description: IT was love at front sight. One day five years ago, Mario Rodriguez, a woodworking teacher, was driving on a rural road in Orange County, N.Y., toward a house he had been told was for sale. What he saw was a wooden doorway unlike anything he had ever seen before.

title: Lesson for Thailand's Small Investors: What Goes Up . . .
description: ''I'm afraid,'' the young investor said, staring at her brightly colored computer monitor on a small stock-trading floor. ''I dare not buy. I'm afraid it will go down more tomorrow.''

title: Deutsche Bank Profits Increase 55%
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., Germany's largest banking concern, said yesterday that its nine-month profit surged 55 percent, to 2.38 billion marks ($1.37 billion), from 1.53 billion marks a year ago, because of strong sales of investment products.

title: INSIDE
description: Fears of Chemicals Undercut

title: Greenspan Sees A Silver Lining In Stock Unrest
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, broke his silence today over the turmoil in the stock market and proclaimed it not such a bad thing after all.

title: Quick & Reilly Buys Loans
description: Quick & Reilly Group Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired the stock loan business of Shelby Cullom Davis & Company, an investment banking firm that is leaving the securities lending business. Financial terms were not disclosed. Quick & Reilly said the deal included $2 billion in outstanding stock loans, which are often used for short sales. Quick & Reilly, based in New York, agreed in September to be acquired by Fleet Financial Group Inc.

title: The China Summit
description: Just as Ronald Reagan tried to make improved relations with the Soviet Union the foreign policy centerpiece of his second term, Bill Clinton now looks to China for his place in the diplomatic history books. This week's visit of President Jiang Zemin has shown the difficulty of trying to construct a stable relationship with China. Mr. Clinton, after several false starts in his first term, has devised a sound China policy that emphasizes engagement rather than estrangement. The question now and in the months ahead is how effectively Mr. Clinton handles the many elements of that policy, from defending human rights to enhancing trade.

title: BB&T TO PAY $359.2 MILLION IN STOCK FOR LIFE BANCORP
description: The BB&T Corporation, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., agreed yesterday to buy Life Bancorp Inc. for $359.2 million in stock, as the bank expands in Virginia. BB&T will pay 0.58 share of its stock for each share of Life Bancorp if BB&T shares are trading at $57 or higher, under the terms of the agreement. That is about $32.93 a share. Shares of Life Bancorp closed at $25.375, up $1.75 a share when it was halted for the merger announcement. BB&T rose $1.3125, to $56.1875. Life Bancorp has $1.5 billion in assets and 20 banking offices in Virginia. BB&T operates 485 branches throughout the Carolinas and Virginia.

title: People Can Claim One or More Races On Federal Forms
description: The Clinton Administration today adopted new rules for listing racial and ethnic makeup on Federal forms, allowing people for the first time to identify themselves as members of more than one race.

title: In U.S., Brokers Gaining Upper Hand : A Besieged Industry Battles to Keep Clients
description: NEW YORK  All is not what it seems in the plush confines of U.S. private banks. Beneath the euphoria shared in recent years by private bankers across America, and beneath all their talk of double-digit annual revenue growth, lies a deeply troubling trend  a steadily eroding market share.

title: Leyritz in Mets' Search For Help Next Season
description: Planning for next season would be less complicated for Steve Phillips, the general manager of the Mets, if he knew exactly what he had in hand. But like many investors these days, Phillips is guessing whether he has blue chips or junk. Injuries again are having an impact on the Mets.

title: Metro Matters; A 'Bellwether' Has the Look Of Pasteboard
description: GARBAGE and tolls. Garbage and tolls.

title: Whitman Steps Up Her Appeals to Women
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman rarely makes the pitch that women should vote for her because she is a woman. But she has been coming close recently in her hard-fought race for re-election, standing in the chill this morning to dedicate a new mobile mammography unit here and to tout her support for a law requiring insurers to cover up to 72 hours of recovery in a hospital after a mastectomy.

title: City Council Endorsements
description: All 51 members of the New York City Council are up for re-election next Tuesday. Here are our endorsements in the more competitive contests.

title: Between Wary Presidents, Signs of Bonding
description: This morning, President Jiang Zemin of China appeared at a White House ceremony in his honor wearing a tie as shiny and orange as a smoked salmon fillet. President Clinton greeted him wearing a black tie with a white diamond pattern.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIBERMAN, GEORGE, M.D.
description: LIBERMAN-George, M.D. The staff, the Officers and the members of the NYS Academy of Family Physicians, sadly acknowledge the death of our colleague, a former Family Doctor of the Year and 50 Year Member.

title: Mainstreet to Buy Regency
description: Mainstreet Bankgroup Inc. said today that it had agreed to purchase Regency Bank, a unit of Regency Financial Shares Inc., for $17 million in stock. Regency has three branches in Richmond and $74.9 million in assets. Mainstreet, based in Martinsville, Va., has five branches in Richmond through its Hanover Bank unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAER, ALBERT M.
description: BAER-Albert M. On October 26, 1997, at his home in Rapidan, Va. Age 92. Beloved husband of Karla. Father of Margery Irish and the late Betsy Kaufman. Grandfather of five and great-grandfather of five. Memorial services will be held on Thursday at 11:30 A.M., Frank E. Campbell, 81st Street at Madison Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Rapidan Virginia Volunteer Fire Department, P.O. Box 96, Rapidan, VA. 22733.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COLE, CHARLES J.
description: COLE-Charles J. Dad, you are in our hearts today as much as when you left us five years ago. We miss you and love you. Abbie and Bradley

title: Global Diversification Takes on New Appeal : Amid Crisis, Asians Shift Priorities
description: KUALA LUMPUR  As Asia's developing economies galloped along in recent years, private banks welcomed the region's nouveaux riches with open arms, provided, of course, that they handed over $1 million in cash, a standard minimum investment.

title: '1776' Will Make It to Broadway
description: It's on again.

title: Phycor to Buy a Competitor, Medpartners, for $6.8 Billion in Stock
description: Phycor Inc., a physician-management company, said yesterday that it would acquire Medpartners Inc., a much larger competitor, for $6.8 billion in Phycor stock.

title: Plan to Delay School-Test Vote
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today to a compromise that would postpone for a year a vote on whether the Clinton Administration can test students nationwide in reading and math. In the interim, they agreed to allow the Administration to proceed with its plan to develop such tests in the next year.

title: BERKSHIRE PARTNERS BUYS HOLMES UNIT FROM PENTLAND
description: The Pentland Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it had sold its Holmes Products division to Boston-based Berkshire Partners L.L.C. for $91.5 million in cash. Pentland, which makes Speedo bathing suits and Ellesse sportswear, said Berkshire would also assume $82 million in Holmes debt. Holmes makes fans and electric heaters in the United States, with $194.3 million in 1996 sales. Holmes generates about 15 percent of Pentland sales and 20 percent of operating profit. Holmes is 20 percent owned by Jordan Kahn, who founded the business in 1982. Mr. Kahn will remain as Holmes's chairman and chief executive and will receive 25 percent of the $91.5 million.

title: Chairman Outlines Blueprint For a Slimmed-Down Pepsico
description: Describing Pepsico Inc. as ''the ultimate challenger,'' Craig E. Weatherup, chairman and chief executive of the Pepsi-Cola Company, took aim at its archrival yesterday while offering a blueprint for Pepsi's slimmed-down, more focused future.

title: National News Briefs; House Supports Measure Favoring Illegal Aliens
description: The House today showed its support for an immigration provision that would permit illegal aliens to remain in the United States while they apply for residency so long as they pay a $1,000 fee.

title: National News Briefs; Screening of Jury Pool Is Finished in Bomb Case
description: Questioning of prospective jurors in the second Oklahoma City bombing trial ended today as the number of jurors in the pool reached 71.

title: Devils Want to Play Messier Only Once
description: Jacques Lemaire shrugged his shoulders and extended his arms, but his mouth stayed closed when he was asked after today's practice whether he was happy to see Mark Messier come into New Jersey just once in the regular season.

title: T. Dale Stewart Dies at 96; Anthropologist at Smithsonian
description: T. Dale Stewart, a physical anthropologist who was an authority on human bones, died on Monday in a nursing home in Bethesda, Md. He was 96 and a longtime resident of McLean, Va.

title: Noises Off: Protests And Shriek Of Jets
description: On the eve of his visit, President Jiang Zemin called on the United States to insure that ''the atmosphere'' of the summit meeting not be disrupted by protesters. At today's welcoming ceremony at the White House, however, the biggest disruption was not the chant of protesters, who were out of earshot, but the roar of airplanes.

title: BOND INSURER MBIA IN TALKS TO ACQUIRE CAPMAC
description: MBIA Inc., the biggest insurer of municipal bonds, said yesterday that it was in talks to buy Capmac Holdings Inc. to expand in the asset-backed bond business, the fastest-growing part of the fixed-income market. The companies declined to comment on the price that MBIA, based in Armonk, N.Y., might pay for Capmac. The talks were disclosed after shares of Capmac closed at $32, up $1.25. At that price the company, which is based in New York, has a market capitalization of more than $550 million. Shares of MBIA, about 10 times as large, rose $2.8125, to $123.75. MBIA insures bonds in the $1.3 trillion market for debt sold by states, cities and other public agencies, providing AAA ratings and lower borrowing costs.

title: Strong Sales Bolster Profits at Electrolux
description: The Swedish appliance maker Electrolux A.B. said yesterday that its third-quarter profit jumped 47 percent, to 462 million kronor ($61.3 million), from 313 million, because of strong sales of outdoor products.

title: Paroled Rapist Convicted In 4 Attacks in Brooklyn
description: On Aug. 16, 1995, James Webb was released on parole after serving 20 years in prison for raping a half-dozen women in the 1970's. The next day, a woman, the first of four, was raped in a series of attacks in neighborhoods near Mr. Webb's.

title: Abuse Laws Cover Fetus, a High Court Rules
description: In a ruling that runs contrary to every other state supreme court that has addressed the issue, South Carolina's highest court this week upheld the criminal prosecution of pregnant women who used drugs, finding that a viable fetus is a ''person'' covered by the state's child-abuse laws.

title: Deaf Students Face Lack of Interpreters
description: Every weekday, Ruth Farias, a deaf teen-ager who came to the United States from Mexico seeking a better education, sits in a Queens high school staring at the blackboard or doodling in the mostly blank pages of her purple spiral notebook.

title: John N. Sturdivant, 59, Federal Union Leader
description: John N. Sturdivant, president of the American Federation of Government Employees, which represents 600,000 Federal workers, died on Tuesday night in Falls Church, Va. He was 59 and lived in Vienna, Va.

title: Baseball's Success Depends on Free Agency; Yankees Buck the Trend
description: To the Editor:

title: Netanyahu Wrestles With Peace Issues, to U.S. Impatience
description: To considerable American impatience, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his top advisers are wrestling to resolve Israel's stance on issues that were supposed to have been discussed with the Palestinians in Washington this week.

title: Conspiracy Overload
description: Some of my politically conservative compeers have been telling wild tales about the Clinton Administration. They see vast conspiracies in the small-time chicanery of Whitewater, Castle Grande and the Madison Guaranty Savings and Loan. They view the shabby, provincial Rose Law Firm as a super-villain cabal worth a new Batman film. They experience fits of credulity about drug smuggling at the airport in Mena, Ark., and an adolescent Bill Clinton's K.G.B. contacts. They monger gossip about the President and his wife participating in what may be politely termed a rich and varied social life, and they claim that webs of hidden influence are spun from such extramaritalities.

title: Measure Is Passed to Broaden Health Insurance for Children
description: The General Assembly passed legislation today to provide health insurance for uninsured children, making Connecticut one of the first states to tap into new Federal money to insure children of the working poor.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Smoke Bomb Linked to Death
description: What began as a prank ended in a death Friday when a teen-ager threw a smoke bomb into a supermarket and a fire vehicle, racing to the apparent fire, struck and killed a man, prosecutors said.

title: Barkley Hints At Retirement
description: Charles Barkley, saying his 9-year-old daughter was harassed by schoolmates over his arrest in Flordia, told several Houston reporters yesterday that he is ''leaning toward retirement'' from basketball.

title: ELECTRONIC RETAILING AND TELEPANEL SYSTEMS TO MERGE
description: Electronic Retailing Systems International Inc., based in Wilton, Conn., and Telepanel Systems Inc. of Canada agreed yesterday to merge in a $68 million deal. Both companies provide electronic shelf labeling technology, which is meant to replace price tags on store shelves with liquid crystal displays. After completion of the deal, Electronic Retailing shareholders will own two-thirds of the combined company and Telepanel shareholders will own one-third. The combined operations will be based in Connecticut. Shares of Telepanel, based in Marham, Ontario, rose 31.25 cents, to $3.0625, while Electronic Retailing rose 37.5 cents, to $6.375.

title: Foreign Affairs; America's Oil Change
description: I was so relieved the other day to see the huge U.S.S. Nimitz aircraft carrier steaming into the Persian Gulf, in the latest high-profile American effort to stabilize this strategic, oil-rich region. I sleep so much better knowing that we are protecting the flow of oil to China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, MICHAEL SILVA
description: WHITE-Michael Silva. Of Summit, N.J., and Edgartown, MA., October 29, 1997. Husband of Molly (nee Edmonson) White and father of Cameron S., Jameson F. and Sean M. Brother of Mrs. Ted (Susan) Sherman of Norfolk, VA., and Christopher S. White of Hong Kong. He is also survived by his parents Joan and John White of Sarasota, FL. A memorial service will be held Saturday, November 1, 1997, 1PM, the Calvary Episcopal Church in Summit, New Jersey. Interment Martha's Vineyard, MA. In lieu of flowers, please donate in his name to Hamilton College, Clinton, New York 13323 or the National Cancer Institute.

title: Link to Teamsters Inquiry Forces a Liberal Group to Close Its National Office
description: Citizen Action, the liberal grassroots group that was a powerful voice in last year's Congressional elections, has been forced to dismiss its 20-member national staff because many large contributors have stopped donating as a result of accusations that the group was involved in illegal fund-raising by the teamsters.

title: Proffitts to Buy Carson Pirie In $790 Million Stock Deal
description: In the universe of department stores, where market share has become the key element to success, small companies have an odd advantage in their home territory over the country's biggest players.

title: Miscellany
description: * Donino & Partners, Atlanta, changed its name to Donino, White & Partners, to reflect the contributions of Ridge White, partner and executive vice president.

title: Child Welfare Doesn't Belong in Police Hands; Harmful Interventions
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer program defect at The Associated Press, the Nasdaq market table in Business Day yesterday carried erroneous prices for Tuesday's trading. The listed prices failed to reflect trades after 3:35 P.M. The table today, on page D16, shows changes from Tuesday's actual closing prices.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WILLIS SPARKS, one of the stars of the Off Broadway show ''Mere Mortals'' at the John Houseman Theater on West 42d Street, will not appear in the matinee performance on Sunday.

title: Waste Management Chairman Quits, the Second in 9 Months
description: Waste Management Inc. said late yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Ronald T. LeMay, had quit, the second chief executive to leave the troubled trash hauling company in nine months.

title: Savarese Can See a Title Shot in Future
description: Lou Savarese was squinting from the medication that was placed in his eyes for an exam yesterday afternoon as he entered a news conference in midtown Manhattan. Blurred vision notwithstanding, Savarese can still see a clear shot at Lennox Lewis, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion.

title: Child Welfare Doesn't Belong in Police Hands; Poverty Isn't a Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Papers Link Donations to 2 On Senate Hearings Panel
description: Documents released by Senate investigators today identified 20 donors to a private conservative organization that worked outside the normal political channels in ways that benefited conservative Republicans, including two members of the Senate committee investigating campaign finances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINICK, FANNIE
description: KAMINICK-Fannie. Beloved aunt of Albert, Miriam, Paula and great aunt to many of the Yackira family. Died Wed. morning, October 29, 1997. Services will be held Friday 10:00AM, The Hirsch Chapel, Jerome Avenue and 167 Street, Bx.

title: A Yield of Little More Than 'Normalization' of Abnormal Relations
description: The Chinese hailed today's summit meeting as a ''normalization of relations'' between Washington and Beijing, but in fact it indicated how abnormal the relationship remains. Hot lines and reciprocal summitry, however useful, inevitably evoke memories of the cold war and United States-Soviet relations, which were anything but normal.

title: Clinton and Jiang in Their Own Words: Sharing a Broad Agenda
description: Following are excerpts from a joint news conference today by President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China, as transcribed by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company. Mr. Jiang's remarks are through an interpreter unless otherwise indicated.

title: Child Welfare Doesn't Belong in Police Hands; State Goes Too Far
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: Fidelity Funds on Tuesday
description: The mutual fund table yesterday included erroneous data for some funds managed by Fidelity Investments. Table lists corrected figures.

title: Economic Scene; Speculators are finding that the Hong Kong dollar is different.
description: IF Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Indonesia and Taiwan, why not Hong Kong?

title: Child Welfare Doesn't Belong in Police Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Spirit Of the 20's, The Athletic As Esthetic
description: Moses Pendleton, idea man behind Momix and co-founder of Pilobolus Dance Theater, is a lucky man. His hobby has become his business, and fantasy is his hobby.

title: School Was Slow in Reporting Attack, Police Say
description: Police Department officials yesterday criticized city school officials for failing to immediately report an 11-year-old boy's allegation that he was sodomized in a classroom closet at a junior high school in the Bronx last week. Three youths, an 11-year-old boy and two 12-year-old boys, were arrested in the case yesterday and charged with juvenile delinquency, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, GOLDIE
description: STEINBERG-Goldie. Beloved wife of Marvin, devoted mother, adored grandmother and loving sister. Service today 12:15PM, ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York.

title: Perot Set to Re-Enter Political Scene
description: Ross Perot said he thought of going up to Washington to ''bang on some doors'' to try to get a campaign finance bill passed, but concluded it would be a waste of time.

title: Hantsmbou Journal; It's No Fish Story: There's a Dinosaur Down There
description: In this tiny fishing village, a place where the black lava rock coastline gives way to a small stretch of white sandy beach, Otsambu Chindini is something of a celebrity.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about Net Day, a volunteer effort to provide Internet access to the nation's schools, misstated the number of students who graduated last year from McClymonds High School in Oakland, Calif. It was 71 of the 81 students in the senior class, not 16 of 150 seniors.

title: Waiters Settle Suit With Chinatown Restaurant
description: In what Asian-American labor groups are calling a big victory, Chinatown's largest restaurant has agreed to pay more than $1.1 million to 58 workers who said they had been cheated out of tips and wages, officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 22 about the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission's designation of three new landmark buildings omitted the names of the architects for two of them. They are Kevin Roche, John Dinkeloo & Associates for the Ford Foundation Building at 321 East 42d Street, and Skidmore, Owings & Merrill for what is now the Chase bank branch at 510 Fifth Avenue.

title: Health Giant Says Earnings Fell Sharply
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that its earnings had dropped significantly in the third quarter, in the wake of a widespread criminal investigation of some of the company's business practices.

title: DSC COMMUNICATIONS IN $165 MILLION DEAL FOR CELCORE
description: The DSC Communications Corporation agreed yesterday to buy closely held Celcore Inc., which makes switches for wireless phone networks, for $165 million in stock to expand its line of products for the fast-growing wireless industry. DSC, which makes equipment for phone networks, expects to complete the transaction by the end of the year. Celcore, based in Memphis, makes switches for networks that use traditional analog and global system for mobile communications digital technology. The company has 180 employees. Shares of DSC, based in Plano, Tex., fell $1.1875 yesterday, to $24, before the deal was announced.

title: Campbell May Split Longtime Ranger Duo
description: A day after the Rangers' most recent defeat a 3-2 loss to the Dallas Stars on Tuesday -- Coach Colin Campbell said he was considering major changes, including breaking up the longtime defensive pairing of Brian Leetch and Jeff Beukeboom.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPKIN, GEORGE
description: POPKIN-George. The AntiDefamation League mourns the passing of George Popkin, beloved longtime leader and generous supporter. George was an Honorary Life Member of our National Commission and blessed our Palm Beach Regional Board with his warmth, wit and wisdom. His sage counsel, active participation and loving personality will be greatly missed. We extend our profound condolences to the entire family. Howard P. Berkowitz, National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman, National Director

title: Accounts
description: * Perrier Group, Greenwich, Conn., owned by Nestle S.A., to McCann Direct, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., as agency of record for relationship marketing for six regional domestic water brands, including Deer Park and Poland Springs, which had been handled by Wunderman Cato Johnson, New York, part of Young & Rubicam Inc. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Fed Chief's Remarks Spur Rally in Bonds
description: Treasury securities rallied yesterday after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told a Congressional committee that despite a tight labor market, ''growth appears to have remained robust and inflation low, and even falling.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Arts Abroad; With Modern Dance, a Renaissance in Bahia Spreads
description: At the municipal theater here, the dancers of the Grupo Corpo creep along the stage and circle slowly, their bent knees and jutting shoulders reminiscent of crabs. Women crouch like the laundresses by lakes in Salvador, the capital of Bahia, their bodies seemingly wound tight with possibilities. The rhythm of a saw against a tree joins the strains of a bow running quickly over a homemade violin, then mixes with a bass and a guitar.

title: Reconciling Madman and Patriot
description: THE HITLER OF HISTORY

title: Exhibits and Haunted Paper
description: Paper Prizes

title: Other Primary Colors
description: To the Editor:

title: IRAQ ISSUES ORDER BARRING AMERICANS FROM U.N. INQUIRY
description: Iraq today ordered all Americans working for the United Nations arms inspection team to leave the country within a week.

title: Isles Get Milbury's Message Quickly
description: Mike Milbury took a look at the Islanders this afternoon and did not like what he saw.

title: Surprisingly Warm Greetings For Several Initial Offerings
description: The shares of start-up companies are usually regarded as those most at risk when markets plummet, as they did on Monday. So gyrating markets often scare fledgling companies from trying to offer shares to the public for the first time.

title: The Devils Score Early And Often
description: The Devils scored from all angles tonight lying down, sitting down -- against the Vancouver Canucks.

title: WORLDTEX TO BUY ELASTIC FABRIC UNIT FOR $76.3 MILLION
description: Worldtex Inc., a producer of elastic yarn, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Elastic Corporation of America for $76.3 million in cash and the assumption of $6 million in debt. Elastic, a division of the privately held NFA Corporation in Chelsea, Mass., supplies elastic fabrics to the apparel industry and had nine-month revenue of $52.7 million. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, Worldtex, based in Hickory, N.C., had sales of $148.4 million. Shares of Worldtex slipped 12.5 cents yesterday, to $8.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Marvel Files Suit in Financial Collapse
description: Marvel Entertainment Group Inc. said yesterday that it was suing the financier Ronald O. Perelman, two Toy Biz Inc. shareholders and the Chase Manhattan Corporation, contending that they are responsible for the comic publisher's financial collapse.

title: In the Inimitable Hand Of a Master Draftsman
description: As a draftsman, the Florentine artist Filippino Lippi (circa 1458-1504) wasn't quite up to Leonardo. But his admirers say he came close. And although honored as a painter, it was in drawing that his fervent invention was most apparent. He pushed 15th-century style and technique to their limits, mastering line in pen and metalpoint to get to the essence of his subjects.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SALOMON, ROSALIND.
description: SALOMON-Rosalind. Lovingly remembered. Chester and Danny

title: Messinger Has Moved Right, But Not Sufficiently for Some
description: Talk to the people best acquainted with Ruth W. Messinger's industrious tenure as a New York City Councilwoman and a myriad of issues get mentioned, from child welfare to campaign finance reform, American intervention in Nicaragua to gay rights. As the Council's resident firebrand from 1978 through 1989, Ms. Messinger was as rarely at a loss for causes as she was for words.

title: Art in Review
description: Pierre Bonnard

title: Sony Profit Up Sharply, Aided by Film Studio
description: The Sony Corporation said today that earnings rose sharply in the latest six months as demand for its digital electronic products soared and the film ''Men in Black'' helped lead a revival at its Hollywood studios.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, HEDWIG (HATTIE)
description: PRICE-Hedwig (Hattie). Beloved mother of Regina Fiorito Sokol, passed away peacefully in her 101st year October 28, 1997. Services Sunday 12:15PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: All Jurors Are Seated In Bombing Trial
description: A jury was seated today in the trial of Terry L. Nichols, charged with murder and conspiracy in the 1995 bombing of the Oklahoma City Federal Building.

title: Brazil Stocks Plunge 9.8% On Worries About Banks
description: Brazilian stocks plunged 9.8 percent today, as investors nervous about the health of the country's banking system sold off shares with a fury not seen for more than two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ASHBURN, FRANK DAVIS
description: ASHBURN-Frank Davis. Age 94, of Westwood on October 2, 1997. Distinguished Headmaster Emeritus of Brooks School, N. Andover, Massachusetts. Beloved husband of Jean (Lang) Ashburn and the late Phyllis (Batcheller) Ashburn. Devoted father of the late Phyllis A. Kissel and Nancy A. Whitaker. He is survived by 7 grandchildren & seventeen great-grandchildren. Private service and burial at the Ashburn Chapel, Brooks School. Memorial services will be at Brooks School on Saturday, November 1, 1997, at 11:00 AM and at the Chapel of St Bartholomew's Church, Park Ave at 51st St, New York City, on Monday, November 3, 1997, 2:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to The Ashburn Chair, Brooks School, N. Andover, MA 01845. Information: the Holden-Westwood Funeral Home, Westwood, MA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHENKER, LUCILLE
description: SCHENKER-Lucille. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Lucille Schenker, associated with The Times from October 28, 1968 until retiring on November 1, 1991.

title: Court Rules Out Woman's Trial In Fetus Death
description: Ruling in the case of a pregnant teen-ager who shot herself in the stomach after failing to obtain an abortion, the Florida Supreme Court said yesterday that a woman cannot be prosecuted for harming her fetus.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Poll Shows Volatile Voters
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman continues to receive high marks as Governor, but she has been unable to convince voters that she would do a better job than her Democratic opponent, State Senator James E. McGreevey, in addressing their top concern, auto insurance, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOSHLAND, DR. MARIAN
description: KOSHLAND-Dr. Marian (Lafayette, CA). The Weizmann Institute of Science and its American Committee note with deep sorrow the passing of a distinguished researcher in immunology and cell biology, renowned expert in the study of antibodies, former head of the Department of Microbiology and Immunology at the University of California at Berkeley. A lifelong friend and generous supporter of the Weizmann Institute and its vision of progress through science, she was the beloved wife of Dr. Daniel E. Koshland, Jr., a member of the International Board of Governors of the Institute and its Scientific and Academic Advisory Committee, and Vice President of ACWIS. We express our heartfelt sympathy to Dan and the entire family. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Haim Harari, President S. Donald Sussman, Chairman American Committee Albert Willner, President Fran Ginsburg, Exec. V.P.

title: Art in Review
description: Carroll Dunham

title: Magic That's Made Comic, and Comedy That's Magic
description: Children begin laughing the minute Tomas Kubinek appears onstage in ''The Maestro Invades Manhattan.'' That's probably because his hair looks as if it belongs to an animated character from ''The Simpsons'' (the style is somewhere between Sideshow Bob's and Krusty the Klown's) who has come to life and then slept restlessly.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Funeral Interrupted by Crash
description: With as many as 5,000 law enforcement officers looking on, a funeral Mass was offered yesterday at Our Lady of the Valley Roman Catholic Church for a state trooper who was killed last week during a confrontation with a suspect he was pursuing. But the funeral procession for Scott M. Gonzalez was interrupted when a carjacking suspect slammed into the procession a block from the church, slightly injuring two troopers, the authorities said.

title: Free Agents
description: Darryl Strawberry, whose career suffered another setback this year, was one of 24 players who filed for free agency yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINS, PETER
description: KAMINS-Peter. We want to wish the entire Kamins family our sincerest condolences on Pete's untimely passing. We cherish the wonderful memories and good times our families shared over many years. Ellen, Jimmy, Ben and Kimberley Ross

title: 10 Writers Are Given Whiting Awards
description: The 10 winners of Whiting Writers' Awards were announced yesterday at a Manhattan ceremony celebrating a group of emerging writers, among them poets, novelists, a playwright and a memoirist.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about two new producers involved in transferring the musical ''1776'' from the Roundabout to the Gershwin Theater in New York referred incorrectly to their connection with the coming revival of ''The Sound of Music.'' The revival's producers include Robert Halmi Jr., not Bill Haber.

title: Naoharu Yamashina, Toy Maker, Dies at 79
description: Naoharu Yamashina, the founder of the Bandai Company, the Japanese toy manufacturer behind the Tamagotchi virtual pet and Mighty Morphin Power Rangers crazes, died on Tuesday at the age of 79.

title: AT&T TO USE MCLEODUSA NETWORK FOR SERVICE IN 30 CITIES
description: The AT&T Corporation will offer local phone service to business customers in 30 Midwestern cities using McLeodUSA Inc.'s network to cut the fees that AT&T pays to the regional Bell companies. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. AT&T has been using the Bells' networks to provide local service in the 30 cities, which are in Illinois, Iowa, Minnesota, North Dakota and South Dakota. AT&T said the fees that it was paying McLeodUSA to connect to its network would be lower than the fees that it had been paying the Bells. Shares of McLeodUSA, based in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, rose $1.75, to $35.75, in Nasdaq trading. AT&T's shares dipped 25 cents, to $48.125.

title: G.O.P.'s Issue Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Komar and Melamid

title: The Final Lap for an Old Track
description: BRONX boyhood is just about the last thing likely to produce an auto racing nut. But with environmental factors working against me, I did at least have a father willing to indulge his son's inexplicable passion.

title: The Challenge for Managed Care
description: The stock price of Oxford Health Plans, one of the largest managed-care plans in New York, plunged 60 percent this week when it announced losses attributed to a flawed billing system that failed to send statements to enrollees and underestimated payments owed to doctors and hospitals. When Oxford decided to absorb the losses rather than jack up premiums, investors ran for cover.

title: Social Security Ceiling
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; A New Chief Suddenly Quits, and Shareholders Are Wondering Why
description: Ronald T. LeMay's sudden resignation as chief executive of Waste Management Inc. left the company in turmoil, but that is not the main thing bothering owners of the company's stock. What has really unnerved them is not knowing why he left after less than four months on the job.

title: Flower Girl Finds True Romance in Asphalt Jungle
description: ''I Love You, I Love You Not'' is an odd film to find on the big screen. Video-ready close-ups and tidy plot parallels would ordinarily relegate such a story to television for sensitive teen-agers, an audience not yet tired of watching Claire Danes coming of age. In a film full of sugar-coated flower imagery (and shot before ''William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet''), Ms. Danes plays a schoolgirl named Daisy. She is sometimes called Flower Girl, and is asked twice to sing ''Daisy, Daisy'' merrily with her beloved grandmother, with whom she has a kissy, tender relationship that helps her through those painful coming-of-age worries.

title: Art in Review
description: Michelle Stuart

title: Duval, Tied for the Lead, Seeking Third in a Row
description: David Duval has the feeling that every athlete dreams about. Call it the zone, call it momentum, call it whatever. Duval simply knows that when he swings a golf club these days, special things happen. Lately, it seems as if Duval can't lose. And judging by today's sparkling performance, Duval's decision to take last week off did nothing to cool off the most torrid player in golf.

title: The Morning After a Contentious Debate, Giuliani Focuses Singularly on His Record
description: A day after the hand-to-hand combat of the campaign's final debate, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani once again adopted a strategy of extolling his own record and barely acknowledging Ruth W. Messinger yesterday, going so far as to refer to her not by name but merely as ''a candidate.''

title: Wellpoint Shares Sink Despite Profit Gain
description: Investors hammered the shares of Wellpoint Health Networks, one of the country's biggest managed-care companies, yesterday, even after it reported relatively strong financial results for the third quarter.

title: Strong Sales Lift Profit at Rhone-Poulenc
description: The French pharmaceutical and chemical company Rhone-Poulenc S.A. said yesterday that strong sales in its main businesses drove third-quarter profits up 38 percent, to 1.04 billion francs ($180 million) from 756 million francs ($304 million) a year earlier. Sales rose 7 percent in the quarter, to 21.9 billion francs ($3.79 billion) from 20.4 billion francs ($3.53 billion).

title: Senate Leader Approves Vote on Campaign Finance Bill
description: Republican leaders seeking to break a three-week logjam in the Senate grudgingly agreed today to allow a test vote by next March on a bill to overhaul the country's campaign finance system.

title: Spare Times
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Woman From Ulster Expected to Win Irish Republic Vote
description: Ireland went to the polls on this cool, rainy day to elect a new President to replace Mary Robinson, who left the office after a seven-year term to become United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights.

title: A Star Player's Latest, Perhaps Last, Chance
description: On March 30, 1996, Marcus Bullard stood in a corridor in Continental Arena in New Jersey contemplating the end of a great run. Thanks largely to Bullard's heady play at point guard, the Mississippi State Bulldogs had reached the Final Four and a semifinal matchup against Syracuse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COMERFORD, E.F. ''FRANK''
description: COMERFORD-E.F. ''Frank''. Of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, NY and Point Lookout, LI, on October 28, 1997. Former President of Comerald Assoc and Group Services Adm Inc, New York City. Beloved and devoted husband of Rose M. (nee Clemente). Loving father of Joellin, Michael and Adrianne, Frank and Maura, Patrice, Elizabeth and William Spinelli, Maria and James Corcoran, K.C. and Justin Faucci, Christina and Pete Lekkas, Timothy and Mary. Cherished grandfather of 11 loving grandchildren. Reposing after 2 P.M., Saturday, Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Avenue (Exit 28N SS Pkwy) Wantagh. Funeral Mass Monday 11AM at Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal R.C. Church, Point Lookout. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Big Brothers and Big Sisters of Long Island, 70 Acorn Lane, Levittown, New York 11756. Family will receive friends Saturday & Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM.

title: Circle Widens in Case of Man Accused of Spreading H.I.V.
description: Health officials in New York City and Chautauqua County upstate said yesterday that they were investigating reports that Nushawn J. Williams had been an intravenous drug user, a possibility that, if accurate, could greatly widen the circle of people the Brooklyn man might have infected with the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Merrill Lynch Buys 450 Acres For New Jersey Office Center
description: Merrill Lynch & Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 450-acre wooded tract in Hopewell, N.J., where it plans to build an office complex for 3,500 employees.

title: Excerpts From New Transcripts of 201 Hours of Secret Nixon Tapes
description: Following are excerpts from tape transcripts from June 21, 1972, to July 12, 1973, from ''Abuse of Power: The New Nixon Tapes'' by Stanley Kutler, to be published in November by The Free Press. The ellipses and emphases are taken from Mr. Kutler's transcripts.

description: Republican leaders agreed to a test vote by March on a bill to change campaign financing. Page A24.

title: Theater Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: For the Feel of Hanoi, Go With the Urban Cyclist Flow
description: HANOI  One of the great sights of Vietnam is guaranteed to disappear within a few years. Go any morning or evening to any major intersection in central Hanoi, a city of roughly three million people, and you will see thousands of bicycles plying their way to and from work and school.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Officer Is Accused of Assaults
description: An Irvington police officer was accused yesterday of assaulting seven local residents, some of whom were not even suspected of breaking the law, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLK, SAMUEL WISTAR, JR.
description: POLK-Samuel Wistar, Jr., 65. Only son of Eloise Wells Vaughan and Samuel W. Polk., Sr., died at home of natural causes on August 12, 1997, in New York City. Born on February 13, 1932 in Mercedes, Texas, he grew up in St. Louis, MO. His parents divorced and his mother married Oscar Johnson, Jr. Mr. Polk was educated at John Burroughs School in St. Louis and then at Princeton University (Class of 1953). He served in the U.S. Army in the Korean era and was a stockbroker for Newhard, Cook & Co. in St. Louis. He moved to New York City in 1966 and founded Plexi-Point, Inc., a manufacturing concern, which ceased operations in 1973. He lived in New York City until his death. Never married, he will be missed for his grace, charm, and style. His sister, Irene Johnson Barnes, predeceased him in 1995. Mr. Polk is survived by his sister Eloise Polk Spivy of Chicago.

title: More Spacious and Gracious, Yet Still Funky at Heart
description: The New York art world expanded a bit this week. And for a change, it happened not in Chelsea, but nearly an island and a river to the east, in Long Island City, Queens. The P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, the city's oldest and largest alternative space, has sprung dramatically back into action, reopening its huge Romanesque Revival building, a former public school, after three years and $8.5 million of renovation, repair and redesign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITING, RICHARD
description: WHITING-Richard. The Amateur Comedy Club mourns the passing of Dick Whiting on September 23. James A. Sutton, President

title: Reebok Expands Its Work With Lowe
description: Reebok International said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with the Lowe Howard-Spink unit of Lowe Group in London by naming that agency to handle its worldwide soccer advertising. Though billings were not disclosed, Advertising Age estimated them at $15 million to $20 million.

title: Poverty Is the Norm for Single-Parent Families; What About Values?
description: To the Editor:

title: National Westminster Reportedly May Sell Unit
description: National Westminster Bank P.L.C. of Britain is in talks over the sale of its equities unit to Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, the investment banking arm of Deutsche Bank A.G. of Germany, The Financial Times reported yesterday. The newspaper said Deutsche Morgan Grenfell was interested in the equities division of NatWest Markets, National Westminster's investment banking subsidiary, but not the advisory units or the corporate finance division.

title: CCL INDUSTRIES TO SELL COSMETICS UNIT FOR $71 MILLION
description: CCL Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Kolmar Cosmetics unit for $71 million (United States) to Outsourcing Services Group Inc. Kolmar packages cosmetics like lipstick and lotions for other companies. CCL Industries, based in Toronto, said in July that it was seeking buyers for noncore businesses so it could concentrate on specialty packaging and custom manufacturing. On Wednesday, CCL agreed to buy Allegheny Teledyne Inc.'s packaging unit, Teledyne Packaging, for $31 million. Outsourcing Services is a holding company formed by the Gordon Morris Group and Harbour Vest Partners L.L.C. of Newport Beach, Calif.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

description: THE WIND-UP BIRD CHRONICLE

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Across 30 Years, Sculptural Solidity
description: In many ways, it's a great time for the extended look at Jackie Winsor's art that this 20-work, 30-year survey provides. The issues of craft, women's work and subtly obsessive repetition that Ms. Winsor and her contemporaries raised in the late 1960's and early 70's are still reverberating in the efforts of artists as diverse as Janine Antoni, Tom Friedman and Beatriz Milhazes, to name but three.
