description: Franz West

title: Gulf War Drug Doesn't Have Side Effects
description: To the Editor:

title: Professor Is Wild Card in the Governor's Race
description: Straining to be heard above the roar of the passing trucks, Murray Sabrin, New Jersey's Libertarian candidate for governor, stood at the side of Interstate 287, complaining about the towering concrete sound barriers being lifted into place behind him.

title: Deal on National Test Faces Opposition From All Sides
description: A late-night agreement on President Clinton's national testing proposal has threatened to upend Congress's largest spending bill of the session as criticism of the compromise mounted today among unlikely allies: conservatives, liberal Democrats and the White House.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Commits $3 Billion To Indonesia Aid Package

title: TV Weekend; The Glass Slipper Fits With a 90's Conscience
description: As Disney's Cinderella for the 90's, Brandy is amazingly good. She wanders the streets of her village, singing ''The sweetest sounds I'll ever hear/Are still inside my head,'' with the longing of a dreamy adolescent and the musical control of a Broadway trouper. She goes to the ball looking less like a princess than a suburban prom queen, with ringlets and too much blue eye shadow, yet captivates the Prince with her guileless manner. And after the ball, she tells her dead father why she must leave her stepmother's house. ''I deserve better, Father,'' she says, with a sincerity that rescues the pop-psychology dialogue. ''I deserve to be loved.'' Of course, before she can set off on her own, the Prince arrives with the glass slipper and the happy ending. Some things never change.

title: China's Leader Is Rebuked By American Legislators
description: A day after his summit meeting with President Clinton, Jiang Zemin, the Chinese President, endured a grilling on Capitol Hill today by legislators from both parties who questioned him sharply about human rights, nuclear proliferation, religious freedom and forced abortion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMBERG, LORRIE NORR
description: BLUMBERG-Lorrie Norr. On October 29, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Leonard. Loving mother of Robert, Peter, Andrew and H. James Erdman. Also survived by two stepchildren, David and Susan Blumberg. Visitation on Saturday, 7-9 PM, at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, New Rochelle, NY. Services will be conducted on Sunday, 11 A.M., at George T. Davis. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her name to the National Kidney Foundation, Inc., 30 E. 33rd St, NYC 10016, attn: Transplant Research Fund, or to the charity of your choice.

title: Left Outside in Isolated Town: Runaways Exposed to H.I.V.
description: Inside the civic center here Wednesday night, at a panel discussion called ''How Do We Protect Our Kids?,'' apple-cheeked high school girls with shiny blond pageboys, crew neck sweaters and pleated skirts ushered people to their seats. These were the class officers at Jamestown High School, the good girls, with their parents in tow, here to ask questions of a somber panel of AIDS experts.

title: Logging Debate in Maine Makes a Referendum Impenetrable
description: The cascades of money. The onslaught of contradictory television advertisements. The level of sheer confusion among the electorate. And the immensity of the stakes: the fate of the 17-million-acre Maine Woods, the greatest swath of forest left in the Northeast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAFT, ROSLYN D.
description: KRAFT-Roslyn D. On October 29, 1997. Loving daughter of the late William and Mary Kraft. Adored aunt of Ronald Dukes and Debra O'Neil and great-aunt. Services are today, October 31, 12 noon, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Gov. Bush Hedges on Plans For Presidential Bid in 2000
description: For months, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has let it be known that he will run for re-election next year. But the answer to another question has been less clear: if he wins, will he pledge to serve a full four-year term?

title: Motivated Islanders Win Again
description: The Islanders are on a binge.

title: $25.8 Billion Put in Stock Funds In September, Topping Estimates
description: Net cash flows into stock mutual funds in September hit their third-highest level of the year, a trade group said yesterday.

title: Leader for School of American Ballet
description: The School of American Ballet has appointed Larry Alan Smith as its president. He replaces Curtis Harnack, who has retired. The school is affiliated with the New York City Ballet.

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Stanley

title: Corrections
description: A listing of guests at the state dinner for President Jiang Zemin of China, provided by the White House and published yesterday, omitted two guests and referred incorrectly to four others.

title: Home Video; Horror Expands As Oldies Vanish
description: Graft the head of a homicidal maniac onto the body of a dim-witted handyman and what do you get (other than someone you wouldn't hire to put up the storm windows)? Most directly, the answer is a surpassingly bad horror film starring Bruce Dern: ''The Incredible Two-Headed Transplant'' (1971). On another plane, though, you have a representative and appropriately seasonal title from one of video's fastest growing genres.

title: New Video Release
description: The Lost World: Jurassic Park

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Running times and ratings of films are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 9.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Overhaul for PATH Station
description: The Journal Square PATH station will get a $9.9 million overhaul, including tiled platforms, new lighting, a sound-absorbent ceiling and an improved public address system, the Port Authority announced yesterday.

title: How to Fix the Asian Economies
description: As East Asia's financial turmoil continues to unfold, pundits have been quick to pronounce the end of the region's economic ''miracle.'' Some have even declared that there never was a miracle, only a mirage.

title: Family Channel Names New Chief
description: The Family Channel cable network, which passed from Pat Robertson's control to Rupert Murdoch's when it was bought by Fox Kids Worldwide Inc. last summer, has snared a key executive from Nickelodeon, the children's cable network, to become its new president and chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDEGGER, CARL MICHAEL
description: LANDEGGER-Carl Michael. On October 28, 1997. Beloved father of Carl John and Camila Landegger. Loving son of Carl C. and Cecilia Landegger. Devoted brother of Christine Mroczek, Claudia Malaya, Cary Paul Landegger, Celia Landegger and Gregory Landegger. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., Friday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84 St, Saturday at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to the Heart Association, 122 East 42 Street, NYC 10168.

title: Los Angeles Journal; Mariachi Musicians Sustaining Their Traditions
description: The corner of Boyle Avenue and First Street on the city's East Side is like a proud old man down on his luck. The elbow of his only suit coat is getting thin, and he needs a shave. But when he smiles and sings the songs of his father's father at the end of the day, there is still a sparkle in his eye.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Scores Arrested in Fraud Case
description: Teams of Federal, state, and local law enforcement agents arrested 41 people yesterday and accused them of participating in an auto insurance fraud ring, the Passaic County Prosecutor's office said. About $1 million in false claims were filed between January 1995 and June of this year on fictitious accidents or staged collisions, sometimes involving innocent bystanders, said Boris Moczula, the first assistant county prosecutor. The suspects bought policies using phony driver's licenses, Mr. Moczula said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about regulators' plans to increase the responsibilities of large brokerage firms that process the trades of smaller firms misstated the views of James E. Cayne, president of Bear, Stearns & Company. While he opposes some proposals to make clearing firms supervise the sales practices of their client firms, he supports the New York Stock Exchange's new rules on clearing firms.

title: Aftershocks From Asia Hit Wall St.
description: The worldwide drop in share prices resumed with waves of selling yesterday, dragging down stock market indexes on six continents and sending Wall Street into another retreat.

title: Who's Likely to Vote? Why the Results Disagree
description: Four years ago, pollsters were reminded how difficult it is to figure out what New Jersey voters will do on Election Day. In fact, the incumbent Governor, Jim Florio, was leading by 10 to 15 points in three of the four polls released in the weeks before the election. He went on to lose.

title: Family Fare
description: Music and Magic For Halloween

title: A Grandchild Remembers Her Roots
description: The modest overview of Lynne Yamamoto's work, installed in a narrow gallery of P.S. 1 with gracefully arched windows, has a nice historical resonance at this institution. The artist, now in her mid-30's, was a participant in its National and International Studio program several years ago, and has returned recently to work in its education program.

title: Overseas Woes Hurt Banks
description: Shares of Chase Manhattan and other banks have been hurt by fears over market plunges in Asia and Latin America. But Chase may also face problems in Russia. Page D1.

title: On My Mind; A Special Foundation
description: United States-China relations are built on a special, growing foundation. Before and during the visit of China's President, President Clinton and his aides showed how deeply that foundation determines the Administration's policies, judgments and moral and political values.

title: In His Own Words
description: RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI

title: Welcome To the Club: Jazz Swings In New Spots
description: New Yorkers like to mention casually, as if it were painfully evident, that we have the best jazz in the world. That's obviously true, at times. But the scene here has long been top-heavy and ruled by a vicious cycle. The B flat blues you hear from jazz musicians goes like this: The market for unknown jazz being what it is, few young musicians get to make records. Budgets in jazz being what they are, the records that are made can be misproduced and badly distributed. And competition being what it is, a jazz musician can only get a plum gig if he has a few good records easily available.

title: Take Two Aspirin, But Don't Dare Call
description: Meet Dr. Butz, the natty, Scotch-swilling chief resident at a major metropolitan hospital. Played with a gruff avuncularity by a gray-haired, almost unrecognizable Albert Brooks in ''Critical Care,'' Sidney Lumet's bracingly funny satire of the medical establishment, Butz is the smug, genial personification of modern medical greed, incompetence and amorality.

title: HOMESTAKE MINING TO BUY STAKE IN GOLD MINE IN QUEBEC
description: The Homestake Mining Company said yesterday that it would acquire a 76 percent stake in the Inmet Mining Corporation's Troilus gold mine in two transactions totaling $110 million, increasing its gold reserves by 7 percent. Homestake will pay $56 million for a 51 percent stake in the Quebec mine, while Prime Resources Group Inc. will buy the remaining 49 percent for $54 million. Because Prime is 50.6 percent owned by Homestake's Canadian unit, Homestake will have a 76 percent interest in the mine. Homestake, based in San Francisco, is expected to take advantage of the current low gold prices and buy new mining properties. The company had $229.9 million in cash as of Sept. 30 and no debt. Troilus began production in January.

title: Pop and Jazz Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Pharmacia & Upjohn Earnings Down 20%
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. said today that net income fell 20 percent in the third quarter as its older drugs faced strong competition and exchange-rate fluctuations ate into sales.

title: Thompson Official Leaves Unexpectedly
description: Susan Gianinno, the top administrative executive of the flagship New York office of the J. Walter Thompson Company, is leaving immediately to pursue other interests, the agency said yesterday, describing her unexpected departure as ''by mutual consent.''

title: The Festive Face of Halloween; With All-Out Displays, It's Creeping Up on Christmas
description: Tonight in Park Ridge, N.J., Scott Galdi's seasonal home improvements will have their ritual unveiling: 21 monsters, 3 homemade pine coffins, 2 smoke machines, tombstones dedicated to the 1997 Yankees and Diana, Princess of Wales, and a life-size, three-dimensional silhouette of the shower scene from ''Psycho,'' which adds that certain something to his Dutch colonial roof.

title: An Aging Messier Hears the Boos
description: The last time Mark Messier and his team played this poorly for this long was in 1992-93. Messier was captain of the Rangers and Roger Neilson was coach. Messier's slump was perceived as a job-action protest against Neilson's strategies. Before long, Neilson was fired and Mike Keenan was hired.

title: Day-Care Center on S.I. Is Closed After a Potentially Harmful Mold Is Found
description: A day-care center on Staten Island was closed yesterday by the City Administration for Children's Services after a potentially harmful mold was found in the basement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, PAUL
description: GOODMAN-Paul. Boca Raton FL, Oct. 28, 1997. Beloved husband of Rita; loving father of Philip (Denise) Goodman & Ellen Reynolds; cherished grandfather of Lisa, Scott, Morgan and Stephanie; dear brother of Julia Kaplan. Mr. Goodman was the retired President of William Penn Life Ins. Co. Services Sunday, November 2, 1997, 10 A.M. at ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, New York.

title: Metro Business; CVS Grows in Manhattan
description: CVS, one of the nation's largest retail pharmacy chains, opened two stores on Manhattan's Upper East Side this week and plans to open four more in the next six months.

title: Big Names Add Presence to Staten Island Race
description: It was billed as an evening of ''pasta and politics,'' and by its end, the New Dorp section of Staten Island had become the setting for a night of uncommon Republican pageantry and bravado. More than 500 of the party faithful gathered last night to see George Bush and Bob Dole, whose presence on behalf of a G.O.P. Congressional candidate underscored the national importance of the race to succeed Susan Molinari.

title: AXA-UAP Profit Gain Exceeds Expectations
description: Axa-UAP S.A., the world's second-biggest insurer, said yesterday that it had earned a higher-than-expected 4.2 billion French francs ($727 million) in the first half. It is the first time the company has posted half-year results since Axa officially acquired UAP on Jan. 1.

title: Expert Panel Says Pentagon Ignored Evidence of Poison Gas
description: The final report of a White House panel will say that the Pentagon has dismissed credible evidence that thousands of marines may have been exposed to poison gas when they crossed Iraqi minefields as they invaded Kuwait in the 1991 Persian Gulf war, officials said today.

title: COLLEGES: BASKETBALL ; Big East Women's Coaches Pick UConn and Rutgers
description: Three seasons ago, Connecticut won the national championship in women's college basketball. Two seasons ago, the Huskies reached the Final Four, last season the Elite Eight.

title: A Defiant Iraq Bars Entry To 3 U.S. Arms Inspectors
description: Iraq barred three American arms inspectors from entering the country today, ignoring threats of retaliation from the United States.

title: City Agency's Delay on Runaway Notification Investigated
description: Child welfare officials are investigating the reasons why a city agency waited four days to tell a Bronx woman that her runaway daughter was in foster care.

title: China's Payoff: New Respect, New Status
description: The first Chinese-American summit meeting since the crushing of democracy protests in Tiananmen Square in 1989 was also the first since the Soviet Union collapsed and the sense that China is supplanting Russia as America's prime concern dominated the meetings, in ways both practical and symbolic.

title: William Crook, 72, Ambassador To Australia and Johnson Aide
description: William H. Crook, a Texas preacher turned politician who used an abortive race for Congress as a springboard into the Johnson Administration, serving as national director of the Vista program and Ambassador to Australia, died on Wednesday at his home in Corpus Christi. He was 72.

title: Gangs in the Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Murray Sabrin is a political wild card in the New Jersey governor's race.

title: French Team Is Leading In World Bridge Final
description: Two great bridge teams were locked in a close battle here today in the world championship final.

title: Op-Art; Caption; No Squash Were Hurt
A Serial Killer Who Just Seems So Darned Nice
description: Say all you want about the visceral thrills of action-adventure films set in outer space, but for gripping down-to-the-wire excitement, you still can't beat the imagistic force of grappling opponents on a train speeding over a gorge with a tunnel around the bend. If Jeb Stuart's film ''Switchback'' is a disorganized mess in many departments, its passion for the mystique of trains is palpable. Long after you've forgotten its convoluted story of a serial killer playing mind games with an obsessed Federal agent whose son he has kidnapped, you will remember the movie's ghostly vision of a mystery train hurtling through the Rocky Mountains at night in a blinding snowstorm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, BERTHA
description: COHEN-Bertha. Beloved wife of David. Cherished mother of Barbara and Richard. Devoted grandmother of Donna, Jill, Stephen and Cristina. Services Friday, 1 PM, at ''Gutterman's,'' 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Antiques; Folk Art: The Spanish Connection
description: Several years ago, Dr. Marion Oettinger Jr., an anthropologist in Texas, curated an exhibition on the folk art of Latin America for the Museum of American Folk Art in New York. Assembling that show had a profound influence on him, he recalled: ''I did three years of field work. After traveling to 17 Latin American countries, I began to see some blatant similarities in the objects, artistically speaking.''

title: Weekend Warrior; Head in the Clouds, Feet on the Trail
description: There is life after the Tavern on the Green finish line after all. It's on top of, say, Wittenberg Mountain in the Catskills.

title: Transcripts of Nixon Tapes Show the Path to Watergate
description: ''Christ, impeach the President,'' Richard M. Nixon raged one April night in 1973, cursing his enemies, giving full voice for the first time to his worst fear.

title: Israel Envoy Says He's Got Power to Negotiate
description: Foreign Minister David Levy said today that he had won Government backing to discuss a full range of issues at a planned meeting in Washington next week with Palestinian negotiators, including a suspension of Israeli settlement construction and troop withdrawals in the West Bank.

title: From Other Side of the Fence, Whitman Takes a More Subdued Approach
description: When Christine Todd Whitman toppled a sitting Governor four years ago, she did so by presenting herself less as a fresh face than as the antithesis of the incumbent, Jim Florio. Up and down New Jersey, she lashed out at Mr. Florio and his $2.8 billion tax increase.

title: Summer Comet or Burnout? Jets' Ward Is Finding Out
description: It took half a season, a benching and some soul-searching, but the rookie Dedric Ward is trying to become a productive Jet again.

title: Dresdner Bank Reports Earnings Are Up 42%
description: Dresdner Bank A.G., Germany's second-largest bank, said yesterday that its third-quarter operating profit rose 42 percent as booming stock markets lifted securities trading income. Operating profit rose to 674 million marks ($390 million) from 474 million marks ($274 million) a year earlier. Nine-month operating profit rose 25.5 percent to 2.374 billion marks ($1.37 billion), at the low end of analysts' expectations.

title: U.N. Blocks Rights Move By North Korea
description: A United Nations human rights committee tried today to keep North Korea from backing out of a pledge to honor international human rights standards by taking the position that such pledges are for all time.

title: 3 Charged With Plotting to Kill Teen-Age Rape Victim
description: Two men, charged with raping a teen-age girl in Brooklyn, and a third man, who was said to have boasted that he was a member of the Bloods gang, were charged yesterday with plotting to murder the girl to keep her from testifying in the rape case.

title: Art Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: To Wash Down a Serbian Autumn, Sad Songs and Clear Plum Brandy
description: The sweet smell of plums, boiling in a huge copper vat, mingled with the dry scent of autumn to mark the start of another yearly ritual in the life of a small Serbian farming village.

title: City's Outside Counsel
description: To the Editor:

description: Bulls, Bears And Auctions

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ENGLISH, CHARLES
description: ENGLISH - Charles. UNITE mourns the passing of a former leader of one of our predecessor unions ACTWU, Charles English, who believed deeply in organizing Southern apparel workers. A memorial service will be held at The Old Dutch Church in Sleepy Hollow, NY on Saturday, November 1 at 5:00 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STURDIVANT, JOHN
description: STURDIVANT-John. The members and officers of the RWDSU join with our brothers and sisters in the labor movement in mourning the loss of John Sturdivant, President of the American Federation of Government Employees, a fine trade unionist who dedicated his life to helping working people achieve a better standard of living. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to his family and the members of his union. Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union Lenore Miller, President Stuart Appelbaum, Secretary Treasurer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINE, NETA (LAMBY)
description: FINE-Neta (Lamby). October 29, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Martin Fine. Devoted mother of Fran and John Shanker and David and Sylvia Fine, and loyal friend of Joyce Dell. Cherished grandmother of Norman and Tabbie, Michael and Nancy, David and Aimee, Sue, Meredith, Jonathan, Debbie. Loving great-grandmother of Miles, Marti Rose, Emily, Isabella and Joshua. Beloved sister-in-law of David Feinstein. You were cherished and loved in life and you will be forever missed.

title: COLONIAL PROPERTIES TO BUY MALLS AND SHOPPING CENTERS
description: Colonial Properties Trust agreed yesterday to buy six shopping malls, five shopping centers and an apartment complex for $197 million in cash, securities and assumed debt in separate transactions. The properties are in Georgia, North Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia and South Carolina. To help finance the purchases, the company, based in Birmingham, Ala., said it planned to sell four apartment complexes worth about $55 million. The malls and shopping centers have about 2.9 million square feet of space, increasing Colonial's retail property holdings by about 40 percent. The apartment complex, which is in Greenville, S.C., has 350 units. Shares of Colonial fell 6.25 cents, to $28, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZ, RICHARD E.
description: METZ-Richard E. On October 26, 1997, in New York, age 85. Beloved husband of Gurdon (Howells), dear brother of Eugene and devoted grandfather of Vittorio Cottafavi. Services to be at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Avenue, 11 A.M., Friday, October 31. Please, no flowers.

title: Bank Stocks Fall On Fears About Overseas Losses
description: Bank stocks plunged yesterday on fears about big banks' exposure to hair-raising drops in overseas markets, especially in Latin America. But traders and bankers say the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's largest bank, may be facing significant losses, at least on paper, in a currently less-noticed part of the world -- Russia.

title: Abroad at Home; Question For Reno
description: If Attorney General Janet Reno gets a moment off from considering independent counsel requests, she should look at a case that raises questions about her own department's honor.

title: Time Out to Stop the Bad Guys From Paving a Mountain Paradise
description: Looking for wholesome? What about ''Grizzly Mountain''?

title: New Jersey Poll Finds Volatility Among Voters
description: Christine Todd Whitman continues to receive high marks as Governor of New Jersey, but she has been unable to convince voters that she would do a better job than her Democratic opponent, State Senator James E. McGreevey, in addressing their top concern, auto insurance, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Metro Business; Business Report Is Rosy
description: Business activity in the New York metropolitan area rose in October from the previous month to the highest level in nearly a year, the National Association of Purchasing Management-New York said yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CONSOLIDATED PAPERS INC., Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., a printing paper manufacturer, said it would spend $245 million on capital improvements.

title: Diner's Journal
description: The man I took to Smith & Wollensky hadn't set foot in the door in 20 years. ''I came the day after they opened,'' he said, ''and I haven't been back. Who can eat all this food?''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Russian Skater, 14, May Earn Spot
description: Although Todd Eldredge deservedly won Skate America last weekend, the real eye-opener was a 14-year-old kid in a green matador's outfit.

title: Jiang's Visit Likely to Bring Traffic Jams And Protests
description: President Jiang Zemin's arrival in New York last night began a kaleidoscopic two-day visit featuring a red carpet from big business, snubs from politicians, jeers from human rights protesters, a tour of Wall Street, a gala dinner at the Waldorf, heavy security for the Chinese leader and his 40-car entourage and, for many New Yorkers, days of traffic chaos.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Hard Line on Air Bags
description: FOR all the talk about air bags being unsafe for some people, most who ask permission to disconnect them do not have a good reason, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. And some to whom it gives permission would be better off with the bags, the agency believes.

title: 25 Years of Long Songs, Marches and High Scales
description: Two decades after its commercial heyday, Yes remains one of the strangest pop aberrations of the 1970's.

title: An Orwellian Tale About Animal Behavior
description: ''The Wind in the Willows'' is an unequivocal delight.

title: Pen in Hand, Raul Salinas Denies Murder and Theft
description: When his brother was President of Mexico, Raul Salinas de Gortari lived the high life, enjoying the thoroughbred horses, fast cars and luxurious houses readily available to someone who could deposit more than $100 million in Swiss bank accounts.

title: Mr. Babbitt's Troubling Testimony
description: The most troubling day in Bruce Babbitt's public career ended in an inconclusive stalemate. Republicans suspect that the Interior Secretary was pressured by the White House into making an important departmental decision in exchange for campaign contributions. Mr. Babbitt says his staff made the decision on the merits. The matter cannot rest there. Congress clearly needs to extend the Senate committee that is investigating campaign fund-raising abuses. Attorney General Janet Reno's investigation into the Babbitt affair is also essential to the search for truth.

title: Touring 3 Boroughs, Messinger Focuses on Education
description: Just five days before next Tuesday's mayoral election, Ruth W. Messinger worked the Bronx yesterday, trying to energize voters in the only borough where polls show her to have a consistent edge over Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Braise Craze: Chefs Taking It Slow and Tender
description: PARIS  You could call it the braise craze. After years of fancy dancing cooking "a la minute" the French chef has gone back to his roots, rediscovering the joys of long, slow cooking.

title: FILM REVIEW; Take Two Aspirin, But Don't Dare Call
description: Meet Dr. Butz, the natty, Scotch-swilling chief resident at a major metropolitan hospital. Played with a gruff avuncularity by a gray-haired, almost unrecognizable Albert Brooks in ''Critical Care,'' Sidney Lumet's bracingly funny satire of the medical establishment, Butz is the smug, genial personification of modern medical greed, incompetence and amorality.

title: Too Perplexed to Panic
description: No one knows how we mutual fund investors will react to the next stock market calamity. But based on this week, I like to think we'll have a devil-may-care attitute.

title: Art in Review
description: Tony Tasset

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROW, LT. GEN. DUWARD LOWERY. USAF (RET)
description: CROW-Lt. Gen. Duward Lowery. USAF (Ret), age 78, of San Antonio, TX, died Tuedsay, October 28, 1997. Known to friends and family as Pete, he was born in Ft. Payne, Alabama, on June 26, 1919. He graduated from West Point in 1941 and received his MBA from Harvard Business School in 1948. Twice recipient of the Distinguished Service Medal, he served as Director of Budget, Comptroller, and Assistant Vice Chief of Staff of the USAF. From 1974-1978 he worked at NASA headquarters in Washington, DC as Assistant Deputy Administrator. In 1978 he retired to San Antonio, TX where he remained active in finance and real estate. He was preceded in death by his wife, Eleanor Stribling Dance, of San Antonio, in 1994. He is survived by his three daughters, Eleanor Dance Crow, Cheney Gaylord Crow, PhD, and Elizabeth Crow Perkins; three granddaughters, Florine Eleanor Canelle, Rainey Dupre Perkins, and Catherine Arianna Perkins; his brother, Paul Crow of Fort Payne, AL; and many nieces and nephews. Graveside service will be on Friday, October 31, 1997 at City Cemetery #

title: Bonds Rally as 30-Year Treasury's Yield Slips to 6.14%
description: Treasury bonds ended mostly higher yesterday, deriving strength from another decline in the wobbly stock market and diminished fears that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates anytime soon. It was the fourth time in five days that the bond market has rallied, reflecting the growing allure of stable fixed-income securities, compared with the seesaw behavior of stocks.

title: Knicks Decide to Turn Into All-for-One Bunch
description: The Knicks could tug their egos through a peephole right now. They are a humble bunch exhibiting manners that have teammates all but throwing their leather coats across puddles for each other.

title: Eating Out; Soup Places
description: Soups have been the rage in New York ever since the ''Seinfeld'' Soup Nazi episode two years ago. It's more than a fad; soup has universal appeal. It's part of every cuisine and can be tailored to every season, from the heartiest winter soup to summer's refreshing chilled fruit soups. Still, soup's greatest moment comes when the weather begins to turn cold and minds turn to that bowl of instant warmth. (Here are summaries, written by Eric Asimov, taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Concerto for Two Pianos And a Hundred Memories
description: Are there armies of erstwhile music majors out there nursing childhood grudges against pushy parents, bumbling teachers and tyrannical conservatory administrators? If so, ''Two Pianos, Four Hands'' will have no problem finding an audience.

title: Judge Tells Two Lawyers To End Feud
description: Quoting the Bible and warning that they were endangering their ''quality of life,'' a Federal District Court judge in Manhattan urged two well-known lawyers yesterday to settle the bitter personal battle that has fueled a long-running legal fight.

title: Interior Secretary Denies Politics Had Role in Dispute Over Casino
description: Under harsh questioning from skeptical Republican senators, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt testified today that a decision by his department in 1995 to deny a permit for an Indian casino in Wisconsin was made by a career civil servant and that political considerations had not influenced the denial.

title: Ducks' Selanne Scores In Sixth Straight Game
description: Mighty Ducks 3, Bruins 0

title: Appearing In the Role Of Underdog
description: IF you think about Ruth W. Messinger's campaign in cinematic terms, just for the heck of it, a couple of film models suggest themselves. ''Rocky'' is always a possibility. You know the drill: an underdog, given no chance, slogs on against all odds, winning hearts if not the title.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANEK, BESSIE
description: GANEK-Bessie. The Board of Trustees of Parker Jewish Institute for Health Care and Rehabilitation extends heartfelt sympathies to fellow Trustee, Howard L. Ganek, on the loss of his beloved mother, Bessie. A warm and caring relationship has come to a close, leaving behind many precious memories. Our condolences to all the family. David S. Taub, Chairman David Glaser, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPP, COL. THEODORE A., USAF (RET.)
description: RAPP-Col. Theodore A., USAF (Ret.) of Nyack, NY died October 28. Col. Rapp was the brother of recently deceased Norman A. Rapp of Collegeville, PA. As a career military officer and pilot in the U.S. Air Force and the New York Air National Guard, Col. Rapp was a veteran of the Korean and Viet Nam conflicts. After retiring from the military, he founded and was CEO of TRAM microphones, Nyack, N.Y. Col. Rapp is survived by Catherine M. (Quay) Rapp, 2 nieces, Nancy A. RappSharp and Nora A. DiNenni and a nephew, Norman A. Rapp Jr. He will be missed by many friends; business associates. Funeral Services and interment private. In lieu of flowers, Col. Rapp's wish is that donations be made to: Brain Cancer Research, Montefiore Medical Center, C/O Peter Lyden, 111 E. 210th St., Bronx, New York 10467.

title: Revamped Nets Start Play Without Two Key Pieces
description: One of Sam Cassell's favorite laments this month has been his conviction that the preseason is too long.

title: Gene-Altered Mice Are Called First True Sickle Cell Model
description: Two groups of scientists have developed genetically engineered mice that they say represent the first true animal model for sickle cell disease, an advance that should speed research on new treatments for the incurable blood condition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BREINER, ERNEST
description: BREINER-Ernest. On Oct. 29. Beloved husband of Erna, loving father of Russell and Naomi, Joanne and Bruce, and Cary. Cherished grandfather, dear brother. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 9:30 AM, Sunday.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of All Saints Day, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: CAPSTAR HOTEL AGREES TO ACQUIRE WINSTON HOSPITALITY
description: The Capstar Hotel Company agreed yesterday to acquire Winston Hospitality Inc., a hotel management company, for $34 million in cash and other considerations. Under the agreement, Capstar will pay $10 million in cash and $24 million in operating partnership units, which are convertible into shares of Capstar stock. Winston Hospitality leases 38 and manages 28 of the operating hotels of Winston Hotels Inc., a real estate investment trust based in Raleigh, N.C. Capstar, based in Washington, owns 42 hotels and manages 29 others. Capstar also will lease and manage five hotels that Winston is developing.

title: In Birthplace of U.S. Democracy, Jiang Finds the Trappings and Traps of Liberty
description: For China's President, Jiang Zemin, a history buff fond of quoting Thomas Jefferson, arriving at the birthplace of American democracy today should have been like reaching the ultimate destination in a journey of enlightenment about the nation's history.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Public Works on the Ballot
description: The governor's race may have plenty of fireworks, but the statewide measures on Tuesday's ballot are a quieter affair. There is no organized opposition to any of the questions.

title: Jogger's Rapist Is Placed Under Notification Law
description: A man convicted in the rape and beating of a female jogger in Central Park eight years ago was declared a ''sexually violent predator'' by a Manhattan judge yesterday.

title: Suspicious Fire Kills Man and Boy in Bronx
description: A 60-year-old man and an 8-year-old boy were killed in a suspicious fire in the Highbridge section of the Bronx yesterday, police and fire officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILBRONER, PAUL STEPHAN
description: HEILBRONER-Paul Stephan. On October 24. Survived by his nephew Steven Salomon. Cryptside services on Monday, November 3, 1 P.M., at Union Field Cemetery, Cypress Hills, New York.

title: $875 Million Bid Made for Phone Company
description: The ACC Corporation, a provider of local and long-distance service, said yesterday that it had received an unsolicited $875 million offer from Tel-Save Holdings Inc.

title: Has Baton, Will Travel; Has Hour, Will Compose
description: Just after 1:30 on Tuesday afternoon, Krzysztof Penderecki sat on the armrest of a seat at the 92d Street Y and quietly confessed to feeling both jet-lagged and peckish, having had little sleep the night before and nothing more nourishing than coffee all morning.

title: Wild Turkey Brand To Saatchi & Saatchi
description: Austin, Nichols & Company said yesterday that it had named Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York as the first agency to manage its Wild Turkey bourbon brand around the world. Billings were estimated at $8 million to $10 million.

title: Council Votes to Rein In Private Parking Police
description: The Department of Consumer Affairs has received more than 400 complaints this year from drivers about companies that patrol store parking lots, attaching bright yellow locks to the wheels of cars when their drivers park in the lot without entering the store. The companies, motorists say, often refuse to accept credit cards, which is against the law, and hold cars hostage until their owners pay as much as $100 in cash.

title: British Concern Still Seeks A Partnership With MCI
description: The chief executive of British Telecommunications P.L.C., which has been outbid by two companies in its quest to take over MCI Communications, showed every sign today of wanting to play kingmaker in the three-way merger talks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BELL, SARAH BAKER
description: BELL-Sarah Baker. Of Bryn Mawr, PA. On October 29, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Chief Justice John C. Bell, Jr. Loving mother of Sophie Bell Donaghy, of Bryn Mawr, and Sarah Bell Bullard, of N. Andover, MA. Also survived by 12 grandchildren and 20 great grandchildren. A family service will be held at All Saints Church, Wynnewood, PA, Saturday, November 1, at 2PM. Burial at St. Asaph's Church (Cemetery), Balacynwyd, PA. Memorial donations may be made to the Children's Aid Society of PA., 311 S. Juniper Street, Philadelphia, PA 19107.

title: N.F.L. Matchups: Week 10
description: GAME OF THE WEEK

title: Fraternity's Rules: Speak at Your Risk
description: How unfortunate that the Jim Harbaugh-Jim Kelly brawl last week at an NBC production meeting in San Diego was not a Fox Sports affair. It could have been the pilot for a new, easy-to-promote, prime-time program: ''They're vicious! They throw pigs! They're coming for you! Watch 'WHEN QUARTERBACKS ATTACK!' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, CAROL S.
description: LEVY-Carol S. On October 29, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Edgar I. Levy. Devoted mother of Liza Levy, Angela Carroll and Kristin Lizotte. Cherished grandmother of Jacklyn, Jennifer and Adam. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, November 2 at 4 PM at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81st St. Contributions may be made in her name to The Education Action Fund, C/O Jonathan Kozol, POB 145, Byfield, MA. 01922 or a charity of your choice.

title: U.S. IS SET TO LEND $3 BILLION TO HELP BOLSTER INDONESIA
description: The United States will announce Friday that it is committing roughly $3 billion to what senior Administration officials describe as a ''second line of defense'' to aid Indonesia -- the first direct American financial contribution to restore financial stability in Southeast Asia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINSTON, JAY
description: WINSTON-Jay. On October 30, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Betty. Loving father of Linda and John,and father-in-law of Renate, grandfather of Claudia, Paul, Valerie, Hella and David. Great grandfather of Ruby Rose. Dear brother of Ruth Winston Frank. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Fila U.S.A. tries to stress performance over fashion.
description: FILA U.S.A., hoping again to make a mountain out of a Grant Hill, will refocus its sales pitches centered on the basketball star.

title: Williams Wants More
description: The Bernie Williams salary debate has escalated to $10 million a year, with the Yankees insisting the All-Star center fielder is not in that rarefied air and Scott Boras, his agent, arguing that he is. This debate could linger since Williams is the property of the Yankees until the end of next season.

title: M.J. Latsis, 70, Emma Lathen Writing Team Collaborator
description: Mary Jane Latsis, who helped make business the backdrop for murder as one half of the Emma Lathen writing team that produced two dozen John Putnam Thatcher mysteries, died on Monday at a hospital in Plymouth, N.H. She was 70 and maintained residences in Warren, N.H., and Brookline, Mass.

title: From a Moscow Troupe, the End of Another Era
description: ''Ya kupil!'' Lopakhin exclaims in Russian, and even without your headphones on supplying simultaneous translation, you know for sure that the headstrong, rags-to-riches businessman of Chekhov's ''Cherry Orchard'' has announced ''I bought it!'' -- it being the beloved grove of cherry trees that represents everything safe and sturdy about the world to its former owner, Mme. Ranev skaya.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARON, MATTHEW
description: AARON-Matthew. Beloved father of Howard and Alice, grandfather of Susanna and Max, great-grandfather of Samuel and Jasper. Services Sunday, 10 A.M., Riverside Chapel, 1 Ocean Pkwy, Bklyn.,N.Y.

title: Westchester, Rockland Endorsements
description: Important elections will be held in New York's Westchester and Rockland Counties next Tuesday. Here are our endorsements in some major races.

title: Nanny Is Convicted In Death of Infant
description: A 19-year-old British nanny was found guilty of second-degree murder in the death of an 8-month-old Massachusetts boy.

title: In Hell's Kitchen With Frances McDormand; Marge's Other Job, You Betcha
description: She walked with a slight slouch, her backpack knitting creases in the gray T-shirt that hung loosely on her shoulders, moving slowly along West 52d Street in nondescript blue jeans and frayed running shoes. She stopped, leaned forward to light a cigarette, cupping it in her hand and turning her back to the river breeze.

title: SARA LEE TO BUY BACK 25 MILLION OF ITS COMMON SHARES
description: The board of the Sara Lee Corporation has authorized the repurchase of up to 25 million shares of the company's common stock. The board of the consumer-products maker in Chicago also voted to increase the quarterly dividend on the common stock to 23 cents a share from 21 cents. The dividend is payable on Jan. 2, 1998, to shareholders of record on Dec. 1. Shares of Sara Lee fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $49.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Art in Review
description: Aaron Rose

title: Corrections
description: A sports chart on Wednesday showing basketball teams with the best chance to dethrone the Chicago Bulls this season referred incorrectly in some editions to the number of consecutive championships titles held by the Bulls. It is two, not three.

title: Paris Journal; AH-lo-een: An American Holiday in Paris?
description: In one of the stranger manifestations of globalization, Halloween fever has abruptly gripped the French, sending pumpkin prices soaring and sorely testing the Gallic ability to pronounce ''trick or treat.''

title: British Nanny Found Guilty Of Murder in Baby's Death
description: After more than three days of deliberations, a jury tonight found Louise Woodward, a 19-year-old British nanny, guilty of second-degree murder in the death of the 8-month-old baby she was hired to watch.

title: Mets
description: The Mets have offered a pitcher for Texas catcher Jim Leyritz, according to a high-ranking baseball executive who asked not to be named.

title: Scandal Pushes Powerful Family From Pinnacle In Mexico
description: Raul Salinas Lozano is a patriarch who raised his family to the pinnacle of the power in Mexico, then watched it slide to the depths of scandal.

title: INSIDE
description: Jiang Goes to Capitol Hill

title: Brown Struggles to Share In the Giants' Success
description: Dave Brown watches the Giants win and feels his teammates' joy, even though he knows, for him, it will mean denunciation by association.

title: Poverty Is the Norm for Single-Parent Families
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Again Vetoes Bill For Outside Police Monitor
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday vetoed the City Council's proposal to create an independent police review board, in a decision that continued a long-running dispute over the need for an outside panel to investigate police corruption.

title: In Her Own Words
description: RUTH W. MESSINGER

title: A Runner-Up Looks to Win
description: Her 22-year-old daughter, Rachel, runs four miles a day for fitness. Her 17-year-old daughter, Jamie, is a good high school cross-country and track runner. Kim Jones could sit back and lazily enjoy life with her daughters and her husband, Steve, a lawyer in Spokane, Wash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, MARY
description: MURPHY-Mary. On October 30, 1997, at the age of 91. Native of Balinlough, Co. Roscommon, Ireland. Loving wife of the late James. Dear mother of Anne Bogart, Eileen Doyle, Margaret Murphy, Theresa Sanders, Michael Murphy, Esq., and Patrick Murphy (Retired Lt. Col.). Cherished grandmother of 23 and great grandmother of 29. Loving sister of Kathleen McHugh, Vincent, Michael and Angela and the late Margaret, Eileen, Thomas and Roddy. Reposing Friday 2-4 and 79 P.M., at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10 AM, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment in Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVITT, CANTOR MARVIN
description: SAVITT-Cantor Marvin. The Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation notes with great sadness the passing of our beloved Cantor Emeritus Marvin Savitt, who served our congregation with distinction for 34 years. We extend condolences to his wife Harriet, daughters Ellen Friedman and Julie Savitt, son Joseph and their respective families. For Shiva information please call us at 516-333-7977. Rabbi Seth J. Sternstein Cantor Jacob Merlis Rabbi Emeritus Melvin Kieffer Roger Fisher, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECANDIA, VICTOR
description: deCANDIA-Victor. Extraordinary human being. Funeral Mass Holy Family Church, 315 East 47 Street, NY, Monday, November 3, 6 PM.

title: Police Say 10 in Gang Attacked Bronx Girls
description: A group of 10 gang members set upon two teen-age girls walking in the Cortlandt Village section of the Bronx Wednesday afternoon, stealing jewelry from one and slashing both across the face, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMANN, ETHEL
description: KAUFMANN-Ethel. On October 30, 1997. Loving wife of the late Robert A. Kaufmann, beloved mother of Phyllis and Jerome Brown, cherished grandmother of Allison and Jennifer, adored sister of Ruth Kobritz, Florence Berliner, Herman Zuckerman, and the late Steve Zuckerman. She will be missed by all who knew and loved her. Services Friday, October 31, 11:30 A.M., at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: An Event for the Brave
description: In the Puissance event at the National Horse Show, the wall's the thing, and, like something out of a science fiction movie, this wall has an inner life of its own. Each time a horse manages to leap it, it grows a little higher.

title: National News Briefs; Senate Votes to Overturn Clinton's Line Item Veto
description: The Senate voted today to restore money for 34 military projects, most of those recently canceled by President Clinton's use of his new line item veto power.

title: Reconsidering A Trade Equation; Why a Stronger Dollar Hasn't Brought a Drop in Exports
description: As the dollar strengthened this year, Ronald D. Bullock, president of the Bison Gear and Engineering Company near Chicago, raised his prices in francs and marks for the metal transmission gears that he exports to Europe. But his customers stuck with him, drawn by Bison Gear's new willingness to custom-design the gears -- similar in shape to bicycle sprockets -- for each factory machine whose speed they regulate. And Bison's exports have risen, despite the sticker shock.

title: Residential Real Estate; New Freedom for a Co-op's Owners
description: Richard J. Grossman, president of a Greenwich Village cooperative, has no plans to sell the one-bedroom apartment he has owned for 10 years. But, given Manhattan's strong housing market, he may consider it one day soon.

title: Worldcom Net Tops Estimates But Stock Price Fails to Climb
description: Worldcom Inc., whose unsolicited bid for the MCI Communications Corporation depends in part on the value of Worldcom stock, announced quarterly results yesterday that exceeded Wall Street's expectations.

title: Metro Business; Commerzbank Unit Expands Its Offices
description: The Commerzbank Capital Markets Corporation, the securities-trading unit of Commerzbank AG, Germany's third-largest bank, is expanding and moving its New York offices uptown, to nearly 80,000 square feet at 1251 Avenue of the Americas, the 54-story tower at 50th Street, the company said yesterday.

title: The Anatomy of a Photographer
description: Elephants kept coming to mind. Large figures with wrinkled gray skin, unfamiliar flaps, impertinent hairs and heavy limbs. Bodies too big to comprehend in a single glance. Comedy mixed with grandeur and something pathetic. But the figure in the photographs is not an elephant: He is John Coplans, now 77, photographed by Mr. Coplans himself at an intimate distance and blown up to mammoth proportions. The result is breathtaking.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I must tell you that all this is absolutely bizarre. I suddenly started seeing pumpkins everywhere in my local Monoprix supermarket and I had no idea what was going on. This is emphatically not a traditional French festival, and my only explanation is that we have belatedly discovered the power of marketing.''

title: He's an All-Australian Boy
description: The 24-year-old Australian singer David Campbell has had the mixed good fortune of being hailed as a ''cabaret sensation'' and compared to the young Barbra Streisand before most people have even heard him sing a note. Such advance hyperbole can weigh heavily, and a lot is riding on the success of his two-week debut engagement (through Nov. 15) at Rainbow and Stars at 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Being a carpenter is more conducive to following the poetic muse than is advertising copywriting.

title: Campaigns Look for a Prop: Vice Presidents Are Willing
description: With lingering concern that the more conservative base of her party had not shown enough enthusiasm for her re-election bid, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman spent much of her time today in Republican-dominated regions of the state, trying to excite a wing of her party that has complained about her pro-choice stand on abortion and her fiscal policies.

title: Shooting Victim's Family Files Wide-Ranging Suit
description: The family of a man who was murdered in a dispute over a parking space at a delicatessen in Dobbs Ferry is suing the New York City police officer who was convicted in the case, the New York Police Department, New York City and Westchester County.

title: Shift of Cable Subscribers
description: Time Warner Inc. will transfer about 640,000 of its cable subscribers in New York, Florida and North Carolina to Time Warner Entertainment, its joint venture with Advance/Newhouse Communications. In exchange, the venture will assume more than $1 billion of Time Warner's debt. Time Warner, the media and entertainment giant, had 1996 revenue of $10.06 billion. Advance/ Newhouse is a unit of Advance Publications Inc.

title: Fidelity Invokes Fine Print And Angers Some Customers
description: When the American stock market rallied on Tuesday, a day after its worst decline in a decade, roughly $20 million flowed into the Fidelity Hong Kong and China fund from investors who expected stock prices in Hong Kong to surge when trading resumed there.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There are more than 350 endowed chairs at Columbia University in fields encompassing lofty academic disciplines, and now there is one for football as well.

title: COLLEGES: FOOTBALL
description: Dartmouth

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIPRUT, SOLOMON, MD.
description: CIPRUT-Solomon, MD. The entire family of Maimonides Medical Center expresses a profound sense of loss on the passing of Dr. Sol Ciprut. A member of our institution for nearly 40 years, his life was intertwined with Maimonides. Through the years, he was an intern, a chief resident, and past president of the Medical Staff Society and leading member of the Department of Surgery. At Maimonides he was a daily presence and will be sorely missed. We extend our sympathy to his wife Lorraine, his sons, daughter, daughters-in-law and grandchildren. Maimonides Medical Center Martin D. Payson, Chairman, Board of Trustees Stanley Brezenoff, President

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: At the Movies
description: Knives Out For 'Anastasia'

title: Seal is Placed On Documents In Clinton Suit
description: In an effort to squelch publicity in an increasingly lurid lawsuit, the judge who is hearing Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct case against President Clinton has issued a far-reaching order sealing any legal motions or briefs that are filed to gather information before the trial.

title: Check That Playbill: It's Nearly Show Time
description: The Dynasty Farewell Tour begins tonight in Boston, where Michael and the Role Players will welcome Rick Pitino back to the National Basketball Association. On the West Coast, the Lakers want to send the Jazz a message even without Shaquille O'Neal. Larry Bird and Chuck Daly are off the golf course and on the sidelines. Charles Barkley, the superstar who cries wolf, is contemplating retirement again. And two women will obliterate another barrier in American sport.

title: Fascination Is Forever: The Arts and Sciences of Diamonds
description: George E. Harlow was guiding a visitor through his diamond show, which displays hundreds of gems and historic treasures. Among them is the Eureka. Found in South Africa during the 19th century, it started a rush that eventually clothed the world in cold fire.

title: Classical Music and Dance Guide
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in New York City.

title: I.B.M. Settles Argentine Fight
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and Banco de la Nacion of Argentina have settled a dispute over a $250 million contract to provide the bank with new computers.

title: Tentative Accord in Columbia Strike
description: Columbia University and a group of 800 striking clerical workers reached a tentative agreement that could end a two-week-old walkout, university and union officials announced last night. But both sides said they would not disclose details of the agreement until after it was rejected or accepted by union members today.

title: Sports of The Times; Dudley Gambles On Knicks
description: HIS degree in economics from Yale notwithstanding, Chris Dudley rejected a guaranteed offer of $16 million over four years from the Detroit Pistons and accepted a shade over $1 million to play this season for the Knicks. No one has called yet from New Haven, demanding he return the diploma.

title: My Manhattan; Stumbling On Neighbors' Old Secrets
description: ''You become a New Yorker,'' I heard someone say recently, ''when you stop talking about moving away.''

title: Lady Killer? Beijing Is Not Charmed
description: In a career move guaranteed to surprise no one, Richard Gere stars in ''Red Corner'' as a seductive middle-aged American who is outraged by the Chinese Government's repressive tactics. His role is that of general counsel to a large entertainment conglomerate, and his mission in China is to expedite a deal involving American satellite interests. This could open China to Western cultural influences, though on the evidence of ''Red Corner,'' American television has already arrived. Grandstanding courtroom drama is alive and well in this tale of a foreigner suddenly seized by the Chinese authorities and put on trial for murder.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COLLINS, PATRICIA
description: COLLINS-Patricia. Happy Birthday. Always in our thoughts, always in our hearts. Love Mother Eileen, Mickey, James and Terry

title: All Over the Lot (The Back Lot, Too)
description: The New York filmmaker, photographer and performance artist Jack Smith (1932-1989), who is being commemorated with a superb retrospective at P.S. 1 this fall, was a protean figure: intemperate, hilarious, impractical, a hothouse exotic of a kind too seldom encountered in the art world today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: At Home, Rosy News for Jiang's Trip
description: Among the mandatory smiles and pageantry of Jiang Zemin's state visit to Washington this week, the impromptu debate on human rights between Mr. Jiang and President Clinton at their news conference Wednesday stood out as unusually frank. For American viewers at least, it was a reminder of the differences that remain despite a multitude of agreements and shared hopes.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the special New York City Marathon Preview section on Tuesday showing sites and landmarks along the route misstated the final year that the cast iron tower was used in Marcus Garvey Park. It was 1878, not 1978.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CROCKETT, DWIGHT L.
description: CROCKETT-Dwight L. March 10, 1925-October 31, 1996. Friend, associate, companion of Garvin Mecking and Paris Fields. Lovingly remembered, greatly missed and mourned for. I have inherited the strength, determination and fortitude from all the training sessions, adventures and arguments we endured. I still hear your words and listen for your footsteps as you knew I would always. Paris (Little G)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRONER, JOSEPH
description: TRONER-Joseph, 93, of West Palm Beach, FL., passed away Monday, October 27, 1997. Beloved husband of Sylvia; loving father of Bruce, Stephen, Michael, brother of Kaye Siegel; grandfather of eight; great grandfather of two. Services and interment in Florida.

title: Pugnacity of Incumbent Is Issue in Suffolk Race
description: To his Democratic opponent, the Suffolk County District Attorney, James M. Catterson Jr., is a bully who intimidates anyone who questions him, including other elected officials.
